{"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "In the memo, drawn from classified material, the staff of the House Intelligence Committee under Devin Nunes, Republican of California, apparently alleges that the Obama Justice Department sought a warrant for an electronic wiretap based on a dossier financed by the Clinton campaign and produced by Fusion GPS with information surreptitiously provided by Russian intelligence. If descriptions of its contents are true, the memo details a shocking collapse of standards in one of the government\u2019s most important jobs: collecting foreign intelligence to stop terrorist attacks and enemy spies.\n\nThe president has the constitutional authority to classify and declassify secrets. President Trump could allow the Justice Department to negotiate with the House over release of the Nunes memo, so as to protect intelligence sources and methods. An agreement could also provide the starting point for review and restructuring of the department\u2019s national security division and its management of electronic surveillance.\n\nBut again, the president seems unable to allow good government to proceed freely. Instead, he has claimed for months that the Obama administration hatched a conspiracy to illegally eavesdrop on him and, according to reports, has decided to approve release of the Nunes memo even before reviewing it. Again, Mr. Trump risks the prospects for departmental reform to score political points against Mr. Obama.\n\nThese episodes reveal a shortcoming in Mr. Trump\u2019s understanding of the presidency. He has the constitutional power to push out Mr. McCabe and to release the Nunes memo. Yet doing so is a serious political misuse of that power.\n\nMachiavelli, the father of modern thinking about executive power, described ideal princes as quick to execute the law and able to act \u201cat a stroke.\u201d In Federalist 70, Alexander Hamilton extended the insight to argue that the executive should act with \u201cdecision, activity, secrecy and dispatch.\u201d The founders believed that presidents advance the public good when they draw upon their undefined powers to respond to emergencies.\n\nMr. Trump acts at odds with the founders\u2019 vision. Rather than conserving his authority for true crises, he seems intent on creating and prolonging false ones. This may appeal to his base, but he is eroding the presidency\u2019s constitutional power and political authority. He may not find them there when necessity forces him to confront a real challenge, as when surely one comes.", "title": "Opinion | Fix the F.B.I. Don\u2019t Politicize It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Some experts suggest climate change is likely to make such events more frequent. And an international body chose this week to publish a study arguing that Paris and the rest of the Seine basin needed greater protection against the risk of a catastrophic flood.\n\n\u201cAll we can do is put up scaffolding to make a pontoon, and hope that the water doesn\u2019t come up much higher,\u201d Diane Bourlier, a 63-year-old who lives on a houseboat in Paris, said as she looked anxiously out at the rising river.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bourlier was among the lucky ones: As of Thursday night, 400 people had been evacuated from homes in the Paris region, and a thousand faced power cuts, according to the police prefecture. It appears to be on a whim. To the extent that the decision was not the result of a process with testimony, deliberation \u2014 the decision that Florida\u2019s coast is more pristine and valuable than California\u2019s coast seems to be just on the request of Governor Scott. Why?\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, Governor Henry McMaster of South Carolina, a Republican, announced plans to do just that, saying that he intends to ask the Trump administration for a drilling exemption just like Florida\u2019s.\n\n\u201cNew York doesn\u2019t want drilling off our coast, either,\u201d Andrew Cuomo, the state\u2019s Democratic governor, said on Twitter on Tuesday night. \u201cWhere do we sign up for a waiver?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, a Democrat, asked why the Trump administration deemed Florida\u2019s coastline valuable enough to preserve, but not California\u2019s.\n\n\u201cCalifornia is also \u2018unique\u2019 & our \u2018coasts are heavily reliant on tourism as an economic driver,\u2019\u201d Mr. Becerra tweeted on Tuesday, quoting Mr. Zinke\u2019s own stated reasons for suddenly withdrawing Florida from the drilling plan. \u201cOur \u2018local and state voice\u2019 is firmly opposed to any and all offshore drilling,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIf that\u2019s your standard, we, too, should be removed from your list. Immediately.\u201d\n\nHogan Gidley, the White House deputy press secretary, said it was in the country\u2019s best interest \u201cto unleash our energy potential to its fullest.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Secretary is currently in the process of speaking to stakeholders, like Governor Scott yesterday, to determine the most responsible and environmentally sound path forward,\u201d Mr. Gidle said, referring to Mr. Zinke. \u201cAll states have different concerns and needs, which is why this is an ongoing process with a built-in 60 day comment period.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe governors of New York, New Jersey, California and several other states requested exclusion from the drilling plan last year, while the plan was being drafted, citing the tourism value of their coastlines.\n\n\u201cThe problem is that the request for exclusion came from most of the East Coast states and all of the West Coast states, and yet it was just granted to Florida,\u201d said Sierra Weaver, an attorney with the Southern Environmental Law Center. \u201cThe problem is treating Florida differently from every other state that requested exclusion.\u201d\n\nIn fact, Florida was not among the states that had requested an exemption to the drilling plan. Throughout his political career, Governor Scott has veered between supporting and opposing offshore drilling.\n\nLegal experts said they were perplexed by Mr. Zinke\u2019s move. \u201cNo one knows what the legal implications are, because this has never been done before,\u201d Ms. Weaver said.\n\nShe said Mr. Zinke\u2019s move may put the administration in conflict with the provisions of the 1953 Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, a law that lays out the standards and procedures for determining which areas will be opened to offshore drilling.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s supposed to be a 60-day public comment period, an environmental-impact statement,\u201d Ms. Weaver said. \u201cIt\u2019s not clear what they did here, and it\u2019s not clear that they understand that there is a legal process that they need to follow.\u201d", "title": "Florida Is Exempted From Coastal Drilling. Other States Ask, \u2018Why Not Us?\u2019", "authors": ["Coral Davenport"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "SACRAMENTO \u2014 One of the most brazen attacks on the rule of law by the Trump administration \u2014 and we\u2019ve seen many \u2014 came last week after the Interior Department opened up 90 percent of America\u2019s offshore waters to drilling for oil and gas, and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke arbitrarily gave Florida a free pass.\n\n\n\nIt was a stunning demonstration of politically motivated policymaking that has provoked nearly a dozen coastal states, both red and blue, to protest. Perhaps no state faces more potential harm than California.\n\nIn a statement attached to a tweet, Secretary Zinke wrote that he was exempting Florida from the new drilling because the state is \u201cheavily reliant on tourism as an economic driver.\u201d\n\nWhether he was referring to the 7.7 million people who worked along Florida\u2019s coast in 2014, or to the $769 billion generated by Florida\u2019s coastal economy, according to a study by the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, we can relate here in California.", "title": "Opinion | Florida Isn\u2019t the Only State That Will Be Hurt by Offshore Drilling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "A Florida man who was angry that his 7-year-old stepson got out of bed to get a cookie brutally beat the boy and left him in bed to die, the authorities said on Tuesday.\n\nThe man, Jack J. Montgomery, 31, who faces charges of first-degree murder and child abuse, called 911 at about 10:50 a.m. on Saturday to report that his stepson, Brice Russell, would not wake up and was not breathing in their room at a hotel in Seffner, Fla., about 20 miles east of Tampa, the Hillsborough County Sheriff\u2019s Department said in a statement on Tuesday. Mr. Montgomery had been watching over the boy and three siblings at the hotel while their mother worked, the department said.\n\nWhen medics arrived at the hotel, they found the boy lying in bed. He was pronounced dead just before 11 a.m., the sheriff\u2019s department statement said.\n\nInvestigators said that Mr. Montgomery had \u201cpunched the child in the face, mouth and stomach with a closed fist, threw the victim around the hotel room and shoved his face into the carpet,\u201d the statement said. It said that the other children told the investigators they were threatened with violence unless they also hit Brice, and one child did.", "title": "Florida Man Charged With Beating Stepson, 7, to Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "That could all change if a proposed constitutional amendment gets enough signatures to be placed on the ballot in November and wins enough support. The initiative would automatically restore voting rights to the vast majority of Floridians who have completed their sentence for a felony conviction, including any term of parole or probation.\n\nThis is a long overdue and urgently needed reform. The only way around Florida\u2019s lifetime ban \u2014 as in the other three states with such a ban, Kentucky, Iowa and Virginia \u2014 is a direct, personal appeal to the governor. In the last few years, Terry McAuliffe, as Virginia\u2019s governor, restored voting rights to more than 168,000 people, and the governors in Kentucky and Iowa granted roughly 9 in 10 of the restoration requests they received in the first half of the decade.\n\nIn contrast, Gov. Rick Scott of Florida grants only 8 percent of the requests that come before the state\u2019s clemency board, which he leads \u2014 for a total of only a few hundred people each year, even though there is a backlog of more than 10,000 petitions awaiting review.\n\nMr. Scott\u2019s predecessor, Charlie Crist, took a far better approach, using his executive power to streamline the restoration process for certain classes of offenders, like those convicted of nonviolent felonies. Once people \u201chave paid their debt, society should honor its part of the bargain and allow citizens to re-enter society,\u201d he wrote in 2007. \u201cTo not do so is more than reckless or irresponsible, it is unjust.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s hard to argue with that logic, but Mr. Scott found a way. Soon after taking office in 2011, he not only reversed Mr. Crist\u2019s policies, but imposed a waiting period of at least five years after people had completed their sentences before they could plead with him to restore their voting rights. The message wasn\u2019t meant to be welcoming, and Floridians have responded accordingly \u2014 the number of restoration requests has cratered during Mr. Scott\u2019s tenure.", "title": "Opinion | Florida\u2019s 1.5 Million Missing Voters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cLinking Generations Through Riches, and Much More\u201d (Wealth Matters column, Business Day, Dec. 30) mentions the remarkable Antinori family of Tuscany, an Italian winemaker since 1385.\n\nThe column says the family \u201cis still linked by its vineyards and grand homes,\u201d but it did not include something else that is sure to contribute to keeping the family together: the new headquarters outside Florence, one of the most outstanding works of architecture of recent years.\n\nThis very large, handsome building, built into a scenic hillside so as to nearly disappear from view, has become an inextricable part of the landscape, symbolizing both continuity and growth \u2014 the essence of a successful family.\n\nG. MACKENZIE GORDON\n\nLAKEVILLE, CONN.\n\nThe writer is an architect and landscape designer.", "title": "Opinion | Flourishing Family Trees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The states said they could file a petition to the United States Court of Appeals, starting the process to determine which court would hear the case. That is the action the attorneys general, as well as Mozilla and the Open Technology Institute, took on Tuesday.\n\nThe states that signed onto the lawsuit include California, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts and Oregon, as well as the District of Columbia. Xavier Becerra, the California attorney general, said the decision to roll back the agency\u2019s declaration of broadband as a utility-like service will harm consumers.\n\n\u201cInternet access is a utility \u2014 just like water and electricity,\u201d Mr. Becerra said in a statement. \u201cAnd every consumer has a right to access online content without interference or manipulation by their internet service provider.\u201d\n\nIn a release, Mr. Schneiderman said the agency\u2019s roll back disregarded a record of evidence that internet service providers\u2019 could harm consumers without rules. A similar argument was made by Mozilla.\n\n\u201cEnding net neutrality could end the internet as we know it,\u201d said Denelle Dixon, Mozilla\u2019s chief business and legal officer in a blog post. \u201cThat\u2019s why we are committed to fighting the order. In particular, we filed our petition today because we believe the recent F.C.C. decision violates both federal law as well as harms internet users and innovators.\u201d\n\nThe issue of net neutrality has been fought in court challenges twice before in the past decade. The rules adopted in 2015, which set rules that sites could not be blocked or throttled, were upheld by the United States Court of Appeals in 2016 after legal challenges by telecom companies. The F.C.C. vote in December was to roll back those 2015 rules.\n\nThe new lawsuits are among several efforts to restore net neutrality rules. On Tuesday, Senate Democrats announced they were one supporter away from winning a vote to restore net neutrality rules. All 49 members of their caucus, as well as one Republican, have signed on to a resolution to overturn the rules. A similar effort initiated in the House has the support of 80 members.\n\nSuccess by members of Congress is unlikely, particularly in the House, where Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, would have to agree to bring the resolution to a vote. The president will also have to agree to the resolutions, if they were passed, but the White House has expressed its support of the rollback of net neutrality rules.", "title": "Flurry of Lawsuits Filed to Fight Repeal of Net Neutrality", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I\u2019m new to Instagram. Aside from the service suggesting Facebook friends who also have Instagram accounts, how do I find new people to follow?\n\nA. Like Twitter, LinkedIn and other networks, Instagram has a search function you can use to look for acquaintances other than those you already have on Facebook (which owns Instagram, hence the social synergy). Tap the magnifying glass in the Instagram tool bar to go to the search page, where you can seek out specific people, hashtags or places that match your keywords. The search page also lists so-called top accounts in the results.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHashtags are labels prefaced with a \u201c#\u201d character (as in #FlyEaglesFly, for example). Users add them to captions as a simple way to whittle down broader categories into narrower subjects. An Instagram hashtag page lists all the posts using the same tag.\n\nPhoto\n\nJust as you can add certain people and businesses to the list of accounts you follow, you can now follow particular hashtags, a feature Instagram introduced late last year. When you are browsing your feed and see a hashtag that piques your interest, tap it. Instagram takes you to a page showing posts using that hashtag and if you like what you see, tap the blue Follow button at the top. New posts that contain that hashtag will then appear in your feed.\n\nLater, if you lose interest in the topic, you can remove it from your feed. Tap the hashtag to return to its page and tap the Following button at the top to stop tracking the tag.", "title": "Following Along on Instagram", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 One by one, former N.F.L. coaches and players, the director of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and even a United States Senator came to the lectern last weekend to deliver the same stern warning: Football is under attack and your job is to change the narrative.\n\nThe game, they insisted at the annual conference of USA Football, the N.F.L.-funded national governing body for the sport, is vital to the American experience, essential for its survival, and it doesn\u2019t have a health and safety problem as much as it has a messaging problem.\n\n\u201cIf we lose football, we lose a lot in America,\u201d said David Baker, the president of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, who was one of the keynote speakers. \u201cI don\u2019t know if America can survive. That\u2019s why you\u2019re so important to what we\u2019re doing. That\u2019s why America needs to huddle up.\u201d\n\nThese were the true believers in just about everything about the gridiron, from its leather-helmeted roots to the high-tech 21st century edition of the game. Preaching largely to the choir, the speakers urged about a thousand youth and high school football coaches and administrators to assure parents the game is not as dangerous as the neurologists and naysayers claim, and that the lessons about discipline and teamwork playing football provides far outweigh the risks.", "title": "Football\u2019s True Believers Circle the Wagons and Insist the Sport Is Just Fine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "I had invited him over only for sex, so when I woke the next morning to the sight of him putting on his pants, I said, \u201cDo you need me to walk you out?\u201d\n\n\u201cNo, I\u2019m just going to use the bathroom,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019d like to stay, if that\u2019s O.K.\u201d\n\nAnd it was. So he stayed for the rest of the day, never more than a few inches from me. We left the room only to use the bathroom or to shuffle to the kitchen for snacks. Meanwhile, my roommates laughed, gossiping about my \u201csexcapade with the cute guy from Tinder.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think you\u2019re the girl of my dreams,\u201d he said. \u201cI can\u2019t believe we met on Tinder.\u201d\n\nI had never been the girl of anyone\u2019s dreams \u2014 not even my own. I always imagined the quintessential girl of men\u2019s dreams to be taller than me, thinner, more poised and blond. But my lover insisted, and we lounged on top of each other until late in the afternoon.\n\nLater, I said, \u201cDo you usually have sex with girls the night you meet them?\u201d\n\nHe cocked an eyebrow. \u201cWhy, do I come off as a slut?\u201d", "title": "For Best Hookup Results, Use Your Words, O.K.?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The recently enacted tax package could also be a moderate benefit for corporate bonds. With a lower corporate tax rate, businesses are expected to bring more foreign earnings home, increasing the cash available to pay for dividends and share repurchases. That could mean the supply of new corporate bonds will shrink a bit, as companies lose some appetite for issuing debt to bolster shareholder returns.\n\nBasic math suggests that there is less reason to invest in lower quality corporate bonds. Kathy A. Jones, chief fixed income strategist at Charles Schwab, points out that high-yield bonds pay about 3.4 percentage points more than similar maturity Treasury issues, in contrast to the 5.4-percentage-point spread investors have typically been paid for taking on the risk of junk bonds. That\u2019s not much compensation, given that junk bonds tend to behave a lot like stock in bad markets.\n\nInvestors who enjoyed the strong 6 percent return for multisector bond funds in 2017 should take note that on average, more than one-third of the assets of these go-anywhere bond funds is invested in junk bonds, according to Morningstar.\n\nMr. Scholnick says Western Asset Management has reduced its high-yield holdings and increased its investment in bank loans. These securities are a form of low-quality corporate bonds with two compelling value propositions over standard junk bonds. In the event of a default, bank loan investors are paid before regular bond investors. In addition, the interest rate on bank loans fluctuates along with a benchmark index, such as the London Interbank Offer Rate, or Libor, and prospects for an increase are viewed as good.\n\nEmerging market bonds may be the best relative value for bond investors these days, considering that in many countries, economies are growing, inflation is low and central bank policy is reasonably strong.\n\n\u201cIn the past, it was emerging markets that held all the debt, but now all the debt is in Japan, Europe and the U.S.,\u201d said Mr. Rieder of BlackRock. In 2018, the best opportunities for positive returns after accounting for inflation could be in emerging markets.\n\nEmerging markets also are often more volatile. So for less adventuresome investors, money market funds may be appealing. The Federal Reserve\u2019s rate increases are slowly pushing these yields off zero. Mr. Bhatia says such funds will probably pay 1.5 to 2 percent by the end of this year.", "title": "For Bond Investors, Low Expectations in a Low-Yield World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "His serious misjudgment, Mr. Miller said, \u201cre-victimized a person who was already the victim of a terrible crime.\u201d\n\nHe went on: \u201cI sincerely apologize to her for that. Mr. Miller was not just any police official, but the one assigned to speak with reporters, so she would have expected more, he said.\n\nStill, an apology from Mr. Miller was something the woman expressed wanting earlier on Friday \u2014 hours before his apology came \u2014 when Mr. Garbus shared a statement from her with The New York Times.\n\nIn it, she traces the arc of her experiences forward to the current #MeToo phenomenon, warning that #MeToo is not a moment or a movement but \u201can ongoing reality\u201d for women.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. They employed racial stereotypes, she said, then turned on her when she protested.\n\n\u201cImmediately after I was raped, the policemen who responded drove me around the park, stopping and questioning black men who looked nothing like the description I had given them,\u201d she wrote. \u201cWhen I told them that as a black woman that made me uncomfortable, that it made me feel unsafe, they were visibly angry.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a column that appeared two days after the attack, the Daily News writer, Mike McAlary, cited questions raised by police investigators about her account, under a headline: \u201cRape Hoax the Real Crime.\u201d Citing unnamed police sources, Mr. McAlary, who died of cancer in 1998, said investigators believed the woman had fabricated the story to promote a gay and lesbian rally. \u201cThe woman, who will probably end up being arrested herself, invented the crime, they said, to promote her rally,\u201d Mr. McAlary wrote.\n\nThough she was not named in Mr. McAlary\u2019s columns in 1994, and has maintained her anonymity since, the public disclosures about her being an activist added to her agony over being doubted since she figured it might help people surmise her identity.\n\nMr. Miller, in his statement on Friday, did not address Mr. McAlary. In a deposition he gave in a resulting libel case, that was dismissed in 1997, Mr. Miller said he told reporters at an off-the-record briefing a day after the attack that detectives had doubts about the woman\u2019s account, but said Mr. McAlary had obtained some information about the doubts of detectives from another source too.\n\nAfter semen was found on the woman\u2019s jogging shorts, Mr. McAlary wrote that a police official had deemed the laboratory wrong. It turned out, however, that top police officials involved in the case had misunderstood the technical language of the lab report.\n\nIn her statement, the woman also said The Daily News owed her an apology. An editorial in the newspaper on Thursday said there were lessons in the episode for law enforcement and journalism. To that, Mr. Garbus said, \u201cThe Daily News non-apology was disgraceful.\u201d\n\nIn her statement, the woman thanked two officers: Detective Andrea Sorrentino, \u201cwho worked tirelessly\u201d on the case in 1994, and Detective Sarah Mathers \u201cwho solved it 23 years later.\u201d", "title": "For Brooklyn Rape Victim, a Long-Awaited Apology From Police", "authors": ["Al Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nReasonably priced does not spring to mind at mention of the chef Thomas Keller\u2019s French Laundry or Per Se. But it does apply to a new line of caviars, Regiis Ova, from Mr. Keller and Shaoching Bishop, who was previously with Sterling Caviar and Tsar Nicoulai Caviar, two California companies. I found the sturgeon caviars \u2014 from sustainable farms in California, Uruguay and central China \u2014 to be generally good quality and range from $66 to $120 for 30 grams (about an ounce), with higher prices delivering the most attractive and best-textured roes. The line also includes trout, salmon and excellent whitefish roe ($20 to $25 for 50 grams, about an ounce and three-quarters): Regiis Ova, regiisova.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. The new members included the billionaire founder of the Japanese telecommunications company SoftBank, Masayoshi Son, and the brothers Jorge and Jos\u00e9 R. Mas, members of one of Miami\u2019s most well-known Cuban exile families and the owners of Mastec, an engineering and construction company based nearby in Coral Gables. The other members of the group are Sprint\u2019s chief executive, Marcelo Claure, and the entertainment mogul Simon Fuller, a longtime associate of Beckham\u2019s.\n\n\u201cThe stars have aligned,\u201d Carlos A. Gim\u00e9nez, the Miami-Dade County mayor, said in a telephone interview on Monday. \u201cThere were a lot of false starts, a lot of obstacles to overcome. David persisted and persisted, and when a door closed, there was always another one.\u201d\n\nBeckham\u2019s first plan was to build a stadium in the county-owned PortMiami, but the cruise industry, heavily invested in the harbor, put up roadblocks to the deal. Later proposals included a waterfront site in downtown Miami and another in the Little Havana neighborhood, next to Marlins Park, but both ran into their own crippling hurdles.\n\nThat \u201crocky road,\u201d as Claure put it in his remarks on Monday, appeared to have come to an end with the ownership group\u2019s agreement to purchase almost nine acres in Miami\u2019s downtrodden Overtown neighborhood. If all goes well, that site will be home to a 25,000-seat stadium that could cost $500 million. Local officials, embarrassed by a deal for the Miami Marlins stadium that left taxpayers on the hook for $2.4 billion, had balked at helping to underwrite the costs of the soccer venue, and Beckham had to opt for private rather than public financing.\n\nAlthough the deal is all but sealed for the Overtown location, at least one legal challenge remains. It concerns part of the proposed site, a 2.8-acre lot owned by the county and used as a storage depot. In a lawsuit filed last summer, Bruce C. Matheson, a wealthy Miami landowner, challenged the county\u2019s approval of the $9 million sale since it had not allowed for competitive bids. County officials argued that Florida law permits such no-bid transactions involving public land if they result in wider economic benefits. In October, a Miami-Dade Circuit Court judge dismissed the lawsuit, but Matheson has appealed.\n\nIn addition, some residents of Overtown, traditionally one of the city\u2019s poorest and most underdeveloped neighborhoods, have objected to the proposed stadium on the grounds that there is no official provision for job creation in the immediate area.\n\nBut most businesses seem to welcome the prospect of a stadium in their midst. \u201cTalk about stimulating the neighborhood,\u201d said Luis Garc\u00eda, whose family has run a seafood restaurant on the Miami River, three blocks south of the proposed soccer venue, since 1966. \u201cI\u2019ve got to believe that local restaurants and bar owners are going to benefit. Consider the demographics: We have the melting pot of Latin America. How come we haven\u2019t had a major soccer team here?\u201d", "title": "For David Beckham and M.L.S., a Miami Marriage at Last", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "When I went on Terry Gross\u2019s radio show last year, the very first question she asked me was one I get asked during my work as a doctor all the time:\n\n\u201cCan I ask how old you are?\u201d\n\n\u201cTwenty-nine.\u201d\n\n\u201cSo when family members or loved ones see you,\u201d she went on, \u201cdo they ever look at you and go, \u2018You\u2019re so young, how can I trust you?\u2019\u201d\n\nIn many professions, a premium is placed on experience, with age often a surrogate for expertise \u2014 but probably no profession places more primacy on age than medicine. Nothing is more reassuring to patients than seeing a silver-haired doctor walk up to their bedside. To this day, medicine is largely an apprenticeship, with young physicians huddling around older physicians, straining to catch every word, so as to not lose a nugget of wisdom. Experience is even written into our dress codes: Students in many medical schools cannot wear long white coats, unlike their seniors; in some, even medical residents can\u2019t have coats that extend much below the waist.\n\nYet, as the field evolves into one where data and evidence are beginning to outweigh anecdotes and opinions, one thing is becoming increasingly clear: In medicine, a lack of experience may not actually be a bad thing.\n\nA paper published last year by researchers at Harvard showed something very striking \u2014 patients being taken care of by younger doctors were less likely to die. Younger, less experienced physicians are also less likely to order unnecessary tests in both men and women, to face disciplinary action from state medical boards or be cited for improper prescription of opioid painkillers and other controlled substances. These findings are far from isolated: The majority of research shows a consistent, positive relationship between lack of experience and better quality of clinical care.", "title": "Opinion | For Doctors, Age May Be More Than a Number", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Delrisa Sewell-Henry, a home health aide, was resigned to spending two hours on a bus and three subway trains just to get across Queens to care for a disabled man.\n\nBut when one train recently stopped for a sick passenger, her commute expanded to a mind-boggling three hours and 15 minutes. She was late. To make up the lost time, she stayed longer with her patient instead of picking up her granddaughter from school. She had to enlist a neighbor to do that \u2014 for $35.\n\nThen last week, another train was delayed. And she was late again.\n\n\u201cIt makes me angry,\u201d said Ms. Sewell-Henry, 54, who earns $13 an hour. \u201cIt\u2019s not like we\u2019re sitting around watching T.V. and doing nothing. We\u2019re doing something. We have to be there on time.\u201d\n\nBy now, the many ways New York City\u2019s failing subway system has upended countless lives has been well documented. But a new report finds that no group has been hurt more than the city\u2019s army of health care workers who fan out across the city every day to take care of older people, the frail and the sick. They ride trains and buses because they do not earn enough to take taxis or Ubers. Every disruption impacts patients and their families who count on them to arrive on time to provide medication and meals. For the workers, it can lead to reprimands, docked pay and being fired.", "title": "For Health Care Workers, the Worst Commutes in New York City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Chenault \u2018s choice to jump into the world of start-ups is more than just a business decision; to him, it is an opportunity to have a larger impact on Silicon Valley and its business culture.\n\nAs he assessed his opportunities, he became convinced that the tech start-up world had often come up short in meeting society\u2019s challenges.\n\nThis area, he said, is where he hopes he can have an impact.\n\nConsider Mr. Chenault some much-needed adult supervision.\n\n\u201cWhat I think is happening right now in the digital space is a maturation cycle and some people, as we\u2019ve seen, are going to handle that well and some people are going to crash and burn,\u201d he said, without naming names.\n\nOf course, he could be talking about any of a host of companies, like Uber, Google or Facebook, the latter of which is facing a revolt among consumers and possibly regulators over the way fake news proliferates on its site.\n\nVenture capital firms themselves are not exempt from these problems, as my colleague Katie Benner chronicled last summer with a striking expos\u00e9 of harassment by powerful investors.\n\n\u201cGiven their age and the scale and size and impact that they can have on our society, unless they make a step up, we are going to have some serious problems,\u2019\u2019 Mr. Chenault said. \u201cAnd we do have serious problems.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCompanies are starting to realize that they are growing up, and in growing up, they have to assume some broader responsibilities,\u201d he added. \u201cCompanies are at different stages, from a self awareness standpoint, in accepting that reality.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Chenault\u2019s management skills may be a perfect fit for the role General Catalyst needs him to fill. As start-ups are staying private longer, venture capital firms are finding that someone has to actually run the companies they invest in, to think beyond the early stages of fast growth \u2014 and a quick sale or initial public offering \u2014 and to help them scale over a decade.\n\n\u201cThe median time to I.P.O. has risen dramatically over the last decade, from 4.9 years in 2006 to 8.3 years in 2016,\u201d according to a report from Pitchbook, a data company that tracks deals. Airbnb has been private for 10 years, Uber for nine.\n\nWhen Mr. Chenault joined Airbnb\u2019s board last week, a company co-founder, Brian Chesky, whom Mr. Chenault has mentored for years, wrote a note to employees announcing the appointment. \u201cMany companies are designed to be finite,\u2019\u2019 Mr. Chesky wrote. \u201cFinite companies are focused on beating their competitors and appeasing short-term interests. But business is not finite. Unlike sports, there is no time clock, so there can be no winning or losing \u2014 there is merely surviving and innovating to endure.\u201d\n\nMr. Chenault believes there is real value in trying to influence start-ups early in their life cycle, so that patience and foresight become embedded in the DNA.\n\nOne problem Mr. Chenault wants to address \u2014 conspicuous to anyone paying attention, but bafflingly inconspicuous to those in the Valley \u2014 is the lack of diversity, both in gender and race, in the tech industry.\n\n\u201cDiversity in the technology digital industry is a big issue,\u201d he said. \u201cIf we don\u2019t make accelerated progress in that area, it will have dire consequences for our society.\u201d\n\nIt is even worse in the venture capital industry, where there are few women and even fewer African-Americans.\n\nThe numbers are embarrassing and depressing: African-Americans make up only 3 percent of the venture capital work force, according to a study conducted in 2016 by the National Venture Capital Association and Deloitte University Leadership Center for Inclusion. Latinos represented only 4 percent of the venture capital industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Chenault said he has known some of founding partners at General Catalyst for more than 20 years, including David Fialkow and Joel Cutler, who have been business partners since they met as children at Camp Cedar (a summer camp in Maine that I also attended). The fund, which has some $3.75 billion, was founded in Cambridge, Mass., in 1999 and has offices in New York; Palo Alto, Calif.; and San Francisco. Mr. Chenault said he would be based in New York.\n\nIn addition to Facebook and Airbnb, he is also on the boards of IBM and Procter & Gamble, which gives him insight into what\u2019s going on in the economy. He acknowledged that there might be times he has to recuse himself from dealing with board issues that conflict with one of the investments General Catalyst makes.\n\nBut at this stage of his career, he believes a move to venture capital is the right \u201cvehicle\u2019\u2019 to try to make a difference. Mr. Chenault hopes to help companies not just make long-term plans, but to think about their role in society.\n\n\u201cVenture capital firms have to be more catalytic agents of change not just in the business development,\u201d he said, \u201cbut in helping change the culture in the technology digital sector so there is a greater focus on the responsibilities they have.\u201d", "title": "For His Next Act, Ken Chenault Turns His Focus on Silicon Valley", "authors": ["Andrew Ross Sorkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "And though he is by most measures exiting on a high note, he has yet to deliver on some of his biggest agenda items, including high-speed rail and repairing the state\u2019s water systems. He also predicted in the interview that California would soon enter a recession, an unusual assertion by a sitting governor.\n\nThere will, no doubt, be some Democrats who will be glad to see Mr. Brown move on; while he is celebrated in some quarters as a centering force for California and the state Democratic Party, Mr. Brown is a moderate in a state that is moving left. His departure clears the way for candidates waiting in the wings who have not shied away from expressing their eagerness for new faces to take it in that direction.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to see a new generation of Democratic leadership being ushered into new political positions,\u201d said Kevin de Leon, 51, the California Senate leader challenging Senator Dianne Feinstein, 84, who is seeking a sixth term.\n\nSenator Kamala Harris, 53, who replaced Senator Barbara Boxer, 77, when she retired, has emerged nationally as what Mr. Brown once was \u2014 a potential presidential candidate representing the nation\u2019s most populous state and embodying the hopes of its liberal wing.\n\n\u201cThere has been a generation of really incredible leaders that have come out of California and proven themselves to be national and global leaders,\u201d Ms. Harris said.\n\nMr. Brown said he was ready for his exit, but demurred when asked if he was confident he was leaving California in good hands. \u201cWell, that\u2019s a loaded question,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat if I say I am not confident? That\u2019s one damn headline. So I have to say I\u2019m confident.\u201d\n\nStill, the state under Mr. Brown is prosperous: Its economy is booming and Mr. Brown\u2019s latest budget projects a $6.1 billion surplus in the next fiscal year, compared with the more than $26 billion deficit he faced when he proposed his first budget. Standing before a racially integrated Town Hall audience in New York, Ms. Hansberry, then 34, sought to counter the growing white liberal criticism of the racial militancy expressed by a younger generation of African-Americans.\n\n\u201cAnd I wrote to The Times and said, you know, \u2018Can\u2019t you understand that this is the perspective from which we are now speaking?\u2019\u201d Hansberry said. \u201cIt isn\u2019t as if we got up today and said, you know, \u2018what can we do to irritate America?\u2019 you know. It\u2019s because that since 1619, Negroes have tried every method of communication, of transformation of their situation from petition to the vote, everything. We\u2019ve tried it all. There isn\u2019t anything that hasn\u2019t been exhausted.\u201d\n\nThis image of Hansberry \u2014 exasperated, fatigued and sympathetic to the nationalist ideologies that would later blossom in the Black Power movement \u2014 might surprise those who know her only through the success of \u201cA Raisin in the Sun.\u201d With that much-lauded play, about a working-class African-American family on the verge of racially desegregating a Chicago suburb, Hansberry became the first African-American woman to have a show produced on Broadway, in 1959.", "title": "For Lorraine Hansberry, \u2018A Raisin in the Sun\u2019 Was Just the Start", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The couple, beaming in their own immaculately pressed blue mess uniforms, the most formal threads in the Army\u2019s wardrobe, were celebrated by a saber-arch salute as they departed the chapel.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve experienced everything from people feeling awkward around us to being called faggots while holding hands and walking down the street, stuff like that,\u201d said Captain Franchino, who was born and raised in Stony Point, N.Y., the youngest son of Holly Franchino, a retired pharmacist, and Robert Franchino, a retired sergeant with the Police Department in Clarkstown, N.Y.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBut despite what we\u2019ve been through,\u201d Captain Franchino added, \u201cnothing was worse than having served during the \u2018don\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u2019 years.\u201d\n\nThe emotions and romantic feelings felt by Captains Hall and Franchino, as well as scores of others from the L.G.B.T. military community, were hamstrung by \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell,\u201d a policy that went into effect in October 1993 under President Bill Clinton; it forbade any homosexual or bisexual member of the military from disclosing his or her sexual orientation or from speaking about any homosexual relationships, including marriages.\n\n\u201cThrough mutual friends at West Point, we had each learned the other was gay, and though we were attracted to one another, we couldn\u2019t say or do anything about it,\u201d said Captain Hall, who grew up in Chattanooga, Tenn., the only son of Kyle Hall, a middle school mathematics teacher, and Stephen Hall, the vice president for nylon polymer strategic development at Koch Industries in Wichita, Kan., where his parents now live.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really frustrating when two people have feelings for each other but are not allowed to act on them,\u201d Captain Hall added. \u201cWe were serving under a policy that was telling all of us \u2014 perfectly capable soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines \u2014 to lie about ourselves.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCaptain Franchino said that lying was much better than the alternative.\n\n\u201cWe couldn\u2019t tell the truth for fear of what would happen to us,\u201d he said. \u201cSo we put it in our minds that we were never going to say we were gay, we were never going to get made fun of, and we were certainly never going to get kicked out of the Army.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first time they met was on a Friday afternoon at West Point in August 2009.\n\nCaptain Franchino was taking part in an annual tradition during Ring Weekend in which freshmen (known as plebes) get a chance to retaliate against their often overbearing senior cadets (known as firsties) by doing all they can to delay the departure of those seniors, who are trying to hurry home after the ceremony to spend a weekend with their families.\n\nIt took Captain Hall, swarmed by plebes, a full hour to cross the final 100 yards to his room. When he got there, he had no idea that four more plebes were waiting patiently to jump out of hiding spots in the room in an effort to scare him and further delay his weekend. After the first three plebes had departed, Captain Hall assumed he was alone, but as he prepared to leave, he was ambushed by Captain Franchino, who had been hiding under the bed.\n\n\u201cWhen I came out from under the bed, Dan was so startled, he jumped over his desk,\u201d Captain Franchino said, laughing.\n\nPhoto\n\nCaptain Hall said he remembered thinking, \u201cThis guy has a lot of guts, and he\u2019s kind of cute too.\u201d\n\nThey went their separate ways, though neither veered too far from the other\u2019s line of vision. In January 2010, they selected each other as a partner in a mentorship program that allowed seniors to offer instruction to freshmen who were following similar career paths.\n\nBy April of that year, it was clear to their fellow cadets that a spark had been ignited, but under the rules, there could be no flame.\n\n\u201cYou could tell that there was this chemistry, this unspoken communication between them,\u201d said Capt. Owen Waits, a close friend to both who was a senior cadet at that time and later married Captain Hall\u2019s sister, Lauren.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was kind of strange because you knew that there was this whole aspect of their feelings and personalities that were being suppressed,\u201d Captain Waits said. \u201cBut that\u2019s just the way it was.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in September 2011, it was that way no longer. Congress repealed \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell,\u201d and Captains Hall and Franchino were soon celebrating their new sense of freedom.\n\n\u201cVinny came out with a big splash to everyone on Facebook, posting all of these pictures of himself and Dan kissing and hugging, and I thought it was so brave that he did that,\u201d said Captain Franchino\u2019s uncle, Charlie Franchino, of Brooklyn, who is also in a same-sex marriage and was often the shoulder that his nephew leaned on when struggling to keep his sexuality a secret.\n\nMr. Franchino said he also stepped in to \u201chelp ease the shock that was initially felt by Vinny\u2019s parents.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMy brother\u2019s a cop, he\u2019s a tough guy, and so I knew it wasn\u2019t going to be easy for him and his couple\u2019s reception at the elegant Skylands Manor in Ringwood, N.J., a 44-room Tudor revival mansion perched high in the heavily wooded Ramapo Mountains along a stretch of long and winding country roads snaking through Ringwood State Park.\n\n\u201cSpeaking from my heart, I love Dan,\u201d Holly Franchino said during the cocktail hour.\n\nHer husband, Robert Franchino, added of their new son-in-law: \u201cThey are two peas in a pod.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou can see the chemistry between them,\u201d he added. \u201cWithout a doubt, Vinny is absolutely a happier person today than he was before he met Dan.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe relationship has not always been so accepted or in tune, including beginning with their first date in February 2012 in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue gun, as well as Hellfire missiles and Hydra Rocket Pods.\n\nUpon hearing the news, Captain Franchino was not feeling quite as macho as Captain Hall. Just five months removed from \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell,\u201d the young soldier was on edge.\n\n\u201cI was so worried about Dan, it was really nerve-racking,\u201d Captain Franchino recalled. \u201cAt the time, there was just too much pressure involved, we were both very nervous about the long-distance thing, so we both thought it was best to just step away.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThey began dating other people but had a change of heart and got back together in November of that year.\n\nThree years later, their relationship was on more solid ground, so Captain Franchino was in a better place emotionally to hear the news that Captain Hall was being deployed to Kuwait.\n\nA year after that, Captain Hall was flying his Apache above war-torn Iraq.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve just grown accustomed to being apart at times,\u201d said Captain Franchino, who spent all of 2017 deployed in Germany and several countries in Eastern Europe. \u201cIt\u2019s a part of who we are, a part of what we do, so we simply accept it.\u201d\n\nCaptain Hall, who said he plans on \u201cleaving the Army after spring,\u201d also said that his military stint, especially the time he spent in the cockpits of Apache helicopters, \u201chas brought a lot of excitement to my life, and so has Vinny.\u201d\n\nBut when pressed, Captain Hall refused to say which of the two has brought him more excitement.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t ask,\u201d he said with a wink and a smile. \u201cI won\u2019t tell.\u201d", "title": "For Love of Country, and Each Other", "authors": ["Vincent M. Mallozzi"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The oven was on in Patricia Elcock\u2019s apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan because the radiators were cold \u2014 and a window in her 10-year-old grandson\u2019s room would not close all the way. They had taped clear plastic over it, hoping the room would feel less drafty.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s cold, it\u2019s cold, it\u2019s cold,\u201d said Ms. Elcock, 59, a security guard who has lived in the building at 99-103 Avenue C. for about 13 years. But she is probably the only person who responded to that feeling by putting herself in a wooden wheel so that she can be rotated 360 degrees around the axis of her nose.\n\n\u201cBy replicating the sensation, I can try to understand it,\u201d she said last week, in a Skype interview from her home in Boulder, Colo. A professor in the theater and dance department at the University of Colorado there, she is quick to say that she is \u201ca dancer, for sure.\u201d Yet her eccentric and marvelously original art defies easy categorization. One of her works, \u201cTifprabap.org,\u201d is both a performance piece and a website for a new religion. For another, \u201cPythagodress,\u201d she created a huge pentagonal costume of fabric and pipes that was part confessional booth, part giant uterus.\n\n\u201cA dance\u201d is how she labels her latest work, which is to be performed Jan. 9-11 at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn as part of American Realness, the annual genre-blurring festival of avant-garde performance. That there is no dancing, per se, in this dance isn\u2019t out of the ordinary for American Realness, but ambivalence about performance is emphasized to an unusual degree in her work\u2019s title: \u201cThe Rehearsal Artist.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy father\u2019s sister was an extraordinary pianist,\u201d Ms. Ellsworth explained. \u201cShe would practice and practice but she never wanted to perform.
