You\u2019re a rehearsal artist.\u2019\u201d", "title": "For Michelle Ellsworth, Practice Makes \u2026 More Practice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI thought my comment on the dollar was actually quite clear yesterday,\u201d he told reporters hours before Mr. Trump arrived in Davos. \u201cI thought it was actually balanced and consistent with what I\u2019ve said before, which is we\u2019re not concerned with where the dollar is in the short term, it\u2019s a very, very liquid market, and we believe in free currencies. And that there\u2019s both advantages and disadvantages of where the dollar is in the short term. Let me say, I thought that was clear.\u201d\n\nMaybe it should have been. But Treasury secretaries have learned over the years that comments they thought were clear have not always been taken that way. More than perhaps any other official in the American government except the Federal Reserve chief, a Treasury secretary finds his remarks flyspecked to an extraordinary degree, with each word often given far more meaning than intended.\n\n\u201cTreasury secretaries normally are highly disciplined when they speak on the dollar to ensure their words are treated seriously when they want to signal policy shifts or to build confidence in challenging economic moments,\u201d said Gene Sperling, who served as the top economic adviser to Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton. \u201cThis type of seemingly off-the-cuff and politically careless back and forth just erodes that type of authority when it will be most needed.\u201d\n\nTony Fratto, who was a Treasury Department official under President George W. Bush, said that Mr. Mnuchin had just come across the same tripwire that his predecessors had stumbled over, but that it was part of learning the job.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not surprising that a Treasury secretary has one of these moments \u2014 almost all of them do,\u201d he said. \u201cThe reason is that the language of currency markets is different from everyday rhetoric. In fact, it\u2019s even different from everyday economic rhetoric. I worked for three Treasury secretaries, and I\u2019m friends with three others. Almost every Treasury secretary I know has had to acquire that language on the job.\u201d", "title": "For Mnuchin, a Lesson in How Words Can Move Markets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "There will be no white smoke from a chapel chimney. There will be no church convention, no lobbying and no election.\n\nMormons don\u2019t do succession drama. When the head of their church dies, as Thomas S. Monson did on Tuesday, the next leader is chosen from the top ranks based strictly on seniority. The system is intended to avoid any hint of instability or intrigue, but it practically guarantees that the president will be elderly \u2014 even very elderly.\n\nPresident Monson was 90, and had served as prophet and head of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints for nearly 10 years. Following a tradition that dates from the church\u2019s early years, he is to be succeeded by the longest-serving member of a church governing body known as the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles.\n\nRight now, that man is President Russell M. Nelson, a former heart surgeon, who is 93. Next in line after him is Dallin H. Oaks, a former president of Brigham Young University and state Supreme Court justice. He is 85. You have to pass four more people in the line of succession before you get to someone born after World War II.", "title": "For Mormons, Succession Drama Is Against Their Religion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "YANGON, Myanmar \u2014 For Myanmar\u2019s army, the campaign of atrocity it has waged to drive hundreds of thousands of ethnic Rohingya Muslims out of the country is no innovation. The force was born in blood 76 years ago and has been shedding it ever since.\n\nIts founders, known as the Thirty Comrades, established the army in 1941 with a ghoulish ceremony in Bangkok, where they drew each other\u2019s blood with a single syringe, mixed it in a silver bowl and drank it to seal their vow of loyalty.\n\nThe army that they formed led the nation to independence in 1948. But except for a brief, initial period of peace, it has spent the last seven decades warring with its own people.\n\nThe army, known as the Tatmadaw, seized power from the civilian government in Burma, as the country is also known, in 1962. The military killed thousands of protesters to keep power in 1988 and suppressed another popular uprising, the Saffron Revolution, in 2007.", "title": "For Myanmar\u2019s Army, Ethnic Bloodletting Is Key to Power and Riches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "TAMPA, Fla. \u2014 Over the past two decades, the N.H.L.\u2019s best players have been participants in the Winter Olympics. But this year, they will have a new role when the Olympic men\u2019s hockey tournament begins Feb. 14: they will be fans.\n\nCiting injury concerns, costs and what it called a lack of tangible benefit, the N.H.L. decided not to schedule its customary three-week Olympic break or loan its clubs\u2019 players for the Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.\n\nFor many players at last weekend\u2019s All-Star festivities here, the disappointment over being unable to participate has lingered, and it is only starting to give way to a mix of national pride, curiosity and support of friends.\n\n\u201cWhen it all came out, I was pretty angry that we weren\u2019t going to be going, so I told myself that I\u2019m probably not going to watch the Olympics,\u201d said Dallas Stars forward Tyler Seguin, who most likely would have been on the Canadian Olympic team for the first time. \u201cNow as it\u2019s getting closer, I\u2019m realizing that I\u2019m still proud to be Canadian and I am going to watch. But, obviously, it\u2019s going to be pretty bittersweet.\u201d", "title": "For N.H.L. Stars, the Olympics Remain a \u2018What If?\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn one of the poorest counties in the nation, the last thing we need is to be constantly sued by these predatory attorneys,\u201d said Phil Lyman, a county commissioner. \u201cOutside people try to put this into a racial divide that simply doesn\u2019t exist in San Juan County.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFights over indigenous voting rights are playing out in the West and the Midwest, a trend that has the potential to tip tight races in states with large native populations, like Alaska and Arizona, and to influence matters of national importance, like the future of Bears Ears National Monument, a conservation area in this county that is at the center of a fierce debate over public lands.\n\nToday, Native Americans are suing over a new voter identification law in North Dakota, where lawyers say there is not a single driver\u2019s license site on a reservation in a state that requires identification to vote. The outcome of the lawsuit could influence this year\u2019s congressional election, helping to secure or flip the seat of Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat with wide Native American support.\n\nIn the battleground state of Nevada, the Pyramid Lake and Walker River Paiutes won a lawsuit in late 2016 that charged that tribal citizens had to travel as many as 100 miles to vote. The suit forced officials to open new polling stations in tribal areas and spurred nine other tribes to request their own election sites.\n\nAnd in Alaska, where native people make up a fifth of the population, officials recently rolled out election materials in the Yup\u2019ik, Inupiaq and Gwich\u2019in languages, following federal rulings that found the state had failed to provide materials equivalent to those used by English speakers.\n\nAfter those changes, turnout in villages rose by as much as 20 percent, increasing the political power of the state\u2019s native residents.\n\nOther native voting cases are proceeding or have been recently settled in Arizona, Montana, South Dakota and Wyoming. And a second case is open in San Juan County, this one challenging the county\u2019s decision to move to an all-mail ballot. Plaintiffs contend this disenfranchises native people who live far from reliable mail service.\n\nRedrawing District Lines Percentage of Native Americans in each district. District 1 District 1 Old New 11 percent 30 percent UTAH San Juan County San Juan County Navajo Nation District 2 29 percent District 2 66 percent District 3 District 3 93 percent 80 percent NAVAJO NATION NAVAJO NATION District 1 Old 30 percent UTAH San Juan County San Juan County Navajo Nation District 2 29 percent District 3 93 percent NAVAJO NATION District 1 New 11 percent District 2 66 percent District 3 80 percent NAVAJO NATION\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s part of a larger political trend of Native Americans organizing and protecting themselves,\u201d said Daniel McCool, a professor emeritus at the University of Utah and a voting rights expert who was hired by the plaintiffs in the Navajo redistricting case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are 6.6 million American Indians and Alaska Natives in the United States, representing about 2 percent of the population. But many live in America\u2019s most remote places \u2014 amid mountain passes or miles of near-empty plains \u2014 and the native path to the ballot box has often been less visible than that of other groups.\n\nIt was not until 1924 that Congress granted native people the right to vote, and for generations afterward, local and state governments have blocked them from doing so, often saying that Native Americans living on reservations were not state residents.\n\nThe Voting Rights Act of 1965 was a critical moment, prohibiting election practices that discriminate on the basis of race. But relatively few lawsuits were filed on behalf of native voters until the 1990s.\n\nThe pace of legal challenges has picked up recently, something observers attribute to a realization that American Indians can influence local and national policy. The fate of Bears Ears, a conservation area that originally occupied a quarter of this 8,000-square-mile county, is one such issue.\n\nWhen President Trump slashed the size of the monument last month, one argument was that he was considering the desires of local officials. A Navajo-controlled commission, however, could oppose the decision, a move that could influence coming legal battles over the monument\u2019s fate.\n\nPhoto\n\nSan Juan County is a hardscrabble expanse in the state\u2019s southeast corner, and home to some 16,000 people. The county population is about half Native American and half white, and battles over resources have often fallen along racial lines.\n\nThe lower portion of the county overlaps the Navajo reservation, and native people bring millions of dollars to the county each year in the form of oil and gas revenue and other taxes. But those living on the reservation do not pay property taxes, frustrating many others who feel they pay more than their fair share.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the south, where most native families live, the library is in the corner of a trailer, there is no hospital or bank, and residents have spent more than a generation suing the county for services.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlicia Coggeshell, 52, lives in the south with two children and three grandchildren. She has no running water or internet service, and on a recent morning she traveled to the footbridge she uses to get to the market.\n\nThese days, it is so dilapidated that her neighbors sometimes fall into the icy water below, she said.\n\n\u201cWe asked the county and the county says, It\u2019s not our responsibility. This is what we mean: forgotten,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhite families live mostly in the north, home to two expansive libraries, a community center on a golf course, a recreation center with a pool, and the seats of local power: the sheriff\u2019s office, the courthouse, the school administration building.\n\nTauna Larson, a retired educator who lives in the north, said she looked at the possibility of two Navajo commissioners with some trepidation. \u201cI worry that they might tend to look out more for the reservation,\u201d she said. \u201cThe majority tends to take care of their own.\u201d\n\nThe county also has a contentious relationship with the federal government, which controls 60 percent of the land here and has battled with local leaders over a range of issues, including the protection of Native American artifacts and access to a beloved public canyon.\n\nCommissioner Bruce Adams and Commissioner Lyman have been intensely critical of the federal government, and both said they believed the judge\u2019s decision was a punishment for their resistance.\n\n\u201cI think there is retribution,\u201d Mr. Adams said. \u201cWe\u2019re tired of being the scapegoat, saying we\u2019re doing everything wrong, when we try to abide by the law.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJudge Shelby declined to comment.\n\nThe old commission map made Native Americans about 30 percent of the population in two districts, and 93 percent in a third district. The new one makes them 66 percent in one district, 80 percent in another, and 11 percent in another.\n\nIt will be used in a 2018 local election.\n\nMr. Jones, the plaintiff in the case, is 62 and was born before most Native Americans could vote in the state.\n\nOn a recent evening he pulled on a black cowboy hat and walked into a tribal meeting to explain the results of the lawsuit to a crowd.\n\nKenny Victor, 57, sat on a couch in the back, looking a bit tearful. He said he was a Navy veteran and that he welcomed the decision. \u201cI served for the right to vote,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s long overdue. We need representation.\u201d", "title": "For Native Americans, a \u2018Historic Moment\u2019 on the Path to Power at the Ballot Box", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "It is unclear whether the strategies are working: There were nine killings during the first 12 days of 2018.\n\nThe Police Department finds signs of hope where it can. The first weekend in January was a bright spot; there was only a single homicide. \u201cThree days, one murder \u2014 that\u2019s no accident,\u201d Kevin Davis, the police commissioner, said at the next daily crime intervention meeting. \u201cBut what gets us is the Mondays and Tuesdays. Let\u2019s do the best we can.\u201d\n\nThe police say the vast majority of homicides are retaliatory and committed by repeat offenders. Last year\u2019s victims had an average of 11 arrests each. Almost half had been arrested in connection with violent crimes and nearly three-quarters on drug charges. The suspected killers had similar rap sheets, though they had been arrested fewer times on average than the victims.\n\nSome woes common to cities are worse in Baltimore. A port city, it has been a center of heroin use and distribution since at least the 1970s. \u201cIf I live in a neighborhood that has been festering with drugs for 20 years, I\u2019m going to be a drug dealer or be on drugs or be a victim of one or the other,\u201d said Tammatha Woodhouse, the principal of Excel Academy, the small alternative school that Mr. Scott attended.\n\nThe neighborhoods she is talking about have been starved of investment in schools, businesses \u2014 even sidewalk repair. The city has 16,000 abandoned homes. Its rate among children of lead poisoning, which often comes from peeling paint and has been linked to lack of impulse control and learning disabilities, is nearly three times higher than the national rate.\n\n\u201cWhen we don\u2019t address the real cause of poverty, we put young people in places and situations they wouldn\u2019t have been otherwise,\u201d Ms. Woodhouse said.\n\nThe deaths of her students bear the hallmarks of a city awash in guns, with too few residents willing to tell the police what they know.", "title": "For One Baltimore School, 7 Killings in Just 15 Months", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Francis identified social networks as the delivery systems for such fake news.\n\n\u201cUntrue stories can spread so quickly that even authoritative denials fail to contain the damage,\u201d he wrote, adding that those living virtual lives in like-minded silos allow disinformation to thrive and that the absence of opposing viewpoints turns people into \u201cunwilling accomplices in spreading biased and baseless ideas.\u201d\n\nRussian hackers took advantage of just such conditions in the 2016 American elections, sowing discord and attempting to sway the electorate through sophisticated influence campaigns. Francis steered clear of such real-world examples. Instead, he broadly identified greed as a key engine for the spread of fake news.\n\n\u201cFake news often goes viral, spreading so fast that it is hard to stop, not because of the sense of sharing that inspires the social media, but because it appeals to the insatiable greed so easily aroused in human beings,\u201d he wrote.\n\nThe results, he said, are soul-killing.\n\nTurning to the \u201cThe Brothers Karamazov,\u201d he quoted Dostoyevsky: \u201cPeople who lie to themselves and listen to their own lie come to such a pass that they cannot distinguish the truth within them, or around them, and so lose all respect for themselves and for others.\u201d This leads to the coarsening of society, Francis said.\n\nTo combat fake news, the pope called for personal efforts to unmask disinformation, but he also praised educational programs, regulatory efforts and social media companies\u2019 progress in verifying personal identities \u201cconcealed behind millions of digital profiles.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, the European Union and several European countries have established offices to combat fake news \u2014 this week, Britain became the latest. And fake news has emerged as a major theme in the Italian elections scheduled for March 4, and it is often discussed in the Italian news media that imbues the Vatican.\n\nThe speaker of the lower house of the Italian Parliament, Laura Boldrini, has backed a program in Italian public schools to teach children how to identify fake news. The government announced this month an online service through the country\u2019s postal police that would respond to, and assess, accusations of fake news.", "title": "For Pope Francis, Fake News Goes Back to the Garden of Eden", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 For most visitors to Rome, the city gets high marks for its monuments, food, temperate climate and laid-back lifestyle \u2014 the dolce vita.\n\nBut Roman cabbies often get a failing grade.\n\nSocial media is rife with cautionary tales of ripoffs and swindles, often involving scenic \u2014 but unsolicited \u2014 drives past Rome\u2019s historic sights or taxi meters that spin faster than they probably should.\n\nIt hasn\u2019t been the best calling card for the Italian capital, especially as cabbies are often the first locals tourists interact with.\n\nWhich is why on a recent morning a few dozen cabdrivers found themselves in a nondescript hotel room taking a crash course in \u201ccourtesy, hospitality, language and excellence.\u201d", "title": "For Rome\u2019s Taxi Drivers, Lessons in Courtesy and Cultural Savvy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Not even the tennis dynamo Serena Williams is immune from the complications and challenges new mothers face during and after childbirth.\n\nIn a Vogue cover story published online on Wednesday, Ms. Williams, who holds 23 Grand Slam titles \u2014 some call her a superhero, others a queen \u2014 shared her agonizing postnatal experience, including an episode in which hospital employees did not act on her concern that she was experiencing a pulmonary embolism, a sudden blockage of an artery in the lung by a blood clot. She is prone to such clots, a condition that nearly killed her in 2011.\n\n\u201cSerena lives in fear of blood clots,\u201d the Vogue article said.\n\nOn Sept. 2, the day after giving birth to her daughter via cesarean section, Ms. Williams was having trouble breathing and \u201cimmediately assumed she was having another pulmonary embolism,\u201d the article says.\n\nShe alerted a nurse to what she felt was happening in her body and asked for a CT scan and a blood thinner, but the nurse suggested that pain medication had perhaps left Ms. Williams confused, according to Vogue. Ms. Williams insisted, but a doctor instead performed an ultrasound of her legs.", "title": "For Serena Williams, Childbirth Was a Harrowing Ordeal. She\u2019s Not Alone.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "North and South Korea also reached an agreement last Wednesday for their athletes to march together under one flag at the opening ceremony on Feb. 9.\n\nWith the official announcement on Saturday that 12 North Korean players would be added to the Olympic women\u2019s team roster, with three of them mandated to dress for each game, some of the South Korean athletes fear losing playing time or being benched for some games.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard because the players have earned their spots, and they think they deserve to go to the Olympics,\u201d the women\u2019s coach, Sarah Murray, told the South Korean news media last week. \u201cThe players said in June not to make them a political statement and that they just want to play the game,\u201d Ms. Murray added. \u201cI agreed with them.\u201d\n\nWithin South Korea, criticism of the government\u2019s decision to field an inter-Korean team has undermined the approval ratings of President Moon Jae-in, who has vocally supported the North\u2019s inclusion in hockey.\n\nAccording to the most recent Gallup poll, his rating has dropped to 67 percent, its lowest mark in 16 weeks. Polls taken in South Korea within the last week have also shown that many respondents disagree with the decision to add North Koreans to the roster.\n\nOn social media and in petitions filed with the presidential Blue House, South Koreans have shown sympathy for the South Korean hockey players. \u201cI don\u2019t think the athletes\u2019 lives should be sacrificed for an event,\u201d wrote one Facebook user, Jaeeok Kim. One petition opposing the inter-Korean team, submitted on the Blue House website, drew more than 50,000 signatures.\n\n\u201cCan abstract values like \u2018peace\u2019 and \u2018unification\u2019 get ahead of individual freedom?\u201d one commenter on the petition wrote. \u201cSouth Korea is a free liberal country, not a socialist country. I hope the government will not force individual sacrifice.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLee Min-ji, a player who lost a spot on the Olympic roster, posted \u2014 and then later took down \u2014 a long statement on Instagram, lamenting the decision to add North Koreans to the team as \u201cextremely unfortunate.\u201d\n\n\u201cHow can one think that the players would take this situation in a good mood,\u201d Ms. Lee wrote, \u201ceven when anyone can become such a sacrificed player?\u201d\n\nMost of the players are still teenagers, and several have battled injuries and endured long commutes and punishing training along with the tormenting embarrassment of blowout losses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith the South Korean team ranked 22nd in the world, many around the team believe the decision to unite with North Korean players is rooted in disrespect. The men\u2019s team was never considered for integration.\n\nLast week, South Korea\u2019s prime minister, Lee Nak-yeon, drew sharp ire when he said that the women\u2019s team was not a medal contender anyway, implying that its athletic unity could be sacrificed for political unity. He later apologized for the comments.\n\nSome analysts said the decision was simply sexist. \u201cThere is a degree of gendered notion that women\u2019s sports aren\u2019t as important and that they can be used in this soft cultural approach,\u201d said Benjamin Young, a Ph.D. candidate in modern Korean history at George Washington University. \u201cThe South Korean government is not having two inter-Korean hockey teams, male and female. They are kind of making explicit their gender bias known. I can certainly understand why the team players, coaches and public are upset.\u201d\n\nAnalysts said young South Koreans in particular objected to the last-minute insertion of North Korean players for political reasons as fundamentally unfair.\n\n\u201cDuring the campaign for the 19th presidential election, President Moon Jae-in stressed, \u2018Opportunity will be fair; the process will be fixed and the result just,\u2019 \u201d a commenter wrote on a petition submitted to the Blue House. \u201cBut the government that took away our athletes\u2019 opportunity; that ignored the preparation process, is this really just?\u201d\n\nLee Byuntae, a professor of information systems and economics at Kaist College of Business in Seoul, said Mr. Moon was particularly vulnerable to such criticism since he was elected on the back of the impeachment of President Park Guen-hye last spring. She was ousted after widespread protests against politically motivated favoritism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the case of the presidential protests, critics initially balked at corruption when they learned that the daughter of a longtime confidante of Ms. Park had illegally enrolled in a prestigious university using her mother\u2019s connections to force the university to accept her despite poor qualifications.\n\nIn the case of the ice hockey team, Professor Lee said, the government is favoring North Korean players in order to make a political statement. \u201cThe government high officers, without any consultation with the hockey players, decided they will form this united team,\u201d he said.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s sports minister, Do Jong-hwan, initially raised the idea of a joint team last June, which bothered players then.\n\n\u201cThey didn\u2019t want it to happen,\u201d said Marissa Brandt, a player who was born in South Korea and adopted by a family in Minnesota, in an interview last October. Ms. Brandt, who said she never \u201cfelt Korean\u201d growing up, is an assistant captain who proudly wears her Korean name on her jersey.\n\n\u201cEvery girl on this team has put in so much time and effort, and it would be tough to see any of us get cut or have to give up a spot to someone else,\u201d Ms. Brandt said. \u201cWe are such a tight-knit team, and we want to stick together.\u201d\n\nSome analysts said the opportunity to create a sense of unity and advance a peace process was more important than the team\u2019s disappointment.\n\n\u201cThe public hoopla on how we are sacrificing the young Korean women\u2019s Olympic dreams, I think, is another political statement with specific aims to undermine the fact that there is going to be some peace process going on with the Pyeongchang Olympics,\u201d said Chung Yong-chul, a professor of sports psychology in the Graduate School of Education at Sogang University in Seoul. \u201cAll the people talking about how unfair it is for them to give up their spot, they didn\u2019t even know what ice hockey was before this issue came up.\u201d\n\nFor now, the South Korean teammates are putting in their last practices before the Games begin next month. The slogan on their black warm-up shirts reads: \u201cMake Korea Proud.\u201d", "title": "For South Korea\u2019s Hockey Women, Unity With North Is a Bitter Burden", "authors": ["Motoko Rich", "Seth Berkman"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "On Monday night, after his victory over Thiem, Sandgren was asked about online exchanges he has had with right-wing activists.\n\n\u201cWho you follow on Twitter, I feel, doesn\u2019t matter even a little bit,\u201d Sandgren said Monday. \u201cWhat information you see doesn\u2019t dictate what you think or believe. I think it\u2019s crazy to think that. I think it\u2019s crazy to assume that.\u201d\n\nYet by Tuesday morning, all of Sandgren\u2019s tweets since June 2016 had been deleted. Several hours later, only a single retweet was left on his feed \u2014 a long tennis article from 2013 that features him prominently.\n\nIn a television interview with ESPN on Tuesday, Sandgren said he deleted his tweets not because it\u2019s \u201csomething that I\u2019m really necessarily embarrassed about,\u201d but because he thought that \u201ccreating a version of a cleaner start is not a bad call.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cPeople can screenshot, save and distribute everything they would like to. I know that, and that\u2019s fine. It is what it is. It\u2019s just something that I thought wouldn\u2019t be a bad way to kind of move forward.\u201d\n\nBefore his social media posts disappeared, dozens of other Twitter users and publications had preserved them.\n\nOn Jan. 14, Sandgren retweeted a video on Twitter posted by Nicholas Fuentes, a young alt-right commentator and a former host of a podcast called \u201cAmerica First.\u201d (Fuentes retweeted support for Sandgren on Monday.) And in November 2016, shortly after the presidential election, Sandgren seemed to support debunked online reports of children being kidnapped, molested and trafficked in a Washington pizzeria as part of a sex-abuse ring connected to Hillary Clinton.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s sickening and the collective evidence is too much to ignore,\u201d Sandgren posted in a Twitter conversation on the topic that was labeled Pizzagate by proponents and critics alike.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Monday night\u2019s postmatch news conference, Sandgren\u2019s coach, Jim Madrigal, tried to shut down the inquiry about Sandgren\u2019s political views by saying, \u201cThis is the Australian Open.\u201d But Sandgren chose to answer and said he did not support the so-called alt-right movement.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t,\u201d he said. \u201cI find some of the content interesting.\u201d\n\nAt the time, he did not elaborate on what he found interesting. In his ESPN interview Tuesday, he clarified that he did not think alt-right content was interesting, \u201cjust some individuals\u2019 specific content.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times on Monday night, Sandgren shook his head when asked if he believed in the Pizzagate conspiracy.\n\nSandgren has described himself as politically conservative, and the people he follows on Twitter include some notable politicians and pundits of the far right, including Sebastian Gorka, Ann Coulter, Mike Cernovich, Tomi Lahren and Alex Jones. (He also follows many of his fellow players, actors like Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds, his favorite band Metallica, and a variety of news organizations.) Sandgren said that following accounts or linking to information on Twitter did not indicate his approval.\n\nIn his interview with The Times, Sandgren said he believed it was important in the current polarized political landscape of the United States to be open to hearing differing viewpoints.\n\n\u201cWe are definitely in an outrage culture where free speech doesn\u2019t seem to be as free as it used to be,\u201d he said. \u201cThere are all kinds of restrictions people want to place on that.\u201d\n\nSandgren said he was interested in hearing all sides of issues.\n\n\u201cIf you already think you are correct and there\u2019s nothing else you can learn in life, then I think you are in trouble,\u201d he said. \u201cI like to consume information. I like to learn. Would I consider myself alt-right, if you want to ask that question? No, I don\u2019t. Not even a little bit. I think I am a pretty devout Christian, and I treat my walk with Christ very seriously, very seriously in a way that I\u2019m constantly looking at the things I do and how that affects me existentially.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cI want to hear your side. I want to hear everybody\u2019s side, and I want to learn, because I\u2019m 26. Do I think I know everything about life? No.\u201d\n\nAsked if he was concerned that he might be associated with alt-right views, Sandgren said: \u201cHonestly, it does concern me a little bit. Because it doesn\u2019t represent my viewpoints.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also recognized that his sudden tennis success would put him under greater public scrutiny.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been in obscurity and I get to do my own thing, which is cool, without really any kind of microscope, and it\u2019s something I think about as far as how would I be viewed,\u201d Sandgren said Monday night, hours before messages began disappearing from his Twitter feed. \u201cBut I don\u2019t think that should censor me to the point where I would censor myself from all things just to be a white rice of a personality so that everybody thinks I\u2019m amazing. If everybody thinks you\u2019re amazing, you probably are doing something wrong.\u201d", "title": "For Tennys Sandgren, Success Brings Scrutiny of His Political Views", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Many readers and viewers have become numb to the stories after watching them play out in public day in and day out. Twitter has made clear that Mr. Trump veers wildly from subject to subject, fight to fight. Fact checkers have made clear that he has a strained relationship with the truth.\n\nMr. Bannon is quoted in the book saying things that other advisers have said confidentially for months \u2014 that the president is stunningly undisciplined with no patience or interest in learning and driven by intemperate, sometimes absurd motivations. At one point, Mr. Bannon describes Mr. Trump acting \u201clike a 9-year-old,\u201d an observation that has power not because it was unique to those who worked for the president but because it is now on the record in Mr. Bannon\u2019s name.\n\nThe phenomenon is so universal that it is a wonder any White House is surprised anymore when someone who sat in the next chair during staff meetings in the Roosevelt Room one day becomes the next day\u2019s featured character in the window of Washington bookstores like Kramerbooks or Politics and Prose.\n\nIndeed, Mr. Trump, of all presidents, should know what to expect given his predilection for making employees sign nondisclosure agreements, a practice he brought from the private sector to his 2016 campaign and the subsequent presidential transition.\n\nVideo\n\nBut other than security reviews that sometimes limit what a former administration official can write in a book, no one has yet figured out a way to muzzle White House aides from telling their stories after departing the West Wing, either in first person or through authors such as Mr. Wolff.\n\nJimmy Carter\u2019s chief speechwriter, James Fallows, wrote a trenchant piece in The Atlantic Monthly called \u201cThe Passionless Presidency,\u201d portraying his former boss as a good man but an ineffective chief executive. Ronald Reagan\u2019s budget director, David Stockman, wrote a book describing an amiable but inattentive and unsophisticated president whose funny math disguised rising deficits.\n\nPerhaps more vexing for Mr. Reagan was the score-settling memoir of Donald T. Regan, his second chief of staff at the White House who was pushed out during the Iran-contra scandal. Mr. Regan\u2019s revelation that Nancy Reagan had influenced the president\u2019s schedule based on advice from her astrologer infuriated the president. \u201cThe media are behaving like kids with a new toy \u2014 never mind that there is no truth to it,\u201d Mr. Reagan wrote in his diary.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere actually was. Just as there was truth to the sometimes unsettling depiction of Bill Clinton\u2019s White House by his former senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos, whose memoir described his disillusionment with a president who recklessly risked his policy agenda for extramarital sex. When that book was released, Mr. Stephanopoulos\u2019s former White House colleagues stayed away from the launch party lest they risk Mr. Clinton\u2019s ire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLeon E. Panetta may hold a record of some sort by writing two tell-all memoirs of his time in two presidential administrations 43 years apart. The first was a scathing description of his service as a civil rights official under Richard M. Nixon that ended when Mr. Panetta was pushed out. The second was a more respectful but at times unflattering portrayal of his experiences as C.I.A. director and defense secretary for Barack Obama, whom he deemed smart but vacillating and overly cautious.\n\nOther advisers have told their stories to authors, as Mr. Bannon did. Paul O\u2019Neill, who served an unhappy tenure as Mr. Bush\u2019s first Treasury secretary, gave interviews and documents to the author Ron Suskind for a searing account of a White House where tax-cutting, neoconservative ideology pushed aside evidence and contrary views. Mr. Bush, Mr. O\u2019Neill concluded, was \u201ca blind man in a roomful of deaf people.\u201d\n\nBob Woodward\u2019s many books have benefited enormously from tales of former aides freed from the shackles of service, usually not attributed directly to them but often clear enough to the presidents who read with seething anger.\n\nAs aggravated as Mr. Trump may be with Mr. Bannon\u2019s apostasy and Mr. Wolff\u2019s book, he may need to get used to it. Just one year in, Mr. Trump faces many years of books to come.\n\nHe may not have to worry much about Sean Spicer, his first White House press secretary who has remained loyal and is now working on a memoir \u2014 although to be sure, no one in the Bush White House initially thought they had to worry about the ever-loyal Mr. McClellan either.\n\nMr. Trump may have more to wonder about with Omarosa Manigault Newman, the veteran of \u201cThe Apprentice\u201d who left her White House post noisily last month saying that as the only African-American woman of prominence on Mr. Trump\u2019s team, she had seen things \u201cthat have upset me.\u201d She added ominously, \u201cIt is a profound story that I know the world will want to hear.\u201d\n\nAnd then there is James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director fired by Mr. Trump last year and trashed on Twitter ever since. Mr. Comey has a different understanding of the meaning of loyalty than the president does. His book is due out on May 1. Its title: \u201cA Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies and Leadership.\u201d", "title": "For Trump, Book Raises Familiar Questions of Loyalty and Candor", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "And on Saturday, Mr. Trump reached out to a group he affectionately refers to as his \u201cbridge people\u201d \u2014 the clump of supporters who religiously gather on the bridge corner near Mar-a-Lago every day they know the president is there. After the motorcade passed by, with Mr. Trump flashing a wide grin and two thumbs up through the window, two cars with Secret Service members circled back. They passed out flag pins and swept about 16 people back to the club.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a classic extrovert,\u201d Mr. Ruddy said, adding that the people Mr. Trump sees at Mar-a-Lago are the ones he feels most connected to. \u201cHe\u2019ll ask everyone their opinion, from the guys parking the car to the sommelier.\u201d\n\nOn Saturday, Mr. Trump, in a gray sweater and white U.S.A. hat, chatted with the so-called bridge people by the pool, posing for pictures and complimenting the beauty of the people who came and their Trump paraphernalia. They were also given a tour of Mar-a-Lago, including the Trump-branded helicopter parked on a helipad intended for presidential business, and a buffet spread with meatballs, fresh fruit and chocolate chip cookies.\n\n\u201cIt was an honor to be chosen by the most powerful man in the world, to be chosen to go to his home,\u201d said Nicolas Giacalone, 14, a Palm Beach resident who started coming to the street corner last month to show his support for Mr. Trump. \u201cHe\u2019s a really nice guy.\u201d", "title": "For Trump, a Glittering Gala Ends a Winter Vacation Rooted in Routine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The strong earthquake that sent panicked Alaskans, fearing a tsunami, to high ground early Tuesday is a reminder that, at least around the Pacific Rim, the biggest danger from quakes often comes not from the land but from the sea.\n\nGiven the need for speed \u2014 deadly waves can strike within minutes in some cases \u2014 tsunami forecasters tend to shoot first and ask questions later, sending out broad alerts that are often scaled back or canceled within hours.\n\nIn the case of Tuesday\u2019s quake, waves could have struck the nearest land, Kodiak Island, within half an hour. The U.S. Tsunami Warning Center, one of two operated by NOAA, sent out its first alerts within 3 minutes of the event, a typical time frame, said Michael Angove, who manages the tsunami program at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.\n\nThe quake Tuesday turned out to be largely harmless, a function of its 7.9 magnitude, which made it about 100 times less powerful than the world\u2019s strongest earthquakes, and its location in the Gulf of Alaska about 170 miles from Kodiak Island.", "title": "For Tsunami Forecasters, Speed Is Everything", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "I want to tell you something true\n\nBecause that\u2019s what she did.\n\nI want to take you down a road she built, only I don\u2019t want to follow it to the end.\n\nI want to step off the edge and go into the underbrush\n\nClearing another way, because that\u2019s also what she taught\n\nNot how to repave her road but how to lay another\n\nEven if it meant the grass came through the cracks of the pavement, and the thicket ate it up.\n\nI want to show you something that I dug up out of the earth inside\n\nBecause she spent her life picking away at the tunnel veins\n\nAnd in the next one over, through the walls I heard her working,\n\nThe rhythmic steady tick-tick-tick of her knocking at the stone, a music of the sharp end\n\nOf a pen digging into paper\n\nAnd tried to learn a rhythm of my own, how to get the weight swinging.\n\nI want to take your hand and put it on the breathing monster\u2019s side\n\nIn the dark room, where we can\u2019t see what we\u2019re touching\n\nWe only feel it\u2019s in here with us, too vast to touch all at once.\n\nHere, it\u2019s rough and scaly, and here, it\u2019s smooth and hard as bone\n\nAnd it\u2019s turning even as we try to make it out.\n\nBut she did her best to tell us of every part that she could reach\n\nCalling back sometimes from the far side, muffled by its bulk\n\nAnd sometimes she put our hands on a tooth\u2019s serrated edge\n\nBut never without kindness\n\nThe teeth were there anyway, and she wanted us to know where we kept cutting ourselves\n\nShe never told the lie that the teeth were the only part that mattered.\n\nBut I\u2019ll do all that tomorrow.\n\nToday I\u2019ll pack some tools, a wide-bladed knife and rake\n\nNothing with a motor, it\u2019s work I want to do by hand\n\nAnd I\u2019ll wave to you, going the same way\n\nMaybe we\u2019ll see someone wandering, and call them over to come walk with us\n\nAs far as the road goes.\n\nTogether we\u2019ll rake up the leaves and cut the grass\n\nAnd pull back thornbush branches, even if we\u2019ve forgotten our gloves\n\nAnd in the morning we\u2019ll say goodbye and go our ways again\n\nMaybe you and I will walk together towards that high hill we caught a glimpse of, a few turns back\n\nWe thought maybe the road would go there, but it never did\n\nSo let\u2019s go and try to find it\n\nAnd if we can\u2019t quite get there, at least leave another marker on the way.", "title": "For Ursula", "authors": ["Naomi Novik"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Hey, everybody, it\u2019s almost Oscar time, when lots of money is spent to hide a bunch of mirrors in a lot of smoke, when starring roles are turned into cameos and we\u2019re all just supposed to say, \u201cYay!\u201d So let\u2019s hear it for Armie Hammer, whose part as a vacationing American Ph.D. candidate and hypnotically bad dancer in \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d is being offered in the supporting actor category, despite his being in most of the movie. \u201cSupport\u201d might be subjective. But who on earth is he supporting? The movie has no title without him \u2014 no leisurely bike rides and no sex, either. (Well, almost no sex.)\n\nI get it. This is a strategy, designed to prevent a vote split between Mr. Hammer and his co-star, Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet. And there can only be one. Mr. Hammer in this movie \u2014 and, really, in every movie \u2014 gets by on variations of earnestness. I\u2019m never really sure he\u2019s right for any part, but he wears you down because not only is he hilariously handsome, he\u2019s also really trying. There\u2019s a soul in there. Ideally, people who give out awards would be asked to consider the charm of Mr. Hammer\u2019s one-dimensionality. Like, say, the films of Christopher Nolan, he\u2019s not deep. He\u2019s pretty vast, and vastness, in the movies, is a virtue. I have a friend who believes, justifiably, that straight people shouldn\u2019t play gay ones, which is a conversation for another time. But I didn\u2019t think Mr. Hammer was playing gay as much as he was playing grad student.\n\nIn this movie, Mr. Hammer is funny and confident and brave and light \u2014 William Hurt in \u201cBroadcast News\u201d as opposed to Heath Ledger in \u201cBrokeback Mountain.\u201d Mr. Hammer\u2019s lightness is essential to the movie\u2019s secret heft. He wafts, like cologne. The eventual sad beauty of Mr. Chalamet\u2019s performance is that he can\u2019t escape his scent. But nobody gets a best actor nomination for wafting, not anymore. People want to see your work (your weight loss, your accent, your physical deformity), and Armie Hammer doesn\u2019t show his.", "title": "For Your Reconsideration: Supporting Whom, Exactly?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Doctors in the fledgling field of face transplants are making great strides, grafting skin and bone and nerve and muscle to give patients new life and hope. In 2015, Dr. Rodriguez performed the most extensive transplant to date, onto a former firefighter.\n\nBut there can be no medical marvel without a donor. And asking a family to donate a loved one\u2019s face is not like asking for a heart or a lung. Transplant procurement groups say that for many families, removing the loved one\u2019s face would amount to a second loss.\n\nN.Y.U.\u2019s hope is simple: that a better replacement face will encourage more families of potential donors to say yes, reducing the wait time for the tiny but desperate pool of candidates for face transplants.\n\nHelen Irving, the president of LiveOnNY, a network that matches organ donors with recipients, said that the 3-D mask would \u201cmake the donation journey more comfortable, and perhaps a bit easier, for the loved ones of donors.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew York University\u2019s 3-D printing center, LaGuardia Studio, housed in a strip-mall-like building south of Washington Square Park, more typically prints projects for arts and engineering departments. But the process of printing a face is the same, just sped up, because the hospital will need to release the donor\u2019s body to the family as soon as possible.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re essentially condensing what we like to do in two weeks into 36 hours,\u201d said Andrew Buckland, the manager of the studio.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s how it works: The hand-held device that scans the donor\u2019s face has five camera lenses that capture it from multiple angles. It projects a grid onto the face, allowing the scanner to build a three-dimensional map.\n\nAfter scanning the face, the technicians will spend several hours tweaking the files on computers at the studio \u2014 \u201cthe equivalent of spot-touching your print,\u201d Mr. Buckland said \u2014 and send them to a very large printer loaded with cartridges of acrylic-based photopolymer.\n\nThe printer lays down layers so thin it takes 1,500 of them to make an inch. A face might require 10,000 layers and take more than 24 hours to print.\n\nThe resulting plastic mask is hard, not supple, but if a low-resolution model made from the face of a hospital administrator is any indication, it will be remarkably realistic. Even at lower resolution, the mask captures the tiny variations in color, texture and reflectivity from one millimeter to the next that characterize real skin: the countless imperfections that comprise reality.", "title": "For the Living, a Donated Face. For the Dead, a Lifelike Replacement.", "authors": ["Andy Newman", "Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "In seventh-grade English class we were required to keep lists of the books we read for pleasure, with brief reviews \u2014 an adjective or two \u2014 then post them on a wall by the door. I was a bookworm, and eager to please. I quickly notched \u201cGone With the Wind\u201d (\u201cgreat\u201d), \u201cJane Eyre\u201d (\u201cso good\u201d), and \u201cWild December,\u201d a fictionalized account of the Bront\u00ebs (\u201creally interesting\u201d).\n\nThen I paused. I was about to add my favorite of the bunch: \u201cA Date for Diane,\u201d by Betty Cavanna. Could I admit publicly that I adored it? I could not. \u201cDumb!\u201d I wrote. My first literary lie.\n\nThe book and its sequels, \u201cDiane\u2019s New Love\u201d and \u201cToujours Diane,\u201d were known, I would later learn, as malt shop novels. Written from the 1940s to the mid-1960s, they tracked a teenage protagonist as she navigated the obstacle course of first love. (And if part of a series, second love.)\n\nThe authors had their specialties. Cavanna tended to write about not-quite-pretty girls with artistic ambitions or interests like aviation or competitive skiing. Anne Emery sometimes worked that same earnest side of the street, notably in her four-novel account of Dinny Gordon, a budding classicist. Lenora Mattingly Weber was known for a 14-book cycle about a close-knit Irish Catholic family, the Malones, with a focus on its youngest member, Beany.", "title": "For the Love of Malt Shop Novels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "But elsewhere during the opening week, the results held prescient revelations.\n\nThe Jacksonville Jaguars had 10 sacks in a romp. The Los Angeles Rams won by 37 points. The Eagles forced four turnovers in a resounding defeat of Washington. The Panthers defense gave up just 3 points and won easily. The Buffalo Bills prevailed in a trap game, soundly dispatching the Jets.\n\nEvery one of those winners advanced to the playoffs.\n\nTrue, the New Orleans Saints didn\u2019t precisely fit the pattern. They lost in the first week of the season, but they put up a good fight in Minnesota, where only one road team won this season.\n\nThe Saints have since won 11 of 15 games. And in a twist, a key to their unforeseen surge has been a defense that ranks among the N.F.L.\u2019s top 10 in most statistical categories, a nice complement to what may be the league\u2019s most potent offense.\n\nAnd let\u2019s talk a little about pro football\u2019s postseason tournament, which begins later this week. The most noticeable thing about the playoff bracket? The teams that are not in it.\n\nNo Packers, Cowboys, Seahawks, Lions or Giants \u2014 all of them playoff teams a year ago. The shift of power this season is stark: Eight of the 12 teams in the postseason did not make the playoffs a year ago. Buffalo had not reached the postseason since 1999. In fact, four of the N.F.L.\u2019s six longest playoff droughts ended this season when you include the Rams (2004), the Jaguars (2007) and the Tennessee Titans (2008).\n\nIt is undoubtedly refreshing to have some new blood involved in an N.F.L. Then There Are the Patriots.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The latest disappointment arrived on Wednesday, when Ford reported fourth-quarter net income of $2.4 billion, or 60 cents a share. That was an improvement over a loss in the comparable period a year ago, but its adjusted earnings were 39 cents a share, about 4 cents less than analysts expected.\n\nProfit fell in North America as sales slowed in the United States, and the company lost about $200 million in the rest of the world. Sales in China fell 6 percent.\n\nThe company forecast a decline in earnings this year, mainly as a result of rising commodity costs and unfavorable exchange rates. Ford also said it would have higher costs related to the introduction of new models \u2014 23 are coming this year globally, compared with 11 in 2017.\n\n\u201cWe need to be fitter,\u201d said Ford\u2019s chief financial officer, Robert L. Shanks.\n\nMr. Shanks told reporters that he didn\u2019t think analysts were unconvinced about Ford\u2019s turnaround plan. \u201cWith the exception of Tesla, the market is skeptical about the sector\u2019s ability to be successful in the world that\u2019s ahead of us\u201d he said.\n\nIn a conference call, analysts pressed Mr. Hackett to talk about initiatives to improve profitability, but he declined to discuss them in detail, except to say they are \u201cup and running.\u201d\n\nJust a few years ago, Ford was considered the healthiest of the three Detroit automakers, having escaped the government-engineered bankruptcies that engulfed General Motors and Chrysler. With Alan Mulally as chief executive, Ford slimmed down, focused on its Ford and Lincoln brands, and roared to record profits.\n\nAfter Mr. Mulally retired in 2014 and passed the baton to Mark Fields, however, Ford began to drift as new technologies started reshaping the industry; as new challengers emerged in Tesla, Google and Uber; and as a revived G.M. and a merged Fiat Chrysler Automobiles provided increased competition in the high-margin business of trucks and roomy sport-utility vehicles. Its stock slumped, and Ford directors began wondering if Mr. Fields had the right strategy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn May, Ford\u2019s board ousted Mr. Fields and called on Mr. Hackett, who had previously served on the board and then joined the company to run its activities in autonomous vehicles and related efforts.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Hackett took three months to dive into Ford\u2019s troubles and found that Ford was spending too much time and money developing new vehicles, and that costs for steel, other materials and components were rising. His prescription called for Ford to refocus investments on growing markets like China and highly profitable vehicles like trucks and S.U.V.s, while cutting back on initiatives in less promising areas like Europe and passenger cars.\n\n\u201cWe are intensely focusing on fixing the fundamental health of our company,\u201d Mr. Hackett said on Wednesday.\n\nTo ensure that Ford will be a player down the road, the company is also ramping up plans to introduce 40 electrified vehicles by 2022 and a driverless car for taxi fleets, ride-hailing services and delivery companies by 2021.\n\nAt the Detroit show, Ford said it planned to spend $11 billion on electric vehicles by 2022.\n\nBut neither the plan nor Mr. Hackett himself has generated much excitement. His appearance in Las Vegas, where Mr. Mulally shined in the past, fell flat. At a conference known for gee-whiz demonstrations of new technologies, Mr. Hackett gave a presentation about how to rethink transportation and cities of the future.\n\n\u201cIt was very philosophical,\u201d said Mr. Whiston, who was in the audience. \u201cHe might be appealing to a nonautomotive audience, but financial analysts want more.\u201d\n\nMore troubling to Wall Street is that Ford\u2019s new strategy is likely to have little immediate impact on its bottom line.\n\nBrian Johnson, a financial analyst at Barclays, wrote in a note to clients issued before Ford reported its fourth-quarter results that \u201cthe path ahead in shifting Ford\u2019s strategy will be rather long.\u201d\n\nG.M. has been ahead of Ford in adding trucks and S.U.V.s to its lineup. At the Detroit show, Ford unveiled a midsize pickup truck, the Ranger. G.M.\u2019s Chevrolet and GMC brands have had midsize trucks for nearly three years.\n\n\u201cThere was a really stark contrast between Ford and G.M. presentations\u201d given to financial analysts at the show, Mr. Whiston said. \u201cG.M. was all about optimism, and Ford talked about fitness and efficiency.\u201d", "title": "Ford Says It\u2019s a New Era. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "While the Kurds in Syria were partners with the United States in fighting the Islamic State, reclaiming villages and cities from the extremist group, they are facing a new twist in the latest complex chapter of the conflict. Turkey says the Kurds in control of the enclave of Afrin, in Idlib Province in northern Syria, are a terrorist threat, and the Turks have recently launched an offensive to dislodge them.\n\nNow, some of those fighting alongside the Kurds are vowing to fight against Turkey. For the Westerners, their personal support for the group\u2019s vision has largely fit with the interests of the American-led coalition for much of the war. The United States provides material support and training to the Syrian Defense Forces \u2014 dominated by the Kurdish fighters \u2014 in their campaign against the Islamic State. But Turkey considers the Y.P.G. a terrorist organization because many of its leaders have links to the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, also known as the P.K.K., putting the Western fighters directly at odds with a NATO ally.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know about the foreigners in the Y.P.G. and what they are doing in Syria.\n\nHow are foreigners joining the militia?\n\nThroughout the Syrian war, Kurdish militias have made themselves accessible to Westerners looking to join the fight, welcoming them to Syria and giving them training. The militia members have an active social media presence geared toward international recruits, and they regularly post updates, often in English, focusing not just on warfare but also on their vision for an autonomous Kurdish society. They call their movement the Rojava revolution, the name the Kurds have given to the region in northeastern Syria that they now control.", "title": "Foreign Fighters Back Kurdish Militia in Syria in Fight Against Turkey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "24A: Were you confused by \u201cDiamond club\u201d? Sounds like two card suits crammed together, doesn\u2019t it? But what if we thought about baseball? Baseball has diamonds. And clubs, if you think about a BAT as a club.\n\n49A: Yes, of course the answer to \u201cOpenings at a day spa?\u201d is PORES. I will be in the corner here, wishing you clean and open ones and trying not to visualize that.\n\n8D: French in the clue, French in the answer. The saison that lasts \u201ctres mois\u201d is summer, or ETE.\n\n60D: This one cracked me up. You can \u201cWave to a math teacher?\u201d and I am sure it will make his or her day, but in the noun sense, a \u201cwave,\u201d to a math teacher, can be a SINE wave.\n\nAlan Southworth: Very excited to be making my New York Times Crossword debut today! A bit about me: I\u2019m a 25-year-old energy market consultant/singer-songwriter/marathoner living in New York City. I found my way into the crossword community through a lifelong love of word games and puzzles (I grew up playing Scrabble and Boggle with my mom, as well as solving Sudoku and Ken Ken before bed), but didn\u2019t really get into crosswords until college, where I met my collaborator, Ryan McCarty. Ryan and I were members of the Princeton University Glee Club and the Princeton Nassoons, the university\u2019s oldest a cappella group, before beginning our crossword collaboration.\n\nI started writing down crossword theme ideas in the \u201cNotes\u201d app of my phone during my commutes to work in 2015. Many of the early concepts I came up with revolved around phrases that lent themselves to literal interpretations involving a letter addition or removal (\u201cDROP THE F\u201d BOMB luckily never came to fruition \u2026). But then NO WAY came to me and I realized dropping an entire word might result in some fresher \u201cwacky\u201d phrases. RUN A TRAIN was the first potential theme answer that I thought of, and with Ryan\u2019s expert grid construction skills and some more theme answer brainstorming, I knew we were on the right track, so to speak.\n\nSide note: As a runner, I was excited to use \u201cMarathon leader?\u201d as the clue for ULTRA, but I wasn\u2019t sure if the Ultramarathon reference was too obscure for the general public. After a quick Google search eased my initial worries, I noticed the following blurb in the Wikipedia article for Ultramarathon:\n\n\u201cSince 1997, runners have been competing in the Self-Transcendence 3,100 Mile Race, which is billed as the longest official footrace in the world. They run 100 laps a day for up to 50 days around a single block in Queens, N.Y., for a total distance of 3,100 miles (5,000 km).\u201d\n\nThis absurd race has been the topic of many conversations since finding out about it during my crossword research. Just thinking about the fact that Suprabha Beckjord ran the race 14 times (i.e. she spent over two years of her life running around a high school in Queens) makes my legs hurt \u2026\n\nRyan McCarty: Excited for my second New York Times puzzle today, co-written with one of my (soon-to-be) groomsmen! For my day job, I work as a tech consultant at the SEC, and I have kept up my singing in three choirs and occasionally in some smaller ensembles in the D.C. area. Alan is the person who actually introduced me to The New York Times Crossword in college \u2014 we would often attempt puzzles together during breakfast, with varying degrees of success. Soon after I got interested in constructing puzzles and made a few for friends before submitting some to publications. Alan and I decided it would be fun to collaborate on a New York Times puzzle and, after a couple of attempts, we got an acceptance with this NO WAY puzzle. We hope you enjoy!", "title": "Forget It", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Baltimore County\u2019s schools had embarked on an ambitious technology makeover, committing more than $200 million to providing laptops for students and millions more on no-bid contracts for learning apps. The Times found that tech industry-funded groups or vendors paid for flights to conferences, as well as hotels and dinners, for school officials.\n\nMr. Dance actively negotiated the terms of a $875,000 no-bid contract between his school district and Supes Academy, a school leadership training service, while he worked for Supes and a related company called Synesi, according to the indictment. Mr. Dance also made false statements on financial disclosure documents, the indictment said, to conceal about $90,000 in earnings from those companies.\n\nThe prosecutor also said that Mr. Dance concealed about $12,000 in payments he received through his consulting work in 2015, including $4,600 from an organization called the Education Research and Development Institute \u2014 ERDI for short \u2014 that pays superintendents to attend meetings with educational tech companies.\n\nAs part of its services, ERDI has in the past charged companies $13,000 to facilitate a meeting with five superintendents or other school leaders to discuss products, according to documents obtained by The Times. After Mr. Dance participated in confidential meetings with two of his district\u2019s tech vendors at an ERDI conference last year, the district extended both companies\u2019 contracts.\n\nOfficials in Maryland and Ohio have begun looking superintendents\u2019 relationships with ERDI.\n\nAndrew Jay Graham, a lawyer representing Mr. Dance, declined to comment on the case. Mr. Dance faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison for each of the four counts against him, according to the indictment.", "title": "Former Baltimore County Schools Leader Charged With Perjury", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The former director of financial aid at Columbia University\u2019s Teachers College took $375,000 in kickbacks from three graduate students after arranging for them to receive inflated awards, the federal authorities said on Thursday.\n\nIn one case, a student received nearly $600,000 in stipends between 2011 and 2017, and kicked back nearly $300,000 to the former administrator, Melanie Williams-Bethea, the authorities said.\n\nChecks from that student, Annice Kpana, were often written within days of when stipend funds were deposited into her account, and frequently included notations like \u201cLove\u201d or \u201cThank you!\u201d in the memo line, according to a criminal complaint unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.\n\nMs. Kpana has been enrolled as a graduate student since 2007, but since at least 2010 she has not been taking classes or actively pursuing her degree, the complaint said. She was seeking a master\u2019s degree in education, it noted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe other students charged were Carmen Canty and Kyla Thomas, both of whom have been enrolled since 2005 and have not obtained their degrees, according to the complaint. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt a hearing on Dec. 1, Mr. Ho was denied bail. A federal prosecutor, Daniel C. Richenthal, argued that \u201cif he were to make it back to China, or for that matter, Uganda or Chad, the countries in which he committed the bribery offenses, we can never get him back.\u201d Mr. Ho\u2019s lawyer, Mr. Kim, argued that \u201cto flee would be a disgrace,\u201d and said, \u201cIt would destroy everything he\u2019s worked for and it would destroy his international reputation.\u201d\n\nMr. Ho\u2019s lawyers on Friday asked Judge Forrest to allow Mr. Ho to live under house arrest, with electronic monitoring, on a $10 million bond, with an agreement that he waive extradition, to minimize the chance he might flee.\n\nThe case has received coverage in China, where CEFC, a once-obscure company, has become a major energy player, with investments in Europe, the Middle East, Central Asia and Africa.\n\nCEFC is one of a small number of Chinese companies to receive Beijing\u2019s approval to pursue high-profile deals at a time when the government has largely restricted overseas acquisitions.", "title": "Former Hong Kong Official Pleads Not Guilty in Africa Bribery Case", "authors": ["Sewell Chan"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA former lieutenant at Brooklyn\u2019s federal jail was convicted on Friday of repeatedly raping a female inmate entrusted to his care. The guilty verdict against the defendant, Carlos Richard Martinez, brought to an end a two-week trial that included emotional testimony from the victim and shed light on the problem of sexual assault at the jail, the Metropolitan Detention Center.\n\nMr. Martinez, 48, was charged in May 2017 with raping the inmate \u2014 a young Dominican woman who was serving a drug-trafficking sentence \u2014 at least four times between December 2015 and April 2016. The jury, in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, found him guilty not only of sexual abuse, but also of the sexual abuse of a ward and of violating the civil rights of his victim, who testified about the assaults using the pseudonym Maria. He now faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.\n\nMr. Martinez was indicted with another lieutenant at the jail, Eugenio Perez, who is awaiting trial, and a rank-and-file corrections officer, Armando Moronta, who pleaded guilty in November to sexually abusing three female inmates.\n\nKnown as the M.D.C., the jail holds about 1,800 inmates; about 3 percent of them are women. In 2016, a federal judge expressed reluctance about sending women there because, as she said at the time, its conditions made it sound like it was in \u201csome third-world country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the trial began on Jan. 9, a federal prosecutor, Nadia Shihata, told the jury, \u201cThis is a case about power and abuse.\u201d Ms. Shihata went on to say that Mr. Martinez raped Maria while she was assigned to clean an office in the jail and ensured that no one walked in on them by watching feeds from security cameras during the attacks.", "title": "Former Lieutenant at Brooklyn Federal Jail Convicted of Raping Female Inmate", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTo celebrate the Lunar New Year, Hakkasan restaurant has enlisted Jay McInerney, the author of \u201cBright Lights, Big City,\u201d to create cynical fortunes. \u201cIf at first you don\u2019t succeed try Botox\u201d will not make your day. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Fortune Cookies for the New York Cynic", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cThe Opioid Plague\u2019s Youngest Victims\u201d (Op-Ed, Dec. 29), Sherry Lachman calls for more people to champion the cause of children in foster care, a group whose numbers are increasing largely because of the opioid crisis. But is it in the best interest of children whose parents have used drugs to be put in foster care in the first place?\n\nOur experience repeatedly shows that placing a child in foster care can be more detrimental than addressing a parent\u2019s drug use as a family. We regularly see parents who use drugs and who are \u2014 or can be \u2014 good parents, and are the best option for their children.\n\nChildren harmed by their parents should of course be protected. But any proposed approach to the opioid crisis that defaults to sending children to foster care once the specter of drug use is raised, and that excludes their parents, is deeply flawed.\n\nEMMA KETTERINGHAM, BROOKLYN\n\nThe writer is managing director of the family defense practice at Bronx Defenders.", "title": "Opinion | Foster Care and Opioids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "The actions \u2014 and in some cases, the absence of actions \u2014 reflected the ways the teams and the league struggled to respond to the protests, which began in August 2016 when quarterback Colin Kaepernick, then a member of the San Francisco 49ers, did not stand for the national anthem to highlight his concern over racial discrimination and oppression in society.. Kaepernick\u2019s contract expired after the 2016 season, and he has been out of a job ever since. He has filed a grievance accusing the N.F.L.\u2019s owners of collusion.\n\nWhile a few dozen players were still protesting at the end of this regular season, the fact that hundreds of players took on complex social issues and didn\u2019t suffer repercussions amounted to progress for player rights in a league known for demanding that its employees subvert themselves and march in lock step, several longtime observers of the league said.\n\nThe protests \u201csent a message of solidarity and cohesion, and made people understand that these guys are entertaining you, but they also have thoughts and ideologies and take a stand on issues,\u201d said Charles K. Ross, the director of African-American Studies at the University of Mississippi and the author of two books on African-American professional football players. \u201cYou can\u2019t simply hide in a hole and not have an opinion on these things.\u201d\n\nThe moment that changed everything occurred in late September, when the president attacked the N.F.L. at a campaign rally on a Friday night in Alabama. He used a derogatory word to describe players who did not stand for the anthem and called on owners to fire them. His comments sparked a crisis at the N.F.L., which would be playing games less than 48 hours later.\n\nThe response from Robert K. As in years past, the NFL Network will simulcast those games and also exclusively broadcast an additional seven games in that time slot. A digital partner for the games \u2014 it was Amazon last season \u2014 has yet to be announced.\n\n\u201cYou either have the rights to the most-watched content, or you don\u2019t,\u201d Peter Rice, president of 21st Century Fox, said on a conference call announcing the agreement. \u201cWe believe in buying the very best rights, and the best rights are N.F.L.\u201d\n\nThursday night games have been something of a neglected afterthought for the league. CBS has broadcast \u201cThursday Night Football\u201d for the past four seasons, splitting the last two with NBC. Those two networks paid a combined $450 million annually for five games each, with NBC paying additionally for a sixth game. Fox is paying more than $660 million annually for the new package, according to ESPN. News of the deal was first reported by Sports Business Journal.\n\nAccording to multiple reports, both CBS and NBC bid less than they had paid previously, underscoring the difficulty in finding profit by showing football on Thursday nights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThursday Night Football\u201d was introduced in 2006. Its ratings slid 12 percent last season. Players have complained vociferously about playing two games in five days, and the N.F.L.\u2019s own data shows a higher rate of injuries on Thursday night compared with games on Sunday and Monday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan.
