Thursday Night Games", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Indeed, Mr. Trump ran his populist campaign against the very plutocrats who populate this forum every year. His former chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, acknowledged as much during the election when he said that the American working class was \u201ctired of being dictated to by what we call the party of Davos.\u201d Mr. Dimon, a longtime Davos attendee, once described the event as a place \u201cwhere billionaires tell millionaires what the middle class feels.\u201d\n\nThe big question is, how will Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cAmerica First\u201d campaign play here? Will he use the stage as an opportunity to deliver a live version of his Twitter feed and publicly eviscerate \u2014 and possibly humiliate \u2014 the crowd? He has already shown he can be hostile toward traditional alliances by scolding European nations for not paying their fair share toward NATO.\n\nOr will Mr. Trump use the gathering as a chance to bring leaders together?\n\nWill he talk about protectionism or free trade?\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s presence has been described as a mixed blessing by many of the participants.\n\n\u201cTrump\u2019s attendance is exciting for attendees inasmuch as it shows them Davos is still the place to be,\u201d said Ian Bremmer, president and founder of Eurasia Group, a political risk consultancy. \u201cThe opposite of love is irrelevance, and Trump gets that as much as everyone else attending.\u201d\n\nAnd while Mr. Trump may alienate much of the intellectual set, many of the chief executives in attendance have become huge beneficiaries of the president\u2019s tax overhaul, which has instantly created bigger profits, higher compensation and a soaring stock market.\n\n\u201cMost attendees like his tax policy, sure,\u201d Mr. Bremmer said.\n\nBut Mr. Bremmer said he did not think the president\u2019s tax policy would convert the audience into supporters. \u201cAt Davos, they\u2019ll see him primarily through an international lens,\u201d he said. \u201cIf he has 5 percent approval among the attendees, I think that\u2019s generous.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump was never invited to Davos during his career in real estate and entertainment. While he is a businessman and entrepreneur, he never formed part of the circle of the Fortune 500 chief executives who frequent Davos, many of whom considered him something of a carnival barker.\n\nAnd while the World Economic Forum always invites the president of the United States, it is rare for one to attend. Many of the organizers were shocked that Mr. Trump had accepted the invitation (as were some members of the president\u2019s own staff.) Mr. Trump will be the first American president to travel to Davos since Bill Clinton did in 2000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think it was a very good, perhaps contrarian move,\u201d Martin Sorrell, chief executive of the advertising giant WPP, told me in an email. \u201cLast year, President Xi filled the vacuum left by non-U.S. government attendance, so President Trump has the opportunity to dominate the agenda and the news flow,\u201d he added, referring to the Chinese leader.\n\nPerhaps Mr. Trump will follow in the footsteps of one of his heroes, Ronald Reagan. \u201cWhen President Reagan addressed the forum in 1982, by satellite video, his presidency was emerging from a bruising period,\u201d Adrian Monck, a member of the World Economic Forum\u2019s managing board, told me. \u201cHe had run as an outspoken cold warrior. But his administration was able to reshape America\u2019s standing in the world.\u201d\n\nMr. Ferguson said that one thing working in Mr. Trump\u2019s favor was the authority of his office. \u201cThe W.E.F. reveres power and the president of the United States has that in abundance,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump has an opportunity to use that power to demonstrate his understanding of how interconnected the global economy is. However, don\u2019t hold your breath.\n\nLate last week, his Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, who will also attend Davos for the first time, sought to play down the idea that somehow they would be rubbing shoulders among the billionaire class.\n\n\u201cIf you look at the list, there\u2019s an awful lot of world leaders, there\u2019s an awful lot of finance chairs, there\u2019s an awful lot of business people,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is an important economic agenda.\u201d\n\nWith a bit of smile, he said, \u201cI didn\u2019t realize that it was the global elite.\u201d", "title": "Fox in the Globalist Henhouse? Davos Awaits Trump\u2019s Arrival", "authors": ["Andrew Ross Sorkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Her father helped her start a recording career by the time she was 16, and her youth, fresh-scrubbed looks and brightly innocent voice made her a rising star in the genre known as y\u00e9-y\u00e9, a sort of bubblegum pop with a young fan base. (According to Le Figaro, a producer suggested she adopt the stage name France because another Isabelle, Isabelle Aubret, had recently won the Eurovision contest.)\n\nRobert Gall wrote the lyrics to her first big hit, \u201cSacr\u00e9 Charlemagne,\u201d a 1964 lament about school.\n\nIn 1965 her career received a big boost when she was the winning singer in the 10th edition of the Eurovision contest, the popular televised competition seen in many European countries. It was held that year in Naples, Italy. Ms. Gall performed a song written by Serge Gainsbourg, \u201cPoup\u00e9e de Cire, Poup\u00e9e de Son,\u201d variously translated as \u201cWax Doll, Sound Doll,\u201d \u201cWax Doll, Singing Doll\u201d or \u201cWax Doll, Rag Doll.\u201d\n\nShe was actually representing Luxembourg in the competition, but the performance propelled her to a new level of fame in France and beyond. She recorded \u201cWax Doll\u201d and other songs in multiple languages, including Japanese.\n\nMr. Gainsbourg, who died in 1991, was known for cheeky, sometimes racy double entendres, and those were employed particularly provocatively in a song Ms. Gall turned into a hit in 1965, \u201cLes Sucettes\u201d (\u201cLollipops\u201d). It seemed to be about a girl enjoying lollipops, but the barely veiled subtext was oral sex. Most of the others have been sentenced, facing penalties that, the authorities said, ranged from six months to five years of probation. The fraternity was acquitted of the murder charge in November.\n\n\u201cMike is my only son and only child, and the truth that he is gone can\u2019t be erased or wiped away no matter how hard I try,\u201d Mr. Deng\u2019s mother, Mary Deng, said in a statement submitted to the court. \u201cI feel like I have no big words to explain this. How can somebody treat another person\u2019s life like this? Like it\u2019s a joke? My husband and I spent 18 years raising Michael to be a good person, a good son. And in a single night, all those years are suddenly gone.\u201d\n\nMr. Deng, an 18-year-old from Queens, collapsed while taking part in a ritual known as the \u201cglass ceiling,\u201d a gantlet meant to represent the plight of Asian-Americans, where pledges wore the backpack and blindfold as they were confronted by fraternity members. He was the most defiant of the pledges, riling other members by resisting and not following their orders, according to a grand jury report released in 2015. The others reacted forcefully, knocking him to the ground, and one of them ran toward him from 15 feet away with his head lowered, the report said.\n\nThe members carried him inside; Mr. Deng\u2019s body was stiff and his breathing became labored. They changed his clothes and tried unsuccessfully to revive him. Some of them used their phones to search phrases like \u201cconcussion can\u2019t wake up,\u201d the report said.\n\nOne of the fraternity members later told investigators, according to the report, they had resisted calling for an ambulance because they had looked up the cost and thought it was expensive. A national fraternity official told members over the phone to hide anything bearing the fraternity\u2019s logo, the report said. About an hour later, Mr. Deng was driven to a hospital, where doctors found that he had sustained severe head trauma and his body was badly bruised.\n\nOn Monday, in tearful statements in court and in sentencing memorandums submitted to the judge, the men expressed their remorse, describing how guilt has hung over their lives.\n\n\u201cThis is something I regret and wish I could take back for Michael,\u201d Mr. Kwan said, sniffling repeatedly as he addressed the judge.", "title": "Fraternity Is Banned From Pennsylvania After Student\u2019s Hazing Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Fred Bass was born on June 28, 1928, in Manhattan, a year after his father, an immigrant from Lithuania, had opened the Pelican Book Shop on Eighth Street, near Greene Street. Ben Bass had developed book fever browsing the stores on Fourth Avenue during lunch breaks from his job in a nearby fabric store. Fred\u2019s mother, the former Shirley Vogel, was an immigrant from Poland who died of cancer when he was 6.\n\nBen Bass, who died in 1978, did not thrive in his new occupation. He was forced out of his Eighth Street premises in 1929 and opened the Strand on Fourth Avenue with $300 in savings and another $300 in borrowed money. The cash register was a cigar box. In the early days, to keep expenses down, he slept on a cot in the back of the shop.\n\nIt was not a successful concern, and the onset of the Depression made it even less so. Destitute, he placed Fred and his daughter, Dorothy, in foster care with a couple in the East Village.\n\nImage Fred Bass and his father, Benjamin, outside the family store in an undated photograph. Credit The Strand Bookstore\n\nAfter graduating from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, Fred enrolled in Brooklyn College, earning a degree in English in 1949. He attended classes by day and worked for his father in the afternoons, as he had since the age of 13. He swept the floor, organized the shelves and visited private homes to scout out books, which he carried on the subway to the Strand, by then at 81 Fourth Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets.\n\n\u201cI got the dust in my blood and I never got it out,\u201d he told McCandlish Phillips, a New York Times reporter and the author of \u201cCity Notebook: A Reporter\u2019s Portrait of a Vanishing New York\u201d (1974).\n\nMr. Bass was drafted into the Army in 1950 and posted to West Germany. In 1952, while serving stateside in New Jersey, he married Patricia Miller. She survives him, as do their daughter, Nancy Bass Wyden, who now owns the business; his sister, Dorothy Bass; a half sister, Eleanor Allen; and three grandchildren.\n\nMs. Wyden, whose husband is Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, took over the store on her father\u2019s retirement.", "title": "Fred Bass, Who Made the Strand Bookstore a Mecca, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "A shift to government jobs, along with employment at places like Trent and in services like health care, has left the city with a healthy economy, he said. At the same time, while the large factories have shut down in Peterborough, the number of small businesses has grown. \u201cThe Peterborough economy is better positioned to be successful than it was in 1975,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Dr. Phillips did acknowledge two significant problems with the city\u2019s transformation. Peterborough\u2019s unemployment rate gyrates. Last summer, it was the highest in the country; last month, it was below the national average. That suggests to him that many of the city\u2019s new jobs are temporary or contract positions.\n\nIn addition, he said, workers in Peterborough haven\u2019t seen wage gains to match the profit growth of the new companies that have appeared. Certainly few salaries match those of G.E., where factory wages start at 30 Canadian dollars an hour and come with generous benefits.\n\nJust as the latest round of Nafta talks neared their opening, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau\u2019s government announced that it had reached a deal to bring Canada into the Trans-Pacific Partnership, another free trade arrangement that had been championed by the United States only to be abandoned by President Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe old days before free trade, of course, weren\u2019t without problems. Often inefficient Canadian factories protected by tariffs offered Canadian consumers a limited selection of products at comparatively high prices. Protectionist policies that kept factories running in Ontario and Quebec sometimes limited the ability of western Canada to export agricultural and natural resource-based products because of retaliatory tariffs.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut I was struck in Peterborough about the widespread disappointment over Nafta. So I\u2019m interested in the thoughts of Canada letter readers about this. How has Nafta and free trade affected you, your family and friends? Have you given up on \u201cBuy Canadian?\u201d What do you want to see emerge from the current Nafta talks? Please send your thoughts to nytcanada@nytimes.com, and don\u2019t forget to tell us your age and where you live. My colleagues in the Reader Center will go through your replies and publish a selection next week.\n\nRead: This City Once Made Much of What Canada Bought. Mr. Schwartz, who is from Calgary, had repurchased a 33-foot sailboat he first owned in 1982. Set aside some time this weekend to read the story of their trip along the coast of British Columbia.\n\nAlso in Travel, the popular 36 Hours series has just featured Calgary. Among the stops the article proposes is the WinSport park, an idea I endorse. The many wonders of that Winter Olympics legacy include an indoor luge and bobsled track. It\u2019s truncated of course.\n\nRead: Sailing Into Today on a Boat From Our Past\n\nRead: 36 Hours in Calgary, Alberta\n\nThe Contemporary Past\n\nPhoto\n\nMy plans this weekend include seeing a new exhibition of photographs of the 19th century gold rushes in California and the Yukon at the National Gallery of Canada. The California ones were pulled from the gallery\u2019s collection of 11,000 daguerreotypes. In a post for The Times\u2019s Lens photo blog, Sarah Moroz wrote that the images made using that early photographic process rival those of modern digital photography in their clarity. That\u2019s not the only thing that seems modern. Luce Lebart, the head of the gallery\u2019s photo institute, told Ms. Moroz that the appearance of many of the miners in the photos \u201cis sometimes so close to that of contemporary hipsters that the viewer is almost perplexed.\u201d\n\n\n\nRead: The Age of Gold and Daguerreotypes\n\nTrans Canada\n\n\u2014Six weeks after the bodies of Barry and Honey Sherman were found hanging in the basement of their mansion in Toronto, the police have concluded that they were murdered.\n\n\u2014Three politicians stepped down this week because of accusations of sexual impropriety. On the political front, it was a particular blow to Ontario\u2019s Progressive Conservatives, whose leader, Patrick Brown, resigned about five months before a vote many had expected the party to win.\n\n\u2014The federal government\u2019s requirement that groups seeking federal grants for student jobs must support abortion rights has set off a cultural battle.\n\n\u2014The International Real Estate House Hunting feature checked out an unusual and historic place in the heart of Old Quebec City.", "title": "Free Trade Disillusionment and the First Hipsters: The Canada Letter", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The transition, though, is off to a halting start.\n\nMr. Macron wants to invest more than \u20ac15 million in programs to improve public and private retraining that have had only mixed success in recent years at ushering the jobless back into employment. Lawmakers won\u2019t vote on the measures until the spring, and any improvements are expected to take months, if not years, to bear fruit.\n\nThat layoffs are being announced before this crucial part is done has fueled suspicion among organized labor. And while new jobs will eventually be created, many unions worry the changes are a ploy to strip away worker protections \u2014 and their own power. In the last several weeks, the country\u2019s most ardent trade organizations have vigorously opposed such plans, with differing results.\n\nThe new rules tip the balance of power from workers to employers. Businesses have been reluctant to hire because it was difficult to shed workers. Employers have turned en masse to precarious short-term contracts to fill the gaps.\n\nNow, companies will be able to negotiate job cuts and restructurings through voluntary departures directly with labor representatives inside the business, rather than under strict industrywide collective bargaining agreements. Multinationals can downsize loss-making French operations more easily, even if the overall business is profitable. Companies will face less risk of legal action over dismissals, and can hire new staff immediately, rather than waiting.\n\nThe government has portrayed the changes as continuing to protect workers. When Pimkie, a struggling fast-fashion chain whose parent company is profitable, sought hundreds of voluntary buyouts, unions and workers rejected the proposal as insufficient. Managers must now go back to the negotiating table until payout terms satisfactory to the unions are reached. And unions will negotiate with management over the terms of at least 2,500 voluntary departures being pushed by the retail giant Carrefour.\n\nYet the measures clearly give companies more flexibility. PSA Group, which makes Peugeot and Citro\u00ebn cars, will offer 1,300 voluntary buyouts to older workers. It will fill most of those vacancies with younger, less expensive employees on full-time contracts after most unions approved the plan, originally unveiled last year. PSA will also offer 2,000 low-paid apprenticeships to young people.\n\nPierre-Olivier Salmon, the head of corporate information at PSA Group, said the carmaker is looking to bring in a new generation of workers with the digital and programming skills needed to develop projects like electric cars and future technology for the automotive industry.", "title": "French Companies Have Newfound Freedom \u2026 to Fire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was attending Hunter College in 1973 pursuing a teaching certificate so that I could teach French. Once I completed my coursework, I was assigned to be a student teacher at Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem.\n\nAs part of the student-teaching experience, I observed other French teachers in the school. The goal was to be exposed to diverse teaching styles and French instruction at different levels.\n\nOne morning, I was observing a French 3 class. As the teacher instructed the class, he spoke entirely in French at a relatively brisk conversational pace. Most of the students seemed engaged in the lesson.\n\nAt one point, however, the teacher noticed a girl who did not seem to be following along. He stopped the class.", "title": "French Lesson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor most women undergoing in vitro fertilization, fresh embryos work just as well as frozen ones.\n\nPrevious trials have suggested that using only frozen embryos might improve pregnancy rates in women with polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS, a hormonal disorder that affects about 10 percent of women. (Women with this condition ovulate irregularly and typically have a poorer response to IVF treatment.) But in two large randomized trials published in the New England Journal of Medicine, researchers found using fresh or frozen embryos makes no difference for the majority of women who do not have PCOS.\n\nIn the first study, of 2,157 women without PCOS, 50.2 percent of fresh embryo transfers resulted in a live birth, and so did 48.7 percent of the frozen transfers. The difference was statistically insignificant.\n\nIn the second, of 782 women without PCOS, live birthrates were 33.8 percent for the frozen-embryo group and 31.5 percent for the fresh, again an insignificant difference.\n\n\u201cUnless there are specific factors that require it, you can safely go with a fresh transfer of your first embryo,\u201d said the senior author of the second study, Dr. Ben W. Mol, a professor of obstetrics at the University of Adelaide in Australia. \u201cTransfer your first embryo fresh. There is no need to completely go around the first fresh transfer.\u201d", "title": "Fresh Embryos as Good as Frozen Ones for In Vitro Fertilization", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s incredibly important that I decided to serve my country before deciding to run for office,\u201d said Ms. Sherrill, whose path to the House became easier on Monday when her Republican opponent, Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, announced his retirement. \u201cThat shows where my center is.\u201d\n\nStrategists in both parties say that women \u2014 as candidates, activists and voters \u2014 are more likely to shape the outcome of the midterm elections than any other part of the electorate.\n\nRepublicans have their own female veterans running for House seats: Aja Smith in inland Southern California and Lynne Blankenbeker in New Hampshire. Representative Martha McSally, Republican of Arizona and an Air Force Academy graduate and decorated fighter pilot, is running for the Senate.\n\nBut Democrats have the trickier task \u2014 flipping enough seats in often gerrymandered Republican districts to take the House. Ms. Luria is running in the Tidewater Region of Virginia, home to the world\u2019s largest naval base and the headquarters of the Christian Broadcasting Network. If she wins her primary race, she is likely to face Representative Scott Taylor, a freshman Republican with his own military credential, as a Navy SEAL.\n\nThe district where Ms. McGrath is running in Kentucky sprawls across 19 rural and urban counties that include Lexington. But her contest, even with her compelling background, might be the toughest of the three. Many Democrats in Washington prefer her primary opponent, Jim Gray, the mayor of Lexington, who is better known and can fund much of the race with his own money.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. McGrath has gained a measure of celebrity with an initial campaign video highlighting her military experience and her criticism of Mr. Trump. It has attracted more than one million page views and, more important, generated more than $1 million in campaign contributions.\n\nThe New Jersey district that Ms. Sherrill is running in went for Mr. Trump by less than a percentage point, then voted for the new Democratic governor, Phil Murphy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll three women lean heavily on their military backgrounds to promote their campaigns, with photos in uniform dominating their websites. But they also share the challenges of any first-time candidate: raising money, building an organization and avoiding rookie mistakes.\n\nSeated at a table in the Norfolk business she started while still on active duty, Mermaid Factory, where customers paint molds of mermaids, Ms. Luria noted how important ties to the Navy were in her district, which includes the state\u2019s largest city, Virginia Beach. She served for 20 years before retiring last June, and decided only a few months later to run for Congress.\n\nMs. Luria said that she felt the pull to run for office after Mr. Trump\u2019s election, and that her husband quit his job to help take over household duties so she could focus on campaigning.\n\nShe grew up in Birmingham, Ala., where her family owned a scrap metal business. She was drawn to two seemingly contradictory passions \u2014 art and engineering \u2014 which she thought she could pursue at the Naval Academy.\n\n\u201cI went to Annapolis and was really just brainwashed,\u201d she said. \u201cThe midshipmen seemed like they knew everything in the world. I wanted to be just like them.\u201d\n\nUnlike many at the academy, she was not particularly athletic. But she had earned a black belt in taekwondo, passed all the required endurance tests and flourished in the classroom. She also mastered the required manner of eating for plebes, squaring her bites and taking no more than three chews before swallowing.\n\nShe decided on surface warfare and rose to become a commander.\n\n\u201cA ship is like a city at sea,\u201d she said. \u201cThe junior sailor cleaning the head is as important as the officer on the radar scope.\u201d\n\nAfter the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, she said, she felt compelled to stay in the Navy. She had a letter of resignation stuck in her desk, but never submitted it.\n\nPhoto\n\nWomen in public opinion polls have been more critical of Mr. Trump than men, and they have used elections to cast a vote against him, most notably in recent races in Virginia. But Ms. Luria said that she would rather focus on policy disagreements than the president\u2019s behavior.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll three women said they were drawn to the idea of public office from their first days at the academy, when they had to memorize a mission statement that said they would dedicate themselves to both citizenship and leadership. The Navy exposed them to Americans, and immigrants, from all walks of life, they said, and that has helped as they campaign in their diverse districts.\n\nWhile Ms. Luria has institutional party support, Ms. McGrath does not. Boisterous, outgoing and quick with an opinion, Ms. McGrath was highly critical of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee for encouraging Mr. Gray to enter the race.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNot only did they not embrace me, they were not even neutral,\u201d Ms. McGrath said. \u201cAll I wanted them to do was to just stay out of it.\u201d\n\nBut she has a history of not shying from a fight. Her older brother, Matt, pushed her to compete with boys in every sport, including football.\n\nAs an 11-year-old, she became enthralled with fighter pilots after watching a documentary on the History Channel and asked her mother how she could become one. Her mother told her the law prohibited it. The young girl asked how laws could be changed.\n\nShe persisted, writing Jim Bunning, her representative in Congress at the time, to ask why women were not allowed to be fighter pilots. Mr. Bunning, who died last May, replied that women were not prohibited because they were considered \u201cinferior,\u201d but rather \u201cwere perceived as a precious commodity of the country that deserved protection.\u201d\n\n\u201cHere I was beating all the boys, and I just did not understand because my name was Amy and not Andy that I couldn\u2019t be a jet pilot,\u201d Ms. McGrath said.\n\nSo she wrote to the members of the congressional armed services committees, and only Patricia Schroeder, then a Democratic congresswoman from Colorado, supported her position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen came the election of Bill Clinton in 1992, and Democrats eventually pushed through the kind of change that Ms. McGrath had been seeking.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThat was my first understanding of the difference between Democrats and Republicans,\u201d she said. \u201cI knew all the Democrats were willing to give me an opportunity to compete, and the Republicans said no.\u201d\n\nShe applied to the Naval Academy because she thought that was where the best pilots trained. Ms. McGrath said she loved the atmosphere from the first day \u2014 the tougher the better. Soon after graduation, she was flying an F-18.\n\n\u201cThe F-18 is the most intense job in the world,\u201d she said. \u201cImagine playing a soccer game and doing math problems and doing a talk radio show at the same time. It completely physically and mentally absorbs everything that you have.\u201d\n\nShe flew missions in Afghanistan and Iraq, and then did a tour at the Pentagon and as a fellow in Congress. She turned down a possible promotion to have the second of her three children, and earned a master\u2019s degree in international relations from Johns Hopkins. After that, she taught at the Naval Academy, and a guest speaker one day was Ben Chandler, a former Congressman from her home state of Kentucky. He gave her his card and asked her to call if she ever needed anything.\n\nForty-eight hours after Mr. Trump\u2019s election, Ms. McGrath was rummaging through a drawer to find Mr. Chandler\u2019s card. She quickly wrote him an emotional email.\n\n\u201cI never really thought I\u2019d ever write you to ask you for some guidance but this week has left me numb,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI\u2019m so taken back by who our nation elected president and what he stands for that I feel as if I must do something. I\u2019ve spent my entire adult life in the service of this country, three combat tours, and literally years of my life living in tents overseas. I love this country, but I\u2019ve never been more ashamed and embarrassed to be an American as I was waking up on Weds morning.\u201d\n\nShe wanted to run for Congress. Mr. Chandler put her in touch with his former campaign manager, and she was off.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI am deeply disappointed in the president,\u201d she said. \u201cHis character, almost everything he has done in his life and stood for in his life is against everything that I have tried to stand for and do.\u201d\n\nIf Ms. McGrath is to win her primary race, it appears likely that she will have to do it as an insurgent.\n\nMs. Sherrill does not have that burden. With the strong backing of her party, she is favored to win her primary and her chances for winning the seat increase with Mr. Frelinghuysen\u2019s retirement announcement. She does not speak of Mr. Trump with the sharp edges of Ms. McGrath, focusing her criticism instead on the new tax law and the president\u2019s effort to weaken the Affordable Care Act.\n\nHer district is a suburban-exurban blend of mainly prosperous New Jersey suburbs. But like many suburban women, she said she was simply \u201cfed up\u201d with the president\u2019s agenda. \u201cI talked to friends and thought if we broke through our own glass ceilings, we would progress, yet we now see again and again we simply haven\u2019t made the gains we thought we made. My children\u2019s future is in peril.\u201d\n\nIn addition to her Navy service, Ms. Sherrill was a federal prosecutor, and fretted that it now felt like \u201cour institutions of democracy are under attack.\u201d", "title": "From Annapolis to Congress? These Three Women Know Tough Missions", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. We all know the urban legend about baby alligators being flushed down the toilet, and the all-too real issue with wet wipes, but what other weird things end up in the sewer system?\n\nA. Of the nondegradable debris the city has to remove from sewage before treatment, wipes make up about 80 percent, said Vincent Sapienza, the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection. The other 20 percent occasionally includes some head-scratchers.\n\nOn a recent morning, Mr. Sapienza led a small group on a tour of the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Greenpoint. Situated along the Superfund-listed waterway of the same name, the Newtown Creek plant is the largest of the department\u2019s 14 treatment facilities. It is designed to handle as much as 700 million gallons of wastewater each day.\n\nSeveral stories underneath the treatment plant\u2019s surface, a river of locally sourced sewage flows through a grate designed to catch nondegradable debris. A large \u201crake\u201d pulls the debris up to ground level, where it deposits the captured material on a platform for landfill disposal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nZainool Ali, the plant\u2019s superintendent, said the recent building boom in North Brooklyn has led to an uptick in construction materials. He laughed while recalling a long wooden beam that had recently been caught in the grate; a twisted piece of metal, possibly once part of a guardrail, lay on the floor nearby.", "title": "From Bicycles to Wooden Beams: The Weird Stuff Found in City Sewage", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "From the surging value of cryptocurrencies to the continuing investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, developments in 2017 were hard to forecast. Who could have predicted that an article in The New York Times in October describing sexual misconduct by the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein would unleash a torrent of claims about media stars, members of Congress and the judiciary and even an N.F.L. owner?\n\nWith a little trepidation, here are my thoughts on a few topics that should continue to be of interest in 2018:\n\nInitial Coin Offerings\n\nFor those of us who remember the dot.com boom, there is a sense of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu with the frenzy over cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, which has shot up to well over $10,000 in 2017 from about $1,000, according to Coindesk. Cryptocurrencies may be all the rage, but the Securities and Exchange Commission is focusing on initial coin offerings as a potential avenue for fraud. These I.C.O.s allow companies to raise money by creating their own private digital currency through a form of online crowdfunding, with some offerings raising millions of dollars in just a few days.\n\nA company raising money from the public by selling something whose value depends on the success of its venture sounds like a security. That is why the S.E.C. has ramped up its scrutiny of I.C.O.s to determine whether issuers are skirting the detailed \u2014 and expensive \u2014 disclosure requirements for dealing with investors.\n\nIf anyone is going to rain on the I.C.O. parade, it will be the S.E.C. On Dec. 1, the agency filed an emergency action in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn to stop an offering of PlexCoin, which the complaint said raised more than $15 million by promoting a return of more than 1,000 percent in a month. The S.E.C. has also filed actions for fraud involving other I.C.O.s. We should expect it to continue to crack down on companies using digital currencies to raise money without following the requirements for selling securities.", "title": "From Bitcoin to Russia Investigation, a Look Ahead at 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe\u2019s fine,\u201d the doctor said. \u201cYou\u2019re doing a good job, don\u2019t worry too much.\u201d\n\nI could not worry too much? That was an option?\n\nI had my daughter while we were living in Brooklyn, the competitive parenting capital of the world. Parenting is hard enough without having one woman in a mothers\u2019 group suggest importing organic formula from Norway while another, baby clutched at her breast, gasps that we could even consider feeding our babies formula.\n\nWhen buying my baby\u2019s first bassinet before she was born, I made the mistake of asking my online mothers\u2019 group for recommendations. I got flooded with responses and links and Amazon reviews and my post quickly devolved into a fight between the co-sleepers and non-co-sleepers. I finally settled on an expensive bassinet (because when you get anxious about child-rearing, you can be tricked into assuming that more expensive means better) and then, once it arrived, spent days worried that I had made the wrong decision.\n\nThe bassinet we got worked perfectly well but just as we were starting to get full nights of sleep and an occasional night out, we got on a plane and flew across the world to India and landed at the airport at 1 a.m. It was bustling with families waiting for loved ones and babies and children of all ages running around excitedly with no concept of a bedtime.\n\nFrom the minute we arrived in India, I had to let go. I had to stop worrying because I couldn\u2019t worry anymore \u2014 it is impossible to worry about everything I might need to worry about in India: contaminated water, mosquitoes that may carry dengue or malaria, traffic that often follows no rules. Against all of that, did it really matter if my daughter had gained three ounces or five?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe next day, in Mumbai, I went to a fancy baby shop to buy cribs, ready to spend a few hours weighing the pros and cons of various options. With the baby strapped to me in a carrier and an iced coffee in my hand, I marched in to the shop and said, \u201cI\u2019d like to see your options for cribs, please.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis one,\u201d the salesperson said. I ordered it and left the shop within 10 minutes.\n\nI myself was born in India and had a perfectly safe and sound upbringing here but, in the eternal battle of nature versus nurture, my surroundings in Brooklyn seemed to be affecting me more than my own childhood or my mother\u2019s suggestions that I calm down. Her advice was impossible for me to hear in my New York environment, surrounded by my fellow mothers whose days are ruled by feeding apps. When I showed my Indian grandmother the feeding app on my phone, instead of marveling at it and saying she wished she\u2019d had such a thing when she was a young mother, she just laughed at me and took a long sip of her coconut water.\n\nI had been nervous about making this big trip with our newborn daughter because to leave our little neighborhood of Brooklyn and travel across the world and set up a different life felt too daunting. Babies are challenging: In a cruel failure of evolution, adults require five hours of uninterrupted sleep in order to function and newborn babies need to feed every three hours.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey say babies thrive on routine and I had just begun to find mine in Brooklyn, but it was a perfectly crafted rhythm with no space for deviation or change. I have the luxury of working from home so I was feeding her as soon as the baby-feeding app beeped and I put her down for naps at exactly the same time every day.\n\nMy baby, who loved 22 out of the 24 hours it took us to get to Mumbai, doesn\u2019t seem to be too bothered about her routine being disrupted so far. She loves all the people in India and reaches for them faster than I can swoop in and force them to cover themselves with antibacterial gel.\n\nShe\u2019s had a stomach upset already but didn\u2019t seem nearly as troubled by it as I was. We went out to dinner with friends who have a 7-month-old and both babies stayed awake for part of the dinner and then fell asleep in their strollers. When we got home we transferred her to her crib and she kept sleeping peacefully.\n\nSome nights she wakes up at 2 a.m. and needs a bit of attention and some nights she doesn\u2019t; there isn\u2019t any method to her madness, whether or not I\u2019ve followed the feeding app perfectly, whether or not we\u2019ve been at a boisterous restaurant.\n\nAnd so we\u2019re both learning \u2014 me to relax and her to not put everything in her mouth. I think we\u2019ll find a happy equilibrium. I\u2019m still worrying about the big things and some very small ones: No mosquito has come within two feet of my daughter and lived to tell the tale. But I\u2019ve found much more mental time for actual enjoyment now.\n\nI don\u2019t claim to have discovered the secret to parenting except, perhaps, just one: There is no secret to parenting.", "title": "From Brooklyn to India, in Search of the Secret to Parenthood", "authors": ["Diksha Basu"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIN THE MIDST OF WINTER\n\nBy Isabel Allende\n\nTranslated by Nick Calstor and Amanda Hopkinson\n\n342 pp. Atria Books. $28\n\nIn Isabel Allende\u2019s new novel, a snowstorm and a car accident bring three people together on an unexpected journey that transforms their lives. As if this premise is not sufficiently hackneyed, Allende adds literary insult to injury by spelling it out in breathy prose: \u201cOver the next three days, as the storm wearied of punishing the land and dissolved far out to sea, the lives of Lucia Maraz, Richard Bowmaster and Evelyn Ortega would become inextricably linked.\u201d The novel is riddled with such formulations. Seemingly intended to stab at the surreal, fablelike quality for which Allende is known, they come off as merely soppy and uninspired.\n\nIn fact, the story owes less to magical realism than to histrionic crime dramas. Richard, a lonely, aging professor, sets out in a car from his Brooklyn apartment and collides with a vehicle being driven by Evelyn, an undocumented immigrant who happens to be driving her employer\u2019s car. She turns up at his apartment later that night, distraught and unintelligible, her Spanglish broken by a stammer she developed after suffering a brutal gang assault in her native Guatemala. Richard calls his tenant Lucia, a middle-aged visiting Chilean professor under his direction at N.Y.U., to help. The three split a pot brownie, as one does during blizzards with strangers, and swap life stories.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt comes out that there is a corpse in Evelyn\u2019s trunk, which won\u2019t close thanks to the crash. She is terrified of returning the damaged car to her employer, the abusive Frank Leroy, who is sure to come after her if he knows she\u2019s seen the body. Naturally, Evelyn can\u2019t go to the police either. Moved by her plight, Richard and Lucia decide to help her dump car and corpse. This fantastic bit of plot \u2014 why on earth should they undertake such a risk for a stranger who, for all they know, committed the murder herself? \u2014 is supposed to be justified by their own immigrant histories: Lucia fled Chile\u2019s military junta in the 1970s; Richard, whose father escaped the Nazis, hears \u201chis father\u2019s voice deep inside him reminding him of his duty to help the persecuted.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the trio journeys upstate, the novel flashes back through each character\u2019s past \u2014 Lucia\u2019s memories of a family fractured by war in Chile, Richard\u2019s doomed marriage in Brazil and Evelyn\u2019s tragic childhood in Guatemala. Some images are memorable: Lucia\u2019s murdered brother is \u201ca feeling, a fleeting shadow, a kiss brushing her forehead\u201d; a Guatemalan gangster has \u201ctattoos spreading like a plague across his skin.\u201d Though inventive, these back stories are marred by simplistic exposition (\u201cthe deep crisis dividing Chile became unsustainable\u201d) and clunky dialogue (\u201cthis violence is the result of an endless war against the poor\u201d). They plead with the reader to have sympathy for Latino immigrants, which is a fine humanitarian agenda. But heaps of suffering and misfortune cannot give depth to thin characters.\n\nNor can love. Lucia and Richard fall into a late-age romance and, as in Allende\u2019s other love stories, their passion inspires some of the novel\u2019s most cringeworthy lines: She accuses him of having spent \u201cmany years with your soul in winter and your heart locked away.\u201d It also leads to a rosy, fairy-tale ending, which figures awkwardly in a novel that wants to tell the truth about immigration.", "title": "From Isabel Allende, a Novel of Three Immigrants and a Brooklyn Misadventure", "authors": ["Elizabeth Winkler", "Isabel Allende"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Only a handful now do so. But the fight has entered a new round, with an American president who has shown a special fondness for truckers and their big rigs. The Trump administration has thrown its America First agenda behind the cause in the Nafta negotiations, demanding that Mexico agree to a provision that could, in the future, block its drivers from making deliveries into the middle of the United States.\n\nMexico has rejected that suggestion outright, challenging the fairness of shielding a slice of laborers from low-paid foreign competitors, in a trade deal meant to allow most everything to flow freely across borders.\n\nThe dispute offers a window into the stakes involved in rewriting, or blowing up, an agreement that has become highly contentious but also extremely lucrative for all sides. It also hints at the impact that market forces \u2014 more than rules agreed to on paper \u2014 may have on the ways two nations exchange wares.", "title": "From Mexico to the U.S., a Nafta Tale of Two Truckers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE TEMPTATION TO BE HAPPY\n\nBy Lorenzo Marone\n\nTranslated by Shaun Whiteside\n\n247 pp. Oneworld. $26.99.\n\nPhoto\n\nCesare Annunziata doesn\u2019t like people very much, doesn\u2019t get along with his two children, cheated on his wife before she died, has lots of regrets \u2014 and seems determined to gather a few more. \u201cI\u2019m old,\u201d he says (a little too frequently), \u201cand I do what I like.\u201d Uh oh, here comes another one of those colorful curmudgeons who drop pearls of senior wisdom on their way to a new lease on life. Cesare certainly fits the stereotype, but he\u2019s funny, interesting and grumpy enough to stay on the winning side of the formula. He lives alone in an apartment in Naples, and along with two equally elderly neighbors \u2014 a mad cat lady and a deaf, anxious octogenarian \u201cwho listens even if he can\u2019t hear\u201d \u2014 is drawn into the life of a new tenant who they suspect is being abused by her husband.\n\nAmid their mostly useless plotting and scheming to save her, Cesare takes stock of his own existence (denying, of course, that he would ever do such a thing) \u2014 and stumbles toward a kind of peace with his family, his friends and his dubious life choices. \u201cIf I were to land on the planet another 10 times, I\u2019d still travel the same journey and crash into the same rocks along the way,\u201d he insists. \u201cMost of us are like ants: We follow a trail that has already been laid for us.\u201d\n\nTHE TIME OF MUTE SWANS\n\nBy Ece Temelkuran\n\nTranslated by Kenneth Dakan\n\n404 pp. Arcade. $24.99.\n\nPhoto\n\nStreet battles, kidnapping, torture, fascists, communists, rocky marriages and class tensions \u2014 and most of it seen through the eyes of two 8-year-old children living in Ankara, in the summer before the 1980 coup in Turkey. Going by the author\u2019s dedication, to her two nephews \u201cwho lived through the July 16, 2016, coup attempt at the same age I lived through the September 12, 1980, coup,\u201d Temelkuran is drawing on her own experiences in constructing this political bricolage.\n\nHer guides are Ali, a \u201cweakly boy\u201d from the poorer side of town, and Ayse, the daughter of a troubled middle-class couple. Despite their class differences, the families are on the same side politically \u2014 the left \u2014 and the children become friends after Ali\u2019s mother takes a cleaning job at Ayse\u2019s house. As the political unrest escalates, the children do their own plotting, first to release butterflies inside the Turkish Parliament, then to save the swans of Swan Park, which are apparently being subjected to \u201can Avian Deflighting Technique.\u201d \u201cUntil the swans are saved,\u201d the children pledge to each other, \u201cand the butterflies get into Parliament ... Even if we get really tired, even if we get sleepy \u2026 we will resist \u2026 I swear it! O.K., we\u2019re done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a perilous undertaking to tell such a complicated story through the imagined magical thinking of childhood, and aside from some bright flashes of ingenuous insight, the telling offers more confusion than clarity.", "title": "From Naples to Tokyo, New Books in Translation", "authors": ["Alison Mcculloch"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "And he was not kidding about his work look. For a performance at Brooklyn Steel last fall and in various videos associated with \u201cSIR,\u201d the new Fischerspooner release, the performance artist, singer and all-around provocateur disported himself in every conceivable manner of shredded, studded, body-revealing raunch-wear that the Tony-award winning designer Jeff Mahshie could devise. When, that is, Mr. Spooner was wearing any clothes at all.\n\nMr. Spooner had been at the men\u2019s shows in Milan and returned on Tuesday to Paris, where he has taken up residence. Here on a visit a month ago, he missed his flight home to New York and impulsively decided to remain. \u201cIt\u2019s time to be an expat and set up the next bohemian paradise compound where we can gather and conspire,\u201d he informed his followers on Instagram, where he is often pictured wearing little besides a huge fur coat that looks like Chewbacca\u2019s pelt.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI had no clothes when I arrived\u201d in Europe, Mr. Spooner added plaintively on Tuesday, though Ms. Chachki was having none of it. \u201cShe says that to everyone,\u201d the drag performer said, lowering the frames of her pink retro-Futurist sunglasses to throw Mr. Spooner some shade. \u201cNow everyone gives her looks. She\u2019s a total looks-whore.\u201d\n\nIf Mr. G\u00f3mez Palomo was among those designers who quickly came to Mr. Spooner\u2019s sartorial assistance, he was in good company. Miuccia Prada and others in Milan generously sent clothes to keep the performer from going naked to assorted fashion-show front rows.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet Palomo Spain may be the best fit of all, since the label designed by Mr. Gomez has, in less than two years, made a singular mark on the industry with designs that don\u2019t test gender binaries so much as flout their existence.\n\nTrue to form, in a presentation titled \u201cHunting\u201d and shown under black lights in a friend\u2019s apartment hung with a huge Gilbert & George work and decorated to look like a forest, the Spanish designer sent out a giddy assortment of his frilly, sometimes feminine, often historicist, always ornamented and minimally concealing designs for brocade chaps, opera cloaks, sleeveless jerkins with shoulder ruffles, peekaboo lace surplices, trailing gowns (yes, for men), velvet lounge suits, tunics resembling chain mail, marabou-trimmed tabarro capes and ruched velvet bloomers from which the models\u2019 skinny hairy legs protruded obscenely.\n\n\u201cMy father hunts every weekend and I grew up surrounded by trophies and horns,\u201d said the designer, who also produced some commercial garments, if you can call a brocade jumpsuit with a buttoned fanny-flap commercial.", "title": "From No Clothes to Almost No Clothes at Palomo Spain", "authors": ["Guy Trebay"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ogrim cautioned that journalists should not overreact to Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks. \u201cThese are somewhat small matters and the frenzy with which they are reported does not perhaps always help the media in their just fight with a president who is doing his best to undermine them and their importance,\u201d he said.\n\nGudmund Hernes, a former minister of education and minister of health from the Labor Party, wrote sarcastically on Twitter: \u201cErna worked: Norwegians are welcome.\u201d (Ms. Solberg is from the Conservative Party.)\n\nThis was not the first time Mr. Trump had rankled Scandinavians with off-the-cuff remarks. In February, he puzzled and alarmed Swedes when, in a speech discussing refugee policies in Europe, he suggested that a terrorist attack had occurred \u201clast night in Sweden.\u201d No such thing had taken place.\n\n\u201cDoes Trump know that Norway is neighbors with what-happened-last-night-in-Sweden?\u201d a Swedish social worker, Ulf Fogelstrom, quipped on Twitter.\n\nMr. Trump was then rebuked on Friday by the United Nations human rights office, which described his comments as dangerous racism that opened the door to humanity\u2019s worst characteristics.\n\n\u201cThese are shocking and shameful comments from the president of the United States,\u201d Rupert Colville, a spokesman for Zeid Ra\u2019ad al-Hussein, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, told reporters in Geneva. \u201cSorry, there is no other word one can use but racist.\u201d\n\nNorway (population 5.2 million) and Haiti (population 10.9 million) are both relatively small countries, but their situations could hardly be more different. Norway is one of the world\u2019s wealthiest nations, with rich oil reserves, a mighty sovereign wealth fund and a gross domestic product per capita that is about 23 percent higher than that of the United States. Haiti, the world\u2019s first free black republic, is one of the poorest countries in the Western Hemisphere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth countries have close relationships with the United States, but from very different positions of power. Norway is a member of NATO and a close military and security ally of the United States. Haiti was occupied by United States Marines from 1915 to 1934, and American troops have intervened several times since. The United States has also been a significant source of aid to Haiti in the wake of several natural calamities.\n\nHaitians and members of the Haitian diaspora were aghast upon hearing of Mr. Trump\u2019s latest remarks.\n\nPaul G. Altidor, the Haitian ambassador to the United States, said that Haitian officials \u201cvehemently condemn\u201d Mr. Trump\u2019s comments, which he said were \u201cbased on stereotypes,\u201d according to Yamiche Alcindor, a journalist reporting for the program \u201cPBS NewsHour\u201d who interviewed him. \u201cEither the president has been misinformed or he is miseducated,\u201d she quoted him as saying.\n\nMs. Alcindor, who is Haitian-American, also quoted Mr. Altidor as saying: \u201cHaitians fought along U.S. soldiers in the Revolutionary War, and we continue to be great contributors to American society.\u201d\n\nMr. Altidor said Haiti\u2019s government had summoned a United States official to explain Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks.\n\nFrantz Duval, the editor in chief of Haiti\u2019s largest newspaper, Le Nouvelliste, took to Twitter to describe Mr. Trump\u2019s words as an opportunity to rouse Haiti\u2019s citizens and rebuild the country, which is still recovering from a deadly earthquake on Jan. 12, 2010.\n\n\u201cNow that the whole world is aware, are we going to take pleasure in this image?\u201d he wrote. \u201cNothing to change it? Are we going to continue to feed the clutter and silly stupid things that serve us as ornaments?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRaoul Peck, a Haitian filmmaker and former minister of culture, cast blame on Americans who were \u201cenabling\u201d their president.\n\nHe accused Republican lawmakers and Trump voters of \u201cprotecting even his most outrageous behaviors,\u201d saying that if they do not \u201cstand up to this sickening and suicidal pathology, they will go down in history as not only accomplices, but as James Baldwin would say, as criminals.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaitian-Americans also expressed anger. \u201cYour words are unkind, untrue and divisive,\u201d Garcelle Beauvais, an actress who was born in Haiti, wrote on Twitter. \u201cWe deserve an apology.\u201d\n\nKarl A. Racine, the attorney general for the District of Columbia, wrote on Twitter: \u201cImmigrants add immeasurable value to our city and our nation \u2014 and they deserve respect. I am proud to be Haitian-American, and I will continue to fight for the dignity and safety of every member of the District\u2019s immigrant communities.\u201d\n\nIn Quebec, where thousands of Haitians have been streaming since this past summer after the Trump administration signaled that the United States would no longer provide Temporary Protected Status for some 59,000 Haitians in the United States, local Haitian leaders reacted with anger to Mr. Trump\u2019s words but were not surprised.\n\n\u201cWe know who he is, and what he says doesn\u2019t surprise anybody,\u201d said Marjorie Villefranche, the director general of La Maison d\u2019Ha\u00efti, a Haitian community organization in Montreal. \u201cWhat Trump said is racist, and it is irresponsible because it threatens to encourage discrimination. That is why Haitians are hurrying to come here.\u201d\n\nMs. Villefranche said that the local Haitians lived in fear of Mr. Trump after his administration announced in November that it was ending the humanitarian program for Haitians, established after the devastating 2010 earthquake in Haiti, that had allowed them to stay in the United States. Now, Haitians in the country under the program are expected to leave the United States by July 2019 or face deportation.\n\nIn El Salvador, where the government is still digesting Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement on Monday that nearly 200,000 Salvadorans granted Temporary Protected Status in the United States since 2001 will have to leave by 2019, Carlos Calleja, a businessman and civic activist who is running to be the presidential candidate for the right-leaning Nationalist Republican Alliance, called for unity.\n\n\u201cOur relationship with the United States is a special, historic one, and it will continue to go on,\u201d he said Thursday night. \u201cWe can\u2019t allow ourselves to be distracted by things like this. There are more important issues to address, specifically the millions of Salvadorans living in the United States that we care deeply about.\u201d\n\nThe United States has had a long history of favoring immigrants from some countries over others. For much of the period from the 1890s to the 1920s, when immigration from Southern and Eastern Europe was at its peak, nativists asked why immigration from Western and Northern Europe had slowed. Religion was a factor: Many of the immigrants then were Catholics and Jews, unlike their Protestant predecessors. In 1965, old quotas based on national origins were replaced by the current system, which has been accompanied by sharp increases in migration from Latin America, Asia and Africa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMae M. Ngai, a historian at Columbia University who has written extensively on Asian immigration to the United States, expressed dismay at Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks.\n\n\u201cHis vulgar racism is exceeded perhaps only by his ignorance,\u201d she said. \u201cCountries like El Salvador and Haiti are in terrible condition in large part because of long histories of American support for right-wing dictatorships and crony capitalism. And why would anyone in Norway give up their social benefits \u2014 universal health care on a single payer system, no college tuition, and the like \u2014 to come to the U.S., which has none of it?\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s remarks came the same day that the United Nations secretary general, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, gave a speech urging reasoned debate on immigration.\n\n\u201cLet us focus on the overwhelming positives of migration and use facts, not prejudice, to address its challenges,\u201d he said.", "title": "From Norway to Haiti, Trump\u2019s Comments Stir Fresh Outrage", "authors": ["Henrik Pryser Libell", "Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration has emphasized that the permissions were originally granted because of wars and natural disasters in the immigrants\u2019 home countries and intended to last only until conditions there improved. But in reality, their permissions have been extended so long that they have become indefinite residents, often buying homes and raising American-born children, even though their status offers no path to citizenship.\n\nThey, like other unauthorized immigrants, have become indispensable parts of certain industries, taking jobs that employers say no one else will and that immigration restrictionists say could attract Americans if companies were willing to pay more.\n\n\u201cT.P.S. does not exist for the convenience of industries that rely on low-wage foreign labor,\u201d said Ira Mehlman, a spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform.\n\nThe companies create \u201cself-fulfilling prophecies\u201d by offering little pay and grueling conditions, he said: \u201cWhen Americans reject the wages and working conditions they offer, they then argue that Americans are unwilling to take the jobs.\u201d\n\nConcentrated in California, Texas, Florida, New York, Virginia and Maryland, those with protected status work mainly in construction, restaurants and grocery stores, and as landscapers and day care workers, according to data on recipients from El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti assembled by the Center for Migration Studies, a nonprofit that has argued for extending the program.\n\nMore than 45,000 Haitians will have to leave by July 2019; about 57,000 Hondurans are hoping, against all indications to the contrary, that they will be spared the next time the Trump administration must decide whether to extend their protections.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnother report, by the Immigrant Legal Resource Center, estimates that stripping the protections from Salvadorans, Hondurans and Haitians would deprive Social Security and Medicare of about $6.9 billion in contributions over a decade, and would shrink the gross domestic product by $45.2 billion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConstruction companies already confronting a nationwide labor shortage will have to replace workers from what industry executives said was a minuscule pool, or turn down projects.\n\n\u201cThere are no Americans out there to take the jobs,\u201d said Mark Drury, a vice president at Shapiro & Duncan, a Washington-area plumbing, heating and cooling firm. The company and its competitors have resorted to poaching each other\u2019s project managers, engineers, welders and plumbers.\n\nThe company even retrained and hired a former coal miner who decided to switch careers, Mr. Drury said, but had not found other miners willing to move to the area.\n\nNot only will the company have to lay off its 14 Salvadoran workers, Mr. Drury said, but it was also worrying about the roughly 30 employees who are protected from deportation by virtue of a government program for immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children. The Trump administration has announced that the program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, will expire in March.\n\nCongress is considering creating a new program for those immigrants, perhaps in exchange for new border security spending, but no deal has been reached. On Tuesday, President Trump said he was open to a comprehensive deal that would shield not only the young immigrants, but perhaps millions of others without legal status, presumably including those with temporary protected status.\n\nThat would be a welcome development to Mr. Drury, who said he had about 40 openings. The company \u2014 which is helping to build a cancer center, the new headquarters of the mortgage giant Fannie Mae and a project at the headquarters of the National Security Agency \u2014 was already turning away work because it could not hire fast enough, he said.\n\n\u201cLosing people just puts us further behind,\u201d he said.\n\nFor Stan Marek, the chief executive of Marek, a Houston-based construction company, the decisions to end temporary protections have come at the worst possible time. Houston is waiting to be rebuilt after Hurricane Harvey, yet, he said, there will be fewer people than ever to overhaul the city\u2019s office buildings, schools, hotels and hospitals.\n\nAbout 30 employees from Honduras, Haiti and El Salvador with temporary protected status have worked for him for over a decade. Some are skilled craftsmen; some are supervisors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Marek has pushed on his workers\u2019 behalf, even paying for a public-relations campaign to call for immigration reform.\n\n\u201cIf they lose their status \u2014 boom, we\u2019ll have to terminate them, and that\u2019s not much fun, telling a guy who\u2019s got three kids in high school, all American-born, that he\u2019s going to be terminated,\u201d Mr. Marek said. \u201cThey\u2019re good people, damn good people.\u201d\n\nThough they will be subject to deportation, many immigrants who lose their temporary protections are likely to stay in the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nAsked what he planned to do when his status expired next year, Noe Duarte said he and his wife and two adult children, who are already living here illegally, would simply \u201chide.\u201d\n\nMr. Duarte came to the United States from El Salvador in 2000, fleeing violence and poverty in his hometown, and was granted temporary status the following year. His family operates two small companies, cleaning and painting houses, in Gaithersburg, Md. When business is slow, Mr. Duarte works as a safety supervisor for a major construction company.\n\nEven knowing that their finances would crater without his work permit, he felt that the family would be safer here than in El Salvador.\n\n\u201cThe country is infested with gangs,\u201d he said. \u201cThe moment we arrived, they would come to our door asking for money. And if we didn\u2019t give it to them, we\u2019d be killed.\u201d\n\nMr. Moran, the janitorial services executive, had been worried about the impending cancellation of the program. His staff cleans buildings throughout the Washington area, including the headquarters of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the federal agency that would be responsible for deporting his workers, and the offices of the special prosecutor, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Trump voter who said he supported the president\u2019s overall approach to immigration, Mr. Moran refuses to hire unauthorized immigrants, saying he believes such hiring practices leave those workers more vulnerable to wage abuse and poor treatment. (And, if caught, his firm could also face prosecution and large fines.) Mr. Moran, himself an immigrant from Spain, hopes that immigration reform will eventually happen under Mr. Trump. Until then, he said, \u201cit could be painful\u201d for thousands of people to uproot their lives.\n\nIt will not be easy on employers, either. Assisted living facilities that rely on skilled nurses to care for older and sick people already struggle to attract applicants to jobs that are both physically and emotionally taxing, said Christopher Donnellan, the director of government relations for the American Healthcare Association, an assisted living facility trade group.\n\nHis affiliates were already shaken once, in November, when the Trump administration announced it would rescind protected status for Haitians, who make up a majority of the staff in some facilities in the Boston area. Salvadorans with protected status make up an even larger proportion of the members\u2019 work force, he said.\n\nBefore the November decision, the Walt Disney Company announced that it, too, supported an extension: It said Disney World employed more than 500 protected Haitians.\n\nSeventeen years ago, Hugo Rodriguez, 43, started as a dishwasher at the Great Neck, N.Y., an outpost of the fabled Peter Luger Steak House. Now he is a cook. Several of his co-workers also have temporary protections, he said.\n\nReceiving his permit \u201cwas the beginning of the American dream,\u201d he recalled.\n\nNow, he fears losing it will be the end.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t stay illegally, I can\u2019t do it,\u201d Mr. Rodriguez said. \u201cBut that means to go back and start at the bottom.\u201d", "title": "From Offices to Disney World, Employers Brace for the Loss of an Immigrant Work Force", "authors": ["Vivian Yee", "Liz Robbins", "Caitlin Dickerson"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "JORDAN, Ontario \u2014 Though his wines are found in many natural wine bars around the world, please do not call Fran\u00e7ois Morissette a natural winemaker. And though Pearl Morissette, his estate near this small town on the Niagara Peninsula, produces wines that are luminous and inspiring, it\u2019s better not to call him a winemaker at all.\n\nHe prefers the term vigneron, a French word without English equivalent, referring to a person who guides the grapes along their journey from vine to bottle. Indeed, shepherding is how Mr. Morissette sees his job, not so much manufacturing wine as helping the grapes realize their destiny.\n\nSometimes a wine never gets there. A 2009 chardonnay, one of Pearl Morissette\u2019s early vintages, is still resting in the winery, unsold. Mr. Morissette judged the wine to be too tight and unyielding, and did not want to release it.\n\n\u201cIt was telling us to go away,\u201d he said. \u201cOnly recently has it become inviting.\u201d\n\nMore often, though, the wines are captivating. The lineup includes savory, textured chardonnays; cabernet francs of uncommon depth and purity; fresh, joyous gamays and pinot noirs that can vary from a pretty, floral 2011 that is delicious right now to a spicy, smoky 2012 that manages to be both brawny and elegant. Like the \u201909 chardonnay, it has not yet been released.", "title": "From Ontario, Cool-Climate Wines of Beauty and Vision", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cIn Baltimore, Anguish Over a Record-Breaking Homicide Rate\u201d (news article, Jan. 17) confirms that real change will come only by addressing the systemic failings that perpetuate the conditions that give rise to violence: neglect of our youth, lack of basic needs, drug dependence, and lack of job and economic opportunity. Hopelessness.\n\nOur Call to Action meetings and Violence Reduction Initiative, which convenes daily at police headquarters, have ushered in a new era of collaboration among community organizers, city agencies and police officers. Together, we are targeting problem situations in real time, de-escalating tensions and frustrations that inevitably lead to violence.\n\nThe Justice Department consent decree, resulting from Freddie Gray\u2019s death and the turbulent aftermath, is proving a catalyst in changing mentalities, approaches and ultimately the culture of our Police Department.\n\nBecause I believe that we have an obligation to smooth the path of our young people and enable their grasp of the skills and resources they need to succeed, I made Baltimore City Community College tuition-free for all Baltimore City high school graduates beginning this year.", "title": "Opinion | From the Mayor of Baltimore: \u2018Fail No More\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Wolff turns to the same device, only from the voice of the opposing camp, in recounting Trump\u2019s fateful decision to fire the F.B.I. director James Comey. \u201cIt was Jared, in the version told by those outside the Jarvanka circle, that pushed for action,\u201d he writes. (\u201cJarvanka\u201d is Wolff\u2019s shorthand, borrowed from Bannon, for Jared and Ivanka.) Wolff\u2019s caution may be explained in his acknowledgments, where he gives a glowing tribute to his trusted libel lawyer. It is that sort of book.\n\nWolff is unsparing in his portrayal of Trump as an aberrant chief executive, not only detached from governance but barely literate. He summons withering on-the-record assessments from ostensible allies of a seemingly infantile president. \u201cIf they tell him the whales need to be saved, he\u2019s basically for it,\u201d says Katie Walsh, a former White House deputy chief of staff, recalling how easily the Kushners could sway Trump. Yet much of Wolff\u2019s sourcing is opaque. \u201cI\u2019ve made stuff up forever, and they always print it,\u201d Trump boasts about his long-running media con. But Wolff, with seemingly unintended irony, does not make clear where he harvested such an explosive line.\n\nWolff is also slippery about whether he was present for some of the conversations he relays or is merely offering a version of events from those who were. He opens the book, for example, with an engrossing dinner conversation that included Bannon and Roger Ailes, the former Fox News president, shortly before the inauguration, offering sentence after sentence of verbatim quotations. Wolff writes that the dinner was held \u201cin a Greenwich Village townhouse,\u201d but leaves out that it was his home and he was the evening\u2019s host.\n\nPhoto\n\nWolff is a media writer by trade and, like his protagonist, he repeatedly scorns the mainline press for what he suggests is its liberal bias. He singles out this paper for treating the Trump presidency as anomalous. Yet putting aside the irony that his own depiction sketches out a shockingly aberrant White House, Wolff shows that his media-bashing is not on the level when he switches from the Ailes hymnal to a more conventional liberal perspective. In a jab at the media, he calls Richard Spencer, the racist alt-right activist, \u201ccatnip for the liberal press,\u201d but then effectively makes the liberals\u2019 case by giving Spencer an open mic to proclaim \u201cwe are the Trump vanguard.\u201d And Wolff casually refers to a \u201cvirulent, if not anti-Semitic (at least toward liberal Jews), right-wing West Wing.\u201d\n\nWolff is strongest when he\u2019s writing on what he knows best: the insecurities and ambitions of Trump and other media fixtures. Yet while much of this presidency does revolve around news coverage, it is still a presidency. And Wolff is far weaker when it comes to politics.\n\nThe collapse of the Affordable Care Act repeal in the Senate is dealt with in less than a single sentence, with no mention of Senator John McCain\u2019s opposition or Trump\u2019s 11th-hour telephone call to him that preceded it. Vice President Mike Pence is largely airbrushed out of the book, which is puzzling given how influential he was in tapping cabinet officials and staff. Similarly, few would see Andrew Card or Erskine Bowles as \u201clarger-than-life\u201d presidential chiefs of staff; the conservative United Nations ambassador Nikki R. Haley is hardly a \u201cJarvanka Republican\u201d; and at a September campaign rally in Alabama for Senator Luther Strange, Trump did not abandon Strange \u201cfor the rest of the speech\u201d after criticizing N.F.L. players for kneeling at the national anthem.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen there is the sloppiness: The former representative Dick Armey was never House speaker, the Washington lobbyist Hilary Rosen spells her first name with only one \u201cl\u201d and it is Mike Berman, Walter F. Mondale\u2019s former counsel, who breakfasts at the Four Seasons, not the Washington Post reporter Mark Berman.\n\nThe writing is often vivid but Wolff, who tries to hold to a chronological narrative, can be as repetitive as Trump, returning again and again to preferred words or phrases (joie de guerre is a favorite). What ultimately salvages the book are those moments when he all but makes Bannon his co-author, letting Bannon describe West Wing showdowns with his moderate nemesis, Jarvanka, in ways that render this the de facto first insider account of the Trump White House.
