Of course, the recollections are just those of a single aide, and may include what Trump himself once called examples of \u201ctruthful hyperbole.\u201d\n\nIn the newspaper business, such stories would be deemed \u201ctoo good to check.\u201d But given the popularity of \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d Wolff might call them something else: liberal catnip.", "title": "From \u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 to Political Firestorm", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin", "Michael Wolff"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Adding to the partisan strain, Democrats are incensed over a move by House Republicans to make public a classified memorandum critical of the F.B.I. that Democrats say is intended to undermine the ongoing special counsel\u2019s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.\n\nAnd Democrats said they were very disturbed by the lack of pushback from Republicans over the White House decision not to impose new sanctions against Russia despite Congress last year overwhelmingly approving the punishment with the support of all but a few members of the House and Senate.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhy is the president ignoring the sanctions?\u201d asked an exasperated Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, a veteran of three decades in Congress. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen it like this.\u201d\n\nRepublicans, in praising the president for bold leadership, say Democrats bear some responsibility for finding bipartisan solutions and need to get past their animosity for Mr. Trump if they want a deal on immigration.\n\n\u201cIf Democrats refuse to negotiate now after what President Trump put on the table, perhaps they should \u2018migrate\u2019 out of Congress,\u201d said Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas.\n\nThe ongoing hostility is not without consequences. Government funding runs out again on Feb. 8 and delicate negotiations are continuing in an effort to reach an immigration deal by early March at the latest. The parties need to have some level of trust and willingness to work together to resolve these difficult issues, since both spending and immigration measures will require votes from both sides of the aisle to become law.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo that end, Mr. Trump said in his speech that he was \u201cextending an open hand to work with members of both parties.\u201d He urged lawmakers \u201cto seek out common ground, and to summon the unity we need to deliver for the people we were elected to serve.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut to many Democrats, that appeal rang hollow given the past year that saw the Republican effort to unravel the Affordable Care Act and Mr. Trump\u2019s tendency to back away from tentative compromise agreements with Democratic leaders after objections from Republicans.\n\n\u201cI wish he was truly the bipartisan uniter, not the divider-in-chief who came into the chamber,\u201d said Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut.\n\nCurrent disputes over spending and immigration have persisted for months. Despite fundamental differences, the efforts to resolve them have been inching forward. But the decision by Speaker Paul D. Ryan to back the release of the report on the F.B.I. and the quiet acceptance by Republicans of administration assurances that added sanctions are not needed have Democrats newly alarmed. They profess deep concern about threats to government institutions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt is amazing to me the lengths that some of the Republicans, particularly in the House, will go to protect the president when they are doing real harm to our democracy, our rule of law,\u201d said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, in an interview. \u201cThis is not just a political battle. It goes to the wellspring of our democracy.\u201d\n\nMr. Schumer faulted House and Senate Republican leaders for not intervening.\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader, sought to distance Senate Republicans from the F.B.I. report prepared by Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee, noting that the Senate intelligence inquiry was on a different track. And he deferred to Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who chairs the Foreign Relations Committee, on the sanctions issue.\n\nMr. Corker \u201cseemed to feel that, under the circumstances, the administration did the right thing,\u201d Mr. McConnell said.\n\nBut as Republicans left Washington on Wednesday for a party retreat to plan strategy for what is looming as a combative midterm election year, the disputes over the Russia sanctions and the House intelligence report are emerging as new partisan flash points.\n\nNo one on Capitol Hill expected Mr. Trump\u2019s first stab at the State of the Union to end the turmoil and conflict that has characterized his first year in office. But lawmakers left the speech seemingly farther apart than when they entered. And the rancor is rising just as Congress is again short on time to find ways to agree.", "title": "From \u2018New American Moment\u2019 to Same Partisan Rancor", "authors": ["Carl Hulse", "On Washington"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The free festival, now in its sixth year, includes a program for children (with free comics); a screening of \u201cWhite Scripts and Black Supermen\u201d; and panel discussions about social justice and representation in comics, the influence of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and black geekdom in the age of social media. Writers and artists include Sheena C. Howard, the author of \u201cEncyclopedia of Black Comics,\u201d and Dawud Anyabwile, a creator of the \u201cBrotherman\u201d series. They will join Mr. Heredia, whose love for comics led to his career in animation. He recently discussed \u201cHeroes of Color\u201d during a recent phone interview. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.\n\nWhat are you looking forward to at the festival?\n\nMy main objective is to encourage students to tell their stories. Every single one of them has met someone or has someone in their life right now who can be considered a hero for whatever obstacles they have overcome. The best writing advice is to tell the story you want to hear first. Don\u2019t worry about telling a story you think people want to hear. It won\u2019t come out as powerful.\n\nHow did \u201cHeroes of Color\u201d come about?\n\nI came up with the idea in 2015. By that time, I had my own small company, Heredia Designs. I was doing animation for Pearson, the educational company. I was creating two-minute shorts, which were covering the Common Core standards of math and English. They had hired me to do 300 short animated videos. I remember the final four characters of the videos were one Asian, one black, one Latino and one white kid. It cemented the importance of representation and planted a seed for what I wanted to see.\n\nWhat has been the response?\n\nI did an episode on the Harlem Hellfighters, an all-black military unit that fought in World War I. The episode won six awards at film festivals. I got a lot of positive feedback, but I also got a lot of negative feedback like, \u201cThese guys were bums. They were losers. Why are you focusing on them?\u201d I was just trying to highlight and ignite pride in the black community.", "title": "Front and Center: Celebrating Black Comics and Their Creators", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "MEDELL\u00cdN, Colombia \u2014 \u00d3scar P\u00e9rez, a helicopter pilot and former police officer who led an armed rebel band against the isolated and embattled government of Venezuela, was killed in a shootout with security forces, Venezuelan authorities announced on Tuesday, bringing an end to a dramatic event that unfolded a day earlier in videos on social media.\n\nMr. P\u00e9rez, 36, rose to prominence last year as a dissident police officer during street protests against President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro. In June, he and a small group commandeered a helicopter in the capital, Caracas, and used it to drop grenades onto the Supreme Court building and fire on the Interior Ministry in a brazen midday attack.\n\nMr. P\u00e9rez then unfurled a banner calling on Venezuelans to rebel against Mr. Maduro, to the cheers of protesters below. He later released a video in which he and a band of masked men repeated their calls for a rebellion. While no one was injured in that attack, it was an embarrassment for the government, and officials vowed to capture him.\n\nHe had been a fugitive \u2014 and an online nuisance to the government \u2014 ever since, posting videos urging Venezuelans to resist what he called Mr. Maduro\u2019s tyrannical government.", "title": "Fugitive Venezuelan Police Officer Is Killed in Shootout", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "It was unclear if Mr. Fujimori\u2019s remarks were a hint that he planned to play a more active role in Peruvian politics. But the message rippled across Peru, where Mr. Fujimori is a deeply divisive figure.\n\nThough respected by some, he has been vilified for leading an administration that led a violent crackdown in the 1990s on the Maoist Shining Path insurgency, which had all but brought normal life in Peru to a standstill with bombings and killings.\n\nIn 2009, Mr. Fujimori was sentenced for his role in two massacres that killed dozens of Peruvians in its effort to quash the Shining Path.\n\nPeru, a country with an authoritarian past, returned to democracy only 17 years ago. And critics denounced Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s pardon as a blow to the fight against impunity and efforts to heal national wounds after Mr. Fujimori\u2019s presidency.\n\nThe Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa and 238 other writers signed an open letter saying the decision covered the nation \u201cin infamy and shame.\u201d The letter said the pardon was not an act of compassion, as the government insisted, but \u201cthe most crude and cynical political calculus.\u201d\n\nBut Prime Minister Mercedes Ar\u00e1oz wrote an op-ed article published in the Lima daily El Comercio on Sunday defending Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s decision to pardon Mr. Fujimori.\n\n\u201cDear countrymen,\u201d she wrote, \u201cthis pardon does not in any way mean impunity or oblivion; this is about starting to heal our wounds as a country.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kuczynski, 79, a former Wall Street banker who took office in July 2016, has been hanging on to power, having narrowly survived a motion in Congress last month to impeach him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe had been accused of lying during an inquiry about possible ties to the Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht, which was engulfed in a graft scandal. It was later revealed that a financial services company Mr. Kuczynski owned had received $782,000 from Odebrecht, a disclosure that set off the impeachment effort.\n\nMany had expected the vote to result in his removal, with the chamber dominated by the opposition Popular Force, a right-wing party founded by Mr. Fujimori\u2019s daughter, Keiko, who supported the effort to impeach Mr. Kuczynski.\n\nBut at the last minute, a faction of the Popular Force led by Mr. Fujimori\u2019s younger son, Kenji, challenged his sister and swung the vote in Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s favor.\n\nSome lawmakers said that Mr. Fujimori had asked them to follow his son\u2019s lead, and the pardon was widely seen as a quid pro quo with Mr. Kuczynski, charges the administration has denied.\n\nIn signs of a split in Popular Force, Kenji Fujimori has accused his sister of \u201cconspiring\u201d to keep his father imprisoned. He has asked that his father be named an aide to the family-run party.\n\n\u201cOn the one hand, there\u2019s Keiko and her bloc that directly opposes the government,\u201d said Gilbert Violeta, a congressman who is president of Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s party, Peruvians for Change. \u201cOn the other hand, there\u2019s Kenji and the bloc that supports Alberto Fujimori.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe will only know the real effects of that confrontation in the following days, when Congress is back in session,\u201d Mr. Violeta added.\n\nLawyers say there is no legal obstacle preventing Mr. Fujimori from seeking public office now that he has regained his freedom.\n\nBefore he was wheeled from the hospital, he asked for Peruvians\u2019 forgiveness \u201cwith all my heart\u201d in a Facebook video.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, he has spent his days inside a rented house in a quiet suburb of the Peruvian capital, Lima, where his doctors say he is recovering from a heart condition.", "title": "Fujimori Urges Peruvians to Set Aside \u2018Grudges\u2019 After His Release", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "All these brave women have power, and we will use our voices to make sure you get what you deserve, a life of suffering spent replaying the words delivered by this powerful army of survivors.\n\nI am also here to tell you to your face, Larry, that you have not taken gymnastics away from me. I love this sport, and that love is stronger than the evil that resides in you, in those who enabled you to hurt many people.\n\nYou already know you are going away to a place where you won\u2019t be able to hurt anybody ever again, but I am here to tell you that I will not rest until every last trace of your influence on this sport has been destroyed, like the cancer it is.\n\nYour abuse started 30 years ago, but that\u2019s just the first reported incident we know of. If over these many years, just one adult listened and had the courage and character to act, this tragedy could have been avoided. I and so many others would have never, ever met you.\n\nLarry, you should have been locked up a long, long time ago. The fact is, we have no idea how many people you victimized, or what was done, or not done, that allowed you to keep doing it, and to get away with it for so long.\n\nOver those 30 years when survivors came forward, adult after adult, many in positions of authority, protected you, telling each survivor it was O.K., that you weren\u2019t abusing them. In fact, many adults had you convince the survivors that they were being dramatic or had been mistaken. This is like being violated all over again.\n\nHow do you sleep at night? You were decorated by U.S.A. Gymnastics and the United States Olympic Committee, both of which put you on advisory boards and committees to come up with policies that would protect athletes from this kind of abuse. They had lived in the apartment building for about a year, Ms. Paul said.\n\n\u201cWe always try to stick together because kids are involved,\u201d said Ms. Paul, whose pregnant daughter lived on the third floor with her husband and 10-year-old son. \u201cIt works that way, like a community for each other.\u201d\n\nMany of the fire\u2019s victims were working-class immigrants, and relatives have been frustrated in their efforts to plan funerals because they are unfamiliar with the process and have little money to cover expenses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But his efforts have been stalled.\n\nEric Durr, a spokesman for the New York National Guard, said federal regulations prevented the military from taking on Private Mensah\u2019s funeral and burial costs because he was on a reserve soldier and did not die in the line of duty. The military requires soldiers to complete 24 months of active duty to be eligible for burial benefits.\n\nMr. Mensah\u2019s family can still choose to have military honors presented at his funeral, Mr. Durr said, and the military had assigned a casualty assistance officer to help the family navigate the process.\n\n\u201cI pleaded with them, but they said they cannot do it,\u201d Mr. Mensah said. \u201cThis is all new to me. Mr. Trump himself has pressed at least one Republican senator to open an investigation into Fusion\u2019s connections to Democrats, and the argument has found a receptive audience with some conservatives in Congress.\n\nMr. Grassley, the Senate Judiciary Committee chairman, has also raised concerns about Fusion\u2019s compliance with the Foreign Agents Registration Act, a tactic that Fusion\u2019s allies have dismissed as a sideshow to protect the president. Fusion has said it is not a lobbying firm and has followed all laws. In an editorial last week, Mr. Simpson and his co-founder at Fusion, Peter Fritsch, another Journal veteran, called on Congress to release the transcripts of the firm\u2019s testimony \u201cso that the American people can learn the truth about our work and most important, what happened to our democracy.\u201d\n\nYet Fusion\u2019s typical mandate, even defenders acknowledge, is not dripping with nobility.\n\nFew Washington industries traffic in sainthood. Many are mercenary in nature. And Fusion seems to be of a piece, hustling for its cut from an office in Dupont Circle.\n\nThe firm said it had \u201cworked for both Republicans and Democrats in a handful of elections.\u201d The Washington Post has reported that research targets included tech giants like Google and Amazon and both major-party presidential nominees in 2012, Mitt Romney and Mr. Obama.\n\nMr. Simpson also conducted work for Planned Parenthood as the group navigated the fallout from videos that appeared to suggest the organization was profiting from fetal tissue sales. Mr. Simpson found that the videos had been edited misleadingly. Conservatives have cited this project as evidence of bias toward liberal causes.\n\nAmid skepticism over the dossier, Fusion has trumpeted Mr. Steele\u2019s strong standing in the intelligence community, noting that the former spy is trained to screen out disinformation.\n\nStill, at a firm that casts itself as a collector of facts, the dossier is not the equivalent of a finished news article, in journalism parlance. It is more a compilation of prepublication notes, requiring further vetting.", "title": "Fusion GPS Founder Hauled From the Shadows for the Russia Election Investigation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Throughout the conference call on Wednesday, Mr. Flannery emphasized that despite its current challenges, G.E. had industrial businesses that were fundamentally strong. \u201cWe have a lot to work on,\u201d he said, \u201cbut we have a lot to work with.\u201d\n\nMuch of the turnaround, Mr. Flannery insisted, could be accomplished with belt-tightening and improved execution. And he pointed to what he described as a bright spot: that cash flow from industrial operations, although down, was above expectations. The cash flow, he said, was one of the \u201cgreen shoots\u201d beginning to emerge as G.E. tries to reverse its slide.\n\nOver all, G.E. reported a net loss of $9.8 billion for the last three months of the year. That included the big charge for insurance obligations and a separate $3.5 billion charge related to the tax law signed at the end of 2017. Many other companies have taken similar charges in connection with the tax overhaul.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe company\u2019s operating earnings per share fell 41 percent to 27 cents a share, or 2 cents below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue last year declined by 5 percent, to $31.4 billion, well below analysts\u2019 forecast of nearly $34 billion.\n\nSales in G.E.\u2019s power unit fell by 15 percent, to $9.4 billion in the quarter. Its operating profit of just $260 million was down 88 percent from nearly $2.2 billion in the same period a year ago. Last month, the company announced it would eliminate 12,000 jobs in that struggling business.\n\nStill, the company\u2019s aviation unit, a leading manufacturer of jet engines, and its health care business, which includes life sciences and medical-imaging equipment, delivered strong profits.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRevenue for the aviation division was flat at $7.2 billion, but the company reported that orders rose 11 percent in the quarter. The health care business saw sales grow by 6 percent to $5.4 billion.\n\nMr. Flannery, who took over in August, told investors last November that aviation, health care and power were G.E.\u2019s three core businesses. That equates to two thriving divisions and one in need of fixing, although with a strong franchise in the power-generation business. G.E.\u2019s lighting and railway locomotive divisions are already up for sale.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet last week, after the surprising setback because of insurance claims at GE Capital, Mr. Flannery suggested that even one of the three core businesses could be a candidate for a spinoff to generate returns for shareholders.\n\nThe company\u2019s share price has dropped by 44 percent over the past year, while the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index has climbed 25 percent. G.E. shares slipped 1 percent during trading on Wednesday morning, after the earnings report and the conference call.\n\nGiven the earlier surprises, G.E.\u2019s new leadership needs to show that it can stabilize the company and begin a turnaround, analysts say. The S.E.C. investigation only adds more uncertainty. After the setbacks in the past few months, class action shareholder suits have been filed.\n\n\u201cThese things are further risks that make G.E. difficult to value,\u201d said Steven Winoker, an analyst at UBS. \u201cThey have to right the ship.\u201d", "title": "G.E. Reports $9.8 Billion Loss and Discloses S.E.C. Accounting Inquiry", "authors": ["Steve Lohr"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The context: It\u2019s unlikely that G.E. will make an announcement in the spring that it will only fiddle around the edges, like more fully spinning off its Baker Hughes oil-field services unit. But it\u2019s also unlikely that Mr. Flannery will be the one to break up the 125-year-old conglomerate.\n\nIt\u2019s more likely that Mr. Flannery and his team will consider unique ways of separating G.E.\u2019s core business units without actually splitting them completely apart. But it\u2019s all somewhat speculative at the moment.\n\nCritic\u2019s corner, from Brook Sutherland of Gadfly:\n\nIt is now abundantly apparent that the previous management team led by Jeff Immelt had little handle on the comings and goings of all the pieces of this sprawling conglomerate. The reasons for keeping GE together \u2014 shared resources and technology \u2014 look increasingly tenuous. If you ask employees, they don\u2019t really see the benefit of having both a power and an aviation business, for example.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer and Michael J. de la Merced\n\nAttorneys general sue to block net neutrality repeal.\n\nThe attorneys general of 22 states filed a lawsuit to block the Federal Communications Commission\u2019s repeal of regulations that ensure an equal and open internet, reports the NYT\u2019s Cecilia Kang.\n\nThe attorneys general said the rollback of so-called net neutrality rules were \u201carbitrary and capricious\u201d and a reversal of a longstanding policy to prevent internet service providers from blocking or charging websites for faster delivery of content to consumers.\n\nThe petition to begin the lawsuit, filed in the United States District Court of Appeals in Washington, is the first legal challenge against the F.C.C.\u2019s order in December. Several others are expected, including by public interest groups such as Public Knowledge and Free Press, which argue that the F.C.C.\u2019s order was harmful to consumers and was done hastily and without proper public input.\n\nNestl\u00e9 gets its U.S. candy deal done\n\nThe business that makes Butterfingers and Gobstoppers will find a new home \u2014 at Ferrero, the producer of Rocher chocolate \u2014 for $2.8 billion in cash.\n\nThe numbers\n\n\u2022 The U.S. candy business, which doesn\u2019t include KitKats, generated $900 million in sales in 2016. (That\u2019s roughly 1 percent of Nestl\u00e9\u2019s overall revenue that year.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The deal is expected to close by March 31\n\nThe context: Nestl\u00e9 said last year that it would explore a sale of the business amid a waning appetite among Americans for candy. The move had been lauded by Dan Loeb\u2019s Third Point, which has put pressure on the food titan to sell off nonessential businesses.\n\nThe pullquote, from Mark Schneider, Nestl\u00e9\u2019s C.E.O.:\n\n\u201cWith Ferrero we have found an exceptional home for our U.S. confectionery business where it will thrive. At the same time, this move allows Nestl\u00e9 to invest and innovate across a range of categories where we see strong future growth and hold leadership positions, such as pet care, bottled water, coffee, frozen meals and infant nutrition.\u201d\n\nThe advisers\n\nFor Ferrero: Credit Suisse, Lazard and the law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind Elliott\u2019s campaign at Bezeq\n\nOne of Elliott\u2019s first campaigns of 2018 sees the activist hedge fund going even further abroad: Its latest target is Bezeq, the once-government-owned Israeli telecom company. The phone service provider is up 5 percent as of this morning on the news of Elliott\u2019s investment and public letter to the telecom\u2019s interim chairman, David Granot.\n\nThe context\n\nBezeq has been under pressure on multiple fronts:\n\n\u2022 The company has been under pressure from regulators amid an investigation into potential securities violations, including an inquiry into the mogul Shaul Elovitch, who owns 26 percent of the company.\n\n\u2022 The company\u2019s ownership structure is complicated. Technically, Mr. Elovitch controls Eurocom, which in turn controls Internet Gold, which in tern controls BCom, which in turn controls Bezeq. (Got that?) But Mr. Elovitch has been grappling with debt at Eurocom and is in talks to sell control of that vehicle to another businessman, Naty Saidoff.\n\nWhat Elliott wants\n\n\u2022 Replacing all directors under scrutiny by Israeli securities regulators, in consultation with shareholders\n\n\u2022 Simplifying the ownership structure of the company\n\nFrom the hedge fund\u2019s letter to Mr. Granot:\n\nAs you well know, Bezeq faces compelling business opportunities and significant challenges. The time that passes without stable, impartial ownership and governance is to the detriment of all stakeholders.\n\nWhat could lie ahead\n\nBeyond the public pressure that the letter by Paul Singer\u2019s hedge fund will bring, Elliott could also call a special meeting of shareholders to vote on matters like choosing new directors, if it can muster up the support of at least 5 percent of shares. (Elliott said that it currently owns a 4.8 percent economic interest in the company. )\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nThe most interesting number from Silver Lake\u2019s deal for Blackhawk Network\n\n\u2022 It isn\u2019t necessarily the $3.5 billion purchase price that Silver Lake and P2 Capital Partners agreed to pay for the operator of gift card stores.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 It isn\u2019t necessarily the 24 percent premium over Blackhawk\u2019s Friday closing price that the $45.25-per-share bid represents.\n\n\u2022 It isn\u2019t even necessarily the nine advisers listed in the press release. (More on that below.)\n\n\u2022 It\u2019s the $1.7 billion equity check that Silver Lake is writing to support the deal. That\u2019s one of the biggest-ever equity commitments that the $39 billion investment firm has ever made.\n\nThe backstory\n\nDan Primack has more on the five-year saga over at Axios.\n\nThe advisers\n\nFor Blackhawk: Sandler O\u2019Neill & Partners, Citigroup and the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz\n\nFor Silver Lake: Barclays, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and the law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett\n\nFor P2 Capital: The law firm Debevoise & Plimpton\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nQualcomm\u2019s day of fighting M.&A. battles on two fronts\n\nThe first\n\nQualcomm unveiled its first official \u201cfight letter\u201d in its campaign to beat back Broadcom\u2019s $105 billion bid for the chip maker.\n\nAmong the highlights of the letter:\n\n\u2022 Qualcomm says that it will deliver between $6.75 and $7.50 in pro forma earnings per share for its 2019 fiscal year.\n\n\u2022 A pledge to continue the company\u2019s its cost-savings program.\n\n\u2022 A reiteration that Broadcom\u2019s offer ignores the upswing that the emerging 5G wireless standard will bring for Qualcomm\u2019s stock.\n\nFrom the letter:\n\nBroadcom is asking Qualcomm stockholders to voluntarily transfer to a hostile acquirer the considerable near- and long-term value creation Qualcomm has in front of it. It is attempting to acquire Qualcomm at an opportunistic, inferior price by installing a slate of conflicted Broadcom/Silver Lake nominees with minimal relevant experience.\n\nThe second\n\nRamius, a money manager that owns stakes in both Qualcomm and NXP Semiconductors, said that it plans to reject Qualcomm\u2019s $110-a-share bid for the smaller chip maker. The firm wants a deal done \u2014 but at a higher price.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat follows the declaration of Elliott that NXP was worth $135 a share on a standalone basis.\n\nFrom Ramius\u2019s news release:\n\nShould Qualcomm fail to complete its acquisition of NXP, Ramius believes that Qualcomm shareholders will seriously question the ability of Qualcomm to execute its strategy as an independent entity.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nCiti takes a big tax charge\n\nCitigroup said that it earned $3.7 billion in its fourth quarter \u2014 if one excludes a $22 billion charge related to the tax overhaul.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at its results by the numbers:\n\n\u2022 $18.3 billion, or $7.15 per share. Citi\u2019s loss in the fourth quarter, including the tax charge. It is the bank\u2019s largest quarterly loss. The new tax law is causing large banks to report big one-time charges to their fourth-quarter results, but the legislation should benefit the banks over time.\n\n\u2022 $1.28. Its earnings per share excluding the tax hit. That beat the $1.19 expected by Wall Street analysts, according to Thomson Reuters and topped the $1.14 per share earned a year ago.\n\n\u2022 $17.26 billion. Citi\u2019s revenue for the quarter, which exceeded the $17.01 it generated a year ago.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 $19 billion. The amount of the $22 billion tax charge that came from writing down deferred-tax assets, which companies use to offset future tax bills.\n\n\u2022 $3 billion. The amount of the tax hit that came from a one-time charge on overseas earnings because of the new tax law.\n\n\u2022 $2.9 billion. The amount Citi generated in trading revenue, down 19 percent. JPMorgan reported a 17 percent drop on Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nGoldman\u2019s bad commodity trading performance\n\nGoldman\u2019s commodity trading revenue fell 75 percent last year, its worst annual performance, Bloomberg reports, citing people familiar with the matter.\n\nGoldman\u2019s commodities unit has been under scrutiny both within the bank and among investors since it revealed its second-quarter performance was the worst in its post-IPO history. That triggered an informal review of the unit and several high-profile departures, including global commodities head Gregory Agran. The bank\u2019s commodities earnings in the final three months of 2017 were better than the previous two quarters as losing natural gas trades were closed. Nonetheless, performance at the unit remained lackluster as it cut back risk-taking.\n\nGoldman reports earnings tomorrow before the bell.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nAnother millennial marker bites the dust\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average is trading above 26,000 for the first time.\n\nIt took just seven days for the blue-chip index to go from 25,000 to 26,000. If it closes above that level, it will mark the quickest move from one millennial marker to the next.\n\nThe previous record was set on Jan. 4 when the Dow finished above 25,000 just 23 trading sessions after surpassing 24,000.\n\nOf course, 1,000 point moves aren\u2019t what they used to be. Going from 25,000 to 26,000 is a move of just 4 percent. By comparison, when the index went from 10,000 to 11,000 in 24 days in 1999, it was a rise of 10 percent, points out the WSJ\u2019s Erik Holm.\n\nAnd it\u2019s not just the Dow that is surging this month. The more widely followed Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index crossed 2,800 this morning and is up more than 4 percent this month. That puts it on pace for its best monthly performance since March 2016, when it was rebounding from the steep sell-off during the first six weeks of that year.\n\nIn fact, the S.&P. 500 hasn\u2019t experienced a monthly decline since March of last year.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nGreenlight Capital\u2019s David Einhorn is betting on Twitter\n\nIn a letter to investors, the hedge fund manager wrote that his firm had bought shares of Twitter in the fourth-quarter at an average price of $21.59.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVia ValueWalk:\n\nDespite a massive user base and broad reach, TWTR has an enterprise value of about 2% of Facebook, the largest social media platform. New management improved the TWTR user experience, which led to rapid growth in number of users and time spent on TWTR in 2017. As a result, we believe TWTR will have a pitch to advertisers in 2018, which should lead to revenue growth. Restructuring actions taken over the past year will allow much of the revenue to fall to the bottom line, and we expect TWTR to begin to close some of the 25% margin gap vs. its social media peers. TWTR shares ended the year at $24.01.\n\nShares of Twitter are down about 1 percent to $25.13.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nBlackRock wants C.E.O.s to show they do good\n\nWhat\u2019s happening: Larry Fink of BlackRock is sending a letter to C.E.O.s of public companies today saying that they must show how they contribute to society, or risk losing the money-management firm\u2019s support.\n\nMore from the letter:\n\nThe public expectations of your company have never been greater. Society is demanding that companies, both public and private, serve a social purpose. To prosper over time, every company must not only deliver financial performance, but also show how it makes a positive contribution to society. Companies must benefit all of their stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customers, and the communities in which they operate. Without a sense of purpose, no company, either public or private, can achieve its full potential. It will ultimately lose the license to operate from key stakeholders.\n\nThe leverage: BlackRock has $6 trillion under management, making it the biggest investor in public companies in the world.\n\nThe context, from Andrew\u2019s latest DealBook column: Mr. Fink\u2019s letter pits the investment mogul \u201cagainst many of the companies that he\u2019s invested in, which hold the view that their only duty is to produce profits for their shareholders, an argument long espoused by economists like Milton Friedman.\u201d\n\nThe assessment: Jeff Sonnenfeld of the Yale School of Management told Andrew, \u201cIt is huge for an institutional investor to take this position across its portfolio.\u201d Mr. Sonnenfeld added that he\u2019s seen \u201cnothing like it.\u201d\n\nMore in corporate social activism\n\n\u2022 Citi said it would measure, publish and address gaps in the pay between male and female employees in the U.S., Britain and Germany, after pressure from an investor. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind Raine\u2019s backing of the \u2018Planet of the Apps\u2019 team\n\nRaine \u2014 the merchant bank that invested early in Vice and counts Masa Son and Steve Ballmer as clients \u2014 has invested in Propagate Content, the studio that produced the first original series for Apple and Twitter. (Propagate\u2019s co-founders are Ben Silverman, once co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, and Howard T. Owens, who was president of National Geographic Channels.)\n\nThe thesis: That content is more important than ever in an era of online streaming. Raine\u2019s betting that Propagate, which is also turning popular podcasts like \u201cLore\u201d into streaming series and working on content for Netflix and CBS, can produce hits from a variety of sources and replicate them around the world.\n\nThe pullquote, from Raine co-founder Joe Ravitch:\n\n\u201cThese guys think global from the very beginning, and the formats and shows that Ben and Howard have developed are some of the best examples of customizing content to different markets and cultures.\u201d\n\nIn other media deals:\n\n\u2022 Saudi Arabia\u2019s Public Investment Fund is in talks to invest more than $500 million in Endeavor, the parent company of WME, as part of its push to diversify the kingdom\u2019s economy, according to unidentified sources. (TheWrap, Bloomberg)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Graydon Carter\u2019s first project after Vanity Fair is an investment in Zig, a start-up described as Instagram for news.\n\nFred Wilson urges start-ups to reconsider equity compensation\n\nFrom the venture capitalist\u2019s blog post from this weekend, which has been making the rounds in Silicon Valley:\n\nA few years ago I met with a very successful entrepreneur who built his company outside of the tech sector. When I asked him about equity compensation he said to me \u201cYou people in tech are crazy. I pay my employees handsomely in cash and I keep all of the equity for myself.\u201d\n\nMr. Wilson\u2019s bottom line: Stock awards have a real cost \u2014 annual dilution of companies\u2019 equity can be as high as 5 percent a year.\n\nHe adds:\n\nWe should be confronting the true cost of this practice and asking ourselves if it is best for our employees, and if so, which ones, and if it is best for our companies and our shareholders.\n\nThe tech and telecom flyaround\n\n\u2022 By potentially spinning out its Japanese cellphone business, SoftBank could raise as much as $18 billion for deals. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Kuaishou, a video site backed by Tencent, is seeking a valuation of about $17 billion in its new round of financing. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nIf Fiat Chrysler won\u2019t split, what lies ahead?\n\nSergio Marchionne, the automaker\u2019s outspoken C.E.O., made it clear that the company won\u2019t sell its Jeep or Ram divisions or otherwise break itself up. But if that idea is \u201cthree years ago,\u201d as he said at the Detroit Auto Show, what is his plan to compete with rivals who are diving headlong into autonomous vehicles?\n\nFrom his interview with Bloomberg:\n\n\u201cWe talk to everybody, and we are continuously learning and making selections on the basis of the best available technology.\u201d\n\nMr. Marchionne also confirmed that this will be his last year leading Fiat Chrysler, with a successor to be named in March.\n\nThe Detroit Auto Show flyaround\n\n\u2022 Automakers are celebrating their best ever three-year stretch, but they could be headed for choppier waters. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 BlackBerry continued its push into the auto industry with a product to help carmakers detect software security flaws. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nA sign of the times, Bitcoin edition\n\nThat\u2019s an actual question posed in a private forum that was sent to us by a reader this weekend.\n\nYour daily reminder of virtual currency prices, courtesy of CoinMarketCap:\n\n\u2022 Bitcoin is at $12,288, down 11 percent over the past day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Ethereum is at $1,137, down nearly 15 percent.\n\n\u2022 Ripple is at $1.45, down 22 percent.\n\nAnd your daily dose of virtual currency skepticism, courtesy of Bloomberg:\n\nInvestors \u201cshould be prepared to lose all their money\u201d in Bitcoin, said Steven Maijoor, chairman of the European Securities and Markets Authority, in a Bloomberg TV interview in Hong Kong.\n\nThe digital money flyaround\n\n\u2022 The head of Singapore\u2019s central bank said he hoped the technology underpinning Bitcoin and other digital currencies would outlast the current \u201cfever.\u201d (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Nine hedge funds who had bet on Bitcoin made a 1,167 percent return last year \u2014 less than the virtual currency\u2019s return but far more than the 8 percent that the hedge fund industry as a whole generated. Weighs Changes, but Investors Hear \u2018Breakup\u2019: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn April 4, 1967, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took the pulpit at Riverside Church in Manhattan and made his strongest denunciation yet of the Vietnam War; a year later to the day he was assassinated in Memphis. King does not appear in David Loeb Weiss\u2019s \u201cNo Vietnamese Ever Called Me Nigger\u201d but this searing 1968 documentary feature is informed by both events.\n\nRestored by Anthology Film Archives and the Smithsonian\u2019s National Museum of African American History and Culture, \u201cNo Vietnamese\u201d is a historical document with contemporary relevance. This weekend it will be shown twice at Anthology in a terrific 16-millimeter print.\n\nThe film alternates between footage taken on April 15, 1967, at the Spring Mobilization to End the War in Vietnam march in New York, which King addressed, and interviews with three Vietnam veterans, filmed less than a month after King\u2019s death. \u201cI\u2019m a man without a country,\u201d one of the interviewees quotes a fellow G.I. as saying, having been radicalized by his war experience.\n\nAccording to its organizers, the New York mobilization attracted 400,000 marchers. (The police and The New York Times estimated between 100,000 and 125,000.) Weiss and his crew followed the 1,500-strong Harlem contingent, led by the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee chairman, Stokely Carmichael, with whom King had to be persuaded to share a platform. Carmichael\u2019s black power position is clear when his followers refuse to let a white Harlem resident join the march.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe filmmakers stand in for the white power structure, eliciting all manner of frank comments from marchers and onlookers: \u201cWhy should we fight for you? You got it all.\u201d Intermittently, the three G.I.s give detailed testimony regarding the Army\u2019s pervasive inequality. One who studied to be an air traffic controller at a Southern base was banned from his squad\u2019s graduation party; once in Vietnam he was assigned to be a driver, but when he complained he was sent into the field. All three men \u2014 Dalton James, Preston Lay Jr. and Akmed Lorence \u2014 were radicalized, expressing alienation from the Army and identification with the Vietnamese.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe movie is alive with incidents. Several youthful observers of the march, followers of Elijah Muhammad, leader of the Nation of Islam, disdainfully tell the filmmakers that, as Muslims, they don\u2019t need to demonstrate (\u201cWe respect the government\u201d) while, several blocks along, in front of a tavern, people enjoy a spring afternoon ragging on the war as the Supremes blast out of the jukebox. Hoberman"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Negotiations over the future of Nafta have been tense. The next round is to begin next Tuesday in Montreal.\n\nAt the investor conference, sponsored by Deutsche Bank, G.M. said it expected 2017 earnings to come in at the high end of its forecast of $6 to $6.50 a share, and it projected its 2018 earnings at roughly the same level. The company, which earned $6.12 per share in 2016, predicted \u201cfurther acceleration\u201d in 2019.\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, the company\u2019s chief financial officer, Chuck Stevens, acknowledged \u201cheadwinds\u201d in the form of pricing pressure in the American and Chinese markets and high costs related to the introduction of a new generation of full-size pickups. Over all, new-vehicle sales in the United States are also expected to decline modestly this year.\n\nMr. Stevens also said that G.M. would take a $7 billion noncash charge against earnings in the fourth quarter of 2017. That reflects the decline in value of certain tax credits the company has on its balance sheet \u2014 a result of the recently enacted tax law, which lowered corporate rates.\n\nG.M. is also losing money or making very little on the cars it sells. With American consumers flocking to roomier models like trucks and S.U.V.s, sales of cars like the Chevrolet Malibu and Impala have plunged. G.M. slashed production at many of its car plants last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address.
