View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile struggling to keep its car lines profitable, G.M. is generating a substantial profit on truck sales and making more S.U.V.s and trucks to take advantage of the trend. The 2019 Chevy Silverado, showcased this week at the Detroit show, will be available in eight variations, said Dan Ammann, the automaker\u2019s president. G.M. also plans to introduce new medium-duty pickup trucks, a lucrative business it exited several years ago.\n\n\u201cWe see a ton more opportunity\u201d in trucks, Mr. Ammann said.\n\nFord and Fiat Chrysler are following the same strategy. Ford has unveiled a new midsize truck, resurrecting the Ranger name, at the Detroit show. Fiat Chrysler is adding a new Ram 1500 truck and expanding its line of Jeeps.\n\nAt the same conference, Ford Motor offer a less upbeat outlook. The company said preliminary results showed it earned $1.95 per share in 2017, up from $1.15 the year before. But for 2018, company officials said its adjusted earnings would fall to $1.45 to $1.70 per share, compared with an adjusted 2017 figure of $1.78.\n\nFord\u2019s chief financial officer, Robert L. Shanks, blamed rising commodity prices and unfavorable exchange rates as well as higher spending on self-driving vehicles and lower industry sales in the United States. \u201cWe are not satisfied with our performance,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFord said it was not taking any charges stemming from the tax legislation.\n\nFord has kicked off a cost-cutting drive under Jim Hackett, who was tapped last year to be chief executive to reinvigorate the company. As part of its new direction, Ford is spending billions in an effort to introduce 40 electrified vehicles by 2022, including 16 fully electric models. It also hopes to begin producing a driverless car for taxi fleets, rider services and delivery companies by 2021.", "title": "G.M. Chief Cautions Trump Administration on Upending Nafta", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "G.M.\u2019s petition calls for producing up to 2,500 Cruise AVs for use in commercial ride fleets.\n\n\u201cMass production and government regulation appear to be within General Motors\u2019 grasp,\u201d said Karl Brauer, a senior analyst at Kelley Blue Book, an automotive data firm. \u201cIf government approval is granted, and G.M. begins providing autonomous taxi service to end users in multiple markets, we\u2019ll officially be living in a world of self-driving cars.\u201d\n\nApproval from the Transportation Department is expected to take several months, and then G.M. would need local clearance before it could provide rides in Cruise AVs to the public. Mr. Ammann said it was not clear how the department\u2019s main auto-safety regulator, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, would evaluate G.M.\u2019s petition, and whether the agency would test the vehicles itself.\n\nThe safety agency said Friday that it would give G.M.\u2019s petition \u201ccareful consideration.\u201d\n\nLocal approval will depend on each state\u2019s regulations, Mr. Ammann said. Michigan, for example, already allows cars with no steering wheels to operate on public roads. Other states would need to decide how to treat driverless cars.\n\nIndustry analysts say automakers and technology companies could generate billions of dollars in revenue and profit by selling or leasing self-driving cars to ride services, taxi fleets and delivery companies. Ford said this week that it would work with Domino\u2019s Pizza and a start-up delivery company, Postmates, to use its autonomous prototypes in limited commercial tests this year.\n\nWaymo, the autonomous-vehicle company spun out of Google, is testing its own fully autonomous cars in Arizona and California. Lyft and a technology start-up called Nutonomy recently began testing self-driving cars in Boston. Uber is running a pilot program in Pittsburgh.\n\nTesla, G.M., Audi and other automakers are also developing driver-assistance systems that take over for drivers in certain conditions, such as cruising along a divided highway. Those technologies, however, require drivers to remain alert and are considered years away from becoming fully autonomous systems.\n\nG.M. is convinced that self-driving cars can play a significant role in reducing deaths and injuries from auto crashes. Traffic accidents kill more than 35,000 people a year, and 95 percent result from driver errors. Ride services with self-driving cars could also make it easier to get around without owning or renting a car \u2014 and producing those cars would help G.M. weather a shift away from individual ownership.\n\n\u201cUltimately we see a very big business opportunity around this,\u201d Mr. Ammann said.", "title": "G.M. Says Its Driverless Car Could Be in Fleets by Next Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is just buying time,\u201d said Representative Mark Sanford, Republican of South Carolina. \u201cI think it\u2019s the best of the available bad choices.\u201d\n\nHouse Democrats, most of whom voted against the last stopgap measure in December, are not likely to embrace this bill either, given the impasse on immigration \u2014 especially after President Trump was said to have made vulgar remarks in a meeting on immigration last week.\n\nThe drama over immigration continued to play out Tuesday in a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee, where Democrats castigated the homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen, for refusing to confirm Mr. Trump\u2019s vulgarity. At one point, Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, the No. 2 Democrat, had young undocumented immigrants protected by the Obama-era program known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, stand in the hearing room as he recited their impressive r\u00e9sum\u00e9s.\n\nIn the meantime, Dreamers and those who support them protested at Republican lawmakers\u2019 offices.\n\n\u201cWe want to keep the government open,\u201d Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, said on Tuesday. \u201cBut we\u2019re not going to be held hostage to do things that we think are contrary to the best interests of the American people.\u201d\n\nIf Republican leaders can push the bill through the House this week, the Senate \u2014 where at least nine Democratic votes will be needed \u2014 is no sure bet. Some Democrats in that chamber \u2014 especially those considering a White House run \u2014 are expected to oppose any spending measure that does not protect the young undocumented immigrants.\n\nBut Democrats up for re-election this year may be reluctant to oppose the bill and risk being blamed for a shutdown.\n\nMr. Trump moved in September to end DACA but gave Congress until early March to come up with a legislative replacement. Last week, a federal judge ruled that, for now, the administration could not end the program, and the government has now resumed accepting renewal requests for it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a result, Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, argued on Tuesday that there was \u201cno urgency right now to try to ram through a major change in immigration law by Friday.\u201d\n\nMr. McConnell said lawmakers have \u201cat least until March, at a minimum, and possibly even longer\u201d to reach a DACA agreement.\n\nIn the bill to be passed this week to avoid a shutdown, Republicans would also suspend a tax imposed by the Affordable Care Act on medical devices, as well as a tax on providers of health insurance. In addition, it would delay the law\u2019s tax on high-cost employer-sponsored health coverage, known as the Cadillac tax.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHaving dithered for months, Congress has suddenly discovered a painless, cost-free way to extend the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, or CHIP. The bill would extend the program\u2019s funding for six years.\n\n\u201cI cannot see the Democrats voting against the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program,\u201d said Representative Mo Brooks, Republican of Alabama, \u201cbut they\u2019ll be given that option in this funding bill.\u201d\n\nLawmakers were able to break a partisan deadlock on the program, started under President Bill Clinton, after they received a new estimate from the Congressional Budget Office showing that the cost would shrink over time and that extending the program for eight to 10 years could actually save money.\n\nMembers of Congress responsible for the program said the new estimate should clear the way for a swift renewal of the program.\n\nThe solution results almost entirely from a curious quirk in the way costs are estimated by the Congressional Budget Office \u2014 and from the unforeseen consequences of Congress\u2019s decision to eliminate a pillar of the Affordable Care Act, the penalties for people who go without health insurance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThanks to the repeal of the individual mandate tax, C.B.O. updated its score and gave us the momentum to push a long-term CHIP extension across the finish line,\u201d said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and the chairman of the Finance Committee. \u201cWe must stop holding CHIP hostage.\u201d\n\nFunds for the program lapsed at the end of September. Congress provided a short-term infusion of money last month, and the Trump administration has shuffled money among states to help those with the most urgent needs. Nevertheless, some states have informed families that their children could lose coverage because of delays and inaction by Congress.\n\nExtending CHIP for six years \u201cmay have no cost\u201d to the federal government, said Representative Greg Walden, Republican of Oregon and the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee.\n\nSenator Ron Wyden of Oregon, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, said that extending the program for 10 years would save $6 billion, according to the budget office. \u201cWith this news,\u201d he said, \u201csecuring kids\u2019 health care for the long-term should be a no-brainer.\u201d\n\nThe Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, created in 1997 with bipartisan support, is given credit for a big increase in the proportion of children who have coverage. But Republicans and Democrats have squabbled for months over how to pay for it.\n\nIn the tax bill signed last month by Mr. Trump, Congress eliminated the penalties for people who go without health insurance, starting in 2019. The Congressional Budget Office, like many health policy experts, believes that healthier people will be less likely to obtain insurance, so that people who remain in the health law\u2019s marketplace \u2014 including children \u2014 will face higher premiums than they otherwise would.\n\nExtending CHIP saves money, the budget office said, because it would be less expensive for the government than the alternatives \u2014 if many of those children enroll in Medicaid or in government-subsidized marketplace coverage.\n\nThe taxes on medical devices, health insurance providers and high-cost employer-sponsored health plans were all imposed by the Affordable Care Act, to help pay for the expansion of coverage under the law. All three would have been repealed under the bill passed last year by the House to dismantle that law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany Democrats have joined Republicans in opposing the device tax, which they describe as a threat to innovative medical technology. The bill would suspend it during two years, 2018 and 2019.\n\nHealth insurance companies have strenuously opposed the tax on insurance providers, saying the additional costs are generally passed on to consumers, businesses, state governments and taxpayers. The bill would suspend it for 2019.\n\nThe \u201cCadillac tax\u201d is meant to help rein in the cost of employee health benefits. Instead of taking effect in 2020, it would be delayed until 2022.", "title": "G.O.P. to Use Children\u2019s Health Insurance as Lure for Averting Shutdown", "authors": ["Thomas Kaplan", "Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "In what situations do you use GIFs, emojis or other images to express your emotions, and why? What does the way you use these images say about you \u2014 your preferences, biases and emotional expressiveness?\n\nAbove are the most distinctly popular GIFs used in each of the five countries for these emotional tags: #angry, #excited, #funny, #happy, #love, #sad and #sorry.\n\nWhat do these GIFs reveal about these different cultures? What do they show about the way people in different countries express their emotions, cultural pride and shame, obsessions and biases?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what we can learn from the different ways people from around the world express emotion through GIFs.", "title": "GIFs", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "DAKAR, Senegal \u2014 Officials in Gabon say they have dismantled the Central African nation\u2019s largest ivory trafficking network, which last year alone was responsible for trading, selling and shipping six tons of ivory across the continent.\n\nA two-year investigation, called Operation Nzok \u2014 which means elephant in a local language \u2014 resulted in the arrests of a Chadian man, Abdoulaye Mohamoud Ibrahim, and eight others, including his wife and other family members.\n\nOfficials said their analysis of the suspects\u2019 laptops and cellphones had revealed links to Boko Haram, the Islamist militant group that has been waging war in northern Nigeria and neighboring areas for nearly nine years.\n\nGabon has the largest population of forest elephants in the world. Also home to gorillas, mandrills and hippos, it is one of the lushest nations on the planet \u2014 80 percent of its land mass is forest.", "title": "Gabon Says It Busted a Major Ivory Smuggling Network", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Gabrielle Melissa Leon and Mark Eric Spatt were married Jan. 6. Rabbi Michael L. Gold officiated at the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach, Fla.\n\nMrs. Spatt, 33, is the program associate in Atlanta for the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation, which encourages high school students and young adults, through educational programs and travel, to develop a connection with Israel and Jewish values. She is also a director of both the Atlanta chapter of the American Jewish Committee and of the Coalition for Collegiate Women\u2019s Leadership, which is in LaGrange, Ga. She graduated from the University of Florida.\n\nShe is a daughter of Diana R. Jacobs of Coral Springs, Fla., and Leslie Leon of Issaquah, Wash. The bride\u2019s father is an information technology and software development consultant in Issaquah. Her mother is a hospice nurse for Vitas Healthcare, and works with patients at Broward Health North, a hospital in Pompano Beach, Fla. The bride is also a stepdaughter of Barbara Leon and of Norman Jacobs.\n\nMr. Spatt, also 33, is a portfolio manager at Cornerstone Investment Partners, an investment firm in Atlanta. He graduated from Princeton University, received an M.B.A. with honors from the University of Pennsylvania, and is also a chartered financial analyst. He is also involved with Atlanta chapter of the American Jewish Committee, through which the couple met in 2014; he is a vice chairman of the young professionals group and manages its interfaith outreach to the Muslim community.", "title": "Gabrielle Leon, Mark Spatt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn your new memoir, \u201cWe\u2019re Going to Need More Wine,\u201d you write about your experience being raped at gunpoint while working at a Payless shoe store when you were 19. The book was published as the #MeToo conversation took off, which has placed you at the forefront of the movement to end sexual harassment and assault. I\u2019ve been doing it for two decades, but there were a lot more microphones this time around than there\u2019s ever been. We\u2019re now seeing how many people have dealt with sexual violence and the toll it can take. All of these disclosures \u2014 from Hollywood to farmworkers to the restaurant industry to television to music to academia \u2014 show that this is so widespread and so many people\u2019s lives have been derailed. All you can think is, I wonder who you could have been and who you can be now? And a lot of those people are waiting for that conversation or for somebody to tell them that they can be anything, that it does not define you.\n\nIt seems as if the book was spawned by a responsibility to use your platform to educate others. What has the feedback been like? Over the last few years, I\u2019ve started feeling worthy of my life, and the more I did, the more I realized that, yeah, maybe I can share this. I definitely got the sense that there are a lot of people who are in tremendous pain, who\u2019ve gone through unspeakable horrors and have been suffering in silence, and the bit of time that they spent with my book made them feel seen and understood.\n\nUnion is the star of \u201cBeing Mary Jane\u201d on BET. \u201cWe're Going to Need More Wine\u201d is her first book. She has her own line of chardonnay, Vanilla Puddin'. Age: 45 Occupation: Actress Hometown: Omaha Her top 5 types of wine: 1. Malbec 2. Sauvignon Blanc 3. Cabernet 4. Syrah 5. Chardonnay\n\nYou open the book with a quote from W.E.B. DuBois about the double consciousness that comes with being black in America, then describe having to constantly code-switch as a smart, self-conscious black girl growing up in the very white, conformist California suburb of Pleasanton. How did you balance those two experiences? A lot of people who experience a dual consciousness have to pretend and stifle and suppress their real feelings. You start to condition yourself, trying to figure out what the right voice is, the right tone, the right word. There are millions of actors: They\u2019re just not in Hollywood. It\u2019s exhausting, and it can fill you with rage.\n\nThe book is largely about self-identity and survival. You write a lot about that basic human desire to be seen and recognized. Is that why you got into acting? I wish I had that cute story where I said something like, \u201cAnd then I saw \u2018Miracle on 34th Street,\u2019 and I knew this was the only thing I could do!\u201d I got into acting because I wanted to be chosen. When you\u2019re insecure, being chosen, whether that be by a man or by a company or by a production, by the right group of friends or the right community, is like being embraced. I was working at the bookstore at U.C.L.A., making $6.15 an hour after three raises, and when an agent asked if I would ever consider modeling, the idea that someone might choose me based on what I look like, for an insecure person, was unbelievable. That vote of confidence was everything.\n\nYou write about how that\u2019s one of the weird secrets of life: Self-confidence is the thing that makes people attractive. And it\u2019s the confidence that comes from being your most authentic self. If, in my 30s, someone asked me to name 10 things that made me happy, I would\u2019ve said ground beef and butter and imitation crab \u2014 not even the real [expletive]! Most of us have no clue what makes us happy. We\u2019re always supercritical of our spouses or our friends or our co-workers for not magically knowing how to be our friend or how to love us. And it\u2019s like, \u201cHow do you even sign up for that when you haven\u2019t even figured it out for yourself?\u201d\n\nMy favorite part of the book was when you joked that people don\u2019t know that you\u2019ve aged, because you were known for playing teenagers for so long. It\u2019s how life balances out. My face must have made a deal with the devil, but my lower back is telling all the tales.", "title": "Gabrielle Union Isn\u2019t Done Talking About Sexual Assault", "authors": ["Molly Lambert"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston has extended a $10 million reward for information leading to the return of 13 works valued at half a billion dollars that were pilfered in 1990.\n\nThe board of directors voted to extend the reward, which was to have reverted to $5 million at the end of 2017, in the hope of enticing tips that would help recover works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Degas, Manet and others that were stolen in the world\u2019s largest unsolved art heist.\n\nThat theft took place just after midnight on March 18, 1990, when a pair of thieves dressed as Boston police officers bamboozled museum guards to gain access to the building, then restrained them and left 81 minutes later with the artworks.\n\nThere have been multiple suspects over the years including members of the mafia and the Irish Republican Army. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said in 2013 that agents had figured out who the thieves were but did not give their names, adding that the two were no longer alive. The statute of limitations on the theft ran out in 1995 but the investigation remains active.\n\nThe woman for whom the museum is named, an art patron and philanthropist who died in 1924, stipulated in her will that the vast art collection in her home, modeled on a 15th-century Venetian palace, remain on permanent display exactly as she left it. Nowadays empty gilded frames that held some of the works that were taken in 1990 still hang on the walls.\n\nWhile searching for leads, the museum\u2019s director of security, Anthony Amore, has searched visitors\u2019 ledgers, compiled a database of names, phone numbers and license plates and created a detailed timeline of events. He has said that he hopes that the lure of the reward might be strong enough to dislodge a crucial bit of evidence that could result in the empty frames being filled once again.", "title": "Gardner Museum Extends $10 Million Reward for Information in Art Heist", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Allegations of inappropriate behavior by Garrison Keillor were more substantial than indicated in November when Minnesota Public Radio severed ties with him, according to a letter the network sent its members on Tuesday.\n\nThe letter from the network\u2019s president, Jon McTaggart, said that MPR received a 12-page correspondence on Oct. 22 from the lawyer for a woman who had worked with Mr. Keillor on \u201cA Prairie Home Companion\u201d that described \u201cdozens of sexually inappropriate incidents directed at her client over a period of years.\u201d\n\nThe woman\u2019s lawyer detailed \u201cmany of the alleged incidents, including excerpts from emails and written messages, requests for sexual contact and explicit descriptions of sexual communications and touching,\u201d according to Mr. McTaggart. The woman has not publicly identified herself.\n\nIt was her allegations that prompted the network to open an independent investigation. \u201cWe told Garrison that we were doing so,\u201d Mr. McTaggart said.", "title": "Garrison Keillor\u2019s Accuser Described \u2018Dozens\u2019 of Offenses Over \u2018Period of Years\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In 2014, after renting in the hamlet for two years, the Wynns bought a four-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath farmhouse, built in 1945 on three acres. Ms. Wynn called it a \u201cmajor fixer-upper.\u201d They paid $610,000.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe originally rented, in case this wasn\u2019t the community for us,\u201d Ms. Wynn said. \u201cNow we can\u2019t imagine ever leaving.\u201d\n\nJust across the northern border of Westchester County, Garrison is a hamlet in the town of Philipstown. It abuts the Hudson River to the west, with dramatic views of the United States Military Academy at West Point on the opposite shore. Richard Shea, Philipstown\u2019s supervisor, approximated Garrison\u2019s size at 16 square miles.\n\nThe population of about 4,400 live among rolling fields and forested hills laced with winding roads, many deliberately unpaved. This rural character is among Garrison\u2019s defining features, prized by residents and supported by zoning regulations passed by Philipstown in 2010 that Mr. Shea described as \u201cconservation minded.\u201d\n\nApproximately 35 percent of Garrison\u2019s land is permanently protected, partly as town- and state-owned parks and preserves, partly through easements held by conservation organizations including Hudson Highlands Land Trust, Scenic Hudson and Open Space Institute. The common objective, said Michelle Smith, executive director of Hudson Highlands Land Trust, \u201cis to ensure that our most precious open spaces do not end up as strip malls.\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nPeppering Garrison\u2019s open spaces are close to 900 single-family residences, said Brian J. Kenney, Philipstown\u2019s assessor. They range from modest colonials and ranches to farmhouses and secluded estates with sweeping river vistas.\n\n\u201cThere is nothing cookie-cutter here,\u201d said Christine Colasurdo, principal broker at Garrison Realty Group. \u201cYou can have an itty-bitty house next to a mansion, and it fits.\u201d\n\nVictor Constant Ski Area at West Point 1 mile Cold Spring PHILIPSTOWN CLARENCE FAHNESTOCK STATE park U.S.Military Academy INDIAN BROOK RD. Boscobel House and Gardens Putnam Valley Hudson R. West Point Garrison\u2019s Landing putnam Garrison station 9 Beverley Robinson house 9W 9D Garrison Beacon Manitoga/The Russel Wright Design Center Fishkill Garrison METRO-NORTH New York Manitou station westchester Bear Mountain BRIDGE New York City Peekskill\n\nThe former estate known as Dick\u2019s Castle was converted into seven luxury condominiums in 2004. Garrison has no other condominium, cooperative or rental complexes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMelissa Carlton, an associate broker with Houlihan Lawrence, estimated 20 percent of Garrison\u2019s properties are purchased as second homes, with many of those owners eventually becoming full-time residents.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\n\u201cThe market here is steady because it\u2019s a sought-after area and not many homes come on at any given time,\u201d Ms. Colasurdo said.\n\nHomes listed between $400,000 and $700,000 are the most competitive, Ms. Carlton said, adding that in that price range \u201cinventory is at an all-time low.\u201d\n\nAs of Jan. 11, there were 36 single-family homes on the market. The least expensive was a 1,488-square-foot, three-bedroom colonial built in 1900 on 1.12 acres, listed at $250,000. The most expensive, listed at $4.95 million, was a 3,382-square-foot, three-bedroom house built in 2007 on 2.38 acres.\n\nData from the Hudson Gateway Multiple Listing Service indicated that the median sales price for a single-family home in the 12-month period ending on Jan. 11 was $382,500, up from $379,000 during the previous 12 months.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Vibe\n\nPredominantly residential, with no downtown, Garrison is filled with cultural and recreational opportunities, not to mention history.\n\nThe tiny riverfront hub called Garrison\u2019s Landing was once a loading dock for 18th-century farmers. In 1968, it provided the backdrop for scenes from the film \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d Today, it is home to the train station, the Garrison Art Center and the Philipstown Depot Theater. A new restaurant in the old Guinan\u2019s pub is set to open this spring.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFarther north, Boscobel House and Gardens has tours of this neoclassical home; in summertime, the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival is held there against panoramic views. South of Garrison, design aficionados can explore Manitoga/The Russel Wright Design Center, the 20th-century industrial designer\u2019s modernist home and studio.\n\nGarrison is crisscrossed by miles of hiking trails, including a stretch of the Appalachian Trail. It has a small ice-skating rink maintained by the Philipstown Recreation Department and two golf courses.\n\nResidents seeking one-of-a-kind shops and restaurants can drive 10 minutes to Main Street in Cold Spring or 20 minutes to Peekskill or Beacon. Big-box options abound in Fishkill, also 20 minutes away.\n\nAnother 20-minute drive leads to the Victor Constant Ski Area in West Point, a favorite wintertime destination. \u201cHow many communities can boast that after school, their kids can head out and ski for a couple of hours,\u201d Ms. Wynn said, \u201cand then come home and do homework?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Schools\n\nMost of Garrison is served by the Garrison Union Free School District, which consists of the Garrison School, a single schoolhouse for kindergarten through eighth grade. The campus includes a 181-acre forest used as an outdoor classroom.\n\nHigh schoolers have a choice. They can attend Haldane, part of the Haldane Central School District, in Cold Spring, or James I. O\u2019Neill, part of the Highland Falls-Fort Montgomery Central School District, across the river in Highland Falls. Laura Mitchell, Garrison\u2019s superintendent of schools, said that of her district\u2019s 301 students, 46 attend Haldane and 40 attend O\u2019Neill.\n\nRoughly 280 students who live in Garrison\u2019s southeastern corner attend the Lakeland Central School District, which serves nearly 5,640 students from six towns in Westchester and Putnam Counties. The district has five elementary schools, a middle school and two high schools.\n\nProperty taxes for Garrison residents zoned for the Garrison school district are among the lowest in Putnam County (around $20 per assessed $1,000, Mr. Kenney, the assessor, said). This is significantly lower than for residents zoned for Lakeland schools (roughly $55 per assessed $1,000).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn 2017 eighth-grade state assessments, 80 percent of Garrison school district students met English standards and 50 percent met math standards, compared with 45 and 22 percent statewide. In Lakeland, 56 percent met English standards and 43 percent met math standards.\n\nFor the 2017 graduating class, mean SAT scores for Haldane were 614 in evidence-based reading and writing and 593 in math; for O\u2019Neill, 589 and 585; for Lakeland, 580 and 550. Statewide means were 528 and 523.\n\nThe Commute\n\nCommuters to Manhattan, 52 miles south, can catch Metro-North Railroad\u2019s Hudson line at the Garrison station at Garrison\u2019s Landing. Rush-hour trains to and from Grand Central take 68 to 76 minutes. Travelers can flag designated trains (one each way on weekdays, several on weekends) at the Manitou station, in the hamlet\u2019s southwestern corner. Monthly fare from both stations is $422.\n\nThe History\n\nHeading north on Route 9D, a roadside marker identifies the site of the Beverley Robinson house, which was Benedict Arnold\u2019s headquarters when his treason was exposed on Sept. 25, 1780. That morning, shortly before he was to meet with General George Washington, he received word that his British contact, the intelligence officer John Andr\u00e9, had been captured with documents incriminating Arnold. By the time Washington arrived at the house, Arnold had fled through the woods to the Hudson, where he escaped by barge to the British warship H.M.S. Vulture. The house burned down in the 1890s.", "title": "Garrison, N.Y.: A Bucolic Hamlet on the Hudson", "authors": ["Susan Hodara", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTortured in Gay Conversion Therapy,\u201d by Sam Brinton (Op-Ed, Jan. 25):\n\nIn 1971 I went to see a psychologist in New York City because my best friend went running out of my home when I told her that I was attracted to her. I was scared to start therapy, but I was also very upset by my college friend\u2019s reaction.\n\nI thought that the psychologist would send me to a mental ward, but I was incredibly fortunate. She told me that there was nothing wrong with me.\n\nWe need to find a way to bring all 50 states on board with banning conversion therapy, which is still legal in 41 states. No one should ever have to be talked out of who they are.\n\nBETH ROSEN, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is a psychotherapist.", "title": "Opinion | Gay Conversion Therapy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Gender diversity in the music industry, it turns out, may be even worse than in Hollywood.\n\nThree years ago, Stacy L. Smith, an associate professor at the University of Southern California and the founder of its Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, drew attention for a study that found that as few as 28 percent of speaking characters in top movies were women and that only 4 percent of films were directed by women.\n\nA new study led by Dr. Smith, announced Thursday, found that over the last six years the representation of women in pop music has been even lower.\n\nIn an analysis of the top 600 songs from 2012 to 2017 \u2014 defined by Billboard\u2019s year-end Hot 100 chart for each of those six years \u2014 the study found that of 1,239 performing artists, 22.4 percent of them were women.\n\nThe numbers are much lower among people behind the scenes. Of the 2,767 songwriters credited on those songs, 12.3 percent were women. Female producers \u2014 the people most responsible for the sound of pop music \u2014 are even rarer, at just 2 percent in a subset of 300 songs across this same period, the study found.", "title": "Gender Diversity in the Music Industry? The Numbers Are Grim", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nOn my way to the subway station near my home in Brooklyn on a recent morning, I had a small but nonetheless upsetting accident.\n\nI was wearing my favorite pair of shoes, and the toe of one of them got scuffed and soiled by an oil hose that a workman was dragging across the sidewalk from his truck to the basement of a building on my route. The shoes were made of suede, which made the problem especially distressing.\n\nFortunately, I have done business in the past with a brilliant shoe-repair man in Manhattan. He is a genius with shoes \u2014 caring, knowledgeable and experienced.\n\nWhen I showed him the impairment, he told me he could indeed clean the suede and brush the stain out so that it would be undetectable.", "title": "Genius of Shoes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Cameron was told by Arena, even before the national team convened in October for the two games, that he would not be starting against Panama or Trinidad and Tobago because of concerns about his fitness. But Cameron said he couldn\u2019t understand that reasoning, especially after he logged a full 90 minutes in Stoke\u2019s victory over Southampton on Sept. 30 before reporting to the United States camp.\n\nNeeding only a draw in Trinidad to secure a spot in Russia, Arena opted for the same attack-heavy formation that had delivered a 4-0 home win over Panama days earlier and kept Cameron, his most experienced and athletic central defender, on the bench against the speedy hosts.\n\nAs every American fan knows now, those tactics backfired. A rough night for Omar Gonzalez and Matt Besler in central defense and an eventual 2-1 defeat, combined with unexpected victories for Panama and Honduras, consigned the Americans to an embarrassing fifth-place finish out of six teams in the region \u2014 leaving Arena with just three wins in eight qualifiers after having replaced Klinsmann in November 2016.\n\n\u201cListen: I hold my hand up \u2014 I didn\u2019t play well against Costa Rica,\u201d Cameron said of a 2-0 loss in a qualifier on Sept. 1, in which his poor performance alongside Tim Ream dropped both out of favor for the October games. \u201cI made a mistake; their second goal was my fault. But it was the 88th minute and we were down, 1-nil. I tried to do something to help the team and I got caught out.\n\n\u201cBut I would have more respect for a coach to say: \u2018You know what, Geoff? I don\u2019t fancy you today. I think this is a better lineup.\u2019 I\u2019d say: \u2018O.K., no problem, you told me the truth.\u2019 But if you tell me I\u2019m not fit enough, that\u2019s like an insult to me as a professional.\u201d\n\nIn response, Arena said in a telephone interview: \u201cCould Geoff have been in the starting lineup that day? Our record was 1-3-1 \u2014 that plays a role. I don\u2019t think 2017 was that impressive of a performance for the player. Hazard Jr., one of the nation\u2019s most respected authorities on legal ethics, who struggled to upgrade the integrity of the legal profession, died on Jan. 11 in Wallingford, Pa. He was 88.\n\nThe cause was heart failure, said his wife, Elizabeth O\u2019Hara Hazard.\n\nProfessor Hazard taught law at the University of Pennsylvania, Yale, the University of Chicago, the University of California, Berkeley, and, most recently, the University of California Hastings College of the Law in San Francisco.\n\nHis journal articles were cited in a number of United States Supreme Court decisions by both conservative and liberal justices, and his law school students included at least one member of the Court, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr.\n\nJudge Anthony J. Scirica, a former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, called Professor Hazard \u201cone of the law\u2019s wise men.\u201d", "title": "Geoffrey Hazard, Influential Arbiter of Legal Ethics, Dies at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "KIEV, Ukraine \u2014 A Georgian court on Friday sentenced former President Mikheil Saakashvili to three years in prison for abusing his pardon powers while serving as president. Mr. Saakashvili, who is now in Ukraine, was sentenced in absentia.\n\nMr. Saakashvili\u2019s legal woes have been piling up in both his adopted country, Ukraine, and his homeland, Georgia, but the ruling is the first time he has been sentenced to prison.\n\nIn a Facebook post on Friday, he called the ruling, and the flurry of cases against him more broadly, a response to his efforts to fight corruption and \u201coligarchs\u201d in both countries.\n\nA gregarious populist and an avowed enemy of Russian influence in former Soviet states, Mr. Saakashvili has cast himself as a fighter for good government and pluralistic democracy, and he has said that the criminal cases against him are pushback from an entrenched, corrupt elite. Detractors call him a showboating has-been.", "title": "Georgian Court Sentences Mikheil Saakashvili in Absentia to 3 Years in Prison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is nothing fair about condemning these complex, sensitive animals to suffer physical suffering and psychological torment in laboratories where they are caged and deprived of fresh air, sunshine, freedom of movement, the companionship of others, and just about everything else that makes any life worth living,\u201d Harald Ullmann, a PETA vice president, wrote in a letter dated Friday to Matthias M\u00fcller, the chief executive of Volkswagen.\n\nThe monkey experiments also provided another example of how Volkswagen used software to conceal emissions of nitrogen oxides that were far above limits allowed by law. The Beetle provided by Volkswagen for the tests had been fitted with software that caused it to produce far less pollution in the lab than the car would have produced on the road. In other words, the results were deliberately manipulated.\n\nThe experiments were commissioned by the European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector, known by its German initials E.U.G.T. The organization received all of its funding from Volkswagen, Daimler and BMW. It contracted the Lovelace Respiratory Research Institute in Albuquerque to carry out the tests.\n\nThe research group commissioned numerous studies on topics related to diesel, such as studies shedding doubt on whether restricting diesel vehicles in urban areas led to better air quality. The organization shut down last year amid controversy over its work, before the results of the Albuquerque study could be published.\n\nThe carmakers said the research group was independent and overseen by reputable scientists. But the studies it commissioned invariably supported the industry\u2019s pro-diesel agenda. Diesel is particularly important to luxury carmakers like BMW, Daimler\u2019s Mercedes unit and Volkswagen\u2019s Audi division. It would be much harder to sell big cars in Europe without the fuel economy provided by diesel.\n\nCarmakers expressed contrition about the experiments.\n\n\u201cThe scientific methods used to conduct the study were wrong,\u201d Volkswagen said in a statement. \u201cAnimal testing is completely inconsistent with our corporate standards. We apologize for the inappropriate behavior that occurred and for the poor judgment of individuals who were involved.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDaimler distanced itself from the study and the E.U.G.T. \u201cWe will clarify how the L.R.R.I. study came about and have launched an investigation,\u201d the company said in a statement, referring to the Albuquerque lab. \u201cDaimler does neither tolerate nor support unethical treatment of animals. The animal experiments in the study are superfluous and repulsive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBMW said in a statement on Sunday that it \u201cdoes not carry out any animal experiments,\u201d adding, \u201cThe BMW Group did not participate in the mentioned study and distances itself from this study.\u201d\n\nNews of the monkey experiments intensified criticism of how the auto industry has used its political clout to preserve tax breaks that make diesel fuel cheaper than gasoline in Europe.\n\n\u201cThe lobbying practices of the industry need to be thoroughly examined, as painful as that might be,\u201d the Stuttgarter Zeitung, a daily newspaper, said in an editorial on Sunday.", "title": "German Carmakers Criticized for Emissions Research on Monkeys", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis proposal is an encouraging and effective method of educating people of all backgrounds about the Nazi attempt to wipe out the entire Jewish population of Europe and the dangers such hatred can yield,\u201d Ronald S. Lauder, the organization\u2019s president, said in an emailed response to a request for comment.\n\n\u201cMore than any other country, Germany has faced up to the crimes of its past in an honest and straightforward way, and has made it clear at the highest levels of government that the memory of the Holocaust must never be forgotten or diminished,\u201d Mr. Lauder said.\n\nThe idea of requiring new arrivals to visit concentration camps was not universally endorsed. Some scholars of German history described it as a simplistic answer to a more complicated and insidious problem. Many acts of anti-Semitism in Germany, they emphasized, are not by immigrants.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t stop someone from being a racist or xenophobe by taking them to a concentration camp,\u201d said Sabine von Mering, the director of the Center for German and European Studies at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. \u201cI don\u2019t think that making it a requirement is somehow going to magically solve this problem. It requires a lot more attention and education.\u201d\n\nMs. Chebli, who suggested the required visits in an interview published Sunday in the newspaper Bild am Sonntag, was not immediately available for comment. Nor was it clear whether the German government would move to make such visits mandatory for immigrants, who are currently offered courses on German language, culture and history.", "title": "German Idea to Fight Anti-Semitism: Make Immigrants Tour Concentration Camps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike the United States, Germany has very strict laws governing hate speech and comments that denigrate ethnic and religious groups, a legacy of its dark, totalitarian past. The new law regarding social media companies solidified the country\u2019s position as one of the most aggressive in moving against online hate speech.\n\nProsecutors must now decide whether there is sufficient evidence of criminal action to open a formal investigation that could lead to charges, Mr. Willuhn said. But before that step can be taken, Germany\u2019s Parliament would have to lift immunity.\n\nMany of the Alternative for Germany\u2019s followers are active on social media, and the party claims nearly three times as many followers on Facebook than either of the country\u2019s two largest parties, Ms. Merkel\u2019s Christian Democrats or the center-left Social Democrats.\n\nIn a message posted to their party\u2019s Twitter feed later Tuesday, the two lawmakers appeared with strips of red tape forming a cross over their lips beside the quote, \u201cExactly our humor: Call for freedom of speech in Iran and prevent it in Germany.\u201d\n\nDigital and human rights groups and others had warned that the new law \u2014 which was passed last year, but fully took effect on Monday \u2014 placed too much of the burden of patrolling the internet on companies such as Facebook, Twitter, Google and Snapchat. Under the law, the companies are required to to remove any content that is illegal in Germany \u2014 such as Nazi symbols or Holocaust denial, but also any remarks that could be considered calling for incitement \u2014 within 24 hours of it being brought to their attention.\n\nOthers have pointed out that the law could lead to mistakes, such as removing messages or videos in which the context is important. Last month, a member of Berlin\u2019s Jewish community had posted a video of an anti-Semitic rant by a German man outside an Israeli restaurant, encouraging people to \u201cpay attention, not look away\u201d as part of efforts to raise awareness about a resurgence in anti-Semitism in the country.\n\nWithin 24 hours of its posting, Facebook had removed the video and closed the man\u2019s account, citing its content. The company later restored the post and apologized for the error, but only after dozens of users had complained about the decision.", "title": "German Lawmaker Who Called Muslims \u2018Rapist Hordes\u2019 Faces Sanctions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Q. We took a six-minute video of the total solar eclipse last August on an iPhone 6s. How do I send it to other phones and devices, or is it simply too large a file? And what\u2019s the best way to get it off the phone so it can be preserved in perpetuity?\n\nA. Many email systems limit file attachments to 25 megabytes or less, which is a much smaller size than six minutes of video recorded on an iPhone. Even at the phone\u2019s lower 720p HD setting, Apple estimates one minute of video requires 40 megabytes of space. One minute recorded at the highest 4K setting can result in a 400-megabyte file.\n\nStill, there are several ways to free the eclipse clip from the confines of the phone, even without buying a third-party program to transfer files to the computer. For example, you can use Apple\u2019s free iTunes software and the USB cable that came with the phone to connect the device to a Windows PC or Mac and import the full video to the computer \u2014 where it can be archived, posted online, backed up, burned to disc or preserved in other ways. Depending on your system, you may also be able to connect the phone with the USB cable and import the video with utilities like Microsoft\u2019s Photos app for Windows 10 or Image Capture (or Photos) for the Mac.", "title": "Getting Those Giant Video Clips Off Your iPhone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Because the hallmark of many gangs is extreme violence, they warrant special attention from the Department of Justice. President Ronald Reagan said that \u201cgovernment\u2019s first duty is to protect the people.\u201d The Justice Department takes that duty seriously, especially with respect to victims of trafficking.\n\nPresident Trump has declared this National Slavery and Human Trafficking Prevention Month. In his proclamation, the president mentioned the role that gangs play in human trafficking, and he called upon all of us to combat this \u201cmodern form of the oldest and most barbaric type of exploitation.\u201d\n\nThe F.B.I. leads the Justice Department\u2019s law enforcement efforts against human trafficking, with support from trafficking prosecutors and coordinators from our program to fight child pornography, Project Safe Childhood, in each of the 94 United States attorney\u2019s offices. Those efforts are assisted by teams of prosecutors based at the Justice Department\u2019s headquarters and deployed throughout the country to assist in dismantling gangs and sex traffickers, including the Human Trafficking Prosecution Unit, the Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section and the Organized Crime and Gang Section.\n\nWe are working to help train state, local and tribal law enforcement officers to identify trafficking cases and provide support for victims. That will help them to uncover human trafficking crimes and combat modern forms of slavery.\n\n\u201cThose who deny freedom to others deserve it not for themselves,\u201d Abraham Lincoln wrote in 1859. That is especially true of human traffickers, who rob victims of their freedom. The Justice Department, in turn, punishes traffickers by taking their freedom through imprisonment.", "title": "Opinion | Getting Tough on Sex Traffickers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How do you do a clean installation of Windows 10 these days with no DVDs to reload the program?\n\nA. Microsoft added a new \u201cFresh Start\u201d utility to the system last year with its Windows 10 Creators Update. The tool is designed to preserve all your personal data and settings before downloading a clean, uncluttered copy of Windows 10, installing it on your computer and restoring your files and settings.\n\nHowever, the Fresh Start operation removes any apps you may have installed yourself that are not part of the standard Windows system. If you added new programs from the Windows App Store or elsewhere \u2014 including security software, games and even Microsoft\u2019s own Office suite \u2014 they will get wiped out with Fresh Start.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore you begin, make sure you have copies of your third-party software available, including the product registration keys and licenses for apps you need to download or install again from their original sources. You should also back up all your personal files and folders to an external drive or disc, just in case. Make sure you have several gigabytes of free space available on your PC for Fresh Start to maneuver.\n\nThe Fresh Start tool lives within the Windows Defender Security Center. Instructing the Cortana assistant to \u201copen the Windows Defender Security Center\u201d is probably the fastest way to get there. If you prefer to leave Microsoft\u2019s virtual helper out of it, open the Windows 10 Settings from the gear-shaped icon in the Start menu, select the Update & Security icon, choose Windows Defender on the left side of the box and then click or tap the Open Windows Defender Security Center button in the center.\n\nOnce you are there, select the Device Performance & Health icon. Below the various diagnostic reports on your computer\u2019s current state, you can find the Fresh Start utility. Select \u201cAdditional Info\u201d to get started.\n\nWhile the Fresh Start option is one of Microsoft\u2019s newer solutions for reinstalling the Windows 10 operating system, older methods like downloading a copy of the software from Microsoft\u2019s site and creating a DVD or USB drive to use for installation can still work if you are leery of the automated approach. The company\u2019s site has a list of other recovery options if you are having trouble with your Windows 10 system.", "title": "Getting a Fresh Start With Windows 10", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "So she did what many others do to keep costs down in an expensive city: She found a roommate.\n\nInstead of placing an ad online, however, Ms. Felstein turned to the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, a Manhattan-based nonprofit. The group has been operating a home-sharing service since 1981, matching people who have space in their homes with those in need of affordable housing. It is one of a number of similar programs that have emerged across the country as the population of older Americans grows, as a way to help people stay in their homes.\n\nThe concept of pairing older people with younger ones, particularly those who are not family members, is not a new one: It was popularized by Maggie Kuhn, an elder-rights activist who opened up her Philadelphia home to others for more than 20 years before she died in 1995. Today\u2019s home sharing, however, is as likely to be between those of the same age as it is to be intergenerational. The crucial thing is that it involves two or more people sharing an apartment or a house to their mutual benefit. And finances often play a big role.\n\nFor those who are still working age, it\u2019s getting harder to pay the rent: According to a StreetEasy survey, rents in the city rose twice as fast as wages between 2010 and 2017. The lowest rents (those up to $2,300) rose 4.9 percent annually since 2010, which means someone who paid $1,500 a month in 2010 likely paid nearly $600 more for the same place in 2017.\n\nFor baby boomers entering retirement, financial security is also increasingly hard to come by. Many Americans may think they have plenty of savings, but about half have not saved enough to maintain their pre-retirement living standards, according to a recent estimate by the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College. The rising cost of health care, increased life expectancy and lower interest rates only exacerbate the situation. In addition, a Fannie Mae survey found that baby boomers are more likely to be carrying mortgage debt into their retirement years than previous generations were.\n\nTo Ms. Felstein, who was confronting these realities, there didn\u2019t seem to be any other option than taking in a roommate. The New York Foundation for Senior Citizens connected her with a licensed social worker who asked a host of questions, including details about her sleeping habits, personality, interests and daily schedule. She also had to provide three personal recommendations and her rental agreement, to prove she was on the lease.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd she was asked to describe what she considered the ideal roommate. Her response: someone who wasn\u2019t home much.\n\n\u201cI knew it would be a long shot,\u201d she said, \u201cbut I thought I should be honest.\u201d\n\nShe found her match in Yukari Honda, a 27-year-old graduate student in interior design at the New School. Ms. Honda, who is from Tokyo, is often at school from morning until past midnight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA year ago, Ms. Felstein moved out of her old bedroom to make room for Ms. Honda. She replaced the living room sofa with a bed, turning the living room into a bedroom for herself. Fortunately, there is a separate kitchen and common room where Ms. Honda studies and Ms. Felstein keeps reams of fabric for her quilting.\n\nThe two split the utilities and the $1,145 rent equally. They rarely share meals or do things together, but have found that they seek each other out in other ways. \u201cShazzi is so patient, she has helped me for hours with my schoolwork,\u201d Ms. Honda said.\n\nMs. Felstein, an avid quilter, said she has been thrilled to talk about design and assist Ms. Honda with her assignments. In return, Ms. Honda has been helping out more with the housework.\n\n\u201cGetting a roommate at my age certainly required some mental adjustment,\u201d Ms. Felstein said. \u201cBut it has been wonderful in so many ways.\u201d\n\nSusan Bendes, the shared housing coordinator at the Women\u2019s Rights Information Center, in Englewood, N.J., said the nonprofit, which has found affordable housing for Bergen County residents since the 1970s, believes there is an urgent need for public policymakers to promote home sharing to seniors to prevent homelessness.\n\n\u201cI have seniors who call and ask me all kinds of questions because they\u2019re in dire need of financial assistance to stay in their homes, but they tend to be gun-shy when it\u2019s time to actually bring in a tenant,\u201d Ms. Bendes said. \u201cThere needs to be more dialogue on how and why home sharing should be a normal thing in our society.\u201d\n\nStatistics show that the number of older Americans who are homeless is growing. In 2007, homeless people 62 and older who sought shelter accounted for 2.9 percent of the country\u2019s homeless population. By 2016, the percentage had risen to 4.7, according to estimates from the National Alliance to End Homelessness, a Washington, D.C., advocacy group.\n\n\u201cPeople were doing O.K. until the recession,\u201d said Nan Roman, president of the alliance. \u201cBut as people lost their jobs and struggled to get rehired, some lost their assets over time.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWendi Burkhardt, chief executive of Silvernest, an online home-sharing and roommate-matching service geared toward older adults, thinks that society\u2019s penchant for independent living has clouded the conversation about how we age.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI really think the \u2018Golden Girls\u2019 were early trendsetters,\u201d she said, referring to the popular TV sitcom from the late \u201980s and early \u201990s, in which four older women lived under the same roof in Miami. \u201cWhy wouldn\u2019t you want to share your home with others, whether it\u2019s for financial reasons or for companionship?\u201d\n\nAlthough placing an ad and setting up a profile is free, Silvernest charges those who have rooms to rent about $30 to use the messaging service to communicate with potential roommates. Those seeking rooms pay the same amount, which covers a background check and gives them access to the listings.\n\nMore than 70 percent of those who have placed an ad since the company was started in 2015 were motivated by financial reasons, Ms. Burkhardt said, noting that while most of the company\u2019s clients are in the West, the service is available nationally.\n\nThe real estate listings site Trulia estimates that there are 3.6 million unoccupied rooms that can be rented out in the country\u2019s largest housing markets \u2014 and there may be more than 17,700 spare rooms that can be rented out for about $868 a month in the New York area alone.\n\nSarah Oswald, a relationship coach who lives in Boulder, Colo., said she messaged numerous people through Silvernest to find her father, John Oswald, a roommate.\n\nMr. Oswald, 69, lives in a one-bedroom rent-stabilized apartment in the West Village and has no pension to rely on, he said, because he worked in the nonprofit world for years. Health issues stemming from his service in the Vietnam War also took a toll on his finances, because numerous surgeries on his legs prevented him from working at times.\n\nMs. Oswald said she tried using Craigslist and university housing boards, but they were difficult to navigate from afar. With Silvernest, she said, she was able to carefully read all the profiles, which made choosing whom to message and to introduce to her father much simpler. \u201cThe vetting the firm does for you helps,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther start-ups are following suit. Nesterly, an online portal that matches intergenerational roommates, will start offering services in New York this year after being introduced in Boston last fall. \u201cWe\u2019d like to help create new units of affordable housing at a time when there\u2019s a dire need for it,\u201d said Noelle Marcus, a founder.\n\nElizabeth Rosania, 86, learned a painful lesson when she found boarders through the classifieds in the local paper. After her husband passed away in 2013, a year of living alone in her four-bedroom, three-bathroom house on a four-acre estate in Lebanon, N.J., left Ms. Rosania lonely and seeking company.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe had worked as a nurse her entire life, she said, and she wanted to continue helping people in another capacity. Her first few tenants, however, were too much for her to handle. One female tenant in her seventies was addicted to OxyContin. Another tenant, a struggling alcoholic in her fifties, stole a nine-foot satellite dish, jewelry and appliances, Ms. Rosania said.\n\nBut last year, she found John Costanzo, 61, with help from social workers at HomeSharing Inc., a nonprofit in Bridgewater, N.J., and the two became fast friends. They now watch TV, run errands and eat most meals together.\n\nFor Mr. Costanzo, a former Marine who owned a crane-rigging business and is on disability after several back surgeries, affordable housing was essential. He pays $600 for his room, a monthly fee that includes utilities and cable. He is not allowed overnight guests, alcohol and drugs are prohibited in the house, and he must keep the bathroom clean at all times.\n\n\u201cI think my blood pressure is lower and I\u2019ve lost 43 pounds since I moved in,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t know where,\u201d Ms. Rosania shot back with a smile.\n\nHome sharing, of course, is not just for those who need the money. Taking in a tenant for little or no rent in exchange for household work suits many who have extra space, like Thelma Chesney, a Brooklyn Heights resident.\n\nMs. Chesney, 91, started living with a new roommate last month. In exchange for light household work \u2014 taking out the garbage, cleaning the house, shopping \u2014 Grace Linderholm, 23, an artist who recently graduated from New York University, gets to live on the top floor of Ms. Chesney\u2019s house for free.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA former associate professor at the New York University Silver School of Social Work, Ms. Chesney said the four-story brownstone became \u201ca lot of room for one person\u201d after her three children moved out and her husband passed away in 2008. She finds all her lodgers through word of mouth, and also rents out the ground floor at a reduced rate, in exchange for handyman work done on the brownstone.\n\nBut more important than the work her tenants do, she said, is having her home lived in, especially when she is on vacation or visiting her children. She recalled previous boarders, including one who practiced the cello for hours on end and another who helped her sew buttons on her clothing.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been able to coexist with everyone quite well,\u201d she said. \u201cHaving someone fetch you milk in bad weather is quite convenient.\u201d\n\nMelissa McHam Green, a licensed social worker and eldercare manager in Brooklyn, has helped some of her clients find roommates and agree on mutually beneficial guidelines. She advises those interested in home sharing not to go about it on their own: Go through a nonprofit service, she said, or ask a trusted eldercare professional, friends or family to help properly vet the prospective roommates. And before you sign a lease with a boarder, make sure to do a background check.\n\n\u201cYou need a huge amount of trust and to be very clear with your expectations,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cBut if you have the help you need to stay in your home \u2014 and the tenant gains affordable housing in exchange \u2014 I think there\u2019s much to gain socially and spiritually when young and old live together.\u201d", "title": "Getting a Roommate in Your Golden Years", "authors": ["Kaya Laterman"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Pat Shurmur, the offensive coordinator of the Minnesota Vikings, has emerged as the leading candidate to fill the Giants\u2019 vacant head coaching job, according to people with knowledge of the team\u2019s deliberations. The Giants cannot offer Shurmur the job or finalize the terms of a contract with him until the Vikings, who play in Sunday\u2019s N.F.C. championship game, are no longer in the playoffs.\n\nThe NFL Network first reported on Monday that Shurmur had risen to the top of the Giants\u2019 short list of candidates for head coach. Two of the most prominent names on that list \u2014 Matt Patricia, the defensive coordinator of the New England Patriots, and Josh McDaniels, the Patriots\u2019 offensive coordinator \u2014 are expected to take head coaching jobs elsewhere. According to news reports, Patricia will become the Detroit Lions\u2019 coach while McDaniels is headed to the Indianapolis Colts.\n\nShurmur, 52, met with Giants officials on Jan. 6 in Minnesota. In his 19 years coaching in various positions in the N.F.L., Shurmur is known best for his development of quarterbacks. The Giants have an aging quarterback in Eli Manning, who had a subpar season in 2017, and they are expected to use the second overall pick of the upcoming N.F.L. draft to select one of the top available quarterbacks.\n\nShurmur\u2019s r\u00e9sum\u00e9 has been buttressed by his work this season with Vikings quarterback Case Keenum, who has gone from an N.F.L. journeyman to a surprising star for Minnesota. Keenum threw 22 touchdown passes and seven interceptions during the regular season, while the Vikings won 11 of the 14 games he started. In a divisional-round playoff game against the New Orleans Saints, Keenum threw a 61-yard game-winning touchdown pass, helping his team advance to the conference championship.", "title": "Giants Focus Coaching Search on Pat Shurmur", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Giants, who missed the playoffs this year for the fifth time in six seasons and lost 13 games for the first time in the team\u2019s 92-year history, completed the second major step in a sweeping overhaul on Monday by naming Pat Shurmur as the franchise\u2019s new head coach.\n\nLast month, Dave Gettleman was named the team\u2019s new general manager. Gettleman recently held the same position with the Carolina Panthers.\n\nShurmur, who comes to the Giants from the Minnesota Vikings, where he thrived as an offensive coordinator, will be charged with resurrecting a roster short on depth. He will also have to mend a fractious locker room frayed by dissension and hobbled by a dearth of veteran leadership. His predecessor, Ben McAdoo, was celebrated as a breath of fresh air when he led the Giants to an 11-5 record and a playoff berth in 2016, but he was unceremoniously discarded this season after the Giants won only two of their first 12 games.\n\nLike McAdoo, Shurmur is known for his ability to develop quarterbacks. He inherits 37-year-old quarterback Eli Manning, who elevated his play under McAdoo for a period before experiencing a precipitous decline \u2014 along with the rest of the team \u2014 this season. Backing up Manning is Davis Webb, whom the Giants selected in the third round of last April\u2019s N.F.L. draft.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Giants also possess the second overall selection of the coming N.F.L. draft, and it seems likely that the team will use that pick on another quarterback, one that Shurmur would presumably be asked to develop into Manning\u2019s successor.", "title": "Giants Hire Pat Shurmur in Hopes of Revitalizing Struggling Team", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "What happens to alter the trajectory of shooting stars like Follett? In \u201cOff the Charts,\u201d Hulbert attempts to capture the complicated lives of child prodigies without descending into voyeurism or caricature. She has tried to \u201clisten hard for the prodigies\u2019 side of the story,\u201d to her great credit.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis is an arduous task, and it sometimes shows in the writing, which can be stilted in its reliance on quotes and documentation. But Hulbert\u2019s diligence results in a surprising payoff: The best advice for managing a child prodigy may be a wise strategy for parenting any child, including the many, many nonbrilliant ones.\n\nHulbert, The Atlantic\u2019s literary editor, wrote her last book, \u201cRaising America,\u201d about the tortured history of parenting advice. So she is appropriately wary of preachy morality tales. \u201cMy goal isn\u2019t to pile on the stark cautionary fare. Nor am I aiming to crack some \u2018talent code,\u2019\u201d she writes in the prologue for \u201cOff the Charts,\u201d to our great relief.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, she tries to place each of the boys and girls featured in the book in a specific time and place; their celebrity reveals much about their particular moment in American history. For example, Bobby Fischer\u2019s chess prowess might not have been impressive enough for adults to overlook his breathtaking egotism \u2014 but for the launching of Sputnik and America\u2019s anxiety about creeping Soviet domination in education and science. One era\u2019s prodigy is another\u2019s anonymous misfit.\n\nThe book begins with the story of two gifted boys who attended Harvard at the same time, in the early 1900s. Norbert Wiener, a budding philosopher and mathematician, was 14, and William Sidis, a star in linguistics and mathematics, was only 11. They were not friends, which was a shame. Both suffered under the weight of their elders\u2019 intellectual expectations, combined with the impossibility of fitting in as boys among men. They were told they were superior, but then punished if they acted like it. Their identities depended on superhuman smarts, which made any academic failure feel like a knife to the heart.\n\nWiener would struggle with depression for the rest of his life, but he did manage to eventually find professional fulfillment at M.I.T., where he helped invent the field of cybernetics. Sidis was not so successful; after fleeing a criminal charge related to a political protest, he did low-level accounting work in New York. He continued to alienate others with his stubborn arrogance before dying at 46 of a cerebral hemorrhage.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat would have helped these boys and the other struggling prodigies in this book? Maybe nothing. But after poring over their words and stories, Hulbert has concluded that they might all offer parents similar advice: Accept who they are.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean protecting them from failure or stress; quite the opposite. \u201cWhat they want, and need, is the chance to obsess on their own idiosyncratic terms \u2014 to sweat and swerve, lose their balance, get their bearings, battle loneliness, discover resilience,\u201d Hulbert writes. Interestingly, this is the same advice contemporary psychologists tend to give to all parents, not just the parents of prodigies. Parents must hold children accountable and help them thrive, which is easier said than done; but if they try to re-engineer the fundamentals of their offspring, they will fail spectacularly, sooner or later. And this lesson is particularly obvious in the extremes.\n\n\u201cExtraordinary achievement, though adults have rarely cared to admit it, takes a toll,\u201d Hulbert writes. \u201cIt demands an intensity that rarely makes kids conventionally popular or socially comfortable. But if they get to claim that struggle for mastery as theirs, in all its unwieldiness, they just might sustain the energy and curiosity that ideally fuels such a quest.\u201d\n\nThe special challenge for prodigies is that they are exceptional in more ways than one. \u201cGenius is an abnormality, and abnormalities do not come one at a time,\u201d explains Veda Kaplinsky, a longtime teacher of gifted students, in Andrew Solomon\u2019s \u201cFar From the Tree,\u201d a book that is cited by Hulbert. \u201cMany gifted kids have A.D.D. or O.C.D. or Asperger\u2019s. When the parents are confronted with two sides of a kid, they\u2019re so quick to acknowledge the positive, the talented, the exceptional; they are often in denial over everything else.\u201d\n\nThe very traits that make prodigies so successful in one arena \u2014 their obsessiveness, a stubborn refusal to conform, a blistering drive to win \u2014 can make them pariahs in the rest of life. Whatever else they may say, most teachers do not in fact appreciate creativity and critical thinking in their own students. \u201cOff the Charts\u201d is jammed with stories of small geniuses being kicked out of places of learning. Matt Savage spent two days in a Boston-area Montessori preschool before being expelled. Thanks to parents who had the financial and emotional resources to help him find his way, he is now, at age 25, a renowned jazz musician.\n\nInterestingly, some prodigies may actually do better when their eccentricities are seen by loving adults as disabilities first \u2014 and talents second. Hulbert tells the story of Jacob Barnett, born in 1998, who withdrew into autism as a toddler in Indiana. His parents tried every form of therapy they could find, before finally discovering that he could be drawn out through his captivation with astronomy. His mother, Kristine, took him to astronomy classes at the local university \u2014 not to jump-start his genius but to help coax him back to life. \u201cIf I had stopped and let myself bask in the awe of Jake\u2019s amazing abilities \u2014 if I had stopped to ponder how unusual he really is \u2014 I don\u2019t think I could have been a good mother to him,\u201d she explained.\n\nThe most vivid section of the book comes at the end, when Hulbert reunites with the musical prodigy Marc Yu, a decade after first interviewing him at age 6. With his mother\u2019s support, Yu had tried to ease up on his musical career and live a more normal life, an approach that had worked for other prodigies, including the child actress Shirley Temple. But Yu found that the strategies that worked at the keyboard were useless in high school, where no amount of discipline and focus could make him cool. The adorable, joke-cracking boy she\u2019d remembered had grown into a lonely teenager. \u201cI always expected things to go my way,\u201d Yu told Hulbert. \u201cIf I wanted it, I worked hard enough, I got it, and people loved me. That\u2019s no longer true, and I feel I exist in the shadow of popular kids.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYu\u2019s story reinforces one of Hulbert\u2019s central, if unsatisfying, findings: Children\u2019s needs change. If you think you\u2019ve got a child figured out, you will be proved wrong momentarily. As Hulbert writes: \u201cProdigies offer reminders writ large that children, in the end, flout our best and worst intentions.\u201d And adults always overestimate their own influence.", "title": "Gifted and Talented and Complicated", "authors": ["Amanda Ripley", "Ann Hulbert"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Kirsten Gillibrand plans to use a prerogative given to home-state senators to try to block the confirmation of Geoffrey S. Berman if he is nominated by President Trump as the United States attorney in Manhattan, her spokesman said on Wednesday.\n\nThe senator, Democrat of New York, intends to use her \u201cblue-slip prerogative\u201d to lodge her objection over reports that President Trump had personally interviewed Mr. Berman as part of the selection process.\n\nMs. Gillibrand, through her spokesman, said those reports were deeply disturbing, because of conflicts of interest inherent in Mr. Berman\u2019s \u201cpotential jurisdiction on matters that could affect the president personally.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnder these circumstances,\u201d Ms. Gillibrand\u2019s spokesman, Glen Caplin, said, if such a meeting took place and Mr. Berman were nominated as United States attorney, \u201cthe senator would have no choice but to stand up for the independence of this office by using her blue-slip prerogative.\u201d", "title": "Gillibrand Vows to Block Trump\u2019s Likely Choice for U.S. Attorney in Manhattan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Angela Ofori-Atta, an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Ghana School of Medicine and Dentistry, led the study and arranged access to chained participants at the prayer camp.
