She said that the treatment produced some dramatic individual improvements \u2014 one man, shackled for 10 years, became strikingly lucid for the first time in memory \u2014 and that more careful, and longer, follow-up likely would have found that chaining was reduced, at least somewhat.\n\nVideo\n\nExperts acknowledged the multiple cultural hazards involved \u2014 including obtaining informed consent, perhaps the slipperiest issue \u2014 but were impressed the trial happened at all.\n\n\u201cThe implications are clear: symptom control through the solitary use of medications is not a means to reduce chaining,\u201d wrote Dr. Vikram Patel of Harvard University and Dr. Kamaldeep Bhui of the London School of Medicine, in an editorial accompanying the study. \u201cThis study reaffirms the need for a comprehensive and humane approach for the management of psychosis.\u201d\n\nPeople are chained at prayer camps throughout West Africa that are mostly Christian retreats. Some are tiny and hidden, while others are sprawling places, with open-air churches and cafeterias that teem with people on holy days.\n\nThe pastors who run the camps and their followers believe that prayer and fasting are the best treatment for mental problems. Camp staffers remove the chains when they decide a person is no longer mentally troubled but consistently lucid, calm, reasonable. That can take days, months or even years, depending on the person and the camp.\n\nThe leader of the Mt. Horeb camp, about an hour\u2019s drive from Accra, the country\u2019s capital, allowed Dr. Ofori-Atta and a team of psychiatric residents to recruit chained attendees for the study. The team obtained consent in the usual way, explaining the trial and its risks to the people and their families in the Twi language native to the region.\n\nObtaining informed consent is an imperfect process even when engaging patients in the United States who live independently, let alone chained, impoverished West Africans, said Dr. Rosenheck. People held in chains are deeply vulnerable, often poor and uninformed about Western medicine; many are apt to agree to almost anything if the staff and religiousleader approve.\n\n\u201cYou explain everything in detail, and you ask people. Still, it is as ambiguous a process there as it is here,\u201d Dr. Rosenheck said. Yale\u2019s Global Health Leadership Initiative worked with Dr. Ofori-Atta to develop the study. Funding came from the University of Ghana and Ghana\u2019s health ministry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the study, the researchers monitored the mental well-being of 110 chained people. The vast majority had a psychotic disorder, like schizophrenia. Half got a diagnosis, using Western labels like schizophrenia and depression, and predominantly drug treatment. The other half continued as before, with no changes to treatment.\n\nAfter six weeks, those on drugs showed clear improvements on a standard rating scale that tracks feelings of hostility, emotional withdrawal and hallucinations. The camp residents doing the ratings did not know which people were on medication and which were not.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe improvements were about the same as we see in trials done in Western countries,\u201d Dr. Rosenheck said. Yet the number of days each person spent in chains was identical in both groups: about 12 days on average, after the initial phase of the trial.\n\nThe reasons that treatment didn\u2019t reduce chaining are not obvious, said Dr. Ofori-Atta, but may include the length of the trial itself. The decision to remove chains was the camp\u2019s to make, and typically staff want to see steady improvement over time.\n\nDr. Ofori-Atta said that another factor was the abuse of recreational drugs. Some people in chains were addicts likely to return to using drugs if freed, so staffers were slow to turn them loose.\n\nIn that sense, the study is yet another demonstration that people have little chance of becoming fully well until they are reintegrated into a community with the supports they need, regardless of diagnosis or treatments.", "title": "Given Medicine, the Patients Got Better. They Remained in Shackles Anyway.", "authors": ["Benedict Carey"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "By the end of Friday, when the number of accusers was estimated at 140 and more than 100 had signed up to speak, we knew we would have another few days of statements before sentencing. Over the weekend and into Monday, Carla and I spent much of our time collecting material.\n\nCarla took on the heroic task of listening to every second of the sentencing hearing \u2014 recording names, who was there, who spoke publicly and who spoke anonymously. As she listened, she marked times and transcribed quotations that she thought were compelling or would work well in the story.\n\nAs she listened, I was in our photo database, working alongside our photo editors to track down every single name. I was determined to gather as many portraits as we could, to represent as many women as possible. For those who chose to remain anonymous but still spoke in court, I reached out to one of our art directors, Agnes Lee, to create a silhouetted drawing to include in the grid online to stand in for the anonymous speakers.\n\nThere were multiple times, as I pulled up yet another photo of a woman facing her abuser in court, that I wanted to burst into tears at my desk. The reason visual storytelling is so compelling is because it creates an intense connection between you and the subject. It\u2019s also the reason creating these pieces can wear on you.\n\nCarla concurred. \u201cMuch of what I heard during the hearing was not new to me, but it still kept me awake at night,\u201d she said. \u201cI understood the scope of the problem long before now, but seeing and hearing the women speak simultaneously broke my heart and inspired me.\u201d", "title": "Giving Larry Nassar\u2019s Victims Their Own Voices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The World Economic Forum is not just any economic conference. The cost of a basic membership and ticket is more than $70,000, and attendees tend to incur heavy expenses on luxury cars or helicopters to get from the airport in Zurich to the resort in Davos, where panel discussions on subjects like global income inequality and the threat of climate change are held.\n\nThose attending include top executives like Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook, Bill Gates of Microsoft and Ginni Rometty of IBM, along with Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, and scores of other executives, economists and academics. Celebrities are also a mainstay, and last year\u2019s forum included interviews with Matt Damon, Shakira and Forest Whitaker.\n\nThe parties surrounding the conference also feature celebrities such as Bono and Leonardo DiCaprio. As for more interactive entertainment, one popular event is a simulation of a refugee\u2019s experience, where attendees crawl on their hands and knees to better understand what it is like to evade an advancing army.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe World Economic Forum has in the past drawn scorn from anti-globalization groups as a symbol of lavishness and elitism, and at times attendees have tried to be less conspicuous. In the wake of the financial crisis in 2009, Gary D. Cohn, who is the director of Mr. Trump\u2019s National Economic Council and was then chief operating officer at Goldman Sachs, was among the banking executives who opted to fly commercial to get to the forum.\n\nMr. Trump will be the first president since Bill Clinton to attend. As a candidate, he lashed out at his opponent, Hillary Clinton, for being a patron of \u201cglobalists\u201d and elite bankers. In 2014, Stephen K. Bannon, who went on to be Mr. Trump\u2019s chief political strategist, said that working-class men and women were tired of being dictated to by \u201cthe party of Davos.\u201d\n\nSome supporters of Mr. Trump have cast him as a populist \u201cparty crasher\u201d at Davos, while others think the journey is unwarranted and unwise. Stephen Moore, the Heritage Foundation economist who advised Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign, told CNN that he was not pleased by the decision.\n\n\u201cI was disappointed that he\u2019s going to Davos because I think it\u2019s a lot of self-important people who have a totally different view of the world than he does,\u201d Mr. Moore said.\n\nIn an interview with The Wall Street Journal on Thursday, the president suggested that he was going to Davos to be \u201ca cheerleader for the country\u201d and highlight his economic success. Mr. Trump is expected to use the platform to boast about the improving American economy, including the rise in the stock market and the low jobless rate, and to deliver the type of protectionist message on trade that he gave during his Asia trip.\n\nMr. Mnuchin, who has never attended the forum himself, said at a White House briefing on Thursday that the gathering was a good place to talk about the administration\u2019s \u201c\u2018American first\u2019 economic strategy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s a hangout for globalists,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said.", "title": "Global Elite? At Davos? That\u2019s News to Mnuchin", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "During bleaching events, overheated seawater causes corals to part ways with symbiotic plantlike organisms called zooxanthella that live inside of them. In addition to giving coral reefs their bright colors, zooxanthella also provide corals with oxygen, waste filtration, and up to 90 percent of their energy. Absent zooxanthella, corals not only take on a ghostly pallor, hence the term bleaching, but they are also more susceptible to death.\n\nIn theory, coral reefs can recover from even a severe bleaching event. Some of the coral will die off from increased disease susceptibility, but once ocean temperatures drop again, many of the corals will start growing back.\n\nBut that\u2019s only if they\u2019re given enough time.\n\nTypically, it takes 10 to 15 years for the fastest-growing corals to recover after a severe bleaching event. Larger corals that provide shelter for bigger fish can take even longer to grow back.\n\nAs bleaching events become more frequent, reefs are unlikely to get that needed reprieve. Earth\u2019s average temperature has increased 1 degree Celsius, or 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit, above preindustrial levels, and the median time between severe bleaching events is now just six years, the Science study found.\n\nCase in point: The Scott Reef, 180 miles off the coast of Northwestern Australia, had over the past few years finally begun recovering from a major bleaching event in 1998, with the fastest-growing corals inhabiting much of their earlier territory. But the area was hit by bleaching again in 2016, causing widespread mortality.", "title": "Global Warming\u2019s Toll on Coral Reefs: As if They\u2019re \u2018Ravaged by War\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGoPro\u2019s genius discount grows larger. The wearable-camera maker styled itself a media company when it went public in 2014, but even its hardware business is suffering job cuts as sales fall short. Success is even harder than usual when \u2014 as at Snap, which fancied itself a camera company \u2014 the boss wastes time and resources chasing whims.\n\nThe company\u2019s portable cameras are popular among snowboarders, sky divers and mountain bikers, but its media partnerships and attempts to launch action shows never amounted to much. GoPro shut down those efforts in 2016. A bid to crack the drone market hasn\u2019t fared any better. The firm now says it will exit that business, blaming competition and a hostile regulatory environment.\n\nWhile GoPro chased those dreams, competition in its core business of making portable cameras grew ever tougher. Asian rivals caught up on quality while cutting prices. And the emergence of waterproof smartphones with quality lenses and better editing software has caused some customers to wonder why they need a separate camera at all.\n\nIt\u2019s one thing to turn a good idea into a thriving business, as GoPro\u2019s founder, Nick Woodman, did with small, rugged cameras for action sports. But one success hardly guarantees another, no matter how clever the vision. Snap, for example, has seen features like its disappearing messages, face filters and story format copied by Facebook. And the company\u2019s camera glasses have proved to be a dud, prompting it to take a $40 million charge against inventory last quarter.\n\nInvestors now attach a hefty discount to the idea that Mr. Woodman can produce a string of hit products. GoPro stock is down more than 90 percent from its peak. It doesn\u2019t take a genius to see that knowing your limits can be more valuable than trying to defy them.", "title": "GoPro Needs to Know Its Limits", "authors": ["Robert Cyran"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Guillermo del Toro, 52, who has best director and best screenplay Academy Award nominations for \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d (he won a Golden Globe Award for best director for the film), is well-known for his science-fiction and horror movies. (His other films include \u201cPacific Rim\u201d and \u201cPan\u2019s Labyrinth.\")\n\nBut Mr. del Toro\u2019s talents go beyond film: he has also co-authored a trilogy of vampire novels and is the creator of the computer-animated Netflix series \u201cTrollhunters.\u201d\n\nOne of his latest projects, the drawings for the box of a limited-edition tequila from Patr\u00f3n called Patr\u00f3n x Guillermo del Toro, is a homage to his upbringing in Guadalajara, in the central western Mexican state of Jalisco. There, he would often see the fields of agave teeming with jimadores \u2014 the farmers who harvest blue weber agave plants used to make tequila. \u201cIt was fascinating to watch them work because their craft of picking and trimming the plants is so intricate,\u201d he said.\n\nIt\u2019s the jimadores who inspired Mr. del Toro\u2019s drawings, he said.\n\nAnd while Mr. Del Toro currently lives in Toronto and Los Angeles, he returns to Guadalajara every six weeks to visit his family and still sees the jimadores working in the fields.", "title": "Going to Mexico? Guillermo del Toro Has Some Recommendations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "I \u2019m not saying I drank too much Brunello di Montalcino. But if I had drunk too much Brunello di Montalcino \u2014 the Podere Le Ripi 2014, for example, at, say, 2 a.m. \u2014 then a hot, dusty barn packed with sheep wouldn\u2019t have been my first choice of places to be at 6 in the morning.\n\nYet there I was, surrounded by a hundred little animals, white wool coats matted down with hay and dirt, making small, timid bleats as they trotted past me up the ramp to the milking station. As the sun rose, rivers of dust filled shafts of light; you could sense the day was going to be scalding by breakfast. But for now, in the barn, it was bearable \u2014 just me, a pretty young farmer named Giulia, and a herd of sheep ready to be milked.\n\nI was at Podere Il Casale, an organic farm outside the tiny Renaissance-era Tuscan town of Pienza, to educate myself on the intricacies of the town\u2019s most famous commodity, pecorino di Pienza. You have likely heard of pecorino \u2014 but the town, not so much. Outside of Tuscany, it\u2019s possible the only place you would hear the word Pienza is at a gourmet cheese counter.", "title": "Going to the Source for a Sacred Italian Cheese", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Best performance by an actor in a motion picture, musical or comedy: James Franco, \u201cThe Disaster Artist\u201d\n\nBest performance by an actress in a supporting role in any motion picture: Allison Janney, \u201cI, Tonya\u201d\n\nBest performance by an actor in a supporting role in any motion picture: Sam Rockwell, \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d\n\nBest screenplay, motion picture: Martin McDonagh, \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d", "title": "Golden Globe Award Winners 2018: The Complete List", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe wristbands at the Bafta tea on Saturday were black, which these days seems terribly significant.\n\nThe party, sponsored by the British film and TV academy, is held every year at the Four Seasons in Beverly Hills the day before the Golden Globes, and it\u2019s an altogether dignified affair, with cucumber sandwiches, famous people, and of course lots and lots of tea.\n\nICYMI, actresses and gents plan to wear black to the Globes to protest sexual misconduct, and as a young man signing people into the tea confirmed, the wrist bands were making a statement.\n\nThe Globes are the first major Hollywood awards gathering since The New York Times reported accusations of sexual harassment against the producer Harvey Weinstein. Conjecture over who might win has been all but eclipsed by the actresses\u2019 plans to wear black, and musings about how on earth Seth Meyers will pull off his high-wire hosting act.\n\nYet the mood at the parties before Sunday\u2019s ceremony didn\u2019t seem all that different from other years. The same ingredients were there: schmoozing, publicists\u2019 introducing their clients to an assembly line of Oscar and Bafta voters, and rubbernecking at the celebrities. There they were at W Magazine\u2019s party on Thursday night at the Chateau Marmont: Gal Gadot, James Franco, Emilia Clarke, Sam Rockwell, Salma Hayek, Mary J. Blige, Kyle MacLachlan and Daniel Kaluuya, and again at the Bafta tea, along with heaps more of their celebrity selves.\n\nYet if anyone was talking about #MeToo, I certainly couldn\u2019t tell, though the actress Andrea Riseborough, who played Billie Jean King\u2019s love interest in \u201cBattle of the Sexes,\u201d was wearing a black tank top emblazoned, in white, with the words #TimesUp, the name of the anti-harassment initiative started by hundreds of Hollywood female bigwigs.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs it happened, her statement was so self-evident we didn\u2019t end up talking it, but instead chatted about the merits of \u201cBlack Mirror\u201d (she recently starred in the series). Maybe that\u2019s what was happening at all the parties (including W Magazine\u2019s It Girl luncheon, also held Saturday). Maybe everyone knows that #MeToo and #TimesUp were there, hovering in the background. But they\u2019re waiting until show time, when the cameras are trained on them \u2013 to roll out the talking points.", "title": "Golden Globes 2018: At Starry Parties, #MeToo Is Barely Noted", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.\n\n\u201cLady Bird\u201d and \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d were among the biggest winners at Sunday night\u2019s Golden Globes ceremony, but you won\u2019t find either movie on your streaming service or digital rental platform of choice. The good news is that you can stream almost every TV winner, and a few of the nominated movies that didn\u2019t win. Here\u2019s a guide to the nominees and winners that are both streamable and worth your time.\n\nMovies\n\nMark Rylance, left, and Cillian Murphy in \u201cDunkirk.\u201d Warner Bros. Pictures\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nNominated for: best picture, drama; best director; best original score\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMost best picture nominees are still in theaters when the Globes air, but one of this year\u2019s welcome exceptions is the latest epic from the writer and director Christopher Nolan. This immersive summer blockbuster revisits a low point in World War II, when hundreds of thousands of Allied soldiers were evacuated from the border town of Dunkirk, France, after Germans swept through the country. The strong ensemble cast, which includes Cillian Murphy, Tom Hardy, Mark Rylance, Kenneth Branagh and the pop star Harry Styles, doesn\u2019t do a whole lot of talking; Nolan lets the sights and sounds of war speak for themselves. The Times\u2019s Manohla Dargis named \u201cDunkirk\u201d the best film of 2017, writing: \u201cMost war movies are about winning. \u2018Dunkirk\u2019 is about surviving.\u201d\n\nWhere to watch: Rent it on Amazon, YouTube, Google Play or Vudu.\n\n\u2014\n\nDaniel Kaluuya in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Justin Lubin/Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nNominated for: best picture, musical or comedy; best actor, musical or comedy\n\nbest picture, musical or comedy; best actor, musical or comedy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201c\u2018Get Out\u2019 is a documentary,\u201d the film\u2019s writer and director, Jordan Peele, tweeted after learning it had earned Globe nominations in the \u201cmusical or comedy\u201d category. And he had a point: \u201cGet Out\u201d sparked enough impassioned debate about the nuances of race relations in 21st-century America to dominate last year\u2019s cultural conversation. Whether you see it as a horror comedy, a biting and serious social critique or both, there\u2019s no question that this story of a young black man\u2019s harrowing visit to his white girlfriend\u2019s suburban family home delivers far more than laughs and jump scares.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on HBO Go.\n\n\u2014\n\n[Interested in getting suggestions on what to watch? Sign up for our newsletter, which we send out every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.]\n\nEmma Stone and Steve Carell in \u201cBattle of the Sexes.\u201d Melinda Sue Gordon/20th Century Fox\n\n\u2018Battle of the Sexes\u2019\n\nNominated for: best actress, musical or comedy; best actor, musical or comedy\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nJonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, the husband-and-wife directing team that delighted festival audiences with the indie comedies \u201cLittle Miss Sunshine\u201d and \u201cRuby Sparks,\u201d bring their quirky sensibility to the era-defining tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs in 1973. Although it offers refreshingly high-spirited takes on gender and sexuality, \u201cBattle of the Sexes\u201d excels most as a showcase for its two Globe-nominated leads: Emma Stone balances King\u2019s feminist grit with touching vulnerability, while Steve Carell locates the childish pathos behind Riggs\u2019s self-proclaimed \u201cmale chauvinist pig\u201d provocations.\n\n0\n\nWhere to watch: Rent it on Amazon, Google Play, YouTube or Vudu.\n\n\u2014\n\nSareum Srey Moch in \u201cFirst They Killed My Father.\u201d Roland Neveu/Netflix\n\n\u2018First They Killed My Father\u2019\n\nNominated for: best picture, foreign language\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter a brief detour into uncomfortably intimate domestic drama with \u201cBy the Sea,\u201d Angelina Jolie returned to her chief directorial preoccupation: global human rights crises. Written with the Cambodian-American activist Loung Ung and based on Ung\u2019s memoir of her training as a child soldier during the Khmer Rouge regime, \u201cFirst They Killed My Father\u201d initially raised eyebrows for Jolie\u2019s approach to casting the children of survivors in lead roles. Still, the film seemed to fly under many viewers\u2019 radars: Despite its famous director, provocative conceit and largely positive reviews, it didn\u2019t attract nearly as much attention as 2017\u2019s other big Netflix original movies, like \u201cOkja\u201d and \u201cMudbound.\u201d\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Netflix.\n\n\u2014\n\nMary J. Blige in \u201cMudbound.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Mudbound\u2019\n\nNominated for: best supporting actress; best original song\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cMudbound,\u201d meanwhile, got shut out of this year\u2019s competitive best drama race. It\u2019s a frustrating exclusion, considering how deftly director Dee Rees (\u201cPariah\u201d) balances stirring human drama, astute social commentary and sweeping, Old Hollywood grandness in this tale of a black family and a white family who share a plot of Mississippi farmland in the 1940s. The singer and actress Mary J. Blige did, however, get a nod for her warm performance as Florence Jackson, an indomitable mother whose resilience is itself a quiet rejoinder to the racism and sexism of the era.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Netflix.\n\n\u2014\n\nTelevision\n\nFrom left, Shailene Woodley, Reese Witherspoon and Nicole Kidman in \u201cBig Little Lies.\u201d Hilary Bronwyn Gayle/HBO\n\n\u2018Big Little Lies\u2019\n\nWon for (in the categories for limited series or made-for-TV movies): best limited series or made-for-TV movie; best actress; best supporting actress; best supporting actor\n\nbest limited series or made-for-TV movie; best actress; best supporting actress; best supporting actor Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter taking home eight awards at last year\u2019s Emmys, HBO\u2019s \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d dominated every category for which it was nominated at the Golden Globes. And it\u2019s easy to see why. This glossy murder mystery has just about everything awards voters love: privileged characters, a lush setting, a prestigious director in Jean-Marc Vall\u00e9e (\u201cWild,\u201d \u201cDallas Buyers Club\u201d) and strong performances from an A-list cast that includes Reese Witherspoon, Nicole Kidman and Laura Dern. It also happens to be a genuinely fascinating collection of rich character studies and a meditation on female solidarity, trauma and the fraught relationships between parents and children.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on HBO Go.\n\n\u2014\n\nElisabeth Moss in \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale.\u201d Take Five, via Hulu\n\n\u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019\n\nWon for: best series, drama; best actress, drama\n\nbest series, drama; best actress, drama Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis zeitgeist-capturing adaptation of the dystopian novel by Margaret Atwood was the big winner in the drama-series category. It isn\u2019t exactly a light diversion. But, as dark as its story lines can be, it\u2019s still a pleasure to watch the show\u2019s Globe-winning lead, Elisabeth Moss, battle the patriarchy as the smart, sardonic narrator, Offred, a young woman who has lost her job, home, family and bodily autonomy to a theocratic revolution. Hulu is bringing \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d back for a second season in April, so now is the perfect time to catch up.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Hulu.\n\n\u2014\n\nMatt Smith, left, and Claire Foy, center, in \u201cThe Crown.\u201d Alex Bailey/Netflix\n\n\u2018The Crown\u2019\n\nNominated for: best series, drama; best actress, drama\n\nbest series, drama; best actress, drama Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d may have been last year\u2019s buzziest show, but can it beat \u201cThe Crown\u201d? The first season of that lavish Netflix historical drama about the reign of Queen Elizabeth II took top TV honors at the 2017 Globes, and its star, Claire Foy, won the award for best actress. Season 2, which covers the tumultuous period between the late 1950s and the early \u201960s, is the final outing for the show\u2019s original cast. (An older cohort of actors will replace Foy and her co-stars in Season 3.) The new episodes are less cohesive than their predecessors, although the unconventional courtship of Princess Margaret (Vanessa Kirby) and her first husband, Lord Snowdon (Matthew Goode), makes for a few of the show\u2019s most thrilling hours to date.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Netflix.\n\n\u2014\n\nSterling K. Brown and Chrissy Metz in \u201cThis Is Us.\u201d Ron Batzdorff/NBC\n\n\u2018This Is Us\u2019\n\nWon for: best actor, drama\n\nbest actor, drama Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNBC\u2019s \u201cThis Is Us\u201d isn\u2019t just the only network show to nab a best drama series nomination this year \u2014 it\u2019s also a ratings juggernaut, regularly drawing 15-20 million viewers in its current, second season. While that high-concept family drama courted its enormous audience through an early sequence of heavy-handed twists, its devastating portrait of the loving but troubled Pearson clan has matured considerably since those somewhat contrived episodes. Much of the credit for the show\u2019s evolution belongs to its cast \u2014 particularly the Globe winner Sterling K. Brown \u2014 for humane performances that rarely devolve into sappiness.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Hulu.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Marsai Martin, Miles Brown, Anthony Anderson, Yara Shahidi, Tracee Ellis Ross and Laurence Fishburne in \u201cblack-ish.\u201d Ron Tom/ABC\n\n\u2018black-ish\u2019\n\nNominated for: best musical or comedy series; best actor, musical or comedy\n\nbest musical or comedy series; best actor, musical or comedy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nKenya Barris is quickly becoming one of the biggest behind-the-scenes forces in Hollywood. The creator of \u201cblack-ish,\u201d a charming ABC sitcom about an upper-middle-class black family, Barris also helped write one of 2017\u2019s funniest big-screen comedies, \u201cGirls Trip.\u201d He kicked off 2018 with the premiere of Freeform\u2019s \u201cgrown-ish,\u201d a \u201cblack-ish\u201d spinoff that follows the Johnson family\u2019s oldest daughter (Yara Shahidi) to college. But Barris hasn\u2019t neglected her parents and siblings in favor of these new projects. \u201cBlack-ish\u201d has never shied away from topical story lines, and with the standout episode \u201cLemons,\u201d which aired last January, the show became one of the first TV series to address the repercussions of the 2016 presidential election.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Hulu.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cMaster of None.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Master of None\u2019\n\nWon for: best actor, musical or comedy\n\nbest actor, musical or comedy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe first season of this finely crafted Netflix comedy from Aziz Ansari was subtly unorthodox, periodically interrupting its Tinder-era love story for episode-length explorations of weighty topics like immigration, sexism and Hollywood\u2019s racism. Season 2, which appeared last spring, doubled down on those experimental flourishes to profound and delightful effect. Although the season does embroil Ansari\u2019s Dev Shah in another wrenching romance, its best episodes focus on entirely different characters: \u201cNew York, I Love You\u201d traces the intersecting lives of a doorman, a bodega clerk and a cabby, while the Emmy-winning \u201cThanksgiving\u201d goes back in time to recount how Dev\u2019s friend Denise (Lena Waithe) came out as a lesbian to her family.\n\n0\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Netflix.\n\n\u2014\n\nPamela Adlon, left, and Mikey Madison in \u201cBetter Things.\u201d Jessica Brooks/FX\n\n\u2018Better Things\u2019\n\nNominated for: best actress, musical or comedy\n\nbest actress, musical or comedy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLike \u201cMaster of None,\u201d this semi-biographical family dramedy from Pamela Adlon followed up a very good debut season with a truly excellent Season 2. When we first met Adlon\u2019s alter ego, Sam Fox, she was a sort of gruff supermom, slaying single parenthood with wry humor and infinite patience. She deflected her three daughters\u2019 thoughtless insults while alleviating their growing pains with perfect gems of insight about the messiness of life. The show\u2019s second season went all-in on that messiness, in an evolution that made \u201cBetter Things\u201d cathartic as well as inspirational, acknowledging that even a supermom can get mired in anger and vulnerability and sheer exhaustion.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on FX Now.\n\n\u2014\n\nRachel Brosnahan in \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel.\u201d Nicole Rivelli/Amazon Studios\n\n\u2018The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel\u2019\n\nWon for: best musical or comedy series; best actress, musical or comedy\n\nbest musical or comedy series; best actress, musical or comedy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt was exciting to watch this dark-horse nominee from Amy Sherman-Palladino (\u201cGilmore Girls\u201d) win big in the comedy series category, just six weeks after its first season appeared on Amazon. The show repurposes the cult-favorite TV creator\u2019s chatty, referential style for a story set in the 1950s. Rachel Brosnahan more than earns her best actress nomination as the lovable Midge Maisel, an ultra-capable Manhattan housewife whose perfect life suddenly falls apart when her amateur-comedian husband leaves her. It doesn\u2019t take long for Midge to show up, drunk and bitter, at his open-mic venue of choice and entertain the downtown crowd with her disgruntled Jewish mom routine. From there, \u201cMrs. Maisel\u201d becomes a mostly lighthearted tale of a remarkable woman who\u2019s embracing her independence \u2014 and cracking up audiences with foul-mouthed jokes that are as funny now as they would have been 60 years ago.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Amazon Prime.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrankie Shaw (here with her television son) in \u201cSMILF.\u201d Mark Schafer/Showtime\n\n\u2018SMILF\u2019\n\nNominated for: best musical or comedy series; best actress, musical or comedy\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis dark Showtime comedy from the actress and filmmaker Frankie Shaw is another surprising nominee. \u201cSMILF\u201d debuted at the end of an extraordinarily crowded year for TV and got somewhat lost amid a crush of other raw, female-fronted comedies. And it is most definitely not a show that will appeal to everyone. Shaw stars as Bridgette Bird, a broke single mom with an eating disorder, a history of sexual abuse and an obsessive fear that childbirth has made her body unfit for sex. Although it didn\u2019t quite reach the brilliantly neurotic heights of \u201cFleabag\u201d and \u201cLady Dynamite\u201d in its first season, \u201cSMILF\u201d (which has already been renewed for Season 2) has limitless potential and will probably appeal to anyone who loves those two series.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Showtime Anytime.\n\n\u2014\n\nKyle MacLachlan in \u201cTwin Peaks: The Return.\u201d Suzanne Tenner/Showtime\n\n\u2018Twin Peaks: The Return\u2019\n\nNominated for: best actor in a limited series or made-for-TV movie\n\nbest actor in a limited series or made-for-TV movie Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMaybe David Lynch and Mark Frost\u2019s wildly ambitious revival of their classic \u201890s crime drama, \u201cTwin Peaks,\u201d was just too weird to merit a nomination for best limited series. That\u2019s a shame, but at least the press association acknowledged Kyle MacLachlan for his stunning performance as the heroic F.B.I. agent Dale Cooper, as well as two new characters: Cooper\u2019s evil doppelg\u00e4nger and a strangely endearing human-shaped blank slate named Dougie Jones. You really have to get on board with the creators\u2019 experimental vision to appreciate this small-town soap that doubles as an abstract rendering of the cosmic battle between good and evil. Luckily, the alternately affable and inscrutable MacLachlan makes a perfect conduit between Lynch\u2019s world and our own.\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on Showtime Anytime.\n\n\u2014", "title": "Golden Globes 2018: Where to Stream the Nominated and Winning Movies and TV Shows", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDespite a viral moment from Oprah Winfrey and a well-reviewed performance by the host Seth Meyers, the ratings for the 75th annual Golden Globe Awards on Sunday night dipped 5 percent compared to last year\u2019s telecast.\n\nThe ceremony, which featured big wins for \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d and \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d drew a total of 19 million viewers, down from just over 20 million last year, according to early Nielsen data shared by NBC. It drew a 5.0 rating in the key 18-49 demographic coveted by advertisers, down from 5.6 last year, a decline of 11 percent.\n\nThe normally glib Golden Globes faced the challenge this year of addressing the widespread sexual assault revelations that have rocked Hollywood; many actresses responded by walking the red carpet wearing black. The red carpet show drew 10 million viewers.\n\nJimmy Fallon, a higher-profile celebrity, hosted last year\u2019s ceremony, which included plenty of jokes about President Trump and inspired a trending Twitter hashtag, #BoycottGoldenGlobes, thanks to backlash from Trump supporters. But this year\u2019s show had the benefit of not going up against a football game, as both N.F.L. wild card games occurred in the afternoon.\n\nEven with the declines, the Golden Globes telecast was the most-watched and highest-rated non-sports telecast since the 2017 Academy Awards.", "title": "Golden Globes Ratings Decrease Slightly", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Goldman Sachs used to seem invincible. In the fourth quarter, it lost money.\n\nThe Wall Street firm on Wednesday reported its first quarterly loss since 2011. It was the result of a one-time $4.4 billion charge stemming from the new tax law. But even ignoring that unusual event, Goldman\u2019s weak core results showed how far the firm has fallen.\n\nThe bank\u2019s per-share earnings and revenue were both higher compared with a year earlier without the tax charge. But the results announced on Wednesday also revealed a decline in Goldman\u2019s trading might, which has been drained by a potent combination of placid markets and quiet clients. Revenue in its business of buying and selling bonds, commodities and currencies \u2014 historically an engine of Goldman\u2019s results \u2014 sank to $1 billion in the fourth quarter, half of what it was during the same period in 2016. For the year, net revenue in that business fell 30 percent.\n\nThe drop sent Goldman\u2019s shares down 3 percent on Wednesday.\n\nTighter financial regulations, strikingly synchronized global monetary policy and new competition from financial upstarts are hitting trading at banks like Goldman especially hard. On Wednesday, the bank used one word to describe current conditions on Wall Street: \u201cchallenging.\u201d Its clients are placing fewer trade orders than they did when market prices were changing more quickly and more dramatically.\n\nCompetitors like Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase have also reported declines in the so-called fixed-income trading business, but none quite as large as Goldman\u2019s. Bank of America said Wednesday that revenue from its trading businesses was down 13 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the same period a year earlier. Citigroup\u2019s was down 18 percent, the bank said Tuesday.", "title": "Goldman Sachs Once Looked Invincible. Now It\u2019s Losing Money.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The media love contrarian man-bites-dog stories that purport to debunk long-established beliefs and advice. Among the most popular on the health front are reports that saturated fats do not cause heart disease and that the vegetable oils we\u2019ve been encouraged to use instead may actually promote it.\n\nBut the best-established facts on dietary fats say otherwise. How well polyunsaturated vegetable oils hold up health-wise when matched against saturated fats like butter, beef fat, lard and even coconut oil depends on the quality, size and length of the studies and what foods are eaten when fewer saturated fats are consumed.\n\nSo before you succumb to wishful thinking that you can eat well-marbled steaks, pork ribs and full-fat dairy products with abandon, you\u2019d be wise to consider the findings of what is probably the most comprehensive, commercially untainted review of the dietary fat literature yet published. They are found in a 26-page advisory prepared for the American Heart Association and published last June by a team of experts led by Dr. Frank M. Sacks, professor of cardiovascular disease prevention at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health.\n\nThe report helps to explain why the decades-long campaign to curb cardiovascular disease by steering the American diet away from animal fats has been less successful than it might have been and how it inadvertently promoted expanding waistlines and an epidemic of Type 2 diabetes.", "title": "Good Fats, Bad Fats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "CLEVELAND \u2014 At Municipal Stadium on the shore of Lake Erie, the crowd that came out to see the Cleveland Indians play often seemed to be just me, some neighbors and the team mascot, Chief Wahoo. This was in the 1960s, when the Indians were horrible and the team averaged 9,000 fans per game in the 78,000-capacity venue. We could sit wherever we wanted after the third inning. The old stadium was demolished in 1996, and Chief Wahoo \u2014 the actual 28-foot neon logo looming over Gate D \u2014 came down too. On Monday the Cleveland Indians owner, Paul Dolan, and the commissioner of Major League Baseball, Rob Manfred, said the chief\u2019s times is up. The racist logo will be off the uniform by the 2019 baseball season.\n\nChief Wahoo \u2014 the version from the stadium \u2014 wound up at the Western Reserve Historical Society, a center of Cleveland memorabilia and regional history. When you walk into the historical society, you see the chief, and then to your left, the classic Cleveland-manufactured cars from the early 20th century. Cleveland likes its history. And we have no beef with nostalgia either. For instance, I have a 1958 baseball card on my desk of Roger Maris in an Indians uniform. Maris played for the Indians for a minute. What if he had hit 61 homers for the Indians instead of the Yankees? The world would be a better place, that\u2019s what. Chief Wahoo is plastered all over the Maris card. Mr. Dolan, the Indians owner, said Wahoo paraphernalia will still be available in Northeast Ohio, exclusively, after next year. Keep the locals happy.\n\nI\u2019m a landlord, and I once rented to a graphic-design shop that did good cash flow with \u201cKeep the Chief in Cleveland\u201d T-shirts and other Cleveland-themed gear. Many locals love Wahoo. My wife\u2019s cousin George Becker is against getting rid of the chief. He said: \u201cChief Wahoo is a representation of Cleveland. It\u2019s highly identifiable with this town. Why have somebody from another city tell us who we are? They don\u2019t know what makes this city tick.\u201d He paused. \u201cBut at least we\u2019ll still be able to buy the Chief Wahoo tchotchkes here.\u201d\n\nI\u2019ve played gigs beneath the Wahoo logo at the historical society. (When I\u2019m not a landlord, I\u2019m a musician.) I did a duo gig with the guitarist Irwin Weinberger, whose parents were Holocaust survivors from Poland. The Wahoo sign irked Irwin. On Monday he said to me: \u201cYahoo! Wahoo! It\u2019s fantastic that Wahoo is gone. That caricature reminded me of the Jews in Germany. It was a very degrading symbol. I understand what it\u2019s like to be a cultural ethnicity, and to be used in a way you don\u2019t want to be used.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Good Riddance to Chief Wahoo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "Good Vibrations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA Connecticut theater well known for presenting musicals has canceled a planned production of \u201cBullets Over Broadway,\u201d following a sexual abuse allegation against Woody Allen.\n\nGoodspeed Musicals, the East Haddam, Conn., theater that gave \u201cAnnie\u201d its start, said Thursday that it was dropping the musical adaptation of Mr. Allen\u2019s 1994 film from its fall schedule.\n\n\u201cIn light of the current dialogue on sexual harassment and misconduct, the author of \u2018Bullets Over Broadway,\u2019 Woody Allen, has come under increasing scrutiny,\u201d Michael Gennaro, the executive director of Goodspeed, said in a statement. \u201cOngoing reports in the media have made this situation even more difficult and complicated and this led us to reconsider the appropriateness of producing the show.\u201d\n\nMr. Allen\u2019s daughter, Dylan Farrow, has accused him of molesting her as a child. Mr. Allen has repeatedly denied the allegation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA spokeswoman for Mr. Allen declined to comment Thursday, but pointed a reporter to a statement he issued recently, declaring, \u201cI never molested my daughter \u2014 as all investigations concluded a quarter of a century ago.\u201d\n\nMr. Allen wrote the stage version of \u201cBullets Over Broadway,\u201d a comedy about a playwright who hires a gangster\u2019s girlfriend while trying to raise money for his show. It ran for four months on Broadway in 2014.", "title": "Goodspeed Cancels Woody Allen Musical", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSAN FRANCISCO \u2014 James Damore was fired from his engineering job at Google last year after he wrote a memo that criticized the company\u2019s diversity efforts and argued that the low number of women in engineering positions was a result of biological differences.\n\nNow he is suing his former employer for workplace discrimination, claiming that Google is biased against white men with conservative views.\n\nThe lawsuit, filed Monday by Mr. Damore and another former Google employee with California Superior Court of Santa Clara County, also claims that the company uses illegal quotas in order to hire women and minorities.\n\nThe two men \u201cwere ostracized, belittled and punished for their heterodox political views, and for the added sin of their birth circumstances of being Caucasians and/or males,\u201d Harmeet K. Dhillon from the Dhillon Law Group, the lead attorney for the plaintiffs, said in the lawsuit. \u201cGoogle\u2019s open hostility for conservative thought is paired with invidious discrimination on the basis of race and gender.\u201d\n\nSilicon Valley, often considered a bastion for liberal thinking, has been wrestling with how to deal with the culture wars that have reverberated throughout the country. At the same time, technology firms are trying to address the shortage of women and minorities in their ranks.\n\nThose issues are coming to a head at Google, one of the richest and largest technology companies in the world. Google is also fighting a pay discrimination lawsuit brought by four women who worked at the company. The women claim that Google systematically pays women less than men to do the same jobs.\n\nMr. Damore\u2019s memo last year argued that biological differences \u2014 citing greater levels of anxiety among women, and a lower tolerance for stress \u2014 helped explain why there were fewer women in key engineering positions and leadership roles at Google. His writing sparked outrage at the company and across Silicon Valley for rationalizing the pay and opportunity gap at technology companies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Damore\u2019s dismissal became a rallying point for conservatives who saw technology companies as workplaces dominated by groupthink. Ms. Dhillon, the lawyer who brought the suit, is a committeewoman for California in the Republican National Committee.\n\nGoogle did not provide immediate comment about the lawsuit. Sundar Pichai, the company\u2019s chief executive, said in the past that Mr. Damore\u2019s memo had violated the company\u2019s code of conduct because it advanced \u201charmful gender stereotypes in our workplace.\u201d", "title": "Google Memo Author Sues, Claiming Bias Against White Conservative Men", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi", "Nellie Bowles"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Google uses the technique while building systems that can recognize faces, products, landmarks and other objects in photos. In some cases, these algorithms are more accurate than something that is designed solely by engineers.\n\nThe new service is part of a widespread effort to expand the power of modern A.I. to businesses that are largely unfamiliar with this rapidly evolving technology. Like Google, a New York start-up called Clarifai offers an online service that helps customers train computer vision algorithms.\n\nAt the same time, several other start-ups, like Boston\u2019s DataRobot and Silicon Valley\u2019s H2O.ai, offer services designed to help businesses analyze the way products, customers, markets and employees behaved in the past and predict how they will perform in the future.\n\n\u201cThey aim to automate data science in general,\u201d said Randy Olson, a data scientist at Life Epigenetics, a company in Portland, Ore.\n\nTech giants like Google, Amazon and Microsoft have hired a large portion of the people who specialize in the machine learning techniques that are rapidly accelerating the progress of A.I. \u2014 a community of only 10,000 researchers worldwide, according to one estimate. That means most businesses don\u2019t have the talent needed to explore the latest machine learning.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe question is whether these new services will work as advertised and how rapidly they will evolve in the years to come.\n\nGoogle, Amazon, Microsoft and others already offer cloud-computing services that let businesses add existing machine learning algorithms to their own products. A company can take a Microsoft computer vision algorithm, for example, and slip it into a new smartphone app.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut with its new service, Google goes a step further, providing an automated way for businesses to build new algorithms. Businesses can upload their own images, provide a list of objects pictured in these images and train their own computer vision systems, tackling tasks that aren\u2019t necessarily handled by existing technology, according to Google.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInitially, Google will open this service only to a small group of businesses. A Google product manager, Rajen Sheth, said the company would work with these customers to determine the price.\n\nRisto Miikkulainen, a professor of computer science at the University of Texas at Austin who has long explored the kind of technology that underpins Google\u2019s new service, agreed that it had the potential to help other businesses build their own A.I.\n\n\u201cIt is really powerful technology,\u201d said Mr. Miikkulainen, who is also vice president of research at Sentient Technologies.\n\nBut sometimes, there is no substitute for good old human labor. With Google\u2019s new service, humans must label the data before the system can learn from it. Google can provide the human labelers, as do companies like CrowdFlower.\n\nAnd even when an online service successfully automates a task, it\u2019s not necessarily worth using.\n\nJames Bradley and his London company, NMT Vision, once used Clarifai to train and operate algorithms to identify websites that are selling products that infringe on copyrights. But he and his company now handle this on their own, mainly because the cost is lower.\n\nServices like DataRobot and H20.ai may bill themselves as automated data scientists, but here, too, automation has its limits. \u201cThese services are only as good as their parts,\u201d said Patrick Dougherty, a data scientist with the Seattle-based firm Slalom Consulting. \u201cAnd humans still supply some of the parts.\u201d\n\nGoogle says that once images are labeled, its new service operates without human involvement. In a matter of minutes, it can retrain an existing algorithm using the customer\u2019s images. Given more time, it can build a model from scratch, specifically for the problem at hand.\n\nIf you are a zoologist who wants an algorithm that identifies jaguars and giraffes, said Fei-Fei Li, chief scientist inside the Google cloud group, all you have to do is supply the right images. \u201cYou upload jaguars and giraffes,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd you are done.\u201d\n\nAll that remains is determining how well it works.", "title": "Google Sells A.I. for Building A.I. (Novices Welcome)", "authors": ["Cade Metz"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "R. Fishell from Toronto wrote, \u201cI am a skeptic of Google, social media and the end of the separation of personal and public spaces,\u201d but added, \u201cI am in favor of letting the experiment proceed as well as encouraging all the public discourse with its resident messiness to evaluate what works and what doesn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nWhile Sidewalk\u2019s plan eclipses in scale and scope everything that came before it, the idea of using data collection and analysis common in the digital world to shape the physical world is not unique to the company or its sibling Google. The federal government is running a \u201csmart cities\u201d competition that will give out millions of dollars to local governments looking to reshape their communities through the \u201cuse of data and connected technology.\u201d\n\nLet\u2019s continue the debate. Humans, Not Technology, Are the Challenge in Toronto\n\nCanada Dines\n\nTo begin the new year, The Times\u2019s Food department will turn its collective gaze to Canada. On Jan. 16, Sam Sifton, the food editor, will lead a public conversation in Montreal with David McMillan, the restaurant owner best known for Joe Beef. Last year Prime Minister Justin Trudeau dined with President Barack Obama at Mr. McMillan\u2019s neighboring restaurant, Liverpool House.\n\nAnyone who has read Mr. Sifton\u2019s recipes, food stories or his Cooking newsletter knows that he has eclectic interests, strongly held views and a deep knowledge of cooking. Mr. McMillan, whom I interviewed last year, has all of that but delivers it at an even higher volume. They are $30 but Canada Letter readers can chop off $10 with the code Cooking.\n\nWorkplace Abuse\n\nMuch of the reporting about workplace sexual harassment and the abuse of power by men has focused on the entertainment industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat was certainly the case this week in Canada. Albert Schultz resigned as the artistic director of Toronto\u2019s Soulpepper Theatre Company after four actors filed a lawsuit against him and the theater. Mr. Schultz has said that he intends to \u201cvigorously\u201d defend himself.\n\nBut most people have jobs in far less glamorous fields. And in the blue-collar world, women must often deal not only with supervisors but also with co-workers who are harassers.\n\nWomen who work at Ford Motor Company plants in Chicago told their stories to Susan Chira and Catrin Einhorn, herself a Chicago native. A powerful union and an employer with sophisticated human resources policies offered them little protection. Ford recently settled sexual and racial harassment cases at the two factories for $10 million.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Bennett, said Thursday the governor \u201cis very confident he will be cleared in any investigation,\u201d calling the relationship \u201ca personal matter that presents no matters of public or legal interest.\u201d\n\nThe woman with whom Mr. Greitens, who was elected in 2016, had the affair is a St. Louis-area hairdresser, according to Albert Watkins, a lawyer for the woman\u2019s former husband. Mr. Watkins said that she had told her then-husband in 2015 that Mr. Greitens had been a customer at the hair salon where she cut his hair and that during their first sexual encounter, Mr. Greitens had threatened her with retribution if she revealed their relationship.\n\nMr. Watkins said his client had recorded the conversation, and Mr. Watkins provided a transcript and audio tape of it to The New York Times and other news organizations. The tape was first broadcast on KMOV, St. Louis\u2019s CBS affiliate, during the late evening news Wednesday.\n\nNeither the woman nor her former husband could be reached for comment.\n\nRoy Temple, a former Missouri Democratic Party chairman, said in an interview that he had met with the woman\u2019s former husband in 2016 and he told him then that Mr. Greitens had threatened her. But Mr. Temple said the man was not willing to go on the record with the claims during the campaign because of the couple\u2019s children.\n\nMr. Watkins said his client changed his mind after becoming convinced that the story would come out because of \u201crelentless media inquiries.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy client realized he had no choice but to get the truth out in a way that was committed solely to doing the best he could to protect his family,\u201d Mr. Watkins said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Greitens held a conference call with donors to make the same admission of infidelity and denials of blackmail his lawyer offered the news media, according to a Republican official familiar with the call, hewing carefully to his public statements and adding only that he would remain in office.\n\nA former Democrat, Mr. Greitens, 43, has a r\u00e9sum\u00e9 that National Review described in a profile last year as \u201calmost too good to be true\u201d: Duke graduate, Rhodes scholar and Bronze Star recipient. He defeated the state attorney general, Chris Koster, on the strength of his record as a political outsider and decorated member of the Navy SEALs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he immediately began to clash with legislators, both Republican and Democrat, and is widely seen in the state\u2019s political circles as using the governorship as merely a steppingstone to the presidency. (Mr. Greitens secured the web address EricGreitensforPresident.com years before he ran for governor.)\n\nHis travels outside the state only fueled this speculation. Mr. Greitens appeared in Iowa, on the campaign trail in the Virginia governor\u2019s race and at a Republican conference on Mackinac Island in Michigan that is a traditional proving ground for White House hopefuls. At home, Mr. Greitens gleefully clashed with legislators and the statehouse press corps, making a show of his willingness to take on the establishment and boasting about his approach in interviews with conservative news media outlets.\n\nIn addition to accepting out-of-state speaking invitations, he aggressively sought to position himself in the national party by cultivating relationships with influential Republican figures. The former George W. Bush adviser Karl Rove, for example, got a call on his cellphone out of the blue last year from Mr. Greitens asking how he could help the party, according to a Republican briefed on the call.\n\nAs word of his affair spread through Jefferson City, the governor found little sympathy from his ostensible political allies, appearing to pay a price for his treatment of legislative Republicans.\n\nA group of Republican state senators signed a letter that called on the state\u2019s attorney general, also a Republican, to investigate the claims against Mr. Greitens.\n\n\u201cLike many Missourians, we find these serious allegations shocking and concerning,\u201d the Republican State Senate leadership said in a joint statement Thursday. \u201cAs this situation is evolving, we expect the governor to be honest and forthright.\u201d\n\nMr. Greitens has also come under fire for his extensive reliance on \u201cdark money\u201d political groups that are not required to disclose their contributors.\n\n\u201cWhatever happens around this issue, I already think we need a new governor, somebody who doesn\u2019t deal in dark money,\u201d said State Senator Rob Schaaf, a Republican, alluding to Mr. Greitens\u2019s affair. \u201cFor me, this is just another problem.\u201d", "title": "Gov. Eric Greitens of Missouri Admits Affair but Denies Threats", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Much of the federal government officially shut down early Saturday morning after Senate Democrats, showing remarkable solidarity in the face of a clear political danger, blocked consideration of a stopgap spending measure to keep the government operating.\n\nThe shutdown, coming one year to the day after President Trump took office, set off a new round of partisan recriminations and posed risks for both parties. It came after a fruitless last-minute negotiating session at the White House between Mr. Trump and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader.\n\nWith just 50 senators voting in favor, Senate Republican leaders fell well short of the 60 votes necessary to proceed on the spending measure, which had passed the House on Thursday. Five conservative state Democrats voted for the spending measure. Five Republicans voted against it, although one of those, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, did so for procedural reasons.\n\nAs the clock ticked toward midnight, when funding for the government was set to expire, senators huddled on the floor of the crowded Senate chamber, searching for some way forward.", "title": "Government Shutdown Begins as Budget Talks Falter in Senate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "But a key part of the deal, a pledge by Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, to allow an immigration vote in the coming weeks, sets the stage for a battle over the so-called Dreamers, young undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States illegally as children.\n\nLawmakers in the House and Senate are offering drastically different visions of how to resolve their fate. But those on both sides of the debate, as well as advocates for immigrants\u2019 rights, said that ultimately Mr. Trump would need to get involved for the immigration dispute to be settled.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s intentions were hard to discern, even as he took time to jab at the Democrats.\n\n\u201cBig win for Republicans as Democrats cave on Shutdown,\u201d the president said on Twitter at 11:30 p.m.\n\nThe message continued: \u201cNow I want a big win for everyone, including Republicans, Democrats and DACA,\u201d referring to the Dreamers, \u201cbut especially for our Great Military and Border Security. Should be able to get there. See you at the negotiating table!\u201d\n\nThe vote in the Senate was lopsided: 81 senators voted to end the shutdown while 18 \u2014 two Republicans and the rest of the Democrats and an independent who caucuses with them \u2014 sided against the measure. In the House, the vote was 266 to 150, with about three-quarters of Democrats opposed.", "title": "Government Shutdown Ends After 3 Days of Recriminations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "A major lingering question was how a compromise might pave the way for passage of legislation to protect the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers. Their status is in jeopardy after President Trump moved last year to end an Obama-era program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, that shields them from deportation. Mr. Trump gave Congress until early March to find a resolution to the issue.\n\nFor as long as the government is closed, the White House has said it will not entertain demands on immigration. Senators in the bipartisan group proceeded anyway in discussing a compromise in which there would be some kind of promise that the Senate would address the issue in the coming weeks.\n\n\u201cWe want to see a commitment to take up immigration,\u201d said Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, \u201cwith a belief that we\u2019ll get to a good result for Dreamers.\u201d\n\nSenator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona, said it was best for Mr. Trump to let the Senate work out its own solution.\n\n\u201cI just don\u2019t think it helps for him to be involved at all right now,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump has vacillated on an immigration deal in recent weeks, leaving both sides confused as to what kind of legislation he might accept.", "title": "Government Shutdown Goes Into Monday as Senate Inches Toward Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nShowdown over shutdown\n\n\u2022 Senate Democrats looked ready to block a stopgap bill that passed the House late Thursday in a bid to keep much of the government running past midnight tonight.\n\nThe Democrats are intent on securing concessions that would, among other things, protect some young immigrants from deportation. We break down the arguments.\n\nThe atmosphere has not been helped by a public spat between President Trump and his chief of staff, John Kelly, over the proposed border wall. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nA lose-lose situation?\n\n\u2022 A government shutdown, which could come at the end of this week, would bring unknown consequences for lawmakers in both parties. We clarify what\u2019s at stake.\n\nSome Democrats insist that any bill to fund the government must also protect the 800,000 young immigrants known as Dreamers. But 10 Democratic senators are up for re-election this fall in states with little sympathy for undocumented immigrants.\n\nRepublicans face their own uncertainties: \u201cTo believe that you can successfully blame Democrats for a shutdown over the DACA debate is na\u00efve,\u201d said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, referring to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which protects Dreamers.", "title": "Government Shutdown, California, Dolores O\u2019Riordan: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 France is struggling to keep up with the constant stream of new migrants, leaving hundreds homeless on the icy streets of Paris. Some of them, including Jibran from Afghanistan, above, shared their stories. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Spanish prosecutors will ask the Danish authorities to arrest Carles Puigdemont, the former Catalan leader, if he travels to Copenhagen for a debate he is billed to host. [The New York Times]", "title": "Government Shutdown, Davos, Syria: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "_____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. Qatar is in the fight of its life.\n\nIts largest neighbors, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, have led a punishing air and sea boycott. Diplomatic ties were severed, and its only land border, to Saudi Arabia, was shut down.\n\nIn recent decades the nation has gotten very rich, very fast. But the emir, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, has finally found a problem that money alone can\u2019t fix.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Across the conservative South, hot-button social issues are gaining little traction in statehouses this year.\n\nStates appear wary of provoking a corporate backlash of the kind North Carolina faced when it passed a measure restricting restroom access for transgender people in 2016. Lawmakers have little appetite for divisive battles.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t go to war on everything all the time,\u201d said Greg Snowden, a Republican state representative in Mississippi.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. It\u2019s no grand surprise to see the New England Patriots back in the Super Bowl. It can feel as if they own the stage.\n\nTheir challengers, the browbeaten Philadelphia Eagles, have an irresistible story line as the anti-Patriots, a franchise with a rich history of letdowns relying on a backup quarterback. Before the Eagles\u2019 victory in the N.F.C. Championship game, the police in Philadelphia made sure to slather street poles with Crisco to deter any foolhardy celebrants from trying to scale them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two teams face off in Minneapolis on Feb. 4.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. About 100 women have now recounted sexual abuse at the hands of Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar at the sentencing hearing for the former U.S.A. Gymnastics team doctor. More women shared their personal stories in horror-filled detail on Monday, while asking how it could have gone on for decades.\n\nSeveral top U.S.A. Gymnastics board members, including the chairman, resigned on Sunday. Lawmakers have also called for the resignation of the president of Michigan State University, where Dr. Nassar was employed.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. In six hours, a young man in New Hampshire overdosed four times. He threatened to kill himself, and his father said he couldn\u2019t live with him anymore. The day ended when he was involuntarily admitted to a hospital, taken there in an ambulance under a police escort.\n\nThe man, Patrick Griffin, and his family allowed The Times to follow him for much of the past year because they wanted people to understand the realities of living with drug addiction and how it upends families. When they weren\u2019t in a state of emergency, they were bracing for the next.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Latino actors, the minority group that Hollywood excludes the most onscreen, are waiting for their own #OscarsSoWhite moment. There are unlikely to be any Hispanic actors named when this year\u2019s Academy Awards nominees are announced on Tuesday.\n\nAbove, the only three Hispanic actors to win an Academy Award in the past 20 years: Benicio del Toro, Pen\u00e9lope Cruz and Javier Bardem.\n\nHoping to avoid a repeat of last year\u2019s embarrassing best picture mix-up, PwC, the accounting firm that tabulates the voting, has adopted some new rules. They include a strict directive for the backstage accountants: no phones or social media during the ceremony.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. SpaceX is preparing for the maiden flight of the most powerful rocket flying today. It could launch within weeks, and some advocates say it could be the quickest and cheapest path for astronauts to go back to the moon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSign up for our space calendar if you want to know when it launches, or if you\u2019d like to be notified of eclipses, meteor showers and other good reasons to look up.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, there are no cashiers or registers at Amazon Go, a new mini-market in Seattle that feels like a store of the future. Instead, shoppers \u2014 who must have the store\u2019s smartphone app installed \u2014 get automatically charged for what they take home, never once needing to pull out a wallet.\n\nThe company won\u2019t say much about the technology that enables it, but hundreds of small cameras are visible. Our reporter tried his best to shoplift (with Amazon\u2019s blessing), but he wasn\u2019t able to fool the cameras.\n\nCongratulations, you made it through Monday. We hope you have a spectacular night.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday.
