Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Government Shutdown, Jerusalem, Super Bowl: Your Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Daniel Victor", "David Scull"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Schumer and Trump came close to a deal on Friday afternoon.\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Trump and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the top Democrat in the Senate, came close to an agreement to avert a government shutdown over lunch on Friday, but their consensus broke down later in the day when the president and his chief of staff demanded more concessions on immigration, according to people on both sides familiar with the lunch and follow-up calls between Mr. Trump and Mr. Schumer.\n\nThe negotiations between Mr. Trump and Mr. Schumer, fellow New Yorkers who have known each other for years, began when the president called Mr. Schumer Friday morning, giving the White House staff almost no heads-up. In a lengthy phone conversation, both men agreed to seek a permanent spending deal rather than the stopgap measure being negotiated by lawmakers on Capitol Hill.\n\nLess than an hour later, Mr. Schumer was meeting with Mr. Trump over cheeseburgers in the president\u2019s study next to the Oval Office. The White House chief of staff, John F. Kelly, was there, as was Mr. Schumer\u2019s chief of staff, Mike Lynch.\n\nRead more from Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman \u00bb\n\nEven as the shutdown dominates headlines, it could be forgotten by November.\n\nIn the fall of 2013, Republican hard-liners engineered a 16-day shutdown of the federal government, implausibly insisting that President Barack Obama acquiesce to their demand that the Affordable Care Act be stripped of all funding.\n\nThe gambit failed miserably. The Republican Party\u2019s already low standing in public opinion polls plunged further. Mr. Obama and Democratic lawmakers were widely seen as victorious.\n\nThen the following November, something happened that plainly informed the moves of Democrats today as they drove the government toward another shutdown: Voters handed Republicans overwhelming victories and a Senate majority \u2014 in large part because of dissatisfaction with the man in the White House. The shutdown was a distant memory.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think anybody paid a big price for it,\u201d Senator Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat who is facing a competitive re-election race this fall, said of the 2014 election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Democrats on the ballot in many of the states that President Trump carried, the fresh government shutdown is unmistakably perilous, especially if it is seen as a strong-armed move to protect undocumented immigrants brought to this country illegally as children. And Mr. Manchin vote to keep the government open, as did four other Trump-state Democrats.\n\nRead more from Jonathan Martin \u00bb\n\nLindsey Graham proposed a three-week extension.\n\nSenator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, released a statement proposing a three-week funding extension, a week shorter than the bill the House had passed.\n\nIn the statement, he said that he thought that lawmakers were \u201cinside the ten yard line\u201d on finding solutions to immigration and other issues involved in the debate over the spending bill.\n\nSoon after Mr. Graham\u2019s statement, Mr. Trump interjected on Twitter casting doubt on whether lawmakers can reach a deal.\n\nWhite House officials outlined what may be involved in a shutdown.\n\nVideo\n\nOfficials at the White House Office of Management and Budget spent the past week consulting with federal agencies on contingency plans in the event of a shutdown, the fourth time in the past year that they have had to make such preparations.\n\nMore than 1 million active duty military personnel will serve with no lapse, they said, but could not be paid until the shutdown ends. Agencies such as the Department of Energy that have funding that is not subject to annual appropriations can use that money to stay open, the officials said, and the administration is encouraging them to do so. Most mandatory programs \u2014 entitlements such as Social Security that are automatically funded rather than subject to congressional appropriations \u2014 can continue without disruption.\n\nOfficials said Mr. Trump may travel on Air Force One to carry out his constitutional responsibilities, such as a planned trip to Davos, Switzerland, next week \u2014 although it was not clear if trips to Mar-a-Lago, his exclusive Palm Beach club, for golf and socializing, such as the one he had planned for this weekend, would fall into that category.\n\nVideo\n\nOverall, the senior officials said, the administration was working to minimize the effect of the shutdown on Americans. But some things will have to wait. One official said there could be no work, at least in the short term, on the president\u2019s forthcoming budget request for 2019 as long as a shutdown remained in effect.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Julie Hirschfeld Davis\n\nPhoto\n\nMulvaney went from shutdown instigator to government defender.\n\nMr. Mulvaney was once a ringleader of the so-called Shutdown Caucus when he helped orchestrate the shuttering of the government in 2013 as a hard-right member of the House.\n\nNow, as Mr. Trump\u2019s budget director, he is doing his best to avert one. At a White House briefing on Friday, Mr. Mulvaney insisted that a shutdown was not a desirable outcome, and that unlike the last such scenario under President Barack Obama in 2013, the Trump administration was doing everything possible to avoid a funding lapse. He said that Democrats \u201cweaponized\u201d the shutdown back then for political purposes.\n\nThe tune on Friday was much different from five years ago when it was Mr. Mulvaney who dared Democrats over funding for the Affordable Care Act. Mr. Mulvaney also helped spearhead the debt ceiling brinkmanship in 2011 over Republican demands to cut Planned Parenthood funding.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRepublicans did bear much of the responsibility for the 2013 shutdown, and Mr. Mulvaney at the time tried to play down the effect that the standoff was having on the government.\n\n\u201cIn many ways, then, this is a government \u2018slowdown\u2019 more than it is a shutdown,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd while Mr. Mulvaney was quick to assail Mr. Obama\u2019s lack of leadership for the most recent shutdown, he said Friday that Mr. Trump should face no such blame if a shutdown happens on his watch.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no way you can lay this at the feet of the president of the United States,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nDon\u2019t worry about that Yosemite vacation.\n\nNational Parks will remain open despite a government shutdown, the Department of Interior announced Thursday in a move that could help assuage public anger at Republicans if Congress fails to agree to a budget.\n\nIncluding the Lincoln Memorial and the Grand Canyon, more than 400 National Park Service parks and properties have been the most visible faces of past government shutdowns.\n\nThe last time Congress failed to agree on a budget, in 2013, a group of veterans aided by Republican lawmakers ignored barricades at the World War II memorial in Washington to visit the site. In southeastern Utah, county commissioners decided to reopen Natural Bridges National Monument in act of self-declared civil disobedience.\n\n\u201cWe fully expect the government to remain open; however, in the event of a shutdown, national parks will remain as accessible as possible while still following all applicable laws and procedures,\u201d Heather Swift, an Interior Department spokeswoman, said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe noted that some services that require staffing and maintenance, like campgrounds and full-service restrooms, will not operate.\n\n\u201cThe American public and especially our veterans who come to our nation\u2019s capital will find war memorials and open-air parks open to the public,\u201d she said.\n\nJacque Simon, the public policy director for the American Federation of Government Employees, the largest federal employee union, said federal workers have not yet been given any instructions about how agencies plan to operate or whom will be sent home if a shutdown occurs. Keeping the parks open, she said, is a smart political move.\n\n\u201cThe White House is very conscious of what\u2019s popular and what\u2019s not, and I think one of the memorable images from the last shutdown was World War II veterans who had come to D.C. to visit the then-relatively new World War II Memorial being turned away. It was not a good visual,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Simon said a shutdown would be an \u201ceconomic disaster\u201d for federal employees, and said she is concerned that national parks my remain open by the government paying contractors while sending federal workers on furlough. That, she said, would amount to an illegal privatization of the work force.\n\n\u201cWe will be watching that very closely,\u201d she said.\n\nEnvironmental activists criticized the plan to keep open the national parks, calling it dangerous to visitors as well as illegal under the Anti-Deficiency Act of 1998 that mandates the government can\u2019t spend funds that haven\u2019t been appropriated.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nothing more than a baldfaced attempt to divert Americans\u2019 attention away from the G.O.P.\u2019s extreme agenda,\u201d Scott Slesinger, the legislative director for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said in a statement.\n\n\u2014 Lisa Friedman\n\nShutdown comes at a terrible time for the I.R.S.\n\nMr. Trump has warned that a government shutdown could blunt the effect of his tax cuts, and he could have a point.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTax filing season starts in less than two weeks, and the Internal Revenue Service, which has been swamped with work trying to carry out the new tax law, may take a big hit. That could take a toll on the tax collection agency\u2019s ability to ensure a smooth transition and deal with the tsunami of questions coming from confused taxpayers.\n\nAbout 56 percent of I.R.S. employees are set to be sent home in the shutdown.\n\nAnd it comes at a time when the agency is already understaffed, having lost 21,000 full-time employees since 2010 as its budget has dwindled.\n\n\u2014 Alan Rappeport", "title": "Government Shuts Down as Bill to Extend Funding Is Blocked; Senate Adjourns for the Night", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "One such incident is intolerable, and it opened our eyes to the urgent need for real reform because we simply cannot risk another. A criminal justice system that ignores its cornerstone principle to the detriment of anyone \u2014 whether they are white, black, Latino, rich or poor \u2014 delegitimizes it. And we cannot allow this to persist.\n\nThis year, I am sending a bill to the State Legislature that will close the gap between what our criminal justice system says and what it does.\n\nThe bill will reform our bail system so that anyone facing misdemeanor or nonviolent felony charges should be released without bail. Those who pose a current danger to a person or persons or pose a risk of flight can still be held in detention, with due process, but no longer will people go to jail for the crime of being poor.\n\nIn addition to bail reform, we also need discovery reform. New York is one of only 10 states where prosecutors are not required to share with a defendant\u2019s lawyers basic evidence, including police reports and witness statements, until just before the trial. Expanding discovery will ensure that attorneys have the tools necessary to adequately represent their clients.\n\nWe will also propose changing procedures and scheduling to move cases faster so that we no longer have people sitting in jail for years waiting to be heard. Backlogs often cause attorneys to request postponements and delays, frequently without the approval of their clients. We propose that any waiver to a speedy trial be put in writing and signed by the defendant.\n\nThese changes will build on the reforms enacted during my tenure as governor. Last year, we raised the age of criminal responsibility from 16 to 18, affecting thousands of young people who will have a brighter future. We passed video interrogation and photo array reforms, important changes that protect the integrity of the investigative process. We ended the Rockefeller-era drug sentencing rules that took discretion away from our judges and filled our prisons with nonviolent offenders, and we closed 24 prisons and juvenile detention centers, eliminating prison beds and reducing by more than 5,000 the number of men and women behind bars.\n\nPerhaps most significantly, New York became the first and only state to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate, and if necessary prosecute, police-involved killings of unarmed civilians.\n\nBut some improvement is not enough. Our tolerance for any continuing injustice is repugnant to our position as a progressive government and flies in the face of the great leaders who took on the fight in the days before us.", "title": "Opinion | Governor Cuomo: The Way to a More Just New York State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "REALITY: Many White House policies will hurt New Jersey. The new federal tax plan will raise taxes for many residents who previously were able to deduct all of their property taxes. Commuters were dismayed when the Trump administration indicated that it would not \u2014 at least for now \u2014 provide financing for a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. To counter Washington, Mr. Murphy has shown a willingness to be creative with the state tax code, though finding sufficient money for the rail tunnel without help from the federal government will likely be impossible. The new governor can also take steps to protect undocumented immigrants, such as providing state identification cards and driver\u2019s licenses and making them eligible for college financial aid. But immigration policy is ultimately set by the federal government.\n\nOn the Economy\n\nPROMISE: \u201cA stronger and fairer New Jersey is rooted in an economy that creates better jobs and provides higher wages that creates places where industries can grow and communities can rise, where innovative companies are born and where millennials want to live and where seniors want to retire.\u201d He added: \u201cfor small businesses, and women, veteran and minority-owned businesses to thrive instead of delivering massive tax breaks to a handful of select and connected big corporations that don\u2019t need them in the first place.\u201d\n\nREALITY: Mr. Murphy inherits a stalled economy \u2014 the unemployment rate is higher than the national average. The state has struggled to retain younger workers and the new tax plan could make things worse. The state\u2019s staggering pension debt has led to 11 credit downgrades in the past eight years. Still, a report by McKinsey last year found that New Jersey had the potential to grow its economy by more than $150 billion and create more than 250,000 jobs over the next decade if it shifted from its practice of providing tax credits to retain old businesses to providing incentives for start-ups. Mr. Murphy, a former Goldman Sachs executive, has embraced the idea of new incentives and on Tuesday talked about \u201ctechnology incubators.\u201d\n\nOn Education\n\nPROMISE: \u201cA stronger and fairer New Jersey funds its public schools and delivers on the promise of property tax relief. It makes a four-year college more affordable and provides free access to community college. And it creates new training programs to prepare our residents for jobs in an innovation-driven economy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nREALITY: New Jersey has the highest property taxes in the nation, driven largely by the way it pays for public schools. The state also has some of the country\u2019s highest paid teachers. Mr. Murphy said the state would fulfill its financing obligation to fully fund public schools as a way to lower property taxes, but it remains unclear how he would generate the additional revenue. Mr. Murphy\u2019s financial blueprint should become clearer when he delivers his first budget address on Feb. 27.\n\nOn Marijuana\n\nPROMISE: \u201cA stronger and fairer New Jersey embraces comprehensive criminal justice reform comprehensively, and that includes a process to legalize marijuana.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nREALITY: Mr. Murphy\u2019s push to legalize marijuana \u2014 which he frames as a way to achieve criminal justice reform while generating hundreds of millions of dollars for the state \u2014 will likely test his ability to marshal the Democratically-controlled State Legislature. While there are two bills that could lead to legalization, there are strong voices of opposition that will need to be reckoned with.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn First Steps\n\nPROMISE: \u201cI ask you to send me the bills, among others, to reaffirm our support for women\u2019s health and Planned Parenthood; to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour; to promote equal pay for women; to give every worker the peace of mind of earned sick leave; to tear down barriers to voting; and, to strengthen our gun laws.\n\nREALITY: Mr. Murphy quickly took action on some of these promises hours after his speech, signing an executive order aimed at promoting pay equity for women by prohibiting state agencies from asking the pay history of prospective employees. Some of his other promises will require legislative approval and though some bills, such as providing funding to Planned Parenthood, are pending, other issues, like increasing the minimum wage, will require intense negotiations.\n\nNotably absent\n\nMr. Murphy made no direct mention of two of the state\u2019s most pressing issues: its large public pension liability and its decrepit transportation system, especially the chronic complaints about the reliability of New Jersey Transit\u2019s commuter trains.", "title": "Governor Murphy Pledges a Progressive Course for New Jersey", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 In 1986, Paul Simon released his seventh solo album, \u201cGraceland.\u201d One year later, my fianc\u00e9 Haywood and I moved to Nashville. Haywood was driving my father\u2019s secondhand panel van with the fake wood-grain wraparound made of shelf liner that masked the previous owner\u2019s business logo. Attached to the van was a trailer too heavy for the hitch. I was driving the Exploding Pinto, the nickname derived from that car\u2019s fuel-tank fires, and on top of the Pinto were several hundred pounds of books in a homemade roof rack built of two-by-fours.\n\nBetween South Carolina, where we had just finished graduate school, and Tennessee, where we would start our new teaching jobs, lay the Appalachian Mountains. Getting over them in one piece would be the first real test of our lives as fully employed adults.\n\nTop-heavy and buffeted by winds, the chugging old Pinto struggled. My traveling companion \u2014 a cat who refused to use the litter box on the back seat \u2014 was perched on my headrest, her claws gripping my scalp as eighteen-wheelers barreled past us in the dark. In the cassette player on the passenger seat, Paul Simon was singing \u201cGraceland.\u201d It is not too much to say that \u201cGraceland\u201d got me safely over Monteagle Mountain when I was in danger of going over the edge.\n\nI grew up in a house without a stereo, and my parents\u2019 car radio was always tuned to big-band music, so my formative years were in no way informed by Elvis Presley, who would have turned 83 on Monday. But you hear a cheerful song just as you\u2019re thinking you might truly die, and you form a kind of bond with it. Driving over Monteagle Mountain with the cat latched to my head, I vowed to see his Graceland estate someday. How lucky to be moving to the very state where Graceland could be found!", "title": "Opinion | Graceland, at Last", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Preet Bharara, the United States attorney when the criminal complaint was unsealed, said at the time that there were \u201cno allegations of any wrongdoing or misconduct by the governor anywhere in this complaint.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Percoco and Mr. Cuomo were close political and personal allies for more than two decades, and Mr. Percoco\u2019s presence in a federal courthouse has the potential to reflect badly on both Mr. Cuomo\u2019s choice of friends and his choice of personnel.\n\nThe allegations against Mr. Percoco involve graft at the highest levels of the executive branch of state government.\n\n\u201cThere is a lot for the public to be concerned about here,\u201d said Susan Lerner, executive director of Common Cause New York. \u201cThis trial raises pay-to-play questions. This trial raises issues of using public resources for private gain.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt raises significant issues about how discretionary funds used for economic development are handled in our state, billions \u2014 literally billions \u2014 of taxpayer dollars,\u201d she added.\n\nMr. Percoco was indicted along with Alain E. Kaloyeros, the former president of the State University of New York Polytechnic Institute, and six executives of companies that had done business with the state; the defendants have all pleaded not guilty. Prosecutors had charged two overlapping bribery and fraud schemes, in a case that grew out of a federal investigation into the Cuomo administration\u2019s upstate economic revitalization plan, known as the Buffalo Billion.\n\nMr. Percoco is to be tried with three of his co-defendants; a second trial, which will include Mr. Kaloyeros as a defendant, will be held in June.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe think that a fair and open-minded finder of fact will conclude that Mr. Percoco is not guilty,\u201d his lawyer, Barry A. Bohrer, said last week. \u201cWe look forward to the trial.\u201d Michael C. Miller, a lawyer for Mr. Kaloyeros, had no comment.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the trial, the prosecution\u2019s star witness is expected to be Todd R. Howe, who pleaded guilty in 2016 to charges associated with the bribery scheme and has his own longstanding Cuomo connections.\n\nA onetime aide to the governor\u2019s father, Mr. Howe had been friends with Mr. Percoco since Mr. Howe hired him out of college to work as an advance man for the elder Mr. Cuomo. Mr. Howe later worked for the younger Mr. Cuomo when he was the secretary of Housing and Urban Development in Washington and, in 2014, he and Mr. Percoco shared an office during Mr. Cuomo\u2019s 2014 re-election campaign for governor, in which Mr. Percoco was the campaign manager.\n\nProsecutors said in a criminal complaint that in order to disguise the nature and source of the bribes that companies paid to Mr. Percoco, they funneled the payments in some cases through bank accounts and a shell company set up by Mr. Howe, who they had retained to help them obtain official state favors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis case is about a scheme that was cooked up between Todd Howe and Joe Percoco to line Joe Percoco\u2019s pockets with money from clients of Howe, who had business before the state,\u201d a prosecutor, Janis Echenberg, told Judge Valerie E. Caproni in December.\n\nTo conceal their schemes in their emails, Mr. Percoco and Mr. Howe used the code word \u201cziti\u201d \u2014 a term used in \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d \u2014 to refer to bribe payments, the complaint said.\n\nProsecutors have alleged that the energy company, Competitive Power Ventures, which was building a power plant in the Hudson Valley, paid more than $287,000 in bribes to Mr. Percoco, which were funneled through a \u201clow-show\u201d job for his wife, Lisa Toscano-Percoco, in return for official actions that benefited the firm. (She has not been charged.)\n\nThe prosecutors also accused COR Development, a Syracuse-area developer, of paying about $35,000 in bribes to Mr. Percoco for his help in, among other things, reversing a decision by the state\u2019s economic development agency.\n\nAs the governor\u2019s go-to \u201cenforcer\u201d for political agendas, Mr. Percoco was responsible for tactics \u2014 persuasion in some cases, outright threats in others \u2014 that have engendered bad blood among many of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s political opponents and even his friends. And few of those seemingly slighted by Mr. Percoco \u2014 and by extension, Mr. Cuomo \u2014 are likely to be running to the governor\u2019s defense in the event that the trial generates negative headlines.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Percoco case marked the second time that Mr. Cuomo\u2019s administration had been investigated by the Southern District prosecutor\u2019s office; in January 2016, Mr. Bharara announced the end of \u201ca thorough investigation\u201d into the governor\u2019s interference with an anticorruption panel that he had created and then abruptly shut down, saying there was \u201cinsufficient evidence to prove a federal crime.\u201d\n\n\u201cCuomo\u2019s political opponents could try to use this case to damage the governor, no matter the outcome,\u201d said Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic political strategist who has worked both for and against the governor in campaigns.\n\n\u201cHe has done well to separate himself from the other Albany scandals,\u201d Mr. Sheinkopf added, \u201cand now a scandal created by someone close to him is going to trial.\u201d\n\nIn his 2014 memoir, \u201cAll Things Possible,\u201d the governor described Mr. Percoco as \u201cthe total package: trained as a lawyer, he had the guts, brains and stick-to-itiveness necessary to attack any project \u2014 hard.\u201d And Mr. Cuomo added that \u201cduring the worst of times,\u201d Mr. Percoco could also \u201cmake us laugh.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo said when the charges were announced that if they were true, he would be \u201csaddened and profoundly disappointed.\u201d\n\n\u201cI have zero tolerance for abuse of the public trust from anyone,\u201d he said. \u201cIf anything, a friend should be held to an even higher standard.\u201d", "title": "Graft Trial Begins for Former Top Adviser to Cuomo", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "The 60th annual Grammy Awards were on Sunday. Here\u2019s what to expect.", "title": "Grammy Awards, Woody Allen, Ingvar Kamprad: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "In the days after the Grammy Awards, some griping about the winners can always be expected, with debates in recent years focusing on racial diversity and the institution\u2019s relationship with hip-hop.\n\nBut following the 60th annual Grammys on Sunday, two words uttered backstage by Neil Portnow, the president of the Recording Academy, ignited a controversy that has drawn rebukes from some of the most powerful women in music at a particularly fraught time, amid the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements against harassment and professional inequality.\n\nAsked about the gender representation among winners on the televised portion of the awards, during which just one woman was given a solo Grammy, Mr. Portnow told reporters that \u201cwomen who have the creativity in their hearts and souls, who want to be musicians, who want to be engineers, producers, and want to be part of the industry on the executive level\u201d need to \u201cstep up.\u201d The comments, first reported by Variety, spread quickly online and gave a viral push to the budding hashtag #GrammysSoMale.", "title": "Grammys President Faces Backlash After Saying Women Need to \u2018Step Up\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Me, I went retro and called dibs on Bubbe, the traditional Yiddish word for grandmother \u2014 though I never used it for my own grandmothers, in an era more disposed to assimilation.\n\nIs there a reason for this trendlet?\n\nSometimes, grandparents have pragmatic reasons for their picks. Given lengthening life spans, a family may already have a presiding great-grandparent, an Opa or an Abuela, which pushes the new grandparent to find some alternative. My friend Dale might have gone with Bubbe, but her children already call their 91-year-old grandmother Bubbe. So Dale will be DiDi to her new granddaughter.\n\nBesides, contemporary family life has grown so complex that the new arrivals may face a whole host of elders \u2014 grandparents, step-grandparents, former spouses of remarried grandparents. They all need to be called something.\n\nWhich may explain why Georgia Witkin\u2019s \u201cThe Modern Grandparent\u2019s Handbook\u201d actually lists 251 grandparental names (I counted), divided by gender into three categories: Traditional, Trendy and Playful. I wouldn\u2019t volunteer to be known as Sweetums, G-dawg, Faux Pa or Grandude, however playfully, but apparently some folks have.\n\nAnd who can criticize them? Nothing is more personal than a name, especially a name only a handful of beloved people will ever use. (My granddaughter\u2019s other grandparents also took a fairly traditional route, selecting Nana and Saba, the latter being Hebrew for grandfather.)\n\nBut my theory is that beyond the logical explanations for the name game, we can discern a couple of underlying motives.\n\nPartly, it\u2019s a boomer thing. Tradition didn\u2019t always seem a good enough reason for this cohort to go along with certain practices back when, so it might not seem like a good enough reason to be called Grandpa now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA generation of women who entered the labor force, and men who entered the delivery room, isn\u2019t so keen on the old standbys, perhaps. A certain rebelliousness, a desire for individuality, persists. Call me Z. Or, like a Montanan named Mitzi Cline, Gramzi.\n\nBut here\u2019s my deeper suspicion: However mightily my peers may pine for grandchildren and adore them when they arrive, some don\u2019t want to acknowledge being old enough to be dubbed Grandpop or Granny.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSuch names conjure up gray hair and orthopedic shoes, along with a status our society may honor in the abstract but few boomers actually welcome. We too often won\u2019t use hearing aids, even if we need them. We may not claim the senior discount at the movie theater.\n\nWe don\u2019t want these wondrous new creatures calling us names that signify old age, either.\n\nA few high-wattage Hollywood types have been quite open about their distaste for grandmotherly names. Maybe that\u2019s reasonable for folks like Goldie Hawn (\u201cGlam-ma\u201d), who have to contend with the shortage of roles for older actresses.\n\nMost of us aren\u2019t worried about casting directors, though, but about something else. My friend Ellen Edwards Villa sent her mother a \u201cgrandma\u201d charm for her charm bracelet when her first grandchild was born.\n\nThe gift came back by return mail. Her mother, a mere 69 at the time, objected that she wasn\u2019t old enough to be a grandma. She insisted her grandchildren call her Sweetie Pie, instead, and they did.\n\n\u201cGigi\u201d seems a particularly popular grandma alternative of late. It makes sense for Frieda Kasden in Rockville, Md., a friend who actually is a great-grandmother. In other cases, I think women just prefer to picture Leslie Caron, circa 1958.\n\nTrying to stave off aging with inventive names doesn\u2019t make sense, of course; you can be a grandparent even before you reach middle age. But ageism, like other prejudices, isn\u2019t rational. In fact, it\u2019s particularly irrational, the elderly being the only marginalized group that all of us, if we\u2019re lucky, will eventually join. But there it is.\n\nThe kids could have the last laugh, though. Often, grandparents wind up with some idiosyncratic or downright oddball name, based on what a small child can pronounce, or mispronounce.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAcquaintances have shared a long list of uncommon names bestowed by the grands themselves: Atti, Lito (toddler for Abuelito), Bammy, Yo-yo, Dander, Dodo, on and on.\n\nMy late mother-in-law was \u201cgrandma\u201d to her older son\u2019s sons. Then her first granddaughter came up with a monosyllabic moniker that was easy to say and suited her, somehow. To her three granddaughters and their parents, she was Fa ever after. She died 17 years ago and I still think of her as Fa.\n\nThis raises a terrifying prospect, of course. My own granddaughter, who is now 17 months old and can sound out quite a few words, is beginning to turn Bubbe \u2014 which is supposed to rhyme with \u201chubby\u201d \u2014 into something very different.\n\nShe\u2019s coming up with a name better suited to a running back at Ole Miss \u2014 and there\u2019s a possibility I\u2019ll be \u201cBubba\u201d for the rest of my life.\n\nOh no. No no no. Is it too late to revert to Grandma?", "title": "Grandude? G-dawg? Nonny? Boomers Name Themselves", "authors": ["Paula Span", "Generation Grandparent"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Like her, many of my sources declined to be quoted by name. I was struck by their reasons: Some, who expressed misgivings about the number of refugees, worried about being seen as xenophobic (\u201cIf you speak out, you\u2019re immediately painted with the Nazi brush,\u201d one man said). Others, who saw the killing as a crime of passion that had little to do with the background of the suspect, said they were worried about becoming targets for the far right.\n\nThis town, I soon realized, was united in grief but very much divided in how to deal with it. As old taboos were broken \u2014 I heard strong language regarding migrants in this traditionally liberal, tolerant town \u2014 new ones seemed to be emerging.\n\nEven the mayor hesitated before agreeing to speak to me. One of his colleagues had received death threats after urging publicly against using Mia\u2019s death as a rallying cry for hatred against foreigners. \u201cThey threatened his children,\u201d the mayor, G\u00fcnther Tieleb\u00f6rger, told me, shaking his head. \u201cThe irony \u2026\u201d\n\nI stopped at a kebab shop and chatted with the owner. He had seen Mia and Abdul, her Afghan ex-boyfriend, who later stabbed her, many times in the restaurant. They had looked happy and always sat in the window. What happened was a shock to him. But so was the reaction, he said.\n\nDid he think the atmosphere in Germany had changed?\n\nHe nodded. \u201cThe looks have changed,\u201d he said. His parents arrived from Turkey 22 years ago. He grew up here and has a German passport. \u201cBut people don\u2019t know that when they see me on the street,\u201d he said. \u201cI could have arrived last year. They can\u2019t tell. And I see that in their looks.\u201d\n\nI left him my card and asked whether I could use his name. He said yes.\n\nBut the next day, he called me.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t use my name,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is getting too big. Everyone is talking about it. I don\u2019t want any problems.\u201d", "title": "Grappling With Death in a Small German Town", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Zig, an app that aims to simplify users\u2019 consumption of news, is Mr. Carter\u2019s first public project since he left Vanity Fair last month. It resembles an Instagram of news: a feed of photographs culled from stories around the web, with the material tailored to a user\u2019s interests.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe idea, said Joshua James, one of the founders, is to deliver useful news without making readers slog through a dozen sites. \u201cI had been going to the same 15 websites for years, and they never knew what I wanted when I got there,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Carter offered advice \u2014 when the founders considered changing their logo, Mr. Carter said he liked the old one, so it stayed \u2014 but his most significant contribution was financial. He is one of several high-profile investors in Zig, along with the music producer Quincy Jones, the Hollywood mogul Ron Meyer and the concert giant Live Nation. Zig declined to disclose how much it had raised.\n\nMr. James and a co-founder, Adam Platzner, pitched the idea to Mr. Carter at a tech-industry conference hosted by Vanity Fair in 2016. (The third founder is John Tornow.) At the time, Mr. Carter was mulling the state of news; he recalled an assistant pointing out to him that millennials \u201cthink in more visual terms, than in textual terms.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat sort of sat with me for a bit,\u201d Mr. Carter said. \u201cAnd then when Josh and Adam came in and saw me and explained Zig, I thought this goes right to that.\u201d\n\nMr. James worked in the music industry, selling a digital start-up to Warner Music Group. Mr. Platzner worked briefly at Cond\u00e9 Nast before investing in media ventures like The Infatuation, a restaurant recommendation site. He is also a founder of Dream Water, a liquid soporific meant as a kind of reverse Red Bull.\n\nOver lunch last week at the Lamb\u2019s Club \u2014 once a popular dining spot for Cond\u00e9 Nast brass \u2014 the founders said that the presentation of news in Zig matched the smartphone habits of a younger generation steeped in Instagram. \u201cFor millennials, we\u2019ve built a delivery system that is familiar,\u201d Mr. James said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe photos that appear in a Zig feed double as links to the underlying articles, a referral system that the founders say could lead to revenue-sharing agreements with news sites. Users can also flip through dozens of photos inside the app, an ad-free way to quickly consume pop culture slide shows from sites like T.M.Z. and PopSugar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe app was originally designed for entertainment news, but Mr. Carter suggested that the founders broaden the scope. \u201cPeople follow Kellyanne Conway the way they follow Kim Kardashian,\u201d Mr. James said, recalling a lesson from Mr. Carter.\n\nEach user\u2019s feed is customized, with the mix of subjects (politics, pop culture) and celebrities (movie stars, members of the Trump administration) determined by his social media activity. Users can also share articles with friends, superimposing a photograph of themselves reacting to a story \u2014 a thumbs-up for a Time\u2019s Up pin, for instance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile honing the idea, the members of the Zig team received coveted invites to last year\u2019s Vanity Fair Oscar party in Beverly Hills, Calif. \u201cIt\u2019s been fun,\u201d Mr. Platzner said. \u201cGraydon\u2019s been good to us.\u201d\n\nMr. Carter said that the founders \u201chave a very good chance of creating something that has lasting value.\u201d\n\nBut the former magazine editor said that he was setting his own ambitions beyond the media realm.\n\n\u201cThis is more of an outlier to what I will be planning over the next six months,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is not my life\u2019s work going forward. But I\u2019m willing to help them in any possible way I can.\u201d\n\nAny details about those other projects? Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "ATHENS \u2014 Greek lawmakers on Monday approved new measures demanded by international creditors, including cuts to benefits for large families and restrictions on trade unions, creating the basis for additional bailout funding.\n\nAddressing Parliament, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who backed the legislation, said the vote would move Greece a step closer to emerging from its third international bailout, which expires in August.\n\n\u201cWe are a breath away from the end of the program and the definitive end to the memorandums,\u201d Mr. Tsipras said, referring to the three loan agreements Greece has signed with foreign creditors since it verged on bankruptcy in 2010.\n\n\u201cThis gives hope and courage to millions of our fellow citizens who all these years have made large sacrifices and now finally see light and a way out,\u201d Mr. Tsipras said, referring to years of pension cuts and tax increases.", "title": "Greece Adopts New Austerity Measures to Placate Creditors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nATHENS \u2014 Greece has passed a law to limit the powers of Islamic courts in a northern region that is home to about 100,000 Muslims, restricting the application of religious law in the country and giving Muslims the option to take civil cases to Greek courts.\n\nLawmakers from all Greek parties except the far-right Golden Dawn voted on Tuesday in favor of the law, which Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras described as a \u201chistoric step\u201d that \u201cbroadens and deepens equality before the law to all Greeks.\u201d\n\nThe legislation was passed a month after the European Court of Human Rights examined an appeal filed by a Muslim woman in Komotini, Greece, of a case involving the application of Shariah, the Islamic legal code, over an inheritance dispute. A ruling in that case is expected this year.\n\nShariah has been applied in the northern region, Thrace, for nearly a century, the result of international treaties signed after World War I and the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, which led to population movements between Greece and Turkey, and affecting the rights of minorities. The treaties stipulated that Islamic law and custom would apply to the thousands of Muslims in Greece.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough many Muslims in Thrace are Turkish-speaking, the Greek authorities object to the term \u201cTurkish minority\u201d \u2014 a phrase Ankara frequently uses \u2014 amid growing concerns that Turkey has territorial designs in the region, chiefly over islands in the Aegean.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThrace is the only place in Greece where the Islamic courts operate, and Muslims who live there were required to take family disputes \u2014 including divorce, child custody and inheritance matters \u2014 to Islamic clerics known as muftis who, rights groups claim, often discriminate against women. The new law gives them the option of going to a Greek court instead.", "title": "Greece Scraps Compulsory Shariah for Muslim Minority", "authors": ["Niki Kitsantonis"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nATHENS \u2014 Tens of thousands of people gathered in Greece\u2019s second city, Thessaloniki, on Sunday to protest the inclusion of the word \u201cMacedonia\u201d in the name of the neighboring former Yugoslav republic amid talks by the two nations to resolve the longstanding dispute.\n\nDrawing what the police estimated at 90,000 people, the rally was the first major protest since Greece and the Republic of Macedonia agreed to join United Nations-mediated talks this month to settle the 25-year disagreement. Organizers say further rallies are planned.\n\nMany Greeks argue that the name Macedonia implies a territorial claim to a region in the north of Greece with the same name; Thessaloniki is its capital.\n\nGreece has blocked attempts by Macedonia to join NATO and the European Union. NATO\u2019s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, told officials last week in Skopje, the Republic of Macedonia\u2019s capital, that the name dispute with Greece must be resolved before the Balkan country can join the alliance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExploratory talks between representatives from both countries, mediated by the United Nations diplomat Matthew Nimetz, began last week. Leaked reports of the solutions being discussed led to vehement speculation and no shortage of nationalist rhetoric in Greece.", "title": "Greeks Protest Over Neighbor\u2019s Use of the Name Macedonia", "authors": ["Niki Kitsantonis"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "SORKIN: Greta, unsurprisingly, just said it better than I did.\n\nBRUNI: Let me get one last hot-button issue out of the way before we move back to your specific movies and \u2026 the upcoming Oscars! Will Kevin Spacey work again? Should he? This question came up with Roman Polanski, it comes up with Woody Allen. Should we care about, reward or punish what artists do beyond the parameters of their art? Should it affect their opportunities? Their reception?\n\nGERWIG: I would like to speak specifically to the Woody Allen question, which I have been asked about a couple of times recently, as I worked for him on a film that came out in 2012. It is something that I take very seriously and have been thinking deeply about, and it has taken me time to gather my thoughts and say what I mean to say. I can only speak for myself and what I\u2019ve come to is this: If I had known then what I know now, I would not have acted in the film. I have not worked for him again, and I will not work for him again. Dylan Farrow\u2019s two different pieces made me realize that I increased another woman\u2019s pain, and I was heartbroken by that realization. I grew up on his movies, and they have informed me as an artist, and I cannot change that fact now, but I can make different decisions moving forward.\n\nSORKIN: I don\u2019t like seeing anyone get disappeared. Personally, I don\u2019t think Kevin\u2019s going to be able to find his way back, but I\u2019m still rooting for a miraculous transformation.\n\nBRUNI: Thank you both for your candor. In reward: a happier topic! We\u2019re in the midst right now of people casting votes for the Oscar nominations, which will be announced on Jan. 23 and may well include both of your names. From a cultural standpoint, how much does who and what gets nominated \u2014 and who and what wins \u2014 really matter? Can you think of a nominee or victor that really changed America by dint of that recognition?\n\nSORKIN: It\u2019s sort of a two-part question, so I\u2019ll answer in two parts. Most of the films in the awards conversation this year are lower-budget films (\u201cDunkirk\u201d and a few others notwithstanding). High-profile award nominations give films like \u201cLady Bird\u201d and \u201cMolly\u2019s Game\u201d a reach they wouldn\u2019t otherwise have. As for a nomination or a win that changed the culture? I\u2019ll go with Hattie McDaniel.\n\nGERWIG: I do think it matters \u2014 when Kathryn Bigelow won the Oscar for best director it meant a great deal to me, personally. I imagine that it impacted other young women as well who had dreams of being a director. Suddenly, there she was, and more seemed possible to me. Also, I love the Mark Harris book \u201cPictures at a Revolution,\u201d which I think does an amazing job of looking at a moment of culture through the best-picture nominees of 1968 and what it meant for a changing Hollywood and a changing country.\n\nBRUNI: Aaron, I have to ask about the White House. You created fictional administrations in \u201cThe West Wing\u201d and \u201cThe American President,\u201d stretching the truth. Could you ever have stretched it so far as to come up with something like the Trump administration?", "title": "Opinion | Greta Gerwig, Aaron Sorkin: Hollywood Must Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The first New Yorker I ever knew was my mother, Chris Gerwig. I grew up in Sacramento, and that was the only place I\u2019ve ever known her to call home. She had, in fact, lived in Brooklyn briefly as a child, but that was not what made her a New Yorker. She had and has the spirit of a quintessential New York City gal. She\u2019s brash and smart and tough and funny, and was always the mother my school dreaded a call from because she would push and push and push until she got what she wanted. I was the only kid who was allowed to take both band and Spanish because of her insistence. She has more go-get-\u2019em energy than almost anyone I\u2019ve ever met.\n\nI was too young to remember New York City the first time I visited from Sacramento. My dad was there on business, and there are pictures of me at 2 years old toddling around Central Park, sitting on the statue of Balto the Alaskan sled dog hero and having \u201ctea\u201d with the \u201cAlice in Wonderland\u201d characters. In the photographs, my mom is right there beside me, looking like I do now, with her big (slightly gummy) smile and lanky arms and a desire to walk until she can\u2019t walk anymore.\n\nAt 5, I visited a second time. We were staying with family friends who taught at Columbia. It was summer but also somehow gray. As a Californian I had never known a gray summer. It was the late 1980s, so New York still had something seedy and dangerous about it. There was a story of the professor\u2019s wife walking into a drug deal going down in the hallway of their apartment building and how she street-smarted her way out of getting hurt. I didn\u2019t understand drugs or mugging, but I did remember an anxiety that was indistinguishable from excitement. It felt a universe away from the kids-on-bikes town that was Sacramento. It seemed impossible that it was the same country. And yet somehow, it also felt like home.\n\nSacramento is a place where you can always see the horizon. It is flat and beautiful and open. But I loved the crowdedness of New York City, how when it rained it seemed like the buildings were raining, not the sky. My mom held my hand tight as she walk-sprinted through the city. She was in her element here; everyone was moving as quickly as she was. She was joyfully sweaty. So was I. The Gerwig women belonged in New York.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe only thing standing out from the concrete and asphalt were the neon lights advertising kicks of different stripes. Musicals, alcohol, women. (I had just learned to read, and the concept of \u201cLive Nude Girls\u201d was extremely interesting.) When we waited for hours to get rush tickets for Broadway shows, Mom befriended people in line, just as she makes friends everywhere (the grocery store, the D.M.V., the library). They became very invested in the little blond girl getting in to see the show. And I did: \u201c42nd Street\u201d with Jerry Orbach. \u201cGypsy\u201d with Tyne Daly. \u201cCats\u201d with cats. At night, back at the apartment, everyone would play music \u2014 my dad on trumpet; his friend, the piano; his friend\u2019s wife, the tuba. Someone taught me how to play spoons. My mom would clap along, saying, \u201cYour dad is the one with the talent\u201d although she had talents that were less performative but no less impressive.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere were children in New York, of course, but they seemed confined to the playgrounds. \u201cIt\u2019s a great place to have a family\u201d is a true thing that is often said about Sacramento. To be a kid in Sacramento then was to be in the right place at the right time. Nearly everyone had a backyard; some people had pools and even their own personal jungle gyms; you could choose which kids were invited to slide and swim and swing. My mom did not believe in having your own play set. She thought it defeated the point of a playground, which was to make new friends and get comfortable with people who weren\u2019t your family. In Sacramento, she would walk me down to McKinley Park. It was a couple of miles away, but it had the best playground. I was walking that distance with her by the time I was 4.", "title": "Greta Gerwig: My Mother, My City", "authors": ["Greta Gerwig"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGretchen Carlson, who was Miss America in 1989 and in recent years has become a prominent voice against workplace sexual harassment, will take over as chairwoman of the pageant\u2019s board of directors, the organization announced on Monday.\n\nMs. Carlson, a former Fox News anchor whose harassment lawsuit against the Fox chairman Roger Ailes led to his departure in July 2016, will be expected to lead the pageant through its own harassment scandal. Three executives resigned last month after reports that leadership had used vulgar language to deride former winners in emails.\n\nMs. Carlson said on Twitter that she was \u201chonored to move this iconic program forward with so many amazing volunteers.\u201d\n\n\u201cEveryone has been stunned by the events of the last several days, and this has not been easy for anyone who loves this program,\u201d Ms. Carlson said in a statement. \u201cIn the end, we all want a strong, relevant Miss America and we appreciate the existing board taking the steps necessary to quickly begin stabilizing the organization for the future.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe organization also added three former Miss America winners to its board: Laura Kaeppeler Fleiss, who won for 2012; Heather French Henry, who won for 2000; and Kate Shindle, who won for 1998.", "title": "Gretchen Carlson, Miss America 1989, Is Picked to Lead Pageant", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "MEMPHIS, Tenn. \u2014 The Memphis Grizzlies were playing without Marc Gasol, but thanks to a huge effort from Tyreke Evans, who had 23 points, including three free throws in the closing seconds, along with 10 assists, they beat the Knicks by a score of 105-99 on Wednesday night.\n\nJaMychal Green added 18 points and 13 rebounds for Memphis, while Dillon Brooks and Jarell Martin added 17 points each. It was the second consecutive win for the Grizzlies.\n\nKristaps Porzingis led the Knicks with 21 points, while Enes Kanter finished with 20, including 18 in the first half. Courtney Lee and Michael Beasley had 18 points each.\n\nHaving struggled for much of the game, the Knicks pulled within 102-99 with about 47 seconds left on a 3-pointer by Lee, but Evans converted three free throws, including one when Lee was called for a technical with 17.8 seconds left.", "title": "Grizzlies, Minus Gasol, Still Manage to Beat Knicks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Kambez Barawi, who had come to Kabul for treatment of a wound, visited the office for a second day, pleading for clarity on when he could return home to western Nimruz Province. Mr. Barawi said he was paying $100 a night at a Kabul hospital. Travel by road, which cuts through Taliban country, was not an option.\n\n\u201cToday I came to the main office to ask again, and the answer I got is, \u2018We don\u2019t know when the flight will be possible,\u2019\u201d Mr. Barawi, 26, said. \u201cI am not able to travel by road because it is not safe. If it was possible, I would never pay for a plane ticket.\u201d\n\nKam Air\u2019s story is resilience in one of the most difficult aviation environments.\n\nThe airline is named for its colorful owner, Zamarai Kamgar. When not hunting in the wilds of Central Asia, he is easily reachable by friends \u2014 to help them get on any flight they want, whenever they want. His first experience with owning an airplane came when a warlord, whose troops he had supplied with food and fuel, could not pay the bill. Instead, the warlord repaid the debt by handing over a Boeing 727.\n\nSince its founding in 2003, Kam Air has not only stayed aloft, but also brought in enough profit to land among the country\u2019s top five taxpaying companies last year, according to its vice president, Farid Peykar.\n\nThe setbacks, though, have been big. A crash in 2005 killed 104 people on board. The airline was briefly blacklisted by the United States military, which said Kam Air\u2019s seedy-looking planes were involved in opium smuggling.", "title": "Grounded and Gutted, Main Afghan Airline Struggles After Taliban Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "He continued his learning at the Kulm Hotel in Switzerland and at several notable restaurants in France, including Ledoyen in Paris. In 1977, he opened his own restaurant in Milan, named after himself, and it quickly drew attention, receiving one star \u2014 signifying a very good restaurant in its category \u2014 from Michelin, the French rating guide. Soon came a second star (excellent and worth a detour), but the third star proved elusive.\n\nCritics of the Michelin system had long said it was biased in favor of French cuisine and a certain type of formal dining that ran counter to Italy\u2019s more relaxed mealtime tradition.\n\n\u201cI am convinced that my dishes can honorably compete with anybody\u2019s,\u201d Mr. Marchesi told The New York Times in early 1985, his restaurant still stuck at two stars, \u201cbut maybe we still are somewhat lacking in choreography, also because we in Italy don\u2019t really have a three-star public.\u201d\n\nMr. Marchesi mixed ideas he had picked up during his sojourn in France with regional Italian recipes and ingredients. One dish was a risotto adorned with a gold foil leaf.\n\nIn December 1985 the breakthrough occurred: His restaurant became the first in Italy to receive a third Michelin star.\n\nThe award, he said at the time, \u201cgives the prize not only to me but also to the renaissance of Italian cooking that has been in progress for the last 10 years.\u201d\n\nMr. Marchesi capitalized on his renown with numerous ventures \u2014 a line of frozen foods, for instance, and a signature Gualtiero Marchesi Liqueur. He closed his Milan restaurant in 1992 but quickly opened another about 45 miles to the east in the luxury hotel L\u2019Albereta, in Erbusco. He was soon branching out further, providing managing services to other restaurants and striking a deal with the Costa cruise line to create menus for its ships.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Marchesi\u2019s interest in promoting regional Italian cuisine grew along with his reputation, and in 2004 he opened Alma, a cooking school in Parma, to promote, as he put it, \u201chigh cooking as applied to everyday recipes.\u201d\n\nWith success came pressures, as Mr. Marchesi told The South China Morning Post in 1995 during a trip to Hong Kong as a guest chef.\n\n\u201cThe best part about being the first Italian chef to be awarded three stars was the satisfaction of gaining recognition for Italian food,\u201d he said. The worst part, he continued, was having to maintain that standard.\n\n\u201cEvery dish we prepare, every meal we serve, every day we have to reconfirm our reputation,\u201d he said.\n\nIn 2008, when Michelin knocked his Erbusco restaurant down to one star from two (it, like his original restaurant, had once had three), he called a news conference and announced that he was repudiating the rating system.\n\n\u201cI do no want to be judged by guides using points or stars,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cI realize I run the risk of not being in any guides, but this is a risk which I can take at my age.\u201d\n\nYet when Michelin dropped him from the guide entirely later that year, Mr. Marchesi was furious.\n\n\u201cFaced with a case of l\u00e8se-majest\u00e9, the Red Guide has responded with a beheading,\u201d he said. \u201cI regard it as an out-and-out attack on Italian cuisine and its symbols.\u201d\n\nThe next year, when a second Italian chef, Ezio Santin, rejected his Michelin rating, Fausto Arrighi, a Michelin representative, fired back.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey were excellent chefs, but in Marchesi\u2019s restaurants in particular, the food is not what it once was,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Marchesi caused another stir in 2011, when he created two new hamburgers and a dessert for McDonald\u2019s restaurants in Italy. One burger, the Vivace, he topped with ingredients typical of Northern Italy, including spinach; the other, the Adagio, featured flavors of Sicily. (The box for that one, according to The Atlantic, read, \u201cAn embrace of eggplant mousse harmonizes with tasty grated ricotta, fresh tomatoes, and beef.\u201d)\n\nSome culinary figures mocked him, but Mr. Marchesi brushed off the criticisms.\n\n\u201cIf I had to worry about all the comments that have been made about me, I wouldn\u2019t have arrived anywhere,\u201d he told The Atlantic.\n\nMr. Marchesi is survived by his wife, Antonietta Cassisa, whom he married in 1957; two daughters, Simona Marchesi Dandolo and Paola Marchesi Magada; and five grandchildren.\n\nStars or no, Mr. Marchesi was a pivotal figure for the current generation of Italian chefs.\n\n\u201cGualtiero made Italian cuisine known to the world and made it possible for Italian chefs to be recognized and celebrated,\u201d Mr. Trabocchi said. \u201cHis genius impacted and touched culinary schools and educational programs throughout the world.\u201d", "title": "Gualtiero Marchesi, Renowned (and Feisty) Chef, Dies at 87", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. King\u2019s assassination, on April 4, 1968, played a direct role in Franklin\u2019s creation. Eleven days later, a Southern Californian named Harriet Glickman wrote to Mr. Schulz, introducing herself as \u201cthe mother of three children and a deeply concerned and active citizen.\u201d In her grief, Ms. Glickman explained, she had been pondering \u201cthe areas of the mass media which are of tremendous importance in shaping the unconscious attitudes of our kids.\u201d She then proposed an idea: \u201cthe introduction of Negro children into the group of Schulz characters.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was acting on the feeling that maybe there was one little thing I can do,\u201c Ms. Glickman, who is now 91, told me in a recent interview. A civil rights and antiwar activist, she was shrewd to petition Mr. Schulz. \u201cPeanuts\u201d was at the peak of its popularity at the time, running in a thousand newspapers, with a devoted daily readership approaching 100 million. Mr. Schulz, as unassuming a man as he was, was a veritable godhead, revered in those divided times by Americans of all stripes.\n\nMr. Schulz wrote back to Ms. Glickman within two weeks, but only to tell her he couldn\u2019t fulfill her request. He and his fellow white cartoonists, he said, were \u201cafraid that it would look like we were patronizing our Negro friends.\u201d Undaunted, Ms. Glickman sent another note, asking if she could share his letter with black acquaintances. Mr. Schulz assented, though he again expressed reluctance to introduce a black character into \u201cPeanuts.\u201d\n\nMs. Glickman wasted little time in enlisting her friend Kenneth C. Kelly, a black father of two, who told Mr. Schulz, essentially, to get over his anxiety.\n\n\u201cAn accusation of being patronizing would be a small price to pay for the positive results that would accrue!\u201d he wrote. Mr. Kelly suggested that Mr. Schulz begin with a \u201csupernumerary\u201d black character, a de facto extra, who \u201cwould quietly and unobtrusively set the stage for a principal character at a later date.\u201d This cautious approach would serve the dual purpose of not burdening Mr. Schulz and \u201cPeanuts\u201d with the duty of making a Major Social Statement and presenting friendship between black and white children as utterly normal.", "title": "Opinion | Guess Who\u2019s Coming to \u2018Peanuts\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Right now, I\u2019m a bit embarrassed to be an American. Not usually. But now. If I see a tourist on the street looking lost, it\u2019s all I can do not to blurt, \u201cI\u2019m sorry about what our president said today and will say tomorrow,\u201d along with directions to the No. 6 train.\n\nI must have a lot of company. How else to explain the staggering pile of self-help books where Americans are offered the path to a better life via the rituals and outlook of other countries? Last year there were lessons in happiness and well-being, via hygge from Denmark. And this year? Japan is teaching us to seize the day (humbly). Sweden is showing us how to find balance and simplify our lives. And France is showing us, well, everything else. Naturellement. Just because they invented Camembert and guilt-free sex, they think they\u2019re soooo perfect.\n\nA FRENCHWOMAN\u2019S GUIDE TO SEX AFTER SIXTY (Greystone, paper, $17.95), by the psychotherapist Marie de Hennezel, immediately catches your attention because the cover shows a woman of a certain age glancing coquettishly over the bedsheets. But that age isn\u2019t 40. It\u2019s perhaps 75. So this isn\u2019t the American version of old; it\u2019s the French version, which is to say: old. And that\u2019s what makes this volume uniquely French: It\u2019s deeply un-American in its realism. Aches and pains, medications that reduce libido, a diminution of hormones that mean friction is tougher on our naughty bits and of course the occasional urge to cover all the mirrors in the house: Aging ain\u2019t pretty, Hennezel admits. Yet for many of us, Eros lives, and Eros wants its due. What\u2019s called for, then, is a revolution in the way we look at sexuality: a de-emphasis on orgasms in favor of kissing and caressing, more solo play to connect with our erotic selves and \u201cmaking affection\u201d as an alternative to making love. Feeling good through exercise and a healthy diet is paramount; looking younger through plastic surgery is mentioned not at all. Reading the stories of septuagenarians and octogenarians who are finding love or intimacy or sometimes just sex, one is reminded that the very French concept of joie de vivre \u2014 a sense of joy that comes from curiosity and playfulness, from looking outward instead of inward \u2014 is its own form of Botox.\n\nThis joie is very much at the heart of Jamie Cat Callan\u2019s lively PARISIAN CHARM SCHOOL: French Secrets for Cultivating Love, Joy and That Certain Je Ne Sais Quoi (TarcherPerigee, $19). Maybe \u201cParisian Charm School\u201d seems so thorough because Callan, who has written several previous books on various aspects of French life, is an American; she approaches her subject with anthropological rigor. Here that subject is French charm, which is some combination of intellectual curiosity, spontaneity, style and a soup\u00e7on of reserve. Charm, she points out, can\u2019t be Googled; it must be cultivated. Yet, at its heart, it\u2019s a tangle of contradictions. As a fashion consultant Callan interviewed put it, \u201cNever be too feminine, too girlie. Never be too complicated. Too obvious. Never look like you\u2019re trying. But you must try!\u201d Being French seems kind of exhausting. Still, we clumsy Americans can worship at this shrine and maybe pick up a few tricks. Who, after all, doesn\u2019t want to be like the woman in this line Callan quotes from Colette: \u201cWhen she raises her eyelids, it\u2019s as if she were taking off all her clothes.\u201d", "title": "Guides for Better Living From Around the World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Dmitriev has devoted the past 30 years to a search for mass graves of victims of Stalin\u2019s purges. Together with his colleagues from Memorial, one of Russia\u2019s oldest and most respected human rights organizations, in 1997 he discovered Sandormokh, where the remains of more than 9,000 victims were buried in communal pits.\n\nOver the years, the site has been transformed into a memorial with several monuments and a small wooden chapel. A day of remembrance is celebrated at Sandormokh every year on Aug. 5.\n\nNikita S. Khrushchev famously denounced Stalin in a 1956 speech to a Communist Party gathering in which he detailed the dictator\u2019s crimes. After the fall of Communism, a more honest examination of Soviet history was tolerated, though not always encouraged.\n\nSo at first, the local government supported the effort, with officials attending the memorial events. But official attitudes have been changing lately, particularly as Russia and the West have descended into a new Cold War prompted by the annexation of Crimea and the conflict in Ukraine.\n\nLast year, President Vladimir V. Putin, who has made the rebuilding of national Russian pride a cornerstone of his rule, said that \u201cexcessive demonization of Stalin is one of the ways to attack the Soviet Union, Russia.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs state-owned television channels began to glorify the Soviet past and promoted the image of Russia as a besieged nation surrounded by enemies, memories of past crimes committed by the Soviet state were suddenly unwelcome.\n\n\u201cThe authorities thought, \u2018Why do so many people come to Sandormokh every year to pay tribute to victims of Stalin\u2019s purges,\u2019 \u201d said Anatoli Y. Razumov, another Gulag historian and Mr. Dmitriev\u2019s friend. \u201cA decision was made to silence the sites of Soviet crimes.\u201d\n\nAt the end of December, Aleksandr V. Bortnikov, the head of Russia\u2019s Federal Security Service, a successor to the Soviet K.G.B., said in an interview to Rossiyskaya Gazeta, a government-run daily newspaper, that \u201carchive materials show that there was an objective side in a significant number of criminal cases\u201d opened during Stalin\u2019s purges.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMonths before Mr. Dmitriev\u2019s arrest, a number of government-friendly news outlets published articles by historians who suggested that Sandormokh could also be the site of a mass execution of Soviet Army servicemen by the Finns.\n\nMr. Razumov, among other historians, disputed the Finnish theory, saying that a similar tactic was used by the Soviet authorities when they tried to hide their crimes in the Katyn forest massacre and at other burial sites.\n\nNear the Russian city of Perm, a museum of a Soviet forced labor camp was replaced by a state-run museum, and an annual memorial event was diluted.\n\nIn this toxic atmosphere, Mr. Dmitriev\u2019s life\u2019s work became increasingly problematic to the authorities. Despite testimony in his favor by his adoptive daughter and a parade of writers, actors, musicians, the court declined to throw out the case.\n\nViktor M. Anufriev, Mr. Dmitriev\u2019s lawyer, said that someone in the government was refusing to let the case against Mr. Dmitriev be dismissed.\n\n\u201cThere is some force that wants to get the desired result,\u201d Mr. Anufriev said. \u201cAlso, they kept him behind bars for a year. It was the worst attack in years in the restive Casamance region in the country\u2019s south, where a separatist insurgency has dragged on for more than three decades.\n\nThe deaths led to fears of renewed unrest in the area, which had been relatively calm for the last several years.\n\nCol. Abdoul Ndiaye said late Saturday that seven others were wounded in the attack, which happened four miles outside the town of Ziguinchor. The military said it had stepped up its presence near the town.\n\nCasamance is separated from the rest of Senegal by the nation of Gambia.\n\nThere was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance, a separatist group that operates in the region, began fighting for independence in 1982.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The victims, all Senegalese citizens, were eventually released.\n\nSaturday\u2019s deaths came just hours after the release of two prisoners belonging to the separatist group, following negotiations that were mediated by the Community of Sant\u2019Egidio.", "title": "Gunmen Kill 13 in Restive Southern Region of Senegal", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Donald Trump \u2014 who yelled about \u201ccarnage\u201d in big cities during his inauguration speech \u2014 has said not a word about the Kentucky shooting except to tweet his \u201cthoughts and prayers.\u201d (Even that, commenters noted, came nearly 24 hours after the prime minister of Canada sent his sympathies.) It is highly unlikely this lack of focus was due to weariness. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to wonder,\u201d Kelly said in a phone interview, whether the president would have had a more intense reaction if the news reports suggested \u201cthe shooter was of a different ethnicity.\u201d\n\nTrue that. During his government-shutdown-immigration rants, Trump kept pointing out that the man who killed eight people with a truck in Manhattan had come to the country through a visa lottery system. That happened on Oct. 31. Since that time, 73 people have been killed in mass shootings in this country. But about gun regulation we have not heard a presidential peep.\n\nThe unusual thing about that terrible Manhattan tragedy is that it was not committed with a gun. Depending on how you count them, we\u2019ve had around 30 acts of terrorism since 9/11 that involved multiple deaths. More than half were committed by right-wing extremists (think Charleston church shooting). And virtually all of them were gun violence.\n\nSo, this is the time when we talk about gun regulation. Come on. Energize.\n\nWe are resigned to the fact that there is nothing, no matter how horrific, that will convince any politician in the thrall of the National Rifle Association to consider even the most modest gun-safety legislation. After the Las Vegas massacre, in which the murderer had purchased at least 55 weapons in the year leading up to the shooting, Kentucky\u2019s Governor Bevin seemed to feel the most unbelievable part was the call by \u201cpolitical opportunists \u2026 for more gun regs.\u201d He tweeted: \u201cYou can\u2019t regulate evil\u2026\u201d\n\nMaybe not, but you can definitely try to disarm evil. A super-modest bill banning bump stocks \u2014 the device the Las Vegas killer used to turn the semiautomatic rifles he could buy legally into functional machine guns \u2014 was introduced in Congress and then shuffled away. Las Vegas can\u2019t ban bump stocks since there\u2019s a state law prohibiting municipalities from doing that kind of thing on their own. Nevada is very strict about this, although not nearly as strict as Kentucky, which makes elected officials criminally liable for passing gun-safety laws.", "title": "Opinion | Guns \u2014 When Trump Can\u2019t Even Tweet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "But according to Ms. Nichols\u2019s lawyer, U.S.A. Gymnastics waited five weeks to notify law enforcement, and did not report the reason for Dr. Nassar\u2019s dismissal to Michigan State University, where he continued to practice medicine until he was arrested. Likewise, Michigan State did not alert U.S.A. Gymnastics when the university investigated Dr. Nassar in 2014, Mr. Manly said.\n\nU.S.A. Gymnastics wasn\u2019t informed in 2014 because the result of the investigation was that there was not a policy violation, \u201cand the local prosecutor\u2019s office reviewed the case and declined to press charges against Nassar,\u201d Jason Cody, a spokesman for Michigan State University, said in an email on Tuesday. \u201cAlso, the complainant was not a gymnast or a minor, nor did the complaint involve allegations of penetration.\u201d\n\nU.S.A. Gymnastics said in a statement on Tuesday that it was \u201centirely baseless\u201d to suggest that it had attempted to silence athletes or keep the investigation secret, and that it never tried to hide Dr. Nassar\u2019s misconduct.\n\n\u201cU.S.A. Gymnastics kept the matter confidential because of the F.B.I.\u2019s directive not to interfere with the investigation,\u201d the organization said. \u201cU.S.A. Gymnastics reported Nassar to the F.B.I. in July 2015 and to a different F.B.I. office again in April 2016.\u201d\n\nWhen Ms. Nichols reported the abuse, U.S.A. Gymnastics hired \u201can experienced, independent investigator to speak with her and others,\u201d it said in the statement, and that investigator recommended that U.S.A. Gymnastics report the abuse to law enforcement, at which point the F.B.I. \u201ctook over the matter.\u201d\n\nU.S.A. Gymnastics said it cooperated fully with the F.B.I. and refrained from discussing the matter in accordance with a \u201crequest to not do anything that might interfere with their investigation.\u201d\n\nMs. Nichols retired in 2016 and has been competing collegiately instead.\n\nWhen she announced that she would be leaving elite gymnastics, Ms. Nichols was a four-time United States medal winner and a member of the 2015 world championship gold-medal winning team, where she also won individual bronze on floor. She was not selected for the Olympic team, and said a knee injury was part of what prevented her from continuing.", "title": "Gymnast Maggie Nichols Wants \u2018Everyone to Know\u2019 About Larry Nassar\u2019s Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The judge consoled the 29 women and girls who spoke or had their statements read on Tuesday, saying they should not blame themselves.
