The Weeknd, a Canadian pop star of Ethiopian descent, was one of those who criticized the clothing giant, writing on Twitter that he would decline to work with the company in the future.\n\nIn a statement, H&M said it agreed with those who were \u201cupset about the image.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are deeply sorry that the picture was taken, and we also regret the actual print,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cTherefore, we have not only removed the image from our channels, but also the garment from our product offering globally.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. One, Meridia Metro, with 222 units, was completed in 2016. The Current on River, with 254 units, is going up on the site of a former tennis club. An art deco, 10-story bank tower and an adjacent building are being converted into 119 luxury apartments.\n\nThe projects include fitness centers, rooftop decks and other amenities sought by young professionals, and those fronting Main Street will have ground-floor retail. The hope is that new businesses will follow apartment dwellers downtown, creating a pedestrian-friendly core, burnishing the city\u2019s cachet and bolstering property values.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want it to be just a shopping area with a bunch of Starbucks,\u201d said Jerome J. Lombardo, chairman of the Hackensack Main Street Business Alliance, the public-private partnership championing the redevelopment. \u201cWe want to keep our local flavor. But we want lots and lots of eateries, maybe even a brew pub or an active brewery.\u201d\n\nMayor John Labrosse sees Hackensack, with its rail and bus links and proximity to highways, as a less-expensive Garden State alternative for millennials. \u201cA one-bedroom luxury apartment in Hoboken is now $2,300 or $2,400 a month, and we\u2019re looking at $1,700 to $1,800,\u201d Mr. Labrosse said. \u201cPlus, the accessibility of Hackensack is above and beyond Hoboken and Jersey City. We\u2019re right in the middle.\u201d\n\nDrew De Grado, 35, a Bergen County native who works from home in digital marketing, moved to a one-bedroom in Meridia Metro after considering Hoboken. I realized she had the exact champagne highlights against a natural base that I had been trying to get for years.\n\nShould I interrupt the conversation she was involved in? I didn\u2019t want to miss this opportunity to find the colorist who might be \u201cthe one.\u201d\n\nI leaned in and tapped her on the shoulder. She took out her phone and used my red pen to write the name and number of her stylist on the back of a manuscript that I was marking, and her name as well.\n\nTwo weeks later I entered a one-seat operation in the back of a shop in Long Island City. Two hours later I walked out with the hair color of my dreams \u2014 and at a reasonable price.", "title": "Hair Tip on the No. 7", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Comments by President Trump during a meeting with lawmakers this week have placed Haiti in the spotlight. Here are three books by Haitian writers that provide insight into the country\u2019s history of struggle and resistance.\n\nImage\n\nDANCE ON THE VOLCANO\n\nBy Marie Vieux-Chauvet\n\nTranslated by Kaiama L. Glover\n\n492 pp. Archipelago. (2017)\n\nIn this book, Minette, the \u201ccolored\u201d daughter of a former slave and her white master, hopes her artistic ambitions will help her escape poverty, allowing her to earn enough money to \u201cbuy all the slaves in the country so that I can free them.\u201d But though the art world does insulate her, she doesn\u2019t manage to escape the racial divides that plagued late 18th-century Port-au-Prince altogether, when the country was still colonized by the French. She falls in love with a freedman, but he is a slave owner and perpetuates the same cruel behaviors she despises in white plantation owners. Our reviewer said the book is \u201cbest read as a slice of Haiti\u2019s past rather than as a work of fiction.\u201d Vieux-Chauvet, one of Haiti\u2019s pre-eminent women writers, had to go into exile once the Duvalier dictatorship deemed her a threat.\n\nImage\n\nGENERAL SUN, MY BROTHER\n\nBy Jacques Stephen Alexis\n\nTranslated by Carrol F. Coates\n\n299 pp. University of Virginia Press. (1999)", "title": "Haiti\u2019s Resilience as Seen Through Literature", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m trying to play 100 percent \u2014 which I was close today \u2014 to run normal, and to run a lot,\u201d Halep said. \u201cBut I still feel it. It\u2019s there, but I can handle it.\u201d\n\nIn the last match of the day\u2019s schedule, which stretched more than an hour into Tuesday morning, Pliskova won, 6-7 (5), 6-3, 6-2, over 20th-seeded Barbora Strycova, a fellow Czech.\n\nPhoto\n\nPliskova hired away Strycova\u2019s coach, Tomas Krupa, in the off-season, which Strycova countered by hiring Pliskova\u2019s previous coach, David Kotyza. The swap led to a frosty atmosphere at the Prague club where they both trained, but the players were able to keep that subplot on the sidelines in their first encounter since the changes.\n\n\u201cI was just trying to play my game,\u201d Pliskova said. \u201cBecause I know if I would get into it and think about what everything happened with the coaches and with her, I would not be playing the best. I think this I did perfect. I was just really focused on my tennis, not on the things around.\u201d\n\nThat composure led the Open\u2019s on-court interviewer, Rennae Stubbs, to describe Pliskova as \u201ccool as a cucumber.\u201d The idiom bemused Pliskova, who later said that she would have to turn up the heat of her game in order to hit through Halep\u2019s relentless defenses in the next round.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI have to get my mind-set ready for this,\u201d Pliskova said.\n\nThere will be a similar challenge for Keys against Kerber, in a comparable battle of puncher versus counterpuncher.\n\n\u201cI think she has an ability to cover the court and anticipate like really no one else does,\u201d Keys said of Kerber. \u201cSo, for me, it\u2019s having to play aggressive but also consistently aggressive, because I know she\u2019s going to make three more balls than other girls may be able to get to.\n\n\u201cSo it\u2019s not feeling rushed and that I have to go for something crazy-big on the first one. I became acutely aware of the imbalance at the time of the white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Va., last August. Suddenly, there history was \u2014 an old history of American racism and nativism \u2014 speaking to the present loud and clear.\n\nThe rally was built around a single object: an equestrian monument to the Confederate leader and Civil War hero Robert E. Lee. A small alt-right army had gathered to protest its threatened removal by the city from a public park. Probably no one had given the statue a serious glance for years. But the alt-right had, and understood its power, which lay in its twofold history. This sculpture represented the Civil War, but it was of a later date. It was made in 1924, when a brew of Lost Cause nostalgia and resurgent racist anger was saturating the South. In that context, the image of Lee was both a memorial to the past and the standard for a white supremacist future.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Charlottesville rally was, as it was meant to be, explosive. And in the aftershock came a wave of monument-fever. In Durham, N.C., anti-right protesters pulled down a second Confederate statue. In the same week, in Baltimore, Md., on an order from city hall, workmen hoisted four Confederate statues onto flatbed trucks and drove them off into the night.\n\nThe iconoclastic impulse spread north to New York, where Mayor Bill de Blasio pledged to review a number of controversial monuments, not necessarily Civil War-related, that stood on city property. He called together a group of historians and artists together to take on the task. And this week, the Mayoral Advisory Commission on City Art, Monuments, and Markers \u2014 \u2014 led by Tom Finkelpearl, the New York City cultural affairs commissioner, and Darren Walker, president of the Ford Foundation \u2014 released a statement of the group\u2019s findings.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s a very by-committee document; measured, all-bases-covered, weighted with consensus, short on surprise. If anything could bring a fever down, this could. It lists a set of wide-angle questions the commission applies in making judgments. If monuments have the power to write history, who, in any given case, is wielding that power? Was the history true when written, and has that truth changed over time? Does the history serve positive or negative ends? Promote inclusion or divisiveness? If monuments are, like history, intrinsically complex, not easily defined as \u201cright\u201d or \u201cwrong,\u201d is complexity alone enough to justify a contested monument\u2019s continuing presence?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the questions, and a group vote, come suggestions for actions the mayor can take. He can let a monument stand as is; re-contextualize it through added signage or programming; move it to another public site, such as a museum; change or expand its meaning by adding new art; or remove it from view. (Destroying is not an option, and in my opinion should never be.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOf the four monuments the commission considered, all of them of sustained contention in the city, only one, an 1894 statue of Dr. J. Marion Sims (1813-1883) on Central Park at Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street, will be sent into exile. A South Carolina slave-owner and physician, Sims did pioneering work in gynecological surgery, but performed many of his experiments on black female slaves, and using no anesthesia. His statue, which has long faced East Harlem and roiled its residents, will be moved to the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, where he\u2019s buried.", "title": "Half-Measures Won\u2019t Erase the Painful Past of Our Monuments", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 In a flash of New Year\u2019s optimism, you write a hopeful essay, and since you\u2019re all in for hope, you invest in three pounds of collard greens and the thickest pork chops at the store, plus a pile of black-eyed peas, for a special supper on New Year\u2019s Day. You don\u2019t even care for collard greens or pork chops or black-eyed peas, but in the American South this is luck-producing food. The president of the United States is engaged in a war of insults with a nuclear-armed enemy, and this is no time to take a chance with luck.\n\nIt\u2019s probably not good parental form to urge your mostly-grown children to take at least one bite of black-eyed peas, but remarking on the food choices of the adults at your table is not your worst offense. Your real mistake is hubris.\n\nIn retrospect, the crowing tweet \u2014 \u201cWhen everything turns out O.K. next year, you can thank this Alabama girl, who is not messing around with luck\u201d\u2014 was definitely a bad idea. And the Instagram video of collards simmering on the stove was nothing less than a gauntlet-toss to fate. You are about to learn the cost of hubris, for the same universe that brought the Tweeter in Chief to office clearly does not stand down in the face of a black-eyed pea.\n\nBut on New Year\u2019s Day the extent of your transgressions is not yet clear. After supper, you chalk up the churning in your stomach to the pork chops and the burning in your eyes to the New Year\u2019s Eve party that lasted till 2 a.m. and the aching in your joints to all the dancing you did in uncomfortable shoes. The pounding headache is of course only a matter of last night\u2019s champagne.", "title": "Opinion | Happy Flu Year!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.\n\nGood morning. Happy New Year! How are you? Hope you\u2019re not feeling woozy and dry-mouthed and sad, with Ian Fleming\u2019s great line from \u201cMoonraker\u201d echoing in your head: \u201cChampagne and Benzedrine! Never again.\u201d It\u2019s time to start over, time for new chances. It\u2019s time to cook better, more often, and with more joy in your heart. (Really it is. You do what I\u2019m saying, and the food becomes more delicious, and the people you serve are happier. It\u2019s weird.)\n\nSo this is the year to learn to make pasta, perhaps. This is the year to learn to make pizza, I\u2019m fairly sure. And this is the day, absolutely, to make black-eyed peas, so as to ensure your prosperity throughout 2018, whatever happened to you when you messed around with the Upshot\u2019s \u201cTax Bill Calculator,\u201d in The Times. I like my peas with a smoked ham hock and plenty of kale, but, if you\u2019ve got the time or a pressure cooker, you might try it with a pig trotter, which will give the beans a silky lip-sticking quality that will lead you, eventually, to make a vat of trotter gear to add to all sorts of meals.\n\nTo go with it: Try this brown-butter cornbread, from Melissa Clark. Or this more cakelike cornbread that Chris Schlesinger used to serve at the East Coast Grill in Cambridge, Mass.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s dinner for you. Right now, though, you may be thinking about brunch. We\u2019ve collected a whole bunch of recipes you could knock off at midday on a national holiday, with a minimum of fuss. I like the idea of citrus salad with prosecco to start, with eggs Benedict to follow, and then an afternoon of \u201cThe Punisher\u201d on Netflix, interspersed with naps.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Cooking Newsletter Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nJan. 1 seems like such an arbitrary date to start a new year \u2014 and it is. The way it became the beginning of our calendar is simply a \u201cbyproduct of a political and religious history that few know much about anymore.\u201d\n\nMeaninglessness aside, the first day of the year can also inspire feelings of immense pressure. That \u201cnew year, new me\u201d mentality can create a sinking sense that if you don\u2019t get started on those resolutions right now, or swear off X, or do more of Y, you\u2019ve already set yourself up for failure.\n\nSure, self-improvement is great. Last week I even wrote about setting and keeping our resolutions. But relaxing and going about things at your own pace is pretty great, too. We have all of 2018 to work on those resolutions and goals \u2014 and if you haven\u2019t sent me yours yet, please do! \u2014 so today, let\u2019s just relax and get ready for the coming year. Here a few ideas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpend some time meditating.\n\nThis will take only a few minutes, and you\u2019ll be thankful you did it for the rest of the day.", "title": "Happy New Year! Start It Off by Relaxing and Centering Yourself", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Iranians discovered that billions of dollars were going to hard-line organizations, the military, the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, and religious foundations that enrich the clerical elite. At the same time, the budget proposed to end cash subsidies for millions of citizens, increase fuel prices and privatize public schools.\n\nThe leak appeared to be intended to tap popular resentment, and it worked. Telegram, a social media messaging app used by over 40 million Iranians, blew up with angry comments.\n\n\u201cIt made me angry,\u201d said Mehdi, 33, from Izeh, a town in Iran\u2019s poor Khuzestan Province, who asked that his family name not be used out of fear of retaliation. \u201cThere were all these religious organs that received high budgets, while we struggle with constant unemployment.\u201d\n\nLast Thursday, hard-liners tried to take back the initiative and embarrass the president, staging a demonstration in the holy city Mashhad, where hundreds chanted slogans against the weak economy and shouted \u201cdeath to the dictator\u201d and \u201cdeath to Rouhani.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nAn Iranian security official confirmed that the Friday prayer leader of the city, Ahmad Alamolhoda, a prominent hard-liner, had been summoned by Iran\u2019s National Security Council to explain his role in the demonstration.\n\nVideos of the gathering then went viral on social media, where people had for weeks been heatedly discussing the proposed budget. Frustrated Iranians elsewhere were emboldened.\n\nIn reaction to the protest in Mashhad, Hesamodin Ashna, a trusted adviser to President Rouhani, sent out a Twitter message on Friday, highlighting \u201cthe unbalanced distribution of the budget.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIran\u2019s military forces, active in several countries in the Middle East, saw their budget increase to $11 billion, a nearly 20 percent rise, he said. The budget for representatives of the supreme leader in universities was increased. An institute run by the hard-line cleric Mohammad Taghi Meshbah-Yazdi was to receive eight times as much as a decade ago.\n\nOnline anger reached a boiling point.\n\nFor decades, those living in Iran\u2019s provincial towns and villages were regarded as the backbone of the country\u2019s Islamic regime. They tended to be conservative, averse to change and pious followers of the sober Islamic lifestyle promoted by the state.\n\nIn less than a decade, all that has changed. A 14-year drought has emptied villages, with residents moving to nearby cities where they often struggle to find jobs. Access to satellite television and, more important, the mobile internet has widened their world.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOn Instagram, I saw a picture of a woman in Tehran with her S.U.V., who wrote she spends $3,000 on her pets each month,\u201d Mehdi said. \u201cA person can live here with that money for a year. I got angry.\u201d\n\nHis city, Izeh, was famous for being home to many who had been exiled by the hard-line judiciary. \u201cIzeh has changed a lot over the years \u2014 more people, but no entertainment, not even a cinema,\u201d he said. \u201cMany people use drugs.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, protests broke out in Izeh. The government news agency said two protesters were killed there by security forces.\n\nIn Tehran, the capital, Mohammad Alinejad had been sitting behind the wheel of his dilapidated Peugeot when he heard of the protests in Mashhad. \u201cI was cheering,\u201d he said. \u201cI want these clerics to go. They have destroyed my life.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe had been hit by shrapnel during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, and a piece had remained stuck in his head. His status as a handicapped veteran exempts his son from the mandatory 24-month military service, but when he tried to get the exemption papers he got stuck in a bureaucratic merry-go-round that is all too common for Iranians.\n\n\u201cI had to pay bribes, or else no one would help me, and in the end we didn\u2019t get anywhere,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe blamed the clerics for everything: privatization, corruption, inequality and long days with low pay.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t care if our country becomes the next Iraq or Syria,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I\u2019m so frustrated with them, that I just want them gone and we can think about the consequences tomorrow.\u201d\n\nIn Qom, the center of Iran\u2019s theological educational institutes, one cleric said he was worried about the level of anger.\n\n\u201cPeople are angry when they see how much money some clerical institutions and Friday prayer leaders are being paid in the budget,\u201d the cleric, Fazel Meybodi, said. \u201cMany of them are old and have no appeal to the youths. They must be changed.\u201d\n\nAs protests took off in about 40 cities across the country, Tehran remained largely quiet. In 2009, over three million people took to the streets disputing the elections.\n\nBut this time, many said they feared the raging, leaderless protests.\n\n\u201cThey are angry, and have a right to be, but there is just nothing more, no plan for the day after,\u201d said Hamidreza Faraji, a cosmetic and honey salesman who struggles to live a decent life.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t keep on going on to change our leaders,\u201d he said, standing in his shop, which like others nearby was empty of customers. No one he knew wanted Iran to become the next Syria or Iraq in the chaos that might follow, he explained.\n\n\u201cMany of the protesters shout, \u201cNeither Gaza nor Lebanon, I will give my life for Iran,\u201d Mr. Faraji said. \u201cBut we have entered this bad game in the region, so now we have to finish it. Just like we have no other option but to live with our leaders. Unless there is a better alternative.\u201d", "title": "Hard-Liners and Reformers Tapped Iranians\u2019 Ire. Now, Both Are Protest Targets.", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Drawn to the romance of treks to kill lions, elephants and rhinos and to photograph native tribes and storybook landscapes, clients flocked from around the world to Selby safaris, which were booked for years with clients like Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, the Maharajah of Jaipur, Prince Stanislas Radziwill of Poland and Western tycoons, industrialists and chief executives seeking thrills and self-fulfillment.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose were anticipated wonders not always to be found in the real Africa. In the Hollywood-inspired popular images of the 1950s, the great white hunter was a fearless Clark Gable or Stewart Granger, tall and deeply tanned, who brought down a charging rhino with a single shot while his arrogant client cowered behind him, and who later romanced the client\u2019s neglected wife after saving her from a snarling lion.\n\nThe reality was Mr. Selby: short and stocky, mild and self-effacing, a man who seemed to listen with his eyes. He had curly hair, a boyishly shy smile, and a wife and two children. He catered to men used to giving orders, not taking them, but did it with tact, avoiding upbraiding a client needlessly and almost never finding it necessary to save anyone. Neither he nor any client was ever seriously injured on a safari, though there were some close calls.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was not all shooting and campfire tales. A Selby safari required an army of bearers, cooks, skinners, porters, drivers and others; game licenses and financial transactions; transportation arrangements, from trucks and horses to planes and boats; and a complex coordination of supplies and equipment: guns and ammunition, food, water, tents, cots, radios, medicines, maps, clothing and a thousand other necessities.\n\nWithout cellphones or evacuation helicopters, Mr. Selby had to be the doctor, mechanic, chauffeur, gin-rummy-and-drinking partner and universal guide, knowledgeable about mountain ranges, grassy plains, rivers, jungles, hunting laws, migratory patterns, and the Bushmen, Masai, Samburu, Dinka and Zulu tribes. He spoke three dialects of Swahili. And he improvised; if there was no firewood, he burned wildebeest dung.\n\nHe was no Gregory Peck, but had an easygoing personality that made for good company in the bush. He coped with emergencies, pulling a client clear of a stampede or a vehicle from a bog, treating snakebites or tracking a wounded lion in a thicket \u2014 his most dangerous game. He was left-handed, but his favorite gun was a right-handed .416 Rigby, which can knock down an onrushing bull elephant or Cape buffalo in a thundering instant.\n\nSafaris changed dramatically in his time. In Kenya and Tanganyika in the late 1940s and \u201950s, he took parties hundreds of miles into trackless bush country by truck, pitched camps with comfortable though primitive amenities, drank gin by kerosene lamp, and pursued game by his own instincts. Safaris lasted two or three months. The showers were often cold, but the food was good and the game plentiful.\n\nIn his later years in Botswana, safaris went out for just a few weeks and focused as much, if not more, on photography as on hunting, although Mr. Selby preferred hunters. Photography buffs stayed in hotel-like lodges and went on day trips to scenic sites. More adventurous hunters and photographers were flown to rendezvous points and driven in Land Rovers to fixed camps elaborately equipped with electric power, refrigerators, flush toilets, hot showers, kitchens and dining facilities with silverware and table linen.\n\n\u201cAfrica itself has changed out of all recognition, both physically and politically, and the old-time self-contained safari would have no place to go in today\u2019s Africa,\u201d Mr. Selby wrote for Sports Afield in 2010, when satellite phones, computers and helicopters made life easy for the busy executive on safari.\n\n\u201cThere are hunters today,\u201d he added, \u201cwho would prefer to have experienced the sense of freedom of an old-time safari, as I am sure there were those who went on safari many years ago who would have preferred something along the lines of what is offered today. The two experiences are as different as night is from day; the only feature common to both is the name \u2026 that magical word, \u2018safari.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJohn Henry Selby \u2014 Harry was his universal nickname \u2014 was born in Frankfort, South Africa, on July 22, 1925, the youngest of six children of Arthur and Myrtle Evelyn Randall Selby. When he was 3, his family moved to a 40,000-acre cattle ranch near Mount Kenya.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSurrounded by a game-rich countryside, the boy learned to hunt from an old Kikuyu tribesman. \u201cHe taught me to use my eyes and ears as well as my nose, and to be patient in order to remain motionless for long periods of time waiting for an animal to come within range,\u201d Mr. Selby told The American Rifleman.\n\nMr. Selby attended local schools, traveling by ox cart, and later the Prince of Wales, a boarding school in Nairobi. After World War II, he worked for Mr. Percival, who recognized his potential as a hunter-guide, and in 1949 he joined East Africa\u2019s foremost safari outfitter, Ker & Downey, based in Nairobi. In 1956, after Mr. Ruark\u2019s book had made him famous, he formed his own safari company, Selby & Holmberg.\n\nIn 1953, he married Maria Elizabeth Clulow, known as Miki. They had two children, Mark and Gail. Mark died in 2017. Mr. Selby is survived by his wife, daughter and a number of grandchildren.\n\nIn 1962, as Kenyan independence loomed and political upheavals dimmed prospects for safaris in East Africa, he accepted a partnership in his old company, which became Ker, Downey and Selby, and in 1963 moved as its trailblazer to Bechuanaland, a British protectorate that became independent Botswana in 1966. It was a hunter\u2019s \u2014 and a photographer\u2019s \u2014 paradise.\n\n\u201cWhat we found exceeded our wildest expectations \u2014 a land which the passage of time had passed by, where nature had remained unchanged in the 20th century,\u201d Mr. Selby said in a 2013 interview for this obituary. \u201cThe vast savannas were teeming with huge herds of elephant, buffalo, kudu, zebra, wildebeest and sable. Lions were everywhere, showing little fear of man.\u201d\n\nFor 30 years, Mr. Selby ran company operations in Botswana, and guided hunters and photographers into leased concessions covering thousands of square miles in the Okavango Delta in the north and the vast Kalahari Desert in the south, home of the click-talking Bushmen. He cut tracks and built airfields in the wilderness.\n\nIn 1970, he established Botswana\u2019s first lodge and camps for photographic safaris. He hired guides and a large support staff for what became a dominant safari business in Southern Africa. After Ker, Downey and Selby was bought by Safari South in 1978, he remained a director, and even after resigning in 1993 he continued to lead safaris privately until retiring in 2000.\n\nIn 2007, President Festus Mogae of Botswana awarded Mr. Selby the Presidential Certificate of Honor in recognition of his contributions to hunting and photographic tourism.", "title": "Harry Selby, Renowned Hunter and Safari Guide, Is Dead at 92", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "To lump together sexual assault and sexual harassment is to draw focus away from the victim. Indeed, it is another symptom of a society so obsessed with patriarchy that even within one of the widest social movements in modern history (#MeToo), a fixation with men is the driving force.\n\nLUCY HALL, LONDON\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nDaphne Merkin claims that women she knows are saying \u201cgrow up, this is real life\u201d and \u201cwhat ever happened to flirting?\u201d What would be the condition of women today if we had accepted as real life the longstanding oppressions and disenfranchisement of women that existed a mere century ago?\n\nMost of the accusations that have been reported have involved forced sexual contact. And she must know some very brave women who, she says, have \u201ctaken the risk\u201d that comes with rejecting sexual advances in the workplace.\n\nShe seems to confuse sexual interest with affection: \u201cIs kissing someone in affection, however inappropriately \u2026 necessarily predatory behavior?\u201d Most adult women have learned that sexual interest and affection are often birds of a very different feather.\n\nSYLVIA STAUB\n\nSPRINGFIELD, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nDaphne Merkin worries that the #MeToo movement is imparting to young women a \u201cvictimology paradigm in which they are perceived \u2014 and perceive themselves to be \u2014 as frail as Victorian housewives.\u201d I believe that the movement is doing the opposite: empowering women, including me, to interrogate power with the support of other women.\n\nSaying \u201cback off\u201d to a man\u2019s inappropriate advances is often fraught with consequences \u2014 the loss of a job perhaps, or the tarnishing of a reputation.\n\nWhen men hold most of the power, it\u2019s na\u00efve to think that women aren\u2019t all vulnerable. That doesn\u2019t mean that we need to be shrinking violets, but it does mean that acting as an individual is less effective than acting collectively.", "title": "Opinion | Has #MeToo Gone Too Far?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "FRUM: Here\u2019s what the Russians have achieved. 1) They blocked from office a capable and effective foreign-policy president who understood them, their aims and how to build effective coalitions against them. 2) They gained a president who for reasons of vanity or worse has left the country vulnerable and exposed to further attack. 3) They gained a president who is smashing apart America\u2019s alliance structures. What intelligent South Korean can look for protection to the United States when its president regularly tweets that it is to China, not the United States, that South Korea should look for protection \u2014 and who is contemplating sacrificing hundreds of thousands of Korean lives to protect mainland U.S.A.? 4) The Russians gained a United States that operates in ways they are comfortable with \u2014 open to corruption and oligarchy \u2014 and they have scored points for the argument that democracy is a joke and a fraud. 5) They have helped install a racial provocateur who identifies every stress point in American political culture and inflames it to the point that the United States polarizes and paralyzes \u2026 I could go on.\n\nDOUTHAT: That the Russians have gained a president who may be seriously endangering America\u2019s broad position in the world I don\u2019t dispute. My argument is just that, so far, your intelligent South Korean could look at the actual moves made by the American state and persuade themselves \u2014 as many world leaders have seemingly persuaded themselves \u2014 that they should act as though McMaster and James Mattis and a few others are really running foreign policy, and the official president\u2019s tweets are so much sound and fury. Likewise an intelligent Pole or Hungarian or Ukrainian, trying to make choices in the shadow of Putin\u2019s ambitions: You just don\u2019t see the kind of dramatic steps, with NATO or anything else, that would suggest that Trump is substantially changing American policy. Which is why despite our agreement about Trump\u2019s character and competence, my general level of alarm has lowered somewhat since his inauguration, and is currently lower than your own.\n\nFRUM: The United States is a big bureaucratic state. Change more often comes to the United States by changing the content of the American state than by changing its forms. For example, the Constitution contemplates a cabinet system of government, with the principal officers confirmed by the Senate. Yet the chief of staff and the national security adviser, two positions never contemplated by the Constitution, matter more than any cabinet officer. On constitutional democracy\u2019s periodic upswings, we develop expectations about how the president should behave that exceed the law \u2014 e.g., no Franklin Roosevelt Jr.\u2019s doing shady deals from the White House \u2014 and we go into reverse on the downswing. Trump has not changed any law or policy about presidential financial integrity. He\u2019s just ignored customs (publish his tax returns), rendered other laws meaningless (financial disclosures that conceal things the public most needs to know, e.g., the upstream debts of the Trump Organization) and simply defied other laws by official lying (the endless misstatements by Trump\u2019s son-in-law and the nation\u2019s de facto chief foreign affairs officer).\n\nDOUTHAT: I agree; this is a definite downswing, a return of certain kinds of presidential sordidness and their exacerbation on certain fronts. But part of what\u2019s been striking about the Trump era to me is how much its events have confirmed trends that are bigger than Trump, that he benefited from during his ascent and that loom larger to me as symptoms of continuing crisis than most of the specific policy moves he\u2019s attempted. In particular, the paralysis of Congress, it\u2019s abdication of power to the presidency and its inability to function as a legislative body \u2014 plus the ideological sclerosis of the Republican Party, its collapse into an entertainment-wing-driven grift \u2014 these have been defining features of life under President Trump, as they were under President Obama before him. Were Trump an effective authoritarian, he could use these features of our politics to claim new powers and execute unilaterally on grand ambitions \u2014 as both of the last two presidents, on matters of war and peace and domestic policy, attempted and sometimes succeeded in doing. But his ineffectiveness so far means that the pre-existing crisis in how the presidency and the legislative branch relate to each other, and how the G.O.P. all functions, is still percolating, but not necessarily becoming dramatically more dire.\n\nFRUM: Your use of the word \u201cunilaterally\u201d casts a useful clarifying light on what may be the foundation of our disagreement. Let me be very clear what I do not mean by \u201cTrumpocracy,\u201d at least not yet: Caesarism. The authoritarian-nationalist system Trump is building is not being built against Congress, but with Congress \u2014 and even more, with Republican Parties at the state level. The big reveal to Republicans in the second Obama term, continuing now into the first Trump term, is that you and Reihan Salam and Ramesh Ponnuru and Henry Olsen and other \u201creformicons\u201d were right on the politics of Paul Ryan-style conservatism: Such politics simply could not prevail in a free and fair democratic contest. You and they (and me, too) assumed, or at least hoped, that Paul Ryan\u2019s party would respond to this better-late-than-never recognition of the obvious by moderating their policies. More health care, less immigration, more infrastructure, more family-friendly tax policy, etc.", "title": "Opinion | Has the U.S. Become a \u2018Trumpocracy\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWithout being tremendously well organized, it can be easy to fail,\u201d said Donald Moynihan , a professor of public affairs at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, who is writing a book on the effects of administrative burdens. Researchers have studied the ways complexity can reduce sign-ups for workplace pension plans, participation in food stamps and turnout in elections, he noted. \u201cThese sorts of little barriers are ways in which humans get tripped up all the time when they\u2019re trying to do something that might benefit them.\u201d\n\nAnyone who has ever forgotten to pay a bill on time, or struggled to assemble all the necessary forms of identification before heading to the D.M.V., is likely to sympathize with how administrative hurdles can stymie someone. But these may be especially daunting for the poor, who tend to have less stable work schedules and less access to resources that can simplify compliance: reliable transportation, a bank account, internet access. There is also a lot of research about the Medicaid program, specifically, that shows that sign-ups fall when states make their program more complicated.\n\nThe Kentucky program won\u2019t just create a work requirement for some beneficiaries; it will set up a broader obstacle course of administrative rules. Many beneficiaries will be asked to pay monthly premiums to the state to retain their coverage, as little as $1 a month for some very poor families, who are unlikely to have bank accounts.\n\nThey will be asked to notify Medicaid officials any time their income changes. Their benefits could rise or fall depending on whether they get an annual checkup, or take a financial literacy course. Beneficiaries who fail to renew their coverage promptly at the end of a year will be locked out for as long as six months. Beneficiaries who are \u201cmedically frail\u201d can get an exemption from the work requirement, but they will need to submit a doctor\u2019s note.\n\nKentucky officials argue that the changes will give beneficiaries more dignity and promote personal responsibility. But they also estimate that around 100,000 fewer people will be enrolled in the program by the end of five years. There are about 1.3 million Medicaid recipients in Kentucky.", "title": "Hate Paperwork? Medicaid Recipients Will Be Drowning in It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "SATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 A challenging and fun one by Peter Wentz, with a mostly clean grid, nine debuts, lots of lively entries and some great cluing.\n\nI\u2019m still fighting whatever this nasty thing is, so please discuss among yourselves and help each other through the solve. My apologies to Mr. Wentz and readers for the brevity, and I hope to be back to 100 percent soon.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis grid layout has become something of a go-to for me, with a similar one published about two years ago and another being written as we speak. It offers good opportunities for a variety of stacks, is reasonably wide-open, and can accommodate edits without sacrificing the entire puzzle. This one appears to hold up even years after its original creation, so it\u2019ll likely continue to be a staple on down the line. I thought I\u2019d struck gold with my original clue for 11-Down (\u201c\u2018Family Matters\u2019 central character\u201d), but the whole \u201ccharacter\u201d bit of wordplay for capitalized entries is basically old-hat at this point, so the revised clue referencing the Gmail logo is a nice alternate. Lots of other improvements in the clue department as well, with my favorite probably being 54-Across. Hope everyone enjoys!\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Have High Hopes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Aging can bring unwelcome surprises, like crusty brown spots that gradually appear on your face, neck or trunk.\n\nThey\u2019re called unflattering names: age spots, barnacles or, God help us, senile warts, but physicians know them as seborrheic keratosis lesions, or SK lesions, for short. They come in as many varieties as apples at a farmers\u2019 market: waxy, warty, raised or flat. The good news is they\u2019re benign.\n\nOf course, that doesn\u2019t stop many of the 83 million Americans who have them from kvetching. Sometimes the lesions itch, bleed or get irritated by a belt or a bra strap, but for the most part, they\u2019re simply an unwelcome reminder that there\u2019s much in life that\u2019s out of our control.\n\nAnd there hasn\u2019t been an easy cosmetic treatment, until now.\n\nOn Dec. 14, the Food and Drug Administration approved a first-of-its-kind liquid called Eskata that targets these unsightly spots. By late April, people who have the means and the patience to sit through at least two visits to their dermatologist\u2019s office can get rid of some raised spots.", "title": "Have We Aged Out of Age Spots?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Happy 2018. If you rang in the new year a little too hard, here\u2019s what to watch while nursing yourself back to health.\n\nI feel quite bad, and I wish to have my spirits lifted\n\n\u201cYounger\u201d is a bingeable romcom, about a woman in her 40s who pretends to be in her 20s to get a job, with the bubbly ease of \u201cSex and the City.\u201d Its 48 episodes are currently on Hulu, and while the show\u2019s ideas about what Brooklyn entails are quite silly, its digs at the publishing industry are a hoot.\n\n\u2018Younger\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI feel quite bad, and I wish to wallow in that badness\n\nSeason 4 of the futuristic thriller anthology \u201cBlack Mirror\u201d is now on Netflix, and while it can be a spiritually corrosive binge-watch, if you\u2019re trying to embrace darkness, go ahead and embrace darkness. Celebrate new beginnings by developing a skepticism about the entire human endeavor!\n\n\u2018Black Mirror\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI think my body is broken\n\nNetflix\u2019s \u201cAmerican Vandal\u201d is a hilarious true-crime spoof about high-school vandalism that\u2019s still as absorbing and intricate as the real deal, just without the morbid guilt. And with drawings of penises spray-painted onto cars.\n\n\u2018American Vandal\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI want to wear sunglasses inside\n\nThe amiable \u201cGreat News\u201d is sort of a \u201c30 Rock\u201d Lite, set at a local news station. The plots for each episode don\u2019t matter much, so if you can only catch the terrific one-liners (\u201cwell, well, well \u2026 said Baby Jessica while having a nightmare\u201d), you\u2019re still in good shape.\n\n0\n\n\u2018Great News\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI\u2019m surprisingly O.K. and I enjoy British shows\n\n\u201cToast of London,\u201d on Netflix, is a showbiz comedy about a washed-up self-aggrandizing star. There\u2019s a lot of shouting on the show, so skip it if you have a headache, but otherwise prepare to accidentally adopt the main character\u2019s habit of saying \u201cthanking you\u201d instead of \u201cthank you.\u201d It\u2019s catchy.\n\n\u2018Toast of London\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI don\u2019t even have the energy to pick something to stream\n\nBravo has a 12-hour \u201cVanderpump Rules\u201d marathon New Year\u2019s Day starting at 9:30 a.m.; FXX has a \u201cSimpsons\u201d marathon starting at 8 p.m. New Year\u2019s Eve and running all day New Year\u2019s Day; and Syfy\u2019s \u201cTwilight Zone\u201d marathon starts at 4 a.m. on Dec. 31 and airs through 6:30 a.m. Jan. 2.", "title": "Have a Hangover From 2017? Here Are Some Suggestions for TV Shows to Stream", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Moscow received contradictory reports as to whether its pilots had shot down an airliner or a spy plane, and Soviet leaders were biased toward trusting their own. So when they declared it a legal interception of an American military incursion, American leaders, who knew this to be false, assumed Soviet leaders were lying. Moscow had downed the airliner deliberately, some concluded, in an act of undeclared war.\n\nAt the same time, Washington made a nearly perfect mirror-image set of mistakes \u2014 suggesting that such misreadings are not just possible, but dangerously likely.\n\nMr. Reagan, furious at the loss of life, accused Moscow of deliberately targeting the civilian airliner. He denounced Soviet society itself as rotten and in pursuit of world domination.\n\nIn fact, a C.I.A. assessment, included in the president\u2019s daily briefing that morning, had concluded the incident was likely an error. Mr. Reagan appeared to have simply missed it.\n\nBut Soviet leaders had never considered this; they assumed Mr. Reagan was lying about their intentions. Some concluded he had somehow lured the Soviet Union into downing the aircraft as cover for a massive pre-emptive attack, which they feared might come at any moment.\n\nEach read the other\u2019s blundering and dissembling as intentional, deepening suspicions among hard-liners that the other side was laying the groundwork for war. And if war was coming, the logic of nuclear deterrence all but required firing first.\n\nNuclear-armed missiles had recently achieved a level of speed and capability so that one power could completely disarm another in a matter of minutes. This created something called first-strike instability, in which firing first \u2014 even if you think you might be firing in error \u2014 is the only way to be sure of preventing your own obliteration.\n\nThe result was that the United States and the Soviet Union repeatedly went to the brink of war over provocations or even technical misreadings. Often, officials had mere minutes to decide whether to retaliate against seemingly real or impending attacks without being able to fully verify whether an attack was actually underway. In the logic of nuclear deterrence, firing would have been the rational choice.", "title": "Hawaii False Alarm Hints at Thin Line Between Mishap and Nuclear War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "The leader of the Hawaii National Guard told state lawmakers that he informed the governor that a panic-inducing missile alert was a false alarm two minutes after it had been sent to cellphones statewide.\n\nThe leader, Maj. Gen. Arthur J. Logan, made the revelation about the Jan. 13 episode at a hearing on Friday during which legislators raised concerns about why that critical information was not conveyed to the public more quickly.\n\nAmid the chaos and confusion, it took officials 38 minutes to send a second message saying the original message was an error. Officials have said a flaw in the alert system delayed the distribution of the correction.\n\n\u201cThe false alarm has identified so many gaps in the system,\u201d Della Au Belatti, the majority leader of the Hawaii State House, said in a phone interview on Saturday. \u201cWe won\u2019t see this kind of communications breakdown again.\u201d", "title": "Hawaii Governor Learned Missile Alert Was False Within Two Minutes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "According to Bruce Oliveira, the retired Army general who led the state investigation, the message spoken by the shift leader did not adhere to the script outlined in the protocol. \u201cWhat was actually said in the script was taken from an actual notification,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the general emphasized that the shift leader had some \u201cflexibility\u201d and did say \u201cexercise, exercise, exercise\u201d before and after his message. That \u201ctells everybody that this is a practice drill,\u201d General Oliveira said.\n\nAlthough other emergency management officials in Hawaii understood that the state was conducting a drill at the time, the employee who sent the alert said in a written statement that he had believed there was a real emergency.\n\nThe employee then chose from options in a drop-down menu that included test and real alerts. When prompted with the question \u201cAre you sure you want to send this alert?\u201d the employee clicked \u201cyes,\u201d according to the commission.\n\nPanic set in across Hawaii almost immediately, with people furiously contacting members of their family and seeking shelter. The escalating tensions between the United States and North Korea added to the level of concern.\n\nWhen the employee was directed to cancel the alert to prevent it from going to any phones that had not yet received it, he \u201cjust sat there and didn\u2019t respond,\u201d the state report said.\n\nIt took about 38 minutes to send a second alert that said the original one was an error. In its report, the Federal Communications Commission faulted Hawaii\u2019s emergency agency for lacking measures to prevent the mistake and to quickly notify the public to disregard it.", "title": "Hawaii Missile Alert Wasn\u2019t Accidental, Officials Say, Blaming Worker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "At no time, officials said, was there any indication that a nuclear attack had been launched on the United States. The Federal Communications Commission announced that it had begun \u201ca full investigation into the FALSE missile alert in Hawaii.\u201d\n\nThe alert went out at about 8:10 a.m., lighting up phones of people still in bed, having coffee by the beach at a Waikiki resort, or up for an early surf. \u201cBALLISTIC MISSILE THREAT INBOUND TO HAWAII. SEEK IMMEDIATE SHELTER. THIS IS NOT A DRILL,\u201d it read.\n\nHawaii has been on high emotional alert \u2014 it began staging monthly air-raid drills, complete with sirens, in December \u2014 since President Trump and Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, began exchanging nuclear threats. Estimates vary, but it would take a little more than half an hour for a missile launched from North Korea to reach Hawaii, traversing an arc of roughly 5,700 miles. State officials said that residents here would have as little as 12 minutes to find shelter once an alert was issued.\n\nWithin moments of the first announcement, people flocked to shelters, crowding highways in scenes of terror and helplessness. Emergency sirens wailed in parts of the state, adding to the panic.\n\n\u201cI was running through all the scenarios in my head, but there was nowhere to go, nowhere to pull over to,\u201d said Mike Staskow, a retired military captain.\n\nAllyson Niven, who lives in Kailua-Kona, said her first instinct was to gather her family as she contemplated what she thought would be her final minutes alive.\n\n\u201cWe fully felt like we were about to die,\u201d she said. \u201cI drove to try to get to my kids even though I knew I probably wouldn\u2019t make it, and I fully was visualizing what was happening while I was on the road. It was awful.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRay Gerst was vacationing on Oahu with his wife to celebrate their 28th wedding anniversary. He received the alert as they pulled up for their tour of Kualoa Ranch.\n\n\u201cAll the buses stopped, and people came running out of the ranch and said, \u2018Just sit still for a minute, nobody get off the bus, nobody get off the bus,\u2019\u201d he said.\n\nThey were taken into the mountains, Mr. Gerst said, and dropped off at a concrete bunker. They sheltered in place for about 15 minutes, he said, during which time they had no cell signal.\n\n\u201cIt was scary,\u201d Mr. Gerst said. \u201cI mean, there was no intel.\u201d\n\nAt Konawaena High School on the Island of Hawaii, where a high school wrestling championship was taking place, school officials, more accustomed to alerts of high surf or tsunamis, moved people to the center of the gym as they tried to figure out how to take shelter from a missile.\n\n\u201cEveryone cooperated,\u201d said Kellye Krug, the athletic director at the school. \u201cOnce they were gathered, we let them use cellphones to reach loved ones. There were a couple kids who were emotional, the coaches were right there to console kids. After the retraction was issued, we gave kids time to reach out again.\u201d\n\nMatt LoPresti, a state representative, told CNN that he and his family headed for a bathroom. \u201cI was sitting in the bathtub with my children, saying our prayers,\u201d he said.\n\nNatalie Haena, 38, of Honolulu, said she was getting ready to take her daughter to ice skating lessons when the alert came. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing to prep for a missile coming in,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have no bomb shelters or anything like that. There\u2019s nowhere to go.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Washington, Lindsay Walters, a deputy press secretary, said that President Trump had been informed of the events. \u201cThe president has been briefed on the state of Hawaii\u2019s emergency management exercise,\u201d she said. \u201cThis was purely a state exercise.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSenator Brian Schatz of Hawaii said the mistake was \u201ctotally inexcusable.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe whole state was terrified,\u201d he said. \u201cThere needs to be tough and quick accountability and a fixed process.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile the cellphone alerting system is in state authorities\u2019 hands, the detection of missile launches is the responsibility of the United States Strategic Command and Northern Command. It was the military \u2014 not Hawaiian officials \u2014 that was the first to declare there was no evidence of a missile launch.\n\nThe false alert was a stark reminder of what happens when the old realities of the nuclear age collide with the speed \u2014 and the potential for error \u2014 inherent in the internet age. The alert came at one of the worst possible moments \u2014 when tension with North Korea has been at one of the highest points in decades, and when Mr. Kim\u2019s government has promised more missile tests and threatened an atmospheric nuclear test.\n\nDuring the Cold War there were many false alarms. William J. Perry, the defense secretary during the Clinton administration, recalled in his memoir, \u201cMy Journey at the Nuclear Brink,\u201d a moment in 1979 when, as an under secretary of defense, he was awakened by a watch officer who reported that his computer system was showing 200 intercontinental ballistic missiles headed to the United States. \u201cFor one heart-stopping second I thought my worst nuclear nightmare had come true,\u201d Mr. Perry wrote.\n\nIt turned out that a training tape had been mistakenly inserted into an early-warning system computer. No one woke up the president. But Mr. Perry went on to speculate what might have happened if such a warning had come \u201cduring the Cuban Missile Crisis or a Mideast war?\u201d\n\nThe United States faces an especially difficult problem today, not just because of tense relations with North Korea but also because of growing fears inside the military about the cyber vulnerability of the nuclear warning system and nuclear control systems.\n\nBecause of its location, Hawaii \u2014 more than any other part of the United States \u2014 has been threatened by escalating tensions and the risks of war, and preparations have already begun there.\n\nOn Friday, the day before the erroneous alert, several hundred people attended an event in Honolulu sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce in which military commanders, politicians and others discussed the threat to the islands\u2019 population.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. is the designated recipient \u2014 and that\u2019s because we are public enemy No. 1 to North Korea,\u201d Dan Leaf, a retired Air Force lieutenant general and Pacific Command deputy commander, was quoted as saying in The Honolulu Star Advertiser.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Hawaii Emergency Management Agency has been holding \u201care you ready\u201d drills. As a chain of islands, Hawaii is subject to all kinds of threats \u2014 hurricanes, volcanoes, earthquakes and tsunamis \u2014 but officials have made clear that none is more urgent now than the threat of an attack by North Korea, given how little time there would be between an alert and the detonation of a bomb.\n\nThe fifth page of an emergency preparation pamphlet issued by the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency features a picture of a rocket lifting off: \u201cNuclear Threat \u2014 Unlikely But Cannot Ignore It.\u201d\n\nVern T. Miyagi, the administrator of the agency, said that during the drill, an employee \u2014 whom he did not identify \u2014 mistakenly pushed a button on a computer screen to send out the alert, rather than one marked to test it. He said the employee answered \u201cyes\u201d when asked by the system if he was sure he wanted to send the message.\n\nMr. Miyagi, going through a detailed timeline of the events at an afternoon news conference, said the agency tried to correct the error on social media. It took 38 minutes to send out a follow-up message canceling the original alert, which he acknowledged was a shortcoming with the alert system that the agency would fix.\n\nMr. Rapoza said he did not know if anyone would be disciplined for the mistake. \u201cAt this point, our major concern is to make sure we do what we need to do to reassure the public,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is not a time for pointing fingers.\u201d\n\nThe panic that followed the alert \u2014 if relatively short-lived \u2014 gripped the islands. There were reports of people seeking shelter by parking their cars inside a highway tunnel that cuts through a mountain. When the announcement was rescinded, a digital highway sign read: \u201cMissile alert in error: There is no threat.\u201d\n\nPeople in Hawaii tend to know what to do to protect themselves to threats of a tsunami or a hurricane. The prospect of nuclear annihilation was entirely new terrain.\n\n\u201cSo this was the most terrifying few minutes of my LIFE!\u201d Paul Wilson, a professor at Brigham Young University-Hawaii, said on Twitter. \u201cI just want to know why it took 38 minutes to announce it was a mistake?!?\u201d\n\nChris Tacker, a veteran who lives in Kealakekua, said the mistake had left her angry and frustrated.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know where to go,\u201d she said. \u201cAnyone try to dig a hole in lava? Good luck trying to build a shelter. I\u2019m stocking my liquor cabinet.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, she added, \u201cIf we don\u2019t have our sense of humor about this, it\u2019s all over.\u201d", "title": "Hawaii Panics After Alert About Incoming Missile Is Sent in Error", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney", "David E. Sanger", "Johanna Barr"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Separately, the Iranian oil tanker that burned off the coast of China for more than a week sank on Sunday. \u201cThere is no hope of finding survivors,\u201d an Iranian official said.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cYou have children watching. You have nations watching.\u201d\n\nThat was just one of the many shocked reactions after President Trump said he did not want immigrants from \u201cshithole\u201d countries. It came from Senator Ron Johnson, Republican of Wisconsin.\n\nBut another senator who attended the meeting forcefully denied that Mr. Trump had used that phrase, saying a Democratic colleague\u2019s account of the session was \u201ca gross misrepresentation.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s vulgar comments, our national immigration correspondent writes, were a sad reminder of racist attitudes that once shaped American policy.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 South Korea proposed that North Korea join it in fielding a joint women\u2019s hockey team at the Pyeongchang Games next month.\n\nIt would be a first for the Games and a dramatic emblem of the recent warming of relations on the Korean Peninsula. The North\u2019s Olympic representative said it was \u201cunder discussion.\u201d\n\nAnd in South Korea, there\u2019s a growing push to overturn an abortion ban. Activists say it puts women at risk and creates a culture of shame.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Male models and assistants are accusing the fashion photographers Bruce Weber and Mario Testino of sexual misconduct.\n\nBoth are huge names: Mr. Weber is best known for his racy advertisements for Calvin Klein and Abercrombie & Fitch, while Mr. Testino is a favorite of the British royal family and Vogue.\n\nAbove from left, Ryan Locke, Robyn Sinclair and Terron Wood. Each said he had experienced sexual harassment during his time modeling.\n\nMark Wahlberg and his talent agency, meanwhile, will donate $2 million to a fund dedicated to fighting pay inequity and harassment of women in Hollywood. The donation comes after an outcry about pay discrepancy in his recent film.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A frenzy over cryptocurrencies has sent their value soaring and investors scrambling.\n\nBut the leading player, Bitcoin, was rattled last week by word that South Korea is preparing a ban on trading in virtual currencies. But it isn\u2019t clear whether, or how quickly, it will follow through.\n\nAnd we went inside the newly megarich cryptocurrency community and found a tightknit group of friends \u2014 developers, libertarians, Redditors and cypherpunks \u2014 who talk about decentralizing power and wealth, and changing the world order. Some tennis stars will not be on hand, so who can take advantage?\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe headquarters for the U.S. military has always stood out.\n\nThe Pentagon building was already in use when it was dedicated 75 years ago today, at the height of World War II.\n\nBuilt just across the Potomac River from Washington in less than two years, the Pentagon was home to 22,000 workers by the end of 1942.\n\nIt remains one of the world\u2019s largest office buildings, with more than 6 million square feet of floor space.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe distinctive design came from the shape of the first proposed site, which was hemmed in by streets on five sides. When President Franklin Roosevelt decided on a different location, the shape stayed, but the sides were made even.\n\nThe first architectural reviews were not glowing, but they improved over time.\n\n\u201cCalled too big, too barren and too expensive when it was completed for $83-million in 1943, the Pentagon is a thriving, functional success in 1968,\u201d The Times wrote in a report for the 25th anniversary of the building, which it extolled as a place of community:\n\n\u201cEveryman, or Littleman, triumphed over all. Thousands of secretaries and office workers have turned the Pentagon into a cluttered, cosy, home-away-from-home.\u201d\n\nSarah Anderson contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.
