Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Hawaii, North Korea, Iran: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "FRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 The typical solving process for Wordplayers, as I understand it, is as follows:\n\n1. Start solving the puzzle 2. Complete the puzzle, with or without Googling or peeking at Wordplay 3. Come to Wordplay to see if they were right and to discuss the puzzle.\n\nThe part that isn\u2019t included in that process is the staring at the grid until the lightning bolt hits, so you can find a theme that is both unexpected \u2014 it\u2019s Friday, after all \u2014 and hidden in plain sight.\n\nDavid Kahn is back, and he offers us a sort-of-themed puzzle that had me staring for quite a while.\n\nAnd then, as they say, it hit me.\n\nWait, There\u2019s a Theme? On a Friday?\n\nThere is a note in today\u2019s puzzle that reads: \u201cThe completed puzzle conceals the name of a famous composer, along with something that might help you listen to him. Who and what are they?\u201d\n\nThe thing I liked about this puzzle is that there is a big H made of black squares in the middle of the grid, which made me believe that the composer was perhaps Haydn or Handel, but that turned out to be a red herring. Or my own mistake, which is highly likely.", "title": "Haydn in Plain Sight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJoe Shadid, 30, is a music and content specialist for Reverb.com in Chicago.\n\nWhat is Reverb.com, and what do you do there?\n\nWe\u2019re an online marketplace where people buy and sell guitars, drums and other music gear.\n\nI appear in our YouTube videos, demonstrating music instruments and gear, giving guitar lessons and discussing music theory. I also teach users how to replicate or change artists\u2019 tones. In other videos, I interview musicians, usually about one of their songs or their gear. The music industry can be tough, and for a musician like me, this is a good way to earn a steady paycheck and stay close to my art.\n\nWhen did you know you wanted to be a musician?\n\nMy brother and I loved music as kids. When I was about 9, we\u2019d sneak across a busy road to buy albums at a music store on the other side. One night I was listening to \u201cI\u2019ve Just Seen a Face\u201d way past my bedtime when a switch turned in my brain. I ran into my parents\u2019 bedroom and asked for a guitar, and they told me to go to bed. Santa brought one that Christmas, and I\u2019ve played it every day since.\n\nHow did you get this job?\n\nIn 2015, a family friend working here asked me to demonstrate a guitar pedal on a video. I was hesitant about appearing on YouTube until I realized what I could do. I love sharing, talking about and exploring the language of music. No one knows everything; there are endless things to discover.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDid you study music?\n\nI attended Berklee College of Music but left before I finished when I had an opportunity to tour with the band I was playing with. I discussed it with a couple of professors I looked up to, who said: \u201cYou came here to prepare yourself for an opportunity like this. Go.\u201d I felt like it was the right call.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow do you decide what goes in the videos?\n\nEvery month I meet with the content team, which runs like a newsroom. We map out our video plan based on artist birthdays, album anniversaries, holidays, bands that have resonated with viewers, audience suggestions and so forth.\n\nWhat was a memorable moment?\n\nA couple of years ago I was playing at a music hall in Chicago when a teenager approached me. He said he and his dad had lived in different cities for most of his life, but they had bonded learning to play guitar from my videos and playing together over Skype. I still get emotional thinking about it.", "title": "He Has a Rarity in Music: A Steady Paycheck", "authors": ["Patricia R. Olsen", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Webster\u2019s career lasted from 1974 to 1990, ending just before the advent of free agency and the massive increase in N.F.L. salaries it sparked. After Webster retired, his declining health, escalating medical bills, long slide into dementia and years of wandering the country took a toll on Garrett Webster, his three siblings and their mother, Pam.\n\nShe exhausted her savings long ago. She lives off credit cards, Social Security and an annuity. Unable to afford a home, she has spent the past five years staying with friends and family. Careful not to overstay her welcome, she traveled during one six-week stretch to Pittsburgh, the West Coast, Minnesota, Wisconsin and then back to Pittsburgh, where she stays with Garrett.\n\nThrough it all, she and her four children have continued a fight to receive a multimillion-dollar award from the N.F.L.\u2019s concussion settlement with retired players.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a part of the settlement, the N.F.L. agreed to make compensation payments that will stretch into the millions to retired players with severe cognitive and neurological problems. On paper, at least, the Websters should receive nearly $3 million based on his age at the time of the diagnosis, 50, and the number of years he played in the N.F.L., 17. The criteria are an attempt to gauge how long players were exposed to head trauma and how directly that exposure could be linked to health problems: Younger players are paid more on the presumption that football, not old age, caused their problems.\n\nTo the Websters\u2019 dismay, they found out after the settlement agreement was announced that Iron Mike, as he was known in Pittsburgh, was not automatically part of it. That\u2019s because the deal excludes players who died before Jan. 1, 2006.\n\nThe N.F.L. pushed for a cutoff date to prevent a stream of families from filing claims for long-deceased fathers and husbands. The plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers ultimately agreed on 2006, which allowed more families to file claims, but was far enough back that it excluded the families of players who died before then from bringing wrongful-death and other suits against the league.\n\nThe Websters and other families in their position still have a glimmer of hope. The federal judge in the case, Anita B. Brody, left open a legal window for families of players who died before 2006 that their lawyers hope to utilize. Jason Luckasevic, the lawyer for the Websters, needs to show that the family still has the right to file a legal case against the league under their state\u2019s statute of limitations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChristopher Seeger, a co-lead counsel for the retired players who sued the league, declined to be interviewed on the phone. In an email, he explained that some players objected to the 2006 cutoff date, but without a settlement that at least captured players dating to 2006, many more would face the same stringent limitations as the Websters.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe 2006 cutoff date \u201cis the result of hard-fought negotiations between the parties,\u201d he wrote in court filings in 2015. \u201cHad the plaintiffs not secured this provision, claimants on behalf of all deceased class members would have had to show that their claims were timely.\u201d\n\nThe exclusion applies to players who died from all diseases covered by the settlement, including A.L.S. and Parkinson\u2019s disease. But it is a particularly crushing blow to the Websters and to the families of two other former Steelers, Terry Long and Justin Strzelczyk, who also died before 2006 and received the same posthumous diagnosis Mike Webster did. They spent many years listening to league officials question any connection between playing football and a degenerative brain condition, before 2016, when the N.F.L. grudgingly acknowledged a link between football and the disease.\n\n\u201cIf you asked the 20,000 retirees who are part of the class, they would say Mike Webster should be paid first,\u201d Mr. Luckasevic said.\n\nThe league and the administrator for the settlement say that despite early hiccups and the need to weed out fraudulent claims, the process is operating as intended. More than $150 million has been awarded and many hundreds of other claims are being evaluated.\n\n\u201cWe are pleased the concussion settlement is proceeding as the parties and the court intended,\u201d Brian McCarthy, an N.F.L. spokesman, said.\n\nPhoto\n\nJo-Ann M. Verrier, who was appointed by the judge to help resolve complicated cases, said there were about 40 claims filed by the families of players who died before 2006 that have the potential to set legal precedent. That means she must make sure to create a process to evaluate them fairly. Once that process is completed, the other special master, Wendell Pritchett, will begin to rule on the claims, which will be reviewed on a first-come-first-served basis.\n\n\u201cWe want to create a process where we can decide on these issues once and for all,\u201d Ms. Verrier said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGarrett Webster, though, is losing his patience.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s insane that we haven\u2019t been paid because every suit uses my dad in their case,\u201d he said. Mr. Webster, who wore a Steelers sweatshirt to a sandwich shop here on a recent afternoon, sat near pictures of his father and other Steelers players on the walls. \u201cIf Mike Webster doesn\u2019t happen, this case doesn\u2019t happen,\u201d he added.\n\nSitting in a booth next to her son, picking at a salad, Pam Webster said she and her children were used to delays. Starting in the late-1990s, Mike Webster and his lawyers spent years fighting for full disability benefits. After he died, a court finally ruled against the league\u2019s disability board. That provided a hollow victory. The Websters are also seeking a so-called Legacy Benefit payment that the N.F.L. pays to families of deceased players. That is not likely to amount to more than a few thousand dollars per month.\n\nAn award in the concussion settlement could provide the Websters with a financial shot in the arm when they really need it. While Pam Webster travels from home to home, Garrett Webster has remained in Pittsburgh, where he lived with his father in his final years.\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth Webster daughters, Brooke, 41, and Hillie, 30, have been treated for substance abuse. Pam Webster said those problems were a result of the stress of seeing their father\u2019s life disintegrate after his N.F.L. career. Her other son, Colin, 38, was in the military. He has kept football at arm\u2019s length for years. \u201cThis isn\u2019t the way it was supposed to end,\u201d Pam Webster said.\n\nAfter Mike Webster retired in 1990, he moved his family to Wisconsin, where he and Pam grew up. But after some poor financial decisions they lost their house. Webster occasionally made money when his friend Sunny Jani found him gigs signing autographs.\n\nTo help pay the bills, Pam Webster went to work at a restaurant, then became a personal care assistant after she found out the family had lost their health insurance. Mike Webster drifted through Pittsburgh, Wisconsin and places in between. Their marriage fell apart.\n\nThe family\u2019s relationship with the Steelers is complicated. At times, the team helped its former player and his family. At other times, especially after his behavior became unpredictable, the organization kept its distance. In November, the team invited Pam and Garrett Webster to a ceremony honoring team legends during a home game. It was the first time she attended a game since 2002, when the Steelers honored her husband after his death.\n\nThey now proudly show off cellphone pictures of the steel football they received that day. They are careful to say they do not resent the Steelers. They want only what they believe the league owes them. Through a spokesman, the Steelers declined to comment on the settlement claim.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t hate football, we just are upset about Mike,\u201d Pam Webster said. But she added: \u201cEvery time we step forward, it\u2019s three steps back. One minute he\u2019s remembered, and one minute he\u2019s forgotten.\u201d", "title": "He Helped Ex-Players Get Benefits. His Family Is Still Waiting.", "authors": ["Ken Belson"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt seemed like that was the right thing to do \u2014 exercising my First Amendment rights to get the information out there,\u201d said Mr. Edelman, who had worked at the agency since 2015 and whose job included photographing events that the agency promoted in news releases, on the web and elsewhere.\n\nThe day after the photos were published by In These Times, a liberal magazine, the Energy Department put Mr. Edelman on administrative leave, seized his personal laptop and escorted him out of its headquarters in Washington, he said. He was later told, without explanation, that his employment agreement had not been renewed, internal agency emails show.\n\nMr. Edelman has now filed a complaint with the Energy Department\u2019s inspector general and, according to his lawyer, is seeking protections provided to federal whistle-blowers. On its website, the Energy Department notes that it is illegal to retaliate against whistle-blowers, who are typically protected when they alert a supervisor or the inspector general to information that they reasonably believe to constitute an abuse of authority, or other misconduct.\n\nIn the complaint, Mr. Edelman accuses the agency of retaliation and asks for his job back or at least to recover his laptop and other personal belongings. In addition, Mr. Edelman accused a former colleague of encouraging him to delete the photos of Mr. Perry and Mr. Murray, which Mr. Edelman and his lawyer argue are public records.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Energy Department declined to discuss the circumstances surrounding Mr. Edelman\u2019s employment, the status of the photos or the details of his complaint, but a spokeswoman characterized his accusations as \u201cridiculous.\u201d Mr. Edelman supported his complaint with emails and other documents, but some claims were based on his statements alone.\n\n\u201cThey are based on his own subjective opinions and personal agenda,\u201d the spokeswoman, Shaylyn Hynes, said in an email. \u201cIndustry and other stakeholders visit the Department of Energy on a daily basis. The secretary welcomes their input and feedback to strengthen the American energy sector. This meeting was no different.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Murray said the coal executive \u201cdoes not have a recollection as to the exact statements allegedly made nearly a year ago.\u201d The spokesman, Gary Broadbent, added that \u201cMr. Murray has frequently said that the Trump administration must advance reliable and low-cost electricity for all Americans and protect coal mining jobs.\u201d\n\nThe confidential documents Mr. Murray brought to his meeting with Mr. Perry called for \u201crescinding anti-coal regulations of the Obama administration\u201d and cutting the staff of the Environmental Protection Agency \u201cin at least half,\u201d according to portions visible in Mr. Edelman\u2019s photographs.\n\nLast week, The New York Times obtained a copy of a separate memo written by Mr. Murray, and reported that the Trump administration had completed or was on track to fulfill most of the 16 policy and regulatory requests contained in it. Mr. Murray told The Times the two memos essentially covered the same material.\n\nMr. Edelman, a Democrat, came to the Energy Department under President Barack Obama two years ago after producing videos at a consulting firm in Chicago and serving as creative director for the electoral campaign of former Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois. After Mr. Trump\u2019s election, Mr. Edelman said, he received greater responsibility, including photographing Mr. Perry\u2019s meetings.\n\nMr. Edelman\u2019s complaint offers a behind-the-scenes look at the meeting on March 29 between Mr. Perry and Mr. Murray, who have been friendly for many years. In addition to his company contributing $300,000 to the president\u2019s inauguration \u2014 and personally holding a fund-raiser for Mr. Trump during the campaign \u2014 Mr. Murray has been a financial backer of Mr. Perry, a former governor of Texas who has also run for president.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Murray\u2019s spokesman said the company had supported Republicans \u201cwho have been staunch defenders of the United States coal industry, and the jobs and family livelihoods that depend on it, and low-cost, reliable, fuel secure electricity for all Americans.\u201d\n\nThe meeting started, the complaint said, with Mr. Perry giving Mr. Murray \u201ca deep bear hug.\u201d Once they got down to business, Mr. Murray presented the memo. \u201cThis needs to be done,\u201d the complaint says Mr. Murray insisted.\n\nMr. Perry replied, \u201cI think we can help you with this,\u201d according to the complaint.\n\nRattled by the exchange, Mr. Edelman said he stayed for about 15 minutes to keep listening, until he drew the attention of an agency official. \u201cHow much does a photographer need of us just sitting around?\u201d the complaint quotes the agency official as asking.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe photos sat for months without much attention.\n\nThen, in September, Mr. Perry proposed that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopt a rule that would increase financial returns for power plants capable of stockpiling at least 90 days\u2019 worth of fuel on-site \u2014 a plan that would effectively subsidize struggling coal and nuclear power plants, particularly in areas where Mr. Murray operates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout the change, Mr. Perry warned, the plants could shut down, which would threaten the \u201creliability and resiliency of our nation\u2019s grid.\u201d\n\nThat phrase rang a bell with Mr. Edelman. The cover page of Mr. Murray\u2019s memo described a plan \u201cto assist in the survival of our country\u2019s coal industry, which is essential to power grid reliability.\u201d\n\nMr. Edelman said he decided to share the photos with the news media \u2014 The Washington Post published the images after In These Times \u2014 hoping to derail Mr. Perry\u2019s proposed rule. The rule faced opposition from a cross section of environmental groups, energy companies, free-market advocates and former regulators, and last week, the energy commission rejected it.\n\nMr. Murray has said that the meeting with Mr. Perry was primarily about the need to study the resilience of the power grid, not to ask for specific actions by the energy commission or other arms of the federal government. Mr. Broadbent, his spokesman, said that \u201ca word-for-word comparison\u201d of the proposed rule and Mr. Murray\u2019s action plan \u201creveals that they have only two words in common.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Dec. 7, the day after In These Times posted the photographs, and a day before they appeared online at The Washington Post, Mr. Edelman said he was summoned by his boss and told he was being placed on administrative leave with pay.\n\nThe agency later declined to extend his two-year employment agreement, which ended late last year, effectively dismissing him despite previously agreeing to extend him for two more years, Mr. Edelman said.\n\nA security officer for the agency also refused to allow him to pack up certain personal belongings, Mr. Edelman said, including his laptop and camera equipment. The next day, a supervisor instructed Mr. Edelman in an email to provide the agency the administrative rights to the Google Drive folder where he stored the photos, according to a copy of the email reviewed by The Times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeparately, another colleague warned him over the phone that \u201cwe can come to your home and have someone watch you delete it,\u201d Mr. Edelman said. Mr. Edelman did not record the call.\n\nIn a phone call a few days later, which was recorded, the colleague reiterated that Mr. Edelman needed to transfer ownership of the folder. \u201cI would suggest that doing it sooner rather than later would probably be a good thing for you,\u201d the colleague said, according to the recording, which was heard by The Times.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou can get access to a computer,\u201d the colleague added, \u201ceven if you need to go to a freaking library to do it.\u201d\n\nMr. Edelman said the department had still not returned his laptop. Among the other items he said he left behind because of the hurried exit: a cake from his colleagues celebrating his 35th birthday.\n\nMr. Edelman hired a lawyer, John Tye, a former whistle-blower from the State Department who works at Whistleblower Aid, a nonprofit firm. Mr. Tye defended Mr. Edelman\u2019s decision to keep the photos, arguing that they were \u201cin the public domain\u201d and were not classified, and that they had been stored on Mr. Edelman\u2019s private drive at the Energy Department\u2019s instruction.\n\nBy filing his complaint with the inspector general, Mr. Tye said, Mr. Edelman was seeking protections provided to federal whistle-blowers, including prohibition from \u201cadverse employment actions and dismissal.\u201d\n\nAfter Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, heard about the incident, his office contacted Mr. Edelman, who also shared the complaint with Senator Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, who is a neighbor in Washington. It was Mr. Whitehouse who shared the separate memo by Murray Energy with The Times.\n\n\u201cFederal employees should not be fired for doing their jobs,\u201d Mr. Sanders said in a statement. \u201cThe Department of Energy must investigate as to why Mr. Edelman was fired.\u201d", "title": "He Leaked a Photo of Rick Perry Hugging a Coal Executive. Then He Lost His Job.", "authors": ["Ben Protess"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Like many pioneers without a business sense, though, Haack did not reap financial rewards: He died of heart failure in 1988 at just 57, having spent the previous 15 years or so living in the basement apartment of his longtime friend and supporter Ted Pandel, a retired professor in West Chester, Penn. \u201cIn his last years he was on welfare,\u201d Mr. Pandel, 82, said by telephone. \u201cWe would go to food stores and I\u2019d be hiding from people from the university.\u201d\n\nRaised in Alberta, Canada, Haack moved to New York in 1954 to attend Juilliard, where he befriended Mr. Pandel. After dropping out, Haack pursued his interest in jerry-built instruments like the touch-sensitive Dermatron and Peopleodeon \u2014 the latter was even featured on the Steve Allen show \u201cI\u2019ve Got a Secret\u201d in 1966.\n\n\u201cHe could be seen as a kind of godfather of circuit-bending,\u201d said Peter Price, a Philadelphia electronic musician and writer who digitized over 200 reel-to-reel tapes of unreleased Haack material before they were shipped to the Provincial Archives of Alberta last fall. \u201cHe would take whatever kind of consumer objects he could get his hands on cheaply and tinker. There\u2019s whole areas of his output that nobody has any idea about, sort of analog-circuit algorithmic music where he would just build circuits and they would endlessly go.\u201d\n\nAhead of dance-music trends, Haack explored loops, samples and vocal distortion. He called his proto-Vocoder Farad and used it prominently on \u201cHaackula\u201d and the unreleased 1982 track \u201cParty Machine,\u201d which sounds like a Kraftwerk outtake. Tellingly, a 2004 documentary was titled \u201cBruce Haack: The King of Techno.\u201d", "title": "He Made Kids\u2019 Music and Albums About Lucifer. Now His Work Is a Rock Opera.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Gauging the effect of the airstrikes on the Taliban and Islamic State is also a high priority for his team. Watching and eavesdropping on the scurrying around by drug-lab operators whose depots were not hit in the first wave of strikes offered keen insights for planners drawing up the next set of strikes, helping them map out local Taliban networks.\n\n\u201cThe Taliban is trying to find other ways to make money,\u201d Lieutenant Conway said. \u201cWe have to stay one step ahead of that. Narcotics is still No. 1. But we\u2019re also looking for other sources of their revenues, such as extorting the local population.\u201d\n\nThe weekly intelligence updates from Lieutenant Conway and his team provide senior officers and planners here \u201cwith the detail and context needed to successfully plan and assess air operations in a very complex fight,\u201d Maj. Gen. David S. Nahom, the deputy United States air commander for the Middle East and Southwest Asia, said in an email.\n\nLieutenant Conway\u2019s path to his job here was a circuitous one. He grew up listening to war stories from his grandfather, a Naval Academy and Korean War veteran. When he considered joining the Navy after college, however, military rules at the time disqualified him because of surgery he had as a teenager to repair a hole in his heart.\n\nAfter law school and a brief stop at a technology company, Lieutenant Conway landed at the office of the Cook County State\u2019s Attorney in Chicago, initially slogging through misdemeanors and traffic court.\n\nWhen a department reorganization offered a job in the public corruption office, Lieutenant Conway, with his accounting background, became the lead prosecutor in several complicated embezzlement cases. One conviction involved a suburban welfare department official who skimmed $125,000 in welfare funds. Another focused on a township treasurer who overpaid himself $135,000 over three years.\n\nAbout this time, Lieutenant Conway learned that military rules had changed and that he could join the Navy Reserve with a medical waiver, which he did in May 2012. The news media picked up on the story.\n\n\u201cWho would steal a 90-pound tortoise?\u201d an anchor on WABC-TV in New York said on its newscast one day after the theft. \u201cThat is the question the police in Queens are trying to get to the bottom of today.\u201d\n\nBack in Connecticut, Millenium\u2019s new owner started to see all the news coverage about a missing 17-year-old tortoise in Queens. He recently spent a day exploring sites in Manhattan with his 16-year-old daughter and has been telling his mother not to worry about him when he is in jail.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Thursday morning, Ms. Waters drove her son to court in Queens, but she said she was too upset about the whole ordeal to be in the courtroom for the sentencing. \u201cI know that Shawn is going to be the laughingstock,\u201d Ms. Waters said.\n\nA judge sentenced him to six months in jail at Rikers Island. Mostly they complain about how Uber treats them poorly, even if they don\u2019t know I\u2019m a journalist. Probably not a good look for these companies.\n\nYou spend a lot of time on social media. You use Twitter in a way that is somewhat unconventional to many Times standards. Does this help with work?\n\nYou mean other Times employees don\u2019t use Twitter the same way I do? I am shocked!\n\nI kid, of course. I am all over the place on Twitter, and use it as a kind of narrative of both my life and the things that interest me. It\u2019s fun, stressful, anxiety-inducing and occasionally cathartic.\n\nBut despite appearances, it\u2019s actually been a very effective tool in doing my job. I talk to a lot of people through Twitter \u2014 either in public or in private \u2014 and feel that it\u2019s facilitated many, many connections that I would have not otherwise made were I not constantly rambling online. For source development, it\u2019s been fantastic.\n\nOutside your job, what tech product are you and your family currently obsessed with?\n\nHmm, probably HQ Trivia, that app that\u2019s literally a game show on your phone. My parents are even on it.\n\nOh, also, I\u2019m very late to this, but I am super into my pedometer on my iPhone. Who knew counting my steps would motivate me to walk more? Here\u2019s Why.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Nelson \u201chandled almost everything,\u201d she said, from securing the church and its pastor, Dr. Trunell D. Felder, to marry them on Christmas Eve, a particularly busy day, to lining up the wedding\u2019s gospel and R&B music performances, which left few dry eyes among the pews.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Cartwright and Mr. Nelson met, fittingly, over a piano in 2015 \u2014 one she was trying to get rid of. \u201cFred had just started as music director at the church, and I had this grand piano I was looking to sell,\u201d she said.\n\nThough the Nelson name was prominent in Chicago music circles \u2014 he started performing at age 6, playing piano as an opener for Ray Charles, and his father, Fred Nelson Jr., helped shape the city\u2019s gospel sound in the 1950s, \u201960s and \u201970s as the organist at First Church of Deliverance \u2014 she knew nothing of Mr. Nelson\u2019s background.\n\nStill, she felt intimidated by his job at the church because of its importance. New Faith, which seats 2,500, is home to six choirs. \u201cOne day I saw him walking down the hall, and I was going back and forth in my mind,\u201d she said. \u201c\u2018Should I tell him about the piano?\u2019\u201d If there was anyone who might know of a buyer, she thought, it would be Mr. Nelson. \u201cI finally got the nerve to ask him directly.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe had a picture of the piano, bought for the eldest of her two sons, Dionte Cartwright, now the youth music conductor at New Faith. But Mr. Nelson wanted to see the Yamaha Grand Disklavier in person. They made loose plans to meet at her house in the Chicago suburb Homewood, at a time when Mr. Nelson\u2019s chaotic schedule allowed. (In addition to his work with Ms. Franklin and at the church, he is an artistic director at the City of Matteson School District; music minister at First Church of Deliverance, where his father had played organ; and an independent producer, performer and arranger.)\n\nMs. Cartwright got word one day while she was driving her son Kyle Hinton, then 16, to the orthodontist that Mr. Nelson would be at her house in 20 minutes.\n\n\u201cI raced to get home \u2014 I barely made it \u2014 and I was trying to act normal,\u201d said Ms. Cartwright, who is curvy and petite. Mr. Nelson, 6 feet tall, barrel-chested and quick to laugh, put her at ease. \u201cHe was looking at the piano, and then we started talking about his daughter, who was having an H.R. problem at her job.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI had also just lost 30 pounds, and I was in my exercise clothes,\u201d she said. \u201cHe said he was diabetic, and I told him diabetes runs in my family, which was why I was exercising. He said he wanted to lose weight.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce Mr. Nelson left Homewood with a promise to be back in touch about the piano, Ms. Cartwright got curious: Did the turns their conversation had taken signal romantic interest?\n\n\u201cNext time I went to the gym, where I have this crew of workout friends, I was like, \u2018It seems like he\u2019s trying to get a little more information.\u2019 They were like, \u2018He\u2019s trying to ask you out!\u2019 So next time I talked to him I said, \u2018You need to find a workout partner,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cFred said, \u2018What about you? Will you be my life coach?\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt had been a while since Mr. Nelson, who was widowed in 2007, met someone he warmed to that quickly. His wife, Cynthia, had inflammatory breast cancer, a rare, aggressive form of the disease. They met as teenagers and had been married 22 years when she died. The couple\u2019s only daughter, Paige Nelson, now 29, was finishing her freshman year in college. \u201cThat was a crazy time,\u201d Mr. Nelson said.\n\nFriends remember it as a sad time. \u201cIt was a very tough period,\u201d said Ira McKenzie, Mr. Nelson\u2019s childhood best friend. \u201cFred is such a giving person. I would have to tell him, \u2018Man, you cannot save everybody\u2019s life.\u2019\u201d\n\nBefore he started dating Ms. Cartwright, who complements her soft-spoken persona with conservative dress and a huge, infectious smile, Mr. Nelson had been in another serious relationship. But something about Ms. Cartwright stood out.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe was pure,\u201d he said, meaning she was unfamiliar with, and not much interested in, many of the music industry figures with whom Mr. Nelson rubs elbows. Valencia Edwards, a friend Ms. Cartwright met on the job at a Chicago pharmaceutical company years ago, recalled Ms. Cartwright asking her who Clive Davis was after she met the music producer at an event with Mr. Nelson. \u201cShe asked me if I had ever heard of this \u2018Cleeve Davis\u2019 everyone was making such a fuss over,\u201d Ms. Edwards said, laughing.\n\nMr. McKenzie confirmed that Ms. Cartwright\u2019s anti-diva attitude won his friend\u2019s heart. The day the couple first met, \u201cFred called me as soon as he got in the car. He said, \u2018I just met the sweetest girl,\u2019\u201d Mr. McKenzie said. \u201cThe thing about Lynda was, she\u2019s grounded. She didn\u2019t want anything from him. He said, \u2018I think this girl is my friend.\u2019 And I knew that was it. You have to be friends before you can be lovers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe couple had their first date on June 13, 2015. Mr. Nelson picked her up and took her to his favorite Chicago restaurant, Tavern on Rush, and she gave up her diet. \u201cWe had three appetizers and two entrees that night, and I loved it,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhen I met Fred, my youngest son still had two years to go in high school,\u201d Ms. Cartwright said. \u201cI said, \u2018I\u2019m not going to date. I\u2019ll wait.\u2019 Because I wanted a storybook love affair.\u201d\n\nBut after she and Mr. Nelson had gone on four dates, \u201che asked me if we could have a committed relationship,\u201d she said. \u201cI had read all these books about how to have a relationship, and there\u2019s a process. I didn\u2019t want it to happen so fast.\u201d\n\nStill, there was no denying she was falling in love.\n\nMs. Edwards, her friend, picked up on it immediately. \u201cI went out with them several times, and every time she talked to Fred she would use her LaToya Jackson-whisper voice,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was all baby-sweetie. They took off so fast.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. McKenzie recalls the couple holding hands when he first met Ms. Cartwright. \u201cI was like, man, you\u2019re 50, not 15,\u201d he said.\n\nWithin months of their first date, Mr. Nelson was bringing Ms. Cartwright to concerts he conducted for Ms. Franklin in cities including Indianapolis and Detroit, and Ms. Cartwright was thinking long term. \u201cI said, \u2018I\u2019ll give him two years to give me a ring,\u201d she said. \u201cI was praying to God. I wanted us to be empty nesters together.\u201d After a year she grew impatient: \u201cHe told me several times he wanted to marry me. I never said it to him, but I started thinking, Why doesn\u2019t he put his money where his mouth is?\u201d\n\nOn Dec. 24, 2016, a year before their wedding day, he did. Between gigs in the waning months of 2016, Mr. Nelson and Mr. McKenzie had gone ring shopping in Chicago. As Ms. Cartwright ordered her second chocolate martini that night at Joe\u2019s Seafood, Prime Steak and Stone Crab, Mr. Nelson excused himself and went to his car, where he had left the princess-cut diamond solitaire ring that he and Mr. McKenzie had picked out.\n\nMr. Nelson said, \u201cI could tell she was getting tipsy, and I thought, Oh, God,\u201d but by the time he returned she had taken only a sip. He asked her to marry him from across the table. Ms. Cartwright, reserved even under the spell of a martini, quietly said yes. A flurry of waiters clapped, and they were engaged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe couple chose to get married in a simple ceremony just after regular Sunday morning services. Of the more than 1,000 congregants who filled New Faith\u2019s pews that snowy day, around 150 people \u2014 some who knew about the wedding in advance and some who didn\u2019t \u2014 stayed behind.\n\nDionte Cartwright walked his mother down the aisle to a church stage set with Christmas poinsettias while a full band performed the \u201cDreamgirls\u201d song \u201cWhen I First Saw You.\u201d Mr. Nelson, in a black tuxedo with a gold bow tie, was waiting with Kyle Hinton, the ring bearer. Before Dr. Felder, the officiant, completed a short, traditional marriage ceremony, there was a musical interlude: the platinum-selling gospel artist Percy Bady, who has known Mr. Nelson for more than 20 years, performed an original composition, \u201cLove Never Dies,\u201d on keyboard. Tears flowed.\n\nAfter the final \u201cI do,\u201d another R&B and gospel star, Terisa Griffin, followed Mr. Bady\u2019s performance with a burn-the-house-down rendition of \u201cI Hope You Dance.\u201d The country artist Lee Ann Womack made the song a hit, but Mr. Nelson had his own ideas about how he wanted Ms. Griffin to sing it.\n\n\u201cHe called me and said, \u2018I want you to do this song at my wedding. Make it the Gladys version,\u2019\u201d she said.", "title": "He Works With Divas, but Didn\u2019t Marry One", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kilic was the last defendant detained in a case against 11 human rights advocates who prosecutors said had links to Mr. Gulen\u2019s organization. The others were released in October.\n\nThe case is still pending, however, and the defendants face potentially long prison sentences if convicted. The next hearing is in June.\n\nMr. Kilic was accused of having used an encrypted cellphone application called Bylock, which prosecutors have claimed was the favored mode of communication among members of the Gulen movement, who were accused of plotting a July 2016 coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The attempt failed, but more than 250 people were killed confronting tanks on the streets.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the government crackdown that followed, tens of thousands of people were detained and accused of involvement in the coup attempt or of links or fealty to the Gulen movement. But the government has been accused of broadening the crackdown to imprison a wide range of political opponents and critics.\n\nMr. Gulen, who lives in Pennsylvania, has denied involvement in the coup attempt and has accused Mr. Erdogan of orchestrating it as an excuse to seize more power.\n\nMr. Kilic\u2019s case had become a symbol of the broader crackdown, Ms. Van Gulik said. The insistence by prosecutors that the representative of a prominent human rights advocacy group should be held with no evidence to explain why, she said, was \u201cemblematic of how far this crackdown has gone.\u201d\n\nMr. Kilic was ordered released after the Istanbul court accepted three expert reports that showed that he never had the Bylock application on his cellphone, said his lawyer, Murat Dincer. Despite the court\u2019s repeated requests, the prosecution also failed to provide police reports showing that he did have the application, Ms. Van Gulik said.\n\nTurkey has been under strong international pressure to release the thousands of detainees, including journalists, human rights activists and foreign citizens, who have languished in prison.\n\nGermany accused Turkey of taking political hostages and threatened economic sanctions against Turkey last summer after the seizure of the human rights advocates, who included a German citizen, Peter Steudtner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the German threat, Turkey\u2019s foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, said that while the government could not influence the judicial process he had urged the courts to accelerate the process.", "title": "Amnesty International Official in Turkey Ordered Released but Remains in Jail", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat do you think this image is saying? After many other large insurers abandoned the individual market created by the federal law and as President Trump has sought to dismantle the law, Centene doubled-down and has become one of the largest insurers still offering policies.\n\nBut the lawsuit underscores a critical question about whether Centene offers plans that provide its customers with access to the level of care required under the law. The suit claims that many doctors won\u2019t accept patients covered by Centene because of the company\u2019s refusal to pay legitimate claims.\n\nAs insurers like Centene have relied on smaller networks to control costs and better manage the care of patients, consumer advocates have raised concerns about whether some plans offered under the law provide sufficient access to doctors and hospitals. The law requires plans to meet certain minimum requirements.\n\nThe lawsuit recounts numerous examples of patients unable to find in-network doctors. In Washington State, Cynthia Harvey was billed for hundreds of dollars in medical costs after she discovered some of her care was out of network. When Ms. Harvey went to the emergency room last year, she was billed $1,544 by the doctor, and the lawsuit claims Centene had no emergency physicians participating in its network in the Spokane area at the time.\n\nThe insurer also denied some of the claims from a colonoscopy she had because she was at high risk for cancer, according to the lawsuit. Ms. Harvey successfully appealed many of the denials to state regulators, the lawsuit said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe lawsuit comes on the heels of a decision last month by Washington State regulators to fine Centene up to $1.5 million for having an insufficient network of doctors to treat people who signed up for plans sold under the Affordable Care Act. State officials said they received more than 140 complaints from people who had trouble finding a doctor, particularly a specialist like an anesthesiologist, who accepted the insurance or from individuals who received a surprise bill after they received treatment.\n\nIn a statement about the consent order the company reached with the state to be allowed to continue selling policies for 2018, Centene said it was committed to addressing \u201cknown issues in our network in select regions of the state\u201d and said it had taken actions to make sure its customers had access to services.\n\nThe company announced this week that it now covers more than 1.4 million people through the state marketplaces, with its chief executive, Michael F. Neidorff, describing its growth in the market as \u201cso dramatic.\u201d Centene attributes some of its success to its experience providing care under the Medicaid program or in its low-cost networks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSteven A. Milman, a periodontist in Round Rock, Tex., who is one of the plaintiffs, signed up for an Affordable Care Act plan from Centene last year. He and his wife paid about $1,200 a month. Dr. Milman had a previous policy from UnitedHealth Group. \u201cThey had a good panel of doctors and easy access,\u201d Dr. Milman said in a telephone interview. But UnitedHealth lost money in the market and stopped selling policies.\n\nChoosing between the local Blue Cross plan and one offered by Centene, Dr. Milman picked Centene after seeing that its network included a large medical group in Austin and getting recommendations for several doctors at that group. \u201cI bought Centene on that promise,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Dr. Milman soon found out finding a doctor within the network was much harder than he anticipated. The medical group he had picked was no longer in the network. When he called the doctor\u2019s office assigned to him by Centene, it turned out to be a obstetrician/gynecologist.\n\nDr. Milman\u2019s wife had no better luck. When she came down with an earache, she was on the phone with the plan for five hours before being sent to a clinic where she was treated by a nurse.\n\nBy the summer, Dr. Milman was fed up. He continued to see the doctor he had under the UnitedHealth plan, paying out of pocket for the visits. He will introduce a men\u2019s collection and work on fragrance as well as fashion and accessories.\n\nThe move is a return home of sorts for Mr. Slimane, 49, who began his career at Yves Saint Laurent and was hired by LVMH in 2000 to create Dior Homme, where his pin-thin jeans and sharp tailoring became the stuff of men\u2019s (and some women\u2019s) obsessions. This became as clear as a bloody footprint to me last week, as I walked through \u201cMurder Is Her Hobby\u201d at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, an exhibition of 19 miniature crime scenes created by Frances Glessner Lee in the 1940s and \u201950s as training tools for police investigators. The models, meticulously handcrafted by Lee, are known as \u2018\u2018The Nutshell Studies of Unexplained Death.\u2019\u2019 Nearly all are owned by the Harvard Medical School and on loan from the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, where they live, and continue to teach, some 70 years on.\n\nI encourage you to drop what you\u2019re doing and go to see them, before they go back into seclusion after the show closes on Jan. 28. The Nutshells are not only ingenious devices for the instruction of crime scene examiners, they are a body of imaginative work that would have established any artist\u2019s career and place in art history.\n\nMs. Lee was not a schooled artist. She was a rich, frustrated woman in her 60s when she began them, and almost belligerent in her pursuit of a place in the infant field of forensic science. Lee shared its passion about the deceptions of crime and the need for truth in investigation. Entry to this professional realm was a double-locked door: men, and in particular police, held the keys. The majority of the victims in the Nutshells are women, found in their homes.", "title": "Heiress Plotted 19 Grisly Crimes. Investigation Underway.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Helio Castroneves was not quite ready to shelve his illustrious career as an IndyCar driver when the racing mogul Roger Penske, his boss since 2000, came to him two years ago with a proposal: racing sleek, high-tech sports cars.\n\nCastroneves, a three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500 and one of the circuit\u2019s biggest stars, had finished third in the race for the 2016 championship, and he wanted to make one last charge to his first series title last year.\n\nBut the time for a career transition has come for Castroneves, 42, who finished fourth in the standings in 2017. He has joined Penske\u2019s Acura team that will compete this year for the International Motor Sports Association\u2019s WeatherTech SportsCar Championship. He plans to race in the Indianapolis 500 in May, but his full-time occupation is now as a sports-car racer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s away from something I did so many times, but I accept the challenge,\u201d Castroneves said over lunch last week in New York. \u201cEverything has seemed to be rejuvenated. Sports cars are something Roger always wanted. It\u2019s part of his core.\u201d", "title": "Helio Castroneves Steps Away From IndyCar and Into a New Role", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWomen the Abortion War Leaves Out\u201d (Sunday Review, Jan. 14):\n\nMichelle Oberman reminds us that reproductive decisions are often shaped by socioeconomic circumstances, and that for poor women in the United States, these factors can feel overwhelming, even determinative.\n\nUnregulated anti-abortion counseling centers are making it increasingly difficult for pregnant women to get access to accurate health information and care. The multimillion-dollar, anti-abortion counseling industry receives public funding in several states, including funds meant to support families in need.\n\nThere is a better way, one led by reproductive justice advocates \u2014 including in Oklahoma \u2014 who are working to ensure that poor women can get access to contraception, abortion and birth care.\n\nThe reproductive justice movement, founded in the 1990s by women of color, understands that we can provide pregnant women and mothers with the support they need to thrive without first requiring that they submit to false information. And it calls on us to craft public policies that make it easier to pursue parenthood without taking other options away.", "title": "Opinion | Help for Pregnant Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea will send athletes to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea next month after shunning the Games for eight years. President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and his government hope the North will take a break from testing missiles while its athletes participate.", "title": "Opinion | Heng on North Korea in the Winter Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGLENDALE, Ariz. \u2014 Henrik Lundqvist had taken his team to the shootout, but the veteran goalie needed a moment to collect his thoughts as he stared down his former teammate Derek Stepan with the game and an additional point on the line.\n\nLundqvist got the job done one final time, stopping Stepan on the final attempt of the shootout.\n\nLundqvist stopped 37 shots through overtime and all three he faced in the tiebreaker, Mika Zibanejad scored in the shootout and the Rangers beat the Arizona Coyotes 2-1 Saturday night.\n\nLundqvist\u2019s save on Stepan, a teammate for seven seasons until he was traded to Arizona last June, sealed the Rangers\u2019 third win in five games, and seventh point in the last four.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a mind game almost when you face Derek there at the end,\u201d Lundqvist said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to start overthinking it. But it was fun.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStepan smiled a little when reliving the moment with his ex-teammate.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s the king for a reason. He backbones that team really nicely and he was excellent,\u201d Stepan said. \u201cI thought it was actually going to squeak by him but somehow he got a pad on it.\u201d", "title": "Henrik Lundqvist Has the Last Word as the Rangers Win in a Shootout", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Herbert Schmertz was born on March 22, 1930, in Yonkers. His father, Max, was a jeweler, and his mother, the former Hetty Frank, was a homemaker.\n\nMr. Schmertz grew up in New Rochelle, N.Y., and received a bachelor of arts degree from Union College, in Schenectady, N.Y., in 1952 and a bachelor of laws from Columbia University in 1955. (He added a doctor of laws degree from Union in 1977.)\n\nHe did intelligence work in the Army in Washington from 1955 to 1957, then worked for the American Arbitration Association before becoming an organizer for John F. Kennedy\u2019s presidential campaign in 1960.\n\nThat work led to a lifelong association with the Kennedy family and, once Robert F. Kennedy became his brother\u2019s attorney general, a job as general counsel to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.\n\nMr. Schmertz joined Mobil in 1966 as a labor lawyer, but took a leave two years later to work on Robert Kennedy\u2019s presidential campaign; he would take another to work on Senator Edward M. Kennedy\u2019s presidential campaign in 1979.\n\nHe took charge of Mobil\u2019s public affairs department in 1969 and filled that role almost continuously until leaving Mobil in 1988 to form his own company. For most of that stretch he had the title of vice president and played a significant role in shaping the company\u2019s policies.\n\nCritical of the news media, Mr. Schmertz advocated what he called creative confrontation \u2014 a markedly different approach from that of most companies, which tried to do their influencing behind the scenes.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor a long time, business and business leaders didn\u2019t feel it was part of their responsibility\u201d to make their voices and opinions heard, he told United Press International in 1986. They believed, he continued, \u201cthat if they ignored unfair criticism it would go away.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added, \u201cI believe you should meet it head on and deal with it.\u201d\n\nTo do just that, in October 1970, Mr. Schmertz began buying space on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times to express the company\u2019s views in essay form. Sometimes the essays responded to the news of the moment; other times they addressed broader issues, like mass transit. They advertorials appeared in other newspapers as well, and Mr. Schmertz made scores of television appearances.\n\nHis methods and visibility brought him all sorts of labels \u2014 \u201cMobil\u2019s superflack,\u201d \u201cthe Billy Martin of corporate P.R.\u201d and, as the headline on a New York magazine profile of him put it, \u201cOil Slick.\u201d\n\nPolitically, Mr. Schmertz was hard to pin down; in addition to working on the Kennedys\u2019 campaigns, he helped Bob Dole, the Republican senator from Kansas, in his 1988 presidential run. Mr. Schmertz often said that his public-relations philosophy was nothing more than applying the sharp-elbowed lessons of politics to the business world.\n\nHe once pulled Mobil advertising from The Wall Street Journal in a dispute over coverage. In 1986 he laid down his ideas and war stories in a book, \u201cGoodbye to the Low Profile: The Art of Creative Confrontation,\u201d written with William Novak.\n\nYet many in the public-relations business thought his blustery approach did as much harm as good.\n\n\u201cTo go out and argue with people in public, it\u2019s like seeing two people fighting in the street,\u201d Richard Cheney, another public relations executive, told The Washington Post in 1988. \u201cYou\u2019re not going to take sides, you just want them to stop.\u201d\n\nThe less flashy pillar of Mr. Schmertz\u2019s philosophy was what he called \u201caffinity of purpose\u201d \u2014 getting policymakers and the public to have a presumptive good opinion of your company by associating it with high-minded things like \u201cMasterpiece Theater\u201d (now known simply as \u201cMasterpiece\u201d). Countless viewers heard the phrase \u201cmade possible by a grant from Mobil\u201d as they tuned in \u201cThe First Churchills,\u201d \u201cI, Claudius\u201d and other British productions presented by \u201cMasterpiece,\u201d an anthology series produced by WGBH in Boston.\n\nBecause of its support from Mobil and other oil companies, PBS was sometimes called the Petroleum Broadcasting Service in those early years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCultural excellence generally suggests corporate excellence,\u201d Mr. Schmertz told New York magazine, explaining the millions of dollars Mobil put into arts ventures.\n\nAmong his clients after he formed his own company was the World Bank, which hired him in 1994 to try to improve its image.\n\nMr. Schmertz and his first wife, the former Ida Schaap, were divorced in 1976. His second marriage, to the former Susan Burley, ended in divorce in 1993. In addition to his daughter Nicole, Mr. Schmertz, who lived in West Palm Beach, is survived by another daughter, Lexy Schmertz; his sons, Anthony, Thomas and Conor; and six grandchildren. His brother, Eric, a noted labor mediator, died in 2010.\n\nAlthough few public-relations specialists today would take as abrasive a tack as Mr. Schmertz sometimes did, the modern media landscape is full of advertiser-influenced or controlled content that calls to mind his early forays into advertorials. On his retirement from Mobil in 1988, he was asked to name his greatest achievement.\n\n\u201cI think,\u201d he told The Times, \u201cthat Mobil has made it respectable for companies to have views, opinions and philosophies and to express them.\u201d", "title": "Herbert Schmertz, Innovative Public-Relations Man, Dies at 87", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWonder Woman,\u201d \u201cGet Out\u201d and \u201cLady Bird\u201d are among the nominees for the Producers Guild of America\u2019s top award, an insider Hollywood prize that often holds clues to the eventual winner of best picture at the Oscars.\n\nThe Producers Guild Award nominees, announced on Friday, are:\n\n\u201cThe Big Sick\u201d\n\n\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d\n\n\u201cDunkirk\u201d\n\n\u201cGet Out\u201d\n\n\u201cI, Tonya\u201d\n\n\u201cLady Bird\u201d\n\n\u201cMolly\u2019s Game\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Post\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d\n\n\u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d\n\n\u201cWonder Woman\u201d\n\nIn eight of the last 10 years, the producers\u2019 winner has also won best picture, though the exceptions have been notable. Last year\u2019s PGA winner, \u201cLa La Land,\u201d lost best picture to \u201cMoonlight,\u201d and the year before, the producers picked \u201cThe Big Short,\u201d while the Academy went with \u201cSpotlight.\u201d", "title": "Here Are the Producers Guild Contenders, Led by \u2018Wonder Woman\u2019 and \u2018Get Out\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Once again, Americans are being treated to a Capitol Hill cliffhanger over a government shutdown. The themes and plot twists differ each time, but this is a formulaic drama that reveals Congress\u2019s bipartisan failure to perform its most basic task: to fund the federal government.\n\nThis battle isn\u2019t over the 2018 budget; lawmakers haven\u2019t gotten there yet. It\u2019s a fight over short-term legislation to extend current funding levels and avert a government shutdown at midnight on Friday.\n\nOne could almost \u2014 but not really \u2014 feel sorry for Republicans. This is a mess President Trump created, and Republicans are tiptoeing around him trying to fashion a temporary fix that he won\u2019t demolish with a tantrum or a tweet.\n\nIn September Mr. Trump abruptly decided he\u2019d be ending the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which protects hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought illegally to this nation as children from deportation. (Those include cuffs, paddles, blindfolds and feathers, if rarely actual sex, according to Simone Justice, a pro-domme and BDSM educator in California.) Political applications of BDSM make sense when you consider the gender roles that trap women in submissive societal positions are the same as those locking men in sexually dominant ones \u2014 which lead men to dominatrixes, to escape, said Ms. Storm: \u201cWomen are socialized to be submissive little kittens. Men think they have to be some kind of alpha male.\u201d\n\nSeveral attendees were hesitant to give their names for this article, fearing friends\u2019 and colleagues\u2019 reactions. \u201cIf they caught wind I did a class with a dominatrix, I\u2019d be a laughingstock,\u201d said one 39-year-old investment bank vice president. Her colleagues don\u2019t know that she has been using the techniques at work. \u201cSomeone looks at you the wrong way on the trading floor. You could spend forever figuring out what that meant. Now I just call it out: \u2018Hey, uh, you look sad.\u2019 You\u2019re testing, and creating transparency.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nIn Academy lexicon, the word \u201cyou\u201d is dominant and the word \u201cI\u201d is submissive. Neither is inherently superior. \u201cIf I\u2019m in control of you, my attention is outward, so precisely fixed on the other person that I almost forget I exist,\u201d Ms. Urbaniak told the audience. If you\u2019re submissive, \u201cyour attention is focused inward, on yourself and your feelings.\u201d\n\nDominant and submissive are, she said, rhetorical and energetic states, and can be unmoored from the social hierarchies that empower men. It\u2019s a post-gender outlook, with as much in common with theories of performativity as with women\u2019s empowerment programs like the Makers Conference and Lean In, which focus on elite communities as a way to tap female power.\n\nDemographically, though, the Academy is similar to those peers. The participants I spoke with said most of the students are straight and cisgender (25 percent are nonwhite, according to the company), although the school is open to anyone who identifies as a woman. At Cornering Harvey, the majority of attendees had heard about the workshop through the School of Womanly Arts. Here is a preview of who you\u2019ll see:\n\nOfficial and unofficial emergency responders\n\nDavid Dahlberg, a fire prevention technician, who saved 62 children and staff members from a blaze-encircled summer camp in July during the wildfires in Southern California.\n\nAshlee Leppert, an aviation electronics technician in the Coast Guard, who rescued dozens from hurricane ruins. After extensive treatment, Mr. Bradford became the first blind double-amputee to re-enlist in the Marine Corps.", "title": "Here\u2019s Who Will Sit With the First Lady at the State of the Union", "authors": ["Emily Baumgaertner"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "I go on Amazon to stock up. In addition to the basics I find a few luxury items: chocolates, scented soap, cologne \u2014 a spray of something lovely might transport someone, I think, even if just for a few moments. As Amazon offers items in bulk I have enough for two bags. I find the bags at Goodwill. One is a soft gray quilted tote; one is a patterned French knockoff. I put $10 in each bag so the freshened-up lady can get a cup of coffee and a muffin. While I wait for the items to arrive, I case my Union Square neighborhood. I spot the perfect recipient, a woman sitting on the street on Park Avenue South at the corner of 17th Street. She is in her late 20s or early 30s, with a backpack and a cardboard sign.\n\n\u201cBetter homeless than a victim of domestic abuse,\u201d the sign reads.\n\nAs soon as my items arrive I rush back to 17th Street. The perfect recipient is gone; the person now sitting on the sidewalk with a sign is a young man. I move on through the neighborhood. This makes me realize a few things: There are far more homeless men than women in the street. When it is winter and someone is huddled under layers of protective covering, it is not easy to tell who is male and who is female. I see only one homeless person I am certain is a woman, who appears to be deranged. After an hour and a half, I have given away nothing.\n\n\u201cThe problem is, I want to give the bag to someone who will use it,\u201d I explain to my friend Herb over dinner. \u201cI don\u2019t want to give it to someone who is so far gone she\u2019ll put the Tampax in her ear. I don\u2019t want to get up the next morning and see the underwear scattered all over 14th Street.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt can\u2019t work that way,\u201d Herb says. \u201cIt\u2019s a gift. You have to hand it to somebody and not look back.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThat might be O.K. if I had dozens of bags,\u201d I say. \u201cBut I just have two. I\u2019m not being unrealistic here. I just want to give it to somebody who will take it into Starbucks and be able to clean up; then she\u2019ll look better and feel better and get a minimum wage job and within a year she\u2019ll be a vice president. Or maybe she\u2019ll be one of those people who writes a play about being homeless a few years later.\u201d\n\nI widen my search to Grand Central. The few women I see seem to be in no shape to care for themselves. One is wearing a blue bunny costume and is seated next to a stack of garbage bags filled with clothing and magazines. Another, an older woman in layers of clothing, comes at me yelling. I back off, frightened and thinking she isn\u2019t the sort of homeless person who I want to give my bag to anyway, and am ashamed of both feelings.\n\nA friend I\u2019ve told about the gift bags has told me that the women I\u2019m searching for go to shelters in freezing weather, that the ones who remain in the street have serious mental problems like dementia and schizophrenia. I think she may be right. On my third day of fruitless searching, when I see a young woman sitting on the sidewalk with two cats on leashes, asking for money, I stop. She may be a hustler, but if sitting on the sidewalk in December is the best way she\u2019s got to make a buck, it\u2019s a pretty bleak hustle. And she\u2019s age appropriate and I\u2019m tired. I give her a bag, wish her luck and leave town for a few days, glad to be taking a break from the gift bag project.\n\nI return just in time for a cold snap.\n\nThe morning temperature is 9 degrees, it\u2019s unlikely anyone will be in the street, but I grab the gray quilted bag anyway and take the train to my Upper East Side appointment. There are no homeless people on the train or the street. Then, returning downtown, just past the gate of the 67th Street subway station, I spot someone. He or she is wearing a dark parka and a black face mask and holding a coffee cup with a few bills, and is asking for change. I think the voice is female but with the face covered I\u2019m not sure. I walk up to the person, trying to figure out a polite way to ask. There\u2019s nothing to do but blurt it out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAre you a lady?\u201d I ask.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d she says, \u201cI\u2019m homeless.\u201d\n\nI give her the soft gray shoulder bag.\n\n\u201cFor me?\u201d she says, stunned, but as far as I can tell from someone whose face is almost completely hidden, happy stunned.\n\n\u201cYeah,\u201d I say.\n\nI put out my hand and we shake.\n\n\u201cGood luck,\u201d I say.\n\nThen I walk away. I\u2019ll tell you the truth, it will be fine with me even if she doesn\u2019t write a play.\n\n##", "title": "Here\u2019s a Present \u2014 if You Qualify", "authors": ["Joyce Wadler", "I Was Misinformed"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The review was previewed to The New York Times on Monday.\n\nWhile Heritage found much that it liked about Mr. Trump\u2019s first year, it also found much that could be improved on \u2014 most notably the snail\u2019s pace of nominations by the White House. Of the 635 major postings across the executive branch that require Senate confirmation, the White House has no nominee for 245 of those.\n\nAs eight years of a Democratic administration drew to a close, Heritage began developing in 2016 a list of 334 policy prescriptions that a new Republican administration could adopt. It included a variety of actions, like reimposing work requirements for welfare recipients, ending the program that shields young immigrants brought here illegally as children, withdrawing from the Paris climate accord and eliminating certain gender identity protections.\n\nHeritage said that 64 percent of those items were enacted by the administration either through executive order or another means of enforcement, or included in Mr. Trump\u2019s budget, which has not been voted on by Congress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Reagan\u2019s first year, only 49 percent of Heritage\u2019s wish list items were embraced by the president or enacted. At the time, Heritage identified a familiar problem for why the administration\u2019s policies were wanting. In almost every federal agency, Heritage said in November 1981, \u201cdelayed appointments, unqualified or misqualified appointments, or the appointment of individuals who are not committed to the President\u2019s goals and policies\u201d had delayed or thwarted policy changes.\n\nIn its endorsement of Mr. Trump\u2019s first year, Heritage is largely echoing a widely shared sentiment across the conservative movement: While conservatives may often find themselves in disbelief about the president\u2019s impulsive and reckless style, his policy decisions are buying him a lot of good will.\n\nEd Feulner, a Heritage founder and former president, described Mr. Trump\u2019s thinking as liberated from the typical cautiousness of a president. \u201c\u2018Hell, why can\u2019t we do that? Let\u2019s try it. Let\u2019s make it happen,\u2019\u201d Mr. Feulner said, speaking of Mr. Trump\u2019s attitude.\n\n\u201cIn some respects, Trump the non-politician has an incredible advantage, even over Ronald Reagan,\u201d Mr. Feulner added. \u201cBecause Ronald Reagan knew there were certain things government couldn\u2019t do.\u201d\n\nMs. James said that regardless of Mr. Trump\u2019s foibles, he has remained focused on keeping his promises to conservatives. And if he keeps doing that, those promises may be what conservative voters care about \u2014 above all else, she added. \u201cSo say what you will, I think the other side of the aisle would be salivating to find their version of a Donald Trump \u2014 someone who came in, kept their promises and did what they said they were going to do,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cEven though,\u201d she added, \u201cthey are unhappy about tweets or language or unforced errors.\u201d", "title": "Heritage Foundation Says Trump Has Embraced Two-Thirds of Its Agenda", "authors": ["Jeremy W. Peters"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Obesity is linked to prostate cancer, scientists know, but it\u2019s not clear why. On Monday, researchers reported a surprising connection.\n\nWhen prostate cancers lose a particular gene, they become tiny fat factories, a team at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston reported in a paper published in Nature Genetics.\n\nThen the cancers spread from the prostate, often with deadly effect. Prostate cancers that have not lost that gene also can spread, or metastasize \u2014 in mice, at least \u2014 but only if they have a ready source of fat from the diet.\n\nThat finding suggests that dietary fat can substitute for the loss of the gene, fueling prostate cancer. Moreover, the investigators found, an obesity drug that blocks fat production can make metastatic prostate cancers regress in mice and prevent them from spreading.", "title": "High-Fat Diet May Fuel Spread of Prostate Cancer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The complaint from the young woman was initially brought to Jess O\u2019Connell, who was the national director of operations for the Clinton campaign.\n\nMs. O\u2019Connell, who is currently the chief executive officer of the Democratic National Committee, handled the investigation and advised the Clinton campaign manager, Patti Solis Doyle, that Mr. Strider should be fired, according to three people familiar with the events.\n\nMs. O\u2019Connell told colleagues that she was concerned that the young woman making the allegations should not be demoted when she was moved from Mr. Strider\u2019s supervision. The woman requested to have no more interactions with Mr. Strider, and she was moved to a different job within the campaign, reporting directly to Mike Henry, the deputy campaign manager.\n\nThe investigation into Mr. Strider\u2019s conduct was described as brief, but it included a review of a number of emails he sent the young woman, who had shared an office with him.\n\nA spokesman for Mrs. Clinton provided a statement from Utrecht, Kleinfeld, Fiori, Partners, the law firm that had represented the campaign in 2008 and which her advisers said has been involved on sexual harassment issues.\n\n\u201cTo ensure a safe working environment, the campaign had a process to address complaints of misconduct or harassment. When matters arose, they were reviewed in accordance with these policies, and appropriate action was taken,\u201d the statement said. \u201cThis complaint was no exception.\u201d\n\nLate Friday night, more than a day after The New York Times reached out to her aides for comment, Mrs. Clinton posted on Twitter that she was \u201cdismayed when it occurred.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe added that she called the woman on Friday \u201cto tell her how proud I am of her and to make sure she knows what all women should: we deserve to be heard.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMrs. Clinton did not address why she ignored advisers\u2019 recommendations that she fire Mr. Strider.\n\nThe woman\u2019s experience and the reaction to it have not been previously reported. Until now, former Clinton associates were unwilling to discuss the events for publication.\n\nBut that changed after the start of the #MeToo movement, in which dozens of men across the country and across different industries have been fired or suspended for sexual misconduct.\n\nThis account was based on interviews with eight former campaign officials and associates of Mrs. Clinton\u2019s.\n\nThey said that Ms. Solis Doyle, the campaign manager, and other senior campaign officials discussed the situation involving Mr. Strider and Mrs. Clinton\u2019s response at the time. Some of them were troubled that he was allowed to remain on the campaign.\n\nThe complaint against Mr. Strider was made by a 30-year-old woman who shared an office with him. She told a campaign official that Mr. Strider had rubbed her shoulders inappropriately, kissed her on the forehead and sent her a string of suggestive emails, including at least one during the night, according to three former campaign officials familiar with what took place.\n\nThe complaint was taken to Ms. Doyle, the campaign manager, who approached Mrs. Clinton and urged that Mr. Strider, who was married at the time, be fired, according to the officials familiar with what took place. Mrs. Clinton said she did not want to, and instead he remained on her staff.\n\nMs. Doyle was fired shortly after that in a staff shake-up in response to Mrs. Clinton\u2019s third-place finish in the 2008 Iowa caucuses. And Mr. Strider never attended the mandated counseling, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation.\n\nThe woman who made the accusation against Mr. Strider in 2008 has not spoken publicly about it. She, like most campaign staff members, signed a nondisclosure agreement that barred employees from publicly discussing internal dynamics on the campaign, according to two people with direct knowledge of the contract. Reached by a reporter, she declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Solis Doyle also declined to comment.\n\nMrs. Clinton\u2019s candidacy has been cited as an inspiration for the #MeToo movement, but she has not played a visible role in it. After several Hollywood actresses told The Times and The New Yorker that Harvey Weinstein, a longtime friend and donor to the Clintons, had harassed or assaulted them, Mrs. Clinton spoke out against his behavior, saying in a statement that she was \u201cshocked and appalled by the revelations.\u201d\n\nWeeks later the actress Lena Dunham, one of Mrs. Clinton\u2019s most visible celebrity supporters in her 2016 presidential bid, told The Times that she warned two Clinton campaign aides against associating with Mr. Weinstein. \u201cI just want you to know that Harvey\u2019s a rapist and this is going to come out at some point,\u201d Ms. Dunham said she told the campaign.\n\nNick Merrill, the communications director for Mrs. Clinton, said at the time Ms. Dunham spoke publicly that she was mistaken. \u201cAs to claims about a warning, that\u2019s something staff wouldn\u2019t forget,\u201d he said.", "title": "Hillary Clinton Chose to Shield a Top Adviser Accused of Harassment in 2008", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Amy Chozick"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "And yet, for Mrs. Clinton, it\u2019s the latest \u2014 and perhaps last \u2014 cruel twist in a public life full of them.
