Her loss to Mr. Trump helped ignite the kind of movement she\u2019d once been poised to lead but that she now mostly watches from the sidelines.\n\nEver since she wielded a bullhorn at Wellesley in the late 1960s and later instructed her classmates to \u201cpractice politics as the art of making what appears to be impossible possible,\u201d Hillary Rodham seemed destined to empower women. But over the next several decades, the promise of that young activist collided with the realities of presidential elections and her husband\u2019s personal scandals.\n\nMrs. Clinton \u2014 scarred by the blowback for saying she chose to pursue a career rather than staying home to bake cookies, chastised by her husband\u2019s West Wing aides for declaring that \u201cwomen\u2019s rights are human rights\u201d in Beijing in 1995 and warned by her 2016 campaign chairman to avoid talking about glass ceilings \u2014 came to adopt a more tentative embrace of how she talked about her gender.\n\nThroughout her career, many women would view Mrs. Clinton as an imperfect vessel for the feminist cause. She was a Yale-educated lawyer who at the height of the 1970s women\u2019s movement moved to Arkansas to put her own ambitions on hold in furtherance of her husband\u2019s career. A refrain I\u2019d often hear from voters on the 2016 campaign trail was that they were happy to vote for a woman, just not \u201cthat woman.\u201d\n\nBut the roiling, messy, often painful progress made since Mr. Trump took office has recast Mrs. Clinton, who recently topped Gallup\u2019s poll of most admired women. Her career brings to light the truth that there is no perfect vessel, that sooner or later, the harder we strive, the higher we climb, we all become that woman.", "title": "Hillary Clinton Ignited a Feminist Movement. By Losing.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Hillary Clinton made an unexpected cameo at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, delighting many in the audience but turning off some high-profile viewers at home.\n\nJames Corden, the show\u2019s host, introduced the bit on the premise of interviewing candidates to record the audio version of \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d the political book by Michael Wolff about chaos inside the Trump administration. After a list of celebrities \u2014 John Legend, Cher, Snoop Dogg, Cardi B and DJ Khaled \u2014 gave it their farcical bests, Mrs. Clinton got big applause as she appeared.", "title": "Hillary Clinton Reads \u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 at the Grammys", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "This is the point where we start sinking into a dark hole, mulling whether she should have spent more time in Wisconsin. Then, of course, comes the question of whether Clinton lost because she was a woman. The answer is: sort of. Her gender was both a handicap and an enormous selling point. Would the Democrats have wanted Harry Clinton to be their nominee? (Just try to construct a Harry Clinton in your mind. I dare you.)\n\nAnd \u2014 wait a minute, don\u2019t get depressed. There\u2019s another side: Even if her sex was a problem, it allowed her to transform the country more than many men who won the job. While losing, she made it normal for women to run for the most powerful office on the planet.\n\nThis is critical. Look at all the breakthroughs women have made in the last century, and you\u2019ll notice how many of them involved just making their presence in some new place seem matter of fact. All that pain and struggle to win the right to vote, and what did it get us short term? Warren Harding. But long term, it created a world where the big gubernatorial election in Virginia was analyzed in terms of women in the suburbs and that knockout Senate race in Alabama was pretty much all about black women streaming to the polls.\n\nOr take a more modest example. There was a time \u2014 not all that long ago \u2014 when television executives believed a woman could not be the solo anchor on the national evening news because our voices didn\u2019t convey the proper sense of authority. Then in 2006, Katie Couric took over at CBS, to great hubbub and commentary. She did fine. Life moved on. In 2009 Diane Sawyer became the anchor at ABC. She did fine. There was barely a peep. The great triumph actually did not arrive until everybody found the whole matter boring.\n\nNow, when people handicap the next Democratic presidential nomination, there are lots of women in the mix \u2014 Elizabeth Warren, Kamala Harris, Kirsten Gillibrand. (And, O.K., Oprah.) Whoever runs, the important thing is that primary debates will no longer resemble Shriner conventions. Women will be all over the place. Soon, they\u2019ll be half the big decision-makers. It will be normal.\n\nWhen Hillary Rodham Clinton graduated from law school and started her career, virtually the only women who had made it into the Senate were either honorary appointees for a brief symbolic term (the first, Rebecca Latimer Felton, got one day) or a senator\u2019s widow. The exceptions proved the rule. The great Margaret Chase Smith came from the House, where she had succeeded her dead husband. Nancy Kassebaum happened to be the daughter of the Republican presidential candidate Alf Landon.\n\nYou get the idea. And there was Hillary. On the one hand, another political wife. On another, a marker for the entire country, driving home the fact that Congress was never going to be just a guy thing again. At times of despair I like to recall that when she was sworn into the Senate in 2001, my little niece watched the coverage intensely, and asked my sister whether it was possible for men to be senators, too.\n\nCampaigning in 2000, almost everywhere Clinton went, she drew enthusiastic crowds. Partly, they were there to see the first-lady-turned-candidate, the one who had come through more disasters than the Titanic. Partly they were already imagining their party\u2019s next standard-bearer. But nobody seemed more excited than women around her own age, who turned out in droves, no matter how unpleasant the weather or remote the spot. I always thought they saw her and thought about second chances: If you put in the time as a stay-at-home mother or took non-dream jobs because of all the responsibilities at home, you could still move on at midlife to something new and totally terrific. And maybe the kids would be sitting proudly behind you on the bus, like Chelsea.", "title": "Opinion | Hillary Lost, but the Future Is Hers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Nowadays, some older residents are returning to the townhouses, while others are investigating new adult communities like Gateway at Royce Brook. In June 2016, Mr. and Mrs. Palinkas paid $604,000 for a three-bedroom house in a gated 55-plus section there, after selling a 3,800-square-foot Country Classics house they bought in 1997 for $430,000.\n\nYounger families are also discovering Hillsborough. Pinal and Abhay Shah and their two daughters, seeking more space and good schools, and wanting to remain close to their Jain temple in Somerset, moved in 2014 from a townhouse in Somerset to a four-bedroom colonial on an acre in Hillsborough\u2019s west side. They purchased their house for $541,000.\n\n\u201cThe lifestyle is pretty urban, and the schools and town are quite high tech, but when you come out and see the farms, you realize it\u2019s really rural,\u201d said Mrs. Shah, 40, a pharmaceutical chemist. \u201dRight outside our house is a huge farm and the big mountain. We watch the sun set there each evening. It\u2019s very pretty.\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nSourland Mountain to the west, and the Delaware and Raritan Canal and Millstone River to the east, serve as the natural borders of Hillsborough. The town\u2019s most distinguishing marker, however, is the line that runs down its middle, Route 206.\n\nThis north-south highway is the commercial spine of Hillsborough, with numerous shopping plazas, big-box stores, and individual and chain restaurants lining both sides. It is also the bane of many drivers\u2019 existence as they crawl from one intersection to the next on a busy Saturday afternoon.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnce meant to be a two-lane highway serving New Jersey\u2019s more rural areas, the stretch of Route 206 between Somerville and Princeton has become a major thoroughfare as towns like Hillsborough and neighboring Montgomery become increasingly populated. Plans to build a Route 206 bypass have been in the works since 1974, and a stretch of that 1.66-mile bypass was built in the early 2010s, but the project was halted in 2015 because of local opposition and a lack of funding.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHillsborough Deputy Mayor Gloria McCauley said the project is scheduled to resume in 2018, and will hopefully be completed by 2020. By then, Ms. McCauley said, Hillsborough should be \u201cbetter able to compete for business against bigger towns like Bridgewater and Somerville.\u201d\n\nFor now, the highway serves as an unofficial dividing line, with larger properties, including older working farms, occupying the west side, and most of the newer homes, including the Country Classics development, on the east side. The more concentrated multifamily housing is found in the central and north sections of town.\n\nJacqueline Haren, an agent with Coldwell Banker who has owned three homes in Hillsborough, said that besides the school system, buyers are drawn to Hillsborough for its inclusiveness and diversity. \u201cThere\u2019s a great sense of community \u2014 there are tons of sports programs, all run by volunteers,\u201d said Ms. Haren, who volunteered as the Pop Warner cheerleading coach for seven years.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\nThere are currently 116 properties on the market in Hillsborough, about a third of which are townhouses or condominiums, according to Karl von Loewe, an associate broker with Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices in Hillsborough.\n\nThe median selling price of homes in 2017 was $318,000, down from $335,000 in 2016. Mr. von Loewe attributed the drop to increased activity at the lower end of the market last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe highest priced home on the market right now is a five-bedroom 1720 farmhouse on three acres, listed at $1.199 million. The lowest priced is a one-bedroom, one-bathroom 1985 townhouse being sold \u201cas is\u201d for $94,000.\n\nHouses in the Country Classics development typically list in the $700,000s to high $900,000s. Townhouses range from $250,000 to $300,000, while monthly rentals go from $1,200 for a two-bedroom apartment in one of the older developments to $2,895 for a two-bedroom, two-bath townhouse in Sunnymeade Run.\n\nThe Vibe\n\nSports fields abound, according to Deputy Mayor McCauley, who took part in last April\u2019s ceremonial opening of the 369-acre Mountain View Park, a former federal storage site, which added state-of-the art ball fields.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe 4,000-acre Sourland Mountain Preserve offers more passive recreation, like biking and hiking trails and a stocked fishing pond.\n\nHillsborough\u2019s crown jewel is Duke Farms. It was once home to the tobacco and power tycoon James Buchanan Duke and his daughter, Doris, and is now a 1,000-acre estate with barns, an orchid house and nature preserve, with trails and programs that are free to the public.\n\nFor the less outdoorsy, the Bridgewater Mall is about five miles north, while downtown Princeton is a 15- to 20-minute drive south.\n\nBridgewater SOMERSET New York City 22 287 Somerville Hillsborough duke farms N.J. 202 Hillsborough sourland mountain preserve 206 Delaware Raritan Canal mountain view park 602 Millstone River Montgomery SOMERSET 601 1 Princeton 1/4 mile\n\nThe Schools\n\nThe public school system has six elementary schools serving students from kindergarten through grade four. Auten Road Intermediate School is for fifth and sixth graders, while Hillsborough Middle School serves seventh and eighth graders. Hillsborough High School has 2,420 students in grades nine through 12.\n\nBeginning in the third grade, all students are provided their own Chromebooks, supplied by the district. The high school offers 29 interscholastic sports programs, and more than 80 extracurricular activities, including marching and concert bands, regionally and nationally competitive debate and robotics teams, and a model peer mentoring program.\n\nFor private schooling, the Immaculate Conception School in Somerville serves 460 students from prekindergarten to grade eight.\n\nFor the 2015-16 year, the average SAT reading score for Hillsborough High School was 599 and the average math score was 614, as compared with the state averages of 537 and 538.\n\nThe Commute\n\nHillsborough is around 50 miles southwest of Midtown Manhattan, and takes about one and a half hours to drive via Interstates 287 and 95.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe town has no train station. Commuters to Penn Station have a couple of options: They can take a New Jersey Transit train from Bridgewater, N.J., with a change in Newark, which takes about 80 minutes and costs $14.75 one way, or $421 for a monthly pass; or they can go direct from New Brunswick to Penn Station in about an hour for $14 one way, or $393 monthly.\n\nIn October 2016, Suburban Transit added a daily express bus route from Hillsborough, making four stops in New York City. Every half-hour from 6 to 7:30 a.m., buses depart from the Hillsborough Promenade shopping center, with four returning from the city each evening, starting at 4:30 p.m. The trip takes about an hour and 20 minutes and costs $15 one way, or $420 for a monthly pass.\n\nThe History\n\nEncamped in Sourland Mountain during the Revolutionary War, General George Washington ran drills with his soldiers using corn stalks as pretend guns. This fooled the British into thinking the colonists had received reinforcement troops and weapons, and caused them to retreat to New Brunswick.", "title": "Hillsborough, N.J.: A Sprawling Community With an Urban and Rural Feel", "authors": ["Jill P. Capuzzo", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "In Hollywood and in the media, 2017 was a year of reckoning \u2014 powerful men brought down under the weight of their own misdeeds. But the opposite happened in hip-hop: Many of the genre\u2019s most creatively promising rising talent arrived with troubling back stories, speeding onto the Billboard charts \u2014 and into the ears of millions \u2014 while operating under the cloud of criminal accusations or convictions. And unlike those who were quickly removed from perches of power, these young artists thrived, in spite of \u2014 or perhaps in part owing to \u2014 the severity of the allegations lodged against them.\n\nThe accusations of heinous criminal behavior are clear: XXXTentacion has been charged with the assault of a pregnant woman and later with witness tampering; he pleaded not guilty to all charges. Tay-K is facing a pair of murder charges, for which he maintains his innocence. Kodak Black has had a string of arrests and is facing trial for criminal sexual conduct; his lawyers say he is innocent. And 6ix9ine pleaded guilty in 2015 to the use of a child in a sexual performance.\n\nBut the statistics are just as clear: XXXTentacion\u2019s first album, \u201c17,\u201d debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart, and his breakthrough single \u201cLook at Me,\u201d which began as a SoundCloud loosie, made it to No. 34 on the Hot 100. Tay-K\u2019s \u201cThe Race\u201d went to No. 44 on the Hot 100. Currently, 6ix9ine has two songs on the Hot 100, \u201cGummo\u201d at No. 14 and \u201cKooda\u201d at No. 54. Kodak Black\u2019s first album, \u201cPainting Pictures,\u201d debuted at No. 3 on the album chart, and was certified gold. \u201cTunnel Vision,\u201d a single from that album, was certified double platinum and went to No. 6 on the Hot 100.", "title": "Hip-Hop\u2019s Year of Dangerous Living Put the Accused on the Charts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Like other novelties of the post-hipster age, the source of the value is not just the finished work, but also the tedious and rarefied conditions of its production. The spectacle of painters hanging from a wall is as much Colossal\u2019s product as the murals themselves. Colossal offers time-lapse footage and photos for clients to share on social channels.\n\nIn a way this makes wall dogs part of a live show. While studio painters can step back and check their work, wall dogs paint close up at a large scale. A few wrong strokes can quickly send a mural off into the realm of the uncanny valley. \u201cKendrick Lamar\u2019s face isn\u2019t like anybody else\u2019s face, but it\u2019s similar,\u201d said Mr. Coatney, painting high above Canal Street. \u201cYou start with the big similarities, and then you make it him.\u201d\n\nMr. Coatney helps run Colossal\u2019s training program, a formalized version of the apprenticeships that preserved hand-paint knowledge for the last hundred years. His apprentice on the Spotify mural was Will Krieg, 24, whose father also works as a sign painter, in Colorado.\n\n\u201cHalf our crew has an art history background,\u201d Mr. Coatney said. \u201cYou know, they went to art school and have a degree. And then the other half has no traditional art experience, and they came in really raw with a lot of drive.\u201d", "title": "Hipster Culture and Instagram Are Responsible for a Good Thing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Elsewhere there have been artistic directors of note who neither teach nor choreograph. City Ballet, however, has been a different organism. Would it be changed beyond recognition by such a director? And, of prime concern to dance-goers and dancers alike: Can the company continue in its dual capacity as the world leader in new choreography and the foremost exponent of the Balanchine-Robbins repertory?\n\nSince Dec. 9, after Mr. Martins took a leave of absence, the day-to-day artistic direction of City Ballet has been in the hands of an impressively young foursome: Craig Hall and Rebecca Krohn (ballet masters), Mr. Peck and Jonathan Stafford (a former principal now on the school\u2019s faculty). The company also has an executive director, Katherine E. Brown, who runs business matters, reporting directly to the board. (The post was created for her in 2009.)\n\nHow now to move forward? For weeks, people on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter have proposed candidates that include men and women, people of various races and sexual orientations. Please note, though, how few of them fulfill the multiple roles of the Balanchine-Martins model. The old creative ballet-master practice has been largely eroded. (Not entirely: Helgi Tomasson at San Francisco Ballet and Ib Andersen at Ballet Arizona \u2014 City Ballet alumni \u2014 are both artistic directors who choreograph, teach and coach.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBalanchine didn\u2019t invent the notion of a directing ballet master \u2014 the teacher who made ballets and controlled policy. It went back to at least the 18th century. (Its 19th-century exemplars included August Bournonville and Marius Petipa.) For Balanchine, like masters before him, a company\u2019s dancers had to be custom-trained by its school. And the choreographer who made the ballets had to keep developing his style by teaching, often daily, in the classroom, which became a kind of laboratory.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf City Ballet is run by a person who neither teaches nor choreographs, it will move far in spirit from the Balanchine-Kirstein principle. Certainly this may well be the moment for greater artistic separation between the company and the school \u2014 and yet that\u2019s easier said than done, since no company depends more on works, by Balanchine and others, in which students of several ages dance.\n\nWe live in post-Balanchine times. \u201cBallet is woman,\u201d he said \u2014 but his kind of ballet was always a man\u2019s view of woman, and a solely heterosexual one. Though the Balanchine worldview made women empowered and inspiring, it did not include women\u2019s equality in the workplace or same-sex relationships. Balanchine brought many women to the top, and yet neither he nor Kirstein considered one to be his successor.\n\nWhen alive, Balanchine was controversial, not least in the demands he placed on his female dancers. Seemingly unstoppable, he transformed his art. And today, many of the teachers and choreographers influenced by him \u2014 including the team now at City Ballet\u2019s helm \u2014 either never met him or were born after his time.\n\nIt was Kirstein who labored to ensure the school and the company would outlive Balanchine. Conversely, Balanchine expressed no confidence that they would, at least on any scale of consequence. Some of his devotees, lastingly despondent about his legacy, still insist either that the flame died with him or that it passed elsewhere. Of the company after his death, Balanchine remarked, \u201cApr\u00e8s moi, le board.\u201d\n\nNow the boards of the company and the school are faced with big decisions about replacing Mr. Martins. Yet these very boards retained him after the first serious complaints were made against him in the last century. Who knew what and for how long?\n\nLet nobody \u2014 the boards, critics, other interested parties \u2014 rush into promoting their special favorites or pursuing their own agendas. The responsibility of redirecting City Ballet is both considerable and complex. Let the thoughts percolate. History is about to change \u2014 but how?", "title": "History Is About to Change at New York City Ballet. How?", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Two of the young men had killed themselves. The scientists do not know if their head injuries had contributed to their suicides. The other two had died of brain swelling that most likely was related to \u201csecond-impact syndrome,\u201d which can occur if someone experiences two head injuries within a short period of time.\n\n\u201cNone of the individual impacts was serious enough, in and of itself, to have caused death,\u201d says Dr. Lee Goldstein, an associate professor of psychiatry at Boston University School of Medicine and the study\u2019s senior author.\n\nBut when the researchers closely examined the young men\u2019s brains, they found more harm than they had expected. The teenagers\u2019 blood-brain barriers, a natural defense system that keeps harmful substances from entering the brain, appeared to have been damaged, and many of the small blood vessels throughout their brains had sprung tiny leaks. Two of the brains showed disquieting accumulations of tau proteins near these broken blood vessels, and one brain had diagnosable Stage I C.T.E.\n\nThis was the first time that scientists had found signs of incipient or actual C.T.E. so soon after a brain injury and in people so young.\n\nBut since so many other factors might have contributed to the brain conditions, from genetics to earlier hits to the head, the researchers next decided to look at similar head impacts in animals and track precisely what happened inside their skulls.\n\nUsing young male mice, they applied relatively mild jolts, designed to result in a sudden, strong jerking of their heads, much as occurs during head-to-head tackles and other impacts. Afterward, some animals showed symptoms of a rodent version of a concussion, stumbling and performing poorly on memory tests.\n\nThe scientists then injected some animals with a dye that cannot cross a healthy blood-brain barrier and scanned the living animals\u2019 brains. In about half of the mice, they saw signs of the dye in their brains, indicated that their blood-brain barriers had become permeable. Many of the mice also showed signs of leaky blood vessels and other damage, including inflammation and disruptions in the electrical activity within their brains. Some had early signs of tau accumulation.", "title": "Hits to the Head May Result in Immediate Brain Damage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "CALGARY, Alberta \u2014 Canada\u2019s Olympic hockey team will not have current N.H.L. players on the ice, but plenty of players from other leagues.\n\nHockey Canada drew talent Thursday from seven different leagues across North America and Europe after the N.H.L. bowed out of competing in South Korea. That\u2019s in stark contrast to Canada\u2019s Olympic champion teams in Vancouver (2010) and Sochi (2014), which were loaded with N.H.L. stars.\n\nForwards Gilbert Brule, Mason Raymond, Derek Roy and Wojtek Wolski and goaltender Ben Scrivens are former N.H.L. veterans on the team. It\u2019s the first time Canada will go to the Olympics without N.H.L. players since 1994.\n\nGeneral Manager Sean Burke, Coach Willie Desjardins and Team Canada officials scoured Russia\u2019s Kontinental Hockey League and Switzerland\u2019s National League, among others, for players talented enough to wear the Maple Leaf on the world stage.", "title": "Hockey Canada Gets \u2018Geography Lesson\u2019 in Forming Men\u2019s Olympic Team", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "There was some concern among NBC executives in November that viewers could flee the morning program after the firing of Mr. Lauer, who had been with the show for 20 years.\n\nBut Ms. Kotb, a longtime fan favorite for her freewheeling segments with Ms. Gifford, has provided more than a steadying hand, and may even have given the show a boost. NBC has defeated its ABC rival \u201cGood Morning America\u201d every week since Mr. Lauer was removed, something it had not done for four consecutive weeks in more than five years.\n\nThe \u201cToday\u201d lead has narrowed \u2014 the program averaged around 4.4 million viewers the week before Christmas, about 54,000 viewers more than \u201cG.M.A.\u201d \u2014 and there is some uncertainty whether the lead is sustainable. Further, all three morning shows experienced rating drops last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA surprise boon from an emergency host isn\u2019t new at NBC. When Brian Williams was suspended for six months in 2015 from his evening newscast after he was caught embellishing stories about a Middle East reporting assignment, Lester Holt replaced him and the show\u2019s viewership figures were strong. Mr. Holt became the permanent replacement later that year.\n\nLikewise, the departures of Charlie Rose from \u201cCBS This Morning\u201d and Mr. O\u2019Reilly from Fox News after public allegations of sexual misconduct have done little to disrupt either network. Fox News is still No. 1 among cable news networks in prime time, and the ratings for \u201cCBS This Morning\u201d have held steady while Gayle King and Norah O\u2019Donnell continue in Mr. Rose\u2019s absence. (CBS has not yet hired a replacement.)\n\nMs. Kotb cut her teeth as a local reporter and anchor, including a six-year stint for the CBS affiliate in New Orleans. She joined NBC in 1998 as a correspondent for \u201cDateline.\u201d\n\n\u201cOver the past several weeks, Hoda has seamlessly stepped into the co-anchor role alongside Savannah, and the two have quickly hit the ground running,\u201d said Andrew Lack, the chairman of NBC News, in an early morning memo to staff on Tuesday. \u201cThey have an undeniable connection with each other and, most importantly, with viewers, a hallmark of \u2018Today.\u2019 Hoda is, in a word, remarkable. She has the rare ability to share authentic and heartfelt moments in even the most difficult news circumstances.\u201d\n\nThough NBC wanted to alert its viewers first, the decision had been made for at least a week and one magazine interview had been arranged. Right at 7 a.m., as the on-air announcement was being made, People magazine released its cover for next week, featuring a smiling Ms. Kotb and Ms. Guthrie under the somewhat incongruous headline \u201cOur hearts were broken.\u201d (That referred to Mr. Lauer.) Both co-anchors were quoted by the magazine, discussing their excitement about the new NBC morning hour.\n\nOn Tuesday, Ms. Kotb also revealed that she had gotten a text from Mr. Lauer.\n\n\u201cHe texted me, and he said congratulations and some really nice words, and it meant the world when I saw the text pop up,\u201d Ms. Kotb told \u201cEntertainment Tonight.\u201d \u201cMy heart just went like, you know, it meant the world to see that.\u201d", "title": "Hoda Kotb Named to Replace Matt Lauer as Co-Anchor of NBC\u2019s \u2018Today\u2019", "authors": ["John Koblin", "Prashant S. Rao"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Natural disasters appeared to contribute to the strong sales, as homeowners began rebuilding after the hurricanes in Texas and Florida and wildfires in California. While much of the destruction occurred before the holiday shopping season, it most likely took time before insurance money and disaster aid began to find its way into consumers\u2019 pockets.\n\nThe strongest holiday sales occurred in Houston, which had been pummeled by a Hurricane Harvey, First Data analysis showed.\n\n\u201cClearly that had an impact in boosting the retail numbers in the affected areas,\u201d said Craig Johnson, president of Customer Growth Partners, a retail consulting firm.\n\nSales at stores offering building materials and supplies increased 8.1 percent in November and December from a year earlier, while home-furnishings and furniture sales increased 7.5 percent, according the retail federation, which draws its data from the Census Bureau. Those two categories showed the biggest gains in sales, followed by electronics and appliance stores, at 6.7 percent.\n\nWhile the storm may have helped in some areas, retail sales showed strength across a broad range of categories, economists at Morgan Stanley pointed out in a research note on Friday, prompting the bank to increase its estimate for economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2017.\n\nEven categories that have struggled the most showed signs of improvement. Sales by general merchandisers \u2014 which include department stores \u2014 increased 4.3 percent in November and December from a year earlier.\n\nLarge traditional retailers such as Macy\u2019s, Target and Kohl\u2019s have reported sales gains during the holidays that have helped lift their investors\u2019 confidence.", "title": "Holiday Retail Sales Soared, With Biggest Increase Since Recession", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The industry had different plans. Hosts installed on red-carpet pre-shows assured viewers that they would still have \u201cfun\u201d while recognizing the \u201cmoment.\u201d E! ran a fashion segment that converted runway trends \u2014 bird decals, princess silhouettes \u2014 into all-black to see how they\u2019d look when repurposed for anti-assault branding. As it turned out, the look mapped easily onto the celebrity body, often with skintight dresses, and E! happily fed actresses into its \u201cGlambot\u201d (the network\u2019s photographic gimmick \u201cpresented by VW\u201d) to capture them in vaguely pornographic slow-motion. By the time the SAG Awards rolled round, E! hosts had come upon a blandly marketable term for this activism-themed display: \u201cgirl power.\u201d\n\nThe fashion industry has been eager to integrate its brands into the \u201cnot-fashion moment,\u201d too. On Instagram before the Golden Globes, Laura Dern, one of the evening\u2019s nominees, lifted a bedazzled wrist to the camera, with the caption: \u201cThanks @bulgariofficial for this amazing watch. Reminds me that Time\u2019s Up.\u201d The post satisfied several imperatives at once: It promoted her appearance at the show, endorsed a luxury brand and protested rape. Viewers at home could show their support by buying their own Time\u2019s Up products, offered at various price points \u2014 from a $12 tote bag to a $380 designer sweater.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn this commodified atmosphere, it was difficult to process the appearance of real activists on the red carpet: The #MeToo founder Tarana Burke came as Michelle Williams\u2019s date, while Meryl Streep brought along Ai-jen Poo, executive director of the National Domestic Workers Alliance. The tactic bucked expectation \u2014 namely, that actresses tie their public personas to their relationships with men \u2014 and gave these pioneering activists exposure that\u2019s hard to come by, but it also revealed the impossibility of dismantling an event bent on promoting a certain kind of femininity and luxury at once.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe image of white actresses paired with activists of color suggested a kind of moral accessorizing. And the meeting of celebrities and \u201cregular\u201d people came tinged with a preset narrative, one where the celebrity\u2019s perceived exceptionalism is only enhanced by her engagement with the real world. But when Ryan Seacrest interviewed Ms. Williams and Ms. Burke on the red carpet, E! made it clear which it valued most \u2014 women\u2019s appearance, or what they have to say. The network shrank Ms. Burke\u2019s image into a corner as soon as she began speaking and turned its gaze to the actress Dakota Johnson. She twirled.\n\nOn social media, the transactional nature of celebrity activism is sharpened. Ms. Portman joined Instagram on New Year\u2019s Day in order to promote Time\u2019s Up, submitting herself to the expectations of modern-celebrity ultra-accessibility for the cause. She followed a few dozen users: fellow activist-actresses, her husband and a suite of Dior accounts. By elevating Dior to that echelon, Ms. Portman ensured a space for the brand\u2019s commentary just under a Time\u2019s Up post: \u201cDearest Natalie, we are proud to have had the opportunity to partner with you to show our support for the #TimesUp Legal Defense Fund by making your dress.\u201d Nicole Kidman also joined Instagram in the midst of the campaign \u2014 the platform itself announced her debut in a news release \u2014 and her first photograph promoted her Golden Globes win, #TimesUp and Instagram itself, all at the same time.\n\nWatching this sparkling protest unfold, it\u2019s easy to forget what exactly is being protested. The ugliness of rape and abuse is polished into optimistic hashtags and spun into glamorous dresses. In glad-handing Hollywood, criticizing the industry is verboten, but using one\u2019s platform to advocate for other people is so expected it\u2019s a clich\u00e9. (Mr. Weinstein himself was a master of linking his films to social causes, cynically pitching the award show ballot as a kind of morality test.) In focusing the messaging of Time\u2019s Up outward \u2014 as a campaign to end sexual harassment in all workplaces \u2014 actresses have stepped into a quite traditional role, actually, of the celebrity who is both superficially appealing and actually deep, an icon of beauty and virtue.\n\nThe campaign\u2019s goal to extend protections to working-class women is admirable. But it\u2019s canny, too: Turning the focus away from Hollywood makes Hollywood a lot more comfortable with the inquiry. It leaves an opening for the industry\u2019s response to the reckoning to also be a dodge. The most electrifying moments of this protest have come when Hollywood women choose instead to model what it looks like to interrogate their own industry\u2019s destructive norms: When Debra Messing broke red carpet geniality to speak out against E!\u2019s underpayment of women, straight into an E! microphone, or when Ms. Portman presented the Golden Globes\u2019 best director nominees as \u201call-male.\u201d\n\nWe often speak of a celebrity\u2019s influence in terms of \u201cexposure,\u201d but exposure can also be destructive, especially for women. In addition to installing a host, the SAG Awards seeded its show with female presenters, which Kathy Connell, the SAG Awards\u2019 executive producer, called \u201ca unifying salute to women who have been very brave in speaking up.\u201d But when actresses present an award, they also present themselves \u2014 their looks, their clothes, their beauty \u201cwork,\u201d their diets and ideally, their affability. In this environment, \u201ccelebrating women\u201d also means shielding problematic men, who are suddenly afraid to show their faces lest they get smacked for their own bad behavior. On the SAG Awards red carpet, the embattled nominee James Franco slipped past the microphones, leaving his sister-in-law, Alison Brie, to awkwardly answer for him.\n\nIt goes without saying that all of this is quite easier for men. Just as they\u2019re not required to uphold the same standards of beauty as their female peers, men are generally excused from carrying the moral weight, too. At the Golden Globes, they got by silently wearing Time\u2019s Up lapel pins. By the SAG Awards, even that small gesture of solidarity had all but vanished. (Kumail Nanjiani and Joseph Fiennes were notable exceptions.) Even men\u2019s financial contributions to the Time\u2019s Up legal defense fund have been overshadowed by women\u2019s. Many male celebrities haven\u2019t even seemed to have done the due diligence of a PR consult. Justin Timberlake captioned his pre-Globes Instagram snap: \u201cHere we come! And DAMN, my wife is hot! #TIMESUP #whywewearblack.\u201d The bar is so low for men that this was, according to Instagram, the most-liked post of the night.\n\nThere is something about the rank hypocrisy on display that is actually useful. One way to push Hollywood toward change is to heighten its contradictions, drawing out the gap between its shimmering idea of itself and its darker realities. The image Hollywood builds for itself at these self-congratulatory events can be used as a bargaining chip for behind-the-scenes activist wins. As the SAG Awards neared, pressure mounted for the guild to protect its workers by installing a real code of conduct to address harassment. And as \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d racked up award nominations, the revelation that Mark Wahlberg earned much more to participate in reshoots than his co-star Ms. Williams \u2014 reshoots necessary to scrub the film of Kevin Spacey, and make it palatable for post-#MeToo audiences \u2014 created such a PR nightmare that Mr. Wahlberg ended up donating his $1.5 million salary to Time\u2019s Up.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven the Time\u2019s Up pin \u2014 so easy to wear, so difficult to justify \u2014 has proved a quietly brilliant tactic for flushing out men who fail to live up to its symbolism. When Mr. Franco attended the Golden Globes earlier this month, grinned down the red carpet and bounded onstage to claim a statuette for \u201cThe Disaster Artist,\u201d he wore the Time\u2019s Up logo pinned to his lapel. As the night unfolded, female acting students and collaborators began filing complaints on Twitter about Mr. Franco\u2019s own behavior, noting the hypocrisy of the pin. When Mr. Franco appeared on Seth Meyers\u2019s show days later, he was grilled over the allegations. A Los Angeles Times report came next. Mr. Franco skipped the Critic\u2019s Choice Awards, and when he turned up at the SAG Awards last Sunday, his very appearance made news. This time, he didn\u2019t wear the pin. Aziz Ansari, who himself weathered his own hypocrisy scandal after wearing the pin at the Golden Globes, didn\u2019t even show up. All of a sudden, a Hollywood awards show is a perilous place for some men to be.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill. When I watched Mr. Franco get questioned by Mr. Meyers, I thought about an incident from a few years ago, when Matt Lauer began a \u201cToday Show\u201d interview with Anne Hathaway by interrogating her about a paparazzi upskirt photo taken as she exited a car, capturing her image without underwear. Hollywood is still a place where women are punished more for doing nothing than men are for doing just about anything. For a woman, getting old is as much of a career-ending affront as an assault allegation is for a man. When Mr. Meyers opened his Golden Globes monologue by greeting the \u201cladies and remaining gentlemen,\u201d I thought of all the women who don\u2019t \u201cremain\u201d in Hollywood, either, pushed out through abuse or just discarded. One of those women \u2014 until recently \u2014 was Rose McGowan.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. McGowan, who made her name starring in 1990s indie films and later the TV show \u201cCharmed,\u201d spoke out this fall about being assaulted by Mr. Weinstein in 1997, during what she was led to believe was a business meeting in his hotel suite. She\u2019s now emerged as the most prominent actress to take aim not just at Hollywood abusers but at Hollywood itself. As Time\u2019s Up organizers walk red carpets, she\u2019s sniping from the sidelines. (Ms. McGowan and other accusers of Mr. Weinstein were not invited to the campaign\u2019s Golden Globes coming-out party.) On Twitter, she\u2019s called out \u201cfancy people wearing black to honor our rapes.\u201d Of Ms. Streep, she wrote: \u201cYOUR SILENCE is THE problem. You\u2019ll accept a fake award breathlessly & affect no real change.\u201d And after CAA opened its doors to hosting Time\u2019s Up organizing meetings, Ms. McGowan accused the agency of sending \u201cmany into the Monster\u2019s Lair\u201d itself.\n\nMs. McGowan\u2019s commentary is both a necessary critique of the smooth-edged Time\u2019s Up tactics and a way to differentiate her own activist content. In the coming days she will release a memoir, \u201cBrave,\u201d and an E! documentary series, \u201cCitizen Rose.\u201d The first trailer for \u201cCitizen Rose\u201d aired during E!\u2019s Golden Globes preshow, and again before the SAG Awards, and its opening line \u2014 \u201cI was in the middle of my second movie for his company, and I get assaulted\u201d \u2014 is itself more real and more damning than anything that\u2019s been said at these Hollywood events.\n\nIn the weeks before the show\u2019s debut, Ms. McGowan knocked the Time\u2019s Up activists who failed to support it: \u201cNauseating Hollywood \u2018progressives\u2019 celebrities suddenly so concerned with their images as sex harassment fighters but won\u2019t even retweet to support BRAVE or Citizen Rose.\u201d It seems absurd to judge another person\u2019s support of assault survivors on whether or not they tweet about your TV show. But in Hollywood, where product and cause are inextricable, it makes a kind of sense.", "title": "Hollywood Uses the Very Women It Exploited to Change the Subject", "authors": ["Amanda Hess"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "We \u2014 as writers and critics, as consumers of popular art, as a culture \u2014 have a lot of rethinking to do. One of the mantras of the moment is that \u201ceverybody knew\u201d about what the predators, rapists and gropers were doing, and that the ubiquity of such behavior was an open secret. That\u2019s a tricky phrase, of course, and it invites observers of the industry to assess our own complicity. Is the open secret that men in power frequently behave despicably and with impunity? Or does it involve the particular things Mr. Weinstein, Louis C.K., Kevin Spacey, Mr. Lasseter, Mr. Ratner, Dustin Hoffman and others (so many others!) are alleged to have done? What did we know, and how did we know it?\n\nPhoto\n\nDARGIS All I ever heard about Mr. Weinstein was that he was a bully. Being a jerk isn\u2019t a crime \u2014 a lot of executives would be in jail if it were \u2014 and it wasn\u2019t news or novel. It was largely hearsay in an industry that runs on fear (which encourages silence) and traffics in gossip, some malicious, some diversionary and some strategic, as we know from too many Oscar campaigns. The difference now is the dozens of women who have publicly accused Mr. Weinstein and the investigations into their allegations by The New York Times and The New Yorker, which have turned hearsay into news. There\u2019s a preponderance of evidence, which brings me to Woody Allen.\n\nIn 1992, Mia Farrow learned that her longtime lover, Mr. Allen, then 56, had been seeing her daughter, Soon-Yi Previn, who was around 21. Later that year, allegations surfaced that he had sexually molested Dylan Farrow, his 7-year-old daughter with Ms. Farrow. The judge in their custody case wrote that evidence of abuse remained inconclusive and Mr. Allen was never charged. For her part, Dylan Farrow has been steadfast in her accusations that he assaulted her. I think that a lot of critics read about this case and tucked that information away. Jump to his latest, \u201cWonder Wheel,\u201d which is about a desperate, morally reprehensible middle-aged woman whose lover, an Allen surrogate, ditches her for her bodacious, much younger stepdaughter.\n\nI\u2019ve liked and loved some of Mr. Allen\u2019s movies, and loathed others, but I\u2019ve always put the allegations against him aside because he wasn\u2019t charged and I wanted to review the work, not the man. Even so, Mr. Allen\u2019s movies can be hard to take if you\u2019re a woman. He has written great female characters \u2014 given humanity by brilliant performers \u2014 but too many are ditzes, shrews and dewy young things gaga over uncomfortably older men and Allen stand-ins. \u201cWonder Wheel\u201d manifests some of his worst tendencies; the sexism is overt and his blurring of life and art is repellent. In my review, I cited his marriage to Ms. Previn and Dylan Farrow\u2019s allegations, a history I\u2019ve seen as a malignant cloud. I had never referred to that history before because I hadn\u2019t seen it in the work. Now I did.\n\nMr. Weinstein was fouling up the air when I wrote my review, so sexual assault was certainly on my mind. But as you said to me when we later talked about the movie, it also felt as if Mr. Allen were trolling his critics.\n\nSCOTT He was also trolling his defenders \u2014 those who cling to the idea that an artist\u2019s work has nothing to do with his life. Mr. Allen and Roman Polanski have figured in can-we-separate-the-art-from-the-artist debates for a long time. Mr. Polanski, who was publicly forgiven by one teenage victim, remains both a fugitive from American justice and an active filmmaker. Mr. Allen continues to make a movie a year, and a dwindling chorus of apologists has insisted that to discuss those movies with reference to very public aspects of his personal life offends the integrity of criticism.\n\nBut the idea that you could separate the art from the life, a conceptually and practically incoherent notion in any case, is as ludicrous for him as it is for Louis C.K. The principal subject of Woody Allen\u2019s work has always been Woody Allen, and his insistence on putting himself into the picture leaves his defenders in the distasteful position of having to choose between denial and apology: Either \u201cbecause I like his movies, I can\u2019t bring myself to believe he molested his daughter,\u201d or \u201cbecause I like his movies, I have decided not to care if he molested his daughter.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNot that I can exactly let myself off the hook. Long before I became a film critic, I was a Woody Allen obsessive. I\u2019m hardly unusual among men of my generation for having learned a lot of what I know (but was afraid to ask) from him. About sex, Jewishness, literature, New York and a whole lot more \u2014 about myself, in sum. I kept his books by my bedside for most of my adolescence, and saw his movies over and over. It\u2019s not possible for me to separate art from life \u2014 his life or mine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDARGIS This year\u2019s anguished discourse about art and artists underscores that criticism is rooted in lived experience. There\u2019s no right or wrong way to review (well, there is, but that\u2019s a discussion for another time). But I\u2019m as impatient with critics who embrace self-serving auteurist fundamentalism or aesthetic formalism as I am with those belligerent fan boys who insist that only a comic-book obsessive can review a superhero movie. None of these camps want their pleasures challenged or their bubble worlds burst by reminders that a cherished director, say, denigrates women. I mean, by all means enjoy! But don\u2019t expect me to shut up about it.\n\nCriticism is always personal and so is movie love, which is why I\u2019ve been delighted by female-driven movies as different as \u201cLady Bird,\u201d \u201cFaces Places,\u201d \u201cWonder Woman\u201d and \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d \u2014 all of which speak to me in some way. These are the movies that in some modest yet real way feel like rejoinders to all the stories of assault and abuse that reminded us, outrage by outrage, of what a cesspool the movie industry can be. Women had been assaulted, their careers derailed. And all because some grotesque excuse for a human being had gone into a business that has historically encouraged, profited from, ignored and rewarded sexism and misogyny.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSCOTT Some of the most insightful writing about the meaning of the Weinstein revelations \u2014 by you, by our colleague Amanda Hess, by Rebecca Traister in New York magazine and Melissa Gira Grant in The New York Review of Books \u2014 has argued that the sexual depredations of Mr. Weinstein and others are also a labor issue. The public record is now overflowing with testimony from women whose ambitions were thwarted, whose aspirations were sullied, whose efforts to get through a meeting or a rehearsal or a day\u2019s shooting were disrupted and derailed because the men they were working for and with saw them not as colleagues or collaborators but as bodies to be humiliated and exploited.\n\nThis isn\u2019t just a matter of individual behavior. The boundaries of complicity have not yet been mapped, and the purging of the bad guys has an air of corporate damage control. If the creeps can be expunged, maybe the system can survive. It shouldn\u2019t. The stories that continue to emerge, in every industry, add up to more than just a catalog of crimes. They constitute a case for reparations.\n\nThe movie business might start by designating a pool of money \u2014 maybe equivalent to the value of the Miramax and Weinstein Company libraries, and the budgets of every Brett Ratner film and some fraction of Pixar\u2019s worldwide revenues \u2014 to fund movies written and directed by women. Some people might see that as a threat to meritocracy. I would challenge those people to use the words \u201cBrett Ratner\u201d and \u201cmeritocracy\u201d in the same sentence. The idea that Hollywood functions by rewarding excellence is laughable on its face.\n\nDARGIS Ha, ha \u2014 though honestly it is hard to laugh given that the revelations of abuse are further proof of what some of us have been saying for a very long time: that the industry\u2019s sexism isn\u2019t in our imaginations. It isn\u2019t a female fantasy or a \u201chysterical\u201d feminist myth. As for compensation, I think that\u2019s a good idea, but it\u2019s instructive that we haven\u2019t heard about many (any?) concrete institutional actions that the industry is taking to correct its wrongs from the inside. Some moves \u2014 like removing names from credits \u2014 evoke the old Soviet-era purges, when so-called undesirable elements were ousted. Of course getting fired isn\u2019t like a bullet to the head, though maybe it feels that way in Malibu.\n\nThe problem is that industry talk is cheap and its apologies feel the same. So what now? The recently announced activist group Time\u2019s Up, which seeks to end sexual harassment both inside and outside Hollywood, looks promising. But how about inside the corridors of power? Is it time for quotas? How about the Rooney Rule? Versions of that rule \u2014 which requires teams in the National Football League to interview at least one minority candidate for top positions \u2014 have been adopted by some tech companies. It\u2019s apparently stalled in the N.F.L., but it is a place to start. In 2014, the Directors Guild of America added language to its contract that required major television studios to maintain or establish director programs that \u201cfocused on diversity \u2014 complete with enforceable provisions.\u201d I\u2019d like to see enforceable provisions throughout the industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nSCOTT The deeply ingrained homogeneity of the business is reflected on the screen. It\u2019s hardly surprising that an industry that often functions as a protection racket for white male mediocrity should specialize in spectacles of white male self-pity. That description covers most of the comedies, action movies, superhero franchises and science-fiction epics produced by the big studios in the past decade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that edifice of monochromatic machismo showed signs of cracking throughout 2017. \u201cGet Out\u201d opened the same weekend that \u201cMoonlight\u201d won best picture. \u201cWonder Woman\u201d temporarily shook the DC/Warner Bros. machine out of its rut. \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d is the most inclusive \u201cStar Wars\u201d chapter to date, thanks in part to the presence of nonwhite, non-male players on the creative team. Two of the most anticipated big-budget movies of 2018 are Ryan Coogler\u2019s \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and Ava DuVernay\u2019s \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d both products of the ever-growing Disney empire. And of course right now there\u2019s Greta Gerwig\u2019s \u201cLady Bird,\u201d which has been embraced with some of the same kind of ardor that critics and audiences brought to \u201cMoonlight.\u201d\n\nDARGIS Movies like \u201cMoonlight\u201d and \u201cLady Bird,\u201d though, are reminders that there are subindustries in entertainment. One gives us small, personal movies like those made by Mr. Jenkins and Ms. Gerwig. The other, far more dominant part of the industry churns out movies that are sometimes good (\u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d), but are also primarily delivery systems for a company\u2019s branded content, including its action figures, bedsheets and theme parks. That\u2019s why Disney\u2019s acquisition of most of 21st Century Fox is so important. It\u2019s praiseworthy that Disney has hired Mr. Coogler and Ms. DuVernay; Disney understands the audience in all its multiplicities.\n\nAt the same time, the end of the old Fox and the Disneyfication of the entire movie mainstream are bleak.\n\nPhoto\n\nSCOTT Good movies are made as much in spite of the industry as by means of it. Disney is moving aggressively to consolidate its dominance of large-scale, global, branded entertainment \u2014 the Fox acquisition gives them more Marvel to go with Pixar and Star Wars \u2014 but the demand for other stories and experiences will persist, and other companies will try to turn that desire into profit: A24, for example, which released \u201cLady Bird,\u201d \u201cThe Florida Project,\u201d \u201cThe Disaster Artist,\u201d \u201cGood Time\u201d and \u201cMenashe.\u201d Netflix may be hastening the demise of the theatrical experience, but it also brought us \u201cOkja,\u201d \u201cMudbound\u201d and the latest projects from Noah Baumbach and Errol Morris.\n\nI\u2019m always anxious about the state of ambitious filmmaking, and about the health of the independent audience, but I also shy away from fatalism. At any rate, the good work we saw this year \u2014 and the public and critical embrace of films as varied as \u201cGet Out,\u201d \u201cThe Big Sick,\u201d \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d \u2014 can at least give us a shred of hope to cling to.\n\nDARGIS So many movies of old racist, sexist Hollywood nonetheless give me pleasure and there are movies with Mr. Weinstein\u2019s imprimatur that I love. But it\u2019s heartbreaking that this pleasure was ever derived at the expense of someone else\u2019s humanity. The art form that we love should not carry such a ghastly price. So hope is good.", "title": "Hollywood on the Brink", "authors": ["A.O. Scott", "Manohla Dargis"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "HEBRON, West Bank \u2014 The Israeli soldier stands at the entrance to Shuhada Street. The street is deserted, its stores shuttered, doors welded shut. The old center of Hebron has been a ghost town for many years. The Israel Defense Forces refer to \u201ctzir sterili,\u201d or sterile roads, because no Palestinian is allowed on them, whether in a car or on foot.\n\nThe occupation of the West Bank is a half-century old. That\u2019s a long time. Jews did not go to the Holy Land to deploy for another people the biological metaphors of classic racism that accompanied their persecution over centuries. But the exercise of overwhelming power is corrupting, to the point that \u201csterile\u201d streets, presumably freed of disease-ridden natives, enter the lexicon.\n\nThe soldier at the checkpoint is a young man with a ready smile. He tells me he\u2019s visited New York. He asks where I bought my watch. I ask him what he\u2019s done to merit the punishment of Hebron. He laughs, a little uneasily. He\u2019s clearly uncomfortable with his mission, enforcing segregation, and wants to connect. No doubt he\u2019d rather be on the beach in Tel Aviv enjoying a beer.\n\nIf there\u2019s an endpoint to the terrible logic of an occupation driven in part by a fanatical settler movement abetted by the state of Israel, that place is the historic center of Hebron. Once home to the souk and jewelry market, a bustling maze of commerce, it is now a stretch of apocalyptic real estate. Wires trail down crumbling walls. Garbage accumulates. Mingling is obliterated. Security demands separation.", "title": "Opinion | Holy City of Sterile Streets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Traditionally the fish came from the shallower waters along the reef. Keoni Chang, the corporate chef of Foodland, a statewide supermarket chain founded by an Irish immigrant in 1948, remembers that his great-grandfather ate poke made of oio (bonefish), caught on the flats, the flesh roughly scraped. It was more of a poi-like paste than the slashed cubes of poke that mainlanders eat today, and funkier; in his memory, his great-grandfather always washed it down with Miller Lite.\n\nIn the 1970s, local preference shifted to the larger fish of the deeps, above all ahi (yellowfin tuna), typically anointed with shoyu (Japanese soy sauce) instead of sea salt. This was in part because of changing demographics: Japanese immigrants, with their own custom of eating raw fish, started coming to Hawaii in 1868 to work the sugar plantations. As of the 2010 census, 57 percent of the state\u2019s residents were of Asian descent, the largest groups being Filipino, Japanese and Chinese; the poke that locals eat is as much of a mix as they are.\n\nTwenty-three years ago, Judy Sakuma, a native of Vietnam who fled Saigon during the war, and her husband, Willy, began selling shoyu ahi poke from a cooler under a parking garage off Kapahulu Avenue, not far from Waikiki Beach. Now she and her daughter, Kim Brug, offer eight kinds of poke at Ono Seafood, a small, eternally besieged storefront with a couple of picnic tables, next to that same garage.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer shoyu ahi is a marriage of Hawaii and Japan, given a sheen of sesame oil and a \u201csecret shoyu\u201d made with premium soy sauce and ingredients known only to her and Ms. Brug, and seasoned with skinny, snaking strands of limu, inamona and a faint but menacing tattoo of chile. Better yet is the spicy ahi, veiled in mayonnaise with a streak of heat. Half the kick comes from ginger, and the pop from tiny beads of masago (capelin roe).\n\nFresh ahi is delivered daily and turned into heaps of translucent ruby cubes. (Tako, or octopus, poke is also available.) Order a \u201cbowl,\u201d and you receive a foam box of rice and poke, no more, no less. The rice itself is impeccably fluffy and exhaling warmth, just enough to leave the fish in a cool blush. Toppings are do-it-yourself from a case by the counter, stocked with seaweed salad, pickled onions, Korean taegu (spicy-sweet dried cuttlefish), tsukemono (Japanese pickles) and boiled peanuts. But you don\u2019t need them.\n\nFish flags \u2014 which fishermen fly over their boats when sailing back to harbor after the day\u2019s catch \u2014 hang from the second-floor railing of a strip mall in Moiliili. Up the stairs is Ahi Assassins, run by Joshua Schade, a third-generation fisherman from Kahaluu on Oahu\u2019s windward side, and his longtime girlfriend, Erika Luna. On their front door a bumper sticker declares: \u201cKeep the country country!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Mr. Schade, poke is inextricable from his life as a fisherman and all its risks. Two summers ago, his boat sank. It was the Fourth of July; no one saw the flares. He swam two miles home in the dark, and brought the Coast Guard back to rescue his father and two uncles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom the moment the fish leaves the boat to the moment it\u2019s served, at most two days pass. Its flesh is a barely muted incarnadine, sliced in larger hunks than typically found elsewhere, and beautifully tender.\n\nAny of a dozen types of poke may be on hand, including shoyu garlic with crisp, clarifying arcs of white onion; pake, Hawaiian for Chinese, contoured with ginger and scallions; and \u201clunatic,\u201d named after Ms. Luna (\u201cif you had to live with her, you\u2019d know,\u201d Mr. Schade said) and essentially spicy ahi, only with sriracha untempered by mayonnaise.\n\nAhi Assassins was supposed to be just a fish store. (There are no tables.) But after the owners invited the neighborhood to an opening-day blessing in the parking lot, with food and poke for everyone, people came by looking for more. \u201cIt\u2019s not just the food,\u201d Mr. Schade said. \u201cIt\u2019s that feeling like you walked into my house.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJunichiro and Ryojiro Tsuchiya, brothers from Kawasaki, Japan, started Maguro Brothers in 2014 as a stand along the back wall of the Kekaulike Market in Chinatown, with a few tables for diners. (They\u2019ve since added a takeout window in Waikiki.) Junichiro spent a decade working at Tokyo\u2019s famed Tsukiji fish market, and the seafood here, fresh from the nearby Honolulu Fish Auction \u2014 the largest in the United States and the only one to sell fresh tuna \u2014 is pristine and exactingly cut. Slabs of ahi sit in a glass case, with thin white rings like a tree trunk\u2019s and a deep, thrilling red at the center.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe recipes lean Japanese, with flavors like ume-shiso, tangy and bright from salted plum, and a tumble of hamachi (yellowtail) stung by wasabi. The brothers\u2019 take on spicy ahi is creamier, with more sweetness to the mayonnaise and a milder, if persistent heat. But they, too, honor Hawaiian tradition in a version strewn with little pronged fronds of limu. It tastes brinier than others around town, and closer to the sea.\n\nSome of Honolulu\u2019s longest-standing poke destinations are grocery stores, like Tamashiro Market, run by three brothers, Cyrus, Guy and Sean Tamashiro. Their grandparents opened the original store in 1941, in Hilo, on the Big Island; after it was destroyed by the 1946 tsunami, they moved to Oahu and set up shop in Kalihi.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey were prescient: The address is just a mile from what is today the Honolulu Fish Auction, where the Tamashiro brothers buy seafood before dawn six days a week. They make poke from almost everything they get their hands on: surf clams, kajiki (blue marlin), nairagi (striped marlin) and kawa kawa (mackerel tuna), whose flesh is the lushest red.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStrong flavors are ascendant here, with nuances that only a kamaaina might understand, like ahi with white onions (clean and sweet) versus ahi with green onions (mellower). Their tako poke, made with octopus caught in local waters, is lovely: The octopus is first lomi-ed, or massaged, with salt, then steamed into submission.\n\nAt Tamura\u2019s Fine Wine & Liquors in Kaimuki \u2014 one of six locations across the islands \u2014 the poke counter is tucked at the back but fills the whole wall. As at Tamashiro\u2019s, the variety of poke is giddying, including dried aku (skipjack tuna), concentrated and blood-rich; smoked marlin; clams, oysters and mussels; nearly a dozen variations with ahi; and even pipikaula (Hawaiian beef jerky). Some of the seafood has been frozen, as noted on signs, but most is fresh from the auction.\n\nPhoto\n\nRecipes are straightforward, with minute shadings. Here is ahi with inamona and sea salt; there, ahi with limu and sea salt. Shoyu is calibrated with little more than ginger. As for \u201cTamura\u2019s secret sauce,\u201d the manager I spoke with laughed and said, \u201cI can\u2019t tell you.\u201d\n\nThe Foodland near my mom\u2019s house, one of more than two dozen statewide, has a sign over the poke counter that says \u201cHawaii\u2019s home for poke,\u201d and it is \u2014 the never-fail poke you run to the store for when friends announce they\u2019re stopping by.\n\nThe shoyu ahi is strong and just salty enough (ask for the shoyu to be packed in a separate container, to add at home); the spicy ahi has a worthy heat. The recipes for all outlets are overseen by Mr. Chang, a graduate of the Kamehameha Schools and the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.\n\nThere\u2019s nothing ceremonial about his approach. He uses ingredients like sea asparagus, truffle oil and gochujang, and makes a deconstructed California-roll poke with avocado, furikake and sriracha, one of the stores\u2019 best-sellers. And he\u2019s not against the mainland poke craze, \u201cso long as you take time to understand the history and apply common sense and restraint.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf it\u2019s amazingly delicious \u2014 \u201d he said, and trailed off. \u201cIt\u2019s a free country.\u201d\n\nIf You Go\n\nAHI ASSASSINS\n\n2570 South Beretania Street, second floor (University Avenue), Moiliili; 808-439-4045; ahiassassins.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFOODLAND\n\nAt Ala Moana Center, 1450 Ala Moana Boulevard (Piikoi Street), Ala Moana, and other locations; 808-949-5044; foodland.com\n\nMAGURO BROTHERS\n\nAt Kekaulike Market, 1039 Kekaulike Street, No. 113 (North King Street), Chinatown, and another location; 808-259-7100; instagram.com/magurobrothershawaii\n\nONO SEAFOOD\n\n747 Kapahulu Avenue (Hunter Street), Kapahulu; 808-732-4806; instagram.com/ono.seafood\n\nTAMASHIRO MARKET\n\n802 North King Street (Palama Street), Kalihi; 808-841-8047; tamashiromarket.com\n\nTAMURA\u2019S FINE WINE & LIQUORS\n\n3496 Waialae Avenue (10th Avenue), Kaimuki, and other locations; 808-735-7100; tamurasfinewine.com\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Home to Hawaii in Search of Poke", "authors": ["Ligaya Mishan", "Garrett Hongo"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhite House Tries to Link Immigration and Terrorism\u201d (news article, Jan. 17):\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s report trying to link foreign-born immigrants to terrorism muddies the waters by giving an incomplete picture of the sources of extremist violence in America.\n\nNew data from the Anti-Defamation League confirms that over the last decade, native-born white supremacists and others identifying with far-right movements have been responsible for the vast majority of extremist-related murders in the United States.\n\nMore than 70 percent of all extremist-related killings in those years were linked to domestic right-wing extremists, while 26 percent of the killings were committed by Islamic extremists. And last year, in the heated political environment that led to Charlottesville, Va., deaths caused by white supremacists doubled year over year. Right-wing extremists were directly responsible for 20 of the total 34 extremist-related murders in 2017.\n\nWhile the federal government builds walls and pours more resources into fighting the violent threat posed by foreign extremists, less attention is being paid to the reality of right-wing violence.", "title": "Opinion | Homegrown Terrorism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Select number of bedrooms Any Beds Studio 1 1 or more 2 2 or more 3 3 or more 4 4 or more 5 5 or more\n\nSelect number of bedrooms Any Baths 1 1 or more 2 2 or more 3 3 or more 4 4 or more 5 5 or more", "title": "Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million", "authors": ["C.
