The main house has front and back staircases, an office and a basement.", "title": "Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Click on the slide show to see this week\u2019s featured properties in New York and New Jersey:\n\n\u2022 In Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., a five-bedroom, four-full and two-half bath 1989 house with fireplaces in the living and family rooms, a finished lower level, a swimming pool, hot tub and a tennis court on 2.6 acres.\n\n\u2022 In Englewood, N.J., a four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house designed by the architect Paul Rudolph in 1953, with steel beam construction, extensive glass, an open layout, and built-in shelving and lighting throughout the four-story home. The house is on .51 acres, with an in-ground pool and a two-car garage.", "title": "Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 Hong Kong has disqualified a 21-year-old democracy advocate from running for the local legislature, the latest in a series of young politicians to be barred from public office over their resistance to the Chinese government\u2019s authority over the city.\n\nThe pro-democracy party Demosisto said on Saturday that election authorities had barred its candidate, Agnes Chow, from running in a March by-election, in which Hong Kong voters will decide on the members of the Legislative Council.\n\nMs. Chow said the ruling was \u201cno less than a declaration to the city that our political rights are handicapped.\u201d\n\nIn a statement Saturday, Hong Kong\u2019s government said that a legislator \u201ccannot possibly uphold\u201d the city\u2019s de facto constitution, the Basic Law \u2014 which says that Hong Kong is an inalienable part of China \u2014 if he or she \u201cadvocates or promotes self-determination or independence by any means.\u201d", "title": "Hong Kong Bars Democracy Advocate From Running for Legislature", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 Hong Kong\u2019s legislature voted on Wednesday to ban all ivory sales by 2021, closing what activists called a major loophole in the global effort to end the trade and protect elephants from poaching.\n\nThe ivory trade has been banned in most of the world since 1990 under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, or Cites, which Hong Kong and all but a handful of countries have agreed to honor. But the sale of antique ivory acquired before the 1970s had remained legal here. Elephant tusks and ivory statues, carvings and chopsticks are still sold in Hong Kong\u2019s antique stores.\n\nCity officials originally said that allowing the sale of antique ivory would give local traders time to liquidate their stocks and find a new line of work.\n\nBut fresh ivory has continued to make its way into Hong Kong. In July, for example, 7.2 tons of elephant tusks were found concealed under frozen fish in a shipment from Malaysia. Activists and lawmakers cite such incidents as evidence that the ivory trade has profited from the Hong Kong loophole, with traders creating an incentive for poaching by selling new ivory among antiques.", "title": "Hong Kong Moves to Ban All Ivory Sales, Closing a Loophole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 After three days of denunciations from around the world, President Trump declared that he is \u201cnot a racist\u201d on Sunday, even as the uproar over his vulgar remarks on immigration overshadowed critical issues facing the capital, including efforts to protect young undocumented immigrants and avert a government shutdown.\n\nMr. Trump also insisted that he had not made the inflammatory comments in a White House meeting on Thursday, part of a newly aggressive defense and a counterattack on Democrats by the president and his allies. But his remarks on Sunday were a departure from the White House\u2019s initial statement last week, which did not deny the comments.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not a racist,\u201d Mr. Trump said on Sunday night as he arrived at Trump International Golf Club in Florida for dinner with Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the majority leader, who attended the meeting last week and has not spoken publicly about it. \u201cI am the least racist person you have ever interviewed, that I can tell you.\u201d\n\nHis comments, while extraordinary coming from a president of the United States, echoed reassurances Mr. Trump has made several times before.", "title": "Hopes Dim for DACA Deal as Lawmakers Battle Over Trump\u2019s Immigration Remarks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the untutored eye, the runners seemed to be jogging most of the way. But the race is deceptively grueling, requiring the gritty strength of a cross-country runner, the tenacity of an all-weather athlete and the speed of a miler who pounds out the meters with great galloping strides.\n\nKazantsev was far ahead on the last lap, seemingly destined for an easy victory. But then Ashenfelter pulled away from the pack and moved behind the leader. Even as they splashed down in the final water pit, Kazantsev was slightly ahead.\n\nBut then, with a surprising burst of stamina, Ashenfelter rose out of the water as if propelled by a rocket. The exhausted Russian, grimacing in pain, stumbled momentarily, struggling to regain his footing, and churned mechanically forward on hopeless legs of iron as the American shot ahead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDown the 200-yard stretch, as 65,000 people shrieked from the stands, Ashenfelter\u2019s powerful sprint widened his lead with every stride. He crossed the finish line 30 meters in front of the broken Kazantsev, who staggered home just ahead of John Disley of Britain. Ashenfelter\u2019s time, 8 minutes 45.4 seconds, smashed the official record, the 1936 Olympic mark of 9:03.8 set by Volmari Iso-Hollo of Finland.\n\nIt was one of the great upsets in Olympic history and the triumph of a lifetime for Ashenfelter, whose unassuming demeanor seemed to personify the Wheaties box all-American athlete in a postwar ideological struggle with lock step Soviet Communism. The competition was heightened by fears of nuclear war, a stalemate in the Korean conflict, diatribes of propaganda from Moscow and a fever of anti-Communism in the United States.\n\nIn Helsinki, the lasting imagery was Ashenfelter beaming atop the victory stand with Kazantsev shaking his hand from a step below. The gold medal draped around his neck, Ashenfelter basked in \u201cThe Star-Spangled Banner\u201d and accepted a bouquet from a young Finn in a peasant dress. The crowd roared as he shook her hand, and there were cries of \u201cKiss her!\u201d Shyly, he complied.\n\nReporters later asked Ashenfelter if he had been sure he would win. \u201cIt would sound conceited if I said sure,\u201d he replied. \u201cJust say I was surprised.\u201d\n\nThere was also a telegram from the F.B.I. director, J. Edgar Hoover: \u201cAll your associates in the F.B.I. are proud of your brilliant victory and happy with you over establishment of a new record.\u201d\n\nIn the end, the United States easily beat the Soviet Union in gold medals, 40 to 22, but led by only 76 to 71 in overall medals. The leaders were far ahead of the 67 other nations attending.\n\nThe New York Times called Ashenfelter \u201ca true model for young Americans,\u201d and he was pictured in the newspapers with sports heroes of the day: Robin Roberts, the Phillies pitcher who led the major leagues with 28 wins, and Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion.\n\nFrom the late 1940s, when Ashenfelter ran for Penn State, until his 1957 retirement from competition, Ashenfelter won 17 national indoor and outdoor titles in a variety of races: cross-country, the two-mile, the three-mile, the 10,000 meters and the steeplechase. He won the Sullivan Award as America\u2019s outstanding amateur athlete of 1952 and entered the National Track and Field Hall of Fame in 1975. In 2001, Penn State\u2019s indoor track was named for him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHorace Ashenfelter III, who was nicknamed Nip, was born in Phoenixville, Pa., on Jan. 23, 1923. He grew up on a farm in nearby Collegeville, competed on football, basketball, baseball and track teams at Collegeville High School, and graduated in 1941. He joined the Army Air Corps in 1942, and became a pilot and stateside gunnery instructor.\n\nHe married Lillian Wright in 1945 and had four sons who survive him: Horace, James, Alan and John. Other survivors include his brother Donald; his sister, Jane; 12 grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren.\n\nDischarged in 1946, he studied physical education at Penn State, joined the track team and won National Collegiate Athletic Association outdoor two-mile runs in 1948 and 1949. The Penn Relay\u2019s four-mile event in 1949 was won by a team that included three Ashenfelter brothers: Horace, Bill and Donald.\n\nHe graduated in 1949, began running for the New York Athletic Club and won 15 gold medals in Amateur Athletic Union competitions. Four years after his triumph in Helsinki, he went to the Olympics in Melbourne, Australia, but did no better than sixth in a steeplechase heat.\n\nAfter nine years as an F.B.I. agent, investigating backgrounds of federal job applicants, Ashenfelter left in 1959 and joined Engelhard Industries as a metals salesman. He retired in 1993 but continued to run frequently in Glen Ridge, N.J., where he lived. The town\u2019s annual Thanksgiving Day run is called the Ashenfelter eight-kilometer classic.", "title": "Horace Ashenfelter, Olympic Victor of a Cold War Showdown, Dies at 94", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "PERRIS, Calif. \u2014 The private school had a welcoming name. The principal was scientifically minded. But the Sandcastle Day School was a nightmare for the six students enrolled there.\n\nDavid A. Turpin created the school inside his nondescript stucco home southeast of Los Angeles. But the only ones enrolled there were the six of his 13 children who were school age. And what took place inside was not teaching but torture, the authorities said, after they raided the house over the weekend and found a horrifying scene of emaciated children chained to furniture. The putrid smell overwhelmed them.\n\nBy creating such a school of horrors, Mr. Turpin had kept the authorities at bay. His children were never seen by teachers or counselors. Their absences never raised suspicions. On Tuesday, state and local officials were on the defensive as they tried to explain how such things could have occurred in a private school the state had sanctioned.\n\nMr. Turpin, 56, and his wife, Louise A. Turpin, 49, were arrested on nine counts of torture and child endangerment after one of their daughters escaped from the home out a window before dawn and called the police on a deactivated cellphone that only allowed her to dial 911. The girl, 17, showed the police photos to corroborate her story. Once the authorities entered the disheveled home, they found the Turpins\u2019 12 other children, ages 2 to 29. They were so malnourished that the older ones looked years younger.", "title": "Horror for 13 California Siblings Hidden by Veneer of a Private Home School", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "My life became entwined with the Hotel Belleclaire on the Upper West Side 35 years ago, and together we have evolved.\n\nWhile living here, I have changed careers, come out of the closet, managed a long recuperation from brain surgery, started meditating, and watched a dear friend die of AIDS in my apartment\u2019s front bedroom. And the building has continued its own endless metamorphosis, shifting from stately residential hotel where Maxim Gorky, Mark Twain and Babe Ruth once stayed, to seedy single-room-occupancy flop joint, to what it is today, a boutique hotel undergoing yet another face-lift.\n\nWhen I first came East from California in 1981, I moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn. But architecturally I took in all five boroughs, which provided a cornucopia of treats for my hungry eyes.\n\nIn 1982, I made my first trek to the \u201cwild wild West\u201d of Manhattan \u2014 the Upper West Side. The upswing anticipated for the neighborhood with the creation of Lincoln Center in the mid-1960s had been slower than anticipated. Still, during those seemingly stagnant years, new consideration was given to many of the forgotten architectural treasures the area had to offer, in part thanks to the establishment of the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1965.", "title": "Hotel Belleclaire: A Dowager on the Rise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Effectively, the vote was almost certainly the end of a debate over 21st-century surveillance and privacy rights that broke out in 2013 after the leaks by the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden.\n\nThe Senate began considering the newly approved House bill on Thursday afternoon; Senators Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, and Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, are expected to oppose the measure in the coming days. But Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, moved to essentially ensure that no amendments to the House legislation would be considered, and it appeared to be on a path to final approval when senators return to Washington next week.\n\nMr. Snowden\u2019s disclosures in 2013 ushered in a period of intense interest in surveillance. Civil libertarians and conservative skeptics of government power worked together to push for new limits, while intelligence and law enforcement agencies and their backers in Congress from across party lines \u2014 and in both the Obama and Trump administrations \u2014 tried to hold the line.\n\nThe post-Snowden privacy movement secured its largest victory in 2015 when Congress voted to end and replace one of the programs that Mr. Snowden exposed, under which the N.S.A. had been secretly collecting logs of Americans\u2019 domestic phone calls in bulk. But lawmakers who hoped to add significant privacy constraints to the warrantless surveillance program, too, fell short on Thursday.\n\nBefore voting to extend the law, known as Section 702 of the FISA Amendments Act, the House rejected an amendment that would have imposed a series of new safeguards. That proposal included a requirement that officials obtain warrants in most cases before hunting for, and reading, emails and other messages of Americans that were swept up under the surveillance.\n\nSupporters of those changes contended that the overhaul was needed to preserve Fourth Amendment privacy rights in the internet era. But intelligence and law enforcement officials argued that it was unnecessary, and dangerous, to limit security officials from being able to freely gain access to information the government already possessed.\n\nRepresentative Devin Nunes, the Republican of California who leads the House Intelligence Committee, celebrated the outcome. \u201cThe House of Representatives has taken a big step to ensure the continuation of one of the intelligence community\u2019s most vital tools for tracking foreign terrorists,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe program\u2019s surveillance can be used for all foreign intelligence purposes. The sharpest points of the debate centered on when information about Americans that is gathered by the program can be used for criminal investigations unrelated to terrorism.\n\nPhoto\n\nRepresentative Justin Amash, the Republican of Michigan who sponsored the privacy measures, expressed disappointment but vowed to keep fighting.\n\n\u201cWe had a bipartisan coalition who worked very hard to protect people\u2019s rights, and we will continue to fight and continue to educate our colleagues about it,\u201d Mr. Amash said.\n\nThe House bill that was approved on Thursday does contain a gesture toward requiring officials to obtain a warrant to read Americans\u2019 emails that are collected under the program. But it is written so narrowly that it will not protect the overwhelming majority of citizens\u2019 information that is queried in the warrantless surveillance repository.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSpecifically, a warrant would be required only if an F.B.I. agent wants to look at emails about a subject of an open criminal investigation for which there is no national security angle. It would not apply to security-related queries by any intelligence or law-enforcement agency, nor to requests from F.B.I. agents who are following up on criminal tips but have not yet opened formal investigations.\n\nMatthew Olsen, a former general counsel of the National Security Agency and the former director of the National Counterterrorism Center, said that while he had concerns about how the F.B.I. would distinguish between criminal and national security cases, the overall thrust of the bill was a positive step.\n\n\u201cCongress has made clear that it is lawful to search using U.S. person identifiers for information that could help stop terror attacks and catch spies without a warrant,\u201d he said. \u201cThat is the way the intelligence community has been operating under 702, and that is the way it will continue to operate if this bill becomes law.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Amash expressed hope that Mr. Trump might yet intervene to push for more changes to the legislation in the Senate.\n\nJust before debate began on Thursday, the president posted a statement on Twitter that suggested skepticism about the surveillance bill.\n\nMr. Trump wrote the message shortly after a libertarian legal analyst on \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d Andrew Napolitano, appealed directly to him to go another route. Mr. Napolitano added that Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cwoes\u201d began with surveillance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president\u2019s tweet enraged Republican leaders who have been trying to renew the 702 law more or less intact. Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Mr. Trump spoke by phone until he posted his next message, a senior Republican congressional aide said.\n\nFewer than two hours later, the president appeared to reverse himself on the issue in another statement on Twitter.\n\nDespite the confusion, Republican leaders pushed forward, counting on moderate Democrats and Republicans to reject the proposed overhaul and pass the extension bill. John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, lobbied members in a House cloakroom before the vote.\n\nSome of the most conservative Republicans in the House joined with some of the most liberal Democrats in the failed bid for more privacy protections. Ultimately, 58 Republicans joined 125 Democrats in voting for the overhaul amendment, while 55 Democrats joined 178 Republicans in rejecting it. On Twitter, Mr. Snowden observed that it would have passed had fewer Democrats broken ranks.\n\nBut Representative Adam B. Schiff of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, said afterward that by rejecting the overhaul amendment, the House had avoided imposing \u201ca crippling requirement in national security and terrorism cases.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe were certainly thrown into plenty of turmoil with the president\u2019s tweets this morning and that made everything look quite speculative,\u201d Mr. Schiff said. \u201cI do think the underlying bill makes a sensible compromise.\u201d", "title": "House Extends Surveillance Law, Rejecting New Privacy Safeguards", "authors": ["Charlie Savage", "Eileen Sullivan", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Below the ground floor, on the basement level, is an indoor pool and sauna. A space off the pool area with a bar and a fireplace is described as a party room; it has access to a small outdoor terrace. The house also has an attic and a four-car garage.\n\nThis property is in the state of Lower Saxony, which is popular with hikers and cyclists. Gross Denkte is a village of about 1,800 people with a market, a gas station and a pharmacy, Mr. von Stosch-Diebitsch said. There are schools and restaurants about three miles away, in the town of Wolfenb\u00fcttel, known for its timber homes and a castle dating to the 13th century. The nearest international airport is in Hanover, about an hour\u2019s drive.\n\nMARKET OVERVIEW\n\nThe largest price increases in Germany have historically been in big cities like Berlin, Munich and Hamburg, according to government data. But since 2012, home prices across the country have increased by more than 30 percent, according to an index tracked by the Association of German Pfandbrief Banks. In the third quarter of 2017, the index price for residential property was up 7.8 percent, compared with the same period a year earlier, the report said.\n\nHomeownership has traditionally been less common in Germany than in other European Union countries, agents said, and many buyers are now purchasing a home for the first time, thanks to higher incomes and low interest rates.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are signs, however, that the real estate market in Germany is starting to slow, said Michael Voigtl\u00e4nder, an analyst with the Cologne Institute for Economic Research. After years of rising prices, he said, \u201cdown payments as well as transaction costs\u201d make buying a home impossible for many households.\n\nIn Lower Saxony, prices are still increasing, but \u201con a lower scale\u201d than in other states, he said, and Hanover is \u201clagging behind other big cities.\u201d\n\nIn the Brunswick area, prices also continue to rise, said Anita G\u00e4rtner, managing partner of Berlin Sotheby\u2019s International Realty. \u201cAlthough the housing prices aren\u2019t as high as Hamburg or Munich,\u201d she noted, \u201cthey have grown almost 10 percent in the last year alone.\u201d Siemens, Volkswagen and other large companies own manufacturing facilities in Brunswick, she said, which helps drive home sales in the area.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lack of inventory in this part of the country is the biggest problem, Mr. von Stosch-Diebitsch said: \u201cWe could sell 10 times more real estate if more properties were available. The new building cannot nearly meet the demand.\u201d\n\nWHO BUYS IN LOWER SAXONY\n\nMost buyers are locals moving to a larger home or buying for the first time, agents said, and international buyers are rare.\n\nBUYING BASICS\n\nPurchasing a home in Germany is a \u201crelatively easy process with few hoops to jump through,\u201d Ms. G\u00e4rtner said. There are no restrictions on foreign buyers. Mortgages are available, but usually require a down payment of 20 to 40 percent, agents said.\n\nA notary certifies the transaction and records it. Many foreign buyers choose to hire a lawyer, but it is not required, agents said.\n\nWEBSITES\n\nOfficial Germany tourism site: germany.travel/en/index.html\n\nHanover tourism: hannover.de/en\n\nBrunswick information: braunschweig.de/english/\n\nLANGUAGES AND CURRENCIES\n\nGerman; euro (1 euro = $1.22)\n\nTAXES AND FEES\n\nBuyers can expect to pay a transfer tax of 5 percent of the purchase price, as well as 1 to 1.5 percent of the price for the notary fee. Agent fees can add another 5.95 percent.\n\nThe annual tax on this property is about 2,300 euros (or $2,800), Mr. von Stosch-Diebitsch said.\n\nCONTACT\n\nRainer von Stosch-Diebitsch, Engel & Voelkers Braunschweig, 011-49-531-21369-00; engelvoelkers.com/de-de/braunschweig/", "title": "House Hunting in \u2026 Germany", "authors": ["Kevin Brass", "International Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Beyond the living room is an open kitchen with walnut cabinetry, marble countertops, an Ilve range and Miele appliances, a large fireplace and French doors to a covered porch. There are also a bedroom, a bathroom and a laundry room on the first floor.\n\nThe master bedroom, on the second floor, has high wood-beamed ceilings, a private terrace and an en-suite bathroom with a walk-in shower. There are three smaller bedrooms on this floor as well, one with French doors that open to a private balcony. These bedrooms share a bathroom with a walk-in shower.\n\nThe basement has a wine cellar, utility room and storage. Outside, a 40-by-20-foot swimming pool is surrounded by a flagstone deck; next to it is a small stone building with storage space, a bathroom and an outdoor fireplace.\n\nThe property, which has a gated entrance, is a short drive from the town of Canelli, where there are shops, restaurants, wine bars and other amenities, Ms. Wisbey said. Turin, the capital of the Piedmont region, which has a population of more than 880,000, is about an hour and 15 minutes away, with trails for cycling and hiking, as well as wineries and restaurants. The beaches in Savona are about an hour\u2019s drive; the Italian lakes and the ski areas in the Alps are about two hours away. The closest international airport is Milan-Malpensa, about an hour and a half away.\n\nMARKET OVERVIEW\n\nThe global real estate crisis of 2008 affected the housing market throughout Italy, with prices falling by 20 to 30 percent, and Piedmont followed the national trend, brokers said. But after several years of decreasing prices, Piedmont\u2019s housing market has begun to stabilize in the past 12 to 18 months, said Eli Anne Langen, owner of the brokerage Case in Piemonte. It was renovated and decorated in 2014 and 2015 by the seller, Nicolo Castellini Baldissera, an interior designer.\n\nPast the front gates, there is a verdant courtyard with a parking space. The house, which is free-standing on three sides and 6,028 square feet, is at the back of the courtyard. One side of the structure shares walls with a neighboring property. At the east side of the house is a studio apartment with a separate entrance; it includes a kitchenette and bathroom.\n\nThe home\u2019s entrance hall has a half-bath, and the building\u2019s elevator is on the right. To the left is a dining room with a fireplace and a long veranda that leads to a back garden. The garden has a fountain designed by Mr. Castellini Baldissera and lined with 18th- and 19th-century tiles. The kitchen and pantry are in the center of the house, and the laundry room and a staff bedroom with an en-suite bath are at the back.\n\nOne staircase is near the elevator; a second, at the back of the house, is outside. The second floor has a grand, partially divided drawing room, currently arranged for entertaining, with a terrace overlooking the back garden and a half-bath near the elevator. Behind the property, a nearby staircase leads to the Battlefields Park, a national park that includes the Plains of Abraham, the site of a defining battle during the French and Indian War.\n\nThe property is less than a mile from the Boulevard Champlain, which runs along the St. Lawrence River. A biking and walking path joins up with the Promenade Samuel-De Champlain, a popular riverside park about three miles away, Mr. Brouard said. The Jean Lesage International Airport is about a 20-minute drive.\n\nMARKET OVERVIEW\n\nThe market in Quebec City has been fairly flat for several years, said Dominic St-Pierre, senior director of the Quebec province for the real estate company Royal LePage. While the city has a low unemployment rate, at less than 4 percent, he said, \u201cit doesn\u2019t have the population growth that some other Canadian cities have,\u201d and a large inventory of homes for sale has kept prices from rising.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been a buyer\u2019s market since 2013,\u201d said Marc Pinsonneault, a senior economist with the National Bank of Canada. \u201cEspecially in the condo segment,\u201d he added, which represented nearly a quarter of sales in the broader Quebec City metropolitan area last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOverbuilding led to a glut of new condos, which stalled the sales of existing condos, stretching their days on market last year to almost twice that of 2011, Mr. Pinsonneault said, noting that prices of resale condos have declined by roughly 1 to 2 percent in each of the last four years.\n\nIn the fourth quarter of 2017, the median sale price for a condo in Quebec City was 240,000 Canadian dollars (or about $192,000), Mr. St-Pierre said. The median sale price for a \u201cbungalow,\u201d or single-level home, he said, was 267,000 Canadian dollars (about $214,000); for a two-story house, it was 355,000 Canadian dollars (or $284,000).\n\nThe areas of the city in highest demand are the borough of Les Rivi\u00e8res, which saw a 27 percent increase in sales last year, and the neighborhood of Sainte-Foy, where sales rose 17 percent, he said. Both are close to the city center and the river.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWHO BUYS IN QUEBEC CITY\n\nForeign buyers are more common in Toronto, Vancouver and Montreal, but Americans and Europeans do buy in Quebec. Martin Dostie, an agent with Sotheby\u2019s International Realty Canada, which has this listing, said that most of his foreign clients are from France and Belgium, but he also has buyers from Spain, Uruguay and Mexico.\n\nBUYING BASICS\n\nThere are no restrictions on foreign buyers in Quebec, Mr. St-Pierre said. The real estate agent\u2019s commission is usually 4.5 to 5 percent, and is paid by the seller.\n\nMortgages are available, but foreigners are typically required to put down at least 25 percent. And new lending rules in Canada require all buyers applying for a mortgage to meet a so-called stress test, Mr. St-Pierre said; they must prove they could still qualify for the mortgage if the interest rate were 2 percent higher.\n\nWEBSITES\n\nQuebec City tourism: quebecregion.com/en/\n\nQuebec government: gouv.qc.ca/\n\nUnesco listing of Old Quebec: whc.unesco.org/en/list/300\n\nLANGUAGES AND CURRENCY\n\nFrench and English; Canadian dollar (1 Canadian dollar = $0.80)\n\nTAXES AND FEES\n\nAnnual city and school taxes on this property are 7,690 Canadian dollars, or about $6,150, Mr. Dostie said. But using the house as a private residence, rather than a B&B, would lower the city taxes, Mr. Brouard said.\n\nTransaction fees usually total around 2 percent of the purchase price, and include a real estate transfer tax, often called the \u201cwelcome tax,\u201d at a graduated rate based on the value of the property.\n\nCONTACT\n\nMartin Dostie, Martin Dostie Group/Sotheby\u2019s International Realty Canada, 418-956-8687; sothebysrealty.ca", "title": "House Hunting in \u2026 Quebec", "authors": ["Lisa Prevost", "International Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "An en-suite master bedroom is upstairs, with a marble and tile bath that has a separate soaking tub and shower stall. There is a seating area near the balcony, which, Ms. Laich said, looks out onto the pond.\n\nThroughout the house are concrete and wood floors, high ceilings, large windows and glass doors.\n\nLa Barra is in the Maldonado Department (with a population of around 165,000), which encompasses Punta del Este. Once primarily a fishing village, it has become increasingly popular during the summer season, from December to February, offering restaurants, clubs, shops and art galleries, as well as surfing and other water sports, to beach-seeking tourists.\n\nMARKET OVERVIEW\n\nUruguay\u2019s housing market peaked around 2010, Ms. Sofio said, and then softened over the next few years, in large part because of economic and political tumult in neighboring Argentina and Brazil.\n\nThere are signs, however, that the market is now on an upswing.\n\n\u201cBusiness has been growing for the last year and a half, since Argentina\u2019s political climate has improved,\u201d Ms. Laich said. \u201cWe\u2019re also seeing a lot of Europeans coming to South America, which they see as safe.\u201d\n\nMs. Sofio said that sales volume in the Punta del Este area is up around 15 percent over last year, though prices have been largely flat. She described the current market conditions as more favorable to buyers, with more inventory available. For now, she said, \u201cYou still can get some bargains.\u201d\n\nLuxury properties on or near the beach typically start at just under $2 million, she said, and can go as high as $20 million, while more modest homes are available farther from the beach, starting at around $200,000 for a small two-bedroom house.\n\nWHO BUYS IN URUGUAY\n\nThe country\u2019s luxury market is dominated by foreign buyers, particularly from Argentina and Brazil, agents said. There is also strong demand for vacation or retirement homes from buyers in the United States, as well as Europe, particularly Germany, Belgium, Britain, Italy and Spain.", "title": "House Hunting in \u2026 Uruguay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The weeks-old standoff on immigration and spending only grew more charged last week after Mr. Trump referred to African nations as \u201cshithole countries.\u201d By Thursday, talks on those matters had produced little visible progress, and prominent House Democrats were introducing a resolution to censure the president for his words.\n\nIn the Senate, Democrats were unifying around a \u201cno\u201d vote. If the stopgap bill passes, Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic leader, said, \u201cthere\u2019ll be no incentive to negotiate, and we\u2019ll be right back here in a month with the same problems at our feet.\u201d\n\nRepublicans were left seething.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re either going to act like 13-year-olds or not,\u201d said Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana. \u201cOur first job is to keep government going, and if you\u2019re going to shut her down, it better be for a damn good reason.\u201d\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, lamented the Democrats\u2019 \u201cfixation on illegal immigration\u201d at the expense of addressing other matters.\n\nIt is anything but clear which side would pay the steepest political price if the government does indeed run out of money a year to the day after Mr. Trump took office. But Democrats appear poised to force the issue.\n\nSenator Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii, complained that Republicans had waited until the last minute to address the fate of the young immigrants and to deal with other pressing issues.\n\n\u201cBut no, they have to fool around with giving the richest people in our country and the corporations huge, huge tax breaks,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s what they were running around doing in the dark of night. You think I\u2019m a little upset? Damn right I am.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump is not making it easier for congressional Republicans. The perilous day on Capitol Hill began with the president firing off a Twitter message that undermined his party\u2019s strategy to keep the government open. Republican leaders had spent Wednesday pressuring Democrats to vote for the spending bill, arguing that opposing it would effectively block the extension of the child health program, known as CHIP, which they had included in the spending bill. Funding for the program lapsed at the end of September.\n\nYet on Thursday morning, Mr. Trump suggested that the funding should not be part of the stopgap bill, writing on Twitter: \u201cCHIP should be part of a long term solution, not a 30 Day, or short term, extension!\u201d\n\nHours after Mr. Trump\u2019s message, the administration tried to walk it back. A White House spokesman said that the president supported the stopgap bill.\n\nBut Democrats pressed their advantage. Mr. Schumer brought up the tweet and questioned whether it meant that the president opposed the stopgap measure that congressional leaders from his own party were trying to pass.\n\n\u201cWho knows?\u201d Mr. Schumer said. \u201cIt\u2019s a mess.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, made clear that she was unmoved by the inclusion of CHIP funding in the stopgap bill.\n\n\u201cThis is like giving you a bowl of doggy doo, put a cherry on top and call it a chocolate sundae,\u201d she said.\n\nIn a sign of the growing opposition, Virginia\u2019s two Democratic senators, Mark Warner and Tim Kaine, whose constituents include tens of thousands of federal workers, announced that they, too, would oppose the temporary spending bill in the Senate.\n\n\u201cCongress should remain in session with no recess until we work out a long-term bipartisan budget deal that addresses all issues,\u201d Mr. Warner and Mr. Kaine said in a joint statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Senate Republicans were unified in support and continued to lack the vote of Senator John McCain of Arizona, they would still need at least 10 Democrats to join them for the bill to succeed in that chamber. With a few expected Republican defections, that number would grow even larger.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAgainst that darkening backdrop, House leaders pressed forward with a planned vote on the temporary spending bill.\n\nNot only were Democrats opposed, but many members of the House Freedom Caucus, a group of hard-line conservatives, had reservations. Earlier in the day, Representative Mark Meadows of North Carolina, the leader of the Freedom Caucus, expressed frustration that Congress was looking to pass its fourth stopgap spending measure for the 2018 fiscal year.\n\n\u201cThree strikes, you\u2019re out,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cI guess the speaker has the best plan, and so we\u2019ll just see how that works out.\u201d\n\nBut shortly before the vote on Thursday night, the Freedom Caucus announced that it had decided to support the stopgap bill, having extracted other concessions from the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin.\n\nTraveling in Pennsylvania, Mr. Trump accused Democrats of provoking a shutdown to drown out discussion of the Republican tax overhaul.\n\n\u201cI think the Democrats would like to see a shutdown in order to get off that subject,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters before delivering a speech.\n\nEighteen members of the Senate Democratic caucus voted for the last stopgap measure in December. But many of those members have already said they would oppose the latest bill, including Mr. Warner, Mr. Kaine, Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Senator Jon Tester of Montana.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Tester, who is up for re-election this year in a state that Mr. Trump won by 20 percentage points, denounced the stopgap bill as a \u201cdisgrace.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe keep doing patches and patches and patches and I\u2019m done,\u201d he said, adding: \u201cWe have to do our job, for God\u2019s sake! People need predictability in government.\u201d\n\nLawmakers were growing frustrated.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to play shutdown politics,\u201d said Senator Cory Gardner of Colorado, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. \u201cI think it\u2019s a bad idea and a pox on both parties.\u201d\n\nHis Colorado colleague, Senator Michael Bennet, a Democrat, agreed.\n\n\u201cIt just makes us all look terrible,\u201d Mr. Bennet said.", "title": "House Passes Short-Term Spending Bill, Setting Up Shutdown Battle in Senate", "authors": ["Thomas Kaplan", "Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Schiff said the committee had opened new avenues to investigate the Justice Department and F.B.I., a characterization disputed by Mr. Conaway.\n\nWhat comes next was less clear. Under the obscure House rule invoked by the committee, Mr. Trump now has five days to review the document and decide whether to try to block it from going public. The White House has repeatedly indicated that it wants the memo out, but Mr. Trump\u2019s Justice Department had been working to slow or block its release.\n\nShortly after Monday\u2019s vote, the memo was taken to the White House, where it was being reviewed by White House lawyers, according to a person familiar with the review.\n\nVoting as a bloc, Democrats tried to advance a series of motions on Monday that they said would help put the Republican memo in context. All but one of those motions failed along party lines. The committee did make a Democratic memo rebutting the Republican version available to the full House, but Republicans said they wanted time for members to review the document before considering its public release.\n\nThe Republican memo, which was made available to all members of the House, is said to contend that officials from the two agencies were not forthcoming to a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court judge. Republicans accuse the agencies of not properly disclosing that the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton\u2019s 2016 presidential campaign helped finance research that was used to obtain a warrant for surveillance of Carter Page, a Trump campaign adviser. The research presented to the judge was assembled by a former British intelligence officer, Christopher Steele.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe memo is not limited to actions taken by the Obama administration, though. The New York Times reported on Sunday that the memo reveals that Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein, a top Trump appointee, signed off an application to extend the surveillance of Mr. Page shortly after taking office last spring. The renewal shows that the Justice Department under Mr. Trump saw reason to believe that Mr. Page was acting as a Russian agent.\n\nThe inclusion of Mr. Rosenstein\u2019s action in the memo could expose him to a torrent of criticism from Republicans on Capitol Hill and from conservatives in the news media who have seized on the surveillance to argue that the Russia investigation may have been tainted from the start. Mr. Rosenstein is overseeing that investigation because Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself. It was Mr. Rosenstein who appointed Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Page, a former Moscow-based investment banker who went on to found a New York investment company, was on the F.B.I.\u2019s radar for years. A trip he took to Russia in July 2016 while working for Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign caught the bureau\u2019s attention again, and by the fall of 2016, shortly after he left the campaign, American law enforcement officials began conducting surveillance on him.\n\nTo obtain the surveillance warrant, the government would have had to demonstrate probable cause that he was acting as an agent of Russia. Investigators must seek approval from the Justice Department for such a warrant, and then prosecutors take it to a surveillance court judge.\n\nPeople familiar with the underlying application have portrayed the Republican memo as misleading in part, they say, because Mr. Steele\u2019s information was insufficient to meet the standard for a FISA warrant. They said the application drew on other intelligence material that the Republican memo selectively omits. That other information remains highly sensitive, and releasing it would risk burning other sources and methods of intelligence-gathering about Russia.\n\nDemocrats tried unsuccessfully on Monday to push forward a motion for the F.B.I. and the Justice Department to brief the entire House in a private session on that material before the release of the Republican memo so that they could make a more informed judgment about its contents.\n\nThere is no known precedent for the Republicans\u2019 action. Though House rules allow the Intelligence Committee to vote to disclose classified information if it is deemed to be in the public interest, the rule is not thought to have ever been used. Typically, lawmakers wishing to make public secretive information classified by the executive branch spend months, if not years, fighting with the White House and the intelligence community over what they can release.\n\nUntil this past weekend, the committee had refused to let anyone from the Justice Department or the F.B.I., who provided the materials underlying the memo, review it. Representative Devin Nunes of California relented on Sunday, allowing Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, to review the document. But Mr. Schiff said later in the day that Mr. Wray had conveyed to him that he still had concerns about its release.\n\nIn a letter last week to Mr. Nunes, the committee\u2019s Republican chairman, Stephen E. Boyd, an assistant attorney general, said it would be \u201cextraordinarily reckless\u201d to release a memo drawing on classified information without official review. He said the department is \u201cunaware of any wrongdoing related to the FISA process.\u201d\n\nSpeaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin largely stayed out of the dispute, deferring to Mr. Nunes and the committee on how to proceed.\n\nRepresentative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, was not so circumspect.\n\n\u201cClearly, House Republicans\u2019 desire to protect President Trump has clouded their judgment and caused them to lose sight of what\u2019s at stake: the security and integrity of our elections,\u201d her office said in a statement.", "title": "House Republicans Vote to Release Secret Memo on Russia Inquiry", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The new House Republicans\u2019 stand underscored the uncertainty about immigration. Mr. Trump\u2019s positions vacillate daily. And members of both parties are divided. Some Democrats are pressing for confrontation, while others seem to fear a political backlash. Some Republicans are searching for compromise against a conservative tide of anti-immigrant fervor.\n\nLorella Praeli, the director of immigration policy and campaigns at the American Civil Liberties Union, described the House legislation as a \u201ccollection of hard-line provisions designed to sabotage, rather than advance, the possibility of a bipartisan breakthrough.\u201d\n\nIt was not clear if the proposal would ever come up for a vote in the House, especially after Tuesday\u2019s White House meeting established the parameters for a bipartisan deal. And it is all but certain to have no future in the Senate, where immigration legislation would need 60 votes for passage and therefore could not make it through the chamber with only Republican support.\n\nThe immigration debate on Capitol Hill grew more complicated after a federal judge ruled Tuesday that, for now, the Trump administration could not end the DACA program.\n\nThe judge, Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court in San Francisco, wrote that the administration must \u201cmaintain the DACA program on a nationwide basis\u201d while lawsuits challenging the decision to end the program move ahead.\n\nMr. Trump lashed out on Twitter, saying that the United States court system was \u201cbroken and unfair,\u201d and members of both parties and immigration activists struggled to understand the legal and political implications of the judge\u2019s ruling.\n\nOfficials at the Department of Homeland Security, which administers the program for young immigrants, said they are preparing to follow the order even as they await possible action by the Justice Department to appeal the ruling in the days ahead.\n\nAdministration officials expressed confidence that the ruling would be overturned on appeal. And activists urged young immigrants not to take any actions to try to renew their DACA benefits until the legal picture is clearer.", "title": "House Republicans\u2019 Hard-Line Immigration Stand Clashes With Trump Overture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "When Mary Lois and I started our relationship on that humid night in Stamford, Conn., we may not have expected it to last. After all, I was unable to scratch my own nose, let alone walk. And she was three years older than me and far more independent.\n\nI asked if I could kiss her. I had to ask because I couldn\u2019t lean in on my own; my body doesn\u2019t work that way.\n\nSo she leaned in and kissed me as I had never been kissed before.\n\n\u201cYou were just a kid,\u201d she told me recently.\n\nI was 19. She wore her straight auburn hair in a short boy-cut then. More than 30 years later, she still does, though the color has faded. I wasn\u2019t only attracted to her iconoclastic spirit, alluring eyes and figure; I was on a mission to lose my virginity.", "title": "How 30 Blocks Became 30 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Curtis James Jackson III, known to most people as 50 Cent, has yet to release his much discussed and delayed sixth album, \u201cStreet King Immortal.\u201d But he has a good excuse for that. Fifty\u2019s been busy. The rapper and actor, who has survived financial hardships and multiple gunshot wounds, is filming the fifth season of the Starz series \u201cPower,\u201d (while advocating for its survival), serving as the host of a new late-night comedy show, 50 Central, on BET, and promoting his next movie, \u201cDen of Thieves,\u201d opening Jan. 19. He also just announced two new shows with Crackle, Sony\u2019s streaming service, \u201cThe Oath\u201d and \u201cRPM,\u201d and a new development deal with Starz and Lionsgate. The 42-year-old lives by himself in Midtown West.\n\nNINE HOURS I\u2019m usually out of bed by 9. In my business, that\u2019s early. When I\u2019m in the middle of recording an album, I could be in the studio until 3 or 4 in the morning, but on Saturday nights, I go to sleep at 11:30 or midnight and get a good nine hours of rest. I need it \u2014 it helps me refresh my body.\n\nEGG-WHITE EXCLUSIVE I want something in my system before I head to the gym, and like to eat healthy so I normally go for four egg whites. I\u2019m not a coffee person at all. Generally, I don\u2019t like to have a lot of caffeine.", "title": "How 50 Cent, Rapper and Actor, Spends His Sundays", "authors": ["Shivani Vora", "Sunday Routine"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "After the game, Saban was asked about the winning throw.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t believe it,\u201d Saban said. \u201cI knew we were running Seattle, which is four streaks and when I saw Smitty come open on the other side and Tua threw it, I said \u2018This is it.\u2019\u201d\n\nGeorgia\u2019s rushing attack, which had been so devastating against Oklahoma in the Rose Bowl, was not nearly as effective this time around, rushing for 133 yards against Alabama\u2019s stout front-seven.\n\nThe national championship is Alabama\u2019s 17th, while Georgia is still seeking the team\u2019s second title after having won it all in 1980.\n\nJoe Drape: This is the way national title games should go: Tua Tagovailoa with a 41-yard touchdown to DeVonta Smith. Nick Saban says it all after the game: \u201cIs it that a good game or what?\u201d\n\nWhy the change, Nick? \u201cI thought we needed to throw the ball and he could do it better.\u201d\n\n\u2014-\n\nWant our most ambitious sports stories, projects and analysis, from a rotating cast of New York Times journalists, delivered to your inbox once a week? Click here to receive our weekly Sports newsletter.\n\n\u2014-\n\nHere\u2019s a drive-by-drive look at how Alabama won the national championship:\n\nPhoto\n\n1Q, 13:38: Alabama\u2019s defense takes control early.\n\nThe Crimson Tide\u2019s defense showed its dominance immediately with an interception on the third play of the game.\n\nAlabama had won the coin toss and chose to defer, which resulted in Georgia receiving the ball to start the game. The ball was kicked out of the end zone for a touchback, which set the Bulldogs up at their own 25-yard line to start.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey got off to a slow start, with Jake Fromm dumping off two quick short passes that accounted for just three yards, but then he tried to be more aggressive, throwing deep to Javon Wims, and had his pass intercepted by Tony Brown.\n\nJoe Drape: Big play to open this slugfest. It was a fine throw by Fromm, but Brown took it away from Wims. Hard nosed play. Let\u2019s expect a lot of them. These are two top-10 defenses.\n\nPhoto\n\n1Q, 9:54: Tide fails to convert after interception.\n\nAlabama got painfully close to putting the ball in the end zone but they settled for a 40-yard field goal attempt by Andy Pappanastos that missed wide-left, keeping the game scoreless.\n\nThe Crimson Tide had started at their own 36-yard line thanks to Tony Brown\u2019s interception, and they made steady progress with their running game, picking up 30 yards on the ground to go with 17 through the air, generating three first downs. Jalen Hurts led the way with two carries for 22 yards.\n\nHurts then flirted with a touchdown when he found Calvin Ridley wide open in the end zone thanks to broken coverage, but the pass sailed over Ridley\u2019s head, taking away Alabama\u2019s best opportunity.\n\nPappanastos initially made a 35-yard attempt, but after a penalty he tried for 40 yards and missed badly.\n\nDrape: Couple of things: Nick Saban\u2019s process is unassailable on everything but the field goal kicking game. I hate criticizing Andy Pappanastos; He\u2019s a kid. But look back at Saban\u2019s Alabama years, and he\u2019s never developed a reliable kicker. What I mean by that, is someone who never gets any pub because he makes the kick he\u2019s supposed to. The false start was inexcusable. But this is exactly how they started against Clemson.\n\nPhoto\n\n1Q, 9:01: Georgia, a great running team, keeps passing.\n\nThrough two possessions, Georgia, which ran all over Oklahoma in the Rose Bowl, has passed on every single offensive play. Jake Fromm has completed just 3 of 7 passes for 17 yards as Sony Michel and Nick Chubb have been relegated to decoy work thus far. The strategy is not working as of yet, with Georgia having just one first down to go with one turnover and one punt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDrape: I like the fact Georgia is wide open. They do have a ground game, but they are challenging Bama\u2019s secondary. As our colleague Marc Tracy pointed out, Jalen Hurts is a game manager. He is there to make good decisions. These are the opening rounds of a heavyweight fight and neither team is backing down.\n\nPhoto\n\n1Q, 6:54: Alabama\u2019s offense sputters.\n\nAfter two short plays, Alabama was faced with a 3rd-and-3, and it was fairly obvious that Jalen Hurts would be running the ball. Georgia sniffed the keeper out immediately, easily stopping the quarterback for a loss of one yard. The quiet start to the game continues with Alabama punting the ball away.\n\nDrape: It\u2019s early, but this game is looking promising. Hurts is going to need to run tonight. He\u2019s more Blake Bortles than Drew Brees, and there is nothing wrong with that. But these two staffs have the other measured so far.\n\nPhoto\n\n2Q, 14:14: Georgia settles for a field goal, and the lead.\n\nAt the end of the first quarter, Georgia finally had something working, but they failed to convert on 3rd-and-11 to start the second quarter and Rodrigo Blankenship came out to hit a 41-yard field goal to give the Bulldogs a 3-0 lead.\n\nIt took several frustrating attempts to get Georgia\u2019s running game on track, but on a 3rd-and-20 near the end of the first quarter the Bulldogs chose to run the ball and Sony Michel broke free on the right sideline, sprinting for a 26-yard run that woke up Georgia\u2019s offense.\n\nBefore Michel\u2019s run it had looked like yet another drive would end in a quick punt. Alabama\u2019s Anthony Averett delivered a huge sack on a 2nd-and-10 play, sending Georgia all the way from Alabama\u2019s 42-yard line to Georgia\u2019s 48-yard line. But despite the Crimson Tide\u2019s powerful front-seven having sniffed out and demolished both Nick Chubb and Michel on most of their previous attempts, Georgia went with a run on the 3rd-and-long and were rewarded with a huge gain, eventually setting up Blankenship\u2019s kick.\n\nDrape: Hot Rod Blankenship, the Dawgs kicker is a helluva story. Him of the Kurt Rambis glasses. He was a preferred walk-on with former Coach Mark Richt. But Kirby Smart was slow to put him on scholarship. He did eventually the day before the Notre Dame game, which Hot Rod won with a field goal. He went for 55-yards against Oklahoma. He may be the difference here. In fact, he already is.\n\n2Q, 12:52: Alabama fails to answer Georgia\u2019s scoring drive.\n\nAfter a touchback, Alabama started at their own 25 and they answered Georgia\u2019s scoring drive by going absolutely nowhere. Two runs and an incomplete pass generated only 4 yards before the Crimson Tide punted the ball away. Georgia had an injury delay early in the drive when David Marshall, a sophomore linebacker, was slow to get up after a running play before being taken to a medical tent for further evaluation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDrape: Here is what Alabama was worried about before the game, and is now in a full blown panic. The Georgia defensive front is strong and harassing. They totally owned Oklahoma\u2019s Baker Mayfield, the Heisman winner. Jalen Hurts looks lost. Unless the Tide opens up a ground game, Hurts is going to be hurting, and the Dawgs are going to be rolling over the Tide.\n\nPhoto\n\n2Q, 7:33: Another Georgia drive ends in a field goal.\n\nGeorgia started using all of their weapons and had the team\u2019s best drive of the game, but after failing to get into the end zone after reaching 1st-and-goal, they settled for a 27-yard field goal from Rodrigo Blankenship that increased their lead to 6-0.\n\nLooking to capitalize on getting the ball back so quickly after they had taken the lead, the Bulldogs started things off when Jake Fromm hit D\u2019Andre Swift with a screen pass that went for 15 yards. Runs by Nick Chubb and Fromm picked up a second first down. Then Fromm aggressively challenged the Alabama defense by throwing downfield, and it worked, with Riley Ridley contributing a 23-yard catch-and-run while Javon Wims made a circus catch on the sideline that stood up to an official review.\n\nThat set up a 1st-and-goal from Alabama\u2019s 10-yard line, but the Bulldogs stalled out, setting up Blankenship for yet another kick.\n\nDrape: Wow, how big has freshman Jake Fromm been? That was a big throw to Riley Ridley, and even a bigger one to Wims to take them into the red zone. He almost made a freshman mistake on 3rd & 6. The Dawgs should have had 7 there. A 6-0 lead over Alabama is not enough after you\u2019ve pushed them around.\n\nPhoto\n\n2Q, 5:15: Tide offense shows some life, but stalls out.\n\nAlabama got a huge start to the drive on a delayed keeper by Jalen Hurts that went for 31 yards, with Georgia seemingly having been caught on their heels. But the Bulldogs quickly made up for that mistake when Davin Bellamy got a huge 6-yard sack on 2nd-and-9. Josh Jacob ran the ball for 5 yards and then the Crimson Tide punted yet again, showing little sign of having figured out Georgia\u2019s defense.\n\n2Q, 2:14: Georgia\u2019s Javon Wims goes to locker room.\n\nA nice punt resulted in Georgia starting from their own 5-yard line, and with so little room to work they settled for two short runs by Nick Chubb before Jake Fromm stepped back into the pocket and found Riley Ridley in the middle of the field for a huge 16-yard completion. It was Ridley\u2019s third big catch of the game, helping somewhat alleviate the concern of Javon Wims having gone into Georgia\u2019s locker room to be evaluated for an injury.\n\nGeorgia quickly found itself in another third down situation, but this time Fromm\u2019s throw was well off its mark, skipping to the ground in front of Mecole Hardman.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Bulldogs were forced to punt, but thanks to Ridley\u2019s catch the field position is not nearly as bad as it could have been.\n\n2Q, 1:19: Nothing for Alabama.\n\nAlabama\u2019s offense is not doing anything right now. Georgia forced a three-and-out, with the Crimson Tide getting seven yards on a pair of runs before an incomplete pass and a punt completed their drive.\n\nPhoto\n\n2Q, 0:07: Bulldogs head into the locker room with a 13-0 lead.\n\nGeorgia did not have much time to work with, but they had all three timeouts remaining, so they decided to be aggressive heading into halftime. It paid off, with Mecole Hardman taking a direct-snap into the end zone from 1 yard out for the first touchdown of the game and a 13-0 lead for the Bulldogs.\n\nThe drive started with 1:19 remaining in the half, and Jake Fromm immediately found Riley Ridley for a 10-yard gain. Fromm was nearly intercepted a few plays later, but when Alabama\u2019s Anthony Averett failed to get his hands on the ball, the Bulldogs capitalized by getting 14 yards on the ground from Sony Michel on the next play.\n\nAn Alabama penalty got Georgia 5 more yards, D\u2019Andre Swift ran for 7 and Fromm, not seeing any good receiving options, pulled the ball down and reeled off a 14-yard run of his own.\n\nWith a short field in front of him, Fromm threw aggressively to Terry Godwin for a 16-yard gain near the goal line setting up a 1st-and-goal from the 3. A roughing the passer call got Georgia all the way to the Alabama 1-yard line, and Hardman took the ball on a direct-snap, running into the end zone easily.\n\nDrape: Wonderful call by Georgia offensive coordinator Jim Chaney to run the Wildcat \u2014 a snap to Mecole Hardman, who waltzes to the corner. This game is far from over. Nick Saban is frustrated in his halftime interview, but he purposefully doesn\u2019t lay it on quarterback Jalen Hurts. Georgia\u2019s Kirby Smart is understated and says Jake Fromm is making good decisions. Fromm is going to make Dawg fans forget Buck Belue with another half like that (not really). I\u2019m not putting this in the victory column for Georgia yet. Saban and the Tide are too good \u2014 see five national championships \u2014 but that was a big score to end the half.\n\nTracy: To go off Joe\u2019s point, the past two national title games \u2014 both of which also involved Alabama \u2014 were shootouts whose final scores were 35-31 and 45-40. At halftime of those games, the scores were, respectively, 14-7 and 21-7. If past is prologue, the second half will involve substantially more scoring than the first.\n\nPhoto\n\n3Q, 13:03: Saban switches to freshman quarterback.\n\nAlabama started the half with Tua Tagovailoa at quarterback rather than Jalen Hurts. It was a somewhat surprising change, which means both teams are playing true freshmen at quarterback.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTagovailoa\u2019s opening drive did not make much of a change in the offense as he ran for 4 yards and passed for 2 before a sack left them with a 3rd-and-8, effectively ending their drive. Alabama had a short injury delay while Jonah Williams was treated on the field, but they eventually punted the ball away.\n\nDrape: Nick Saban is either panicking or a genius. He\u2019s put in Tagovailoa in at quarterback, a freshman, after saying it wasn\u2019t Jalen Hurts\u2019s fault the Tide struggled in the first half. I vote for panicking. He has decided that he can\u2019t stop Georgia, and needs to score with them. Hurts is 25-2. At least we know now that Robo-Coach Saban is human after all. Kirby Smart has gotten under Nick\u2019s skin.\n\nPhoto\n\n3Q, 10:51: Tide\u2019s defense picks up the intensity.\n\nAlabama\u2019s offense may have looked slow coming out of the locker room, but the Tide\u2019s defense was clearly fired up, forcing consecutive plays of negative yards before Georgia\u2019s drive fizzled out with a 4-yard run by D\u2019Andre Swift. The Bulldogs had the ball for just 93 seconds of clock time, but the team\u2019s fans were left angry about a missed face mask call on Swift\u2019s second-down run which went for minus-8 yards.\n\nPhoto\n\n3Q, 8:52: And just like that, Alabama is back in it.\n\nTua Tagovailoa showed why Nick Saban put him in. The true freshman led a drive that was far more impressive than anything Jalen Hurts had offered, and he got the Crimson Tide their first touchdown of the game, narrowing Georgia\u2019s lead to 13-7.\n\nHe started with beautiful deep pass to Calvin Ridley that nearly went for a 44-yard touchdown, but the ball was just out Ridley\u2019s hands and it fell incomplete. On the next play he saw no openings and fought for a 3-yard gain, lowering his shoulder into a defender at the tail end of the play.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn 3rd-and-7 the pass protection was broken down and he cut to the right of the field before cheating back to the left for a 9-yard gain, and then picked up 39 more yards with a completion to Robert Foster and two to Henry Ruggs III.\n\nWith a 1st-and-goal from Georgia\u2019s 6-yard line, Tagovailoa again found Ruggs for the touchdown, dramatically changing the landscape of this game.\n\nDrape: Nice Alabama drive keyed by Tua Tagovailoa. His third down scramble was the key play. Chris Fowler says we have a \u201cFreshman Quarterback Duel.\u201d Hurts is the first one on the field to congratulate his rival on the touchdown. The balance inches back to Nick as a genius, but I\u2019m doubling down on panic.\n\nPhoto\n\n3Q, 6:52: Georgia answers with an 80-yard touchdown.\n\nAlabama had made it a football game with Tua Tagovailoa\u2019s thrilling touchdown drive, and their special teams piled on by pinning Georgia down at their own 7-yard line to start their next drive. But Jake Fromm was not intimidated. Fromm\u2019s 80-yard touchdown pass to Mecole Hardman made the score 20-7 in Georgia\u2019s favor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFromm started the drive by immediately picking up a first down with a 14-yard pass over the middle to Terry Godwin, but Nick Chubb gave 8 yards of that back when Anthony Averett dropped him deep in the backfield.\n\nChubb ran up the middle for 7 yards, getting the Bulldogs to 3rd-and-11, and Fromm aggressively threw deep to Hardman on the sideline. The sophomore wide receiver fought past the coverage for the long touchdown and the play stood up to a review by officials.\n\nDrape: Wow! I say it again because we are a public forum. But Fromm to Hardman for 80 yards on 3rd and 18 is pretty spectacular. Saban, who some of our readers say never panics, has to be a bit puckered now. Still, it\u2019s a great game. Bring on Tua Tagovailoa!\n\n3Q, 6:32: Tagovailoa throws into trouble.\n\nNot wanting Jake Fromm to get all the fun, Tua Tagovailoa again threw deep on the first play of a drive, but this one fell incomplete just in front of DeVonta Smith. On second down he rolled out to his left and forced a bad pass down the sideline, which was intercepted by Georgia\u2019s Deandre Baker. As good as Tagovailoa looked on the previous drive, the pick was exactly what you would expect from a true freshman pushed into such a difficult circumstance.\n\nPhoto\n\n3Q, 6:21: Alabama\u2019s defense takes the ball back.\n\nAlabama answered an interception with one of their own. On the first play of Georgia\u2019s drive, Jake Fromm threw to his left, had it deflect off the helmet of a defensive lineman, and then fall into the hands of Raekwon Davis for the turnover.\n\nQ3, 5:15: Alabama cuts into Georgia\u2019s lead.\n\nAn Alabama field goal made it 20-10 in Georgia\u2019s favor.\n\nGiven a short field thanks to the interception, Alabama ran the ball twice, picking up a first down, and then Tua Tagovailoa took a shot at the end zone with a pass that sailed over the hands of Cam Sims. Tagovailoa was nearly intercepted on second down when a bad drop by Calvin Ridley popped into the air, and then the drive stalled with an incomplete pass on third down.\n\nAndy Pappanastos came out and hit a 43-yard field goal to pull within 10 points.\n\nDrape: Critical drive coming up here. Nick Saban rolled the dice with Tua Tagovailoa. Briefly looked like a genius, but ultimately gets an interception by the freshman, and eventually a field goal. Bad penalty sets up the Dawgs. A touchdown puts this out of reach.\n\nPhoto\n\nQ3, 1:55: Fromm\u2019s third-down magic runs out.\n\nAfter the kickoff, Georgia got 15 yards for free thanks to an unnecessary roughness call against Alabama\u2019s Mekhi Brown, who continued to rant and rave on the sideline when he was pulled out of the game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNick Chubb did not get far on two runs, giving Jake Fromm yet another big third down opportunity, and the freshman capitalized with a 13-yard pass to Riley Ridley, who has been superb all game.\n\nThe third-down magic was nowhere to be found a few plays later on an incomplete pass to Ridley, setting up a Georgia punt.\n\n3Q, 0:08: Georgia\u2019s defense keeps Tagovailoa in check.\n\nAlabama got a quick first down with a 16-yard run by Bo Scarbrough, but a 7-yard pass from Tua Tagovailoa to Calvin Ridley was followed by a run by Scarbrough for no gain and a pass from Tagovailoa to Scarbrough for 1 yard, leading to a punt.\n\nDrape: This title game delivered what it promised: two hard-nosed teams from the best conference in college football, the S.E.C. Every series matters. I still can\u2019t believe Nick Saban replaced his 25-2, two title-game starter, with a freshman.\n\n4Q, 11:39: Georgia starts working the clock.\n\nStarting the fourth quarter with a 10-point lead, Georgia was clearly thinking about the clock and they started their drive with four consecutive running plays by Sony Michel, accounting for 31 yards. Michel was spelled by Nick Chubb, who ran twice for 6 yards. But on 3rd-and-4, Nick Fromm dropped back to pass and was crushed to the ground by Raekwon Davis for a 9-yard sack, forcing the Bulldogs to punt and keeping Alabama in the game.\n\nPhoto\n\n4Q, 9:24: Another field goal for Alabama cuts into Georgia\u2019s lead.\n\nThe Crimson Tide would have liked a touchdown, but after a pass was nearly intercepted in the end zone they should be happy with a field goal that made the score 20-13.\n\nAlabama was steadily moving down the field, taking what Georgia would give them before Najee Harris uncorked a 36-yard run to the left side of the field, fighting past tacklers all the way.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHarris had another short run before Tua Tagovailoa just missed Jerry Jeudy on a throw to the end zone, setting up a 3rd-and-8 from Georgia\u2019s 12-yard line. Georgia burned a timeout and then Tagovailoa took another shot into the end zone, just missing Jeudy on a ball that was very nearly intercepted by Dominick Sanders.\n\nThat brought out Andy Pappanastos, who hit from 30 yards out to pull within seven points.\n\nDrape: These two teams are hitting harder the deeper into the game we go. Harris was punishing on his 36-yard run. On the big 3rd-and-8 from the 12-yard line, Saban lets Tagovailoa throw it. It looked like it was intercepted by Sanders, who already has 16 interceptions, but it doesn\u2019t stand up to review. In Vegas, you are still ahead if you took the Dawgs plus 6.\n\n4Q, 7:10: Georgia stalls again, giving Alabama a chance.\n\nGeorgia is not able to keep its offense on the field, which is giving Alabama a lot of opportunities to get back into this game.\n\nA direct snap to Nick Chubb fooled no one and the running back was hit for a 1-yard loss. Georgia then got 9 yards from Mecole Hardman on a sweep to the right. Sony Michel went up the middle to try to extend the drive but he was stopped immediately, forcing a punt.\n\nThe Crimson Tide now have the ball down seven points with just over seven minutes remaining in the game.\n\nDrape: Georgia\u2019s offensive coordinator Jim Chaney got too cute on this drive. Two Wild (Dawg) calls that went nowhere. Let Fromm win or lose it. He\u2019s gotten you that far. Seven minutes left. Now, it\u2019s Georgia\u2019s defensive line against the freshman quarterback. We\u2019ll see if Nick Saban is worth his $7 million a year here.\n\nPhoto\n\n4Q, 3:49: Alabama ties it up.\n\nTua Tagovailoa did not look like a true freshman when he hit Calvin Ridley for a 7-yard touchdown pass on 4th-and-4 that along with the extra point tied this game at 20-20.\n\nAlabama got a quick start on a screen pass to Damien Harris that the running back caught in the backfield before picking up 17 yards. A short run by Tagovailoa, and an incomplete pass set up a 3rd-and-9, which Georgia gave them by way of a pass interference call that resulted in a 35-yard penalty.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGiven fresh life, the Crimson Tide picked up another 20 yards on a pass from Tagovailoa to Jerry Jeudy and nearly got a touchdown on a pass to Calvin Ridley on the next play before the ball fell to the ground.\n\nTagovailoa ran to Georgia\u2019s 6-yard line, Harris got hit for a 1-yard loss, Alabama went for it on 4th-and-4 and then Tagovailoa hit Ridley for the game-tying score.\n\nDrape: Great third down stuff by Georgia\u2019s Thompson. Bama is 14 of 17 on 4th down. They went for it. And ... Big Brother Ridley hauls it in for Tagovailoa. So now it\u2019s all tied up at 20-20. Give it to the kid quarterback: he keeps his poise and drills it into traffic. Big Brother Ridley, you are back in the top bunk.\n\n4Q, 2:55: Three-and-out for Georgia gives Alabama another shot.\n\nWith the game all tied up, Georgia had a chance to retake control, but they went three-and-out, with Jake Fromm\u2019s third down pass sailing well out of D\u2019Andre Swift\u2019s reach. The Bulldogs punted the ball away and Alabama has a chance to win the game with just under three minutes to play.\n\nPhoto\n\nQ4, 0:00: Alabama misses field goal. We\u2019re headed to overtime.\n\nAlabama had a chance to win the game on a 36-yard field goal attempt by Andy Pappanastos, but the kicker missed wide left, sending the game to overtime.\n\nAlabama\u2019s drive had started with Najee Harris being knocked for a 1-yard loss. Harris then took the ball to the right side and very nearly got brought down at the line of scrimmage before stumbling for an 11-yard gain and a first down.\n\nTua Tagovailoa hit Calvin Ridley for a 9-yard gain, which had 15 yards tacked onto it thanks to a face mask by Malkom Parrish, then got 6 yards by running the ball. A handoff to Harris went for no gain, setting up a 3rd-and-3, which Tagovailoa took care of himself with a run to the left side where he fought through tacklers for the first down.\n\nAlabama ran the clock down before sending Pappanastos out for the attempt to win the game, but he missed badly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDrape: Got to feel bad for Alabama kicker Andy Pappanastos. He had missed 2 of his past 3 kicks entering the game. When he lined up for a 35-yard field goal early in the game, his attempt split the uprights. But Alabama was called for a false start, pushing Pappanastos back an extra five yards. He missed. It foreshadowed perhaps the kick he had to win the game from 36 yards with .03 seconds left. He hooked it left. Pappanastos, a senior, was just 16 of 21 on the season.\n\nOT: Blankenship\u2019s leg gives Georgia the lead.\n\nIn Georgia\u2019s first try in overtime, a sack of Jake Fromm led to Rodrigo Blankenship having to kick from 51 yards. The steady kicker for the Bulldogs crushed the kick, putting the Bulldogs temporarily on top 23-20.\n\nOT: Game over.\n\nTua Tagovailoa took a bad sack on first down, but his perfect strike to De\u2019Vonta Smith was the ultimate reward for Nick Saban\u2019s choice to put him in the game.", "title": "How Alabama Won the National Championship, Drive by Drive", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman", "Joe Drape", "Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 The other week, 218 cities and states lost in the sweepstakes to be the home of Amazon\u2019s second headquarters, failing to make the list of 20 finalists.\n\nBut Amazon thanks them for playing.\n\nThat is because the hundreds of applications gave Amazon a hidden benefit: free research that the company can mine when picking spots for future warehouses and satellite offices.\n\nAmazon asked every city and state applying for its second headquarters for details about local resources, like available talent and transit options.
