Local officials were also prodded for tips on local education programs and tax incentives.\n\nThe answers \u2014 most of which have not been released publicly \u2014 essentially do Amazon\u2019s homework for it, providing valuable information that the company otherwise would have needed to dig up on its own or obtain through one-on-one negotiations.", "title": "How Amazon Benefits From Losing Cities\u2019 HQ2 Bids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wardle\u2019s curiosity was piqued by recent news that Russian spies had used Kaspersky antivirus products to siphon classified documents off the home computer of an N.S.A. developer, and may have played a critical role in broader Russian intelligence gathering.\n\n\u201cI wanted to know if this was a feasible attack mechanism,\u201d Mr. Wardle said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to get into the complex accusations. But from a technical point of view, if an antivirus maker wanted to, was coerced to, or was hacked or somehow subverted, could it create a signature to flag classified documents?\u201d\n\nThat question has taken on renewed importance over the last three months in the wake of United States officials\u2019 accusations that Kaspersky\u2019s antivirus software was used for Russian intelligence gathering, an accusation that Kaspersky has rigorously denied.\n\nLast month, Kaspersky Lab sued the Trump administration after a Department of Homeland Security directive banning its software from federal computer networks. Kaspersky claimed in an open letter that \u201cD.H.S. has harmed Kaspersky Lab\u2019s reputation and its commercial operations without any evidence of wrongdoing by the company.\u201d\n\nFor years, intelligence agencies suspected that Kaspersky Lab\u2019s security products provided a back door for Russian intelligence. A draft of a top-secret report leaked by Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, described a top-secret, N.S.A. effort in 2008 that concluded that Kaspersky\u2019s software collected sensitive information off customers\u2019 machines.\n\nThe documents showed Kaspersky was not the N.S.A.\u2019s only target. Future targets included nearly two dozen other foreign antivirus makers, including Checkpoint in Israel and Avast in the Czech Republic.\n\nAt the N.S.A., analysts were barred from using Kaspersky antivirus software because of the risk it would give the Kremlin broad access to their machines and data. But excluding N.S.A. headquarters at Fort Meade, Kaspersky still managed to secure contracts with nearly two dozen American government agencies over the last few years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast September, the Department of Homeland Security ordered all federal agencies to cease using Kaspersky products because of the threat that Kaspersky\u2019s products could \u201cprovide access to files.\u201d\n\nA month later, The New York Times reported that the Homeland Security directive was based, in large part, on intelligence shared by Israeli intelligence officials who successfully hacked Kaspersky Lab in 2014. They looked on for months as Russian government hackers scanned computers belonging to Kaspersky customers around the world for top secret American government classified programs.\n\nIn at least one case, United States officials claimed Russian intelligence officials were successful in using Kaspersky\u2019s software to pull classified documents off a home computer belonging to Nghia H. Pho, an N.S.A. developer who had installed Kaspersky\u2019s antivirus software on his home computer. Mr. Pho pleaded guilty last year to bringing home classified documents and writings, and has said he brought the files home only in an attempt to expand his r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKaspersky Lab initially denied any knowledge or involvement with the document theft. But the company has since acknowledged finding N.S.A. hacking software on Mr. Pho\u2019s computer and removing it, though the company said it had immediately destroyed the documents once it realized they were classified.\n\nThe company also said in November that in the course of investigating a surveillance operation known as TeamSpy in 2015, it had tweaked its antivirus program to scan files containing the word \u201csecret.\u201d The company said it had done this because the TeamSpy attackers were known to automatically scan for files that included the words \u201csecret,\u201d \u201cpass\u201d and \u201csaidumlo,\u201d the Georgian translation for the word secret.\n\nKaspersky continues to deny that it knew about the scanning for classified United States programs or allowed its antivirus products to be used by Russian intelligence. Eugene Kaspersky, the company\u2019s chief executive, has said he would allow the United States government to inspect his company\u2019s source code to allay distrust of its antivirus and cybersecurity products.\n\nBut Mr. Wardle discovered, in reverse-engineering Kaspersky antivirus software, that a simple review of its source code would do nothing to prove its products had not been used as a Russian intelligence-gathering tool. (Watch how he reverse-engineered the software.)\n\nMr. Wardle found that Kaspersky\u2019s antivirus software is incredibly complex. Unlike traditional antivirus software, which uses digital \u201csignatures\u201d to look for malicious code and patterns of activity, Kaspersky\u2019s signatures are easily updated, can be automatically pushed out to certain clients, and contain code that can be tweaked to do things like automatically scanning for and siphoning off classified documents.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn short, Mr. Wardle found, \u201cantivirus could be the ultimate cyberespionage spying tool.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Wardle said it was relatively easy to use a vulnerability in Microsoft\u2019s Windows software to manipulate the Kaspersky software. Because officials routinely classify top secret documents with the marking \u201cTS/SCI,\u201d which stands for \u201cTop Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information,\u201d Mr. Wardle added a rule to Kaspersky\u2019s antivirus program to flag any documents that contained the \u201cTS/SCI\u201d marker.\n\nHe then edited a document on his computer containing text from the Winnie the Pooh children\u2019s book series to include the marking \u201cTS/SCI\u201d and waited to see whether Kaspersky\u2019s tweaked antivirus product would catch it.\n\nPhoto\n\nSure enough, as soon as the Winnie the Pooh text was saved to his machine, Kaspersky\u2019s antivirus software flagged and quarantined the document. When he added the same TS/SCI marker to another document containing the text \u201cThe quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog,\u201d it, too, was flagged and quarantined by Kaspersky\u2019s tweaked antivirus program.\n\n\u201cNot a whole lot of surprise that this worked,\u201d Mr. Wardle said, \u201cbut still neat to confirm that an antivirus product can be trivially, yet surreptitiously, used to detect classified documents.\u201d\n\nThe next question was: What happens to these files once they are flagged? Mr. Wardle stopped short of hacking into Kaspersky\u2019s cloud servers, where suspicious files are routinely uploaded.\n\nHowever, he noted that antivirus customers, including Kaspersky\u2019s, agreed by default to allow security vendors to send anything from their machine back to vendors\u2019 servers for further investigation.\n\nThere are legitimate reasons for this: By uploading these items to Kaspersky\u2019s cloud, security analysts can evaluate whether they pose a threat, and update their signatures as a result.\n\nKaspersky Lab said Mr. Wardle\u2019s research did not reflect how the company\u2019s software works.\n\n\u201cIt is impossible for Kaspersky Lab to deliver a specific signature or update to only one user in a secret, targeted way because all signatures are always openly available to all our users; and updates are digitally signed, further making it impossible to fake an update,\u201d the company said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe company added that it applied the same security standards and maintained the same levels of access as other security vendors, and reiterated that it was willing to make its source code, threat detection rules and software updates available for audit by independent experts.\n\nBut, as Mr. Wardle\u2019s research demonstrated, an untrustworthy vendor, or hacker or spy with access to that vendor\u2019s systems, can abuse its deep access to turn antivirus software into a dynamic search tool, not unlike Google, to scan customers\u2019 computers for documents that contain certain keywords.\n\n\u201cAnd no one would ever know,\u201d he added. \u201cIt\u2019s the perfect cybercrime.\u201d", "title": "How Antivirus Software Can Be Turned Into a Tool for Spying", "authors": ["Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Sharon, meanwhile, had been maintaining constant pressure on Lt. Gen. Rafael Eitan, chief of staff of the Israeli Defense Forces, for the operation to move forward. The air force put two F-15 fighters on alert for immediate takeoff from the Tel Nof air force base. Ivry, ever cautious, briefed the lead pilot himself. He understood the stakes. It was clear to him how disastrous it would be if Israel shot down the wrong aircraft. \u201cYou don\u2019t fire without my O.K.,\u201d he told the pilot. \u201cClear? Even if there\u2019s a communications problem, if you don\u2019t hear my order\u201d \u2014 he emphasized that part: hear my order \u2014 \u201cyou don\u2019t open fire.\u201d\n\nAt 2:05 p.m. on Oct. 23, one of the Caesarea operatives in Athens called Mossad headquarters. \u201cHe\u2019s here,\u201d he said. \u201cPositive ID.\u201d His excitement was audible. He reported that he had watched the P.L.O. leader and his men making final preparations to board a DHC-5 Buffalo with a tail painted blue with brown marks and the registration number 1169.\n\nPhoto\n\nMossad passed the confirmation to Canary. To Ivry, though, something seemed off. \u201cI didn\u2019t get this whole story,\u201d he told me years later, sitting in his executive suite overlooking Tel Aviv, where he works now as the president of Boeing Israel. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t clear to me why Arafat would be flying to Cairo. According to intelligence, he had nothing to look for there at the time. And if he was going there, why in that kind of transport plane? Not at all dignified enough for a man of his status. I asked the Mossad to verify that he was the man.\u201d\n\nThe two Caesarea operatives once again insisted that it was Arafat. \u201cThe objective has grown a longer beard to mislead,\u201d they reported. Mossad reconfirmed the positive identification.\n\nAt 4:30 p.m., the operatives reported that the plane had taken off. Ivry got the formal order, by telephone, from Eitan: Shoot it down. Ivry told his F-15 pilots to take off. It wouldn\u2019t take long to intercept the sluggish transport plane.\n\nAs the jets closed in, Ivry still harbored doubts. He told his aide to contact Mossad again and demand that it provide secondary confirmation that it was Arafat on the plane and not just someone who looked like him. Ivry seldom displayed any emotion. \u201cBut we could see he was very worried,\u201d said one of his subordinates who was present at the time.\n\nIvry needed to buy time. He also knew that pilots can be overeager, that sometimes they\u2019ll look for a reason to fire on a target, interpreting a burst of radio static as an order to shoot, for instance. \u201cHold your fire,\u201d he reminded his pilots. \u201cIf there\u2019s no radio contact, do not open fire.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEitan kept calling to find out what was happening and to see whether his order to shoot down the plane had been carried out. Even though the Caesarea operatives had confirmed and then reconfirmed that it was Arafat, Ivry gave the same reply each time: \u201cRaful,\u201d Ivry said, using Eitan\u2019s nickname, \u201cwe do not yet have final positive confirmation that it is him.\u201d\n\nSeparately, Ivry told the Military Intelligence directorate (known by its acronym AMAN) and Mossad that the visual identification was insufficient and he demanded yet another crosschecked confirmation that Arafat was on the plane. That\u2019s when the pilots picked up the radar blip and sought permission to engage.\n\nIvry couldn\u2019t stall much longer. He had been given a direct order. If he didn\u2019t take down the aircraft soon, he would have to explain why to Eitan and Sharon.\n\nTension was heightening. The minutes dragged on.\n\nAnd then, five minutes before 5 o\u2019clock, 25 minutes after the fighters took off, a phone jangled in Canary. It was the secure line that connected directly to Mossad headquarters. \u201cDoubts have arisen,\u201d said the voice on the line, with embarrassment. Mossad had other sources who insisted that Arafat had been nowhere near Greece, and that the man on the plane couldn\u2019t possibly be Arafat.\n\nIn the absence of another order, the pair of F-15s continued to track the Buffalo. Ivry repeated his orders. \u201cWe\u2019re waiting for more information. Keep eyes on the target and wait.\u201d\n\nAt 5:23 p.m., another report came in to Canary. Sources from Mossad and AMAN said the man on the plane was Fathi Arafat, Yasir\u2019s look-alike younger brother, a pediatrician and the founder of the Palestinian Red Crescent Society. With him were 30 wounded Palestinian children, survivors of the massacre that the Lebanese Maronite Christian Phalange militia had perpetrated in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in Beirut a month before. Fathi Arafat was escorting them to Cairo for medical treatment.\n\nIvry breathed a sigh of relief. \u201cTurn around,\u201d he ordered the pilot. \u201cYou\u2019re coming home.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe choice facing Ivry on that day in October 1982 was only one example of a dilemma that has confronted many Israeli authorities over the course of the nation\u2019s brief history \u2014 the violent and sometimes irreconcilable clash between the fundamental principles of democracy and a nation\u2019s instinct to defend itself.\n\nAs a reporter in Israel, I have interviewed hundreds of people in its intelligence and defense establishments and studied thousands of classified documents that revealed a hidden history, surprising even in the context of Israel\u2019s already fierce reputation. Many of the people I spoke to, in explaining why they did what they did, would simply cite the Babylonian Talmud: \u201cIf someone comes to kill you, rise up and kill him first.\u201d In my reporting, I found that since World War II, Israel has used assassination and targeted-killing more than any other country in the West, in many cases endangering the lives of civilians. But I also discovered a long history of profound \u2014 and often rancorous \u2014 internal debates over how the state should be preserved. Can a nation use the methods of terrorism? Can it harm innocent civilians in the process? What are the costs? Where is the line?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIncreasingly, people want to talk. It was during a conversation in 2011 with a senior officer in a North Tel Aviv cafe that I heard for the first time about how Sharon had ordered that transport plane carrying Arafat to be shot down in 1982. He described everything in detail but set a stiff condition for publication of the story \u2014 another person had to describe the event on the record as well. Only by doing that could I publish the story. I went to see that person, knowing how difficult it would be to get him to speak about the episode. I approached in a roundabout manner before I touched on the relevant point. The man looked at me with his steely gaze, but then a softer and slightly sad expression came over his face. \u201cFor more than 30 years,\u201d he said, \u201cI have been waiting for someone to come and ask me about this story.\u201d\n\nNo target thwarted, vexed and bedeviled the Israeli assassination apparatus more than Yasir Arafat, the charismatic P.L.O. leader who died in 2004. Sometimes he would simply escape, and sometimes the officials overseeing an effort would call it off because the target could not be confirmed or because the price in civilian lives was deemed too high. Time and again, the desire to kill Arafat placed Israel at the center of the ongoing debate about what a nation can and cannot do to survive.\n\nIn the years after Arafat founded Fatah, a forerunner of the P.L.O., in 1959, Mossad dismissed him and his friends as students and intellectuals. By 1965, when Fatah was carrying out its first guerrilla and terror operations against Israel, Rafi Eitan, the chief of Mossad operations in Europe (no relation to Raful Eitan, the I.D.F. general), asked the Mossad director, Meir Amit, to order Caesarea to break into an apartment that Arafat was using as an operational base in Frankfurt and kill him. \u201cWe can do it easily,\u201d he wrote to Amit. \u201cWe have access to the target, and this is an opportunity that we may not get again.\u201d According to Eitan, Amit refused to sign off. He didn\u2019t see the group as much more than a gang of young thugs. \u201cToo bad they didn\u2019t listen to me,\u201d Eitan told me decades later. \u201cWe could have saved ourselves a lot of effort, heartache and sorrow.\u201d\n\nUltimately, though, it was Eitan\u2019s attitude that prevailed. The belief that assassinating the P.L.O. leader would solve the entire Palestinian problem would be the predominant opinion in Israeli intelligence for many years to come. \u201cIsrael must strike at the heart of the terror organizations,\u201d Yehuda Arbel, the Shin Bet commander in Jerusalem and the West Bank in the late 1960s, wrote in his diary. \u201cThe elimination of Abu Ammar\u201d \u2014 Arafat \u2014 \u201cis a precondition to finding a solution to the Palestinian problem.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd this is exactly what Israel would try to do, numerous times. Sometimes the efforts involved direct military action. Right after the Six Day War, Arafat launched a series of guerrilla operations from East Jerusalem and the West Bank. Acting on a tip, Israeli soldiers stormed the house where he was based, minutes too late. They found his food still warm on the table.\n\nSome plans were more elaborate. Inspired by the movie \u201cThe Manchurian Candidate,\u201d the Israelis spent three months in 1968 trying to transform a Palestinian prisoner into a programmed killer. Within five hours of being released to carry out his mission, he had turned himself in to the local police, handed over his pistol and explained that Israeli intelligence had tried to brainwash him into killing Arafat.\n\nThese and many other attempts not only failed and not only caused Israel much embarrassment; they also increased Arafat\u2019s popularity, as he told the tales of his miraculous escapes.\n\nBeyond securing the adoration of his own people, Arafat also began to make many powerful friends abroad. The East German leader Erich Honecker regarded him as a true revolutionary, like Fidel Castro, and his spies provided Palestinians with intelligence and weapons. At the same time, the C.I.A. had cultivated Arafat through a back channel, an effort with support at the highest levels. As the 1970s drew to a close, Arafat seemed untouchable. He was a de facto head of state with broad support. Openly assassinating such a man would break all of the norms of international relations. The Israelis looked on and ground their teeth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy 1979, Israel and the P.L.O. had settled into a rote and seemingly endless pattern of strikes and counterstrikes. And then a horrifying murder raised the tension even higher. On April 22, 1979, a terror squad from the Palestine Liberation Front, a P.L.O.-affiliated group, landed in a rubber dinghy on the beach at Nahariya, an Israeli city six miles south of the Lebanese border. One of its four members was Samir Kuntar, then 16 years old. After trying to break into a house and being frightened away by gunfire, and after killing a policeman who tried to arrest them, the men broke into a family\u2019s apartment and took Danny Haran, and his daughter Einat, 4, as hostages. They dragged them to the beach, where soldiers and police had already deployed, and a firefight ensued. Kuntar shot Danny, killing him, and then smashed Einat\u2019s head with the butt of his rifle until she was dead. Danny\u2019s wife, Smadar, hid in a crawl space in their apartment with their 2-year-old daughter, Yael. Smadar covered the toddler\u2019s mouth with her hand, to keep her from crying out and allowing the attackers to find them. In her panic, she smothered her child.\n\nIn the wake of the Nahariya atrocity, Raful Eitan, the I.D.F. general, gave the regional commander Avigdor Ben-Gal a simple order: \u201cKill them all,\u201d meaning all members of the P.L.O. and anyone connected to the organization in Lebanon. With Eitan\u2019s blessing, Ben-Gal appointed the man he considered the I.D.F.\u2019s top expert in special ops, Meir Dagan, to lead the efforts in south Lebanon. The three of them set up the Front for the Liberation of Lebanon From Foreigners. The operation ran almost entirely without the authorization or knowledge of the rest of the military, the defense ministry, the intelligence agencies or the government. (I did not speak with Eitan, who died in 2004, about any of these events.)\n\nBetween 1979 and early 1983, when it disbanded, the Front killed hundreds of people. David Agmon was head of the I.D.F.\u2019s Northern Command staff, one of the few who knew of Dagan\u2019s secret ops. \u201cThe aim,\u201d he said, \u201cwas to cause chaos among the Palestinians and Syrians in Lebanon, without leaving an Israeli fingerprint, to give them the feeling that they were constantly under attack and to instill them with a sense of insecurity.\u201d In order to do that, Dagan and his crew recruited Lebanese locals: Druze, Christians and Shiite Muslims who resented the Palestinians and wanted them out of Lebanon.\n\nOn Aug. 5, 1981, Prime Minister Menachem Begin appointed Ariel Sharon as defense minister of Israel. Begin, a hero of the underground movement in Israel\u2019s prestate era, had a deep admiration for the former general \u2014 \u201ca glorious commander of armies,\u201d he called him \u2014 but he was somewhat apprehensive about Sharon\u2019s unwillingness to accept the authority of his superiors. \u201cSharon is liable to attack the Knesset with tanks,\u201d one of Begin\u2019s deputies half-joked two years earlier.\n\nSharon quickly raised the stakes. He put a renewed focus on Arafat and gave the greenlight for Ben-Gal and Dagan to carry out an operation that, if it succeeded, would change the course of Middle East history. Operation Olympia called for Israeli agents to plant a massive set of bombs under a V.I.P. dais under construction in a Beirut stadium where, on Jan. 1, 1982, the P.L.O. was going to celebrate the anniversary of its first operation against Israel. With the push of one button, they would achieve the destruction of the entire Palestinian leadership.\n\nEverything was ready, including powerful explosive charges already secreted beneath the dais, as well as three vehicles loaded with explosives that were supposed to be parked on the streets around the stadium; these were to detonate about a minute after the dais exploded, when the panic was at its height and the survivors of the initial blast were trying to flee the scene. The resulting death and destruction were expected to be \u201cof unprecedented proportions, even in terms of Lebanon,\u201d in the words of a very senior officer of the Northern Command. But a group of worried AMAN officers, as well as the deputy defense minister, went to Begin and demanded that he order Dagan to call it off. \u201cYou can\u2019t just kill a whole stadium,\u201d one officer recalled telling Begin. \u201cThe whole world will be after us.\u201d Begin shut down the operation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy then, Sharon was at work on a far grander scheme. On June 6, the I.D.F. stormed across the border into Lebanon. An army of 76,000 troops, 800 tanks and 1,500 armored personnel carriers advanced northward and within two weeks had commenced a harrowing siege and bombardment of Beirut\u2019s western neighborhoods. Sharon presented the war as a limited incursion, aimed only at removing P.L.O. artillery that threatened Israelis, but he in fact had a far more radical vision: Israeli forces would conquer Lebanon and expel the Palestinians to Jordan, where they would be a majority able to establish a Palestinian state in place of the Hashemite Kingdom. This, Sharon reckoned, would eliminate the Palestinian demand for a state in the West Bank, which thus would become part of Israel. In that fantastical plan, there was one more critical element: killing Yasir Arafat. Sharon believed that in a war against a terrorist organization, symbols were as important as body counts.\n\nTo this end, a special task force was set up, code-named Salt Fish. Sharon appointed his two experts on special ops, Dagan and Rafi Eitan, who was then adviser to the defense minister on counterterror, to oversee it. \u201cI thought that hitting him would have changed the course of history,\u201d Dagan told me. \u201cArafat was not only a Palestinian leader, but a kind of founding father of the Palestinian nation. Killing him would unleash a large part of the internal conflicts inside the P.L.O. and significantly hinder its capability to make any strategic decisions from then on.\u201d\n\nLt. Col. Uzi Dayan, the outgoing chief of the Sayeret Matkal, the Israeli army\u2019s elite commando unit, took command of Salt Fish. AMAN hooked up to the telephone exchanges in Beirut and tried to trace Arafat\u2019s movements. The preferred method of attack would be an airstrike. \u201cIt was a very complicated mission,\u201d Dayan said. \u201cWe had to collate the information from the various sources, to understand which building or cave was the right one, to pinpoint it on the map, to narrow it down to the precise coordinates, to transmit them to the air force, giving them enough time to put a plane in the air and bomb it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nArafat understood that it was not a coincidence that bombs were repeatedly falling on places he was about to enter or had just left, and he kept breaking his routine. The team, growing desperate, came up with increasingly provocative schemes.\n\nOn July 3, 1982, Uri Avnery, a left-wing Israeli magazine editor, along with a reporter and photographer, crossed the front line in Beirut to interview Arafat in the heart of the city. The meeting was highly controversial in Israel. Arafat was seen as the country\u2019s worst enemy, and this was his first formal meeting with Israelis. The Salt Fish team decided to take advantage of the opportunity to let the three journalists unknowingly lead a group of assassins straight to Arafat. An argument broke out among the Salt Fish team members: Was it right to endanger, and probably kill, the Israeli citizens? The answer, they decided, was that it was. But Arafat suspected that Mossad might be keeping tabs on Avnery. His security guards took strict deceptive countermeasures, and the Salt Fish team lost their trail in the alleys of south Beirut.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the days went by, Sharon and Raful Eitan (the I.D.F. general) put increasing pressure on the air force and the Salt Fish teams to get Arafat. \u201cThe feeling was that it was something personal for Sharon,\u201d Ivry said. \u201cI thought that it was messy, with the danger of harming civilians.\u201d Uzi Dayan had the same misgivings. \u201cArafat was saved by two things,\u201d he said. \u201cHis interminable good luck and me.\u201d\n\nDayan thought Arafat was a legitimate target but not if it meant killing many civilians. \u201cRaful used to blow up with anger,\u201d Dayan continued. \u201cHe\u2019d call me up and say: \u2018I understand you have information on such and such a place. Why aren\u2019t the planes in the air?\u2019 I replied that it was impossible because there were a lot of people around. Raful said: \u2018Forget about it. I\u2019ll take responsibility for it.\u2019 I wasn\u2019t prepared to allow it. Raful would not teach me the ethics of war.\u201d\n\nEitan would remind Dayan that he did not have the authority to decide whether or not to drop a bomb. But Dayan nonetheless found a way to take a hand in the decision-making. \u201cAll I had to do was to report when the target was ripe from the intelligence point of view,\u201d he said. \u201cSo from that point on, each time we knew that bombing would lead to massive civilian casualties, we reported that the target wasn\u2019t ripe from the intelligence angle.\u201d\n\nPerhaps sensing this resistance, Eitan at one point decided to take more direct action. On the evening of Aug. 4, he asked the head of the air-force operations department, Aviem Sella, to come and see him. The two men had a close relationship, and Eitan had a soft spot for Sella, a promising officer considered a potential commander of the air force.\n\nEitan greeted Sella and told him that the next day he wouldn\u2019t be working in Canary as usual but would be \u201cgoing on a trip.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnything like our last trip together?\u201d asked Sella, alluding to a visit to Beirut in May, in preparation for the invasion and the operation to assassinate Arafat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSomething like it,\u201d Eitan replied. \u201cBut from above. Meet me tomorrow morning at Hatzor\u201d \u2014 an air force base to the south. \u201cYou\u2019ll fly the plane, and I\u2019ll navigate and operate the combat systems. We\u2019re going to bomb Beirut.\u201d\n\nSella was convinced he wasn\u2019t hearing right. \u201cIt was totally insane,\u201d he told me. \u201cI was in shock. If someone had told me that the chief of staff, who isn\u2019t really an airman, was taking the head of the air-force operations department for a break in the running of the war while they bombed Beirut, I would never have believed it.\u201d\n\nThe next day, the two met at Hatzor, climbed into an F-4 fighter jet and set out with three other planes on an expedition to bomb an office block in west Beirut, where, according to Salt Fish operatives, Arafat was supposed to be attending a meeting. \u201cRaful\u2019s functioning was so-so; I think he was feeling a little bit sick,\u201d Sella said. \u201cI did my own navigation. He operated the munitions systems, which by today\u2019s terms were rather primitive. We made two bombing runs over the target, and then another one to see if we\u2019d hit it. Raful was happy, and we flew home to Israel.\u201d Arafat was once again saved by timing: The bombs had fallen just before he arrived.\n\nSharon\u2019s intention to kill Arafat, however, never wavered. After the battles in Beirut were over and the P.L.O. leaders and their forces had been evacuated, Sharon and Eitan \u201cwere dying, simply dying, to kill him,\u201d said Amos Gilboa, who was then a brigadier general and the head of AMAN\u2019s Research Division. Sharon\u2019s team now realized, though, that an open assassination would only make Arafat a martyr. Undaunted, Sharon instructed the intelligence organizations to find a more subtle way to dispose of the P.L.O. leader. Operation Salt Fish morphed into Operation Goldfish. But the mission remained the same, and Sharon ordered that it be given top priority. Every day, the Goldfish team gathered in Gilboa\u2019s office. \u201cWe had a thousand matters that were a hundred times more important,\u201d Gilboa recalled. But Sharon insisted.\n\nEven the near disaster of October 1982 \u2014 coming within one jittery pilot\u2019s finger of murdering a flight crew, a doctor and 30 wounded children \u2014 did not weaken Sharon\u2019s hand or dissuade him from the idea of targeting Arafat in the air. In fact, he became even more reckless. When Mossad reported that Arafat was flying more commercial flights, with the P.L.O. often buying the entire first-class or business-class cabin for him and his aides, Sharon decided that such flights would be legitimate targets. The plane would have to be shot down over the open sea, far from the coast, so that it would take investigators a long time to find the wreckage and establish whether it had been hit by a missile or had crashed because of engine failure. Deep water would be preferable, to make recovery even more difficult. (Oded Shamir, Sharon\u2019s adjutant at the time, says that all the targeted planes were private aircraft. However, at least three officers present at these incidents have told me that some of the targets were commercial airliners.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe air force drew up a detailed plan. They found a spot over the Mediterranean where there was commercial air traffic but no continuous radar coverage by any nation and where the sea below was three miles deep, making a salvage operation extremely difficult, perhaps impossible. Executing the attack in this ideal spot, however, meant there would be a narrow window of opportunity.\n\nBecause the operation would take place far from Israeli airspace, beyond Israel\u2019s radar and radio range, the air force had to set up an airborne command post, in the form of a Boeing 707 fitted with radar and communications equipment. Sella would command the operation from this aircraft.\n\nUnder Sharon\u2019s direct orders, then, surveillance of Arafat was maintained continuously, and four F-16 and F-15 fighters were placed on interception alert. Over the course of nine weeks, from November 1982 to early January 1983, these planes scrambled at least five times to intercept and destroy airliners believed to be carrying Arafat, only to be called back soon after takeoff.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGilboa expressed his sharp opposition to these operations time and again. \u201cIt was clear to me that the air force would execute it as well as could be,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I had additional responsibility.\u201d It was Gilboa\u2019s job to evaluate the political, military and economic implications of each operation. \u201cI told chief of staff Eitan that it could ruin the state internationally if it were known that we downed a civilian airliner.\u201d\n\nIn each instance, air-force commanders intentionally obstructed the operation, refusing to obey orders that they believed to be manifestly illegal. \u201cWhen we received the order,\u201d Sella said, \u201cI went to see Eitan. I told him: \u2018Chief of staff, we do not intend to carry this out. It simply will not happen. I understand that the minister of defense is dominant here. No one dares to stand up to him, and therefore we will make it technically impossible.\u2019 Raful looked at me and never said anything. I took his silence as consent.\u201d\n\nIn one instance, with a commercial plane believed to be carrying Arafat from Amman to Tunisia over the Mediterranean, and the Israeli jets closing in, Eitan asked Gilboa if he thought their target was definitely on the plane. The two were standing in the central space inside Canary.\n\n\u201cChief of staff, do you really want to hear what I think?\u201d Gilboa asked. Eitan nodded.\n\nGilboa could feel his heart thumping in his chest. He stalled, elaborating all the many reasons for believing Arafat might be on the plane, then enumerating all the many reasons to doubt he was on the plane.\n\nEitan grew impatient. \u201cGilboa,\u201d he barked. \u201cYes or no?\u201d\n\n\u201cMy gut feeling,\u201d Gilboa said, \u201cis that he isn\u2019t on the plane.\u201d\n\nEitan turned around and went to the red secure phone at the side of the room. He told Sharon the operation would have to wait for another day.\n\nIn another instance, the radios on the flying command post, the air-force Boeing 707, were intentionally set to the wrong frequencies, blacking out communications long enough to make the whole operation impossible. In yet another, Sella simply misled Eitan, informing him that the target plane had been identified too late and there was a danger that the interception would be detected. On the remaining occasions, \u201cwe simply drew the time out until the plane had left the zones in which it would have been possible to hit them without discerning what had happened.\u201d\n\nIn the end, though, Sharon\u2019s plans for an intentional war crime were finally derailed by his own past unscrupulousness. Under intense pressure from the Israeli public and after heavy international criticism, Begin was compelled to establish a judicial inquiry into the massacre at the Beirut refugee camps. The commission determined that the Phalange militia was directly responsible for the massacre, but ruled that some Israelis, among them Sharon, had to be held accountable as well for permitting the Phalange to enter the camps when it was clear the organization would take the opportunity to commit atrocities. Sharon was forced to resign as defense minister. \u201cGradually,\u201d Gilboa said, \u201cthe awareness grew that Arafat was a political matter, and he must not be seen as a target for assassination.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSharon, of course, recovered from the blow, and in 2001 became Israel\u2019s prime minister. He came to a gradual understanding with the administration of George W. Bush under which the United States would support Israel even as it waged a massive campaign of targeted killings, the biggest in the country\u2019s history. In exchange, Sharon would cease settlement in the occupied Palestinian territories. And Arafat would be off limits.\n\nThe campaign seemed to work. Hamas sought a cease-fire and stopped dispatching suicide bombers. But Sharon, too, underwent a change, beginning for the first time to consider a political solution to the problem of the Palestinians. \u201cThe moment Sharon understood that the settlements are a burden and not an advantage,\u201d said Dov Weissglas, Sharon\u2019s chief of staff and close adviser, \u201che had no problem evacuating them and turning his back on the settlers.\u201d Sharon, the sworn hawk, \u201cwanted to exit the stage as a battle-worn general who became a great peacemaker.\u201d\n\nSharon had come to accept that there was no way to preclude the creation of an independent Palestinian state, but this didn\u2019t decrease his loathing for its leader. In Israel, a new round of discussions were held over how to deal with Arafat, and many suggestions were put forward: exile him to a desert island, put embarrassing videos of him on the internet, release the many documents seized from his office ordering the transfer of funds to terrorists. Some heads of the intelligence community and the army, as well as cabinet ministers, still thought that he should be killed.\n\nOn March 22, 2004, an Israeli helicopter gunship struck down Sheikh Ahmed Yassin on the streets of Gaza City. Yassin was a founder of the Hamas movement and, like Arafat, a political leader of world renown. On April 23, Sharon told an Israeli reporter that he was no longer bound by his 2001 agreement with Bush, saying \u201cthis commitment of mine no longer exists.\u201d Asked to clarify if he meant harming Arafat, he answered, \u201cI do not think this matter can be made any clearer.\u201d\n\nAnd then, suddenly, Arafat, the man who had managed to elude death so many times, succumbed to a mysterious infection that led to a stroke. He died on Nov. 11, 2004, at 75. To this day, an argument rages among forensic medicine experts and laboratory chiefs over the cause of death and whether traces of polonium, a radioactive material that has been used in assassinations, were or were not found on Arafat\u2019s clothes and remains. Israeli spokespersons categorically denied that Israel was in any way involved in Arafat\u2019s death.\n\nIn one of our last conversations before he succumbed to cancer in early 2016, Meir Dagan tried to explain why Sharon had spent so much of his life trying to kill Arafat, even as it became clear that killing him would do little to solve the larger problems that confronted his nation. \u201cSharon saw Arafat as a murderer, a Jew murderer,\u201d he said. \u201cSharon himself was quite a tough man, quite callous, and sometimes also quite a bastard. But he took to heart every casualty of every terror attack. There were some things that he simply could not let pass.\u201d", "title": "How Arafat Eluded Israel\u2019s Assassination Machine", "authors": ["Ronen Bergman"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Horoscopes have always been tailored to their audiences. Newspaper astrology columns used to offer different advice in papers catering to working- and middle-class readers, with middle-class horoscopes recommending spending more money, traveling more, and focusing more on their careers. (Both versions were feminized, encouraging readers to nurture others and avoid confrontation.) But these new online products advance the game by offering seemingly endless customizations. Co-Star bills itself as \u201chyper-personalized astrology,\u201d serving \u201calgorithmically-generated insights personalized to a degree unattainable elsewhere.\u201d Its name implies that every user has a supporting role in the drama of the universe. And it works off the user\u2019s natal chart, not their basic sign: When you sign up, you\u2019re prompted to plug in the date, time and place you were born. (If you don\u2019t know your exact time of birth, you\u2019re directed to \u201ctext your mom.\u201d) As The Daily Hunch puts it, \u201cYou\u2019re one in 7 billion \u2014 not one in 12.\u201d\n\nModern horoscope apps and columns are also fitted to satisfy up-to-the-minute psychological fixations. Co-Star has advised me to keep up my \u201crituals of self-care,\u201d while Lenny has warned that the pressures of \u201cthe internet and commerce and politics and fashion and relationships\u201d can \u201chave a blinding effect on our third eye.\u201d Other internet-savvy astrologers are explicitly branding their practices as tools of the #resistance, looking to planetary alignments to shed light on the machinations of the tax bill or Russian election meddling. And Ms. Nicholas has linked her astrology with other front-of-mind millennial preoccupations, like capitalism and the patriarchy.", "title": "How Astrology Took Over the Internet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "You are horrified and gather evidence to file a report. Then your boss finds out and reports you before you can bring it to a government watchdog, like the Inspector General of Intelligence and Security.\n\nUnder the proposed bills, rather than being protected from retaliation by your boss, you could be prosecuted and go to prison \u2014 just for handling the information.\n\n\u201cA person who prints, copies or makes notes from a document for one of these purposes, but has not yet or is prevented from, communicating the information to the IGIS would be exposed to criminal liability,\u201d according to a report by the Inspector General submitted to Parliament.\n\nThis would be the case even if the person who stopped you from filing a complaint was the individual you aimed to report for misconduct.\n\nThe result? Fewer disclosures of misconduct big and small, according to the Inspector General, the Commonwealth Ombudsman and legal scholars.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is worrying because we know a culture of secrecy does not produce good government,\u201d said Dr. Aruna Sathanapally, the director of the Sydney office of the Human Rights Law Center. \u201cAbuses of power hide in dark corners.\u201d\n\nIf you\u2019re a journalist \u2026\n\nNow, let\u2019s say you are a journalist. Maybe you meet a retired Australian Border Force officer who worked to turn boats of migrants back to Indonesia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou ask your source to describe his job and he sends you a photo from a day at work in 2013, showing him and a friend posing at sea with rusty fishing boats in the background. You write a story and include the photo.\n\nImmigration officials then tell you that the photo is classified, as it came from a government employee. Your source says it was classified only after he left the job.\n\nBut just having the image means you are already in trouble. Offenses tied to dealing with unauthorized government information carry a penalty of up to five years in prison \u2014 and that includes simply receiving it.\n\nEven though what you have is not as damaging to the government\u2019s image as, say, the Nauru files, which showed a pattern of abuse at Australia\u2019s offshore detention centers (and which would also probably be illegal under the bill\u2019s provisions), it does not matter.\n\nUnder the new espionage law, anything deemed classified by the government \u2014 even something as innocuous as a lunch menu \u2014 would be seen as \u201cinherently harmful information.\u201d\n\nYou can defend your actions by arguing your story is in the public interest, with \u201cfair and accurate reporting.\u201d But how that is defined is subjective and if you lose, you could face up to 15 years in prison.\n\n\u201cFor the first time the whole reporting process and everybody involved in it, from research to publication, is potentially criminalized,\u201d said Gaven Morris, news director for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the country\u2019s largest public broadcaster.\n\nIn short, news media companies told Parliament in a joint statement: \u201cThere is a real risk that journalists could go to jail for doing their jobs.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf you work in international trade \u2026\n\nWhen it comes to economic policy, conflicting data and analyses are common.\n\nBut if you are a government economist \u2014 or just work in international trade \u2014 the new espionage law has some provisions for you too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNational security under the bills would be extended to include economic relations \u2014 an expansion that set off alarm bells among some lawyers.\n\n\u201cThe breadth of the expression \u2018national security\u2019 extending to the country\u2019s political or economic relations with another country or countries may have a stifling effect on freedom of expression,\u201d wrote the Law Council of Australia, a national association of the country\u2019s attorneys.\n\nMore specifically, some legal experts asked, would internal opposition to trade deals favored by the government now amount to a breach of national security?\n\nIf you\u2019re a human-rights activist \u2026\n\nNow, let\u2019s say you work to advocate women\u2019s rights or human rights.\n\nYou often talk to government and private sector officials about your cause. You also talk to officials from other countries \u2014 those who share a passion for your issue or work in that field.\n\nSometimes, what one official tells you becomes part of a conversation with another official. But if the new espionage bills become law, notes or any other records of those conversations could be illegal.\n\nFor Ms. Pearson of Human Rights Watch, that means it becomes dangerous for her to talk to American or United Nations officials about what the Australian authorities might have told her about human rights in any given country, not just Australia.\n\nCasual conversation could become criminal if she or someone else dares to take notes about what was discussed, and if the government deems the information vital to its broadened definition of national interests.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Morris at the ABC said that the bills essentially threaten a wide swath of conversations and research involving dissenting or competing viewpoints.\n\n\u201cConsistently, we\u2019ve seen overreach where governments seek to suppress information because it is embarrassing, not because there is a genuine security risk,\u201d he said.\n\nMs. Pearson put it more directly. She said she would like to give Parliament a simple message: \u201cIf you pass this law you\u2019re basically taking away freedom from Australians, including the freedom of expression,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s completely ridiculous.\u201d", "title": "How Australia\u2019s Espionage Laws Could Silence Whistle-Blowers and Activists", "authors": ["Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The Republicans are counting on a favorable congressional map to help their majority ride out a possible \u201cwave\u201d election this November. But the congressional map got a little less favorable on Monday when the Pennsylvania Supreme Court struck down the state\u2019s Republican-drawn congressional map.\n\nIf the ruling holds \u2014 and it is expected to, because it\u2019s based on state law, not federal \u2014 this will be the fourth Republican gerrymander to be eroded by the courts since the 2014 midterm elections. It will probably cost the Republicans at least one seat in this year\u2019s midterms, while eroding their position in several others.\n\nPennsylvania has one of the harshest gerrymanders in the country. Republicans have held a 13-to-5 majority in the state\u2019s congressional delegation since the map took effect in 2012, even though the state is traditionally competitive in state and federal elections.\n\nIt\u2019s impossible to predict exactly what the new map will look like. The court ordered the Republican-controlled state legislature to produce a new map by Feb. 9. Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, will have a veto, and if a new map isn\u2019t approved by Feb. 15, the court will probably redraw the map itself. Neither outcome will necessarily yield an incumbent-blind nonpartisan map, like the kind that would be drawn by a commission in California or Arizona.", "title": "How Big a Deal Is a New Congressional Map for Pennsylvania?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "And then it all went to pieces. As manufactured pop groups tend to do. Only in this case, the split seemed sudden and surprisingly vicious: One day, Fifth Harmony was performing at the final stop of the Jingle Ball tour, smiling and hair-flipping. The next, a series of contentious and contradictory statements were released, and Ms. Cabello found herself on the lonely end of a sharp divide.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat was just over a year ago. In the interim, Ms. Cabello has struck out on her own, putting her hands on the controls of her professional life for the first time.\n\nHer new album, \u201cCamila,\u201d arriving Jan. 12, will test her prospects as a solo proposition. The biggest stars to break away from groups \u2014 Michael Jackson, Justin Timberlake, Beyonc\u00e9 \u2014 did so from stronger footing, in eras when the music industry was thriving. Today, Ms. Cabello is just one in a cacophony of voices aiming to break through in a harsh, post-streaming environment.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not easy for anybody, regardless of your starting point,\u201d said Tom Poleman, the chief programming officer for the radio conglomerate iHeartMedia, which recently booked Ms. Cabello solo for its Jingle Ball. \u201cThe field is so competitive that you really need the planets to align.\u201d\n\nAt times, sole proprietorship has been overwhelming, with people constantly asking Ms. Cabello for her creative input or asking what happened with Fifth Harmony \u2014 a subject she does her best to avoid. \u201cI think there\u2019s a healthy amount of space you need to give certain things,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd so for 11 days in late December, in the cocoon of her hometown, she took a break. She settled into old rhythms at her family home and came to Pinecrest to pick up her younger sister, Sofia, only after wresting herself from a savored \u201cSex and the City\u201d binge. (\u201cIn my heart I\u2019m a Carrie, but sadly I think I act like a Charlotte,\u201d she said.)\n\nOn a tour of its green, al fresco campus, wearing True Religion overalls with one suspender undone and black hightop Chuck Taylors, she looked at ease and made everyone around her feel the same. An old teacher asked whether she would be going on tour soon and she said she was in no rush. \u201cFor now,\u201d she said, \u201cI just want to be a kid.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Cabello comes from a lineage of strivers. She was born in Havana to a Cuban mother and Mexican father and moved back and forth between Coj\u00edmar and Mexico City until the age of 6. One day, her mother, Sinuhe, told her she was going to Disney World, and the two spent the next month together riding by bus to an immigration center at the Mexican border with the United States. Sinuhe had been an architect in Cuba, but in Miami, where she and her daughter moved in with a close family friend, she found work in the shoe department at a Marshall\u2019s.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlejandro, Ms. Cabello\u2019s father, emigrated later and earned money washing cars at the mall. Eventually the couple saved enough to start their own construction company.\n\n\u201cMy parents\u2019 story helps me to know what\u2019s important in life,\u201d Ms. Cabello said. \u201cA lot of times you can be here and be on Twitter and you think that the world is the internet. But I know what it\u2019s like in the places my family has come from and the struggles people go through.\u201d\n\nIt caught Sinuhe and Alejandro by surprise when, for her 15th birthday in 2012, Ms. Cabello asked them to drive her to audition for the second season of \u201cThe X Factor.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe was so shy, so shy,\u201d said Sinuhe, who now travels with her daughter on the road, describing how her oldest child would regularly burst into tears at family parties with large crowds and loud music. \u201cWe didn\u2019t even think music was a possibility for her,\u201d Sinuhe said.\n\nIn Fifth Harmony \u2014 with Ally Brooke, Dinah Jane, Lauren Jauregui and Normani Kordei \u2014 Ms. Cabello was living a dream. The group performed at the White House (twice) and released addictive hits like \u201cWorth It\u201d and \u201cWork From Home\u201d that alone racked up over one billion streams, according to Nielsen Music, and earned them legions of fiercely loyal fans.\n\nBut dreams can change. In a statement released at midnight on Dec. 18, 2016, the four other members of the group suggested that Ms. Cabello had turned her back on them, communicating her intentions to leave \u201cthrough her representatives.\u201d Ms. Cabello, in a subsequent statement of her own, said that she had long been open about her desire to explore a solo career and was blindsided by what amounted to a public excommunication.\n\nOver a feast of Cuban food at one of her family\u2019s favorite restaurants in Miami, and in a subsequent interview in New York a week later, she agreed to speak at length about how things fell apart.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe said that her collaboration in late 2015 with Mr. Mendes \u2014 the first time a Fifth Harmony member released music under her own name \u2014 had created tension; that she had asked to help write lyrics for Fifth Harmony songs and was rebuffed; that she initially wanted to stay in the group while working on a solo album but the other members shut her out instead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was just curious and I wanted to learn and I saw all these people around me making music, writing songs and being so free,\u201d she said. \u201cI just wanted to do that and it did not work.\u201d\n\nMs. Cabello said that after the awkwardness of her collaboration with Mr. Mendes, things further soured when she began attending writing sessions with producers including Diplo, Cashmere Cat and Benny Blanco. Eventually, she said, she was given an ultimatum.\n\n\u201cIt became clear that it was not possible to do solo stuff and be in the group at the same time,\u201d she said. So she made her choice, basing it on what she said was her conviction that \u201cif anyone wants to explore their individuality, it\u2019s not right for people to tell you no.\u201d\n\nSince the breakup, Ms. Cabello has tried to move on from hard feelings, throwing herself into \u201cCamila.\u201d (She changed its name from \u201cThe Hurting, the Healing, the Loving\u201d partly to wash her hands of drama.)\n\nBut it hasn\u2019t always been easy. In August last year, the remaining members took a less-than-subtle jab at their former groupmate with a stunt that opened a high-profile performance at the MTV Video Music Awards. As the camera zoomed in on a dark, elevated platform showing five women in silhouette, one was dramatically yanked off the stage as if hit by a truck.\n\nMs. Cabello\u2019s eyes welled up as she recalled watching it live. She had been at home in the living room with her mother. \u201cIt definitely hurt my feelings,\u201d she said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t expecting it, I wasn\u2019t prepared for it \u2014 especially because at that point I\u2019d moved on from it. I was just like, \u2018What? Why?\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe gathered herself. \u201cI have to make space for the good stuff to happen in my life,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t like holding onto the past, especially when it\u2019s stuff that, in my opinion, is just petty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike the pop astronauts who went solo before her, Ms. Cabello is now both a known quantity and a blank slate, caught between an outsize past and an uncertain future. Her first single as a solo artist was an early artifact of this wobbly developmental period.\n\n\u201cCrying in the Club\u201d \u2014 an arch, dancehall-flecked power ballad released last spring \u2014 was produced by Benny Blanco from an original demo written and recorded by Sia. The track underperformed commercially and was left off the final track list of \u201cCamila.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe reality of that song is it doesn\u2019t feel or sound like Camila,\u201d said Roger Gold, Ms. Cabello\u2019s manager and a former lawyer for Fifth Harmony. Mr. Gold said it took time for Ms. Cabello, free of the army of handlers and tacticians who maintained creative control of the girl group, to feel comfortable asserting herself in front of more seasoned collaborators. \u201cThe most important learning in this whole thing was that we were most successful when Camila trusted in her own instincts,\u201d he said.\n\nA breakthrough came while she was working with the producer Frank Dukes, born Adam Feeney, who has made his name as a prolific but low-key co-conspirator of self-styled stars like Drake and Lorde. Many potential collaborators had come to the studio armed with sleek, brassy Top 40 munitions in the style of Fifth Harmony hits. But Mr. Feeney\u2019s approach was more nonchalant.\n\nOver sushi during an early session with Ms. Cabello last winter, he played her a deceptively simple instrumental with a prominent salsa piano riff. It reminded the singer of her birthplace, and she wrote the chorus for what became \u201cHavana\u201d on the spot.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not another artist in the world who could have done that song \u2014 she just owns it,\u201d Mr. Feeney said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany of the songs on \u201cCamila,\u201d which Mr. Feeney executive produced and includes writing by Ms. Cabello on every track, are infused with tonal or lyrical references to her Latin heritage. Ms. Cabello said she took inspiration from the Latin music that soundtracked her childhood, as well as more contemporary reggaeton revisionists like Calle 13 and J Balvin. Then she blended those sounds with the auteur pop of artists like her friends Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran, hoping to unearth her own original recipe.\n\n\u201cI feel like the best way to come up with something new and different is just to be the you-est you possible,\u201d Ms. Cabello said. \u201cIf you pull from all the different little parts of yourself, nobody can replicate that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Poleman, of iHeartMedia, said it is Ms. Cabello\u2019s sensibilities as a songwriter that will define her career. With \u201cHavana\u201d and \u201cBad Things,\u201d he said, \u201cshe has quickly established herself as one of the most important young artists in pop music.\n\n\u201cIt always comes down to whether or not you have a song that resonates,\u201d he added. \u201cI know she spends a lot of time thinking about that.\u201d\n\nIn an under-lit, overpriced restaurant in Midtown Manhattan after her break in Miami had ended, Ms. Cabello, who has lately imagined herself as a vegan, provoked a kale salad while bopping along to Michael Jackson\u2019s \u201cThe Way You Make Me Feel.\u201d The song had been a highlight from a recent Christmas Eve karaoke night with her family (she was the only one who knew its final \u201cGive it to me\u201d pre-chorus), and she grieved for her cocoon.\n\nIn 48 hours, she would perform before Mariah Carey at \u201cDick Clark\u2019s New Year\u2019s Rockin\u2019 Eve With Ryan Seacrest\u201d in a bejeweled, ankle-length coat and metallic jumpsuit that made her look like a glamorous conquistador. Then she had a tour to design, and music video concepts to finalize and a social media campaign to figure out.\n\nShe started to explain why things were trickier now, how she no longer had anyone to pick up the slack.\n\n\u201cEven when there\u2019s a day off, there\u2019s never really a day off, because there\u2019s so many decisions to be made and you\u2019re always rushing to make stuff,\u201d she said, as Jackson ad-libbed in the background. The music kept making her lose her train of thought. Finally, after a few vain attempts to catch it, she gave in and stopped explaining herself and sang along.", "title": "How Camila Cabello Lost Some Friends and Found Her Voice", "authors": ["Reggie Ugwu"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "When Volkswagen developed a smallish S.U.V. to meet the segment\u2019s growing demand, it faced a challenge: The truck had no name.\n\nA car\u2019s name is crucial \u2014 it defines the car and can provoke an emotional response among consumers. It will be front and center on TV ads and billboards. Above all, a car\u2019s name is brand equity, its very identity. A Mustang is a Mustang, with or without \u201cFord\u201d in front of it. A Cherokee is a Cherokee, even if it\u2019s always a Jeep.\n\nVW sought the public\u2019s input \u2014 a tricky proposition. Its unorthodox approach included a poll, which produced a stunning response. About 350,000 readers of the German magazine Auto Bild cast votes. Among the names on the ballot: Namib, Rockton, Samun and Nanuk.\n\nThe winner was Tiguan, a m\u00e9lange of \u201ctiger\u201d and \u201ciguana.\u201d\n\nSexy? Perhaps not. But it stuck, and the Tiguan has stuck around. The Tiguan, which first went into production in 2007, has earned a redesign for 2018. And when a model doesn\u2019t quite meet expectations, its replacement in the lineup often gets a new moniker: The Tiguan\u2019s bigger, older sibling \u2014 the Touareg \u2014 has been replaced in the United States by the new Atlas.", "title": "How Car Companies Decide You\u2019ll Ride a Mustang or Catch a Tiguan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The system included seven schools with more than 2,000 pupils, cadres and teachers. Many of the pupils were children of cadres and party members killed during the wars against the French and the Americans. Pupils were brought from different areas of Vietnam, from the South as well as from the North. They reportedly represented around 30 nationalities, although the nationalities were not specified. They arrived at different times, they had different levels of education and they were different ages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe program had its shortcomings, though. The schools were concentrated on a limited piece of land (less than a square kilometer) that lacked sufficient classroom space, as well as sufficient space for housing, outside activities, production or social activities. Moreover, despite their political pedigrees, the students came with a frustratingly broad range of political convictions. One group followed the Hanoi line. This group was \u201cin the care of the Party and of Uncle and that\u2019s why they had hatred toward the Americans and their lackeys\u201d \u2014 in other words, South Vietnamese anti-communists \u2014 \u201cwho sell the country.\u201d Pupils in this group were \u201cconnected to socialism, felt absolute trust in Uncle Ho, and in the Workers Party of Vietnam.\u201d On the other side of the spectrum, there were pupils who had experienced, in one report, the \u201cputrid American influence\u201d and who lacked discipline, a sense of national identity and love for the nation.\n\nIn addition to these difficulties, there was a shortage of teachers, and those who were there, according to an assessment by the North Vietnamese Ministry of Education, had very low educational levels. Many teachers wanted to return home. Many of them did not have revolutionary morale and thus made serious mistakes, such as illicit liaisons among male and female cadres and violations of the principles of socialist education, like hitting or harshly disciplining students.\n\nAdministrators were a problem, too. Many of them were still \u201cunder the old conventions and backward concepts,\u201d according to one analysis, that superseded revolutionary notions of friendship, love and service. Their bad attitudes, according to the Ministry of Education, prevailed over their commitments to the party and its youth organizations. Material problems aggravated ideological difficulties. Living quarters were overcrowded and did not meet hygienic requirements. Classrooms were not sufficiently equipped. Sometimes children of very different ages had to study together. Teaching materials arrived slowly.\n\nChina had three main considerations in hosting an extension of the Vietnamese educational system. First was solidarity with a prot\u00e9g\u00e9. That feeling arose from the close alliance between the Chinese and Vietnamese communists during the war against France, when the Chinese provided the means for continuing the war and the Vietnamese responded with gratitude and emulation. Chinese communists saw the achievements of the Vietnamese communists as an extension of their own revolutionary agenda.\n\nSecond was competition with the Soviet Union for leadership of the international communist movement and for influence in what were then called \u201cthird world\u201d countries, which included Vietnam. The Sino-Soviet competition developed in the late 1950s and continued through the 1960s. Giving their Vietnamese allies a safe haven for schools just across the border was something that the Soviet Union was not in a position to provide to the Vietnamese, and this created a venue for nurturing both practical assistance and a spirit of sympathetic patronage.\n\nFinally, the program offered an opportunity to support a war that kept the United States militarily occupied beyond China\u2019s borders \u2014 rendering America less of a threat to China itself.\n\nDespite its difficulties, the system persevered until mid-1975, when it was terminated and all students, teachers and administrators returned to Vietnam. By 1975, North Vietnam was on the verge of conquering the south, and the need for educational facilities that were out of harm\u2019s way was lessening. But Sino-Vietnamese relations were souring as well. Hanoi\u2019s final push toward Saigon was fueled by Soviet assistance, and the consolidation of communist rule across Vietnam turned an ally of China into a threat. While it is possible that when Vietnam and China went to war in 1978 there were some Vietnamese soldiers who had once studied on Chinese soil, there are nevertheless many who continue to cherish their study years in China.", "title": "How China Used Schools to Win Over Hanoi", "authors": ["Olga Dror"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "During the eight years I lived in China, people would often say they felt as if they had no voice under Communist Party rule. This was especially true for minorities.\n\nSo when Tashi Wangchuk, a Tibetan herder turned shopkeeper, showed up at my apartment in Beijing in the spring of 2015, I of course wanted to listen to his story.\n\nHe told me the Chinese authorities on the Tibetan Plateau had been slowly eradicating the Tibetan language from schools and the business world. Mr. Tashi believed prohibiting the study of the Tibetan language went against China\u2019s constitution.\n\nThe New York Times was not Mr. Tashi\u2019s first stop in his attempt to raise this issue, I learned. Chinese state-controlled media had refused to listen to him. And years earlier, the Chinese authorities had briefly jailed him for expressing his opinions on social media. Foreign media were his last resort to be heard.", "title": "How China Used a Times Documentary as Evidence Against Its Subject", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Chris Cuomo, 47, is a host of CNN\u2019s morning show \u201cNew Day,\u201d which means he is up before sunrise. Born in Queens and based in Southampton, Mr. Cuomo balances a tough schedule among work, life and parenting. (He and his wife, Cristina Cuomo, have three children, who are 7, 11 and 14.) He is also a fitness buff, though he does not believe in bodybuilding. Here\u2019s how he stays in shape and uses motivational books and podcasts to help him get through the daily grind.\n\nWake-Up Tactics\n\nI wake up sometime between 3:30 and 4:30 a.m. depending on what I can tolerate. What I have to do is I have to pivot sideways and fall onto the floor, then I can look at my phone from there. Otherwise, the light of the phone will wake up my wife, Cristina, and whatever child is in our bed. I look to see if the world has changed in the five hours I slept.\n\nGrooming Regimen\n\nThe main objective is to be clean. I only use baby soap, even in my hair, because I have allergies. Also, my wife is into wellness and is not into chemicals. I used to like Old Spice body wash but my wife and 14-year-old found it repulsive.", "title": "How Chris Cuomo Looks Buff Without Bodybuilding", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "By the summer of 1968, major antiwar organizations took notice of the controversy the UFO was stirring up in Columbia and initiated a \u201cSummer of Support\u201d to organize funds for more coffeehouse projects around the country. In ensuing years, more than 25 \u201cG.I. coffeehouses\u201d opened up near military bases in the United States and at a number of bases overseas.\n\nOver the course of six years, the coffeehouse network would play a central role in some of the G.I. movement\u2019s most significant actions. At the Oleo Strut coffeehouse in Killeen, Tex., local staff and G.I.s mobilized to support the Fort Hood 43 \u2014 a large group of black soldiers who were arrested at a meeting to discuss their refusal to deploy for riot control duty at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. A black veteran present at the meeting described its mood: \u201cA lot of black G.I.s knew what the thing was going to be about and they weren\u2019t going to go and fight their own people.\u201d Army authorities were caught off guard by the publicity the coffeehouse brought to the case, and began to examine their strategies for dealing with political expression among the ranks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen eight black G.I.s, each of them leaders of the group G.I.s United Against the War in Vietnam, were arrested in 1969 for holding an illegal demonstration at Fort Jackson, the UFO coffeehouse served as a local operations center, drumming up funds for lawyers and promoting the \u201cFort Jackson Eight\u201d story to the national media. After G.I. and civilian activists created intense public pressure, officials quietly dropped all charges, signaling a shift in how the military would respond to soldiers expressing dissent.\n\nDuring its brief lifetime, the G.I. coffeehouse network was subjected to attacks from all sides \u2014 investigated by the F.B.I. and congressional committees, infiltrated by law enforcement, harassed by military authorities and, in a number of startling cases, terrorized by local vigilantes. In 1970, at the Fort Dix coffeehouse project in Wrightstown, N.J., G.I.s and civilians were celebrating Valentine\u2019s Day when a live grenade flew in through an open door; it exploded, seriously injuring two Fort Dix soldiers and a civilian. Another popular coffeehouse, the Covered Wagon in Mountain Home, Idaho (near a major Air Force base), was a frequent target of harassment by outraged locals, who finally burned it to the ground.\n\nThough their numbers dwindled as the war drew to a close in the mid-1970s, G.I. coffeehouses left an indelible mark on the Vietnam era. While popular mythology often places the antiwar movement at odds with American troops, the history of G.I. coffeehouses, and the G.I. movement of which they were a part, paints a very different picture. Over the course of the war, thousands of military service members from every branch \u2014 active-duty G.I.s, veterans, nurses and even officers \u2014 expressed their opposition to American policy in Vietnam. They joined forces with civilian antiwar organizations that, particularly after 1968, focused significant energy and resources on developing social and political bonds with American service members. Hoping to build the resistance that was already taking shape in the Army, activists at G.I. coffeehouses worked directly with service members on hundreds of political projects and demonstrations, despite relentless government surveillance, infiltration and harassment.\n\nThe unprecedented eruption of resistance and activism by American troops is critical to understanding the history of the Vietnam War. The G.I. movement and related phenomenon created a significant crisis for the American military, which feared exactly the kind of alliance between civilians and soldiers that Fred Gardner had in mind when he opened the first G.I. coffeehouse in 1968. Despite the extraordinary political and cultural impact that dissenting soldiers made throughout the Vietnam era, their voices have been nearly erased from history, replaced by a stereotypical image of loyal, patriotic soldiers antagonized and spat upon by ungrateful antiwar activists. In the decades since the war\u2019s end, countless Hollywood movies, books, political speeches and celebrated documentaries have repeated this image, obscuring the war\u2019s deep unpopularity among the ranks and the countless ways that American troops expressed their opposition.\n\nThis historical erasure serves a distinct purpose, casting dissent \u2014 from wearing an antiwar T-shirt to kneeling during the national anthem \u2014 as inherently disrespectful, even abusive, to American soldiers. A fuller reckoning with the era\u2019s history would begin by acknowledging the countless G.I.s and civilians who stood together against the war. G.I. coffeehouses are a vital window onto this history, showing us places where men and women came together to share their common revulsion at the war in Vietnam, and to begin organizing a collective effort to make it stop.", "title": "How Coffeehouses Fueled the Vietnam Peace Movement", "authors": ["David L.
