Even Trump\u2019s recent \u201cwhat, me, racist?\u201d tweet noting an all-time-low in the black unemployment rate was not wrong: These are the best economic times for African-Americans in a decade.\n\nBut there is strong evidence that our problems with sex and gender and male-female relations are worsening \u2014 which is why it\u2019s understandable that they\u2019re at the heart of how the country has reacted to the Trump presidency, and fitting that this year of public protests and intimate revelations have thrown them into sharp relief.", "title": "Opinion | How Sex Trumped Race", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "How is technology affecting the publishing industry?\n\nAbout a decade ago, when Amazon introduced its first e-reader, publishers panicked that digital books would take over the industry, the way digital transformed the music industry. And for a while, that fear seemed totally justified. At one point, the growth trajectory for e-books was more than 1,200 percent. Bookstores suffered, and print sales lagged. E-books also made self-publishing easier, which threatened traditional publishers.\n\nBut in just the last couple of years, there has been a surprising reversal. Print is holding steady \u2014 even increasing \u2014 and e-book sales have slipped.\n\nOne possible reason is that e-book prices have gone up, so in some cases they\u2019re more expensive than a paperback edition. Another possibility is digital fatigue. People spend so much time in front of screens that when they read they want to be offline. Another theory is that some e-book readers have switched to audiobooks, which are easy to play on your smartphone while you\u2019re multitasking. And audiobooks have become the fastest-growing format in the industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nSocial media has also had an enormous impact on publishing, as it has on all corners of the media industry. It has definitely become a new way for readers to connect with authors and discover books, but it has probably also cut into the time that people spend reading. (A depressing article in Quartz estimated that if people spent the same amount of time reading that they did on social media, they could read 200 books a year easily.)\n\nMany new authors are skipping traditional publishers and use tech tools to go straight to self-publishing their own e-books or print books. What will be the fate of traditional publishers in the next few years?\n\nSelf-publishing has been one of the most fascinating corners of the industry to me. There have been a handful of massively successful self-published authors who have started their own publishing companies, and they\u2019ve started to publish other \u201cself-published\u201d authors. But publishers have survived so far through consolidation, and we\u2019ll probably see more of that.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat will be the fate of physical bookstores? And what do you think about Amazon\u2019s bookstores?\n\nIndie bookstores have made a surprising comeback in recent years (a trend that might be connected to the resurgence of print books). A lot of independent stores have been so successful that they\u2019ve expanded into mini-chains.\n\nThe future of Barnes & Noble looks uncertain, and the company has suffered setbacks after a few disastrous strategies. It made a huge and, in retrospect, unwise investment in digital hardware and its Nook device, and then tried to become more of a general-interest gift and toy and books store, which probably alienated some of its core customers. Lately, it has tried smaller concept stores, with cafes with food and wine and beer. There was some snickering online after its new chief executive announced that its latest strategy was to focus on selling \u2026 books. Snickering aside, I think it\u2019s the smartest thing the company can do. In many parts of the country, Barnes & Noble is the only place people can buy books, and it\u2019s still a beloved brand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmazon\u2019s entry into the physical retail space has been fascinating. I\u2019m not sure how successful the experiment has been. When I visited the Amazon bookstore at New York\u2019s Columbus Circle, it definitely felt like a device store that also sold books. The store even looks like a 3-D version of the website, with book covers facing out and curated sections that reflect what\u2019s popular with Amazon\u2019s customers. But they\u2019re expanding rapidly across the country, so something must be working.\n\nI\u2019ll be curious to see how Indigo Books, the Canadian chain, will do here next year when it expands into the United States. Maybe it will shake up the model.\n\nOutside your job, what tech product are you currently obsessed with?\n\nI am, my family would confirm, not great with gadgets. It would be fair to say that I\u2019m actively bad with them. I\u2019m wary of some of the new home assistants like Amazon\u2019s Echo and Google Home, not necessarily because I\u2019m paranoid about my conversations being recorded \u2014 Amazon and Google already know everything about me \u2014 but because my kids would likely be yelling at the devices all the time, and the Taylor Swift and Ariana Grande songs would play in an endless loop.\n\nI have become a podcast junkie. I found The Daily to be habit forming. My other go-tos are Planet Money (disclosure: my husband is a reporter there), The New York Times Book Review podcast (where I sometimes appear), Longform, the New Yorker Radio Hour and some of the shows from Gimlet Media, like StartUp and Reply All. (Heavyweight, Jonathan Goldstein\u2019s show, is hilarious and engrossing.)\n\nWhat tech is popular with your family?\n\nThe one app that\u2019s popular with the whole family is this Japanese game Neko Atsume: Kitty Collector. You buy virtual presents for these cartoon cats, which come and go as they please, and the cats leave you fish. You can\u2019t really control the cats or win in any way. Just like with real cats, I suppose.", "title": "How Technology Is (and Isn\u2019t) Changing Our Reading Habits", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "When President Trump addresses Congress in his first State of the Union speech on Tuesday, he will be able to plausibly claim that the first year of his presidency represented one of the most successful years for conservative domestic policy goals since the end of the Cold War. But to succeed in 2018 and beyond, the president should chart a course that returns to his roots in the 2016 campaign and breaks with the surprisingly conventional Republican nature of his policies. He has a golden opportunity to do so in the State of the Union by making a strong case for a policy few Republicans will even address publicly: paid family leave.\n\nDuring the campaign, it became clear that a major part of Mr. Trump\u2019s appeal was that he frequently broke with Republican orthodoxies on a host of issues, including foreign policy, trade, entitlements, health care and, to some degree, immigration. His unorthodoxy proved to be an asset for his campaign and is among the reasons exit polls indicated he prevailed over Hillary Clinton among independent voters.\n\nYet these same independents are by and large the supporters Mr. Trump has lost over the past year. Much of this is no doubt due to the tenor of this presidency and the daily barrage of tweets, leaks, investigations and general partisanship that is the hallmark of Washington these days. But his loss of support among independents may also be partly because his presidency has turned out to be much more generically Republican than what many anticipated.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s tax cut bill, his repeal of the individual health insurance mandate, withdrawal from the Paris climate accord and rollbacks of regulations have extended Republican priorities or undone policies enacted under President Barack Obama. Republicans have every reason to be happy with the results, but Mr. Trump has yet to entertain policies no other Republican would consider \u2014 as he had once promised to do.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump Can Be More Trumpian", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nOn the day that Donald Trump was inaugurated president almost a year ago, a Chinese military leader named Jin Yinan gave a speech to top Communist Party officials in China. \u201cWe repeatedly state that Trump \u2018harms China,\u2019\u201d Jin said. \u201cIn fact, he has given China a huge gift.\u201d\n\nThat gift, Jin explained, was Trump\u2019s planned pullout from the trans-Pacific Partnership, which formally happened three days after Jin\u2019s speech, on Jan. 23. The partnership was a trade deal in which the United States and Pacific countries like Australia, Malaysia and Vietnam had banded together to check the economic rise of China. The likely economic effects of the pact were the subject of intense debate in this country, on both the right and left. In reality, though, the economic effects would never have been as large as either the deal\u2019s boosters or critics argued.\n\nInstead, the most important effect of the deal was geopolitical. The deal was, as the Australian academic Salvatore Babones has said, \u201cprimarily a tool for spreading U.S. interests abroad.\u201d Above all, the deal was a response to China\u2019s new global assertiveness.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump Is Helping China", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "A short time later, Mr. Schumer called the president, the person said, but the conversation drove the pair even further apart. The immigration concessions from Democrats were not conservative enough, Mr. Trump told Mr. Schumer. The president said he needed more border security measures as well as more enforcement of illegal immigration in parts of the country far from the border.\n\nAs the evening wore on, Mr. Schumer got a call from Mr. Kelly that dashed all hopes for a Trump-Schumer deal before the shutdown deadline of midnight. Mr. Kelly, a hard-liner on immigration, the person familiar with the call said, outlined a long list of White House objections to the deal.\n\nA White House official familiar with the call said Mr. Kelly urged Mr. Schumer to work out the details of an agreement with Mr. McConnell.\n\nIn a Twitter post at 9:28 p.m., Mr. Trump vented his pessimism on Twitter, returning to his administration\u2019s efforts to try to make sure that Democrats receive the blame from voters angry about a government shutdown exactly one year from his inauguration.\n\n\u201cNot looking good for our great Military or Safety & Security on the very dangerous Southern Border,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cDems want a Shutdown in order to help diminish the great success of the Tax Cuts, and what they are doing for our booming economy.\u201d\n\nWith talks between Mr. Trump and Mr. Schumer over, Republicans in the Senate scheduled a vote on a House-passed measure that leaders in both parties expected to fail. After the shutdown began, Mr. Schumer lamented the failure to reach a deal with the president, and blamed Mr. Trump for abandoning an agreement that was within reach.\n\n\u201cWhat happened to the President Trump who asked us to come up with a deal and promised to take the heat for it?\u201d Mr. Schumer asked on the Senate floor. \u201cWhat happened to that President Trump?\u201d", "title": "How Trump and Schumer Came Close to a Deal Over Cheeseburgers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "And yet it\u2019s precisely when he is trying to act like a normal president that he is least effective. Remember: The circus is his friend.\n\nJust consider the past six weeks. They\u2019ve included Stormy Daniels, his vulgar rant about Haitians, his much-mocked physical exam and the many stories spawned by Michael Wolff\u2019s book, \u201cFire and Fury.\u201d You know what else has happened in the last six weeks? Trump\u2019s approval rating has risen a couple of percentage points, as have the share of voters saying they plan to vote for a Republican congressional candidate this year.\n\nNot all of Trump\u2019s outrages can or should be ignored. His lies need to be fact-checked. His racism needs to be called out. Most important, his attempts to obstruct justice need to be stopped, not encouraged, by Congress. But people who are disturbed by his presidency should keep reminding themselves of the big goal here: persuading Trump supporters and Trump agnostics that his presidency is damaging the country.\n\nThe trouble with constantly disparaging him \u2014 as a person and as the Worst President Ever \u2014 is that it doesn\u2019t win over very many Americans. Hillary Clinton\u2019s campaign took a version of this approach in many television ads, and it wasn\u2019t a crazy strategy at the time, given how unpresidential Trump was and is. But given the campaign\u2019s outcome, the strategy doesn\u2019t seem worth rerunning.\n\nLuigi Zingales of the University of Chicago has written what I think remains the smartest essay on this point. In an Op-Ed published shortly after the election, he explained that Trump fit a global pattern. Demagogues like him \u2014 and like Silvio Berlusconi of Italy \u2014 rise to power because people feel alienated. The demagogues are often odious. But when the opposition focuses on their outrageous qualities, it usually loses.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump\u2019s Critics Should Respond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The $1.5 trillion tax cut signed by Mr. Trump in December is his first major legislative achievement in office. But he is wrong to characterize it \u2014 as he has done at least four times this year \u2014 as the largest in history (at least three are bigger) or the first since President Ronald Reagan\u2019s 1981 tax cut (most presidents since Reagan have cut taxes).\n\nThe \u2018Trump bump\u2019 in the economy\n\nMr. Trump is likely to boast about a roaring American economy and healthy job growth, though his claims should be viewed in context.\n\nHe has, for example, boasted at least seven times in the past two weeks that the black unemployment rate, 6.8 percent in December, is the lowest ever recorded. While true, it is the culmination of a longer-term trend. It is also an open question how much credit a president, especially in his first year, can take for the economy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe same can be said of Mr. Trump\u2019s repeated claim that nearly 2.4 million jobs have been added since his election in November 2016. The number is accurate, but appears less groundbreaking with the appropriate context: More jobs were added in the 14 months before his election than in the 14 months since.\n\nMr. Trump has also misrepresented the tax cut\u2019s effect on the decisions of American businesses.\n\nContrary to his claims that Chrysler is \u201cleaving Mexico and coming back to the United States,\u201d the automaker continues to operate several plants in Mexico even as it shifts production of some pickup trucks to Michigan. Similarly, he has trumpeted Apple\u2019s announcement of a $350 billion, five-year investment as a boon for manufacturing, but the company was already on track to spend $275 billion over the next five years.\n\nInternational deals\n\nMr. Trump often talks up his deal-making prowess. But he has taken credit for agreements that were drawn up before he was involved or relies on fuzzy math to promote the most impressive dollar figure possible.\n\nMr. Trump claimed to have signed $250 billion worth of deals with China, Japan and South Korea in November and $350 billion of deals in Saudi Arabia that would add \u201chundreds of thousands of jobs\u201d in June. Both packages include plans made before his trips and rely on verbal agreements.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has also made inaccurate statements about international deals he dislikes.\n\nAs his trade team negotiates revamping the terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Trump has erroneously said the United States has a trade deficit with Canada, when it actually has a surplus. He has also exaggerated the trade deficit totals with China and Mexico.\n\nMr. Trump mischarachterized the Iran nuclear deal, alleging that Mr. Obama \u201cso foolishly gave\u201d gave money to the Islamic republic\u2019s leaders to fund terrorism. The diplomatic agreement did not cut Iran a check, but it did release about $100 billion in previously Iranian frozen assets, much of which is tied up in debt obligations.\n\nThe immigration debate\n\nIn pushing Congress to approve a new immigration policy, Mr. Trump has made several erroneous statements.\n\nHe has falsely accused other countries of \u201csending their worst\u201d through the diversity visa lottery. Applicants enter of their own volition and are denied a visa if they have a criminal record or would rely on public assistance.\n\nHis repeated claim that Sayfullo Saipov, the suspect in the Manhattan truck attack, brought in dozens of relatives through what he calls \u201cchain migration,\u201d or family-based immigration, is implausible. As a green card holder, Mr. Saipov is not allowed to sponsor extended family.\n\nFinally, Mr. Trump is right that illegal border crossings \u201care way, way down\u201d under his watch, but he has exaggerated the extent of that decline.", "title": "How Truthful Was Trump in His First Year? Before His State of the Union, What Our Fact Checks Show", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Tagovailoa met Mariota, then a Saint Louis star, at a passing camp. Only 9, Tagovailoa had barged his way into a passing camp intended for high school quarterbacks, but much as he did on Monday, he performed so well that the older boys, especially Mariota, let him stick around.\n\nTagovailoa eventually followed Mariota at Saint Louis, and still considers him a role model for Polynesian children.\n\n\u201cHe is very big for our state,\u201d Tagovailoa said. \u201cFor kids back home, making our state proud is the biggest thing, and to be able to do this on a national level, on a big stage, is just a great opportunity.\u201d\n\nTagovailoa demonstrated his self-confidence simply by enrolling at Alabama, where Hurts, a sophomore, was firmly established as the starter. While Tua\u2019s parents came to Alabama with him to ease his transition to college, he said early Tuesday that he still feels homesick at times.\n\n\u201cThe biggest difference from Hawaii and Alabama would probably be there\u2019s no beaches,\u201d he said, presumably referring only to the Tuscaloosa campus. \u201cBut other than that, the people are very nice.\u201d\n\nReligion, Tagovailoa said, is an important aspect of his life, and he added that faith contributes to the remarkably calm demeanor he displayed in the hectic final moments of Monday\u2019s game. He prays before every drive begins, asking for inner peace.\n\nYet as good as he was Monday, Tagovailoa was not perfect. At times he still had the markings of a freshman: he threw an interception in the third quarter when all his receivers, expecting a run, were downfield blocking, and he almost fouled up the last few seconds of regulation, forcing Saban to put Hurts back in to manage the clock.", "title": "How Tua Tagovailoa Stepped Up, Dropped Back, and Saved Alabama", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The C.I.A. and other American intelligence services had predicted this moment would come, eventually. For decades, they accurately projected the broad trajectory of North Korea\u2019s nuclear program. Yet their inability to foresee the North\u2019s rapid strides over the past several months now ranks among America\u2019s most significant intelligence failures, current and former officials said in recent interviews.\n\nThat disconnect \u2014 they saw it coming, but got the timing wrong \u2014 helps explain the confusion, mixed signals and alarm that have defined how Mr. Trump\u2019s untested national security team has responded to the nuclear crisis.\n\nIn an interview, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser, acknowledged that Mr. Kim\u2019s race to the finish line \u2014 a bid to establish the North as a nuclear power before any negotiations begin or sanctions take a more punishing toll \u2014 \u201chas been quicker and the timeline is a lot more compressed than most people believed.\u201d\n\nAs a result, he argued, \u201cwe have to do everything we are doing with a greater degree of urgency, and we have to accelerate our own efforts to resolve the issue short of conflict.\u201d\n\nSenior intelligence officials said they began investing more heavily in acquiring information on North Korea\u2019s weapons program in 2012, reaping benefits over the past two years. But they acknowledged they made two key assumptions that proved wrong.\n\nThey assumed that North Korea would need about as much time to solve the rocket science as other nations did during the Cold War, underestimating its access to both advanced computer modeling and foreign expertise. They also misjudged Mr. Kim, 33, who took control of the dynastic regime in late 2011 and made the weapons program more of a priority than his father or grandfather did.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Obama warned Mr. Trump during the transition a year ago that North Korea would pose the most urgent national security threat, and almost immediately the newly installed president began repeating, publicly and privately, that he inherited \u201ca mess\u201d in North Korea because his predecessors did not do enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFormer officials in the Obama administration dispute that. But some concede that the intelligence community\u2019s flawed assessment of the North\u2019s progress meant there was less pressure to bolster missile defenses, more vigorously enforce sanctions or consider stepped-up covert action.\n\nIt is not clear that even with more advanced warning the Obama or Trump administrations would have been able to slow Mr. Kim\u2019s progress.\n\nOver many years, the North Koreans have outmaneuvered several American presidents \u2014 Republicans and Democrats alike \u2014 with technological advances that seemed highly threatening but not worth the risk of a war that could kill millions in South Korea and Japan. A beefed-up military presence off the North Korean coast, cyberattacks, sabotage of imported parts and simulated bombing runs may have slowed but ultimately failed to stop the country\u2019s nuclear program.\n\nNow, facing the biggest advances of all, Mr. Trump faces the same dilemma his predecessors did, but with less time to respond.\n\nAnd the shakiness of intelligence on North Korea \u2014 even on fundamental questions like how many nuclear weapons Mr. Kim possesses \u2014 casts a shadow over Mr. Trump\u2019s options going forward.\n\nHe has repeatedly raised the prospect of war with North Korea. He has also ordered up a range of new military plans, from a limited \u201cpunch in the nose\u201d to signal American resolve to a large-scale attack aimed at destroying the country\u2019s nuclear and missile facilities \u2014 all of which, his aides worry, could trigger a devastating wider conflict.\n\nYet many in the Pentagon see the failure to anticipate the North\u2019s recent breakthroughs as an ominous reminder of how much could go wrong. A successful pre-emptive strike, for example, might require precise knowledge of the locations of manufacturing facilities, nuclear plants and storage areas, and confidence that cyberstrikes and electronic strikes would cripple Mr. Kim\u2019s ability to retaliate.\n\nThe past year, one senior administration official said, had been a \u201chumbling lesson\u201d in the limits of American electronic, satellite and human intelligence operations against a sealed-off society with few computer networks, a high degree of paranoia about American covert action, and a determined young leader.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump, however, was not disturbed by the absence of warning, General McMaster said. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t have the expectation of perfect intelligence about anything. He is very comfortable with ambiguity. He understands human nature and understands he will never have perfect intelligence about capabilities and intentions.\u201d\n\nThe North\u2019s rapid progress raises a number of awkward questions: Did the American sabotage effort, for example, prompt Mr. Kim to scrap an ailing missile program for a new generation of more capable rocket engines? Or was that his plan all along? And does the new program have similar vulnerabilities the United States can exploit?\n\nDuring a talk last fall, Gen. John E. Hyten, who heads the United States Strategic Command, which controls the American nuclear arsenal, acknowledged he had no idea when North Korea would pass its final technological hurdle: proving its warheads can survive fiery re-entry into the atmosphere to hit targets in the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWill they get there in 2017, 2018, 2019?\u201d he asked rhetorically. \u201cI see a lot of the detailed intel. I can honestly tell you, I don\u2019t know the answer.\u201d\n\nMissing Critical Turns\n\nEver since the United States began tracking North Korea\u2019s efforts to obtain a nuclear weapon, a pattern has repeated itself: American intelligence agencies excelled at forecasting the direction and overall timeline of the program, yet repeatedly missed critical turns.\n\nRecently declassified documents show the C.I.A. recognized the North\u2019s ambitions in the early 1980s, when spy satellites first spotted evidence that it was building a reactor to produce plutonium, a main fuel for nuclear arms. A division of the agency immersed itself in studying the North\u2019s factories and reactors, trying to gauge how fast the backward state could build advanced rocket engines, specialty fuels and nuclear warheads.\n\nAfter the collapse of the Soviet Union, waves of its impoverished missile scientists began to head for North Korea. While Russian security forces intercepted some, others made it out or assisted the North from afar. In retrospect, former American intelligence officials say they almost certainly missed significant transfers of technology.\n\n\u201cThese are designs you can put on a thumb drive,\u201d said a senior official who has tracked North Korea for years and spoke on condition of anonymity because of the topic\u2019s sensitivity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe missiles Mr. Kim has launched in recent months bear numerous signs of Soviet provenance. But analysts and intelligence officials say the specific dates, places and means of transfer remain murky.\n\nOstensibly, North Korea suspended its nuclear weapons program in 1994 after a tense standoff with the United States that brought the two countries closer than ever \u2014 until recent months \u2014 to resuming the Korean War. With the Clinton administration weighing military options, former President Jimmy Carter negotiated a deal that ultimately resulted in a freeze of the North\u2019s nuclear program in exchange for fuel oil and the construction of nuclear power plants, which ultimately were never built.\n\nThat deal appeared to hold for six years but, in fact, the North began cheating on the agreement within a few years. Secretly, it was pursuing an alternative path to the bomb using uranium fuel.\n\nThe intelligence community eventually spotted shipments from Russia and Pakistan containing parts for centrifuges used to enrich uranium. Confronted with the evidence, North Korea acknowledged the program, prompting the Bush administration to suspend the agreement. But the North pressed ahead, and today analysts believe it uses uranium for many of its new warheads.\n\nFrom as early as 2000, the National Intelligence Council was remarkably prescient about North Korea\u2019s overall direction, predicting in an unclassified report that it would \u201cmost likely\u201d have a nuclear missile that could hit American cities by 2015.\n\nFour years later, when the United States was mired in the first year of the Iraq war, the council refined its prediction, saying a \u201ccrisis over North Korea is likely to come to a head sometime over the next 15 years,\u201d that is, no later than 2019.\n\nNone of this was ignored. President George W. Bush began a program to interdict ships delivering material for the North\u2019s weapons program, and he accelerated secret efforts to cripple the program by sabotaging its supply chain with bad parts.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s Run of Successful Missile Firings Late in 2016, North Korea ditched a failing missile technology for a new type that in 2017 racked up major successes, potentially putting its nuclear warheads in range of American cities. 2016 Estimated ranges of major missiles launched in North Korea April 15 Failed April 27 Failed Intermediate-range missile (1,800 to 3,400 miles) April 28 Failed May 30 Failed Intercontinental-range missile (more than 3,400 miles) June 21 Failed June 21 Oct. 14 Failed Oct. 19 Failed 2017 April 4 April 15 Failed April 28 May 14 July 4 July 28 Aug. 29 Sep. 15 Nov. 28 2,000 miles 4,000 6,000 8,000 2016 Estimated ranges of major missiles launched in North Korea April 15 Failed April 27 Failed Intermediate-range missile (1,800 to 3,400 miles) April 28 Failed May 30 Failed Intercontinental-range missile (more than 3,400 miles) June 21 Failed June 21 Oct. 14 Failed Oct. 19 Failed 2017 April 4 April 15 Failed April 28 May 14 July 4 July 28 Aug. 29 Sep. 15 Nov. 28 2,000 miles 4,000 8,000 6,000 2016 Estimated ranges of major missiles launched in North Korea Apr. 15 Failed Apr. 27 Failed Apr. 28 Failed Intermediate-range (1,800 to 3,400 mi.) May 30 Failed Jun. 21 Failed Intercontinental-range (more than 3,400 mi.) Jun. 21 Oct. 14 Failed Oct. 19 Failed 2017 Apr. 4 Apr. 15 Failed Apr. 28 May 14 Jul. 4 Jul. 28 Aug. 29 Sep. 15 Nov. 28 2,000 miles 4,000 6,000 8,000\n\nBut the C.I.A.\u2019s main focus was on counterterrorism, and satellite coverage over North Korea was often diverted to keep troops safe in the Middle East.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States was surprised in 2006, when it received a heads-up about the North\u2019s first underground nuclear test \u2014 from China, only about an hour before the explosion.\n\nIt was surprised again the next year when the head of the Mossad, Israel\u2019s intelligence service, arrived at the White House with photographs showing a nuclear reactor under construction in Syria that matched the North\u2019s Yongbyon reactor. One picture, eventually released by the C.I.A., showed the chief of North Korea\u2019s nuclear-fuel production at the Syrian site. Though the plant was less than 100 miles from the Iraqi border, the United States had missed it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 2010, North Korea invited Siegfried S. Hecker, the former director of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, to visit and showed him a complete uranium-enrichment plant it had built inside an old building at Yongbyon. The Koreans had installed the facility, at a site under regular satellite surveillance, without being detected.\n\nIntelligence officials said there were good reasons for this spotty record.\n\nForeign governments almost never succeed in recruiting North Korean scientists as sources because they are rarely allowed to go abroad. The North also appears to have figured out the patterns of some American spy satellites.\n\nAnd while documents released by Edward J. Snowden showed the National Security Agency had penetrated North Korea, it is unclear whether its cybersnooping gleaned anything useful in a nation with minimal computer networking.\n\nA Remarkable Sprint\n\nFor years, North Korea devoted itself to short-range missiles that posed little threat to the United States.\n\nBut in 2008, two years after its first nuclear test, Condoleezza Rice, then secretary of state, warned allies that the North was on the verge of another leap: A Soviet rocket engine representing \u201ca substantial advance\u201d had aided its development of longer-range missiles, according to a secret memo disclosed in 2010 by WikiLeaks.\n\nInside the Pentagon, the alarms grew louder. In early 2011, while visiting Beijing, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told reporters North Korea was within five years of being able to fire a long-range missile. Pyongyang, he added, \u201cis becoming a direct threat to the United States.\u201d\n\nThen, rather suddenly, the urgency seemed to recede.\n\nWhen Mr. Kim came to power, many in the intelligence community doubted he would survive: He was young, inexperienced and distrusted by his military. And over the next four years, during Mr. Obama\u2019s second term, North Korea\u2019s missile program experienced repeated public failures, prompting more than a few jokes on late-night television in the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe worst humiliation came in April 2012, two days after Mr. Kim\u2019s formal elevation to the highest level of state power, on the 100th anniversary of his grandfather\u2019s birthday. He marked the occasion with a satellite launch intended to demonstrate technology used in an intercontinental ballistic missile, and even invited foreign journalists. But the rocket shattered soon after launch and fell into the Yellow Sea.\n\nBy late 2013, the intelligence community had largely changed its view of Mr. Kim. He was eliminating his rivals, sometimes ordering public executions with antiaircraft guns that shredded their bodies. And he seemed far more serious about the nuclear and missile program.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis father and grandfather tested weapons to make a political point. Mr. Kim, however, turned the program into North Korea\u2019s version of the Manhattan Project, the race to develop the atomic bomb in the United States. He made the development of a nuclear arsenal one of the state\u2019s top priorities, on equal footing with economic development. Only with a nuclear deterrent, he argued, would the nation be secure enough to focus on growth.\n\nIt now appears that Mr. Kim had several missile programs underway simultaneously, and sped efforts to make parts and missile fuel indigenously, so that the United States and its allies could not cut off his supplies.\n\nPresident Obama, increasingly concerned, ordered multiple reviews, including the one in early 2014 in which he authorized an intensification of covert cyberstrikes and electronic strikes on the North\u2019s missile program.\n\nThe pace of missile tests accelerated, reaching a peak of more than two dozen in 2016. But at least 10 launches failed that year, including seven of an intermediate-range missile known as the Musudan.\n\nFormer senior officials in the Obama administration say it remains unclear whether the sabotage effort contributed to the failed tests; there are many alternative explanations. But this much is clear: In October 2016, Mr. Kim ordered a halt to the Musudan tests, and the missile program rapidly shifted in a different direction, focusing on a new generation of more reliable and potent engines.\n\nIn May, North Korea successfully tested the new design in an intermediate-range missile capable of hitting the American territory of Guam. Then, on July 4, it stunned the world with its first successful test of an ICBM \u2014 and repeated the success a few weeks later. In November, it tested a greatly improved ICBM, known as the Hwasong-15, that could fly about 8,100 miles, far enough to threaten all of the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was a remarkable sprint, and there was surprise inside the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies. Mr. Kim appeared to have solved the problems that plagued the Musudan \u2014 and perhaps outmaneuvered the American sabotage program.\n\nThe latest missiles appeared to have been based on old Soviet designs. In interviews, intelligence officials said \u201cfreelancers\u201d from the former Soviet Union \u2014 \u201ca handful\u201d by the estimate of one official \u2014 are almost certainly working with North Korea. The Russian government, they added, does not appear to be providing support.\n\nBetween the missile tests, in September, North Korea also detonated its most powerful underground nuclear blast yet. The North claimed it was a hydrogen bomb, and after initial skepticism, many experts now say it probably was.\n\nRichard L. Garwin, a main designer of the world\u2019s first hydrogen bomb, called the North\u2019s hydrogen claim quite plausible given the \u201cenormous advances\u201d in computer modeling and \u201cthe dedication of the small group of nuclear technologists in North Korea.\u201d\n\nSeveral officials who served under Mr. Obama said that was a real surprise; they had been told that moment was still years away.\n\nFor several weeks, as this article was being prepared, intelligence agencies declined on-the-record comment. After it was posted online Saturday, Brian P. Hale, the spokesman for the director of national intelligence, issued a statement saying that \u201cany suggestion that we didn\u2019t see these tests coming is dead wrong.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe intelligence community has always assessed that Kim Jong-un is firmly committed to developing a nuclear capability,\u201d Mr. Hale added. \u201cWe were, therefore, not surprised by his accelerated pace of testing over the past few years.\u201d\n\nHe said that the North\u2019s capabilities today \u201care within the projection windows\u201d of assessments in recent years and concluded: \u201cWe have no higher intelligence priority.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nForecasts and Physics\n\nEntering 2018, there are several disputes inside the intelligence world about the North\u2019s capabilities.\n\nMost intelligence agencies say the North has an arsenal of about 20 or 30 nuclear weapons, for example, but the Pentagon\u2019s Defense Intelligence Agency puts the number above 50.\n\nIt is more than an academic argument. If Mr. Trump attempted to destroy the arsenal, or if the North Korean government collapsed, the challenge would be to neutralize the weapons without any launch taking place or any warhead falling into the wrong hands. The more there are, the more difficult that task becomes.\n\nThe intelligence agencies are also intently focused on not missing the next big milestone: the moment North Korea learns how to design and build a warhead that can survive the heat and stresses of re-entry into the atmosphere, continue to plunge downward and succeed in destroying its target.\n\nWhen the United States built its nuclear arsenal in the 1950s and \u201960s, that \u201cwas the hardest part for us,\u201d said General Hyten of the United States Strategic Command.\n\nBut the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, told an audience in October that predicting when North Korea crosses this final threshold is less relevant now because \u201cyou\u2019re now talking about months.\u201d\n\nAnd Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, who has urged diplomacy over military action, said the November ICBM test flight indicated the North already has the ability to hit \u201ceverywhere in the world, basically.\u201d\n\nHaving underestimated the North, though, Washington now faces some risk of overstating its capabilities and intentions, some experts hold.\n\nDr. Hecker, the former director at Los Alamos, recently argued that North Korea needs \u201cat least two more years and several more missile and nuclear tests\u201d to perfect a weapon that can threaten American cities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is still time \u201cto start a dialogue,\u201d he said, \u201cin an effort to reduce current tensions and head off misunderstandings that could lead to war.\u201d", "title": "How U.S. Intelligence Agencies Underestimated North Korea", "authors": ["David E. Sanger", "William J. Broad"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump\u2019s decision to impose sweeping tariffs on imports of solar panels and components is the opening salvo of his America First campaign to protect domestic manufacturers from Chinese competition. The stakes are high: Solar is the world\u2019s fastest-growing energy industry, attracting over $160 billion in investment in 2017.\n\nYet these tariffs will do little to make American manufacturers competitive with dominant Chinese ones. Instead, they might actually discourage domestic investments in innovation, crucial to an American solar manufacturing revival. On top of this, the tariffs will cause collateral damage by slowing down the installation of solar panels in the United States, destroying more jobs than they create, and provoking trade disputes and retaliation.\n\nThe United States enacted tariffs on solar imports from China in 2012 (they were expanded to include Taiwan in 2014), when the Obama administration concluded that China had lavished generous subsidies on its domestic manufacturers, which dumped below-cost solar panels on global markets.\n\nBut by that point, established manufacturers as well as Silicon Valley start-ups developing solar technologies had already been washed away by a flood of cheap Chinese panels based on conventional silicon technology. American manufacturers\u2019 share of global solar-components production had plunged below 5 percent by 2011, down from over a quarter a decade earlier. What remained after the carnage was a hollowed-out American industry in no shape to compete with the huge scale of Asian producers.", "title": "Opinion | How U.S. Tariffs Will Hurt America\u2019s Solar Industry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Sept. 6, 2017\n\nMr. Trump strikes bipartisan deal to increase the debt limit and keep the government open until mid-December and tells Democrats that he wants to do something to help the Dreamers. \u201cChuck and Nancy would like to see something happen, and so do I,\u201d the president said.\n\nSept. 13, 2017\n\nThe president has dinner with \u201cChuck and Nancy\u201d in the Blue Room of the White House and discussed a possible deal in which Congress would legalize Dreamers in exchange for border security. The two Democrats left the dinner and declared they had reached \u201ca deal\u201d with the president.\n\nSept. 14, 2017\n\nConservatives recoil at the idea of Mr. Trump embracing what they call amnesty for lawbreakers. The White House says that no deal was reached. Trump tweets: \u201cNo deal was made last night on DACA. Massive border security would have to be agreed to in exchange for consent\u201d and says that would include \u201cthe wall.\u201d\n\nOct. 1, 2017\n\nNew fiscal year begins without Congress passing any of the 12 appropriations bills necessary to fund the government. The government is now operating on stopgap spending bills that maintain spending at the previous year\u2019s levels. Funding for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program is allowed to lapse.", "title": "How Washington Reached the Brink of a Shutdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "What about the dishes that seem to only be found in Canada?\n\nWe\u2019re actually at this fascinating moment in Canadian history where, yeah, we do talk about Nanaimo bars and others will talk about doughnuts \u2014 we probably should talk about Tim Hortons and its problems these days when talking about Canadian food.\n\nBut I think we\u2019re getting to a point where we might say, gosh, what\u2019s more Canadian than the dosa or the string hopper or many other different things.\n\nHow do you make a dosa in our climate? And with the rice that\u2019s available here, with the potatoes that are available here, the chilies that are available? That\u2019s a very different and new kind of dish. And there you have in some sense the making of what is now Canadian food.\n\nCanadians cook food in ways that come from all over the world but they haven\u2019t adopted much from the indigenous people who were first here. Why is that?", "title": "How We Cook, Eat and Drink: The Canada Letter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "For the 13th year, the Travel section presents its annual 52 Places to Go issue. You will likely have some questions: How did the No. 1 spot get there? What\u2019s the deal with those looped videos in the online version? And why is my favorite spot not on the list? Here are some frequently asked questions about how we chose our 52 Places to Go in 2018.\n\nWhat made New Orleans the top choice?\n\nIn a year that seemed particularly traumatic for many around the world, we look to a place where centuries of trauma have yielded something magical. New Orleans is unlike any other city in the world, largely thanks to its ability to synthesize that history \u2014 and the myriad populations that participated in it \u2014 into a place full of joy and wonder. New Orleans is also turning 300 this year, so there\u2019s no better time to celebrate that history, whether it be through anniversary events, food, music, art or simply wandering this amazing city.\n\nWhat is special about the list online?\n\nLast year\u2019s list featured about a dozen 360 videos. This year, you\u2019ll find a series of short, looped videos shot by photographers in places as disparate as Cambodia, Germany and Japan. We also had our staff photographer Josh Haner head to New Orleans to capture video shot with a camera attached to what is called a gimbal, which steadies the image, as well as a drone camera, which he flew over the city.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a certain elation that overtakes you when walking with a second line \u201d \u2014 a traditional type of brass band parade \u2014 \u201cin New Orleans,\u201d Mr. Haner said. \u201cI found myself dancing while filming and was grateful for the gimbal so my bouncing wasn\u2019t too noticeable.\u201d", "title": "How We Put Together the 52 Places List", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Look at any failing democracy and you will find constitutional hardball. In postwar Argentina, when President Juan Per\u00f3n encountered Supreme Court opposition, his congressional allies impeached three of five justices on grounds of \u201cmalfeasance\u201d and replaced them with loyalists. In 2004, when Venezuela\u2019s high court proved too independent, congressional allies of President Hugo Ch\u00e1vez added 12 seats to the 20-member court and filled them with loyalists. Both Per\u00f3n\u2019s and Ch\u00e1vez\u2019s court-packing schemes were legal, but they nevertheless destroyed judicial independence.\n\nNorms of forbearance have not always been strong in the United States: They were weak in the republic\u2019s early years and they unraveled during the Civil War. But for most of the 20th century, Democrats and Republicans accepted each other as legitimate and exercised power with forbearance.\n\nThere were no partisan impeachments or successful court packing. Congress routinely funded the government, obstructionist tools like the filibuster were used sparingly, and the Senate used its power of advice and consent with prudence, routinely confirming qualified nominees. There were instances of executive overreach (Franklin Roosevelt, Richard Nixon), but the most egregious abuses were checked by Congress and the courts.\n\nHistory suggests, however, that democratic norms are vulnerable to polarization. Some polarization is healthy, even necessary, for democracy. But extreme polarization can kill it. When societies divide into partisan camps with profoundly different worldviews, and when those differences are viewed as existential and irreconcilable, political rivalry can devolve into partisan hatred.\n\nParties come to view each other not as legitimate rivals but as dangerous enemies. Losing ceases to be an accepted part of the political process and instead becomes a catastrophe. When that happens, politicians are tempted to abandon forbearance and win at any cost. If we believe our opponents are dangerous, should we not use any means necessary to stop them?\n\nThis is how democracy died in Chile. Before the 1973 coup, Chile was Latin America\u2019s oldest democracy, buttressed by vibrant democratic norms, including a well-established \u201cculture of compromise.\u201d Chileans liked to say that there was no political disagreement that could not be settled over a bottle of Chilean cabernet. But beginning in the 1960s, Chile\u2019s culture of compromise was shattered by Cold War polarization. Mutual toleration eroded, and political parties eschewed forbearance for a \u201cwin at all cost\u201d strategy. Chilean democracy fell into a death spiral, culminating in a bloody coup. (The intervention of the United States accelerated but did not cause this death spiral.)\n\nCould it happen here? It already has. During the 1850s, polarization over slavery undermined America\u2019s democratic norms. Southern Democrats viewed the antislavery position of the emerging Republican Party as an existential threat. They assailed Republicans as \u201ctraitors to the Constitution\u201d and vowed to \u201cnever permit this federal government to pass into the traitorous hands of the Black Republican Party.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | How Wobbly Is Our Democracy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The cultural gaps among nations are even more stark. According to a 2003 Gallup survey, 65 percent of American and Russian drivers thought they\u2019d been subjected to aggressive behavior from others, compared with only 26 percent of Japanese drivers. There are significant differences in driving culture between disciplined northern European countries and the more permissive southern ones, where lane markers are regarded as dubious suggestions.\n\nSome traffic patterns require a tradition of deference to central authority. According to The Economist, half the world\u2019s traffic circles are in France, where they work well. In Nairobi, they are a complete disaster.\n\nDriving means making a thousand small moral decisions: whether to tailgate to push the slowpoke faster, or to give space; whether to honk only as a warning or constantly as your all-purpose show of contempt for humanity.\n\nDriving puts you in a constant position of asking, Are we in a place where there is a system of self-restraint, or are we in a place where it\u2019s dog eat dog?\n\nDriving puts you in a constant position of asking, Are my needs more important than everybody else\u2019s, or are we all equal? BMW drivers are much less likely to brake for pedestrians at crosswalks. Prius drivers in San Francisco commit more traffic violations. People who think they are richer or better than others are ruder behind the wheel.\n\nDriving also puts you in a position where you are periodically having to overrule your desire for revenge. When somebody cuts you off, you want to punish the jerk and enforce all that is right and good. But that only leads to a cycle of even worse driving, so it\u2019s better, as Francis would say, to turn the other cheek. How would Jesus drive?\n\nIn short, driving puts you into social situations in which you have to co-construct a shared culture of civility, and go against your own primeval selfishness, and it does so while you are encased in what is potentially a 4,000-pound metal weapon.\n\nOf course, we are all appalled at the clowns who are bespoiling our culture from the top. But I\u2019m going to try to remember one lesson when I hit the road: Though I may be surrounded by idiots, I\u2019m potentially an artisan of the common good.", "title": "Opinion | How Would Jesus Drive?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "A year after millions of people participated in the Women\u2019s March to protest Donald Trump\u2019s inauguration, demonstrators across the United States took to the streets on Saturday to speak out against the president and his administration\u2019s policies.\n\nA poem by the activist, poet and writer Cleo Wade about being an active citizen prompted us to ask readers how they\u2019ll be getting involved in politics in their communities. Below is Ms. Wade\u2019s poem, followed by lightly edited responses from readers.\n\nI get up\n\n(I don\u2019t always want to)\n\nI\u2019m tired\n\nI am run down\n\nMy thoughts run me down\n\nThe news runs me down\n\nMy country runs me down\n\nOur history runs me down\n\nBut\n\nSomething pulls me from the safety of my sheets\n\nPuts me in the shower\n\nDresses me and says\n\nShow up\n\nSometimes I show up\n\nBecause Heather Heyer can\u2019t", "title": "Opinion | How You Are Showing Up This Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pace\u2019s discovery is known as M77232917 and was announced on Jan. 3. It is expressed as 277,232,917 \u2013 1 and is 23,249,425 digits, nearly one million digits larger than the previous record-holder, which The New York Times wrote about in 2016. As we explained then:\n\nA prime number is not divisible by any positive integer except 1 and itself. Some prime numbers are named after Marin Mersenne, a French theologian and mathematician who studied them in the early 17th century. They can be written in the form 2n \u2013 1 where n is an integer. For example, 3 is a Mersenne prime. Plug in 2 for n, and you find 22 \u2212 1 = 4 \u2212 1 = 3. But not all integers plugged into this expression generate a prime number, and as integers get bigger, prime numbers become rarer.\n\nTo recruit hunters for them, a volunteer project called the Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search, or Gimps, came on the scene in 1996.\n\nMr. Pace said that when he became a Gimps volunteer, 14 years ago, he was excited by the idea of finding the first Mersenne prime with at least 10 million digits, and winning the $100,000 prize. But that discovery was made on a U.C.L.A. computer in 2008.\n\nMore Reporting on Mathematics\n\nAs the years went by, and other Mersenne prime numbers were found, Mr. Pace kept running the software in the background. \u201cThe C.P.U. will only work on it if there is literally nothing else for it to do,\u201d he said. He started with computers at home and then used the ones at the Germantown Church of Christ, where he is a deacon and the network administrator.\n\nMr. Pace, who has a bachelor\u2019s degree in electrical engineering and an M.B.A., described growing up in a community so small and rural that there were \u201ccattle across the street.\u201d He said his passion for math was ignited by an inspirational high school teacher named Harold Knight, who had a reputation for putting together formidable math teams.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was giving me problems that were unambiguous, as in there was one and only one correct answer,\u201d Mr. Pace said, explaining how this appealed to his problem-solver personality.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019d challenge me, and if I failed he\u2019d show me where I\u2019d made a mistake or used an incorrect method, then move to the next challenge,\u201d Mr. Pace recalled of the teacher, who died years ago.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe moment of the discovery on Dec. 26 was not immediately apparent. The system is supposed to tell you if you find a Mersenne prime, Mr. Pace said, but that didn\u2019t happen. Instead George Woltman, who founded the Gimps project, emailed him.\n\n\u201cCongratulations Jon!\u201d Mr. Woltman wrote. \u201cIt\u2019s either a new Mersenne prime (99.999%)\u201d or a \u201cbug (.001%).\u201d\n\nThe software itself can help spot problems. Mersenne prime software is used to test computers for hardware errors, Mr. Woltman said. Smaller prime numbers are important to cryptography, but larger ones, so far, mostly just dazzle us.\n\nTo demonstrate the length of the number, Mr. Pace said that it took 69\u00bd sheets of 11 by 17 paper to print out the number he found \u2014 in two-point font.\n\nDiscoverers of a Mersenne prime get their names recorded and, if it\u2019s not a benchmark number, a modest cash prize. Mr. Pace is eligible for a $3,000 award. He has been interviewed by TV crews from as far away as Brazil.\n\nAll that publicity has led his college-age son and daughter, who were less interested before, to proudly make it known that this nerdy discovery was made possible by their father.\n\nMr. Pace\u2019s son, Bryan, 22, who is studying computer engineering and shares an interest in math, said that the recent success had motivated him to set up the Gimps program again on his own computer.\n\nAnd Mr. Pace\u2019s daughter, Katherine, 19, has her own thoughts about the discovery. \u201cIt\u2019s something that I\u2019m oddly proud of, even though it isn\u2019t actually my accomplishment,\u201d she said. \u201cThe coolest thing about it is really seeing my dad\u2019s humility on display. He is quick to tell people that anyone could have done it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndeed, even as Mr. Pace promised to keep searching for the next big trophy \u2014 the 100-million-digit Mersenne prime, with a prize of $150,000 \u2014 he said there were two much smaller numbers he was even prouder of: \u201cthe 20 years I\u2019ve served as a deacon at Germantown,\u201d and \u201cthe 44 gallons of blood and platelets I\u2019ve donated in my life.\u201d", "title": "How a Church Deacon Found the Biggest Prime Number Yet (It Wasn\u2019t as Hard as You Think)", "authors": ["Valencia Prashad"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe power of the fossil fuel industry around here is so great I think the industry feels they can count on simply not complying with requests,\u201d Mr. Whitehouse said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Energy Department did not respond to a request to discuss the memos from Mr. Murray.\n\nThe Trump administration has had an unusually close relationship with Mr. Murray. He and 10 of his miners were invited to watch the president sign an executive order to rollback President Obama\u2019s climate change regulations. He has met with Mr. Perry to discuss the needs of coal producers. His longtime attorney, Andrew Wheeler, is awaiting Senate confirmation to the No. 2 slot at the E.P.A., and David Zatezalo, the nation\u2019s new top mine safety and health regulator and previously the president of a coal mining company, told his hometown paper that Mr. Murray had encouraged him to put his hat in the ring for the job.\n\nJeffrey Holmstead, a lawyer with the firm Bracewell and a deputy administrator of the E.P.A. in the George W. Bush administration, called Mr. Murray\u2019s action plan \u201can ambitious list.\u201d While interest groups always try to influence policy in a new administration, Mr. Holmstead said Mr. Murray\u2019s status with the administration set him apart.\n\n\u201cI really don\u2019t think it\u2019s at all unusual that Murray would have this wish list or a set of recommendations. What makes it different is that it\u2019s pretty clear that he has a personal relationship with the president,\u201d Mr. Holmstead said. \u201cIt seems like given Mr. Murray\u2019s relationship with the president that he had more of an expectation that these things were going to be accepted or implemented.\u201d\n\nOne item not on the list yet important to Mr. Murray was an order the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission rejected Monday to subsidize struggling coal and nuclear power plants. Mr. Murray railed against that decision saying it would lead to the decommissioning of coal and nuclear power plants.\n\nEnvironmental groups have accused Mr. Murray of directly asking Mr. Perry for a proposed rule to reward coal and nuclear power plants for providing \u201cgrid resiliency.\u201d The March 1 memo does not mention the grid, though photographs of the cover page of the March 23 document to Mr. Perry obtained by In These Times shows its focus is \u201ca plan for achieving reliable and low cost electricity.\u201d\n\nSoon after Mr. Murray\u2019s meeting at D.O.E., Mr. Perry ordered the agency to prepare a study on the country\u2019s electric grid reliability, a precursor to ordering the federal government to subsidize struggling coal and nuclear plants.\n\nMr. Murray and a spokesman, Gary Broadbent, said the difference between the two memos was that the one provided to Mr. Perry asked the Energy Department to study the security of the nation\u2019s power grid.\n\n\u201cI suggested that the study be made,\u201d Mr. Murray said. \u201cWhat they did from there, the administration did. I did not have involvement in it.\u201d\n\nOne of the items on the 16-point list was an overhaul of FERC regulators, and the Trump administration accomplished that. Personnel from 17 city agencies have supported emergency management operations, sorting donations and cleaning up debris, according to Nancy Silvestri, the press secretary for the city\u2019s department of emergency management.\n\nNew York City was one of a handful of local governments that sent workers to the island. The State of New York, for example, has sent 452 workers to help repair the power grid, 152 medical volunteers and 152 National Guard police officers, among others. Florida deployed 500 law enforcement officers and has coordinated more than 2,500 flights carrying over 15,000 tons of cargo and more than 12,000 people.\n\nCity inspectors said they also brought water, food and diapers to distribute to residents in communities left isolated.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe were going to areas of San Juan like the barrios in the mountains,\u201d Luis Vasquez, a chief inspector, said. \u201cIn a lot of places we were like heroes. We were the first ones they saw.\u201d\n\nThe first team of two sent on Sept. 24 inspected critical infrastructure like hospitals, schools and even city hall in San Juan. The second team of 12 left on Oct. 6 and mapped the damage to thousands of homes.\n\nUsing their smartphones, inspectors used a color key to map the damage: Green meant the building was safe; yellow, the building was damaged, but habitable; and red denoted unsafe conditions. They uploaded descriptions and photos of the damage to a digital dashboard.\n\nThe data allowed officials to identify houses that needed roof tarps, as well as buildings that could serve as centers for the distribution of food and water.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNew York helped with many things, not just inspections, but inspections are one of the most underrated and important things because it gives you data on which you can base tangible actions,\u201d Mr. Carrasquillo Medrano, the San Juan official, said.\n\nNew York City inspectors reached about 65 to 70 percent of neighborhoods in the capital, he said in a phone interview. However, officials in Puerto Rico often had trouble accessing the data because the internet connection was too weak at the time. But, since mid-October, San Juan officials have added data of their own, he said.\n\nNearly four months after the storm, about 40 percent of the island is still without electricity, and some parts of the island are expected to be without power for another eight months.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s surreal \u2014 churches split in half, electricity poles down, houses that flew up-mountain,\u201d said Edgardo Butler, a New York City inspector who also was born on the island. \u201cThe Puerto Rico I remember was ripped away.\u201d", "title": "How a Team of New York City Inspectors Helped Puerto Rico After Maria", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Another, they say, is New Hampshire\u2019s low per capita spending on services to help drug users break free from addiction. Nationally, the state, which has no income or sales tax, ranks at the bottom in availability of treatment programs. The fire departments\u2019 safe stations are one effort to fill that void.\n\nThe researchers also noted that the state has pockets of \u201ceconomic degradation,\u201d especially in rural areas where jobs are few, and that may contribute to the problem.\n\nBeyond that, the researchers say, doctors here have long prescribed \u201csignificantly higher rates\u201d of opioid pain relievers, almost twice the national average. When the government cracked down on legal painkillers, New Hampshire residents were primed to seek out illegal street drugs.\n\n\u201cThis is a kind of perfect storm,\u201d says Lisa A. Marsch, a professor of psychiatry and health policy at Dartmouth\u2019s Geisel School of Medicine and the study\u2019s principal investigator.\n\n\u201cWe have highly available, highly potent opioids in New Hampshire,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd highly limited resources to reduce the risk.\u201d\n\nThe researchers noted other factors, too:\n\n\u2022 A shortage of workers in addiction and recovery. Northeast states have an average of 15.5 doctors per 100,000 residents who can prescribe Suboxone and other medication-assisted treatments; New Hampshire has seven.\n\n\u2022 No needle exchanges, which can reduce the transmission of diseases like hepatitis C and save health care costs. New Hampshire finally legalized needle exchanges in June, long after many other states had done so, but did not fund them. Dartmouth medical students, using donations and grants, opened the first needle exchange last summer in a Claremont, N.H., soup kitchen, but it was shut down in October because it was too close to a school.", "title": "How a \u2018Perfect Storm\u2019 in New Hampshire Has Fueled an Opioid Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Few of the books remain. Mr. Adams first came across a copy last year at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture at the New York Public Library, which has a rare, nearly complete set (which they digitized in 2015). At the time, he was digging through the archive of the trailblazing 1980s African-American fashion designer Patrick Kelly, the subject of his current show at at the Countee Cullen Library in Harlem (organized with the Studio Museum in Harlem and the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture), through Feb. 23.\n\nFor an art exhibition, \u201cthe curatorial challenge was how to bring all of the information in the books to life, to make it emotional and aesthetic, not didactic,\u201d said Dexter Wimberly, the executive director of Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art in Newark, who organized the show with MAD\u2019s Samantha De Tillio (MAD\u2019s chief curator, Shannon Stratton, brought the show to the institution).\n\n\u201cSanctuary\u201d includes wallpaper printed from pages of the Green Books, but that\u2019s about the only literal reference to the guides. Mr. Adams uses them \u201cto suss out ideas about mobility.\u201d He conjures the experience of the traveler who might have circled names in them, like Blue Duck Inn Grill, New Candle Light or Silver Moon, and reimagines what those places and the path to get there might have felt like. Anchoring the show, for instance, is a miniaturized highway, sitting around three feet off the ground.", "title": "How an Artist Learned About Freedom From \u2018The Negro Motorist Green Book\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The universe is a swirling cosmic cocktail of galaxies made up of specks of dust, and Alex Dimitrov and Dorothea Lasky are alive and writing poetry in it. The two poets, who are also best friends and creative collaborators, are always thinking about the stars. The first thing the pair ever talked about, when they met in a Brooklyn loft in 2010, while drinking cheap champagne at an after-party for a poetry reading, was the movement of the constellations. \u201cAlex walked up to me and told me he was a Sagittarius,\u201d said Ms. Lasky, 39. \u201cAnd I knew, it was going to work. When a Sagittarius spots an Aries across a room, there\u2019s an immediate connection.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI used to tell everyone that Aries and Sagittarius are the strongest astrological match,\u201d said Mr. Dimitrov, 33. The poets were sitting across from me in a velvet banquette at the dark Temple Bar in the NoLIta neighborhood of Manhattan. Mr. Dimitrov cut a sleek profile, wearing a black leather jacket and a nonchalant smudge of kohl eyeliner. Ms. Lasky wore piles of jewelry on every exposed surface of her body, and looked like a modern incarnation of the elegant mystic Madame Blavatsky. Together, under the light of the dim Edison bulbs, they looked like members of a long-lost 1970s prog-rock band. \u201cAries women just love me,\u201d Mr. Dimitrov went on. \u201cI wish I could get married to an Aries woman, but alas, I like men. So this is the next best thing. I guess we are in a \u2018spiritual marriage.\u2019 I always refer to our Twitter as a marriage.\u201d\n\nThe Twitter account he speaks of is Astro Poets, a feed of whimsical astrological musings that the two launched together in late November 2016 (their account is a Sagittarian) and that has grown exponentially in popularity since. The account now boasts more than 232,000 followers \u2014 fans include the pop artists Lorde and Michelle Branch and the actor/writer Lena Dunham \u2014 and a coveted book deal with Macmillan\u2019s Flatiron Books. (The book will be published in 2019.) The two recently hosted a sold-out poetry reading for 500 fans in the New York Public Library\u2019s Celeste Bartos Forum. The beige auditorium was sardined with admirers \u2014 average age somewhere between 18 and 25, many with unicorn-hued, asymmetrical haircuts \u2014 who came for a glimpse of their horoscope gurus.\n\nThe Astro Poets idea was born over text message, late at night. Ms. Lasky and Mr. Dimitrov, who are both published poets (Ms. Lasky with four books, Mr. Dimitrov two), were up into the wee hours in November of 2016 chatting about their favorite subjects: romance and astrology. Mr. Dimitrov had double-booked dates with two men, and he was waffling back and forth about which plans to cancel. He turned to a Twitter poll, and then directly to Ms. Lasky, for cosmic advice. \u201cI was choosing between a Taurus and a Virgo,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s funny is, I didn\u2019t go on either date. But we did get the idea for the Twitter out of it,\u201d \u201cMr. Dimitrov said. \u201cEvery time we got dinner or drinks, we\u2019d be talking about astrology the whole time. And we were like, let\u2019s take this to Twitter and see if people care.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs it turned out, people did care. The first tweet the Astro Poets posted was \u201cWe\u2019ve been born on this truest evening, November 26, 2016 in New York City. A Sagittarius babe we are & we love our planet & all the signs.\u201d Within three days, the account had amassed more than 4,000 followers.\n\nThe mission of Astro Poets was simple: Use Twitter to write tiny poems about the star signs. Because Mr. Dimitrov and Ms. Lasky are creatures of the internet, they are as well-versed in pop culture as they are in literary history. As a result, the account has a very specific, charming tone, one that unites zeitgeisty interests with ancient knowledge about the solar system. A typical tweet will list the star signs as emoji, or punctuation marks. Early on, the pair developed the idea of \u201cthe series,\u201d a quick list of 12 tweets describing all of the signs in terms of a single conceit. They described the signs in terms of Britney Spears songs, Virginia Woolf novels, adverbs and passive-aggressive email signoffs.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI approach each series we do thinking about structure, really,\u201d Mr. Dimitrov said. \u201cI like the fact that there are 12 signs. I like the fact that there are the four elements. If you think about it, those are poetic constraints.\u201d", "title": "How the Astro Poets Lit Up the Internet", "authors": ["Rachel Syme"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Vikings scored on their opening drive, undoubtedly allowing fans to dream of the possibility of Minnesota being the first team to play a Super Bowl at home, but a pick-six by Case Keenum on the Vikings\u2019 second offensive possession set the tone for how the game would play out.\n\nKeenum, who has a tenuous hold at best on the starting quarterback position in Minnesota, completed 28 of 48 passes for 271 yards and one touchdown, with much of that yardage coming once the game was well out of hand. He also accounted for all three of his team\u2019s turnovers by way of two interceptions and a fumble on a strip-sack.\n\nPhiladelphia has taken great pride in being underdogs in both of their playoff games despite being the top-seeded team in the N.F.C., and they are sure to continue that trend when facing Brady and the Patriots.\n\nChris Long, who had a fantastic day for Philadelphia\u2019s defense, recovering a fumble and helping force an interception, looked remarkably calm on the stage receiving the N.F.C. championship trophy with his coaches and teammates.\u201cWe\u2019re not surprised at all,\u201d he said. \u201cThey went up seven early and a lot of teams would have folded their tents. Not us. We don\u2019t panic.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s how the Eagles beat the Vikings in the N.F.C. Championship game:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Nick Foles show keeps rolling.\n\nAbsolutely everything is going Nick Foles\u2019s way. Philadelphia\u2019s backup quarterback has looked like a superstar, and he delivered yet another scoring drive with a 5-yard pass to Alshon Jeffery. The Eagles now lead 38-7, with this game already representing Minnesota\u2019s worst defensive effort of the season.\n\nThe latest scoring drive was a thing of beauty, with Foles working his way down the field with a series of quality passes while benefiting greatly from some solid work after the catch by his receivers. It was then a perfect throw to Jeffery which put yet another touchdown on the board.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFoles, who had been remarkably conservative since taking over for Carson Wentz late in the season, has thrown four passes of more than 35 yards in the game and is up to 341 passing yards and 3 passing touchdowns against one of the two best secondaries in the N.F.L.\n\nThe Vikings will now get the ball back down 31 points with just over 14 minutes left in the game. If they are going to make this a game, they need to score almost immediately.\n\nVikings have a touchdown taken away by replay.\n\nAdam Thielen pulled down a hugely improbable touchdown reception on a 4th-and-goal play, but after a review showed the ball had hit the ground before the wide receiver secured it, Philadelphia takes over from their own 7-yard line still leading 31-7.\n\nThe Vikings\u2019 offense looked considerably better than it had in quite some time, starting the drive with one first down before Case Keenum found Jarius Wright for a fantastic 33-yard gain on the sideline that could potentially have been a touchdown if Wright had not lost his balance.\n\nJerick McKinnon got Minnesota inside the Philadelphia 10-yard line with an 11-yard reception, but on 3rd-and-goal from the 7-yard line, Keenum missed badly on a pass to a wide-open Thielen, and on fourth down he threw to Thielen again. The ball was tipped at least once, with Thielen falling to the ground before reaching out to pull it into his chest. It was only when the play was shown from the other side of Thielen that it was clear where the ball made contact with the ground before he pulled it back in.\n\nPhoto\n\nFoles airs it out again and the Eagles build a huge lead.\n\nNick Foles was at it again, launching a 41-yard pass to Torrey Smith, who beat Harrison Smith to the ball and then dove across the goal line into the end zone. Philadelphia now leads 31-7 in what has turned into a blowout. Adding to the Vikings\u2019 woes is Andrew Sendejo, Minnesota\u2019s standout safety, being doubtful for the remainder of the game with a calf injury while Xavier Rhodes, their top cornerback, has been sitting out with a toe injury. Rhodes is probable to return, but if the Vikings\u2019 secondary is not at full-strength, coming back from this huge deficit seems nearly impossible.\n\nEagles add to their lead at halftime.\n\nAt halftime, the N.F.C. Championship game is all Philadelphia, with the underdog Eagles leading 24-7. Nick Foles has looked like a different player than what we had seen in recent weeks \u2014 maybe even something resembling his incredible run of success in 2013 \u2014 and the Eagles\u2019 defense forced two huge turnovers against the conservative Minnesota offense.\n\nThe Vikings allowed 21 consecutive points after starting out the game with a 7-0 lead, and they got the ball back with just 1:09 left in the half. They tried to get something going with a few fairly conservative plays that picked up one first down, but the drive ended with an awkward pass from Case Keenum to Kyle Rudolph that fell incomplete.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith only 38 seconds left, the Vikings punted the ball away, hoping for better fortune in the second half.
