But the Eagles took advantage by driving down the field quickly to set up Jake Elliott for a 38-yard field goal attempt that increased their lead to 17 points.\n\nThe Eagles will receive the ball to start the second half and are currently outgaining the Vikings 242 to 185 despite trailing in time of possession.\n\nFoles finds Jeffrey for a 53-yard touchdown.\n\nSo much for Philadelphia running a conservative offense with Nick Foles. The team\u2019s backup quarterback looked like a starter on a 53-yard touchdown pass to Alshon Jeffery, which along with the extra point gave Philadelphia a 21-7 lead late in the second quarter.\n\nAt the two-minute warning, the Eagles faced a tough 3rd-and-6 at their own 28-yard line. They converted thanks to a great effort from Corey Clement on an 8-yard pass, and then got another first down on an 11-yard pass from Foles to Torrey Smith.\n\nFoles threw a pair of incomplete passes, and then on 3rd-and-10 from his team\u2019s 47-yard line he dropped back, avoided a tight pass-rush, and nearly fell to the ground with effort as he launched the ball 50-plus yards in the air to Jeffery for the huge score.\n\nEagles\u2019 defense forces another turnover.\n\nThe Eagles\u2019 defense forced their second turnover of the game with a strip-sack by Derek Barnett that was recovered by Chris Long.\n\nThe teams had traded punts without much offense to show for either drive, but the Vikings got back to basics on a drive that saw them glide down the field with a succession of first downs provided by Stefon Diggs, Adam Thielen and Jerick McKinnon.\n\nBut on 3rd-and-5 from the Philadelphia 16-yard line, Case Keenum dropped back to pass and Barnett came up on the blind side and jarred the ball out of Keenum\u2019s throwing hand as the quarterback tried to get set to throw.\n\nPhoto\n\nEagles put together a balanced scoring drive.\n\nAfter Nick Foles got the Eagles close, LeGarrette Blount hammered the ball into the end zone for an 11-yard touchdown that made the Vikings\u2019 formidable defense look helpless to stop him. Philadelphia now leads by a score of 14-7, having successfully answered Minnesota\u2019s 7-0 start to the game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the drive, Foles looked like a different quarterback than the one who struggled at the end of the regular season. He threw aggressively to his receivers, picking up several first down passes with confident throws to Alshon Jeffery and Zach Ertz.\n\nThe progress was slow and steady, but Jay Ajayi and Blount showed that the Eagles\u2019 running game is tough enough to keep Minnesota from keying on Foles, which should dramatically help the former backup quarterback succeed.\n\nEagles\u2019 defense making life difficult for Keenum.\n\nThe Vikings\u2019 first possession resulted in a Minnesota touchdown, and their second gave a touchdown to Philadelphia. On a third try, it was far less dramatic with the team going 5 yards on three plays before punting. The only good news on the drive came in the form of Stefon Diggs making his way back onto the field after leaving briefly with a back injury.\n\nPhoto\n\nPick-six gives Eagles a big boost.\n\nThe Eagles tied the game, 7-7, thanks to a pick-six by Patrick Robinson on a bad throw by Case Keenum.\n\nKeenum dropped back on 3rd-and-8 and was under pressure from Chris Long, who made contact with Keenum\u2019s throwing arm on a pass intended for Adam Thielen. Robinson stepped right in front of Thielen, taking the ball away and then he found his way through the crowd for a 50-yard touchdown.\n\nThe offensive drive for Minnesota not only resulted in points for the Eagles, but also saw the Vikings lose Stefon Diggs, the hero of the divisional round, to a back injury, at least temporarily. The wide receiver appeared to be ok after taking a knee to the back on an incomplete pass, but he was removed from the game as the team helped him get back to his feet.\n\nEagles can\u2019t answer Vikings\u2019 opening score.\n\nThe Eagles looked aggressive on their first drive of the game, but when they were asked to answer a quick 7-0 deficit, they ended up punting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPhiladelphia started from its own 25-yard line and Nick Foles started off with an 11-yard completion to Nelson Agholor. He went deep to Torrey Smith on the second play of the drive, and very nearly pulled out a huge gain, but Smith couldn\u2019t hang on to the ball.\n\nFoles recovered to get one more completion to Agholor, this one going for 6 yards, but on 3rd-and-4 Trey Burton, who was wide open, could not land inbounds on a ball thrown to him, resulting in the punt.\n\nPhoto\n\nKeenum has Vikings looking sharp at the start.\n\nThe Vikings did almost anything they wanted on the opening drive of this game. Case Keenum gave his team a 7-0 lead with a beautiful 25-yard touchdown pass to Kyle Rudolph that left the Eagles looking flat-footed. Latavius Murry and Jerick McKinnon combined for 27 yards on the ground during the scoring drive, keeping the Eagles from being able to pressure Keenum, and the journeyman quarterback took advantage of that by tearing them apart, completing all three of his passes for 48 yards and the score.", "title": "How the Eagles Beat the Vikings in the N.F.C. Championship Game", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "For example, days after news broke of the Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein\u2019s history of sexual harassment, LawCash, a settlement-advance company, was trying to cash in. \u201cSexual abuse is a crime #HarveyWeinstein,\u201d read a LawCash tweet. The Brooklyn company offered cash upfront to sexual abuse plaintiffs \u201cif you or someone you know is in need of financial help.\u201d\n\nThe settlement-advance firms get paid back only if a plaintiff collects money from a lawsuit. They make money by charging interest rates as high as 100 percent, which they are able to do because technically the money is considered an advance \u2014 not a loan \u2014 and therefore is not subject to state usury laws.\n\nConsumer groups call the industry predatory. The companies counter that they are providing a vital service to people without other options.\n\nLegal and business experts said there are scores of firms providing advances to tens of thousands of plaintiffs each year. The largest firms make cash advances totaling up to $40 million a year, according to an unpublished 2014 report by Diligence, a business intelligence firm.\n\nLegal Bay of Fairfield, N.J., is one of the settlement-advance firms trawling for sexual harassment clients.\n\nIn one October news release, Christopher R. Janish, its chief executive, said he had \u201cset aside a large portion of their presettlement cash advance funding specifically for plaintiffs of sexual harassment cases.\u201d The next month, the firm trumpeted its \u201cspecial focus for victims of unwanted sexual advances.\u201d\n\nMr. Janish said he did not know if the pitches had landed any clients. \u201cIt just really is more of a public awareness and branding thing,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe firms advertise on television and include hot-button search terms on their websites to lure traffic. That was how Heather Rothermund of Redding, Calif., learned of Nova Legal Funding in Los Angeles last summer. She had sued her employer, an adult care facility, for failing to discipline a co-worker who she said had groped her breasts and forced his hands down her jeans. Along with a state civil rights agency, she sought $250,000 in damages. The facility\u2019s owner did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMs. Rothermund, 41, said the alleged assault left her with bills for therapy and anxiety medications that she couldn\u2019t afford. Her car was about to be repossessed when she came across Nova\u2019s online advertisement. The company advanced her $2,000 against an anticipated future legal settlement, she said.\n\nThe money got her out of a financial hole and helped her avoid having to accept a lowball settlement offer. She said that if the case settled within the year she might owe $4,000 \u2014 double what she borrowed. If the case drags on, she will owe more.\n\n\u201cIt is expensive, but it does help and it is available,\u201d Ms. Rothermund said.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor the past two decades, settlement-advance companies have been chasing the hottest \u2014 and most lucrative \u2014 trends in litigation. They have provided advances to victims of surgical vaginal mesh products; those suffering from ailments related to the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks; and former National Football League players with brain injuries.\n\n\u201cThere are some companies that are trying to ride that \u2018me too\u2019 thing, and we are not doing that,\u201d said T. Thomas Colwell, chief executive of TriMark Legal Funding in Oregon. \u201cThat is just opportunistic.\u201d\n\nMr. Colwell said his firm had been providing cash advances to women with sexual harassment claims for 15 years. He said many clients worked in less glamorous industries than Hollywood and needed money to cover basic living expenses.\n\nOnly a handful of states regulate or license the settlement-advance firms, and little more than a website is necessary to get into the business.\n\nMr. Janish formed Legal Bay in 2014, a few years after getting out of state prison in New York for orchestrating a $13 million stock manipulation scheme.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLegal Bay\u2019s promotional materials don\u2019t mention Mr. Janish\u2019s past. He said his legal history wasn\u2019t relevant to customers. \u201cMy only obligation is to disclose to them the terms of the money they seek,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the New York attorney general sued R. D. Legal, claiming the New Jersey firm took advantage of former N.F.L. players who expected to receive money in the league\u2019s landmark concussion settlement. The authorities claimed that R. D. Legal had tricked the players \u201cinto costly advances on settlement payouts.\u201d\n\nJust last week, Colorado\u2019s attorney general announced a $2 million settlement with LawCash and another settlement-advance firm, Oasis Financial, saying they charged personal injury plaintiffs \u201cpredatory interest rates.\u201d\n\nThe industry says it charges high fees to compensate for the risk of not being repaid.\n\nBut the industry\u2019s lucrative model has attracted mainstream financial institutions. The D. E. Shaw hedge fund, the private equity firms Parthenon Capital and Victory Park Capital, and Germany\u2019s DZ Bank have either bought stakes in or lent money to settlement-advance firms. D. E. Shaw has sold its stake in Oasis Financial.\n\nIn addition to providing cash upfront to sexual harassment plaintiffs, some firms are pursuing the more traditional form of litigation finance, providing money to law firms in exchange for a cut of potential settlements.\n\nNova \u2014 the same company that advanced money to Ms. Rothermund \u2014 plans to announce that it will provide financing for lawyers pursuing Hollywood sexual harassment cases.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to level the playing field in cases against big Hollywood players,\u201d said Ron Sinai, Nova\u2019s founder.\n\nAnd Legalist, a San Francisco litigation finance start-up, said that a Weinstein-related marketing pitch had attracted new clients, and that the company was now bankrolling three lawsuits against alleged sexual abusers.\n\nThe practices used by the settlement-advance industry have proved particularly controversial, uniting consumer groups and big business in opposition. Consumer activists argue that recipients don\u2019t understand how quickly the costs accumulate. Business groups, including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, argue that cash advances artificially drive up litigation costs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI would never recommend an individual finance his or her recovery,\u201d said Robert Kraus, a New York employment lawyer. \u201cIt is inconsistent for a lawyer, if he believes in a client\u2019s case, to recommend that he or she should limit their recovery.\u201d\n\nSome of the larger settlement-advance firms use lawyers to drum up business. The firms recruit lawyers in much the same way that pharmaceutical companies woo doctors: with perks such as holiday gift baskets and invitations to year-end parties.\n\nAt Oasis, one of the industry\u2019s biggest players, employees who got a lawyer to send at least three clients in a year were celebrated as \u201chunters,\u201d according to court documents in an employment dispute.\n\nOasis, which spends millions of dollars each year on TV advertising, said it had provided funds to 200,000 customers since it opened in 2003.\n\nMichael Gibson, a former case manager at Oasis, said he had worked on up to 70 cases a day. The typical customer, he said, borrowed less than $2,000 but paid a fee that was the equivalent of an 80 percent annual interest rate.\n\n\u201cMy personal opinion is that legal financings are predatory loans,\u201d Mr. Gibson said.\n\nSome customers say the cost is worth it.\n\nNickie Burdick, 28, had been unable to work for two years after she was injured in a car accident. Ms. Burdick, of Batavia, N.Y., said her attorney had suggested she take out a loan against a potential settlement in her case.\n\nShe knew the rates were steep, but she didn\u2019t see another viable option, she said. She recently has been borrowing $2,000 a month from Oasis, accruing $220 in fees each time.\n\n\u201cIt was either that or I lose my house and be homeless,\u201d she said.", "title": "How the Finance Industry Is Trying to Cash In on #MeToo", "authors": ["Matthew Goldstein", "Jessica Silver-Greenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The ravines where oblivious schoolchildren played by day and drunk men sprawled at night taunted Soviet Jews, reminding us of our impotence under Communist rule. \u201cVon tam\u201d (\u201cover there\u201d), Jewish fathers whispered to sons in Russian while discreetly nodding at trash-covered pits such as Babi Yar in Kiev and Drobitsky Yar in my home city of Kharkiv. \u201cVon tam\u201d was a rite of passage, like a bar mitzvah in the land where the rabbis had been sent to the gulags and synagogues were refurbished into Komsomol youth centers.\n\nEven after being shamed into confronting its silence by Yevgeny Yevtushenko\u2019s seminal 1961 poem \u201cBabi Yar,\u201d the Kremlin refused to fully acknowledge the Holocaust. Instead of ignoring the dead Jews, Moscow conscripted them into the Soviet mythos of the Great Patriotic War, as World War II was known. Inconspicuous plaques mentioning \u201cSoviet victims of Nazi aggression\u201d were placed at a handful of the larger sites, where they joined the thousands of plaques and memorials on every corner of the Soviet Union. The K.G.B. continued to monitor the ravines for signs of organized prayer, and the Soviet Jews remained consigned to whispers.\n\nIt was only during the late \u201980s, with restrictions loosened by Mikhail Gorbachev\u2019s glasnost, that the Holocaust began appearing in the Soviet press. On Oct. 4, 1991, two months before the collapse of the Soviet Union, a monument to Jewish victims was erected in Kiev. \u201cToday at Babi Yar the Spirits Will Rest,\u201d proclaimed The New York Times\u2019 headline about the opening ceremony. And so they could. For a while.\n\nThe Nazis did not act alone. The Holocaust, especially in Eastern Europe, was made possible with the aid of local governments and paramilitaries, which rounded up and massacred Jews, sometimes in the service of the Nazis, sometimes on their own volition.\n\nToday, these collaborators \u2014 groups and individuals responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Jews \u2014 are being glorified and rehabilitated as part of the ultranationalism surging across Eastern Europe. Nationalists seek to rally around men who fought for independence against both Russia and Germany; unfortunately, the World War II-era figures being chosen had expressed their vision for independence by murdering Jews.", "title": "Opinion | How the Holocaust Haunts Eastern Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "About 11 million Iranians, around 50 percent of the work force, work in irregular employment, according to Iran\u2019s Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs. Almost all young workers I met during my extended fieldwork in the past 15 years have been in irregular employment, rarely paid on time, with little protection from exploitative employers. Between 10 million and 13 million Iranians are entirely excluded from health, work or unemployment insurance.\n\nThe Iranian poor do see the vast riches of the Iranian elite. Since the early 2010s Iran has witnessed the growth of a consumerist culture and rising inequality. An increasing number of imported luxury cars have appeared on the roads; buildings whose price per square meter equals three years of a worker\u2019s wage have come up across the cities. Ice cream covered in edible gold \u2014 worth a worker\u2019s monthly salary \u2014 is on the menus of luxury restaurants.\n\nAfter the day\u2019s work, I would walk with workers from Darab\u2019s village from the construction sites in wealthy neighborhoods in North Tehran to their modest rented rooms in the poorer South Tehran. As we walked past Porsches and Maseratis parked outside luxury boutiques and restaurants, they would address God satirically and say, \u201cIf these people are your creatures, what am I then?\u201d\n\nAlongside financial insecurity and drought, Iranians are reeling from intense pollution in the cities. A decade of sanctions has significantly increased the prices of groceries, medicines and fuel. The sanctions also excluded Iranians from the formal international banking system and forced them toward informal cash-based transactions, making them vulnerable to fraud and black market prices. The value of the Iranian toman has fallen by more than half against the dollar since 2012, which affected all other costs inside the country.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s anti-Iranian tirades leave no hope for lifting or easing sanctions on Iran. The fear of military attack by Israel or the United States has added to the popular anxieties.\n\nYet hope for democracy and social justice in modern Iran has been replicated time and again through political struggles, from the constitutional revolution in 1911, the oil nationalization movement in 1950, the revolution in 1979, the green movement in 2009 and the most recent protests led by the poor.\n\nAs the images of the protests in Iran appeared on screens worldwide, I thought of my conversation with Darab in his village. We had stared at the distant mountains rising toward a clear, blue sky in silence. \u201cSee all these lands that we cannot get one single toman from. We do not have water. Write it,\u201d he had commanded. \u201cAnd write that those in Tehran have been taking all money for themselves and have forgotten that we also are people.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | How the Other Half Lives in Iran", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "In an on-field interview with CBS after the game, Brady discussed the hand injury that had dominated the conversation before the game.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had a lot worse,\u201d Brady said. \u201cI didn\u2019t know that on Wednesday, it was a crazy injury.\u201d He added, \u201cToday we did just enough to win.\u201d\n\nOn going to the Super Bowl again: \u201cIt\u2019s pretty crazy. It\u2019s pretty amazing. To be on a team that wins these kids of games is a great accomplishment.\u201d\n\nBortles was given one final try late in the fourth quarter to regain the lead, but a fourth-down pass fell incomplete and a despondent Bortles lay on the field trying to figure out how the game had slipped away.\n\nThe Patriots\u2019 top receiver for most of the game was Brandin Cooks, a deep threat who caught 6 passes for 100 yards, but it was Danny Amendola who took over in the fourth quarter, catching two touchdowns from Brady to erase Jacksonville\u2019s lead. Amendola finished the game with 7 catches for 84 yards.\n\nHere\u2019s how the Patriots beat the Jaguars in the A.F.C. Championship game:\n\nPhoto\n\nPatriots\u2019 first drive ends with a field goal.\n\nNew England is up 3-0 after a drive that showed some serious promise before fizzling out in the red zone.\n\nThe Patriots got the ball first and Tom Brady immediately completed a 5-yard pass to Dion Lewis and a 31-yarder to Brandin Cooks. The offense then managed just 8 yards on three short plays \u2014 a short run by Brady, a reverse to Rex Burkhead and a short completion to Burkhead \u2014 before aggressively going for it on 4th-and-2 with Brady tossing a high floater of a pass that somehow found its way into Danny Amendola\u2019s hands for a 20-yard gain, putting the Patriots in the red zone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJacksonville then tightened things up considerably, and a sack on 3rd-and-goal from the 12-yard line forced New England to send Stephen Gostkowski in for the 31-yard kick.\n\nDespite having a stitched-up hand that was the subject of a great deal of speculation, Brady looked perfectly comfortable on the opening drive, completing all six of his passes for 57 yards.\n\nDropped passes hurt Jaguars as drive stalls out.\n\nThe Jaguars stayed true to their style of football on their opening drive, running the ball and going for conservative passes, but a pair of dropped balls resulted in them punting away the ball after picking up 23 yards.\n\nJacksonville started the drive from their own 26-yard line and they alternated between runs up the middle by Leonard Fournette and passes by Blake Bortles, which were on their mark even if they lacked much zip on them.\n\nBut after picking up two quick first downs, the Jaguars stalled thanks to a badly dropped pass by T.J. Yeldon on 2nd-and-8 from the Jacksonville 49-yard line, and a more difficult drop from Marqise Lee on 3rd-and-8.\n\nOften mocked, the Jaguars succeeded this season by executing their game plan each and every week. Dropping easy passes that Bortles threw accurately could be a major problem.\n\nPhoto\n\nJaguars grab the lead after a balanced drive.\n\nThe Jaguars defense produced a quick three-and-out, and given another chance on offense, Jacksonville was far more aggressive. The change in strategy paid off with a smooth-as-butter 76-yard drive that ended with a 4-yard touchdown pass from Blake Bortles to Marcedes Lewis. With the extra-point, the Jaguars are now on top 7-3.\n\nOnce they got the ball back, the Jaguars went to work immediately with a 20-yard catch-and-run by Corey Grant. They then had a series of solid gains with a 7-yard pass from Blake Bortles to Marqise Lee, a pair of runs by Leonard Fournette that combined for 10 yards, and a nice pass by Bortles that found Keelan Cole on the sideline for an 11-yard gain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first quarter ended after Cole\u2019s reception, but after changing sides of the field, the Jaguars picked up right where they left off with another impressive catch-and-run by Grant that went for 24 yards.\n\nSet up with a 1st-and-goal at the New England 4-yard line, everyone was expecting a Fournette run up the middle, but Bortles faked to his power back before lofting a pass over the right side of the line for the Lewis touchdown.\n\nPhoto\n\nFournette gives Jaguars a 14-3 lead in first half.\n\nLeonard Fournette barreled into the end zone for a 4-yard touchdown and the Jaguars, against all odds, are leading 14-3 in a game that is going exactly as they had hoped.\n\nThe Jacksonville defense did its part by following up the team\u2019s first touchdown by continuing to suffocate New England\u2019s offense. Tom Brady has completed just 1 of 3 passes since his 6-for-6 start, and the Patriots have resorted to punts on consecutive drives.\n\nAfter New England\u2019s second punt, Bortles and the Jaguars took over at their own 23-yard line and through a combination of Fournette, Corey Grant, and a beautiful 27-yard completion to Allen Hurns, they found themselves with yet another 1st-and-goal.\n\nThis time instead of using Fournette as a decoy, they just gave the ball to the huge rookie running back and let him take care of the scoring by himself. His injured ankle does not appear to be limiting him thus far as he has 38 yards on 9 carries despite a defense that seems designed to try to take him out of the game.\n\nJaguars threaten again, but Pats\u2019 defense holds.\n\nThe Jaguars had everything going their way, with touchdowns on consecutive drives and a third chance to score thanks to a miracle 26-yard reception by Keelan Cole that extended the drive. But a penalty pushed them out of scoring range, a sack forced them into a punt, and Jacksonville gave the ball back to Tom Brady and the Patriots with just over two minutes left in the half. An 11-point lead feels comfortable, but if the Patriots can narrow that to four points before halftime, the makeup of the entire game would be dramatically different.\n\nJaguars\u2019 mistakes give Patriots some relief.\n\nAs they have so many times, Tom Brady and the Patriots\u2019 offense willed the team back into contention in a game that seemed to be slipping away. A pair of gigantic penalties against the Jaguars defense provided most of the yardage, but James White took care of the scoring with a 1-yard run that narrowed Jacksonville\u2019s lead to 14-10. Unfortunately for the Patriots, they may have lost Rob Gronkowski in the process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew England got a strong start to the drive with Brady finding Brandin Cooks for a 10-yard gain. Short passes to Danny Amendola and James White picked up a second first down, and the Patriots got 15 yards by way of an unnecessary roughness call against Barry Church for going helmet-to-helmet on a collision with Gronkowski. The hit sent Gronkowski off the field so he could be evaluated for a concussion, potentially ending his day, but the Patriots immediately picked up another 32 yards on a pass interference call against A.J. Bouye, setting them up to score on the 85-yard drive that took just 67 seconds off the game clock.\n\nClosing the gap, especially with Jacksonville getting the ball to start the second half, was a huge development for New England, but Gronkowski\u2019s status going forward could determine the outcome of this game.\n\nPhoto\n\nHalftime: Jaguars have the lead, but not the momentum.\n\nAt halftime, the Jaguars are on top 14-10, but they ceded much of the momentum of the game by letting the Patriots sneak in a score in the final minute of the first half, thanks largely to penalties.\n\nThe Jaguars\u2019 offense got the ball one more time, and despite having a pair of timeouts and 55 seconds left, they stuck to a conservative game plan and knelt on the ball for two plays to ensure that they went into the locker room with a lead.\n\nJacksonville will get the ball to start the second half, which could let them regain some momentum, but the Patriots are known for second-half adjustments so it could be considerably more difficult for Jacksonville regardless of Rob Gronkowski\u2019s status.\n\nJaguars open second half with a field goal.\n\nBlake Bortles was as close to perfect as he gets in the first half, completing 13 of 15 passes for 155 yards and a touchdown. But after stretching his streak of consecutive completions to 12 to open the second half, he had a ball knocked to the ground on a 3rd down pass attempt, resulting in Jacksonville sending Josh Lambo out for a 54-yard field goal attempt that he sent right through the uprights for a 17-10 lead.\n\nJacksonville did not stray from what typically works for them on the drive, with Leonard Fournette running the ball several times and Tommy Bohanon, the team\u2019s fullback, contributing a solid 20-yard catch-and-run.\n\nThe Jaguars got some bad news on the scoring drive when Cam Robinson, a rookie who starts at left tackle, was removed from the game with a shoulder injury. He is listed as questionable to return.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith Gronkowski sidelined, Patriots stumble.\n\nStill without Rob Gronkowski, who is being evaluated for a concussion and is listed as questionable to return, the Patriots started the second half out of sync. A pair of deep passes from Brady to Brandin Cooks went for nothing thanks to fantastic coverage on one play and a drop by Cooks on the second, and the drive ended with New England punting the ball away.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJaguars build 10-point lead in fourth quarter.\n\nIt briefly looked like New England had made some terrific second-half adjustments to limit Blake Bortles\u2019s effectiveness, but the Jaguars\u2019 quarterback made some adjustments of his own. Jacksonville picked up 66 yards on 11 plays, setting Josh Lambo up for a 43-yard field goal that increased Jacksonville\u2019s lead to 20-10.\n\nThe teams traded punts, with the battle of field position resulting in Jacksonville starting its latest drive from the team\u2019s own 9-yard line. But a pair of runs by Leonard Fournette generated 7 yards, and that generated enough cushion for Bortles to pick up a first down with an 18-yard pass to Marqise Lee.\n\nBortles picked up two more first downs with passes to Allen Hurns and Lee, the first of which came on a flea flicker, and then Fournette rumbled for 14 yards on the ground.\n\nThe next two plays went nowhere, closing out the third quarter, and the fourth quarter began with Jacksonville facing a 3rd-and-8 from New England\u2019s 25-yard line. Bortles threw an incomplete pass, but the Jaguars had gone far enough to set up Lambo\u2019s kick.\n\nPatriots will have to come back without Gronkowski.\n\nRob Gronkowski is officially out for the remainder of the game with a concussion, which will continue to limit New England\u2019s offense as they start their first possession of the fourth quarter down 20-10.\n\nJaguars force a huge fumble to thwart Patriots\u2019 drive.\n\nThe Jaguars got a huge break when a 22-yard gain by the Patriots ended with Myles Jack jarring the ball out of Dion Lewis\u2019s hands for a fumble and a recovery, giving Jacksonville\u2019s offense a chance to extend its lead. Tom Brady had picked up a quick first down with an 18-yard pass to Brandin Cooks, and then the Patriots appeared to have a huge gain on a trick play that involved a short pass from Brady to Danny Amendola who then threw across the field to Lewis. Lewis rumbled for big yardage, but then Jack simply stole the ball out of his hands, and the call stood up to a review by officials for the first turnover of the game.\n\nPhoto\n\nTom Brady\u2019s not done yet.\n\nRepeatedly throwing deep down field, Tom Brady and the Patriots showed they are still fighting in this game, and they went 85 yards on 8 plays, with Danny Amendola diving into the end zone for a touchdown, that made it a 20-17 game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Patriots dodged a bullet on their previous drive when a fumble by Dion Lewis gave the Jaguars a huge scoring opportunity that they proceeded to immediately waste. Jacksonville\u2019s three-and-out gave Brady the ball back on his own 15-yard line, and as so many teams have found out over the years, the more opportunities you give Brady, the worse off your team tends to be.\n\nThe 40-year-old quarterback, who was supposed to be limited by an injured hand, endured a sack by Marcell Dareus on the drive, but looked spry and aggressive, challenging Jacksonville\u2019s star-studded secondary and repeatedly finding success.\n\nBrady has now completed 23 of 32 passes for 263 yards against the most talented secondary in the N.F.L.\n\nPatriots grab the lead on Amendola\u2019s circus catch.\n\nIt had been a defensive clinic for both teams over the last few drives, but the Patriots showed why experience is so valuable in the N.F.L. by taking a 24-20 lead thanks to Danny Amendola\u2019s circus catch in the back of the end zone. It was Amendola\u2019s second touchdown of the quarter.\n\nThe Patriots started the drive on Jacksonville\u2019s 30-yard line after a series of punts by both teams finally broke New England\u2019s way with a 20-yard return by Danny Amendola giving them a short field.\n\nNew England then went into automatic mode, with a series of short runs and passes pushing the ball into the end zone in a span of 2 minutes and 10 seconds of game clock.\n\nJacksonville has plenty of time to score, but with New England\u2019s defense having tightened up considerably, that could be very difficult unless the Jaguars have something hidden up their collective sleeve.", "title": "How the Patriots Came Back to Win the A.F.C. Championship", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "So while the anti-abortion movement is often considered central to traditionalist culture-war politics, it also has an individual rights approach, owing to its progressive (largely Catholic) roots. Even before Roe, parts of the pro-life movement emphasized the universal rights of the unborn, drawing upon the language of human rights that was prominent in post-New Deal liberalism. These liberal pro-life activists sought to marry their cause to language used to support civil rights for African-Americans and promote human dignity by supporting antiwar efforts. The National Right to Life Committee, for example, was founded in 1968, intentionally emphasizing the rights of the unborn in its name.\n\nFollowing Roe, many evangelical Christians were slow to join the anti-abortion movement, and when their pace increased at the end of the 1970s, their public arguments against abortion focused more on the immorality of abortion than the right-to-life of the unborn. If one leader epitomizes this approach, it was Jerry Falwell, leader of the Moral Majority. Yet by the early 1990s, the right-to-life public argument would prevail, as evangelical advocates would emphasize, and the evangelical base would accept, the rights-of-the-unborn justification over the immorality of obtaining an abortion.\n\nNot only did the pro-life movement teach about public rights arguments, but battles over abortion forced the movement to frequently claim expansive free-speech rights. Most notably, pro-life groups fought legal and legislative battles to defend their right to protest at abortion clinics and health care facilities many times between the late 1980s and 2000s.\n\nIn doing so, conservative Christian legal organizations were formed, and pro-life groups marshaled liberal free speech precedents established by antiwar and anti-government protesters. In the most recent abortion protest case decided by the Supreme Court in 2014, McCullen v. Coakley, several conservative Christian groups filed a brief arguing that the court should strike down a \u201cbuffer zone\u201d outside a clinic in Boston. In their brief, the groups drew upon the pinnacle of free speech doctrine, Cohen v. California, in which the court in 1971 overturned a young man\u2019s citation for wearing a jacket with a vulgar antiwar slogan on it in a courthouse. These conservative groups claimed for themselves a precedent they would have despised four decades ago.\n\nThese Conservative Christian groups are not just using these precedents when it serves them: They have also been supporting free speech cases when abortion is not directly involved. For example, many defended the student who was suspended for holding a \u201cBong Hits 4 Jesus\u201d banner at an Alaska school event in Morse v. Frederick in 2007.", "title": "Opinion | How the Pro-Life Movement Has Promoted Liberal Values", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "And the cost for investors to save millions of dollars in taxes? A few thousand dollars in fees to the firm that manages the exchange proceeds.\n\nThis preferential treatment is great if you\u2019re a real estate investor. But it\u2019s baffling for anyone else and may be downright infuriating to homeowners in high-tax states who could end up paying more in taxes because of limits placed on their ability to deduct property taxes on their federal income tax.\n\nTake, for example, someone who bought real estate in San Francisco 20 years ago versus someone who bought an equivalent amount of stock in Apple, based nearby in Cupertino. Both assets have appreciated wildly and made a tremendous amount of money for their investors.\n\nBut here\u2019s where the investors\u2019 fortunes diverge. If the owner of Apple stock sold it all and put the proceeds into other technology companies, the stock sale would be subject to a capital-gains tax of 20 percent.\n\nIf the investor who bought real estate in San Francisco sold the property, the money could be used to buy another property in San Francisco \u2014 or anywhere in the country \u2014 without the seller\u2019s paying a tax on the appreciated gains in the original property.\n\n\u201cFrom the I.R.S.\u2019s perspective, the taxpayer gives up property and what they receive is other like-kind property,\u201d said Matthew K. Scheriff, a certified public accountant and executive vice president of Legal 1031 Exchange Services. \u201cWhy that should apply to real estate and not other property? Obviously, real estate received a little bit of a favorable outcome on that side of the tax package.\u201d\n\nFavorable, indeed.\n\nCombine those tax-free gains with the higher estate tax exemption, and it is possible that a real estate investor would never have to pay capital gains or estate tax on tens of millions of dollars in real estate. If, at the investor\u2019s death, the assets totaled less than the $22.4 million exemption for a couple, decades of embedded gains would be erased.\n\nPhoto\n\nMoreover, any property tax the investor paid over the years would have been deducted as a business expense \u2014 even though the deduction for property taxes for a homeowner has been capped at $10,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClever investors could even sell the properties tax-free. Mr. Scheriff, who completed about 400 exchanges for his clients last year, gave this example: A person sells a building in New York for $1 million and uses 1031 exchanges to buy two rental houses on a golf course in Florida. A few years later, the investor evicts one tenant and moves into the house. After a few years, the investor sells it and claims the personal residence exemption, then repeats the process with the second home.\n\nThere are some residency requirements, but if handled the correct way, the strategy produces tax-free gains to be enjoyed in the investor\u2019s lifetime \u2014 gains that would be taxed if they were from other investments.\n\nWhy is this allowed? \u201cIt\u2019s a result of tax law inertia,\u201d Mr. Pegg said. He pointed to the history of farmers swapping odd parcels of land to create contiguous farms that were easier to maintain.\n\nIn the last major tax overhaul, which occurred in 1986, a provision in the code allowed for a delay of 180 days between selling one property and buying another, without any tax on the gains from the sale of the first property. A ruling from the I.R.S. also allows people to do \u201creverse exchanges\u201d \u2014 buying a property first and then picking other properties of equal value to sell without paying tax.\n\nToday, 1031 exchanges can turn air into a McDonald\u2019s on Long Island, tax-free. Peter E. Buell, a partner at Marcum, the national accounting firm, said that one of his clients had sold the air rights over a three-story building on 125th Street in Harlem that he had owned for decades. Without doing a 1031 exchange, the client would have had to pay tax on the entire sale price. To avoid paying tax, the client used the proceeds to buy the land on which a McDonald\u2019s sits.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019ll collect his rent check for what was air rights,\u201d Mr. Buell said.\n\nIn keeping these exchanges just for real estate, lawmakers may have inadvertently signed a decree that will send some museum-worthy pieces of art outside the country.\n\nTop collectors, who may spend millions of dollars for a single work of art, have taken advantage of 1031 exchanges that allowed them to use sales from their collection to buy new art \u2014 and save the nearly 30 percent tax on the gains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that stopped with the new law. Michael Kosnitzky, a partner at the law firm Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, said American art collectors could lose their advantage over those in the Middle East and elsewhere in Asia, who have been buying big-ticket works like Leonardo da Vinci\u2019s \u201cSalvator Mundi,\u201d which sold for $450 million to a Saudi prince who did not have the same tax concerns.\n\n\u201cThis is really bad for U.S. collectors,\u201d Mr. Kosnitzky said. And, he said, it is a potential blow for museums in the United States.\n\n\u201cWhen Steven Cohen or Steve Wynn or another significant U.S. investor \u2014 and there are only a handful of them \u2014 buys a piece of art, they\u2019re often going to place their artwork in U.S. museums,\u201d Mr. Kosnitzky said.\n\n\u201cNow, those works are going to be out of the U.S. because of that tax law change,\u201d he added. \u201cOr they\u2019ll be kept in private collections where no one will be able to see them unless you know the Saudi prince or the Malaysian billionaire. That\u2019s not cool.\u201d\n\nWilliam J. Kambas, a partner at Withersworldwide, a law firm that was particularly active in doing 1031 exchanges for art, hopes buyers\u2019 passion for collecting overrides their tax concerns. \u201cI think many collectors, with or without the tax benefit, are going to buy and sell art,\u201d he said. \u201cBut maybe a piece that someone had to reach for, it might be difficult.\u201d\n\nOne thing he is certain of: \u201cThis is a boon for those in real estate.\u201d", "title": "How the Tax Code Rewrite Favors Real Estate Over Art", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cStart with the right bottle,\u201d says Greg Alvey, a builder and restorer of ships in bottles who has owned some 800 since he started collecting them in the late 1990s. You want clear glass without visible seams, flaws or raised lettering. The classic version is the Haig Dimple whisky bottle, with its short neck and flattened sides. \u201cIt can\u2019t roll away,\u201d Alvey says.\n\nBeginners should consider constructing what\u2019s known as a waterline ship, which sits atop a sea usually made of modeling clay or plumber\u2019s putty, thereby saving you from having to make a full hull that needs to fit through the opening. For dimensions, find a plan online or in a book. Alvey suggests a schooner whose sails will seem impossibly tall inside the bottle. The point of this type of folk art is to evoke a sense of bewilderment in the viewer. \u201cIt\u2019s a puzzle,\u201d Alvey says. \u201cHow is it possible to get that in there?\u201d\n\nShape a hull from soft basswood. Using toothpicks or wooden sticks from cotton swabs, make masts, booms and the spar extending from the vessel\u2019s front prow, which is called the bowsprit. Attach your masts to the hull with a piece of wire that will serve as a hinge. Glue the sails (made from tea- or coffee-soaked paper for a seaworn-canvas look), the masts and booms and rig them all with strings that go through the bowsprit. Place a few drops of glue atop the putty sea inside your bottle. Loosen your rigging lines and bring the sails and masts down alongside the hull. Insert the boat into the bottle stern first, using a bent metal coat hanger or a surgeon\u2019s tool called polypus forceps. Hoist the sails up by pulling your strings. Glue them to the bowsprit. Let the glue dry for a few days. Cork your bottle.\n\nSome people refer to curious miniatures like these as \u201cpatience bottles,\u201d but Alvey says the virtue doesn\u2019t need to come naturally \u2014 \u201cYou can learn patience doing this.\u201d Beginners should expect a level of exasperation when trying to drill holes in toothpicks or whittle miniature anchors. \u201cWhen things start going wrong,\u201d says Alvey, who once put a project aside for seven years, \u201cit\u2019s usually best just to walk away and come back when you\u2019ve calmed down.\u201d", "title": "How to Build a Ship in a Bottle", "authors": ["Malia Wollan"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Focus downward. \u201cWe tend to live in our heads,\u201d says Jessica Rose, a professor of orthopedic surgery at Stanford University and director of the Motion & Gait Lab at Lucile Packard Children\u2019s Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. \u201cWe should be directing more attention to our feet.\u201d\n\nWhatever your reason for refashioning your stride, symmetry should be the goal. Determine whether your walk is off-kilter by studying the wear pattern on the soles of your shoes. Have you ground your heels down into a lopsided wedge? \u201cIf you see uneven wearing, get new shoes,\u201d Rose says. You can\u2019t learn a new gait when the old one is imprinted on your shoes. Listen to the cadence of your footstep \u2014 is it rhythmic? Are your feet clearing the ground with each step? Rose\u2019s patients tend to have severe gait abnormalities associated with neurological conditions like cerebral palsy that often require bone and muscle surgery. A more minor correction to increase your athletic performance, say, or to remedy a step torqued by high heels or an aging body can often be accomplished in as little as six weeks with regular practice (and maybe some in-shoe orthotics).\n\nTake off your shoes, stroll barefoot up and down a hallway and notice where you feel pressure. Make adjustments to your body alignment and foot placement until your weight is evenly distributed (consider consulting a physical therapist for this step). Make sure you\u2019re striking the ground heel-first and pushing off your forefoot. \u201cPractice until it becomes your habitual way of walking,\u201d Rose says. Toddlers walk about a mile a day, which is the amount of input your neural circuits need to create a gait pattern. You may need to do daily balance training, as well as exercises to strengthen the muscles of your hip.\n\nBy around age 7, a child has already developed the specific style of walking she will have into adulthood. In fact, gait is such a distinctive biometric that the United States Department of Defense has researched technologies that identify individuals at a distance by just their walk. Changing the way your body ambulates won\u2019t be easy. \u201cBe very vigilant,\u201d Rose says. \u201cDon\u2019t go back to your old pattern.\u201d", "title": "How to Change Your Gait", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Meryl Block Weissman was returning to New York from Costa Rica on New Year\u2019s Eve when she heard that 10 American tourists and two pilots had been killed in the crash of a Nature Air charter flight at the Pacific coast town of Punta Islita. Just days earlier, she, her extended family and others on a group tour were scheduled to fly the same airline.\n\nBut Nature Air made a last-minute change and \u201cinstead of three, two-engine planes the group would be put on four, single-engine Cessna planes,\u201d Ms. Block Weissman said. Concerned about the unexpected switch, their tour guide canceled their plans to fly and had them travel by bus and boat instead.\n\nMs. Block Weissman said that she was \u201cdisappointed not to see the rain forest from the air,\u201d but when she learned about the tragedy days later, she wondered if there was anything she could do to judge the safety of a foreign air charter.\n\n\u201cWe want the people in the back seat to know there is a resource to get information,\u201d said Art Dawley, the chief executive of Wyvern, which assesses air charter services for corporate flight departments, frequent users of private aviation and more recently, ordinary travelers who do not usually take charters like Ms. Block Weissman.", "title": "How to Check the Safety of a Charter Airline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Next, think about how you\u2019re going to use the table. \u201cFigure that each place at the table needs 22 to 24 inches of table space and that larger-scale chairs will require more,\u201d said Max Dyer, a furniture industry veteran and a current vice president of casegoods (a category of hard furniture like tables, cabinets, and chairs) at La-Z-Boy Industries.\n\nAs a longtime apartment-dweller, I\u2019ve found that the \u201cvisual weight\u201d of a piece of furniture can really influence how big it feels in a room. It may technically fit, but it\u2019ll seem huge if it\u2019s a dark or bulky piece or if it\u2019s too close to other furniture.\n\nTo visualize how a bigger piece of furniture will look, take the time to block out the length and width on the floor (I like to use painter\u2019s tape), and also the height of the table. I usually stand on my tape corners with a tape measure, then try to fill in that space with furniture of a similar size (like a couple of chairs), and take a step back to see how it\u2019ll feel. It also helps to have a friend stand there with the tape measure while you have a look.\n\nIf you\u2019re tight on space, consider options like leaves that allow the table to extend. \u201cThese let you customize the table for different entertainment needs and party sizes,\u201d said Meredith Mahoney, founder and design director of Birch Lane.\n\nThe one thing Mr. Pourny warned against was too many mechanisms or leaves that are attached or hidden within the table (versus stand-alone leaves). \u201cIf you buy things that are too complicated, it\u2019s just more opportunity for something to fail,\u201d he said.\n\nConsider your needs before settling on shape\n\nPhoto\n\nSquare and rectangular tables are the most common, so you\u2019ll find the greater number of choices there with styles, sizes and extendable options. But a round or oval table can give you a little more space to move around since it cuts off the corners but still has a good surface area. \u201cFor tighter, rectangular spaces, the oval might be the best option,\u201d Mr. Dyer explained.\n\n\u201cRound or oval tables can be great for parties and conversation because there\u2019s no head of the table, too,\u201d said Ms. Harris. In terms of squeezing people in, you\u2019re only limited by the perimeter of the table \u2014 but you can lose a little space for serving pieces once you have all your place settings at a round or oval table.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPay attention to the table supports\n\nPhoto\n\nThe base \u2014 usually legs, a pedestal, or a trestle \u2014 can have an effect on how many people you can fit at a table. \u201cYou just want to be sure the leg space isn\u2019t being invaded by the supports,\u201d said Jackie Hirschhaut, the vice president of public relations and marketing for the American Home Furnishings Alliance. When you see a table in person, sit at it to see if your legs hit the table\u2019s legs. Verify you have enough space for your knees when you scoot all the way in, and if you can cross your legs underneath the table. The apron \u2014 the frame that holds up the tabletop \u2014 can cut down on your room to maneuver.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf you want to be more flexible with your guests, pay attention to the leg width and where the legs are placed. \u201cIn general, a table with thinner legs, or where the legs are at the corners, will make it easier to squeeze an extra chair in,\u201d said Ms. Harris. And, as Mr. Dyer noted, be aware: \u201cA leg table is generally limited to how long it can be extended without bowing in the middle.\u201d\n\nWith a pedestal or trestle table, you have more flexibility to add more people to the table. \u201cA center base is the best option to squeeze people in,\u201d said Ms. Harris. But Mr. Pourny told us he was wary of larger round pedestal-style tables because they can be a little less sturdy than those with four-legs.\n\nTrestle tables can give you flexibility along the sides of the table, but can limit space at the ends of it. Look closely at how much space there is between the edge of the table and where the trestle supports are attached to make sure there\u2019s room for your knees.\n\nChoose the right table materials for your style\n\nPhoto\n\nChoosing the material for your dining table can be difficult. You have to balance price, ease of care, and your personal style to choose the right one, and a table that\u2019s not a good fit on any of those could mean a buying decision you regret later. Here are the most common materials, and what to consider for each:\n\n\u25a0 Wood: Solid wood is a classic material because it is durable and easy to repair. Pine, acacia, mango and teak are popular, less expensive options. \u201cSolid wood is the most popular, though it\u2019s often the most expensive,\u201d said Ms. Hirschhaut. Manufacturers have been working to bring down the price of solid wood \u2014 Ikea has an unfinished solid pine table for just $69, but larger ones from other retailers can cost $1,000 or more. Wood expands and contracts with heat and humidity and can show scratches and wear, but is fairly easy to repair.\n\n\u25a0 Veneer/Wood-Look: Wood veneer is often a more affordable alternative to solid wood. Here a very thin layer of solid wood (or material printed to look like wood) is glued to a plywood or other wood core. To identify good veneer, look for tables with clearly-labeled core interiors, like kiln-dried hardwood. One way to spot cheaper veneers is to look underneath the table at the store. \u201cIf just the outside is finished, but the underneath looks like a different material, the manufacturer is cutting costs,\u201d Mr. Dyer suggested.\n\n\u201cMake sure particleboard says it\u2019s CARB compliant, which means it\u2019s passed emissions tests,\u201d said Thomas Russell, senior editor at industry newsletter Furniture Today. And you can always ask the salesperson exactly what the table is made of \u2014 if they\u2019re not sure, that\u2019s a red flag, says Mr. Dyer. You can expect to pay under $500 for a less expensive veneer, but the higher-end ones go into the thousands.\n\n\u25a0 Stone and Stone-Look: Stone tabletops can include marble, quartz composite or cast stone (like cement). Stone is durable but can be porous and can absorb stains easily. \u201cDepending on how it\u2019s made, it can chip or crack,\u201d said Ms. Hirschhaut, and once that happens, it can be tough or impossible to repair. They can also be quite heavy. The price of stone can really vary \u2014 cement-topped pieces can be under $500, but marble-topped ones will run into the thousands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u25a0 Glass: Glass tabletops can include clear, frosted or tinted versions. They\u2019re relatively inexpensive and \u201ccan create a feeling of space and openness,\u201d Ms. Hirschhaut said. Though glass isn\u2019t susceptible to moisture, it can chip, scratch or crack from heat. It also shows every fingerprint. A good glass table top can last decades if you\u2019re not too clumsy, but it will start to look bad quickly if you\u2019re prone to chipping the edges or scratching the tabletop. You can find large glass-topped tables under $750.\n\n\u25a0 Metal: Metal, including stainless steel, brass, zinc and lacquered or painted versions of these, is used more frequently for table bases than tops. \u201cMetal is durable and not easily damaged,\u201d Ms. Hirschhaut said. But because of its higher-shine, it shows every fingerprint and can require special cleaning tools. Also, painted metals can be hard to repair. These can be less expensive than wood tables, though it\u2019s rare to find an all-metal dining table beyond utility tables.\n\n\u25a0 Plastic and Laminates: Man-made materials, either molded into a shape or glued onto plywood or another core, are an inexpensive option. \u201cThey can last a long time, but aren\u2019t considered the nicest quality material,\u201d Ms. Harris explained. These materials tend to resist staining and require little upkeep, but they\u2019re often perceived as cheap.\n\nCheck for sturdy, reliable construction\n\nPhoto\n\nA good dining table will be sturdy and well-made, with a finish that withstands heavy use and shows little obvious wear. \u201cThe material is a major part of good construction, but a table is only as good as the joinery,\u201d Mr. Dyer said. The joinery is the industry term for the places where the base and tabletop fit together \u2014 the more solid this is, the longer the table will last.\n\nLook underneath the floor sample at the store: Wood joined directly with wood is very strong; too many attachments and hooks can weaken the construction. In general, simpler is better. \u201cLook at the connection points where the legs meet the table tops and at the corners \u2014 if the pieces are starting to separate, you see gaps at the corners, or it\u2019s wobbly when you move it, it\u2019s not well constructed,\u201d Ms. Harris said. And beware of really inexpensive tables: They could be held together just with staples and glue.\n\nA note on chairs for your new table: If you don\u2019t have dining chairs already, the most important thing is to make sure the new ones fit at the table. \u201cPeople used to always buy tables and chairs as sets, but don\u2019t do that as much anymore,\u201d explained Ms. Harris. If you\u2019re starting from scratch and buying online, Mr. Russell suggested buying as a set, but if you\u2019re in-store, you can try out different floor models. \u201cPeople should feel free to mix and match,\u201d Mr. Pourny suggested. In a small space, he also recommends buying extra chairs and using them in other rooms when you don\u2019t need them at the table to save space.", "title": "How to Choose the Right Dining Table for Your Home", "authors": ["Ayn-Monique Klahre"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Like Ms. Ronan, Mr. Chalamet was born in New York. He graduated from Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts in 2013. Along with roles on the television series \u201cHomeland\u201d and in the films \u201cMen, Women & Children\u201d and \u201cInterstellar,\u201d he starred in the Off Broadway production of John Patrick Shanley\u2019s play \u201cProdigal Son,\u201d for which he won the Lucille Lortel Award for lead actor in a play.\n\nOver lunch this month, two days after the Golden Globes ceremony and two weeks before the Academy Award nominations were announced, at Il Cantinori restaurant in Greenwich Village (shrimp scampi for Ms. Ronan and roast salmon for Mr. Chalamet), the pair discussed the eternal lure of coming-of-age films, the nostalgia (and worries) of young people, #MeToo on the red carpet and needing a break.\n\nPHILIP GALANES Favorite coming-of-age films. Go!\n\nSAOIRSE RONAN \u201cDirty Dancing.\u201d Is that coming-of-age?\n\nPG Why not? Baby becomes an adult.\n\nSR I love the way the women support each other. And \u201cRebel Without a Cause.\u201d There\u2019s a romance there, but it feels more platonic. I didn\u2019t realize, until \u201cLady Bird\u201d came along, how starved we are for female coming-of-age stories that don\u2019t revolve around a girl being validated by romance.\n\nTIMOTH\u00c9E CHALAMET The one that took hold of me was a book, \u201cThe Perks of Being a Wallflower,\u201d which was made into a movie later. It\u2019s written in a way that only a young person could speak. And the unabashed lostness of the protagonist \u2026\n\nSR Exactly. I love them because you can see elements of yourself in them.\n\nPG When I was a kid, coming-of-age films \u2014 like \u201cPretty in Pink,\u201d \u201cThe Breakfast Club\u201d \u2014 normalized the march to adulthood. They made it safe. And I was a worrier.\n\nSR So are we. We\u2019ve talked about that before.\n\nPG What do you worry about?\n\nTC When you get to act in things as good as \u201cLady Bird\u201d or \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d you\u2019ve got a huge responsibility to do them truthfully. So that young people watching can say, \u201cI see myself on that screen!\u201d What if I can\u2019t do it?\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nSR Every time I act, I worry: Can I do it again?\n\nTC That\u2019s always at the forefront of my brain.\n\nSR And every time I finish a job, I feel like, \u201cOh God, I got away with that one.\u201d Plus, I\u2019m a people-pleaser. I don\u2019t like upsetting anyone. But I\u2019ve gotten to a point in my work where I need to stand firmly with decisions I\u2019ve made or feel free to go in another direction \u2014 even if everyone around me is telling me to do the opposite. It\u2019s hard.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPG Let me ask about acting. You both have incredibly expressive faces, transmitting complex feelings in a nonverbal way. Do you know how you do it? Is it innate or craft?\n\nSR Well, there\u2019s definitely a practice. The more you do it, the more open you are to accessing feelings. But you know, sometimes you see little kids onscreen, and it\u2019s just amazing how open and uninhibited they are.\n\nPG I\u2019m thinking of you \u2014 and your eyes \u2014 in \u201cAtonement.\u201d\n\nSR And I hadn\u2019t had any training or even life experience at that stage.\n\nPG Are you better on the 13th take, Timoth\u00e9e?\n\nTC As Armie [Hammer, Mr. Chalamet\u2019s co-star in \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d] says, \u201cI wear my heart on my sleeve.\u201d That argues for innateness, I guess. But the greatest lesson for me in drama school was failing, time after time. In my sophomore year, I struggled with this one scene. I never did it right. It was always bad.\n\nPG What was it?\n\nTC It was from \u201cThe Graduate.\u201d\n\nPG You were playing Dustin Hoffman?\n\nTC I was playing Benjamin. But as bad as I was, there was a release that came with the failure. It let me stretch a little more, try something else. It didn\u2019t make me any better necessarily, but it gave me more freedom in my head.\n\nSR Some stage actors have difficulty when they come back to film. The camera can paralyze them. But I love knowing that the camera is watching me and what it needs to see. That\u2019s when craft develops. But I still come back to that childlike sensibility when I act \u2014 to be completely in it and give myself up to it.\n\nTC One of my favorite scenes in \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d is the morning after Elio and Oliver have made love for the first time, and there\u2019s this weird tension that develops. There was some dialogue, and we tried it a few times. Then we tried it without the lines. And it works so much better that way because it\u2019s unclear. It invites the viewer to figure out what the characters are going through.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSR My favorite, favorite thing is not to speak.\n\nPG Walking home, after your films, I started humming \u201cSugar Mountain,\u201d this old Neil Young song about a boy who can\u2019t go to his favorite club anymore because it\u2019s just for teenagers, and he\u2019s turned 20. Your films let you feel nostalgic for childhood.\n\nTC You know what\u2019s weird? My favorite moment in my film is one I shouldn\u2019t be able to relate to: when Michael Stuhlbarg, who plays my father, says, \u201cAs for our bodies, there comes a time when no one wants to come near them.\u201d That moment shatters me.\n\nSR What these films have in common \u2014 even that scene \u2014 is that each moment is so big for the young person experiencing it that they don\u2019t have time to process it properly before it\u2019s gone. That\u2019s the heartbreaking thing about childhood. It\u2019s only at the end you go, \u201cOh, I wasn\u2019t ready for this to be over yet.\u201d\n\nPG There are two uncannily parallel scenes in your movies: Your characters are on emotional overload \u2014 Elio has just said goodbye to his lover, Lady Bird has lost her virginity to Timmy\u2019s character \u2014 and they both fall apart, in cars, with their mothers.", "title": "How to Come of Age Onscreen? Saoirse Ronan and Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet Know", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Table For Three"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Wirecutter, a New York Times company, tested a multitude of light boxes to find the best ones available. A writer, Kit Dillon, found the Carex Day-Light Classic Plus lamp to be effective, safe, and cheaper than several others. It also comes recommended by the Center for Environmental Therapeutics, a nonprofit collective of scientists and clinicians who research environmental therapies. Before you run out and get one, keep in mind that because SAD is a medical condition, even light boxes should be used under the care of a professional.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have SAD, but I did manage to shift my circadian rhythm a bit just from waking up early and taking in small doses of the light before dawn,\u201d Mr. Dillon said. \u201cI\u2019d compare it to something like a strong cup of coffee without the crash.\u201d\n\nCognitive-behavioral therapy teaches you coping skills\n\nOne of the challenges facing SAD patients and the physicians who treat them is its annual recurrence. A SAD expert and the director of clinical training at the University of Vermont, Dr. Kelly Rohan, found that a form of cognitive behavioral therapy tailored to SAD patients works not only when SAD strikes, but can actually help break the cycle.\n\n\u201cCognitive behavioral therapy is a form of talk therapy that seeks to change thought patterns and behavior,\u201d Dr. Rohan said. She explained that C.B.T. and light therapy \u201ccould not be more different.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIn one, you\u2019re sitting in front of a box to jump-start your circadian rhythms,\u201d she explained. \u201cIn C.B.T., a person\u2019s thoughts and behaviors provide an entry point.\u201d In other words, C.B.T. is active and light therapy is palliative. Dr. Rohan\u2019s study found that over time, the behavioral skills C.B.T. instills reduced the recurrence of SAD in a greater proportion of patients than those who used light therapy alone.\n\nDr. Michael Young, past president of the the Society for Light Treatment and Biological Rhythms, said it makes sense that changing one\u2019s behaviors would affect SAD symptoms. While he called Dr. Rohan\u2019s findings \u201ca little disappointing for those of us in the light field,\u201d he also touted the long-term benefits of C.B.T.\n\n\u201cOn the psychological side, part of [C.B.T.] teaches people skills to help themselves,\u201d he said. \u201cOnce people learn those, they don\u2019t tend to forget them. It doesn\u2019t require putting aside half an hour [to sit in front of a light lamp] or continuous meds, which only work if you take them.\u201d He also emphasized the importance of finding a C.B.T.-trained practitioner who has experience treating SAD specifically, since more focused treatment is more effective, over all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExercise and small behavioral changes can keep depression at bay\n\nAll of the experts agreed that, especially when combined with either light therapy or C.B.T., small behavioral changes can make a big difference. Dr. Young recommended heading outside and getting some exercise, especially in the morning.\n\n\u201cPeople\u2019s behaviors can affect biology and psychology,\u201d he said. \u201cFor all sorts of depression, [sufferers] decrease activity, decrease social interactions and decrease activities that give us pleasure because we think we won\u2019t enjoy things. It\u2019s a biological phenomenon: Physical activity is good for our mood.\u201d Even on cloudy days, he noted, the amount of sunlight outside still has a better effect than artificial light indoors.\n\nSo-called natural antidepressants like getting out of the house and staying active can have a great effect on SAD symptoms, Dr. Rohan noted. \u201cI don\u2019t necessarily push people to do winter activities, but find your own way to engage [with the season],\u201d she advised. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to change the hands and trying to change the head, but the hands can change the head.\u201d\n\nDr. Young also advised setting specific times for mood-boosting activities. \u201cIf you don\u2019t put it on the schedule, you\u2019ll get to the end of the day and somehow it didn\u2019t happen. Have a plan,\u201d he suggested. \u201cLife gets in the way, even if you\u2019re highly motivated.\u201d\n\nWhile he has not tested it extensively yet, Dr. Rosenthal has also found success with meditation. He uses Transcendental Meditation, but said other forms may have a similar effect. \u201cYou want to be able to internally enjoy every day,\u201d he explained. \u201cIt\u2019s not a matter of beating the winter, but a matter of embracing it.\u201d\n\nAntidepressant medication can help when nothing else does\n\nSometimes even light therapy, C.B.T., and behavioral changes don\u2019t quite cut it. Dr. Rohan noted that the Food and Drug Administration approves certain antidepressant medications for the treatment of SAD.\n\nSome studies have shown selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (S.S.R.I.s), sertraline (also known as Zoloft) and fluoxetine (also known under the brand name Prozac) in particular have improved SAD symptoms. Another study discovered that patients who started bupropion XL (also known under its brand name, Wellbutrin) before the onset of symptoms actually saw a lower recurrence. In those trials, early antidepressant treatment reduced the overall risk of SAD by about 44 percent.\n\nAs with any other disorder, what works for one SAD patient might not work as well for another. \u201cThe most important thing is, there are options,\u201d Dr. Rohan said. \u201cThere\u2019s no need to suffer in silence.\u201d", "title": "How to Cope With Seasonal Affective Disorder", "authors": ["Lizz Schumer"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "This may explain how an Australian celebrity chef named Pete Evans cannot only promote the health benefits of a Paleo diet but also feel knowledgeable enough to make pronouncements on fluoride, sunscreen and vaccinations. He responded to criticisms in a television interview by saying: \u201cWhat do you need a qualification for? To talk common sense?\u201d He added, \u201cWhy do you have to study something that is outdated, that is industry backed, that is biased, that is not getting the results?\u201d\n\nEngaging is difficult when the alternative-health proponents are on such a different astral plane that it is a challenge even to find common language for a conversation, especially when they promote spurious concepts such as \u201cpyrrole disease,\u201d which they can speak about in great, false detail, drawing the well-informed physician, dietitian or scientist into a vortex of personal anecdote and ancient wisdom, with quips about big pharma thrown in for good measure.\n\nIt is kind of like an aerodynamics engineer trying to argue about alien spacecraft with the founder of a U.F.O. museum. How can an aerodynamics engineer speak with authority on the matter when he or she has not even bothered to research the events at Roswell and is not even aware that there are alien dissection videos freely available on the internet?\n\nCountering the online health gurus is especially difficult when they offer the irresistible cocktail of medical language muddled with a much more pleasing aesthetic than medicine, far from the clinical world of linoleum and antiseptic, a better place where patients\u2019 conditions are diagnosed with metaphors (\u201cadrenal fatigue\u201d) and treated with poetry (holy basil, bone broth, Himalayan sea salt).\n\nJust like that naturopath on Facebook describing herself as a \u201cspecialist\u201d with a \u201cpractice,\u201d alternative-health gurus harness the language of medicine to seem authoritative. They order investigations, adopt protocols. And of course what they say is always half right, which is how pseudoscience works.\n\nBut it is not the vocabulary of science that is important \u2014 it is the methodology. It would be much better if they left the language and took the rigorous approach to evidence instead, which might mean, for example, Goop choosing not to sell an $84 water bottle with amethyst quartz to \u201cinfuse water with positive energy.\u201d\n\nIn the face of this circus, we doctors must hold tight to evidence. We must hold tight to our doubt, our knowledge of our fallibility as individuals and as a profession, knowing that humility is a strength, not a weakness.\n\nBut we must also as a profession engage in the public conversations about health, including on social media, along with our colleagues in allied health fields. If we do not, the discussion will be dominated by the passionately uninformed, who build trust only to sell false cures. And we must listen to patients, as we are taught to do, showing care and understanding. We must take on the difficult challenge of inspiring and motivating with the truth.", "title": "Opinion | How to Counter the Circus of Pseudoscience", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Most people agree that the federal government should tackle public health crises, and there is a particular consensus about the current epidemic involving opioids. The White House announced last fall that President Trump was \u201cmobilizing his entire administration to address drug addiction and opioid abuse by directing the declaration of a nationwide public health emergency to address the opioids crisis.\u201d\n\nYet as of today, there is no permanent head of the Drug Enforcement Administration. The president\u2019s nominee for \u201cdrug czar\u201d to run the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy withdrew from consideration in October and no replacement has been named. The acting chief of staff and general counsel for that office was dismissed last month. All this as overdose deaths continue to rise faster than ever, killing some 64,000 people last year, making the opioid epidemic a top national priority.\n\nWe need to rethink how the federal government carries out this mission. The Food and Drug Administration, in approving new opioid drugs, puts more opioids in the marketplace because these drugs meet the standards for safety and efficacy in treating certain forms of pain. But the more opioids there are in the marketplace, the greater the opportunity there is for abuse. The D.E.A. tries to curb the amount by limiting the number of pills that can be manufactured, but when the agency cracks down on one form of the drug, opioid addicts move to other forms to sustain their addiction. Playing Whac-a-Mole is hardly a strategy.\n\nWhite House czars are largely ineffective because they do not control the agency heads who are legally responsible for carrying out the various congressional mandates of the czars. Historically, the relevant agency heads don\u2019t pay much attention to czars. There is a world of difference between someone whose authority is to coordinate and someone who has the true authority to impose change. Moreover, the president\u2019s drug control policy office has been more heavily focused on law enforcement than on public health strategies.", "title": "Opinion | How to Fight the Opioid Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "The good news is that modern societies have developed a solution to the tragedy: Charge money to use the commons. Doing so not only discourages overuse, it also raises funds that can solve the larger need \u2014 to grow another field where cows can graze, say, or to build a well-functioning subway system. And, yes, I realize that both grazing cows and well-functioning subways sound far-fetched to today\u2019s New Yorkers.\n\nThe charge for using clogged roads is known as \u201ccongestion pricing,\u201d and it works well where it has been tried, like London, Singapore and Stockholm. In New York, the daily charge to drive below 60th Street might be around $8, with additional charges for vehicles that linger all day.\n\nKen Livingstone, the London mayor when congestion pricing began in 2003, has said it\u2019s the only thing in his political career that \u201cturned out better than I expected.\u201d\n\nLondon\u2019s vehicle speeds would be 20 percent to 30 percent lower without the charge to enter central London, the urban expert Charles Komanoff has estimated, and a separate study found a significant decline in crashes.\n\nThe reason more cities haven\u2019t adopted congestion pricing, Livingstone says, is \u201cpolitical cowardice.\u201d People cling to the idea that driving should be free, even though it imposes big costs on others.\n\nIn New York, de Blasio opposes congestion pricing. He instead favors a millionaires\u2019 tax to pay for subway improvements. Higher taxes on the rich are a fine idea, but won\u2019t unclog roads.
