For that, de Blasio has offered a series of small, complex measures, like banning deliveries during rush hour. Good luck enforcing that one.\n\nCuomo is more positive about congestion pricing, but has not filled in the details. He may ultimately support a charge only on taxis and companies like Lyft, Uber and Via. That\u2019s a strangely anti-environment compromise, because it encourages people to own their own cars. The New York of the future should have fewer space-clogging cars, not more.\n\nThe most serious argument against congestion pricing is that it hurts lower-income workers. That argument also falls apart on inspection, though.", "title": "Opinion | How to Get New York Moving Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Cheryl Strayed: A good place to start changing your ex\u2019s place in your psyche would be to reframe the story you\u2019ve told yourself about his power. You\u2019ve given an awful lot of it to him when in truth it resides within you. You describe your wish to be free of your ex as an exorcism, but I encourage you to think of it in another way: not an opportunity to rid yourself of a man you no longer love, but as an opportunity to know yourself and your desires more deeply. One act is an expulsion, the other is an expansion. One is about someone else, the other is about you.\n\nI\u2019m going to guess you\u2019re haunted by your ex not because of who he is (in the end, a man you loathe), but because he represents something to or about you. Danger? Shame? Your own dark impulses, which have thus far expressed themselves only through your relationship with him? Only you can know. I suggest you do the internal work it takes to find out. A therapist can help you in this process, but if that\u2019s not an option, you can also do this sort of emotional excavation on your own, through journaling, contemplation and perhaps conversations with a trusted friend.\n\nSA: We\u2019re often the most stubbornly attracted to those who represent forbidden, or unresolved, aspects of our personality. In this light, it\u2019s worth considering that you\u2019ve cheated on \u201cmultiple boyfriends\u201d with this man. Could it be that your overwhelming desire for him allows you to behave in ways that otherwise violate your sense of self? After all, it\u2019s not exactly \u201csensitive\u201d or \u201cempathic\u201d to betray a series of lovers. I say this not to make you feel guilty but because the path to the truth so often runs through shame. Perhaps being with this man allows you to indulge certain darker aspects of his personality that dwell within you while also disavowing them.\n\nCS: Bingo. This is precisely what I mean when I suggest you consider the narrative you\u2019ve established about your ex, which is all about dichotomy. You\u2019ve described him as your \u201ccomplete and utter opposite,\u201d and yet perhaps what draws you to him are not the ways he\u2019s unlike you, but rather traits or impulses you share. These emerge when you speak to him or even think about him \u2014 and they thrill you. Pay attention to that.\n\nLike Steve, I\u2019m struck by the fact that you cheated on several boyfriends with your ex. He has functioned in your life as someone who disrupts your romantic stability (even if he doesn\u2019t destroy it). We generally see that as a negative, but very likely, in your deepest truth, you wanted or needed that disruption. Do you want or need it now? Your concern about living near your ex \u2014 a concern, I\u2019ll note, you describe as terror \u2014 seems to me to be both a fear and a wish, and it takes you entirely out of the equation, as if his hold over you and your agency is inevitable. But it isn\u2019t. You ask us for advice about how to free yourself of him, but it\u2019s not him you need to be free of. It\u2019s your own desire for the part of yourself he makes manifest.\n\nSA: One other significant aspect of all this is the timing. You\u2019ve settled into a stable marriage and just had your first child. You\u2019re at a moment in your life when everyone expects you to behave like a dutiful and doting mother \u2014 to suppress the uninhibited and frankly destructive lust that made your affair with this man so exhilarating. Nobody knows the precise ingredients of temptation. We can only attempt to know ourselves. That\u2019s ultimately how we gain control of our lives. It\u2019s not that we banish our desires. We simply learn to manage them, so that they no longer hold the power to destroy our happiness.", "title": "How to Get Over an Infatuation", "authors": ["Cheryl Strayed", "Steve Almond", "The Sweet Spot"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Abramson agrees that new killer whales should not be captured, but noted that those already in captivity would not fare well in the wild. Engaging these animals in research hopefully yields insights that will help protect wild populations, he said.\n\nFor their study, Dr. Abramson and colleagues trained Wikie\u2019s calf, Moana, to make five sounds outside of Wikie\u2019s natural repertoire, including that of a creaking door, an elephant and a raspberry. Then they instructed Wikie to copy each vocalization, either by listening to Moana directly or through speakers. Here\u2019s Wikie attempting some breathy raspberries:\n\nThey also tested whether Wikie could emulate six human words or phrases, including \u201cone two three,\u201d \u201cah ah\u201d and \u201cAmy:\u201d\n\nThe researchers first asked human listeners to judge whether Wikie\u2019s calls matched the ones she was asked to parrot. Then they used an algorithm to evaluate her vocalizations, based on features like tonality, rhythm and melody contour.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth human and machine methods deemed Wikie successful at learning the novel sounds presented to her, including those uttered by humans.\n\n\u201cThis is the first study to show that killer whales can make recognizable copies of human sounds,\u201d Dr. Abramson said, which is unexpected because orcas have very different anatomical structures for vocalization than us.\n\nHeike Vester, director of Ocean Sounds, a nonprofit cetacean research organization based in Germany, noted that this research was limited by its sample size of one. While it shows that a captive killer whale can produce novel sounds when trained, it doesn\u2019t reveal how wild orcas use this ability.\n\nDr. Rendell said it is \u201csomewhat ironic\u201d that this study, performed on captive animals, adds to a growing case against keeping orcas captive.\n\nThe learning of culture, including vocal traditions, \u201cis a key capability in the intertwining lives of killer whales,\u201d he said, \u201cand one that is critically harmed in captivity,\u201d where animals are isolated and unable to develop the depth of emotions they would in the wild.\n\nWikie, who was born in captivity, has never acquired the culture she would need to rejoin her wild counterparts, Dr. Rendell added. Based on what she has shown she can learn in captivity, we can only imagine what she would have inherited in the wild.\n\nWhile you consider that, let\u2019s bid farewell to Wikie for now:", "title": "How to Get a Killer Whale to Say \u2018Hello\u2019", "authors": ["Steph Yin"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Occasionally the package may be supplemented with other materials. For example, it may include a news article to show that an investigation has become public knowledge, which could make it more likely that a target is taking steps to conceal his activities.\n\nWhat does the Republican memo say?\n\nAccording to people familiar with it, the Republican memo contends that the application for an order authorizing surveillance of Mr. Page relied on information provided by Christopher Steele, the former British intelligence agent who compiled a notorious dossier about President Trump and Russia, without adequately explaining that the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton\u2019s campaign was funding his Trump-Russia research. The suggestion is that the court was misled about Mr. Steele\u2019s credibility.\n\nDemocrats on the committee, led by Representative Adam B. Schiff of California, maintain that the Republican memo is misleading \u2014 both making inaccurate assertions and omitting context in order to support a Republican narrative that the Russia investigation stems from a conspiracy by partisan F.B.I. officials who were biased against Mr. Trump. For example, people familiar with the memo have said it omits discussion of other evidence cited in the application that stemmed from other intelligence sources and methods, exaggerating the importance of Mr. Steele\u2019s information.\n\nDavid Kris, who ran the Justice Department\u2019s National Security Division early in the Obama administration and helped write a book about FISA, says that when the department submits material from sources to the court, \u201cit should also include information that would cast material doubt on their credibility \u2014 sources often come with bias or baggage of one sort or another.\u201d\n\nBut, he said, \u201cthere is no requirement for elaborate accounting: Courts routinely accept and uphold affidavits that generally describe a source\u2019s shortcomings\u201d without every specific detail.\n\nWilliam C. Banks, a Syracuse University law professor who has studied the FISA Court, said that without reviewing all the documents involved in the surveillance request, it was impossible to judge the importance of how Mr. Steele was described. But he emphasized that the government had broad leeway in seeking FISA warrants.\n\n\u201cCarter Page was doing business in Russia, talking to Russian diplomats who may have been involved in intelligence activities directed at the United States,\u201d Mr. Banks said. \u201cGame over. The standards are incredibly open-ended.\u201d", "title": "How to Get a Wiretap to Spy on Americans, and Why That Matters Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Scandinavia can be one of the most expensive regions in the world to visit, according to Kelly Brennan, a travel adviser at the New York City travel company Indagare. However, Norway \u2014 a country with a bustling capital (Oslo), an unspoiled countryside and stunning fjords \u2014 is the exception.\n\n\u201cNorway is a great choice for travelers on a limited budget who want a luxury experience, because it\u2019s still up-and-coming in popularity,\u201d Ms. Brennan said. She also offered some tips on how to enjoy a luxury vacation in Norway without emptying your wallet in the process.\n\nStay at the Most Upscale Hotels\n\nThe best hotels in Norway are a bargain compared with other countries in Scandinavia and other global tourist destinations.\n\nLuxury properties like the Storfjord Hotel, which is the best place to stay to explore the fjords and the charming town of Alesund, have rates starting at $200 a night. \u201cUpscale tourism is still new to Norway so travelers don\u2019t have to break the bank to enjoy high-end accommodations,\u201d Ms. Brennan said.", "title": "How to Have a Luxury Vacation in Norway for Less", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "How can parents know if a doctor is touching a child in an inappropriate way?\n\nAfter scores of young women testified about being sexually molested by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, the former doctor for the American gymnastics team who was sentenced to 40 to 175 years in prison on Wednesday, their parents wondered how they could have missed the signs. Some were even in the exam room at the time but were unaware that anything was wrong.\n\nDetecting sexual abuse in a medical setting can be challenging. We teach young children that doctors are among the only people allowed to touch their genitals. That can make it confusing if a patient encounters an abusive physician like Dr. Nassar.\n\n\u201cThe natural inclination is to trust a doctor, especially when they tell you, \u2018This is something that will make you feel better,\u2019 \u201d said Scott Berkowitz, president of the Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network, or RAINN.\n\nThat said, parents should trust their instincts. If they\u2019re alarmed by a health provider\u2019s practices \u2014 frequent genital exams, unconventional medical treatments that involve genital manipulation, disregard for rules about using gloves during sensitive exams or having an adult chaperone present during a child\u2019s exam, even inappropriate jokes or comments \u2014 they should question the doctor, get another opinion or switch doctors, experts said.", "title": "How to Keep Children Safe From Abuse at the Doctor\u2019s Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Jensen\u2019s Bangs is a shaggy, complicated, likable man who tries to confront the dark side of the music he loves. The show suggests that Bangs\u2019s approach \u2014 his immersive writing style anticipated the current passion for the all-sharing I \u2014 was fueled by his desire to make music, not just chronicle it. But over all the portrait does not coalesce into much of a point.\n\nMore energetic staging might have helped pull us into Bangs\u2019s world. After he praises a Troggs song for \u201cblasting you through the wall, out across the rooftops, straight outta your box into perfect release in a troposphering limbo of blizzardnoise at last,\u201d he plays the track, but at a meek 3 instead of the necessary \u201cSpinal Tap\u201d 11. That scratch that does not soothe the rock \u2019n\u2019 roll itch.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt least the BRIC House theater\u2019s sound system delivers the necessary volume at \u201cThe Hendrix Project.\u201d But then unlike the wordy \u201cRock Critic,\u201d this show tackles the transformative power of music without a single line of dialogue.\n\nRoger Guenveur Smith follows up plays like \u201cA Huey P. Newton Story\u201d and \u201cRodney King\u201d with another look at an epoch-making African-American man \u2014 but this time his subject is offstage, glimpsed only through grainy videos. What we watch is a dozen 20-somethings who, in turn, are watching Jimi Hendrix at the Fillmore East on New Year\u2019s Eve 1969. The cast members look down at the audience in a scenic device not unlike the one in Annie Baker\u2019s play \u201cThe Flick.\u201d\n\nPerched on the set designer Levi Lack\u2019s rendering of the Fillmore\u2019s mezzanine, the actors are motionless, unsmiling as the music booms around them. This goes on for quite a while. Gradually, they begin to shake off the stillness in Robert Wilson-esque slow motion, still intently staring ahead.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe discrepancy between the deliberate movements and Hendrix\u2019s extroverted guitar freakouts is startling, and part of the achievement of Mr. Smith, who conceived and directed the show: the evocation of an audience\u2019s internal world, as they go from fascinated befuddlement (Hendrix played mostly new material at the Fillmore, as he was introducing his new combo, Band of Gypsys) to euphoria.\n\nArchival footage of Hendrix appears on a screen, flanked by disparate images: war scenes, jellyfish, military parades. These projections are not all that necessary, and the focus remains firmly on the concertgoers, who eventually begin flirting, smoking and drinking; every so often, some slink into the sound booth in the back and canoodle against the window.\n\nMr. Smith tries to freeze-frame a moment in American history. Some of the concertgoers were likely bound for Vietnam, others were or would be involved in the feminist struggle or the black-liberation movement. Nothing much happens: It\u2019s just some people at a show. But the moment is suffused with both elation and unease: A decade was ending, and less than a year later, Hendrix would be dead.", "title": "How to Listen to Rock \u2019n\u2019 Roll in a Theater", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf there are certain days or weeks where you are going to be less available, giving your friend a heads up can go a long way toward minimizing misunderstandings or conflicts where somebody feels left out or like they\u2019re being ignored,\u201d she said.\n\nTell your friends how long you expect to be off the radar, how to communicate with you best during this time (\u201cI\u2019m drowning in emails; texts are better!\u201d), and when your schedule is expected to go back to normal.\n\nNix \u2018I\u2019m too busy\u2019 \u2026\n\nYou might be booked from dusk until dawn, but without giving your friend context, that phrase \u201cI\u2019m too busy\u201d can feel like a blowoff.\n\n\u201cWhen we hear somebody say, \u2018I\u2019m too busy,\u2019 we don\u2019t actually know if that is true for just their lives at this time, or if that\u2019s their way of not really valuing us or wanting to spend time with us,\u201d said Shasta Nelson, the author of \u201cFrientimacy: How to Deepen Friendships for Lifelong Health and Happiness.\u201d\n\n\u201cTherefore, the friendship often just dies, not from lack of anything wrong or anybody even necessarily wanting it to die, but just simply chaotic lives and a lot of distance gets put in there,\u201d she said.\n\nInstead of offering vague, blanket statements about your bustling schedule, qualify your busyness: \u201cI\u2019m busy for the rest of the month,\u201d or \u201cI\u2019m tied up until the end of the year.\u201d Then make a counter offer. If you can\u2019t meet face-to-face anytime soon, suggest a phone date, Skype session, or other way to connect so your friend doesn\u2019t feel abandoned.\n\n\u2026 Then examine your busyness\n\nIf you find yourself telling longtime pals you\u2019re too snowed under to connect, it\u2019s time to look at how you truly spend your time.", "title": "How to Maintain Friendships", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "For some medication and specialized equipment used to administer them, some countries require documents to be submitted to government officials well in advance of your arrival. Ms. Harmon, for example, was questioned at the Singapore airport once for entering with an EpiPen, but she had prior authorization allowing its transport.\n\nKnow the Names and Amounts of Active Ingredients\n\nThe documentation you carry should also indicate the generic and chemical names of the active ingredients, which determines permissibility, not brand names.\n\nFor example, the active ingredient in Benadryl, diphenhydramine, is banned in Zambia in over-the counter products. In Japan, it is allowed only if the amount in a tablet or injection is limited. However, a typical 25 milligram tablet of Tylenol PM in the United States exceeds the 10 milligram maximum amount in a tablet you can bring into Japan. Some countries restrict the overall total amount of an active ingredient an individual traveler can legally import, which may impact longer stays.\n\nReduce or Substitute Medication\n\nIn countries where a medication is allowed, but its amount is capped, reducing your dosage or switching to another available medication is the best way to stay compliant. Allow enough time beforehand to ensure the smaller dose or new medicine works effectively, and consider making the switch before your trip to give yourself time to adjust.\n\nSome medications can be used for several diagnoses. Hormones used for birth control may also be used to treat excessive menstrual bleeding, Ms. Harmon said. \u201cDoctors need to get creative sometimes. Substitutions can allow authorities to accept the drug as a medical need rather than going against the country\u2019s religious or moral code.\u201d\n\nReassess Your Travel Plans\n\nParents with a child doing well on Adderall for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder who prefer not to make adjustments on the fly, or a student with bipolar disorder may want to consider vacation or study abroad locations where the medications they rely on for mental health are not banned or restricted.\n\n\u201cViewpoints on treatment and diagnoses can vary widely,\u201d Ms. Harmon said. \u201cWestern Europe and North America understand that brain chemistry is often at the root of these problems. But some countries, like Russia, do not consider mental health challenges as medical problems and often treat them criminally.\u201d", "title": "How to Make Sure You Travel with Medication Legally", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "For me, a Korean-American adopted to the United States the year of South Korea\u2019s first Olympics in 1988, the 2018 encore has been an occasion I\u2019ve long anticipated. Now, three decades later, the Pyeongchang Winter Games are nearly upon us. And my life so far, book ended by Olympics, feels close to coming full circle.\n\nThe XXIII Winter Games, set among the temple-dotted mountains of South Korea\u2019s northeastern Gangwon Province, will take place February 9 to the 25th. With 102 events, they\u2019re poised to be the most action-packed Winter Olympics to date and feature a number of firsts: history-making attendance by North Korea, the premiere of mixed doubles curling, alpine team skiing, big air snowboarding and mass start speed skating \u2014 and maybe even Afghanistan\u2019s debut Winter Olympians.\n\nIf you\u2019ve been dreaming of spectating, snow-frosted and shivering with glee, like I have, there\u2019s still time. Despite the scant days between now and the opening ceremony, it\u2019s not too late to plan a trip.\n\nIt\u2019s Pyeongchang, Not Pyongyang\n\nWhile the Winter Olympics never attract the same crowds as its splashier warm-weather sibling, the Pyeongchang Games have faced even greater challenges, due in part to their proximity to the peninsula\u2019s demilitarized zone, a mere 40 miles away.", "title": "How to Plan a Last-Minute Trip to the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cObserve toddlers \u2014 they\u2019re the best and funniest fallers out there,\u201d says Tim Cunningham, who has performed in more than a dozen countries with Clowns Without Borders. A pratfall is a staged tumble, often onto your buttocks, for comedic effect. In addition to new walkers, these dramatic spills have long been a go-to move for physical comedians, including Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton.\n\nIt will take you three months of intense physical training (situps, push-ups, squats) to get in shape for pratfalling. \u201cStart low and slow,\u201d says Cunningham, who suggests learning on a padded surface. Don\u2019t linger on the ground (your audience will begin to worry). Right yourself quickly, whether it\u2019s butt-over-head back to your feet or into a handstand. Cunningham has a general rule for impact: no bony parts. \u201cButts and thighs are great,\u201d he says. Avoid landing on your elbows, knees or head. Learn to control your descent and rebound. Once you have that restraint, restore the ungainliness. \u201cThe hard part is making it look gross and sloppy and scary and funny,\u201d Cunningham says.\n\nMost Clowns Without Borders performances occur in war zones or refugee camps, not on a stage. Check first to make sure you have sufficient space free of hazards, which for Cunningham might include broken glass or animal dung. Avoid looking obviously at your landing spot \u2014 to be humorous, your topple must be a surprise. If you can get one person giggling, others will probably follow. Be a catalyst for their joy; it doesn\u2019t matter if they\u2019re laughing at you or at one another laughing. After performing for refugees fleeing Syria, the clowns have been approached by parents who said it was the first time in months they\u2019d seen their children smile.\n\nFind a reason to fall down. Pretend to be frightened by a balloon popping or a child squealing with glee. Or maybe you see someone so beautiful in the audience you trip over your shoelaces trying to get closer. The higher your social status, the funnier your fall is. As a white American, Cunningham often wears a tuxedo and plays the part of the perpetually stumbling boss alongside more sure-footed female clowns. \u201cA good pratfall is like a good story,\u201d he says. \u201cIt has a clear beginning, middle and end.\u201d", "title": "How to Pratfall", "authors": ["Malia Wollan"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Step one: Check your footwear. Shoes and boots should have slip-resistant soles (rubber or neoprene, not plastic or leather). Or equip them with external traction cleats, sold under brand names like Yaktrax.\n\nStep two: Take smaller steps, bend forward slightly, go slow and walk as flat-footed as possible when it\u2019s icy or snowy. Check the steps and sidewalk for black ice before going out in the morning, even if only to pick up the paper or mail. Do likewise when stepping out of a vehicle. Although the air temperature may be above freezing, dew or fog can freeze on a colder surface.\n\nRegardless of the season, scan the path six or more feet ahead of you for trip hazards. Avoid carrying items that block your ability to see the ground in front of you. I once tripped and landed hard on an irregular sidewalk while carrying two shoeboxes in my arms. Even when empty-handed, be sure to pick your feet up to avoid catching a shoe.\n\nNow for the most common place for falls: Your home. Most dwellings contain a catalog of trip hazards, including piles of papers, loose carpets or floorboards, extension cords and clothing carelessly dropped on the floor, not to mention water or grease on the kitchen or bathroom floor. Remove as many of these as possible and wipe up all spills as soon as they happen.\n\nWhile important at any age, these precautions are critical for the elderly. Falls are the No. 1 cause of injury to seniors, one in three of whom can expect to fall each year. Too often the result is a debilitating fracture, loss of independence or death. Nearly three times as many people die after falling (some 32,000 a year) than are killed by guns in the United States. Even when the injury from a fall is minor, it can create fear that prompts people to avoid certain activities lest they fall again.\n\nWhen walking indoors, always wear shoes or slippers with nonskid soles \u2014 not barefoot (unless you want a broken toe), and never just socks unless they have nonslip grips on the soles. My slippers, which are really shoes with rubber soles, reside next to my bed so I can slip directly into them when I get up.\n\nAlways use a handrail when going up and down stairs. Consider installing a railing on stoops that lack them. If the item you want to carry is too big to hold in one hand or arm, ask someone to help. Bathrooms are particularly dangerous, especially for the elderly, who can benefit greatly from safety bars in the tub or shower and next to the toilet. Nonskid mats in the shower and tub and on tile floors are a must for all ages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong other steps to take that can reduce the risk of falling is to maintain physical strength and balance as you age. If you\u2019re uncertain of your stability or agility, consider some sessions with a physical therapist and practice the recommended exercises regularly. Higher levels of physical activity have been shown to protect against falls in a study of Canadian men and women 65 and older.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThink before you climb. Always use a safety stool \u2014 not a chair or ledge \u2014 when trying to reach a high-up item. I now ask a tall customer or store clerk to help retrieve a grocery item on the top shelf, instead of standing on the edge of a lower shelf to reach or knock it down.\n\nAt home, move all frequently used items to lower shelves, or purchase a cabinet that sits on the floor to store them in.\n\nSome experts recommend learning \u201cthe right way to fall.\u201d In the Netherlands, physical and occupational therapists even teach classes on the art of falling. The advice tends to focus on minimizing the risk and extent of injury by landing on soft tissue as gently as possible. It includes trying to stay relaxed as you fall; the stiffer you are, the more likely an injury. As you land, try to roll like a football player.\n\nWhen falling forward, the instinct is to stick out one\u2019s hands to break the impact, which often results in broken wrists instead. If possible, try to twist as you go down to land on a side and then roll over to your back.\n\nWhen falling backward, tuck your chin to your chest to avoid hitting your head, which can result in a concussion, and keep your arms in front of you.\n\nIn all honesty, these measures are more easily described than executed. Several friends of a certain age who have fallen maintain that there was nothing they could do to mitigate an injury in the split second between being upright and lying flat on the ground. But consider mentally reviewing scenarios in which you \u201cpractice\u201d falling more safely by visualizing the measures described above.", "title": "How to Prevent Falls", "authors": ["Jane E. Brody", "Personal Health"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 When pollsters asked Australians a year ago to list three words associated with Australia Day \u2014 the country\u2019s Jan. 26 national day \u2014 the most popular responses were barbecue, celebration and holiday. But among Indigenous Australians, the most popular words were invasion, survival and murder. That, in miniature, is why the country finds itself in the throes of an intense debate over the timing of Australia Day.\n\nJan. 26 is the day in 1788 when the first fleet of ships from Britain entered Sydney Cove. Put simply, the holiday commemorates the British colonization of Australia \u2014 and with it the dispossession of the indigenous population, a centuries-long story of subjugation and countless atrocities, like the Gippsland massacres in the 1840s, in which up to 1,000 indigenous people were killed by white settlers over the course of a decade.\n\nAboriginal Australians have been objecting to the celebration of this date for decades. Back in 1938, for example, around 100 indigenous people held a Day of Mourning on Jan. 26. In recent years, aided by a \u201cChange the Date\u201d campaign and a growing awareness among non-indigenous Australians of what Jan. 26 means to the Aboriginal population, scrutiny of the date has come to dominate public conversations about the holiday.\n\nThis year, a popular youth radio station decided to move its annual \u201cHottest 100\u201d countdown to avoid the date after surveying its listeners. Three local councils in Melbourne have refused to hold Australia Day celebrations this year, two of them suspending citizenship ceremonies for the day. At the federal level, the Green Party started a formal political campaign to change the date. Last year, tens of thousands marched in \u201cInvasion Day\u201d protests \u2014 and those numbers will almost certainly be matched this year. Statues of British explorers have been vandalized recently.", "title": "Opinion | How to Rethink Australia Day", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Strive for linguistic plausibility. In 2014, Sara Maria Forsberg was a recent high-school graduate in Finland when she posted \u201cWhat Languages Sound Like to Foreigners,\u201d a video of herself speaking gibberish versions of 15 languages and dialects. Incorporate actual phonology to make a realistic-sounding gibberish. \u201cExpose yourself to lots of different languages,\u201d says Forsberg, now 23, who grew up speaking Finnish, Swedish and English.\n\nAssemble your raw linguistic materials. Shortly after her YouTube video went viral \u2014 it has since been watched more than 19 million times \u2014 Lucasfilm contacted Forsberg and asked her to make up a language for one of the alien fighter groups in \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens.\u201d The actors were Indonesian, so Forsberg studied online videos in various Austronesian languages including Bahasa Indonesia and Sundanese, a language spoken in western Java. \u201cListen for repeated syllables,\u201d she says. Write them down phonetically. Note the rhythm of the language. Look at the way a speaker\u2019s lips and tongue give shape to his or her words. You don\u2019t need to be a linguist to get an impression of real syntactic rules, which you can borrow. It helps to love listening to the singsong quality of people talking. For Forsberg, \u201cit\u2019s like music.\u201d\n\nKeep nonverbal cues in mind. If you want to communicate, you\u2019ll need to work on your affect, because the words themselves will be gobbledygook. In one study, researchers in Belgium used a computer program to devise gibberish and recorded an actress reading the lines, first in a neutral tone and then in distinct moods: angry, disgusted, fearful, happy, sad and surprised. Most of the children and adult listeners accurately recognized the emotions, especially sadness (correctly identified by over 90 percent of the study\u2019s subjects). Forsberg likes to imagine a character and a scene before she starts speaking gibberish, which allows her to tap those universal emotional cues.\n\nWrite a script. Make sure you repeat familiar syllables and sounds. Read through your script aloud, throwing out anything that seems unnatural or awkward. Once you\u2019re comfortable with your lines, try improvising. Avoid stereotypes. After her video received so many views, Forsberg regretted certain imitations that relied more on cultural clich\u00e9s than imagination and pure sound. \u201cTo speak good gibberish,\u201d Forsberg says, \u201cyou need to learn to really listen.\u201d", "title": "How to Speak Gibberish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Grief has a language all its own, but even the best therapists can get tongue-tied around the tricky stuff. Our grief vocabulary isn\u2019t clinical, and you probably won\u2019t find it in the self-help books that friends hand you after the memorial service. But this does come from some hard-earned experience: We both lost parents as young adults. Loss is messy, melancholic and often darkly hilarious. It also lingers forever. Here\u2019s a glossary that takes all that into account. Use it well.", "title": "How to Speak Grief", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "There was only one reference to the deficit in last night\u2019s State of the Union speech, and it had nothing to do with the federal budget. I found that refreshing \u2014 we can carry a deficit if the money\u2019s spent wisely \u2014 but that\u2019s another story. What President Trump talked about was America\u2019s staggering infrastructure deficit, a whopping $2 trillion fault line in the backbone of the American economy, according to the latest estimates from the American Society of Civil Engineers.\n\nThe president\u2019s proposal sounded like an ambitious plan to take a big bite out of the problem. He urged Congress to produce a bill that would \u201cgenerate at least $1.5 trillion\u201d to modernize our decrepit infrastructure. The problem \u2014 at least for Democrats \u2014 is that the bulk of the financing is apparently supposed to come from private investors, who would ultimately shift most of those costs onto the public in the form of user fees and tolls. Most Democrats won\u2019t sign on to this kind of legislation.\n\nYet without the support of many Democrats, there can be no bill. So where does that leave us?\n\nDoing nothing is itself costly. As water mains break, roadways deteriorate and bridges crumble, businesses forgo trillions in sales, families lose an estimated $3,400 a year in disposable income, and our economy sacrifices millions of jobs. That\u2019s why Larry Summers, the former Democratic Treasury secretary, urged the next president to go big on infrastructure spending.\n\nIf Democrats were in control, they would be pushing not only for the brick-and-mortar projects the president spoke of last night but also for enormous investments in high-speed broadband and renewable energy. Unfortunately, the president wants to spend more money on 20th-century technology \u2014 so-called clean coal \u2014 instead of modernizing our electric grid and reorienting our economy away from coal and other fossil fuels.", "title": "Opinion | How to Spend Trillions on \u2018Infrastructure\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "China is one of the world\u2019s most exciting and rewarding places to visit, but can be intimidating even to experienced travelers, who might struggle with communication and lack of familiarity with rules and customs. Here\u2019s a handful of practical tips to help make sure your trip to the world\u2019s most populous country is smooth sailing from start to finish.\n\nEasier Visas\n\nThe good news: Those annoying and expensive single-entry visas are a thing of the past. Americans can now apply for a 10-year, multiple-entry visa from the Chinese consulate. Download the form from the embassy website, type up the application and bring copies of your travel itinerary to your local consulate or embassy (depending on your location). Several days and a $140 fee later, you should be all set. There are also visa services that, for a fee, will take your application to the consulate for you.\n\nOne other important note: Passport and visa expiration dates rarely line up exactly, creating situations where a passport might expire while a visa is still valid. I found myself in this exact situation before my last trip \u2014 would I have to go through the whole costly and time-consuming application process again? No \u2014 you are allowed to travel on a valid visa that\u2019s in an expired passport as long as personal details like name and date of birth match up exactly (bring both passports).\n\nCashlessness\n\nYou\u2019ll notice blue and green QR codes at nearly every business in China, from the glitziest boutique to the most humble dumpling shop. WeChat Pay and Alipay are gradually turning the Chinese economy cashless: Simply enter the amount you want to pay, scan the business\u2019s QR code, and boom, you have paid directly from your bank account. It\u2019s something of a revolution \u2014 one that you, as a tourist, will not be a part of.", "title": "How to Travel to (and Around) China, From VPNs to T.P.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cChristians Need a New Right-to-Life Movement\u201d (Op-Ed, Dec. 25):\n\nMargaret Renkl proposes a new right-to-life movement in which the contentious issues of abortion, birth control and homosexuality would be set aside. Instead, faithful Christians would unite in assisting the poor and the vulnerable.\n\nUnfortunately, the problems the poor and the vulnerable face are inextricably bound up with the contentious social issues that Ms. Renkl would like to avoid. According to the Guttmacher Institute, in 2014, about 75 percent of all abortion patients were low-income. These women are less likely to have access to birth control. To prevent unwanted pregnancies, and the need for abortion, and to permit women to plan their educational and professional lives, they must have access to affordable and effective birth control and to abortion when birth control fails or fails to be used or when a woman is a victim of coercion.\n\nAccess to accurate sex education for all our children that includes but is not limited to abstinence has also been shown to reduce the number of abortions. It has the added benefit of teaching our children about healthy sexual expression and that it is not limited to heterosexuals.\n\nIn my view, Ms. Renkl\u2019s call for a new right-to-life movement allows faithful Christians to remain ideologically pure while they ignore the real-life consequences of restrictions on access to abortion, birth control and real sex education for the poor and the vulnerable she purports to champion.", "title": "Opinion | How to Truly Help the Poor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The story of how Americans came to peer beyond their own properties is also, inescapably, about race. As urbanization brought blacks and whites closer together, white communities reacted with racially restrictive covenants, aiming to keep blacks and their perceived threat to property values out of white neighborhoods. The Supreme Court ruled such covenants unenforceable in 1948, but they had long-lasting effects on how homeowners looked at the world around them, and the need to control it.\n\n\u201cOne of them was to make white people think that the value of their homes depended on living in a segregated community,\u201d said Carol Rose, a law professor at Yale. \u201cThat outlived racially restrictive covenants.\u201d\n\nAnother shift came with the advent of citywide zoning in New York City in 1916. Nuisance laws had targeted problems like noxious odors or chemical spills that crept across property lines. Zoning, rather than punishing people for proven harms that came from their property, told people what they could do on their property in the first place. And it prohibited many things \u2014 like buildings of a certain height \u2014 that had never been considered nuisances before.\n\nZoning effectively invited homeowners to look beyond their properties in ways they hadn\u2019t. And it helped create the expectation that communities would change little over time \u2014 or that homeowners would have a say if they did.\n\n\u201cPrior to zoning, you didn\u2019t ask yourself if you were buying a piece of property, \u2018What\u2019s the use of the land next to me, or down the block, or half a mile away?\u2019 \u201d said William Fischel, an economist at Dartmouth. \u201cZoning becomes an opportunity for you to think outside the box of the lot lines of your own property. And people definitely start doing it.\u201d\n\nAmericans fretted about property values in the early 20th century (and government documents at the time warned of how racial integration would harm them). But Americans didn\u2019t broadly begin to think of homeownership as a means to create wealth until around the 1970s, when housing started to appreciate faster than many other assets. And once housing became a financial asset \u2014 the largest one many families own \u2014 homeowners began to take more seriously anything they feared would harm it, Mr. Fischel said.\n\n\u201cThe mere possibility that a funeral home three blocks away might cause a funeral procession to go down a street just when a buyer\u2019s there, these remote threats \u2014 almost imaginary threats \u2014 start to become more resonant,\u201d Mr. Fischel said.", "title": "How \u2018Not in My Backyard\u2019 Became \u2018Not in My Neighborhood\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The 10-episode season will present, from start to finish, the book\u2019s story of Dr. Laszlo Kreizler, a brilliant, prickly psychiatrist \u2014 or alienist, in the parlance of the day \u2014 and his team of cohorts tracking a killer who preys on boy prostitutes in the vice-ridden city. The German actor Daniel Br\u00fchl (\u201cRush\u201d) stars as the titular doctor, with Dakota Fanning (\u201cAmerican Pastoral\u201d) and Luke Evans (\u201cBeauty and the Beast\u201d) rounding out the leads.\n\nMr. Carr said the past film attempts failed because producers like Scott Rudin sought to turn his layered psychological tale into a more conventionally formatted blockbuster, proposing to cut characters, add a love story and otherwise abandon the main focus on the team tracking the murderer.\n\n\u201cIf you don\u2019t get what the central dynamic of a book is, you\u2019re not going to be able to make a good movie out of it,\u201d Mr. Carr said. (\u201cI wish him well with the show,\u201d Mr. Rudin emailed in response.)\n\nPhoto\n\nFor all his exasperation, Mr. Carr remained eager for an adaptation \u201cthat enough resembled the book that I didn\u2019t have to fight that battle anymore,\u201d so he could move forward with the next chapter of the saga. He is now working on the third book in the series, \u201cThe Alienist at Armageddon,\u201d slated to arrive in September. (The second, \u201cThe Angel of Darkness,\u201d came out in 1997.)\n\n\u201cIt seemed like a really futile struggle to continue the series when there was no interest in making a decent product out of the first book, much less the second book, much less a future book,\u201d Mr. Carr said.\n\nThat pessimism lifted after the television arm of Paramount, which held the movie rights, was revived in 2013. \u201cThe Alienist\u201d was \u201cliterally the first book I took off the shelf,\u201d said Amy Powell, the studio\u2019s president.\n\nFor TNT, still best known for procedurals and ampersands \u2014 \u201cRizzoli & Isles,\u201d \u201cFranklin & Bash,\u201d \u201cLaw & Order\u201d reruns \u2014 \u201cThe Alienist\u201d heralds a new focus on shows \u201cthat engage people more, that have a stronger, deeper pull on them,\u201d said Sarah Aubrey, TNT\u2019s executive vice president for original programming.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the past few years, the network has forged a new path under the president Kevin Reilly, with more provocative series like \u201cAnimal Kingdom\u201d and \u201cClaws.\u201d But \u201cThe Alienist\u201d represents its biggest swing yet.\n\nIt is the most expensive show the network has produced, Ms. Aubrey confirmed, though she wouldn\u2019t say how much \u201cThe Alienist\u201d cost. (Variety reported that TNT was paying $5 million per episode.)\n\nSet mostly in 1896, the series was shot in Budapest on an elaborate ersatz fin de si\u00e8cle Manhattan set that was designed to allow 360-degree movement of the cameras and actors, where designers obsessed over not just cobblestone streets, costumes and gas lamps but also pocket watches, hairpins and shop windows.\n\n\u201cEvery detail matters,\u201d said Jakob Verbruggen (\u201cThe Fall\u201d), a director and executive producer of the series. \u201cWe could only sell this world if we made it 100 percent believable.\u201d\n\nSuch historical specificity was a big part of what captivated readers of \u201cThe Alienist,\u201d which unfolds in a grimy New York teeming with beleaguered immigrants, sordid brothels, crooked cops and uptown oligarchs, and included real-world figures like Theodore Roosevelt, then a police commissioner, and the financier J.P. Morgan. The philosophical question at its dark heart \u2014 is evil born or bred? \u2014 is debated throughout by the agreeably ragtag group pursuing the killer, which in addition to the alienist includes a crime reporter for The New York Times; a police secretary who was the department\u2019s first female employee; and two quirky detective brothers. Their innovative tactics include what we now recognize as criminal profiling, fingerprinting and forensic science.\n\nPhoto\n\nThough the series is faithful to the team dynamic that animates the novel, there are differences. The killer\u2019s perspective, absent from the book, is introduced early in the series. The reporter character, played by Mr. Evans, is now an illustrator. Sara Howard, the secretary played by Ms. Fanning, has been broadened into a fuller portrait of a young woman trying to be tough enough to thrive in a man\u2019s world without losing her femininity and sexuality, Ms. Fanning said.\n\n\u201cAs women, I think that\u2019s something we all deal with and especially right now, it\u2019s being talked about a lot,\u201d she added, alluding to the ongoing national reckoning with toxic male behavior.\n\nMs. Powell said, \u201cWhen people see it, I think it will be even more relevant than we thought it was when we were working on it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdditional modern resonance can be found in the book\u2019s story of forgotten refugees seeking better lives in a new country and in the economic chasm between its impoverished New Yorkers and privileged ones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can parallel it almost perfectly to certain societies we know today,\u201d Mr. Evans said. \u201cIt\u2019s very topical, and I think people will talk about it a lot and make the comparisons.\u201d\n\nBut what does the toughest critic of all say about \u201cThe Alienist\u201d?\n\nMr. Carr sounded annoyed that his being named a consulting producer meant little in practice. \u201cMy contribution was neither sought or when it was volunteered, paid attention to,\u201d he said.\n\nBut he had no complaints that the project\u2019s original main creative force, Cary Fukunaga (\u201cBeasts of No Nation,\u201d \u201cTrue Detective\u201d), left \u201cThe Alienist\u201d before filming started. His take on the story was too salacious and \u201cnearly completely mistaken,\u201d Mr. Carr said.\n\n(The reason given by the studio for his departure, then and now, was that production delays led to conflicts with his other commitments. Mr. Fukunaga, who didn\u2019t respond to requests for comment, remains credited as an executive producer and is currently working on another Paramount series, an adaptation of the Norwegian comedy \u201cManiac\u201d for Netflix. \u201cCary put a huge fingerprint on the project,\u201d Ms. Powell said.)\n\nMr. Carr also said he liked much of the pilot, the only episode he\u2019s watched, praising in particular the visuals and performances by Mr. Br\u00fchl and Mr. Evans. Finally seeing his most famous story onscreen, after decades of starts, stops and misfires, brought a sense of bifurcation, he said, as he separated his author self from his viewer one in an effort to assess the series\u2019s chances in an overstuffed TV universe. But it brought no relief, at least not yet.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll feel a sense of relief if it succeeds,\u201d he said. \u201cIf it doesn\u2019t, it\u2019s just further frustration.\u201d", "title": "How \u2018The Alienist\u2019 Finally Found a Screen", "authors": ["Jeremy Egner"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Making \u201cThe Daily\u201d has been a singular experience, both for Mr. Barbaro, who had been a business and political reporter for The Times since 2005, and for the founding producers, who came from an equally august \u2014 and entrenched \u2014 tradition, in public radio. Ms. Tobin, the executive producer of New York Times Audio, formerly worked at WBUR; Andy Mills came from \u201cRadiolab,\u201d and Theo Balcomb from \u201cAll Things Considered.\u201d\n\nAll four knew from the beginning that \u201cThe Daily\u201d would stand apart from both the kind of incremental, by-the-book radio news broadcasts that date back to the 1920s and the kind of pure narrative that has made shows like \u201cThis American Life\u201d so popular in more recent years. Rather, \u201cThe Daily\u201d combines elements of both \u2014 often in very different ways from day to day. Over two days last month, for example, an interview with the Times reporter Catrin Einhorn about her reporting on sexual harassment at Ford was followed by an episode consisting entirely of sound clips from throughout 2017, with no preamble or commentary: an audio time capsule.\n\nThe show\u2019s team has benefited from the free rein to produce boldly experimental work, as well as from the considerable intellectual resources represented by their colleagues in The Times\u2019s newsroom. Most episodes of the show center on Mr. Barbaro interviewing Times reporters, focusing especially on how the particulars of the day\u2019s breaking news are shaped by the contours of the beats they\u2019ve covered, in many cases, for years.\n\nIt was, at first, a big ask. \u201cSo often, we were asking the reporter who truly had the least time to spend the most time with us,\u201d Ms. Tobin said. But if the 126 journalists who have appeared on the show have been generous with their time, \u201cThe Daily\u201d has presented a fresh opportunity for them, too.\n\nThe Washington correspondent Matt Apuzzo, who has been featured on 19 episodes, said that taping a spot on the show in the middle of writing a big story often helped him to clarify his approach. The feedback, too, is better: \u201cI think people understand better the time that we put into the reporting, and the time it takes to try to figure things out,\u201d he said. In a particularly frenzied year for news out of the White House, talking with \u201cThe Daily\u201d also helped listeners understand \u201chow we\u2019re trying to make sense of it, in a way that you just can\u2019t do in the printed word,\u201d he added.", "title": "How \u2018The Daily\u2019 Comes Together, One Year In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "For a generation now, the moral journeys of TV\u2019s best shows have mostly run in the other direction. Tony Soprano spent six seasons in therapy yet learned nothing except how to be a better criminal. The corrupt police officer Vic Mackey, in \u201cThe Shield,\u201d rationalized his brutality as what it took to bust gang members.\n\nThe exceptions \u2014 ambitious series about people seeking grace and improvement like HBO\u2019s \u201cEnlightened\u201d and Sundance\u2019s \u201cRectify\u201d \u2014 tended to be overshadowed. Sunnier sitcoms like \u201cParks and Recreation,\u201d from \u201cThe Good Place\u201d creator Mike Schur, dealt with characters who were already decent, not striving to become that way.\n\nOver time, antihero culture spread from premium cable to the mainstream. The bristly protagonists of Fox\u2019s \u201c24\u201d and \u201cHouse, M.D.\u201d broke rules to get the job done. Reality TV made stars of people who, in the credo of that genre, weren\u2019t there to make friends. Antiheroes are de rigueur in noirish streaming dramas like \u201cBloodline\u201d and \u201cOzark.\u201d\n\nThe mind-set even bled into in public life. Donald J. Trump, reality-TV star, in many ways ran an antihero candidacy, contrasting himself with political nice guys like Jimmy Carter: \u201cWe want someone who is going to go out and kick ass and win.\u201d (When he suggested threatening the families of ISIS fighters, he was borrowing a tactic from Jack Bauer in Season 2 of \u201c24.\u201d)\n\nNone of this is to say that antihero stories are necessarily amoral. Some, like \u201cBreaking Bad,\u201d assumed moral universes of retribution and consequences. But they were a kind of rebellion against the pat moral lessons of earlier TV, in which you could count on the good guys to win simply because they were good.\n\n\u201cThe Good Place,\u201d on the other hand, avoided falling into easy moralizing by committing to the idea that becoming good is hard work.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis was built into the structure of \u201cThe Good Place.\u201d For most of the first season, Eleanor Shellstrop (Kristen Bell), a selfish ne\u2019er-do-well, believes \u2014 as part of Michael\u2019s ruse \u2014 that she\u2019s in heaven and was placed there by mistake. So she gets her assigned \u201csoul mate,\u201d the moral-philosophy professor Chidi Anagonye (William Jackson Harper), to teach her to be a better person.\n\nThe result is a running crash course in remedial ethics, with the most madcap name-dropping of the greats of moral thought since Monty Python\u2019s \u201cBruces\u2019 Philosophers Song.\u201d (\u201cThe Good Place\u201d has something in common with the absurdist, meaning-of-life-obsessed humor of the 1970s, like Python and \u201cThe Hitchhiker\u2019s Guide to the Galaxy.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a Season 2 episode, for instance, Chidi brings up the \u201ctrolley problem,\u201d a thought experiment devised by Philippa Foot: You\u2019re driving a trolley and must either continue on the track and kill five people or switch tracks and kill one. Is it better to kill five innocents through inaction or one by choice?\n\nTo give the conundrum some oomph, Michael conjures up an actual trolley, forcing Chidi to live out his dilemma over and over, complete with copious blood spatter. The scene is slapstick, gross-out brilliance \u2014 and a clever illustration of how applying hypotheticals to real life (or a convincing illusion) becomes, er, messy.\n\nThe characters of \u201cThe Good Place\u201d ended up in hell for relative misdemeanors. Eleanor is an oaf, but hardly a murderer. Tahani (Jameela Jamil) is a vain social climber with a jealous streak; Jason (Manny Jacinto) is a sweet dimwit. Chidi\u2019s sins are intellectual paralysis and self-flagellation. (When he learns he\u2019s in hell, he assumes it\u2019s for drinking almond milk: \u201cI knew it was bad for the environment, but I loved the way it coated my tongue with a weird film.\u201d)\n\nThis may seem unfair \u2014 is anyone good enough for The Good Place? \u2014 but it serves a purpose. It\u2019s easy to feel distance from a true monster like Tony Soprano. The characters on \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d on the other hand, have everyday failings. They have work to do \u2014 just like we do.\n\nIn \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d morality is not something you have; it\u2019s something you do. It\u2019s a muscle that requires exercise. The show shares with dramas like \u201cBreaking Bad\u201d the belief that being good is hard. But it doesn\u2019t believe that being good is futile.\n\nThe series feels like part of a wider reaction against the dark TV view of human imperfection, something that was once groundbreaking but has become a commodity.\n\nCBS All Access\u2019 \u201cThe Good Fight, \u201d like its predecessor \u201cThe Good Wife,\u201d is about the conflict between principle and the cynical practice of law. ABC\u2019s \u201cThe Good Doctor\u201d (anyone notice a pattern in the titles?) is a sort of syrupy reverse \u201cHouse\u201d in which the diagnoses come not from a misanthrope but a well-meaning autistic savant.\n\nBut the upbeat sophistication of \u201cThe Good Place\u201d is still rare, in this world and, apparently, in the next. When Ms. Rudolph\u2019s judge agrees to hear the characters\u2019 case, she says that she\u2019s only doing it out of boredom. \u201cIt\u2019s either this,\u201d she says, \u201cor start \u2018Bloodline.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "How \u2018The Good Place\u2019 Became an Antihero Antidote", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGeoffrey said that when you walk in a room full of people, you should set a tone,\u201d he said. \u201cYou should announce yourself. You should look as lovely as possible.\u201d\n\nMr. Buchwald and his four siblings were raised in Brooklyn. His mother, a schoolteacher, was the breadwinner for many years; his father, who worked in the curtain business, lived to be 100. \u201cWe had the kind of household where we could say, \u2018Mother, that is the worst pasta I\u2019ve ever tasted.\u2019\u201d Mr. Buchwald said. \u201cAnd she would say, \u2018Oh go on.\u2019\u201d\n\nAt 16 he enrolled in Brooklyn College, wanting to be an actor, but he worried that it would be more of a passion than a profession. He left school and enrolled in the Army in 1954, and was stationed in Korea after the war had ended. He returned to the college a few years later and graduated. (He has been a trustee of the Brooklyn College Foundation for 20 years and is on the advisory board of the Barry R. Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema at Steiner Studios.)\n\nThrough the early 1960s, he found work in regional theaters, as a business manager and actor. (What kind of acting? \u201cBad acting.\u201d) He found he had a knack for negotiating, and took on work as an agent for actors he met.\n\nHe also took a job as a travel agent specializing in honeymoons, making cold calls to baby boomers who were planning weddings. Many of his colleagues were voice-over artists who dreamed of Broadway or radio glory or even commercial spots. He started representing them too.\n\nIn 1977, Mr. Buchwald opened his own agency. His approach was simple, and he has stuck with it. \u201cEverybody will say, \u2018He\u2019s full of baloney,\u2019 but I don\u2019t lie,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen you\u2019re telling the truth, it can be a disarming thing.\u201d", "title": "Howard Stern\u2019s Superagent Is Getting With the Program", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Recently, for instance, a contributor with the byline Waqas KH published an article about Felix Sater, an associate of President Trump, that he had been paid to post. The site has since deleted the article.\n\nIn place of the unpaid contributors platform, the site introduced new opinion and personal sections that will include paid contributors who will work with HuffPost editors.\n\nThe elimination of the platform, which drove 10 to 15 percent of the site\u2019s traffic, is only the latest change for the site since Ms. Polgreen, 42, took the helm after Ms. Huffington stepped down. In short order, she changed the site\u2019s name and redesigned its home page. Though she is closing one of the site\u2019s most populist components, she has also articulated an inclusive vision for the site inspired by big-city tabloids and local television news and aimed at an ideologically agnostic population of Americans who are \u201cnever going to pay for news.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHer first year has not been without its challenges. Over the summer, HuffPost laid off some 40 employees, including the site\u2019s only Pulitzer Prize winner, David Wood. (HuffPost has roughly 210 editorial employees in the United States, in addition to the 340 who work for its international editions.) Within the company, there was a sense that the Washington bureau had been hit particularly hard, which some viewed as unsettling given HuffPost\u2019s long association with political reporting.\n\nAlso, Ryan Grim, the Washington bureau chief, and Sam Stein, the senior politics editor, left the site last year. Ms. Polgreen has refocused the political coverage to include more in-depth reporting beyond Washington and New York.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re thinking less about how many people are crawling around the halls of Congress asking the same questions to the same senators all day every day,\u201d she said. She added that she wanted to have \u201ca large cadre of journalists\u201d who reported from around the country.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd while Ms. Polgreen has not been shy about sharing her vision for HuffPost and her opinions about journalism \u2014 she has appeared three times on CNN\u2019s media analysis program, \u201cReliable Sources,\u201d since joining HuffPost and is a frequent presence at media events \u2014 not all of her ambitious plans have been borne out yet. Ms. Polgreen, for instance, has yet to hire any reporters outside Washington and New York. She said in the interview that she had been focused first on building out an editing team and intended to hire more reporters this year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTraffic to the site has fallen in the last several years, though Ms. Polgreen said she cared more about connecting with readers than audience size. Neither she nor Jared Grusd, HuffPost\u2019s chief executive, would comment on whether the company was profitable.\n\nDuring the interview, in a conference room that serves as her makeshift office, Ms. Polgreen, a former correspondent and editor at The New York Times, spoke enthusiastically about her global ambitions (almost 60 percent of the site\u2019s traffic comes from outside the United States) and her plans for HuffPost\u2019s business model (she did not rule out offering some sort of subscription product in the future).\n\nShe also showed no concerns about running a historically left-leaning, labor-supporting website owned by the corporate giant Verizon.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re working as part of a company that\u2019s developing really exciting new products that will be consumed on mobile phones,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd we actually work for the phone company.\u201d", "title": "HuffPost, Breaking From Its Roots, Ends Unpaid Contributions", "authors": ["Sydney Ember"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 An oil spill from an Iranian tanker that sank in the East China Sea is rapidly spreading, officials said Tuesday, alarming environmentalists about the threat to sea and bird life in the waterway.\n\nThe tanker, the Sanchi, was carrying 136,000 tons of highly flammable fuel oil when it crashed into a freighter on Jan. 6. On Sunday, the Sanchi sank after a huge blast sent up a great plume of black smoke and set the surface of the water on fire, China Central Television said.\n\nThe bodies of three crew members have been recovered, and the remaining 29 were presumed dead, the Iranian government said. Thirty Iranians and two Bangladeshis were believed to have died.\n\nThe oil slicks from the sunken tanker were growing in size, China\u2019s State Oceanic Administration said Tuesday. There are now two huge slicks covering 52 square miles, compared with just four square miles the previous day. Strong winds were pushing the spill toward Japan, away from China, and it was now less than 200 miles from Naha, Japan.", "title": "Huge Oil Spill Spreads in East China Sea, Stirring Environmental Fears", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Reviewing a 1989 performance by Mr. Masekela in New York City, Peter Watrous wrote in The New York Times: \u201cMr. Masekela, playing the cornet, contrasted short melodies against bristling long lines that flowed with the authority and phrasing reminiscent of the trumpeter Clifford Brown. When he sang, in the hoarse shout of the township music from Johannesburg, the band percolated behind him. The show ended with a tribute to Nelson Mandela, which had the audience both dancing and holding fists in the air.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Masekela tended to emphasize the breadth of the musical tradition that inspired him. \u201cI was marinated in jazz, and I was seasoned in music from home,\u201d he said in a 2009 interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. \u201cSong is the literature of South Africa.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cThere\u2019s no political rally that ever happened in South Africa without singing being the main feature.\u201d\n\nThroughout his time in exile, Mr. Masekela remained committed to seeing democracy implemented in his home country. His son, Sal Masekela, noted in a statement that \u201cdespite the open arms of many countries, for 30 years he refused to take citizenship anywhere else on this earth\u201d because of his belief \u201cthat the pure evil of a systematic racist oppression could and would be crushed.\u201d\n\nRamopolo Hugh Masekela was born on April 4, 1939, in Witbank, South Africa, a coal-mining town near Johannesburg. His father, Thomas Selema Masekela, was a health inspector and noted sculptor; his mother, Pauline Bowers Masekela, was a social worker.\n\nAs a young child, Mr. Masekela was raised primarily by his grandmother, who ran an illegal bar for mine workers. \u201cOne of the great things also about Witbank was that all these people brought their different music and their different stories about where they came from,\u201d he said of the miners. \u201cAs a little kid, I hung out with them in the backyard and the kitchen and I knew all about their countries.\u201d\n\nWhen he was 12, he entered St. Peter\u2019s Secondary School, a boarding school in Rosettenville, closer to Johannesburg. By that point he had already begun to pursue music, singing in groups on the street and learning piano in private lessons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe grew infatuated with the trumpet in 1950, after seeing Kirk Douglas in the film \u201cYoung Man With a Horn,\u201d based on a novel inspired by the life of the trumpeter Bix Beiderbecke.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt St. Peter\u2019s, he was encouraged to pursue music by Archbishop Trevor Huddleston, an influential anti-apartheid advocate and organizer. He took lessons from Uncle Sauda, an esteemed local trumpeter, and quickly mastered the basics. Archbishop Huddleston established the Huddleston Jazz Band, a youth orchestra, partly to give Mr. Masekela an opportunity to play, and later, during a trip to the United States, he met Louis Armstrong, who had a trumpet sent to the band. The instrument made its way into Mr. Masekela\u2019s hands.\n\nBy 1956, Mr. Masekela was performing in dance bands around Johannesburg and in cities across the country. In 1959, he played in the pit band of the hit musical \u201cKing Kong,\u201d with music composed by the seminal South African pianist Todd Matshikiza.\n\nThe next year he joined Abdullah Ibrahim (then known as Dollar Brand) and four other upstart instrumentalists in the Jazz Epistles, South Africa\u2019s first bebop band of note. With a heavy, driving pulse and warm, arcing melodies, their music was distinctly South African, even as its swing rhythms and flittering improvisations reflected affinities with American jazz.\n\n\u201cThere had never been a group like the Epistles in South Africa,\u201d Mr. Masekela said in his 2004 autobiography, \u201cStill Grazing: The Musical Journey of Hugh Masekela,\u201d written with D. Michael Cheers. \u201cOur tireless energy, complex arrangements, tight ensemble play, languid slow ballads and heart-melting, hymnlike dirges won us a following, and soon we were breaking all attendance records in Cape Town.\u201d\n\nThe group recorded just one album, which was printed in a run of 500 and eventually became a kind of Holy Grail for collectors.\n\nAfter the so-called Sharpeville massacre in March 1960, in which 69 protesters were killed by police officers in a township outside Johannesburg, the government banned public gatherings of more than 10 black people. This forced groups like the Jazz Epistles to take their performances underground; Mr. Masekela and Mr. Ibrahim soon chose to leave the country.\n\nIn 1960, Mr. Masekela moved briefly to London, where he studied at the Guildhall School of Music, before the singers Harry Belafonte and Miriam Makeba helped him secure a scholarship to attend the Manhattan School of Music. He studied classical trumpet there for four years.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1962, he recorded his debut album, \u201cTrumpet Africaine,\u201d for the Mercury label. He followed it in 1964 with \u201cGrrr,\u201d also on Mercury. That album \u2014 which featured the trombonist Jonas Gwangwa, a veteran of the Jazz Epistles who had also relocated to New York \u2014 included a number of Masekela originals that reflected his devotion to his musical roots. On tunes like \u201cSharpeville,\u201d the effortless churn of the rhythms and the thrumming harmonies reflected the influence of marabi, an instrumental style developed in the early 20th century by workers in the townships outside Johannesburg.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring this time, Mr. Masekela often wrote instrumental arrangements for Ms. Makeba. Their partnership turned romantic, and the couple married in 1964. The marriage ended in divorce two years later, but the two later continued to collaborate.\n\nMr. Masekela is survived by a son, Sal Masekela, from his relationship with Jessie Marie Lapierre; a daughter, Pula Twala, from his relationship with Motshidisi Jennifer Ndamse; and his sisters, Elaine and Barbara Masekela. Three other marriages \u2014 to Chris Calloway, Jabu Mbatha and Elinam Cofie \u2014 also ended in divorce.\n\nIn 1964, Mr. Masekela and Stewart Levine, a fellow student at the Manhattan School, established the independent label Chisa, named for the Zulu word for \u201cburn.\u201d The two would remain lifelong collaborators and friends.\n\nThe label struck gold in 1968 when Mr. Masekela released the album \u201cThe Promise of a Future,\u201d featuring \u201cGrazing in the Grass.\u201d With a sanguine two-chord hook, the song registered as a beatific ode to summer; it was released in May and hit No. 1 on the Billboard charts in mid-July.\n\nBy that time, Mr. Masekela had begun to sing; on other tracks on the album, including \u201cVuca (Wake Up)\u201d and \u201cBajabula Bonke (The Healing Song),\u201d he sang in Zulu, sounding tones of uplift and resistance.\n\nBut alongside success came overindulgence. Mr. Masekela developed a dependence on alcohol early in his career, and by the early 1970s he was addicted to cocaine, as well. His substance abuse began to inhibit his work. \u201cNo recording company was interested in me,\u201d he told the music historian Gwen Ansell last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe sought solace on his home continent. \u201cFor me, songs come like a tidal wave,\u201d he said. \u201cAt this low point, for some reason, the tidal wave that whooshed in on me came all the way from the other side of the Atlantic: from Africa, from home.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 1970s, Mr. Masekela toured sub-Sarahan Africa and began a partnership with the Nigerian musician Fela Kuti, who had recently pioneered the genre known as Afrobeat. He also worked with the exiled South African saxophonist Dudu Pukwana and began fronting the Ghanaian group Hedzoleh Soundz. He recorded two albums with the group, \u201cIntroducing Hedzoleh Soundz\u201d and \u201cI Am Not Afraid,\u201d and toured the United States with them in 1974.\n\nPartly thanks to Mr. Kuti\u2019s influence, Mr. Masekela began to record longer, more immersive tracks, using electronic effects and letting grooves linger for minutes on end. That style is heard to perhaps its greatest effect on \u201cThe Boy\u2019s Doin\u2019 It,\u201d which Mr. Masekela recorded in Lagos with Nigerian musicians in 1975.\n\nWhen he kicked his addictions in the 1990s, Mr. Masekela established the Musicians and Artists Assistance Program of South Africa, to help South Africans battle substance abuse.\n\nIn 1980, Mr. Masekela returned to Africa. He settled in Botswana, where he set up a mobile recording studio and recorded two albums. In 1987, he traveled to London to record the album \u201cTomorrow,\u201d which included \u201cMandela (Bring Him Back Home).\u201d\n\nMr. Masekela moved back to South Africa in 1990, the year Mandela was released from prison. He continued to record and tour around the world into his mid-70s.\n\nIn 2010, Mr. Masekela was awarded the Order of Ikhamanga in gold, South Africa\u2019s highest medal of honor. Since 2014, Soweto has been the site of an annual Hugh Masekela Heritage Festival, with the stated aim \u201cto restore our South African heritage and to uplift the local artisans of Soweto.\u201d", "title": "Hugh Masekela, Trumpeter and Anti-Apartheid Activist, Dies at 78", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wilson, Vincent Canby wrote in reviewing the film for The New York Times, \u201cknows what he\u2019s about.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe remains unembarrassed by the material,\u201d Mr. Canby wrote. \u201cThe movie plows through one outrageous sequence to the next with the momentum of a freight train.\u201d\n\nThe movie was a box-office hit and spawned numerous sequels, though Mr. Wilson was not involved in those.\n\nHugh Hamilton Wilson Jr. was born on Aug 21, 1943, in Miami. His father was a surveyor, and his mother, the former Frances Nugent, was a housewife.\n\n\u201cMy father had a really nice, gentle sense of humor, and my mother had kind of a saberlike sense of humor,\u201d he told the archive. \u201cI\u2019m maybe a mix of those two.\u201d\n\nHis family got its first television set when he was in second grade. He was especially intrigued by the commercials of the day.\n\n\u201cThey were kind of cooler than the shows,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I thought to myself, maybe I could get into advertising.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Florida in 1965 with a journalism degree, he went to New York to try to crack Madison Avenue, but had no luck and took a job in the advertising department of the Armstrong Company, a maker of flooring and related products in Lancaster, Pa.\n\nPhoto\n\nEvery year Armstrong would bring its sales representatives to Lancaster from around the country, and Mr. Wilson\u2019s department would put on a show for them introducing new products, hiring actors from New York to perform the skits and songs.\n\nThat is how he met Tom Patchett and Jay Tarses, struggling performers who would soon form a comedy team, with Mr. Wilson serving as their road manager. After Mr. Wilson split off from them for a job at an advertising agency in Atlanta, Mr. Patchett and Mr. Tarses ended up in Los Angeles as comedy writers.\n\nWhen Mr. Wilson visited them on a West Coast trip and expressed a desire to switch to comedy writing himself, they arranged an interview with Grant Tinker, Mary Tyler Moore\u2019s husband and co-founder of her production company, MTM Enterprises. Though 30 years old, he took a job as a gofer.\n\n\u201cThey all said, \u2018You\u2019re too old to be getting sandwiches,\u2019 \u201d he recalled of cast and crew members\u2019 reactions to seeing him on the set. But the job allowed him to observe the TV-making process, and in 1976 he was given the chance to write some episodes of \u201cThe Bob Newhart Show\u201d and \u201cThe Tony Randall Show.\u201d\n\nOne day Mr. Tinker came through the Randall show\u2019s set asking if anyone had any ideas for new pilots. Mr. Wilson responded with the pitch for \u201cWKRP,\u201d honing it by spending a week at WQXI, a radio station in Atlanta where he knew a lot of the staff from his advertising days.\n\n\u201cI wanted the show to be authentic in the eyes of people who worked in radio stations,\u201d Mr. Wilson explained. \u201cAnd it all was, except I wanted turntables, and by then they were using cassettes.\u201d\n\nHe said his favorite episode \u2014 it is many fans\u2019 as well \u2014 was \u201cTurkeys Away,\u201d from Season 1.
