The episode, inspired by a real story one of his Atlanta friends had told about an ill-conceived Thanksgiving promotion, involved throwing live turkeys out of a helicopter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an era dominated by comedies like \u201cM*A*S*H,\u201d \u201cThree\u2019s Company\u201d and \u201cHappy Days,\u201d \u201cWKRP\u201d was never a huge ratings success \u2014 partly, Mr. Wilson said, because its time slot was changed several times during its run. But it captured new fans later when it ran in syndication.\n\n\u201cWe were kind of an after-the-fact hit,\u201d he said.\n\nIn 1991 a sequel, \u201cThe New WKRP in Cincinnati,\u201d made its debut. Though it had Mr. Wilson\u2019s name on it as creator, he was not involved with the new show. It ran in first-run syndication for 46 episodes.\n\nMr. Wilson used Mr. Reid again in \u201cFrank\u2019s Place,\u201d a 1987 show he created that lasted only a year but that won Mr. Wilson an Emmy for outstanding writing in a comedy series. He also created the series \u201cThe Famous Teddy Z.\u201d\n\nIn addition to \u201cPolice Academy,\u201d Mr. Wilson\u2019s films as a director included \u201cGuarding Tess\u201d (1994), starring Shirley MacLaine and Nicolas Cage, and \u201cThe First Wives Club\u201d (1996), with Goldie Hawn, Diane Keaton and Bette Midler.\n\nMr. Wilson is survived by his wife of almost 40 years, the former Charters Smith; his children, Cannon Wilson Sayers, Price Wilson White, Margaret Wilson Thomas, Caroline Charters Wilson and Hugh Patrick Wilson; and four grandchildren.\n\nAfter moving to Virginia from Los Angeles in 1992, Mr. Wilson sometimes taught screenwriting at the University of Virginia. A few years ago, he said, he tried to get back into television, floating a show idea in Hollywood, but got nowhere. He said he fully understood why no one was interested in an aging TV writer, even one with his r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\n\u201cI know the feeling,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen I was working on \u2018KRP\u2019 or \u2018Bob Newhart,\u2019 if some \u2018I Love Lucy\u2019 writers came in and wanted a job, we\u2019d go, \u2018Please; you\u2019re so done.\u2019 So what goes around comes around.\u201d", "title": "Hugh Wilson, Who Created \u2018WKRP in Cincinnati,\u2019 Dies at 74", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople are skipping doses, people are rationing, people are going into bankruptcy because of this drug,\u201d he said in an interview, arguing that Humira is both more expensive per dose and has a far higher volume than Daraprim.\n\nAbbVie, which was spun off from Abbott Laboratories in 2013, declined to comment.\n\nHow much you actually pay out of pocket, and whether you can afford Humira at all, depend on your insurance and eligibility for discounts.\n\nAnne Marie Garza, 51, an administrative assistant in Houston who suffers from colitis and Crohn\u2019s disease, said she had held off buying her latest dose because her insurer had changed. She was trying to see if she could avoid an out-of-pocket payment of more than $1,200, one of two she would have to make this year, on top of her rising expenses for vitamins and supplements to manage the disease. She has relatively good insurance, but the payments will strain her budget.\n\n\u201cDuring the holidays, I was contemplating what am I\u2019m going to do,\u201d she said. \u201cI was thinking should I just go on a liquid diet, because I can\u2019t afford this.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a difficult choice.\n\n\u201cIt does give you your life back,\u201d she said of the drug. \u201cI literally couldn\u2019t go away from the house or very far from a bathroom, 20, 25 times in the bathroom all day long, I can\u2019t imagine living like that,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cI was becoming a hermit because I was so sick.\u201d\n\nHumira, which accounted for nearly two-thirds of AbbVie\u2019s $25.6 billion in revenue in 2016, was not simple to develop. It is among a new class of drugs known as biologics, which are made from living cells rather than synthetic chemicals. The industry has argued that high American prices are needed to fund drug development, but a 2016 study published by the Journal of the American Medical Association found \u201cno evidence of an association between research and development costs and prices; rather, prescription drugs are priced in the United States primarily on the basis of what the market will bear.\u201d\n\nCompetitive pressures have been muted. Copies of biologic drugs, known as biosimilars, are not as easy to produce as normal generic drugs, and AbbVie\u2019s aggressive patent strategy has allowed it to further push off rivals. While there are name brand competitors to Humira, they are not exactly alike, complicating efforts by doctors or insurers to switch a patient from one drug to another.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLooking at the international picture tells its own story about drug costs. A prefilled carton with two syringes costs $2,669 in the United States, compared with $1,362 in Britain, $822 in Switzerland and $552 in South Africa, according to a 2015 report from the International Federation of Health Plans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got the largest market for pharmaceuticals, which has the highest prices,\u201d said Christopher Raymond, senior biotech analyst at Piper Jaffray. \u201cThat doesn\u2019t make any sense.\u201d\n\nBut it is typical. Other countries have single-payer systems, like Britain\u2019s National Health Service, that negotiate with drug companies or governments that exert price controls.\n\nAbbVie has put some of its earnings to work lobbying against efforts at price controls in the United States, recently in California. The industry also successfully lobbied in 2006 to bar Medicare from negotiating over drug prices. While President Trump once talked about taking action on drug prices, his administration did not follow through in the health care debate last year.\n\nBy contrast, Britain\u2019s National Health Service, while strained of late, has more formidable negotiating leverage.\n\n\u201cI do think we need something like that in the United States, not the N.H.S. broadly, but some means of dealing with the extreme pricing instances,\u201d said Richard Evans, founder of SSR Health.\n\nAn analysis by the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review found that Humira\u2019s list price would need to be discounted by at least 55 percent to be cost effective for rheumatoid arthritis, its originally approved use.\n\nDr. Steven D. Pearson, the founder of the institute, which provides cost benefit data to health plans, said competing drugs were overpriced as well.\n\n\u201cEven in a space like this, where there is a lot of competition, we don\u2019t see the prices coming down,\u201d he said. \u201cThat speaks to the fact that it doesn\u2019t often function like a free market usually would.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor now, Americans have to rely on the generosity of the drug industry, such as it is. I took a spin through AbbVie\u2019s corporate Code of Conduct, entitled \u201cInspired by Integrity.\u201d It\u2019s a lofty document. \u201cWE ARE COMMITTED TO IMPROVING PATIENTS\u2019 LIVES,\u201d it says, in all caps.\n\nIt even makes a point of saying that AbbVie supports the United Nation\u2019s Universal Declaration of Human Rights. That declaration, if you read it, says, \u201cEveryone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care.\u201d\n\nAbbVie joined a few of its rivals in saying it would limit price increases to single digits this year, and so only raised Humira by another 9.7 percent this month, roughly four and a half times the inflation rate. For the drug industry, that counts as generosity.", "title": "Humira\u2019s Best-Selling Drug Formula: Start at a High Price. Go Higher.", "authors": ["Danny Hakim"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "His apprehension, on the same single charge that could have been brought years ago, is the latest development in one of the most damaging affairs in modern C.I.A. history. But it does nothing to settle the question of how or whether Mr. Lee was involved. For years, he was the prime suspect in a mole hunt, but officials disagreed over whether he was actually to blame.\n\nOne government official said there was no plan at the moment to charge Mr. Lee with espionage, handing over American secrets to the Chinese or anything beyond the one felony count of illegally possessing classified information. That would leave open the mystery of how China managed to unravel the C.I.A.\u2019s web of informants.\n\nNeither the F.B.I. nor the Justice Department would discuss this high-stakes back story on Wednesday. \u201cThis is an example of the system working,\u201d said Ian Prior, a Justice Department spokesman. \u201cThe defendant arrived in this country, we apprehended him and he has been charged with an extremely serious offense.\u201d\n\nIn an email, Mr. Lee\u2019s college-age daughter declined to discuss the case and said that no lawyer or family member was available to speak on his behalf.\n\nThe New York Times revealed the decimation of the C.I.A.\u2019s network last year, citing 10 current and former government officials, who were not authorized to speak publicly about the investigation. Several of them identified Mr. Lee as the key suspect at the time.\n\nMr. Lee, 53, took an unremarkable path through the C.I.A. He became a United States citizen and, after four years in the Army, studied international business management at Hawaii Pacific University. He graduated in 1992 and received a master\u2019s degree in human resource management the next year.\n\nFrom there, he joined the C.I.A., posing as an American diplomat while serving as a clandestine case officer. From old address records, he appears to have served in Tokyo from about 1999 to 2002. Officials say he also worked at the East Asia Division at C.I.A. Headquarters and the agency\u2019s Beijing station before he left in 2007 and took a job in Hong Kong.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the C.I.A. noticed in late 2010 that its spies were disappearing, suspicion did not immediately turn to Mr. Lee, according to current and former officials. But as fears of a mole grew, the government set up a secret task force of C.I.A. officers and F.B.I. agents. A veteran F.B.I. counterintelligence agent, Charles McGonigal, was assigned to run it, former American law enforcement officials said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs the disappearances continued, analysts concluded that Mr. Lee, even though he had been out of the C.I.A. for years, had known the identities of many of the those who had been killed or imprisoned. He showed all the indicators on a government matrix used to identify potential espionage threats, one former official recalled.\n\nBut warning signs can be wrong. At the C.I.A., top officials ruefully remembered the treatment of Brian J. Kelly, an agency officer who in the 1990s was wrongly suspected by the F.B.I. of being a Russian spy. More recently, the Justice Department\u2019s efforts to unearth Chinese spies have suffered embarrassing setbacks, including dropped charges against prominent Chinese-Americans.\n\nIn Mr. Lee\u2019s case, other possible explanations existed. Some investigators believed that China had cracked the C.I.A.\u2019s system for communicating with its informants. The spy agency had encountered similar problems in other countries, and some investigators believed the technology was too clunky to stand up to China\u2019s sophisticated computer specialists.\n\nAnother group accused C.I.A. officials in Beijing of being sloppy and allowing themselves to be identified when meeting with their informants. It was an acrimonious dispute, and some officials conceded that a combination of factors could account for the damage.\n\nSome former officials who reviewed the evidence described the case against Mr. Lee as strong but circumstantial, not bulletproof. Some at the C.I.A. argued that officials were too quick to suspect a mole \u2014 especially a Chinese-American \u2014 when there were other explanations.\n\nThe F.B.I. was watching in August 2012 when Mr. Lee returned to the United States with his family. Agents secretly entered his hotel rooms in Hawaii and Virginia and discovered two small books with handwritten notes that contained classified information, including the identities of undercover C.I.A. officials, court papers show.\n\nThe information the books contained, including details about meetings between C.I.A. informants and undercover agents, as well as their real names and phone numbers, matched documents that Mr. Lee had written while at the C.I.A., according to court documents. It was not clear whether any of the people identified in his documents were part of the Chinese roundup of C.I.A. sources.\n\nAgents spoke with him repeatedly in the following months. Both the attorney general at the time, Eric H. Holder Jr., and Robert S. Mueller III, then the F.B.I. director, were personally briefed on the investigation and pledged whatever resources were necessary. But senior government officials said they cannot recall any serious push to arrest Mr. Lee at the time or to try to charge him with espionage in connection with the lost Chinese informants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo in June 2013, the agents let Mr. Lee leave. Current and former officials have said that the C.I.A.\u2019s losses had ended by late 2012, so there is no evidence that the decision allowed more informants to be captured or killed.\n\nAt least once in recent years, according to a government official, Mr. Lee returned to the United States without attracting the F.B.I.\u2019s attention. It was not clear how or why he did so.\n\nAt some point the Justice Department decided that if it had the chance, it would charge Mr. Lee. Officials suspected that opportunity might come later this year when Mr. Lee\u2019s daughter graduated from college, an occasion that might draw him back to the United States.\n\nWhen Mr. Lee surprised the government recently by booking a trip to New York, prosecutors hurried to file the charge that they had kept waiting for years.", "title": "Hunting a C.I.A. Mole, Agents Gambled and Let a Suspect Return to China", "authors": ["Matt Apuzzo", "Adam Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Assured Guaranty, a company that has insured some of Puerto Rico\u2019s bonds, said in a statement Thursday that the plan was \u201cfiscally irresponsible\u201d for failing to identify real economic reforms, and \u201cwould insure that Puerto Rico would be distracted by years of costly litigation.\u201d It warned that Puerto Rico\u2019s actions could shake confidence in the entire public finance system of the United States, making it more expensive for all states and cities to raise money for infrastructure and essential services.\n\nThe federal government has questioned whether Puerto Rico is as cash-poor as it says. On Jan. 9, the Treasury Department and FEMA notified Puerto Rico it could not begin drawing on its share of a $4.9 billion disaster-relief loan approved by Congress, because the territory still has about $1.7 billion in cash available to spend on its own \u2014 as well as another $6.9 billion in cash \u201con deposit in over 800 accounts across all Commonwealth governmental entities.\u201d\n\nLast Friday, the oversight board asked Puerto Rican officials about the $6.9 billion, which was discovered in December. About $4.3 billion was said to be tied up in funding for other government agencies, even as utilities struggle to make ends meet.\n\nPuerto Rico declared a form of bankruptcy last May, giving the island a way to decide how much to cut pensions, debt payments and other obligations under federal court supervision. The board will represent the Puerto Rican government in the proceedings \u2014 but first it must accept the governor\u2019s fiscal plan by Feb. 23. If it disagrees, it is empowered to impose its own fiscal plan on the island.\n\nThe board has been at odds with Puerto Rican leaders over how to restore fiscal balance after years of the island spending more than it had and borrowing to make up the difference. The board, for example, has insisted on reducing public employee pensions by 10 percent, on average, as a way to spread the economic suffering evenly among Puerto Ricans. Mr. Rossell\u00f3 maintained on Wednesday that the pensioners are too \u201cvulnerable\u201d a population.\n\n\u201cThe Oversight Board views implementing structural reforms and investing in critical infrastructure as key to restoring economic growth and increasing confidence in residents and businesses,\u201d Natalie Jaresko, the board\u2019s executive director, said in a statement. \u201cOur focus in certifying the revised plans will be to ensure they reflect Puerto Rico\u2019s post-hurricane realities and provide a realistic basis\u201d for recovery and sustainability.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Rossell\u00f3 announced his intention to privatize the power authority. The governor said that privatizing it would make electricity cheaper and more reliable and attract more business to the island. He also suggested that the proceeds from selling Prepa to private investors could be used to pay the pensions of retired public workers.", "title": "Hurricane-Torn Puerto Rico Says It Can\u2019t Pay Any of Its Debts for 5 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI started when I was 12 years old and I\u2019ve been hutting my way through football for 55 years \u2014 but I have no clue why,\u201d Theismann said.\n\nAlthough the former Giants defensive end Justin Tuck offered no insight into the source of \u201chut,\u201d he was unequivocal that quarterbacks had no choice but to use it.\n\n\u201cCan you imagine if they said, \u2018Bacon-bacon-bacon?\u2019\u201d Tuck told NFL Films several years ago. \u201cEveryone on the line would be like, \u2018Where, where?\u2019\u201d\n\nA dig into the etymological roots of \u201chut\u201d must begin at \u2026 \u201chike!\u201d\n\nThat call was the brainchild of John Heisman, the pioneering coach for whom the trophy for the best college player of the year is named.\n\nBeginning in the late 1890s, Heisman helped spread the growth of the game like a coaching Johnny Appleseed through jobs in Ohio, Alabama, South Carolina, Georgia and Texas. A tireless innovator, Heisman, promoting the forward pass, divided the game into quarters and, in 1898, came up with \u201chike\u201d as a way for an entire team to know when the ball would be snapped into the backfield.\n\nBefore then, backs used silent gestures to begin plays. Heisman, a part-time stage actor who had been trained as a lawyer, prized gifted oratory and preferred a dynamic sound that would spring his charges into action. Hike fit the bill and also aptly described what was happening: a ball hiked backward from the ground.\n\nQuarterbacks nationwide dutifully summoned the ball with a resolute \u201chike\u201d for most of the first half of the 20th century.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn time, however, like so many things in football \u2014 where there is too much time to think between game weekends \u2014 the unadorned hike became increasingly complicated.\n\nAgain, Heisman played a part. Another of his innovations was a sudden shift of backfield players before the snap, which allowed Heisman\u2019s teams to overload one side of a formation. To augment the advantage, an element of deception was added, with code words used to signal the shift.\n\nThen, as the forward pass became a bigger part of football in the 1910s, concealing the offense\u2019s play call became a major imperative. Some teams even approached the line of scrimmage knowing they might change the play called in the huddle before the ball was snapped. This required much more than a single, shouted \u2018\u2018hike.\u2019\u2019 Additional coded signals were soon developed, a system now known as an audible.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA century of football evolution later, quarterbacks throughout college and the N.F.L. regularly call plays not in the huddle, but as they wait at the line of scrimmage. Fans watching at home hear a host of seemingly disconnected terms and words, even the names of cities \u2014 who can forget Peyton Manning\u2019s \u201cOmaha!\u201d \u2014 and animals.\n\nMuch of it is mumbo-jumbo, phony phrases meant to confuse the defense.\n\n\u201cMy friends outside of football ask me, \u2018What\u2019s all that chatter at the line?\u2019\u201d Weston Richburg, the Giants center, said. \u201cI tell them, \u2018Ignore it, because we do.\u2019 I mean, some of it matters. But a lot of it doesn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nWhen it does matter, yelling a color like blue or red can be a code for the play being changed. Or, barking \u201cEagle 18\u201d can be a signal that the ball will be snapped on the next sound coming from the quarterback\u2019s mouth no matter what that sound is.\n\nSometimes the directive to snap the ball is not a voice command at all. Known as a silent count, it is communicated with a hand motion or when the quarterback lifts his leg off the ground.\n\nWide receivers, lined up far from the center of the formation, usually cannot hear the quarterback\u2019s signals because of crowd noise. They try not to move until they see the football leave the ground.\n\nDefensive linemen, at least most of the time, do the same thing.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t listen to anything,\u201d Eagles defensive tackle Fletcher Cox said. \u201cThe fastest thing on the field is the football when it\u2019s snapped. When it moves, so do I.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBecause those quarterbacks are paid to trick me. I shut them out \u2014 what are they saying anyway? Hike? Whatever.\u201d\n\nStill, for roughly the last 60 years, the signal has most assuredly not been hike.\n\n\u201cHike is a term used by people outside football,\u201d Spencer Long, the Redskins center, said. \u201cHike is too hard to say. That\u2019s probably why they got rid of it.\u201d\n\nThe Giants quarterback Eli Manning, referring to his father, Archie, a college and N.F.L. quarterback in the 1960s and 1970s, said: \u201cI don\u2019t think even my dad said hike. I think our family has always been hut guys. But it\u2019s a good question: Why do we say that?\u201d\n\nIt turns out hike evolved into hut because of football\u2019s longtime love of military terminology.\n\nAfter studying \u201chut,\u201d Ben Zimmer, a noted linguist and lexicographer, published findings several years ago that linked the term to the cadences used by marching soldiers. In American military settings, it was often a substitute in basic marching commands, as in \u201chut, two, three, four\u201d instead of \u201cone, two, three, four.\u201d\n\nAnd drill sergeants in the middle of the 20th century also called troops to order with, \u201cAtten-hut!\u201d\n\nMany football coaches and players in the late 1940s and early 1950s had served in the armed forces during World War II. Returning to football fields after the war, they borrowed hut as a clear, concise command that could be heard by a large group of men scattered across a plain.\n\nTheismann was happy to finally have an answer.\n\n\u201cWith the great synergy between football and the military, it figures that it had something to do with following orders,\u201d Theismann said. \u201cThen again, think of the chaos and the penalties there would be if we didn\u2019t have a word that got everyone moving together as a team.\n\n\u201cSo that\u2019s what it comes down to. Why do we say hut? Because it works.\u201d", "title": "Hut! Hut! Hut! What?", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe saved like four match points in the semifinals,\u201d Chung said this week in the players\u2019 restaurant at Melbourne Park. \u201cIf I lose that match, maybe I am not here now. I would have to go to the army.\u201d\n\nChung said he later served in the military for a few weeks, which did not pause his tennis career for long. It is not beyond the realm of possibility that Chung can win the Australian Open, too, after defeating three seeded players, including the six-time champion Novak Djokovic in the fourth round.\n\n\u201cLook, I\u2019m very excited to play Chung,\u201d said Federer, 36, who will face an opponent 15 years his junior at this late stage of a major tournament for the first time. \u201cI thought he played an incredible match against Novak. To beat him here is one of the tough things to do in our sport, I believe. I know that Novak maybe wasn\u2019t at 110 percent, but he was all right. He was giving it a fight till the very end. To close it out, that was mighty impressive.\u201d\n\nDjokovic was definitely not at the peak of his elastic powers, coming off a six-month break and still suffering from right elbow pain. But he posed a serious challenge to Chung, who was also facing the mental barrier of playing his idol in the same stadium where Djokovic beat Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in 2008 to win his first major title.\n\nThat was the first Grand Slam final that Chung remembered watching on television, but he had been pretending to be Djokovic for years in makeshift matches against his older brother, Hong, in a parking lot in front of the family\u2019s home and elsewhere.", "title": "Hyeon Chung\u2019s Tennis Breakthrough Was Shaped in a Parking Lot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Yep, that\u2019s my byline above a Monday puzzle. *Rubs eyes* Is this real life?\n\nThe theme I came up with was friendly enough for beginner solvers?\n\nThere\u2019s nothing too crazy in the fill?\n\nThe clues are ... easy?!\n\nI started where most constructors don\u2019t, and shouldn\u2019t: telling myself that I really needed to make a Monday puzzle with no ideas for it whatsoever. I decided to poke around the Archives for past themes I enjoyed, and came across this Lynn Lempel gem, which contained eight phrases that all rhymed despite having different spellings. I thought the idea was so clever, and wondered if I could vary it somehow while still introducing a novel concept.\n\nI figured the long \u201cA\u201d sound was worth pursuing, and noticed that MILO O\u2019SHEA and ANCHORS AWEIGH stacked nicely together in a grid. From there, I refined the long \u201cA\u201d answers to have the \u201cshort-short-short long\u201d cadence of the two above: CHINESE BUFFET, SO NOT OKAY, etc. But I still wasn\u2019t satisfied yet.\n\nThat\u2019s when CAFE AU LAIT emerged from the cobwebs to make a grand entrance: AU LAIT double-rhymed with both OKAY and O\u2019SHEA, their associated phrases followed the same rhythm, and they were all spelled differently. What an \u201caha\u201d moment that was! With OBEY and OJ proving viable as well, I realized that this was the grid I had to make.\n\nAs far as fill goes, I obsessively focused on keeping proper nouns to a minimum, unless they were truly zippy and worth knowing (TY COBB, ST. CLAIR). After watching my friends develop from novices into regular solvers, I now know that normally fine answers such as LETO and TULL may be tough early in the week.\n\nHope you enjoyed! Have you signed up for the ACPT yet?", "title": "Hypnotist\u2019s Command", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "At 18, in 1968, I moved to New York from Delaware. Within a week I got a job at the Strand packing books for shipment, along with one other guy, much older, who\u2019d been there for years and seemingly spent quite a bit of his meager salary on weekly psychoanalysis. He showed me how to tie knots, as in those days packages had to be tied up.\n\nThe Strand was much smaller then, just the ground floor and a basement, where I worked. There was no air-conditioning and it was a very dusty place. Books were stacked two to three feet high in rows two deep in most of the aisles.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was great working there. Many on the staff were much older, and one, Burt, knowing I was a hayseed, would throw books at me, saying: \u201cHere kid\u2026 read this\u2026 he\u2019s a great writer.\u201d I can\u2019t recall his suggestions, but soon my writing-deprived mind became very excited. It seemed you could do anything with words.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere weren\u2019t any musicians working there back then. Most of the staff was interested in literature, and some of them were writers, painters, photographers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFred Bass, the owner of the Strand who died this week at 89, was a very good guy. After I was late for work over 20 times, he finally just warned me he\u2019d have to let me go because other workers were noticing and coming in late too. I asked him to reduce my paycheck, but he wouldn\u2019t.\n\nAs I recall, he liked Matisse, and any book about him he didn\u2019t have he took home.\n\nI never saw him lose his temper, even with his dad, who was an incredibly loud, impatient, insulting porcupine of a man\u2026though no workers took him seriously. He was a source of comedy \u2014 a book of anecdotes about him would be very funny.", "title": "I Did the Strand", "authors": ["Tom Verlaine"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGood morning and first of all let me say I love your show. That piece you did last month about the age-shaming subtext of \u2018Happy Birthday\u2019 sung nonconsensually in the workplace \u2014 all I could think was \u2018Finally!\u2019 But my problem: I\u2019ve been seeing who I thought was a very nice man for some time, and last Saturday he asked me over to his house for dinner. He\u2019d obviously put a lot of effort into it; the house was filled with flowers, he\u2019d cooked a wonderful meal, he\u2019d had the cat I was allergic to euthanized.\u201d\n\nWow, he sounds like a keeper!\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what I had been thinking, too. I was ready to get intimate \u2014 I\u2019d brought the legal papers of consent, signed and notarized. Then he clicks on his playlist and the first song that comes up is, \u201cTeach Me Tonight.\u201d I walked out immediately, of course. But it was so degrading. And the worst part is, I feel like I asked for it, going to his house.\u201d\n\nRachel, first let me say that what happened to you was awful. I completely understand why you\u2019re traumatized. But I want you to listen to me very, very carefully: What a man selects for his playlist is not your fault. \u201cTeach Me Tonight\u201d is one of the most offensive examples of mansplaining music in the American Songbook with the singer, of course, always a woman:\n\n\u201cDid you say I\u2019ve got a lot to learn?\n\nWell don\u2019t think I\u2019m trying not to learn \u2026\n\nTeach me tonight.\u201d\n\nCan you imagine what the reaction would be if a man, say Dwayne Johnson, sang this number, perhaps in a tender moment with his love interest in his upcoming RomSplat, \u201cRampage\u201d? The other male action stars would be on the phone with him in a minute saying: \u201cDude, what were you thinking? No man, especially one with delts so huge that they need to call their own Uber, should have to play dumb to be considered sexually attractive. You\u2019re fine JUST THE WAY YOU ARE.\u201d\n\nI\u2019ll take it a step further: No one, of any gender, should sing \u201cTeach Me Tonight.\u201d Unless you\u2019re taking a course in advanced French grammar because that stuff is hard.\n\nNext caller, Gloria in Woodstock, N.Y. Sing out, Gloria, what song would you like to see eradicated from the so-called Great American Songbook?", "title": "I Told You Never to Play That Slut-Shaming Song Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "A 2016 study found that it took longer for people to correctly identify the gender of female faces displaying an angry expression, as if the emotion had wandered out of its natural habitat by finding its way to their features. A 1990 study conducted by the psychologists Ulf Dimberg and L.O. Lundquist found that when female faces are recognized as angry, their expressions are rated as more hostile than comparable expressions on the faces of men \u2014 as if their violation of social expectations had already made their anger seem more extreme, increasing its volume beyond what could be tolerated.\n\nIn \u201cWhat Happened,\u201d her account of the 2016 presidential election, Hillary Clinton describes the pressure not to come across as angry during the course of her entire political career \u2014 \u201ca lot of people recoil from an angry woman,\u201d she writes \u2014 as well as her own desire not to be consumed by anger after she lost the race, \u201cso that the rest of my life wouldn\u2019t be spent like Miss Havisham from Charles Dickens\u2019s \u2018Great Expectations,\u2019 rattling around my house obsessing over what might have been.\u201d The specter of Dickens\u2019s ranting spinster \u2014 spurned and embittered in her crumbling wedding dress, plotting her elaborate revenge \u2014 casts a long shadow over every woman who dares to get mad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf an angry woman makes people uneasy, then her more palatable counterpart, the sad woman, summons sympathy more readily. She often looks beautiful in her suffering: ennobled, transfigured, elegant. Angry women are messier. Their pain threatens to cause more collateral damage. It\u2019s as if the prospect of a woman\u2019s anger harming other people threatens to rob her of the social capital she has gained by being wronged. We are most comfortable with female anger when it promises to regulate itself, to refrain from recklessness, to stay civilized.\n\nConsider the red-carpet clip of Uma Thurman that went viral in November, during the initial swell of sexual-harassment accusations. The clip doesn\u2019t actually show Thurman\u2019s getting angry. It shows her very conspicuously refusing to get angry. After commending the Hollywood women who had spoken out about their experiences of sexual assault, she said that she was \u201cwaiting to feel less angry\u201d before she spoke herself. It was curious that Thurman\u2019s public declarations were lauded as a triumphant vision of female anger, because the clip offered precisely the version of female anger that we\u2019ve long been socialized to produce and accept: not the spectacle of female anger unleashed, but the spectacle of female anger restrained, sharpened to a photogenic point. By withholding the specific story of whatever made her angry, Thurman made her anger itself the story \u2014 and the raw force of her struggle not to get angry on that red carpet summoned the force of her anger even more powerfully than its full explosion would have, just as the monster in a movie is most frightening when it only appears offscreen.\n\nThis was a question I began to consider quite frequently as the slew of news stories accrued last fall: How much female anger has been lurking offscreen? How much anger has been biding its time and biting its tongue, wary of being pathologized as hysteria or dismissed as paranoia? And what of my own vexed feelings about all this female anger? Why were they even vexed? It seemed a failure of moral sentiment or a betrayal of feminism, as if I were somehow siding with the patriarchy, or had internalized it so thoroughly I couldn\u2019t even spot the edges of its toxic residue. I intuitively embraced and supported other women\u2019s anger but struggled to claim my own. Some of this had to do with the ways I\u2019d been lucky \u2014 I had experienced all kinds of gendered aggression, but nothing equivalent to the horror stories so many other women have lived through. But it also had to do with an abiding aversion to anger that still festered like rot inside me. In what I had always understood as self-awareness \u2014 I don\u2019t get angry. I get sad \u2014 I came to see my own complicity in the same logic that has trained women to bury their anger or perform its absence.\n\nFor a long time, I was drawn to \u201csad lady\u201d icons: the scribes and bards of loneliness and melancholy. As a certain kind of slightly morbid, slightly depressive, slightly self-intoxicated, deeply predictable, pre-emptively apologetic literary fan-girl, I loved Sylvia Plath. I was obsessed with her own obsession with her own blood (\u201cWhat a thrill ... that red plush\u201d) and drawn to her suffering silhouette: a woman abandoned by her cheating husband and ensnared by the gendered double standards of domesticity. I attached myself to the mantra of her autobiographical avatar Esther Greenwood, who lies in a bathtub in \u201cThe Bell Jar,\u201d bleeding during a rehearsal of a suicide attempt, and later stands at a funeral listening \u201cto the old brag of my heart. I am, I am, I am.\u201d Her attachment to pain \u2014 her own and others\u2019 \u2014 was also a declaration of identity. I wanted to get it tattooed on my arm.\n\nWhenever I listened to my favorite female singers, it was easier for me to sing along to their sad lyrics than their angry ones. It was easier to play Ani DiFranco on repeat, crooning about heartbreak \u2014 \u201cDid I ever tell you how I stopped eating/when you stopped calling me?\u201d \u2014 than it was to hear her fury, and her irritation at the ones who stayed sad and quiet in her shadow: \u201cSome chick says/Thank you for saying all the things I never do/I say, you know/The thanks I get is to take all the [expletive] for you.\u201d\n\nI kept returning to the early novels of Jean Rhys, whose wounded heroines flopped around dingy rented rooms in various European capitals, seeking solace from their heartbreak, staining cheap comforters with their wine. Sasha, the heroine of \u201cGood Morning, Midnight\u201d \u2014 the most famous of these early picaresques of pain \u2014 resolves to drink herself to death and manages, mainly, to cry her way across Paris. She cries at cafes, at bars, in her lousy hotel room. She cries at work. She cries in a fitting room. She cries on the street. She cries near the Seine. The closing scene of the novel is a scene of terrifying passivity: She lets a wraithlike man into her bed because she can\u2019t summon the energy to stop him, as if she has finally lost touch with her willpower entirely. In life, Rhys was infamous for her sadness, what one friend called \u201cher gramophone-needle-stuck-in-a-groove thing of going over and over miseries of one sort and another.\u201d Even her biographer called her one of the greatest self-pity artists in the history of English fiction.\n\nIt took me years to understand how deeply I had misunderstood these women. I\u2019d missed the rage that fueled Plath\u2019s poetry like a ferocious gasoline, lifting her speakers (sometimes literally) into flight: \u201cNow she is flying/More terrible than she ever was, red/Scar in the sky, red comet/Over the engine that killed her \u2014 the mausoleum, the wax house.\u201d The speaker becomes a scar \u2014 this irrefutable evidence of her own pain \u2014 but this scar, in turn, becomes a comet: terrible and determined, soaring triumphant over the instruments of her own supposed destruction. I\u2019d always been preoccupied with the pained disintegration of Plath\u2019s speakers, but once I started looking, I saw the comet trails of their angry resurrections everywhere, delivering their unapologetic fantasies of retribution: \u201cOut of the ash/I rise with my red hair/And I eat men like air.\u201d\n\nI\u2019d loved Rhys for nearly a decade before I read her final novel, \u201cWide Sargasso Sea,\u201d a reimagining of Charlotte Bront\u00eb\u2019s \u201cJane Eyre\u201d whose whole plot leads inexorably toward an act of destructive anger: The mad first wife of Mr. Rochester burns down the English country manor where she has been imprisoned in the attic for years. In this late masterpiece, the heroines of Rhys\u2019s early novels \u2014 heartbroken, drunk, caught in complicated choreographies of passivity \u2014 are replaced by an angry woman with a torch, ready to use the master\u2019s tools to destroy his house.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt wasn\u2019t that these authors were writing exclusively about female anger rather than female sorrow; their writing holds both states of feeling. \u201cWide Sargasso Sea\u201d excavates the deep veins of sadness running beneath an otherwise opaque act of angry destruction, and Plath\u2019s poems are invested in articulating the complicated affective braids of bitterness, irony, anger, pride and sorrow that others often misread as monolithic sadness. \u201cThey explain people like that by saying that their minds are in watertight compartments, but it never seemed so to me,\u201d Rhys herself once wrote. \u201cIt\u2019s all washing about, like the bilge in the hold of a ship.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt has always been easier to shunt female sadness and female anger into the \u201cwatertight compartments\u201d of opposing archetypes, rather than acknowledging the ways they run together in the cargo hold of every female psyche. Near the end of the new biopic \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d Tonya Harding\u2019s character explains: \u201cAmerica, they want someone to love, but they want someone to hate.\u201d The timing of the film\u2019s release, in late 2017, seemed cosmically apt. It resurrected a definitional prototype of female anger \u2014 at least for many women like me, who came of age during the 1990s \u2014 at the precise moment that so many women were starting to get publicly, explicitly, unapologetically angry.\n\nHarding was an object of fascination not just because of the soap opera she dangled before the public gaze \u2014 supposedly conspiring with her ex-husband and an associate to plan an attack on her rival figure skater Nancy Kerrigan \u2014 but also because she and Kerrigan provided a yin and yang of primal female archetypes. As a vision of anger \u2014 uncouth and unrestrained, the woman everyone loved to hate, exploding at the judges when they didn\u2019t give her the scores she felt she deserved \u2014 Harding was the perfect foil for the elegant suffering of Kerrigan, sobbing in her lacy white leotard. Together they were an impossible duo to turn away from: the sad girl and the mad girl. Wounded and wicked. Their binary segregated one vision of femininity we adored (rule-abiding, delicate, hurting) from another we despised (trashy, whiny, angry). Harding was strong; she was poor; she was pissed off; and eventually, in the narrative embraced by the public, she turned those feelings into violence. But \u201cI, Tonya\u201d illuminates what so little press coverage at the time paid attention to: the perfect storm of violence that produced Harding\u2019s anger in the first place \u2014 her mother\u2019s abuse and her husband\u2019s. Which is to say: No woman\u2019s anger is an island.\n\nWhen the Harding and Kerrigan controversy swept the media, I was 10 years old. Their story was imprinted onto me as a series of reductive but indelible brush strokes: one woman shouting at the media, another woman weeping just beyond the ice rink. But after watching \u201cI, Tonya\u201d and realizing how much these two women had existed to me as ideas, rather than as women, I did what any reasonable person would do: I Googled \u201cTonya and Nancy\u201d obsessively. I Googled: \u201cDid Tonya ever apologize to Nancy?\u201d I Googled: \u201cTonya Harding boxing career?\u201d and discovered that it effectively began with her 2002 \u201cCelebrity Boxing\u201d match against Paula Jones \u2014 two women paid to perform the absurd caricatures of vengeful femininity the public had projected onto them, the woman who cried harassment versus the woman who bashed kneecaps.\n\nIn the documentaries I watched, I found Harding difficult to like. She comes off as a self-deluded liar with a robust victim complex, focused on her own misfortune to the exclusion of anyone else\u2019s. But what does the fact that I found Harding \u201cdifficult to like\u201d say about the kind of women I\u2019m comfortable liking? Did I want the plotline in which the woman who has survived her own hard life \u2014 abusive mother, abusive husband, enduring poverty \u2014 also emerges with a \u201clikable\u201d personality: a plucky spirit, a determined work ethic and a graceful, self-effacing relationship to her own suffering?\n\nThe vision of Harding in \u201cI, Tonya\u201d is something close to the opposite of self-effacing. The film even includes a fantastical re-enactment of the crime, which became popularly known as the \u201cwhack heard round the world,\u201d in which Harding stands over Kerrigan\u2019s cowering body, baton raised high above her head, striking her bloody knee until Harding turns back toward the camera \u2014 her face defiant and splattered with Kerrigan\u2019s blood. Even though the attack was actually carried out by a hired hit man, this imagined scene distills the version of the story that America became obsessed with, in which one woman\u2019s anger leaves another woman traumatized.", "title": "I Used to Insist I Didn\u2019t Get Angry. Not Anymore.", "authors": ["Leslie Jamison"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In the early 2000s, when I was a middle schooler in Florida, I was subjected to a trauma that was meant to erase my existence as a newly out bisexual. My parents were Southern Baptist missionaries who believed that the dangerous and discredited practice of conversion therapy could \u201ccure\u201d my sexuality.\n\nFor over two years, I sat on a couch and endured emotionally painful sessions with a counselor. I was told that my faith community rejected my sexuality; that I was the abomination we had heard about in Sunday school; that I was the only gay person in the world; that it was inevitable I would get H.I.V. and AIDS.\n\nBut it didn\u2019t stop with these hurtful talk-therapy sessions. The therapist ordered me bound to a table to have ice, heat and electricity applied to my body. I was forced to watch clips on a television of gay men holding hands, hugging and having sex. I was supposed to associate those images with the pain I was feeling to once and for all turn into a straight boy. In the end it didn\u2019t work. I would say that it did, just to make the pain go away.\n\nI have begun to repair the damage that conversion therapy caused me and my family. But the failed promise of change has very likely caused a permanent tear in our relationship.", "title": "Opinion | I Was Tortured in Gay Conversion Therapy. And It\u2019s Still Legal in 41 States.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Paul Melia, Canada\u2019s top antidoping official, called that statement na\u00efve. \u201cIn the face of evidence of a state-run doping program going back to at least 2011, to think that overnight there\u2019s a new generation of Russian athletes ready for the Olympics?\u201d he said.\n\nThomas Bach, president of the I.O.C., has called Russia\u2019s cheating reflective of an \u201cunprecedented level of criminality.\u201d Mr. Melia said the I.O.C.\u2019s actions were unlikely to deter similar such cheating. \u201cIf you wanted to send a strong message that this is absolutely unacceptable, you\u2019re not going to let their athletes come to the next Games,\u201d he said.\n\nThe International Paralympic Committee, which barred all Russian athletes from the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro, is expected to announce whether the nation can compete in Pyeongchang. In contrast to Olympic officials, Paralympic officials have demanded that Russian officials admit to the schemes before the country\u2019s team returns to competition. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn clearing a path for Russian athletes, the International Olympic Committee sought to emphasize the wrongdoers it had indeed excluded. None of the approved athletes were among those disciplined by the organization for doping in Sochi, and none have been suspended for a doping violation in the past. Each athlete\u2019s candidacy was considered anonymously, according to Olympic officials.\n\nBeyond being declared clean by the I.O.C., Russian athletes will need to have qualified for the Games by the standards of their respective sports. As a handful of qualifying events continue before Jan. 28 \u2014 the deadline by which athletes must be registered for the Games \u2014 the I.O.C. said Friday that it was impossible to estimate the number of Russian competitors.\n\nStill, the generous pool established Friday makes it possible for the number to rival the size of Russia\u2019s delegation in Sochi, where now-disgraced medalists used a cocktail of anabolic steroids and had their incriminating urine samples destroyed.\n\nIn Pyeongchang, Russian athletes will technically compete under the Olympic flag, with no Russian emblems identifying them or appearing at the opening ceremony on Feb. 9. Nonetheless, Russian athletes and officials have expressed pride that their athletes will be referred to by the acronym OAR: Olympic Athlete from Russia. In past cases in which athletes from suspended countries like Kuwait have competed under the Olympic flag, there have been no references to national origin.\n\nPhoto\n\nAntidoping officials from more than 20 countries have called the level of public detail about the I.O.C.\u2019s evaluation process insufficient, requesting on Thursday that Olympic officials publish specific criteria in light of the I.O.C.\u2019s own statement in 2016 that Russian athletes ought to be presumed tainted by a corrupted system and required to prove themselves innocent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe I.O.C. said Friday that the soonest it could publish the names of the athletes invited to compete would be Jan. 27, following an I.O.C. meeting on the matter to be held in Pyeongchang that day.\n\nLegal challenges, too, are to be considered by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which has 39 appeals related to Russian doping to be decided ahead of the Games. Those hearings are expected to begin in Switzerland next week.\n\n\u201cAs the qualification process is still ongoing and more preconditions have to be met by some of the athletes, it is still not possible to project how many athletes will participate in Pyeongchang,\u201d the I.O.C. said, prompting outcry from officials who called for a clue to the number of approved athletes who were likely to meet qualifying standards.\n\n\u201cThis chosen group of Russian athletes have gone through the most rigorous testing worldwide,\u201d Val\u00e9rie Fourneyron, France\u2019s former sports minister and the chairwoman of the I.O.C. review panel, said Friday. Days earlier, at a tournament in Siberia, three dozen Russian athletes abruptly withdrew from a regional track and field competition after drug-testing officials had arrived unannounced, according to Russian media.\n\n\u201cWe need to know what kind of tests these athletes have had, and we need to know who carried out those tests,\u201d Mr. Melia said, noting that Russia\u2019s drug-testing operations had been decertified by international regulators for the last two years. \u201cThat\u2019s information that would give other clean athletes around the world some confidence.\u201d", "title": "I.O.C. Ruiz"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The I.R.S. excuses hardship cases from collection efforts to ensure that households can still pay for basic living expenses. But an analysis by the advocate\u2019s office found that 45 percent of the collections by private contractors were from taxpayers whose incomes fell below the minimum threshold, including those who received Social Security disability payments.\n\nThe report underscored Ms. Olson\u2019s repeated complaints that Congress is underfunding the agency, warning that the new tax law will bring added pressures that will further impair its ability to respond to taxpayers, update technology and maintain compliance programs. Since 2010, funding for the I.R.S. has shrunk by a fifth, after taking inflation into account.\n\nThe agency receives more than 95 million phone calls a year, for example, but it expects to answer only about 60 percent during the current filing season; that number is estimated to decline to 40 percent for the rest of the year. And that was before the new law was passed. If previous tax code changes are any guide, the number of queries is likely to rise significantly, pushing down the response figure even more.\n\nA preliminary estimate by the I.R.S. figured that the new law would require an additional $495 million over the next two fiscal years to handle tasks like updating programming, answering phone calls, drafting and publishing new forms, revising regulations and training employees on the new code.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Olson said in the report that \u201cthe discussion about I.R.S. funding has largely proceeded based on false choices \u2014 either \u2018you can\u2019t trust the I.R.S. to administer the tax system, so don\u2019t fund it\u2019 or \u2018because the I.R.S. doesn\u2019t have enough funding, it can\u2019t do the things it needs to do to administer the tax system.\u2019\u201d Both added that funding and service improvements are needed, she said.\n\nThe I.R.S. is rushing to move taxpayer services online and limit personal contact, she said, but the problem is that many households aren\u2019t in a position to keep up. A 2016-17 survey by the advocate\u2019s office found that 41 million taxpayers had no broadband connection in their homes, including 14 million with no internet access at all. Many other Americans who do use the agency\u2019s online service still want to be able to speak to a person on the telephone or face to face at times, the I.R.S. has found.\n\nAmong the most serious problems identified by the advocate\u2019s office is a lack of advance notice when citizens are in danger of losing their passports because they owe the I.R.S. more than $50,000.\n\nIn addition, Ms. Olson reiterated previously expressed worries that the expedited process of approving organizations\u2019 tax-exempt status was resulting in rubber-stamp approvals of groups that had not established their qualifications. She cited an error rate of 46 percent in a sampling last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe streamlined process, for charities with assets under $250,000, was partly a response to a furor over the agency\u2019s intensive scrutiny of certain political groups, including some associated with the Tea Party movement. Flaws in the new process, the report said, can undermine public trust in the charitable sector.\n\nSarah Allen, an I.R.S. spokeswoman, said the agency\u2019s leaders would review the taxpayer advocate\u2019s proposals.\n\nRepresentative Kevin Brady, Republican of Texas and the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who helped spearhead the tax revision efforts, has said he plans to focus on reforming the Internal Revenue Service this year. Paid $20 Million to Collect $6.7 Million in Tax Debts", "authors": ["Patricia Cohen"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIBM reported revenue growth for the first time in five and a half years on Thursday, ending a streak of 22 consecutive quarters of shrinking sales.\n\nThe gain was modest \u2014 revenue rose by 4 percent \u2014 and one quarter does not make a trend. The quarterly result will also not erase the doubts of industry analysts who are skeptical that a genuine turnaround is underway at IBM.\n\nBut the company\u2019s fourth-quarter report is an encouraging sign that IBM\u2019s financial performance is stabilizing, and perhaps the transformation effort led by Virginia M. Rometty, the chief executive, is gaining ground. The company\u2019s long run of slipping revenue began shortly after Ms. Rometty took over in 2012.\n\nThe corporate technology giant is remaking itself and investing heavily in new businesses like cloud computing, data analytics and artificial intelligence. The litmus test of success will be when those new units grow large enough to more than offset the steady erosion of its traditional hardware and software products, delivering revenue growth consistently.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement, Ms. Rometty noted the strong growth in the new businesses, which IBM collectively calls \u201cstrategic imperatives\u201d and now represent 46 percent of the company\u2019s revenue. \u201cWe are pleased with our overall revenue growth in the quarter,\u201d she said. Company executives said they expected revenue growth to continue throughout 2018.", "title": "IBM Ends 22-Quarter Streak of Falling Revenue", "authors": ["Steve Lohr"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "For five and a half years, nearly the entire tenure of its chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, IBM has reported a steady erosion of revenue.\n\nSelling off its chip manufacturing and smaller data-center computer businesses contributed to the decline. So, too, did the fact that new businesses like cloud computing, data analytics and artificial intelligence had not yet grown big enough to make up for the downturn in IBM\u2019s traditional hardware and software products.\n\nBut IBM\u2019s half-decade losing streak will most likely end on Thursday, analysts predict, when the company reports its quarterly performance.\n\nThe crossover to growth would be a long-awaited bright spot for Ms. Rometty and IBM, a challenged giant that has been overshadowed in recent years by the younger technology giants on the West Coast.", "title": "IBM May Finally Stop Shrinking. But Is It a Turnaround?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "By nighttime, Ravi had been flown to Miami. I spent the day unsure where he was and struggling to accept that my husband had been taken from me.\n\nAs a longtime immigrant rights lawyer and advocate, I am aware of the horrific conditions in the jails that hold immigrants. I know how deportation tears at the fabric of families and communities.\n\nBut now I am inside this nightmare personally and it hurts more than I ever thought it would. I come home to an empty apartment, and everything screams Ravi\u2019s absence.\n\nLike Jean and thousands of other immigrants caught in ICE raids, Ravi threatens no one. On the contrary, he and other immigrant leaders have led their communities with dignity and courage in a brutal time. That\u2019s why they were snatched \u2014 and why ICE wants to deport them.\n\nThe last time I saw my husband was through Plexiglas at the Krome Detention Center in Miami. After six tense days and a court hearing on Tuesday, ICE said it would bring Ravi back to the New York area so that he could be closer to his family, his legal counsel and his community. But he remains detained, and he is still not safe from deportation.\n\nWe are continuing to challenge his detention. My greatest fear is that he will be sent back to Trinidad, where he has not lived for more than 25 years. We must keep Ravi, and other immigrant leaders, at home in the United States where they belong.", "title": "Opinion | ICE Detained My Husband for Being an Activist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Details of the attack remain murky, and members of the patrol have given conflicting accounts of it. It is unclear whether the patrol was simply ambushed, or whether it was attacked after the troops were reassigned to support a separate, clandestine counterterrorism mission against Islamist militants in the area.\n\nAid workers and tourists have long been urged to avoid the area where the attack occurred, near Niger\u2019s border with Mali, because of the presence of both Al Qaeda- and Islamic State-affiliated groups.\n\nIn its statement sent to the website, Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s group also claimed responsibility for an attack on a convoy of French troops in Mali on Thursday, which the French military said wounded three soldiers, according to Reuters.\n\nThe extent of Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s ties with the Islamic State is unclear. The website in Mauritania that carried the group\u2019s statement on Friday is an outlet favored by Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s former colleagues in Al Qaeda, not by the Islamic State. The area in which Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s group operates contains some of the most forbidding terrain on the planet, a landscape of undulating dunes where cellphone towers are few and far between.\n\n\u201cThere is a lot we don\u2019t know about how his operation connects back to the mother ship \u2014 what\u2019s the connective tissue?\u201d said Thomas Joscelyn, an analyst who has tracked the group for years as a senior fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies in Washington. \u201cThere are a lot of possibilities and many factors in play.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe remoteness of the area in which Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s group operates, and the difficulty of getting reliable cellphone signals or internet access, could be one factor to explain the delay in releasing the statement. Another possibility is that the Islamic State\u2019s media apparatus was disrupted after the group lost nearly 98 percent of its territory in Iraq and Syria.\n\nAdditionally, there have been reports of unrest among from Al Qaeda loyalists after Mr. Sahraoui made his pledge of allegiance to the Islamic State. \u201cThere were even reports at one point that he was injured in a shootout with Al Qaeda,\u201d Mr. Joscelyn said.\n\nMr. Sahraoui cut his teeth in Al Qaeda\u2019s branch in the region, which reported to Osama bin Laden through letters that were carried across the desert by couriers. He joined the Qaeda branch sometime in 2010, according to one account, and became a deputy to Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, one of Al Qaeda\u2019s most notorious commanders in the area and among the first to discover that foreigners were lucrative bargaining chips. He bankrolled his operations through kidnappings for ransom, pioneering a business model that was later adopted by the terrorist group in Yemen, Syria, Afghanistan and elsewhere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy 2011, Mr. Sahraoui was in charge of taking care of foreign hostages kidnapped by the group, according to Mariasandra Mariani, an Italian who was held by him for more than a year after her abduction in Algeria on Feb. 2, 2011.\n\nHe parted ways with Al Qaeda in 2012, after the jihadists seized most of northern Mali. He resurfaced as the spokesman of the Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa, a separate jihadist group based in Mali, which merged with a third group in 2013.\n\nThen in May 2015, he swore loyalty to the Islamic State leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. But his video pledge was not released by the group\u2019s news agency for more than a year, until October 2016. Since then, Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s statements have not been promoted on ISIS media outlets, including Friday\u2019s claim, which was sent to the Mauritanian website. The Islamic State affiliate operating in Nigeria regularly succeeds in uploading messages and photo essays through established ISIS media channels.\n\nThat lack of a consistent media presence may suggest that Mr. Sahraoui\u2019s unit has not been fully accepted by the Islamic State, or else that the group has not managed to establish the logistical ties that have allowed other affiliates to post statements and videos of attacks on its platforms.\n\nIn Bangladesh in 2016, for example, a relatively new affiliate was able to send images of an attack on a restaurant to the Islamic State\u2019s Amaq News Agency before members of the security forces broke down the doors and ended the siege. Survivors later described how the attackers had demanded that employees turn on the restaurant\u2019s wireless network so that they could send their images.\n\nSimilarly last June, the assailants who broke into Iran\u2019s Parliament and the tomb of its revolutionary founder, managed to send a graphic, 24-second video to Amaq, showing them inside the building, walking past the dead and shouting Islamic State slogans.", "title": "ISIS Affiliate Claims October Attack on U.S. Troops in Niger", "authors": ["Rukmini Callimachi"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Islamic State on Wednesday claimed responsibility for the twin suicide bombings in Baghdad this week that killed at least 27 people. It was the first major attack in Iraq\u2019s capital since the government declared victory over the terrorist group last month.\n\nThe nearly simultaneous explosions occurred minutes apart just after 6 a.m. on Monday, with the first assailant detonating his explosives in a square where day laborers were gathering to find work. The second bomber set off his explosives as people rushed to help the wounded, according to a traffic police officer who witnessed the episode. That sequence is a well-established pattern for the Islamic State and Al Qaeda, and is aimed at killing the maximum number of civilians.\n\nBut the statement released on the messaging app Telegram had a number of errors, including the location of Monday\u2019s attack. It said that it had occurred at Aden Square in Baghdad, where the police said an attack was foiled on Saturday, rather than in Tayaran Square, where Monday\u2019s explosions took place. That error, and the delay in issuing a claim of responsibility, suggests that the Islamic State\u2019s media apparatus has been disrupted in the period since the group lost nearly 98 percent of its territory in Iraq and Syria.\n\nIn addition, the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, said that there were three attackers, not two. The communiqu\u00e9 identified them by code names, and said that the first two detonated their explosive vests in quick succession, while the third hit another gathering in the same area sometime after the first two explosions, according to a translation of the statement provided by SITE Intelligence Group.\n\nIn its statement, ISIS identified the open-air market that was attacked as a gathering of \u201crafidha\u201d and of \u201cpolytheists,\u201d two words they use to refer to Shiite Muslims in a derogatory manner. The first term, derived from the Arabic root meaning \u201cto reject,\u201d is a reference to the fact that members of the Shiite branch of Islam chose to follow a different lineage from the one followed by Sunnis after the death of the Prophet Muhammad. The second refers to the group\u2019s view that Shiites have strayed from Islam\u2019s monotheistic creed because of the reverence they show for historical figures, like Imam Ali.\n\nOf note is the length of time it took for the Islamic State to issue its claim of responsibility. While the group has sometimes taken days to claim responsibility for attacks outside Iraq and Syria, it is unusual for ISIS to delay announcements for an attack in Baghdad, which may suggest a weakening of the group\u2019s media arm.", "title": "ISIS Claims Responsibility for Baghdad Bombings", "authors": ["Rukmini Callimachi", "Margaret Coker"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Sinai militant group that later pledged allegiance to the Islamic State has been at war with the Egyptian government since 2013, when the military ousted the country\u2019s Islamist government.\n\nThe group has since become one of the Islamic State\u2019s most effective local affiliates. It downed a Russian jetliner in 2015, killing 224 people, and appears to have been responsible for an attack on a Sufi mosque in north Sinai in November, killing 311 people in Egypt\u2019s worst terrorist attack.\n\nHamas is essentially a Palestinian national movement whose main effort is directed against Israel. It has periodically cracked down on more extreme jihadists in Gaza \u2014 who are ideologically closer to the Islamic State and Al Qaeda \u2014 including in a recent wave of arrests as extremists fired rockets into Israel to protest President Trump\u2019s Jerusalem move.\n\nIslamic State sympathizers argue that those arrests served only Israel.\n\nSalah Bardawil, a senior Hamas official, described the video as a \u201cZionist\u201d production. Another senior Hamas official, Mahmoud al-Zahar, said the Islamic State\u2019s Sinai branch \u201cdoes not want there to be weapons in Hamas\u2019s hands to resist the Israeli occupation.\u201d\n\nGenerally, though, Hamas has remained tight-lipped about the video, not wanting to draw more attention to it. Families whose sons have joined the Islamic State are reluctant to talk about them for fear of repercussions from Hamas, which dominates the Palestinian coastal territory.\n\n\u201cThere is an undeclared war between Hamas and Daesh,\u201d said Mkhaimar Abusada, a political scientist at Al Azhar University in Gaza, using the Arabic acronym for the Islamic State. \u201cThese are guys who disassociated themselves from Hamas and joined Daesh because they disagreed with Hamas\u2019s participation in the 2006 elections. They don\u2019t like Hamas\u2019s behavior as it doesn\u2019t enforce Shariah\u201d \u2014 Islamic law \u2014 \u201cand there are aspects of corruption regarding its rule in Gaza.\u201d\n\nEhud Yaari, an Israel-based fellow of the Washington Institute for Near Eastern Policy, said that in the past Hamas had provided the Islamic State\u2019s Sinai branch with training and advanced weapons, and had allowed wounded fighters to come to Gaza for treatment. The recent shift, Mr. Yaari said, was \u201ca typical story of Middle Eastern changing alliances.\u201d", "title": "ISIS Declares War on Hamas, and Gaza Families Disown Sons in Sinai", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates \u2014 In just three years, the Iraqi prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, has rebuilt the army, defeated the Islamic State and restored sovereignty across this deeply divided nation, accomplishments that, in the eyes of many, give him the stature of an Iraqi Abe Lincoln.\n\nStill, as Mr. Abadi is quick to warn in weekly addresses to the nation, stability remains fragile.\n\nThe country is coping with an ever-bubbling threat of violent sectarianism between the Shiite and Sunni populations, as well as endemic government corruption and overwhelming economic despair, especially among millions of citizens left homeless after the battles against the Islamic State.\n\nThis is a crucial moment for Iraq as it gears up for an election that could undo its hard-fought gains. The vote could also reshape the influence of Iran across the Middle East and determine the likelihood of a resurgent Islamic State.\n\nBut it\u2019s an important moment for Mr. Abadi, too. He has never spearheaded an electoral campaign, and has already stumbled as he tries to negotiate the mind-numbing complexities of Iraqi politics for a vote that will test his own political acumen in a challenging security environment.", "title": "ISIS Is Weakened, but Iraq Election Could Unravel Hard-Won Stability", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "GENEVA \u2014 In 1868, a 27-year-old American engineer named Florentine Ariosto Jones arrived in Schaffhausen, a Rhine River town in the German-speaking part of Switzerland, intent on teaching the Swiss a thing or two about watchmaking.\n\nThough Mr. Jones returned to the United States seven years later, it is a testament to his efforts that the company he founded turns 150 this year. It is also the ultimate success of his revolutionary vision, which helped transform what had been one of Switzerland\u2019s home-based industries into the industrial powerhouse it is today.\n\nThe brand, now called IWC Schaffhausen and owned by Compagnie Financi\u00e8re Richemont, is marking the milestone with a global series of events, including an exhibition of contemporary and historic timepieces that will travel the world from May through November. The festivities are to begin this week at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie in Geneva. The actor Bradley Cooper, IWC\u2019s newest celebrity ambassador, is to join the singers Aloe Blacc and Ronan Keating there as well as Cate Blanchett and James Marsden, both longtime ambassadors, at a gala dinner to celebrate Mr. Jones\u2019s forward-thinking ethos.", "title": "IWC Schaffhausen Celebrates 150 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "For wage equality, Iceland ranked fifth in the report, which said that globally, the average pay for women in 2017 was $12,000, compared with $21,000 for men. In Iceland, women earned 14 percent to 20 percent less than men, according to government figures for 2015.\n\nIn 2016, women accounted for 48 percent of the elected representatives in Iceland\u2019s Parliament \u2014 although that proportion declined to 38 percent in the subsequent election. Men are offered parental leave equal to women, and women have risen through the ranks of government. Icelandic law since 2013 requires private companies with more than 50 employees to have at least 40 percent women \u2014 or men \u2014 on their executive board.\n\nBut gender pay gap issues have stubbornly persisted, breaking into full view with public protests in October 2016, when women left their jobs at 2:38 p.m., before the official end of the workday, but at the time that many calculated they stopped being paid for equal work.\n\nMs. Valdimarsdottir, an organizer of the demonstrations in 2016, said inequality still persisted in other areas of Icelandic society, such as wealth distribution and representation in the arts and literature, as well as in the upper echelons of business.\n\n\u201cWe have come a long way and we are in the forefront of gender equality in the world,\u201d she said. \u201cBut we are so far from having equality in Iceland.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
