View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile Icelanders have generally celebrated the new law, one survey shows a difference between income brackets and professions. Forty-two percent of executives and senior officials oppose the law, while over all just 21 percent of Icelanders are against it, according to a survey conducted by Market and Media Research, an Icelandic company.\n\nThe law, experts say, will bring to light inequality that has until now surfaced only coincidentally, sometimes with unexpected consequences.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2013, Jofridur Hanna Sigfusdottir, a payroll clerk at a municipality office in Kopavogur in southwestern Iceland, filed a complaint to the government\u2019s Complaints Committee on equal rights arguing that a male counterpart was a pay grade higher.\n\nAfter the committee ruled in her favor, the municipality lowered the man\u2019s wages to Ms. Sigfusdottir\u2019s level.\n\n\u201cI went home crying,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cI would have never gone forward with the case knowing it would only lead to my colleague receiving less.\u201d\n\nHalldor Benjamin Thorbergsson, manager of the Confederation of Icelandic Employers, a business association, who is one of the law\u2019s critics, said the initiative created complications and additional expenses for all but big businesses.\n\n\u201cThe law mandates smaller companies to collect records that are technically difficult to obtain,\u201d he said.\n\nWhile equal pay audits should be encouraged, he added, it should be left to businesses to decide whether to institute such measures.\n\nMr. Thorbergsson said he could not predict how broadly the law would affect employees in different industries. \u201cI hope there will be change,\u201d he said, adding that the law tackled more than gender-based pay gaps. \u201cThe law is about equal pay for equal work, between everyone.\u201d\n\nThorgerdur Einarsdottir, a professor of gender studies at the University of Iceland, said the equal pay law was useful but was \u201cno magic wand.\u201d\n\n\u201cA law implementing a standardized job evaluation is not a solid fix to a problem this ambiguous,\u201d she said. \u201cThe deeply rooted stereotypes that favor men and women for certain jobs and professions are the "Dr. Idris Eleanor Leppla and Justin Benjamin Shubow are to be married Jan. 14 at Congregation Emanu-El in San Francisco. Leppla of San Francisco. The bride\u2019s father is a partner in the San Francisco office of Lieff, Cabraser, Heimann & Bernstein, a law firm in New York. Her mother is a special-education teacher at Bowditch Middle School in Foster City, Calif.\n\nThe groom, 40, is the president of the National Civic Art Society, a nonprofit group promoting public art and architecture, in Washington. He graduated, magna cum laude, from Columbia and received a master\u2019s degree in philosophy from the University of Michigan and a law degree from Yale.", "title": "Idris Leppla, Justin Shubow", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mere tinkering won\u2019t alleviate the deep rot in the liberal project, Deneen insists. He says we need to envision a future after liberalism, where local, preferably religious communities tend to the land and look after their own. These groups would cultivate \u201ccultures of community, care, self-sacrifice and small-scale democracy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nReaders of all political stripes can probably find something in this book that rings true, even if it\u2019s followed by the rude awakening of a record scratch. His thoughts on the environment sound like they came out of a Greenpeace brochure \u2014 \u201cShort-term exploitation of the earth\u2019s bounty,\u201d he writes, \u201cforces our children to deal with shortages of such resources as topsoil and potable water\u201d \u2014 while his musings on women, when he deigns to mention women, sound like they came out of an especially cranky episode of \u201cThe 700 Club.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe main practical achievement of this liberation of women has been to move many of them into the work force of market capitalism,\u201d he writes, \u201ca highly dubious form of liberation.\u201d You don\u2019t have to be a raging neoliberal to find this a highly dubious form of generalization. \u201cChildren are increasingly viewed as a limitation upon individual freedom, which contributes to liberalism\u2019s commitment to abortion on demand, while overall birthrates decline across the developed world.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere\u2019s so much moral panic packed into this sentence it\u2019s hard to know where to begin, though the blithe phrasing of \u201cabortion on demand\u201d reflects the old and spiteful stereotype of the so-called modern woman as a dissolute, selfish pleasure-seeker. \u201cToday we consider the paramount sign of the liberation of women to be their growing emancipation from their biology,\u201d Deneen writes. We do? How many women has he talked to about what they want?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDeneen approvingly cites the radical feminist Nancy Fraser to bolster his assertions about women in the work force, yet nowhere does he sufficiently address how gendered injustices \u2014 what Fraser calls \u201cdomestic violence, sexual assault and reproductive oppression\u201d \u2014 might fare in his own faith-based, localist program. Despite his buttoned-up solemnity Deneen occasionally plays peekaboo with his sources, especially the left-wing ones, shining the klieg lights on certain parts of their arguments while eliding others that might complicate his own.\n\nIn an otherwise illuminating section on the development of capitalism, Deneen refers to the great economic historian Karl Polanyi, who showed how the state had to take a strong hand in the creation of ostensibly free markets: \u201cAs Polanyi pithily says of this transformation, \u2018Laissez-faire was planned.\u2019\u201d But Polanyi drew different conclusions from his own observations. An ardent social democrat who fled his beloved Red Vienna when the fascists took over, Polanyi went into exile four times, eventually landing in Canada. This cosmopolitan intellectual, born into a Hungarian-Jewish family, would most likely have been highly suspicious of Deneen\u2019s extreme disdain for what he calls \u201clives of deracinated vagabondage\u201d and his sentimentalization of communal norms enforced by \u201cpeople of good will.\u201d\n\nDeneen says that the only proper response to liberalism is \u201cto transform the household into a small economy.\u201d Home may be where the heart is, but it can also be the site for homegrown prejudice, petty grievances and a vicious cruelty. Deneen is so determined to depict liberalism as a wholly bankrupt ideology that he gives exceedingly short shrift to what might have made it appealing \u2014 and therefore powerful \u2014 in the first place. With all its abiding flaws, liberalism offered a way out for those who didn\u2019t conform to the demands of the clan.\n\nBesides, nobody is truly stopping Deneen from doing what he prescribes: finding a community of like-minded folk, taking to the land, growing his own food, pulling his children out of public school. His problem is that he apparently wants everyone to do these things \u2014 which suggests he may have more in common with his caricature of a bullying liberal than he cares to admit.\n\nOr perhaps it just goes to show that everyone has his blind spots \u2014 even erudite political philosophers keen to denounce the blind spots of others. Deneen and his fellow localists are cast as virtuous souls who would necessarily make discerning, merciful and respectful yeoman farmers once the revolution comes. Yet this generous forbearance doesn\u2019t seem to extend to liberals \u2014 or to use his awkward slur, \u201cliberalocrats\u201d \u2014 who get tarred in this book as a bunch of condescending, self-satisfied chumps. Hypocrites, every one: They\u2019re all the same.", "title": "If Liberalism Is Dead, What Comes Next?", "authors": ["Jennifer Szalai", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s an interplanetary botany discovery that took college students and not NASA scientists to find: Hops \u2014 the flowers used to add a pleasant bitterness to beer \u2014 grow well in Martian soil.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if it\u2019s a practical plant, but it\u2019s doing fairly well,\u201d said Edward F. My apartment on the top floor of a Brooklyn co-op faces a courtyard. A resident on the opposite side of the courtyard complained to management that I have been spotted naked in my apartment. I\u2019m a male in my 70s and no exhibitionist. The neighbor must see me early in the morning when I go to the kitchen to boil water. (I don\u2019t turn on a light.) The waist-high window has curtains pulled back at the bottom around a plant on the sill, and the courtyard is about 150 feet across. This person must be working pretty hard to catch this view. What does the law say about my right to be naked in my own home?\n\nA. New York State decency laws do apply to some behavior inside a private residence. You could cross a line if you were to, say, intentionally flash your neighbors for an extended period of time, a situation I pondered a few years ago in this column.\n\nBut when it comes to walking in the buff in your own home, you\u2019re not breaking New York law \u2014 even if your neighbor spots you. \u201cNudity is, for better or worse, something that pretty much has to be tolerated when you live in a city as densely populated as New York,\u201d said Eric D. Sherman, a real estate lawyer and a partner at the Manhattan law firm Pryor Cashman. Who among us hasn\u2019t walked to the kitchen naked to turn on the kettle, or stepped out of the shower to find the curtains open? And, frankly, why should we feel obligated to stop?", "title": "If a Neighbor Can See You Naked, Do You Have to Cover Up?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Maybe it\u2019s not about her per se \u2014 maybe 12 years as a chancellor is too long not to become complacent, no matter who you are. Ms. Merkel\u2019s first comment after Election Day, when her party came in first but also racked up its largest decline in votes ever, was that she was \u201cnot disappointed\u201d and that she could not see what needed to change now.\n\nNo wonder the public is no longer sure whether Ms. Merkel herself still knows the difference between serenity and fatigue. If one European, after all, has reason to be tired, it is Ms. Merkel.\n\nShe certainly has been confusing two things for far too long: quiet and silence. While one might still think it wise for a head of government to stay away from the hastiness of Twitter, to rarely speak to the public at all is the other extreme. With the exception of dutiful TV appearances during the election campaigns, Ms. Merkel speaks so little to the Germans that it appears she doesn\u2019t have anything to say, or doesn\u2019t see a reason to explain herself or doesn\u2019t deem it necessary to convince anyone of her sapience.\n\nAll this merges into the impression that she feels she herself embodies the country, similar to a monarch who makes rareness a sign of authority. It conveys a whiff of arrogance to tell the Germans, during the migration crisis, \u201cWe will manage this,\u201d and then to switch back to loaded silence instead of explaining exactly how \u201cthis\u201d will be managed.\n\nThat the lady\u2019s not for talking is a particular disappointment to reporters and politicians who have interacted with her in background conversations, where she is outspoken and charming. Had Ms. Merkel displayed more of the talent publicly, she could have spared Germany a good part of the rise of right-wing populism.\n\nIn times like these, it is simply not enough for the chancellor to be the country\u2019s first civil servant, particularly not when the electorate calls for action. That is what is on offer from President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Sebastian Kurz of Austria. Whatever one thinks of their aims (and in Mr. Kurz\u2019s case, of his far-right coalition partner), both manage to convey ambition. During a recent 24-hour stint in Berlin, Mr. Kurz delivered more clear ideas on migration than Ms. Merkel did in the past 24 months. You may take issue with his policies \u2014 which are more restrictive than many Germans would like \u2014 but at least they are clear.\n\nMs. Merkel has lost her message over too many issues. There is no reason to believe this is going to change in a shaky coalition with the Social Democrats, unless the chancellor is planning a surprise. After all, she has indicated that this is her last spin on the Berlin merry-go-round. And nobody knows yet how she\u2019ll behave, freed of the pressure to win \u2014 or lose \u2014 another election. The lady was not for talking. But perhaps, now, for turning?", "title": "Opinion | Imagining a Post-Merkel Germany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement, 7-Eleven Inc., based in Irving, Tex., distanced itself from the situation, saying that the individual stores are franchises that belong to independent business owners, who \u201care solely responsible for their employees, including deciding who to hire and verifying their eligibility to work in the United States.\u201d\n\n\u201c7-Eleven takes compliance with immigration laws seriously and has terminated the franchise agreements of franchisees convicted of violating these laws,\u201d the company said.\n\nIf ICE hoped to make a bold statement, it could hardly pick a more iconic target than 7-Eleven, a chain known for ubiquitous stores that are open all the time and sell the much-loved Slurpees and Big Gulps. Many a 7-Eleven franchise has been a steppingstone for new legal immigrants who want to own and run their own small businesses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNot all franchisees have been scrupulous about whom they hire. ICE called its Wednesday sweep a \u201cfollow-up\u201d of a 2013 investigation that resulted in the arrests of nine 7-Eleven franchise owners and managers on Long Island and in Virginia on charges of employing undocumented workers. Several have pleaded guilty and forfeited their franchises, and have been ordered to pay millions of dollars in back wages owed to the workers.\n\n\u201cThis definitely sends a message to employers,\u201d said Ira Mehlman, the spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which favors more limits on immigration and stricter enforcement.\n\nAccording to ICE, federal agents served inspection notices to 7-Eleven franchises in California, Colorado, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Michigan, Missouri, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Texas, Washington State and Washington, D.C.\n\nEmployees at two 7-Eleven stores on Staten Island said that immigration agents visited the stores on Wednesday. But the agents were shown valid employment records with Social Security numbers, two workers at each of the stores said, and no one was arrested.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn all, 16 of the 98 stores visited on Wednesday were in the New York City area, according to an ICE spokeswoman, Rachael Yong Yow, who would not specify their locations.\n\nIn Miami Beach, an employee at one 7-Eleven said that while no agents showed up at her store, her boss asked workers to make sure their employment records were up to date, in case ICE continued its visits. Agents dropped in on 7-Eleven stores in seven cities in southeast Florida, including Miami Beach, according to Nestor Yglesias, an ICE spokesman; he, too, declined to identify specific stores.\n\nUnder President George W. Bush, ICE grabbed headlines by rounding up unauthorized workers at meatpacking plants, fruit suppliers, carwashes and residences. In a shift, the agency under President Barack Obama focused on catching border crossers, deporting convicted criminals and pursuing employers on paper, by inspecting the I-9 forms that employers are required to fill out and keep to verify their workers\u2019 eligibility.\n\nBy targeting 7-Eleven franchisees and their workers on Wednesday, ICE under Mr. Trump appeared to be melding the approaches of his two predecessors: Go after employers while also detaining employees whom agents encountered without work authorization.\n\nOne of the biggest workplace immigration raids, in May 2008, resulted in the detention of nearly 400 undocumented immigrants, including several children, at an Iowa meatpacking plant. Sholom Rubashkin, the chief executive of the Agriprocessors plant, which was then the largest kosher meatpacking operation in the country, was eventually convicted of bank fraud in federal court.\n\nPresident Trump commuted Mr. Rubashkin\u2019s 27-year prison sentence last month, after years of lobbying by a number of prominent lawyers and politicians who considered his term unduly harsh, and perhaps even anti-Semitic.", "title": "Immigration Agents Target 7-Eleven Stores in Push to Punish Employers", "authors": ["Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Congress has about another month before Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the Obama-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants from deportation (and which President Trump terminated in September), officially comes to an end. It remains to be seen whether Congress will legalize these so-called Dreamers, and what concessions will be made in return. But this much is certain: Any deal will include appropriations for enhanced border enforcement.\n\nWe\u2019ve been here before. The last major immigration reform bill, the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which was signed by President Ronald Reagan, legalized nearly three million undocumented immigrants in exchange for increased enforcement along the United States-Mexico border. (It also legislated sanctions against employers who knowingly hired undocumented workers.) The law was more than just a compromise between pro-immigrant liberals and pro-enforcement conservatives. It embodied the idea that we could \u201cwipe the slate clean\u201d by legalizing the undocumented already here and preventing future unauthorized entries.\n\nThis idea, which continues to shape the national debate about immigration, is based on the false premise that the nation\u2019s borders can be made impregnable. In truth, undocumented migration is not an aberration of \u201cnormal\u201d immigration. It is the inevitable result of any general policy of immigration restriction. Restriction creates two streams of immigration, lawful and unlawful. It is a conceit of the sovereign power to think that it can have only legal immigration.\n\nThe history of immigration in the United States demonstrates this. The Chinese exclusion laws of the late 19th century led to unlawful entry by so-called paper sons (those born in China who claimed they were sons of United States citizens) and spawned an immigration bureaucracy based on extreme vetting, detention and deportations, all tactics that were largely unsuccessful.", "title": "Opinion | Immigration\u2019s Border-Enforcement Myth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHow Not to Impeach\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 2):\n\nGreg Weiner is correct that the process of impeachment must be conducted with \u201csobriety.\u201d While it may still be \u201cunclear\u201d whether or not Donald Trump has committed impeachable offenses, if he has, there should be no question that impeachment is the \u201cprudent political remedy.\u201d\n\nIt is na\u00efve to think that it is possible, if the process confirms that impeachable offenses were committed, to \u201creconcile the public, including Mr. Trump\u2019s base,\u201d with his critics.\n\nWe cannot ignore the simple truth that this base is unmoved by the irrefutable evidence that Mr. Trump, among other character flaws, is a proven liar and dangerous egomaniac and is the most unfit and unqualified president in our history.\n\nYes, impeachment is a political process, but it is the responsibility of Congress, if warranted, to exercise one of its \u201cmost solemn\u201d constitutional powers without regard to whether or not it can muster enough public opinion to give it cover.", "title": "Opinion | Impeachment and Public Opinion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAttacks on Mueller and F.B.I. Open a Rift in the Party of Law and Order\u201d (news article, Dec. 30):\n\nAs a member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, I would like to address claims about the supposed bias at the F.B.I.\n\nI questioned the deputy F.B.I. director, Andrew McCabe, in a closed committee session. While the discussion was confidential, I can assure you that the men and women at the bureau are dedicated public servants committed to defending the American people and upholding the law.\n\nFiring the special counsel, Robert Mueller, would cross a line that congressional leaders in both parties have made clear. Instead, the president\u2019s team is attacking the credibility of Mr. Mueller and the F.B.I. in what appears to be an attempt to sow doubt about Mr. Mueller\u2019s eventual findings.\n\nThese attacks are beyond the scope of normal political dialogue and raise a profound question: What is the president\u2019s team afraid of?", "title": "Opinion | Improper Attacks on Mueller and the F.B.I.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 From Hudson Valley trains to Nassau County bus shelters and Coney Island subways, Joseph J. Lhota, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, seemed to have an answer Thursday for every question at a hearing over the authority\u2019s part of the proposed state budget.\n\nMore than two dozen senators and Assembly members from districts served by the agency got a chance to ask Mr. Lhota about the needs and problems of their particular districts.\n\nThe volley of questions highlighted an almost endemic frustration with the agency, which oversees an octopus-like transit network that includes not just city buses and subways but also the Long Island and Metro-North railroads, making clear that its problems go far beyond the city\u2019s crumbling subway system.\n\nTo most queries, Mr. Lhota indicated that help or a more detailed response was on the way.\n\nThe nearly five hours of questioning, during which Mr. Lhota was joined by other M.T.A. officials, came as the authority is facing questions about its performance, about several high-profile accidents and about claims of deceptive practices. In addition, the agency has been caught in the middle of a public feud between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over how New York City Transit should be funded and improved.", "title": "In 5 Hours of Budget Hearing, Frustration With M.T.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "I soon received a text that a table had opened up and we walked over to Merchant\u2019s. The place effectively operates as two restaurants, a pricier steak and seafood restaurant on the second floor, and a less expensive, modern southern bistro on the ground floor. We opted for the latter and grabbed a booth in the bright, spacious dining room. The fried green tomatoes ($11) were spot-on, and the Nashville Caesar salad with cornbread croutons ($12), and a pulled pork sandwich ($13) were satisfying. One nice thing: When they saw we were sharing everything, they were happy to split the dishes into separate portions.\n\nThat strip of Broadway is just a stone\u2019s throw from Ryman Auditorium, an indelible piece of Nashville history that belongs on every to-do list, especially if the Grand Ole Opry happens to be in residence. The Opry, an artistic home to country musicians since it began in 1925, takes place primarily at Opryland, about 25 minutes northeast of downtown. But if you can, see the show at the Ryman, home to the show from 1943-1974, which sometimes still hosts the Opry. The building itself is a relic \u2014 opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle, it earned the moniker \u201cMother Church of Country Music.\u201d Near the back steps of its hallowed halls, Halena and I passed a young street performer with an amazing voice crooning a song I didn\u2019t recognize. In Nashville, even the buskers have exceptional talent.\n\nTickets aren\u2019t terribly cheap \u2014 the premium seats run close to $100 \u2014 but there\u2019s a slight workaround. I picked up the cheapest tickets I could find: Two obstructed view seats for $48 apiece. (I also checked StubHub and other second-hand ticket sites; they weren\u2019t helpful.) I was expecting to sit smack in front of a column \u2014 I wasn\u2019t. The seats, on the main floor, right in the middle of the auditorium, were perfect. And while there was a thin pole in my line of sight, it didn\u2019t bother me at all.\n\nOnto the show \u2014 the Opry was one of the most pleasurable music performances I\u2019ve attended in recent memory. After grabbing a $9 draft beer, we found our seats to the din of audience chatter and the buttery baritone of the evening\u2019s announcer and M.C., Eddie Stubbs. The Opry functions simultaneously as a live radio show, broadcast on 650 AM WSM. If you\u2019re familiar with public radio\u2019s \u201cLive from Here\u201d (the show formerly known as \u201cA Prairie Home Companion\u201d), it functions in a similar way. Different acts come on and play just two or three songs \u2014 while that\u2019s happening, the next act is hanging out in the wings, which gives the show a casual, collegial quality.", "title": "In Affordable Nashville, Grain Bowls, Hot Chicken and Blistering Guitars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The rangers have learned forensic crime-scene principles and the importance of the so-called chain of custody to ensure that the samples are not corrupted. Dr. Harper\u2019s lab performs the analysis and stores DNA fingerprints.\n\nThe scientists\u2019 database, which they call Rhodis, is modeled after Codis, the F.B.I. system used to link the DNA of suspects to evidence at a crime scene.\n\nThe approach is promising, said Crawford Allan, senior director of Traffic, which monitors illegal wildlife trade at the World Wildlife Fund.\n\nA poaching scene is a crime scene, he said: \u201cIf you want to get through detection and investigation and prosecution, treat it as a crime scene and use forensics.\u201d\n\nPoaching has escalated exponentially in the past decade, he noted. More than 7,000 rhinos have been killed in the past ten years. The World Wildlife Fund estimates that 20,00 to 30,000 African elephants are killed each year for their tusks.\n\nTheir tusks and horns are trafficked through experienced criminal networks. \u201cYou really need sophisticated tools to help solve these crimes,\u201d Mr. Allan said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe rhino project provides \u201ca \u2018cold hit\u2019 database,\u201d said Stephen J. O\u2019Brien, referring to the identification of a perpetrator by DNA when there are no other apparent clues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. O\u2019Brien, an expert on DNA fingerprinting and chief scientific officer of the Theodosius Dobzhansky Center for Genome Bioinformatics at St. Petersburg State University in Russia, is co-author of a new paper, published on Monday in Current Biology, describing the anti-poaching effort.\n\nA similar attempt to use DNA to convict poachers is led by Sam Wasser, director of the Center for Conservation Biology at the University of Washington. His group\u2019s focus is African elephants.\n\nOver a period of 15 years, he and his colleagues have collected and analyzed DNA from dung to create a map of the ranges of various elephant groups based on their genetic differences. It helps show where ivory seized from poachers originated.\n\nThe project has not linked specific carcasses to specific tusks recovered from traffickers. But the analysis has provided valuable clues about the regions in which poachers are operating.\n\n\u201cTo our surprise, the ivory was consistently coming from two areas,\u201d Dr. Wasser said. Tusks from savanna elephants were initially coming from southeastern Tanzania and northern Mozambique, the data showed, but the illegal trade then shifted northward to southern Kenya.\n\nTusks from forest elephants originated in a small triangular area in northeast Gabon, northwest Republic of the Congo, and southeastern Cameroon.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cInstead of focusing everywhere, if we really want the big criminals we should focus on those two spots,\u201d Dr. Wasser said.\n\nThe sale of ivory and rhino horns is hugely lucrative. Rhino horns may bring $60,000 or more per kilogram. A horn generally weighs a few kilograms, but a few have been as heavy as 10 kilograms, or about 22 pounds.\n\n\u201cPound for pound, a rhino horn is worth more than heroin or gold or platinum,\u201d Mr. Allan said. And prosecutions are so rare that the risks for the traffickers are \u201cvery low.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe poacher sells horns to a trafficker, who disguises them and ships them to destination countries, mainly Vietnam and China. Some horns are carved into jewelry while still in South Africa, which can make it extremely difficult to trace them.\n\nMost horns are ground and used as medicine in Asia, believed to cure cancer, impotence \u2014 or, Mr. Allan said, \u201cyou name it.\u201d More recently, people in Asia have begun wearing beads or bangles made from rhino horns thought to have curative powers and to be status symbols. Some horns are made into ceremonial cups.\n\nPhoto\n\nElephant tusks currently sell for $1,000 a kilogram, Dr. Wasser said. Unlike rhino horns, which are shipped in relatively small volumes, traffickers typically collect and ship at least half a ton of ivory, or 500 kilograms, in a container.\n\nSome seizures have uncovered as much as seven tons of ivory in a single shipment, Dr. Wasser said. Ivory is primarily bought by collectors or as an investment.\n\nDr. Wasser\u2019s primary target is traffickers, not poachers. Even when poachers are caught and convicted, he said, \u201cthere are 10 more waiting in line to replace them.\u201d\n\nBut traffickers form the basis of the business that makes poaching profitable. \u201cThe analogy is, are you after a serial killer or a one-time murderer?\u201d he asked.\n\nTo catch a serial killer, Dr. Wasser added, authorities require \u201cintelligence-based forensics to prevent future crimes.\u201d\n\nDr. Harper also hopes to disrupt the criminal networks shipping contraband \u2014 in this case, rhino horns \u2014 to destination countries. So far, the rhino database has been used to convict hunters and traffickers in South Africa, Namibia, Kenya and Swaziland.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the group has not disrupted the criminal conglomerates at the top of the chain, she said.\n\nThe rhinoceros project began in 2010, when poaching was skyrocketing. Thirteen were poached in South Africa in 2007; more than 1,000 are now killed each year.\n\nIn 120 criminal cases completed or still pending, Rhodis has linked DNA on horns, equipment or clothing to particular carcasses, Dr. Harper said. But it can take years for a case to move through the courts and end in a conviction.\n\nThe first successful such conviction involved a Vietnamese smuggler who was caught with seven horns at O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg in 2010. Two were matched to carcasses, and he was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nBut the case involving Mr. Mukwena was one of the first to involve a well-known smuggler. He was arrested on Jan. 16, 2012, after a police officer spotted him walking across a field carrying a black bag.\n\nWhen the officer confronted him, Mr. Mukwena dropped the bag and ran. It contained three rhinoceros horns, two from a cow and one from her calf.\n\nApprehended, Mr. Mukwena admitted to killing the cow but said an accomplice had killed the calf because it was bothering him.", "title": "In Africa, Geneticists Are Hunting Poachers", "authors": ["Gina Kolata"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Since Mr. Trump took office a year ago, the political press has endured a sustained assault from a chief executive who has called journalists \u201cthe enemy of the American people.\u201d Yet the news media has also driven decisions inside the West Wing to a degree perhaps unmatched since the scandal-ridden days of Richard Nixon. And White House aides and reporters alike say that political reality is being refracted by the media in an unprecedented way.\n\nSome reporters, in unguarded moments, say that they fear for journalists\u2019 safety. Margaret Talev, the president of the White House Correspondents\u2019 Association, was moved to tears in an interview as she recounted the death threats that now routinely land in her colleagues\u2019 emails.\n\nOther journalists \u2014 ironic, cynical or simply enterprising, depending on your point of view \u2014 have embraced the moment as the wildest ride of their lives, and a lucrative one, too: The number of Washington reporters with cable television contracts, some with salaries verging on six figures, has surged.\n\nIt is a boom time for investigative reporting \u2014 witness the revelations unearthed by The New York Times, Politico, The Washington Post and others \u2014 and also for rank incrementalism. A story\u2019s \u201cbuzz,\u201d variously defined by the number of retweets, Facebook likes or panicked text messages from White House aides that it generates, is at a premium, fueling news outlets that condense political reporting from 1,000-word stories into stand-alone nuggets designed to set Twitter aflame.\n\nTrust in the press has eroded thanks, in part, to Mr. Trump and his allies, the ubiquitous phrase \u201cfake news\u201d osmosing its way into the American psyche. Yet newspaper subscriptions and television news ratings, once in free fall, have perked back up.\n\n\u201cWhen he says you\u2019ll miss me when I\u2019m gone, and your ratings will go through the floor, he\u2019s absolutely correct,\u201d Mr. Bannon said, mischievously, of Mr. Trump. \u201cThat\u2019s McLuhan talking through Trump.\u201d\n\nMr. Bannon played a not-minor role in creating the current media atmosphere: At Breitbart News, where he was executive chairman until his abrupt exit this month, he whipped up anger against CNN and other major news organizations; upon entering the White House, he instructed the news media to \u201ckeep its mouth shut and just listen for a while.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWearing four visible layers of shirts (including a zip-up fleece from West Point, which one of his daughters attended), Mr. Bannon declined to speak on the record about his own role in making the fraught new media environment. But there were signs that, like Mr. Trump, he is aware he has benefited from the same news media that he likes to denigrate.\n\nPhoto\n\nA copy of \u201cDevil\u2019s Bargain,\u201d a chronicle of Mr. Bannon\u2019s rise to prominence by the Bloomberg Businessweek journalist Joshua Green, sat on the mantel above the fireplace. The book is being adapted into a television series by the powerful Hollywood producer Jason Blum, who recently flew to Washington to meet with Mr. Bannon at his home.\n\nA year ago, the worries of Washington journalists were manifold: eviction from the West Wing, the end of regular pool reports and briefings, a Breitbart takeover of White House coverage. None of these anxieties came to fruition; in fact, last week, when Mr. Trump wandered into a small reporters\u2019 briefing with his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, Breitbart\u2019s White House correspondent was one of the journalists grumbling afterward about not being invited.\n\nMr. Trump has forsaken formal news conferences, and his usual forum for sit-down interviews has been Fox News. (Last week, in Davos, the president acquiesced to interviews with CNBC and the British presenter Piers Morgan, who has usually been friendly toward Mr. Trump.) But he has embraced the so-called \u201cpool sprays\u201d \u2014 journalist jargon for a White House photo-op \u2014 to spar with reporters off-the-cuff, sometimes for nearly an hour at a time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAmid the insanity of the attacks on our industry, you have this journalistic nirvana,\u201d said Jim VandeHei, a co-founder of Politico who now runs Axios, an outlet that went live a year ago with the aim of distilling Washington\u2019s complexities into highly tweetable micro-scoops. \u201cYou get play-by-play visibility you could only dream of under previous presidents.\u201d\n\nMr. VandeHei proselytized for his site\u2019s \u201csmart brevity\u201d philosophy during an interview at Axios\u2019s Virginia offices, inside a co-working space where pale ale is on tap and the coffee urns specify the altitude at which the beans are grown.\n\nAxios covers the Trump administration with a bullet-pointed morning newsletter, by the well-connected Washington journalist Mike Allen, and quick-hit scoops from its sole White House reporter, Jonathan Swan. To hear Mr. VandeHei tell it, the era of the in-depth newspaper story is over.\n\n\u201cPeople aren\u2019t reading that long and, to be honest, they shouldn\u2019t have to,\u201d he said.\n\nAn Axios buzzword is \u201cilluminate\u201d \u2014 tell readers exactly what they need to know, and nothing more. Mr. Swan, a newcomer to Washington who regularly breaks news, does not attend White House briefings, where fresh information can be scarce.\n\nHis avoidance of the ritual is likely to cheer liberal critics who say the Washington press has been too meek and rigid in adjusting to the Trump juggernaut. There were groans, in November, after a briefing during which the press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, asked White House reporters to preface their questions with a list of what they were thankful for \u2014 a schoolyard exercise that some journalists played along with.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Ms. Talev, a Bloomberg News correspondent and the president of the Correspondents\u2019 Association, said that the briefing remains an opportunity to force the administration to speak on the record \u2014 a crucial forum in an era when truth is blurred. \u201cWe think briefings serve people; we think open dialogue serves people,\u201d she said in an interview at Peet\u2019s Coffee, a block from her West Wing desk.\n\nMs. Talev said that her father escaped Communist Bulgaria in the 1960s, where dissent was squashed and criticizing government officials was forbidden. Her work, she said, feels personal these days. Under her watch, the Correspondents\u2019 Association has created a new committee on reporters\u2019 security, to assist members who receive threats, an increasingly common occurrence.\n\nApril D. Ryan, the White House reporter for American Urban Radio Networks and one of the few black correspondents in the briefing room, has described receiving menacing and racist messages; she was subsequently derided as \u201cMiss Piggy\u201d by a high-ranking official in the Department of Housing and Urban Development.\n\nLast week, a man in Michigan was arrested on suspicion of threatening CNN\u2019s Atlanta headquarters, the kind of real-world effect that reporters here worry may be the inevitable result of a president who once called the press \u201ca great danger to our country.\u201d\n\nWork in the capital, however, goes on. Beneath the White House briefing room, where about two dozen journalists occupy a warren of cramped offices and cubicles, the mood is like that of any other workplace, as it was under past administrations.\n\nBut subtle subversions do exist. For months, a New Yorker cartoon has been tacked to the wall in a prominent place by the stairs. It shows two bearded prisoners hanging inside a dungeon.\n\nOne prisoner to the other: \u201cPersonally, I prefer the old White House pressroom.\u201d", "title": "In Age of Trump, Political Reporters Are in Demand and Under Attack", "authors": ["Michael M. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Interior Department is poised to approve a land swap in Alaska that would allow the remote town of King Cove to build a road through the sensitive wetlands of Izembek National Wildlife Refuge, state and local officials said Saturday.\n\nThe agreement, first reported by The Washington Post, is expected to be signed this month. The King Cove Corporation, a tribal organization that manages the area, will exchange approximately 250 to 500 acres of land for the ability to cut an approximately 200-acre strip through the refuge, said Henry Mack, the mayor of King Cove.\n\nThe decision by Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke will effectively overturn a determination made by former President Barack Obama\u2019s interior secretary, Sally Jewell, in 2013. Ms. Jewell found that a road would cause irreparable harm to Izembek\u2019s ecology and wildlife, including the grizzly bear, caribou and geese for whom the refuge is a critical habitat.\n\nThe community of King Cove, whose population is under 1,000, has been fighting for decades for the right to build a single-lane road through the refuge to the neighboring town of Cold Bay, which has an all-weather airport that can provide flights to hospitals in Anchorage.", "title": "In Alaska, a Deal Is Made for a Controversial Road Inside a Refuge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Alps faced widespread avalanche warnings, and some villages were cut off this week after the winter storm Eleanor swept through the region, dumping more than six feet of snow in some areas.\n\nThe road into the French ski resort of Val Thorens was closed because of the snowfall for a period of time from Wednesday into Thursday, leaving thousands of vacationers stranded. Authorities advised those staying in the area to remain indoors until the storm passed by.\n\nBut even after the snowfall stopped, the risk for avalanches continued, with Val Thorens and other areas remaining on the highest alert in the days after the storm.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the Austrian Alps, two German skiers were killed in an avalanche on Friday near Kals in Tyrol province, according to the German news outlet Bild.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the Italian ski resort town of Cervinia, the storm blanketed the area with two meters, or six and a half feet, of snow. The only road connecting the resort to the outside world was closed for 24 hours, leaving nearly 10,000 tourists stranded in the town, according to the Italian news agency ANSA. Photos posted to social media showed buried cars and sidewalks and streets made impassable by the snow.\n\nWhen the road out of Cervinia reopened on Friday afternoon, a line of cars was waiting to exit the town.", "title": "In Alps, Avalanche Warnings and Stranded Skiers After 6 Feet of Snow", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "It is one of the indisputable axioms in pro sports: Teams that open new stadiums raise prices for tickets, parking and food. After all, the owners have to recoup the hundreds of millions \u2014 or billions \u2014 of dollars in construction costs.\n\nArthur M. Blank, the owner of the N.F.L.\u2019s Atlanta Falcons and Atlanta United of Major League Soccer, has tried to break the mold, at least for food and drinks. When he opened Mercedes-Benz Stadium last year, he included concession stands selling craft beer, designer sandwiches and high-end barbecue.\n\nBut he also included a value menu, with bottomless soft drinks, $2 hot dogs, $5 cheeseburgers and other affordable items. The idea was to give fans a break while acknowledging that the price to attend games, including personal seat licenses for season-ticket holders, was more expensive than in the Falcons\u2019 previous home, the Georgia Dome.\n\nThe approach has paid dividends. Despite a 50 percent decrease in prices for food and nonalcoholic drinks compared to prices in the Georgia Dome, the amount spent per fan increased by 16 percent, Blank\u2019s sports company, AMB Sports and Entertainment, said on Thursday.", "title": "In Atlanta, Concessions Prices Go Down and Revenue Goes Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "At 75, this eminence grise of Canadian cooking, an early champion of indigenous cuisine, is traveling around the province teaching young chefs reared in the age of Twitter how to use the techniques of their ancestors \u2014 such as covering a partridge in clay and simmering it for eight hours on top of hot stones in the ground.\n\nMs. Nottaway, who also goes by her French-Canadian name, Marie-Cecile, is a member of the Algonquin nation, one of the 11 indigenous groups in Quebec whose people lived here long before European settlers arrived in the 17th century.\n\nAfter decades in which these communities have grappled with discrimination, poverty, gambling, suicide and alcoholism, Ms. Nottaway sees her embrace of traditional cooking techniques as nothing less than \u201cdecolonizing myself.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is the food I grew up on,\u201d she said. \u201cThey took away our land, our culture, our language, and I am fighting to bring it back with my food.\u201d\n\nThe plucky, charismatic chef, who speaks three languages (English, French and Algonquin), juggles her catering business with raising her two children, and is as at home with a shotgun as with a frying pan. Her interest in traditional cooking took root when she was a teenager, eschewing trips to McDonald\u2019s in favor of learning Algonquin recipes, passed on orally from her grandmothers.", "title": "In Canada, Hunting and Preserving an Indigenous Way of Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "One lawmaker after another rose to support her bill, and in some cases, argue that it should be strengthened.\n\nThe debate came, coincidentally, as Canada is reeling from a maelstrom of accusations of sexually inappropriate behavior against men in positions of power, and their swift removal.\n\nJust last week, two provincial Conservative Party leaders and a federal cabinet minister resigned. Outside of politics, one of the most prominent members of Toronto\u2019s theater community quit the company he founded, accused in a lawsuit of sexual harassment. And last fall, two of Quebec\u2019s most well-known celebrities disappeared from stages and television screens amid accusations of sexual impropriety.\n\nAll of the Canadian cases came after revelations last fall about the American film producer Harvey Weinstein set off a wave of accusations of sexual harassment and impropriety, with women speaking out loudly through the #MeToo movement and dozens of men resigning from their posts in entertainment, politics, publishing and journalism.\n\nCanada had already been grappling with the issue of sexual assault in various cases through the years, but the volume of women\u2019s voices across the border gave many reason to believe that the climate in their country might have changed, too.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a perfect storm for reform,\u201d said Michelle Coffin, a political science professor at Saint Mary\u2019s University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, who worked in provincial politics for more than five years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not only that Canadian women feel emboldened by their American counterparts, she added. They also feel propelled by American politics, she said.\n\nWomen are speaking up to make sure \u201cthat we do not get to that place where we have a prime minister accused of sexual assault, where there\u2019s a tape of him talking about women in a misogynistic way,\u201d Professor Coffin said, referring to the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d recording in which Donald J. Trump bragged about grabbing women\u2019s genitals.\n\nPaulette Senior, president of the Canadian Women\u2019s Foundation, which finances gender equality projects across the country, said the election of Mr. Trump galvanized Canadian feminists, too.\n\n\u201cIt woke up women out of their slumber, those of us, even me, who took it for granted that could never happen,\u201d Ms. Senior said. \u201cWe realized that all we have worked for can be lost.\u201d\n\nOver the past week, as the accusations piled up, Canadian politicians from all parties have been swift to demand change and, even more unusually, publicly applaud female victims for disclosing their stories of abuse or assault, even anonymously.\n\nPhoto\n\nLisa Raitt, the deputy leader of the Conservative Party, called the women whose disclosures have toppled two provincial leaders from her own party \u201cbrave young women\u201d on the national Canadian Broadcasting Corporation over the weekend. \u201cI commend them for coming forward. Now, it\u2019s caused an awful lot of turmoil in politics, but that\u2019s O.K.\u201d\n\nRachel Notley, the premier of Alberta, put out a message on Facebook on Monday evening: \u201cI say to everyone in Alberta who has been subject to sexual harassment, you have a right to tell your story and share your experience. And that right must come without fear of retribution. Any form of intimidation is wrong. Threats associated with speaking out are also wrong. Completely.\u201d\n\nMs. Notley\u2019s public announcement came after an Alberta political staff member last week on Twitter accused Kent Hehr, federal minister of sport and persons with disabilities, of making sexual comments about her, prompting his resignation. The staff member told various Canadian media outlets that after her accusations she received a barrage of death threats, including one slipped under her door at home.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnlike the government in Washington, the federal government in Canada under Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, a self-described feminist, has been leading the push to address sexual harassment. The legislation his government introduced Monday defines it broadly, as any comment, gesture or touching \u201cof a sexual nature\u201d that could offend or humiliate an employee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bill also includes as sexual harassment any \u201ccondition of a sexual nature\u201d that might affect a worker\u2019s job security or opportunities for promotion. If passed, the changes will set up a formal complaint system and give the labor department sweeping investigatory powers.\n\nThe proposed measure also extends the rules to political staff members for the first time. Over the past week, many former political staff members have told personal stories of unwanted groping, kissing and lewd comments they suffered so regularly they thought it was part of the job.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThings need to change and it starts with saying emphatically that it is never O.K.,\u201d said Ms. Hajdu, the labor minister, on Monday. She said Parliament was \u201ca place where often the victimized individual is blamed for the harassment that she herself has experienced. We are all familiar with this phrase: \u2018She brought it on herself.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe new definitions and complaint systems will, in practice, benefit a minority of Canadian workers \u2014 those who work in the federal government and in federally regulated businesses like banks, airlines and railways.\n\nJust over three years ago, the debate over sexual harassment flared up in Canada after the firing and arrest of a prominent musician and radio host, Jian Ghomeshi. That brought the topic of sexual assault out from women\u2019s shelters into coffee shops and onto daily radio shows, where it has mostly remained.\n\nBut instead of emboldening other women, the spectacle of Mr. Ghomeshi\u2019s criminal trial proved to silence women. In declaring Mr. Ghomeshi not guilty, the judge described the female complainants as insincere and deceptive.\n\nNow that the movement is back on its feet, Canadian feminists say, they hope the grass-roots movement catches up with the political leadership, and changes spread from politics and the media into other domains.\n\n\u201cIt is a very interesting political time,\u201d said Lise Gotell, a professor of women and gender studies at the University of Alberta. \u201cThere is a lot of space for feminism. I certainly would not have predicted this.\u201d", "title": "In Canada, a \u2018Perfect Storm\u2019 for a #MeToo Reckoning", "authors": ["Ian Austen", "Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Scientists on Thursday announced the discovery of a fossilized human jawbone in a collapsed cave in Israel that they said is between 177,000 and 194,000 years old.\n\nIf confirmed, the find may rewrite the early migration story of our species, pushing back by about 50,000 years the time that Homo sapiens first ventured out of Africa.\n\nPrevious discoveries in Israel had convinced some anthropologists that modern humans began leaving Africa between 90,000 and 120,000 years ago. But the recently dated jawbone is unraveling that narrative.\n\n\u201cThis would be the earliest modern human anyone has found outside of Africa, ever,\u201d said John Hawks, a paleoanthropologist from the University of Wisconsin, Madison who was not involved in the study.", "title": "In Cave in Israel, Scientists Find Jawbone Fossil From Oldest Modern Human Out of Africa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "He did not mention abortion rights, same-sex marriage or gender identity, three issues over which Chilean lawmakers have sparred in recent months. But he called on Chile to \u201clisten to migrants who are knocking on the door of this country in search of a better life, and at the same time, with the strength and hope to build a better future for all.\u201d\n\nThe pope also championed indigenous rights ahead of a visit on Wednesday to a region in southern Chile that has become embroiled in the Mapuche indigenous people\u2019s fight to reclaim ancestral lands.\n\nThe speech was interrupted by bursts of applause, but the pope drew criticism for what he did next. After leaving the presidential palace, Francis celebrated Mass in Santiago alongside Bishop Juan Barros Madrid of Osorno, a city in southern Chile. Bishop Barros has been accused of protecting the Rev. Fernando Karadima, a former priest who was defrocked by the Vatican for abusing teenagers during the 1980s and 1990s.\n\nThe pope has been criticized for elevating Father Barros to bishop in 2015 despite being aware of the allegations against him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The decline in Chile has been among the steepest. Between 1995 and last year, the number of Chileans who described themselves as Catholic dropped to 45 percent from 74 percent, according to a poll conducted by Latinobar\u00f3metro, which Ms. Lagos runs. The poll had a margin of error of 2.8 to 3 percentage points.\n\nMr. Cruz, the abuse victim, said the pope\u2019s decision to offer Mass alongside Bishop Barros brought into sharp focus why many across Latin America had turned away from the church.\n\n\u201cThat is such a terrible sign and an incoherent signal to survivors,\u201d he said, calling it \u201cthe reason Chile has lost so much faith in the hierarchy and we have become a much less Catholic country.\u201d", "title": "In Chile, Pope Francis Apologizes for \u2018Irreparable Damage\u2019 Caused by Sexual Abuse", "authors": ["Ernesto Londo\u00f1o"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mayor Bill de Blasio took the oath of office on Monday, a frigid New Year\u2019s Day, to begin his second and last term, with broad promises for building a fairer city and with his sights already fixed beyond the five boroughs.\n\nHe was sworn in by the populist senator and leftist icon Bernie Sanders of Vermont, in an outdoor ceremony that was truncated because of the cold \u2014 a youth chorus and the city\u2019s youth poet laureate were eliminated from the program, and Mr. de Blasio said that he shortened his remarks out of consideration for his shivering audience. The temperature was in the teens, under a powdery blue sky, with a sharp wind that picked up once the mayor began speaking.\n\nSeveral hundred people, including other elected officials, watched the ceremony in the plaza in front of City Hall, although empty seats were scattered throughout \u2014 a contrast to four years ago when thousands packed Mr. de Blasio\u2019s first swearing in (the weather then was warmer).\n\nAside from Mr. Sanders, the political star power was significantly reduced from Mr. de Blasio\u2019s first inauguration. The city has argued that the site would be much busier, with ferries coming and going most of the day to fill their gas tanks and unload wastewater.\n\nEven if Waterway received the permits it would need to operate there, Hoboken could try to use eminent domain. That is where New Jersey Transit comes in. As a state agency, its ownership would trump Hoboken\u2019s power to take the property, city officials said.\n\nAlthough the transit agency does not operate any ferries of its own or have any control of Waterway or the fares it charges \u2014 as much as $9 for an eight-minute ride across the river \u2014 it is planning to buy the site and lease it back to the ferry company. Nancy Snyder, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, said she could not divulge the terms of the proposed deal until after the board voted. There are five voting board members, including three who are allies of Mr. Christie, a Republican.\n\nMs. Snyder said that the agency had statutory responsibility to embark on capital projects and make improvements that \u201csupport robust ferry service in the trans-Hudson corridor.\u201d She added that \u201coptimizing the availability and use of ferries will be a crucial part of a coordinated transportation strategy to meet future travel needs of New Jersey residents.\u201d\n\nNew Jersey Transit has relied on the ferry company to help get commuters across the Hudson when train service was disrupted, as it was for several weeks last summer.\n\nPat Smith, a spokesman for Waterway, said the company would pay more than $100,000 in annual rent to New Jersey Transit and intended to invest more than $10 million in the property.\n\nIn November, Waterway\u2019s chairman, Armand Pohan, told Hoboken\u2019s City Council that it would be a mistake to try to take the site because, in addition to paying fair value for the property, the city would have to find another location for the facility.", "title": "In Christie\u2019s Last Days, Hoboken Waterfront Tussle Drags On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "The clash between California and Mr. Trump and his supporters \u2014 between one America and another \u2014 began the morning after he won the presidency, when Kevin de Le\u00f3n, the State Senate leader, and his counterpart in the Assembly, Anthony Rendon, said they \u201cwoke up feeling like strangers in a foreign land.\u201d\n\nSince then the fight has metastasized into what could be the greatest contest over values between a White House and a state since the 1950s and 1960s, when the federal government moved to end segregation and expand civil rights.\n\nBack then, of course, the ideologies and values at issue were reversed, as conservative Southerners, under the banner of states\u2019 rights, fought violently to uphold white supremacy. In these times it is liberal California making the case for states\u2019 rights, traditionally a Republican position.\n\n\u201cIt seems like every day brings a new point of contention between two very different types of leadership,\u201d said Jim Newton, a lecturer at the University of California, Los Angeles.\n\nAnd it does not end there: New laws that went into effect on Jan. 1 in California raised the minimum wage, allowed parents to withhold gender on birth certificates and strengthened what were already some of the toughest gun laws in the country by restricting ammunition sales and assault weapons, and barring school officials from carrying concealed weapons at work. Taken together, the measures are the surest signs yet of how California is setting itself apart from Washington \u2014 and many parts of America, too.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. de Le\u00f3n, along with almost the entire leadership of California, has been a bulwark against the Trump administration. Mr. de Le\u00f3n introduced the so-called sanctuary state legislation \u2014 the California Values Act \u2014 that restricts state authorities from cooperating with federal immigration agents, and places limits on agents entering schools, churches, hospitals or courthouses to detain undocumented immigrants. The law went into effect Jan. 1, provoking a prankster \u2014 presumably a Trump supporter \u2014 to put up those highway signs, and setting off a war of words between California and the administration.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nThe state should \u201chold on tight,\u201d said Thomas Homan, the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, in an interview on Fox News last week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey are about to see a lot more special agents, a lot more deportation officers,\u201d he said. \u201cIf the politicians in California don\u2019t want to protect their communities, then ICE will.\u201d\n\nMr. Homan went on to assail politicians who support the sanctuary policy, suggesting they should be arrested.\n\nDarrell Steinberg, the mayor of Sacramento, California\u2019s capital, reacted angrily on Wednesday, saying on Twitter that \u201cthey certainly know where to find me.\u201d\n\nAlso this week, Mr. de Le\u00f3n introduced legislation to limit the impact of the new tax bill on Californians by essentially allowing residents to pay their state taxes in the form of a charitable contribution, which could then be deducted when filing federal income tax.\n\nMr. de Le\u00f3n also said he was working with Eric H. Holder Jr., an attorney general under President Barack Obama, to push back against attempts to enforce federal marijuana law, which Attorney General Jeff Sessions said Thursday he would allow federal prosecutors to do.\n\n\u201cWhether Jeff Sessions likes cannabis is not the question,\u201d Mr. de Le\u00f3n said. \u201cThe people of California voted overwhelmingly to legalize marijuana for recreational use.\u201d\n\nFor his part, Mr. Trump is the first president since Dwight D. Eisenhower to not take a trip to California in his first calendar year in office, not even to visit his golf course in Rancho Palos Verdes, south of Los Angeles, or a mansion he owns in Beverly Hills, or to tour the vast damage left in the wake of a series of wildfires. By contrast, he has made multiple trips to other states hit by natural disasters, including Texas and Florida after Hurricanes Harvey and Irma.\n\nIn California, every state leader is a Democrat, including the governor and the leaders of the State Senate and Assembly. Of the state\u2019s 53 members in Congress, only 14 are Republicans, and analysts believe several of them are in jeopardy of losing their seats to Democrats in next year\u2019s midterm elections because of opposition in California to Mr. Trump.\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, not every Californian is lining up to join the opposition. Representative Kevin McCarthy, the Republican House majority leader, has stood firm with the president, was a strong supporter of the tax bill, and has said he believes there is still an opportunity for Democrats and the administration to come together, particularly on immigration. In an interview with Fox News on Friday, he said, \u201cI think there is a plan for securing the border, for dealing with chain migration.\u201d He added, \u201cI think there is a common ground that both sides can get to.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut California\u2019s diversity \u2014 40 percent Latino, and with an estimated 2.3 million undocumented workers, according to a Pew Research Center survey \u2014 is regarded by many people here as a powerful counternarrative to the Trump administration\u2019s anti-immigration policies and the ugly racial incidents and outbursts of white supremacy that have surfaced during his presidency in places like Charlottesville, Va.\n\nBeyond demographics and politics, charting its own course is part of the identity of California. \u201cWe are the frontier,\u201d said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at the University of Southern California. \u201cBeyond us, there\u2019s nothing but ocean.\u201d\n\nCalifornia is not the only liberal state standing up to the Trump administration. But as the most populous state, with close to 40 million people \u2014 if it were a country it would be the world\u2019s sixth largest economy, sandwiched between Britain and France \u2014 California has been energized in the age of Trump to take the lead in opposing what many here believe is a depressing reversal of American progress.\n\n\u201cCalifornia has distinguished itself from the federal government for a long time,\u201d said Elizabeth Ashford, a political consultant who has worked for Gov. Jerry Brown, former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Senator Kamala Harris. \u201cCertainly Arnold spent a lot of time talking about California as almost a nation-state. And many Californians feel that way.\u201d\n\nShe continued, \u201cFor Californians and California there\u2019s always this concept of a Golden State, a model of what a state can be and achieve.\u201d These days, with the country roiled by a resurgence in white supremacy and nasty fights over immigration and diversity, essentially a battle over American identity, she said, \u201cthere are sharp distinctions that many Californians are drawing between us and them.\u201d\n\nThose distinctions may become sharper, as a generational shift in California Democratic politics, driven by leaders like Mr. de Le\u00f3n, could tilt the state further to the left. Mr. de Le\u00f3n, 51, is mounting a primary challenge to Senator Dianne Feinstein, 84, by positioning himself more to the left \u2014 and more stridently opposed to the president \u2014 than his rival.\n\nOrdinary Californians have found other ways to push back.\n\nOne of them is Andrew Sturm, a graduate student in visual arts at the University of California, San Diego. Last year, Mr. Sturm was with a friend in Tijuana, Mexico, at a spot near the border where prototypes of Mr. Trump\u2019s planned wall had been positioned.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe were thinking, man, these things look like drive-in movie screens,\u201d he said. \u201cWe were thinking about how we could do something with them.\u201d\n\nThe result was a display of political art, in the form of light. One evening this fall at dusk, Mr. Sturm and other activists, working from the Mexican side of the border, erected theater lights and used stencils to project images onto the prototypes \u2014 of a ladder, of the Statue of Liberty.\n\n\u201cI felt kind of sick as a U.S. citizen,\u201d he said, referring to Mr. Trump\u2019s immigration policies. \u201cI didn\u2019t want folks in Mexico to think this is how we all feel.\u201d", "title": "In Clash Between California and Trump, It\u2019s One America Versus Another", "authors": ["Tim Arango"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "BOGOT\u00c1, Colombia \u2014 The crowd gathered here in the capital, wearing white shirts and waving campaign signs, as what had once been Colombia\u2019s largest rebel group opened its campaign for the presidency.\n\nBut at a northern port, bombs exploded as a different group continued to attack. Five police officers were killed and more than 40 were wounded in the city of Barranquilla in a bombing at a police station. A faction of the National Liberation Army, the guerrilla organization known as the E.L.N., claimed responsibility.\n\nThe contrasting scenes this weekend highlight the challenge Colombia now faces in its road to peace. While the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC, have signed a peace deal with the government and entered politics, many guerrillas of the E.L.N. seem bent on pressing their long battle against the state.\n\nOn Monday, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia, whose government had been negotiating with the rebels in Ecuador, said he was suspending the talks.", "title": "In Colombia, Two Rebel Groups Take Different Paths", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "The vote this month follows parliamentary elections in October won by the populist Ano movement, led by the billionaire Andrej Babis, who was then appointed prime minister.\n\nAfter those parliamentary elections, \u201cit seemed that the Czech Republic may be sliding to what we see in Hungary and Poland,\u201d said Jiri Pehe, who was a political adviser to President Vaclav Havel and is now the director of New York University in Prague.
