And in the 11 months before he was inaugurated, 2.1 million jobs were added.", "title": "In Davos Speech, Trump Mixes Facts With Fiction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "When she is not pushing the boundaries of scientific knowledge, Dr. Gianotti\u2019s other passion is music: She is a dedicated pianist.\n\nPhoto\n\nChristine Lagarde\n\nManaging director of the International Monatery Fund in Washington\n\nChristine Lagarde has been a trailblazer throughout her career in both her native France and abroad, dotted with many a \u201cfirst woman to hold the position of\u201d preface.\n\nAfter earning a law degree in Paris and a master\u2019s in political science, she worked as a lawyer for nearly 25 years at Baker McKenzie in Chicago, becoming the firm\u2019s first chairwoman.\n\nIn 2005, she was appointed France\u2019s trade minister, and in 2007 she became minister of finance, the first woman to hold the latter position not only in France but in any of the Group of 8 countries. She became the first woman to lead the International Monetary Fund in 2011.\n\nIn 2016, she was one of 17 French female former government ministers who signed an op-ed article published in the weekly Journal du Dimanche decrying sexism and sexual harassment in French politics.\n\nPhoto\n\nGinni Rometty\n\nChairwoman, president and chief executive of IBM, New York\n\nGinni Rometty has been at the helm of IBM since 2012, when she became the company\u2019s first female chief executive. She joined IBM in 1981 as a systems engineer, after having worked at General Motors. Ms. Rometty studied computer science and electrical engineering on a scholarship provided by General Motors at Northwestern University.\n\nForbes has ranked her 10th on its list of the world\u2019s 100 most powerful women (2017) and 61st among the world\u2019s most powerful people (2016).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt IBM, she has championed diversity initiatives, leading the women in technology council and the women\u2019s leadership council.\n\nPhoto\n\nChetna Gala Sinha\n\nFounder and president of the Mann Deshi Mahila Bank and Mann Deshi Foundation in India\n\nA woman of many talents, Chetna Gala Sinha has been working for social change in her native India since 1986.\n\nIn 1987, she left Mumbai for Mhaswad, a drought-prone area in western India, where she and her husband, Vijay Sinha, an activist and farmer, worked in agriculture. Witnessing the difficulties that women faced in the region, she chose to focus on teaching them entrepreneurial skills and financial literacy to empower them and offer them more independence.\n\nIn 1997, she founded India\u2019s first rural cooperative bank owned by women: the Mann Deshi Mahila Bank, which provides women with access to financial services, business loans and training. In its first two decades, the bank has reached over 200,000 women in Maharashtra, a state in the western region.\n\nA Yale World Fellow in 2002 and an Ashoka Fellow in 1996, Ms. Sinha last year received the Forbes India Leadership Award for an entrepreneur with social impact.\n\nPhoto\n\nErna Solberg\n\nPrime minister of Norway\n\nNicknamed Norway\u2019s Angela Merkel, Erna Solberg was elected in 2013 and again in 2017, becoming the first Conservative prime minister to win a second term since 1985. Ms. Solberg leads a right-wing coalition and is the second woman to serve as prime minister of the Scandinavian country. In 2016, she was appointed a leader of the United Nations secretary general\u2019s Sustainable Development Goals Advocacy Group.\n\nMs. Solberg has led the Conservative Party since 2004 and represented it in Storting (Parliament) since 1989. From 2001 to 2005, as minister of local government and regional development under Prime Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik, she earned the title \u201cIron Erna\u201d for her tough stance on immigration.\n\nAfter her re-election, she appointed women to the posts of finance minister and foreign minister. For the first time, the three top posts in Norway\u2019s cabinet are held by women.", "title": "In Davos, Pioneering Women Are Chosen to Lead Again", "authors": ["B\u00e9reng\u00e8re Sim"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Rather than touting the virtues of lowering economic barriers, Mr. Trump will promote the growing American economy and argue for foreign investment.\n\n\u201cThe president will continue to promote fair economic competition and will make it clear that there cannot be free and open trade if countries are not held accountable to the rules,\u201d said Gary D. Cohn, his economics adviser. \u201cAs the president has said repeatedly, America and his administration supports free and open trade, but it needs to be fair and reciprocal.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHis message will stand out. In the forum\u2019s opening address on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India defended globalization. Later in the day, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced that his country and 10 other Pacific Rim nations had concluded talks for a trade pact without the United States.\n\nScheduled to depart from Washington on Wednesday night, Mr. Trump will stay in Davos just one night and meet with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, with whom he had testy exchanges over his posting of anti-Muslim videos distributed by a far-right British group, as well as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, with whom he is friendlier. He will also attend a reception of world leaders in his honor and host a dinner for European corporate chieftains.\n\nSeven cabinet secretaries, including Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, are scheduled to attend. Among those who will not come is Melania Trump, who has kept a low profile since a new book reported that she was so wary of life in the White House that she cried on election night and The Wall Street Journal reported that her husband\u2019s lawyer sent $130,000 to a porn actress before the election to keep her from discussing an alleged sexual encounter with Mr. Trump.\n\nMrs. Trump denied the book\u2019s account and has otherwise largely remained silent. Her spokeswoman, Stephanie Grisham, said on Tuesday that the first lady was not coming to Davos because there were \u201ctoo many scheduling and logistical issues.\u201d\n\nHow Mr. Trump will calibrate his message is the preoccupation of the forum so far. Will he declare victory over the fat cats? Lecture them about trade? Or seek to win them over?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s not going to get up to the stage of Davos and insult them,\u201d predicted Anne-Marie Slaughter, the president of New America, a Washington-based research organization, and a former director of policy planning at the State Department under President Barack Obama. \u201cHe\u2019s so often a chameleon. He will adapt his message completely to the crowd. What he tweets, on the other hand, is likely to be very different.\u201d\n\nNo American president has attended Davos except Bill Clinton, who came in 2000, and many were perplexed that Mr. Trump, who styles himself as a billionaire populist, would choose to.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so fascinating that he wanted to go,\u201d said Karen Donfried, the president of the German Marshall Fund of the United States, a research group that focuses on trans-Atlantic affairs, and a former national security aide to Mr. Obama. \u201cMaybe he thinks these are his people, the corporate people. But his statements are to the other side.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo be sure, many of the American 1-percenters here have Mr. Trump to thank for the substantial corporate and personal tax cuts that he helped push through Congress in December. But privately, they consider him a global wild card and bristle at his efforts to build walls, figuratively and literally, against immigration and free trade.\n\n\u201cWill political and corporate leaders at Davos seek to flatter Trump to get on his good side or give him the cold shoulder given their growing concerns about his leadership?\u201d asked David J. Kramer, a former State Department official under President George W. Bush who just hosted a conference on foreign policy under Mr. Trump at Florida International University.\n\nMr. Trump, after all, is the president who has taken a wrecking ball to the liberal international order that Davos represents. In his first year in office, he abandoned the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement with Asian nations, threatened to pull out of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada as well as a separate trade pact with South Korea if they are not renegotiated to his liking, threatened a trade war with China and announced that he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord now signed by every other nation in the world.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe has also offended many by referring to African nations in a meeting with lawmakers as \u201cshithole countries,\u201d or some variation of that, and saying in another meeting that Nigerians who visit the United States would not want to \u201cgo back to their huts.\u201d At least 10 heads of state or government from Africa are scheduled to attend this year, and Mr. Trump will meet with President Paul Kagame of Rwanda, the chairman of the African Union.\n\nBut Davos participants rarely confront the grievances that globalization has produced in a visceral way, and some analysts said Mr. Trump\u2019s message might be a bracing reminder that the wheeling and dealing has real-world effects on people far below this mountain retreat.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important for the Davos elite to hear from the populist president who, although a billionaire businessman himself, is better able than they to understand what real people need in the United States and perhaps in other countries as well,\u201d said Peter Van Praagh, the president of the Halifax International Security Forum, another annual gathering.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI hope President Trump brings with him to Davos a message to the business elite and to the political elite of some of the lessons he has learned as a candidate and in his first year in office, which is that making all of these issues real to people is the path to success,\u201d Mr. Van Praagh added. \u201cAnd although many of the people gathered at Davos intuitively understand this, they probably have a lot to learn from Mr. Trump.\u201d\n\nWhether they will listen is another matter. And whether they will accept the messenger as an authentic envoy from the 99 percent or a wannabe member of the elite still banging on their door remains to be seen.\n\n\u201cThese same folks, as well as the business-media elite, generally find Trump to be a troublesome and boorish man,\u201d Mr. D\u2019Antonio said. \u201cThey may do what they can to ingratiate themselves, but privately and in some cases publicly they will reject him. He knows this as well as he knew that New York\u2019s social elite rejected him in a similar way.\u201d", "title": "In Davos, a Club Trump Has Revered and Resented Finally Opens Its Doors", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Early Sunday morning, with temperatures in the single digits in the city, the subway became the shelter of last resort for some of New York\u2019s homeless. On just one E train at about 2:30 a.m., 45 homeless people had sought refuge from the longest spell of freezing days in New York since 1961.\n\nSeven people were counted in a single train car. They were stretched out on the seats, using backpacks for pillows, curled up beneath blankets with tattered suitcases by their side. A similar scene unfolded on car after car.\n\nThere was a man with a trash bag filled with cans, and another man dozing next to a pizza box. It was quiet and warm, and everyone was sleeping. A man with a cane had taken off his soaked boots to dry his socks, and he briefly woke up.\n\n\u201cHelp for the homeless?\u201d he said.\n\nThere are an estimated 3,900 unsheltered homeless people living around New York City, according to the latest figures from 2017, a 40 percent increase over the previous year. In normal weather, they sleep on the streets, in tunnels and overpasses, and in the subway. But during extremely cold weather, more than usual descend into the subway, open and heated 24 hours a day, and transform its trains into rolling shelters.", "title": "In Deepest Cold, a Subway Car Becomes the Shelter of Last Resort", "authors": ["Annie Correal"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "But on a recent trip to Dubai to research a nonfiction book that unfolds in the falconry world, I was seeking an opportunity to closely observe the raptors in flight, and so I suppressed my fears and signed up for an outing (prices vary, depending on group size; I paid about $325). The project, I reassured myself, came with a top pedigree: Sheikh Butti Bin Juma al-Maktoum, the brother-in-law of the ruler of Dubai, and an ardent conservationist and falconer, initiated it in early 2016, and brought together the staffs of two of his popular touristic enterprises to make it happen. Royal Shaheen Events, co-founded by the South African falconer Peter Bergh and the Zimbabwean falcon breeder Howard Waller, runs luxury falconry demonstrations by Land Cruiser in the desert. The other, Balloon Adventures Dubai, co-founded by the Hungarian ballooning expert Peter Kollar, has been flying tourists over Dubai since 2005.\n\nThe first chicks designated for the project were hatched in May 2016 at Sheikh Butti\u2019s breeding center in Scotland, and then taken by Land Cruiser for training in Umbria, Italy, where Mr. Kollar runs a ballooning company during the summer. \u201cWe had no idea how they would react to the basket and to the burning jets. But we were surprised by how quickly they learned,\u201d Mr. Kollar told me. \u201cThe falcons look at the basket as their nest, and they\u2019re trained to return to it. They were very young, and they didn\u2019t even pay any attention to the fire.\u201d\n\nAt 3:30 on an October morning, a van picked me up at the Dubai Marina and shuttled me down the empty highway for an hour to Sheikh Butti\u2019s sprawling property near the Desert Conservation Reserve. Staffers were still inflating the balloon in the darkness; a thick jet of propane-fed flame filled the huge nylon sack with an eerie orange glow. Mr. Freeman, a stocky and bearded Zimbabwean, stood off to the side, stroking the feathers of his 17-month-old bird, Bomber. Bomber, he said, was a mix of gyrfalcon, a highly prized, nonmigratory species often found north of the Arctic Circle, and the more common saker falcon, a migratory species that crosses the Arabian Peninsula every winter. Arab falconers trapped them here until Dubai banned capturing birds from the wild in the 1970s. The saker bloodline, he said, \u201chelps Bomber deal with the desert heat.\u201d", "title": "In Dubai, Flying With the Falcons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "FLORENCE, Italy \u2014 Symbol of Florence, most celebrated of Michelangelo\u2019s works and a feature of every souvenir shop in this ancient city, the statue of David was briefly clad for an evening this week, after a full five centuries of nudity.\n\nThe occasion was a video installation created by Felice Limosani, an artist and former D.J., and sponsored by a prominent local milling family to celebrate the somewhat shaky proposition that fabric is art.\n\nPurists might view it as impious to cloak David in patterns drawn from the commercial archives of Lanificio Luigi Ricceri and then projected onto the statue. Yet Florence stands at the forefront of a movement to disrupt what some consider the stasis of Italy\u2019s rich artistic heritage.\n\nIn recent seasons, the artist Ai Weiwei was invited to stage an intervention on the subject of migration in the courtyard of the 15th-century Palazzo Strozzi; Jenny Holzer was asked by the organizers of the Pitti Uomo trade fair to project scraps of political poetry onto the facade of the Palazzo Pitti; and, in connection with an international antiques biennial being held here, the Swiss artist Urs Fischer was enjoined to park his monumental sculptural blob, \u201cBig Clay #4,\u201d in the middle of the storied Renaissance Piazza della Signoria.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cArt is not only art inside a museum or gallery,\u201d Mr. Limosani said Tuesday evening, as a crowd of enraptured locals held their phones up inside the Galleria dell\u2019Accademia to capture the sight of the 17-foot marble figure washed in a sequence of patterns that each began as shreds of color staining calves or biceps and then slowly enveloped the biblical hero in yellow pin dots or blue jacquard. \u201cYou can also think of art as being created in the factories where artistic inspiration and craft both meet.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe apparent ease with which the Ricceri family gained permission to interact with one of the world\u2019s most celebrated works of art can be coincidentally chalked up to the former Kate Middleton, according to Francesco Ricceri, a proprietor of his family-owned company.", "title": "In Florence, the David Gets Dressed and Gucci Gets a Garden", "authors": ["Guy Trebay"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 In January 2017, on the coldest day of the year, six actors from Syria, Afghanistan and the Palestinian territories set out from Berlin on a two-week road trip through Germany.\n\nTheir somewhat reluctant guide was Niels Bormann, an actor in the Maxim Gorki Theater\u2019s house ensemble, and his passengers were the members of the theater\u2019s newly assembled refugee troupe, the Exil Ensemble. That winter journey forms the basis for the Gorki\u2019s absorbing and bittersweet \u201cWinterreise,\u201d the first production devised by the Exil Ensemble and developed together with Yael Ronen, the Gorki\u2019s innovative in-house director.\n\nThe actors\u2019 dysfunctional bus ride through Germany (with a brief excursion into Switzerland) becomes the framework for a performance that mixes personal narratives of displacement, escape and disorientation with shrewd, witty and, at times, irreverent observations. The Palestinian actress Maryam Abu Khaled seems less shocked than downright confused when her new German boyfriend introduces her to his other girlfriend. Beyond navigating the complex sexual mores of their new homeland, the new arrivals struggle to comprehend German bathrooms (How do people clean themselves using only paper? What\u2019s with the ubiquitous toilet shelf?), the freezing weather and the even chillier vibe they often get from the natives.\n\nThe Israeli-born Ms. Ronen often builds her shows around biographical monologues that boldly examine her performers\u2019 emotional scars. Although the members of the Exil Ensemble are from countries torn apart by war and conflict, their stories are tempered with generous doses of humor. Hussein Al Shatheli, a Palestinian born in Syria, describes his harrowing flight to Germany via Turkey, Greece and Switzerland and his many costly attempts to buy forged travel documents as a surreal, Kafkaesque odyssey.", "title": "In Germany\u2019s Theaters, Stories of Exiles and Refugees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "I plead with Congress to stop Donald Trump before he gets us all killed. It is too bad that none of his congressional supporters were here to experience the idea that we were going to die.\n\nSaturday was real. I don\u2019t know if we will ever fully recover.\n\nL. A. WEBB, KEALAKEKUA, HAWAII\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI live in Honolulu. On Saturday morning I received a ballistic-missile attack alert over my cellphone in a hospital near downtown, along with staff members on the floor. There was nothing that we could do except to hope that it was a mistake.\n\nNo one was rattled. People went about their ordinary business. I called my loved ones, and we all tried to get information.\n\nWe are the early warning system for the mainland but are inadequately protected ourselves. My only emotion this morning was not fear. It was outrage. The idea that nuclear war is an \u201coption\u201d is insane.\n\nJEAN E. ROSENFELD, HONOLULU\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMy wife and I grew up in the days of \u201cduck and cover,\u201d so we\u2019re both perhaps a little jaded when it comes to bomb alerts. We retired to Hawaii, but we still have some of that skeptical attitude so characteristic of the big cities on the mainland.", "title": "Opinion | In Hawaii, Reacting to a False Alarm of an Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn the corner of Sunset Boulevard and Sweetzer Avenue in front of The Standard in West Hollywood beginning on Feb. 27, a monumental white neon outline of a uterus \u2014 with fiberglass boxing gloves in place of the ovaries \u2014 will slowly rotate at a height of 43 feet. Well-positioned to be adopted as the logo of the #MeToo movement, this declarative image of female empowerment is the first public art project by Zoe Buckman, a 32-year-old British artist based in New York. Titled \u201cChamp,\u201d the kinetic sculpture was commissioned by the Art Production Fund and will remain on view for a year.\n\n\u201cI find Sunset Strip to be objectification overload, with all these advertising images and movie billboards of young women not only promoting the same standards of beauty but also images that can be quite sexually violent,\u201d Ms. Buckman said, referring to the legendary stretch through West Hollywood with a long history of louche casinos, nightclubs and erotic businesses. She is interested in how her illuminated sign in this context \u201coffers a completely different view of femininity\u201d and will be prominently visible to passing cars.\n\nA small-scale version of \u201cChamp,\u201d exhibited in the 2016 pop-up show \u201cTruth to Power\u201d during the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, among other venues, went viral on social media, said Casey Fremont, executive director of Art Production Fund. \u201cIt\u2019s speaking to women for so many different reasons and getting conversations going that are so important,\u201d said Ms. Fremont, who is working with Ms. Buckman on a series of public programs throughout the year addressing topics including sexual assault and rape, reproductive rights and women\u2019s health awareness.\n\nWhile the diagram of the uterus is anatomically correct, \u201cI get some men who ask, Is that a ram\u2019s head?\u201d said Ms. Buckman. She likes how the ambiguity of the image can bring them into the discussion. The surreal juxtaposition of the neon uterus armed with boxing gloves \u201cspeaks to the fight and struggle we\u2019ve been through and have ahead of us,\u201d Ms. Buckman said. \u201cBut I also want it to feel celebratory and uplifting.\u201d", "title": "In Hollywood, Another Sign of Women Punching Back", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "TEHRAN \u2014 Two of the detained young men killed themselves, and another was a terrorist who died in a clash with security forces, Iran\u2019s government officials have declared with finality. But in an extraordinary display of audacity, many Iranians, including a number of lawmakers and a top entertainment star, have assailed such conclusions.\n\nThe three young men were among more than two dozen Iranians who died in the wave of antigovernment protests that swept the country a few weeks ago, the most serious unrest to confront the Islamic republic\u2019s political-religious hierarchy in nearly a decade.\n\nThe men\u2019s personal stories that have since emerged have struck a nerve among many Iranians, who see glaring contradictions in the official accounts of the facts.\n\nTheir push for further investigation, including a parliamentary demand for an inquiry into the prison deaths, suggests that while the protests have largely subsided, the fallout in Iran may be just beginning.", "title": "In Iran, Protester \u2018Suicides\u2019 Stir Anger and Calls for Accountability", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "While they have just enough money to buy processed foods like potato chips, which are now widely available in low-income areas for a few cents, they often do not have enough to join a gym or buy fish or fresh vegetables.\n\nAnd instead of working in the fields (which is how most Kenyans lived just a generation ago), they are marooned in squalid urban areas and are less physically active. Some of the least expensive foods to buy in the Kibera slum where Ms. Akinyi lives are French fries and fried dough, each around 20 cents. Apples, at the equivalent of 40 cents, are outside her budget, though soda isn\u2019t.\n\n\u201cAnd I love Sprite,\u201d Ms. Akinyi said with a guilty smile.\n\nOne of Coca-Cola\u2019s strategies in Kenya has been to reach the lower economic classes by making smaller 200 milliliter bottles, or about 6.75 fluid ounces, that cost about 15 cents (compared with the standard 300 milliliter bottle that costs 25 cents). Burger King, Domino\u2019s, Cold Stone Creamery and Subway have all recently opened their first stores in Kenya, part of their strategy to break into Africa.\n\nDespite insults like \u201celephant,\u201d there is also a stigma to being thin in some Kenyan circles. It goes back generations but was especially true in the 1990s, at the height of the AIDS epidemic when millions of Africans died.\n\nTo many Kenyans, Dr. Kunyiha said, being thin still means being poor or sick.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really frustrating,\u201d Dr. Kunyiha said. \u201cThe image here is: The bigger your tummy, the better you\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nOne of her patients, she says, is a rich man who drives a Mercedes and suffers from hypertension and obesity. She keeps telling him to switch from fast food and meat to the old fashioned Kenya diet of beans, carrots and a vegetable called sukuma wiki that is similar to kale.", "title": "In Kenya, and Across Africa, an Unexpected Epidemic: Obesity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "As the myth goes, on the night before the battle, Lazar was visited by a saint in the form of a gray falcon with a message from the Virgin Mary.\n\nHe could win the battle and find a kingdom on earth. Or he could lose the battle and find a kingdom in heaven. He chose to lose.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn June 28, 1989, on the 600th anniversary of the battle, Slobodan Milosevic arrived by helicopter at the site and reframed the choice that faced Lazar. It was time, he said, for Serbs to find their \u201cheaven on earth.\u201d\n\nIt was a call to arms and what eventually followed was an ethnic cleansing campaign against Kosovo\u2019s Albanians that ended only after a 78-day United States-led NATO bombing campaign in 1999.\n\nBut two decades after the bombing helped stop the violence, and a decade after Kosovo declared itself independent from Serbia, this remains a land more divided than at peace.\n\nHere in Mitrovica, in the northern part of the country, ethnic Serbs dominate; only recently have the police begun wearing the country\u2019s official uniform.\n\nMany people here do not see themselves as part of Kosovo as it currently exists. They want to be a part of Serbia but feel like pawns in the bigger game as Serbia seeks membership in the European Union, and expect to be forsaken by Belgrade if that day comes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis was my first visit to Kosovo in my new post covering Eastern and Central Europe, a quick trip to cover a hastily arranged visit by the Serbian president, Aleksandar Vucic, who came to talk to a community on edge after the murder of a prominent ethnic Serb politician in Mitrovica.\n\nAt a town-hall meeting, Mr. Vucic was greeted by angry and distrustful residents who asked who would protect them, saying they needed weapons.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey were gathered in a crowded hall in a city full of daily reminders of how near their former foes remain but how far apart their lives have become.\n\nEvery day, the call to prayer echoes from a mosque on the southern side of the bridge that spans the Ibar River, which cuts through the city. Ethnic Serbs across the bridge can hear the muezzin\u2019s song as they walk past a statue only recently erected. It is dedicated to Prince Lazar. He is looking across the bridge, which is guarded by international peacekeepers. The Italian Carabinieri currently have the job.\n\nThey are just one of the scores of outside organizations that are trying to make sure the peace here does not unravel. The most visible is the NATO-led security force, KFOR.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is easy to tell when you are driving in the ethnic Serbian area even before you see any international troops. Many of the cars don\u2019t have license plates or have plates issued by Serbia, which are considered illegal by the government in Pristina.\n\nChildren go to separate schools. Men work in separate industries. Families eat in different restaurants. Students who graduate from the university in Mitrovica do not have their diplomas recognized by the government in Kosovo, which is led by ethnic Albanians. Even the cellphone service is divided, with Serb areas inexplicably often linked to service based in Monaco.\n\nGiven all the division, it was interesting to note \u2014 and perhaps a hopeful sign \u2014 that the shooting of the local politician, Oliver Ivanovic, did not lead to immediate finger pointing across the river to the ethnic Albanian community.\n\nInstead, many speculated that Mr. Ivanovic\u2019s fight against the criminal networks within the ethnic Serbian community led to his killing.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe sense of fear among people is incredible,\u201d Mr. Ivanovic said not long before his murder.\n\n\u201cI want to make it very clear: these people are not afraid of Albanians, but Serbs, local strongman and criminals,\u201d he said. \u201cPolicemen are watching, not doing anything about it and residents feel like they have not protection, even though it\u2019s our people, Serbs, in the Kosovo police in the North.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe monk, who only goes by his given priestly name Georgije, agreed. \u201cThere are too many people living in sin,\u201d he said.\n\nBut his prescription for change seemed to dismiss both the roots of the last war, the cause of so much bloodshed, and the carnage that it would likely take to carry it out.\n\nThe Serbs in Kosovo were lost, he said, blaming the separation of church and state. The only way to restore the natural balance, he said, would be to have a government based on Serbian Orthodoxy \u2014 a solution that is anathema to Kosovo\u2019s Muslim population.\n\n\u201cWe need the unity of the state and the church and the people,\u201d he said, citing the principles espoused by the ancient king who was once buried at this monastery. \u201cYou cannot have one without the other.\u201d\n\nOver the centuries, the monastery he calls home has been ravaged by fire, abandoned and razed to the ground. Under Ottoman rule and until the end of World War I, it was a mosque. It underwent a restoration in 1990, when it was declared a Cultural Monument of Exceptional Importance by the Serbian government. Always, the Serbs came back.\n\nThat long history shaped his views and the views of many still living in Mitrovica. As a descendant of Milutin and Lazar, the monk gave voice to the Serb sense of persecution.\n\n\u201cFirst we were forced to live under the Turks,\u201d he said. \u201cNow it is under the Albanians and the Americans.\u201d\n\nBut Serbs remember, he said. And he was hopeful that the Serbs would restore their medieval dominion over Kosovo once again.", "title": "In Kosovo, a Peace Built on Separation", "authors": ["Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "There is downhill skiing and snowboarding on the trails that decided the outcome of six Olympic races at Whiteface Mountain. The terrain at Whiteface caters to all abilities and can be as challenging as anywhere, too \u2014 its vertical drop of 3,430 feet is the most in the East, including New England\u2019s famed ski areas.\n\nAnd last but certainly not least, in the center of the village is the rink where the powerhouse Soviet Union ice hockey team was dethroned as Olympic champion by a band of American college students in what has become known as the Miracle on Ice. It draws more than a million visitors annually.\n\nThe public skating opportunity is not limited to the speedskating oval; there is also public skating inside a rink from the 1932 Olympics, which is contained in the village\u2019s Olympic Center, where there is an Olympic museum.\n\nThe various sports facilities have been maintained and periodically upgraded \u2014 the area still hosts World Cup events \u2014 by New York State, which shortly after the 1980 Olympics recognized the need to protect and develop the state\u2019s investment in the Lake Placid Games.\n\nA website, whiteface.com/activities, explains all the details of the Olympic venues and lists the prices to use them. Some venues are more affordable than others \u2014 skating on the oval is $8, for example, while the bobsled experience costs $95 for an adult (and includes a photo and T-shirt). There is also a discounted $35 one-day ticket called the Olympic Sites Passport that allows access to various venues; visit whiteface.com/tickets.\n\nBut as much as Lake Placid offers a wealth of exhilarating outdoor winter recreational activities, it is much more than a quasi-Olympic fantasy camp. It is a year-round resort \u2014 more popular, in fact, in the summer than winter \u2014 and as such is chock-full of shops, restaurants, bars, cozy inns and large resort hotels.\n\nImage\n\nIt is the reason that Ski Magazine readers regularly select Lake Placid as the best ski village in the Eastern United States.", "title": "In Lake Placid, Olympic Sports and Spirit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Rachael Denhollander had the first word and the last one.\n\nA former gymnast who became a lawyer and a coach, Ms. Denhollander told The Indianapolis Star in 2016 that Dr. Lawrence G. The exchange was first reported by The Washington Post.\n\nThe question was unusually and overtly political for an interview related to a position in the Justice Department, which is supposed to maintain its independence from politics.\n\nAt their final meeting, Mr. Trump offered Mr. McCabe the job and told him he planned to give him the role of acting director. The president also said that he planned to make an appearance that week at F.B.I. Headquarters to bolster morale. Official How He Voted", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "SAN JER\u00d3NIMO COYULA, Mexico \u2014 This ragged town at the foot of the smoking Popocat\u00e9petl volcano is one of the communities in Mexico with deep ties to the United States. Since the 1980s, thousands of its residents have trekked to what they call El Norte, particularly to New York City and the Hamptons of Long Island. For decades, migrants have mixed the cement, laid the bricks and painted the walls of grand houses there.\n\nMany families here depend on the remittances sent to them by relatives who have migrated north to buy medicine for the old and schoolbooks for the young. Family members in the United States use their earnings to help fund a free town festival every September.\n\nUnsurprisingly, when I ask a dozen people from the plaza to the main street what they think of President Trump, they all have negative opinions. \u201cTrump is a hypocrite \u2014 he employs Mexicans for his buildings and then he attacks us,\u201d said Humberto Ramos, a stocky 40-year-old with cement stains on his overalls. \u201cThe Mexicans are the ones that work the hardest there. We have helped build the country.\u201d\n\nBut while Mr. Trump\u2019s language angers residents here, his first year in power did not affect them as much as they feared. Migrants still send home money. In fact, last year is estimated to be a record-breaker for remittances, with the Central Bank of Mexico estimating that Mexicans living in the United States sent home $26.1 billion between January and November alone. Not a single brick has been laid to build Mr. Trump\u2019s promised \u201cbeautiful wall.\u201d And total trade between the two countries continues to grow.", "title": "Opinion | In Mexico, Trump\u2019s Bark Has Been Worse Than His Bite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "When the N.C.A.A. kicked off an investigation of Michigan State on Tuesday, it opened itself up to a brand of controversy not seen since the Jerry Sandusky scandal at Penn State several years ago, with similar potential pitfalls but also a chance to reaffirm its relevance.\n\nAt issue is whether the N.C.A.A., an organization whose stated mission is largely to enforce ideals specific to college sports such as competitive balance and amateurism, has the wherewithal and heft to manage a complex investigation outside its expertise while juggling several other inquiries at the same time.\n\nThe Michigan State case and the Sandusky scandal that started in 2011 share horrific subject matter: the sexual assault of minors. Sandusky, a longtime assistant football coach, was convicted of abusing 10 boys, and it ultimately resulted in several top university officials, including a president and athletic director, being sentenced to prison time for their roles in covering up the crimes.\n\nAt Michigan State, Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar has been sentenced to more than 100 years in prison, with more than 150 female athletes and family members giving statements before Dr. Nassar in court during the past week. It is unclear how many university officials were aware of accusations against him, although the school\u2019s president, Lou Anna K. Simon, resigned late Wednesday under pressure from lawmakers and others.", "title": "In Michigan State Investigation, N.C.A.A. Moves Beyond Its Comfort Zone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "MILAN \u2014 Let a brick be a brick. To paraphrase the great American architect Louis Kahn, professional achievement at a fundamental level requires a practitioner first to consult the materials.\n\n\u201cIf you think of brick, you say to brick, \u2018What do you want, brick?\u2019 \u201d Mr. Kahn said during a legendary 1971 master class lecture at the University of Pennsylvania. Perhaps brick spoke and said it wanted to be an arch. \u201cAnd it\u2019s important, you see, that you honor the material that you use,\u201d Mr. Kahn said. \u201cYou can only do it if you honor the brick and glorify the brick instead of shortchanging it.\u201d\n\nIf it would be overreach to liken the designer Neil Barrett to one of the greatest architects of the 20th century, it would also sell him short to suggest he is anything less than a master. Few in the current design landscape are more consistently exploratory than Mr. Barrett or deploy materials with anything like his confidence and restraint.", "title": "In Milan, Military Rigor Meets Instagram Excess", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "MONTECITO, Calif. \u2014 A green, military-style Humvee drove along the shore here, the beach on one side, the shuttered Four Seasons Hotel on the other. Up in the hillsides, a no-go zone for civilians, multimillion-dollar mansions are flooded with mud, and cars, tossed about like playthings, are now just hunks of twisted metal, jammed against trees.\n\nOn the facades of the big homes are orange markings. An X denotes the house was checked and cleared by rescuers. A V indicates a victim was pulled, alive, from the wreckage. A V with a slash through it indicates a dead body was found.\n\nUnimaginable tragedy struck this small, exclusive enclave, nestled between the mountains and the ocean and home to many celebrities, last week when a torrential downpour \u2014 a \u201conce in 200 years\u201d storm, officials are quick to say \u2014 set off deadly mudslides in a landscape that, just last month, was scorched from the state\u2019s largest wildfire on record.", "title": "In Montecito, Enclave of Wealth and Fame, Unimagined Tragedy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Think about that for a moment: Approximately 0.6 percent of American adults identify as transgender, just under 0.2 percent of the world population is Jewish, and 100 percent of us will get sick, yet it is being chronically sick that makes me feel like an outsider. That\u2019s how much our society fears and rejects the core human experience of being ill, of having a body that gets sick, that ages, that is not controllable.\n\nI went from doctor to doctor looking for answers, but overnight I had gone from being a trusted rabbi and chaplain (who works with seriously ill and dying people on hospital medical teams) to a \u201chysterical\u201d chronically ill person. Though I had seen it happen to my clients, I now understood firsthand that being disbelieved is nearly universal for people with chronic illnesses, especially those that are largely invisible or hard to diagnose or both. I had believed that as a health care professional, equipped with skills and advocates to navigate the system, I would be treated differently. I soon learned how hubristic that was.\n\nEventually, because of the tireless advocacy of my wife, I was diagnosed with central nervous system lupus (an autoimmune disease that attacks the brain and central nervous system), as well as fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome and complex migraines. My lupus diagnosis would later be taken away and then given back countless times as suited the needs of health insurance and disability insurance companies to sort and manage me and decide how much care I was entitled to. The needs of my body were virtually irrelevant in this process as my diagnosis become a monetized affair where I had to jump through increasingly difficult hoops to \u201cprove\u201d it.\n\nLike most of us, I had been raised to see illness as something temporary: a stopover on the way to recovery or to death, not a place to live. But weeks, months and then years passed, and I did not get better. My doctors, and even some friends and family members, suggested that I could get better if only I tried harder, relaxed more deeply, thought more positively. I became a lightning rod for others\u2019 fears of disability, dependence and fragility. In a political moment where health care is treated as a luxury and hurricane victims are blamed for their own disasters, an ethic of personal responsibility reigns. But sometimes, sick people just stay sick. And there\u2019s no meditation, medication, positive outlook, exercise or smoothie that can fix it.\n\nEventually, I stopped hoping to be well, or even pretending that I lived in that future-heavy land of hope anymore. I stopped trying to \u201covercome\u201d my body and started living a present-tense life in chronic illness. As the pace of my life slowed, I could appreciate sensual pleasures in a new and heightened way: sunlight outside my bedroom window, my dog\u2019s velvety fur, a cool breeze in my garden, richly colored flowers. On days when my brain was too fogged to do anything, I let myself float in and out of a rich, infinitely layered dream world.", "title": "Opinion | In My Chronic Illness, I Found a Deeper Meaning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "And they accused the university of failing to conduct a top-to-bottom, truly independent investigation, settling instead for a review by a legal team that was also trying to protect the school from any damage in the courts. Michigan State portrayed Mr. Fitzgerald as reviewing the Nassar cases even as he was hired to defend the university from lawsuits.\n\n\u201cMichigan State led the public to believe that there had been an independent investigation,\u201d Tom Leonard, the Republican speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives, said on Friday in an interview. \u201cAnd then as we continued to dig into this, we found out it was not an independent investigation. It was an internal investigation to shield them from liability.\u201d\n\nMr. Fitzgerald said on Friday that his team had never been \u201cengaged to produce a public report\u201d on the Nassar case. He suggested that his team\u2019s role had been misinterpreted by some. In fact, the initial contract between Michigan State and Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s firm makes no mention of carrying out an independent investigation or producing any report.\n\n\u201cWe were engaged to provide counsel regarding anticipated litigation and to make sure that any internal reviews did not interfere with the two law enforcement inquiries underway,\u201d he said, referring to criminal investigations that led to Dr. Nassar\u2019s guilty plea and sentencing. \u201cIn the course of gathering facts for the representation, the team of attorneys and investigators has conducted approximately one hundred interviews and reviewed a large number of documents. Our work is still ongoing.\u201d\n\nUnder the terms of the law firm\u2019s contract, the lawyers were to defend the university in civil lawsuits, facilitate \u201ccooperation\u201d with law enforcement and provide \u201ccounseling on any internal reviews conducted to make sure they are carried out in a manner that will best assist the university\u2019s response.\u201d\n\nThough some women say they told university employees about abuse years ago, Mr. Fitzgerald wrote in December that no one who knew Dr. Nassar believed he could be capable of such behavior. \u201cIt is clear that Nassar fooled everyone around him \u2014 patients, friends, colleagues, and fellow doctors at M.S.U.,\u201d Mr. Fitzgerald wrote.\n\nOver the months since they hired Mr. Fitzgerald, 57, and his team of lawyers, Michigan State officials have highlighted his review \u2014 sometimes noting Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s involvement by name \u2014 as a sign of the seriousness of their response. Lou Anna K. Simon, who resigned as president on Wednesday, had portrayed the university\u2019s review as a robust and \u201ctireless effort\u201d that would go on as long as needed. \u201cEven as we examine \u2014 through both criminal investigations and a thorough internal review \u2014 how something so abhorrent happened here and went on for so long, we are taking action,\u201d she said last April.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Nassar was sentenced to 40 to 175 years in prison on Wednesday, after days of wrenching testimony from more than 150 women who have accused him of molesting them while he was a doctor for Michigan State and the national gymnastics team. The president stepped down hours later.\n\nBy week\u2019s end, Michigan State\u2019s athletic director, Mark Hollis, had also resigned. And two outside agencies \u2014 the federal education department and the Michigan attorney general \u2014 had begun what the university\u2019s critics hoped would be truly independent investigations into its handling of Dr. Nassar.\n\nBill Schuette, the state attorney general, said on Saturday that his office was leading a review that would \u201cput a bright light in every corner of the university.\u201d He promised that the investigation would look \u201cfrom the president\u2019s office down\u201d for answers about what had happened.\n\nMr. Schuette also said he would ask the university\u2019s trustees to have Mr. Fitzgerald \u201cturn over all information he has gathered in the course of his work.\u201d\n\n\u201cTheir response to this simple request will speak volumes,\u201d said Mr. Schuette, whose investigation involves a special prosecutor and Michigan\u2019s statewide police agency.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Friday, Joel I. Ferguson, a Michigan State trustee, said he agreed with criticism of Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s role: \u201cWe have the person who was defending us investigating us.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere was a conflict,\u201d he added.\n\nBut Brian Breslin, the chairman of the board of trustees, said that he had \u201cevery confidence\u201d in Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s interviews and information. \u201cHe never developed a report and was never asked to,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAsked whether there was a conflict in employing the same person to both defend and review the institution, Mr. Breslin said he had no comment.\n\nMichigan State was dealing with a public relations crisis and a growing number of lawsuits when it hired Mr. Fitzgerald, who as the United States attorney in Chicago had built a reputation as a meticulously prepared, unyielding foe of crooks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDeclaring that the corruption would \u201cmake Lincoln roll over in his grave,\u201d Mr. Fitzgerald oversaw the prosecution of Rod R. Blagojevich, the idiosyncratic former governor of Illinois accused of trying to get something in exchange for an appointment to the United States Senate seat that Barack Obama vacated when he was elected president.\n\nMr. Fitzgerald drew national attention by getting a conviction in a C.I.A. leak case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff for then Vice President Dick Cheney. And he had worked on high-profile terrorism cases from New York, including the trials of four defendants in connection with the 1998 bombings of United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.\n\n\u201cAs far as investigating something, there\u2019s absolutely nobody better,\u201d Sam Adam Jr., one of Mr. Blagojevich\u2019s defense lawyers, said. \u201cAs a criminal defense attorney, I can tell you, he was so good at applying pressure to people.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s role in the Michigan State case is not as prosecutor. Since 2016, Michigan State\u2019s trustees have paid him and his law firm, Skadden, Arps, along with other lawyers, to deal with the Nassar case and to respond to litigation against the school. The true scope and purpose of the lawyers\u2019 internal review have become a matter of fierce debate in recent days, but the trustees last February said the lawyers\u2019 role was to \u201crepresent the university in all aspects of this matter,\u201d adding, \u201cThis representation will include conducting the factual review necessary to address the allegations being made and to assess Nassar\u2019s former work at the university.\u201d\n\nA Michigan State contract with Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s firm included an hourly rate of up to $990. The ABC affiliate in Detroit reported this month that Mr. Fitzgerald\u2019s firm has billed the university nearly $4.1 million.\n\n\u201cThe public relations team at Michigan State gave the impression that he was going to do some sort of dispassionate, independent investigation, and that simply was not true,\u201d said John C. Manly, a lawyer for more than 100 of the women who have sued or made claims against Michigan State.\n\nMr. Manly said that no one from Michigan State or their legal team had sought to interview his clients about what had happened. Mr. Fitzgerald said that his team took \u201caffirmative steps\u201d not to interview victims of the abuse because of ethics rules restricting contact with plaintiffs in civil cases.\n\nAmong the women suing are five who reported feeling uncomfortable or violated to coaches, trainers and counselors in the late 1990s and early 2000s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the women, Larissa Boyce, said she was molested by Dr. Nassar for over two years, beginning at age 16, while training with Michigan State\u2019s youth gymnastics program in 1997 and 1998. Ms. Boyce said she had told the women\u2019s gymnastics coach at the time, Kathie Klages. But instead of helping, the coach explained to Ms. Boyce that she was probably \u201cmisunderstanding\u201d the situation and implied Ms. Boyce would get in trouble if she filed a more formal complaint, according to a lawsuit.\n\nAnother gymnast said she had also told Ms. Klages about abuse by Dr. Nassar around that time. Ms. Klages retired last year amid the scandal. Her lawyer declined to comment, citing the pending litigation.\n\nMichigan State\u2019s policies require all employees to promptly report any sexual misconduct that they learn about involving a faculty member, staff member or student. But it is not clear that any of the people who heard the complaints in the late 1990s and early 2000s reported it to university administrators.\n\nIn a court motion two weeks ago seeking to dismiss the case against the university and its employees, including Ms. Klages, Michigan State said supervisors did not even know there were allegations against Dr. Nassar until 2014, when another woman complained to the head of the university\u2019s sports medicine clinic, Jeff Kovan, that Dr. Nassar had massaged her breasts, buttocks and vaginal area.\n\nIn that case, an investigator consulted with three doctors and a certified athletic trainer, who backed Dr. Nassar\u2019s explanation that his actions were medically appropriate to treat the patient\u2019s pain. Each of the four had a connection to Dr. Nassar: One of the doctors studied under him and was a colleague and friend, the investigative report said; one had known him since 1988 and was a classmate and teaching colleague; one had known him since 1995, and he had treated her daughter; and the trainer worked regularly with Dr. Nassar in the training room, an average of four hours a week for 17 years.\n\nThe university found that Mr. Nassar\u2019s actions were appropriate and \u201cnot of a sexual nature.\u201d\n\nDr. Nassar continued to molest patients, according to lawsuits, and even as late as August 2016, just before victims began to go public, some Michigan State employees told gymnasts that Mr. Nassar\u2019s methods were appropriate. The employees also sternly warned gymnasts not to speak to the media, according to allegations in court filings.", "title": "In Nassar Case, Michigan State Wanted Famed Ex-Prosecutor to Both Examine and Defend It", "authors": ["Monica Davey", "Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "To some, the prospect of adding new subway elevators not far from the World Trade Center is a godsend, a desperately needed portal for the disabled to a subway system that is among the least accessible in the nation.\n\nTo a group of neighbors who live beside the proposed site, the elevators seem like something else entirely: a hazard a terrorist could turn into shrapnel.\n\nOn one side of a growing skirmish on Broad Street in Lower Manhattan are disabled riders, advocates and a real estate developer building the elevators in exchange for being granted permission by the city to add more square footage to the mixed-use building the developer is erecting at 45 Broad Street.\n\nOn the other are tenants of nearby buildings like 15 Broad Street, a high-rise designed by the architect Philippe Starck. It is a pocket of the city that has long been under intense security because of its proximity to prime potential targets like the New York Stock Exchange, and critics say the elevators could pose a threat in an area where police and bomb-sniffing dogs routinely check vehicles driving through.", "title": "In New Proposed Subway Elevators, Some See a Terrorism Risk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "One area that would be most affected is the largely working-class neighborhood of Canarsie, in Brooklyn along the coast of Jamaica Bay. When the original maps are compared with FEMA\u2019s 2013 proposal, the difference for the area is stark: Just 26 buildings were in the 1983 FEMA flood zone; under the revised maps, that would have skyrocketed to 5,000 buildings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCanarsie, which is home to many Caribbean immigrants, has a higher percentage of owner-occupied homes with mortgages than the city as a whole. But in a neighborhood that weathered the city\u2019s highest foreclosure rate after the subprime mortgage crisis, homeowners, many of whom rent out their basements to help pay the bills, have \u201clittle to put toward mitigating their flood risk,\u201d according to a city report released in May.\n\nEven though the final flood maps are years away, city officials and community groups are exhorting residents to take advantage of low-cost or even free programs funded by the state Governor\u2019s Office of Storm Recovery. By buying flood insurance now, officials say, policy holders would be grandfathered in and subject to only gradual increases once new maps are established.\n\nWith such coverage, premiums would probably be around $500 a year; without it, the annual rates could be $3,000.\n\nBut even $500 a year can be a hard sell in Canarsie, as made clear by a recent tour with Zachary Paganini, a doctoral student at the City University of New York, who has been researching what the looming changes to flood insurance might mean for the neighborhood.\n\nOn Flatlands Eighth Street, adjacent to Fresh Creek, Nelson Lopez, who does not have flood insurance, noted that his entire block was decimated by Hurricane Sandy, even though the houses were outside FEMA\u2019s flood zones. If the revisions were made permanent, his house would go from a no-risk area to a high-risk zone.\n\n\u201cIf you get flood insurance, you can\u2019t pay your other bills,\u201d he said.\n\nDrawing the Lines in Canarsie Canarsie, built on reclaimed marshes, is at the center of New York\u2019s battle with the rising ocean. 1 Before Hurricane Sandy, the official floodplain made it seem like Canarsie was safe.
