About two feet of water rushed into her basement during Hurricane Sandy.\n\nAfter seeking advice from the Center for New York City Neighborhoods, a nonprofit group that created a flood mapping tool, she purchased flood insurance to qualify for FEMA disaster funds. But Ms. Fraser, a day-care teacher, dropped it after a year because she could not afford the $600 annual premium.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI definitely don\u2019t want to be in a high-risk zone, but I don\u2019t want to move,\u201d said Ms. Fraser, a Guyanese immigrant who moved into her house 20 years ago. \u201cYou can\u2019t always run from one place to the next because you\u2019re worried things will happen.\u201d\n\nOne clue to the possible contours of any future maps may be found in a single column buried in the city\u2019s 2015 appeal.\n\nThe city estimated that if the scientific errors were removed from FEMA\u2019s revision, the number of people in the flood zone could increase by 6 percent to 230,000 over the 1983 maps, and the number of one- to four-family buildings could grow by 38 percent to 36,000. Both increases would be much smaller than the 100 percent jumps suggested by FEMA\u2019s initial maps.", "title": "In New York, Drawing Flood Maps Is a \u2018Game of Inches\u2019", "authors": ["David W. Chen"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 It is against the backdrop of a world and a time when everyone aspires to do and own the same things that Rick Owens is pursuing his own gnarly and contrarian vision. Titling his latest men\u2019s wear collection \u201cSisyphus,\u201d he showed it in a gallery of the Palais de Tokyo under the blinding glare of morgue lighting and with a soundtrack of deafening techno.\n\nIn Mr. Owens\u2019s slightly self-dramatizing worldview, the challenge is rolling his particular boulder up a hill of cultural conformity. While he is far from the sole creative practitioner stuck with that dilemma, he is one of the very few doing it in fashion. The struggle tends to energize Mr. Owens, who has stealthily managed over the years to import his bombastic alt-cult vision squarely into the mainstream.", "title": "In Paris, Pushing the Men\u2019s Wear Boulder Along", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The high jewelry showcases held during couture week in January tend to be more low-key affairs than those in July: A wet and wintry Paris attracts fewer wealthy clients than in the summer months, when much of the 1 percent flocks to France from all over the world.\n\nStill, some of the biggest houses could be relied upon to put some showstoppers on display. Here are a few highlights of the week:\n\nBoucheron\n\nWhat does one do in Paris when turning 160? To kick off a year of celebrations around this anniversary, Boucheron unveiled its latest couture collection as part of Vend\u00f4rama, an exhibition in a courtyard of the Monnaie de Paris that opened this month. Inside, visitors are guided around the retrospective via a smartphone app with an augmented reality rendering of Wladimir, the black cat owned by G\u00e9rard Boucheron, the house\u2019s founder. There are interactive opportunities to learn about the craftsmanship required for high jewelry, or haute joaillerie; see historical documents like ledgers and early advertisements; and admire some famous creations from the Boucheron archive. The maison\u2019s latest pieces are also on display. Textured gold necklaces and bracelets from the signature Serpent Boh\u00e8me collection are followed by exquisite animal-inspired pieces: diamond vixen and wolf rings, finished in aquamarine or malachite, and glittering parrot brooches with feathers in stones of exotic hues. A secret watch, with a white and black diamond husky perched on a white-jade ice ledge and looking into a rock-crystal lake, was a highlight, as was a 1920s-style headband, the Lumi\u00e8re de Nacre, made from 574 round diamonds set in mother-of-pearl and white gold. The exhibition closes on Sunday in Paris, and will be traveling to Asia later this year.", "title": "In Paris, the Glitter of High Jewelry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "I suspect that part of me wants to evangelize for Evan S. Connell, who died in 2013, because he didn\u2019t seem to do it very much for himself. He is said to have lived a solitary life. And though he wrote many books over his lifetime, including a celebrated work of nonfiction, \u201cSon of the Morning Star,\u201d it\u2019s his sublime first novel that I turn to.\n\nNot much that can be considered \u201cbig\u201d happens in \u201cMrs. Bridge, which has been called a quiet masterpiece, but many small \u201cbig\u201d things do, over 117 numbered, titled, short chapters (\u201cGuest Towels,\u201d \u201cLady Poet,\u201d \u201cAnother Victim of Circumstances\u201d), giving the book a spare, crisp quality that is something of an optical illusion, since it is also fully-lived-in and expansive.\n\nThe novel is an extended character study, and in understanding the desperately conforming Mrs. Bridge, whose first name is India (\u201cIt seemed to her that her parents must have been thinking of someone else when they named her\u201d), Connell shows us her desires, the limitations imposed upon her and, again and again, her own personal limitations. Scattered throughout the novel are various attempts on her part, followed by retreats. When, for instance, Mrs. Bridge wants to see a psychoanalyst, she seeks her husband\u2019s permission while he reads the newspaper: \u201c\u2018Walter,\u2019 she began in a tremulous voice, and went on rapidly, \u2018I\u2019ve been thinking it over and I don\u2019t see any way out except through analysis.\u2019\u201d He did not look up. Minutes went by. Finally he muttered, \u201c\u2018Australian wool is firm.\u2019\u201d\n\nImage Credit Patricia Wall/The New York Times\n\nBut it\u2019s not just that the novel is an eerily perceptive character study, though it is. I\u2019m reminded of John Williams\u2019s \u201cStoner,\u201d or Jane Gardam\u2019s \u201cOld Filth.\u201d Like those other remarkable novels, \u201cMrs. Bridge\u201d offers not just a closegrained look at a character, but a wider view of what\u2019s around her. In this case, it captures a person moving \u2014 or not \u2014 through life. And it\u2019s not just that the novel is formally unconventional, about a supremely conventional person, or has much to say about repression, subjugation and emptiness. Its tone \u2014 knowing, droll, plaintive, shuttling rapidly between pain and hilarity \u2014 elevates it to its own kind of specialness. When Mrs. Bridge\u2019s former art instructor appears at the door in bad shape, selling magazines, out of pity she agrees to buy a subscription to The Doberman, despite not owning a dog. \u201cGadbury raised his head and looked at her in grave astonishment.\u201d As do we, repeatedly.\n\nConnell\u2019s 1969 novel \u201cMr. Bridge\u201d focuses on the man behind the newspaper, but I\u2019ve never entirely warmed to it. There was also a handsome 1990 Merchant-Ivory film, \u201cMr. and Mrs. Bridge,\u201d starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward. But despite the impressive pedigree the movie didn\u2019t seem to do enough to make readers see \u201cMrs. Bridge\u201d as the particular achievement it really is. It\u2019s faithful to both books, but what\u2019s missing, to me, is that hard-to-describe thing that makes any good book singularly itself. It\u2019s the sensation that you get being inside it. This is more than a matter of character or social acuity or tone; it\u2019s also what might be considered the book\u2019s room temperature.", "title": "In Praise of Evan S. Connell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Under the newest plan, a congestion zone would stretch to 60th Street from the Battery. Drivers would be charged a fee of $11.52 to enter during peak traffic times, while trucks and commercial vehicles would be charged $25.34. The plan would also impose a surcharge of $2 to $5 on trips in for-hire vehicles, including yellow taxis and Uber cars, in much of Manhattan.\n\nWhile congestion pricing has been put in place in other cities around the world, such as London and Singapore, New York has never gotten a comparable plan off the ground. The most notable effort came in 2008, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed an $8 fee to drive into Midtown and Lower Manhattan. But that proposal \u2014 which was loudly opposed by politicians outside Manhattan, including Mr. Weprin \u2014 died in the State Assembly without coming to a vote.\n\nWhat makes the newest framework potentially different, though, is the growing sense that the subways are in an existential crisis. And, increasingly, frustrated New Yorkers are blaming Mr. Cuomo, who has control over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It was against that backdrop that Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, declared a state of emergency in the subways last June, and convened a task force, Fix NYC, to come up with remedies.\n\nSo far, many subway riders, transit advocates and business leaders have applauded the contours of the plan, saying that the city\u2019s economy is at stake. Even Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat and proud Brooklynite who has opposed congestion pricing, called it \u201cdefinitely a step in the right direction.\u201d\n\nAt the rally on Sunday, Jon Orcutt, a former director of policy at the city\u2019s Transportation Department, said the new proposal benefited from having Mr. Cuomo\u2019s full attention. \u201cWith the governor leading it, we\u2019re at a better starting point,\u201d said Mr. Orcutt, who is now the director of communications and advocacy for Transit Center, a research organization. \u201cI\u2019d say we\u2019re at the 50-yard line.\u201d", "title": "In Protests, a Hint of the Fight to Come Over Congestion Pricing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "In the wake of Hurricane Maria\u2019s crushing devastation of Puerto Rico, leaving half the island without power and the official death toll rising, Klaus Biesenbach, the director of MoMA PS1 and chief curator at large for the Museum of Modern Art, and Christopher Gregory, a Puerto Rican photojournalist based in New York, traveled together to see how artists were facing the challenges of a post-disaster island.\n\nThrough decades of economic hardship, and years of financial crisis, the art world in Puerto Rico has had to learn to survive during lean times through a new artistic \u201csharing\u201d economy \u2014 sharing knowledge; resources; and access to infrastructure, materials and spaces. Might these artists now serve as an example \u2014 and catalyst \u2014 for other communities?\n\nIn Santurce, a district in San Juan, the visitors found Zilia S\u00e1nchez, 91, in the remnants of her studio where she had worked for nearly 50 years. Sunlight streamed through the jagged beams. There were no tarps to protect the roofless houses in her neighborhood, but Ms. S\u00e1nchez considered herself fortunate. Born in Havana in 1926, she settled here after years working abroad and is one of the most influential art teachers in Puerto Rico. Now her former students, including Jorge Gonz\u00e1lez, had come to help her rebuild her studio which she envisions with a protective concrete box around it, so she could continue to create the shaped paintings, suggesting female bodies, which look like ocean waves.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Gonz\u00e1lez is now an internationally recognized artist who will be featured in a group show in July at the Whitney Museum of American Art. He took his teacher\u2019s example to heart and extended his artistic practice to what can be called \u201csocial practice\u201d \u2014 creating spaces for collective learning. He developed the Escuela de Oficios (Trade School), engaging participants in traditional artisanal techniques, including weaving with plant-based materials found in nature.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Naranjito, the island\u2019s central region, Mr. Biesenbach and Mr. Gregory found Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez and Chemi Rosado-Seijo teaching a lace workshop with local children from an elementary school. Mr. Rosado-Seijo is an artist whose practice also combines community engagement and collaboration. Since 2002 he has been active in El Cerro, a rural, working-class neighborhood in the mountains of Naranjito, where he helps residents paint their houses a green shade of their choosing, in a community-building exercise that emphasized its hillside surroundings.", "title": "In Puerto Rico, Artists Rebuild and Reach Out", "authors": ["Klaus Biesenbach", "Christopher Gregory", "Ariana Mclaughlin"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal \u2014 The last time anyone saw Gauri Kumari Bayak alive, she was gathering grass and firewood. Considered impure because she was menstruating, she was about to sleep outside in a cold hut.\n\nShe never woke up.\n\nAccording to the police, Ms. Bayak is the latest victim of a very old tradition in rural Nepal, in which religious Hindus believe that menstruating women are unclean and should be banished from the family home. She was found dead on Monday, apparently having asphyxiated after building a small fire inside the hut to keep warm.\n\nIn Nepal, one of Asia\u2019s poorest countries, dozens of women and girls have died in recent years from following this tradition, despite activists\u2019 campaigns and government efforts to end the practice.\n\nMenstruating women often trudge outside at night to bed down with cows or goats in tiny, rough, grass-roofed huts and sheds. Many have been raped by intruders or died from exposure to the elements.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast summer, the Nepalese government made it illegal for anyone to force a menstruating woman or girl to sequester herself, with violators subject to jail time or fines. But the law came with a grace period to give people time to absorb the new rules, and no punishments are to be handed out until August.", "title": "In Rural Nepal, Menstruation Taboo Claims Another Victim", "authors": ["Bhadra Sharma", "Jeffrey Gettleman"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 \u201cThe Death of Stalin,\u201d a blackly comic movie about the Soviet leader and his cowed entourage, has earned widespread praise in Britain as a tongue-in-cheek spoof about a bygone era in a country that has long since collapsed. In Russia, the movie has been denounced as a sacrilegious portrayal of those responsible for victory over Fascism. And now it has been pulled from theaters.\n\nOn Tuesday, two days before the movie\u2019s official release in Russia, the Culture Ministry withdrew the film\u2019s distribution license. The ministry\u2019s lawyers recommended that the film be banned on grounds of \u201cextremism,\u201d citing its unfavorable portrayal of historical figures like Georgy Zhukov, the Red Army marshal lionized in Russia for his role in defeating Hitler\u2019s forces.\n\n\u201cThe film desecrates our historical symbols \u2014 the Soviet hymn, orders and medals, and Marshal Zhukov is portrayed as an idiot,\u201d Pavel Pozhigaylo, a member of the Culture Ministry\u2019s advisory board, told the RBC newspaper after a private screening on Monday to determine the film\u2019s fate.\n\nHe added that the film\u2019s release in advance of the 75th anniversary of the end of the Battle of Stalingrad, which will be celebrated nationwide on Feb. 2, would be an affront to Russia\u2019s World War II veterans.", "title": "In Russia, \u2018The Death of Stalin\u2019 Is No Laughing Matter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The result has been legal limbo: People whose behavior would not now be considered illegal are sometimes unable to find work, get college loans, obtain professional licenses, or find decent housing because of the blot on their record.\n\nThose who argue against expunging criminal records say people who violated the law should live with the consequences, regardless of subsequent legal changes.\n\n\u201cIn all the other states, the process has been messy,\u201d said Robert Mikos, a professor at Vanderbilt University who studies marijuana law and policy. \u201cBut whether people agree with what they did or not, California at least addressed it and there\u2019s value in that.\u201d\n\nEven in California, there is significant variation in how counties are handling misdemeanor marijuana convictions. Some, like Fresno County, are dealing with them on a case-by-case basis, said Steve E. Wright, the county\u2019s assistant district attorney. Jeff Rosen, district attorney of Santa Clara County, said he was working with the local public defender\u2019s office to identify cases. And prosecutors in San Francisco and San Diego have been more proactive, with both cities planning to automatically dismiss misdemeanor convictions and to reduce felony convictions to misdemeanors.\n\nIn San Francisco, Mr. Gasc\u00f3n said he wanted to avoid putting people through a process that he said violates the spirit of legalization.\n\n\u201cA lot of people don\u2019t even know they qualify, and I don\u2019t think it\u2019s the right thing to do to make people pay lawyers\u2019 fees and jump through a bunch of hoops to get something they should be getting anyway,\u201d he said.\n\nIn November 2016, California voters approved Proposition 64, which allowed adults 21 and older to buy or possess 28.5 grams of marijuana \u2014 about one ounce \u2014 or grow up to six plants at a private residence.", "title": "San Francisco Will Clear Thousands of Marijuana Convictions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The academic gaps between groups of students \u2014 the poor and the middle class, or black and Hispanic children and their white and Asian peers \u2014 often are examined in broad strokes, across a district or an entire city. But a new analysis from the Center for New York City Affairs at the New School takes a closer look by mapping the achievement gaps within each public elementary school in New York City. The results reveal the challenges of integrating students across the system, and of integrating under one roof.\n\nThe study is a snapshot that looks at student performance on a single test, the state math assessment given in 2016 to third through fifth graders. At each school, it looks at the race of the test takers and estimates their household income using census information about where they live.\n\nThe report illustrates how closely race, income and academic performance are tied in this city. Almost all students in the study with estimated household incomes below $30,000 were black or Hispanic, while students with household incomes above $80,000 were predominantly white. And the poorer students were, the lower they tended to score on the test, even when they went to the same school as wealthier children.\n\nTake P.S. 8, the Robert Fulton school in Brooklyn Heights, which the Center for American Progress identified last year as having one of the richest Parent Teacher Associations in the country, and which has a relatively diverse student body. While 64 percent of its students passed the state math test in 2016, compared with 36 percent of students citywide, black students at the school were nearly a full proficiency level behind their white peers.", "title": "In School Together, but Not Learning at the Same Rate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The gesture is both disarming and thematic. It was at a German flea market, we learn, that Mr. Turkowski, who often works with found video, bought for 20 euros the trove of eight-millimeter-film reels he now begins to project. Genially, self-deprecatingly and in charmingly accented English \u2014 he pronounces the \u201cw\u201d in \u201canswer\u201d \u2014 he tells the story of how he became captivated by what are evidently someone\u2019s silent home movies. But whose? And why should we care?\n\nEven overlaid with lovely recorded music (by Roger Anklam and Przemek Radar Olszewski), the films do not at first seem fascinating, filled as they are with banal images of people en route to Eastern European tourist sites in what seems to be the late 1950s or early 1960s. Here is a bus! Here\u2019s a cruise ship! Here\u2019s a brutal Soviet-style building called (we are mordantly told) the \u201cfinger of culture\u201d!\n\nBut the finger of culture points in unexpected directions; as Mr. Turkowski becomes fascinated with one particular figure who appears in much of the footage, so do we. She is a white-haired woman he provisionally calls Margarete, and the bulk of the play\u2019s 55 minutes consists of his sometimes comical attempt to pin down her real identity and understand the meaning of her movies. One scene, which Mr. Turkowski repeatedly replays on a video transfer and enlarges for study as if it were the Zapruder film, suggests, at least to our credulous host, a possible spy mission at a nuclear facility. Another hints at a gender transformation.\n\nI won\u2019t say what Mr. Turkowski eventually discovers; the revelation may not be on the scale of a Cold War thriller but in its ordinariness turns out to be just as exciting. Or rather: exciting and sad, as old family mementos so often are. (The found-audio mystery \u201cSay Something Bunny!\u201d has a similar setup.) It seems that humans must look for meaning in everything \u2014 and seeing that dramatized in Mr. Turkowski\u2019s retelling was enough, for me, to turn \u201cMargarete,\u201d though just a bunch of film clips, into theater. For what does theater need beyond a story and someone willing to let it unfold?\n\nThat is not Dickie Beau\u2019s aesthetic. Though he too works with found materials \u2014 in his case, audio recordings \u2014 he does not use them to narrow his focus, as \u201cMargarete\u201d does, but rather to expand it as much as a solo play will allow.", "title": "In Solo Shows, Lip-Syncing \u2018Hamlet\u2019 and Investigating Home Movies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "The changes are being made as the company finds itself embroiled in a larger debate over its role in spreading fake news and misinformation aimed at influencing elections in the United States and other nations.\n\nFacebook said these News Feed modifications were not identical to those introduced last fall in six countries through its Explore program, but both alterations favor posts from friends and family over professional news sites. And what happened in those countries illustrates the unintended consequences of such a change in an online service that now has a global reach of more than two billion people every month.\n\nIn Slovakia, where right-wing nationalists took nearly 10 percent of Parliament in 2016, publishers said the changes had actually helped promote fake news. With official news organizations forced to spend money to place themselves in the News Feed, it is now up to users to share information.\n\n\u201cPeople usually don\u2019t share boring news with boring facts,\u201d said Filip Struharik, the social media editor of Denn\u00edk N, a Slovakian subscription news site that saw a 30 percent drop in Facebook engagement after the changes. Mr. Struharik, who has been cataloging the effects of Facebook Explore through a monthly tally, has noted a steady rise in engagement on sites that publish fake or sensationalist news.\n\nA bogus news story that spread in December illustrates the problem, Mr. Struharik said. The story claimed that a Muslim man had thanked a good Samaritan for returning his lost wallet, and had warned the Samaritan of a terrorist attack that was planned at a Christmas market.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe fabricated story circulated so widely that the local police issued a statement saying it wasn\u2019t true. But when the police went to issue the warning on Facebook, they found that the message \u2014 unlike the fake news story they meant to combat \u2014 could no longer appear on News Feed because it came from an official account.\n\nFacebook explained its goals for the Explore program in Slovakia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Bolivia, Guatemala and Serbia in a blog post in October. \u201cThe goal of this test is to understand if people prefer to have separate places for personal and public content,\u201d wrote Adam Mosseri, head of Facebook\u2019s News Feed. \u201cThere is no current plan to roll this out beyond these test countries.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe company did not respond to a list of questions about the Explore program, but Mr. Mosseri said in a statement on Friday that the company took its role as a \u201cglobal platform for information\u201d seriously.\n\n\u201cWe have a responsibility to the people who read, watch and share news on Facebook, and every test is done with that responsibility in mind,\u201d he said.\n\nThe impact of the changes to the News Feed were also felt in Cambodia. Months into the experiment (Facebook hasn\u2019t said when it will end), Cambodians still don\u2019t know where to find trusted, established news on Facebook, said Stuart White, editor of The Phnom Penh Post, an English-language newspaper.\n\nNongovernmental organizations working on issues like education and health care also complained that the changes broke down lines of communication to Cambodians in need.\n\nFacebook has become particularly important in Cambodia. The country\u2019s leader, Hun Sen, has cracked down on political opponents, activists and media, effectively transforming the struggling democracy into a one-party state. Journalists have been arrested, newspapers have been shut down, and Facebook has emerged as an important, more independent channel for information.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat is, if you can find that information. Mr. White recalled a conversation this month with a friend who casually observed the lack of political conversation on Facebook.\n\n\u201cHe said he thought the government had banned politics on Facebook,\u201d Mr. White said. \u201cHe had no idea that Facebook had created Explore or was placing news there. He\u2019s a young, urbanite, English-speaking Cambodian. If he didn\u2019t know about it, what do you think the effects are on other parts of the country?\u201d\n\nIn Bolivia, the alterations to the News Feed also occurred in a country where the government and the press have found themselves at odds, with news sites like P\u00e1gina Siete frequently criticizing Mr. Morales, a left-wing populist who has accumulated enormous power since being elected president in 2006.\n\n\u201cWe became the only media to take on the government,\u201d said Rodolfo Huallpa, the web editor of P\u00e1gina Siete. Half of the site\u2019s traffic came from social media, with the lion\u2019s share of that from Facebook, he said. Since Explore was introduced, overall web traffic to the site has dropped 20 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe loss of visitors from Facebook was readily apparent in October, and Mr. Huallpa could communicate with Facebook only through a customer service form letter. He received an automatic reply in return.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter complaints from other outlets, Facebook eventually released a statement on a blog in Spanish explaining the Explore feature and the testing being done in Bolivia and other countries. But Facebook offered no means to contact it, Mr. Huallpa said.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t talk to Zuckerberg, we can\u2019t even talk to a customer service representative,\u201d said Isabel Mercado, the editor of P\u00e1gina Siete, referring to Facebook\u2019s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg.\n\nThe Explore experiment has reduced traffic by 30 to 60 percent at the website of Los Tiempos, the main newspaper of Cochabamba, the country\u2019s fourth-largest city, said Fabiola Chambi, the publication\u2019s web editor.\n\nMs. Chambi, however, fears the main consequence of the Explore function will be deepening polarization in a country already divided by ideology. \u201cIt\u2019s good to see things from your friends and your family, but there needs to be diversity of information,\u201d she said. \u201cThe miscellany is good.\u201d\n\nBolivia has also seen an increase in fake news as the established news sites are tucked behind the Explore function.\n\nDuring nationwide judicial elections in December, one post widely shared on Facebook claimed to be from an election official saying votes would be valid only if an X was marked next to the candidate\u2019s name. Another post that day said government officials had put pens with erasable ink in the voting booths.\n\nVladimir Tirado, a social media expert in Bolivia, said the government might simply begin paying for posts to appear on users\u2019 News Feeds, an option that he said most newsrooms could not afford.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhoever has more money will appear more,\u201d Mr. Tirado said. \u201cIn this sense, the government will certainly win.\u201d\n\nMs. Chambi of Los Tiempos said her newsroom hardly had enough money to pay its journalists to report stories, let alone to distribute them as paid posts on Facebook. The situation has left her uneasy about the role that the tech giant may play in her country.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a private company \u2014 they have the right to do as they please, of course,\u201d she said. \u201cBut the first question we asked is \u2018Why Bolivia?\u2019 And we don\u2019t even have the possibility of asking why. Why us?\u201d", "title": "In Some Countries, Facebook\u2019s Fiddling Has Magnified Fake News", "authors": ["Sheera Frenkel", "Nicholas Casey", "Paul Mozur"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Quite a few things, it turns out. His ideas reportedly included a new association to represent players\u2019 interests in a more forceful, independent capacity that could recoup a greater share of profits from tournaments.\n\nAfter the closed-door meeting dispersed, the word that echoed out from the room was \u201cunionization,\u201d and a possible restructuring of the ATP World Tour, which currently represents both men\u2019s players and tournaments.\n\nAs the tournament got underway, players were asked for their thoughts on a union, and the idea resonated among men and women alike. Many players support trying to bring tennis more in line with other sports in terms of the percentage of revenue that goes to the athletes.\n\nBut among the WTA players, there were concerns that they would not be included in the discussions and that they currently had no leader like Djokovic fighting as passionately for their causes. Some suggested a joint union would be a solution in an era where the biggest events are combined.", "title": "In Talk of a Tennis Union, Women Seek a Leading Voice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Poli House, a sleek Karim Rashid-designed property rising above one of urban Tel Aviv\u2019s most trafficked intersections, breathes new life into a Bauhaus landmark that until its recent renovation had seen better days. Previously known as the Polishuk House, the ship-like structure was first purchased by Yehuda Polishuk, a Ukrainian immigrant who arrived in pre-state Palestine in 1934 and leased its three curving floors to businesses including a shoemaker and a printing press. The Israeli architect Nitza Szmuk, an expert in preserving the historic buildings that comprise Tel Aviv\u2019s Unesco-designated White City, took care to maintain the building\u2019s original curved staircase and to source Italian tiles that would resurrect the original external facade. But while grounded in historic Tel Aviv, the Poli House , which opened in 2016, is a futuristic fun house: guests are whisked from its street-level entrance and art gallery to the neon rooftop lobby via translucent elevators, common areas feature egg-like pod chairs in fluorescent yellow and pink and corridors are ringed by cheeky phrases of scrolling LED text.", "title": "In Tel Aviv, a Futuristic Hotel With a Past", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "It might not keep the sun out of our eyes, but it can still keep some of the sweat out of our eyes. And once you get used to wearing one, it is also a security blanket in a sport where habits \u2014 good, bad or otherwise \u2014 can be hard to break.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been wearing my hat backwards for about five or six years now,\u201d said Maximilian Marterer, a 22-year-old German who qualified for the Australian Open. \u201cI did it at first because I had long hair, and I wanted to keep it in place. But I cut it, and I don\u2019t really need it anymore. It\u2019s confidence, so I\u2019m keeping it.\u201d\n\nRafael Nadal, arranger of beverage bottles and adjuster of shorts, knows this all too well.\n\nIt is working so far for Marterer in Melbourne. He was 0-14 in tour-level matches upon arrival, but has advanced to the third round.\n\nThe French veterans Adrian Mannarino and Richard Gasquet also made it that far wearing their caps backward \u2014 a now-unusual move for Gasquet, who was once urged to ditch the style by a leading French tennis writer who saw it as a sign of his inability to grow up (or intimidate his opponents).\n\n\u201cWho is afraid of a backwards cap and the childlike silhouette it creates?\u201d Philippe Bouin wrote in L\u2019Equipe 2007.\n\n\u201cCome on!\u201d Hewitt might have barked in response.\n\nSome have definitively moved on, though.\n\nIt is largely forgotten that Federer, the balletic antithesis of the grinder, wore his hat backward for much of the match when he made his Grand Slam debut at the French Open in 1999 at age 17, losing in the first round to the Australian star Patrick Rafter.\n\nHe soon switched to bandannas and started reserving the reversed cap for practice sessions, just like his longtime rival Rafael Nadal, even if Nadal seems much more of a natural for the get-down-to-business look.", "title": "In Tennis, the Backward Cap Makes No Sense. Nevertheless, It Persists.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Yates\u2019s previous book, \u201cBlack Chalk,\u201d had a delicious premise: an escalating game of dare over the years among friends who meet at Oxford. But it didn\u2019t, in the end, prove as thrilling as it might have. This one is more sophisticated, starting from the fully realized stories the characters are awarded in the service of an elegant narrative.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen we catch up with him later, Patrick appears to be suffering the most of the three. (His narrative appears as a kind of first-person journal addressed to his psychiatrist, though it\u2019s clear he\u2019s writing for himself.) Laid off from a bank, he fills his days stalking his former boss, cooking intricate meals and working on an elaborate website devoted to Red Moose Barn, the restaurant he dreams of opening.\n\nThough he ended up saving Hannah\u2019s life all those years ago, he has never told her the full story: where he was during the shooting and what kept him from intervening. When he learns, years after the fact, that Hannah did not see him at the scene and is unaware of his complicity, the burden is more than he can bear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis revelation has become the monstrous secret that paces the perimeter of our marriage, like something that prowls in the shadows, a dangerous creature awaiting its moment, the right time to strike,\u201d he says. \u201cTo have kept the truth to myself for so long feels like a crime in itself.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf Patrick feels like both criminal and victim, punishing himself with his secret culpability, Hannah appears to be doing just fine, thanks. A crime reporter at a Daily News-style tabloid, she works out of the Shack \u2014 the reporters\u2019 row of offices at Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan \u2014 covering grisly murders and trading banter with a seen-it-all central-casting cop. She\u2019s at work on a true-crime story about her girlhood experience, which, we realize, forms the book\u2019s meta-narrative.\n\n\u201cJust as with my favorite book, \u2018In Cold Blood,\u2019\u201d she writes, \u201cthis story you\u2019re reading once started out as a perfectly ordinary, everyday tale. Until, very suddenly, it wasn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nInto this intriguing setup comes something even better: a message on Patrick\u2019s website from someone identifying himself as a fan with a business proposition. Who this turns out to be, what his proposal is, and the intricate pattern of misunderstandings, hopes and delusions that connects him to Patrick and Hannah \u2014 that\u2019s what we gradually discover.\n\nBut along the way we learn about the past, and what drew Patrick, Hannah and Matthew to one another back in the rural New York community where they grew up. All of them \u2014 Hannah, rich from her family\u2019s cement fortune; Patrick, the fallen-from-grace son of a local politician; and Matthew, who has a surprisingly soulful sensibility despite his father\u2019s abuse and his reputation as a delinquent \u2014 turn out to be both victim and perpetrator in a crime that is less straightforward than it appears. Whether they understand it or not, the characters have been propping themselves up by their complex web of misunderstandings and lies.\n\nAs Patrick says at one point: \u201cThe reality is there are more than two sides to most stories. Truth is seldom a lens, truth is a kaleidoscope.\u201d\n\nNot all of the motivations ring entirely true, and I\u2019m not sure I fully believe the explanation for the central crime. But it doesn\u2019t really matter. You have to work hard to follow the winding road Yates sends us down, and the drive is full of pleasantly unpleasant surprises.", "title": "In This Thriller, a Cold Case Turns Hot 26 Years Later", "authors": ["Sarah Lyall", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Its resurfacing in the public sphere capsizes a half-century of mainstream consensus: that immigrants enrich the United States, no matter where they come from.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s remarks were \u201csadly reminiscent of the language used by nativists and racists in the early 20th century against Eastern and Southern Europeans and Asians,\u201d said Mae Ngai, an immigration historian at Columbia University.\n\n\u201cObviously he likes Norwegians because they are white,\u201d she added. \u201cBut he knows nothing about Norway, a country with single-payer universal health care and free college education. Why would anyone want to leave Norway for the U.S.?\u201d\n\nThe more liberal immigration policies of 1965 still form the scaffolding of the United States\u2019 legal immigration system, ushering in \u2014 if unintentionally \u2014 an America that grows less white every year. For years now, Asians, Africans and Hispanics have accounted for an expanding proportion of the country\u2019s visas.\n\nBut first came 1924, when the people in charge spoke openly of ranking immigrants of certain origins above others.\n\nThat was the year Congress passed an immigration overhaul that set strict quotas designed to encourage immigrants from Western Europe, block all but a few from Southern and Eastern Europe and bar altogether those from Asia. Overall immigration levels were slashed. The racial theories at play in the legislation, wrote the immigration historian Roger Daniels, would later become the first draft of \u201cthe official ideology of Nazi Germany.\u201d\n\nThere were some familiar refrains in the 1924 immigration debate. Cheap immigrant labor had depressed wages, the restrictionists said. Immigrants had seized jobs from Americans, they said. But it was also heavy on racist rhetoric aimed at preserving what eugenicists and social theorists of the time called the \u201cNordic\u201d race that, in their telling, had originally settled the United States.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe bill\u2019s authors had been avid readers of the 1916 book \u201cThe Passing of the Great Race,\u201d in which the eugenicist Madison Grant warned that the country was in danger of a \u201creplacement of a higher type by a lower type here in America unless the native American uses his superior intelligence to protect himself and his children from competition with intrusive peoples drained from the lowest races of Eastern Europe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder the 1924 law, the number of visas given to each country could not exceed annual quotas based on the number of people from that country who were living in the United States as of the 1890 census, before the flow of new Americans had begun to tilt away from Western European countries.\n\nThe United States, the law\u2019s supporters said, could now dispense with the \u201cmelting pot.\u201d The only new immigrants who would be allowed to come would already look, act and speak like the Americans already here.\n\n\u201cEach year\u2019s immigration should so far as possible be a miniature America, resembling in national origins the persons who are already settled in our country,\u201d the bill\u2019s chief author, Senator David A. Reed of Pennsylvania, wrote in The New York Times on April 27, 1924.\n\nEnglishmen and Germans were welcome; Italians and Jews, not so much. No Asians need apply. (Incidentally, Norway, home to many Nordics, was also subject to a quota, though it was given significantly more slots than countries including Greece, Spain, Turkey and Hungary.)\n\nBy 1965, Congress had repealed the per-country quotas, replacing them with a system that emphasized new immigrants\u2019 family ties to American citizens and residents and, to a lesser degree, the skills they brought. Under the framework established then, people already admitted to the United States can sponsor their relatives overseas through the process Mr. Trump calls \u201cchain migration.\u201d Others now come for jobs, for study, as refugees or through the diversity visa lottery, a program put in place in 1990 and intended for nationalities that are underrepresented in the normal immigration stream.\n\nPhoto\n\nConservative members of Congress, including some Democrats, had fought to include the family-based preferences for relatives of people already living in the country, believing, according to historians, that more white Europeans were likely to come that way.\n\nBut fewer Europeans, and far more Latin Americans and Asians, knocked on the door.\n\nIn the 2016 fiscal year, according to government statistics, there were about 98,000 people from Europe who became lawful permanent residents. More than four times as many, 443,000, came from Asia, and half a million from North, South and Central America and the Caribbean. Africa sent another 111,000. Over all, nearly 1.2 million people obtained green cards that year, compared with about 700,000 in all the years from 1930 to 1939 combined.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe consequences of the 1965 law were unforeseen by all. They were downright alarming to some.\n\nIn an October 2015 radio interview with Stephen K. Bannon, who would become Mr. Trump\u2019s chief strategist, Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, who would become attorney general, pointed out that the country\u2019s population was heading toward a historically high proportion of foreign-born Americans. Mr. Sessions, a longtime supporter of tighter controls on immigration, helped craft Mr. Trump\u2019s immigration proposals during the 2016 presidential campaign.\n\n\u201cWhen the numbers reached about this high in 1924, the president and Congress changed the policy, and it slowed down immigration significantly,\u201d Mr. Sessions said. Those who came to the United States through the 1924 quotas assimilated into the country and helped create \u201creally the solid middle class of America,\u201d he continued.\n\nBut, he said, \u201cWe passed a law that went far beyond what anybody realized in 1965, and we\u2019re on a path now to surge far past what the situation was in 1924.\u201d\n\nMr. Sessions and Mr. Trump have called repeatedly for ending chain migration and the diversity visa lottery. Haitians, too, have found themselves partially shut out by the Trump administration. In November, homeland security officials announced that they would end a humanitarian program that had given some 59,000 Haitians temporary permission to live and work in the United States since an earthquake shattered their country in 2010.\n\nLiving conditions in Haiti, they said, had improved enough that Haiti could \u201csafely receive\u201d its citizens.", "title": "In Trump\u2019s Immigration Remarks, Echoes of a Century-Old Racial Ranking", "authors": ["Vivian Yee"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDonald Trump is America\u2019s id,\u201d said the Rev. William H. Lamar IV, pastor of the 180-year-old Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church, which is five blocks from the White House. \u201cHe is as American as baseball and apple pie.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cAmerica has to think long and hard about whether it wants something different.\u201d\n\nFor millions of Americans, Mr. Trump\u2019s first year in office has been a time of fresh uncertainty and anxiety, full of setbacks both on policy and in attitudes. Worshipers on Sunday were heavy with those feelings.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe mood? It\u2019s cold, like the weather,\u201d said Shirley Ambush, 62, as she huddled in a winter coat, waiting with friends for the doors to open at an auditorium in Washington where the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. was to preach.\n\nMs. Ambush, a retired school principal from Frederick, Md., put the blame squarely on Mr. Trump. \u201cHe is slashing everything that we achieved,\u201d she said as she pushed inside with the crowd. \u201cCutting it with a knife. Shredding it to pieces.\u201d\n\nIn the Little Haiti neighborhood of Miami, Saintalise Briceus, 85, a worshiper at the Notre Dame d\u2019Haiti Catholic Church, was offended by the president\u2019s remarks.\n\n\u201cHe said my country was caca,\u201d said Ms. Briceus, a native of Port-de-Paix who moved to the United States in 1978. \u201cI don\u2019t feel good about it. I\u2019m angry. My country is a good country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Atlanta, the Rev. Dr. Raphael G. Warnock, the senior pastor of the church where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was co-pastor, rewrote part of his sermon after Mr. Trump\u2019s comment. (Mr. Trump later denied he said it, and on Sunday, a Republican senator who was present did as well.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat we heard was not new; it was a new low,\u201d Dr. Warnock said. \u201cI had to wrestle with how do I characterize what he said without saying it.\u201d\n\nWhat emerged was a service that swerved between the past and the present, a renewed political reckoning and another denunciation of the president from one of the country\u2019s most prominent black churches. Before a rapt crowd that included Dr. King\u2019s only surviving sibling, Dr. Warnock accused Mr. Trump of trafficking in \u201chate speech\u201d and described him as \u201cwillfully ignorant, racist, xenophobic.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know that he\u2019s listening, and I don\u2019t know that it matters,\u201d Dr. Warnock said in an interview. \u201cEven if Trump were to leave tomorrow, we still have to deal with the large segment of white evangelicals who voted for Trump. My battle is not so much with Trump as it is with Trumpism.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists.
