View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Tucker said that perhaps the progress the civil rights movement had fought for had missed parts of the country. Maybe black progress had engendered more resistance than he had understood.\n\n\u201cWe moved beyond a point, but we didn\u2019t carry the country with us,\u201d he said. Today he hears white people complain that their problems have been forgotten as political leaders focus on black misery. \u201cWhite people are saying that what has happened is you took equality from some white people and gave it to black people,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s where we are right now, I think.\u201d\n\nSome say that Mr. Trump\u2019s language is distracting from an important policy question that will affect millions of people. But church leaders said that made his remarks all the more inexcusable. Words matter all the more, they said, when they come from the mouth of the president.\n\n\u201cThis is not a Confederate uncle that\u2019s locked away in the attic,\u201d said Thabiti Anyabwile, pastor of Anacostia River Church in Washington. \u201cThis is someone who is making policies, and he\u2019s doing so from an openly racist point of view.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe added: \u201cIt teaches us that our country is in peril. We are in danger of going back to those old policies. If we are not awake and active, that will surely be what will happen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome worshipers on Sunday prayed for Mr. Trump.\n\nIn Brockton, Mass., a largely blue-collar city south of Boston, the pastor at St. Edith Stein Roman Catholic Church never mentioned Mr. Trump in the morning service. But Beatrice Wakahia, 40, an immigrant from Kenya who came to worship, was thinking about him anyway.\n\n\u201cI was praying for the country, I\u2019m praying for his cabinet,\u201d Ms. Wakahia said. \u201cMaybe the Holy Spirit will guide him.\u201d\n\nThe pastor of Kuomba United Methodist Church on the northeast side of Kansas City, Mo., was thinking of Mr. Trump as well. The Rev. Fataki Mutambala, a refugee from the Democratic Republic of Congo, told his congregants not to let President Trump\u2019s words disturb them.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t be mad about the message that you received from Donald Trump,\u201d said Mr. Mutambala, who came to the United States three years ago. \u201cThe respect that you receive is from God.\u201d\n\nHe urged his flock to ignore the president\u2019s remark. \u201cForgive the message that has been said,\u201d he told them, \u201cand feel happy and hope in the name of Jesus Christ.\u201d\n\nAmerican-born black church leaders were angrier.\n\nMr. Anyabwile noted that today\u2019s problems were rooted early in the nation\u2019s history, and observed that in contrast to Germany after the Holocaust, the American South has not been forced to fully confront the legacy of slavery and the Civil War.\n\n\u201cCorners of the country could put their hands in their pockets, whistle and quietly shuffle off, as if the history was never theirs,\u201d he said.\n\nBut that history can rear its head. \u201cWe are in the grips of the revenge of an American conscience that\u2019s never repented of its racist history,\u201d he said. \u201cThings that were left smoldering, embers have caught a bit of wind from our current president, and from time to time we are seeing flashes of fire.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPastor Lamar agreed that there was a problem with the American story.\n\n\u201cThe narrative that held America together has been fractured,\u201d he said. \u201cThe ground is shifting underneath us. You have to tell a truthful story about how America got to where it is. The factories are not gone because of immigration.\u201d\n\nIn Miami, Mr. Trump\u2019s negative stereotyping of immigrants, especially Haitians, seemed to rankle most.\n\n\u201cThe Haitians are family-oriented, strict with their kids, and hard-working,\u201d said Xavier L. Su\u00e1rez, who became Miami\u2019s first Cuban-American mayor in the 1980s. He went to Notre Dame d\u2019Haiti on Sunday to show support.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re going to stereotype them, you should say they\u2019re law-abiding, super ethical, warm and kind to strangers,\u201d he said. \u201cThey want to thrive in this country, as I did, and become part of the American dream.\u201d", "title": "In Trump\u2019s Remarks, Black Churches See a Nation Backsliding", "authors": ["Sabrina Tavernise"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Nozdrovska, who was 38, argued in her appeals that the police, aware they had detained the relative of the district chief judge, Sergei Kuprienko, delayed testing Mr. Rossoshansky for drugs or alcohol for eight hours, allowing him time to sober up.\n\nA judge working under Mr. Rossoshansky\u2019s uncle paid no heed to the bungled police investigation and released the young man on bail.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cRossoshansky had influence and connections,\u201d said Volodymyr Timofiychuk, a journalist who covered Ms. Nozdrovska\u2019s crusade on Ukrainian television. \u201cThis was all done quietly.\u201d\n\nMs. Nozdrovska appealed to higher courts to transfer the case from the district where the uncle held sway and then for a new trial, arguing that the police had falsified evidence while the local court looked the other way.\n\nMs. Nozdrovska fought tirelessly while judges serving under the man\u2019s uncle dragged their feet. As the case went on, the powerful family of the accused openly threatened her with violence.\n\n\u201cI will win this case if it costs me my life,\u201d Ms. Nozdrovska told a friend and fellow lawyer, Tamila Ulyanova, who did not take the statement literally.\n\nPhoto\n\nFinally, at a hearing on Dec. 27, with her elderly parents in the courtroom holding photographs of the dead sister, Ms. Nozdrovska did win. A judge accepted her argument of official misconduct and ordered a new trial for Mr. Rossoshansky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter that final hearing, Mr. Rossoshansky\u2019s father, Yuri Rossoshansky, told Ms. Nozdrovska that \u201cthis will end badly for you,\u201d Mustafa Nayyem, a member of Parliament who has followed the case, wrote.\n\nHow the government deals with the murder is being seen as a test case in corruption fighting for the government and President Poroshenko.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost a clich\u00e9 case, where a relative of a judge avoids punishment and the person who tries to fight this injustice is herself punished in the most horrible way,\u201d said Mykhailo Zhernakov, a former judge and director of a judicial reform group, Dejure.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Monday, the police announced they had detained a suspect, identified by the newspaper Ukrainska Pravda as the father, Yuri Rossoshansky, but there was no immediate indication of progress in untangling the abuses in the local court.\n\nA lawyer representing Dmytro Rossoshansky, Igor Eismont, denied that his uncle had meddled in the case. \u201cNobody helped him,\u201d Mr. Eismont said. \u201cEven I, his lawyer, could not help him. He was convicted.\u201d\n\nThe lawyer declined to comment on the reported arrest of Yuri Rossoshansky, other than to note that the father had not specifically threatened to kill Ms. Nozdrovska. \u201cHe never said exactly, \u2018I will kill you,\u2019\u201d Mr. Eismont said.\n\nThe new anti-corruption court demanded by the International Monetary Fund and other Western donors would threaten the Soviet-legacy system of \u201ctelephone justice,\u201d in which a phone call from a politician is all it takes to fix a verdict. In exchange for fealty to the executive branch, judges are given carte blanche to take bribes, rule in favor of relatives and run businesses on the side, said Mr. Zhernakov.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a survey last year, an almost impossibly low 0.5 percent of Ukrainians said they trusted Ukraine\u2019s judges. In recent rulings, judges have let off a string of officials charged with seemingly solid evidence of corruption, like the prosecutor who was caught with a trove of diamonds and cash at home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn her work, Ms. Nozdrovska had looked into corruption in state tenders and testified against a member of Parliament, making plenty of enemies along the way and exposing the rot still in the judicial system years after Ukraine\u2019s pro-European swivel. She did much the same in her struggle for justice for her sister.\n\nMs. Nozdrovska vanished on her way home from work on Dec. 29. Anastasia Nozdrovska, her 18-year-old daughter, became alarmed immediately when her mother did not answer her phone. \u201cAn hour went by, and we understood something was wrong,\u201d Ms. Nozdrovska said.\n\nInspired by her mother, the young woman is studying law at a Kiev university. \u201cMy mother was a fighter,\u201d she said.\n\nDiminutive and understandably afraid for her life, despite an armed guard provided by the police, Ms. Nozdrovska wore a black sweatshirt and spoke barely above a whisper.\n\n\u201cShe always fought injustice in this country,\u201d she said. \u201cShe wanted me to be a fighter, too.\u201d", "title": "In Ukraine, a Successful Fight for Justice, Then a Murder", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The host who met me at the head of the stairs wore a pressed white shirt and a trim little bow tie. Most of the people at the tables and the long bar were neatly dressed, too, without the straitjacketed stiffness you sometimes see at more expensive restaurants. Everybody seemed to have gotten dolled up just for the fun of it.\n\nThis is a rarity in the Pacific Northwest. I can\u2019t say it\u2019s especially common in Los Angeles or New York right now, either. But after a decade or so of tumbling into no-reservations gastro pubs and ramen counters wearing rumpled morning-after T-shirts, diners seem to be growing curious about restaurants that offer a bit of costume drama, and invite some in return.\n\nThe world Kissa Tanto dreams up is so much more appealing than the one I\u2019d left behind that I can understand why reservations usually have to be made two months out, when you can find them. In the year and a half the restaurant has been in business, drawing national attention, tables have not gotten much easier to come by, and the few that are set aside each night for walk-ins tend to be claimed minutes after the doors open at 5:30 p.m.\n\nWhat they will be eating could be described as Italian food made with Japanese sensibility and ingredients. Marriages of this sort are rumored to be successful in Japan, but for some reason they tend to fall apart almost anywhere else. (In Italy, Italian food is made with Italian ingredients, Japanese food with Japanese ingredients, and to suggest a different arrangement would be like bringing scuba gear to a ski slope.)\n\nAfter eating in other restaurants that tried to pull off Italian-Japanese fusion, I have walked out asking: Why? My first few tastes of Jo\u00ebl Watanabe\u2019s cooking at Kissa Tanto made me ask: Why not?", "title": "In Vancouver, a Door to a Parallel Culinary World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Until late June Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 is restricted from talking about plans for Panerai, which was founded in 1860 in Florence and, until 1993, primarily supplied instruments and timepieces for the Italian navy.\n\nBut as he takes his technical experience to the new job \u2014 both brands have been developing new materials for watches, like carbon fiber \u2014 Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said he thought his management skills would actually prove to be most important for the role. \u201cIt\u2019s much more about how I\u2019ve been able, with a small team, to change a brand and grow it to a different scale, at a different speed, and create a different interaction with dealers, customers and so on,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt Dubuis, Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 was behind the effort to shape an unusual focus for the company. \u201cWe are switching from operating in the watchmaking business to operating within the world of motor sport,\u201d he said late last year during an interview at the Bulgari Hotel when he came to see Dubuis\u2019s new boutique at Harrods in London. (At the time, he was in discussions about a move to Panerai but it had not been formalized.)\n\nMany watch companies have links to automobile companies and sports, like Parmigiani Fleurier\u2019s recent Bugatti model or Richard Mille\u2019s McLaren style. But at the boutique, there was the Excalibur Spider Pirelli with the yellow Pirelli colors and a rubber strap made from tires on winning Formula One cars as well as timepieces inspired by Lamborghini\u2019s Aventador S. And more variations are to be introduced at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie in Geneva this week, including a black rubber and pink gold Aventador S and a black and white titanium Excalibur Spider Pirelli.\n\n\u201cWhen we were thinking about what could open new doors for our brand,\u201d Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said last fall, \u201cwe thought of motor sport with its different network, thinking process and rhythm, but with the same customers, same price level, in a different industry, so we are not competing and can be open-minded.\n\n\u201cI would never launch a car and they would never make a watch,\u201d he added.\n\nSince May 2016, the executive said, he had been spending about a third of his time nurturing such partnerships, including sponsorship of the FFF Racing Team, a GT championship series sponsored by a Chinese tycoon, and developing an eight-piece Excalibur Spider collection with the concept carmakers Italdesign.\n\nThe partnerships also have produced some unusual customer experiences, the kind of events that many luxury brands today consider crucial to turning buyers into fans with long-term brand affinity. A case in point: the Lamborghini racetrack events that Dubuis has organized in moneyed hot spots from Palm Springs, Calif., to Beijing. \u201cWhen you are at the circuit, it\u2019s all about the sport, experience and fun so the customers become your friends and are not in a business relationship,\u201d Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe strategy seems to work; according to the executive, 80 percent of Dubuis\u2019s new clients last year were drawn by the partnerships: \u201cWe are accessing customers who did not think about us before they had the watch on the tray or were buying a complication.\u201d\n\nDuring Mr. Pontrou\u00e9\u2019s tenure he also formalized the brand\u2019s made-to-order collection, Rarities, as a dedicated business unit and developed the Velvet line for women.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe brand\u2019s founder, Roger Dubuis, who died in October, had a significant impact on Mr. Pontrou\u00e9\u2019s approach to watchmaking. \u201cOf course you need to create spectacular platforms, spectacular products, limited editions, crazy materials but what makes you different is the human touch and that\u2019s what I learned from Roger big time,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s something you can\u2019t buy today when you go to a store.\u201d\n\nAnd, Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said, working with creative people like John Galliano and Alexander McQueen at Givenchy, where he was sales manager in the late 1990s, also taught him how to translate intense creativity into business operations, as \u201cyou can\u2019t drive these people.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey didn\u2019t work with the same rhythm as the sales or business side, same as Roger,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is something that brands in the luxury world are forgetting \u2014 the capacity of an organization to integrate creativity, giving it the same rhythm as other departments.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Pontrou\u00e9 then joined Richemont, spending 11 years on product management at Montblanc, narrowing his focus to watches at Roger Dubuis. (He still wears the Roger Dubuis Skeleton double tourbillon watch he received the day he joined the company \u201cso I can explain the concept easily to clients,\u201d he said).\n\nWith the watch market slowly recovering from the downturn of the last few years (figures from November, the most recent available, show that Swiss watch exports increased 6.3 percent year over year, according to the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry), Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said last fall that he was optimistic about the industry\u2019s future. There is, he said, growing global affluence, with more tourists making multiple purchases during their trips.\n\nAnd, he said, the Chinese are buying again, as their purchasing habits have adjusted to Beijing\u2019s anti-corruption campaign. (The federation\u2019s November statistics said exports to mainland China were up 39.8 percent year over year, the category\u2019s strongest growth in 30 months.)\n\nLittle wonder, then, that China has been a priority at Roger Dubuis. \u201cWe are at the beginning of our development,\u201d Mr. Pontrou\u00e9 said last fall, \u201cand there is a growing share of young entrepreneurs who have made serious money from high tech and finance to food in the last five to 10 years, and they spend millions.\u201d\n\nIran also was on his list; \u201c80 million people live there, it is a fast-growing country and there\u2019s an appetite for luxury,\u201d he said. \u201cWe also find Iranian customers in Paris, Los Angeles and New York, who are not ready yet for big purchases \u2014 but will be.\u201d", "title": "In Watches, Swapping a Motor Sport Focus for the High Seas", "authors": ["Melanie Abrams"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "We think of summer as prime time for produce, but winter has bright seasonal salads, too. A cold-weather salad bowl may hold a lively mixture of sturdy-leafed, multicolored greens in the chicory family, instead of lettuce, along with a riot of citrus fruits.\n\nIt is bit odd to term them \u201cgreens,\u201d since many chicories\u2019 leaves are a deep red, ranging from burgundy to crimson. This is especially true of the slightly-but-pleasantly-bitter Italian varieties of red chicory known as radicchio.\n\nThe round-headed red radicchio di Chioggia, which looks something like a small red cabbage decorated with distinct white veins, is the most common found in supermarkets in the U.S. Some like to chop it or even shred it like slaw, but I usually prefer to tear the leaves in to fairly large pieces for a salad.", "title": "In Winter, Take the Bitter With the Sweet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Jenkins said the afternoon was the group\u2019s opportunity to explain why players had chosen to demonstrate, sacrifice their time and \u201cput our necks out there, because these are things happening every day and happening in N.F.L. cities.\u201d\n\nJust days later, the league was trying to dance around the political third rail of the anthem protests and the president. The league\u2019s sponsors and television partners were jittery. Through the fury, the Players Coalition became a way to approach the issues productively, and the league and the group had established a degree of trust.\n\n\u201cOne of the things you come away with is, they are incredibly knowledgeable, articulate and passionate about these issues,\u201d the Atlanta Falcons\u2019 owner, Arthur Blank, said of the members of the Players Coalition.\n\nGetting to Work\n\nIn an odd way, the president may have done the Players Coalition a favor. His obsession with the anthem protests accelerated the discussion about the issues the group was trying to highlight. Those discussions were awkward for some owners, but also for the players who were being branded unpatriotic. Jenkins said the group was determined to seize the moment.\n\n\u201cI realized I could have a far greater impact than I ever had,\u201d said Jenkins, a nine-year veteran.\n\nAll he needed was time, and Jenkins already had a lot on his plate. His foundation, which provides leadership and life skills to young people in underserved communities, had expanded to four states. He had also recently opened a high-end clothing store in Philadelphia. The baby was on the way, and the Eagles were suddenly one of the league\u2019s top teams.", "title": "In a Busy Year, Malcolm Jenkins Raised a Fist and Checked All the Boxes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Residents of the Seventh tell tales of confusion among next-door neighbors who have different House representatives. Rather than keep communities intact and follow natural borders, the district slices and dices pieces of five counties and 26 municipalities, and tosses them together in a crazy salad.\n\n15 miles PENNSYLVANIA N.J. Seventh District King of Prussia 76 Valley Forge Coatesville Philadelphia Swarthmore 95 Chester DEL. MD.\n\nWhat the mapmakers were trying to do was to link up enough pockets of conservative voters to ensure that a Republican would keep the seat, no matter the insult to geography or common sense.\n\nAs it happens, Mr. Meehan got into political trouble that would have made Walt Disney blush: He admitted this week that he had settled a sexual harassment claim by a former aide he called his \u201csoul mate,\u201d and on Thursday he announced he would not seek re-election.\n\nElizabeth Moro, a Democrat who wants to run for Mr. Meehan\u2019s seat, said that gathering signatures to get on the primary ballot can be maddening as she tries to figure out who is eligible to sign.\n\n\u201cPeople say, \u2018I want to vote for you, but oh my gosh, maybe I\u2019m not in your district, even though I\u2019m down the road from you,\u2019 \u201d she said.\n\nLike Pennsylvania\u2019s 17 other House districts, the Seventh was drawn using mapmaking software that analyzes voting patterns block by block. The idea is to set the boundaries so they dilute one party\u2019s voting power and create as many safe seats as possible for the other. In Pennsylvania, the Republicans who control the State Legislature wielded the mapmaking mouse, but in other states it has been the Democrats.\n\nSome of the Seventh\u2019s twists and turns are bizarre. At the point on the map where Goofy\u2019s foot contacts Donald Duck\u2019s rump, the district is precisely as wide as the Brandywine Hospital.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo the west, the boundary juts across the grounds of an elementary school, bisects the Kingswood Lane cul-de-sac and heads to the north of a Turkey Hill market before plunging south again, all to exclude the Democratic-leaning town of Coatesville.\n\nJim Carney, 76, a retiree who lives near Coatesville, said districts should be drawn along community lines, not by party registration. \u201cYou take a contiguous group of counties and you put them together and say, \u2018That\u2019s your district,\u2019 \u201d he said. \u201cYou don\u2019t count the Republicans and Democrats and independents, you count the heads.\u201d\n\nThe Supreme Court long ago ruled that gerrymandering to divide voters by race was unconstitutional. But it has yet to say the same about doing it by party. The court is expected to hand down a major decision this year on whether partisan mapmaking has gone too far.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, though, it was the State Supreme Court, not the federal courts, that threw out the map on Monday and ordered it redrawn in time for the midterm elections in the fall.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDemocrats in the Seventh are not the only ones who complain about it. Dave Dumeyer, chairman of the Republican Committee of Lancaster County, has never liked that the map splits his county, putting its eastern portion into the Seventh to add conservative Amish voters as a counterweight to the increasingly Democratic Philadelphia suburbs.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t say we\u2019re happy about it,\u201d Mr. Dumeyer said. \u201cI think most people here would like to see Lancaster County whole again.\u201d\n\nThere are zigs and zags all along the perimeter of the Seventh, roping conservative rural areas in and shoving Democratic enclaves out.\n\nAt the juncture where Goofy\u2019s head connects to his body in Montgomery County, the district is only as wide as a parking lot \u2014 the one at Creed\u2019s Seafood and Steaks in the community of King of Prussia.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe nonprofit group that sued to overturn the Pennsylvania map, the Public Interest Law Center, recently held a fund-raiser at the restaurant, the symbolic ground zero of its case. Ms. Lawn, the Chester resident, was there; she is one of the plaintiffs in the suit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJim Creed, the restaurant\u2019s owner, hopes that being a gerrymandering landmark might be good for business at his \u201cCheers\u201d-like establishment, where the $31 Surf and Turf features filet mignon, shrimp and a Chianti demi-glace.\n\n\u201cWe like Republicans and Democrats equally \u2014 that\u2019s a quote,\u201d Mr. Creed said.\n\nFrom the restaurant, the Seventh\u2019s boundary doubles back east along the Pennsylvania Turnpike, then bisects the township of Upper Merion, depositing many Democratic-leaning voters there in the 13th District, which includes part of Philadelphia.\n\nFor a few blocks, the boundary runs down the middle of Valley Forge Road, named for the spot nearby where George Washington and his army huddled in the winter of 1777 in the fight for American self-government. On Thursday, residents on both sides of the road reflected on the principle of one-person, one-vote, which critics say is undermined by gerrymandering.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s ridiculous,\u201d said Chris Light, 49, a Starbucks supervisor who lives on the Seventh District side of the road, talking about the way the map was drawn to help Mr. Meehan. \u201cHe\u2019s not going to represent the concerns of the people. He\u2019s going to protect his base.\u201d\n\nKathy Anderson, 60, a nurse and a Republican, was surprised to learn that Mr. Meehan was her congressman. \u201cI thought he\u2019s in Delaware County,\u201d she said \u2014 which is correct, though her confusion was understandable. Mr. Meehan\u2019s home in picturesque Chadds Ford is a world away, in suburban terms, from hers in Upper Merion.\n\nEven so, Ms. Anderson said she was glad to be living in the Seventh District, and not across the street in the 13th, which stretches to take in some city neighborhoods. \u201cI wouldn\u2019t want to be assigned with Philadelphia,\u201d she said.", "title": "In a Comically Drawn Pennsylvania District, the Voters Are Not Amused", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Minnesota native Jerry Johnson, who also prefers chalets over hotels, booked directly with Swiss Maid Services on his second visit to Wengen, after mixed success with VRBO.com. When he arrived, there were groceries on the doorstep and an immaculate condo with a view of the Jungfrau. \u201cYou can see actual pictures of rooms and views of where you are staying versus checking in to find your hotel room is over a Dumpster with no view,\u201d he said.\n\nBeyond the homey ambience, guests often book apartments, rather than hotels, to save money. \u201cIt\u2019s a good deal less \u2014 up to 40 percent,\u201d said Julie Doyle, the owner of Swiss Maid Services. For a two-bedroom, her rentals range from 1,200 to 2,650 Swiss francs per week. She has a one-week minimum during high season periods that include Christmas, New Year\u2019s, and school holidays, which are staggered throughout February. Otherwise, the minimum is four nights.\n\n(A weeklong stay in mid-March for a family of four at the Beausite Park, a four-star hotel near the children\u2019s beginner slopes, currently starts at 3,136 Swiss francs.)\n\nWengen now has a number of chalet service providers that offer a host of extras. \u201cWe have a concierge available daily,\u201d said Rachel Padley of Alpine Holiday Services, a Swiss native who founded her business four years ago after sensing growing demand for a personalized service that would boost rental prices of top-end chalets. Two-bedroom flats she manages range from 1,800 to 2,600 Swiss francs per week. Extra services, charged separately, include daily cleaning, breakfast and grocery delivery, champagne and flowers on arrival.\n\nDuring high season, booking far in advance is advisable. In October, returning Philadelphia guest Mark Putnam found only one three-bedroom chalet available over the holidays. He took it for his party of five at a cost of 5,485 Swiss francs for nine days. \u201cAs it turned out, we have a gorgeous view, a good location, and it\u2019s well equipped,\u201d he said.\n\nIn Wengen, chalet rentals started accelerating a decade ago when many longtime visitors began to snap up properties as fast as developers could build them, a trend that lost momentum in 2012 when Swiss voters approved a \u201csecond home law\u201d that prohibited more holiday home building in Swiss resort areas, partly to stop the increase in absentee owners who leave their holiday homes shuttered most of the year.", "title": "In a Swiss Ski Town, Private Chalets Have Become the Place to Stay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "It would be misleading to suggest any of this is new. A joke used to make the rounds at Anfield, when Liverpool was England\u2019s pre-eminent team. \u201cFor those of you watching in black and white,\u201d it went, \u201cLiverpool is the team with the ball.\u201d The set-up dates it to the days when television was not yet in color. It has always been this way: The best teams monopolize possession, which means their opponents have always focused on damage limitation.\n\nAnd sometimes, like Stoke did, they have decided that the gap is simply too wide to bridge, and have left their fate in the hands of fortune. In 2009, when Manchester United was the league\u2019s dominant force, Mick McCarthy, then the manager of Wolves, made 10 changes to his team for a game at Old Trafford. His decision forced the Premier League to alter its rules regarding the fielding of weakened teams.\n\nThe difference lies in both the scale and the ramifications of the problem. The Premier League has long sold itself as the most competitive league in the world, as a division where might does not make right, in which teams never know when they are beaten, where the emphasis is always on attacking.\n\nThat notion is central to the marketing that has made it such a fearsome, global success. The fans, of course, also play a crucial role, providing the sense of occasion that accompanies every game: the full stands, the echoing songs, the electric atmosphere.\n\nBoth, though, are threatened by the strain of thought made manifest by Stoke, Newcastle and Everton: The idea that all anyone outside the league\u2019s Big Six \u2014the Manchester clubs, Arsenal, Chelsea, Tottenham and Liverpool \u2014 can hope to do when confronting them is endure.\n\nIn part, simplistic as it sounds, that is because there are six of them. When Manchester United \u2014 or the great Arsenal or Chelsea sides of earlier this century \u2014 \u201chad opponents beaten in the tunnel,\u201d as Hughes, a former United player, once said, only one or two teams inspired such fear. Now, with six, there are weekends when the majority of Premier League games follow the same pattern. That jeopardizes the uncertainty that has become the league\u2019s calling card.\n\nJust as important, it serves to muffle the fans. \u201cIt is hard for the crowd to engage,\u201d Neville said of Newcastle\u2019s supporters during the game against City. Goodison Park was quieter than usual, too, for much of United\u2019s visit. Watching what amounts to a training exercise \u2014 one attack against one defense \u2014 offers precious little reason to cheer.", "title": "In a Top-Heavy Premier League, More Teams Rush to the Bunker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s hard to miss a musk ox: It looks like a buffalo decked out in a hairy fur coat. And yet this easy-to-spot giant, which lives on tundras from Siberia to Greenland, is still surprisingly mysterious.\n\n\u201cHere is the largest land mammal of the polar zones, but we hardly know anything about musk oxen,\u201d said Joel Berger, a wildlife biologist at Colorado State University and a senior scientist at the Wildlife Conservation Society.\n\nDr. Berger has studied musk oxen in Alaska for nearly a decade, and on Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, he and his colleagues reported a disturbing finding: Musk oxen are unexpectedly vulnerable to rapid climate change in the Arctic.\n\nIn a warming landscape, pregnant female musk oxen may struggle to find enough food for their unborn calves, the researchers found. Their undersized offspring may die young or fail to produce many calves of their own. In places, musk oxen may disappear altogether.", "title": "In the Arctic, More Rain May Mean Fewer Musk Oxen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The girl\u2019s remains were unearthed at the Upward Sun River archaeological site in the Tanana River Valley in central Alaska. Ben A. Potter, an archaeologist at the University of Alaska, discovered the site in 2006.\n\nIt was apparently home to short-lived settlements that appeared and disappeared over thousands of years. Every now and then, people arrived to build tent-like structures, fish for salmon, and hunt for hare and other small game.\n\nIn 2010, Dr. Potter and his colleagues discovered human bones at Upward Sun River. Atop a hearth dating back 11,500 years were the cremated bones of a 3-year-old child. Digging into the hearth itself, archaeologists discovered the remains of two infants.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe two infants were given names: the baby girl is Xach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay (\u201csunrise girl-child,\u201d in Middle Tanana, the dialect of the local community), and the remains of the other infant, or perhaps a fetus, is Ye\u0142kaanenh T\u2019eede Gaay (\u201cdawn twilight girl-child\u201d).\n\nThe Healy Lake Village Council and the Tanana Chiefs Conference agreed to let scientists search the remains for genetic material. Eventually, they discovered mitochondrial DNA, which is passed only from mother to child, suggesting each had different mothers. Moreover, each infant had a type of mitochondrial DNA found also in living Native Americans.\n\nThat finding prompted Dr. Potter and his colleagues to begin a more ambitious search. They began collaborating with Dr. Willerslev, whose team of geneticists has built an impressive record of recovering DNA from ancient Native American bones.\n\nAmong them are the 12,700-year-old Anzick Child, the oldest genome ever found in the Americas, and the Kennewick Man, an 8,500-year-old skeleton discovered in a riverbank in Washington State. Questions over his lineage provoked a decade-long legal dispute between scientists, Native American tribes and the Army Corps of Engineers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLiving Native Americans descend from two major ancestral groups. The northern branch includes a number of communities in Canada, such as the Athabascans, along with some tribes in the United States like the Navajo and Apache.\n\nThe southern branch includes the other tribes in the United States, as well as all indigenous people in Central America and South America. Both the Anzick Child and Kennewick Man belonged to the southern branch, Dr. Willerslev and his colleagues have found.\n\nSo he was eager to see how the people of Upward Sun River might be related. But the remains found there represented a huge scientific challenge.\n\nThe search for DNA in the cremated bones ended in failure, and Dr. Willerslev and his colleagues managed to retrieve only fragments from the remains of Ye\u0142kaanenh T\u2019eede Gaay, the youngest of the infants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the researchers had better luck with Xach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay. Eventually, they managed to put together an accurate reconstruction of her entire genome. To analyze it, Dr. Willerslev and Dr. Potter collaborated with a number of geneticists and anthropologists.\n\nXach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay, they discovered, was more closely related to living Native Americans than to any other living people or to DNA extracted from other extinct lineages. But she belonged to neither the northern or southern branch of Native Americans.\n\nInstead, Xach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay was part of a previously unknown population that diverged genetically from the ancestors of Native Americans about 20,000 years ago, Dr. Willerslev and his colleagues concluded. They now call these people Ancient Beringians.\n\nBeringia refers to Alaska and the eastern tip of Siberia, and to the land bridge that joined them during the last ice age. Appearing and disappearing over the eons, it has long been suspected as the route that humans took from Asia to the Western Hemisphere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere has been little archaeological evidence, however, perhaps because early coastal settlements were submerged by rising seas. Thanks to her unique position in the Native American family tree, Xach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay has given scientists a clear idea how this enormous step in human history may have happened.\n\nHer ancestors \u2014 and those of all Native Americans \u2014 started out in Asia and share a distant ancestry with Chinese people. In the new study, the scientists estimate those two lineages split about 36,000 years ago.\n\nThe population that would give rise to Native Americans originated somewhere in northeast Siberia, Dr. Willerslev believes. Archaeological evidence suggests they may have hunted for woolly rhino and other big game that ranged over the grasslands.\n\n\u201cIt wasn\u2019t such a bad place as we kind of imagine it or as we see it today,\u201d he said. In fact, Siberia appears to have attracted a lot of genetically distinct peoples, and they interbred widely until about 25,000 years ago, the researchers determined.\n\nAncient Beringians DNA recovered from an infant who died 11,500 years ago has revealed a previously unknown population of early Native Americans. The Ancient Beringians are thought to have split off from the ancestors of all living Native Americans about 20,000 years ago, and to have remained in Beringia. Arctic Ocean CANADA ALASKA Upward Sun River site SIBERIA BERINGIA Approximate coastline 20,000 years ago. Pacific Ocean East or west? Researchers have not determined whether the ancestors of Native Americans split after they reached Alaska, or whether the split happened in Siberia and led to two or more migrations into Beringia. Ancient North Eurasians Ancient Beringians Split 20,000 years ago Northern Native Americans Ancestral populations in Asia Split 15,700 years ago East Asians Southern Native Americans SIBERIA ALASKA Ancient North Eurasians Ancient Beringians Northern Native Americans 20,000 years ago 15,700 years ago East Asians Southern Native Americans Arctic Ocean ALASKA SIBERIA Upward Sun River site BERINGIA Approximate coastline 20,000 years ago. Pacific Ocean East or west? Researchers have not determined whether the ancestors of Native Americans split after they reached Alaska, or whether the split happened in Siberia and led to two or more migrations into Beringia. Ancient Beringians Northern Native Americans 20,000 years ago 15,700 years ago Southern Native Americans SIBERIA ALASKA Ancient Beringians Northern Native Americans 20,000 years ago 15,700 years ago Southern Native Americans\n\nAbout a third of living Native American DNA can be traced to a vanished people known as the ancient north Eurasians, known only from a genome recovered from the 24,000-year-old skeleton of a boy.\n\nBut the flow of genes from other Asian populations dried up about 25,000 years ago, and the ancestors of Native Americans became genetically isolated. About 20,000 years ago, the new analysis finds, these people began dividing into genetically distinct groups.\n\nFirst to split off were the Ancient Beringians, the people from whom Xach\u2019itee\u2019aanenh T\u2019eede Gaay descended. About 4,000 years later, the scientists estimate, the northern and southern branches of the Native American tree split.\n\nAccording to Ripan Malhi, an anthropologist at the University of Illinois and a co-author of the new study, these genetic results support a theory of human migration called the Beringian Standstill model.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBased on previous genetic studies, Dr. Malhi has argued that the ancestors of Native Americans did not rush across Beringia and disperse across the Americas. Instead, they lingered there for thousands of years, their genes acquiring increasingly distinctive variations.\n\nBut while the new study concludes early Native Americans were isolated for thousands of years, as Dr. Malhi had predicted, it doesn\u2019t pinpoint where.\n\n\u201cThe genetics aren\u2019t giving us locations, with the exception of a few anchor points,\u201d said Dr. Potter.\n\nIndeed, while the co-authors of the new study agree on the genetic findings, they disagree on the events that led to them.\n\nMore Reporting on Archaeology\n\n\u201cMost likely, people were in Alaska by 20,000 years ago, at least,\u201d said Dr. Willerslev. He speculated that the northern and southern branches split afterward, about 15,700 years ago as the ancestors of Native Americans expanded out of Alaska, settling on land exposed by retreating glaciers.\n\nDr. Potter, however, argues that the lineage that led to Native Americans started splitting into three main branches while still in Siberia, long before reaching Alaska.\n\nPointing to the lack of archaeological sites in Beringia from 20,000 years ago, he believes it was too difficult for people to move there from Asia at that time. \u201cThat split took place in Asia somewhere \u2014 somewhere not in America,\u201d Dr. Potter said.\n\nIf he is right, the mysterious earliest settlers of this hemisphere didn\u2019t arrive in a single migration. Instead, the Ancient Beringians and the ancestors of the tribes we know today took separate journeys. \u201cEven if there was a single founding population, there were two migrations,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut these scenarios all depend on timing estimated from changes in DNA, which \u201ccan be very sensitive to errors in the data,\u201d Dr. Reich cautioned. More tests are required to be confident that the Ancient Beringians actually split from other Native Americans 20,000 years ago, he said.\n\nAnd while the new study reveals the existence of the Ancient Beringians, it doesn\u2019t tell scientists much about their ultimate fate.\n\nBut knives and other tools found at the Upward Sun River site belong to a tradition, called the Denali Complex, that endured until at least 7,000 years ago. The people who made those tools elsewhere in central Alaska may have been Ancient Beringians.\n\nIf so, they survived for nearly 13,000 years after splitting from the ancestors of other Native Americans. \u201cThe archaeology fits with them lasting for quite long,\u201d said Dr. Potter.\n\nThe Native Americans who today live around the Upward Sun River site belong to the northern branch of the genetic family. The new study indicates that their ancestors returned north at some point to Alaska, perhaps replacing or absorbing the Ancient Beringians.\n\nIf the latter, and if geneticists are able to sequence more DNA from northern branch tribes, then they may stumble across living proof of an ancient North American people that no one knew existed.\n\n\u201cMy answer to the question, \u2018What happened to the Ancient Beringians?\u2019 is: \u2018We don\u2019t know,\u2019\u201d said Dr. Potter. \u201cAnd I like that answer.\u201d", "title": "In the Bones of a Buried Child, Signs of a Massive Human Migration to the Americas", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE YEARS, MONTHS, DAYS\n\nTwo Novellas\n\nBy Yan Lianke\n\nTranslated by Carlos Rojas.\n\n192 pp. Black Cat. Paper, $16.\n\nThe first Chinese recipient of the Franz Kafka Prize and a frequent target of government censorship, the novelist Yan Lianke creates imaginary wounds in real blood. Yan was born in Henan province in 1958, and his childhood coincided with the worst years of the Great Leap Forward, when China\u2019s rush toward modernity thrust millions into biblical-level famine and privation. (His mother, Yan later recalled, was forced to teach him the most edible forms of bark and clay.) As his translator, Carlos Rojas, explains in his introduction, these experiences profoundly marked Yan\u2019s sensibility. Yan has called his style \u201cmythorealism.\u201d His books read like the brutal folklore history couldn\u2019t bear to remember, and his characters feel stranded, forgotten by time.\n\n\u201cThe Years, Months, Days,\u201d the first of the two novellas collected in this volume, begins with an arresting line: \u201cIn the year of the great drought, time was baked to ash.\u201d Set after a mass migration, the story has three major characters: a 72-year-old man known as the Elder, a sun-blinded dog and a cornstalk. The minimal staging recalls a Beckett play. Like Beckett\u2019s most memorable characters, the Elder is drawn from a long tradition of absurdist sages, barely lucid but often wise. He talks to his dog, weighs sunlight on a scale and waters the cornstalk with his own urine.\n\nThe Elder\u2019s world is nauseatingly vivid, reminiscent of the too-sharp smells and sounds associated with a migraine. When he licks the powder from a flour jug, \u201cthe pure white taste of wheat\u201d blossoms in his mouth. When the sun is at its height, he hears his hair burning. Desolation has rarely seemed so sensual, so insistently alive. In chronicling with extraordinary sensitivity the suffering of an ordinary man, Yan forces us to pay attention.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe second novella, \u201cMarrow,\u201d revolves around the efforts of Fourth Wife You, the widowed parent of four epileptic and mentally compromised children, to marry off her third daughter to a healthy man \u2014 what they enviously call \u201ca wholer.\u201d Her children are what used to be called village idiots. (And the village is, in fact, named after them: Four Idiots Village.) Their lives seem hopeless until a ghost reveals that they can be cured by drinking soup made from a dead relative\u2019s bones.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere is a rich tradition in China, going back to the advent of written narrative and predating fiction, called zhiguai: accounts of the inexplicable and occult, often featuring ghosts. \u201cMarrow\u201d is a saucy sendup of that genre. Fourth Wife You argues with her husband\u2019s ghost, exposes herself in exchange for help cultivating her field and tries to keep her son from sleeping with his sister. Everyone is out for himself. \u201cGood soil in this tomb,\u201d Fourth Wife You remarks, disinterring her husband.\n\nYan\u2019s world is earthy, male and often very juvenile: snot, urine, phlegm and voluminous breasts almost qualify as secondary characters. It\u2019s also funny, although Rojas\u2019s otherwise smooth translation mishandles Yan\u2019s curses. (\u201cThat ass caressed her breasts!\u201d conjures a mental image more surreal than even Yan would intend.) Yan\u2019s vulgarity is the flip side of his sensuality, and recalls Upton Sinclair\u2019s line about aiming for his readers\u2019 hearts and hitting them in the stomach. In Yan\u2019s case, the effect is deliberate. His tools as a social critic are shame and disgust.", "title": "In the Brutality of the Chinese Countryside, \u2018Mythorealism\u2019 Reigns", "authors": ["Jamie Fisher", "Yan Lianke"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors didn\u2019t deny that McKnight was driving dangerously the night he was killed. In closing arguments, Seth Shute, an assistant district attorney, alluded to witness testimony that McKnight had wove in and out of traffic, cutting off Gasser and others off at high speed.\n\nBut Shute said Gasser had escalated the danger, taking McKnight\u2019s driving as a challenge. \u201cMr. Gasser thought that Mr. McKnight had thrown the gauntlet down,\u201d Shute told jurors, later adding: \u201cHe followed him off the exit. That was not his exit.\u201d\n\nShute acknowledged that McKnight had a hand on the open passenger side window of Gasser\u2019s car before he was shot. But he said physical evidence had proved that Gasser lied when he told the police that McKnight had lunged at him.\n\nShute cited the lack of gun powder on McKnight\u2019s body as evidence that McKnight had not been close to Gasser. \u201cJoe McKnight was not lunging,\u201d he added, citing autopsy results. \u201cThere would be a hole in his deltoid muscle if he was.\u201d\n\nShannon Swaim, another assistant district attorney, summed up the case by telling jurors that Gasser had been the aggressor as the incident drew to a close. But even if he wasn\u2019t, she added, Gasser was not justified in firing.\n\nMcKnight was considered the No. 1 running back recruit in the country when he came out of John Curtis Christian School in Louisiana in 2006. He signed with the University of Southern California, where he ran for 2,213 yards and 13 touchdowns and caught 66 passes for 542 yards and two scores in three seasons.\n\nIn the N.F.L., he played three seasons for the Jets and one with the Kansas City Chiefs. He spent a season in the Canadian Football League, playing two games for the Edmonton Eskimos and three for the Saskatchewan Roughriders.", "title": "In the Death of Ex-Jet Joe McKnight, Jury Returns a Manslaughter Verdict", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "This initial phase takes one to four days. \u201cThe more you inhale, the shorter the incubation period,\u201d said Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease specialist at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine in Nashville. \u201cIn the beginning, you don\u2019t feel sick. You don\u2019t even know it\u2019s there.\u201d\n\nAs the virus colonizes your respiratory tract, your body starts to figure out something is amiss and rallies its immunologic troops in an inflammatory response, releasing proteins called interferons \u2014 because they interfere with alien invaders. Interferons flood your bloodstream and set up camp in your mucus, prompting more proteins called cytokines to join the battle. These protein soldiers circulate throughout your body, ready to rumble.\n\n\u201cParadoxically, our own soldiers created for the fight are what cause us to have symptoms,\u201d said Dr. Schaffner.\n\n\u201cWar creates damage and so you get fever and a headache and muscular aches and pains,\u201d which you experience as the abrupt and intense opening salvos of the flu. These early symptoms are usually what distinguishes the flu from just a normal cold.\n\nThe achiness and fever also signal that you need to start drinking a lot of fluids. The battle royal being waged inside you will dehydrate you more than you think. You may notice that your urine will get darker and you\u2019ll have to go less often. Experts say to make sure you drink a cup or so of water or other liquid every hour, avoiding alcoholic and caffeinated beverages.\n\nDrinking fluids will diminish your headache and also bolster your immune response because your protein soldiers are conveyed via bodily fluids. Dehydration hampers their movement. It\u2019s one reason people tend to want soup when they\u2019re sick and may crave watery fruits like citrus and melon.\n\nWhile you may feel rotten all over, the real battle is going on in your respiratory tract where the virus is localized. When the war is winding down, you stop feeling achy and feverish but you have residual inflammation in your throat, sinuses and bronchial tubes. All those cells lining your mucous membranes have been damaged and are like weeping sores, Dr. Schaffner said. That\u2019s why your nose is runny and you start to sneeze and cough to clear out the detritus.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGiven this, over-the-counter medications that suppress your cough and dry your sinuses may not be the best idea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCertainly there is the thought that you don\u2019t want to suppress a cough too much or dry out your nasal passages because you want to get rid of the infection,\u201d said Dr. Tara Vijayan, an assistant clinical professor in the division of infectious diseases at the University of California, Los Angeles, David Geffen School of Medicine. \u201cThere\u2019s a balance for sure. I don\u2019t think you should suffer unnecessarily, but you need to weigh the true benefit.\u201d\n\nAlthough you want to rest, lying flat all the time can be problematic because it collapses your lungs so you can\u2019t cough as efficiently, trapping bacteria in your respiratory tract. If the virus destroys enough cells in your bronchial tubes it creates openings for bacteria to get into your lungs, which can lead to pneumonia, a potentially life-threatening complication of the flu.\n\nWhen your lungs are vertical rather than horizontal, \u201cyou\u2019re able to breathe deeply and freely and you\u2019re able to cough out any inadvertent material, even microscopic bacteria, that get down into bronchial tubes,\u201d Dr. Schaffner said.\n\nThe C.D.C. recommends people who are hospitalized or at high risk for complications of the flu, such as older patients, pregnant women and those who are otherwise immunocompromised, take the antiviral drug oseltamivir, sold under the brand name Tamiflu, because observational data indicate it might reduce the likelihood of death.\n\nOther researchers, including those at the Cochrane Collaboration, disagree, saying that there\u2019s not enough evidence to support taking oseltamivir or its chemical cousin zanamivir (brand name Relenza). They question the wisdom of spending billions stockpiling them as many countries, including the United States, began doing amid fears of a future flu pandemic in the mid 2000s. Indeed, the World Health Organization last year downgraded oseltamivir from its list of essential medicines. It may or may not help, depending on which study you look at.\n\nFor healthy people who get the flu, most researchers agree the data indicates oseltamivir taken within 48 hours of onset can reduce the duration by about two-thirds of a day. But at around $154 for a course of the medication, that may not be worth it, given that the side effects include nausea and vomiting.\n\n\u201cWe wish we had better drugs that could wipe out flu,\u201d said Angela Campbell, a medical officer with the C.D.C.\u2019s Influenza Division. But she said oseltamivir is \u201cwhat we have right now\u201d and in outpatient situations \u201cit\u2019s really the clinician\u2019s decision with the patient based on a number of factors,\u201d including cost and effectiveness, whether it should be prescribed or not.\n\nThe C.D.C. also still recommends getting this season\u2019s flu shot, despite its questionable prophylactic value, because it might reduce the severity of the flu should you contract it. In previous years, against strains other than H3N2, flu shots have had reported effectiveness of about 40 percent to 60 percent.\n\nBut beyond that, rest, fluids, not staying horizontal all day and perhaps also letting in fresh air and sunlight are the best things you can do for yourself. To prevent friends, family members and colleagues from getting sick, keep to yourself until 48 hours after your fever has subsided and you\u2019re feeling better.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile you may continue to cough for weeks, Dr. Schaffner said you probably aren\u2019t infectious. Just annoying.", "title": "In the Flu Battle, Hydration and Elevation May Be Your Best Weapons", "authors": ["Kate Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich. \u2014 An intricate boat ballet plays out each January on the frigid waters of the northern Great Lakes.\n\nThousand-foot freighters scramble to make final deliveries of iron ore to steel mills. The Coast Guard carves paths through ice-clogged shipping routes. And the Soo Locks, the engineering marvel connecting Lake Superior with points to the south and east, shut down for 10 weeks of maintenance while the weather is at its most brutal.\n\nLast Friday, with the locks\u2019 annual closing looming and temperatures hovering in the single digits, the crew members of the United States Coast Guard Cutter Mackinaw were at work before dawn. The day\u2019s first mission: Guide their ship through the locks to free a hulking westbound freighter marooned on the ice.", "title": "In the Great Lakes, They\u2019re Battling Ice, and Time. Take a Look.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI love crosshatching,\u201d said the painter Leelee Kimmel, walking around her Upper East Side studio on a recent morning. The space is a converted prewar apartment, and her large, spattery abstract paintings provide a sharp contrast to the clean moldings. \u201cWe\u2019re the generation of crosshatching, when you think about it,\u201d she added. \u201cBecause we\u2019re always hashtagging everything.\u201d\n\nKimmel used to act under her maiden name, Sobieski, and is best known for her roles in \u201cDeep Impact,\u201d \u201cJoy Ride,\u201d and \u201cEyes Wide Shut.\u201d She\u2019s also always painted, stealing moments in her trailer, on sets and \u2014 since she became a mother more recently \u2014 late at night in her studio. She paints, while listening to NPR or podcasts, on large canvases or in her HTC Vive Virtual Reality headset. \u201cMy paintings are only good when I\u2019m not aware of what I\u2019m doing,\u201d she said, \u201cwhich is actually the same as acting.\u201d\n\nImage Kimmel\u2019s work on view in \u201cChannels.\u201d Credit Courtesy of The Journal Gallery and the artist; photographed by Thomas M\u00fcller\n\nLast week marked the debut of her first solo show, called \u201cChannels,\u201d at The Journal Gallery in Williamsburg, a collection of bright abstractions on nine, large-scale black or white canvases. \u201cI\u2019m just really happy now that it\u2019s out there because I feel like I\u2019ve been having this conversation with myself for so many years,\u201d Kimmel said. The day after the show opened, a Page Six headline read: \u201cIt Girl From the 90s Has Her First Solo Art Show.\u201d Though it may sound like Kimmel has just become an artist, she says she has been painting privately for years. Her father Jean is also an artist and they used to paint together when she was growing up. A portrait he painted of a female bodybuilder currently hangs in the back room of her studio, and they still frequently speak over WhatsApp video chat. But the days when they would mix up the canvases and ask her mother to guess who was responsible for which have long passed.\n\nImage Kimmel frequently speaks with her father, another actor-painter, on WhatsApp. Credit Nicholas Calcott\n\nThe paintings at Journal first call to mind childhood scribbles. This might sound derogatory, but many artists, like Jean-Michel Basquiat and Cy Twombly, have done great work with scribbles. These shapes form the basis of all her works, and they appear to have a kind of internal logic or architecture. Viewers have a chance to explore the paintings further in the form of a virtual reality film, which Kimmel has set up in the gallery\u2019s back offices. The experience offers flyby tours of skyscraper-size versions of her shapes; you can soar above and through them. On the night of the opening, lines for these headsets were 15-people deep. (Klaus Biesenbach, the director of MoMA PS1, emerged from his session nodding vigorously, and maybe a little nervously.)", "title": "In the Studio With an Actress-Turned-Painter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "You can see where this is heading. Hadi returns home one evening and his oozing creature has fled, without bothering to leave a note.\n\nWhat follows, in this assured and hallucinatory story, is funny and horrifying in a near-perfect admixture. Funny because Saadawi wrings a good deal of black humor out of the way the monster\u2019s pieces fall off at inopportune moments.\n\nHe delves into its \u201cserious putrefaction problems.\u201d The creature is blamed for a series of murders. All the authorities know is that he\u2019s terrible to look at, so they begin rounding up all the ugly people in Baghdad as suspects.\n\nPhoto\n\nSaadawi\u2019s tone can be sly, but his intentions are deadly serious. He\u2019s written a complex allegory for the tribal cruelties in Iraq in the wake of the American invasion. His book is especially moving about women who have lost their sons and husbands, and who wonder if they are alive and will ever return. In Iraq, the dead sometimes really do return, from dungeons among other places.\n\n\u201cFrankenstein in Baghdad\u201d is about many things other than a creature who terrorizes the city at night. It\u2019s a real estate novel in which there are struggles over old houses and hotels. It\u2019s a journalism novel; one central character is an editor who chases the creature\u2019s story.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe meet barbers and hotel guards and astrologers and film directors. A lot of kebabs and tripe and boiled beans are consumed, washed down with glasses of arak. Shishas are smoked; lusty thoughts are entertained. Saadawi wedges a lot of humanity into his narrative.\n\nLike the monster in Mary Shelley\u2019s \u201cFrankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus\u201d (1818), Saadawi\u2019s creature feels he is misunderstood. He\u2019s not a bad guy, he wishes to explain. He\u2019s not killing at random. Instead, he\u2019s after revenge. He is killing the men whose bombs created his parts.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe creature becomes a media obsession. It grants interviews. It thinks things like, \u201cBecause I\u2019m made up of body parts of people from diverse backgrounds \u2014 ethnicities, tribes, races and social classes \u2014 I represent the impossible mix that never was achieved in the past. I\u2019m the first true Iraqi citizen.\u201d\n\nIf the creature is after revenge, you begin to wonder, why does he not commandeer a jet and lumber after George W. Bush and Tony Blair? If this monster thinks globally, however, he is committed to murdering locally.\n\nSome think the monster is merely a manifestation of people\u2019s fears. He assures them he is more than that. In any case, as Toni Morrison put in \u201cSong of Solomon,\u201d \u201cWhat difference do it make if the thing you scared of is real or not?\u201d\n\nThe creature experiences its own sort of mission creep. He starts by killing only bad men. Before long he realizes that he needs replacement parts. He begins killing nearly at random in order to acquire them. Who among us is not part evil?, he rationalizes.\n\nIn this translation from the Arabic by Jonathan Wright, Saadawi blends the unearthly, the horrific and the mundane to terrific effect. It is no surprise to learn that he won the International Prize for Arabic Fiction, a kind of Booker Prize for the region, for \u201cFrankenstein in Baghdad.\u201d There\u2019s a freshness to both his voice and vision; he is working through a country\u2019s trauma from a series of unusual angles.\n\nThere are moments you feel you are reading a war story. At other moments, the book unloads a freight of black magic. We meet a journalist who is compiling an anthology of \u201cthe 100 strangest Iraqi stories.\u201d We learn of the activities of the Tracking and Pursuit Department, which monitors unusual crimes, investigates urban legends and makes predictions about future attacks.\n\nGhosts hover over bridges. Four beggars are found dead in a \u201cweird tableau,\u201d each with his hands around the neck of the one in front of him. A woman\u2019s phone number is 666, only the first sign she might have boundary issues.\n\nYou get the sense, throughout \u201cFrankenstein in Baghdad,\u201d that Saadawi\u2019s creature, alive with malevolent intelligence, is feeding off its own destructive energy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe reader feeds off it as well. What happened in Iraq was a spiritual disaster, and this brave and ingenious novel takes that idea and uncorks all its possible meanings.", "title": "In \u2018Frankenstein in Baghdad,\u2019 a Fantastical Manifestation of War\u2019s Cruelties", "authors": ["Dwight Garner", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Protests are already erupting in many places and rowdy mobs have vandalized movie theaters, tollbooths, road dividers, buses and cars.\n\nAn Indian TV station reported Wednesday night that a mob had attacked a school bus, pelting it with stones as children and teachers took cover in the aisle.\n\nIndian intellectuals watching the hysteria have been perplexed by two issues.\n\nFirst, few people have actually seen the film. The most strident protesters admit that they have not watched \u201cPadmaavat\u201d and that their objections rely on hearsay. The source of the rumors is unclear. The filmmakers have been careful about leaks of advance copies.\n\nSecond, Queen Padmavati might never have existed. Although Alauddin Khilji, the leader of the Muslim invasion depicted in the film, and the Hindu king at the time, Ratnasimha, known as Ratan Sen in the film, were historical figures of the 14th century, several scholars said they could find no mentions of Queen Padmavati in sources from that era.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are living in strange times,\u201d said Manish Tewari, an official with India\u2019s leading opposition party, the Indian National Congress, who supported the release of the film.\n\nThe Indian police services are taking no chances, busing reinforcements into place on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cWe have geared up our local intelligence machinery,\u201d said Anand Kumar, a police chief in Lucknow, in northern India. \u201cWe have also told them to deploy policemen at sensitive points. We have asked the cinema owners also to deploy their own private security.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
