The idea is the same: Truth is not found, but made, and making truth means exercising power.\n\nIt is not usually the job of political journalists to analyze postmodernism, so I turned to some scholars who are devoted to the subject.\n\nTrump\u2019s \u201ctruths,\u201d as Alan Schrift, a professor of philosophy at Grinnell College, pointed out,\n\nare not socially constructed but emerge from his own personal sense of what will promote his popularity, his power, and his wealth. This is why his particular, and acute, narcissism is so dangerous: he appeals to no social standards at all, only his own imagination as to what is in his own personal interest.\n\nPut in the most straightforward terms, Johanna Oksala, a professor of social science and cultural studies at the Pratt Institute, responded by email to my inquiry:\n\nI don\u2019t think Trump should be called a postmodern president, but simply a liar.\n\nFor something to be objectively true, Oksala wrote,\n\ndoes not mean that we have to have (or can have) absolute and eternally infallible knowledge of it. But our knowledge claims have to be available for public scrutiny by the scientific community and go through a rigorous peer-review process in order to qualify as scientific or objective truths.\n\nIn the Trump era, the core concept of truth has become deeply politicized and among Trump supporters there is scant appetite for \u201ca rigorous peer-review process.\u201d Andrew Cutrofello, a professor of philosophy at Loyola University Chicago, argues this point in an email:\n\nIn the present political climate truth and power have become uncoupled to a certain extent. It\u2019s natural to wonder whether this means the notion of objective truth has been undermined. But it could be the opposite, namely, that what we\u2019re living through isn\u2019t the loss of the category of objective truth but rather a battle over who has objective truth on their side. In other words, the very category of objective truth has become an ideological weapon, having been displaced from relatively neutral territory to the political battlefield.\n\nFor some scholars, the attempt to link Trump\u2019s lies \u2014 his falsehoods, his prevarications, his exaggerations, his duplicity, his \u201ctruthful hyperbole\u201d \u2014 with postmodernism grows out of a misperception of the term.", "title": "Opinion | Is President Trump a Stealth Postmodernist or Just a Liar?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Fourteen months ago, in the first flush of power, Steve Bannon gave an interview to Michael Wolff \u2014 beginning a relationship that would prove his undoing \u2014 in which he boasted about his plan to realign our politics. His nationalist-populist movement, he argued, would transform the G.O.P. into something truly new: a right-wing worker\u2019s party that spent freely, \u201cjacked up\u201d infrastructure all over the country, and won \u201c60 percent of the white vote\u201d and \u201c40 percent of the black and Hispanic vote\u201d on its way to a 50-year majority.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re just going to throw it up against the wall and see if it sticks,\u201d Bannon said. \u201cIt will be as exciting as the 1930s.\u201d\n\nAs exciting as the 1930s is not a line you hear every day, but rather than an alt-right dog whistle, what I heard in Bannon\u2019s formulation was the idea that in the Trump era, as in the crisis years that gave us both F.D.R. and Hitler, everything might be up for grabs: not just electoral coalitions, but the nature and destiny of the liberal order. Which would be a terrifying prospect but also an exciting one, since it would mean that the long \u201cend of history\u201d that followed the Cold War had irrevocably ended, and that it was time to imagine radical revisions to a stagnant-seeming liberal West.\n\nFlash forward a year and a couple months, though, and Bannon\u2019s vision seems pretty much dead: its rumpled leader sacked and ritually denounced, its bold populism subsumed into the same old, same old Republican agenda. Trump remains temperamentally authoritarian and personally vile, but the idea of Trumpism as an ideological revolution, whether akin to Roosevelt\u2019s or Mussolini\u2019s, has mostly evaporated.", "title": "Opinion | Is There Life After Liberalism?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Is there a downside to following a gluten-free or grain-free diet for someone who is not highly sensitive to gluten? Are there any benefits?\n\nA. A gluten-free or grain-free diet can pose risks and is not recommended for someone who is not highly sensitive to gluten. Such a diet is also unlikely to provide any benefits.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no reason for someone who feels well to start a gluten-free diet to promote wellness,\u201d said Dr. Benjamin Lebwohl, director of clinical research at the Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University. \u201cIt is not an intrinsically wellness-promoting diet.\u201d\n\nOne of the main problems in avoiding gluten-containing grains like wheat, rye or barley as well as other grains is that it can reduce the overall quality of someone\u2019s diet. \u201cThe most common issue people run into when starting a gluten-free diet is fiber intake often plummets,\u201d Dr. Lebwohl said. Fiber is important for overall digestive health, so inadequate intake can lead to constipation and other bowel problems; it may also make you not feel as full, which can lead to excess calorie intake and potential weight gain. While grains aren\u2019t the only source of fiber available, they are a good one, and most Americans fail by a long shot to get the recommended intake of about 20 to 40 grams a day, depending on gender and age.", "title": "Is There a Downside to Going Gluten-Free if You\u2019re Healthy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In May 2016, Paul Erickson, an activist who has raised money for the National Rifle Association, sent an email to Rick Dearborn, an adviser to Donald Trump\u2019s presidential campaign, with the super-subtle subject heading \u201cKremlin Connection.\u201d As The New York Times reported last December, Erickson wrote that Russia was \u201cquietly but actively seeking a dialogue with the U.S.\u201d and planned to use the N.R.A.\u2019s annual convention in Louisville, Ky. that month to make \u201cfirst contact\u201d with the Trump camp. At the convention, Donald Trump Jr. met with Aleksandr Torshin, an ally of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, reputed mobster and deputy governor of the Russian central bank.\n\nThis is one of those episodes that is easy to lose track of amid the avalanche of evidence connecting the Trump administration and Russia. But it takes on new significance because of an intriguing, potentially explosive article that McClatchy published Thursday headlined, \u201cF.B.I. Investigating Whether Russian Money Went to N.R.A. to Help Trump.\u201d We know of numerous secret communications between members of the Trump campaign and Russia, and favors asked for and received. This, however, is the most significant hint of a money trail. Norman Eisen, Barack Obama\u2019s White House ethics czar, tweeted: \u201cthis could well be the collusion we have been waiting for, prosecutable as possible campaign finance crimes.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s important not to get carried away, if only because a scenario in which the Russian investigation ensnares the N.R.A., probably the most influential conservative group in the United States, seems a bit too much like Resistance fan fiction, too delicious to be true. Indeed, if it is true, it has devastating implications for the entire Republican Party, since many officeholders enjoy lavish financial support from the N.R.A. Still, an N.R.A. role in Russiagate would explain a few things, including why the N.R.A. has, in recent years, developed such a close relationship with Russia.\n\nThere\u2019s been a lot of reporting about that relationship, which is widely seen as part of Russia\u2019s efforts to cultivate right-wing groups throughout the United States and Europe. As The Washington Post noted last year, \u201cOn issues including gun rights, terrorism and same-sex marriage, many leading advocates on the right who grew frustrated with their country\u2019s leftward tilt under President Barack Obama have forged ties with well-connected Russians and come to see that country\u2019s authoritarian leader, Vladimir Putin, as a potential ally.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Is This the Collusion We Were Waiting For?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018That\u2019s the Way of the World\u2019\n\nA few years ago, Varla, Sherry Vine, and Jackie \u2014 20 years, 25 years, and 28 years in drag, respectively \u2014 had lunch. \u201cDrag Race\u201d had been on for several seasons, and bookings dwindled. \u201cThe clubs only wanted \u2018Drag Race\u2019 girls,\u201d Sherry said by phone. \u201cAnd we were like: \u2018Oh my God, what are we supposed to do?\u2019\u201d\n\nLady Bunny, the D.J. and Wigstock founder, knows a bar owner who regularly books \u201cDrag Race\u201d queens. \u201cHe said the fans watch the first number and go get in line for the meet-and-greet,\u201d she said over breakfast. \u201cWhen getting a picture with someone you\u2019ve seen on TV so people can like you on social media is more important than the performance?\u201d She shook her head. \u201cThat\u2019s not \u2018Drag Race,\u2019 though. That\u2019s the way of the world.\u201d\n\nVarla was still a cabaret fixture in Palm Springs and Provincetown and Sherry and Jackie began to explore theater gigs. Their reputations and stage chops prevailed; club and bar owners began to call again.\n\n\u201cLook at where they are, without that \u2018Drag Race\u2019 golden ticket,\u201d Bianca said. \u201cTalent will always prevail.\u201d\n\nCoco Peru, who is known from the film \u201cTrick\u201d and a YouTube series in which she runs errands and rants, plans to retire in six years. \u201cI\u2019ve been lifting heavy suitcases around this globe for 27 years,\u201d she said during her cabaret at Birdland in New York.\n\nIn her dressing room, she swatted at a fly with her pantyhose. \u201cI\u2019ll go anywhere they\u2019ll pay me,\u201d she said. \u201cI travel on the weekends. I\u2019ll do three or four shows and be home for a week. At my age that\u2019s a nice schedule.\u201d\n\nCoco started in New York\u2019s West Village in 1990. \u201cI was going out in full drag to sing at open mics, to pass out my postcards,\u201d she said. \u201cI would spray paint on the sidewalk, \u2018Miss Coco Peru, she knows,\u2019 just to create buzz. There was no internet back then.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVarla, who performed in bars like the Pyramid, the Brake, and the Works \u2014 \u201cThat was right behind the Natural History Museum; they\u2019d put a piece of plywood on the pool table\u201d \u2014 credits Coco with helping her into the cabaret scene. \u201cWe\u2019d go out and beg people to come to the show,\u201d Varla said. \u201cThere was no other way. Now, you\u2019re on TV for five minutes, you\u2019ve got a career.\u201d\n\nSherry moved to New York in 1992, a time when drag flourished. \u201cLimelight, Palladium, and Tunnel \u2014 all the big clubs would pay queens $200 or $300 to hang out for two hours,\u201d she said. \u201cYou could do three of those a night.\u201d\n\nAs film students, Mr. Barbato and Mr. Bailey skipped their editing class to go to the Pyramid, where they saw performers like Tabboo! and Ethyl Eichelberger.\n\nThe Los Angeles scene was similarly vibrant, Jackie remembered. \u201cClubs like Trade and Dragstrip 66 came along and it seemed like everyone was doing drag,\u201d she said. \u201cRetro, grunge, fetish. People like Alexis Arquette, Karen Dior and Steven Loya as Mondo Connie, the Bally Sisters, Sean DeLear \u2014 so many of them are gone.\u201d\n\nThings in New York changed when Rudolph Giuliani, then the mayor, used the Prohibition-era, now-repealed Cabaret Law to crack down on nightclubs. \u201cGiuliani killed night life,\u201d Sherry said. \u201cYou\u2019d get in drag and go to a bar, and you\u2019re there five minutes and the fire department turns the lights on. It was like: \u2018Where are we? Is this 1938 Berlin?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Roxy hired Shequida for the first of its weekly gay dance nights, Roxy Saturdays, in 1990. En route to host Drag Brunch at Highline Ballroom, she pointed at a construction pit along the West Side Highway. \u201cThat\u2019s where it used to be,\u201d she said; the club closed in 2007.\n\nLady Bunny, who started performing at the Pyramid in 1984, sighed. \u201cThe venues that I grew up in, they\u2019re gone,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s not a large gay club that is open seven days a week with a dance floor in Manhattan, other than the Monster. Thank God it\u2019s there.\u201d\n\nLinda Simpson, another Pyramid veteran, now hosts bingo at Le Poisson Rouge. \u201cRu is incredible,\u201d she said in an Uber. \u201cBut it\u2019s telling that the top person of the genre has been the same since 1992. Drag is still a ghetto. The entertainment industry is still unsure of what to do with drag. Why not give Bianca her own talk show? Why not have Sharon Needles do some sitcom? They\u2019re wildly popular. Not to unseat Ru, but is there room for other sensibilities?\u201d", "title": "Is This the Golden Age of Drag? Yes. And No.", "authors": ["Isaac Oliver"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "But that was not the case in 2017, a year in which several strains of contemporary jazz thrived: flourishing scenes in Chicago (Makaya McCraven and others) and England (radiating outward from Shabaka Hutchings), a bold experimental recording by Esperanza Spalding, evolutions in crossover from Yazz Ahmed and Christian Scott, and more. It was also a year of loud debates about how women have been treated in jazz historically, and how that mistreatment continues to the present day.\n\nTo discuss the year in jazz on this week\u2019s Popcast, the last of our 2017 roundup editions, Mr. Caramanica was joined by Giovanni Russonello, who covers jazz for The New York Times, and Natalie Weiner, a staff writer for Bleacher Report who writes about jazz for Billboard and JazzTimes.", "title": "Is Today\u2019s Jazz Finally Outrunning the Past?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "In his first year in office President Trump gave himself credit for numerous accomplishments that he had little or nothing to do with: the passage of the Republican tax bill; Walmart\u2019s creating 10,000 jobs in the United States; the invention of the phrase \u201cprime the pump\u201d; and the fact that in his brief tenure, nobody died in a commercial aviation accident. (The last fatal crash on a domestic commercial airline in the United States was in 2009.) But one thing that Mr. Trump almost certainly managed to do, without effort or notice, is alter our perception of time.\n\nWe\u2019re all aware that our experience of time is fungible: Days fly by, conversations drag on, that weeklong vacation seems to last forever until suddenly it doesn\u2019t. As long ago as 1890 the psychologist William James noted that our feelings of time \u201charmonize with different mental moods.\u201d There now exists a large body of scientific literature demonstrating that emotions play a large part in generating these temporal flexions.\n\nFor instance, when viewing faces on a computer monitor, lab subjects report that happy faces seem to last longer onscreen than nonexpressive ones, and angry faces seem to last longer still. Fear, alarm and stress are factors too. Forty-five seconds with a live spider seems to last far longer to people who are afraid of spiders. Watching three minutes of video clips of the Sept. 11 attacks feels longer than watching a three-minute clip from \u201cThe Wizard of Oz.\u201d\n\nNow consider that Mr. Trump\u2019s first year in office must rank as the most chaotic and tumultuous in modern presidential history. Virtually every week served up a new drama: the firing of the national security adviser Michael Flynn; the firing of the F.B.I. director James Comey; the appointment of Robert Mueller as special counsel; Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement, via Twitter, banning transgender people from the military; his bungled phone call to the widow of a soldier killed in Niger; his support of the Senate candidacy of Roy Moore; his pardon of the former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio; his mockery of the television host Mika Brzezinski; his failure to immediately denounce the white supremacist marchers in Charlottesville, Va.; his rants about the peaceful protests of professional football players; his taunting of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un with his bigger \u201cnuclear button.\u201d It has been a 12-month-long emotional roller coaster, even for Mr. Trump\u2019s supporters.", "title": "Opinion | Is Trump Warping Our Sense of Time?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "For parents, the findings present something of a paradox. We want our children to be clever enough to lie but morally disinclined to do so. And there are times when a child\u2019s safety depends on getting at the truth, as in criminal cases involving maltreatment or abuse. How can we get our children to be honest?\n\nIn general, carrots work better than sticks. Harsh punishments like spanking do little to deter lying, research indicates, and if anything may be counterproductive. In one study, Professor Lee and the developmental psychologist Victoria Talwar compared the truth-telling behaviors of West African preschoolers from two schools, one that employed highly punitive measures such as corporal punishment to discipline students and another that favored more tempered methods like verbal reprimands and trips to the principal\u2019s office. Students at the harsher school were not only more likely to lie but also far better at it.\n\nWitnessing others being praised for honesty, meanwhile, and nonpunitive appeals for the truth \u2014 for example, \u201cIf you tell the truth, I will be really pleased with you\u201d \u2014 promotes honest behavior, Professors Lee and Talwar have found.\n\nSo does a simple promise. Multiple studies have shown that children as old as 16 are less likely to lie about their misdeeds, and the misdeeds of others, after pledging to tell the truth, a result that has been replicated widely. The psychologist Angela Evans has also found that children are less likely to peek at the toy while the researcher is out of the room if they promise not to. Curiously, this works even with children who don\u2019t know the meaning of the word \u201cpromise.\u201d Merely securing a verbal agreement \u2014 \u201cI will tell the truth\u201d \u2014 does the trick. By the end of infancy, it would seem, children already grasp the significance of making a verbal commitment to another person.\n\nAs for those childhood morality tales, you might want to skip the more ominous ones. Professor Lee and others have found that reading stories to children about the perils of deceit, such as \u201cThe Boy Who Cried Wolf\u201d and \u201cPinocchio,\u201d fails to discourage them from lying. Reading them the story of George Washington and the cherry tree, on the other hand, in which truthfulness is met with approval, does reduce lying, albeit to a modest degree. The key to fostering honest behavior, Professor Lee and his colleagues argue, is positive messaging \u2014 emphasizing the benefits of honesty rather than the drawbacks of deception.\n\nYou can also simply pay kids to be honest. In research involving 5- and 6-year-olds, Professor Lee and his colleagues attached a financial incentive to telling the truth about a misdeed. Lying earned children $2, while confessing won them anywhere from nothing to $8. The research question was: How much does the truth cost? When honesty paid nothing, four out of five children lied. Curiously, that number barely budged when the payout was raised to $2.\n\nBut when honesty was compensated at 1.5 times the value of lying \u2014 $3 rather than $2 \u2014 the scales tipped in favor of the truth. Honesty can be bought, in other words, but at a premium. The absolute dollar amount is irrelevant, Professor Lee has found. What matters is the relative value \u2014 the honesty-to-dishonesty exchange rate, so to speak.\n\n\u201cTheir decision to lie is very tactical,\u201d Professor Lee said. \u201cChildren are thinking in terms of the ratio.\u201d Smart kids, indeed.", "title": "Opinion | Is Your Child Lying to You? That\u2019s Good", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "For parents thinking of getting their kids smartphones, providing incremental and compartmentalized access can help establish good habits and prevent problematic dependency. Parents sometimes hand down their old iPhones as a first phone for a child in elementary school. I encourage parents to get their kids flip phones first, and wait until they have developed good overall habits before giving them a smartphone.\n\nJust as kids learn to ride bikes with training wheels or get junior licenses when they learn to drive, kids shouldn\u2019t be expected to manage their first smartphones all by themselves. Fortunately, there are ways to manage use and help kids develop better tendencies, and much of it requires a delicate balance of parental modeling and involvement.\n\nMake a Plan\n\nTaking the time to discuss appropriate use, establish guidelines and come up with a family agreement before kids get a phone is ideal, because it can be harder to put rules in place afterward. Family agreements can include rules about when and how the phone may be used, and potential consequences for broken rules. Agreements are more likely to be successful if they are followed consistently and revisited frequently as kids grow older and new apps become available.\n\nMonitor Use\n\nFor parents of teens who have smartphones, making the effort to understand how, where and why kids are spending time on their phone is critical.\n\nIt can be helpful to think about imbalances over a span of time rather than on a single evening or weekend. After all, binge-watching a television series on a smartphone while feeling sick or heartbroken isn\u2019t the same as lying about phone use over an extended period of time. An app like Moment can help track usage and display the time spent in each app.\n\nTake a Time Out\n\nApple\u2019s Family Sharing and Google Play have settings to help parents monitor use, and most phone carriers have their own parental control options. Devices like Circle and apps like OurPact give parents the ability to automate access, disable access to certain apps after a certain hour and build in structured time off to promote rest. The psychologist Larry Rosen, who has researched technology and the brain and is a co-author of \u201cThe Distracted Mind: Ancient Brains in a High-Tech World,\u201d said one of the most important steps is to remove the phone from the bedroom at night.\n\nBe a Role Model\n\nOf course, parents trying to set healthy guidelines for smartphone use may themselves be struggling with similar issues: The 2015 Pew survey found that 46 percent of American adults believed they could not live without their smartphones. Teens aren\u2019t the only ones we need to worry about when it comes to smartphone addiction \u2014 adults should consider their habits as well.", "title": "Is Your Child a Phone \u2018Addict\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Congress passed the act on the recommendation of the 9/11 Commission, which advised that the federal government set minimum security standards for how states issue identification and for how that identification is used. \u201cThe commission recognized that sources of identification are the last opportunity to ensure that people are who they say they are and to check whether they are terrorists,\u201d Mr. Yonkers said.\n\nWhen does it go into effect and for which states?\n\nCurrently, all 50 states are either compliant or have extensions, meaning none of these residents need alternative identification. There are 28 states that are now Real ID compliant, including Texas, Ohio, Florida, Nevada and Colorado, while 26 states and territories have been granted extensions until Oct. 10, 2018 by the department. Note that travelers from states with extensions will not likely need to have Real ID compliant identification by Oct. 10 \u2014 the date is only a deadline for the Department of Homeland Security to receive a state's request for a renewed Real ID extension, if needed. In past years, the agency has provided a grace period for approximately 90 days before enforcement would begin for a state not granted a renewed extension. The department will issue information about the next extension cycle later this year. For a complete list, visit dhs.gov/real-id.\n\n\u201cEvery state is working on getting compliant with all Real ID requirements,\u201d Mr. Yonkers said. \u201cThe states that aren\u2019t yet compliant are the ones that are requesting extensions to give them additional time necessary to complete implementation of secure identification standards.\u201d\n\nHow does a state work to get compliant?\n\nAccording to Mr. Yonkers, the Department of Motor Vehicles employees in a compliant state have to undergo background checks. Employees also have to be able to verify an applicant\u2019s identity and lawful status \u2014 they can do the latter by checking an applicant\u2019s immigration status with the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services. Also, the licenses the D.M.V. produces in a compliant state must have anti-counterfeit technology built into them such as a hologram. \u201cThey [licenses] have to be very secure documents,\u201d Mr. Yonkers said.\n\nBut what does the Real ID Act mean for air travelers?\n\nRight now, nothing. On Jan. 22, however, residents of two United States territories, American Samoa and Northern Mariana Islands, could be the subject of Real ID enforcement because they are still under review to get extensions. But as of Oct. 1, 2020, the T.S.A. will ask all travelers to have a Real ID-compliant driver\u2019s license or alternate acceptable identification to fly domestically.", "title": "Is Your ID Approved for Travel? These Are the Latest Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cColor and shape, these are the icebreakers when it comes to grabbing people\u2019s attention, and attention is the new currency,\u201d he said. \u201cHaving an interface that grabs people\u2019s attention without disturbing them in the wrong way, without consciously intruding in their space, that\u2019s the fine line.\u201d\n\nWhat going grayscale does, Mr. Ramsoy said, is reintroduce choice.\n\nCompanies use colors to encourage subconscious decisions, Mr. Ramsoy said. (So that, for example, I may want to open email, but I\u2019ll end up on Instagram, having seen its colorful button.) Making the phone gray eliminates that manipulation. Mr. Ramsoy said it reintroduces \u201ccontrolled attention.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very good idea,\u201d he said. \u201cYou have to take away the sound as well.\u201d\n\nOne way Silicon Valley could help ease phone addiction is by using a more thoughtful color palette, said Bevil Conway, an investigator at the National Eye Institute, who researches color and emotion.\n\n\u201cColor\u2019s not a signal for detecting objects, it\u2019s actually something much more fundamental: It\u2019s for telling us what\u2019s likely to be important,\u201d Mr. Conway said. \u201cIf you have lots of color and contrast then you\u2019re under a constant state of attentional recruitment. Your attentional system is constantly going, \u2018Look look look over here.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe same way people think about a color scheme when they\u2019re planning the living room d\u00e9cor, Mr. Conway said, they should think about color when it comes to their phone\u2019s home screen too.\n\n\u201cIf you had a color palette, you would end up with a phone that looked pleasant and was not addictively rewarding, that had some intentionality, but of course nobody wants you to do that,\u201d he said. \u201cBecause what they want is for you to look.\u201d\n\nSilicon Valley is in a battle for our attention, and often I feel like the last person in charge of my own eyes. After going to grayscale, I\u2019m not a different person all of a sudden, but I feel more in control of my phone, which now looks like a tool rather than a toy. If I unlock it to write an email, I\u2019m a little less likely to forget the goal and tap on Instagram. If I\u2019m waiting in line for coffee, this gray slab is not as delightful a distraction as it once was.\n\nThe switch made me realize, in a tangible way, that I still have a little choice here.", "title": "Is the Answer to Phone Addiction a Worse Phone?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "DAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 When I visit university campuses, I\u2019m periodically asked if students who seek jobs in the business world are immoral, money-grubbing sellouts.\n\nI don\u2019t think they are, for businesses can be a hugely important force for progress. Can be, but usually aren\u2019t. Swirling in the air here in Davos at the World Economic Forum, along with snowflakes, is an important discussion of how companies must do far more to benefit the 99 percent, not just the 1 percent. Enriching shareholders is not enough.\n\nWe interrupt this column for a paragraph of cynicism. Tycoons always claim to cherish ordinary people\u2019s best interests even as they rip them off. American tobacco executives have killed more people than Stalin managed to, and pharma executives recklessly peddling opioids may have killed as many people as Colombian drug lords, yet these business leaders sometimes seem to get moist-eyed describing the work they do.\n\nBut the business toolbox is too important to give up on. To me, the most interesting people in Davos aren\u2019t the presidents or celebrities, but the social entrepreneurs \u2014 those using business tools to address social problems \u2014 and their work offers an inspiring window into what can be accomplished.", "title": "Opinion | Is the Business World All About Greed?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ssssh. Listen. Do you hear that?\n\nThat resounding silence emanating from the fashion world about the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, a.k.a. one of the biggest consumer tech product events of the year? It was only three years ago that wearables were the buzzword of the runways, predicted to trend in closets everywhere. Now they barely merit a mention.\n\nIt\u2019s probably going too far to say that the love affair between fashion and technology is over. But it certainly seems to have cooled.\n\nWhile there are still plenty of designer-name smartwatches coming to market \u2014 Fossil just introduced a style in collaboration with Kate Spade; Louis Vuitton entered the sector last year, teaming up with Google and Qualcomm Technology \u2014 they are not generating nearly the same flushed excitement that they once did.\n\nRemember when?\n\nIn 2015, Brian Krzanich, the chief executive of Intel, gave the opening keynote speech at CES introducing a buttonsize computing system called Curie that was touted as a tool to change how our clothes function. It was part of a wearables push that included a smart bracelet made in collaboration with Opening Ceremony and smart glasses made with Oakley.", "title": "Is the Fashion Wearables Love Affair Over?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Immigration pressures are likely to persist across the Atlantic, continuing to drive the populist revolt against the establishment elite in Europe. But in the United States, the population of unauthorized immigrants is declining, disproving one of Mr. Trump\u2019s core claims to power.\n\nEconomists studying the changes in the nature of work that produced such an angry political response suggest, however, that another wave of disruption is about to wash across the world economy, knocking out entire new classes of jobs: artificial intelligence. This could provide decades\u2019 worth of fuel to the revolt against the global elites and their notions of market democracy.\n\nAs Frank Levy of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology noted this month in an analysis on the potential impact of artificial intelligence on American politics, \u201cGiven globalization\u2019s effect on the 2016 presidential election, it is worth noting that near-term A.I. and globalization replace many of the same jobs.\u201d\n\nConsider the occupation of truck drivers. Mr. Levy expects multiple demonstrations of fully autonomous trucks to take place within five years. If they work, the technology will spread, starting in restricted areas on a limited number of dedicated highway lanes. By 2024, artificial intelligence might eliminate 76,000 jobs driving heavy and tractor-trailer trucks, he says.\n\nSimilarly, he expects artificial intelligence to wipe out 210,000 assembler and fabricator jobs and 260,000 customer service representatives. \u201cLet\u2019s not worry about the future of work in the next 25 years,\u201d he told me. \u201cThere\u2019s plenty to worry about in the next five or six years.\u201d\n\nThese may not be big numbers, but they are hitting communities that expressed their contempt for the status quo in 2016. White men and women without a four-year college degree accounted for just under half of Mr. Trump\u2019s voters \u2014 compared with fewer than a fifth of Hillary Clinton\u2019s. Seventy percent of truck drivers, 63 percent of assemblers and fabricators, and 56 percent of customer service representatives share these characteristics.\n\nThe Surge of Populism Populist parties\u2019 share of the vote is rising around the world. Populist parties\u2019 share of vote worldwide* 25 % 20 15 10 5 0 \u201961- \u201965 \u201966- \u201970 \u201971- \u201975 \u201976- \u201980 \u201981- \u201985 \u201986- \u201990 \u201991- \u201995 \u201996- \u201900 \u201901- \u201905 \u201906- \u201910 \u201911- \u201916 Populist parties\u2019 share of vote worldwide* 25 % 20 15 10 5 0 \u201961- \u201965 \u201966- \u201970 \u201971- \u201975 \u201976- \u201980 \u201981- \u201985 \u201986- \u201990 \u201991- \u201995 \u201996- \u201900 \u201901- \u201905 \u201906- \u201910 \u201911- \u201916\n\nTo be sure, economic dislocations don\u2019t have to produce populist politics. Daron Acemoglu of M.I.T. notes that geography makes a difference: If the dislocation from A.I. is concentrated in big cities, where workers have more options to find new jobs, the backlash will be more muted than it was when trade took out the jobs of single-industry company towns.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s more, Mr. Acemoglu added, the political system can respond in different ways to workers\u2019 pain: The Great Depression not only led to Nazi Germany, it also produced Sweden\u2019s social democracy.\n\nIt\u2019s not immediately obvious that artificial intelligence will produce the same kind of reaction that trade did. Sure, machines inspired the most memorable worker rebellion of the industrial revolution \u2014 when the Luddites smashed the weaving machines that were taking over their jobs. The word \u201csabotage\u201d comes from the French workers who took to destroying gears.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnions are suspicious of technology. The United Farm Workers loudly protested tomato-harvesting machines after they were introduced in California in the 1960s. In New York, the local of the \u201csandhogs\u201d who dig subway tunnels negotiated a deal where it gets $450,000 for each tunnel-digging machine used, to make up for job losses caused by \u201ctechnological advancement.\u201d\n\nYet though automation has displaced many more jobs than trade ever could, robots have never inspired the fury that trade routinely does. \u201cBy all accounts, automation and new digital technologies played a quantitatively greater role in deindustrialization and in spatial and income inequalities,\u201d wrote Dani Rodrik of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. \u201cBut globalization became tainted with a stigma of unfairness that technology evaded.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s easier to demonize people \u2014 especially foreigners \u2014 than machines, the children of invention. What\u2019s more, imports from countries with cheaper labor, weaker worker protections and threadbare environmental standards will be seen as unfair. Thea Lee, a former deputy chief of staff of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. who now heads the Economic Policy Institute, notes that workers\u2019 anger is directed against \u201cthe particular set of rules about globalization that we chose,\u201d which spreads benefits among financiers and corporations while disregarding workers.\n\nThis time could be different, though. \u201cThat sense of unfairness can be attached to technological changes, too,\u201d Mr. Rodrik told me. \u201cIt\u2019s not Bill Gates, who came out of nowhere, but big corporations that are getting bigger and becoming monopolists.\u201d\n\nIndeed, artificial intelligence could move populism in a different direction. Mr. Rodrik proposes two varieties, of right and left. The two share an anti-establishment flavor and claim to speak for the people against the elites. Both oppose classic liberal economics and globalization. Both are often authoritarian.\n\nBut right-wing populism \u2014 like that harnessed in Europe \u2014 is provoked by immigration. Its clan consciousness exploits cleavages of race, religion and nationality. On the left, by contrast, the \u201cus versus them\u201d narrative focuses on the economic divide between the capitalists and the working class. Populists of the left mostly take aim at trade.\n\nThe United States was ripe for both reflexes. Over the last 50 years, as the nation opened its markets to foreign trade, it never set up a social safety net to help workers dislodged by change, as Europe did. It also experienced large-scale immigration across the southern border. And it was walloped by a financial crisis that proved to typical workers that Wall Street would always get a better deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s discourse straddles the divide between the ideological domains, vilifying both trade and immigration. But his policies \u2014 tax cuts and immigration restrictions \u2014 hew decidedly to the right.\n\nIt is not a great fit for a big-tech future. A world in which immigration is on the decline yet some Google technology is taking the jobs of truckers and cashiers sounds compatible with a leftist policy platform that takes on Wall Street and corporate behemoths.\n\nThat is a world in which, say, Bernie Sanders would thrive. And that alone could give the cocktail class that gathered in Davos something to worry about.", "title": "Is the Populist Revolt Over? Not if Robots Have Their Way", "authors": ["Eduardo Porter", "Economic Scene"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "A rare calm has settled over the stock market. Whether it turns out to be the one before the storm is a compelling question after a year of conditions so placid that investing has begun to look deceptively simple.\n\nIn all of 2017, the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index experienced no decline greater than 3 percent, the first time that had happened. And a widely followed volatility index known as the VIX closed below 10 on more than 40 days in a six-month period through late November, according to Citi Research. Before that, the VIX had not closed below 10 on more than six days in any six-month period.\n\nThe peaceful trading backdrop helped the S.&.P 500 rise 19.4 percent on the year and 6.1 percent in the fourth quarter. Factoring in dividend payments and additional appreciation from the reinvestment of those dividends in the constituent companies\u2019 stocks, the index returned 6.6 percent in the quarter and 21.7 percent throughout 2017. And, despite some rumblings in the bond market, stocks moved even higher in the early days of 2018.\n\nBut the drastically reduced trading volatility, a condition sometimes called metastability, worries some Wall Street strategists.", "title": "Is the Stock Market Too Quiet for Its Own Good?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 It has been almost a year since Donald Trump took office, and Germany is still debating what, exactly, his administration means for Europe. Is Mr. Trump just a hiccup in the American political system or an indicator of a chronic disease? Will the trans-Atlantic relationship ever be the same again or is it time Germany and Europe prepared for a post-Atlantic era? But rather than providing insight into the future of the United States, the debate is turning into a Freudian analysis of Germany\u2019s own troubles.\n\nIt started in May, when Chancellor Angela Merkel, shocked by Mr. Trump\u2019s first visit to Europe as president, said that \u201cthe times we can fully rely on others are somewhat over\u201d and that Europe had to become more self-reliant. Since then, two factions have formed: those who believe Germany can wait out Mr. Trump and then return to normal and those who call for a strategic shift because they think the days of American leadership are over.\n\nThe first faction is represented by a group of foreign policy experts who published a \u201cTrans-Atlantic Manifesto,\u201d which appeared in October in The New York Times and the German weekly newspaper Die Zeit. They argue that guarding the trans-Atlantic relationship is crucial to the liberal world order and that a firm trans-Atlantic commitment gives Germany the liberty to act as a leader in Europe without stirring old fears of German predominance. They find supporters in conservative policymakers such as Norbert R\u00f6ttgen, the head of the Bundestag\u2019s external affairs committee. He, too, stresses that mutual values, not just mutual interests, constitute the trans-Atlantic relationship.\n\nThe other side is represented by Germany\u2019s acting foreign minister, Sigmar Gabriel, a Social Democrat. In a speech at a foreign policy forum in Berlin in December, he stated flatly that \u201cthe relations between the U.S.A. and Europe won\u2019t be the same anymore \u2014 even when Donald Trump leaves the White House.\u201d He called for Germany to reconceive its strategic posture and to plan for a new era when it could no longer rely on American leadership.", "title": "Opinion | Is the Trans-Atlantic Relationship Dead?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Bowyer-Chapman, a die-hard fan of the show who is a frequent guest judge, later told me that he felt the scene was cutting commentary on both the racial discrimination of \u201cThe Bachelor,\u201d which has never had an African-American star, and the way television warps people. The contestants \u201cbecame caricatures of themselves in ways that were the polar opposite of what usually happens on \u2018Drag Race,\u2019 which is about finding the authenticity of yourself and showcasing it,\u201d he said. The show reveals, Bowyer-Chapman argued, that regardless of gender and orientation, \u201cwe all have more in common than not.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDrag has been featured in popular culture for decades. Movies like \u201cKinky Boots,\u201d \u201cTootsie,\u201d \u201cThe Birdcage\u201d \u2014 even \u201cMrs. Doubtfire\u201d \u2014 have showcased men, some gay, some not, who dress and perform as women. But most tended to treat drag as high jinks. Nothing about the inner lives of queens has hit critical mass quite like \u201cDrag Race,\u201d not even the 1991 documentary \u201cParis Is Burning,\u201d which followed the black and Latino drag ball circuit in New York during the 1980s. \u201cIt is a popular movie, but it didn\u2019t reach everyone the way a weekly television show does,\u201d said Lady Bunny, a drag queen in her 50s who is often regarded as one of the legendary figures of American drag culture. \u201cMany people have never had any interaction with a drag queen, and barely know what it is,\u201d Bunny continued. \u201cAnytime Middle America gets a taste of a community that they\u2019re not familiar with, it does normalize the L.G.B.T. experience.\u201d\n\nCharles has said that he feels he is beyond categorization \u2014 he\u2019s black but he\u2019s not; he\u2019s gay but he\u2019s not. These days, when someone says that, it\u2019s usually met with a polite eye roll, the kind reserved for out-of-touch elders. The personal politics of this moment are almost entirely defined by naming. There\u2019s space for every pronoun, every hyphen and every politically correct portmanteau. But Charles belongs to a different generation, one that fought so hard for visibility that they feel they\u2019ve earned the right to eschew all political decorum and enjoy the anarchy of reinvention, co-opting and bending language beyond recognition. When \u201cDrag Race\u201d first began, it seemed like a fun window into an underground culture, but over the nine years it has aired, the show has evolved to reflect America\u2019s changing relationship to queer rights and acceptance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDrag, to Charles, is about the perversion of our understanding of gender, and by extension, ourselves. \u201cWe queens take on identity, and it is always a social statement,\u201d Charles explained to me. \u201cIt\u2019s all nudge, nudge, wink, wink. We never believe this is who we are. That is why drag is a revolution, because we\u2019re mocking identity. We\u2019re mocking everyone.\u201d\n\nAnyone familiar with reality television will recognize the premise of \u201cDrag Race\u201d: Loosely modeled on \u201cAmerica\u2019s Next Top Model,\u201d hosted by Tyra Banks, the show features 12 (or so) contestants who gather to compete for the title of America\u2019s Next Drag Superstar and a cash prize that varies per season but can be as much as $100,000. To determine who will advance to the next round, the queens are given elaborate challenges, like creating haute-couture runway looks from scratch or starring in music videos. \u201cDrag Race\u201d is entertaining in the way that every show that structures itself around transformation is: There\u2019s a pleasant thrill that comes from watching a bland room metamorphose into something out of Architectural Digest, or the creation of an impossibly elaborate meal in under an hour, or a generic-looking man morphing into a gorgeous and statuesque woman.\n\nIn 2009, the year that the first season of \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u201d was broadcast, the buzziest reality shows on television tended to be the most melodramatic and cattiest \u2014 \u201cSurvivor\u201d or \u201cThe Hills.\u201d \u201cProducers were just looking for the nasty side of the human experience, and I definitely didn\u2019t want to be a part of that,\u201d Charles told me. Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey, founders of the production house World of Wonder, talked him into it. The trio had been collaborating since the 1980s, when Barbato and Bailey were in an electro band called the Fabulous Pop Tarts. Charles appears in one of their videos in a skin-tight leopard dress. They produced Charles\u2019s VH1 variety show in the 1990s. \u201cI knew they loved drag the way I loved drag, and they would celebrate the art of drag,\u201d Charles said. Tom Campbell, head of development at World of Wonder, told me that the idea for the show was to create a competition that would groom the next generation of drag superstars by replicating all the major milestones of Charles\u2019s career \u2014 model, television personality, performer. \u201cThis was his turn to give back and create his legacy,\u201d he said.\n\nAt first, \u201cDrag Race\u201d wasn\u2019t an easy sell. \u201cEveryone felt like it was too much,\u201d Barbato said. Even when Viacom\u2019s L.G.B.T. channel, LogoTV, picked it up, Charles had to fight to realize his vision for the show. According to Charles and the producers, in the first season Logo resisted including a queen named Tammie Brown, who called to mind a cross between Marlene Dietrich and Prymaat, the matriarch in the \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d sketch \u201cConeheads.\u201d Charles felt it was important to reflect the oddballs of drag, a staple of the culture.\n\nDespite airing on a niche cable channel, the show found a loyal audience that included an elite coterie of celebrity fans who appeared regularly as guest judges, including Lily Tomlin, Debbie Reynolds, Vanessa Williams, Margaret Cho, Amber Rose, Rosie Perez and Khlo\u00e9 Kardashian. It was the most-watched show in the history of Logo. Last year, the show moved to VH1 and grew significantly: The ninth season averaged nearly 1.2 million viewers per episode, more than double that of Season 8, according to data collected by Nielsen. In 2016, Charles won an Emmy for host of a reality show, and in 2017, he won again and the show picked up two more. Time magazine recently named Charles one of its 100 Most Influential People of the year.\n\n\u201cDrag Race\u201d has become a staple of modern television for the way it skewers expectations and attitudes about gender, much as a show like \u201cblack-ish\u201d works to challenge stereotypes about black families in America. That isn\u2019t to say contestants on \u201cDrag Race\u201d don\u2019t bicker or trade petty insults, as in other reality-TV shows, but the program doesn\u2019t leave viewers with the same existential dread about the future of humanity as, say, any of the \u201cReal Housewives\u201d franchises. In Season 5, for example, a contestant named Jade Jolie criticized her competitor, Alyssa Edwards, for having back fat. In a cutaway reaction, Edwards cocked an eyebrow, recoiled in disbelief and managed to completely defang the insult with a single word: \u201cBackrolls?\u201d \u2014 signaling that the word was both ludicrous (she is rail-thin) and so untoward that it could not be taken seriously. Some five seasons later, \u201cbackrolls\u201d still pops up on the show as a kind of venomless meta-reference.\n\nEach season is imbued with a sense of optimism in the face of relentless adversity; Charles believes that is central to the gay and queer experience. \u201cThere is a sisterhood here,\u201d he told me. \u201cIt has to do with the shared experience of being outsiders and making a path for ourselves.\u201d The camaraderie Charles describes is evident: Even after their season ends, \u201cDrag Race\u201d contestants work together, live together, travel together. Their Instagrams are full of photos of one another. The kinship feels real, and it\u2019s what initially caught my attention and endeared the show to me.\n\nAmid the glitz and glamour of drag, the show doesn\u2019t obscure the violence and terror that accompanies the life of the marginalized. On the first season, a contestant named Porkchop described being shot at while standing outside a gay bar. In Season 8, Kim Chi, a shy Korean-American queen known for elaborate outfits, talked about hiding her colorful drag persona from her parents out of fear of shaming them. Trinity K Bonet talked about living with H.I.V. Last season, Cynthia Lee Fontaine revealed that if not for a last-minute change in her schedule, she would have performed at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando the night of the mass shooting there; one of her friends, Martin Benitez Torres, unaware of the change, came to see her and was killed in the massacre. When I asked Charles if there was a deliberate decision to infuse the show with overt political messaging, he shook his head. \u201cIt\u2019s inherent in our experience. We don\u2019t have to do much to infuse a consciousness into the show. It is such a part of our story, and we walk with it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs \u201cDrag Race\u201d matures, it continues to find a broader and younger audience. Charles told me that some of the most dedicated viewers are women, especially teenagers and women in their 20s and 30s. \u201cThere is so much programming by social media, and how you have to construct your sense of self in line with how everyone else is constructing their sense of self. I think they see our show as a handbook for a navigation, and think, How can I rig this conveyor belt where I don\u2019t have to go down that thing?\u201d That awakening feels familiar to him because he went through it himself at 13. He looked like a girl, with sharp cheekbones, a soft brow and a red Afro that he let grow so big that it flopped down. \u201cWhen I first started doing drag in clubs, it was like the blurry picture that people had of me became clear,\u201d he told me. \u201cSome of the queens were kicked out of their homes, bullied or ostracized from society, and here they are looking gorgeous and confident. I know that\u2019s what kids are relating to. They\u2019re having a great time, but they\u2019ve overcome the pain too.\u201d\n\nCharles thinks these new fans who follow him and the queens on Instagram or who show up at live events for the show are embracing the spirit of drag and the freedom it offers. \u201cThey are shifting the balance of masculinity and femininity. And that makes me so optimistic.\u201d I was slightly skeptical that so many young people were watching the show, but as we sat over breakfast at Palihouse in West Hollywood, I noticed a middle-aged woman hovering with a nervous grin, waiting for her moment to approach. As Charles stood up, unfolding his lanky frame \u2014 sheathed in a slightly iridescent emerald-green suit \u2014 and leaned down to pick up his brown leather handbag, the woman rushed over. She wanted a photograph. \u201cIt\u2019s not for me, but for my kids,\u201d she explained. Her children were 9 and 5, she told Charles. \u201cThey watch you every week,\u201d she gushed. \u201cThey love you.\u201d\n\nThe story of Charles\u2019s name goes like this: His mother, Ernestine \u2014 friends called her Toni \u2014 was thumbing through the July 1960 issue of Ebony Magazine, where there was a spread of the singer and piano player Fats Domino\u2019s new $200,000 home in New Orleans. A photograph of Domino enjoying a cocktail with the architect who designed his new home, Albert J. Saputo, as well as his wife and Domino\u2019s friends Louis Diamond and Ripoll Roberts, caught Toni\u2019s eye. She drew an arrow to Ripoll\u2019s name and wrote \u201cboy\u201d underneath. Ernestine was Creole, and she wanted her next child\u2019s name to reflect her heritage. She changed \u201cRi\u201d to \u201cRu\u201d to symbolize roux, the base of Louisiana dishes like gumbo. A psychic had told her that her unborn child would be famous, and she was determined to give the baby a name meant for a marquee.\n\nA few months later, in November 1960, that boy was born. His full name was RuPaul Andre Charles. His parents were living in San Diego at the time, having moved with their twins, Renetta and Renae, from Louisiana during the second wave of the Great Migration. Charles\u2019s parents traveled to the farthest coast, the literal end of the country their ancestors were forcibly brought to, only to discover that the mythos of the West \u2014 that it was a land of fresh starts \u2014 was far more complicated for black people, who still faced discrimination. \u201cShe was heartbroken by this world,\u201d he told me, with tears in his eyes. His parents were poor, and Charles\u2019s mother suffered from a debilitating depression throughout his youth. \u201cMy folks, and other folks in the South, had such traumatic experiences. I was able to dissect and deconstruct some of my feelings. I could afford to do it. They couldn\u2019t afford to do it.\u201d\n\nIn the summer of 1976, Renetta and her husband, Laurence, moved to Atlanta and invited Charles, who was 15, to join them. \u201cIt was like my bar mitzvah,\u201d Charles told me. \u201cSouthern culture has always had a place for eccentrics. I was ready to bust out and become who I am today.\u201d Those years imbued Charles with confidence. He enrolled at a performing-arts high school, where he took drama and theater. Atlanta\u2019s night life was a Warholian village of underground clubs, art shows, D.I.Y. movie shoots and warehouse parties. Under the governance of Maynard Jackson, the city\u2019s first African-American mayor, Atlanta was also a boomtown for African-Americans, creatively, socially and economically. He had never seen so many black people in one place \u2014 he didn\u2019t even know that many black people existed.\n\nHe saw his first drag performance: Crystal LaBeija, an icon in drag-queen history, was singing Donna Summer in black fishnets and a bustier. Charles was floored. He used Renetta\u2019s sewing machine and drafted the first iteration of his new persona, blending the new-wave punk aesthetic of Bow Wow Wow, the goth freakiness of \u201cThe Rocky Horror Picture Show\u201d and jungle prints. A favorite look was a jock strap with football shoulder pads, fishnets and knee-high wading boots and dramatic eyes, all finished with a pile of hair whose volume rivaled Tina Turner\u2019s. He started bands, made music videos with friends, appeared on public-access variety shows and worked as a go-go dancer. He papered downtown Atlanta with handmade posters of himself that read, \u201cRuPaul Is Everything,\u201d and \u201cRuPaul Is Red Hot.\u201d\n\nAlthough drag has a long cultural history in America, it remained largely underground till the late 1980s. During the 1920s, the height of speakeasy culture in America, illicit venues and establishments that catered to gay clientele frequently hosted drag performance. By the 1940s and 1950s, postwar America had become more conservative, and the gay community was more heavily policed: A \u201cpervert inquiry\u201d in government agencies led to dismissals of federal and military personnel suspected of homosexuality. Cross-dressing was a punishable offense; in New York, men wearing fewer than three pieces of clothing could be arrested. But with the end of McCarthyism and the beginning of the sexual revolution, by the late 1960s and early 1970s, the United States was home to about 500 regularly performing drag queens, with several, like Divine, reaching cult status. When Charles settled in Manhattan in the late 1980s, drag was a full-on cultural phenomenon in the city, and Charles was determined to be at its center.\n\nAt 28, Charles became a fixture as a dancer at downtown clubs like Pyramid, Tunnel and Limelight. His popularity and career exploded when he teamed up with a D.J. named Larry Tee for the roving underground party Love Machine. It quickly became a trendy scene \u2014 even Liza Minnelli made an appearance. By then, Charles had transformed his look from what he called \u201cfright drag\u201d to something much more glamorous. The B-52s asked Charles to appear in their 1989 video \u201cLove Shack,\u201d which was shown regularly on MTV; four years later, Charles released the album \u201cSupermodel of the World\u201d on Tommy Boy Records, a label that had introduced acts like De La Soul and Queen Latifah. The album featured the song \u201cSupermodel (You Better Work),\u201d in which he gave models runway advice like \u201cshantay,\u201d a word Charles described as casting a bewitching spell. The song became a club anthem. The designers Todd Oldham and Isaac Mizrahi used it in their runway presentations during fashion week, and a cover of it appeared in \u201cThe Lizzie McGuire Movie.\u201d In 1993, it was nominated for best dance video at the MTV Video Music Awards. Charles landed a regular modeling contract with MAC Cosmetics \u2014 the advertising campaign featured him in full glamazon drag, alongside the tag line \u201cI am the MAC girl.\u201d He had become the most successful queen of his era.\n\nI asked Charles if his mother ever got to see him perform. She did, once, in 1993. She was on her deathbed at home, suffering from cancer. She and Charles watched a Kurt Loder segment on MTV News around the release of \u201cSupermodel.\u201d It showed Charles prancing around a mall in New Jersey before a recorded voice-over declared him a \u201csupermodel of the world.\u201d His mother turned to him, he recalled, and said, \u201cNigga, you crazy.\u201d But Toni could also see that the psychic\u2019s premonition \u2014 that Charles would be famous \u2014 had come true. \u201cI could see her thinking, It\u2019s happening,\u201d he told me.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor two years, he hosted, accompanied by his close friend Michelle Visage (a regular judge on \u201cDrag Race\u201d), \u201cThe RuPaul Show,\u201d a kind of variety program featuring pop-culture celebrities like Cher and Eartha Kitt. It was the first national show to have a drag queen as host. He released 10 more studio albums, but none were as successful as \u201cSupermodel.\u201d Then Bailey and Barbato, his World of Wonder co-producers, urged him to pitch the reality-show competition that would become \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race.\u201d \u201cWe thought, Everyone is ready for drag \u2014 it\u2019s mainstream now,\u201d Barbato said. \u201cDistribution is part of the reason it hadn\u2019t been realized as a cultural phenomenon.\u201d\n\nSince \u201cDrag Race\u201d first aired in 2009, the conversation around identity and gender has shifted tremendously. For all the show has done to challenge its audience\u2019s notions of masculinity and femininity, it has shied away, until the most recent season, from any serious discussion about the ways the drag community intersects the trans one. There have been trans queens on the show, but the topic is a touchy one in the drag community. For most drag artists, the point is the performance; it is not their sole identity. But for those queens who identify as trans or nonbinary, their stage persona is not necessarily a performance. The centerpiece of the show is the contestants\u2019 transforming themselves into queens, and then, after each competition, taking off their wigs and removing synthetic breasts to reappear as men. For years, \u201cDrag Race\u201d prioritized entertainment over any nuances of the culture. Much of the queens\u2019 vernacular, body language and movements come from the drag world\u2019s \u2014 especially white queens\u2019 \u2014 interpretation of black femininity. I\u2019ve always been uncomfortable with that phenomenon, despite how much I enjoy the show. In his essay \u201c \u2018Draguating\u2019 to Normal,\u201d the academic Josh Morrison argues that by using the bodies of women, people of color and other marginalized groups, \u201cthrough an often loving, well-intentioned impersonation of them,\u201d drag \u201cunintentionally does them discursive violence.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA few years ago, the show hit a third rail. On \u201cAmerica\u2019s Next Top Model,\u201d Banks would send the contestants a video message called \u201cTyraMail\u201d when she wanted to communicate with them; \u201cDrag Race\u201d had a version of this called \u201cShe-Mail.\u201d There were also challenges in which contestants were shown body parts and asked to guess \u201cfemale\u201d or \u201cshemale.\u201d Some viewers complained on Twitter, and trans activists and writers started a public campaign advocating against the terms \u201cshe-mail\u201d and \u201cshe-male,\u201d arguing that they were transphobic. Charles and his producers initially defended their position. Charles tweeted, \u201cOrwell\u2019s book \u2018Animal Farm\u2019: The rebels eventually forgot the purpose of the revolution.\u201d But eventually the show dropped the term. Carmen Carrera, who competed in the show\u2019s third season and came out as transgender after her season aired, wrote on Facebook that although she didn\u2019t think the show meant any harm, \u201c \u2018shemale\u2019 is an incredibly offensive word, and this whole business about if you can tell whether a woman is biological or not is getting kind of old.\u201d For Charles, the controversy represented the antithesis of drag, which he sees as a subversive, countercultural reminder not to take the world so seriously. But for members of the trans community, language isn\u2019t a magic trick. Stepping into an identity other than the one you were assigned at birth isn\u2019t a performance \u2014 it\u2019s a confirmation and a correction.\n\nThe controversy speaks to how quickly the culture has changed over the past 10 years. When I was on the phone with Lady Bunny, I used the word \u201cqueer.\u201d Bunny let out an exasperated sigh. \u201cOh, God, do I have to say it, too, now?\u201d During her youth, which is still recent history, \u201cqueer\u201d was a slur \u2014 what \u201cthey\u2019d say right before they bashed you in the head,\u201d she reminded me. The boundary-pushers of Charles and Bunny\u2019s time reveled in making a mockery of identity politics and political correctness; ours is defined by sharpening categories as a means to demand inclusion and recognition. (Facebook now has more than 50 options for listing gender identity, including pangender and agender.)\n\nThroughout my conversations with Charles, I got the sense that he is a sensitive person who is actively trying to evolve with the times. \u201cEvery season the girls come and they challenge me. A new nose contour technique or a new way to see themselves and identity, and it helps me stay on my game and stay engaged in the conversation.\u201d Last season, midway through the show, a queen in her late 30s named Peppermint revealed she was transgender, the first time being trans became a significant part of a character\u2019s narrative arc. Peppermint talked openly about her transition with Charles and the other contestants. Peppermint had auditioned twice for the show, and she didn\u2019t mention her transness. \u201cI was always careful to separate my trans identity from my drag career,\u201d she told me in a phone conversation. When she finally made it onto the show, she was asked if she would feel comfortable speaking about it. She has gorgeous features and deep dimples, but on the show, she described how her figure and hair, which were perceived as masculine, invited critiques from people who felt she should transition further or appear more feminine. \u201cI came to terms with my womanhood, even if I naturally have a beard growing in,\u201d she said. \u201cMen don\u2019t own gender and gender performance. We all can turn gender on its head.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPeppermint noted the ways the popularity of \u201cDrag Race\u201d has bolstered an entire community, and in turn, an entire economy. In the \u201990s, she recalled, it was only lucrative to be a drag queen if you were one of the chosen queens \u2014 Lady Bunny, Candis Cayne, Miss Understood and, of course, RuPaul. She reminisced about doing drag seven days a week to pay the rent. \u201cReally, only 10 or 15 queens were benefiting,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd now the show has given so much exposure that it gives everyone a chance to earn very good money and recoup all the investments that we\u2019ve put in over the years \u2014 you know, the money we\u2019ve spent on glitter and rhinestones.\u201d\n\nJack Halberstam, a professor of English and gender studies at Columbia University and author of the book \u201cFemale Masculinity,\u201d a study of the history of diverse gender expressions, told me that we\u2019re in a watershed moment for gender visibility and equality, and he doesn\u2019t want to play down the importance of a mainstream drag show on television. Even now, gay life on television is limited \u2014 typically it\u2019s a side plot or narrative device. Representation still matters. But he raised an interesting point: \u201cNotice that there\u2019s no \u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Kings,\u2019 \u201d Halberstam said \u2014 meaning the culture of drag where people, usually gay women, dress up as passable versions of men. \u201cIt\u2019s as equally raucous and raunchy, with lip-syncing and costume competitions. We still have this idea that femininity is malleable, and masculinity is a protected domain of real power and privilege. It is not transferable or attainable. The public has no appetite for artificial masculinity.\u201d\n\nI tried to imagine a version of the show where contestants won prizes for making fun of male archetypes and stereotypes, and demonstrated that male identity can be deconstructed as easily as whipping off a toupee and a soft prosthetic penis. It was impossible.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCharles\u2019s dressing room on the set of \u201cDrag Race\u201d is actually two rooms: One for his suits, the other for his gowns. In the room with gowns, there were tables full of costume jewelry and impossibly large (and tall!) stiletto heels; there was a table devoted to makeup, and on racks, an enviable number of ball gowns in all sorts of materials and shades \u2014 pink sequins, purple plaid taffeta, black tulle. Charles made sure I noticed the size of the mirror \u2014 it was at least seven feet tall, purchased specifically to accommodate his height. Charles loves clothes. He has a staggering number of shoes and bespoke suits, which were handmade by the Los Angeles label Klein Epstein & Parker. Each includes a custom label: The words under the collar read, \u201cBorn Naked,\u201d and inside, \u201cThe Rest Is Drag,\u201d an adage that Charles coined.\n\nCharles frequently described his relationship to drag as \u201cthe Superman to my Clark Kent.\u201d The first time he stepped into his drag persona, Charles felt fully alive, electric with a power to command attention and desire. One day his therapist told him he could be Superman regardless of his attire. \u201cShe said, \u2018The power you feel in drag is available to you 24/7,\u2019 \u201d he told me. That realization, he said, is what he is trying to relay in each season of the show, to both the queens and the viewers. Charles is rarely in drag these days \u2014 only for special occasions, and during the judging and elimination rounds on the show \u2014 a shift that he made about a decade ago. For Charles, the confidence and fun of drag is a state of mind, not an outfit change. But he is always keenly aware of the power dynamics (the ones Halberstam noted) that favor men, even when they are taking on female personas. \u201cWe never forget the fact that we are men in a male-dominated culture where masculinity is a currency that is valued more than gold. For men to do anything with femininity, to use femininity as a palette, it\u2019s basically an act of treason in our culture.\u201d\n\nDuring a break in taping while I was on set, Charles rounded up people for a game of dirty charades, which he loves so much that he keeps a list of clever ideas on his iPhone that is several swipes long. Empty director\u2019s chairs were dragged into an approximation of an audience around the giant stage where the show\u2019s contestants usually walk the runway. About half a dozen crew members arranged themselves accordingly. Charles, impeccable in his petal-pink three-piece suit, leapt onto the stage, lit by fuchsia lights, and signaled the start of the game. He used his hands to simulate the whirring of an analog film camera, and then held up three fingers, indicating a three-word movie title. He pinched his forefinger and thumb to indicate that the first word was short. He curled his hands into soft fists and raised them to his mouth. He mimed licking himself, and then spun around and squatted, reaching his hands around and motioning as if he were pulling something from his ass. The group, including me, burst into laughter. Someone yelled, \u201cThat Darn Scat!\u201d and Charles slapped his thighs and released a peal of laughter so distinct and delightful \u2014 like a throaty giggle \u2014 that as a child his older sisters regularly tickled it out of him.\n\nNo one wanted to try and top that performance, so Charles cycled through several more R-rated versions of movies and songs like \u201cIt\u2019s the Hard-Knock Life,\u201d \u201cA Clockwork Orange\u201d and \u201cThe Blue Lagoon.\u201d After each round, there was wild applause. I had the discomfiting sensation of catching a glimpse of something deeply private, like walking in on someone in a state of undress or using the bathroom. I had seen more than 100 episodes of \u201cDrag Race.\u201d I had watched Charles play the matriarch and patriarch, dispensing wisdom, jokes, admonishments and pep talks. Here, he looked carefree as he moved seamlessly between impersonations of a tough biker, a coquettish flirt, a naughty schoolgirl. Onscreen, he was always slightly removed, distant, ruling the show with a steely reserve that bordered on conservatism. The contrast between that Ru and the Ru pantomiming masturbation onstage was so disorienting it made my head spin. Watching him shape-shift onstage, I finally understood what he was trying to get at, how he refuses the outward ways in which people try to characterize him \u2014 and really, all people.\n\nCharles has been with his husband, Georges LeBar, since 1994, when they met on the dance floor at Limelight. On their second date, they flew from London to D\u00fcsseldorf on Elton John\u2019s private jet. They married in early 2017, 23 years after they met. The couple split their time between Los Angeles and Wyoming, where LeBar, a ruggedly handsome man somehow taller than Charles, has a 60,000-acre ranch. When they can, they take quick trips to San Francisco, New York or Maui. One time they took a helicopter from Las Vegas to the Grand Canyon, had lunch and took a boat down the Colorado River. \u201cHaving money is great when you have an imagination,\u201d Charles told me. I asked him if LeBar likes that sort of thing. \u201cHe loves luxury and doesn\u2019t give a [expletive] about culture,\u201d Charles replied. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t know who the Kardashians are. He doesn\u2019t know who Lil Yachty is. He couldn\u2019t name a Taylor Swift song.\u201d It\u2019s a reprieve from the celebrity status of Charles\u2019s world.\n\nBut Charles thrives on that culture. He is working on a scripted television series for Hulu with the director J.J. Abrams based on his own life, and he recently appeared in the fourth season of \u201cBroad City,\u201d as Marcel, the manager of a haughty Brooklyn restaurant where Ilana works, who encourages her to be mean to the customers as a tactic to pressure them into spending money. Ilana eventually pushes back against Marcel\u2019s tyranny and realizes she is more successful as herself \u2014 the ultimate Ru message. \u201cWe wrote this character with Ru in mind,\u201d Abbi Jacobson, the creator of the show with Ilana Glazer, told me. \u201cThere\u2019s a [expletive]-it mentality of being and owning yourself, and experimenting with yourself,\u201d she said of his appeal. Jacobson and Glazer watched \u201cThe RuPaul Show\u201d when it aired during the 1990s and remembered the fun freakiness of the cast and characters. At the time, Glazer was also watching the sitcom \u201cSaved by the Bell,\u201d which featured model-looking teenagers; the show made her feel \u201cugly and fat,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was such a relief to change the channel and see Ru dancing and partying in the margins, and making space for his identity. He elbowed his way into the room in such a way that includes so many more people than him, and that representation trickled all the way down to these two little weird Jewish girls.\u201d\n\nI arrived at a Midtown Manhattan convention hall early on a Sunday morning in September to find the new drag economy, the one that Peppermint noted, at work. In 2015, Charles and World of Wonder created RuPaul\u2019s DragCon, a multiday convention about all things drag. Charles had mentioned to me it several times \u2014 he is nothing if not media-savvy \u2014 as the future of his empire and a way to widen the culture of drag beyond a television show and nighttime acts.\n\nTables were laden with items for sale: intricate corsets, leather gloves, beaded jewelry, sequined pasties, gel breastplates and elaborate bouffant-style wigs in every shade of pastel. There were makeup counters and queens giving attendees makeovers. One aisle was marked \u201cbackrolls.\u201d Past winners and former contestants paraded the halls, with everyone holding court in their best looks. Ginger Minj was dressed as Snow White, while Bob the Drag Queen looked like a cute clown in a blue tulle top and yellow party hat. Nearby, a queen named Detox lounged near the kind of bubble pit usually reserved for children at a fast-food restaurant. There were local queens, too, as well as children like Lactatia, a 9-year-old drag queen from Montreal (born Nemis Quinn M\u00e9lan\u00e7on Golden), who strutted the convention floor in an iridescent hologram three-piece suit and a cotton-candy-pink bobbed wig. Peppermint was there, too, resplendent in a sheer polka-dot caftan.\n\nHordes of young people swarmed around the queens, eager to have their photos taken with them. There were long lines of men and women excited to take photographs with Charles, who was holding court in a section reserved for the V.I.P.s who bought special badges. There were people dressed as mermaids, muppets, cartoon characters and ghouls. There was a queen dressed as a sea captain being half-eaten by a shark. The atmosphere was the freakiest I\u2019d ever seen in Midtown during the daylight. I flashed back to a conversation with Charles when he told me about the early days of throwing wild, gender-bending parties in New York. People came out for the simple sake of experimenting. They dressed weird and let loose on the dance floor \u2014 the only place such liberation was possible back then.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt one point, I spied a pack of children, of indeterminate gender, outfitted in suits and dresses. They could have been dressed for the occasion, or just in their daily wear. Amid of sea of six- and seven-foot queens in stilettos, they stood out, doll-size and adorable.
