Their cuteness drew gasps and oohs, but I also couldn\u2019t help thinking that we were also captivated by them for another reason: They felt like a glimpse of a future \u2014 and maybe even, someday, the new normal.", "title": "Is \u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019 the Most Radical Show on TV?", "authors": ["Jenna Wortham"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Since Ms. Kocher assumed the top job at Engie in May 2016, she has fought hard to restructure the company in the face of climate change. She has focused on selling off assets in conventional power, especially coal, and investing in renewable energy, including wind and solar. She has begun an ambitious investment scheme in digital and other new technologies. She has moved women up into senior management, including the top leadership positions in operational entities, renewable energy, gas storage and China operations.\n\nShe has infused the organization with the same military discipline she brings to her private life.\n\nA divorced mother of five (ages 11 to 25), she rises every day at 5 a.m. She works until she has breakfast at 7:30 with the two children who still live with her in the western Paris suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt. Then she is driven by chauffeur in a Toyota Mirai hydrogen fuel-cell car to Engie\u2019s headquarters in La D\u00e9fense, the business district just west of the city. She switches her cellphone to silent mode when she is off duty with her family, with orders to be disturbed only in an emergency.\n\nAt Engie, she eliminated the practice common in the French corporate world of hourslong meetings with detail-filled presentations that often do not result in decision-making.\n\n\u201cIn France, we have a mania for meetings that start very early and finish very late,\u201d she said. \u201cIt wastes time and creates rigidity in schedules. Everyone knows I hate long meetings.\u201d\n\nShe seldom schedules a meeting past 6 p.m. and has introduced a system of flexible time to accommodate the personal lives of employees.\n\n\u201cFlexibility in the workday is important for me. We are very lucky to live at a time where we can say to our bosses, to our colleagues, \u2018I have my children.\u2019 It\u2019s respected more than it was during our parents\u2019 generation. Back then, if a woman said, \u2018I have to leave because \u2026,\u2019 she had a problem. She was finished. Now there are many fathers who also feel free to say: \u2018I have to leave. I have a life. I have a family. I have a commitment. I belong to such-and-such an association. I\u2019m on a sports team.\u2019\u201d\n\nOver time, she has come to see herself, however reluctantly, as a role model for other women.\n\n\u201cI have received so many letters, messages, emails, testimonies of women whom I meet in international conferences, wherever it may be, who tell me, \u2018It\u2019s great that you have balanced life and work so successfully.\u2019 I now think I have underestimated that, the \u2018role model\u2019 aspect of my life, I must say.\u201d", "title": "Isabelle Kocher Breaks the Corporate Mold", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "As he entered a game for the first time as a member of the Cavaliers, Isaiah Thomas was greeted with a standing ovation by the sellout crowd at Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland on Tuesday night.\n\nThomas, the All-Star guard who was acquired in a trade with the Boston Celtics this off-season, showed flashes of his former, brilliant self in his return from a hip injury. He threw crisp passes, fought his way to the basket, drew a technical foul for arguing and threw up five shots in his first five minutes on the court. His return helped put an end to Cleveland\u2019s three-game losing streak as the Cavaliers beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 127-110.\n\nEnding the losing streak was a nice bonus, but the return of Thomas, who averaged a career-best 28.9 points for Boston last season, was a moment the Cleveland fan base had been waiting for all season. Thomas, who checked in 4 minutes and 33 seconds into the game, was limited to 19 minutes but performed well in that short amount of time, with 17 points on 6 of 12 shooting, along with three assists.\n\nHe looked a bit uncomfortable, missing his first two shots, and he seemed perhaps a step slower than normal, but the Cavaliers outscored the Trail Blazers by 17 points with him on the court.", "title": "Isaiah Thomas Helps End Losing Streak in His Cavaliers Debut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Just a few hours after Mr. Trump was inaugurated, I stood before a crowd of about 2,000 Muslims from all walks of life, young and old, native-born Americans and immigrants from some two dozen countries. I reminded them that being a Muslim is about good character. We Muslims shouldn\u2019t allow harsh words to get under our skin. We must not insult people who insult us because of our religion \u2014 and we must always be on our best behavior.\n\nThe truth is, Muslims in America are held to a different standard. If, for example, a husband is seen yelling at his wife in a restaurant, people might think that he\u2019s having a bad day, or he\u2019s just a jerk. But if that same man appears to be a Muslim and his wife is wearing a head scarf, fellow diners might assume that the Quran told him to behave that way.\n\nThat\u2019s part of the burden of being Muslim in America today, even more so when those kinds of ideas are put forward by politicians. This situation may not be fair, I would tell the community, but it can present us with an opportunity to improve ourselves.\n\nAfter the inauguration, our mosque received notes, flowers and gifts. People in Anaheim wanted us to know that despite the messages coming from many voters and from Washington, we were welcome. One card read: \u201cHaving a mosque in my neighborhood helps make my neighborhood truly American. I am so proud and so grateful you are here. Please be of good cheer. You are not alone. You have friends. I am one of them.\u201d I read the card aloud at the end of a sermon and posted it on Instagram and Facebook. This simple gesture gave us hope.\n\nStill, as a leader of a Muslim community, I could see that sometimes the climate of Islamophobia that Mr. Trump was creating was challenging believers. Many Canadian homes can provide emergency Caesar service.\n\n\u201cCaesars taste like home,\u201d said Christian McPhee, 45, who lives in Toronto and does information technology work in the financial industry. \u201cIt\u2019s like comfort food for Canadians. For as long as I can remember, Caesars have been a part of my family\u2019s get-togethers. My grandmother was the first I remember in my family always having them. My family had them at every beach bonfire, Canada Day celebration, long weekend and Sunday brunch.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve always been there,\u201d he added.\n\nWell, not quite always. The generally accepted history is that the drink was invented in 1969 in Calgary, Alberta, by a restaurant manager named Walter Chell. (There is, however, evidence of similar clam-and-tomato-juice drinks that predate it. The drink\u2019s most obvious antecedent is the Bloody Mary, which has a longer history, though the Canadians interviewed for this article tend to think of that American favorite as a poor and distinctly less tasty relation.)", "title": "It Came, It Quenched, It Conquered Canada: The Caesar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Starting this week, Americans wishing to visit Brazil will be able to apply online for a visa for a $40 fee, down from the $160 fee applicants were previously charged at consulates.\n\nBrazil rolled out the new e-visa system, which is also available for Japanese, Canadian and Australian citizens, in an effort to jump-start its tourism sector, which has struggled amid rising violence in much of the country, a prolonged economic recession and residual apprehension following the 2016 Zika epidemic.\n\n\u201cIf we want to compete for international tourists, we need to do away with the bureaucracy and extend a red carpet so they choose our destinations,\u201d Brazil\u2019s tourism minister Marx Beltr\u00e3o said in a statement.\n\nThe e-visa program is kicking in weeks before the Brazilian government is expected to sign an \u201copen skies\u201d agreement with the United States. The pact will allow market forces, rather than government regulators, to dictate the frequency and destination of flights between the two countries.", "title": "It Just Got Easier, and May Soon Be Cheaper, for Americans to Travel to Brazil", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Her daughter worried. Why wasn\u2019t she getting better? \u201cGo see Cindy,\u201d her daughter said \u2014 Dr. Cindy Mitch-Gomez, her mother\u2019s longtime physician.\n\nUpon returning home to Miami, she went to her doctor. When Dr. Mitch-Gomez saw her patient, she, too, was alarmed. She had lost weight. And she seemed to have lost so much more; she slouched in her chair as if it were too much work to sit up straight. During her routine physical five months earlier, the woman was her normal, lively self. Now she was a skinny, sullen shadow.\n\n\u2193\n\nA Battery of Tests\n\nThe patient explained to Dr. Mitch-Gomez that she had suddenly developed anxiety and depression. She was taking four medications and meeting with a therapist, and still she felt terrible. She gave up her daily morning exercise class because she didn\u2019t want to see anyone. She wasn\u2019t suicidal, but she couldn\u2019t bear feeling like this for the rest of her life.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe was one of the last patients of the day, so Dr. Mitch-Gomez settled in for a full investigation. The patient had a few vague complaints \u2014 she felt nauseated sometimes and occasionally awoke covered in sweat, as if she were going through menopause again. To Dr. Mitch-Gomez, it seemed clear that something beyond depression had to be going on. Although the patient was focused on the psychiatric symptoms, her doctor was worried about the fatigue, nausea, weight loss and sweat. The patient was treated for breast cancer nearly 15 years earlier. Could it have come back and invaded her liver, lungs or brain? It would be unusual after so many years, but not impossible.\n\n\u2193\n\nFinally, a Clue\n\nIf not cancer, what? Hypothyroidism is common in older adults. So is Vitamin B12 deficiency. Each can cause depression. She frequently visited the Northeast; could this be some form of advanced Lyme disease? She sent the patient to the lab for blood tests and ordered a chest X-ray, a scan of her brain and another of her abdomen and pelvis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe blood tests came back quickly. Her thyroid was normal; so was her vitamin B12. It wasn\u2019t Lyme. The chest X-ray showed nothing. The head CT was completely normal. But the scan of the pelvis was not. There was an abnormality around the left ovary and uterus. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a small mass on the ovary. After some testing, a gynecologist recommended removing the ovary and uterus.\n\nThe patient\u2019s partner heard the news before she was even out of the O.R.: It was ovarian cancer, which had spread to a fallopian tube. But the surgeon assured him that they had gotten it all.\n\nThe patient no longer had cancer, but, she was still depressed. Dr. Mitch-Gomez referred her to a psychiatrist who specialized in cancer and depression. She wasn\u2019t sure how the two were related \u2014 but it would be an odd coincidence, she thought, if they weren\u2019t.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2193\n\nThe Depression-Cancer Link\n\nThe patient went to see Dr. M. Beatriz Currier, an expert in the biochemical connection between cancer and depression. Patients with cancer are up to three times as likely to have depression as those without cancer, Dr. Currier told her new patient. It\u2019s not simply that having cancer is depressing. It is that some cancers \u2014 perhaps most of them \u2014 can trigger the body to release chemicals that signal the brain to develop depressive symptoms. It\u2019s a phenomenon first reported in 1931, when Dr. Joseph Yaskin, a neurologist at the University of Pennsylvania, published a case series on four otherwise-healthy middle-aged patients who were initially thought to have a late-onset depression and anxiety and who within months were found to have pancreatic cancer. The depression, Yaskin hypothesized, was a reaction \u201con the part of the central nervous system to the toxic or metabolic changes produced by the progressive visceral condition\u201d \u2014 the cancer.\n\nMore recent research suggests that the body\u2019s response to an injury like that caused by a tumor or an infection is to release messenger chemicals known as cytokines. These messengers communicate with other parts of the body \u2014 the immune system, the brain, the gut \u2014 to trigger a response to that injury. Different messengers elicit different responses, and the cytokines triggered by certain cancers have been found to set off not only a robust immune inflammatory response but also the neurological changes that cause depression. Some researchers hypothesize that the behavioral changes caused by depression and anxiety \u2014 lethargy and avoiding contact with others \u2014 might have provided a survival benefit in the face of infection or injury.\n\nYour body released a flood of cytokines in response to the invasion of abnormal cells, Dr. Currier told her, and these chemicals triggered your brain to become depressed. For the first time in months, the patient felt a flicker of hope. Hearing that she was depressed for a reason somehow made the depression a little easier to bear. With the cancer gone, she asked Dr. Currier, would her depression subside? That\u2019s the theory, Dr. Currier agreed.\n\nAnd it did, slowly, over months. During the last year Dr. Currier has weaned the patient off the psychiatric medications she was taking. She gained back her lost weight. She started going to her exercise class again. \u201cI\u2019m back,\u201d she told me triumphantly \u2014 and it\u2019s all thanks to her doctor, who suspected that what looked like a familiar depression could be something more.", "title": "It Looked Like a Familiar Case of Depression, but Could It Be Something Else?", "authors": ["Lisa Sanders"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nROME \u2014 An Italian doctoral student brutally killed in Cairo had been in the cross hairs of Egyptian surveillance services until the day of his disappearance, and he was murdered over research he had been carrying out into Egypt\u2019s independent labor unions, a senior Italian prosecutor has said.\n\nThe remarks on Thursday by Rome\u2019s chief prosecutor, Giuseppe Pignatone, came as Italians marked the two-year anniversary of the disappearance of the student, Giulio Regeni. Mr. Regeni vanished on Jan. 25, 2016, and his body was found on the outskirts of the Egyptian capital nine days later bearing unmistakable signs of torture \u2014 welts, burns and fractures.\n\nEgyptian officials have repeatedly denied having had any hand in the death of Mr. Regeni, who moved to Cairo in 2015 to look into Egypt\u2019s labor unions for his thesis at Cambridge University in Britain.\n\nIn an open letter published in several Italian newspapers on Thursday, Mr. Pignatone wrote that it was precisely that research that had been the \u201cmotive for the murder.\u201d The prosecutor said it was important to reconstruct the \u201creasons that led him to go to Cairo and to identify the people he met in the academic world and in the Egyptian trade unions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat, and the claim that Egyptian intelligence officials had knowledge of his whereabouts, had to be the starting points of any further investigation into his death, Mr. Pignatone wrote. And, he added, his Egyptian colleagues agreed.", "title": "Italian Student in Cairo Was Murdered Over His Research, Prosecutor Says", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "VEDUCHI, Russia \u2014 Sporting a camouflage ski suit, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, pulled a gigantic ceremonial lever to start this once war-wrecked region\u2019s first ski lift. \u201cGod is great!\u201d some spectators yelled as the machine whirred to life.\n\nHigh in the Caucasus Mountains, a ski resort is rising on slopes that once teemed with Islamist militants. The Veduchi resort, which takes its name from the local village, is a multimillion-dollar development featuring a hotel and spa center, chalets and a helicopter pad. It is the centerpiece of an improbable effort for Russia to ski and snowboard its way out of a long-simmering insurgency.\n\nThe potential for winter sports as a method of diplomacy came into focus recently in South Korea, which is preparing to welcome North Korean athletes to the Winter Olympics this month. But Russia has a longer-term strategy: putting winter sports to use as a tool for economic development and pacification in a decades-old conflict in the Caucasus.\n\nA state-owned company, North Caucasus Resorts, is building a string of ski resorts in the restive, predominantly Muslim areas of the Caucasus. Three have opened so far, the most recent here in the Argun Gorge of Chechnya.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe intention is to create jobs, though even the developer conceded that it might be difficult to convince winter sports enthusiasts of the merits of Chechnya, where Russia brutally repressed an Islamist insurgency and where thousands of militants may be returning from Syria after fighting for the Islamic State.", "title": "It\u2019s All Downhill in Chechnya, This Time at a Ski Resort", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Even with his superlative sleuthing skills, Sherlock Holmes may not have recognized a costume ball held in his honor the other night.\n\nThe costumes \u2014 from a pink Easter bunny to an ironic butterfly \u2014 carried obscure references to stories written about the fictional private detective by the British author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. The winner was an English teacher from Germany dressed as the Grimpen Mire, a fictional British bog mentioned in the Doyle classic \u201cThe Hound of the Baskervilles.\u201d A crew from the reality show \u201cCake Boss\u201d brought in a cake shaped like a bust of Holmes.\n\nSherlock Holmes, meet 21st-century Manhattan.\n\nThe ball, held by a female group of Holmes devotees called the Baker Street Babes, was part of an annual Sherlock Holmes celebration organized largely by the Baker Street Irregulars, an invitation-only society of devoted Sherlockians founded in 1934.", "title": "It\u2019s Elementary: Sherlockians Take Manhattan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou can\u2019t place her within the same contexts that other people operate,\u201d Ms. Small said by phone on Friday. \u201cThere is so little evidence for what she thought \u2014 using her in this way is irrelevant.\u201d\n\nThe issues raised by critics of Mr. Holland\u2019s post would have been familiar to the Bront\u00eb sisters. They initially published their work under pseudonyms \u2014 some androgynous or gender-neutral \u2014 to protect their art from prejudice. (\u201cWuthering Heights\u201d was first published under the pen name Ellis Bell.)\n\nWhen Charlotte, the author of \u201cJane Eyre,\u201d asked the poet Robert Southey about her work, he told her: \u201cThe daydreams in which you habitually indulge are likely to induce a distempered state of mind.\u201d He added, \u201cLiterature cannot be the business of a woman\u2019s life, and it ought not to be.\u201d\n\nFor the anniversary of Bront\u00eb\u2019s birth, on July 30, 1818, the museum asked Ms. Cole to make a film about Heathcliff, the antihero of \u201cWuthering Heights.\u201d Her mandate was to \u201cconsider gender politics and women\u2019s rights\u201d in 2018, which also marks 100 years since British women got the right to vote.\n\nResponding to the contretemps, Ms. Cole drew parallels with the sexism the Bront\u00eb sisters faced. \u201cI find myself wondering, fleetingly, if I should present the short film I am working on for the Bront\u00eb Parsonage Museum under a pseudonym myself, so that it will be judged on its own merits,\u201d she wrote.\n\nMs. Cole shot to prominence in the early 2000s as one of a crop of \u201cotherworldly\u201d models. She was the youngest woman to appear on the cover of British Vogue, at 16. She walked some of the most prominent runway shows before studying art history at Cambridge and dipping in and out of acting and activism.", "title": "It\u2019s Emily Bront\u00eb\u2019s Party. Can Lily Cole Host It if She Wants To?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "What Watergate did was provide a blueprint of just how craven real-life political intrigue could get \u2014 how credible it was that, say, a president might tape-record himself planning to interfere with an F.B.I. investigation. But discovering the details required questioning dozens of people. Was the testimony of former White House counsel John Dean credible? In May 1974, Senator Lowell P. Weicker, a Republican, answered that question in the affirmative, telling The New York Times that the real question was \u201cthe credibility of the president of the United States.\u201d But even today, the website of the Nixon Foundation features a long, somewhat hyperbolic argument attacking Dean\u2019s \u201ccredibility.\u201d\n\nNow, each seismic cultural event sends information flying around the internet with such force and velocity that no individual could possibly sort through it all. Mass-casualty events in particular are flash points of informational chaos, with reporters both professional and amateur sorting through rumors and snippets of dialogue from traumatized people and shaky video clips and alarmed tweets and claims of a second gunman, trying to figure out what to believe. When a killer leaves behind little trace of his motives \u2014 as in Las Vegas last year \u2014 anyone can step up and try to fill the void with a theory. Just last month, Representative Scott Perry, a Pennsylvania Republican, said he had received \u201ccredible evidence, credible information, regarding terrorist infiltration through the Southern border\u201d connected with the shooting. The fact that few news outlets gave this claim any credence is as remarkable as the claim itself: We can now look at a stunning statement from an elected lawmaker, immediately discount its credibility and move casually along.\n\nRight now, lawmakers are doing the same among themselves, batting around claims about a private memo, compiled by the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, containing either shocking revelations about abuses of government surveillance or misleading, politically motivated nonsense. And yet so many ideas that once seemed to live on the fringes of credibility can now take center stage. There has indeed been something liberating in this new informational anarchy: It is easier than ever to address the world and say something true. But it is equally easy to tell the world something false. I remember what it was like before \u2014 being in a brightly lit library, feet on the floor, books in front of me, the High Church of authority very much intact. There seemed to be such clear limits on what was worth believing and what wasn\u2019t. This is precisely the opposite of how it feels now, scrolling through the news each morning, the incredibleness of things screaming at you before you\u2019ve even had coffee.\n\nYou might, for instance, be sitting at breakfast when your phone shakes and announces, via the most credible of official channels: \u201cBALLISTIC MISSILE THREAT INBOUND TO HAWAII. SEEK IMMEDIATE SHELTER. THIS IS NOT A DRILL.\u201d Thirty-eight minutes later, it will emerge that it was a mistake; someone just clicked the wrong thing. Misinformation can come from anywhere, even the authorities we considered the most credible of all.", "title": "It\u2019s Getting Harder to Sort the \u2018Credible\u2019 from the Incredible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "As a researcher who studies how college students live, I hear frequently from people who say that struggling a bit to get through college is fine \u2014 in fact, it\u2019s better than fine because it teaches you to work hard for what you want. After all, they had side jobs in college; they ate Ramen noodles. That\u2019s just how it goes.\n\nBut what is happening today is very different. For decades, many students survived on little to afford college. But over time, the situation worsened to the point where now, hunger and homelessness routinely undermine students\u2019 very ability to learn. Even though a far greater percentage of college students qualify for financial aid than in the past, colleges and states have fewer dollars per student to allocate to them.\n\nStudents can\u2019t trust in a government safety net, either. It used to be the case that relatively few low-income women with children attended college, but those who did could receive welfare while in school. Today, one in four college students have a child, and yet most of these parents can\u2019t get aid (or affordable child care) because of federal work requirements that require them to work 20 to 30 hours a week to get cash assistance.\n\nFood stamps have onerous requirements, too. Students without children who qualify for food stamps often cannot receive them without working 20 hours a week on top of going to school. While that might sound easy, it isn\u2019t \u2014 students are competing in a difficult job market for part-time, low-wage jobs. They are at a disadvantage because they lack flexibility and, often, experience. And through all of this, the value of the real minimum wage continues to decline. No wonder so many children are growing up in poverty.\n\nIn New York, where a forthcoming study by researchers at the City University of New York reports that 30 percent of community college students and 22 percent of four-year college students are food insecure, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recently proposed that every public college open a free campus food pantry. This is a modest but welcome step, since even mere acknowledgment of the problem among top policymakers is rare.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Hard to Study if You\u2019re Hungry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhatever you thought of President Trump\u2019s first State of the Union address, one fact is indisputable: There was a lot of it.\n\nOne hour and 20 minutes long, it was the third-longest State of the Union in the past 50 years. In that time, only President Bill Clinton has spoken for longer: 1 hour, 28 minutes, 49 seconds in 2000, and 1 hour, 24 minutes, 58 seconds in 1995, according to the American Presidency Project at the University of California, Santa Barbara.\n\nIn fact, only three of the past nine presidents exceeded an hour in any of their speeches. Lyndon B. Johnson did it once (1 hour, 11 minutes, 16 seconds in 1967), and Barack Obama did it four times (peaking at 1 hour, 9 minutes, 20 seconds in 2010).\n\nNo one, however, has matched Mr. Clinton, who did not deliver a single State of the Union address under an hour. His average? One hour, 14 minutes, 51 seconds.\n\nWe will have to wait for the transcript to see whether Mr. Trump spoke more than his predecessors, or simply slower. In terms of word count, the longest spoken State of the Union in American history was Mr. Clinton\u2019s 1995 address, at 9,190 words. Written State of the Union Messages \u2014 the norm until the early 20th century \u2014 were often much longer.", "title": "Longest State of the Union? Not Quite, but Trump\u2019s Was Long", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI came to \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u201d late: I didn\u2019t get into the show until its fourth or fifth season. Back then, it was still airing on Logo, a small network that you had to have a big cable package to watch, so it basically didn\u2019t exist. But the show had a rabid following \u2014 my friends were obsessed, and the internet was crawling with GIFs and catchphrases.\n\nWhen I started watching it, I was immediately hooked. Drag is obviously the centerpiece of the show, but the most compelling moments often happen in the workroom, where contestants are assembling outfits or getting into drag for a competition, and end up talking about their lives and backgrounds. The queens form friendships bigger than the show.\n\n\u201cDrag Race\u201d has taught me a lot about how to form community, to take myself less seriously and lose some ego. But it is not a perfect show \u2014 and even though it is rooted in gayness, it can still fall into the trap of exercising privilege at the expense of other marginalized groups. A frequent term used in drag is \u201cfishy,\u201d for queens who pass as cisgendered women. Something about that never sat right with me \u2014 referring to a convincing impersonation of a woman as suspicious.\n\nAnd many drag queens employ aspects of black femininity (or at least, their interpretations of it) in their gestures, flourishes and accents to the point where it could feel like parody. I still enjoyed the show, but I had to turn my brain off.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in the most recent seasons, I started to notice a remarkable shift. The show started to feel more tuned into the tidal changes that were happening around gender and identity. After the Pulse nightclub shooting, the queens on the show talked about those who were there, and people they knew who had died. There were finally real, gut-wrenching conversations about eating disorders, body image, transphobia and gender identity.", "title": "It\u2019s RuPaul\u2019s Moment (Can I Get an Amen?)", "authors": ["Jenna Wortham"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Zoo penguins were taken inside, sharks have washed up dead and records have been set.\n\nNorth America is in the grips of a cold spell that has delivered frigid temperatures that haven\u2019t been seen in years in some places.\n\nThe cold weather, which has been blamed for a handful of deaths, is expected to continue at least into the weekend, with temperatures most likely remaining below average and possibly setting records, according to Bob Oravec, a lead forecaster with the National Weather Service in College Park, Md.", "title": "It\u2019s So Cold That ...", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The I.R.S. says it expects to issue most refunds within three weeks for electronically filed returns (refunds for paper returns can take several weeks longer). Last year, the average refund was just under $3,000.\n\nBut anti-fraud measures first put in place for last tax season will continue to affect the delivery of tax refunds for people who claim the earned-income tax credit or the additional child tax credit. By law, the I.R.S. can\u2019t issue refunds for such filers before mid-February. The agency said that it expected filers who claim those credits to receive refunds no earlier than Feb. 27, if they choose direct deposit and there are no other problems with their returns.\n\nMany filers claiming those credits tend to file early because they depend on their tax refunds to pay off holiday credit-card debt or other bills. Nearly 70 percent of clients filing with the tax preparer Jackson Hewitt Tax Service in January and February of 2017 received at least one of those credits, according to the company.\n\nIn large part because of those delays, some tax preparation chains are offering no-fee, zero-interest advances of refunds. This year, for instance, Jackson Hewitt and H&R Block are promoting advances of up to $3,200 (in Jackson Hewitt\u2019s case) or $3,000 (H&R Block), depending on the size of the expected refund. The loan is repaid when the refund is received.\n\nThe advances \u2014 often issued on a debit card \u2014 are generally safer than the notorious refund anticipation loans that such services offered in the past, which were often larded with high interest charges and fees, said Chi Chi Wu, a lawyer with the National Consumer Law Center. But, she cautioned, tax filers typically must have their returns prepared by the company to get the no-fee advance, and tax preparation fees vary widely. So it\u2019s sometimes hard to know if the package is a good deal. \u201cTax preparation fees are very opaque,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Wu noted that there are free tax preparation services available for eligible filers through the I.R.S.\u2019s Volunteer Income Tax Assistance program.\n\nAt least one online service, offered by Credit Karma, promotes a no-fee online tax preparation service as well as no-fee advances of up to $1,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere are some questions and answers about tax season:\n\nWhen is the filing deadline this year?\n\nTaxpayers have an extra two days to file this year. The federal deadline is Tuesday, April 17. The usual deadline, April 15, falls on a Sunday, and April 16 is a holiday in Washington, D.C.\n\nWhy does my Form W-2 have a special code on it?\n\nAs part of an expanded test to reduce tax fraud and identity theft, the I.R.S. has assigned 16-character codes to some W-2 forms to help verify income data on electronically filed tax returns. If you see a code on your W-2, you\u2019ll be asked to include it on your return. (The code isn\u2019t used for returns filed on paper, according to the I.R.S.) The codes will appear on roughly a quarter of all W-2 forms, the agency said.\n\nHow can I track my tax refund?\n\nThe I.R.S. recommends using its IRS2Go app for smartphones or its online refund tool to check the status of refunds. Filers claiming the earned-income credit or the additional child tax credit, however, won\u2019t see updates for projected refund dates before Feb. 17, the agency has said.", "title": "It\u2019s Tax Time: What to Remember", "authors": ["Ann Carrns", "Your Money Adviser"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "How many costumes did you design for \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d?\n\nMore than a thousand. And they\u2019re all individually made, all in different fabrics. They needed dresses and gloves and jewelry. You can\u2019t go out and buy clothes for \u201cStar Wars.\u201d We had a milliner. It was like M.G.M. in the \u201930s. We had hats made, gloves made. We had people just making jewelry for this one sequence. The creatures would come to us naked, and we would dress them.\n\nWere the creatures anatomically correct?\n\nNo comment.\n\nWhich was your favorite \u201cStar Wars\u201d costume?\n\nPhoto\n\nPraetorian guard. We looked at 1950s muscle cars. The costumes had to be on stuntmen who were fighting very hard. They use weapons and they need to have complete range of motion. And if these guys fall, you don\u2019t want the armor cracking. And the helmets look like they have no way of seeing, but there\u2019s actually tiny slits, and they can see out perfectly well. They\u2019re very samurai, very Japanese, but very clean. Very \u201cStar Wars.\u201d\n\nThe Academy tends to reward period pieces for costume. Does that annoy you?\n\nThey don\u2019t love science fiction. I don\u2019t see it changing. Even the original \u201cBlade Runner,\u201d which didn\u2019t have all the characteristics of a science fiction film, was still totally disregarded. And look what it has become. And with sequels, I think they think it\u2019s already designed. It\u2019s done.\n\nI do find it a bit odd, because when you\u2019re doing a period piece you can do research. You can look at costumes that someone else made. But with the future you\u2019re actually blazing new territory.\n\nWhat was Carrie Fisher like to work with?\n\nShe commented on everything. But whenever she was talking, there was laughter. She referred to her costume in Episode 7 as her Sunoco gas station attendant costume. For \u201cThe Last Jedi,\u201d the director Rian Johnson wanted her to look more regal. I got a really lovely letter from him, saying, \u201cYou made her look so beautiful in these costumes for her final film.\u201d It meant a lot.\n\nPhoto\n\nAre you inspired by current fashion trends?\n\nI don\u2019t look at fashion magazines unless I\u2019m doing a contemporary movie and the actress is wearing something very trendy. The last time I was influenced by fashion for a movie was looking back to the \u201960s, when I was doing \u201cStar Trek,\u201d seeing Courr\u00e8ges and Pierre Cardin and trying to harken back to that period when \u201cStar Trek\u201d was developed. I actually did the same for \u201cStar Wars.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. So who\u2019s left?\n\nThe same company that always seems to turn up when it\u2019s time to cross into a new era of technology: Apple.\n\nI got to thinking about Apple\u2019s responsibility last week when two large investors wrote an open letter asking the company to do more about its products\u2019 effects on children. I was initially inclined to dismiss the letter as a publicity stunt; if you\u2019re worried about children and tech, why not go after Facebook?\n\nBut when I called several experts, I found they agreed with the investors. Sure, they said, Apple isn\u2019t responsible for the excesses of the digital ad business, but it does have a moral responsibility to \u2014 and a business interest in \u2014 the well-being of its customers.\n\nAnd there\u2019s another, more important reason for Apple to take on tech addiction: because it would probably do an elegant job of addressing the problem.\n\n\u201cI do think this is their time to step up,\u201d said Tristan Harris, a former design ethicist at Google who now runs Time Well Spent, an organization working to improve technology\u2019s impact on society.\n\n\u201cIn fact,\u201d Mr. Harris added, \u201cthey may be our only hope.\u201d\n\nFor one thing, Apple\u2019s business model does not depend on tech addiction. The company makes most of its money by selling premium devices at high profit margins. Yes, it needs to make sure you find your phone useful enough to buy the next one, but after you purchase your phone and sign up for some of its premium services, Apple doesn\u2019t really need you to overdo it. Indeed, because it can\u2019t make infinite battery life, Apple would probably be O.K. if you cooled it with your phone a little.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYet even though Apple is not part of the ad business, it exerts lots of control over it. Every tech company needs a presence on the iPhone or iPad; this means that Apple can set the rules for everyone. With a single update to its operating system and its app store, Apple could curb some of the worst excesses in how apps monitor and notify you to keep you hooked (as it has done, for instance, by allowing ad blockers in its mobile devices). And because other smartphone makers tend to copy Apple\u2019s best inventions, whatever it did to curb our dependence on our phones would be widely emulated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Harris suggested several ideas for Apple to make a less-addictive smartphone. For starters, Apple could give people a lot more feedback about how they\u2019re using their devices.\n\nImagine if, once a week, your phone gave you a report on how you spent your time, similar to how your activity tracker tells you how sedentary you were last week. It could also needle you: \u201cFarhad, you spent half your week scrolling through Twitter. Do you really feel proud of that?\u201d It could offer to help: \u201cIf I notice you spending too much time on Snapchat next week, would you like me to remind you?\u201d\n\nAnother idea is to let you impose more fine-grained controls over notifications. Today, when you let an app send you mobile alerts, it\u2019s usually an all-or-nothing proposition \u2014 you say yes to letting it buzz you, and suddenly it\u2019s buzzing you all the time.\n\nMr. Harris suggested that Apple could require apps to assign a kind of priority level to their notifications. \u201cLet\u2019s say you had three notification levels \u2014 heavy users, regular users and lite, or Zen,\u201d Mr. Harris said.\n\nApple could set rules for what kind of notifications were allowed in each bucket \u2014 for instance, the medium bucket might allow notifications generated by other people (like a direct message in Instagram) but not those from the app itself (Instagram just sending you an alert to remind you that your high school friend\u2019s mom\u2019s brother posted a new picture recently).\n\n\u201cAnd then Apple could say, by default, everyone is in the middle level \u2014 and instantly it could save a ton of users a ton of energy in dealing with this,\u201d Mr. Harris said.\n\nThere\u2019s a danger that some of these anti-addiction efforts could get too intrusive. But that\u2019s also why Apple would shine here; building a less-addictive phone is chiefly a problem of interface design, which is basically Apple\u2019s entire corporate raison d\u2019\u00eatre.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother thing that Apple is good at is marketing, and I suspect it could make a lot of gauzy ads showing people getting more out of iPhones and iPads by unplugging from them for a little while. Note that it already sells a device, the Apple Watch, whose marketing extols the magic of leaving your phone behind.\n\nDone right, a full-fledged campaign pushing the benefits of a more deliberative approach to tech wouldn\u2019t come off as self-interest, but in keeping with Apple\u2019s best vision of itself \u2014 as a company that looks out for the interests of humanity in an otherwise cold and sometimes inhumane industry.\n\n\u201cHow we live with technology is the cultural issue of the next half-century,\u201d said James Steyer, the founder and chief executive of Common Sense Media, a nonprofit group that studies how children are affected by media.\n\nHe suggested that the feeling was ripe for Apple to tap into. \u201cIt\u2019s something that everyone cares about \u2014 whether you\u2019re a Republican or a Democrat, liberal or conservative, whether you live in San Francisco or Biloxi, Miss., you know that you and your kids are part of the arms race for attention,\u201d he said.\n\nApple released a statement last week saying it cared deeply \u201cabout how our products are used and the impact they have on users and the people around them,\u201d adding that it had a few features on addiction in the works.\n\nApple hardly ever talks about future products, so it declined to elaborate on any of its ideas when I called. Let\u2019s hope it\u2019s working on something grand.", "title": "It\u2019s Time for Apple to Build a Less Addictive iPhone", "authors": ["Farhad Manjoo", "State Of The Art"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Abbas remains committed to a two-state outcome. But belief in a two-state peace is dwindling. Shikaki, the pollster, told me that Palestinian support for two states is now about 46 percent, down from about 80 percent in the mid-1990s. Still, he said, a two-state solution remains viable. Surveys show that various incentives \u2014 like the release of prisoners for Palestinians, or a wider peace with the Arab world for Israelis \u2014 can quickly shift opinion.\n\nSooner or later, whether in the next several months through an indictment or later through the ballot box, Netanyahu will be gone. It\u2019s idle to think any successor will easily cede territory for peace. Yet it\u2019s possible; it\u2019s happened before. Trump, too, will be gone one day. Abbas could live on for several years, but the damage he is doing the Palestinian cause is such that he should quit now if he is not prepared to organize an election in 2018.\n\nIn the current vacuum, a dream of one state with equal rights for all peoples \u2014 a kind of United States of the Holy Land \u2014 has gained some traction. It is pure, if seductive, illusion \u2014 flimsy code for the destruction of Israel as the national homeland of the Jews. It will not happen.\n\nTrump\u2019s instinct to blow up the status quo is dangerous. So is Abbas\u2019 comfort with that status quo. It corrodes. The threat from Trump to cut off aid could leave millions of Palestinian refugees without access to schools or hospitals. That\u2019s unacceptable. But it\u2019s equally unacceptable that Arab states only contribute about 3.5 percent of the budget of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinians refugees, compared with the American contribution of about 25 percent. The \u201cpeace process,\u201d unable to resolve the refugee issue, has become an infernal, corrupted mechanism incubating victimhood and masking myriad abuses. The Palestinian Authority is its poster child.\n\n\u201cThe Palestinian Authority is a subcontractor to the occupation,\u201d Issa Amro, a human-rights activist in Hebron told me. \u201cAbbas should stop corruption and start organizing an election.\u201d\n\nThe road from Ramallah to Nablus winds from \u201cArea A,\u201d which is under Palestinian control, through \u201cArea C,\u201d the 60 percent of the West Bank under direct Israeli rule: the lexicon of the moribund Oslo Accords endures. A settler, Rabbi Raziel Shevach, had been shot dead near Nablus a few days before my visit, a killing applauded by Hamas. Young settlers with the hilltop look \u2014 large kippas and side locks \u2014 milled around the roadside as a squad of Israeli soldiers tried to keep them away from Palestinians: just another day in the West Bank.\n\nIn Nablus, with its beautiful covered market, I met Saed Abu-Hijleh, a 52-year-old university professor and poet. In 2002, Israeli forces killed his mother. He raised his shirt to reveal scars from bullet wounds. Wandering through the market, he saluted friends, all of whom seem to have been in prison with him at one time or another. He describes Israel as a \u201ccolonial apartheid state\u201d built on the \u201cperpetuation of violence and dehumanization.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Time for Mahmoud Abbas to Go", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Larry Nassar had a day of reckoning last week for his years of molesting young gymnasts and other athletes, and he will spend the rest of his life in prison. But the leaders of Michigan State University, where he worked, have yet to take full responsibility for their failures to protect those girls, or to even learn what went wrong and regain the trust of the public.\n\nTo ensure real accountability, members of the university\u2019s Board of Trustees, which picks the university\u2019s president, oversees its administration and sets policy, should resign to make way for new leadership unencumbered by the Nassar scandal and the recent report by ESPN that the university concealed allegations of sexual violence by members of its prized football and basketball programs. If the trustees refuse to do so, Michigan\u2019s governor, Rick Snyder, and its Legislature ought to remove them.\n\nFor about two decades, university officials \u2014 administrators, coaches, trainers, even police officers \u2014 either dismissed or silenced Dr. Nassar\u2019s victims, allowing him to abuse several generations of athletes at the university and U.S.A. So officials continued to let him treat young women, even while the campus police followed up on the complaint.\n\nSeparately, ESPN quoted a former sexual-assault counselor at Michigan State who described a pattern of disturbing behavior in which senior university officials hid information about sexual-assault complaints against student-athletes and protected them from punishment.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Time for Michigan State to Clean House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "During awards season, a handful of performances from the past year become the only ones we talk about, leaving the rest draped in shadow. If there were a Most Valuable Per Minute of Screen Time award, surely Michael Stuhlbarg\u2019s name would be the one on everyone\u2019s lips.\n\nSince his breakthrough lead performance in the Coen brothers\u2019 \u201cA Serious Man\u201d (2009), Mr. Stuhlbarg, a Juilliard graduate who made a name for himself in New York theater, has been cast only in minor roles in movies, albeit by major directors. He\u2019s probably best known to viewers for his recurring TV characters on \u201cBoardwalk Empire\u201d and \u201cFargo.\u201d\n\nNow Mr. Stuhlbarg, 49, is enjoying a midlife big-screen breakout, effortlessly elevating everything he appears in. He had a standout year in 2017 with supporting performances in three major awards contenders: \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d \u201cThe Post\u201d and \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d But is he getting his due? While some critics\u2019 groups have given him prizes, he wasn\u2019t nominated for a Golden Globe, and it remains to be seen if the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will follow suit.\n\nFar from your typical Hollywood leading man, Mr. Stuhlbarg nevertheless is making a strong case for juicier parts as he quietly steals scenes in acclaimed films opposite more decorated performers.", "title": "It\u2019s Time to Take a Serious Look at Michael Stuhlbarg", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "If you can, put aside for a moment your opinion of Donald Trump\u2019s words and actions and let\u2019s be perfectly honest: One year into his presidency, could the economy be any rosier?\n\nThe economy grew at a rate of about 3 percent in the last three quarters, something that economists said was very unlikely just a year ago. The more than 40 percent increase in the Dow Jones industrial average since Election Day means a nearly $7 trillion jump in wealth. That has benefited the rich, yes, but every one of the 55 million Americans with a 401(k) plan, the 20 million with IRAs and the millions more with public and private pension plans have benefited, too. I would argue that investors are turning lower business tax rates on profits and the administration\u2019s rollback of regulations into higher stock valuations.\n\nThe job market improved impressively under Barack Obama\u2019s presidency after the Great Recession, when millions of jobs vanished seemingly overnight. But the past year\u2019s continued decline in joblessness is impressive as well. In recent weeks, the number of new unemployment insurance claims and the unemployment rate for blacks and Hispanics have been at or near their lowest levels in more than four decades.\n\nThen there is the cheerful news for the Rust Belt areas of the country: Blue-collar manufacturing, construction and mining jobs have risen by almost half a million in just one year.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Trump\u2019s Economy Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Also divorced, Mr. Thompson had five children from his previous marriage. \u201cI only had one and that\u2019s a big difference,\u201d Ms. Callan said. At the end of the semester, Mr. Thompson transferred to Wesleyan.\n\nFrom 1995 to 1998 the two stayed in touch. There were phone calls, movies and dinners. One night when he hugged her goodbye, \u201csomething had changed,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s when the love affair started.\u201d\n\nFive years later, Mr. Thompson proposed at the Olympia Tea Room in Westerly, R.I. \u201cMy daughter left for college, his children were on their own, he was no longer a student and had gotten his Ph.D.,\u201d Ms. Callan said. \u201cThe time felt right, things had progressed to a point where we both felt we were ready.\u201d\n\nWhat I\u2019ve Learned\n\nMs. Callan: With a second marriage, you come with a lot of baggage. I\u2019ve learned to be more patient and accepting. We\u2019re careful to never take each other for granted and to be very aware of this thing we\u2019re creating. I didn\u2019t do that with my first marriage. With marriage comes all these distractions. Work, kids, a house. This time I\u2019m mature enough to step back and make sure I take care of this marriage, and this relationship. Bill and I are also very conscious of how things can go wrong.\n\nIn my first marriage, we had a date night and it didn\u2019t stop us from heading to Divorceland. I think that separates romance and love from the rest of life. What you\u2019re saying is that you\u2019ll take six days for granted and then have one special night.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe other danger with marriage is becoming the same person and losing your essential differences. This isn\u2019t a business, it\u2019s a romantic relationship. We make a cognizant effort to weave that romance into our everyday life. I call him handsome or Dr. Thompson \u2014 it\u2019s sort of formal and sexy, and he calls me gorgeous. We stop to hug and be physical. We make ordinary, everyday things special. He makes coffee and brings it to me in bed, and every night I set up the cups and the can of espresso for him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019ve learned it\u2019s not the grand gestures; it\u2019s the ordinary things you do to make someone feel special that matter.\n\nMr. Thompson: Experience teaches you a lot. There\u2019s a desire to make more of an effort the second time around. I\u2019m a different person, too. Less anxious, more confident, more knowledgeable about life.\n\nWhat I know with Jamie is to stay connected to the person you\u2019re with. You have to communicate, which means you need to learn to listen. If you\u2019re focused on getting your point across, you\u2019re not doing either of those things. I\u2019ve learned to acknowledge my frustrations, and that they will pass. With Jamie I know there are ways to get past those frustrations. She has a rare happiness about her. She gets excited about things. That\u2019s contagious. I\u2019m very down-to-earth and antisocial by nature. I\u2019ve learned to appreciate our differences and celebrate that.\n\nTwenty or 30 years ago it would have been a bone of contention if someone didn\u2019t see the world the way I do. The important thing is to come back to how much we appreciate each other.\n\nOur lives really come together at the end of the day. One of the ways I show love is to cook. I usually make dinner, and I make us each a cocktail. Jamie likes a sidecar; I\u2019m more of a beer or gin and tonic person. It\u2019s a little piece of love I give each night, I look forward to making it. It\u2019s a bit of a production to make, so to me, it\u2019s like giving her a small gift. We sit, have our drinks and watch the sunset. We take in the moment of satisfaction and appreciation, and think, How did we get so lucky?", "title": "It\u2019s the Little Things, Like Coffee, Cocktails and Listening", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The Philadelphia Eagles, who routed the Minnesota Vikings by 38-7 to win the N.F.C. championship, certainly are a worthy, powerful opponent. Until their stellar quarterback Carson Wentz was injured late in the season, they would have probably been predicted to win the Super Bowl no matter whom they were playing.\n\nIt helps give the Eagles an irresistible story line. They are, for example, the anti-Patriots in so many ways. Their back-up quarterback, Nick Foles, is not a nationally known figure, a castoff who began the year firmly planted on the bench.\n\nWhile Patriots fans are haughtily delirious with success, Philadelphia fans are shamed by decades of harrowing letdowns.\n\nThe Brady-led Patriots often have benefited from quirks of good fortune in the postseason. The Eagles, who have been to two Super Bowls but never won, are usually doomed by ill-timed bounces, unlucky injuries and other bad breaks \u2014 not only in the playoffs but whenever they get near the playoffs.\n\nThey lost their last Super Bowl appearance to the Patriots, 24-21, in 2005.\n\nSo in that context, the browbeaten Eagles may be a fan favorite, and not just because of the virulent backlash against the Patriots outside of New England (see Deflategate).\n\nBut can they win?\n\nThe Eagles pass rush, so evident Sunday, is the perfect nuisance to get under Brady\u2019s skin. Philadelphia\u2019s defense forces turnovers, which is another key to defeating New England. The Eagles also have plenty of moxie, which they displayed with their goal line stand Sunday when the Vikings were trying to claw back into the game in the third quarter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn offense, Foles looked newly confident and self-reliant, never more so than during the Eagles\u2019 opening drive of the second half when he tossed an extraordinary touchdown pass on a flea-flicker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFirst, Foles caught a wayward, slow lateral on the play, then he avoided the pressure in a disintegrating pocket and finally stepped up and emphatically threw the football through a narrow window in the Vikings defense to wide receiver Torrey Smith for a 41-yard touchdown. It was the dagger that all but finished off Minnesota (the defensive goal line stand was truly the final blow).\n\nAfterward, Foles exulted in a way that spoke for the essence of Eagles fandom.\n\n\u201cEveryone was against us,\u201d he said. \u201cWe weren\u2019t anyone\u2019s pick in this game. But you know what, we stuck together and just jumped on them.\u201d\n\nSo watching these Eagles negotiate the Super Bowl landscape in the next two weeks is going to be entertaining. Cue the \u201cRocky\u201d theme.\n\nBut at the same time, there will be an overriding narrative in the run-up to the game and it will be the Patriots\u2019 ongoing campaign to rewrite the history of pro football.\n\nThis would be their sixth Super Bowl victory, which would not only tie the Patriots with the Pittsburgh Steelers for the most ever, it might cement the team as the best, or at least one of the best, of any N.F.L. era.\n\nSince the Patriots championships are occurring in an age of free agency and the N.F.L. salary cap, which are two factors that would likely have broken up dynastic teams like Vince Lombardi\u2019s Green Bay Packers, the 1950s Yankees and the 1960s Boston Celtics, another Patriots Super Bowl victory raises the question: Where does their current run rank among the great championship streaks of any team in any sport?\n\nAll their wins have come since 2001, and so another victory would give them more championships than any franchise in any major American sport in the same period.\n\nThe most titles by any N.B.A. team since 2001 is four, by the Los Angeles Lakers and the San Antonio Spurs. In Major League Baseball, the Boston Red Sox and San Francisco Giants have won three World Series each.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Sunday, the Patriots came back to win despite having lost one of their best players, the tight end Rob Gronkowski, to a head injury. Their defensive unit\u2019s lack of speed on the corners of the field was being exploited by the Jaguars fleet-footed running backs. Brady had an injured hand. For a long time Sunday, things did not look good for the home team.\n\nAnd still they won. It\u2019s what they do.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just been an unbelievable run,\u201d Brady said Sunday evening. \u201cIt\u2019s a different team every year and the results have been pretty consistent. It\u2019s pretty amazing. It\u2019d be really great if we take care of business in a couple weeks.\u201d\n\nAnd so another Super Bowl, another Patriots appearance.\n\nThey are a team not only made for the big stage, they always seem to know where to find it.", "title": "It\u2019s the Patriots\u2019 Stage; All the Rest Are Merely Players", "authors": ["Bill Pennington", "On Pro Football"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "The argument came at an auspicious time, ahead of the tide of cotton-candy publicity that will accompany Prince Harry\u2019s wedding in May. Advisers were concerned that \u201ccoverage of the royals was constantly just going out and opening a supermarket,\u201d Mr. Geffen said, and were looking for ways to focus attention on the more solemn aspects of the monarchy.\n\nVideo\n\nNothing could be as solemn as the coronation, in which the monarch is anointed with oil and is believed to be brought into direct contact with God.\n\nAncient rules surround every aspect of the ceremony. Mr. Geffen was surprised to discover that he was prohibited from filming the two crowns used in the ceremony from above, because that is the vantage point reserved for God.\n\n\u201cThey didn\u2019t want you to really stand above them at all,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to realize, the crowns are considered quite sacred, and even filming them is seen as if it could devalue them in some way.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Coronation\u201d marks the first time the crown jewels, a collection of regalia used in British coronations, have been filmed, and offers loving, hypnotic footage of crowns rotating slowly on velvet-swathed stands, with resolution so high that you can see motes of dust circulating in the light beams.\n\nVideo\n\nFor decades, Britain\u2019s royal family has measured out media access with teaspoons.\n\nQueen Elizabeth led this approach at the age of 26, siding with palace traditionalists who feared that allowing cameras into her coronation would erode the monarchy\u2019s mystique. The decision provoked such public outrage that she then backpedaled, allowing the BBC to broadcast the early stages of the ceremony, though not her anointing.\n\nIn the years that followed, royal gatekeepers have retained stringent control over broadcasters seeking interviews.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA 15-page contract leaked to The Independent, a daily newspaper, in 2015, laid out an eye-popping list of conditions for interviewing Prince Charles, including the right to preapprove the wording of questions, and to review the film at the \u201crough cut\u201d and \u201cfine cut\u201d stages, with the option to withdraw the interview at any point.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlienating the royal family, meanwhile, has proved damaging to broadcast careers.\n\nIn 2007, a trailer for a BBC documentary was edited, inaccurately, to make it appear that the queen had angrily left a photo session with Annie Leibovitz. (The footage had actually shown her walking into the session.) The corporation waited until the next day to publish a correction, allowing the story to proliferate in tabloids and stoking such resentment that the head of one of the BBC\u2019s TV networks, Peter Fincham, was forced to resign.\n\nA reminder of that hazard came this week, when Rigby & Peller, a bra manufacturer that had designed undergarments for the royal family since 1960, lost its royal warrant, a coveted designation, after its director, in her autobiography, \u201cStorm in a D-Cup,\u201d described interacting with the queen. Buckingham Palace gave no reason for the decision.\n\nFor the most part, Britain\u2019s broadcasters have refrained from pushing back against the palace, which has the power to curtail access altogether, said Valentine Low, who covers the royal family for The Times of London.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe broadcaster is essentially going to play ball,\u201d he said. \u201cThey know they have got a massive property on their hands and therefore you have to accede to any palace demands.\u201d\n\nThough \u201cThe Coronation\u201d does not interrogate the monarchy \u2014 indeed, it comes off as a lush advertisement for the institution \u2014 it does capture Queen Elizabeth in revealing, unscripted moments.\n\nIn preparation for the shoot, two crowns were removed from the Tower of London and transported, under secretive conditions, to Buckingham Palace, where the queen is given the chance to examine them. She does so with an unsentimental, appraiser\u2019s eye, as if they were racehorses or hunting dogs, and deems them, with a perfect deadpan, \u201cunwieldy.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t look down to read the speech,\u201d she remarks. \u201cBecause if you did, your neck would break.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Geffen, whose previous subjects have included Barack Obama and Saddam Hussein, said he was pleasantly surprised at the queen\u2019s relaxed manner during the shoot, especially when she reached out to touch one of the crowns. According to custom, she is one of three people on earth \u2014 along with the archbishop of Canterbury and the crown jeweler \u2014 who are allowed to touch it, he said.\n\n\u201cThe atmosphere during the filming, even for the courtiers looking on, was \u2018Wow, this is the queen we might not have seen before,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cI think everyone was delighted to see that happen. Because she was quite free-flowing. She wasn\u2019t guarded.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe impression is one of a woman considering her legacy, but Mr. Geffen warned against reading too much into that.\n\n\u201cSome people thought, \u2018Gosh, now that she\u2019s done that, she\u2019s going to resign,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cBut from what I gathered, from everything in that room and from that day, there was absolutely never an intention of that.\u201d\n\nHe added, though, that the next monarch is almost certain to simplify and shorten the ceremony. Mr. Geffen, whose lineage can be traced to Anne Boleyn, a queen beheaded by her husband, Henry VIII, stopped there, noting jokingly that Tudor-era statutes made it a crime to plan the next coronation.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re not allowed to talk about the next coronation, you know,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s treason. So you have to be careful.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s the Ultimate TV Prize: An Unscripted Queen Elizabeth", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new production of Mozart\u2019s \u201cDon Giovanni\u201d directed by Ivo van Hove, who has led fierce Broadway stagings of \u201cA View From the Bridge\u201d and \u201cThe Crucible,\u201d will be a highlight of the Paris Opera\u2019s ambitious 2018-19 season, announced late Monday.\n\nA co-production with the Metropolitan Opera, the \u201cDon Giovanni\u201d is part of a broad celebration of the company\u2019s 350th anniversary \u2014 the season\u2019s slogan is \u201cModern Since 1669\u201d \u2014 and the 30th birthday of the larger of its two theaters, the Op\u00e9ra Bastille. French works will be a focus, including Berlioz\u2019s \u201cLes Troyens\u201d (directed by Dmitri Tcherniakov, with Elina Garanca and Bryan Hymel); Rameau\u2019s opera-ballet \u201cLes Indes Galantes\u201d (staged by the film director Cle\u0301ment Cogitore); and Meyerbeer\u2019s \u201cLes Huguenots\u201d (directed by Andreas Kriegenburg, with Diana Damrau and Mr. Hymel). A new opera, \u201cBe\u0301re\u0301nice,\u201d composed by Michael Jarrell and based on Racine, will star Barbara Hannigan and be staged by Claus Guth.\n\nOther highlights of the director-driven season, announced by the company\u2019s director, St\u00e9phane Lissner, include Romeo Castellucci\u2019s version of Scarlatti\u2019s rarely-seen \u201cIl Primo Omicidio\u201d; Krzysztof Warlikowski\u2019s new production of Shostakovich\u2019s \u201cLady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District\u201d; Calixto Bieito\u2019s take on Verdi\u2019s \u201cSimon Boccanegra\u201d; Simon Stone\u2019s staging of \u201cLa Traviata\u201d; and Barry Kosky\u2019s of Borodin\u2019s \u201cPrince Igor.\u201d\n\nMr. Tcherniakov\u2019s pairing of Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cIolanta\u201d and \u201cThe Nutcracker\u201d will return, as will Peter Sellars and Bill Viola\u2019s production of Wagner\u2019s \u201cTristan und Isolde,\u201d to be conducted by the company\u2019s music director, Philippe Jordan. Mr. Jordan, who leaves Paris in 2020 to lead the Vienna State Opera, will also conduct \u201cLes Troyens,\u201d \u201cDon Giovanni,\u201d \u201cPrince Igor\u201d and \u201cBe\u0301re\u0301nice.\u201d The tenor Jonas Kaufmann will sing Cavaradossi in Puccini\u2019s \u201cTosca\u201d opposite Anja Harteros, who also stars in Verdi\u2019s \u201cLa Forza del Destino.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Paris Opera Ballet season includes Ohad Naharin\u2019s \u201cDecadance,\u201d new to the repertory, and works from Mats Ek, who announced two years ago he was taking some time off from choreography. He is back with two new pieces: \u201cBolero,\u201d to Ravel\u2019s well-known score, and \u201cAnother Place,\u201d set to Liszt\u2019s Sonata in B Minor. Crystal Pite will create an evening-length piece, her second for the company (after \u201cThe Season\u2019s Canon\u201d). The Japanese artist Hiroshi Sugimoto will collaborate with the Italian choreographer Alessio Silvestrin on a new work, and other fresh pieces will come from Marco Goecke and Pontus Lidberg, who has previously collaborated with the Paris Opera Ballet\u2019s director, Aur\u00e9lie Dupont.\n\nThe company will also offer tributes to Rudolf Nureyev on the 80th anniversary of his birth, with productions of his \u201cCinderella\u201d and \u201cSwan Lake.\u201d Another tribute program, dedicated to Jerome Robbins, is one of many worldwide celebrations of the Robbins centennial and features four works by the choreographer, who worked frequently with the Paris Opera Ballet. Visiting companies include the Martha Graham Dance Company, marking the troupe\u2019s first visit to the Palais Garnier in 27 years.", "title": "Ivo van Hove\u2019s \u2018Don Giovanni\u2019 Will Be Shared by Paris and the Met", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "DAKAR, Senegal \u2014 Officials in Ivory Coast said Thursday that they had broken up an international ivory-smuggling network, the second announcement of such a bust on the African continent this month.\n\nLaw-enforcement officials in Ivory Coast said they had arrested six people and confiscated more than half a ton of ivory, leopard parts and illegal firearms. The loot also contained a half of a ton of pangolin scales.\n\nThe pangolin, a mammal sometimes confused with the armadillo, has become one of the most trafficked animals. Demand for its pinecone-ish scales, made of keratin, like fingernails, has soared in China, where they are used in medicines.\n\nThe operation was carried out with help from United States officials as well as by the Eco Activists for Governance and Law Enforcement, also known as the Eagle Network, an organization that supports the enforcement of anti-wildlife trafficking laws. A photo distributed by American officials showed dozens of elephant tusks seized in the operation.", "title": "Ivory Coast Arrests Six in Ring That Smuggled Parts of Elephants, Leopards and Pangolins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Exactly one year ago BuzzFeed published what\u2019s now known simply as \u201cthe dossier\u201d: a set of reports put together by a former British intelligence officer named Christopher Steele during the 2016 presidential campaign. The 35-page dossier suggested that the Russian government had both compromised and colluded with President-elect Donald Trump.\n\nOur choice to publish the dossier was greeted by outrage from two sources. Journalistic traditionalists didn\u2019t like the idea of sharing an unfiltered, unverified document with the public, whatever the caveats and context. NBC\u2019s Chuck Todd told me on air, \u201cYou just published fake news.\u201d Mr. Trump agreed. He described CNN\u2019s reporting on the dossier as \u201cfake news\u201d and called BuzzFeed a \u201cfailing pile of garbage.\u201d\n\nBut a year of government inquiries and blockbuster journalism has made clear that the dossier is unquestionably real news. That\u2019s a fact that has been tacitly acknowledged even by those who opposed our decision to publish. It has helped journalists explain to their audience the investigation into Russian influence on the 2016 election. And Mr. Trump and his allies have seized on the dossier in their efforts to discredit the special counsel leading the investigation, Robert Mueller.\n\nWithout the dossier, Americans would have found it difficult to understand the actions of their elected representatives and government officials. Their posture toward Mr. Trump was, we now know even more comprehensively than we did in January 2017, shaped by Mr. Steele\u2019s report. The Russia investigation, meanwhile, didn\u2019t turn out to be some minor side story but instead the central challenge to Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency.", "title": "Opinion | I\u2019m Proud We Published the Trump-Russia Dossier", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Still, I had high hopes for its new store, just north of Grand Central Terminal. The stretch of 44th Street that runs from Avenue of the Americas to Vanderbilt captures both the elegance of New York as it once was and the reality that New York is no longer that way. There are the Harvard and Cornell Clubs, the New York Yacht Club and the Algonquin, Brooks Brothers and Allen Edmonds. But also at least three huge empty storefronts.\n\nThis street is as close to a conceptual cul-de-sac as Midtown can manage, but also reflects the receding influence of a certain generation of the city\u2019s elite.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJ. Press perseveres, however. The new location is cozy and carefully segmented: suits and sport coats and pants on the back wall, sweaters and ties on tables in the middle, slightly fancier jackets and blazers in a small alcove on the left, and a modest made-to-measure setup in the rear.\n\nNo surprise, but the cut of the jackets was cylindrical, with little nuance. Not that Harris tweed ($895) is the gentlest of fabrics, but the rigidity was a challenge. I tried on a cheeky pair of wool pants in a black and white check ($330), but the legs were 1990s wide.\n\nIn the back alcove, I found a compromise: a tweed Golden Bear varsity jacket ($595) that had aristocratic zest. One of the salesclerks walked by and offered an assist: \u201cIt\u2019s a tweed jacket without looking like you\u2019re an extra on \u2018Downton Abbey.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis style, though, is best consumed in tiny, accessory-size doses: knit ties in bold colors ($89) or something from the circular racks of needlepoint belts, maybe in your Ivy League motif of choice ($165, PTSD optional). The array of trad college scarves ($98) have some gems: Try the hypermodern colorblocking of the Yale School of Management.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI admired what seemed like an out-of-season raw silk regimental tie with pastel pink, blue and yellow stripes ($79), probably the only item in the store that could go with the pink velvet Gucci slippers I\u2019ve been coveting for a year and not had the courage to buy.\n\nSuch fabrics \u2014 such garments, as Lil Uzi Vert might say \u2014 were in short supply, though. Instead, I spotted corduroy. The return of corduroy is always unwelcome. It bespeaks a dowdy period to come. To this day, I\u2019ve never met a pair of flattering corduroy pants (though I have a lovely forest green jacket). I did see a yellow pair here, but to be fair, I\u2019m skipping the coming regatta season, so it was tough to feel at home.\n\nBefore I left the store and stepped back out into the December icebox, I took a look at some lovely British wool knit caps in bold colors ($58), but got distracted by something very unlikely: a corduroy baseball cap. It was floppy and unstructured, a dad hat made for actual dads. The way it sagged suggested wealth around long enough to have heated, and then settled, like the earth itself.\n\nI was trying on the green one when the clerk informed me there was a pink one as well.
