Press Is for the Ivy League Faithful (or Those Who Like Preppy Drag)", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica", "Critical Shopper"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Scores of rescheduled flights, damaged equipment and other lingering effects of this week\u2019s winter storm combined to create long delays for passengers at Kennedy International Airport and forced federal officials to limit some flights into the airport on Saturday night.\n\nIn a statement on Saturday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said all flights scheduled to arrive at Terminal 1, which is operated by Air France, Lufthansa, Japan Airlines and Korean Air, would be affected by the limitations for the rest of the night. It also warned that the delays of Saturday were expected to continue.\n\nLeah Golubchick, 31, had been trying to get to Denver since Friday.\n\nHer itinerary on Delta Air Lines was rescheduled once, then rescheduled again for a flight that was supposed to leave at 8:30 a.m. on Saturday. At noon, she was still waiting.\n\n\u201cThe crew has no estimated time for when the plane is supposed to come in,\u201d she said.\n\nShe was first told the delay was because \u201cthe baggage machines were frozen.\u201d A few hours later, she was told a plane was snowed in at the hangar.", "title": "J.F.K. Airport Plagued by Delays After Winter Storm", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "In a news conference on Sunday evening, Rick Cotton, the executive director of the Port Authority, said that he was ordering an investigation of the water main break and the continuing flight problems. He emphasized that the terminal with the flooding was operated by a private company, not the Port Authority.\n\nFor the second day in a row, the Port Authority had to ask federal aviation officials to block some international flights from landing at Kennedy. That order would add to the two dozen flights that had been diverted to other airports since Saturday.\n\nThe protracted chaos at the airport drew harsh condemnation from Senator Chuck Schumer, who called for \u201ca thorough review\u201d of the airport and the Port Authority to find out what went wrong, especially since Thursday\u2019s storm had not come as a surprise.\n\n\u201cThey should have been way better prepared, plain and simple,\u201d he said. \u201cJ.F.K. has to follow the Boy Scouts\u2019 motto: \u2018Be prepared.\u2019 They weren\u2019t.\u201d\n\nMr. Cotton said he too wanted a review of how and why the system had broken down.\n\nMr. Cotton, an appointee of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and the Port Authority\u2019s director of aviation, Huntley Lawrence, were at Kennedy Airport on Sunday to address concerns. A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo referred an inquiry to the Port Authority.\n\nMr. Lawrence said the airport would resume normal operations on Monday.\n\nThough the Port Authority serves as the landlord and overall operator of the airport, maintaining the runways and roadways, the airlines and other private companies operate the six terminals and are responsible for getting passengers and their baggage on and off planes, and the planes to and from the gates.\n\nMr. Cotton said the trouble this weekend resulted from miscommunication between some terminal operators and the airlines that are their tenants. With operations on the ground slowed in the aftermath of the storm by frozen equipment and understaffed crews, the airlines should not have brought as many planes to Kennedy as they did, Mr. Cotton said. The incoming traffic proved overwhelming, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhat broke down \u2014 and it broke down badly \u2014 was the coordination between terminal operators and the airlines to assure that there were gates available for the arriving airplanes,\u201d Mr. Cotton said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said some airlines reached out to the Port Authority for help on Saturday, but not before the situation at Terminal 1 had reached a crisis. One goal of the review of the situation will be to determine how the Port Authority can provide aid sooner, he said.\n\nWhile Kennedy has remained open since Friday morning, parts of it had sunk into complete dysfunction, with planes full of passengers sitting for several hours on taxiways with no place to go. Passengers on more than two dozen flights were transported on buses while their luggage remained on the planes.\n\nBrittany Morris, 20, of Stow, Ohio, waited hours Sunday for an Air France flight to Paris as part of a group headed to a study-abroad program through Kent State University.\n\n\u201cI hate traveling in the first place, so this is like kind of a nightmare,\u201d she said.\n\nAnother student, Bekah Baker, propped herself against a pillar at the airport with a laptop. By midafternoon, she had been sitting in the same spot for about five hours, and her delayed flight was not scheduled to leave for another six.\n\nThe international gates at Terminal 1 and Terminal 4 were nearly paralyzed during the weekend. On Saturday evening, international flights bound for Terminal 1 were blocked from arriving, and there were reports of passengers in Terminal 4 growing so restless over a canceled flight that fights broke out.\n\nThen on Sunday, the broken water main sent people fleeing in a partial evacuation and left bags and suitcases in water. Entire areas of the terminal, including the heavily used bathrooms at both ends of the ground floor waiting area, were cordoned off. Outside, the taxi stand was shut down while the traffic lanes closest to the terminal were cleared.\n\n\u201cYou would think with water mains breaking all over town they would have a contingency plan,\u201d said Michael Rossiter, 54, of Jersey City. \u201cA couple of guys with squeegees doesn\u2019t seem to do the job.\u201d\n\nAs Mr. Rossiter waited, water spread across the terminal floor, flooding a diner and newsstand while terminal employees, state troopers and others rushed to sop up water with wide-brushed mops.\n\nMr. Rossiter said he and his family \u201cjust want to get home \u2014 and now this.\u201d", "title": "J.F.K. Travelers Ask: When Can I Catch a Flight Home?", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan", "Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "What are the challenges of playing a variation of the same character?\n\nThere were logistical and technical challenges and long days. Waa waa waa! I try not to complain too much about how hard my fabulous show business job is. The good news was that Justin and I had a lot of time to figure out how to differentiate these characters \u2014 and what not to do. I considered all kinds of subtle things in terms of appearance that ultimately seemed unnecessary because the more interesting thing was how has a person really changed at his core in the second 30 years of his life due to his environment, his experiences.\n\nWhich Howard is the dominant scene partner?\n\nIn general, we preferred shooting the kinder, gentler Howard first. For the first 20 pages of the script, I was thinking, this is the character that I\u2019ll play, this is our protagonist, and this is the guy that I\u2019m identifying with. And when I got to the scene where we meet Howard from the Other Side and the two worlds are revealed, I was as surprised as I wish audiences could be.\n\nT: The New York Times Style Magazine recently included you in a roundup of outstanding character actors. Do you consider yourself one?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAbsolutely. My standard joke is that character actors are just actors who are not particularly good-looking. I think the public perception is there\u2019s your leading man, your Clooney and your Pitt, and then there\u2019s the other guys. The vast majority of actors that I have worked with like to think of themselves as character actors. To me, putting the word character in front of the word actor is a compliment because it means people are seeing the character rather than the actor, which at the end of the day is my ultimate goal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did life change after your Oscar for best supporting actor for playing the tyrannical music instructor Terence Fletcher in \u201cWhiplash\u201d?\n\nWell, the sheer number of offers immediately increased greatly, and I had already gotten to a point in my career well past anything I had fantasized about. But the result is that I\u2019ve felt like rather than take advantage of the opportunities to work, work, work, work, work, I\u2019ve actually taken advantage of the confidence that I will continue to have a career. And that has oddly provided me with more free time to spend with my family.\n\nI hear you\u2019ve got a drum set at home. I trust you don\u2019t fling cymbals.\n\nBoth kids actually competently play the drum kit.\n\nYou\u2019re so good at playing the bad guy. What\u2019s your secret?\n\nI put \u201cbad guy\u201d in quotes because as an actor I have to find a way to identify with, or at least understand, my character\u2019s perspective. Certainly Terence Fletcher doesn\u2019t perceive himself as a bad guy or even Vernon Schillinger [the brutal neo-Nazi inmate on HBO\u2019s \u201cOz\u201d]. One of the great \u201cbad guy\u201d parts that I ever played was Colonel Jessep in \u201cA Few Good Men\u201d on Broadway. And I realized that everything this colonel does comes from a place of love \u2014 his love for the Marine Corps, his love for his country, his love for God. Not to say that he\u2019s not also an egomaniac and a power freak, but that\u2019s his motivation. And I think the majority of the time in my work, and I hope in my life, the primary motivation for most behavior is love.", "title": "J.K. Simmons on the Art of Being the Bad Guy", "authors": ["Kathryn Shattuck"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "In 2014, years after he moved from South Africa to Australia, the novelist J.M. Coetzee finally sold his own apartment in Cape Town. Soon after a researcher went through a cardboard box left behind in the vacated flat \u2014 and inside, to his astonishment, he discovered a welter of remarkable unpublished materials by the taciturn Nobel laureate. But they were not manuscripts. They were photographs: sheafs of yellowing prints that depicted \u201cscenes from provincial life,\u201d as his three volumes of autobiography are subtitled, as well as undeveloped negatives.\n\nBefore he turned to literature, it turns out, Mr. Coetzee was a committed teenage photographer \u2014 and his black-and-white impressions of his family, his school and daily life on his uncle\u2019s farm are on view for the first time, in an exhibition at the Irma Stern Museum in Cape Town. Mr. Coetzee had never showed the photographs to anyone; he was suspicious, when the exhibition was proposed, whether a writer\u2019s early experiments with the camera had any importance at all. But the images, shot in 1955 and 1956, when the author was 15 and 16 years old, offer a crucial vista onto the formation of an author as restrained in his personal disclosures as in his prose. More than that, they give a new depth to his fiction, which owes as much to the arts of the lens as of the page.", "title": "J.M. Coetzee\u2019s Boyhood, in Black and White", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u2014 Mr. Smith, 59, is head of the bank\u2019s consumer and community bank. He oversees 140,000 of the bank\u2019s 240,000 employees. Mr. Smith joined JPMorgan in 2007 from American Express.\n\nThe question now is whether the move positions one of the two to succeed Mr. Dimon as chief executive of the nation\u2019s largest bank by assets. Both Mr. Pinto and Mr. Smith are old enough that it is unclear whether they will be serious contenders for the top job.\n\nIn the press release annoucing their appointments, the bank said Mr. Dimon planned to stay on the job for another five years. That would mean both executives would be in their 60s when Mr. Dimon retired.\n\nBut both men could be prepared to step in if unforeseen events cause Mr. Dimon to leave. There has been, of course, much speculation that Mr. Dimon may run for president. (Mr. Dimon has said he is not running.)\n\nMonday\u2019s moves feel similar to the promotion of Jes Staley to run JPMorgan\u2019s investment bank in 2009. Mr. Staley was close in age to Mr. Dimon, so he was viewed less as a long-term solution to JPMorgan\u2019s succession planning and more an executive who could step in if something happened to Mr. Dimon.\n\nAntonio Weiss is back in the deal business, thanks to Keurig\n\nListed in the phalanx of bankers and lawyers behind the $18.7 billion acquisition of Dr Pepper Snapple is a name that you might easily miss, \u201cAFW LP.\u201d\n\nThat happens to be short for \u201cAntonio Francesco Weiss,\u201d the former Lazard banker and Treasury Department official \u2014 and an adviser to Keurig.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring his career at Lazard, Mr. Weiss became one of the investment bank\u2019s biggest deal makers, eventually becoming the firm\u2019s global head of investment banking after having done tours of duty in New York and Paris.\n\nAmong the deals he worked on were InBev\u2019s acquisition of Anheuser Busch, Reynolds American\u2019s takeover of fellow cigarette maker Lorillard, Burger King\u2019s takeover of Tim Hortons and Google\u2019s purchase of Motorola Mobility. (He was also publisher of The Paris Review.)\n\nDuring his career, he came to know the executives who run JAB, which is Keurig\u2019s majorityshareholder, and sold the company D.E. Master Blenders, the international coffee business then owned by Mondelez. JAB later combined D.E. Master Blenders with Keurig in a nearly $14 billion deal.\n\nBut Mr. Weiss left Lazard to become a counselor at the Treasury Department in the Obama administration, taking on issues like Puerto Rico\u2019s debt crisis and the marketplace lending practiced by the likes of Lending Club.\n\nSince leaving government, Mr. Weiss has taken up residence as a senior fellow at the Mossavar-Rhamani Center for Business and Government at Harvard\u2019s Kennedy School, as well as a directorship at the Volcker Alliance. (He\u2019s also a prolific op-ed and briefing writer.)\n\nHe has weighed whether to get back into investment banking, and has been courted by many an investment bank. It\u2019s unclear whether he will ultimately join an existing shop or start his own, as rain makers like Paul Taubman have done.\n\nThe other advisers on the deal\n\nFor Keurig Green Mountain:\n\n\u2022 Goldman Sachs, BDT & Company (which is also investing in the deal), Mr. Weiss, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America Merrill Lynch and the law firms Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and McDermott, Will & Emery\n\n\u2022 JPMorgan, Bank of America and Goldman are also providing financing for the deal. (The combined company is expected to have some $16.6 billion in debt if the deal closes, though it also anticipates keeping an investment-grade credit rating.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Dr Pepper Snapple\n\n\u2022 Credit Suisse and the law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius\n\nFor Mondelez\n\n\u2022 The law firm Clifford Chance\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nWho\u2019s afraid of an I.P.O.?\n\nCompanies want to go public. They just want to avoid the initial public offering process.\n\nThat\u2019s at least one take away from Monday morning\u2019s deal news.\n\nExhibit #1: Keurig Green Mountain\u2019s $18.7 billion deal for Dr Pepper Snapple Group.\n\nUnder the terms of the proposed transaction, Keurig, which was taken private in 2016 by JAB Holding, would merge with Dr Pepper Snapple. The deal would create a new company to be called Keurig Dr Pepper, which would trade on the New York Stock Exchange. Keurig\u2019s current shareholders would own about 87 percent of the combined company, with Dr Pepper Snapple investors owning the remainder.\n\nExhibit #2: Speculation that Dell could merge with VMware through so-called reverse merger.\n\nAlex Sherman of CNBC reports:\n\nDell Technologies could emerge as a public company through a reverse-merger with VMware, the $60 billion cloud computing company it already controls, according to people familiar with the matter. The reverse merger, whereby VMware would actually buy the larger Dell, would then allow Dell to be traded publicly without going through a formal listing.\n\nThe news comes as Spotify is planning to hit the public markets through a so-called direct listing. Such listings essentially move trading in a company\u2019s stock from private markets to public ones, with new investors buying shares on the open market. Instead of a prospectus many weeks before the market debut, the company files a registration statement soon before a direct listing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWall Street and Silicon Valley are closely watching Spotify\u2019s listing. If it goes well, it could spur other high profile start-ups to pursue a direct listing. That would be bad news for Wall Street since direct listings generate lower fees than the typical I.P.O.\n\nSpoofing.\n\nA small provision in the Dodd-Frank Act outlawing something called \u201cspoofing\u201d has generated the latest round of criminal charges against eight traders along with civil settlements by Deutsche Bank, HSBC, and UBS. All for doing something that happens every second of the trading day: entering and then canceling orders.\n\nThe law makes it illegal to engage in \u201cbidding or offering with the intent to cancel the bid or offer before execution.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe federal appeals court in Chicago upheld the first criminal conviction for spoofing last year in United States v. Coscia, in which the judges rejected the argument that no one was deceived by orders placed and then quickly canceled because other traders do that routinely. \u201cHis scheme was deceitful because, at the time he placed the large orders, he intended to cancel the orders.\u201d\n\nApparently, the only requirement to prove spoofing is that the defendant enters orders without any real hope they will be filled to pull the market in one direction so that other orders can be filled, generating a small profit. Proving the case requires showing multiple orders were used and not just isolated transactions, such as one defendant who engaged in what the government claims was 36,000 different instances of spoofing.\n\nAnd it wouldn\u2019t be a case involving traders if there weren\u2019t the usual messages showing how they were gladly abusing the market. In one chat, a trader wrote \u201cso glad I could help . . . got that up 2 bucks . . . that does show u how easy it is to manipulate it.\u201d Describing something as manipulation sure does help prove intent.\n\nWho is fooled by the spoofing? It turns out that most of the time it is competing computer algorithms of other high-frequency trading firms. So this isn\u2019t a case in which mom-and-pop investors are taking it on the chin.\n\n\u2014 Peter J. Henning\n\nPhoto\n\nThe activists pushing Avon to sell itself\n\nMeet Shah Capital, Barington Capital Group and NuOrion Partners, who together own about 3.5 percent of the cosmetics maker and today publicly called upon the company to consider selling itself.\n\nBarington and NuOrion were behind a previous campaign to force out Avon\u2019s C.E.O., Sherilyn McCoy. Ms. McCoy has already announced plans to step down.\n\nFrom the hedge funds\u2019 letter:\n\nThe shareholder group is extremely disappointed with the deteriorating operating and share price performance that has occurred under the stewardship of the current board. The shareholder group is also dismayed by the Board\u2019s failure to act quickly and decisively on the past recommendations its members have made to improve the long-term performance of the company, including promptly hiring a new chief executive officer \u2013 a step that has been long overdue and members of the shareholder group recommended over two years ago.\n\nThe context\n\nAvon is just over two years removed from an agreement to spin off its North American business into a privately held company that was majority-owned by Cerberus Capital Management. After the sale, Avon announced a three-year strategic plan to focus on its remaining operations outside the U.S. and reduce costs.\n\nAvon reported $12.5 million in profit for its third fiscal quarter, after previously reporting three consecutive quarterly losses. The company is set to report its fourth quarter results next month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s next for Steve Wynn\n\nIn the wake of a WSJ investigation into allegations of sexual assault and misconduct, the casino magnate\u2019s empire has already taken a hit. He has also resigned as the Republican National Committee\u2019s finance chairman.\n\nBut more pain is probably in store for Mr. Wynn, whom the veteran reporter Jon Ralston calls \u201cthe biggest name in the history of Nevada business.\u201d\n\nThe corporate fallout\n\nThe Wynn board \u2014 long criticized as too cozy with its chairman \u2014 has already said that it will form an independent investigating committee.\n\nThen there\u2019s the question of what will happen to Mr. Wynn\u2019s casinos, particularly in Macau, which accounts for the vast majority of Wynn Resorts\u2019 revenue.\n\nMore from Daniela Wei and Bruce Einhorn of Bloomberg:\n\nAny fallout from the allegations could have a major impact on Macau. Gaming regulators in Nevada and Massachusetts are looking into the accusations, and punitive actions in the U.S. could prompt Macau regulators to ramp up their scrutiny, said Wang Changbin, director of the Gaming Teaching and Research Centre at the Macau Polytechnic Institute.\n\nWhether Mr. Wynn will be ousted \u2014 for a second time \u2014 is unclear. He owns 21 percent of Wynn Resorts, but has no extra voting power.\n\nThe political fallout\n\nLawmakers are starting to distance themselves, with House Speaker Paul Ryan donating $1,000 he had received from a Wynn affiliate to charity. \u201cWe were in the dark for 24 hours,\u201d one unnamed R.N.C. member fumed to Robert Costa of the WaPo.\n\nMr. Wynn wasn\u2019t among the top 100 political donors in the 2016 election cycle. But President Trump chose him as the R.N.C.\u2019s finance chair, and he hosted a fund-raiser for the president at Mar-a-Lago on Jan. 20.\n\nMore misconduct news\n\n\u2022 Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, fired his chief of staff this weekend over inappropriate relations with lower-level employees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Investment funds are piling into the settlement-advance industry, in which firms pay plaintiffs in anticipation of a big court victory.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow did Trump do at Davos?\n\nAndrew\u2019s take:\n\n\u201cAll week, Davos-goers worried that he was going to try to humiliate and verbally attack them. He did the opposite. He stayed on script and made a compelling argument for investment in the U.S. C.E.O.s from around the world wanted selfies with him.\u201d\n\nPer Daniel Yergin of IHS Markit:\n\n\u201cHe was selling America, he was selling the economic story and he was selling himself to an international business community who expected something else.\u201d\n\nAnd Ishmael Sunga of the Southern Africa Confederation of Agricultural Unions:\n\n\u201cHe made no controversial statements. He was talking to the crowd of people that he\u2019s been brought up to be part of.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s speech, largely written by Gary Cohn and the White House staff secretary, Rob Porter, was both a defense of the White House\u2019s nationalist policies and a case for international cooperation, on U.S. terms. (\u201cAmerica first does not mean America alone.\u201d)\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nWhile Mr. Trump sought to play down any isolationist tendencies \u2014 and the director general of the World Trade Organization said, \u201cI haven\u2019t seen anything at this point that we are in a trade war\u201d \u2014 China was still in his sights.\n\nA headline from The South China Morning Post: \u201cChina should \u2018be ready for a trade war\u2019 after Donald Trump\u2019s Davos speech.\u201d\n\n(To many attendees, China remained the real star of this year\u2019s World Economic Forum.)\n\nA bit of color: Many C.E.O.s left Davos before Mr. Trump\u2019s speech.\n\nAlso, this happened: Andrew was pelted with a snowball by Steven Mnuchin.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow would nationalizing 5G work?\n\nDepends what we\u2019re talking about. Axios reported that the White House has considered creating a centralized, national 5G network for national security reasons, citing a National Security Council memo.\n\nMore from Jonathan Swan, David McCabe, Ina Fried and Kim Hart of Axios:\n\nThe memo argues that a strong 5G network is needed in order to create a secure pathway for emerging technologies like self-driving cars and virtual reality \u2014 and to combat Chinese threats to America\u2019s economic and cyber security. A PowerPoint slide says the play is the digital counter to China\u2019s One Belt One Road Initiative meant to spread its influence beyond its borders.\n\nBloomberg, citing its own sources, paints a slightly different picture: \u201cThe U.S. is in talks with private companies to build a secure 5G network amid concerns about China and cybersecurity.\u201d The decision deadline is the end of September.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nAT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and others have already spent billions of dollars on 5G networks. Given its speed and data capacity, it remains their biggest initiative, and it\u2019s unclear how much control, if any, they would be willing to give up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAny nationalization effort would run counter to how the government has handled wireless infrastructure for decades: by auctioning off the airwaves and letting private companies do the work.\n\nFrom AT&T\u2019s statement on the issue:\n\n\u201cThanks to multibillion-dollar investments made by American companies, the work to launch 5G service in the United States is already well down the road.\u201d\n\nThe policy flyaround\n\n\u2022 Republican lawmakers warned Mr. Trump not to fire Robert Mueller, but showed little interest in a bill to protect him. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Koch brothers\u2019 political network plans to spend as much as $400 million on this year\u2019s midterm elections. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 A portrait of Paul Manafort as a dangerously successful foreign-policy entrepreneur. (Atlantic)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat will Alwaleed bin Talal do now he\u2019s free?\n\nHe spoke to Reuters shortly before being freed from detention in the Riyadh Ritz-Carlton over the weekend:\n\nQ: Do you expect to retain ownership of Kingdom Holding and stakes in companies like Citigroup? \u201cYes, Kingdom Holding will remain under my ownership, the same ownership.\u201d\n\nThe prince denied forfeiting a significant part of his fortune or pledging donations to projects spearheaded by his jailer, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. But analysts in the region still think his ultimate settlement will be pricey.\n\nShares in Kingdom Holding are back to where they traded before Mr. bin Talal\u2019s detention.\n\nThe big questions: Will international businesses feel better about investing in Saudi Arabia after what the crown prince said was a crackdown on corruption? And how much will the kingdom collect from the royals who were detained?\n\nIn other Saudi news: The government still hasn\u2019t decided where to list Aramco, and it may not begin trading on an international stock exchange this year. Meanwhile, the U.S. oil industry is still riding high.\n\nEric Schneiderman will investigate fake social media followers\n\nThat\u2019s in the wake of the NYT Magazine\u2019s inquiry into Devumi, a company that sold millions of fake followers (some using stolen identities) to the likes of Michael Dell and the Twitter director Martha Lane Fox. \u201cImpersonation and deception are illegal under New York law,\u201d the state attorney general said.\n\nThe big question\n\nDo Twitter and other social media companies really want a crackdown? Here\u2019s the take of Dan Leal, a pornographer who bought followers:\n\n\u201cCountless public figures, companies, music acts, etc. purchase followers,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIf Twitter was to purge everyone who did so there would be hardly any of them on it.\u201d\n\nIn other tech news: Intel\u2019s initial disclosures about flaws in its chips included briefings for Chinese tech companies but not the U.S. government, the WSJ reported, citing unnamed sources.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Sanofi agreed to buy Ablynx, a Belgian biotech company, for $4.7 billion. (Reuters)\n\nPhoto\n\nMore regulation looms for virtual currencies\n\nCoincheck, a Japanese digital currency exchange, promised to partially reimburse customers after being hit by a $500 million theft on Friday. But the heist has again raised the prospect of more regulation.\n\nCoincheck has until Feb. 13 to explain the cause of the incident and how it will stop it happening again.\n\nAnother Bitcoin no-trade zone: Deutsche Bank\u2019s wealth management unit is advising clients against investing in virtual currencies\n\nPhoto\n\nThe obits corner\n\n\u2022 Ingvar Kamprad, who made a multibillion-dollar fortune with Ikea and introduced the world to cheap, Nordic-designed furniture, died on Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 William McDonough, who led the New York Fed through both Sept. 11 and the Long-Term Capital Management crisis, died last week.\n\nPhoto\n\nQuote of the day\n\n\u201cThe problem now is that innovation is not viewed as an unalloyed way to improve the human condition. And that\u2019s fair, because it\u2019s not pure.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Bill Gates, speaking about social media, A.I. and many other topics in the NYT\u2019s Table for Three column.\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Every major economy on earth is expanding. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The expansion of the U.S. economy rests on consumer confidence. But history indicates that it will eventually shift the other way, writes Robert Shiller. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The L.A. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "JPMorgan Promotes Pinto and Smith to Co-Presidents: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJPMorgan Chase\u2019s financial results came in slightly stronger than expected on Friday, despite a big one-time hit from the new tax law, and they indicate that the bank and its peers could grow even more profitable in the years ahead.\n\nJPMorgan\u2019s results are an important bellwether for the entire financial industry. It\u2019s the biggest bank in the United States by assets. And it\u2019s the first large bank to report its quarterly and annual results, most likely foreshadowing the performances that its rivals will report over the next week.\n\nIn the fourth quarter, JPMorgan\u2019s underlying finances were obscured by accounting for the new tax package, which slashed the corporate income tax rate and applied a new, lower rate to earnings that companies had been stockpiling overseas \u2014 and that they now need to bring back to the United States.\n\nThe changes prompted many banks and other corporations to adjust their balance sheets to create the optimal mix of assets that ultimately will result in the lowest possible tax rate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the short term, that resulted in some modest pain: JPMorgan took a $2.4 billion charge, and Wells Fargo, which also reported its results on Friday, logged $173 million in costs related to moving money back to the United States to comply with the tax law\u2019s so-called repatriation provision.", "title": "JPMorgan\u2019s Profits Are Strong, and They\u2019ll Likely Get Stronger", "authors": ["Emily Flitter"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI sincerely believe that in the black community of artists, especially those of us dealing with abstraction, art has to go beyond the general notions of race, gender, nationalism,\u201d he told Art in America magazine in 2013. \u201cThings have evolved to the degree where there is a possibility of a new sensibility out there. We\u2019re into a global aesthetic here, and anyone that doesn\u2019t see that has a real old-fashioned way of thinking.\u201d\n\nThat curious and all-embracing spirit led him to create works on subjects as diverse as quantum physics and the 2012 shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn. It also led him to experiment with different ways to use paint, and even occasionally to try other art forms. In April the Baltimore Museum of Art is scheduled to open an exhibition featuring 40 sculptures he made, beginning in 1963.\n\nMr. Whitten was born on Dec. 5, 1939, in Bessemer, Ala., near Birmingham. His father, Mose, was a coal miner who died when Jack was young. His mother, Annie B. Cunningham, was a seamstress and, as Mr. Whitten put it in a 1994 interview with Bomb magazine, \u201ca believer in education\u201d; she later opened a private kindergarten.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Whitten attended Tuskegee University in Alabama and briefly met the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1957 when Mr. Whitten went to hear him speak in Birmingham. After he transferred to Southern University in Louisiana, he said, he joined student civil rights protests, trying to practice Dr. King\u2019s precepts of nonviolence, but a march on the state Capitol was a personal turning point.\n\n\u201cWe made it all the way to the state Capitol building as they were hitting us with sticks,\u201d he told the arts journal The Brooklyn Rail in an interview last year. \u201cI did it then, but I made a vow I would never put myself in that position again. That march is what drove me out of the South. I took a Greyhound bus to New York City.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe studied art at the Cooper Union from 1960 to 1964, falling in with the Abstract Expressionists of the day. Willem de Kooning was a particular influence and mentor.\n\n\u201cI came in one night after a horrific critique when one of my professors put me down for concentrating too much on process,\u201d Mr. Whitten recalled in a 2013 interview with The Boston Globe. \u201cThat was not a word used much then, in 1961. He said I accepted too many accidents. I spoke to de Kooning, and he said to me, \u2018There\u2019s no such thing as accidents in painting!\u2019 That was very helpful to me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the 1960s advanced, Mr. Whitten began venturing into different ways to paint, trying to avoid the pop trends of the decade.\n\n\u201cAnybody with any sense from my generation who was serious about painting by the late \u201960s had to realize that the psychedelic was a perpetual dog chasing its tail,\u201d he said in a 2007 interview with The Brooklyn Rail. \u201cAnd in our way, we had to invent our way of making paintings.\u201d\n\nHe became interested in process art, which espouses the idea that the making of a work is as vital as the end product. In 1970, he and three other artists received grants from the Xerox Corporation, which invited them to experiment with its equipment and work with its engineers.\n\nAnd Mr. Whitten moved beyond the paintbrush, creating art by dragging paint across a canvas with a squeegee, an Afro comb or a large rakelike tool he had made. He began to attract attention.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat Mr. Whitten does is to rake across a richly prepared paint substance with a 12-foot-wide instrument of his own devising,\u201d John Russell wrote in The New York Times in 1974, describing an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art. \u201cIt is, as he says himself, a gambling situation, and sometimes the gamble doesn\u2019t come off; but in the best pictures the immediacy is captured intact.\u201d\n\nOver the years Mr. Whitten worked in paint so heavily layered that he could, and did, cut slices out of it. He made a sort of tile from paint compounds, applying the result to canvas for a mosaic effect. On the Greek island of Crete, where he spent many summers, he began making the sculptures that will be the focus of the Baltimore exhibition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Whitten sometimes responded to the events of the day with artwork. One such event was the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001, which Mr. Whitten witnessed at close range, from his studio on Lispenard Street in TriBeCa.\n\n\u201cWhen it hit,\u201d he said of the first plane, \u201cthe first thing you saw was this big crystal burst; before you saw any smoke, before you saw any flame, the sky was just filled with crystal glass.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe produced from that experience the painting \u201c9-11-01\u201d in 2006.\n\nMr. Whitten, who at his death lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, was divorced from his first wife, Florence Squires. He is survived by his wife, the former Mary Staikos, whom he married in 1968; two daughters, Mirsini Alexandra Amidon and Keita A. Whitten; two brothers, James M. Cross and Jesse Whitten; and two grandsons.\n\nAmong the many exhibitions centered on Mr. Whitten was a show at Alexander Gray Associates in Chelsea in 2013.\n\n\u201cWith a career grazing the 50-year mark,\u201d Holland Cotter wrote of that exhibition in The Times, \u201cJack Whitten is still making work that looks like no one else\u2019s, which is saying something, given the flood of abstract painting in New York in the past few years.\n\n\u201cHe invented new forms of abstraction and standards of beauty to match them. Even more to his credit, he\u2019s still restless enough to make every picture a complex one-off formal event. And he\u2019s stayed invested enough in art as an intimate medium to make those events personal.\u201d", "title": "Jack Whitten, Artist of Wide-Ranging Curiosity, Dies at 78", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJaclyn Sara Lopez and Andrew John Witmer were married Jan. 20 at the Palms Hotel and Spa in Miami Beach. Rabbi Robert Silverman officiated.\n\nDr. Witmer, 29, is a licensed clinical psychologist at a group private practice in Washington. She graduated from Johns Hopkins, and received a doctor of psychology degree in clinical psychology from George Washington University.\n\nShe is a daughter of Stacey E. Lopez and Tomas G. Lopez of Scotch Plains, N.J. The bride's parents own Luminar Solutions, a graphic design and printing firm there.\n\nMr. Witmer, 28, is the communications director in Washington for Representative Frank D. Lucas, Republican of Oklahoma. The groom graduated magna cum laude from Texas A&M University. He is also president of the Republican Communications Association, a congressional staff association in Washington.\n\nHe is the son of Heidi M. Witmer and Roger J. Witmer of Brevard, N.C. The groom's mother is a Brevard-based artist and a professional bluegrass musician. His father is a retired oil and gas exploration geologist who worked at Chevron in Houston.\n\nThe couple met in February 2013 at a jazz bar in Washington.", "title": "Jaclyn Lopez, Andrew Witmer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "PITTSBURGH \u2014 In an endlessly surprising year for the N.F.L., filled with attacks on the league from a sitting president, a politically charged debate over the national anthem, and more controversy over the league\u2019s handling of its concussion protocol, perhaps what happened here Sunday on a frigid afternoon was only fitting.\n\nThe Jacksonville Jaguars, a franchise that had not won a division title since Bill Clinton was president, upset the Pittsburgh Steelers, those mighty six-time Super Bowl champions, by 45-42 in a divisional-round game that was not actually that close. The result upended expectations for the rest of the playoffs.\n\nThe Steelers were supposed to be the last team capable of stopping the New England Patriots, who will appear in their seventh consecutive conference title game next week. Instead, the Jaguars \u2014 that\u2019s right, the usually hapless Jaguars! \u2014 will try to deny the Patriots a third Super Bowl berth in four years. The N.F.L. will have to wait at least another year for a Patriots-Steelers showdown that would have been a shot in the arm to the league\u2019s sagging television ratings.\n\nMaybe hubris played a part. The Steelers finished the season with 13 wins and might have claimed home field through the A.F.C. playoffs had a touchdown pass to tight end Jesse James in a game against the Patriots last month not been overturned by a controversial call. The Steelers have burned for a second shot at New England ever since.", "title": "Jaguars Upset Steelers, Continuing an N.F.L. Season of Surprise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "But recent military exercises suggest that the U.S. military is preparing for the last resort.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Iran, angry citizens are disputing the official line that two young men detained in the wave of antigovernment protests killed themselves, and that another was a terrorist who died in a clash with security forces.\n\nThe men\u2019s personal stories have struck a nerve with Iranians, who see glaring contradictions in the official accounts. Above, President Hassan Rouhani, center, in Tehran on Sunday.\n\nTheir demand for an investigation suggests that while the protests have subsided, the fallout may be just beginning.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 The Philippines shut down an award-winning news website that has been critical of President Rodrigo Duterte. An industry group called the move a vendetta by Mr. Duterte and urged journalists to protest.\n\nThe outlet, Rappler, was said to have broken media ownership rules, but industry groups saw an attack on press freedom.\n\n\u201cThe decision, which is tantamount to killing the online news site, sends a chilling effect to media organizations in the country,\u201d one group said.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Jakarta, a balcony collapsed inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange building, sending people fleeing in panic and injuring more than 70 people, according to the police.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA large number of university students were said to be on the balcony when it suddenly crumbled. A police spokesman ruled out the possibility of terrorism.\n\nIn 2000, the stock exchange was struck by two rogue army soldiers who planted a car bomb in the building\u2019s basement, killing 15 people.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The day before Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday, our reporters spoke with African-Americans at churches across the U.S. \u201cThere\u2019s not a lot of honesty in the country now about who we are and where we are,\u201d one activist said.\n\nAnd we imagined what it would have felt like in 1968 if phone alerts had existed then. Benny Goodman, the jazz clarinetist, would perform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe event will be decisive in the history of swing,\u201d a Times writer later declared. \u201cWhat will it sound like in this strange milieu of righteousness and uplift, and what will be its effect on swing?\u201d\n\nFans of swing were concerned that exposure to New York\u2019s elite would eventually rob the grass-roots genre of its \u201celusiveness, its absolute freedom from technique or rules.\u201d\n\nThose fears were dispelled by Mr. Goodman\u2019s success in captivating the audience.\n\nCarnegie Hall \u201chad never seen an audience that behaved this way: listeners who not only listened but swayed to the music, made sounds and seemed ready to break into some kind of hysterical dance,\u201d The Times reported. Above, Mr. Goodman at Carnegie Hall in 1982.\n\nOur critic found the music liberating in a dark era of totalitarian ideologies. \u201cIt is not so much a doctrine set to music as it is a revolt against doctrine.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf the individual has his unhampered say in music, he may manage to have it in other fields,\u201d he wrote. \u201cDictators should be suspicious of swing.\u201d\n\nPatrick Boehler contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. He\u2019s sober now 15 months, post finishing the movie. He has changed exponentially in the past 15 months. More than anybody I know. But it doesn\u2019t come without him struggling. It\u2019s not like, \u201cOh, I\u2019ve had my troubles with alcohol and then all of sudden they\u2019re just gone.\u201d Sometimes movies do paint things like that, and I think some of those things are misleading.\n\nVideo\n\nThe physicality is amazing. Your hair was really curly. Did you get a perm?\n\nYep, I got a perm. Yes, I did.\n\nI didn\u2019t know that you could even do that anymore.\n\nYes. It was a soft perm, because we didn\u2019t want it to be too curly. When you see Jeff\u2019s hair, you know, it\u2019s a distinctive feature. His hair is very specific. So Donald Mowat, \u2014 he\u2019s an amazing makeup artist \u2014 said, \u201cI think to get the kind of messiness that Jeff has, we should do a perm.\u201d And I was, like, \u2018I\u2019m always down for a perm, you know?\u2019\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow many have you had? Was it tough, chemically?\n\nIt was my first. And yeah, it was smelly.\n\nObviously when I said physicality, I meant the fact that you had to haul around your whole body with your arms and pretend you didn\u2019t have legs. How do you prepare for something like that?\n\nI spent almost a year with Jeff before we started shooting the movie. The first week that I met him, we all met up, we went to dinner in [a hotel] banquet room. Jeff took off his Genium Ottobock legs and showed me how he put them on, took them off, and how he moved around the room. And that was the very first moment that I saw him navigate a space without his bionic legs. And then over a year I saw it over and over and over again. When he would get on the floor, I would get on the floor with him, and it was a perspective and a height differentiation that was sort of infantilizing. People end up talking to you and treating you differently in a way, not knowing how to relate. Also one of the keys was \u2014 The New York Times did a Pulitzer Prize-winning piece on him. And I asked Jeff if there was any outtakes. That was really during the period of time where he was just totally lost. It was only a month or so after the event. Everything was raw. It\u2019s palpable, his feelings, and his eyes, and experience of what\u2019s going on. For me, behaviorally, it was a gold mine\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHad you spent this much time with a subject?\n\nOnly once before kind of, with a number of police officers when I was doing \u201cEnd of Watch.\u201d One of the police officers is one of my closest friends now. But nothing compares to this. I feel like it\u2019s so much more than a movie now. Because [Jeff\u2019s] my friend, and because all the people around him I know, and I love them. When you\u2019re with him, anything that you might normally complain about ends up seeming so petty and small. That\u2019s how he makes you feel. It\u2019s his spirit. He has a light.", "title": "Jake Gyllenhaal on Ambivalent Heroes and, Um, Perms", "authors": ["Cara Buckley", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ANTONIO, Jamaica \u2014 Port Antonio is known for its water. It is home to the Blue Lagoon, a placid pool fed by the Caribbean Sea that is surrounded by waterfalls, a lush green jungle and a string of idyllic beachside resorts.\n\nAll that water is a natural training camp for the band of girls who have their hearts set on an unusual dream for this island nation: to someday compete as synchronized swimmers in the Olympics .\n\nThe sport has never quite taken root here. Though the specialty has been an Olympic event for more than 30 years , it is far less established than other water sports, like diving and swimming, which have been around since the early 1900s. For a small country, Jamaica has won an impressive 78 Olympic medals , but there has never been a Jamaican synchronized swimming team in the Olympics. And for a country surrounded by water, it has never won an Olympic medal for an aquatic sport.", "title": "Jamaica Has Never Had Olympic Synchronized Swimmers. These Girls Want to Change That.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The James Beard Foundation on Monday named Clare Reichenbach as its chief executive. She replaces Susan Ungaro, who was the foundation\u2019s president for 11 years and formally stepped down from the leadership position at the end of December.\n\nMs. Reichenbach\u2019s appointment was announced by Frederic M. Seegal, the chairman of the nonprofit\u2019s board of trustees. Ms. Reichenbach\u2019s title is new, chosen by the board of directors as being more in line with standards in the corporate and nonprofit world. (There will no longer be a president.)\n\nA joint statement that Mr. Seegal issued with Emily Luchetti, the foundation\u2019s chairwoman emeritus, emphasized that the selection had been unanimous and that they had found \u201cthe right person to expand the impact and operational strength of the foundation on a global level.\u201d Ms. Reichenbach will take the reins on Feb. 20.\n\nPhoto\n\nUnlike Ms. Ungaro, who was the editor in chief of Family Circle, a magazine that featured food, Ms. Reichenbach, 44, admitted to having no culinary experience beyond that of \u201ca deeply impassioned home cook.\u201d She is the founder of CJJR Consulting in New York, whose clients include New York Public Radio and Samsung. Before that, she was with AMC Networks and BBC Worldwide.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA native of Oxford, England, she is a graduate of Oxford University and the Advanced Management Program of Harvard Business School. She has lived in New York for nearly 10 years and has attended a number of events at the James Beard Foundation.\n\nIn a telephone interview, she said that her goals included extending awareness of the foundation and bringing it greater global recognition through programs dealing with education diversity, women\u2019s issues and childhood nutrition. They lost another player when Eric Gordon, who is second on the team in scoring with 19.5 points a game, left early in the second quarter with lower back stiffness.\n\nHarden played a season-high 46 minutes and 26 seconds with Houston missing so many players.\n\nIt was his fourth 50-point game this season, and Tuesday\u2019s performance improved upon his previous career-high of 56 points, set in November against Utah.\n\nOrlando led by 2 points with about nine and a half minutes left before the Rockets used a 10-4 run to make it 101-97 with about seven minutes to go. Harden made two 3-pointers in that stretch, the second one coming as the shot clock was about to expire and with Shelvin Mack right in Harden\u2019s face.\n\nHouston didn\u2019t lead for long though, as Speights was fouled while making a 3-pointer and added the free throw to tie it seconds later.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Magic had a 2-point lead with about five and a half minutes left before Houston used a 6-2 run, with all its points from Harden, to take a 107-105 lead with about four minutes left.\n\nThe Rockets were up by 1 early in the third quarter when Harden scored all of the team\u2019s points in a 6-2 spurt that made it 64-59. Harden capped that run with his first 3-pointer of the game after missing all seven tries in the first half.\n\nHouston had pushed its lead to 7 later in the third after scoring four quick points. But the Magic used a 7-2 run, highlighted by a 3-pointer by Mario Hezonja, to get within 72-70 midway through the quarter.\n\nThe Magic tied it on a basket by Jonathon Simmons with about four minutes left in the third, but the Rockets used a 5-2 run to regain the lead, 83-80.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpeights made a 3-pointer to put Orlando back on top with just under a minute remaining in the quarter, but Houston scored the last 4 points of the quarter to take a 90-88 lead into the fourth.\n\nHarden found Luc Mbah a Moute for a layup for the first basket in that span and added a jump shot just before the shot clock expired for the other points.\n\nHarden piled up 16 points in the first quarter and had 24 by halftime despite his early 3-point shooting woes.\n\nOrlando led by 55-54 at halftime.", "title": "James Harden Sets Rockets Record With 60 Points", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s required to keep a show going for that long?\n\nAs many twists and turns as one can provide. When I first read the script, at the end I realized I knew less about the character than when I first started reading. And I thought, \u201cWhat a great trick that is\u201d \u2014 to retain a certain enigmatic aspect. It felt like the premise was perfectly suited to go in any direction and somehow find its way back on track again.\n\nHow did Nathan Lane end up on the show?\n\nThough the years, I\u2019ve had an arm\u2019s-length acquaintance with Nathan because we share an agent. I\u2019m a great fan of his, and he\u2019s been a lovely, faithful fan of mine. I had seen him in \u201cThe Iceman Cometh,\u201d and Nathan mentioned that he\u2019d love to do the show. So when his name was suggested, I mentioned that I personally would love to have him. I was being absolutely as selfish as I possibly could.\n\nIs there a turn you\u2019d to see Red take?\n\nA surprising one. I\u2019ll tell you something funny. I didn\u2019t watch much television growing up, and before I did \u201cBoston Legal,\u201d I had no understanding of what it was like for a viewer to look forward to finding out what was going to happen the next week. There will be an episode of \u201cThe Blacklist\u201d that is just fun and another that is very intense and then another that is rather ruthless and brutal. I still love the element of surprise, even for myself.\n\nYou often play the provocateur, and people tend to assume you are your characters.\n\nMy career had been split pretty evenly between good guys and bad guys until I finally grew into myself enough to play a decent antihero, where you can combine the two. The protagonists that I\u2019ve played tend to be people who make trouble. Or even if they don\u2019t make it, they certainly disrupt things. It\u2019s fun to do that in life as well. But I don\u2019t think I ever played myself.\n\nWere you surprised to read that Charlie Rose was accused of asking a female employee to watch \u201cSecretary,\u201d your movie of a sadomasochistic relationship, with him?", "title": "James Spader Still Lives for the Surprise of \u2018The Blacklist\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "He wrote for me from 1968 until the day he died [in 1991]. They\u2019re not always the most well known, the songs that I sang, but they\u2019re among the most beautiful. And the most tear-jerky, in a way, was when I left him. Why he went on asking me to interpret the songs that I had inspired I don\u2019t know \u2014 but perhaps he knew that I\u2019d be faithful at least to that.\n\nThe idea of taking the songs \u2014 which are so rooted in different styles, from pop to chanson to y\u00e9-y\u00e9 to reggae \u2014 and making them orchestral sounds counterintuitive. But I understand classical music was important to him. How so?\n\nA lot of the songs he wrote, not only for me but for others, were from classical music. So \u201cJane B.\u201d was Chopin.\n\nWhenever he wanted to give us something really beautiful, he sometimes wrote it on classical music \u2014 perhaps out of a sort of modesty, of always being so admiring of classical work that somehow he wanted to give us the best. From his pianist days \u2014 he was a pianist at a bar in Le Touquet [a seaside town in northern France], and his father was a classical musician \u2014 it was from his upbringing that he knew so much about classical music. Brahms was \u201cBaby Alone in Babylone.\u201d\n\nDid he listen to much classical music?\n\nHe did when his mother died. He had bouts of wanting to be sad, and then he would put on classical music. Glenn Gould he always had under his elbow. And he had, on his little table, a picture of Chopin, and Chopin\u2019s hand.\n\nPhoto\n\nIs it harder or simpler to sing songs that were written for you, that must bring up so many memories?\n\nWhen he first gave them to me, they were personal \u2014 and then I was not necessarily the best receiver. I sometimes thought that he had a hidden message. And, actually, when I listen to the words now, they\u2019re even more beautiful than I understood then. Many sad things have happened now, like Kate [one of her daughters, who died in 2013]. So if I think of anything, I sometimes think of her.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt sounds as if this project had its roots in that tragedy.\n\nI wasn\u2019t very good on my own. I didn\u2019t know what to do. I realized the importance of going into other people\u2019s lives, of going to the cinema \u2014 I\u2019d sometimes see three, four films a day, sometimes see two, three plays a week. To understand other people\u2019s stories, not to think about yourself so much. It helps, other people\u2019s stories. Somehow singing Serge\u2019s songs, and knowing that people would have memories, probably about when I sang them first, that\u2019s rather nice.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat was it like recording a sexually charged song like \u201cJe T\u2019Aime \u2026 Moi Non Plus,\u201d knowing it was written for Gainsbourg\u2019s ex, Brigitte Bardot, who did not want their recording of it released because she was married to someone else? Was that strange?\n\nNo, no \u2014 I didn\u2019t want anybody else to sing it! Serge rang me up years after that and he said, \u201cI\u2019ve got some bad news for you.\u201d And I said: \u201cWhat? Say it quickly, then.\u201d And he said, \u201cBrigitte\u2019s been on the phone and she wants to bring out \u2018Je T\u2019Aime\u2019 \u2014 her version.\u201d I remember thinking that that was quite just and proper, because it was her song. I still find her version very troubling \u2014 it\u2019s a lovely and gorgeous version \u2014 so, if anything, I have to thank her for not wanting it to come out.\n\nI understand you plan to publish your diaries?\n\nYes, I\u2019m trying to translate them into French, even now. There are funny things, charming things with Serge \u2014 but pretty depressing personal stuff. It was much more about how disheartened I was, of not being pretty.\n\nFrom the outside looking in, that\u2019s hard to believe. Few people have been more glamorous, or more universally considered beautiful.\n\nI know it must be annoying when people say that \u2014 I\u2019ve read about really beautiful people saying, \u201cWell, I didn\u2019t think I was much,\u201d and I think, \u201cOh God, with looks like that, I could have sunk a ship.\u201d It\u2019s true that if you\u2019re not with the person you love, and they\u2019re not looking at you, then it doesn\u2019t matter what you look like.", "title": "Jane Birkin on Love, Life and Serge Gainsbourg\u2019s Classical Roots", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nDuring a Grammy Awards show that largely shied away from discussing the entertainment industry\u2019s reckoning around sexual harassment and misconduct, Janelle Mon\u00e1e broke through.\n\nJust over two hours into the ceremony, Ms. Mon\u00e1e, an actress and recording artist, used her introduction of Kesha to deliver a message on behalf of women in the industry: \u201cWe come in peace, but we mean business.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just going on in Hollywood, it\u2019s not just going on in Washington, it\u2019s right here in our industry as well,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd just as we have the power to shape culture, we also have the power to undo a culture that does not serve us well.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics.
