She has starred in \u201cHidden Figures\u201d and \u201cMoonlight,\u201d and has been nominated for six Grammys for her music.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe delivered her remarks while wearing a \u201cTime\u2019s Up\u201d pin on her lapel, much like the actors and actresses who began the movement during January\u2019s Golden Globe Awards. While red carpet interviews and acceptance speeches at film awards shows have been filled with #MeToo and #TimesUp references, they were less present at the Grammys, and leaders at the top of the music industry have largely been unaffected.", "title": "Janelle Mon\u00e1e Brings a \u2018Time\u2019s Up\u2019 Message to the Grammy Awards", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Analysts and investors are unruffled by the impending departure of Ms. Yellen and installation of Mr. Powell. They have accepted Mr. Powell\u2019s assertions during the confirmation process that he intends to continue the Fed\u2019s current approach to monetary policy.\n\n\u201cThe way I think about it is, Jay Powell will be a reassuring force of continuity,\u201d said Vincent Reinhart, chief economist for Standish Mellon Asset Management.\n\nMs. Yellen is also leaving a clear road map. When the Fed began in October to reduce its holdings of Treasuries and mortgage bonds, which it purchased as part of its post-crisis stimulus campaign, it announced a multiyear timetable that it said would remain unchanged barring emergencies.\n\nThe Fed has made clear that the January meeting will be a place holder, not least because of the transition in leadership, and markets have taken the message. The headline on Morgan Stanley\u2019s preview of the January meeting: \u201cWhere\u2019s the Snooze Button?\u201d\n\nBut markets are equally convinced that the Fed will tighten policy for the sixth straight quarter at its next policy meeting in March, which will be Mr. Powell\u2019s first meeting as the chairman.\n\nMs. Yellen\u2019s priority was ensuring that the Fed did not raise rates too quickly; Mr. Powell could face the challenge of making sure that the Fed does not move too slowly.\n\nFed officials said as they embarked on the tightening process that they wanted to avoid the mechanical predictability of the previous tightening cycle between 2004 and 2006. Like the proverbial frog in the stovetop pot, investors found it easy to ignore the slow and steady increases.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Fed, wary of surprising markets, has once again fallen into a pattern of carefully signaling each rate hike \u2014 and markets, once again, are largely unconcerned. The ease of borrowing has increased over the last year, according to measures of financial conditions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey said that policy was too gradual and predictable\u201d during the last tightening cycle, said Mr. Reinhart, who played a key role in the last round of rate increases when he was head of the Fed\u2019s division of monetary affairs. \u201cAnd now it is predictable and gradual and even slower.\u201d\n\nUnder Ms. Yellen, the unemployment rate has declined to 4.1 percent from 6.7 percent in February 2014, while inflation has remained below the Fed\u2019s 2 percent target. During the first three years of her tenure, in particular, Ms. Yellen repeatedly found reasons to argue that the Fed should delay raising interest rates, extending the Fed\u2019s stimulus campaign.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nScott Sumner, an economist at George Mason University, wrote in an October appraisal that Ms. Yellen\u2019s performance was \u201cnear perfection.\u201d He added that, at the end of her tenure, Ms. Yellen will likely have achieved the Fed\u2019s dual mandate of maximizing employment and stabilizing inflation \u201cbetter than any other chair in history.\u201d\n\nThere were plenty of critics along the way. A coalition of labor and community groups, the Fed Up campaign, pressed Ms. Yellen throughout her term to increase the Fed\u2019s stimulus campaign. Republicans and conservative economists fretted that the Fed was doing too much.\n\nChris Rupkey, chief financial economist at MUFG Union Bank in New York, said that the persistence of low interest rates had been painful for banks and other financial firms, many of which also resented Ms. Yellen\u2019s focus on strengthening financial regulation. \u201cIt\u2019s not goodbye, good luck from Wall Street,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s don\u2019t let the door hit you on the backside on your way out.\u201d\n\nEleanor Herlands, a 92-year-old retiree in Stamford, Conn., said that she and other savers had suffered during the long years of low interest rates.\n\n\u201cThey pushed people to buy stocks, people that knew nothing about the stock market,\u201d said Mrs. Herlands, who opted instead to keep her money in savings accounts. \u201cI made my own choices, but I never dreamed that it would go on this long. Now I\u2019m pleased that I\u2019m finally getting at least a little relief.\u201d\n\nShe said she was now earning an average of 1.6 percent on her accounts.\n\nMs. Yellen, 71, is the first person in modern history to serve a four-year term as Fed chairman without being appointed to a second term. She has not said what she plans to do next.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe leaves behind some challenges for her successor.\n\nFed officials in recent months have begun to debate whether the central bank should adjust its approach to monetary policy before the next downturn. The Fed\u2019s traditional approach is to stimulate growth by reducing interest rates. But rates, which reflect real borrowing costs and inflation, are expected to remain low for the foreseeable future.\n\nThe potential solutions mostly involve embracing more inflation.\n\nThe current economic expansion also is approaching the end of its ninth year, one of the longest periods of uninterrupted economic growth in American history.\n\nSome forecasters say they can see clouds on the horizon, though a little squinting is required.\n\nOliver Jones, markets economist at Capital Economics, predicted the Fed\u2019s march toward higher interest rates may finally begin to pinch financial markets by the second half of the year \u2014 just as the stimulus provided by the tax cuts is beginning to fade.\n\n\u201cAs growth in the U.S. economy starts to slow, we think that the long-running rally in the U.S. stock market will go into reverse,\u201d Mr. Jones wrote in his predictions for 2018. He added, \u201cHistory suggests that a correction in the U.S. stock market would be contagious, even if growth in the rest of the world generally remains healthy as we expect.\u201d", "title": "Janet Yellen\u2019s Fitting Finale: Fed Plans to Stand Still", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Geri Allen\u2019s final album as a leader was \u201cGrand River Crossings,\u201d a solo piano recording from 2013 released on Mot\u00e9ma Records.\n\nDiversity in the Mainstream\n\n\u2018JAZZ-AGEDDON:\u2019 RAY ANGRY, WARREN WOLF AND FRIENDS The Blue Note, Jan. 22\n\nYears ago, if you put a few musicians from one of jazz\u2019s major creative streams into a room, you could more or less predict the registers they would hit and the roles each instrument would play. Not today. For three nights in January, the pianist Ray Angry and the vibraphonist Warren Wolf took over the Blue Note, inviting a sundry crew of collaborators to participate in what they called the \u201cJazz-ageddon\u201d series, and the result was a multihued patchwork.\n\nMr. Angry and Mr. Wolf come from opposite ends of the same general spectrum. Mr. Angry has been a first-call pianist for pop acts like John Legend and Joss Stone, but his big influences are jazz and gospel. Mr. Wolf is a vibraphonist who\u2019s most often heard in acoustic combos, playing straight-ahead jazz and its offshoots. On Jan. 22, they were joined by seven other musicians, including the saxophonists Tia Fuller and James Carter, the bassist Ben Williams and the drummer Marcus Gilmore.\n\nThe music included \u201cThe Community Theme Song,\u201d a samba-inflected tune by the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon with a gently lingering melody; David Bowie\u2019s \u201cSpace Oddity\u201d; and a surprise cameo from Black Thought of the Roots, who rapped a casually prodigious freestyle over the beat from Nas\u2019s \u201cOne Love,\u201d played by Mr. Wolf, Mr. Williams and Mr. Gilmore.\n\nThere was just one moment when the musicians fell into a crisp, midtempo swing feel, and it was on a song you wouldn\u2019t expect: \u201cMy First Mine,\u201d an early-90s garage-rock scorcher from the indie-rock band Pavement.\n\nWarren Wolf returns to New York March 6-10, playing a run at Birdland with the Cyrus Chestnut Quartet.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMythmaking for the Present Day\n\nJEN SHYU The Jazz Gallery, Jan. 24\n\nPhoto\n\nJen Shyu\u2019s latest song cycle, \u201cNine Doors,\u201d grew out of loss. After her friend, the Indonesian shadow puppeteer Sri Joko Raharjo, died in a car accident with his wife and infant child, only his 4-year-old daughter survived. With her in mind, Ms. Shyu set about culling folkloric tales from traditions across East and Southeast Asia, and created her own syncretic saga for the present day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe work is more than conceptual inquiry or personal discovery. At the Jazz Gallery, Ms. Shyu turned the stage into a space of imaginative ritual; she framed storytelling and mythmaking as contemporary phenomena \u2014 even necessities. She opened the performance by leading the room in a stretching exercise, then explained the story of the crash in a somber but welcoming tone. Standing by the piano, she explained how the collision had occurred, almost acting as if the instrument were the vehicle.\n\nMany minutes later, after a song of cold, raging grief \u2014 Ms. Shyu singing in a blustery howl, clawing at the strings of the Japanese biwa \u2014 she wandered back toward the piano. Eventually it became clear that she was simply retrieving an instrument perched along the wall, but for a moment my breath stopped. The piano still seemed to represent the scene of the crash, and it felt as if she were re-entering a space of peril. That magic remained throughout the set: A simple jazz club stage became a territory of belief, narrative and wonder.\n\nJen Shyu\u2019s \u201cSong of Silver Geese\u201d was released in November on Pi Recordings. It was on our list of the year\u2019s best albums.\n\nFree, Forceful and Unified\n\nLOGAN RICHARDSON QUARTET Smalls, Jan. 29\n\nBy certain appearances, the alto saxophonist Logan Richardson\u2019s performance at Smalls should have made a listener feel impatient or unfocused. Leading a standard sax-piano-bass-drums quartet, Mr. Richardson played eight original tunes, each one tumbling out with a sense of bold disassembly. Their sections were hard to define; the band swelled and crested without settling into closely knit patterns. Often, polyrhythms were implied, and then the band quickly started to play outside and around them. The group sometimes shambled into a free-flowing rubato right in the middle of a fast tune, but it maintained conviction, and avoided melodrama.\n\nBut there was a kind of rich cohesion here, even though you only really felt it in retrospect. Partly that\u2019s because of the confidence and strength brought by Mr. Richardson\u2019s band mates: John Escreet on piano, Harish Raghavan on bass and Kenny Grohowski on drums. They rendered each individual note with stark, upstanding force, holding firm amid the swarm.\n\nAnd as a saxophone soloist, Mr. Richardson went in every direction but the one you expected; he played arcing, bluesy, honeydew phrases without submitting to clich\u00e9. He\u2019s fond of soul-inflected grace notes, but he always articulates them thickly and cleanly, rolling into and out of them. In his hands, every warm gesture is a forceful statement.\n\nLogan Richardson\u2019s \u201cShift\u201d was released in 2016 on Blue Note Records.\n\nA Large Ensemble With an Expansive Palette\n\nJOHN HOLLENBECK\u2019S LARGE ENSEMBLE Le Poisson Rouge, Jan. 30\n\nPhoto\n\nWe\u2019re about 70 years into the eerie afterlife of the jazz big band. What started out as an engine for popular American dance music hasn\u2019t had much to do with dance floors \u2014 or pop culture \u2014 since the end of the 1940s. Since then, the big band has been a medium for expansively minded composers, who aren\u2019t aiming for dancers but have a lot to say about physical movement as it occurs on the bandstand, within the music.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJohn Hollenbeck, a drummer and composer, is one of today\u2019s most dynamic orchestral jazz bandleaders, a fact that\u2019s reinforced by the release of \u201cAll Can Work,\u201d the arresting new album from his Large Ensemble. With this 19-piece group (20 including its conductor, J.C. Sanford), he pulls from the annals of that big-band afterlife: Gil Evans\u2019s work with Miles Davis in the 1950s; Bob Brookmeyer\u2019s slyly locomotive arrangements of the 1970s and \u201980s; the lush, tangled vibrancy of Guillermo Klein\u2019s music from the 1990s and early 2000s.\n\nThe John Hollenbeck Large Ensemble\u2019s CD release performance began with \u201cElf\u201d \u2014 an extended composition based around \u201cIsfahan,\u201d the deliquescent Billy Strayhorn ballad \u2014 and ended on a bridling, crosshatched rendition of Kraftwerk\u2019s \u201cThe Model.\u201d In between were four Hollenbeck originals, all from the new album, each one doused in citrusy, corrugated harmonies, with currents that built big circles around crescent-shaped melodies. The record\u2019s title track was a highlight, with the vocalist Theo Bleckmann singing lyrics drawn from messages that the trumpeter Laurie Frink had written to Mr. Hollenbeck soon before her death in 2013. The trumpet section played a bobbing, elliptical pattern based upon Ms. Frink\u2019s instructional exercises, and Mr. Bleckmann sang in a gentle, matter-of-fact tone: \u201cI will miss you all, and especially the music.\u201d\n\nJohn Hollenbeck\u2019s Large Ensemble just released \u201cAll Can Work\u201d on New Amsterdam Records.", "title": "January in Live Jazz: 5 Standout Shows", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "TOKYO \u2014 On matters of history, Japan and South Korea can never seem to agree to disagree.\n\nThree days after South Korea said it would not roll back a 2015 accord over women forced into sexual slavery for the Japanese military during World War II, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan rejected on Friday \u201cadditional measures\u201d sought by Seoul.\n\nThe issue even threatened to jeopardize his attendance at the Winter Olympics\u2019 opening ceremony next month.\n\nResponding to a call by South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, for a renewed and sincere apology to the so-called comfort women, Mr. Abe told reporters, \u201cWe can by no means accept South Korea\u2019s unilateral request for additional measures.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Japan-South Korea deal was a promise between countries,\u201d Mr. Abe said. \u201cIt is an international and universal principle to keep it.\u201d", "title": "Japan Balks at Calls for New Apology to South Korea Over \u2018Comfort Women\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA volcano erupted Tuesday in Japan, killing one soldier who was training nearby and injuring more than a dozen people, including several at a ski resort, officials said.\n\nThe eruption of Mount Kusatsu-Shirane triggered avalanches and launched debris that smashed a gondola and hit people on ski slopes.\n\nSeven members of Japan\u2019s military who were training in the area were caught in one of the avalanches and had to be taken to a hospital, the Ministry of Defense said. One of the soldiers was later confirmed to have died, officials said.\n\nTen people were hit by rocks at the ski resort, injuring five seriously, the public broadcaster NHK reported, citing the police. Five others were hurt by debris that smashed the windows of a gondola.", "title": "Japan Volcano Eruption Kills Soldier and Injures Skiers at Resort", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "PRAGUE \u2014 In a move that could signify the end of his N.H.L. career, Jaromir Jagr has been reassigned by the Calgary Flames to the Kladno Knights, a team he owns in his native Czech Republic.\n\nThe move on Monday came after Calgary placed Jagr, 45, on unconditional waivers for the purpose of terminating his N.H.L. contract so he could return to Europe to finish the season.\n\nKladno, just west of Prague, is Jagr\u2019s hometown.\n\nJagr thanked Calgary \u201cfor giving me the immense opportunity to be a part of their team and continue my N.H.L. career,\u201d adding, \u201cI am very disappointed that things did not turn out as we had hoped.\u201d\n\nJagr had only a goal and six assists in 22 games for Calgary after signing a one-year, $1 million contract on Oct. 4. He has not played since Dec. 31 because of what the team called a lower-body injury.", "title": "Jaromir Jagr Returns to the Czech Republic to Continue His Career", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter a sluggish start to the off-season, the Mets struck a deal to bring back a key piece of last season\u2019s lineup. Outfielder Jay Bruce agreed to a three-year, $39-million deal with the Mets on Wednesday night, according to multiple people familiar with the negotiations.\n\nThe people were not authorized to discuss the deal publicly because it was pending a physical examination, and the team had not yet officially announced it.\n\nBruce is expected to play primarily in right field but he could see action at first base, one person familiar with the deal said. The Mets sought a reunion with Bruce, a three-time All-Star, because of his positional versatility, his reliable power and his experienced presence in the clubhouse.\n\nBruce, who will turn 31 in April, was the most consistent power hitter in the Mets\u2019 lineup last season and a well-liked teammate who quickly became one of the team\u2019s veteran leaders. The Mets acquired Bruce from the Cincinnati Reds at the nonwaiver trade deadline in 2016 as they made a push for a National League wild-card berth, but he struggled until the final weeks of that season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Mets brought him back for 2017, exercising his $13 million option, and Bruce was a bright spot on a team that struggled. He hit .256 with 29 home runs and 75 runs batted in over 103 games before he was traded to the Cleveland Indians on Aug. 9 for cash and a prospect.", "title": "Jay Bruce Will Return to Mets on a 3-Year, $39 Million Deal", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, on Friday injected himself into one of the most contentious political debates in the United States, announcing that he and his wife had donated $33 million to a college scholarship program geared toward young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children.\n\nMr. Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, gave the money to the nonprofit Dream.US. The group said the donation, the largest in its history, would finance scholarships for 1,000 high school graduates who have been allowed to stay in the United States under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, known as DACA.\n\nThe roughly 800,000 so-called Dreamers affected by the program face an uncertain future after President Trump said last year that he planned to end the protections.\n\nUncertainty continued to swirl around the program this week, with a federal judge ruling that the Trump administration must maintain it as a legal fight over the president\u2019s decision proceeds and Mr. Trump sending mixed signals about his willingness to strike a deal with Congress that would offer Dreamers a path to citizenship.", "title": "Jeff Bezos Jumps Into \u2018Dreamer\u2019 Fight With Gift for Scholarships", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "As he was shaping Amazon into one of the world\u2019s most valuable companies, Mr. Bezos developed a reputation as a brilliant but mysterious and coldblooded corporate titan. He preferred to hunker down in Amazon\u2019s hometown, Seattle, at least partly because he thought it was better for Amazon\u2019s growing business, largely avoiding public causes and the black-tie circuit.\n\nBut while Mr. Bezos \u2014 who at 54 is the world\u2019s richest person, with a net worth of more than $100 billion \u2014 can afford virtually any luxury, obscurity is no longer among them.\n\nAmazon, now a behemoth valued at more than $600 billion, has become one of the faces of \u201cbig tech,\u201d along with Apple, Alphabet\u2019s Google and Facebook. These companies are facing a backlash. Amazon is under the microscope for what critics say is its corrosive effect on jobs and competition, and Mr. Bezos has become a b\u00eate noire for President Trump, who repeatedly singles out him and Amazon for scorn on Twitter.\n\n\u201cPeople are starting to get scared of Amazon,\u201d said Steve Case, a co-founder of America Online, who recently started an investment fund focused on start-ups in underserved areas, with Mr. Bezos among its contributors. \u201cIf Jeff continues to hang out in Seattle, he\u2019s going to get a lot more incoming. Even for just defense reasons, he has to now play offense.\u201d\n\nMr. Bezos\u2019 portfolio of other ventures has thrust him farther into the spotlight. In October 2013, he bought The Washington Post for $250 million, jump-starting a renaissance of the paper. In 2016, Mr. Bezos bought a $23 million home in Washington, one of the city\u2019s most expensive, which is undergoing extensive renovations to make it a suitable party spot for the city\u2019s political class. Nearby neighbors include former President Barack Obama and his family, and Mr. Trump\u2019s daughter Ivanka Trump and her husband, Jared Kushner.", "title": "Jeff Bezos, Mr. Amazon, Steps Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The piece, which is almost 12 meters high and 8 wide (40 by 26 feet), is one of Mr. Koons\u2019s largest. It is intended to evoke the hand of the Statue of Liberty, a gift from France to the people of the United States. Mr. Koons\u2019s sculpture, made of polychrome bronze, stainless steel and aluminum, depicts a hand holding a bunch of multicolor flowers.\n\nIn the letter to Lib\u00e9ration, the signatories objected to the fact that Mr. Koons\u2019s donation extended only to the \u201cidea\u201d of the work, not to its production and installation, which required donations, some of which qualified for tax deductions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nBack to Square 1 on immigration\n\n\u2022 Senator Chuck Schumer has withdrawn an offer to fully fund President Trump\u2019s proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, the biggest gesture the Democratic leader had made to try to secure an immigration deal.\n\nMitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, says he will allow a \u201cfair and open\u201d immigration debate if the fate of the hundreds of thousands of young immigrants known as Dreamers is not resolved by Feb. 8. Le Guin, Academy Awards: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado, where legalized marijuana has spawned a $1 billion industry, threatened to block all nominees to the Justice Department until the new policy is dropped.\n\nRepresentative Dana Rohrabacher, a California Republican, laid the blame at the feet of Mr. Sessions, saying he \u201cbetrayed us on this.\u201d A 2014 law co-sponsored by Mr. Rohrabacher prohibits the Justice Department from going after users, growers or sellers of medical marijuana in states where it is legal. The use of recreational marijuana became legal in California on Jan. 1. Even Matt Gaetz, the Florida representative last seen trying to get the special counsel Robert Mueller fired, said the new policy showed Mr. Sessions\u2019s \u201cdesire to pursue an antiquated, disproven dogma instead of the will of the American people.\u201d\n\nNone of this will bother the attorney general, a lifelong antidrug crusader who runs the Justice Department like it\u2019s 1988, when the war on drugs was at full throttle and the kneejerk political response was to be as punitive as possible. Mr. Sessions has long held a particular enmity for pot, which he continues to demonize. \u201cGood people don\u2019t smoke marijuana,\u201d he said in 2016.\n\nThis is wrongheaded for so many reasons. It\u2019s out of step with current knowledge about the risks and benefits of marijuana, which the federal government classified as a Schedule I drug in 1970. By that definition, it has no accepted medical use and is more dangerous than cocaine. Obviously this is outdated, and Congress needs to do its part by removing marijuana from Schedule I. But nothing is stopping Mr. Sessions in the meantime from accepting scientific facts.\n\nThe new policy is also blind to the massive cultural shift toward legalization that has been happening at the state level in recent years, after decades of outrageously harsh punishments that have fallen disproportionately on the shoulders of people of color. Eight states have now legalized marijuana for recreational use. California is now the world\u2019s largest legal market for pot. Twenty-nine states and the District of Columbia allow marijuana to be used for medical purposes. By the end of this year, it is estimated that legal marijuana will be a $9 billion industry.", "title": "Opinion | Jeff Sessions\u2019s Endless War on Marijuana", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "In an oddly slow winter across baseball, with big-name free agents such as Eric Hosmer, Jake Arrieta and J. D. Martinez still available, the Mets have been among the biggest spenders to date. They dished out nearly $54 million to sign outfielder Jay Bruce, reliever Anthony Swarzak and first baseman Adrian Gonzalez.\n\nBut that still pales in comparison with the last off-season, when the Mets spent nearly $120 million on free agents (mostly to re-sign outfielder Yoenis Cespedes) and ended up spending the second-most of any team on free agents, according to Spotrac.com. But their overall payroll still remained outside the top 10.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThrough much of the 2000s, before the team had to rebuild its roster and deal with its entanglement in the Bernard L. Madoff financial scandal, the Mets regularly ranked in the top five in payroll. In 2013, when the payroll dropped to $93 million, Fred Wilpon, a Mets\u2019 owner and their chief executive officer, said the team would spend money when it became competitive again.\n\nThat began midway through the 2015 season, when the Mets traded for several players, including Cespedes, and eventually reached the World Series behind a talented group of young and inexpensive starting pitchers that included Jacob deGrom, Noah Syndergaard, Matt Harvey and Steven Matz. But injuries and underperformance led to a disappointing 2017 season with a 70-92 record during which the Mets traded away several veteran players, and the team does not appear to have any desire to dig deeply into its wallet soon.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d rather look at what we can do in terms of wins and losses,\u201d Jeff Wilpon said. \u201cBeing top five in payroll, I don\u2019t think that won us a World Series. We\u2019re set out to make the playoffs and do well deep into the playoffs and try to win the World Series, not try to be the top five in payroll.\u201d\n\nWilpon admitted that the team\u2019s attendance and revenue were indeed factors in the following year\u2019s payroll. Their attendance saw the third-biggest drop in baseball from 2016, when they reached the National League wild card game, to last season, according to Baseball-Reference.com.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t want the revenues so far to lag behind what the payroll would be,\u201d Wilpon said. \u201cIt all goes into the mix in determining what we should do. But I get where the fan perception is. It\u2019s not lost on any of us. We have a plan, and because we believe in Sandy and the baseball department we\u2019re going to stick with that plan.\u201d", "title": "Jeff Wilpon Makes Rare Appearance to Defend Mets\u2019 Spending", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJEFFERSON\u2019S DAUGHTERS\n\nThree Sisters, White and Black, in a Young America\n\nBy Catherine Kerrison\n\nIllustrated. 425 pp. Ballantine Books. $28.\n\nFawn Brodie would be astonished \u2014 and gratified. In 1974, her biography \u201cThomas Jefferson: An Intimate History\u201d contended that the third president had fathered children with his slave Sally Hemings. For this, Catherine Kerrison, a professor of American history at Villanova University, accurately notes, Brodie was \u201cexcoriated by a cadre of Jefferson experts.\u201d A lot has changed, and largely because of the work of Annette Gordon-Reed, who took seriously Hemings family stories and, bolstered by a DNA study, convinced nearly all scholars, including Kerrison, that Brodie was correct. \u201cJefferson\u2019s Daughters,\u201d Kerrison\u2019s beautifully written book, takes the relationship\u2019s existence as a given.\n\nAnd so, to a nuanced study of Jefferson\u2019s two white daughters, Martha (born 1772) and Maria (born 1778), she innovatively adds a discussion of his only enslaved daughter, Harriet Hemings (born 1801). The result is a stunning if unavoidably imbalanced book, combining detailed treatments of Martha\u2019s and Maria\u2019s experiences with imaginative attempts to reconstruct Harriet\u2019s life.\n\nKerrison first examines the ill-fated marriage of Thomas Jefferson and the young widow Martha Wayles Skelton. Not ill-fated because of a lack of love or resources, but because of Martha\u2019s repeated problems with childbirth, which caused her death in 1782. Alone of all their children, the two daughters survived into adulthood. Kerrison\u2019s account of the girls\u2019 residence with their father in Paris in the 1780s includes vivid descriptions of the streetscape and architecture they encountered, as well as of the impact of their divergent educational experiences. While the vivacious Martha had five years of rigorous convent education, her sister Maria had less than two. As a result, the older girl, Kerrison contends, later stressed the importance of educating the daughters born to her and her husband, Thomas Mann Randolph, whereas Maria was content to be a conventional wife of the planter Jack Eppes.\n\nThe lives of four Virginia families \u2014 Jeffersons, Randolphs, Eppeses and Hemingses \u2014 were intertwined. Sally Hemings, daughter of Jefferson\u2019s father-in-law by his mulatto slave Elizabeth Hemings, arrived in the Jefferson household in Paris in 1787 at the age of 14 assigned to be the child Maria\u2019s companion. Following Hemings\u2019s oral history, Kerrison relates how Sally, knowing she could claim freedom by remaining in France when Jefferson returned home in 1789, negotiated a promise of eventual freedom for herself and all her children, who were by parentage seven-eighths white \u2014 a promise kept in part by Martha Randolph after her father\u2019s death in 1826. Jefferson listed Beverley, the oldest boy, born 1798, and his younger sister, Harriet, as \u201crun\u201d in 1822, but other sources reveal that he quietly facilitated their departure.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe book\u2019s most innovative chapters attempt to reconstruct, from scattered fragments, Harriet\u2019s life in slavery and freedom. At Monticello, she and her mother \u2014 along with the Randolph family \u2014 lived as adjuncts to the plantation\u2019s master. The house was designed solely for Jefferson\u2019s comfort; Kerrison comments that \u201cfamily life, however, was architecturally all but invisible\u201d there; the master\u2019s white and black dependents lived and worked in small, inconvenient or upstairs rooms. By age 14, Harriet was put to work on a spinning jenny, suggesting to Kerrison that Jefferson might have thought he was training her adequately \u201cfor her future role as a housewife in a working-class household.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 1873, Harriet\u2019s younger brother Madison offered deliberately opaque clues about her, declaring that she was \u201cpassing\u201d and had married a prosperous white man in Washington, D.C. Kerrison identified 58 \u201cHarriets\u201d who wed in Washington between 1822 and 1830. She takes readers along on her research journey through disparate records, but ultimately concludes that Harriet Hemings \u201cwill keep her secret.\u201d\n\nThe last chapter, \u201cLegacies,\u201d ruminates on the fate of each of the women from a contemporary perspective. Maria, who like her mother died young from childbirth, leads Kerrison to point out that current attacks on women\u2019s reproductive health threaten \u201cto return women to the conditions endured by their 19th-century forebears,\u201d making Maria\u2019s fate \u201cboth timely and crucial.\u201d Martha and her daughters prompt Kerrison\u2019s musings on women\u2019s education, for \u201cin spite of all their scholarly attainments, they remained, after all, women,\u201d with no obvious way to use their learning in their own day. And Harriet, who passed as white, most likely abandoning her family in the process, prompts Kerrison to wonder about the persistence of racism in American society. Why, she asks, \u201cdo the discredited ideologies of gender and race continue to control and separate Americans so powerfully?\u201d", "title": "Jefferson\u2019s Three Daughters \u2014 Two Free, One Enslaved", "authors": ["Mary Beth Norton", "Catherine Kerrison"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI knew that it was always going to be important to get the message out, because I knew everything that was going on that people didn\u2019t know about,\u201d Dokic said. \u201cI\u2019ve been thinking about it for a while and I just wasn\u2019t ready until now.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDokic first made a splash on the tennis scene at Wimbledon in 1999, stunning top-seeded Martina Hingis, 6-2, 6-0, in the first round on her way to the quarterfinals. A year later, she reached the semifinals at Wimbledon and at the Sydney Olympics.\n\nThough her rise was swift, her father\u2019s dark, looming interference consistently eclipsed her bright career. His public outbursts at Grand Slam tournaments were well documented, from smashing a reporter\u2019s phone at Wimbledon to throwing salmon at the players\u2019 restaurant at the United States Open because he considered it overpriced. But Dokic was reluctant to acknowledge the abuse during her career.\n\n\u201cI wish I had done it while I was playing, but it just wasn\u2019t the time,\u201d Dokic said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t ready to talk about it.\u201d\n\nThe cruelty began in Yugoslavia, where Dokic spotted bodies floating in a river. She eventually fled Croatia for Australia with her ethnically Serbian family when she was a small child. She enjoyed picking up tennis, but pressure from her father to excel in the sport, she says, quickly became violent.\n\n\u201cHis huge right hand strikes my 6-year-old cheeks \u2014 once, twice, three times rapidly,\u201d she writes of what she described as her first beating. \u201cThe shock of the smack is more severe than the pain of his hand against my cheek. He has never done this.\u201d\n\nBy the time she was 14, the police were called to the family\u2019s hotel room amid a beating at a junior tournament, and her father was taken into custody. Dokic denied the abuse.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t budge,\u201d she writes. \u201cI don\u2019t even cry now. I am emotionless. I treat the Victoria Police like an opponent on the tennis court; I don\u2019t give them a thing. I am cold. They can\u2019t break me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThough her tennis career took off here, Dokic often felt ostracized and isolated in Australia, which she believes was caused by jealousy and xenophobia, as well as her father\u2019s behavior.\n\n\u201cYou wouldn\u2019t have to speak English to know that we, the Dokics, are not welcome,\u201d she writes. \u201cThere\u2019s palpable annoyance that a Serbian refugee has been awarded a state tennis scholarship. Even though I have won everything, beaten everyone, am No. 1 in Australia in multiple age groups, it\u2019s evident that some parents don\u2019t think a foreign kid with an erratic father who rattles the fence to distract their children from serving correctly should be getting help from the Institute.\u201d\n\nDokic now contends that members of the news media who glibly covered her father\u2019s outbursts should have shown more concern for the teenage girl in his grips and understood that his private behavior was likely worse.\n\nMany in Australian tennis suspected that Damir Dokic was abusive, and some even said they saw bruises on Jelena\u2019s body.\n\nNow that she is opening up about the abuse she once denied, the tennis community is responding. In a statement after her book\u2019s release, Tennis Australia praised Dokic\u2019s courage and defended its actions during her playing days.\n\n\u201cThere were many in tennis at the time who were concerned for Jelena\u2019s welfare, and many who tried to assist with what was a difficult family situation,\u201d the federation said in the statement. \u201cSome officials even went as far as lodging police complaints, which, without cooperation from those directly involved, unfortunately could not be fully investigated.\u201d\n\nDokic now writes that persistent beatings occurred as she traveled the tour with her father \u2014 including one long session in Montreal in 1999 that left her nearly unconscious. She finally broke free from him in 2002, but she also lost his direction and discipline, which had brought her to the top of the sport.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs much as he did negative things, he had certain things he did provide for me,\u201d she said in the interview. \u201cMy father definitely knew, tennis-wise, what he was doing. Everything was organized, and the decisions that he was making tennis-wise were the correct ones.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExcept one.\n\nDokic\u2019s father had forced her to switch from representing Australia to representing her native Yugoslavia in 2001, which alienated many in Australia and deprived her of support once she left him. When she faced top-seeded Lindsay Davenport in the first round of the Australian Open after switching, the crowd expressed its displeasure.\n\n\u201cEven with all the physical abuse and everything else, that\u2019s actually the one thing that I could take back, if I could,\u201d Dokic said. \u201cI never wanted to do that, and I never agreed with it. It was a disgraceful decision and something that I really hated that he did and made me do.\u201d\n\nEventually Dokic was again representing Australia after navigating the depths of a depression that had her considering suicide. She made a fairy-tale run to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open in 2009 but was unable to sustain the surge.\n\nThat year, Dokic first acknowledged some abuse at her father\u2019s hands, in an interview with the Australian magazine Sport & Style. Damir Dokic did not deny the accusations but played them down, telling the Serbian newspaper Blic that \u201cthere was no child that was not beaten by parents \u2014 the same with Jelena.\u201d\n\nDamir Dokic then threatened to blow up Claire Bergin, the Australian ambassador to Serbia, and was arrested and jailed for 15 months after the police found a cache of weapons in his home. It is the only jail sentence he has served. He could not be reached for comment for this article.\n\nDokic, 34, was wrapping up her tennis career by 2013.\n\n\u201cI love tennis. I always have, and I always will,\u201d she said. \u201c Even though I\u2019ve had a lot of bad moments ultimately because of tennis, I would still definitely recommend the sport.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThough the issue hasn\u2019t received as much attention in recent years, tour contemporaries of Dokic\u2019s such as Mirjana Lucic-Baroni and Mary Pierce also said they had dealt with abusive fathers, and such abuse was seen as endemic in women\u2019s tennis at the turn of the millennium.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDokic said she hadn\u2019t spoken to other players who had suffered similarly but hoped her book would help.\n\n\u201cMy book can change a lot of things,\u201d she said. \u201cThe conversation has now started on these things, what can be done. That\u2019s a positive thing.\u201d\n\nIn an interview at the Brisbane International this month, Lucic-Baroni said that the \u201cUnbreakable\u201d excerpts she had read rang all too true.\n\n\u201cMy heart broke for her,\u201d she said, adding that she couldn\u2019t finish the book. \u201cIt\u2019s tough because I\u2019ve lived it. I know every feeling that she felt, all too well, unfortunately.\u201d\n\nLucic-Baroni, who had her own fairy-tale run at the Australian Open by reaching the semifinals last year, said she had felt she and Dokic shared an unspoken bond.\n\n\u201cWe are members of this unfortunate club, so to speak,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019ve never discussed it, but I knew about her and she knew about me. It\u2019s a really tough cycle, and it\u2019s not something that you\u2019re going to talk to somebody about.\u201d\n\nThe Women\u2019s Tennis Association, not blamed by Dokic but often scrutinized as these patterns of abuse in the sport emerged, offered her a note of support upon the book\u2019s publication.\n\n\u201cThe WTA is steadfast in its commitment to provide a respectful, healthy and safe environment for all WTA players and worked closely with Jelena throughout her career on the WTA Tour,\u201d the organization said in a statement. \u201cWe\u2019re glad that she has finally been able to break her silence.\u201d", "title": "Jelena Dokic Recounts Her Rise in Tennis With an Abusive Father", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNo one wanted their name on it,\u201d Mr. Lefkowitz recalled in an interview with The New York Times in 2002, \u201cbecause the New York City unions were very articulate in their opposition to the law.\u201d\n\nWhile the Taylor Law made instigating, encouraging or condoning public employee strikes illegal, it replaced an even harsher statute, the 1947 Condon-Wadlin Act. That law had not only barred strikes but also penalized striking workers with dismissal. Regulations drafted under the new law also protected workers against reprisals for organizing.\n\nThough the Taylor Law was often flouted, it provided for painful penalties, including hefty fines and loss of a union\u2019s automatic dues deductions from employees\u2019 paychecks. It also mandated binding arbitration for vital workers, including police officers and firefighters, and created a cadre of skilled negotiators.\n\n\u201cMediators must have the facility to listen to what the negotiators are saying and to hear priorities and demands that may not be articulated explicitly,\u201d Mr. Lefkowitz said in 2005. \u201cWhen they start making progress, more trade-offs follow pretty quickly, once you can break the ice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBy granting public employees the right to organize and bargain collectively, the law expanded the political leverage unions wielded over elected officials.\n\n\u201cPeople began to realize that public employees have a weapon that exceeds the right to strike in the private sector,\u201d Mr. Lefkowitz said in 2002. \u201cThey can vote their bosses out.\u201d\n\nJerome Lefkowitz was born on March 24, 1931, in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx to Jack Lefkowitz, a garment industry executive, and the former Sue Horowitz. Both his parents were active in Jewish organizations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter graduating from Christopher Columbus High School, he earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in history from New York University and a law degree from Columbia, where he later taught.\n\nHe served in the Army in West Germany in the mid-1950s, began his career as an assistant state attorney general and later served as counsel to the New York State Department of Labor and as deputy state industrial commissioner.\n\nIn addition to his son Jay, he is survived by his wife, the former Myrna Weishaut; two other sons, Mark and Alan; a daughter, Miriam Lefkowitz; a brother, Leonard; and 10 grandchildren.\n\nMr. Lefkowitz resigned as deputy chairman of the Employment Relations Board in 1987 to become deputy counsel of the Civil Service Employees Association, one of New York\u2019s largest public employee unions.\n\nHe returned to the board in 2007 as its chairman, appointed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer, and retired from the post in 2015.\n\nWilliam A. Herbert, who was deputy chairman of the board under Mr. Lefkowitz, wrote last year that Mr. Lefkowitz \u201ceschewed explicit ideology and political labels, preferring pragmatism as his guide.\u201d\n\nRecalling the Taylor Law and other regulations, Danny Donohue, president of the civil service union, said in a statement that Mr. Lefkowitz\u2019s tenure on the board had been \u201cmarked by fairness, balance and neutral application of the very laws he helped craft.\u201d", "title": "Jerome Lefkowitz, a Force in New York Labor Law, Dies at 86", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Who is Jay Powell: Here\u2019s a refresher.\n\nOne last defense of Ms. Yellen\n\nWho had a harder time before the Senate: Martin Goodfriend, who is a nominee to join the Fed\u2019s board of governors. Mr. Goodfriend had a tough time defending his assertion after the 2008 financial crisis that government intervention would spur high inflation \u2014 which never came.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s what Disney, Verizon and JPMorgan are doing\n\nDisney\n\nPer a company press release:\n\n\u2022 More than 125,000 employees will receive a $1,000 cash bonus\n\n\u2022 The company will spend $50 million to cover hourly employees\u2019 tuition costs for education or vocational training, including for courses unrelated to their current jobs\n\nThe total is $175 million this fiscal year.\n\nNotable: Disney C.E.O. Bob Iger is a Democrat who had previously weighed running for president. He didn\u2019t explicitly link his company\u2019s move to the tax bill, but it\u2019s hard not to read the initatives that way.\n\nVerizon\n\nAnnounced on CNBC as part of the telecom giant\u2019s fourth-quarter earnings rollout (emphasis added):\n\nVerizon says employees, other than top management, will receive 50 shares of restricted stock, the price of which will be set on February 1. About 155,000 employees will be affected, Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam told CNBC\u2019s \u201cFast Money: Halftime Report\u201d on Tuesday. The award could total over $400 million, based on Verizon\u2019s current share price.\n\nThe company said that it expects to reap an additional $3.5 billion to $4 billion in operating cash flow from the tax code change.\n\nJPMorgan\n\nHere\u2019s what the bank, whose C.E.O. has been a vocal proponent of the tax overhaul, is doing:\n\n\u2022 Raising wages by about 10 percent on average, to between $15 and $18 an hour, and improving benefits\n\n\u2022 Expanding branches, at a time when other banks are scaling back\n\n\u2022 Raising philanthropic giving by 40 percent, to $1.75 billion, over five years\n\n\u2022 Increasing lending to small businesses by $4 billion\n\n\u2022 Improving lending to low- to -moderate-income communities and to affordable housing projects\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll that will cost an estimated $20 billion.\n\nThe comparison to other corporate titans\n\n\u2022 Walmart is raising minimum hourly wage to $11, from $9; handing out bonuses; and improving parental benefits. The wage rise and bonuses will cost about $700 million.\n\n\u2022 AT&T is handing out $1,000 bonuses to more than 200,000 employees and increasing capital spending by $1 billion. That\u2019s somewhere north of $1.2 bilion.\n\n\u2022 Boeing is committing about $300 million to corporate giving, \u201ctraining and education\u201d for its employees and \u201cworkplace of the future\u201d initiatives.\n\nWorth remembering: Arguably the wage raises have as much to do with tight labor markets and the desire of companies to keep existing employees or attract new ones as they do with the tax code change.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nMick Mulvaney to C.F.P.B. staff: No more envelope-pushing\n\nFrom a memo that Mr. Mulvaney, who is the acting chief (or one of two, depending on whom you ask) of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, sent to the agency\u2019s staffers today:\n\nIndeed, I think it is fair to say that the previous governing philosophy here was to aggressively \u201cpush the envelope\u201d in pursuit of the \u201cmission;\u201d that we were the \u201cgood guys\u201d and the \u201cnew sheriff in town,\u201d out to fight the \u201cbad guys.\u201d Simply put: that is what is going to be different. In fact, that entire governing philosophy of pushing the envelope frightens me a little. I would hope it would bother you as well.\n\nAnd:\n\nWrit large, I intend to exercise our statutory authority to enforce the laws of this nation. I intend to execute the statutory mandate of the Bureau to protect consumers. But we will no longer go beyond that mandate. If Congress wants us to do more than is set forth in the Dodd-Frank Act, they can change the law. Until then, we will enforce the law as currently written.\n\nThe context: Mr. Mulvaney, a longtime critic of the C.F.P.B., has been working to rein in the bureau, a longtime target of Republican ire.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nTension at the top of Airbnb\n\nThe home rental company\u2019s C.E.O., Brian Chesky, isn\u2019t always seeing eye to eye with his C.F.O., Laurence Tosi, according to an article in The Information.\n\nIn one instance, Mr. Chesky thought about starting an airline as Airbnb weighed a move into the air travel business. Mr. Tosi insisted on a lower-key approach of partnering with an existing app, according to the news site.\n\nThe context: Mr. Tosi was brought in from Blackstone to help professionalize one of Silicon Valley\u2019s biggest unicorn darlings, much as Ruth Porat joined Alphabet from Morgan Stanley. That was more than likely to foster a clash between Silicon Valley idealism and Wall Street pragmatism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Cory Weinberg of The Information:\n\nMr. Tosi, who moved with his wife and two young children to the Bay Area for the Airbnb job, has tried to fit in, swapping Wall Street suits for jeans and vests. But his arrival also was a shock to Airbnb\u2019s culture, with its emphasis on an idealistic brand. Mr. Tosi sent marching orders across the company in 2016 that it had to get profitable. Before Airbnb could go public, it would have to have a better handle on predicting its earnings. \u201cI believe we have built this path but can do more,\u201d he wrote to employees. Mr. Tosi initiated cost-cutting efforts, including cuts to customer service and food staff, that longtime Airbnb employees saw as hurting the culture. But Airbnb\u2019s cost per customer service \u201cticket\u201d fell by 30% to 40% between 2016 and mid-2017 last year, an Airbnb official said, thanks largely to Mr. Tosi.\n\nWhy it matters: Airbnb is expected to pursue an I.P.O. as soon as next year. Which vision for the company will win out?\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nWas there fraud at KPMG?\n\nThe charges against five former employees of KPMG and a former government accountant show the lengths an accounting firm will go to get a good report from the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.\n\nThe indictment is a bit odd, though, because the defendants are accused of defrauding both the S.E.C. and the accounting board. They used confidential information to help deal with potential problems in KPMG\u2019s audits. But did getting a sneak peek at how they would be evaluated constitute theft, or just a form of cheating?\n\nFraud is a type of larceny, and normally the perpetrator obtains something from the victim, who suffers a loss. But in this case, the scheme was to help KPMG clean up its act to get a better grade in pending reviews.\n\nIn the world of white-collar crime, most fraud prosecutions involve at least some form of tangible gain to the defendants, and not a better report card. Courts have also required prosecutors to show there was at least some harm to the victim from the misuse of their property.\n\nOne way around this issue would be to charge a breach of the honest services statute, but that\u2019s not in the indictment. Nor did the Justice Department charged them under a law prohibiting the theft of government records. The S.E.C. did not accuse the accountants of securities fraud, only that they engaged in unethical or improper professional conduct.\n\nA statement by Steven Peikin, the co-director of the S.E.C.\u2019s enforcement division, said that the defendants were \u201cliterally stealing the exam.\u201d I\u2019m not sure that\u2019s quite accurate, however, as it was more like learning when the teacher would give a pop quiz.\n\nIs that a fraud?\n\n\u2014 Peter J. Henning\n\nWhat will Twitter do now that Anthony Noto has flown the coop?\n\nAt Twitter, Mr. Noto \u2014 former Goldman Sachs banker, former N.F.L. finance chief \u2014 was the highest-ranking full-time employee. (Jack Dorsey splits his time with Square, remember.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow he will finally get to be a C.E.O. He\u2019ll have his hands full at SoFi.\n\nThe social media network made clear that it has a contingency plan:\n\nNoto\u2019s responsibilities for the company\u2019s business operations and revenue generating operations will be assumed by other members of Twitter\u2019s leadership team. Matt Derella, Twitter\u2019s Vice President of Global Revenue and Operations, will continue to lead the company\u2019s advertising sales efforts.\n\nMr. Dorsey offered his own statement on Mr. Noto\u2019s departure:\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nElon Musk swings for the fences\n\nHe\u2019ll earn billions of dollars for leading Tesla over the next decade \u2014 or nothing.\n\nThat\u2019s under a new compensation plan that Andrew reported first today. Critics, and there are many, may regard it as yet another publicity stunt by the electric car marker, which has struggled to meet production targets for its Model 3.\n\nBut Mr. Musk and the head of the Tesla board\u2019s compensation committee said the arrangement would benefit shareholders, since it\u2019s directly linked to company performance.\n\nHere\u2019s what Mr. Musk told Andrew:\n\n\u201cIf all that happens over the next 10 years is that Tesla\u2019s value grows by 80 or 90 percent, then my amount of compensation would be zero,\u201d he said. (His calculations were based on the stock price at the beginning of this year, when the company was worth about $50 billion.)\n\nTrivia: California law requires that Tesla pay Mr. Musk minimum wage, even though he doesn\u2019t want a salary. So it cuts him a check for a little over $37,000 each year, which he never cashes.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the ground at Davos, Day 1\n\nHere\u2019s what movers and shakers are saying in the Swiss Alps:\n\nDara Khosrowshahi on Uber's very bad year:\n\n\u201cThe leaks, etc. led Uber to finally understand that it had to make the changes that it is making as a company, to break from the past and go forward as a company that does the right thing. And the press played a very very big part in it.\u201d\n\nMarc Benioff of Salesforce on why trust has to be a company\u2019s highest value (something he says isn\u2019t always true in Silicon Valley):\n\n\u201cWhat is the most important to you. Is it trust or is it growth? Because if anything trumps trust, then you are in trouble.\u201d\n\nMichael Corbat of Citigroup on the \u201cnumbness\u201d that has descended upon the global economy:\n\n\u201cWhen the next turn comes \u2014 and it will come \u2014 it\u2019s likely to be more violent than it would otherwise be if we let some pressure off along the way.\u201d\n\nJohn Studzinski, a Blackstone vice chairman, on the focus on the world\u2019s wealthiest:\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s stop talking about that and focus on whether the real working class is actually doing better.\u201d\n\nMore from the World Economic Forum\n\n\u2022 Did Emmanuel Macron persuade President Trump to attend? (Axios)\n\n\u2022 PWC\u2019s latest survey of C.E.O.s survey shows record confidence \u2014 but also worries about terrorism, climate change and global politics. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Edelman\u2019s newest trust barometer shows suspicion of public institutions rising fast among Americans \u2014 and the opposite in China. (Edelman)\n\nPhoto\n\nExclusive: Paddle8 gets a new backer and moves into blockchain\n\nA year ago, the online art auctioneer found itself suddenly on its own, after its merger partner of just under a year filed for bankruptcy. Now the company, best known for selling a Wu Tang Clan album to Martin Shkreli, has struck a new deal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. They may respond in kind, as well as by appealing to the W.T.O.\n\nMeanwhile, shares in affected companies appeared little changed. \u201cInvestors are not too worried about the news, because these sectors have already discounted possible tariff moves by Trump,\u201d Linus Yip, the chief strategist at First Shanghai Securities, told Bloomberg.\n\nMike Bloomberg, however, wasn\u2019t happy.\n\nPhoto\n\nFox\u2019s bid for Sky is on thin ice\n\nBritain\u2019s Competition and Markets Authority said in a provisional ruling that 21st Century Fox\u2019s offer was \u201cnot in the public interest.\u201d So where does that leave Rupert Murdoch\u2019s quest for control?\n\nFox said that it still expects to win over the regulator before its final ruling in June.\n\nSky is looking on the bright side, saying the authority suggested potential remedies. (Those included selling Sky News or protecting it from Murdochian influence.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn other Murdoch news: Mr. Murdoch argued that Facebook and Google should pay trusted publishers a fee similar to the carriage payments that cable companies pay to channel operators. (Sky has long enjoyed some exceptions.)\n\nThe media and tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Another stellar earnings report from Netflix lifted its stock price, at least in after-hours trading. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Jerome Powell Clears the Senate: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Jerry Van Dyke, who after decades in show business finally emerged from the shadow of his older brother, Dick, with an Emmy-nominated role in the long-running ABC sitcom \u201cCoach,\u201d died on Friday at his ranch in Arkansas. He was 86.\n\nJerry\u2019s wife, Shirley Ann Jones, who confirmed the death, said his health had deteriorated since a traffic accident in 2015.\n\nFrom the beginning, Mr. Van Dyke\u2019s television career was intertwined with his brother\u2019s. One of his earliest TV appearances was in 1962 in a two-part episode of \u201cThe Dick Van Dyke Show,\u201d as Stacey Petrie, the would-be comedian brother of Dick\u2019s character, Rob Petrie.\n\nA boisterous performer who supported himself with a banjo-and-comedy stage act when television or film roles were scant, Mr. Van Dyke was a ham to his brother\u2019s more dignified persona. But while Dick had runaway success early on, with the Broadway show and film \u201cBye Bye Birdie,\u201d the Disney musical \u201cMary Poppins\u201d and \u201cThe Dick Van Dyke Show,\u201d his brother\u2019s career was long defined by a string of short-lived projects, like \u201cThe Judy Garland Show\u201d and the game show \u201cPicture This.\u201d", "title": "Jerry Van Dyke, \u2018Coach\u2019 Actor and Foil for His Brother, Dick, Dies at 86", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSUNRISE, Fla. \u2014 Jets wide receiver Robby Anderson faces several criminal charges in Florida after being accused of threatening a police officer and his family and of saying he would rape the officer\u2019s wife.\n\nA Sunrise police report said Anderson, 24, was stopped early Friday in a sport utility vehicle after it ran two red lights and was swerving while traveling about 105 m.p.h.\n\nIt is Anderson\u2019s second arrest in the last eight months. He also faces a charge of resisting arrest in Miami.\n\n\u201cThis is a pending legal matter, and we will have no further comments,\u201d the Jets said in a statement.\n\nThe N.F.L. spokesman Brian McCarthy said, \u201cWe will be looking into this matter.\u201d\n\nAfter Anderson was stopped, the police said, he made the threats and then boasted about how much money he had. Jail records show Anderson faces nine charges, including threatening harm to a public servant, resisting arrest and traffic violations.\n\nA 2011 graduate of South Plantation High School in Florida, Anderson caught 63 passes for 941 yards and seven touchdowns this season with the Jets.", "title": "Jets Receiver Robby Anderson Is Accused of Threatening a Police Officer", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe: \u201cCan a Jew Love France?\u201d by Alexander Aciman (Opinion, Jan. 16). I chose years ago to live in France, raise my children here, and am concerned for its Jewish future. But I also chose to stay, to understand the complex, multiple roots of anti-Semitism, advocate for firm government action, and strengthen our resilient Jewish community, the largest in Europe.\n\nIdentifying the sources of anti-Semitism in France is critical. Comparing the current situation to the 1930s, even to the Dreyfus affair, is neither accurate nor helpful.\n\nYes, the National Front, which has anti-Semitic roots, is a far-right danger to Jews and other minorities. But it is not the only threat. Among some on the left, demonization of Israel has increasingly become a mask for anti-Semitism in France. Some Muslims, motivated by twisted political or religious beliefs, have threatened and killed Jews.\n\nAsserting that \u201cFrance has done nothing to curb its Jewish problem\u201d is simply not true. While successive French governments took too long to confront anti-Semitism, and more needs to be done, few European governments have so seriously taken concrete steps combating anti-Semitism in the past five years.", "title": "Opinion | Jews and the Future of France", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJill Furman and Andrew Blauner were married Jan. 13 at the Pool restaurant at the Seagram Building in New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated.\n\nThe bride and groom graduated from Brown and each received M.B.A.s from Columbia.\n\nMs. Furman, 49, is a theatrical producer; her producing credits include the Tony-award winning musicals \u201cIn the Heights\u201d and \u201cHamilton.\u201d She is on the board of the Lung Cancer Research Foundation in New York.\n\nShe is a daughter of Roy Furman of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and the late Frieda Bueler Furman The bride\u2019s father is a vice chairman of the Jefferies group, the global investment banking firm, and a vice chairman of Lincoln Center, both in New York. He is also a Tony-award-winning producer of many Broadway shows, including the current shows \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d and \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d; \u201cThe Color Purple,\u201d which closed in 2017 and is now on tour; and \u201cCarousel,\u201d which is to begin previews in February. Her mother was on the board of American Friends of the Israel Museum in New York. The bride is also a stepdaughter of Marjorie Fisher Furman.\n\nThe bride\u2019s previous marriage ended in divorce.\n\nMr. Blauner, 53, is the founder and owner of Blauner Books Literary Agency in New York. He is also the editor of seven anthologies including \u201cCoach,\u201d essays by 25 writers about their athletic mentors (Warner Books, 2005), and \u201cCentral Park,\u201d essays by writers sharing memories about the park (Bloomsbury, 2012).\n\nHe is a son of Sheila Ellis Weisman of New York and the late S. Richard Blauner, who lived in New York; and a stepson of Alan Weisman. The groom\u2019s mother is an associate at Sotheby\u2019s International Realty in New York. His father was the president of Suzy Perette, a dress manufacturer that was in New York.\n\nMs. Furman and Mr. Blauner met at a movie premiere at the Museum of Modern Art on Oct. 13, 2015, after their lives echoed each other over the years \u2014 they were born four years apart at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, grew up three blocks from one another on the Upper East Side, went to the same pediatrician and dentist, and received degrees from the same schools. Their first date was March 11, 2016, and after their second one a week later, Ms. Furman wrote on a Post-it, \u201cTonight I had the second date with the man I\u2019m going to marry.\u201d", "title": "Jill Furman, Andrew Blauner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJillian Holmes Vandall and Andrew Miao were married Jan. 6 in Manhattan. Devon G. Kelley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at the Bowery Hotel.\n\nMrs. Miao, 31, is a senior publicity manager, representing children\u2019s book authors and illustrators, at Random House in New York. She is also a freelance calligrapher. She graduated cum laude from the University of New Hampshire.\n\nShe is the daughter of Peter J. Vandall of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Betsy Holmes Vandall. The bride\u2019s father retired as the vice president for sales and marketing at Pez Candy in Orange, Conn. Her mother was a nurse in the recovery room at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn.\n\nMr. Miao, 31, is a risk-management consultant at Promontory Financial Group, a financial services risk manager in Manhattan. He graduated from Williams College.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe is the son of Terry Shu of Boston and Walter C. Miao of Belleville, N.J. The groom\u2019s mother retired as a managing director in the asset management division of JPMorgan Chase & Company, the Manhattan investment bank. His father retired from a subsidiary of the International Data Corporation, a market research and consulting firm, for which he was a senior vice president for technology research in the Manhattan office.\n\nThe groom is a great-grandson of Dai Jitao, a politician and leading member of China\u2019s Kuomintang political party, a nationalist organization founded in the early 20th century and now the main opposition party in Taiwan.", "title": "Jillian Vandall, Andrew Miao", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s unclear who would be in charge of choosing any potential injury replacements if needed. The United States opens the Olympics Feb. 14 against Slovenia.\n\nThe talent pool now and in other tournaments is deeper in part because of Johannson, who has overseen the growth of hockey in the United States beyond the \u201cMiracle On Ice\u201d in 1980. The retired American forward Jeremy Roenick said, \u201cUSA hockey is a world power now because of people like Jimmy Johannson.\u201d\n\nThe United States. won 64 medals, including 34 gold, in major international competition during Johannson\u2019s tenure. The Americans in particular became a perennial threat to win the world junior championship, showing the program\u2019s improvement at the youth levels.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCarolina Hurricanes president Don Waddell said Johannson \u201chas been a driving force in making both the USA Hockey men\u2019s and women\u2019s programs into consistent winners.\u201d and Phil Housley, who coached the 2015 junior team to a gold medal, said Johannson \u201cgrew our game to new heights.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn building the teams that achieved so much success for USA Hockey, Jim Johannson had a sharp eye for talent, a strong sense of chemistry and a relentless pursuit of excellence,\u201d N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said. \u201cAs we mourn his loss, we will remember the positive outlook Jim brought to his tireless efforts to advance USA Hockey.\u201d\n\nJohannson, who played for the U.S. at the 1988 and 1992 Olympics, began working for USA Hockey in 2000 after spending five years as the general manager of the Twin Cities Vulcans in the United States Hockey League. He was promoted to assistant executive director of hockey operations in 2007, overseeing the organization\u2019s efforts in fielding teams for international competition.\n\nHe played college hockey at Wisconsin and helped the Badgers win the N.C.A.A. championship as a freshman. He was selected by the Hartford Whalers in the seventh round of the 1982 draft, and although he never played in the N.H.L., he was respected and well-liked by those all over hockey.\n\n\u201cWe lost a true friend in Jim Johannson today,\u201d said Granato, who played with Johannson on the 1988 Olympic team. \u201cHe was so compassionate and as loyal a friend as you could have. He was the ultimate teammate. I am deeply saddened and shocked and sorry that he is no longer with us. He was a special human being. Please pray for Jim\u2019s wife and daughter, Abby and Ellie.\u201d\n\nKelleher said USA Hockey would think about ways to pay tribute to Johannson at the Pyeongchang Games after grieving this loss.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cToday it\u2019s really just trying to help his family as best as we can and really just try and honestly put one foot in front of the other,\u201d Kelleher said. \u201cWe\u2019ll have to see what we can do to try and honor him in some fashion.\u201d", "title": "Jim Johannson, General Manager of U.S. Men\u2019s Hockey Team, Dies at 53", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s bad enough to have cancer,\u201d she told the website Medscape.com in 2015, \u201cbut when all of your family and friends are saying that you have to be positive and you have to fight this thing, and the patient is exhausted and beaten up by the treatments \u2014 it seemed to me that adding that burden to be positive was just ridiculous.\u201d\n\nIn a letter to The New York Times in 1985, Dr. Holland and a colleague, Morton Bard, wrote of cancer patients, \u201cShould they be viewed as weak or as somehow having contributed to their own demise?\u201d\n\nDr. Holland treated depression in patients undergoing treatment and anxiety in survivors, sometimes over body image after the loss of a breast or a testicle.\n\nShe urged doctors to screen for emotional distress as a vital sign, just as they do for temperature, pulse, respiration, blood pressure and pain. Physiological symptoms, she said, could often be relieved by antidepressants, anxiety medicine, meditation and other treatments.\n\nIn her book \u201cThe Human Side of Cancer,\u201d written with Sheldon Lewis and published in 2000, she quoted a patient of hers as saying: \u201cThey have measured everything but my thoughts and mind. Somehow, my mental attitude, the stress, the anguish should be analyzed and studied the same as my physical condition.\u201d\n\nDr. Holland was the founding president of the American Psychosocial Oncology Society and the International Psycho-oncology Society. She also taught at Weill Cornell medical school.\n\n\u201cFor more than 40 years, Jimmie made an essential question \u2014 \u2018How do people with cancer feel?\u2019 \u2014 the center of her work,\u201d her husband said in an email.", "title": "Jimmie Holland, Who Cared for the Cancer Patient\u2019s Mind, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\n\u2018Bargaining\u2019 CHIP?\n\nJimmy Kimmel leaped back into the debate over health policy on Thursday, urging Congress to fund the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program without tying it to a short-term spending bill. And now we\u2019re on the brink of the whole government shutting down.\u201d\n\nHis assessment grazes past key details \u2014 and it didn\u2019t account for the fact that on Thursday night, the House passed a bill that would fund CHIP for six years.
