He was 71.\n\nHis death was announced by the Celtics, who did not say where or how he died. White received a diagnosis of brain cancer in 2010. White\u2019s daughter Meka White told ESPN that the cause was complications of dementia, noting that he had developed pneumonia.\n\nDuring his 10 years in Boston, White, who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame, embodied the tradition, pride and excellence associated with the Celtics. On the court, White could do it all. With quick hands and quick feet, he jump-started fast breaks, finding teammates with clever passes or taking matters into his own hands with a deadeye jump shot.\n\n\u201cHe was a champion and a gentleman; supremely talented and brilliant on the court, and endlessly gracious off of it,\u201d the Celtics, for whom White worked as the director of special projects, said in a statement on Tuesday.", "title": "Jo Jo White, Deadeye Shooter for Boston Celtics, Dies at 71", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "I am a co-founder of a start-up that helps companies with their efforts to hire more women. In the fall, in meetings with potential clients in the San Francisco Bay Area, I became aware of a dangerous trend: Employers are turning to techniques that \u201cmask\u201d the gender of the candidates they interview \u2014 removing names from r\u00e9sum\u00e9s and altering voices on phone calls, for example \u2014 with the hope that this will offer a quick fix to diversity failures.\n\nThese gender-masking tools and the related trend of \u201cblind hiring\u201d have recently been chronicled in The New York Times and Wired, and discussed at tech conferences. One head of talent at a major financial services company told me she\u2019s getting up to five pitches a week for tools that can mask applicants\u2019 gender. My team is regularly told by potential clients in the Fortune 100 that they are already using tools to obscure gender in hiring. Yelp has tried using a voice disguiser on initial interview calls to hide applicants\u2019 gender.\n\nThis is a misguided distraction from the hard work of evaluating and fixing the ways in which their cultures drive out the women who are actually hired.\n\nI understand the appeal of gender-masking for companies that are rightly concerned that bias could be eliminating qualified female candidates, especially in tech roles, where women are severely underrepresented. In 2016, a group of computer scientists compared acceptance rates for code written by women and men on the code repository GitHub. It found that developers accepted nearly 72 percent of code written by women when they did not know their gender. When it was revealed that women had written the code, acceptance rates fell to 62 percent. After reading this study, I suggested that using virtual reality \u2014 with candidates identifiable to interviewers only by avatar names \u2014 might be a promising way to keep sexism out of the hiring process.", "title": "Opinion | Job Interviews Without Gender", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe could possibly win a primary because of his popularity among a hard-core group of supporters in the G.O.P. and his national fund-raising ability,\u201d said Tyler Montague, a Republican campaign strategist in Arizona.\n\n\u201cBut in the end he\u2019ll be another Roy Moore,\u201d said Mr. Montague, referring to Mr. Moore\u2019s contentious hard-line positions. \u201cI think a lot of serious conservatives will realize that and reject his candidacy.\u201d\n\nMr. Arpaio began his long career in law enforcement as a police officer in Washington in 1954. He later worked for the Drug Enforcement Administration in Latin America before his election as sheriff of Maricopa County in 1991.\n\nIn almost a quarter-century in that office, Mr. Arpaio developed a national reputation for severe correctional practices and a tireless crusade against illegal immigration. He opened an outdoor jail known as Tent City, turning the desert heat into a punitive element, and forced inmates to wear striped jumpsuits and pink underwear. His department conducted broad \u201csaturation patrols\u201d of heavily Hispanic neighborhoods, often without evidence of criminal activity, and routinely detained people beyond their court-ordered release dates so they could be handed over to federal immigration authorities.\n\nA professed media hound, Mr. Arpaio reveled in publicity, using bold headlines and public outrage to his advantage in firing up conservatives who embraced his hard-line policies. \u201cArpaio was Trump before Trump was Trump,\u201d said David Berman, professor emeritus of political science at Arizona State University.\n\nIn 2016, Mr. Arpaio, who had advanced the myth that President Barack Obama was not born in the United States, emerged as an early Trump endorser in Arizona, where Mr. Trump held no fewer than seven campaign rallies during the presidential race. But the communities Mr. Arpaio had agitated with such persistence ultimately drove him from office: He lost his bid for a seventh term as sheriff that November, pushed out by energized Latino voters. Mr. Trump would carry the state by four percentage points in the same election.\n\nChuck Coughlin, a veteran Republican strategist in Arizona, said in an interview that his first reaction to Mr. Arpaio\u2019s announcement was that it could be \u201csome kind of a joke,\u201d referring to previous talk by Mr. Arpaio about running for governor.", "title": "Joe Arpaio, Ex-Sheriff Pardoned by Trump, Announces Senate Run in Arizona", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "After the Maricopa County sheriff\u2019s office detained a Latino man with a valid visa for nine hours in 2007, a class-action lawsuit led to an injunction requiring Mr. Arpaio\u2019s office to end its immigration-related stops. Mr. Arpaio defied the injunction for years, boasting about it to the news media. He was convicted and facing a potential six-month jail sentence when he was pardoned.\n\nMr. Arpaio is similar to Roy Moore, the Republican Senate candidate vanquished by Doug Jones in Alabama last month. A tough-talking champion to far-right conservatives, Mr. Arpaio is a morally repugnant publicity hound to Arizonans who\u2019d like their state to be known for something more noble than racial profiling and \u201cTent City.\u201d\n\nHis entire platform pretty much consists of \u201cI\u2019m a big supporter of President Trump.\u201d And since Mr. Trump suggested on Tuesday that he\u2019d endorse a deal to eventually grant millions of undocumented immigrants a pathway to citizenship, a squirming \u201cSheriff Joe\u201d came up with what he called \u201ca far-out plan\u201d:\n\n\u201cWhen they come to your attention that they\u2019re here illegally, these young people, deport them back to Mexico \u2014 or whatever \u2014 and then try to put them on a fast track to come back into the United States legally with special permits. What\u2019s wrong with that? They\u2019d say they don\u2019t know where their home country is, so let them go there and spend six months, because it might take that long to do paperwork to get them here legally, and let them see their home country and see what it\u2019s really like. They ought to be proud where they came from \u2026 So, you could kill two birds with one stone.\u201d\n\nMr. Arpaio acknowledges this idea \u201cmay look stupid.\u201d Yep.", "title": "Opinion | Joe Arpaio\u2019s Latest Offense \u2014 Running for Senate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "And, with exacting \u2014 sometimes maddening \u2014 workmanship, Mr. Frank edited and scored his programs as if they were films.\n\nIra Glass, the host of the NPR show \u201cThis American Life,\u201d said in a telephone interview that Mr. Frank had been more comparable to movie auteurs from the 1970s than to storytellers like Jean Shepherd and Garrison Keillor. Mr. Frank\u2019s tales, he said, threw listeners \u201cinto a gritty world where it won\u2019t all come out so clean and the moral lines won\u2019t be clear. And it will be a little philosophical.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cHe was a mind-expanding example of what the medium could be, in all its power, that nobody else was doing.\u201d\n\nDuring one of his shows, Mr. Frank called former girlfriends on the East Coast late in the evening \u2014 guaranteeing that he would rouse them from sleep \u2014 to sing \u201cI Remember You\u201d to them.\n\n\u201cWas that just for me?\u201d one of his former exes asked. Assured that it was, she said, groggily, \u201cThat was sweet.\u201d\n\nWhen Terry Gross, the host of NPR\u2019s \u201cFresh Air,\u201d interviewed Mr. Frank in 1990, she called the encounters with his former lovers \u201creally funny and really cruel.\u201d Mr. Frank said he had felt guilty about waking them and inviting them to sing along with him. But, he said, the show was a hit.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re kind of torn between things that may not be very nice but make really extraordinary radio,\u201d he told Ms. Gross.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Frank was born Joseph Langermann on Aug. 19, 1938, in Strasbourg, France. His father, Meier, was a Polish-born shoe manufacturer in Nazi Germany, and his mother, the former Friederike Passweg, was a homemaker. The family fled Germany in 1939 and settled in New York City.\n\nBut Joseph had club feet and needed corrective surgery. His parents\u2019 marriage was deteriorating, as was his father\u2019s health. His father died of kidney failure on the day of one of Joe\u2019s operations.\n\n\u201cSo when I came home, my mother lied to me and told me that my father had gone to Boston on business,\u201d he told Slate in an interview conducted last summer and published after he died. \u201cI was five and a half.\u201d\n\nAfter his mother remarried, he took his stepfather\u2019s surname.\n\n\u201cI think he was plagued by themes of inadequacy and insecurity, and a search for meaning that began in his childhood,\u201d Jennifer Ferro, the general manager of KCRW, said in a phone interview.\n\nHe attended Hofstra University on Long Island \u2014 he said he cheated on the entrance exam \u2014 and spent two years at the Iowa Writers\u2019 Workshop but did not get a degree. In his 20s, he learned that he had testicular cancer. It was followed in later years by bladder cancer and two bouts of colon cancer. He also received a kidney transplant and had scoliosis.\n\nHe taught English and Russian literature and philosophy for 10 years at Dalton, a private school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and then promoted musical acts in Massachusetts. Listening to the radio during rides between Manhattan and Northampton made him think about changing careers.\n\n\u201cThe radio became a real comfort and companion on those drives,\u201d he told LA Weekly in 2008. \u201cI particularly loved listening to baseball because the announcer wouldn\u2019t just say, \u2018He hit the ball to third base.\u2019 He\u2019d talk about the history of baseball, the weather, the lives of the different players \u2014 it was like being with somebody I liked.\u201d\n\nHe found work at WBAI, a noncommercial station in Manhattan, as an engineer and host of an overnight show, on which he began to tell stories. They caught the attention of National Public Radio, which hired him to host the weekend edition of \u201cAll Things Considered.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe did not last long at the job; he told Salon in 2000 that it had impeded his ability to pursue existential questions like, \u201cIf nature is bred with tooth and claw, is human compassion just an anomaly?\u201d But he managed to produce meticulously produced free-form segments that mesmerized Mr. Glass, who was an intern.\n\n\u201cI remember thinking, \u2018I don\u2019t understand why this is affecting me this way, but I want to learn how to do this,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Glass said. \u201cCertain things he did, like the way he holds back information \u2014 he tends to throw you into a story in the middle of a dream and in the middle of a plot you have to figure out where you are and learn your way forward.\u201d\n\nMr. Frank was hired by KCRW in 1986. He won a Peabody Award five years later.\n\nBut he was fired in 2002 in a dispute with the station\u2019s general manager. He then built a website and subscription service and started performing at clubs and theaters. He also wrote short essays, which he posted on Facebook. He returned to KCRW for a few years but left in 2015 when his health began to fail.\n\nMs. Story \u2014 who met Mr. Frank during a KCRW pledge drive in which she critiqued his on-air work \u2014 is his only survivor.\n\nLife, Mr. Frank once said in a monologue, is like being in a restaurant on a first date with a woman you\u2019ve long admired. But \u201cthere is a waiting list and the names will be called in alphabetical order \u2014 and your name is Zarathustra.\u201d", "title": "Joe Frank, Spinner of Strange Radio Tales, Is Dead at 79", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The photo of the Hartwig House is the first photograph Meyerowitz made with an 8-by-10-inch view camera. Certain small stylistic adjustments are expected when subject matter shifts, and for photographers, this is a difference often heralded by a change of camera. With a tripod and much larger negative, the \u201caction\u201d in the picture is now all in the thoughtfulness and calm description, the warm light that suffuses everything, the unfailing verticals of the doors and walls.\n\nSusan Sontag once noted that \u201cseeing tends to accommodate to photographs.\u201d Once the thrill of originality fades, we are often left with the merely picturesque. A landscape by Edward Weston is absorbing; a landscape in the style of Weston less so. Diane Arbus revolutionized portraiture, but her numerous imitators cannot command our interest to the same degree.\n\nThe renovation of photography\u2019s possibilities happens generationally. But within this slow evolution are faster cycles, certain artists who keep it moving so that their individual oeuvres come to constitute minihistories of photography: artists like Paul Strand, Berenice Abbott and Joel Meyerowitz.\n\nPhoto\n\n3. Some communication has happened between the young woman in blue and the photographer. In the swirl of the party, she had, like him, been moving, evidence of which is captured in the photograph: one leg is placed in front of another. But she read the photographer\u2019s eyes, which had pleaded with her to hold her pose, and for the duration of time that the camera\u2019s aperture is open, she does hold still. There\u2019s a second woman, on the left, who also meets the photographer\u2019s glance and is also still, but her look is blurred. The woman in blue, centrally placed, standing in contrapposto next to a tree, direct and crisp in her gaze, becomes the story.\n\nMeyerowitz does something unusual with the view camera here: He uses its slowness, its difficulty with moving subjects, as an asset. He has become interested not only in the descriptive power of the large camera but in the technical limits of what it can do. \u201cCocktail Party, Wellfleet, Massachusetts, 1977\u201d is related to the photograph of the Truro interior both in its format and in the emphasis on verticals. But the light-filled house is suspended in time like an afternoon in which the clocks have stopped, and there\u2019s nothing to prove that it\u2019s not a photo from 1987 or 1997 or yesterday. The party, meanwhile, is quite obviously of that moment, that fraction of a second it took for the image of the young woman and the blur around her to be registered. We may wonder where all those people are now, more than 40 years on.\n\nPhoto\n\n4. \u201cFive More Found, New York City, 2001\u201d brings to mind Rembrandt\u2019s \u201cNight Watch\u201d or one of those complex tableaux by Jacques-Louis David. The setting and its drama \u2014 a drama of vertiginous darkness and theatrical lighting \u2014 emphasize the environment more than the numerous small-scaled people present. The image, made as part of Meyerowitz\u2019s \u201cAftermath: World Trade Center Archive,\u201d which he began working on in the days after the Sept. 11 attacks, records a particularly sad moment: The \u201cfive more found\u201d are firefighters, dead in the rubble.\n\nIt is a photograph that, like many others in the project, approaches the sublime. But I find more to admire than to love in it. It is straightforward in form, stately in appearance, awesome in subject but ultimately dutiful in effect. But perhaps this isn\u2019t entirely regrettable. The very last thing you want in a photograph of the ruins of the World Trade Center is some obnoxious individuality.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn reading artists, we ought to focus more on what they intend than on the stylistic gestures that help us identify their works. Meyerowitz is certainly stylish \u2014 there is always a formal clarity in his work \u2014 but he can\u2019t be pinned down to two or three styles. His oeuvre is as varied as any among contemporary photographic masters, but this is not a matter of restlessness. The variety is organically related to whatever he is exploring at any given point. He changes because he must.\n\nPhoto\n\n5. A gray skull sits on a gray table with a gray wall as the backdrop. There is no supporting cast and there are no special lights, just the object itself, set down, more interesting for what it means than for how it looks.\n\nWe can never really see our own faces as they are seen by others. Even mirrors, photographs and videos place us at a certain distance from our own faces. And harder to see is the skull behind the face; an X-ray is at best an approximation. You would have to be dead to really see your own skull, an inescapable paradox.\n\nThis skull was photographed by Meyerowitz in Aix-en-Provence. The photograph is in fact half of a diptych titled \u201cC\u00e9zanne\u2019s Studio (Skull and Void), 2013.\u201d We don\u2019t know the name of the human being whose macabre fate was to become a prop in an artist\u2019s studio. The skull is most likely one of three that C\u00e9zanne painted several times. The attraction of C\u00e9zanne\u2019s studio for Meyerowitz lies in part in the flattening effect of those gray walls. Photographing the individual objects in natural light against that wall, he explores some of the plainness of setting that may have helped C\u00e9zanne intensify his proto-cubist approach to still life.\n\nWhat a tremendous stylistic gulf there is between this skull and the photograph of the New York City camel coats from 1975. Here, simplicity reigns. The complications are pared down and the jokes and puzzles are dropped, as are the grand visions. This is a quiet world, but not the sweet quiet of the Hartwig House, in which human presence is at least implied. The skull and its accompanying void inhabit a more abstract reality, a statement stripped of all superfluity.\n\nJoel Meyerowitz, nearly 80 now, must, from time to time, give thought to mortality. But the vision in his recent pictures (he has also made a series about objects in the studio of the painter Giorgio Morandi) is dispassionate, not tragic. Certain pictures are easy to make but hard to see. A skull, a table, a wall: In this latest of his numerous styles, Meyerowitz moves from what it means to look to what it means to have looked. The skull on one side of the diptych suggests it, and the void on the other leaves no doubt.", "title": "Joel Meyerowitz\u2019s Career Is a Minihistory of Photography", "authors": ["Teju Cole", "On Photography"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Barton was also a writer and adapter. Among his most enduring creations was \u201cThe Hollow Crown,\u201d a sort of sampler of British monarchs, which after its premiere by the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1961 had a run on Broadway in 1963, with Mr. Barton in the cast. Howard Taubman, writing in The New York Times, called it \u201can ingratiating entertainment of immense theatrical flare.\u201d The company revived it as recently as 2005.\n\nMr. Barton, though, did not limit himself to Shakespeare or British themes. Among his most ambitious projects was \u201cThe Greeks,\u201d a nine-hour production spread over three evenings that adapted 10 plays by Euripides, Aeschylus, Sophocles and Homer to tell the story of the Trojan War.\n\n\u201cI love the contradictions,\u201d Mr. Barton told The Times, describing his fascination with the subject matter. \u201cApollo is the god of reason and unreason. Clytemnestra turns from the loving wife into the husband-killer. The contradictions give the cycle a certain coherence of life.\u201d\n\nHe defended the mash-up of various texts.\n\n\u201cSome people will be horrified,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I don\u2019t think we\u2019ve twisted the spirit of the plays. I hate the clich\u00e9s of updating the classics. Helen doesn\u2019t wear sunglasses. But she can anoint herself with modern suntan lotion, because the Greeks anointed themselves with oil.\u201d\n\nMr. Barton married Anne Righter in 1969. She died in 2013. The company\u2019s announcement listed no survivors.\n\nIn a foreword to Mr. Barton\u2019s \u201cPlaying Shakespeare\u201d book, Trevor Nunn, who became artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1968, recalled Mr. Barton\u2019s reputation in the early 1960s: \u201chilariously absent-minded, obsessed with cricket, a chain smoker, an expert on Napoleon and somebody who enjoyed working 16 hours a day without a break.\u201d\n\nThen, Mr. Nunn continued, he had a chance to work closely with Mr. Barton on a production of \u201cHenry V.\u201d \u201cFor six weeks of the rehearsal period,\u201d Mr. Nunn wrote, \u201cI became the world expert on John\u2019s absent-mindedness, I came to love the 16-hour day (I was already O.K. on cricket and Napoleon), and I learned more about unlocking a Shakespeare text than any scholarship could have taught me.\u201d", "title": "John Barton, Revelatory Shakespeare Director, Is Dead at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t want him to be light,\u201d Mr. Rhodes said. \u201cAnd I don\u2019t want our show to be light. That doesn\u2019t mean that each of them won\u2019t be approachable to the audience. I think each of them is and can be. But we\u2019re not hiring him for this program to be something that he\u2019s not.\u201d\n\nMr. Rhodes added that he believed real reporting had a place in the early hours of the TV day.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m hoping that the audience sees John, sees Gayle, sees Norah, as serious journalists, and I think that\u2019s our value proposition for a really large audience,\u201d Mr. Rhodes said.\n\nSo far, that approach has paid off in the ratings. CBS, for years an also-ran in the morning show wars, has lately drawn within striking distance of its ABC and NBC rivals.\n\nMr. Dickerson \u2014 whose mother, Nancy Dickerson, in 1960 became the first female correspondent at CBS News \u2014 plans to move his family to New York and relinquish his duties at \u201cFace the Nation.\u201d CBS has not yet chosen his successor, effectively setting off a horse race for one of television\u2019s most influential political roles.\n\nLikely contenders include Major Garrett, CBS\u2019s chief White House correspondent, and two of the network\u2019s Washington reporters, Margaret Brennan and Nancy Cordes.\n\nMr. Dickerson, who is also a contributing editor at The Atlantic, said he planned to continue his political reporting. He is among the few television journalists outside of Fox News who have interviewed President Trump in the Oval Office. His persistent questions \u2014 specifically about Mr. Trump\u2019s unsubstantiated claim that his campaign had been wiretapped by the Obama administration \u2014 so agitated the president that Mr. Trump abruptly walked out of the room.\n\nThe addition of Mr. Dickerson is the second major shift in morning TV this year. Last week, Hoda Kotb replaced the longtime morning host Matt Lauer, who was fired after allegations of workplace sexual misconduct, as a co-anchor for the opening hours of \u201cToday.\u201d", "title": "John Dickerson to Replace Charlie Rose on \u2018CBS This Morning\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Immigration has become one of the most polarizing issues of our day. But it is worth remembering that this century opened with a tale of family and migration that was as contentious as many of the stories that punctuate our current debate: the case of Eli\u00e1n Gonz\u00e1lez.\n\nIn November 1999, when Eli\u00e1n was 6, he left Cuba in a small boat with his mother, who was seeking a better life in Florida. She and 10 others died when the boat sank in a storm. Eli\u00e1n survived by clinging to an inner tube. Courts eventually ruled that he must return to his father in Cuba rather than stay with relatives in Florida. He remains there to this day.\n\nRegardless of your views of the underlying legal arguments in the case, the image of a small, frightened boy being pulled from the arms of a sheltering adult by a team of heavily armed federal agents remains seared in the minds of many people as a low point in the immigration debate.\n\nBrace yourself for the possibility of seeing this kind of scene again.\n\nAs Republicans, whose party has consistently and rightly advanced policies to support the essential role of families in America, we are deeply troubled by the harm that is about to be done to hundreds of thousands of families that have legally called America home for more than two decades.", "title": "Opinion | John Kasich and Jeb Bush Jr.: A Bad Idea on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "His hostility toward immigration has been evident from the beginning of his time in the administration.\n\nWhen Kelly was brought on as chief of staff in July, The Nation warned, \u201cJohn Kelly\u2019s promotion is a disaster for immigrants,\u201d pointing out that in just six months as secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, he turned it into \u201ca deportation machine.\u201d\n\nThe Nation went on:\n\n\u201cIndeed, in the last six months, Kelly has turned the DHS into one of the most productive arms of the Trump administration. Kelly managed to translate much of Trump\u2019s brazen anti-immigrant campaign rhetoric into actual policy. And if the numbers are any indication, Kelly has certainly flourished. Arrests since Trump took office in February increased by 40 percent over the prior year. But perhaps more important than the numbers is Kelly\u2019s impact on immigrant communities, where apprehension and fear now reign.\u201d\n\nWhile at the D.H.S., Kelly even considered separating immigrant parents from their accompanying children if they enter the country illegally. As The Times reported:\n\n\u201cStill, the prospect of breaking a sacred bond between parent and child has not been an easy decision. Mr. Kelly said early this year that he was considering the move, but after an uproar from immigrant advocates and some members of Congress, he said that families would be separated only in extreme circumstances, such as when the child was in danger because of the parent.\u201d\n\nOne of Kelly\u2019s primary targets has been the Temporary Protected Status program.\n\nAs The Times has reported: \u201cThe protection for Haitians was most recently extended in May, by John F. Kelly, the Homeland Security secretary at the time. He allowed only a six-month extension, a shorter one than is typical, saying that the Haitians \u2018need to start thinking about returning.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Times also reported that in November, Kelly \u201cunsuccessfully tried to pressure the Homeland Security Department to end a program that allows hundreds of thousands of people from countries affected by natural disasters or violence to live in the United States without fear of being deported, according to people familiar with the discussions.\u201d\n\nMany of those countries have populations that are either black or brown. Those were the countries Trump vulgarly disparaged. So why are Trump and Kelly so dogged in their opposition to these particular programs?\n\nI, along with many others, have pointed out Trump\u2019s obvious racism, but Kelly\u2019s relationship to race is also troubling.", "title": "Opinion | John Kelly, Deacon of Deportation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Sometimes my gigs were intensely nostalgic. I appeared on stages where I had first performed in my teens and early 20s, like Harvard\u2019s Loeb Drama Center, Cleveland\u2019s Great Lakes Theater Festival, New Haven\u2019s Long Wharf and Princeton\u2019s McCarter Theaters. On those nights, I sensed the presence of ghosts watching me from the wings.\n\nPhoto\n\nI grew up in a peripatetic family, following the unpredictable fortunes of my regional-theater-producer father. I went to eight different public schools. As a result, at several of my tour stops, long-lost childhood friends would send word backstage that they were out in the house.\n\nOn one such occasion, I arrived in Pittsfield, Mass., near the town of Stockbridge, where I had lived for a year when I was 12. At the theater box office, there was a message waiting for me from someone named Vincent Flynn.\n\nI immediately recognized the name as an old friend from my year in Stockbridge. I called up Vincent and heard his high, piping voice, unchanged after all these years. I arranged tickets for him and when I made my entrance that evening, I introduced him from the stage.\n\nMy intro was met with silence. I searched the crowd for Vincent. After a long pause, an elderly man shyly got to his feet out there in the half-darkness. I cried out, \u201cLadies and gentlemen, meet Vincent Flynn! My very best friend from eighth grade! This is the first time I\u2019ve laid eyes on him in 52 years!\u201d\n\nGreeting Vincent backstage, I was thrilled to learn that he\u2019d made a career of recording sacred songs in that beautiful tenor voice of his.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn London I was invited to do two successive Monday night performances of my show on the Lyttelton stage of the National Theater. The first fell on October 19, 2009. As I walked onstage, I made an impulsive decision. When the entrance applause died down, I greeted the audience:\n\n\u201cLadies and gentlemen, this is a big night for me. It\u2019s my first appearance at the National Theater. In fact, it\u2019s my first professional performance on any London stage. Best of all, tonight just happens to be \u2026 my 64th birthday!\u201d\n\nThey applauded that as well.\n\nThen I lifted my hands, belted out one of the most recognizable lead-ins in the history of popular song, and led the whole crowd in the first verse of the Beatles\u2019 \u201cWhen I\u2019m Sixty-Four.\u201d An audience of 900 Brits sang along, full throated and word perfect.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen we finished the verse, I spoke again:\n\n\u201cNow if you\u2019ll excuse me, I\u2019m going to walk back into the wings and die of happiness.\u201d\n\nSuch moments made my days on the road fun and memorable. But in the meantime, something far more important was happening. \u201cStories By Heart\u201d was getting better.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy essential collaborators were the people out front. Audiences teach you a lot, and the toughest audiences arguably teach you the most. Just think what you can learn by performing a one-man show at a casino in Reno, Nev., in a cavernous space which, for many years, was advertised as \u201cthe largest stage in the world.\u201d\n\nEvery time I presented the show, I found ways to refine it. I would cut, reorder, rewrite and discover new physical business and tricks of comic timing.\n\nTake \u201cHaircut,\u201d for example. Ring Lardner\u2019s short story is told by a barber to his customer in a small town in Michigan, circa 1925. Having performed the story for 10 years, I\u2019ve perfected every tiny gesture of an oldtime shave-and-a-haircut, from start to finish. All the props in the barber shop are invisible, but by now the audience sees them anyway.\n\nBeyond all those incremental improvements, I have gradually developed a deeper understanding of what my own show is really about. I\u2019ve come to see that, beyond purely entertaining, I am in the business of consciousness raising.\n\nI am helping people discover or rediscover the dazzling work of Lardner and Wodehouse. I am offering ruminations on why actors perform and why people watch. I am reminding people of the simple power of great writing spoken out loud and of the indispensable role that storytelling plays in our lives.\n\nAnd on a personal level, I am informing people of the remarkable career of a quixotic pioneer of the American regional theater movement, my father, Arthur Lithgow, who died in 2004. Nothing is more fleeting than a career in show business. How many actors are lucky enough to bring a father back to life in front of an audience?\n\nFinally, I am celebrating our collective imagination. I perform \u201cStories By Heart\u201d on an empty stage with a few sticks of furniture and a dusty old book. But if all the real and imagined people, places and things that inhabit my show were concrete and tangible, I would need a Reno-size stage to contain them.", "title": "John Lithgow, on Barnstorming His Way to Broadway", "authors": ["John Lithgow"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Writing that film\u2019s main theme required several weeks, Mr. Morris said. \u201cThe theme had to convey someone who worked on the edges of the circus, and the melody had to be poignant,\u201d Mr. Morris said in the Film Score Monthly interview. \u201cIt has two layers. It has the tune and then it has the over-layer, which is the circus. It took me a long time to arrive at that point.\u201d\n\nJohn Leonard Morris was born on Oct 18, 1926, in Elizabeth, N.J. His father, Thomas, was an engineer who designed the revolving doors at the Tiffany & Company flagship store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. His mother, the former Helen Sherratt, was a homemaker.\n\nWhen John was about 3, he and his parents visited friends in the Bronx who owned a piano, and he immediately became fascinated with the instrument, and eventually, his parents bought him one of his own.\n\nThe Morrises moved to Independence, Kan., when John was young, and he began taking piano lessons before returning east to study piano at the Juilliard School in the late 1940s. He also attended the University of Washington and the New School for Social Research.\n\nMr. Morris was too shy for the public life of a concert pianist, so he worked as an accompanist (for Judy Garland, among others), dance arranger, conductor and composer. He worked for Joseph Papp\u2019s Public Theater, where he wrote music for Shakespeare in the Park and was musical director for the pre-Broadway production of \u201cHair.\u201d And he helped create \u201cA Time for Singing\u201d (1966), a Broadway musical inspired by the novel \u201cHow Green Was My Valley,\u201d for which he wrote the music and collaborated on the lyrics and book with Gerald Freedman.\n\nFor the next 40 years, he composed music for numerous movies, including those directed by Mr. Wilder and Marty Feldman, as well as the comedy \u201cThe In-Laws\u201d (1979) and the stark drama \u201cIronweed\u201d (1987), and for television shows including the sitcom \u201cCoach\u201d and the mini-series \u201cThe Adams Chronicles\u201d (1976) and \u201cScarlett\u201d (1994), a sequel to \u201cGone With the Wind.\u201d", "title": "John Morris, Composer for Mel Brooks\u2019s Films, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "John S. Coleman, a co-founder of the Weather Channel, the original meteorologist on ABC\u2019s \u201cGood Morning America\u201d and, later in his career, a vocal climate change skeptic, died on Saturday at Summerlin Hospital Medical Center in Las Vegas. He was 83.\n\nHis death was confirmed by his family.\n\nBefore it became possible to use mobile phones to check humidity levels and wind speeds by ZIP code on demand, Mr. Coleman pioneered the concept of round-the-clock weather reporting.\n\nHe popularized the use of chroma key \u2014 better known as green screen \u2014 which allowed him to speak against a backdrop of ever-changing maps and images. Throughout his career his shows included warning systems to allow viewers to prepare for coming storms and incorporated lifestyle segments.\n\nNearly half of American households now tune in each month to the Weather Channel, which Mr. Coleman helped launch with Frank Batten Sr. in 1982.", "title": "John S. Coleman, Weather Channel Co-Founder, Dies at 83", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mill believed that schooling should be compulsory and that education should elevate the tastes of each generation. He worried, as Reeves writes, that \u201can ill-educated mass, with little time or inclination for moral musing, would threaten its own advancement if it simply adopted its own collective views, gathered up by the mass media and played back to the originating audience.\u201d\n\nMill\u2019s life was as energetic as his writing. He served in Parliament, worked as a colonial administrator and a university rector. He championed the labor movement, was the first member of Parliament to call for women to be given the right to vote, was the leading British philosopher of the 19th century and served as a loving son, husband and friend.\n\nMill had an optimistic view of human nature and probably an insufficient appreciation of human depravity. As Isaiah Berlin wrote in his essay \u201cJohn Stuart Mill and the Ends of Life,\u201d Mill was living in a Victorian moment when the chief problem was claustrophobia \u2014 the individual being smothered by society. He emphasized individual liberation. His emphases probably would have been different if he had lived today, when our problem is agoraphobia \u2014 too much freedom, too little cohesion, meaning and direction.\n\nBut Mill is a model for a life of balanced convictions. He had enough conscience to believe that there is moral truth, worth dying for. But he had enough humility to understand that none of us can ever fully know that truth, because it cannot be reduced to a single thing.\n\nHe championed the egalitarian belief that the best society allows maximum space for each member to craft his own life, but he had the civilized belief that there are clear distinctions between honor and dishonor, excellence and laziness.\n\nHis example cures us from the weakness of our age \u2014 the belief that we can achieve democracy on the cheap; the belief that all we have to do to fulfill our democratic duties is be nice, vote occasionally and have opinions. Mill showed that real citizenship is a life-transforming vocation. It involves, at base, cultivating the ability to discern good from evil, developing the intellectual virtues required to separate the rigorous from the sloppy, living an adventurous life so that you are rooting yourself among and serving those who are completely unlike yourself.\n\nThe demands of democracy are clear \u2014 the elevation and transformation of your very self. If you are not transformed, you\u2019re just skating by.", "title": "Opinion | John Stuart Mill Showed Democracy as a Way of Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "In 1970, when he was 36, Mr. Tunney ran for the Senate. He was blessed with a weak Republican opponent, the one-term incumbent George Murphy, a former actor and song-and-dance man whose age \u2014 he was in his late 60s \u2014 and health were issues. Mr. Murphy was also hurt by the revelation that while a senator he had been paid $20,000 a year as a public relations consultant for a movie company.\n\nMr. Tunney\u2019s victory margin in 1970 was bigger than that of Ronald Reagan, who was re-elected California governor that year. Soon, Mr. Tunney was being mentioned as a possible running mate of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, who seemed to have the inside track for the Democratic nomination to run against President Richard M. Nixon in 1972. But Mr. Muskie\u2019s campaign flamed out early in 1972.\n\nThat summer, Robert Redford starred in \u201cThe Candidate,\u201d a film based on Mr. Tunney\u2019s 1970 campaign, and the senator still appeared to have a bright future.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1974, the independent California Poll showed him to be more popular than Mr. Reagan, then in his last year as governor. In 1975, Mr. Tunney led a successful fight in the Senate to cut off funds for covert military operations by pro-American rebels in Angola. Mr. Tunney and like-minded lawmakers feared that involvement in Angola could lead to a Vietnam-like quagmire in Africa.\n\nBut many liberal Democrats were disenchanted with him. They thought he had been too slow to turn against the Vietnam War, which he had supported early on, and they were disappointed by his refusal to embrace a boycott of California grapes by striking farm workers.\n\nLiberals found a champion in Tom Hayden, the former campus radical, who challenged Mr. Tunney in the 1976 Senate Democratic primary. Mr. Hayden raised a lot of money and was a surprisingly effective campaigner, accusing Mr. Tunney of being beholden to big business, though Mr. Tunney had supported antitrust legislation as a senator.\n\nMr. Hayden also sought to turn Mr. Tunney\u2019s friendship with Senator Edward M. Kennedy against him, calling Mr. Tunney \u201ca Chappaquiddick waiting to happen,\u201d a reference to the 1969 incident in which the political aide Mary Jo Kopechne died when the car in which she was riding, driven by Mr. Kennedy, plunged off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island in Massachusetts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hayden later apologized for the remark. But after finishing a strong second in the June primary, Mr. Hayden offered only the most tepid support for Mr. Tunney in the general election. And the Kennedy allusion, fair or not, fanned complaints that Mr. Tunney preferred the companionship of elite Easterners over the company of Californians.\n\nIn fact, Mr. Tunney was a transplanted Californian, having had a privileged childhood in the East. His father, the former heavyweight boxing champion Gene Tunney, read widely and aspired to social status to go with his ring riches. He achieved it in 1928, when he married Polly Lauder, an heiress to the Carnegie steel fortune.\n\nJohn Varick Tunney was born on June 26, 1934, in New York City. He grew up in Connecticut with his brothers, Jay and Gene, who is deceased, and a sister, Joan, who is also deceased. He studied anthropology at Yale, graduating in 1956. He attended the Hague Academy of International Law, worked on John F. Kennedy\u2019s 1958 Senate campaign in Massachusetts and roomed with Edward Kennedy at the University of Virginia Law School, graduating in 1959.\n\nJohn Tunney later admitted to a certain immaturity and lack of purpose until, around the time he was in law school, he said, \u201cI suddenly became aware of the fact that this world was cold and cruel, and that people were indeed very, very hungry.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe practiced law briefly in New York City, then joined the Air Force as a judge advocate and was stationed near Riverside, Calif. He remained in California after leaving the service.\n\nSix feet three inches tall and fit in his prime, John Tunney was often described as handsome (although his bulging eyes and prominent teeth had saddled him with the nickname \u201cHorse\u201d in prep school). He was a far more imposing physical presence than his 1976 opponent, Dr. Hayakawa, who stood about 5-foot-5 and often sported a tam-o\u2019-shanter.\n\nBut Dr. Hayakawa, a world-renowned semanticist, had a priceless moment in the spotlight from his past. In 1968, when he was president of San Francisco State College, he climbed onto a sound truck used by student protesters and yanked out the wires to the microphones. Long afterward, the image resonated with Californians fed up with campus unrest.\n\nOn Nov. 2, 1976, Dr. Hayakawa received about 3.7 million votes to just under 3.5 million for Mr. Tunney, even though Democrats far outnumbered Republicans in California. Dr. Hayakawa was aided by a strong showing by President Gerald R. Ford, who carried California in his loss to Jimmy Carter. The numbers also suggested that some former supporters of Tom Hayden had voted for Dr. Hayakawa just to spite Mr. Tunney. (Dr. Hayakawa retired after one term.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen you get into public life, you\u2019ve got to be prepared to take your knocks,\u201d Mr. Tunney said after his defeat.\n\nAfter leaving office, he practiced law, served on corporate boards and was active in civic and cultural affairs. He enjoyed skiing, fly-fishing, biking, hiking and travel with his wife, the former Kathinka Osborne, who had been an Olympic skier from Sweden.\n\nIn addition to his brother Jay, he is survived by his wife; their daughter, Tara; his sons, Mark and Edward; a daughter, Arianne, from his first marriage, to Mieke Sprengers, which ended in divorce; a stepson, Cedric Osborne; a stepdaughter, Dariane Hunt; and three grandchildren.\n\nMr. Tunney seemed content to view politics from afar after 1976, although he did appear at a 1980 Los Angeles fund-raiser for his old friend Edward Kennedy in Mr. Kennedy\u2019s unsuccessful presidential bid that year. In 2003, Mr. Tunney joined two former Senate Democrats, George S. McGovern and Fred Harris, in opposing the war in Iraq.\n\nIn recent years, Mr. Tunney had homes in Sun Valley, Idaho; New York City; and Los Angeles.\n\nIn a 2013 interview with The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Tunney said he had good memories about his days in Washington, and he lamented the later \u201chostile\u201d atmosphere he saw there. \u201cIt\u2019s appalling what\u2019s happening in Congress,\u201d he said, \u201cthat these men and women who are elected to get things done are not even able to get to the point of an up-or-down vote.\u201d", "title": "John V. Tunney, Boxer\u2019s Son Who Lasted One Term in the Senate, Dies at 83", "authors": ["David Stout"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "But Robert Crippen, who flew with Mr. Young on the first space shuttle flight, called him an inspiration to the astronauts who followed him, remarking, \u201cIf they have a hero, that hero is John Young.\u201d\n\nIn addition to his versatility in flying all manner of spacecraft, Mr. Young was considered a meticulous engineer in troubleshooting technical problems during the preparation for his missions and other spaceflights, and he remained with NASA when many an astronaut headed for the business world.\n\nAs Mr. Crippen put it: \u201cIt\u2019s rare when an individual comes along that actually personifies his chosen profession, but rare is what John Young is.\u201d\n\nAfter serving as a Navy test pilot, Mr. Young joined NASA in 1962 at the outset of the Gemini program, a bridge between the missions of the original Mercury 7 astronauts and the Apollo program, which sent men to the moon.\n\nMr. Young flew twice in Gemini spaceships, flew on the Apollo mission that preceded Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin\u2019s landing on the lunar surface and later drove a rover vehicle through the moon\u2019s highlands. He closed out his explorations of space by flying on two shuttle missions.", "title": "John Young, Who Led First Space Shuttle Mission, Dies at 87", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Below, edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Bon Jovi.\n\nYou and Jesse visited Languedoc-Roussillon for your wine project. What was your impression of the region?\n\nI have been to the C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur at least 30 times before but never to this region, which is also in the south of France. It\u2019s a storybook area with castles and ruins and rolling hills, and I really loved the architecture \u2014 the medieval castles were in such good shape. Also, you\u2019re not really going to find any chain restaurants there. We dined at all tiny, family-run places, and I ate a lot of seafood, especially shellfish. Americans haven\u2019t discovered this part of France yet, and it was a pleasure to discover. Growing up in New Jersey, I\u2019ve been preaching my whole life that you have to get out to find the beautiful places in this world.\n\nHow much are you on the road for work?\n\nRock \u2019n\u2019 roll is cyclical. You do a record and you support it [by going on tour], and then it could be two years before you\u2019re out on the road again.\n\nWhen you\u2019re on tour, what kind of hotels do you like to stay at?\n\nI don\u2019t need opulence. I need simplicity because I\u2019m in a different hotel every day so the biggest suite is a waste because I can\u2019t use it. But I do need a hotel with a gym and a humidifier for my room. I also don\u2019t want any flowers in my room because they give me allergies.\n\nDo you have a favorite hotel?\n\nThe Peninsula in Chicago is my favorite in the U.S. Everything about it is awesome \u2014 the gym, the bar, the restaurant and the beds in the rooms.", "title": "Jon Bon Jovi Loves France and Wine (and Now Has His Own Label)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The Oakland Raiders are set to bring Jon Gruden back for a second stint as the head coach, according to various media outlets.\n\nThe Raiders are planning a news conference on Tuesday to announce that Gruden is leaving the broadcast booth to return to coaching, a person with knowledge of the team\u2019s plans told The Associated Press. More than any other Hollywood union, the Directors Guild\u2019s top award is heavily predictive of Oscar gold, with nearly 80 percent of all D.G.A. best director winners\u2019 pictures going on to land the academy\u2019s top prize.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe nominations of Ms. Gerwig and Mr. Peele also forecast a more diverse slate of best-director Oscar nominees the the all-white male roster that garnered Golden Globe nominations. Fall River was built by immigrants and was once the leading textile center in the United States. But its prosperity ebbed after World War I and it never fully recovered.\n\nMr. Trump captured only a third of the vote in Fall River in 2016 but he won several neighboring towns. The region is home to the sort of working-class voters the Democrats need in their efforts to regain control of Congress in the midterm elections this year. And it served as a fitting backdrop Tuesday night for the Democratic view that Mr. Trump has presided over an economy that benefits the nation\u2019s wealthy elite but has left the working class behind.\n\nVideo\n\nA raft of others in the party expressed dissent in their own statements and speeches.\n\n\u201cDonald Trump\u2019s presidency has been a series of broken promises to the middle class and workers, a fact which tonight\u2019s address did not change,\u201d Senator Bob Casey, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said in a statement.\n\nSenator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, put it this way: \u201cAmerica isn\u2019t stronger when Donald Trump tries to rip health care away from millions of Americans. Our future isn\u2019t stronger when he gives away gigantic tax breaks to billionaires and giant corporations so there\u2019s no money for education, infrastructure and the tools we need to succeed.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Kennedy III Gives Democratic Response to State of the Union", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Joseph A. Rice, who, as the head of a New York bank in the 1980s, played a leading role in a corporate battle that shook up an industry that had mostly avoided such fights, died on Jan. 8 at his home in New Paltz, N.Y. He was 93.\n\nHis death was confirmed by his son Philip.\n\nJoseph Rice was the chairman and chief executive of the Irving Bank Corporation in 1987 when a regional rival, the Bank of New York, made a hostile takeover offer, a startling move in an industry known at the time for its genteel business codes.\n\nMr. Rice, mild-mannered by nature, fought the deal and warned against such aggressive tactics. \u201cThe prospect of a Wild West shooting spree is not an admirable one in our business,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Bank of New York refused to take no for an answer. The battle lasted for more than a year, becoming the longest-running takeover fight in American business history to that point. Irving Bank drew on every resistance tool in the corporate armory, culminating in a close proxy fight.", "title": "Joseph Rice, Bank Chief Who Fought Hostile Takeover, Dies at 93", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 The democracy activist Joshua Wong was sentenced to three months in prison on Wednesday for his role in a protest in 2014 demanding freer elections for the leader of this semiautonomous Chinese territory.\n\nMr. Wong had pleaded guilty to contempt of court for refusing to obey a court order to leave a protest site in the last days of demonstrations, known as the Umbrella Movement, that paralyzed parts of Hong Kong without winning any political concession from the Chinese government.\n\n\u201cThey can lock up our bodies, but they cannot lock up our minds,\u201d Mr. Wong, a leader of the political party Demosisto, told reporters outside the High Court in Hong Kong before his sentencing.\n\nThe prison term dealt the latest blow to Mr. Wong, who was sentenced in August to six months in prison after he was found guilty of unlawful assembly. The pair made up the first female partnership to lead a London playhouse.\n\n\u201cI was proud to be the first woman director to run a major London theater, but I\u2019m even prouder that the landscape has now changed beyond recognition, and forever,\u201d Ms. Rourke said in a statement.\n\nDuring their tenure, the pair promoted the work of female actors and directors. In 2012, they worked with the director Phyllida Lloyd to produce an all-female Shakespeare trilogy starring Harriet Walter. \u201cThe impact of Phyllida\u2019s all-female Shakespeare Trilogy in promoting the value of women\u2019s and diverse voices on our stages has been particularly energizing,\u201d Ms. Pakenham said in a statement.", "title": "Josie Rourke and Kate Pakenham to Depart London\u2019s Donmar Warehouse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOnstage, he exuded simplicity, charisma and charm,\u201d she said by email. \u201cThe audience adored him.\u201d\n\nLater in life, Mr. Molina also made an impact as a teacher, introducing countless students to Spanish dance.\n\n\u201cHe taught by example, and he didn\u2019t lower his standards even when teaching beginners,\u201d recalled Ms. Shapiro, who now teaches flamenco at the Alvin Ailey School. \u201cHe would say, \u2018Better to do one thing right than 10 things badly.\u2019 And students endured the endless repetition not only because of his expertise, but because he taught with such generosity, warmth, humor and charm. Everyone had a crush on him.\u201d\n\nJos\u00e9 Molina Quijada was born in Madrid on Nov. 19, 1936. When, as a young boy, he took an interest in dance, his mother, Carmen, was supportive, but his father, Ramon, initially was not.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t want his son to be a dancer,\u201d Mr. Molina told The Palm Beach Post in 1972. \u201cIn those days they had prejudices about men in dance. Today \u2014 after I have become a success \u2014 he is proud of me and salutes my choice.\u201d\n\nTo earn money for dance lessons, Mr. Molina worked at the fish market where his father was employed. From ages 16 to 19 he toured nightclubs in Europe and the Middle East before making his television debut in the United States.\n\nDancing with Greco\u2019s company during a surge of interest in flamenco often put Mr. Molina in front of very large crowds. The audience for a June 1960 performance in New York at City College\u2019s amphitheater was estimated at 11,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce he formed his own company, he continued to play at prestigious outlets like Carnegie Hall and Jacob\u2019s Pillow in Massachusetts. He was not shy about giving traditional Spanish styles a show-business sheen aimed at American audiences, a tendency that some critics decried but that others found essential to maintaining interest in what could have been a fading fad.\n\n\u201cJos\u00e9 Molina and his troupe have elevated the Spanish dance form from the jaded nightclub floor show to the concert stage \u2014 its rightful place,\u201d Thelma Newman wrote in reviewing a 1972 performance in Florida for The Palm Beach Post.\n\nMr. Molina was also familiar to television audiences, especially from his more than 20 appearances on \u201cThe Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson\u201d in the 1960s, \u201970s and early \u201980s.\n\nMr. Molina, who lived in Manhattan, leaves no immediate survivors.\n\nLater in life he imparted flamenco and other forms to countless students in the humble but beloved Fazil\u2019s Times Square Studio, on Eighth Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets.\n\nSince it opened in the 1920s, the studio, nicknamed the Snake Pit, had been a rehearsal space for all sorts of dancers, including Fred and Adele Astaire, Judy Garland, Gene Kelly and Gregory Hines.\n\nFazil Cengiz, who operated the studio from 1978 until it closed in 2008, always took pains to make it available to flamenco dancers, who sometimes had trouble booking space because their furious footwork was thought to destroy floors. Mr. Molina, Ms. Shapiro said, \u201cwas the go-to teacher for flamenco in New York City when I started in the 1990s.\u201d\n\nInterviewed by The Times in 2000 for a feature article about the studio, Mr. Molina used the Spanish word \u201caire\u201d \u2014 \u201cwind\u201d or \u201catmosphere\u201d \u2014 to describe the ambience of the history-steeped place.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a genie going around the rooms, and we have to believe in that,\u201d he said. \u201cThe aire is not every day, but we catch it sometimes.\u201d", "title": "Jos\u00e9 Molina, 81, Who Brought Spanish Dance to U.S. Audiences, Dies", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "I had met Sandy only in passing at the Dunkin\u2019 Donuts when she dropped off Patrick for our interview, but she was clearly at her wit\u2019s end, having been enmeshed in his addiction for so long.\n\nAs a reporter, I was struck not only by her pain but also by her willingness to be identified. So often, people whose loved ones are addicted are ashamed and afraid of being stigmatized. When someone decides to go public, it is a godsend, as it helps combat accusations of \u201cfake news\u201d and shows that, as Sandy said in the article, \u201cwe are your neighbors.\u201d\n\nFrom there, the family drama of coping with addiction overtook the original story about New Hampshire. The Times assigned the photographer Todd Heisler to work with me, and the family allowed us to witness their grueling intervention with Patrick in July.\n\nSeveral people have asked how that worked. Journalists often worry that their mere presence will change people\u2019s behavior and render it inauthentic. In this case, the family members, all of whom were in extremis, were so focused on their own difficulties that they hardly noticed us. And we were discreet. No klieg lights. No microphones. We blended into the background and kept our mouths shut.\n\nThe reaction by readers has been overwhelmingly compassionate toward the Griffins. Many felt we had captured the tortured dynamics of their own families. In a shower of emails and postings on social media, they told their own stories of how continuing battles with addiction had destroyed the lives of loved ones.\n\n\u201cOverdoses and hospitals and rehabs and AA meetings and medications and arrests and pleading and interventions and court dates and driving to pick him up in the middle of the night from the most horrific holes,\u201d a colleague wrote of a close friend, adding, \u201cI finally had to cut him out of my life entirely two years ago.\u201d\n\nA tiny fraction of readers thought taxpayers should not spend a dime trying to help people like Patrick. \u201cNo one is forcing him to shoot up,\u201d one wrote, asking whether the money spent to save him might \u201chave been better spent on someone that actually CONTRIBUTES something to society?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA handful complained that the media never lavished such attention on black families when they were the main ones caught up in drug scourges.\n\nBut the vast majority thanked the Griffins for their \u201cbravery\u201d in going public. Total strangers offered to help by paying for rehab for Patrick or offering him a free place in their treatment programs.\n\nThe Griffins were overwhelmed. Like many families in their circumstance, they had allowed their silence about Patrick\u2019s addiction to isolate them. After the family told their story publicly, many people who had been close to them sought to reconnect. \u201cI had no idea what you guys were going through until I read that article,\u201d a long-estranged niece wrote to Sandy.\n\nAnother estranged niece also wrote a supportive note, concluding, \u201cI love you all and so proud and grateful to call you my family.\u201d\n\nWhat kinds of stories on the opioid crisis would you like to see us cover? If you have ideas, please take a few moments to answer this confidential survey.", "title": "Journalists at an Intervention", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA federal judge on Wednesday acquitted Senator Robert Menendez and his co-defendant of seven of the 18 corruption charges they faced, less than a week after prosecutors said they intend to retry the case.\n\nThe judge, William H. Walls, filed the opinion in Federal District Court in Newark in response to a motion to acquit the men on all charges after their trial ended in a mistrial in November.\n\nJudge Walls also recused himself from the second trial, but offered no explanation in the opinion.\n\nMr. Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, and his co-defendant, Dr. Salomon Melgen, still face 11 charges, including six bribery charges alleging that Mr. Melgen, a wealthy Florida ophthalmologist, provided the senator with lavish gifts and flights on his personal jets in exchange for political favors.\n\nThe Department of Justice said on Friday it intended to retry the two men, raising the possibility that Mr. Menendez will be on trial in a year when he is up for re-election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe legal team for Mr. Menendez released a statement reiterating one of its central arguments during the trial: The actions taken by the two men grew out of their friendship, and nothing more.", "title": "Judge Acquits Senator Menendez of Several Charges", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "It was not the first time that has happened. Twenty years ago, a federal judge in Manhattan issued a similar opinion, accusing the Law Department of \u201ca cavalier attitude\u201d toward discovery requests and saying that it treated them with the \u201clowest priority.\u201d The judge in that case, John S. Martin, ordered the city\u2019s top lawyer at the time, Michael D. Hess, to devise a method for \u201csystemizing and streamlining\u201d its discovery procedures.\n\nBut Judge Pollak\u2019s decision, which still requires approval from a senior judge, seems to suggest that Mr. Hess\u2019s improvements were not entirely successful.\n\n\u201cI fear that there has been a relapse of such misbehavior,\u201d Joel Berger, the lawyer who argued the case before Judge Martin, wrote in an email Wednesday night. Mr. Berger, who once served on the Law Department\u2019s executive staff, called Judge Pollak\u2019s decision \u201ca watershed opinion revealing misconduct that many of us have been experiencing in other police misconduct cases.\u201d\n\n\u201cVictims of police misconduct are made to suffer twice,\u201d he wrote. \u201cFirst by the officer who abused them, and then by a Law Department that subjects them to a nightmare of virulent opposition.\u201d\n\nNicholas Paolucci, a spokesman for the Law Department, said on Thursday that its lawyers take their discovery duties seriously and acted in good faith in the Martinez case to \"promptly produce all information known to them at the time.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe will vigorously oppose this recommendation,\u201d Mr. Paolucci said, \u201cwhich we believe is not supported by the record.\u201d\n\nWhile the production of discovery might seem like a minor aspect of the law, it is in fact crucial, allowing lawyers in a civil case to get a full picture of the facts before making motions or taking depositions. Judge Pollak\u2019s decision strikes that note, saying that the Law Department\u2019s serial excuses and delays had Ms. Martinez\u2019s lawyers \u201cchasing their tail.\u201d\n\nFrom the beginning of the case, her chief lawyer, Gabriel Harvis, tried to get the city to give him the names of the officers who had questioned her, a process that took seven months and four court orders. Yet even when he got the first two names \u2014 Lt. Jason Weitzman and Sgt. Jason Forgione \u2014 both men claimed that they had nothing to do with Ms. Martinez.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs discovery continued, however, \u201cit became apparent,\u201d Judge Pollak wrote, \u201cthat despite all of their efforts\u201d Ms. Martinez and her lawyers \u201chad not been given the full story.\u201d First, Mr. Harvis learned that the city had not turned over Sergeant Forgione\u2019s entire personnel file, which was missing records about a previous abuse complaint, the decision said. Then he learned that the city had not disclosed detective reports about the heroin deal that led to Ms. Martinez\u2019s arrest. When Mr. Harvis got those reports \u2014 after more delays and orders \u2014 they showed that she was not the dealer. Ms. Martinez, a housekeeper, wasn\u2019t even there.\n\nIt was then, in November, nearly two years after the lawsuit had been filed, that Judge Pollak held a hearing and asked the city\u2019s lawyer, Paul H. Johnson, why it took so long for the reports to be produced. \u201cI do not know,\u201d Mr. Johnson told her. \u201cThe client produced these documents, not me. I wasn\u2019t the one, like, searching for them.\u201d\n\nBut the worst was still to come, Judge Pollak wrote. One month later, the city committed what she called its \u201cmost critical failure\u201d \u2014 one that, as she put it, \u201ccast a completely different light on what may have occurred.\u201d\n\nOn Dec. 18, a new city lawyer \u2014 Mr. Johnson was replaced \u2014 suddenly provided Mr. Harvis with more than 1,000 pages from three police investigations of his client\u2019s claims. The inquiries not only cast doubt on the officers\u2019 contention that Ms. Martinez had hurt her hand while punching the wall of her cell, the decision said; they were also never mentioned by anyone, including the 11 officers who had been through depositions.\n\n\u201cNone of them came forward with information about this incident or the investigations for almost two years,\u201d Judge Pollak wrote. \u201cThis suggests either a failure to conduct even the most superficial investigation by counsel or, of deeper concern, that counsel was deliberately not informed due to a cover-up perpetrated by the N.Y.P.D.\u201d", "title": "Judge Blasts City for Delays in Queens Police Abuse Case", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe executive branch has a choice to make,\u201d the lawyer, Michelle Gelernt, wrote last week in a motion to dismiss Mr. Lett\u2019s charges. \u201cWhether to proceed with the criminal case against Mr. Lett or whether to proceed instead with his removal.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat the executive branch cannot do,\u201d Ms. Gelernt said, \u201cis to use its immigration authority to detain Mr. Lett while pursuing its criminal case against him.\u201d\n\nIn making her argument, Ms. Gelernt, of the Federal Defenders of New York, relied on two recent orders by Judge Irizarry that came in similar cases of immigrants who were arrested on detainers after being freed on bail. In her orders, Judge Irizarry wrote that by holding immigrants released on bail with immigration detainers, the government was essentially making \u201can end run\u201d around the country\u2019s bail laws.\n\nAt play in all three cases is a tension between the Bail Reform Act, which protects defendants\u2019 rights to be released before their trials, and the Immigration and Nationality Act, which gives the government the power to detain and deport people who are in the country illegally. Though appeals courts have not yet addressed the conflict, Judge Irizarry wrote in one of her orders that criminal cases legally take precedence over deportation efforts, adding in the other that the government cannot \u201cproceed on a dual criminal prosecution and deportation track.\u201d\n\nBut by using its immigration powers to hold immigrant suspects freed on bail by legal means, the government, Judge Irizarry wrote, had placed in jeopardy \u201cthe constitutional rights of the accused.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn both of the cases she considered, Judge Irizarry gave the government two options: it could either deport the defendants through the immigration system or dismiss the charges against them. But it could not detain them for immigration violations while continuing to pursue their criminal prosecutions, she said.\n\nThe first case, decided in November, concerned a Dominican man, Saba Rosario Ventura, who arrived in New York from Santo Domingo on April 7 with a green card that had expired the previous day. When border agents at Kennedy Airport determined that Mr. Ventura had been deported once before for an immigration violation, they took him into custody.\n\nIn August, he was indicted in Brooklyn on immigration charges and released on bail within two weeks with his case still pending. But instead of going free as the court had ordered, Mr. Ventura was arrested by the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, and is now in the Hudson County jail as the government decides if it will appeal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe defendant in the second case, decided on Dec. 20, is Salomon Benzadon-Boutin, a dual citizen of Panama and Spain. In July 2015, Mr. Benzadon-Boutin arrived in New York on a Panamanian visa that had expired six months later.\n\nIn October \u2014 while in the country illegally \u2014 Mr. Benzadon-Boutin was charged with money laundering after an investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Although he was granted bail in November and was supposed to be released, he was arrested on an immigration detainer and taken to the Hudson County jail.\n\nIn court papers, Mr. Lett\u2019s lawyer, Ms. Gelernt, said that she spoke in December with the Customs and Border Protection agent who arrested her client and claims the agent told her that detaining immigrants who had already been freed on bail marked a change in policy.\n\n\u201cThe agent verified that, under previous policy, arriving aliens who were charged with federal crimes and released on bail pursuant to the Bail Reform Act, were routinely released after a brief detention at JFK,\u201d Ms. Gelernt wrote. \u201cThe CBP agent further informed defense counsel that, as a result of a recent executive order, CBP was now instructed to request \u2018bed space\u2019 in an immigration detention facility for arriving aliens charged with federal crimes, but released on bond.\u201d\n\nTeddy Camlen, a spokesman for Customs and Border Protection in New York, said the authority to use detainers in bail situations was not new, but was being newly enforced.\n\n\u201cThese are charges that could possibly get people deported and we don\u2019t want them out walking on the street,\u201d Mr. Camlen said. \u201cThat\u2019s the whole point of the detainer.\u201d", "title": "Judge Faults U.S. for Holding Immigrant Defendants Freed on Bail", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Kate writes: I have been asking my boyfriend, Brian, for a fun, fancy birthday cake for 10 years. I\u2019ve relaxed the definition over time to include prefab cakes, like Carvel\u2019s Cookie Puss. But he has never done it. I\u2019m turning 40. Please order Brian to provide a custom-made fun, fancy cake.\n\nUntil \u201cCookie Puss,\u201d I was beginning to worry you were using \u201cfun, fancy\u201d as a euphemism for \u201cerotic.\u201d Do people still buy those? In Essex Street Market there used to be a pastry stall that had a model cake on display with an orgy on top: nude revelers barely concealed by a blanket of fondant. It collected dust for years, but my revulsion remained fresh. Anyway, yes: Brian is a monster. He must order you a custom fun, fancy cake at punishing expense for your 40th. (Unless Cookie Puss is erotic to you. Please order that every booty photo needs a cute baby animal superimposed on top of it. I suggest a wombat.\n\nMostly this column is a court of last resort to restrain the bad behavior of a spouse, and in such cases, the court has your ear. Marriages and other glum adult partnerships are defined by the restraint of base impulses in favor of the pleasure of compromise and mature self-censorship. But a cousin-in-law is a stranger to you, so you have no claim on his bum enjoyment. Your case is hopeless. After all, the first law of the internet is: I will see flesh I did not intend to see. I have allergies, and when I visit her cubicle, I often have to blow my nose. I toss my tissues in her trash, which she finds revolting. Tissues have no smell, and I think her insistence that I return to my own cubicle to use the trash is unreasonable.\n\nThis court\u2019s sinuses are also a disgusting phlegm factory, and so I extend my sympathy. It\u2019s debilitating not only to have to fight with your own mucus day after day but also to know that you are grossing out the innocents around you. Or maybe you haven\u2019t recognized that last part. While I agree your snot is odorless (I hope), it is still a viscous discharge from inside your head. It is a human right to limit how much of another person\u2019s DNA is left behind in your own cubicle. I insist that it is, at best, a moronic misspelling. She says that it fits the definition of a pun whether or not I think it\u2019s funny. Does it?\n\nFor those unfamiliar with this track, the title is derived from the song\u2019s call and response, \u201cBut are you getting it?/Armageddon it!\u201d (in which \u201cit\u201d refers to lead singer Joe Elliott\u2019s deep, deep personal affection). That it\u2019s a complete non sequitur doesn\u2019t change the fact that it is obviously wordplay (a kind of intentional mondegreen; look it up). And the best proof that it is, in fact, a pun is that you think it is dumb, as puns are a very specific form of nonjoke designed to entertain only the dads who tell them. \u201cDef Leppard\u201d itself, though, is just moronic misspelling on purpose.", "title": "Judge John Hodgman on a Vexing Glam-Metal Lyric", "authors": ["Judge John Hodgman"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Julia Dorothy Yost and Matthew James Schmitz were married Jan. 27 at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. After his challenges to the extradition order were refused, he skipped bail and fled to the embassy in June 2012. He was granted asylum two months later and has remained at the embassy, in the wealthy Knightsbridge district of West London, ever since.\n\nMr. Assange feared that Sweden would turn him over to the United States to face prosecution over WikiLeaks\u2019 publication of troves of classified government documents on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, classified diplomatic cables and electronic hacking by the C.I.A., among other subjects.\n\nSweden dropped the rape inquiry in May, and withdrew the European arrest warrant it had requested. He was 67.\n\nManuel Quintanilla, the federation\u2019s current president, said his predecessor died after an illness he had had \u201cfor several months.\u201d\n\nA federation spokesman, Moises Avalos, told Nueva Radio Ya that Rocha had cancer. He added that family members petitioned for him to be able to return from the United States to die in his home country, \u201cbut unfortunately nothing could be done.\u201d\n\nRocha was president of the federation from 1987 to 2012 and director of the Central American Soccer Union from 2003 to 2007.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2013, he became development director for Concacaf. It was in that capacity he was arrested in May 2015, along with other soccer executives from Latin America, at a hotel in Switzerland.
