View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRocha was accused of taking more than $150,000 in bribes linked to the sale of marketing rights, and in 2016 he pleaded guilty in a United States court to racketeering conspiracy and wire fraud conspiracy.\n\nRocha was awaiting sentencing at the time of his death, and faced a maximum of 20 years in prison for each count.", "title": "Julio Rocha, Jailed FIFA Official From Nicaragua, Dies at 67", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Lester\u2019s first published book, which appeared in 1965, was an instructional manual, \u201cThe Folksinger\u2019s Guide to the 12-String Guitar as Played by Leadbelly,\u201dwritten with Pete Seeger.\n\nIn the 1960s, Mr. Lester was closely involved as a writer and photographer with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, becoming the head of its photography department. In that capacity, he traveled to the South to document the civil rights movement and to North Vietnam to photograph the effects of American bombardment.\n\nFor much of this period he was an ardent separatist, arguing, as The Boston Globe reported in 1970, \u201cthat all effort should be turned to finding a way to establish a black nation within the territorial confines of the United States.\u201d\n\nIn \u201cLook Out, Whitey!,\u201d his first book about race, Mr. Lester wrote: \u201cThe world of the black American is different from that of the white American. The difference comes not only from the segregation imposed on the black man, but from the very nature of blackness and its evolution under segregation.\u201d\n\nReviewing \u201cLook Out, Whitey!\u201d in The Times Book Review in 1968, the novelist and historian Truman Nelson called it \u201ca magnificent example of the new black revolutionary writing that could generate the tidal force to sweep aside all the tired and dead matter on our literary shores.\u201d\n\nIn 1968, Mr. Lester became the host of a weekly show about political issues, broadcast on WBAI.\n\nLate that year, Leslie R. Campbell, an African-American New York City schoolteacher, appeared as a guest on the show. The broadcast came on the heels of the racially charged controversy over local control of public schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn, a predominantly black neighborhood whose schools were staffed by a predominantly white cadre of teachers.\n\nAmid the crisis, the United Federation of Teachers, many of whose members were Jewish, went on strike throughout the city, affecting hundreds of thousands of students and resulting in dozens of lost school days.", "title": "Julius Lester, Chronicler of Black America, Is Dead at 78", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Modern computers have reduced those weeks of work to hours, and both maps and census and political data have become far more accurate, he said. In creating 2011 redistricting maps, Wisconsin Republicans created a composite partisan score for each of the state\u2019s 6,000-plus wards based on the results of statewide elections since 2004. North Carolina used results from as many as 20 state elections; Maryland\u2019s NCEC Services used a regularly updated \u201cDemocratic performance index,\u201d a proprietary analysis of the party\u2019s strength in state and federal races.\n\nRedistricting that begins in 2021 is likely to be even more finely tuned, Mr. Brace said, relying on the explosion of marketing and online information that can infer personal preferences down to individual households. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing that more and more in campaigns,\u201d he said, \u201cso I think you\u2019ll see people wanting to use it in redistricting.\u201d\n\nWhile consultants can and sometimes do produce hundreds of suggested maps, most present political leaders with between five and 10 options that can be fine-tuned to meet incumbents\u2019 wishes.\n\nIn states where political power is divided, district maps may be politically neutral \u2014 or drawn to shield incumbents in both parties. In other states under one-party control, the political marching orders may be more brazen: North Carolina Republicans ordered that no more than three of the state\u2019s 13 House seats be given to Democrats.\n\nMr. Gaddie, who analyzed the partisan impact of proposed Wisconsin State Assembly maps for the chamber\u2019s Republicans, says partisan gerrymandering has become a threat to the political system because politics has devolved into all-out ideological war, not because of redistricting software or dark-hearted mapmakers. He said he abandoned a sideline as a redistricting adviser and expert witness in redistricting lawsuits after finishing work in Wisconsin.\n\n\u201cI liked working for them in \u201902,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause I\u2019d sit down with a lawyer and they\u2019d say, \u2018I like competitive maps. When a map is competitive, we can win on the merits.\u2019 By the time I get around to 2011, they\u2019ve changed. I can\u2019t defend this crap.\u201d\n\nThat is not to say that mapmakers are wholly innocent bystanders in the process. \u201cIt would be good for the country and politics if partisan gerrymandering ended,\u201d Mark Gersh, the former president of NCEC Services, said in an email this week. But in a subsequent interview, Mr. Gersh stood up for his firm\u2019s work in Maryland and elsewhere.", "title": "Just How Bad Is Partisan Gerrymandering? Ask the Mapmakers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "This article, which is part of the Opinion Today newsletter, has been expanded and updated since publication.\n\nWhen it comes to President Trump and race, there is a predictable cycle. He makes a remark that seems racist, and people engage in an extended debate about whether he is personally racist. His critics say he is. His defenders argue for an interpretation in which race plays a secondary role (such as: Haiti really is a worse place to live than Norway).\n\nIt\u2019s time to end this cycle.\n\nNo one except Trump can know what Trump\u2019s private thoughts or motivations are. But the public record and his behavior are now abundantly clear. Donald Trump treats black people and Latinos differently than he treats white people.\n\nAnd that makes him a racist.\n\nIs it possible to defend some of his racially charged statements by pointing out that something other than race might explain them? Sure. Is it possible that he doesn\u2019t think of himself as a racist who views white people as superior to nonwhite people? Yes.", "title": "Opinion | Just Say It: Trump Is a Racist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFrom the very beginning, I never wavered in my innocence and my belief that justice would prevail,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cI am grateful that the Department of Justice has taken the time to re-evaluate its case and come to the appropriate conclusion.\u201d\n\nThe initial indictment against Mr. Menendez was brought in 2015, well before the Supreme Court\u2019s McDonnell decision in 2016. Since then, political corruption cases against two of New York State\u2019s major power brokers, Dean G. Skelos, the former Senate majority leader, and Sheldon Silver, the former speaker of the Assembly, were both overturned by judges who cited the McDonnell decision.\n\nIn seeking to press their case against Mr. Menendez, prosecutors not only would have had to likely address the Supreme Court\u2019s ruling, but they would have been armed with a smaller trove of evidence given the reduced number of charges, a combination that seems to have led to the decision not to move forward.\n\n\u201cTo me, it was an overall evaluation of what\u2019s left. Can we get some of these key pieces of remaining evidence in?\u201d said Rebecca Monck Ricigliano, a former federal prosecutor. \u201cAnd then, is it going to be enough to meet this heightened standard?\u201d\n\nDespite the jury\u2019s inability to reach a verdict in November, Mr. Menendez emerged politically wounded. Polls immediately after the mistrial showed a majority of voters believed that he should not run in November. But he enjoyed the support of nearly every key Democratic leader in the state, including Gov. Philip D. Murphy, who on Wednesday said that \u201cthe notion to have two extraordinary senators in this state, unencumbered, 1,000 percent focused on pushing forth the interest of the nine million folks who call New Jersey home is a new and great day.\u201d\n\nMr. Menendez now enjoys a clearer path to victory in the Democratic primary and in his campaign for his third full term in the Senate. \u201cSenator Menendez is looking forward to running a strong campaign and onto victory in November, fighting for the people of New Jersey against Donald Trump\u2019s failed policies,\u201d said Michael Soliman, a top political adviser to Mr. Menendez.\n\nHaving started his career in New Jersey politics at age 20 on the Union City school board, Mr. Menendez methodically worked his way up the state\u2019s political ladder \u2014 mayor, assemblyman, state senator and congressman \u2014 before reaching the United States Senate in 2005. And in a state with a long and deep history of political back scratching, accusations of wrongdoing dogged him for years before he was indicted three years ago along with his longtime friend, Dr. Melgen.", "title": "Justice Department Dismisses Corruption Case Against Menendez", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Among the specific sports marketing companies that prosecutors are scrutinizing, according to the subpoena, is Helios Partners, a firm that has lobbied global sports officials to award high-profile events to particular cities and countries. Helios helped Russia secure the 2014 Winter Olympics and the coming 2018 World Cup, before its acquisition in 2012 by the Amaury Group, a French media company.\n\nAmerican prosecutors are also specifically interested in Eugene\u2019s successful bid for the track and field event, which the U.S.O.C. actively supported, and Doha\u2019s successful effort to host the 2019 edition of that competition, which occurs every two years.\n\nAbroad, the same competitions have drawn intense scrutiny. France\u2019s national financial prosecutor\u2019s office has been investigating the track and field governing body and its choices of Eugene and Doha. Track and field\u2019s world governing body gave the 2021 event to Eugene without a bidding process. The BBC reported in June that the F.B.I. and the I.R.S. were investigating Eugene\u2019s selection.\n\nLamine Diack, who ran the international track federation for 16 years and served as a longtime member of the I.O.C., has been detained in France since November 2015, accused of accepting bribes for covering up the doping violations of Russian athletes.\n\nConnections to Mr. Diack and his son led the Brazilian authorities to arrest Carlos Arthur Nuzman, the head of Brazil\u2019s Olympic committee, last fall amid suspicions that Rio de Janeiro\u2019s successful bid to stage the 2016 Summer Games was helped by bribery to secure supportive votes from members of the I.O.C.\n\nThe wide net newly cast by American prosecutors suggests overlapping threads with the French investigation, but the Justice Department is also soliciting broader information, including about FIFA \u2014 suggesting that American authorities\u2019 scrutiny of that organization, which figured prominently into a federal trial late last year, is far from over.\n\nFIFA itself has sought to turn the page on its corruption scandal, emphasizing its status as a victim in the American case and its cooperation with investigators. Former officials were charged with an array of crimes, including racketeering conspiracy and fraud \u2014 the same issues central to the prosecutors\u2019 continuing scrutiny.\n\nFIFA, too, has a major competition scheduled to be held in Qatar: the 2022 World Cup. At the FIFA trial last year, new information emerged about alleged bribery that helped to steer that tournament to Qatar.", "title": "Justice Dept. Escalates Inquiry on Global Sports Corruption", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Department of Justice said on Tuesday that it will ask the Supreme Court to immediately review a federal judge\u2019s ruling that ordered the government to restart a program that shields some young illegal immigrants from deportation.\n\nThe administration\u2019s request is unusual, and it comes amid an ongoing political battle over immigration. The program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, is at the center of it.\n\nThe Justice Department said it had also appealed the decision, issued by Judge William Alsup of the Federal District Court in San Francisco. His ruling imposed a nationwide stop on the Trump administration\u2019s decision to end the program until litigation can be heard.\n\nElaine Duke, the acting homeland security secretary at the time, \u201cacted within her discretion to rescind this policy with an orderly wind-down,\u201d Attorney General Jeff Sessions said in a statement. \u201cWe are now taking the rare step of requesting direct review on the merits of this injunction by the Supreme Court so that this issue may be resolved quickly and fairly for all the parties involved.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s request means that the case, brought by the University of California system and its president, Janet Napolitano, herself the former secretary of homeland security, could be heard by the Supreme Court even before it winds its way through the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.", "title": "Justice Dept., Fighting to Kill DACA, Asks for Supreme Court Review", "authors": ["Katie Benner"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Too often, this is the case. The fine for a misdemeanor is typically about $1,000, which can be unmanageable for a low-income person. This comes on top of many other costs. The application fee a defendant must pay to hire a public defender (appointed because a person charged with a crime cannot afford to pay for an attorney) can be as high as $400. Jail booking fees range from $10 to $100. In some states, defendants can be made to pay fees upward of $200 for the juries who hear their cases. After conviction, victim\u2019s panel classes, where some defendants are mandated to hear about victims\u2019 experiences and loss, can cost up to $75. Drug courts can and often do make people pay for their own assessment, treatment and frequent drug testing.\n\nThis system shifts the costs of our criminal justice system to the people processed by the system. Juvenile, traffic, misdemeanor and felony courts all rely on monetary sanctions. Fines, court-user fees, surcharges, assessments, interest, collection and per-payment fees fund everything from local law enforcement departments to county jails. Even some municipal services not connected to law enforcement, like campaign elections, are paid for by fines and fees imposed on citizens convicted of \u2014 or simply accused of \u2014 breaking the law.\n\nThese people are paying for the system of justice from which we all benefit, but they cannot afford to do so. They are often poor, unemployed and of color. In research on monetary sanctions in nine states, my research team and I found that many people have trouble navigating the legal process associated with fines and fees, like finding out how much money they owe and meeting minimum payment requirements. Of the 380 people we interviewed, over half received public assistance and a vast majority had problems paying their legal debt. Many people with court debt suffered added consequences related to their indigence \u2014 like difficulty meeting other financial obligations, and mental and physical ailments. They also had to answer to the court for their nonpayment.\n\nFines for drug offenses, in particular, can have long-term consequences for people who are unable to pay. In many jurisdictions, if a person cannot pay a court-imposed fine, probation is lengthened, warrants are issued and he or she can even be jailed for nonpayment. The burden is piled on, as interest, surcharges and collection fees are added to unpaid court costs.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t have to be this way. While prosecutors do not directly fine defendants, they have discretion when it comes to which fines and fees they recommend to judges. New prosecutors who are serious about making progressive changes should be aware that alternatives to incarceration like diversion programs and classes and treatment come at a cost \u2014 literally.\n\nThey can reform the justice system without adding the financial burden of fees and classes that defendants must pay for. They should instead search for ways to reduce criminal justice budgets by prioritizing preventive measures proved to decrease recidivism and improve public safety such as free drug and alcohol treatment programs, low-cost housing, restorative justice and job training. To start, lower courts should rely on day fines, where monetary sanctions are determined based on a person\u2019s daily wage and the seriousness of the offense. The sanction is proportionate to a person\u2019s ability to pay and the degree of harm inflicted. Jurisdictions could reduce justice-related budgets by restructuring drug-sentencing laws to match public opinion and revise the use of mandatory minimum, long-term and life sentences.", "title": "Opinion | Justice Shouldn\u2019t Come With a $250 Fine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed inclined to rule that people not listed as authorized drivers on rental car agreements nonetheless have privacy rights when they are pulled over by the police.\n\nViolating a rental agreement by letting a family member or friend drive a car may be a breach of a commercial contract, several justices said. But it does not follow, they added, that the police may search the cars without the driver\u2019s consent.\n\nThe alternative, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said, would give the police too much power.\n\n\u201cIf we rule that someone without permission has no expectation of privacy even when the renter has given it to them,\u201d she said, \u201cthen what we\u2019re authorizing is the police to stop every rental car and search every rental car, without probable cause, that might be on the road.\u201d\n\nSeveral justices said that violating other provisions of a rental contract \u2014 by talking on a cellphone, say, or driving on an unpaved road \u2014 should not lead to the forfeiture of constitutional protections. They suggested that failing to list an additional driver was, similarly, a mere breach of contract that does not overcome the protections of the Fourth Amendment, which bars unreasonable searches.", "title": "Justices Seem Ready to Back Driver of Rental Car in Privacy Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "After three election cycles using the interim maps, the district court ruled that they were flawed. \u201cAlthough this court had \u2018approved\u2019 the maps for use as interim maps, given the severe time constraints it was operating under at the time of their adoption,\u201d the court said that approval was \u201cnot based on a full examination of the record or the governing law\u201d and was \u201csubject to revision.\u201d\n\nThe court concluded that Texas\u2019s adoption of the interim maps was part of \u201ca litigation strategy designed to insulate the 2011 or 2013 plans from further challenge, regardless of their legal infirmities.\u201d\n\nState officials then filed emergency applications in the Supreme Court, asking the justices to block the district court\u2019s order until their appeal was heard. In a brief order in September, the Supreme Court agreed. The vote was 5 to 4, with the court\u2019s more conservative members in the majority.\n\nThe new cases, Abbott v. Perez, No. 17-568, and Abbott v. Perez, No. 17-626, join two voting rights cases already on the court\u2019s docket concerning partisan gerrymandering.\n\nInternet Sales Taxes\n\nThe Supreme Court also agreed to reconsider a 1992 ruling that helped spur the rise of internet shopping. The ruling, Quill Corporation v. North Dakota, barred states from forcing companies to collect sales taxes if they do not have a local physical presence.\n\nStates say the ruling has deprived them of tens of billions of dollars in annual revenue. Brick-and-mortar companies complain that they are put at a competitive disadvantage when they are required to collect sales taxes and online companies are not.\n\nThree members of the Supreme Court have indicated that they may be ready to re-examine the Quill decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJustice Anthony Kennedy, in a concurring opinion in 2015, seemed to call for a fresh challenge to the ruling.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt is unwise to delay any longer a reconsideration of the court\u2019s holding in Quill,\u201d he wrote. \u201cA case questionable even when decided, Quill now harms states to a degree far greater than could have been anticipated earlier.\u201d\n\nJustices Clarence Thomas and Neil M. Gorsuch have also written about their uneasiness with the decision and the constitutional justifications for it.\n\nThe petition in the new case, South Dakota v. Wayfair, No. 17-494, asked the Supreme Court to overrule Quill, and 35 states and the District of Columbia filed a supporting brief making the same request.\n\nThe petition said that a central rationale for the decision \u2014 that it would be burdensome for out-of-state retailers to calculate and collect taxes for thousands of state and local jurisdictions \u2014 has been solved by modern software.\n\nThe defendants in the case, three internet retailers, responded that \u201cthe largest online sellers collect sales tax in all states.\u201d\n\n\u201cAmazon.com, the poster child of online marketing, which accounts for half of all internet sales and 60 percent of the growth, now collects sales tax in every state that has a sales tax,\u201d they wrote. \u201cIf Quill is overruled the burdens will fall primarily on small and medium-size companies whose access to a national market will be stifled.\u201d\n\nIn-House Judges\n\nThe Supreme Court also announced that it would decide whether in-house judges at the Securities and Exchange Commission had been deciding cases without constitutional authorization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe in-house judges, known as administrative law judges, were appointed by the commission\u2019s personnel office rather than by the five-member commission itself. That may have run afoul of the Constitution\u2019s appointments clause, which requires \u201cinferior officers\u201d to be appointed by the president, the courts or \u201cheads of departments.\u201d The commission itself is a \u201chead of department,\u201d while its personnel office is not.\n\nIf the in-house judges were \u201cinferior officers,\u201d their appointments were unconstitutional. If they were mere employees, there is no constitutional problem.\n\nThe Justice Department, which had long contended that the in-house judges were employees and not officers, switched positions in the Supreme Court in November 2017. In an unusual move, it urged the justices to grant review in the case, Lucia v. Securities and Exchange Commission, No. 17-130, even though it had won in the appeals court.\n\nThe day after the Justice Department request, the commission appeared to cure the constitutional problem. It issued an order ratifying the appointments of the in-house judges. And it instructed judges to give fresh consideration to pending matters.\n\nThe case arose from charges that Raymond J. Lucia and his firm had made misleading presentations to prospective clients about a retirement strategy they called \u201cBuckets of Money.\u201d\n\nMr. Lucia lost before an administrative law judge and the S.E.C., and a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit rejected a challenge to the judge\u2019s authority. The full appeals court agreed to rehear the case, but its judges deadlocked 5 to 5.\n\nIn a brief filed last month urging the Supreme Court to hear the case notwithstanding recent developments, Mr. Lucia\u2019s lawyers said he would not benefit from the commission\u2019s order.", "title": "Justices to Hear Cases on Voting Rights and Internet Taxes", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMan of the Woods\u201d posits Mr. Timberlake not as a sex-symbol soul supernova, but as an affable bro who enjoys the funk, soul and disco of the 1970s. The music here is tactile and warm: erotically lush disco on \u201cMontana,\u201d offhand Southern gospel on \u201cYoung Man,\u201d casual country-funk on the title track.\n\nTimbaland and the Neptunes handle the vast majority of the production, and most of it looks backward, not forward. The Neptunes, especially, thrive with this approach, especially on \u201cHigher Higher,\u201d a gleaming 1970s soundtrack homage. There are outliers \u2014 the throbbing pulse of \u201cFilthy\u201d has reverberations of acid house, and \u201cSupplies\u201d suggests someone has been listening to Migos \u2014 but for much of this album, Mr. Timberlake is content to live in the past.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, Mr. Timberlake has a third friend now: Chris Stapleton, stoic king of earthen country music, who appears here a few times as a songwriter, on guitar, and on \u201cSay Something,\u201d in duet. His writing, especially on \u201cThe Hard Stuff,\u201d is evocative. (That song would sound better sung by Mr. Stapleton.) And on \u201cSay Something,\u201d he sings with grounded purpose.\n\nEarly whispers about this album, prompted in part by a video teaser in which Mr. Timberlake wore fringe and frolicked on a plain, suggested Mr. Timberlake was embracing American roots and country music. But while it turns out that visual marketing tactic wasn\u2019t much more than that \u2014 in the eyes of some, it was meant to telegraph a return to whiteness for an artist who\u2019s always openly flirted with black aesthetics \u2014 there was some truth embedded therein.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow Mr. Timberlake goes about it, though, is novel. Rather than bow explicitly to country music, he revisits its greasy overlaps with funk. The guitars on this album often bend, but the basslines are punchy too.\n\nThat musicology lesson is the loudest part of this album, certainly louder than Mr. Timberlake, whose reticence is a recurring feature here. His vocals often recede so far in the mix that their inherent sweetness gets lost.\n\nAnd his words often fall short, serving as a better a rhythmic component than an emotional one. His lyrics are cheesy, or simply empty \u2014 that\u2019s harmless when the production sparkles, but they glow with a radioactive tint when it\u2019s not, like on the tacky \u201cWave\u201d (\u201cWe\u2019re getting better, aging like your favorite wine/I\u2019ve got on rose-colored glasses, you\u2019re batting your eyelashes\u201d) or the inexplicable \u201cLivin\u2019 Off the Land,\u201d which suggests a never-made 1970s hicksploitation film.\n\nMr. Timberlake is at his best on \u201cMan of the Woods\u201d when he sounds like he\u2019s fronting a family band. (Sometimes, that\u2019s literal, as both his wife and son have credited vocals on this album.) In an exceedingly un-pop-star way, the whole of these songs is far greater than his input. He never crowds the room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s possible that Mr. Timberlake does not perceive himself \u2014 or wish to present himself \u2014 as the oxygen-hoovering superstar the celebrity ecosystem has long demanded of him. And maybe this album that barely flirts with the sounds of the day is, in actuality, the ultimate superstar indulgence \u2014 not too big to fail, but too big to care.", "title": "Justin Timberlake Looks Beyond the Pop Star Life on \u2018Man of the Woods\u2019", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "1. But he died as a celebrated poet of the United States and its people, especially the flinty farmers of New England.\n\nRobert Frost, whose life was full of paradoxes, died on this day in 1963 in a Boston hospital. A gifted observer of nature and the human spirit, he won four Pulitzer Prizes and spoke at John F. Kennedy\u2019s inauguration in 1961.\n\nFrost lived for years in Vermont and New Hampshire, initially working as a farmer, reporter and shoemaker. His poetry, including works like \u201cThe Road Not Taken\u201d and \u201cStopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening,\u201d used colloquial language and spoke to an urbanized generation that longed for the simplicities of rural life.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like to write anything I don\u2019t see,\u201d he said before his 88th birthday.\n\nBut he \u201chad no illusions about the life of the soil,\u201d The Times noted the day after his death in 1963, in part because he knew it could be \u201cspiritually crippling and physically exhausting.\u201d\n\nMike Ives contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. But there was some confusion when, after it was Ms. Gerber\u2019s turn to speak (\u201cOmega always takes such great care of our family,\u201d she said), the M.C. tried to wrap up the presentation prematurely.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a fourth member of the Gerber family,\u201d said Ms. Gerber, who had emerged as one of the world\u2019s most in-demand celebrity models, ever since she made her runway debut in New York a few weeks earlier.\n\nOh, right.\n\nStanding alongside, but almost lost amid their sheer wattage, was the family\u2019s 55-year-old patriarch, Rande Gerber. Tall, fair-complexioned and background-handsome (think Kevin Costner in \u201cThe Bodyguard\u201d), he exuded the patience of a man who was used to being overlooked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Gerber, a former model, took the mic and, with the modesty of a supporting player, thanked Omega for employing his family. \u201cBecause now I can retire,\u201d he said, to polite chuckles. \u201cThey\u2019re all working.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn fact he may have been one of the richest men at the party.\n\nCasamigos, a tequila brand that he created with the actor George Clooney and the developer Michael Meldman, was acquired last June by Diageo, the multinational beverage giant, for $700 million to $1 billion. The deal was a new high in Mr. Gerber\u2019s successful career as a night-life entrepreneur, which began in the 1990s with a string of hip bars, with the Morgans Hotel Group, that defined an era.", "title": "Kaia Gerber\u2019s Dad Was a Model, Too", "authors": ["Ben Widdicombe"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Kansas\u2019 preseason Associated Press ranking was No. 4, but it is now No. 10, and should drop some more after this loss.\n\nThat its three losses came at home is particularly notable. In December, Kansas lost back-to-back games, first against Washington in Kansas City, Mo., then against Arizona State at the campus arena in Lawrence. Arizona State has developed into a very strong team, it turns out, but Washington is nothing special so far, currently rated around 100th by computer rankings.\n\nBefore the season, Self\u2019s total of conference championships, 13, exceeded his total losses at Allen Fieldhouse, 10. The loss total at the fieldhouse is now 12, and there is a good chance it will grow.\n\nKansas had been 101-3 over the previous 10 seasons against major conference opponents at home, ESPN reported.\n\nKansas is not a bad team; 11-3 against a good schedule is certainly creditable. It ranks in the top 10 in field-goal percentage and the top 20 in 3-point shooting.\n\nBut its long record of success has led to much higher expectations: home-court dominance, a Big 12 title every year, a deep N.C.A.A. run.\n\nKansas lost its two top scorers, Frank Mason and Josh Jackson. Both were drafted into the N.B.A., and Jackson went No. 4 over all. But elite programs in this era lose top players every year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne glaring statistic is the team\u2019s free-throw rate. It has taken only 180 shots from the line, 347th out of 351 Division I teams.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s a sign that Kansas may be relying too much on small players rather than big men who get inside and get fouled. And indeed, its top three scorers, and five of its top six, are all listed as guards.\n\nThat means the Jayhawks may have to live and die by the 3. Against Texas in their previous game, they were 17 for 35 and won by 6. On Tuesday, they were 6 for 26.\n\nA freshman expected to help out in the frontcourt, Billy Preston, a top 20 recruit, has not played while the N.C.A.A. investigates him over the financing of his car. Preston was the team\u2019s only top 100 recruit this season, according to ESPN\u2019s rankings. The 6-foot-9 Silvio De Sousa, originally part of next year\u2019s class, has enrolled early and is awaiting N.C.A.A. approval to play.\n\nDevonte\u2019 Graham is the team\u2019s top player, and he has taken a step forward this year. But teams dependent on 6-2 seniors don\u2019t tend to be national championship contenders.\n\nSelf has hope for the future. \u201cI think we\u2019re going to be really good by the end,\u201d he told The Kansas City Star last week. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019ll be close to what we can be until February.\u201d\n\nBut after Tuesday\u2019s loss, he was more negative, questioning the team\u2019s will to win: \u201cThose are hungry athletes on the other side we didn\u2019t match from an intensity standpoint. We got what we deserved. I hate to say this as a coach because I\u2019m really disappointed in the way we competed.\u201d\n\nBesides the embarrassing home losses, the team has some good wins, including an early one against Kentucky. But a game Saturday at T.C.U., ranked 16th, could send the Jayhawks to 1-2 in the Big 12. West Virginia and Oklahoma are also having strong seasons and are ranked in the top 10. Kansas may not get its usual stroll to a Big 12 title.", "title": "Kansas Is Suddenly Vulnerable at Home, and in the Big 12", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Huck has been the sole owner of his company since 2012, when he bought out his partner, Jonathan Cheban, the reality TV star. He now employs seven and travels frequently, often watching his deals come to life \u2014 hey, there\u2019s Neil Patrick Harris for Heineken Light! \u2014 on the television screen of an airport lounge or hotel room.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the most gratifying feeling, to see it all come together,\u201d he said.\n\nIf Mr. Huck is awake, he is working, phone in hand \u2014 even when vacationing in Greece or in the Middle East with Mrs. Kardashian West. \u201cHe could be on a camel in Egypt reciting a paragraph from the contract,\u201d said Carla Laur, a commercial endorsement agent at Creative Artists Agency who has worked on dozens of deals with Command Entertainment Group.\n\nMr. Huck suggested his dedication arises from mistrusting his good fortune. \u201cI still have moments where I feel like someone is going to pull the rug from under me and be like, \u2018You actually have to go to law school,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cIt sometimes all feels like a dream.\u201d\n\nThe seeds of success were sown during a snowstorm in 2005, when he was taking a break from studying political science at Queen\u2019s University in Kingston, Canada, and flipping through the pages of US Weekly. The high-profile publicist Lizzie Grubman had been spotted making out with the singer John Mayer at the New York City hot spot Marquee.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI went home, spent 24 hours on Google researching everything about P.R. and found Lizzie\u2019s number,\u201d Mr. Huck said.\n\nTwo days later he was in Manhattan for the first time.\n\nWearing a shiny khaki suit and square-toed Diesel shoes, Mr. Huck, positive he looked \u201cso New York,\u201d was given two minutes with Ms. Grubman\u2019s chief financial officer.\n\n\u201cI was bumbling all over the place,\u201d Mr. Huck said. \u201cI left the office and I remember doing a Myspace upload in the elevator.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne hour later, Mr. Cheban, then Ms. Grubman\u2019s partner, called him to come back in. He had a job \u2014 well, an unpaid internship.\n\nMr. Huck abandoned his college apartment and everything in it, packed a duffel bag and stayed on friends\u2019 couches for two years. He worked putting together invitation lists and securing red-carpet press. Sean Combs\u2019s White Party in the Hamptons was one of his first big projects.\n\nWhen Mr. Cheban left Ms. Grubman\u2019s company to return to his own agency, Command PR, which he had started in 1999, he took Mr. Huck with him.\n\nThe two quickly went from giving brands suggestions of whom they should work with to negotiating the entire deal. They also met and befriended Kim Kardashian, who was then running a successful eBay closet along with the Dash boutique chain she founded with her sisters.\n\nWhile they were at dinner with Kim and Kourtney Kardashian in Los Angeles, Kim said they were planning to do a reality show about their life and their families on the E! network.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t think anything of it, but Kim always had conviction,\u201d Mr. Huck said. \u201cShe\u2019s one of the most brilliant marketers I\u2019ve ever met in my life.\u201d Moreover, \u201cIf I ever need advice, she\u2019s the person I call and it\u2019s straight up, tell it like it is. She\u2019s a pragmatist.\u201d\n\nEven the executive-producing talents of Mrs. Kardashian West, alas, could not save the E! reality show Mr. Huck and Mr. Cheban did themselves: \u201cThe Spin Crowd.\u201d\n\nStill, Mr. Huck feels elevated by the experience, and excited for the future.\n\n\u201cI want to continue to grow and grow,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is just the beginning.\u201d", "title": "Kardashian Bestie Simon Huck Is Selling You Beer and Shampoo", "authors": ["Caitlin Keating"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "He virtually immobilized her in a Chagall-inspired costume with huge wings and a burdensome long train in his 1974 \u201cFirebird.\u201d In \u201cVariations Pour Une Porte et Un Soupir,\u201d to musique concrete that represented the creaks of a door and the sound of sighing, she was the femme fatale attached to a huge cape that spanned the stage and with which she swallowed up a writhing male dancer. Erotic, highly romantic or gimmicky, the piece never left a viewer indifferent.\n\nBy contrast, a brilliant novelty of a different kind, Balanchine\u2019s \u201cUnion Jack,\u201d exploited Ms. Von Aroldingen\u2019s bravura. Here, at an imaginary gathering of Scottish clans, she stunned viewers in the \u201cMacDonald of Sleat\u201d section as the leader of a turbulent, leaping, hard-driving female ensemble in kilts and toe shoes. And all to the thunderous beat of unaccompanied drums.\n\nEssentially, Ms. von Aroldingen saw herself as an allegro dancer. \u201cI\u2019m used to dancing very open, very big,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nBalanchine used her strong technique in \u201cWho Cares?,\u201d his foray into George Gershwin\u2019s music of big-city romance. The dance writer Don McDonagh suggested in The New York Times in 1970 that Ms. Von Aroldingen\u2019s solo had captured the energy of \u201ca career girl who seems to know exactly where she is going.\u201d\n\nShe later described the difficulties behind the number: \u201cMy variation is a killer \u2014 lots of high jumps.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKarin Anny Hannelore Reinbold von Aroldingen was born in Griez, Germany, on Sept. 9, 1941. Originally from Berlin, her family had been evacuated to Grieze, in eastern Germany, during the first years of World War II.\n\nMs. von Aroldingen told an interviewer in 1997 that her father, a scientist, had gone to a meeting in Czechoslovakia toward the end of the war and never returned.\n\nAfter the war, her mother moved with her three daughters to what by then was West Berlin, where Karin studied ballet as a child.\n\nAt 17, she joined the Frankfurt Opera Ballet, where her Russian \u00e9migr\u00e9 teacher, Tatjana Gsovsky, choreographed a new version of Kurt Weill\u2019s \u201cSeven Deadly Sins.\u201d (It was originally choreographed by Balanchine in 1933.) She cast Ms. von Aroldingen as the dancing double to Lotte Lenya, who had the major singing role.\n\nMs. Lenya soon wrote a letter to Balanchine recommending Ms. von Aroldingen, who auditioned for him in 1962 in Hamburg, where he was staging an opera. The audition went badly by Ms. Von Aroldingen\u2019s account, but two months later she was invited to join City Ballet\u2019s corps in New York.\n\nShe was promoted to soloist in 1967 and to principal dancer in 1972. By that time she had danced a large variety of roles.\n\nJerome Robbins cast her only once in a premiere, the 1971 \u201cGoldberg Variations,\u201d in which she and Peter Martins performed an eccentric puppetlike duet. But over the years she also appeared in Frederick Ashton\u2019s \u201cIlluminations\u201d and Antony Tudor\u2019s \u201cDim Lustre.\u201d\n\nMs. von Aroldingen gave viewers a new look at familiar roles. In Balanchine\u2019s \u201cProdigal Son,\u201d her Siren was not aloof but a cruel temptress who threatened to devour Mikhail Baryshnikov methodically with every acrobatic embrace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInitially, for some in the audience, Ms. von Aroldingen was a dancer outside the City Ballet fold. Her broad-shouldered physique and muscular legs \u2014 traditional among European dancers but no longer so at City Ballet \u2014 made her controversial. Yet she retrained her body and her style, taking classes at the School of American Ballet.\n\n\u201cIt took me years to unwind myself, to be good,\u201d she once said.\n\nThat Balanchine had spotted her potential was obvious: He created 18 roles for her. Along the way she married Morton Gewirtz, a real estate broker and architectural consultant. He died in 2011.\n\nIn addition to their daughter, Margo, Ms. von Aroldingen is survived by two grandsons and a sister, Elga Weininger.\n\nAs Balanchine, who was divorced four times, grew older in the 1970s, he began to spend more time with Ms. von Aroldingen and her husband, even becoming Margo\u2019s godfather. Ms. von Aroldingen and her husband had a home on Long Island, in Southampton, and Balanchine acquired a condominium nearby. They celebrated and cooked together for Russian Christmas and Easter.\n\nMany who knew Balanchine said that Ms. von Aroldingen had provided him with a family, and that she had played a major role in caring for him in his final illness, a progressive neurological disorder. He died in a Manhattan hospital.\n\nWhile Balanchine insisted that music was the springboard for his ballets, he often captured a dancer\u2019s personality in unexpected ways. The Karin von Aroldingen who athletically executed a rotating backbend in a tension-filled duet with Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux in the model Balanchine leotard ballet, \u201cStravinsky Violin Concerto,\u201d was also the passionate, elusive feminine ideal in \u201cTchaikovsky Suite No. 3\u201d and the equally elusive aristocrat in \u201cVienna Waltzes.\u201d\n\nThe tenderness audiences sensed in these roles burst into the open in \u201cRobert Schumann\u2019s \u2018Davidsb\u00fcndlert\u00e4nze,\u2019 \u201d the most emotional of Balanchine\u2019s rare neo-Romantic works. Ms. von Aroldingen was cast as the unnamed woman representing Clara Schumann, who, with warmth and caresses, finally bids her husband a poignant farewell.\n\nBalanchine did not tell her whom she was depicting when he was choreographing the ballet, she said. In keeping with his general approach to dancers, he told her: \u201cI can tell you certain things, but in the end, it\u2019s you who has to do it. I can chew for you, but you have to swallow it.\u201d", "title": "Karin von Aroldingen, a Major Dancer for Balanchine, Is Dead at 76", "authors": ["Anna Kisselgoff"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKate Whitman Aufses and Dr. Justin Hunter Oldfield were married Jan. 13 in New York. Rabbi Ari S. Lorge officiated at the Rainbow Room.\n\nThe bride, 31, is an associate with the New York law firm Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann. She graduated magna cum laude from Kenyon College, and received two master's degrees, in American literature and art history, from Cambridge University. She received a law degree from University of Michigan.\n\nShe is the daughter of Robin Dissin Aufses and Arthur H. Aufses III of New York. The bride's father is a litigation partner in the New York law firm Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel. He is the president of the board of Hudson Guild, a settlement house focused on serving the Chelsea community in New York. The Union South Bay residential apartment complex in Carson, Calif., for example, is being built by Katerra from a design created by Architects Orange.\n\nThe idea, according to Mr. Marks, is to approach construction more like a factory run by Toyota, which is known for efficient mass production, rather than the current method of assembling disparate components in a less organized fashion. The business model has similarities to that of the electronics industry, which Mr. Marks and one of the company\u2019s biggest investors, Foxconn, know well.\n\nThe idea is to not have every building be a one-off prototype, the company says.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s shocking how poorly things work,\u201d Mr. Marks said of the construction industry in a telephone interview. He added, \u201cThere\u2019s a lack of quality processes throughout the system.\u201d\n\nBy contrast, Katerra\u2019s approach, he contends, allows clients to save money and erect buildings like offices and multifamily homes more quickly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile Katerra loses money now, Mr. Marks said that the company was on track to become profitable as soon as next year.\n\nThat different approach had already drawn the interest of prominent investors like Foxconn; DFJ, the venture capital firm; and Louis Bacon, the hedge fund mogul. About four months ago, Katerra began talks on raising a new round of capital, and a number of connections \u2014 including Foxconn\u2019s chief executive, Terry Gou, and Jerry Yang, the Yahoo co-founder \u2014 put the start-up\u2019s leaders in touch with Masayoshi Son of SoftBank.\n\n\u201cKaterra is leveraging the latest technologies to radically transform the way people build,\u201d Jeffrey Housenbold, a managing partner at SoftBank Investment Advisers, said in a statement.\n\nAs part of the investment, Mr. Housenbold and Adam Fisher of the Soros fund will join Katerra\u2019s board.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile Mr. Marks declined to comment on the valuation that this new round has bestowed upon Katerra, he said that it was a sizable step up from the roughly $1 billion of the previous round.\n\nThe new money will allow Katerra to build yet more factories \u2014 up to four over the next few years \u2014 and finance more research and development, he added.\n\nFurther down the line, Mr. Marks said, is an initial public offering.\n\n\u201cOver time we expect that we might get offers, but this is intended to stay an independent company,\u201d he said. \u201cThis will be a public company at some point.\u201d", "title": "Katerra, a Construction Start-Up, Raises $865 Million", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKathryn Marchand Minor and Geoffrey Gardner Jones were married Jan. 13 at Stein Eriksen Lodge in Park City, Utah. The Rev.
