The groom graduated from Stanford, from which he also received an M.B.A.\n\nHe is a son of Mr. Jones of Washington, and the late Olivia Barclay Jones.\n\nThe groom\u2019s father was a congressman from Oklahoma (1973-87), president of the American Stock Exchange (1989-93) and ambassador to Mexico (1993-97).\n\nThe couple were set up by a mutual friend and met in November 2008 on a blind date in Washington.", "title": "Kathryn Minor, Geoffrey Jones", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Katy Jean Mason and Devin Coy Hampton are to be married Jan. 14 at the Prospect House in Dripping Springs, Tex. Amanda Brown Lierman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.\n\nMs. Mason, 30, works remotely from Oakland, Calif., where she is an operations manager for Giffords, a Washington-based nonprofit organization aiming to end gun violence; the group was founded by former Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords. Ms. Mason graduated from the University of Washington in Seattle.\n\nShe is the daughter of Barbara Mason of Absecon, N.J., and Joseph Mason of Brigantine, N.J. The bride\u2019s father is a freelance carpenter in Brigantine, where he retired as a firefighter with the City of Brigantine Fire Department. Her mother is an elementary school teaching assistant in Pleasantville, N.J.\n\nMr. Hampton, 37, also works in Oakland, where he is the vice president for business development for UtilityAPI, an energy sector start up. He also graduated from the University of Washington.", "title": "Katy Mason, Devin Hampton", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "It has replaced Russian with Kazakh as the main language of education and government, put English on a par with Russian in foreign language teaching and produced a torrent of Kazakh-language films and television programs that celebrate the country\u2019s culture and long-vanished nomadic traditions.\n\nThe shift to the Latin alphabet, to be completed by 2025, has been widely cheered as a long overdue assertion of the country\u2019s full independence from Russia \u2014 and its determination to join the wider world. The main objections have come from the Russian Orthodox Church in Moscow and ethnic Russians living in Kazakhstan.\n\nFar less popular, however, has been a decision by the president in October to ignore the advice of specialists and announce a system that uses apostrophes to designate Kazakh sounds that don\u2019t exist in other languages written in the standard Latin script.\n\nThe Republic of Kazakhstan, for example, will be written in Kazakh as Qazaqstan Respy\u2019bli\u2019kasy.\n\nIn a country where almost nobody challenges the president publicly, Mr. Nazarbayev has found his policy on apostrophes assailed from all sides.\n\nLinguists, who had recommended that the new writing system follow the example of Turkish, which uses umlauts and other phonetic markers instead of apostrophes, protested that the president\u2019s approach would be ugly and imprecise.\n\nOthers complained the use of apostrophes will make it impossible to do Google searches for many Kazakh words or to create hashtags on Twitter.\n\n\u201cWe are supposed to be modernizing the language but are cutting ourselves from the internet,\u201d Mr. Sarym said.", "title": "Kazakhstan Cheers New Alphabet, Except for All Those Apostrophes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Fitzwilliams is an ardent supporter of keeping the wild wild, but he is well aware that if the Forest Service becomes increasingly responsible for fatalities on mountains, they will have to act to mitigate such risks \u2014 and since more and more individuals are heading into the mountains for self-discovery and the peculiar breed of ecstasy the mountains provide, injuries and deaths are also increasing.\n\nThe political response in Colorado has been predictable. Local sheriffs and senators and governors are calling deaths in the mountains \u201cunprecedented,\u201d and demanding more signs, \u201cbetter\u201d trails and other intrusions.\n\nSo far, the argument for preserving the \u201cwilderness experience\u201d has kept these changes at bay. But if the Forest Service (or national parks) assume greater risk for visitor safety, they will be forced to institute a range of solutions to reduce their liability \u2014 like apps that guide us along virtual routes or keep us on trail as though we were in car lanes, or other \u201csoft\u201d intrusions.\n\nOf course, if American policymakers and citizens conflate urban and wild space \u2014 as the French have already done on Mont Blanc \u2014 we will see more and more lawsuits against the Forest Service, or another agency, for failing to protect individuals when they are in a natural setting.\n\nAround the country, parks are getting sued for wild animal attacks on visitors within their boundaries, for falling trees or for not warning visitors for the most obvious of risks, such as rivers flooding during storms. These cases indicate a population out of touch with natural danger. If this trend continues, the mountains will have undergone as radical a transformation as they did in the 18th century, when they morphed from ominous landscapes of gloom to topographies of heroic conquest.\n\nThe origins of mountain climbing lay in the middle of the 19th century. Before that, they were seen as landscapes of evil otherness, where the tempestuous gods exercised their wrath. The curious ventured not.\n\nAfter the 1850s, climbing became for some a way to \u201covercome the self\u201d or \u201cexperience the sublime.\u201d As townspeople and shepherds found their way to the tops of the Alps, the ability to thwart death and overcome human limitation in mountainous landscapes became valued \u2014 but that value assumed an environment of risk. A hero needs adversity, and the extreme conditions and danger of the mountains provided that. Later, in the middle of the 20th century, the literature of the golden era of big Himalayan climbing lionized first ascensionists because they, like great generals or explorers, navigated risk successfully.\n\nMountains are inherently dangerous. But just as free speech makes a place for disgusting speech, wild places need to make a place for irresponsible activity. It is our life, after all. Right? Not really. Our right to life doesn\u2019t always include our right to risk it. If that thought doesn\u2019t feel strange to you, think about it again. It should.", "title": "Opinion | Keep Our Mountains Free. And Dangerous.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "When a character in a crime novel snaps and kills a child, it\u2019s usually a mother stressed beyond endurance. In Leila Slimani\u2019s unnerving cautionary tale, THE PERFECT NANNY (Penguin, paper, $16), subtly translated by Sam Taylor, we know from the outset that it\u2019s a beloved and trusted nanny who murders the two children in her care. That\u2019s pretty radical for a domestic thriller; but what\u2019s more remarkable about this unconventional novel (which was awarded France\u2019s prestigious Prix Goncourt) is the author\u2019s intimate analysis of the special relationship between a mother and a nanny.\n\nMyriam and Paul, the Parisian couple who hire Louise to help care for their son and daughter, are delighted to discover that she\u2019s \u201ca miracle worker\u201d who cleans, reorganizes the household and even cooks delicious meals. \u201cNothing rots, nothing expires\u201d in Louise\u2019s kitchen. At first, they bask in their unexpected comfort, \u201clike spoiled children, like purring cats.\u201d Much too late, Myriam realizes that the new nanny may not be entirely benevolent: \u201cShe is Vishnu, the nurturing divinity, jealous and protective.\u201d But already Louise \u201chas embedded herself so deeply in their lives that it now seems impossible to remove her.\u201d Despite Myriam\u2019s fears, Louise has no intention of replacing her as the woman of the house; rather, in her pathological loneliness, the nanny increasingly fantasizes that she has become a de facto member of the family.\n\nSlimani writes devastatingly perceptive character studies. Dropping their children at day care, the mothers are \u201crushed and sad,\u201d the children \u201clittle tyrants.\u201d She also raises painful questions. Could Myriam be projecting onto her nanny her own forbidden desire to be free of her children and their insatiable needs? (\u201cThey\u2019re eating me alive,\u201d she thinks.) Is there an element of racial prejudice in the Moroccan-born Myriam\u2019s attitude toward her French nanny? Is Louise\u2019s pitiless act the transference of her forbidden feelings about her privileged employer? One thing is clear: Loneliness can drive you crazy, and extreme loneliness can make you homicidal.\n\n\u2666\n\nThe intense thrills of Thomas Perry\u2019s THE BOMB MAKER (Mysterious Press, $26) are almost unbearable. After sweating through a scene in which a member of the Los Angeles Police Department Bomb Squad narrowly escapes a lethal explosion, we\u2019re knocked back by the loss of 14 team technicians \u2014 half the squad \u2014 who are blown to smithereens. \u201cBombs were acts of murder,\u201d Perry writes, but \u201cthey were also jokes on you, riddles the bomber hoped were too tough for you.\u201d", "title": "Keep Watch Over Your Children: Danger Lurks Everywhere", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "And the remedy can be ridiculously simple: Just sit up.\n\nSocial psychologists like Amy Cuddy claim even standing in a confident posture, with your head up and shoulders back, can heighten testosterone and cortisol flow in the brain, preventing much of the above. So, why aren\u2019t we heeding these signs? It might be simple denial.\n\nInattentional blindness is a problem\n\nSome 75 percent of Americans believe their smartphone usage doesn\u2019t impact their ability to pay attention in a group setting, according to the Pew Research Center, and about a third of Americans believe that using phones in social settings actually contributes to the conversation.\n\nBut does it?\n\nEtiquette experts and social scientists are adamantly united: Nope.\n\nThat \u201calways-on\u201d behavior that smartphones contribute to causes us to remove ourselves from our reality, experts said. And aside from the health consequences, if we\u2019re head down, our communication skills and manners are slumped, too. But, ironically, that might not be how most of us see ourselves.\n\n\u201cWe think somehow that this antisocial behavior is not going to affect me,\u201d said Niobe Way, professor of applied psychology at New York University.\n\nMs. Way studies technology\u2019s role in shaping adolescent development. These head-down interactions take us away from the present, no matter what group we\u2019re in, she said. And it\u2019s not just a youth problem. It\u2019s ingrained, learned, copied and repeated, much of it from mimicking adults. When kids see their parents head down, they emulate that action. The result is a loss of nonverbal cues, which can stunt development.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s happening more and more is we\u2019re not talking to our children,\u201d Ms. Way said. \u201cWe put them in front of the tech when they\u2019re young, and when we\u2019re older, we\u2019re absorbed in our own tech.\u201d\n\nYou\u2019ve seen it: Think of how some parents deal with screaming toddlers. \u201cHere kid, take this iPhone and go to town,\u201d according to Ms. Way \u2014 not, \u201cLet\u2019s talk this out, what seems to be the problem, son?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe added: \u201cWe think, \u2018Somehow my kids will know what\u2019s a good and bad interaction, they\u2019ll have empathy.\u2019 But when I go upstairs into my son\u2019s room and seven teens are all looking at their phones, none of them saying a word, there\u2019s all sorts of disengagement happening. It\u2019s not Facebook that\u2019s the problem, it\u2019s how we\u2019re using Facebook.\u201d\n\nAll ages are affected\n\nA study in 2010 found that adolescents ages 8 to 18 spent more than 7.5 hours a day consuming media. Since then, our digital addictions have continued to, in some ways, define our lives: In 2015, the Pew Research Center reported that 24 percent of teenagers are \u201calmost constantly\u201d online.\n\nAdults aren\u2019t any better: Most adults spend 10 hours a day or more consuming electronic media, according to a Nielsen\u2019s Total Audience Report from last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe National Safety Council reports cellphone use makes drivers more accident prone than drunk driving, causing 1.6 million crashes annually, mostly from young people ages 18 to 20. One out of four accidents in the United States are caused by texting and talking on the phone while driving.\n\n\u201cMobile devices are the mother of inattentional blindness,\u201d said Henry Alford, the author of \u201cWould It Kill You to Stop Doing That: A Modern Guide to Manners.\u201d \u201cThat\u2019s the state of monomaniacal obliviousness that overcomes you when you\u2019re absorbed in an activity to the exclusion of everything else.\u201d\n\nThe social scientist Sherry Turkle analyzed 30 years of family interactions in her book \u201cAlone Together: Why We Expect More From Technology and Less From Each Other.\u201d She found that children now compete with their parents\u2019 devices for attention, resulting in a generation afraid of the spontaneity of a phone call or face-to-face interaction. Eye contact now seems to be optional, Dr. Turkle suggests, and sensory overload can often mean our feelings are constantly anesthetized.\n\nResearchers at the University of Michigan claim empathy levels have plummeted while narcissism is skyrocketing, with emotional development, confidence and health all affected when we tuck our chins in and let our heads hang like human ostriches.\n\nFacebook\u2019s former president, Sean Parker, recently said the platform was designed to be addictive and to \u201cconsume as much of your time and conscious attention as possible,\u201d which he characterized as boosting our self-esteem, ever-present in the dopamine hit of likes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt literally changes your relationship with society, with each other,\u201d he said. \u201cIt probably interferes with productivity in weird ways. God only knows what it\u2019s doing to our children\u2019s brains.\u201d\n\nThat said: You\u2019re probably reading this story on a mobile device right now. And that\u2019s O.K.! (As long as you\u2019re not behind the wheel.) We\u2019re not here to tell you to throw away your iPhone and abandon digital media. But like many addictions, admitting a problem is the first step to treatment. And, mercifully, the fix isn\u2019t anti-tech \u2014 it\u2019s pro-conversation, according to Dr. Turkle.\n\nMake an effort to interact with people\n\nDigital detoxes have never been so popular, but they\u2019re no cure-all, and realistically, there simply isn\u2019t a black-and-white fix.\n\nThe simplest answer for all of us is biblical: Do unto others \u2014 and maybe do it without clutching your smartphone. Next time you\u2019re in the checkout lane or stopped at a red light, look around. How many people are really there with you?\n\n\u201cActual human beings, in the flesh, take precedence,\u201d Ms. Martin chided. \u201cTo ignore people you\u2019re with is rude, whether you ignore them for virtual friends or distant friends by snubbing them.\u201d\n\nIt sounds so obvious it almost borders on stupid. But like Dr. Turkle\u2019s hope of building dialogue, not denigrating the digerati, it\u2019s an obvious dialogue we\u2019re not having enough of.\n\nMr. Alford, who used to write a monthly manners column for The New York Times, described the issue as a \u201cmonomaniacal obliviousness\u201d of being absorbed in an activity to the exclusion of the rest of the world.\n\n\u201cTo treat the person standing in front of you as secondary to your phone, is usually, as the kids say, a micro-aggression,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany Silicon Valley pundits go to war when anyone so much as suggests that tech\u2019s merits aren\u2019t uniformly positive. But in light of the brutal schoolyard that social media has become, that approach now appears moot.\n\nYoung or old, we\u2019re all a generation of literal test cases. Etiquette, manners, body language, the way we respond, interact and even look is changing. We\u2019re missing a whole life happening a mere 90 degrees above our smartphones. Start looking up.\n\n\u201cNever be the first person in the group to whip out his phone,\u201d Mr. Alford said. \u201cDon\u2019t be Patient Zero.\u201d\n\nCorrection 1/30/2018: An earlier version of this article misstated the number of car accidents attributed to the use of smartphones. About one quarter of car accidents in the United States are caused by texting and talking on the phone while driving, not solely by texting.", "title": "Keep Your Head Up: How Smartphone Addiction Kills Manners and Moods", "authors": ["Adam Popescu"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Afterward, there are enough products, samples and ideas in the archives, said Carla Sozzani, the owner of the 10 Corso Como boutique and one of Mr. Ala\u00efa\u2019s closest collaborators, for the studio he left behind to create new seasonal collections \u201cfor generations.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think this is what he would have wanted,\u201d she said. Despite the fact that Mr. Ala\u00efa was 82, he had not exactly strategized for the future, and there had never really been any discussions of formal succession.\n\n\u201cHe thought he was eternal,\u201d Ms. Sozzani said. But while not focused on the mechanics of the house, he was \u201cvery concerned with legacy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo that end, he and his partner, the painter Christoph von Weyhe, created the Azzedine Ala\u00efa Association in 2007, a nonprofit that will be administered by Ms. Sozzani, Olivier Saillard (the former director of the Palais Galliera, one of Paris\u2019s two fashion museums), and Mr. von Weyhe. That took place at the same time that a majority stake in the company was being sold to Richemont.\n\n\u201cWe were reorganizing his life, and he wanted to protect his work and archives,\u201d Ms. Sozzani said. According to Mr. von Weyhe, Mr. Ala\u00efa set aside enough money to endow the association, which is in the process of applying for more formal foundation status.\n\nMr. Ala\u00efa had been saving his own work since the 1980s, and he has been collecting the work of designers he admired for even longer, including pieces from Charles James, Paul Poiret, Vionnet, Chanel, Madame Gr\u00e8s and many others. Neither Ms. Sozzani nor Mr. Saillard could venture a guess as to how many pieces there were, but together they occupied five floors and approximately 14,760 square feet in Mr. Ala\u00efa\u2019s compound on rue de la Verrerie. To create more room there, a portion of the archive is being moved to a building near rue de la R\u00e9publique, which has an additional 9,840 square feet.\n\n\u201cI never saw such archives in my life,\u201d said Mr. Saillard, who is effectively the association\u2019s curator. \u201cHe has the most important private collection devoted to the history of fashion. For 20 years I used to see him at auctions, and we curators were all very jealous because he always bought the masterpiece we wanted, and he always refused to show them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd it wasn\u2019t just clothes. Mr. Ala\u00efa collected furniture from designers including Pierre Paulin, Jean Prouv\u00e9, Shiro Kuramata and Marc Newson, as well as books. It is the clothes, however, and the patterns, fabrics, buttons and sketches \u2014 the record of his creative process \u2014 that will form the basis of the continuing life of the house.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe kept everything,\u201d Ms. Sozzani said.\n\n\u201cI think what they are doing is actually spot on because they are continuing his work and his legacy by showing what he worked on but never showed,\u201d said Ikram Goldman, of the Chicago boutique Ikram, who has sold Mr. Ala\u00efa\u2019s clothes to Michelle Obama and other clients since opening in 2001. \u201cThese days there is so much chopping and changing of designers that you can often lose the essence of a house, but his essence was working and reworking his technique \u2014 not responding to the trends of the moment.\u201d\n\nThat is part of what Mr. Saillard is hoping will be conveyed by the exhibition, which will include about 38 pieces of Ala\u00efa from the 1980s to today, all in black and white. The message is not about looking back but rather, Mr. Saillard said, \u201cthe timelessness of his work.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere is a leather dress there from the 1980s and you could wear it today,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s like Prouv\u00e9: The chair is as great today as it ever was. The dress is as perfect.\u201d\n\nDaniella Vitale, the chief executive of Barneys New York, where Ala\u00efa is among the top 10 brands, said that it remained committed to the brand. Last year, she pointed out, Ala\u00efa created a special collection of pieces from the archives to celebrate his 35 years with the store, pieces that \u201chadn\u2019t been seen for a long time, and they all sold very well.\u201d\n\nThe staff of the house is intact, and in many ways it is functioning much as it did before. Everyone still eats together every day in the kitchen. There is, Mr. von Weyhe said, a \u201cfeeling of solidarity.\u201d Mr. Saillard\u2019s word is \u201cmission.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe difference is where they work. When Mr. Ala\u00efa died, his friends closed the door to his personal studio, as well as his apartment on the floor above, to preserve it exactly as he left it, down to \u201cthe last glass he touched,\u201d Ms. Sozzani said. His designers and assistants migrated across the courtyard to other sample rooms and ateliers.\n\nThe idea, she said, is that at some point they will open both floors to the public, and they will become a museum of sorts. (Mr. Ala\u00efa, who rarely left his studio and was famous for working through the night, slept in a Prouv\u00e9 glass gas station that he had installed in his apartment, and he had a vertical garden in his bathroom.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis staff and colleagues are also creating a bookstore, which will be housed in the former sale shop of the house, with books on Mr. Ala\u00efa, the designers he loved and catalogs from the exhibitions he hosted in his gallery, including shows on the Syrian poet Adonis and the British artist Richard Wentworth.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t want money or glory, but he wanted his work and the work of designers he admired to be available to the next generation,\u201d Ms. Sozzani said.\n\nThe main floor of the headquarters will remain a working store. Ms. Goldman said she expects the response to the clothes to be as robust as ever. \u201cWe will definitely continue to buy it, and we will definitely continue to sell it,\u201d she said. None of the brand\u2019s plans for growth are being put off. A store will open in London in late March or April, and a major retrospective at the Design Museum there in May.\n\n\u201cThere are only a few designers who create a strong enough foundation for a brand to pull this off,\u201d Ms. Vitale said.\n\nIf Mr. Ala\u00efa\u2019s partners succeed, their story will not only be the classic one about writing a new chapter, but also perhaps the most effective riposte to the frenetic musical chairs of fashion the industry has seen yet.", "title": "Keeping Ala\u00efa Alive: A Designer Died, but His Brand Did Not", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTaylor Winkler, 24, is a public warning specialist at the New York City Emergency Management Department.\n\nWhat do you do at Emergency Management?\n\nMy department sends emergency alerts to New York residents about storms, traffic tie-ups and the like. I send them through Twitter, text, email, mobile app or another channel to New York residents who have signed up for Notify NYC. On rare occasions, we send Wireless Emergency Alerts, for more severe threats, to people in New York City who have cellphones equipped to accept them. One example are the alerts sent during the 2016 Chelsea bombing, for which Ahmad Khan Rahimi was convicted.\n\nHow did you get this job?\n\nMy education may have had a lot to do with it. I studied emergency management at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy, where I was valedictorian. Also, my internship in emergency management at Yale University, and others at a security firm and a business continuity firm, provided experience.\n\nWhy did you choose this field?\n\nMy parents are retired New York City police officers. They\u2019re my heroes. Every day growing up, I would hear how they helped people. After living with them and researching my local emergency management group for a class at the academy, I knew I wanted this type of job.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is your workday like?\n\nI work in a 24/7 operations unit, alone or with one of five colleagues, monitoring emergency activity in New York City. We use five computers to scan social media and over 1,000 emails a day from other city agencies and operations centers. We listen to various radio frequencies, monitor five news channels at a time and communicate with federal and city agencies over the telephone.", "title": "Keeping People Safe in New York City Emergencies", "authors": ["Patricia R. Olsen", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The Kids Are All Right\n\nWhen the Los Angeles Philharmonic tapped the wunderkind Gustavo Dudamel in 2009, when he was just 28, it shook up the music world, encouraging other orchestras to take chances on the young.\n\nMr. Dudamel, now 37, has extended his contract in Los Angeles through the 2021-22 season, and continues to be one of the biggest stars in music \u2014 even as his recent criticism of the rulers of his native Venezuela has led the government there to cancel a series of his tours.\n\nPhoto\n\nAndris Nelsons, who became the Boston Symphony Orchestra\u2019s youngest music director in more than a century when he took the post in 2014, at 35, extended his contract before his first year was done through 2021-22. In February, he starts another job, as music director of the venerable Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra in Germany, and is embarking on an unusual collaboration between his two ensembles.\n\nYannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, who became music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra in 2012, at 37, has been credited with bringing new vibrancy to its playing. He recently extended his contract there through 2026. The extension, announced when he was named the next music director of the Metropolitan Opera, reassured Philadelphia that he would not forsake them for the lures of the opera pit.\n\nLong-Term Relationships\n\nThe Cleveland Orchestra has a contract with its music director, Franz Welser-M\u00f6st, through his 20th season, in 2022, which would give him the second-longest tenure in the ensemble\u2019s history, after George Szell. Osmo Vanska is in his 15th season leading the Minnesota Orchestra \u2014 he briefly resigned in 2013 when the players were locked out by management \u2014 and has a contract there through 2022.\n\nManfred Honeck is in his 10th season with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and has a contract through 2019-20. Louis Langr\u00e9e, who took over the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in 2013, is already on his second contract extension, through 2021-22. (And he has a newly renovated Music Hall to play in.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMarin Alsop, the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra since 2007, has raised the orchestra\u2019s profile with tours and premieres and strengthened its ties to its community, including by starting an ambitious music training program for some of the city\u2019s poorest students. She has a contract there through 2021, and this week was named the next chief conductor at the ORF Vienna Radio Symphony Orchestra.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne thing has not changed, though: Although more than a decade has passed since she took the post, she remains the only woman leading a top American orchestra. (Susanna Malkki became the principal guest conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic last year.)\n\nTwo orchestras find themselves entering the dating market for the first time in decades: The San Francisco Symphony needs to find someone to succeed Michael Tilson Thomas when he steps down in 2020, after a transformative 25 seasons. And the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra must find a replacement for Robert Spano, who plans to leave in 2021, after 20 seasons making that ensemble a force in new music.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn the Market\n\nNot only are San Francisco and Atlanta hiring, but the Dallas Symphony Orchestra has yet to name a replacement for Mr. van Zweden, who is wrapping up his decade-long tenure to move to New York. And the Detroit Symphony Orchestra has yet to say who will replace Leonard Slatkin, who is in his 10th and final season.\n\nIn the Pit\n\nMr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin will take over the Met in 2020. Two other major American opera companies are looking: The San Francisco Opera is seeking a successor for Nicola Luisotti, who conducted his final performance as music director there in October. And the Washington National Opera is looking for a replacement for Philippe Auguin.\n\nJames Conlon, at the Los Angeles Opera since 2006, has a contract through the 2020-21 season. Emmanuel Villaume was named music director of the Dallas Opera in 2013, with a contract that goes through June 2022.\n\nThe Lyric Opera of Chicago still has its inaugural music director: Andrew Davis, who became the first conductor to hold that position at the company in 2000, and whose current contract lasts through 2021. And Patrick Summers \u2014 who has been the music director of Houston Grand Opera since 1998 and its artistic director since 2011 \u2014 is scheduled to remain until at least, yes, 2026.", "title": "Keeping Score of Who\u2019s in Charge of America\u2019s Orchestras", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "To find out details for your particular system, Graz University of Technology\u2019s \u201cMeltdown and Spectre\u201d site at https://meltdownattack.com has an extensive collection of links to information about patches from most major hardware and software makers, including several Linux companies. Intel also has a page on its site with links and information about updates.\n\nAs for the origin of the names assigned to these bugs, the \u201cMeltdown and Spectre\u201d site has an explanation. Meltdown gets is name because it \u201cbasically melts security boundaries which are normally enforced by the hardware.\u201d Spectre\u2019s moniker is \u201cbased on the root cause, speculative execution,\u201d and as the researchers note, \u201cAs it is not easy to fix, it will haunt us for quite some time.\u201d", "title": "Keeping Up With the Meltdown and Spectre Bugs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou always know it\u2019s a big game when Keith\u2019s there,\u201d Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach, once said.\n\nMr. Jackson had the same reputation among his colleagues in the booth. As the former quarterback Bob Griese, Mr. Jackson\u2019s color commentator for many years, recalled: \u201cAt our first game, he said to me, \u2018All right, what do you want to do?\u2019 I said: \u2018You\u2019re the guy who\u2019s been here. You\u2019re Mr. College Football.\u2019\u201d\n\nEven after decades in the job, Mr. Jackson retained an old-fashioned, wide-eyed love for the college game.\n\n\u201cThe N.C.A.A. can make anybody cynical,\u201d he once told Sports Illustrated. \u201cBut I\u2019m not. It\u2019s still fun to see new generations enjoy the game peaceably. I get there an hour and a half before the game and watch the bands rehearse, the people carry on. You let it seep into you.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association, now known as the National Sports Media Association, named Mr. Jackson sportscaster of the year five consecutive times, from 1972 to 1976.\n\nHe told The New York Times how the broadcaster Ted Husing had inspired his breezy style, advising him: \u201cNever be afraid to turn a phrase. If you can say something in such a way that\u2019s explanatory, has flavor and people can understand it, try it. If it means quoting Shakespeare or Goethe, do it.\u2019\u2019\n\nHe was more partial to the lingo of his native rural South.\n\nMr. Jackson\u2019s \u201cWhoa, Nellie!\u201d punctuating an exciting play was his best-remembered good ol\u2019 boy touch, though he maintained that he didn\u2019t use it all that often.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said he had a mule named Pearl while growing up on a Georgia farm but attributed the expression to his great-grandfather Jefferson Davis Robison, who evidently plowed many a field holding the reins of a mule.\n\n\u201cHe was a farmer and he was a whistler,\u201d Mr. Jackson told The Los Angeles Times in 2013. \u201cHe loved two phrases: \u2018Dad gummit\u2019 and the other was \u2018Whoa Nellie.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Jackson informally christened the University of Michigan\u2019s cavernous stadium at Ann Arbor \u201cthe Big House\u201d; he relished broadcasting the Rose Bowl game, \u201cthe granddaddy of \u2019em all\u201d; and he admired the enormous linemen, who were \u201cthe Big Uglies in the trenches.\u201d\n\nKeith Max Jackson was born on Oct. 18, 1928, in the western Georgia town of Roopville, and he grew up nearby, just outside Carrollton.\n\nHe joined the Marines as a teenager, then attended Washington State University in Pullman, Wash., receiving a degree in broadcast journalism in 1954. He spent 10 years at the ABC affiliate KOMO in Seattle in news, sports and production, became sports director of ABC Radio West, then began broadcasting college football for ABC Sports in 1966.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen ABC\u2019s \u201cMonday Night Football\u201d was introduced by Roone Arledge in 1970, Mr. Jackson was named the play-by-play broadcaster to work alongside Howard Cosell and Don Meredith, but a year later Mr. Arledge replaced him with a glamorous name, the former Giants star Frank Gifford.\n\nMr. Jackson returned to broadcasting college football and teamed with Bill Russell on N.B.A. games.\n\nMr. Jackson was considered well prepared and accurate, but amid the plaudits he was also remembered for a tumultuous moment\u2019s action that he missed.\n\nIt happened at the December 1978 Gator Bowl game between Ohio State and Clemson.\n\nWith about two minutes remaining and Clemson leading, 17-15, a Tigers player, Charlie Bauman, intercepted a pass and went out of bounds in front of the Ohio State bench. Woody Hayes, the Buckeyes\u2019 coach and one of college football\u2019s biggest names, slugged him. An ABC camera showed the blow, but neither Mr. Jackson nor his color commentator, Ara Parseghian, were looking at the monitor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nABC showed a replay, but it was from a different camera angle and did not capture the punch. Mr. Jackson signed off at the game\u2019s end, Clemson having run out the clock, without reporting on the punch, which was seen by millions on television. Ohio State fired Hayes the next day.\n\nMr. Jackson, who lived in Southern California, had planned to retire after the 1998 season, but changed his mind when ABC suggested that he concentrate on Pacific 10 games so he could remain close to home.\n\nHe continued with a largely regional schedule, then retired after broadcasting the 2006 Rose Bowl game.\n\nMr. Jackson is survived by his wife, Turi Ann; his children Melanie Ann, Lindsey and Christopher; and three grandchildren.\n\nMr. Jackson shunned controversy in his college football broadcasts.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not a journalist,\u201d he told The Boston Globe in 1999. \u201cIt\u2019s a simple thing. When ABC spends half a billion dollars on something, I\u2019m not going to rip and tear it apart.\u201d\n\nHe prided himself on being concise and was loath to steal the spotlight from the players.\n\n\u201cThis is not my stage,\u201d he said. \u201cThe stage belongs to the athletes and coaches who play the game. People don\u2019t throw down 1,000 bucks for a TV to hear me talk.\u201d", "title": "Keith Jackson, Voice of College Football, Dies at 89", "authors": ["Richard Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cGame Change,\u201d Dryden explores the career of Montador, a journeyman defenseman who played for six N.H.L. teams. He saw his career ended by concussions \u2014 at least seven of them. After struggles with addictions, Montador died in 2015 at 35. Post-mortem studies of his brain revealed that Montador had been suffering from the effects of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease commonly known as C.T.E.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe book also skates deep into hockey history: Underlying Montador\u2019s story is Dryden\u2019s comprehensive view of how the game has failed to adapt to its own evolution in pace, equipment and tactics. For Dryden, it all comes down to this: Now is the time for hockey to eliminate hits to the head, and the N.H.L.\u2019s commissioner, Gary Bettman, is the only person who can make that happen. Dryden has called it a test \u2014 for himself, for Bettman, for hockey. And so, in September, Dryden traveled from his home in Toronto to New York to carry that message, along with his book, to Bettman. They met for lunch.\n\nDryden sat down in Toronto in December to talk about \u201cGame Change\u201d and his vision for hockey. The interview has been edited and condensed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did that meeting with Bettman go?\n\nIt was a good lunch. We\u2019ve known each other for a long time. We\u2019ve worked together. We each know how the other thinks, and does things. I introduced it as a serious book about a serious subject, and the next few months will be a challenge for both of us. But a worthwhile challenge. I just told him about what was in the book. I told him that he was the first person to receive a final copy of the book. He said he would read it.\n\nI came away feeling that he would. And that he would think about it very hard.\n\nWhy was Steve Montador\u2019s story the right one to build your book around?\n\nI wanted to write about somebody who was an Everyman player. I didn\u2019t want somebody who was a superstar, who was unique and not relatable. And I didn\u2019t want somebody who was a fighter and a goon, for the same reason. I wanted somebody who, when people read about Steve, they would see themselves, see their kids. Coaches would see their players. He was somebody a lot like them. And whose experience was a lot like theirs. He was somebody who was not dismissible.\n\nYou\u2019ve talked about what you\u2019re trying to say in your title: not just that the game needs to change, but how it has been changing, always, and keeps changing. Is that why you think this is all so eminently doable?\n\nIt\u2019s one change that\u2019s needed: No hits to the head. No excuses.\n\nAt the core of the problem of brain injuries is hits to the head. So you focus your attention there. The increased speed of the game generates more collisions and more forceful collisions. It\u2019s not hard to see how this happens.\n\nYou can think about dealing with it as a revolutionary change, or you can think about it as an incremental and really evolutionary change. Right from the beginning of hockey, we\u2019ve recognized the danger of hits to the head. We created high-sticking penalties. We created the elbowing penalty.\n\nWhat we\u2019ve come to understand better, with the force and the frequency of the collisions now, is that the dangerous instrument is not the stick or the elbow, it\u2019s the body as a whole. So you don\u2019t call a penalty for a stick or an elbow and not call one for a shoulder or a fist. It\u2019s not the cause, it\u2019s the effect. It\u2019s not whether it\u2019s intentional or accidental. The brain doesn\u2019t distinguish. The brain is affected similarly. So you think of it in those terms, and you approach it in those terms. You connect it to the very set of understandings that is already in place, and to the penalties that are already in place. You just extend them to the changed circumstances of the game.\n\nAs you point out, Bettman never played the game. But he is surrounded in the N.H.L. head office by plenty of smart, committed people who did play. Why haven\u2019t they recognized the problems you\u2019re identifying. What\u2019s kept them from urging the changes you\u2019re advocating?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey haven\u2019t played this game. We know what we\u2019ve learned, we know what we\u2019ve heard, and we tend to then apply both, as if everything else were constant. The myth and lore of a game like hockey are very difficult to undo and rewrite. And whether it\u2019s in hockey, sports or climate change \u2014 anything \u2014 we all have a certain set of understandings. We\u2019re comfortable with them. We always believed in them, and believed deeply.\n\nBut it\u2019s a question of going beyond what you know to what there is to see. We\u2019ve stopped seeing what is there. We notice the speed of the game, we notice the frequency and the severity of the head injuries, but we haven\u2019t quite made the connection that then generates the response that\u2019s needed. There\u2019s this gap that is almost always present in terms of decision-making.\n\nTo get somewhere and change circumstances, you have to undo a set of understandings that are already in place. All we need to do is just see, see the game that\u2019s there on the ice. And it\u2019s a game that\u2019s played with far greater skill than was the case in the past. Players are faster. They\u2019re using lighter sticks, which become precision instruments in their hands, so they\u2019re developing a dexterity that in turn pushes their creative minds.\n\nAnd in the game now, the idea is not to go in straight lines: You go to open ice, wherever open ice is, and so the pass is more important than the rush. All of a sudden, you\u2019ve got this incredible freedom, this possibility. The excitement with which people talk about Connor McDavid and Auston Matthews \u2014 that\u2019s how they play. That is the game that has emerged, and it\u2019s the game that\u2019s being developed and understood by 10-year-olds and 12-year-olds everywhere in the world.\n\nYou\u2019ve been traveling with the book, talking about it across Canada. Do you get the sense that parents and coaches and the people who run minor hockey have an appetite for change? Is it coming from the bottom up, too?\n\nYes. But a bottom-up movement is not going to change things as much or as quickly as needs to happen. But what it means to that decision-maker at the top is important: He can feel a kind of confidence that, in fact, a decision that he would make about hits to the head would be understood and accepted. The conditions are present.\n\nYou haven\u2019t heard back from the commissioner yet. Not to doubt or prejudge him, but what if he doesn\u2019t see what you\u2019re seeing as quickly as you would hope? Does the challenge \u2014 and your campaign for change \u2014 simply continue?\n\nSomething that\u2019s been so powerful for me on my book tour has been talking to the hockey guys, the sports guys on the all-sports radio stations: A lot of them are thinking in these directions. This is not a matter of starting at zero and trying to argue or persuade your way to 100; they\u2019re already at 60 or 70. They see the problem. And so do people in the game I\u2019ve been hearing from.\n\nSo all of this just kind of builds. That\u2019s not unimportant. It will be moving forward, a little faster or a little slower. Five years from now, the game will be extremely different. How much in advance of that the change happens is really up to Gary Bettman.", "title": "Ken Dryden Says Change Can\u2019t Wait: End N.H.L. Head Hits Now", "authors": ["Stephen Smith", "Q A"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cKentucky Adds Work Rule for Recipients of Medicaid\u201d (news article, Jan. 13):\n\nAs a Kentuckian barely making ends meet in graduate school, I am troubled by Gov. Matt Bevin\u2019s Medicaid work requirement plan because the evidence suggests that work requirements are ineffective. Selling this sweeping overhaul as a means to lift Kentuckians out of poverty is misleading.\n\nRepublicans count the 1996 federal welfare law, which required recipients to work, a success. But earnings during the late 1990s were not enough to lift low-income people above the poverty line.\n\nWork requirements don\u2019t solve the underlying problem, which is that low-income people lack the skills and education to secure a stable job. From 2009 to 2017, 32 Kentucky counties experienced a 10 to 32 percent decline in the number of jobs.\n\nThis is another example of the Republican agenda of rejecting health as a citizen\u2019s right and pushing policies that punish our vulnerable.", "title": "Opinion | Kentucky and Medicaid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Financial literacy courses are more widely available but still not a routine part of general education.\n\n\u201cIf these topics are taught at all in primary education, they certainly aren\u2019t addressed consistently or in an evidence-based way,\u201d said Harold Pollack, a professor at the University of Chicago who was a co-author of a book on basic financial education. \u201cBut singling out the Medicaid population for classes as a condition for access to insurance suggests that shrinking and stigmatizing the program, not literacy, is the goal.\u201d\n\nNumerous studies document the widespread need for greater health and financial literacy. By one estimate, one-third of adults have health literacy deficits. For example, most people make errors in selecting health plans and don\u2019t know basic features of the plans they choose.\n\nThe last large national survey of U.S. adult literacy (including health literacy) was conducted in 2003. One study found that 60 percent of Medicaid enrollees had only \u201cbasic\u201d or \u201cbelow basic\u201d health literacy, meaning, for example, they could not recognize a medical appointment on a hospital appointment form (below basic) or would have trouble understanding why a specific test was recommended for someone with certain symptoms, even when given a clearly written and accurate explanation (basic).\n\nBut Medicaid enrollees are not the only ones. Nearly the same proportion of Medicare enrollees also had basic or below basic health literacy. Privately insured people scored better. They are typically younger than Medicare enrollees, and they typically have higher education levels and are less likely to have cognitive impairments than those with public coverage. However, only a small minority even of the privately insured had a \u201cproficient\u201d level of health literacy \u2014 meaning, for example, that they could deduce the employee share of health insurance costs from a table that listed that cost as a function of income and family size.\n\nAnother study, based on data collected in 2013, showed adults\u2019 blood test results alongside the normal range (typical of reports many of us receive from our doctors after blood tests). Only about half of the subjects could recognize if the blood glucose level indicated on the test was outside the normal range. Of those with diabetes \u2014 to whom blood glucose measurement and levels should be familiar given the importance to their condition \u2014 only 56 percent could identify out-of-range values.\n\nPoor health literacy is associated with worse health care outcomes and higher health care spending. But causality could run both ways. It is likely that people in greater need of health care are also less likely to have high literacy skills in general. It\u2019s also possible that poor health literacy contributes to worse self-management of health and lifestyle issues that could result in worsening health and increased health care use.", "title": "Kentucky\u2019s New Idea for Medicaid Access: Pass Health Literacy Course", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019re not paying any attention to such a declaration,\u201d Mr. Lone said.\n\nEarlier in the day, police officers and officials from the Communications Authority of Kenya descended on a broadcast transmission station in Limuru, about 18 miles outside Nairobi, the capital, and disconnected broadcasting equipment, according to Linus Kaikai, the chairman of the Kenya Editors Guild and the general manager of the television division at Nation Media Group, which owns NTV, one of the three channels disconnected.\n\nMr. Kaikai said that the authorities had disabled the equipment shortly before 9 a.m. \u201cThere was no explanation given,\u201d he said.\n\nRepeated calls to multiple officials at the Communications Authority were not returned.\n\nThe television blackout and the criminal designation seemed to add legitimacy to Mr. Odinga\u2019s oath, which some observers had earlier dismissed as political theater.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve urged them to ignore it, to downplay it,\u201d said one Western diplomat, who asked for anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter. \u201cIt has no legal or practical effect, so the best solution here would be to just ignore the entire thing. But they\u2019re not doing that.\u201d\n\nMr. Njoka, the Interior Ministry spokesman, described the oath as an assault on legitimate government. He also said the government had \u201cgood reasons\u201d for interrupting television broadcasts of the gathering.\n\n\u201cThe government had to do what it did because the lives of Kenyans are more important than what you call freedom of the press or what might turn out to be an inciting broadcast,\u201d he said.", "title": "Kenyans Name a \u2018People\u2019s President,\u2019 and TV Broadcasts Are Cut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Keorapetse Kgositsile, a South African poet whose writing and activism helped bridge his country\u2019s freedom struggle with the Black Arts Movement in the United States, died on Jan. 3 in Johannesburg. He was 79.\n\nHis death was announced by the South African government, which did not give a cause.\n\nMr. Kgositsile \u2014 whose full name was pronounced KERR-ah-PET-seh HO-set-SEAL-eh, but who was affectionately known as Bra Willie \u2014 first received acclaim while living in the United States in the 1960s. When he returned to South Africa after the fall of apartheid in the early \u201990s, he was welcomed as a national hero. In 2006, he became the second person to be named the country\u2019s poet laureate.\n\nHis poetry addressed themes of black solidarity, displacement and anticolonialism with an uncompromising directness. In their declaratory rhythms as well as their content, his poems often echoed the music of black America and of Africa.\n\n\u201cI believe my work is contemporaneous with me,\u201d he told Callaloo, a journal of black literature, in 1972. After moving to the United States in 1962, he said, \u201cmy acceptance of my environment did not erase my memories of Africa on the continent.\u201d", "title": "Keorapetse Kgositsile, 79, South African Poet and Activist, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 Kering, the owner of high-fashion labels such as Gucci, Saint Laurent and Alexander McQueen, is getting out of the sports lifestyle business.\n\nOn Thursday, the French conglomerate said it would spin off the German sports brand Puma to its shareholders, the final move in a series of deals brokered by Kering as part of its transformation into a pure luxury player. The move is a signal of Kering\u2019s belief in the health of the highest-end of the consumer market.\n\nThe group said that it planned to distribute 70 percent of Puma shares in kind to existing Kering investors, out of the 86 percent it currently owns. Kering would retain the 16 percent of shares left outstanding. Art\u00e9mis, the holding company of France\u2019s billionaire Pinault family that holds 41 percent of Kering shares, would then become a \u201clong-term strategic shareholder\u201d in Puma, with an ownership stake of about 29 percent. The number of Puma\u2019s publicly traded shares would be increased to approximately 55 percent, a statement from Kering said.\n\nSpeculation that Kering would divest Puma has been longstanding. The group first acquired a majority stake in Puma in 2007 for 5.3 billion euros (about $7 billion) as part of a move into the athletics and lifestyle arena. However, Puma underperformed and consistently posted flat sales, only seeing a turnaround in 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy that stage Kering \u2014 which started in 1963 as a trader of timber and construction materials, eventually moving in and out of sectors as opportunity allowed \u2014 had divested most of its non-luxury assets, such as French retail brand Printemps and the catalog label La Redoute, and narrowed its focus to increasing market share in the fast-growing, high-margin world of global luxury.", "title": "Kering to Spin Off Puma, Saying Goodbye to Sports Lifestyle", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "JAB Holding Company has struck deal after deal over the years in an effort to create a food-and-coffee empire.\n\nNow the investment company has orchestrated its biggest one yet: Keurig Green Mountain\u2019s takeover of Dr Pepper Snapple Group for $18.7 billion.\n\nWith the bid \u2014 one of the biggest ever for a beverage company \u2014 Keurig and its majority owner, JAB, are betting that they can create a beverage giant with an estimated $11 billion in revenue, and brands such as Keurig\u2019s single-serve coffee pods, Dr Pepper, 7Up and Snapple.\n\nThe deal is the latest attempt to consolidate in the food and beverage industry, as companies focus on building size and scale. JAB has been one of the leading proponents of that strategy. Using its war chest \u2014 drawn in part from its founding family, the wealthy Reimann clan of Germany \u2014 the investment firm has rolled up brands including Peet\u2019s Coffee, Caribou Coffee and Krispy Kreme.", "title": "Keurig Green Mountain Plans to Buy Dr Pepper Snapple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKevin Joseph DeYager and Kewchang Lee were married Jan. 23 at San Francisco City Hall. Denise Daley, the San Francisco County deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.\n\nMr. DeYager (left), who is 49 and works in Foster City, Calif., is a product manager at Guidewire, a software provider for the insurance industry. He graduated from Carnegie Mellon University.\n\nHe is a son of Robert DeYager of Bradford, N.Y., and the late Mary DeYager.\n\nDr. Lee, 51, is a clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of California, San Francisco, and on staff at the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Health Care System, also in San Francisco. He graduated cum laude from Harvard and received a medical degree from New York University.\n\nHe is the son of Dr. Ho Chong Lee of Highland Park, N.J., and the late Soon Mie Lee.\n\nThe couple met in San Francisco in 1994 through mutual friends.", "title": "Kevin Joseph DeYager, Kewchang Lee", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cShark Tank,\u201d the reality show on which aspiring entrepreneurs jockey for investments, is in its ninth season. Now there are people pitching you who have already-established businesses with millions of dollars in revenue. Do you miss the early seasons when some dude would show up with something he duct-taped together in his garage? No. I think the platform has evolved. It can take an idea and turn it into a real business, and it can also accelerate an existing business. You take a company, their story comes on \u201cShark Tank\u201d and all of a sudden they become No. 1 in America, and their customer-acquisition cost is zero.\n\nIs any of the drama on the show manufactured? Is there a producer in your ear going \u201cget in a beef with Mark Cuban right now\u201d? You don\u2019t need anybody to tell you to get into a beef with Cuban. That just happens.\n\n\u201cShark Tank\u201d airs updates for its successful businesses, but viewers don\u2019t hear about all the businesses that fail. Is there a danger in glamorizing entrepreneurship? No. Even in the updates you see how brutal people\u2019s lives are. Entrepreneurship is a personal sacrifice for a long period of time. I never saw my kids grow up \u2014 they just went from zero to teenagers when I was traveling the world selling software, and yet today they enjoy certain freedoms that I could never have afforded had I not been successful.\n\nMany contestants have a sad or inspirational back story. What goes through your head when they start crying during a pitch? Tears buy you nothing. At the end of the day, the market is a brutal place. Nobody cares that you had a little dog when you were in high school that you fell in love with. Nobody gives a [expletive]. You\u2019re now in the real world, competing with people in Mumbai and Shanghai and Hong Kong who want to eat your lunch.\n\nYou\u2019ve said you\u2019re not mean on the show: You just tell the truth. Have you ever felt bad afterward about something you\u2019ve said to an entrepreneur? Never. Business is so binary: Either you make money or you lose it. It\u2019s so disingenuous to say to an entrepreneur, \u201cI won\u2019t write you a check, but you should keep going.\u201d I would rather say \u2014 and I do \u2014 \u201cThis has no merit; you\u2019re going to lose all your money.\u201d I\u2019m the only shark that tells the truth. The others make themselves feel better by lying to these poor people who are going to lose all their money. You deserve to burn in hell for that.\n\nO\u2019Leary is a businessman and a star of ABC\u2019s \u201cShark Tank,\u201d on which he is called Mr. Wonderful. Age: 63 Occupation: Entrepreneur Hometown: Boston His Top 5 \u201cShark Tank\u201d Investments: 1. Wicked Good Cupcakes 2. BenjiLock 3. Lovepop cards 4. Potato Parcel 5. O\u2019Leary Fine Wines\n\nYour co-sharks deserve to burn in hell? For that? They should.\n\nLast year you were the favorite in the race to become leader of Canada\u2019s Conservative Party, but you dropped out because you felt you couldn\u2019t speak French well enough to win Quebec in a general election. Have you been practicing since then? I have been. I felt that I could bring something to the Canadian market as the prime minister, because Canada\u2019s incredibly mismanaged at a provincial and federal level. Would I do it again? Probably not the same way. Am I glad I did it? Yes.\n\nIf you did run again, what would you do differently? I\u2019d be completely bilingual.\n\nWhat\u2019s the most Canadian thing about you? I\u2019m born from Lebanese and Irish parents. The greatest thing about Canada is that it has allowed anybody to come from anywhere and be accepted in that society. That\u2019s the biggest difference in policy when people say I am like Trump. How can I be Trump? I\u2019m half Lebanese, half Irish. I wouldn\u2019t exist if there were a wall around Canada!\n\nI\u2019ve heard you say one of the books that most influenced your success was \u201cAtlas Shrugged.\u201d How did that help you? I realized that in capitalism, either you believe in the intrinsic concept about the pursuit of wealth and why it\u2019s good for you, or you don\u2019t. I never question it. I never even think for a second that it was not the right path. To me there is darkness and light. Capitalism is the light. Socialism is the darkness. Nothing could ever change my mind about that.", "title": "Kevin O\u2019Leary Is Unmoved by Your Tears", "authors": ["Dan Amira"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index rose 2.6 percent after posting four straight records during the holiday-shortened week. That was its best start to a year since 2006.\n\nTech stocks surged 4.2 percent to begin the New Year.\n\nHere\u2019s what to expect this earnings season.\n\nFourth-quarter earnings season kicks off next week with JPMorgan, Wells Fargo & Co. and BlackRock all reporting Friday. Here\u2019s what Wall Street analysts are expecting, courtesy of FactSet.\n\n\u2022 Analysts expect companies in the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index to report profits rose 10.5 percent from a year ago, according to FactSet.\n\n\u2022 All 11 sectors are forecast to report earnings growth.\n\n\u2022 The index\u2019s energy companies are expected to show the biggest jump, up 132 percent. That increase is largely a result of the continued rebound in oil prices. The two-year free-fall in oil prices that began in 2014 decimated the bottom line of energy companies, but since the second half of last year, the sector\u2019s profits have been rebounding.\n\n\u2022 If analysts forecast for earnings prove correct, it will mark the third quarter in the past four that the S.&P. 500 has posted double-digit gains in earnings.\n\n\u2022 Sales are forecast to grow 6.7 percent.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nHow many rate increases next year?\n\nMost Federal Reserve officials expect to raise rates three times this year. A number of private economists, including Goldman Sachs\u2019s Jan Hatzius, are forecasting four.\n\nThe market, meanwhile, has priced in only two. The Fed, though, could surprise investors to the upside, writes Christopher Beddor of Breakingviews.\n\n\u201cDecember\u2019s relatively weak jobs and wage growth figures give policymakers a breather. But with 2.1 million jobs created in 2017 and unemployment nearing historically low levels, long-awaited wage rises \u2014 along with new tax cuts \u2014 might soon bring the prospect of higher inflation on the agenda.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Beddor added:\n\n\u201cThe question is how much tighter the job market can get before pulling wages, and inflation, higher. Minutes from the December FOMC meeting, released this week, suggest some members worry tighter labor market conditions could start feeding into inflation. The readout also showed uncertainty about the extent that tax cuts might stimulate the economy and boost prices. Already companies including AT&T, American Airlines and Wells Fargo have announced bonuses or wage increases after President Donald Trump signed the cuts into law last month.\u201d\n\nSpotify\u2019s chief content officer is exiting ahead of its I.P.O.\n\nRecode\u2019s Peter Kafka reports that \u201cStefan Blom, Spotify\u2019s chief content officer, announced his departure via an internal memo Friday.\u201d\n\nThe NYT and others reported earlier this week that Spotify had filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in the first quarter of this year.\n\nVia Recode:\n\n\u201cThe timing of Blom\u2019s exit may raise questions for investors as they look at Spotify. \u201cLast year, the executive helped Spotify secure critical licenses with the big music labels that paved the way for the company\u2019s IPO. But he has also been in charge of the company\u2019s attempted push into video, which has stopped and started a few times without gaining traction.\u201d\n\nAfternoon speed reads\n\n\u2022 F.B.I. agents have renewed asking questions about the dealings of the Clinton Foundation amid calls from President Trump and top Republicans for the Justice Department to take a fresh look at politically charged accusations of corruption. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The first known criminal referral has emerged from Congress\u2019s Russia inquiries. The target is the author of the Trump-Russia dossier. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The nation\u2019s political and financial capitals have never felt so far apart. Washington is kicking off the new year with a fresh round of Trump-fueled chaos. On Wall Street, meanwhile, the sky hardly seems the limit. (WaPo)\n\n\u2022 Gary Cohn told Bloomberg TV that the Trump administration may try to block potential plans by high-tax states including New York and California to shield residents from state and local tax break changes. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 American cannabis startups raised a record amount of venture capital last year, with 69 companies snaring nearly $274 million. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Netflix shares jumped 1.4 percent to an all-time high after the video-streaming service announced a Jan. 12 premiere for the new show from longtime talk-show host David Letterman. (FastFt)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Lionel Messi has written a clause into his contract with FC Barcelona allowing him to leave the team if Catalan independence means he can\u2019t play top-league soccer. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Berkshire Hathaway\u2019s Class A shares closed above $300,000 for the first time Thursday, marking a new record for the world\u2019s most expensive stock. Here are some items you can buy from Berkshire businesses for the price of one A share. (MoneyBeat)\n\nHow soft was the jobs report?\n\nThe headline number of 148,000 jobs added came in well below the 198,000 expected by Wall Street economists. But don\u2019t read too much into the miss. The trend remains strong. The United States economy has added jobs for 87 straight months, an unparalleled run, and the unemployment rate remained at a 17-year low.\n\nOn top of all that, the number may be revised upward in the coming months. Joe Brusuelas, chief economist at RSM, writes:\n\n\u201cThe details of the data does leave some doubt that the first estimate of job creation in December, in particular the estimate that retail hiring declined by 20,000 during the holiday shopping season and a decline of 10,000 in trade and transport. Thus we think that there will be material upward revisions to the BLS estimate when the next monthly data is published. Outside of the two aforementioned categories, job creation was strong across the board.\u201d\n\nBut this jobs report was all about wages, and growth there remained lackluster. Year over year, earnings increased by around 2.5 percent.\n\n\u201cWe expect a clear upturn over the first half of this year, but it isn\u2019t happening yet,\u201d wrote Ian Shepherdson, chief economist of Pantheon Macroeconomics.\n\nThis mysterious lack of earnings growth has helped provide cover for Federal Reserve officials to slowly raise rates.\n\nSo what does this mean to the Fed\u2019s rate plan? \u201cAt the margin, this report reduces the odds of a March rate hike, but two more reports are due before the FOMC meeting, by which time these numbers will be ancient history,\u201d wrote Mr. Shepherdson.\n\nFitbit makes its first start-up investment.\n\nFitbit is investing $6 million into Sano, which is developing a patch to track a person\u2019s blood sugar level, reported Christina Farr of CNBC.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe move could help Fitbit reverse declining sales. Via CNBC:\n\n\u201cBuilding blood-sugar tracking into a future device could dramatically increase the market for Fitbit devices since more than 100 million Americans are now living with diabetes or pre-diabetes, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Fitbit has recently suffered declining sales: It sold 3.6 million devices in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from 5.3 million a year earlier.\n\nKeeping pace with Apple: Last month The New York Times reported that device manufacturers are tapping into new features on the Apple Watch to develop medical accessories. Apple is also looking for its own medical breakthroughs, such as a noninvasive continuous glucose reader, the NYT reported.\n\nCan the markets keep rising?\n\nPhoto\n\nDavid Tepper of Appaloosa Management thinks so, telling CNBC:\n\n\u201cExplain to me where this market is rich? It\u2019s not rich with the tax thing that just changed earnings projections. With earnings forecasts going up and interest rates where they are, how is this market expensive? I don\u2019t see the overvaluation. World growth is higher.\u201d\n\nA dissenting voice: The market historian James Stack told Jim Stewart of the NYT: \u201cA correction would be healthy. The longer we go without one, the greater the risk this will end badly. A lot of people will get hurt.\u201d\n\nThe next thing to look out for: It\u2019s Jobs Friday today. A Reuters survey of economists expects the nonfarm payroll report to show a gain of 190,000 for December.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat constitutes obstruction of justice?\n\nLegal experts are poring over the question, after a report by Mike Schmidt of the NYT that President Trump told the White House\u2019s top lawyer to stop Jeff Sessions recusing himself from the Russia investigation.\n\nFrom Mr. Schmidt\u2019s story:\n\nLegal experts said that of the two primary issues Mr. Mueller appears to be investigating \u2014 whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice while in office and whether there was collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia \u2014 there is currently a larger body of public evidence tying the president to a possible crime of obstruction. But the experts are divided about whether the accumulated evidence is enough for Mr. Mueller to bring an obstruction case.\n\nAbout that Michael Wolff book: \u201cFire and Fury\u201d is to go on sale today, ahead of schedule \u2014 and despite legal threats from Mr. Trump.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo a steady drip of excerpts \u2014 from Steve Bannon calling a meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and Russians \u201ctreasonous\u201d to the former adviser suggesting that money laundering charges were in the offing \u2014 is about to become a flood.\n\nThe most damaging may be the book\u2019s descriptions of Mr. Trump\u2019s erratic behavior and of aides\u2019 private contempt for their boss. Many Washington reads are underway (you start in the index, looking for your name).\n\nThe firestorm has also propelled Mr. Wolff from local media gadfly into national newsmaker.\n\nThe fallout for Mr. Bannon: Rebekah Mercer, the adviser\u2019s longtime benefactor, disavowed him in a rare public statement. And Breitbart\u2019s board members have debated whether to oust him as the media organization\u2019s chairman, according to the WSJ, citing unnamed sources.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout that money-laundering accusation: Tim O\u2019Brien of Bloomberg View says that Mr. Bannon\u2019s allegation is as serious as any claim of \u201ctreason.\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump may have dismantled his voter fraud commission, but he wasn\u2019t happy about it. (NYT)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 Ajit Pai, the chairman of the F.C.C., canceled his speaking appearance at the Consumer Electronics Show, citing death threats, according to unnamed sources. (Recode)\n\nPhoto\n\nHas the Justice Dept. set fire to the marijuana industry?\n\nAlready, its decision to let prosecutors more freely enforce federal law against the drug has taken its toll on publicly traded pot-related companies.\n\n\u2022 Shares in Scotts Miracle-Gro, whose C.E.O. has courted marijuana growers, dropped as much as 5 percent yesterday.\n\n\u2022 Those in Cannabis Sativa Inc., which produces edibles and other pot-related products, plunged 24 percent.\n\n\u2022 And shares in GrowGeneration, a cannabis farming company, fell 21 percent.\n\nIt\u2019s a shocking turnaround, too. Cannabis-related shares had rallied this week as California began recreational marijuana sales.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe response\n\n\u2022 Senator Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado, threatened to hold up Justice Department appointments.\n\n\u2022 The head of California\u2019s Bureau of Cannabis Control, Lori Ajax, said the state was legalizing as planned.\n\nWeekend pot reading: If you\u2019re a budding cannabis entrepreneur and need financing, you\u2019ll probably have to turn to a small credit union outside Denver.\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout those companies warning of hits from tax cuts \u2026\n\nYes, corporations like Apple will have to repatriate overseas earnings under the new code. And the tax analyst David Zion estimates that they will pay some $235 billion.\n\nBut he also reckons that the new repatriation treatment alone is worth $500 billion more compared with the old law. And analysts in general think the overhaul will help corporate America.\n\nAs J. Richard Harvey, a Villanova law professor, told Jesse Drucker of the NYT, multinationals have sought a change like this for over a decade:\n\n\u201cWe wouldn\u2019t have the legislation if they didn\u2019t want it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWho\u2019s cheering the reopening of U.S. offshore drilling?\n\nEnergy companies, obviously. And the president of the National Ocean Industries Association, Randall Luthi, called the offshore leasing proposal \u201cbold and broad.\u201d\n\nBut investor reaction yesterday was fairly muted: American depositary receipts in Royal Dutch Shell and BP, for instance, each rose less than 1 percent.\n\nWhat the proposal will do\n\nFrom Lisa Friedman of the NYT:\n\nThe plan would give the energy industry broad access to drilling rights in most parts of the outer continental shelf, including Pacific waters near California, Atlantic waters near Maine and the eastern Gulf of Mexico.\n\nInterior Department Secretary Ryan Zinke had a simpler explanation: \u201cWe\u2019re going to become the strongest energy superpower.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat it won\u2019t\n\nImmediately green-light drilling.\n\nWho\u2019s opposed\n\nEnvironmental activists, obviously. But also nearly a dozen governors, including the Republicans Chris Christie of New Jersey and Rick Scott of Florida.\n\nPhoto\n\nTravis Kalanick is on track to become an actual billionaire.\n\nThat is, if he follows through on his plan to sell about 29 percent of his stake in Uber to a group led by SoftBank, as Bloomberg reports. (We hear that the report is accurate.)\n\nWhat he stands to make: about $1.4 billion.\n\nMore from Eric Newcomer of Bloomberg:\n\nKalanick, who owns 10 percent of the company, had offered to sell as much as half of his stake \u2014 the maximum board members were allowed to tender. He had to pare back the amount because of limits outlined in the agreement between Uber and the buyers, the people said.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Intel struggled for months to address Meltdown, one of two computer chip security flaws that came to light this week. Apple said that nearly all of its computing devices, including iPhones, were vulnerable and that it was issuing updates. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 What you can do to protect your devices against the flaws. Briefly: Update! (NYT)\n\n\u2022 A close look at Iran\u2019s hackers, who have begun cyberespionage campaigns against the U.S. and others. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s 2018 personal goal: \u201cfix\u201d Facebook. He\u2019s also looking closely at encryption and digital currencies. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 Don\u2019t rush to regulate A.I., Andrew Burt, the chief privacy officer of the data management company Inmuta, writes in an NYT Op-Ed. But the eventual buyer is expected to pay less than $500 million, and shareholders like the Weinsteins, the advertising giant WPP and SoftBank could be wiped out. (Remember that Tom Barrack\u2019s Colony Capital had agreed to buy the embattled studio, but backed out.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho\u2019s in the running, according to Ben Fritz and Keach Hagey of the WSJ:\n\nThe bidders include a group led by businesswoman Maria Contreras-Sweet; production company Killer Content working with philanthropist Abigail Disney; studio Lions Gate Entertainment Corp.; and investment firms Vine Alternative Investments and Shamrock Capital Investments.\n\nThe media flyaround\n\n\u2022 Disney\u2019s proposed acquisition of Fox assets has raised questions about the future for Fox\u2019s television properties, including, \u201cAm I going to have to put Mickey Mouse in \u2018American Horror Story\u2019?\u201d (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Newsroom employees at the L.A.
