Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Kicking Off the New Year With a Bang: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSchool Gunfire Every Other Day\u201d (front page, Jan. 23):\n\nSo it happened again, a high school shooting and kids killed by a kid. This one is so tragically, numbingly and predictably the same as we have so sadly witnessed so many times.\n\nWe will eventually find out about the shooter\u2019s motivations, troubles and challenges. But here\u2019s what we know now \u2014 he had access to an efficient killing device, even at age 15. And here\u2019s what we eventually will know \u2014 that prayers don\u2019t really mitigate the unspeakable pain of parents burying their child, do they?\n\nAnd just one more thing worth considering before we move on from this latest tragedy. Every vote for National Rifle Association-backed candidates increases the likelihood of more such tableaux, because certain politicians on this issue have shown they have no more conscience than the weapons they make so very available.\n\nNORMAN L. BENDER\n\nWOODBRIDGE, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe ultimate solution to school shootings is to restrict the numbers of available guns. However, in today\u2019s environment that is highly unlikely. A reasonable solution, therefore, is a campaign to require that guns be secured in a locked \u201csafe\u201d away from ammunition and addled adolescents.", "title": "Opinion | Kids Killing Kids: America\u2019s Tragic New Norm", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Two polio vaccinators \u2014 a mother-daughter team \u2014 were shot dead in Pakistan on Thursday, the first time in two years that the polio eradication drive had been shaken by assassinations.\n\nWhile tragic, the killings in Baluchistan Province will not seriously disrupt Pakistan\u2019s eradication drive, said one of its leaders.\n\n\u201cWe are very close to winning the battle,\u201d said Aziz Memon, a textile executive who heads Rotary International\u2019s local polio vaccination efforts.\n\nLast year, Pakistan had only eight confirmed cases of polio paralysis; four years ago, the nation had 306.", "title": "Killing of Mother-Daughter Team Shakes Polio Fighters in Pakistan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Kim Jones will leave his role as artistic director of men\u2019s wear at Louis Vuitton after the fall 2018 catwalk show on Thursday, the French luxury house has announced, capping months of speculation that he might be departing and prompting questions about where in the fashion world he might go next.\n\nMr. Jones, an Englishman who held his position at Louis Vuitton for seven years, is the fifth major designer to leave a job in six weeks, including Phoebe Philo from C\u00e9line and Jonathan Saunders from Diane von Furstenberg in December. He is a Central Saint Martins graduate who founded his own men\u2019s wear line in London, closing it in 2008 to become creative director of Dunhill and then moving to Louis Vuitton in 2011.\n\nMr. Jones has been widely applauded for revitalizing the Vuitton men\u2019s wear line for a younger generation, mixing the house\u2019s travel heritage (at the highest end of the price spectrum) with a more street-friendly style.\n\n\u201cThese houses are under tremendous pressure to be right on the money of what certain generations want,\u201d said Michael Hainey, the executive director of editorial for Esquire magazine. \u201cHe showed just how you can take something that\u2019s got a fantastic heritage and still do something very modern with it.\u201d", "title": "Kim Jones to Exit Louis Vuitton, Reviving Speculation About What\u2019s Next", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kim\u2019s lightly striped jacket came with a matching tie and slacks. His trademark hairstyle was carefully coifed, and in a twist, it was shorn above the ears, leaving what has been dubbed a \u201ctrapezoid shaped\u201d haircut.\n\nThe soft tones of his outfit did not carry through to his message, in which he boasted of having \u201ca nuclear button on the desk in my office.\u201d And it stood at stark odds with the reputation of a leader who is suspected of ordering the assassination of his half brother with VX nerve agent, having his uncle and mentor killed with antiaircraft machine guns and running a state security apparatus that enslaves even children in prison camps.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a flimflam,\u201d Mr. Kelly said. \u201cJust a show.\u201d\n\n\n\nThe address was closely watched in South Korea, a country known for its attention to outward appearances, with a cosmetic surgery industry that is the envy of Asia. Initial reaction there was positive, at least on the substance, with a South Korean government spokesman saying, \u201cWe have already expressed our willingness to engage in a dialogue with North Korea at any time.\u201d\n\nIn dressing up for his speech, Mr. Kim, who was educated in Swiss schools, may just be hearkening back to his grandfather, Kim Il-sung, the founder of North Korea and a man the young Mr. Kim is often said to emulate, even in his rotund frame and haircut. The grandfather was known for occasionally wearing Western-style suits, a marked contrast to other Communist revolutionary leaders of the time, like Mao Zedong and Ho Chi Minh.", "title": "Kim Jong-un Goes Dapper, Updating His Style Along With His Arsenal", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Kim also reiterated his country\u2019s achievements with its nuclear weapons program.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a mere threat but a reality that I have a nuclear button on the desk in my office,\u201d he said. \u201cAll of the mainland United States is within the range of our nuclear strike.\u201d\n\nNorth Korea made a similar claim on Nov. 29, when it launched an intercontinental ballistic missile, or ICBM, with engines powerful enough to send a warhead to the eastern coast of the United States. But it has yet to demonstrate that its nuclear warhead could survive the re-entry into the Earth\u2019s atmosphere and hit such long-range targets.\n\nStill, Mr. Kim on Monday reiterated that his country had mastered a state nuclear deterrent force, which he said would prevent the Trump administration from starting a war on the Korean Peninsula. He said his government would accelerate the production of nuclear warheads and rockets to launch them.\n\nAssessing North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons program for the new year, government and private analysts in South Korea have recently said that despite its claim to have achieved its nuclear ambitions, the North is likely to conduct more weapons tests to improve its nuclear and long-range ballistic missile capabilities.\n\nBut at the same time, they said North Korea will also seek opportunities to engage in dialogue with South Korea and the United States, hoping to use its nuclear threats as leverage to gain concessions, like the easing of sanctions.\n\nLast year, the United Nations Security Council adopted four sanctions resolutions seeking to deprive North Korea of key sources of hard currency by banning its exports of coal, iron ore and sea products and curtailing the employment of North Korean workers in other countries.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt also tried to squeeze the North\u2019s fuel supplies by demanding that member nations drastically reduce exports of refined oil to North Korea. While gas prices in the North more than doubled in the past year, analysts said the country could feel more pain this year, depending on how successfully the sanctions are enforced.\n\nSouth Korea has seized two oil tankers, one with a Hong Kong flag and the other registered in Panama, on the suspicion that they were used to smuggle refined petroleum products into North Korea through ship-to-ship transfers on the high seas, trade that is prohibited by United Nations sanctions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s overture on Monday came after a year in which Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump regularly exchanged personal insults and threats of war. Mr. Kim threatened to launch ballistic missiles around Guam, an American territory in the Western Pacific, while Mr. Trump said he would \u201ctotally destroy North Korea.\u201d\n\nIncreasingly anxious over possible military conflict, President Moon has repeatedly urged North Korea to take part in the Winter Olympics, hoping its participation would ease tensions. Last month, Mr. Moon even proposed that his country and the United States postpone their joint military exercises, which were originally expected to start in late February, if North Korea suspended weapons tests in the coming weeks.\n\nMr. Moon hopes to create a lull in the nuclear standoff during the Olympics and use it as momentum to start talks with North Korea. South Korea is scheduled to host the Winter Olympics in February in Pyeongchang, a mountainous county about 60 miles south of the heavily fortified border with the North.\n\nWhen North Korea said it completed its nuclear force after its ICBM test in November, some analysts said the North might now be open to stopping its program there and to start negotiating.\n\nIn any talks with the United States, North Korea is likely to insist on being recognized as a nuclear weapons state, analysts said. With that status, they said, the North would seek arms-reduction talks in hopes of gaining concessions from Washington, such as easing sanctions and reducing the American military presence around the Korean Peninsula. In return, Pyongyang could offer to freeze or give up its ICBMs while retaining the rest of its nuclear capabilities, analysts said.\n\nBut Washington and its allies, South Korea and Japan, say that their goal remains to dismantle the North\u2019s entire nuclear arsenal.\n\nThe isolated North made major strides in 2017 in its nuclear weapons program. On Sept. 3, it detonated what it called a hydrogen bomb in its sixth and most powerful nuclear test. It has also launched three intercontinental ballistic missiles, demonstrating rockets powerful enough to deliver warheads to all of the continental United States.\n\nBut all three of its ICBM tests took place in the sea between North Korea and Japan. Though the missiles soared to extremely high altitudes, demonstrating their power, they never flew beyond Japan.", "title": "Kim Jong-un Offers North Korea\u2019s Hand to South, While Chiding U.S.", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump accused a former Clinton aide, Huma Abedin, of \u201cdisregarding basic security protocols,\u201d and called his own Justice Department a \u201cdeep state,\u201d a term that typically refers to a shadow government that plots to influence politics.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 The reckoning over sexual harassment is reshaping U.S. culture.\n\nPeter Martins, who led the New York City Ballet for more than three decades, stepped down, while rejecting accusations of harassment and physical and verbal abuse.\n\nGretchen Carlson, who spoke out against sexual harassment at Fox News, will lead the board of the Miss America pageant \u2014 a competition she won in 1989.\n\nBut our food critic, Pete Wells, says that revelations are playing out \u201cexcruciatingly slowly,\u201d if at all, in the restaurant world.\n\n_____", "title": "Kim Jong-un, Pakistan, Iran: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "As part of the overture, Mr. Kim also agreed to a request by Mr. Moon to send a North Korean delegation to the Winter Olympics. The South Korean president is betting that the North is far less likely to disrupt the Olympics, with missile launchings or an act of terrorism, if North Korean athletes are competing.\n\nThe diplomatic tug-of-war comes amid a backdrop of increasing fears over North Korea\u2019s nuclear arsenal. Over the past year, the North made such fast technological advances that it says it can now strike the East Coast of the United States with a missile. The North has yet to demonstrate a key component of its nuclear threat \u2014 the ability to build a warhead that can withstand the heat and stresses of re-entering the atmosphere \u2014 but there is little dispute that it is getting much closer to such a capability.\n\nThe threat is considered strong enough by the administration that Mr. Trump has hinted at the possibility of a pre-emptive strike as a last resort.\n\nThat type of thinking \u2014 as well as fiery rhetoric from both Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim \u2014 has shaken South Korea, which would be expected to be on the front line of a war. The advances have also led the United States to push for tougher sanctions than before, and to close the types of loopholes Mr. Trump\u2019s predecessors were more likely to overlook.\n\nDespite the changes in the North\u2019s nuclear capabilities, Mr. Kim\u2019s New Year\u2019s statement was similar to last year\u2019s: The North\u2019s nuclear program is unstoppable, and Mr. Trump should simply learn to accept it.\n\nThis time Mr. Kim described plans for \u201cmass producing nuclear warheads and ballistic missiles for operational deployment\u201d this year. While it is unclear what \u201cmass producing\u2019\u2019 means in this context, American estimates of Mr. Kim\u2019s arsenal range from 20 to 60 weapons; over the next few years that could easily double or triple, experts say, to an arsenal similar to Britain\u2019s or France\u2019s.\n\nThose same officials, however, dismissed Mr. Kim\u2019s comment that he now has a \u201cnuclear button\u201d on his desk as a rhetorical flourish. Currently, Mr. Kim cannot launch a weapon in seconds, as his declaration seemed intended to suggest. All of the tests he has conducted of intercontinental ballistic missiles have involved liquid-fuel weapons that take hours, sometimes days, to prepare for a launching.", "title": "Kim Jong-un\u2019s Overture Could Drive a Wedge Between South Korea and the U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Kimberly-Clark, the maker of Huggies and Kleenex, is laying off about 13 percent of its work force and shedding factories worldwide, amid declining birthrates that are affecting diaper sales and a retail price war that is weighing on profits.\n\nThe company said Tuesday that it would cut between 5,000 and 5,500 jobs in an effort to reduce expenses as it faced stiffer competition for consumer staples like tissues, paper towels and wet wipes.\n\nTo help pay for the cuts and other restructuring moves, Kimberly-Clark said, it will use savings from the recently enacted corporate tax cut.\n\nThomas J. Falk, the chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the cuts would make the company \u201cleaner, stronger and faster.\u201d", "title": "Kimberly-Clark Cutting 5,000 Jobs Amid Pressure on Prices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWELLINGTON, New Zealand \u2014 Searchers examined an expanding zone of the Pacific Ocean around the islands of Kiribati on Monday in hopes of finding more survivors of a ferry sinking after rescuers found seven passengers alive on an aluminum dinghy following more than a week at sea.\n\nThe 56-foot wooden catamaran that vanished on Jan. 18 was believed to have been carrying at least 50 other passengers. On Friday, the New Zealand authorities were first alerted by the government of Kiribati \u2014 which is about halfway between Hawaii and Australia \u2014 that the vessel had vanished after leaving for what was supposed to be a two-day, 150-mile voyage.\n\nNew Zealand\u2019s military joined the search the next day, and rescued seven people, including a 14-year-old girl, on the small dinghy. A spokesman for the operation said the group had survived \u201cin the baking sun\u201d for more than a week without supplies, shade or a motor for the dinghy.\n\nAir Commodore Darryn Webb said Monday that the seven survivors were still on the fishing boat that had rescued them, because New Zealand\u2019s military needed it to stay in the area in case more survivors were spotted during an air search.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKiribati, an independent country of atolls and islets, is within the maritime zone that New Zealand is responsible for patrolling.", "title": "Kiribati Ferry Search Expands After 7 Are Found Alive", "authors": ["Charlotte Graham-Mclay"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Knausgaard\u2019s strongest writing tends to concern childhood and parenthood. In \u201cSetting Limits\u201d he scrutinizes the external signs of his daughter\u2019s tantrum. After reacting to it in the moment, he realizes he has crossed the razor\u2019s edge between healthy discipline and humiliation, and broods that he has channeled his disciplinarian father. So he decides to \u201cmake things right again,\u201d though he knows a simple apology won\u2019t cut it. The piece ends with a gentle redirection, an act of self-comfort expressed as parental comfort: \u201cSo what I am going to do is to get out a hammer and some of those little staples that one uses to fasten cables to the wall, and put up the lamp that for several months now I\u2019ve been promising to hang from the ceiling of her room. It is made up of a long row of little round paper lanterns in various colors and will hang above her bed like a garland.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nQuite a few of the sections feel stereotypically Scandinavian, with their focus on darkness, snow, quiet, emptiness and depression. One of the best (and most Scandinavian) is \u201cLoki,\u201d which retells the myth of the Norse god and ends with an exquisite description of anticipated horror. Sometimes an essay doesn\u2019t proceed very far beyond setting a Scandinavian mood: \u201cThe Funeral Procession\u201d concludes with Knausgaard\u2019s report of watching an ambulance boat float away, carrying a corpse: \u201cAs the boat was swallowed up by all the gray, I thought that that is exactly how death is.\u201d\n\nIn a collection of 60-odd pieces, not every one can be a home run, but too many of these essays anticipate a point of arrival that never comes. \u201cCold\u201d begins to discuss the physics of entropy, but it barely restates the general principle, meanders a bit, then stops before it discovers anything unfamiliar. Twenty more pages would have allowed \u201cThe Nose,\u201d a clinical consideration of the facial feature\u2019s essential qualities, to proceed to a worthier climax. More concerning are the essays that indulge in lax thinking, which is hard to hide in a 750-word piece. In \u201cHollow Spaces,\u201d \u201call the thoughts we produce are organized like clothes in a wardrobe, with trousers on one shelf, sweaters on another.\u201d That isn\u2019t the way memories are laid down in the brain; it\u2019s faux science deployed in support of a convenient metaphor. Elsewhere, \u201cthe Milky Way might be the comma in a sentence in a newspaper that hasn\u2019t been picked up yet.\u201d This familiar idea doesn\u2019t elevate itself above its familiar context. I could blame the translator for deadening the prose, but I think the larger problem is that three pages just isn\u2019t enough space to hold a complete Knausgaardian thought.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith few exceptions, mature writers each carry the burden of an individual style. I frequently suspected, while reading this book, that Knausgaard doesn\u2019t consider the three-page essay even to possess form; just size. The form doesn\u2019t seem to interest him, and his prose is poorly suited to it. To do it right he\u2019d have to write all new, non-Knausgaardian sentences and paragraphs. He\u2019d have to stop being Knausgaard.\n\nThe \u201cfour seasons\u201d quartet started as a completely private project, apparently unintended for publication. As I read \u201cWinter\u201d I wondered whether its author had grown bored by his facility with very long prose; whether he wished to elude being pigeonholed as a certain type of writer, or worried that he\u2019d discovered the limits of his interests or, perish the thought, of his talent. After all, \u201cMy Struggle\u201d ends with the avowal that he will never write again.\n\nIt\u2019s easy to give advice, even if I wouldn\u2019t take it myself, so when my graduate students write labored work out of some misplaced sense of obligation, I tell them to write after pleasure and relief; to let writing come to exist as a byproduct of pure need; and not to let an idealized end product twist them away from what they must write, or what they\u2019d write anyway, without a teacher or even a reader \u2014 in other words, to be the writers they already are. Or perhaps I should be less judgmental of an artist who tries new things and works against his natural style. Perhaps I should admire Knausgaard for daring to become an amateur again.", "title": "Knausgaard\u2019s Seasonal Book Series Continues With a Wintry Mix", "authors": ["Sarah Manguso", "Karl Ove Knausgaard"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Knicks\u2019 talented yet inexperienced lineup has a 20-24 record thus far. The good vibes from their encouraging start were punctured by a stretch in which the team lost 10 of 13 games, thanks in part to losing Tim Hardaway Jr. for six weeks with a left leg injury. On Sunday, they let a 19-point lead slip away in an overtime loss to the New Orleans Pelicans. Monday, they allowed 39 third-quarter points to the Nets.\n\nThe victory over the Nets provided something of a lift. It was also the beginning of seven-game road trip \u2014 though fans at Barclays were chanting in favor of the visitors by the game\u2019s end \u2014 that could help decide how this season ends for the Knicks. A trip to Memphis Wednesday, followed by five games out West, will prove far trickier.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be huge,\u201d Porzingis said of the coming stretch. \u201cIt\u2019s going to show us where we are right now. We\u2019ve been so close in so many games on the road that we\u2019re right there. All we need is to stick together, finish the games better, and I\u2019m sure the wins will come.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Knicks have not posted a winning record since the 2012-13 season, and the Nets\u2019 most recent one came the season after. They are both mired in long, occasionally painful rebuilds. Two stargazing organizations have one legitimate star between them \u2014 Porzingis. The Knicks are hoping that by finally keeping their first-round picks they can find a strong complement for Porzingis one of these years. The Nets have a bleaker outlook; they are bereft of picks after a disastrous 2013 trade with the Celtics and have turned to dealing for depressed assets that they hope to revitalize.\n\nThe Knicks remain pegged in the present, hoping to avoid a second-straight midseason collapse and nab a playoff spot. The Nets are still chasing the future. But after consecutive seasons with the worst and third-worst records in the N.B.A., the Nets are, at least, no longer laughable.\n\nThough 16-28 is still far from enviable, there are signs of progress under General Manager Sean Marks. We initially thought it was a joke,\u201d the Perm news site 59.ru quoted another as saying.", "title": "Knife Attack at Russian School Leaves at Least 12 Wounded", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "So the party that currently controls all three branches of the federal government is increasingly for bigotry and against education. That should disturb you for multiple reasons, one of which is that the G.O.P. has rejected the very values that made America great.\n\nThink of where we\u2019d be as a nation if we hadn\u2019t experienced those great waves of immigrants driven by the dream of a better life. Think of where we\u2019d be if we hadn\u2019t led the world, first in universal basic education, then in the creation of great institutions of higher education. Surely we\u2019d be a shrunken, stagnant, second-rate society.\n\nAnd that\u2019s what we\u2019ll become if modern know-nothingism prevails.\n\nI\u2019ve been rereading an important 2012 book, Enrico Moretti\u2019s \u201cThe New Geography of Jobs,\u201d about the growing divergence of regional fortunes within the United States. Until around 1980, America seemed on the path toward broadly spread prosperity, with poor regions like the Deep South rapidly catching up with the rest. Since then, however, the gaps have widened again, with incomes in some parts of the nation surging while other parts fall behind.\n\nMoretti argues, rightly in the view of many economists, that this new divergence reflects the growing importance of clusters of highly skilled workers \u2014 many of them immigrants \u2014 often centered on great universities, that create virtuous circles of growth and innovation. And as it happens, the 2016 election largely pitted these rising regions against those left behind, which is why counties carried by Hillary Clinton, who won only a narrow majority of the popular vote, account for a remarkable 64 percent of U.S. G.D.P., almost twice as much as Trump counties.\n\nClearly, we need policies to spread the benefits of growth and innovation more widely. But one way to think of Trumpism is as an attempt to narrow regional disparities, not by bringing the lagging regions up, but by cutting the growing regions down. For that\u2019s what attacks on education and immigration, key drivers of the new economy\u2019s success stories, would do.\n\nSo will our modern know-nothings prevail? I have no idea. What\u2019s clear, however, is that if they do, they won\u2019t make America great again \u2014 they\u2019ll kill the very things that made it great.", "title": "Opinion | Know-Nothings for the 21st Century", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "What do you get when you cross the feverish world of cryptocurrencies and a faded industrial giant desperate for a new lease on life? The answer, provided Tuesday by Eastman Kodak, is KodakCoin.\n\nKodak filed for bankruptcy protection in 2012 after fumbling the shift to digital images. Now, the company is betting its future on digital currencies with an initial coin offering intended to help photographers sell their work. The announcement more than doubled Kodak\u2019s stock, but it\u2019s unlikely to do anything like the same to the company\u2019s sales or profit.\n\nKodak, based in Rochester, N.Y., emerged from bankruptcy in 2013, relieved of much of its debts and patents. It refocused around digital printing, packaging and a legacy film business that\u2019s a shadow of the glory days when Paul Simon had a hit song rhapsodizing about Kodachrome. None of those has caught on. Sales fell by a third in the first three years after bankruptcy. They dropped another 8 percent in the first three quarters of 2017, to $1.1 billion, and the bottom line dipped into the red. The company\u2019s market capitalization, nearly $30 billion at its peak in the late 1990s, fell to just $135 million early this week.\n\nThe announcement of the planned blockchain platform and initial coin offering changed the stock\u2019s trajectory. Kodak is just the latest to see the potential halo effect of cryptocurrencies after Bitcoin soared some 14-fold in 2017. In December, shares of the tiny Long Island Iced Tea tripled after it renamed itself Long Blockchain.", "title": "Kodak Last-Gasp Hope: KodakCoin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Erik Holm of MoneyBeat writes:\n\n\u201cFor the past several years, people have been experimenting with ways to adapt the technology behind bitcoin, usually called blockchain. At its essence, blockchain is an open record of transactions, maintained in an online ledger that is distributed across a network of computers, that cannot be tampered with. That makes it like an indelible timestamp, which could be useful in a case of copyright and digital rights management.\u201d\n\nKodak plans to hold an initial coin offering for KODAKCoin on Jan. 31. Coin offerings, which allow companies to raise money by creating their own private digital currency through a form of online crowdfunding, have surged in popularity during the past 12 months.\n\nKodak\u2019s shares are just the latest to get a digital currency boost. The stocks of a number of companies have surged in recent months after those firms rebranded themselves as having something to do digital currencies or blockchain.\n\nCritic\u2019s corner: Kodak is \u201cbetting its future on digital currencies with an initial coin offering designed to help photographers sell their work. The crypto buzz more than doubled its stock, but it\u2019s unlikely to do anything like the same to the company\u2019s sales or profit,\u201d writes Tom Buerkle of Breakingviews.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nCarlos Ghosn ups the ante.\n\nThe chief executive of Renault-Nissan has escalated the auto industry\u2019s technology-driven arms race.\n\nThe Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance said Tuesday it is setting up a venture capital fund to invest $1 billion in automotive technologies over the next five years. Mr. Ghosn pushed for the fund \u201cto speed development of technologies that the three automakers don\u2019t have in-house,\u201d the WSJ reported.\n\nMore about the fund:\n\n\u2022 It\u2019s named Alliance Ventures.\n\n\u2022 Francois Dossa is leading the fund and will have teams in Silicon Valley, Paris, Japan and China looking for startups in which to invest.\n\n\u2022 The fund has already invested in Ionic Materials, a Woburn, Mass., startup working to develop solid-state batteries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAutomakers have poured money into automobile technology startups in recent years. General Motors bought Cruise Automation in a deal potentially valued at more than $1 billion. Last summer Toyota set up a $100 million investing arm called Toyota AI Ventures.\n\nFrom Reuters:\n\n\u201cThe traditional auto industry model based on individual ownership is threatened by pay-per-use services such as Uber, as well as ride- and car-sharing platforms, a challenge heightened by parallel shifts towards electrified and self-driving cars.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nBannon is stepping down from Breitbart.\n\nFrom The New York Times:\n\nStephen K. Bannon is stepping down from his post as executive chairman of Breitbart News, the company announced Tuesday. Mr. Bannon\u2019s departure, which was forced by a onetime financial patron, Rebekah Mercer, comes as Mr. Bannon remained unable to quell the furor over remarks attributed to him in a new book in which he questions President Trump\u2019s mental fitness and disparages his elder son, Donald Trump Jr. Mr. Bannon\u2019s departure from the website is the latest ignominious turn in a career that was once one of the most promising and improbable in modern American politics.\n\nPhoto\n\nDonald Trump is going to Davos.\n\nHere\u2019s what White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders told Maggie Haberman and Michael Shear of the NYT:\n\n\u201cAt this year\u2019s World Economic Forum, the president looks forward to promoting his policies to strengthen American businesses, American industries, and American workers.\u201d\n\nHe\u2019ll be the first U.S. president to do so since Bill Clinton in 2000. The BBC previously noted that Ronald Reagan spoke to the crowd at the World Economic Forum via videoconference, but that neither of the Bushes nor Barack Obama attended. (Joe Biden did, however.)\n\nWhy? As the NYT adds, presidents have been concerned that being seen rubbing shoulders with some of the world\u2019s wealthiest might send the wrong political message. (Other heads of state, like Xi Jinping of China, have attended.)\n\nOne additional note: Having attended the forum a few times, I\u2019d say that one thing that a visit from Mr. Trump would definitely do is make the traffic in Davos during the event \u2014 which often moves at a glacial pace as V.I.P.\u2019s vehicular escorts crawl through the windy streets \u2014 probably more difficult.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nPutting Jeff Bezos\u2019s wealth into perspective.\n\nShot: \u201cJeff Bezos is now the richest person of all time,\u201d CNN reported. (The Bloomberg article that the news item cited makes no such claim.)\n\nChaser:\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech reckoning is gaining steam.\n\nLet\u2019s count the ways:\n\n\u2022 Apple is being pressed to protect young users from smartphone addiction by an unusual coalition: the hedge fund Jana Partners and the California public pension fund Calstrs.\n\n\u2022 Alphabet, Facebook and Twitter are under scrutiny over Russia\u2019s use of social media to manipulate elections.\n\n\u2022 Amazon is facing scrutiny for its effect on jobs.\n\n\u2022 Europe is examining many U.S. tech companies on competition and privacy grounds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs Barry Rosenstein, the managing partner of Jana, told David Gelles of the NYT:\n\n\u201cAs more and more founders of the biggest tech companies are acknowledging today, the days of just throwing technology out there and washing your hands of the potential impact are over.\u201d\n\nThe growing fear about tech addiction: Two former Facebook executives, Sean Parker and Chamath Palihapitiya, spoke last year about how the company hooks into users\u2019 psyches. And Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia, held a briefing on the issue. (Axios has more.)\n\nOne place you don\u2019t yet see a problem: These companies\u2019 stocks. Apple\u2019s shares dipped only slightly yesterday, and its market capitalization is still just shy of $900 billion. Shares in Facebook, Alphabet and Twitter gained slightly.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Shira Ovide writes, \u201cWhen financial mercenaries start caring about the potential human harm of technology, Silicon Valley should be extremely nervous.\u201d (Gadfly)\n\n\u2022 Jennifer Saba writes of Jana\u2019s campaign, \u201cIt\u2019s an unusual issue for an activist, and apps from Facebook and Snap would make better targets.\u201d (Breakingviews)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Oprah 2020\u2019 has been good for Weight Watchers.\n\nShares in the weight-loss company, of which Ms. Winfrey owns 10 percent, jumped as much as 13 percent yesterday amid speculation that she may run for president.\n\nNot everyone was as euphoric about the possibility. Here\u2019s what Rebecca Katz, a Democratic strategist, told the NYT:\n\n\u201cBeating Trump isn\u2019t just about finding the right candidate \u2014 we have to show what we stand for,\u201d Ms. Katz said. \u201cOther than \u2018we all get a car,\u2019 what will an Oprah presidency look like?\u201d she added, referring to when Ms. Winfrey famously gave a car to every audience member at her show.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill the tax law make U.S. companies stay, or go overseas?\n\nIt comes down to how they respond to the provision that taxes the income of overseas subsidiaries at half the domestic rate \u2014 even as Mr. Trump has promised to bring jobs back to struggling cities.\n\nCompanies have a new reason to move plants abroad, Natalie Kitroeff of the NYT reports:\n\n\u201cHaving such a low rate on foreign income is outrageous,\u201d said Stephen E. Shay, a senior lecturer at Harvard Law School and a Treasury Department official during the Reagan and Obama administrations. \u201cIt creates terrible incentives.\u201d\n\nThe caveat: Some companies may want to stay, for America\u2019s legal system and skilled workers. But big manufacturers like auto companies may be tempted to move anyway.\n\nMore in taxes\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump celebrated the passing of the tax overhaul in Nashville, where he overstated the size of the cuts. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Residents of high-tax states rushed to prepay their bills before deductions are capped, giving those areas a welcome, if brief, revenue boost. (Bloomberg)\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Robert Mueller is likely to seek an interview with President Trump as part of his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. (NYT)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. That raises questions about what else the Trump administration can do to prop up an industry that \u2014 even as pollution regulations loosen \u2014 is being battered by market forces.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Brad Plumer of the NYT:\n\nLast year, utilities announced plans to shut down more than 22 gigawatts of coal capacity across the country, and more retirements are expected this year. Mr. Perry\u2019s proposal was the most aggressive move yet in support of coal and nuclear power and would have shielded a number of plants in the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic from those competitive forces.\n\nThe policy flyaround\n\n\u2022 A Senate resolution to block the F.C.C.\u2019s repeal of net neutrality rules has enough support to force a vote \u2014 but the House is unlikely to follow suit. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 The Labor Department revived guidance on overtime regulations from the George W. Bush era. (WaPo)\n\nPhoto\n\nGoogle memo author sues, claiming discrimination.\n\nThe plaintiff: James Damore, the engineer who gained fame when he was fired for criticizing Google\u2019s diversity efforts and asserting that fewer women held engineering jobs because of biological differences.\n\nHis lawsuit: It claims that he and others were \u201costracized, belittled and punished for their heterodox political views, and for the added sin of their birth circumstances of being Caucasians and/or males.\u201d It also includes screenshots from internal company forums.\n\nThe context: Google is already responding to a lawsuit from four women asserting that it has systematically paid women less than men for the same work.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s happening at CES.\n\n\u2022 AT&T has backed out of a long-awaited deal to sell Huawei phones in the U.S., according to unnamed sources. (Recode)\n\nQuestions about CES? Ask Brian Chen, the NYT\u2019s personal tech columnist.\n\nSpeaking of gadgets\n\nGoPro disappointed Wall Street yesterday morning when it cut its sales expectations for its fourth quarter, saying it would lay off more than 250 employees and stop making drones. Its founder and C.E.O., Nick Woodman, cut his cash salary to $1.\n\nThe company\u2019s shares climbed back amid news reports that it had hired JPMorgan Chase to run a sales process. But Mr. Woodman eventually told Bloomberg that while JPMorgan is the company\u2019s main bank, GoPro wasn\u2019t actively looking to sell itself.\n\nGoPro\u2019s problem: It\u2019s too dependent on its action cameras, according to Dan Gallagher of Heard on the Street.\n\nPhoto\n\nSign of a market top? Hedging is pass\u00e9.\n\nSome investors have apparently decided that protecting themselves against a decline in the markets is a waste of money, Gunjan Banerji of the WSJ reports:\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen hedging activity this light since the end of the financial crisis,\u201d said Peter Cecchini, a New York-based chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald. \u201cIt started in late 2016 and accelerated in the second half of the year.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, analysts have raised their forecasts for corporate profits as fast as they have in a decade. History suggests that might presage a slump.\n\nQuote of the Day\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s made it the best penny stock and the worst currency in the world.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Matt O\u2019Brien of the WaPo, writing about why Bitcoin is doing well as a speculative investment and terribly as a way to buy and sell things. (For what it\u2019s worth, Jamie Dimon now regrets calling Bitcoin a \u201cfraud,\u201d though he\u2019s still not interested in it.)\n\nOr maybe it\u2019s this, from the S.E.C.\u2019s Fort Worth division:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Jack Ma said he would seriously consider listing Alibaba in Hong Kong, which is preparing to allow dual-class share listings. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Kodak to Issue Its Own Virtual Currency: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Cameron Chell, a lead adviser to the KodakCoin project, told me that the initial offering represented a \u201cseminal moment\u201d for Kodak, and that the company\u2019s interest in blockchain technology was a savvy long-term investment.\n\n\u201cThe real story is that it\u2019s about to be a renaissance,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Mr. Chell, a Canadian entrepreneur and motivational speaker who once opened for Tony Robbins, has a troubled track record. In 1998, Mr. Chell agreed to a five-year ban from the Alberta Stock Exchange in Canada and paid a $25,000 fine in connection with a violation of the exchange\u2019s rules. A previous company of his ended in ignominy after its chairman was charged with fraud.\n\nAsked about these incidents, Mr. Chell said that he was \u201cyoung, inexperienced and was irresponsible in my actions,\u201d and that he had \u201clearned a lot since 1998 and work hard to conduct myself in a manner that does not reflect that poor judgment.\u201d A Kodak spokesman did not return a request for comment about Mr. Chell and whether it knew about the ban.\n\nMr. Chell has refashioned himself as a blockchain expert in recent years, and KodakCoin is his biggest project so far. He is the chairman of Appcoin Innovations, which was registered as a literary agency \u2014 Redstone Literary Agents \u2014 until last year, when it became a consulting firm that provides \u201ca turnkey set of services for companies to develop and integrate blockchain and cryptocurrency technologies,\u201d according to securities filings.\n\nThe company, which trades over the counter as a penny stock, earned no revenue in 2015 or 2016, according to S.E.C. filings. Appcoin Innovations is slated to receive 20 percent of all KodakCoins issued and a portion of the offering proceeds, a stake that could amount to millions if the offering is successful.\n\n\u201cOnce formally launched,\u201d Mr. Chell wrote to me in an email, \u201cthe company will hopefully provide shareholders a traditional and transparent place to participate in the crypto space with projects that are regulatory compliant.\u201d\n\nNow, about those coins. You might think that a digital currency that is trying to \u201cdemocratize photography and make licensing fair to artists,\u201d in Mr. Clarke\u2019s words, would be easily accessible. But because of regulatory requirements, KodakCoins will be available only to so-called accredited investors in the United States. An accredited investor is defined as a person with a net worth of $1 million or more, or an annual income above $200,000.", "title": "Kodak\u2019s Dubious Cryptocurrency Gamble", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA divided Korea was something unprecedented,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the divide lasted in part because of competing visions among Koreans for the country\u2019s future. \u201cFundamentally it was a civil war, fought over issues going back into Korea\u2019s colonial experience,\u201d said Bruce Cumings, a professor of history at the University of Chicago.\n\nIn 1948, the American-backed, anti-communist southern administration, based in Seoul, declared itself the Republic of Korea. It was led by Syngman Rhee, who lived in exile in the United States for many years and was installed as the South Korean leader by the Office of Strategic Services, a predecessor to the Central Intelligence Agency, Professor Cumings said.\n\nSoon after, the Soviet-backed, communist northern administration, based in Pyongyang, declared itself the Democratic People\u2019s Republic of Korea. Its leader was Kim Il-sung, who fought alongside communist forces during the Chinese civil war and was the grandfather of North Korea\u2019s current dictator, Kim Jong-un.\n\nEach regime was unstable, rejected the legitimacy of the other and considered itself to be Korea\u2019s sole rightful ruler. Border skirmishes between the two were frequent before the Korean War began.\n\nPhoto\n\nWho were the combatants?\n\nThe war pitted South Korea and the United States, fighting under the auspices of the United Nations, against North Korea and China.\n\nOther nations contributed troops, too, but American forces did most of the fighting. \u201cThe South Korean Army virtually collapsed\u201d at the start of the war, Professor Cumings said.\n\nThe Soviet Union supported North Korea at the beginning of the war, giving it arms, tanks and strategic advice. But China soon emerged as its most important ally, sending soldiers to fight in Korea as a way to keep the conflict away from its border.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Chinese leader, Mao Zedong, also saw China\u2019s participation in the war as a way to thank Korean Communists who fought in the Chinese civil war, Professor Cumings said.\n\n\u201cThere was a lot of field contact between American and Chinese forces,\u201d Professor Armstrong said. \u201cIn a sense, this was the first and only war between China and the United States, so far.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHow damaging was it?\n\nThe war devastated Korea. Historians said that between three million and four million people were killed, although firm figures have never been produced, particularly by the North Korean government. As many as 70 percent of the dead may have been civilians.\n\nDestruction was particularly acute in the North, which was subjected to years of American bombing, including with napalm. Roughly 25 percent of its prewar population was killed, Professor Cumings said, and many of the survivors lived underground by the war\u2019s end.\n\n\u201cNorth Korea was flattened,\u201d he said. \u201cThe North Koreans see the American bombing as a Holocaust, and every child is taught about it.\u201d\n\nDamage was also widespread in South Korea, where Seoul changed hands four times. But most combat took place in the northern or central parts of the peninsula around the current Demilitarized Zone, which divides the countries, Professor Cumings said.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow did it end?\n\nTechnically, the Korean War did not end.\n\nThe fighting stopped when North Korea, China and the United States reached an armistice in 1953. But South Korea did not agree to the armistice, and no formal peace treaty was ever signed.\n\n\u201cThere is still a technical state of war between the combatants,\u201d Professor Cumings said.\n\nNeither North nor South Korea had achieved its goal: the destruction of the opposing regime and reunification of the divided peninsula.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince 1953 there has been an uneasy coexistence between North and South Korea, which hosts over 20,000 American troops. At one time hundreds of American nuclear weapons were based there.\n\n\u201cIt was from the Korean War onward that we had a permanent, global American military presence that we had never had before,\u201d Professor Armstrong said. Other countries that host American troops include Qatar, Japan, Italy and Germany. \u201cIt was a real turning point for America\u2019s global role.\u201d\n\nIn the decades after the war, South Korea transformed into an economic powerhouse. Professor Cumings said many of its citizens now know little about the conflict and have \u201ca fatalistic orientation\u201d toward the economically isolated North.\n\nMeanwhile, North Korea became \u201cthe world\u2019s most amazing garrison state with the fourth largest army in the world.\u201d\n\n\u201cIts generals are still fighting the war,\u201d Professor Cumings said. \u201cFor them it has never ended.\u201d", "title": "Korean War, a \u2018Forgotten\u2019 Conflict That Shaped the Modern World", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump began the new year with an apocalyptic Twitter outburst, taunting the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, that \u201cI too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, like an adult trying to carry on an intelligent conversation while a child is having a tantrum, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea has tried to resume direct engagement with Pyongyang, which was cut off nearly two years ago. It provided at least a dim glimmer of hope that the North Korean nuclear arms crisis can be resolved peacefully.\n\nIt\u2019s a move that requires patience and humility, qualities Mr. Trump generally lacks. The North Koreans have long made clear that they view South Korea as a lackey of their chief adversary, the United States. Yet since his inauguration in May, Mr. Moon has called for dialogue with the North, which severed all communications with Seoul in 2016 after Mr. Moon\u2019s conservative predecessor shuttered an industrial complex in the North.\n\nMr. Moon has been pressing Pyongyang for months to send a delegation to the Winter Olympics his nation is hosting next month. The proposal was effectively ignored until Mr. Kim used his annual New Year\u2019s Day speech to signal he was \u201copen to dialogue\u201d with the South to discuss easing military tensions on the Korean Peninsula, as well as to sending North Korean athletes to join the Games.", "title": "Opinion | Koreans Turn Down the Volume", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKristaps Porzingis scored 28 points, Enes Kanter had 20 points, 20 rebounds and 5 assists, and the Knicks completed a regular-season sweep of the Nets with a 111-95 victory Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.\n\nThe Knicks returned home from their longest trip of the season in new uniforms \u2014 a darker blue than their usual uniforms designed to pay homage to New York\u2019s firefighters \u2014 but continued their same old dominance of the Nets, with their fourth victory in four tries this season. They controlled the interior again and swept the series for the first time since 2010-11 \u2014 before the rivals shared the same city.\n\nKanter was 8 of 10 from the field and Tim Hardaway Jr. added 15 points for the Knicks, who went 3-4 on their trip, which started with a victory in Brooklyn on Jan. 15. Michael Beasley finished with 12 points and 13 rebounds.\n\nThe Knicks kept up their strong offensive play on Tuesday that they had displayed on their trip, when they averaged 111.3 points, fourth-best in the N.B.A. during that stretch.\n\nDeMarre Carroll scored 13 points for the Nets, who lost their fourth straight game. They played their second in a row without starting forward Rondae Hollis-Jefferson (strained right groin) and the reserve guard Caris LeVert (sore left groin).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Knicks were again without Joakim Noah, who is not expected to play Wednesday in Boston, Coach Jeff Hornacek said. The backup center left the team near the end of the trip after getting frustrated with Hornacek.\n\nThe Nets fell behind by 18 in the second quarter but cut the deficit to 10 midway through the period before the Knicks opened it up again, building a 61-41 advantage at halftime.\n\nThe Knicks took a 25-point lead that the Nets again trimmed to 10, but Porzingis made a 3-point shot with seven and a half minutes remaining to halt their push.\n\nNets Coach Kenny Atkinson said the team would determine Wednesday whether guard D\u2019Angelo Russell, recently back from knee surgery, would be able to play the second night of a back-to-back, when the 76ers visit Barclays Center. Russell finished with 7 points and 5 rebounds in 20 minutes of play on Tuesday. If he is not available Wednesday, and if LeVert remains out, Atkinson said that Nik Stauskas and Isaiah Whitehead could be ball-handling options.", "title": "Kristaps Porzingis and Enes Kanter Lead Knicks in Rout of Nets", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Making a big bet on poetry might seem counterintuitive, but it could prove commercially savvy. Novels in verse have become a surprisingly vibrant and popular literary form with young readers. The best-selling author Ellen Hopkins publishes young adult novels in verse that tackle controversial issues like drug addiction, suicide and teen pregnancy. Jacqueline Woodson\u2019s memoir in free verse, \u201cBrown Girl Dreaming,\u201d won the National Book Award for Young People\u2019s Literature in 2014, and became a best-seller.\n\nMs. Woodson, who is a friend of Mr. Alexander\u2019s, said she expects that he will discover new voices that might have otherwise gone overlooked by the publishing industry.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s going to challenge us as readers,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Giles, a founding member of the organization We Need Diverse Books, said he was immediately intrigued when Mr. Alexander sent him a text message asking if he had any novels in the works. \u201cThe imprint is going to be groundbreaking because Kwame is groundbreaking,\u201d Mr. Giles said. \u201cHe\u2019s like the Willy Wonka of children\u2019s publishing.\u201d\n\nWith his pivot to publishing, Mr. Alexander is joining a small but influential group of children\u2019s book authors who have launched their own imprints and are helping to reshape children\u2019s literature. The prolific best-seller James Patterson created a kids\u2019 book imprint, Jimmy Patterson, with Little, Brown & Company in 2015, and has since released 48 books, and sold more than seven million copies. In 2016, the author and artist Christopher Myers founded his imprint, Make Me a World, with Random House Children\u2019s Books, in part to address the lack of racial and cultural diversity in children\u2019s publishing. Rick Riordan, the author of the Percy Jackson series, recently started an imprint with Disney-Hyperion, Rick Riordan Presents, which features middle grade books that draw on mythology from around the world, including Indian, Korean and Mayan myths and folklore, written by emerging writers from underrepresented cultures.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Alexander sees Versify as a way to leverage his professional connections and marketing savvy to boost the profiles of newer writers.\n\n\u201cI see a lot more publishers being in tune to what\u2019s happening outside their communities, and you have a lot more writers of color having an opportunity to get their voices heard,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is an opportunity with this imprint for me to do that on a mass scale.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGrowing up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and later, Chesapeake, Va., Mr. Alexander was surrounded by books: His father was a college professor, book publisher and Baptist pastor, and his mother worked as a teacher and then a school principal.\n\nMr. Alexander, who lives in Virginia and is married with two daughters, decided in college that he wanted to be a writer, even though he found little encouragement at first. At Virginia Tech, he studied medicine, but then he took a writing class with the poet Nikki Giovanni, and became determined to be a poet. She gave him a C, but he signed up for more of her classes, he said. (She later became a mentor to him, and recently agreed to write a book of poetry for his new imprint).\n\nAfter graduating, he gave poetry readings at universities, coffee shops, churches, community centers and any other place that would have him. He sold copies of his self-published poetry collections for around $10 a piece. He started his own publishing company, the Alexander Publishing Group, and ran the company for 10 years. But he lost money on the venture, and abandoned the company in 2005 to focus on writing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA few years later, he started working on \u201cThe Crossover.\u201d When the book came out in 2014, it catapulted him to prominence. He has since published six other children\u2019s books \u2014 including the best-sellers \u201cSolo\u201d and \u201cBooked,\u201d coming-of-age stories that unfold in verse \u2014 and his books have collectively sold more than a million copies. Following \u201cThe Crossover,\u201d he signed two separate seven figure, multi-book deals, with Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and Blink, a HarperCollins young adult imprint. His next book, \u201cRebound,\u201d a novel in verse and prequel to \u201cThe Crossover,\u201d comes out this spring.\n\n\u201cThere are very few authors like him,\u201d said Ellen Archer, president of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt trade publishing. \u201cHe reaches reluctant readers and makes them avid readers.\u201d\n\nTall and energetic, Mr. Alexander is a charismatic performer who often breaks into spontaneous poetry when addressing crowds. He seems to have an almost hypnotic command over audiences, whether he\u2019s speaking to squirmy first graders, high school seniors or a room full of publishing executives. In the last couple of years, he\u2019s visited more than 300 schools around the country, sometimes startling students who had written him fan letters with surprise visits in front of their lockers. He occasionally visits juvenile detention centers and leads poetry workshops.\n\nIn December, Mr. Alexander spoke to a group of middle school students at Unity Preparatory Charter School of Brooklyn. He gave away prizes and recited a short poem he wrote when he was a kid (it was about his mom). He recounted his early struggles to get published, drawing out the tale of his successive rejections in a perfectly timed routine.\n\n\u201cI believe that the nos are a part of life,\u201d he told the students. \u201cRaise your hand if you\u2019ve ever been told no?\u201d\n\nYou only need one yes, he told them, as the auditorium erupted into cheers.", "title": "Kwame Alexander Will Start His Own Imprint. The Name? Versify. Get It?", "authors": ["Alexandra Alter"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Showing works that were overtly critical of the government and the war in Vietnam as well as of museums themselves, the exhibition set out to disturb the artistic and political status quo. That it was held in a museum as prominent and as Balkanized (in terms of art mediums) as the Modern made it all the more effective.\n\n\u201cInformation\u201d was rife with unfamiliar artists: the South Americans H\u00e9lio Oiticica and Marta Minujin, for example, and Group OHO, a five-person collective from Yugoslavia.\n\nBut there were also plenty of Downtown Manhattan stalwarts, among them Richard Serra, Robert Smithson and Yvonne Rainer, as well as the art critic Lucy R. Lippard. She had given Mr. McShine access to her extensive files on art\u2019s new directions while he was working on the show.\n\nThose files became, in 1973, the basis for Ms. Lippard\u2019s book \u201cSix Years: The Dematerialization of the Art Object From 1966 to 1972.\u201d Primarily a densely annotated chronology, it includes \u201cInformation.\u201d\n\nThe disruptive spirit of the show was apparent in its catalog, which was printed on cheap stock using a typewriter font and gave each artist at least one full page to use as desired. The astounding range of creativity, irreverence and abstruseness that resulted was bracketed between endpapers with wide-angled views of masses of humanity: The first showed the 1963 March on Washington, the last the 1969 Woodstock festival.\n\nKynaston Leigh Gerard McShine was born on Feb. 20, 1935, in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, the oldest of two boys of Austen Hutton McShine and the former Leonora Pujadas. His father was a bank president; his mother founded Trinidad\u2019s League of Women Voters and was its first president. His large, close and comfortably well-off family had produced doctors, lawyers and a judge or two among its branches.", "title": "Kynaston McShine, Curator of Historic Art Exhibitions, Dies at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In the latest sign of turmoil in an unusually tumultuous New York ballet season, the dancers at American Ballet Theater voted early Thursday to authorize a strike should their tense negotiations with the company\u2019s management fail to yield an acceptable contact proposal.\n\nThe company\u2019s dancers and stage managers, who have been negotiating with management since April and whose last contract expired at the end of July, took the vote after talks stalled amid questions over how much the company should contribute to their retirement plans. The threat of a strike comes as Ballet Theater plans to go on tour at the end of January to Washington; Detroit; Lincoln, Neb.; and Chicago. It plans to tour Asia in March.\n\nThe labor unrest comes during a difficult moment in the dance world. Peter Martins, who led New York City Ballet for more than three decades, retired this month as the company investigated accusations (which he has denied) that he engaged in sexual harassment and verbal and physical abuse over the years. And last month one of Ballet Theater\u2019s brightest stars, Marcelo Gomes, resigned after an accusation of sexual misconduct.\n\nLeonard Egert, the national executive director of the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents Ballet Theater\u2019s dancers and stage managers, said that retirement benefits had emerged as a key sticking point. He said that after the last recession hit, the company eliminated its contributions to the workers\u2019 defined contribution retirement plans for a year, and then restored them at half their previous level \u2014 at 3.75 percent of their income, down from 7.5 percent. He said that the dancers were seeking modest increases to get back to the old level.", "title": "Labor Unrest Hits Ballet Theater, and Dancers Consider a Strike", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Govan identified another reason for seeking a satellite space: the museum currently pays for offsite commercial storage, with no such facilities under its own control. A new site could have built-in storage, if renovated to meet standards. He estimated that the Wetlands building would cost \u201c$300 to $400 per square foot zone to renovate, so we\u2019re looking at roughly $25 to $30 million for capital investment.\u201d\n\nLacma has already spent several years raising money for the transformation of its main Wilshire campus, which involves razing three existing buildings to replace them with a single dramatic structure by the architect Peter Zumthor. With David Geffen\u2019s gift of $150 million, the museum has raised about $450 million but is still $200 million short of its stated budget for construction and related costs.\n\nDespite that big ask still in progress, the museum doesn\u2019t seemed worried about taking on another capital campaign. Mr. Govan said he doesn\u2019t think there would be any overlap in donors, noting that the South L.A. projects appeal to those supporting \u201ca different set of national initiatives toward social justice.\u201d\n\n\u201cUntil the funding drive has been finished for Lacma on Wilshire Boulevard, we are not seeking any resources from those who should and can be giving to that campaign,\u201d Mr. Govan said. \u201cWe are looking elsewhere.\u201d\n\nThe Ford Foundation, which is not involved with the Zumthor project, has already issued a $2 million flexible grant to Lacma \u201cfor the acquisitions of sites and community-based programming\u201d in South Los Angeles, said the foundation\u2019s president, Darren Walker. He called the project \u201ca radical idea, not being done at this scale by any museum in America.\u201d", "title": "Lacma Seeks to Expand Its Footprint Into South Los Angeles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s interesting that Sandusky\u2019s name wasn\u2019t more prevalent over the past week, as the attention to Nassar\u2019s story and the efforts to wring some meaning from it intensified. The parallels are striking and instructive. Although Sandusky\u2019s victims were boys, he, like Nassar, constructed his professional life so that he had steady access to children and appeared to be an altruist in their midst. He started a foster home, which evolved into a nonprofit group for troubled youth so large and well regarded that it received one of President George H. W. Bush\u2019s \u201cPoints of Light\u201d awards.\n\n\u201cChildren constantly surrounded Sandusky, so much so that they became part of his persona,\u201d Joe Posnanski wrote in his book \u201cPaterno.\u201d That same description applies to Nassar. It also applies to many of the abusive priests who went undetected and unpunished before the Catholic Church finally owned up to its failures and instituted necessary reforms.\n\nNassar had girls stretched out and pliant on his examining table. Sandusky roughhoused, wrestled and showered with boys in the name of sports. Nassar\u2019s victims and their parents were awestruck by his ties to Olympic athletes, his floor passes to elite competitions, the mementos on his office walls. Sandusky\u2019s victims were dazzled by his position smack in the middle of all of those football stars and all of that football glory.\n\nIn an article about Sandusky in The New Yorker, Malcolm Gladwell observed that he \u201cbuilt a sophisticated, multimillion-dollar, fully integrated grooming operation, outsourcing to child-care professionals the task of locating vulnerable children.\u201d Change \u201cchild-care professionals\u201d to gymnastics coaches and Gladwell could have been analyzing Nassar.\n\nGrooming. Such a chilling word. Such an apt one. Abusers introduce themselves as instructors and allies. They can lift your score. They can improve your grades. They can provide the guidance that you lack or the fun that you\u2019re missing. Bit by bit, they ask for bigger chunks of your time and suggest increasingly private encounters. The pace of the journey varies, but not its arc or its destination.\n\nAnd they concoct justifications for what they\u2019re doing, trying to persuade their victims of its righteousness as they simultaneously persuade themselves. Nassar\u2019s so-called medical treatments exemplified this, as did the actions of many priests. I recall one who told a boy that the touching was part of his confession and his purification. I recall another who told a girl that she\u2019d been assigned the task of helping him, a professed celibate, to better understand human sexuality so that he could minister more effectively to his flock.\n\nMany abusive priests invoked the permission of God. Nassar cited the demands of science.\n\nAn overwhelming majority of adults who treat, teach, coach and counsel children are nothing like these men. To distrust all of them would be a terrible mistake and grievous disservice, both to them and to the kids who stand to benefit mightily from their attention.", "title": "Opinion | Larry Nassar Is a Familiar Monster", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis letter tells me you have not yet owned what you did,\u201d she said. \u201cYou still think somehow you are right, you\u2019re a doctor, that you\u2019re entitled, so you don\u2019t have to listen. That you did \u2018treatment.\u2019 I wouldn\u2019t send my dogs to you, sir.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nDr. Nassar, 54, was accused of molesting girls for years under the guise of giving them examinations or medical treatment. Some were as young as 6. Many of them were Olympic gymnasts. In November, he pleaded guilty to sexually abusing seven girls. He had already been sentenced to 60 years in federal prison for child pornography convictions.\n\nThe case and its ramifications are far from over. It has ignited outrage in the sports world and beyond, leading to the resignation this week of the chairman and several board members of the governing body for gymnastics in the United States, U.S.A. Gymnastics. Last week, the organization cut ties with the private training center at a remote Texas ranch where some of the abuse occurred.\n\nAnd at Michigan State, where Dr. Nassar spent years on the faculty and treated many of its athletes, an outpouring of political pressure led to the resignation of the university\u2019s president, Lou Anna K. Simon, late Wednesday.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Simon\u2019s resignation may have just been the beginning at Michigan State, as the N.C.A.A. on Tuesday formally opened an investigation into the university\u2019s conduct.\n\nThe United States Olympic Committee, which some of the young women condemned for not doing enough to protect them when they joined the team and had to continue to see Dr. Nassar, said on Wednesday it was now taking action.\n\nMoments after the judge delivered her sentence, the Olympic committee issued a statement calling on the entire U.S.A. Gymnastics board to resign and promising additional steps to investigate Dr. Nassar\u2019s conduct and ensure athletes are not harmed in the future. The Olympic committee\u2019s chief executive, Scott Blackmun, also apologized for not attending the hearing, after gymnasts pointedly condemned the U.S.O.C. for lack of support.\n\nVideo\n\nA number of civil lawsuits have also been filed.\n\nThe sentencing hearing itself, streamed live on the internet, captured national attention for extending several days to allow for victim impact statements from girls and women who said they were molested by Dr. Nassar over the years. Many of the victims had not previously identified themselves. Initial plans to conclude after four days were altered as more women came forward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong those who have accused him are the Olympic gold medalists Aly Raisman, McKayla Maroney, Gabby Douglas, Jordyn Wieber and Simone Biles.\n\nThe final three victims spoke on Wednesday. Rachael Denhollander, who was one of the first women to come forward with public accusations against Dr. Nassar, was the last to speak at his sentencing hearing. \u201cLarry is the most dangerous type of abuser,\u201d she said. \u201cOne who is capable of manipulating his victims through coldly calculated grooming methodologies, presenting the most wholesome and caring external persona as a deliberate means to ensure a steady stream of young children to assault.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Sign up to receive an email from The New York Times as soon as important news breaks around the world.
