Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJudge Aquilina praised Ms. Denhollander for opening the floodgates. \u201cYou are the bravest person I have ever had in my courtroom,\u201d she said.\n\nThe sentence carries a minimum 40 years imprisonment, adhering to the terms of the plea agreement, but the judge advised that should Dr. Nassar improbably live longer than any human has, and come up for parole after serving the federal and state sentences, his time in state prison should extend to 175 years.\n\nNassar also pleaded guilty in November on three sexual abuse counts in a neighboring county. That sentencing is later this month.\n\nThe statements by the young women in the past week were forceful and at times anguished.\n\n\u201cImagine feeling like you have no power and no voice,\u201d Ms. Raisman said in court last Friday. \u201cWell, you know what, Larry? I have both power and voice, and I am only just beginning to use them. All these brave women have power, and we will use our voices to make sure you get what you deserve: a life of suffering spent replaying the words delivered by this powerful army of survivors.\u201d\n\nAs part of a lawsuit settlement, Ms. Maroney had signed a nondisclosure agreement with U.S.A. Gymnastics that would have caused her to be fined more than $100,000 for speaking about the abuse. After several celebrities offered to pay the fine, the organization said it would not fine her.\n\n\u201cDr. Nassar was not a doctor,\u201d she said. \u201cHe in fact is, was, and forever shall be a child molester, and a monster of a human being.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the end, though, Judge Aquilina had the final words.\n\n\u201cYour decision to assault was precise, calculated, manipulative, devious, despicable,\u201d she told Dr. Nassar in part. \u201cI don\u2019t have to add words because your survivors have said all of that and I don\u2019t want to repeat it. You can\u2019t give them back their innocence, their youth.\u201d", "title": "Larry Nassar Sentencing: \u2018I Just Signed Your Death Warrant\u2019", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola", "Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "CHARLOTTE, Mich. \u2014 Back in court Wednesday for his third and final sentencing hearing, Lawrence G. Nassar, the former U.S.A. Gymnastics and Michigan State University sports clinic doctor, heard statements from more than 20 accusers, many of whom shared accounts of sexual abuse by Dr. Nassar at a local gymnastics club known for grooming stars.\n\nDr. Nassar\u2019s accusers include elite athletes, such as the Olympic medalists Simone Biles, Aly Raisman, McKayla Maroney and Gabby Douglas. But the speakers in court on Wednesday were not global superstars. They were mostly regular teenagers who told of being charmed by Dr. Nassar\u2019s \u201cstrange laugh\u201d and by the autographed posters of revered gymnasts on the walls of his office at the Michigan State sports clinic.\n\nTwistars Gymnastics Club, outside Lansing, Mich., was supposed to catapult young female athletes to a fruitful career, under the guidance of John Geddert, who owned the gym and coached there. Instead it became a site of anguish and devastation, according to the statements, some of which described long-lasting injuries, both mental and physical, inflicted by the doctor known as the \u201chealer of gymnasts.\u201d\n\nLast week, more than 150 young women and teenagers finished publicly confronting Dr. Nassar during a seven-day hearing in Ingham County Circuit Court, where he had pleaded guilty in November to seven counts of sexual assault. He has received sentences of 60 years for a conviction related to child pornography and of 40 to 175 years for the sexual abuse charges in Ingham County.", "title": "Larry Nassar, Sentenced in Sexual Abuse Case, Is Back in Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The search warrants detail how law enforcement focused on Marilou Danley, the girlfriend of Mr. Paddock. She has not been charged with a crime and has spoken to investigators several times, and her lawyer has said she was not aware of Mr. Paddock\u2019s deadly plans. The investigation is continuing, and the warrants only reflect its early stages.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cShe has been identified thus far as the most likely person who aided or abetted Stephen Paddock based on her informing law enforcement that her fingerprints would likely be found on the ammunition used during the attack,\u201d according to one of the documents.\n\nShe told investigators she occasionally helped Mr. Paddock load magazines. The F.B.I. said there was no evidence that she knew of his plans or had been deceptive, but it cautioned soon after the shootings that she was still the \u201csubject of intensive review.\u201d\n\nMs. Danley corroborated much of what had been previously pieced together by investigators, but she has been adamant that she had no prior knowledge of Mr. Paddock\u2019s intention to carry out the mass shooting.\n\nAccording to the documents, it appears that Mr. Paddock relied on the internet to buy many of the items used in the attack, including guns and ammunition, during the 12 months leading up to it.\n\nHe spent \u201csignificant time and expense prior to the attack purchasing and caching weapons\u201d and other items, such as glass cutters and suitcases. The authorities have said he used the glass cutters so he could fire out of his hotel window at the people below, who were attending a country music concert.\n\nMuch of what investigators found in the hotel room had already been made public, but the search warrants add additional details. The F.B.I. said there were hundreds of rounds of spent ammunition as well as \u201cpreloaded high-capacity magazines,\u201d found in suitcases that Mr. Paddock had brought to the room. Investigators also found body armor, range finders and a homemade gas mask.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInvestigators also revealed that Mr. Paddock may have been treated for \u201cunidentified medical conditions.\u201d In October, Ms. Danley told investigators that Mr. Paddock\u2019s physical and mental health seemed to have deteriorated in recent months.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn an affidavit submitted as part of a search warrant application, an investigator said that access to Ms. Danley\u2019s email account could \u201clead investigators to determine the full scope of Stephen Paddock\u2019s plan and Marilou Danley\u2019s possible involvement.\u201d The authorities also requested information about several Instagram accounts that they believed were connected to Ms. Danley.\n\nIn their requests for data from Instagram, investigators said they were seeking \u201cevidence showing the possession, use, purchase or sale of firearms, firearms accessories, ammunition or explosives by Paddock.\u201d They also sought information about Ms. Danley\u2019s \u201cstate of mind as it relates to the crime under investigation\u201d and the identities of anyone who communicated with her about what would amount to violations of federal weapons laws.\n\nMs. Danley deleted her Facebook account just hours after the attack, investigators wrote in their affidavit. At 12:30 a.m., about two-and-a-half hours after the shooting began, she changed the status of her account to private. By 2:46 a.m., she had deleted the account entirely.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn September, the court records suggested, Mr. Paddock ordered from Amazon a holographic weapon sight that investigators believe he ultimately used during the assault. On Friday night, Amazon listed the same model, which was described as \u201cdesigned for close-in combat speed and versatility.\u201d The price is $429, according to the listing, which said the sight \u201cimproves target acquisition, boosts accuracy and increases control.\u201d\n\nThe F.B.I. also discovered emails between two accounts connected to Mr. Paddock. One from early July indicated that Mr. Paddock had begun taking steps to carry out the attack, referring to a \u201cbump stock,\u201d an attachment that enables a semiautomatic rifle to fire faster.\n\nIn an email Mr. Paddock sent on July 6 to an account that also may have belonged to him, he wrote: \u201ctry an ar before u buy. we have huge selection. located in the las vegas area.\u201d Another email sent between the accounts read, \u201cfor a thrill try out bumpfire ar\u2019s with a 100 round magazine.\u201d By \u201car,\u201d Mr. Paddock appeared to be referring to rifles.\n\nThe affidavit later adds that \u201cinvestigators have been unable to figure out why Stephen Paddock would be exchanging messages related to weapons that were used in the attack between two of his email accounts,\u201d and that it was possible that someone else was controlling one of the accounts. If that was the case, the investigator said, the F.B.I. needed to identify that person. Receiving a search warrant for that account \u201cwill lead investigators to determine the full scope of Stephen Paddock\u2019s plan,\u201d an F.B.I agent wrote to the judge.", "title": "Las Vegas Gunman Took Elaborate Steps to Hide His Tracks, New Documents Show", "authors": ["Adam Goldman", "Jennifer Medina"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLauren Elizabeth DeNatale and Paul William Lyons were married Jan. 27 at the Mandarin Oriental in Boston. Tisch\u2019s apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan has spectacular views of Central Park. Reflecting her passions and role as a trustee at the Whitney Museum of American Art, it is filled with classic paintings by the country\u2019s renowned modernists, including Edward Hopper, Milton Avery, Jacob Lawrence, Thomas Hart Benton and Georgia O\u2019Keeffe (with a radiant new acquisition of her \u201cBlue Morning Glories\u201d).\n\nYet what often captures the attention of visitors, Ms. Tisch said with amusement, as she gave a recent tour of her home, are her trophies from the New York Giants\u2019 Super Bowl XLII and XLVI victories.\n\n\u201cThose were two very close games against the Patriots, where New York basically had no business winning,\u201d said Ms. Tisch, whose father, Preston Robert Tisch, bought half the team in 1991. Now Ms. Tisch has inherited his stake in the Giants, together with her brothers, since the passing of their mother, Joan Tisch, at age 90 in November.\n\n\u201cI grew up with six boys \u2014 two brothers and four male cousins \u2014 not the easiest thing being the only female,\u201d said Ms. Tisch, as she pointed to Jenny Holzer\u2019s marble bench in the foyer, carved with the artist\u2019s \u201ctruism\u201d: \u201cMen don\u2019t protect you anymore.\u201d While some of those Tisch men now run Loews Corporation, passed on from her father and uncle, who started in business by buying and revamping hotels, Ms. Tisch has followed in her parents\u2019 philanthropic footsteps with the Laurie M. Representative Devin Nunes of California has led a push to release a memo, drawing on classified information, that is said to accuse the F.B.I. of abusing its power.\n\n\u201cI just signed your death warrant\u201d\n\n\u2022 With those words, Judge Rosemarie Aquilina sentenced Lawrence Nassar, the former doctor for the U.S. gymnastics team, to 40 to 175 years in prison on Wednesday for multiple sex crimes.\n\nMore than 150 women confronted Dr. Nassar, 54, during his seven-day sentencing hearing, accusing him of abuse. We highlighted some of their poignant comments.\n\n\u2022 Dr. Nassar was also on the faculty at Michigan State University until 2016, when the abuse came to light. Amid fallout from the scandal, the university\u2019s president, Lou Anna Simon, resigned on Wednesday.\n\nPhoto\n\nDefeated ISIS fighters still pose a threat\n\n\u2022 It was a major security mistake of the Iraq war: Militants, including the current leader of the Islamic State, were held for years at a U.S. detention facility, where they became even more radicalized.\n\nNow, American-backed Kurdish militias in Syria have detained hundreds of ISIS fighters and their families in makeshift camps, raising fears among U.S. military officials of another breeding ground for extremists.\n\n\u2022 President Trump warned Turkey on Wednesday to limit its attacks on the Kurds. The Turkish government views them as terrorists, but they have helped the U.S. fight Islamic State militants.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: The Doctor and the Judge When the former physician for the American gymnastics team pleaded guilty to sex crimes, the judge opened her courtroom to his accusers. More than 150 women came forward. Audio\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 President Trump is on his way to the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, to explain his \u201cAmerica First\u201d approach. But the world has moved ahead with a trade agenda that no longer revolves around the U.S.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhatever reception Mr. Trump receives at the forum, one thing is true for its moneyed elite: The president has been good for business. You can find all of our Davos coverage here.\n\n\u2022 More large companies like Starbucks and Walmart are seeing the value in paid leave and other benefits for parents, and are beginning to close the gap between salaried and hourly workers.\n\n\u2022 Demand for coal in the U.S. continues to fall, and the impact is being felt in Pennsylvania, where the closing of a mine will idle 370 workers.\n\n\u2022 Britain\u2019s \u201cmost un-P.C.\u201d charity is shutting down. An undercover investigation revealed that participants at the annual fund-raising dinner of the Presidents Club groped and propositioned young women hired as servers.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were mixed on Wednesday. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets today.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\n\u2022 Throw an incredible Super Bowl party.\n\n\u2022 Should you give back the engagement ring?\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Satisfy a sweet tooth with salted chocolate chunk shortbread cookies.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Governor, mayor and soon-to-be retiree\n\nJerry Brown, 79, says his time in public service is \u201cgetting close to the end.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe spoke to the two-time governor of California, the face of the state\u2019s old political order, who will deliver his final State of the State speech today.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Pope Francis on \u201cfake news\u201d\n\nThe serpent in the Garden of Eden hissed the first fake news to Eve and it all went downhill from there, Pope Francis wrote in a major document about the phenomenon.\n\n\u2022 Those magazines sure stack up\n\nEven as print flails, piles of Vogues, Playboys and other publications are being painstakingly preserved in a former cannon foundry in London. We visited the Guinness World Record-holding collection.\n\nPhoto\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nPresident Trump is traveling to Davos with the message that America is open for business. \u201cAnd who better to make that declaration than a man who declared bankruptcy six different times?\u201d Jimmy Kimmel asked.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cMaybe there was some sort of presumption on the part of the president and his team that if the U.S. said stop, this process would come to a halt. What this shows is that\u2019s not true. The world just moves on without us.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Phil Levy, a former White House economist, on President Trump\u2019s approach to trade pacts.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nIn honor of Australia Day, Friday\u2019s holiday marking the anniversary of Britain\u2019s arrival Down Under in 1788, we\u2019re looking at one of the country\u2019s most recognizable exports: \u201cG\u2019day, mate!\u201d\n\nAustralian National University points to an early use of the greeting in \u201cThe Romance of a Station,\u201d a novel from 1889:\n\n\u201cHe pulled up, nodding to Alec\u2019s \u2018Good-day, Tillidge,\u2019 and replying in a short, morose manner, running his words one into the other, as a bushman does, \u2018G\u2019d-day, sir.\u2019 \u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA century later, the phrase was popularized the world over in a tourism campaign featuring Paul Hogan, the Australian actor who would later gain international fame as Crocodile Dundee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAustralians have a long tradition of abbreviating and slackening words and phrases, particularly by adding \u201cie\u201d to the end.\n\n\u201cAussie\u201d appears in references from World War I. A book by Gertrude Moberly, recounting the experiences of a nurse, described a \u201cfarewell dance for the boys going home to \u2018Aussie\u2019 tomorrow.\u201d\n\nAnd Australians always have their \u201cmates.\u201d The nation\u2019s unique camaraderie, known as mateship, is especially evident during commemorations of the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (or Anzacs), the World War I-era fighting force.\n\nAdam Baidawi contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. Check out our full range of free newsletters here.", "title": "Lawrence Nassar, Davos, Pope Francis: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Stager believed that by condemning the worship of calf deities, the early Israelites were seeking to purge their forebears\u2019 Canaanite influence and establish themselves as a separate people.\n\nIn 2016, Dr. Stager and Daniel M. Master, a former student of his who is an archaeology professor at Wheaton College in Illinois and was a director of the Ashkelon dig for a decade, made what they described as another one-of-a-kind discovery: a Philistine cemetery.\n\n\u201cThe uniqueness of Ashkelon,\u201d Dr. Stager said at the time, \u201cis that we now have both places where we can study the living and the dead.\u201d\n\nCoupled with earlier discoveries in Ashkelon of painted inscriptions that represented a form of writing, the colorful pottery and other artifacts found at the 3,000-year-old burial site suggested that the Philistines were artistic and cosmopolitan and that it was unfair to equate them with boorishness and barbarity.\n\n\u201cStager has been a formidable influence upon the history and archaeology of the Eastern Mediterranean and the Levant for more than 30 years,\u201d Jeff Hudon, a biblical historian, wrote in the journal Seminary Studies in 2010, \u201cboth through his own research and indirectly through his students.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLarry Elwood Stager (he adopted the first name Lawrence while studying at Harvard) was born on Jan. 5, 1943, in Kenton, Ohio, to Francis Stager, a farmer, and the former Marcella Mae Wilson.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGrowing up about 50 miles northwest of Columbus, he was recruited by the Harvard Club of Dayton to become the first member of his family to attend college.\n\nHe graduated in 1965 with a bachelor\u2019s degree in Near Eastern languages and civilizations from Harvard, where his thesis was on burial customs in the Iron Age, and where he also earned master\u2019s and doctoral degrees in Near Eastern languages and civilizations.\n\nAfter his wife, the former Susan Simmons, and his mentor, Professor G. Ernest Wright, submitted a job application on his behalf while he was off on an excavation, he was hired to teach in 1973 at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.\n\nHe returned to Harvard in 1986 as the inaugural Dorot professor of the archaeology of Israel. He retired in 2012 as professor emeritus.\n\nIn addition to his wife and his daughter, Dr. Stager is survived by a son, David, and four grandchildren.\n\nPhoto\n\nBefore joining the Levy expedition, which was conducted under license from the Israel Antiquities Authority, Dr. Stager directed digs in Carthage, Tunisia, and Idalion, Cyprus.\n\nHe dodged friendly fire at a military proving ground in the Buqe\u2019ah Valley to study ancient farms in the Judean desert.\n\nAnd he teamed up with the maritime archaeologist Robert D. Ballard in 1999 to explore Phoenician shipwrecks dating from 750 B.C., vessels that sank with hundreds of wine amphoras aboard that were being shipped to Egypt from Tyre in Lebanon. Their discovery was featured in a National Geographic Society documentary, \u201cLost Ships of the Mediterranean.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDr. Stager was also credited with coining the term \u201cport power\u201d to explain the impact of maritime trade as an urban magnet during the Bronze Age.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the early 1980s, the Rev. Philip J. King, president of the American Schools of Oriental Research, introduced Mr. Levy and Ms. White, two of his trustees, to Dr. Stager, whom Professor King considered a creative and undoctrinaire researcher \u2014 just the right person to pursue the Israeli historian Benjamin Mazar\u2019s goal of revealing the sequence of civilizations layered beneath a nondescript field in Ashkelon, which was the region\u2019s largest port.\n\nDr. Stager\u2019s field research focused on Canaanites, Phoenicians, Philistines and Israelites as he studied the origins of monotheism and amassed hard evidence of ancient life.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany of those findings were featured in \u201cLife in Biblical Israel\u201d (2001), which Dr. Stager wrote with Professor King.\n\n\u201cLarry had an awful lot of originality that colleagues never thought about, wasn\u2019t one to borrow from others, and shared the information he found,\u201d Professor King said in a phone interview.\n\nAt his death, Dr. Stager was editing the final volumes detailing technical findings of the Ashkelon expedition for the Shelby White-Leon Levy Program for Archaeological Publications at Harvard and the Harvard Semitic Museum.\n\nUnlike some of his colleagues, Dr. Stager never shied from the controversy that comes with challenging conventional wisdom or trying to reconcile archaeological finds with biblical legends.\n\nHe scoffed at the view that Jesus was born in Bethlehem, rather than Nazareth. He suggested that accounts of the destruction of Jericho by Israelites might have been a \u201cliterary embellishment\u201d of a pastoral migration punctuated by sporadic armed conflicts.\n\n\u201cAs he saw it,\u201d Professor Master said in an email, \u201cthe Bible and archaeology were intertwined \u2014 not as some sort of apologetic exercise, but as a critical frame of interpretation.\u201d", "title": "Lawrence Stager, Creative Biblical Archaeologist, Dies at 74", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The case is one of several filed last year by the president\u2019s critics accusing Mr. Trump of violating the Constitution\u2019s emoluments clauses, which prevent a president from accepting government-bestowed benefits either at home or abroad. No court has interpreted what the clauses mean, and no previous president has ever been sued for violating them.\n\nIn his decision last month, Judge Daniels said it was up to Congress, not the courts, to decide whether Mr. Trump had illegally accepted any valuable benefits, such as trademark approvals, from foreign governments. And if Mr. Trump\u2019s businesses had profited because consumers are more interested in patronizing Trump-owned hotels or golf courses in the United States since his election, Judge Daniels said, the president was not to blame.\n\nBut Judge Messitte seemed more sympathetic to claims by attorneys general for the District of Columbia and Maryland that the president had created an unfair playing field for convention centers and other facilities that compete against Trump-owned properties. \u201cThe argument is that as president he is unduly attracting business,\u201d the judge said. \u201cThere is some evidence of that.\u201d\n\nAsked how the hearing went, Brian E. Frosh, Maryland\u2019s attorney general, said, \u201cGreat.\u201d\n\nHe said the Justice Department was trying to say that even though the emoluments clauses were meant to protect Americans from a president who uses the position to enrich himself, no one could sue the president for violating it. \u201cI don\u2019t think that\u2019s a winning position,\u201d Mr. Frosh said.\n\nThe complaint, filed at the federal court in Greenbelt, says in part that the Trump International Hotel in Washington diverts customers from businesses that the District of Columbia or Maryland license, tax or own, depriving them of revenue. Lawyers for the plaintiffs urged Judge Messitte to allow the case to proceed to discovery and allow them to obtain financial records of Mr. Trump\u2019s Washington hotel.", "title": "Lawsuit on Trump Emoluments Violations Gains Traction in Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Talking to reporters after the game, Dwyane Wade, who won two N.B.A. championships with James in Miami before joining him in Cleveland, said he was happy he could be on the court for his friend\u2019s achievement.\n\n\u201cHe can start moving to 35 now,\u201d Wade joked. \u201cI\u2019m sure he\u2019ll be there in no time.\u201d\n\nJames joined Abdul-Jabbar, Karl Malone, Kobe Bryant, Michael Jordan, Wilt Chamberlain and Dirk Nowitzki as the only N.B.A. players to reach 30,000. And at 33 years and 24 days old, he shattered Bryant\u2019s record for getting to the milestone fastest, as Bryant was 34 years and 104 days old when he hit the mark in 2012. Even accounting for James\u2019s status as a prep-to-pro player, allowing him to join the league at an age three to four years younger than that of all the players on the list besides Bryant, James did it in the fourth-fewest games, trailing only Abdul-Jabbar, Jordan and Chamberlain.\n\nSpeculation has been rampant over whether James is capable of finishing as the top-scoring player in N.B.A. history \u2014 Abdul-Jabbar, with 38,387 points, has been the career scoring leader since he passed Chamberlain on April 5, 1984 \u2014 but James has made a point of telling anyone who will listen that he still does not view himself as a scorer, regardless of his career average of 27.1 points a game.\n\n\u201cWhen you categorize who I am as a basketball player, it won\u2019t say \u2018scorer,\u2019\u201d he told reporters after scoring 16 points in a win over the Orlando Magic last week. \u201cThere\u2019s too much more attributes to my game, and then you can talk about scoring as well.\u201d\n\nJames, as he often is, was being too modest. He has 5,846 more points than Abdul-Jabbar had at the same age and he has not averaged fewer than 25.3 points a game in a season since his rookie year.", "title": "LeBron James Celebrates 30,000th Point and Then He Scores It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe\u2019s had all the bad luck he needs for a while,\u201d Mr. Jolley said before the Derby. \u201cLet somebody else take the worst of it this time.\u201d\n\nFoolish Pleasure\u2019s jockey, Jacinto Vasquez, rode the colt conservatively until he orchestrated a furious stretch run near the end that overtook Avatar and Diabolo to win by 1\u00be lengths. After finishing second in the Preakness and Belmont Stakes, Foolish Pleasure faced Ruffian, an unbeaten filly, in a much-ballyhooed match race on July 6, 1975, at Belmont Park.\n\nHolding the lead after nearly half a mile, Ruffian suddenly shattered both sesamoid bones in her right foreleg and had to be euthanized. Recognizing that horse racing can be a rough, heartbreaking business, Mr. Jolley offered an unsentimental view of Ruffian\u2019s death. After the race, he said, \u201cThis game wasn\u2019t cut out for anybody wearing short pants.\u201d\n\nNearly five years later, another filly, Genuine Risk, brought more glory to Mr. Jolley. But he nearly stood in her way. After her third-place finish in the 1980 Wood Memorial, he vowed that he would not send her to Churchill Downs for the Derby. \u201cI found out what I wanted to learn yesterday,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s no sense shipping her a thousand miles to find it out again.\u201d\n\nBut after discussions with her owners, Bertram and Diana Firestone, he reversed his decision: Genuine Risk traveled to Louisville, Ky., where she became the first filly to win the Kentucky Derby since Regret in 1915. And, like Foolish Pleasure, Genuine Risk finished second at the Preakness and Belmont.\n\n\u201cShe wanted to win, and she would run so hard after some of her races, she just practically would lay down for three or four days,\u201d Mr. Jolley told The Associated Press in 2008 after Genuine Risk died at age 31.\n\nLeroy Stanton Jolley was born on Jan. 14, 1938, in Hot Springs, a hotbed for horse racing known as the Saratoga of the South. He would follow his father on the racing circuit, where, in Florida, his barn was next to Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who trained two Triple Crown winners, Gallant Fox in 1930 and Omaha in 1935.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t imagine better tutors than my father and Sunny Jim,\u201d he told The New York Times in 1981.\n\nMr. Jolley left the University of Miami after one year, preferring to be schooled in barns and paddocks.\n\nHe had his first winner in 1958 with Somnus, which his father bred and his mother owned. and, after taking Ridan to the Kentucky Derby and the Travers Stakes (which he lost by a nose to Jaipur), Mr. Jolley took a low-profile detour for nearly a decade, training horses in New York, Illinois and Florida to modest acclaim. He gained greater renown for Foolish Pleasure\u2019s victory at the 1975 Derby, and for his anger about track conditions at Pimlico Race Course after Honest Pleasure (who shared a sire with Foolish Pleasure) finished second at the Preakness Stakes in 1976.\n\nThat year, Mr. Jolley starred in a commercial for Miller Lite beer with Foolish Pleasure and Honest Pleasure. The campaign \u2014 which used sports celebrities to market a beer that \u201ctastes great\u201d and was also \u201cless filling\u201d \u2014 put Mr. Jolley in a barn at Belmont Park with his two horses.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a man who\u2019s known for his pleasures,\u201d Mr. Jolley said. \u201cThese two I train. And this one I drink. But what I love best is the way it tastes. What a pleasure.! Right, guys?\u201d\n\nAfter their whinnied assent, Mr. Jolley added, \u201cAm I a trainer or am I a trainer?\u201d\n\nIn addition to his son Leroy Jr., Mr. Jolley is survived by another son, Tim; a daughter, Laura Jolley; two grandchildren; and a sister, Rosalyn McCullars. His marriage to the former Myrna Griffiths ended in divorce. He lived in Saratoga, N.Y., and Ocala, Fla.\n\nOver his career, Mr. Jolley saddled 991 winners and won purses of more than $35 million. He was inducted into the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where three of his horses (Genuine Risk, Foolish Pleasure and Manila) are also enshrined. He retired for a while but returned in recent years to train horses again.\n\nThey were not the high-quality horses he had trained in the past. \u201cThe people that owned them were trying to find out if they were good enough to compete in New York, and most of them weren\u2019t very good,\u201d LeRoy Jolley Jr. said.\n\nBut it was a world that the elder Mr. Jolley missed.\n\n\u201cI got bored,\u201d he told The Paulick Report, a horse-racing news website, in 2016. \u201cI don\u2019t play golf anymore and I don\u2019t fish, so I went back to doing what I know.\u201d", "title": "LeRoy Jolley, Who Trained Two Derby Winners, Dies at 79", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "It took a few weeks for me to recognize the potential for a story that traced his re-emergence into ordinary life. For fear of seeming intrusive, I asked Ms. Speights O\u2019Neill if she would mind arranging for us to meet in a setting that was not as intimate as a physical therapist\u2019s table. Mr. Mika was surprisingly receptive to talking about his suffering.\n\nWhat followed was a remarkable few days, and months, of recovery and restoration that I chronicled in a recent article. I aimed to provide a glimpse at what it looks like to survive a mass shooting \u2014 and what it takes in the months after to reckon with the fact that although you\u2019re still alive, the only life you knew was taken from you.\n\nWhat is often neglected in stories about shooting victims is the period of time months afterward, when loneliness and isolation set in more dramatically, and when friends and acquaintances often wrongly assume that the patient has returned to a kind of normalcy. There are no more surgeries, fewer doctors\u2019 checkups and hours of physical therapy, and not as many well-wishers worried about your condition. It is this period, as Mr. Mika helped me understand, when the ravages of gun violence can be most unnerving.\n\nThe resources that go into saving the life of someone shot by an assault rifle are staggering. I spent a December afternoon in a high-tech ambulance with the paramedic who saved Mr. Mika\u2019s life, Chad Shade, as he showed me the needles and fabrics and liquids he used just to give Mr. Mika a small chance of living. In essence, Mr. Shade was showing me how to perform trauma surgery in a moving car. Many of the tools he uses are common to war medics.\n\nI spent time with Mr. Mika\u2019s trauma surgeon at the hospital, Libby Schroeder, who is still haunted by what she saw that day. The night of the shooting, she went on a run to try to process what she had seen and done, and she found herself late at night at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial on the National Mall, unsure how she ended up there.", "title": "Learning from a Shooting Victim: What Comes After Trauma?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "In a series of studies published in 2012, two psychologists, Ara Norenzayan and Will Gervais, set out to test a simple question: When people think about God, do they feel or act as if they are being monitored? Subjects of varying religiosity were primed to think about God, then asked to complete self-evaluations based on statements like \u201cI am sometimes irritated by people who ask favors of me\u201d and \u201cNo matter whom I\u2019m talking to, I\u2019m always a good listener.\u201d Results, researchers said, were consistent with what they call the \u201csupernatural-monitoring hypothesis\u201d \u2014 that is, that \u201cthinking of God triggers the same social cognitive processes that are activated by real-time social surveillance.\u201d A sense that you\u2019re being seen \u2014 whether by a fellow human or by a supreme consciousness from which no thought can be withheld \u2014 does seem to change how you see yourself as well as how you behave.\n\nSince 2012, online platforms have moved to the center of hundreds of millions more lives, popularizing their particular brands of social surveillance. Services like Facebook and Twitter and Instagram are inextricably tied to the experience of being monitored by others, which, if it doesn\u2019t always produce \u201cprosocial\u201d behavior in the broad psychological sense, seems to have encouraged behaviors useful to the platforms themselves \u2014 activity and growth. These businesses serve many different purposes, but the one thing they have in common is that they have figured out new ways to monetize the powerful twin sensations of seeing and being seen by others.\n\nBut alongside this exhilarating, debilitating, empowering and terrifying human spectacle, these sites have also fostered \u2014 inadvertently \u2014 a new but not entirely unfamiliar feeling, that of being watched from above. There is little about the ruthless, marketlike social-media experience that primes you to think about any sort of god. But there are, I\u2019ve noticed, persistent and ever-more-obvious experiences that remind you of another kind of higher power: the automated systems on which these platforms run.", "title": "Learning to Fool Our Algorithmic Spies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Nehru, unlike Mr. Modi \u2014 who is decidedly not a reader and who has an almost childish regard for the Indian past \u2014 can look hard at himself and his country. \u201cA country under foreign domination seeks escape from the present in dreams of a vanished age, and finds consolation in visions of past greatness,\u201d he writes in \u201cThe Discovery of India.\u201d\n\nNehru is never more prescient, seeming truly to speak across the decades, than when he addresses the nationalism that will one day endanger his vision of India. \u201cNationalism,\u201d he writes in \u201cToward Freedom,\u201d \u201cis essentially an anti-feeling, and it feeds and fattens on hatred against other national groups, and especially against the foreign rulers of a subject country.\u201d\n\nI was stunned, reading these lines at a moment when Mr. Modi\u2019s Hindu Renaissance has proved to be precisely the \u201canti-feeling\u201d Nehru described: a culture war against two enemies, Westernized Indians and the country\u2019s approximately 170 million Muslims.\n\nIf Mr. Modi stands for authenticity, Nehru forces us to question the premium we place on it. He forces us to ask ourselves if purity is even desirable, and whether India\u2019s true genius does not lie in its ability to throw up dazzling hybrids, like Nehru, who seem, in intellect and sophistication, vision and worldliness, to be every bit Mr. Modi\u2019s superior.\n\nMr. Modi has certainly ushered in an age when the \u201cIndian soul\u201d \u2014 like the German and Russian soul before it \u2014 is finding utterance. But what is it saying? Last month, in Rajasthan, a state whose government is run by the B.J.P., we were given yet another sampling of what Mr. Modi\u2019s brand of authenticity looks like: a Hindu man axed to death a Muslim man, then set the body alight, while asking his nephew to film the murder.\n\nThe killer posted the video on Facebook. He wanted to send a message that the \u201cLove Jihad\u201d \u2014 a baseless B.J.P.-promulgated conspiracy theory in which Muslim men lure unsuspecting Hindu women into marriage and conversion \u2014 would not be tolerated. The response of the B.J.P. leadership was, as it usually is after such killings, strategic silence.\n\nRajasthan, in recent months, has become a byword for this kind of religious murder. It also happens to be one of those states where last year Nehru was erased from school textbooks. Otherwise the eighth graders there might have grown up with these words of his, which the historian Ram Guha quoted last month in an essay for The Hindustan Times: \u201cIf any person raises his hand to strike down another on the ground of religion,\u201d Nehru said on Gandhi\u2019s birthday in 1952, \u201cI shall fight him till the last breath of my life, both at the head of government and from outside.\u201d\n\nTime may have trifled with Nehru. But time will also reveal him to be the giant that he was.", "title": "Opinion | Learning to Love Nehru", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI got on the M4 on Madison Avenue after work. All of the seats at the front of the bus were occupied, except for one that had a black leather jacket on it.\n\nThe man in the seat in front of that one was busily pulling sweaters from a plastic bag and trying them on. I asked him if the leather jacket was his. He said it was a nice jacket and belonged to whoever wanted it.\n\nI decided to move a few rows back. I watched everyone who got on after me ask the same question about the leather jacket.\n\nThe bus became crowded. A woman was explaining to everyone around her that the man would not claim the jacket, that it had come out of a plastic bag of what were probably thrift shop clothes and that it was in good condition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe suggested that if someone wanted a seat they could move the leather jacket onto the floor. No one did.\n\nEventually, someone hung the leather jacket on the rail near the door. The passengers near the door decided that was a dangerous place for it, and a second woman brought it the bus driver. He said he wanted no part of it.", "title": "Leather Jacket on the Bus", "authors": ["Adele Burstein", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "December was a big month for advocates of regulating artificial intelligence. First, a bipartisan group of senators and representatives introduced the Future of A.I. Act, the first federal bill solely focused on A.I. It would create an advisory committee to make recommendations about A.I. \u2014 on topics including the technology\u2019s effect on the American work force and strategies to protect the privacy rights of those it impacts. Then the New York City Council approved a first-of-its-kind bill that once signed into law will create a task force to examine its own use of automated decision systems, with the ultimate goal of making its use of algorithms fairer and more transparent.\n\nPerhaps not coincidentally, these efforts also overlap with increasing calls to regulate artificial intelligence along with claims by the likes of Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking that it poses a threat to humanity\u2019s literal survival.\n\nBut this push for broad legislation to regulate A.I. is premature.\n\nTo begin with, even experts can\u2019t agree on what, exactly, constitutes artificial intelligence. Take the recent report released by the AI Now Institute, aimed at creating a framework for ethically implementing A.I. While itself focused on A.I., the report also acknowledges that no commonly accepted definition of A.I. exists, which it describes loosely as \u201ca broad assemblage of technologies \u2026 that have traditionally relied on human capacities.\u201d\n\n\u201cArtificial intelligence\u201d is all too frequently used as a shorthand for software that simply does what humans used to do. But replacing human activity is precisely what new technologies accomplish \u2014 spears replaced clubs, wheels replaced feet, the printing press replaced scribes, and so on. What\u2019s new about A.I. is that this technology isn\u2019t simply replacing human activities, external to our bodies; it\u2019s also replacing human decision-making, inside our minds.", "title": "Opinion | Leave A.I. Alone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSo I start a new life,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd it was not easy.\u201d\n\nElizabeth is an industrial city just across from Staten Island that has long been a critical portal for immigrants escaping persecution and searching for opportunity.\n\nListen to This Story Matt Katz and WNYC produced an audio version of Mr. Twendele\u2019s story. You can hear it here.\n\nGermans and Irish came in the 19th century; European Jews and then Cubans followed in the 20th. Since 2015, Elizabeth has settled 646 refugees \u2014 about half from Syria, and 95 from Congo. The city accepts more refugees than anywhere else in New Jersey.\n\nChris Bollwage, the seven-term mayor, traces his own history back 202 years to German immigrants. \u201cThe city of Elizabeth has been a melting pot, but it hasn\u2019t been a melting pot for the last 25 years \u2014 it\u2019s been a melting pot since the Constitution,\u201d Mr. Bollwage said. Its residents are said to come from about 50 countries and speak 37 languages.\n\nMr. Twendele\u2019s journey \u2014 11 years in a refugee camp, then one lucky application for a visa to the United States \u2014 roughly traces the experiences of the three million other refugees admitted into the country since 1975. But that path is now narrowing as President Trump enacts the most severe curtailment of America\u2019s refugee program in a generation.\n\nLast September Mr. Trump set the annual cap for refugee admissions at 45,000, less than half of the amount that President Obama accepted and the lowest by any president since the Refugee Act of 1980.\n\nMr. Twendele was fortunate to get to the U.S. before new refugee restrictions went into place. But he now lives with a greater burden: Lisette Lukoji, a woman he met and married in the refugee camp, is still stuck in southeastern Africa.\n\nAs a teenager, Lisette Lukoji had a daughter, Lorette, with a boyfriend who went to war and never returned. She enrolled in school to become a seamstress, raising Lorette and living at her uncle\u2019s house in Lubumbashi. That\u2019s where they came for her. She was 19.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Lukoji told me her story as we sat side by side on another bench \u2014 this one in the main room of her home at the Dzaleka Refugee Camp in Malawi, a landlocked sliver of a country that borders Tanzania, Mozambique and Zambia. The walls were made of mud, sticks and plastic served as a roof, and an old sweatshirt was used as the doormat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was around 6 or 7 p.m.,\u201d Ms. Lukoji remembered of the day she was arrested. \u201cI was preparing food in the kitchen. I saw people enter that weren\u2019t wearing uniforms.\u201d\n\nWhether they were militia or military or police, she doesn\u2019t know. She recalls her uncle was aligned with Paul Joseph Mukungubila, a professed Christian prophet and politician who had run against President Kabila in 2006. As part of an operation to round up Mr. Mukungubila\u2019s supporters, Ms. Lukoji said, her entire family was detained and imprisoned in separate cells. Lorette was stripped away from her.\n\n\u201cTo this day, I don\u2019t know where she is,\u201d Ms. Lukoji said. If alive, she\u2019s 6 years old.\n\nOne night in jail three soldiers came to Ms. Lukoji\u2019s cell. She said they raped her, all three of them. Then they handed her 5,000 Congolese francs, about $3.50, and told her to leave.\n\n\u201cI walked, I don\u2019t know how to explain for how long, but I walked for a long time,\u201d Ms. Lukoji said. She had neither shoes nor identification. She ended up in a dusty town bordering Zambia. For days, she lived on the streets, using the little money she had to buy beignets, mixing the leftover sugar with water for sustenance.\n\nA Tanzanian truck driver stopped to help her. He smuggled her into Zambia, where she got on a bus to Malawi, which has hosted refugees for decades despite being one of the poorest nations on the continent. Ms. Lukoji walked into Dzaleka barefoot. It took her two weeks to get a pair of shoes, she said. She had to find someone to take her in, or build her own earthen house. She had to collect her own food.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI realized that life would be very complicated there,\u201d she said. \u201cVery complicated, really.\u201d\n\nDzaleka Refugee Camp was built as a prison camp for about 10,000 people. But for more than 20 years it has been home to the displaced from Congo, Rwanda, Burundi and elsewhere, with a population that now exceeds 32,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said that it receives less than a third of the $18 million it needs to care for Malawi\u2019s refugees. Charcoal is hard to come by, so children ask strangers for empty water bottles, which can then be burned and used to cook food. Refugees build their own homes, which lack indoor plumbing, and the camp\u2019s one medical clinic mostly serves the neighboring villagers.\n\nYet there\u2019s life in Dzaleka. People gossip, argue and dance. There are churches, schools and hair salons. Refugees may be forbidden by the Malawian government from working, but an underground economy is driven by barter and cash sent from relatives abroad. Ms. Lukoji sells clothes that she makes, and Mr. Twendele tutored refugees in his native French and, later, English. He became fluent while living in the camp because he won admission to a competitive college equivalency program there. Six days a week for three years he took online classes through Regis University in Colorado, earning a near 4.0 G.P.A. and a degree in liberal studies.\n\nSome months after he graduated, Mr. Twendele fell in love. He remembers the day well: He was playing Scrabble, in French, at a friend\u2019s house when he first caught a glimpse of Ms. Lukoji.\n\n\u201cThat girl!\u201d Mr. Twendele thought. \u201cI want to talk to her. I don\u2019t know where to start, how can I talk to her?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThey were both devout Christians from the Luba ethnic group. At first, Ms. Lukoji refused to give Mr. Twendele her phone number. \u201cI didn\u2019t even know him!\u201d she said.\n\nSome refugees get cellphones through charities, relatives in the West or the underground market. When Mr. Twendele finally got her number and called, she hung up on him. Not interested.\n\nBut Mr. Twendele, handsome with a shaved head, was determined.\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018Even if you refuse, I am the one marrying you, there is no one besides me,\u2019\u201d Ms. Lukoji said. \u201cThat even if I hung up I would be the one he marries and the father of my children.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Lukoji, short with a bright smile, was astounded at his persistence. Eventually she warmed to him and they began dating. They\u2019d go for walks together, maybe buying sweet drinks and stopping to watch soccer games on the big dirt field near the camp\u2019s entrance.\n\nAnd in May 2015, they married, right there in the camp. Their church helped pay for his suit. She borrowed a dress. There was a big spread of food: beans, rice, sweet potatoes, chicken, fish, salad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was like a dream,\u201d Mr. Twendele said. \u201cShe was very happy that day.\u201d\n\nFrom the beginning, they both knew they would have to leave the camp, so Mr. Twendele applied to the U.N.H.C.R. to resettle in a new country.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Dec. 19, 2012 \u2014 he remembers the date \u2014 Mr. Twendele had his first interview with a refugee agency representative at the camp. More interviews followed, including two with officials from the Department of Homeland Security. In each, Mr. Twendele told his story of escape and provided biographical information. Refugee officers ran his name against terrorist watch lists. They took his photograph and his fingerprints.\n\nFinally, on Oct. 22, 2016, nearly four years after the first interview, Mr. Twendele received the news he had waited so long to hear: He was headed to the United States.\n\nBut it was in the middle of this process that he had met Ms. Lukoji, and he opted not to change his application midstream to take his marriage into account. He assumed, correctly, that it would delay the process. He also assumed, incorrectly, that she could join him in six months or so.\n\n\u201cI was crying like a baby,\u201d said Mr. Twendele. \u201cShe told me: \u2018Just go. I know that you are my husband, and you love me, and will do your best to help me so I can join you there in the U.S.A.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe next day, Mr. Twendele landed at Kennedy International Airport, thrilled by the flight across the ocean. \u201cYou stay in one place \u2014 you are not moving, but the airplane is going,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t understand that technology.\u201d\n\nThe International Rescue Committee arranged to have Mr. Twendele picked up and taken to an apartment complex in Elizabeth filled with refugees from Africa, the Middle East and South America. He would be sharing a room with two Congolese men in a brick building on the same street where Jared Kushner\u2019s grandparents moved after fleeing the Holocaust.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the day Mr. Twendele moved in, Mr. Trump was campaigning in North Carolina, attacking Hillary Clinton and her stance on immigration. \u201cShe wants, in her words, to have totally open borders, which would destroy America\u2019s middle class,\u201d Trump said. He called refugees \u201cTrojan horses.\u201d Thirteen days later, he was elected president.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe job of resettling new Americans falls on designated nonprofit agencies like the International Rescue Committee, which the State Department pays $2,125 per refugee to cover resettlement expenses, like a security deposit for an apartment and a few days of food in the refrigerator, as well as administrative costs.\n\nThe I.R.C. also holds classes to familiarize refugees with the complexities of New Jersey Transit and the welfare system. And it connects refugees with employers, which is exactly how Mr. Twendele got an overnight job at Elizabeth\u2019s True World Foods, a sprawling, bone-cold seafood distributor that abuts the New Jersey Turnpike at Exit 13A. He earns $11 an hour alongside immigrants from the Philippines, Liberia, Nigeria and Congo, cutting and packaging fish from all over the world that becomes sushi at high-end restaurants like Nobu in Manhattan. Bundled up in ski pants and three jackets, Mr. Twendele handles fish that he won\u2019t eat \u2014 though he loves seafood, he has yet to try sushi.\n\nBy about 4 a.m., in the middle of his shift, Mr. Twendele was in the break room. He was on his phone, trying to reach his wife on WhatsApp, which allows free international calls. He used his first True World Food paychecks to buy his wife a new phone. They speak multiple times a day, and for hours at a time on the weekends.\n\n\u201cWhen I speak to him, I feel like he is here, even though he is not here,\u201d Ms. Lukoji said from the bench in the refugee camp. She had just spoken with Mr. Twendele and was still smiling. \u201cHe loves me, and he tells me this on the phone. Like today he said, \u2018I love you, I adore you, you are the mother of my children.\u2019\u201d\n\nNearly 50,000 Congolese refugees have resettled in the United States since 2010. More than 2,500 moved to New York, most ending up in Buffalo and Syracuse. Almost all Congolese refugees in New Jersey are in Elizabeth, the second largest refugee group behind Syrians, and through word of mouth an unofficial Congolese community group has sprung up.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast July 1, I joined Mr. Twendele at the group\u2019s Congolese Independence Day party in a Korean church above a Dollar Store in downtown Elizabeth. Mr. Twendele marked his country\u2019s 1960 victory over the Belgian colonial rulers by eating traditional African fufu with new friends who spoke his language. They prayed, danced and drank (Sprite for Mr. Twendele; Heineken for his roommates).\n\nAt the party, Mr. Twendele opened his cellphone. His wife had sent a photo. Over the image, using the English version of his first name, Ms. Lukoji wrote: \u201cI love my husband Andrew forever.\u201d\n\nElizabeth, with its Colombian bakeries and kosher restaurants, is a model for those who believe that the United States should be a haven during what is now considered the worst refugee crisis since World War II \u2014 there are more than 22 million people designated as refugees worldwide, with a notable spike in the last five years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Elizabeth is also home to a privately run immigrant detention center, filled with people accused of overstaying their visas or smuggling themselves over the Mexican border. Elizabeth may be their last stop before deportation.\n\nAnd near the city\u2019s train station sits a garbage can that serves as a reminder of the risk of terrorist attacks by disaffected immigrants. In September 2016, a month before Mr. Twendele arrived, prosecutors say an Afghanistan-born man named Ahmad Khan Rahami stashed six pipe bombs in a garbage can. Mr. Rahami was a naturalized American citizen who lived above his father\u2019s First American Fried Chicken restaurant in Elizabeth. The Elizabeth bombs were found before they went off, but Mr. Rahami is now awaiting sentencing for the other explosives he planted that weekend that actually blew up \u2014 in Manhattan\u2019s Chelsea neighborhood, injuring 31.\n\nMr. Trump, who was the Republican nominee for president then, blamed the attacks on the United States\u2019 \u201cextremely open immigration system, which fails to properly vet and screen the individuals and families coming into our country.\u201d And yet since the current vetting system was put into place in 1980, no refugee has committed a deadly terrorist attack on American soil.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s changes to the refugee program have directly affected Ms. Lukoji. His administration suspended the visa program for so-called following-to-join refugees, which was her fastest path to reuniting with her husband. A federal judge has since lifted the suspension, but more stringent security requirements for the visa are expected, which could further delay her application.\n\nMs. Lukoji does have another option. Mr. Twendele has filed an \u201caffidavit of relationship\u201d to certify their marriage and initiate the vetting process, but his application has yet to be reviewed, according to advocates working on the case.\n\nMs. Lukoji longs to leave not just to reunite with her husband; her health depends on it, too. She has blocked fallopian tubes, a painful condition that has left her infertile, according to a gynecologist whom she sees in Lilongwe, Malawi\u2019s capital. Their hopes for children \u2014 Mr. Twendele wants as many as eight \u2014 now rests in the United States, with in vitro fertilization.\n\nHe is 35. She is 26. He calls this \u201cthe beginning of life.\u201d\n\nOne day in his apartment, Mr. Twendele expressed confidence, as he often does, in the future.\n\n\u201cI know that one day I will be with myself, my wife, my family \u2014 comfortable,\u201d he said.\n\nNot long after, his phone buzzed. The name popped up: Mon cheri, my sweetheart.", "title": "Leaving Africa, and Living in Limbo", "authors": ["Matt Katz"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The attackers were targeting journalists and activists, as well as government officials, military personnel, financial institutions, defense contractors and others in 21 countries. Those countries included the United States, China, Germany, India, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Korea and inside Lebanon.\n\nThe researchers traced the attacks to a building in Beirut that houses Lebanon\u2019s GDGS, using Wi-Fi networks and so-called internet protocol addresses assigned to attackers\u2019 machines. While researchers said they could not be sure whether the attacks were the work of the GDGS or rogue employees, many of the attacks appeared tied to an email address \u2014 op13@mail.com \u2014 that had been linked to various online personas, including \u201cNancy Razzouk\u201d and \u201cRami Jabbour.\u201d All of the physical addresses listed with registrations made by that email account were clustered around the GDGS building in Beirut, according to the user\u2019s wireless activity.\n\nEmails sent to that email address were not returned.\n\nAs part of their work, researchers found evidence that Lebanese spies were directing victims to install the spy apps through WhatsApp messages that began innocuously with a \u201cHow are you?\u201d Those then linked to the spy apps with additional messages like \u201cYou can download from here to communicate further.\u201d\n\nIn other cases, the spies found their targets on Facebook, inviting them to Facebook groups, where they posted links to their decoy apps, which they often referred to by names like \u201cWhatsApp plus.\u201d The spies also directed victims to fake login sites for social media services like Twitter and Facebook to steal their credentials, hijack their accounts and push out trick messages to more people.\n\nResearchers also found evidence that Lebanese officials had previously used FinFisher, a product manufactured by the British company Gamma International, which sells surveillance tools that let customers turn computers and phones into listening devices to monitor a target\u2019s messages, calls and whereabouts. Increasingly, researchers discovered that the spies had built their own custom mobile spy tools that were less sophisticated than FinFisher but as effective in getting the intelligence they were after.\n\nMartin J. Muench, the managing director of Gamma International, has told The New York Times that his company only sells surveillance tools to governments for criminal and terrorism investigations. The Times has covered several instances in which Mr. Muench\u2019s tools have popped up on devices used by journalists and activists. Gamma Group did not respond to a request for comment on Thursday.\n\nResearchers also uncovered evidence that Lebanese officials deployed several variants of malware to victims\u2019 desktop machines; the malware was designed to work across several operating systems, including Microsoft Windows, Apple\u2019s Mac and Linux. That malware could steal screenshots of victims\u2019 computer screens, use the victim\u2019s webcam to spy on their physical whereabouts, record sound, grab photos and any Skype activity, file listings and files, and even iPhone backups.\n\nIn the hours after researchers published their report on Thursday, the servers conducting the spying went dark.", "title": "Lebanese Intelligence Turned Targets\u2019 Android Phones Into Spy Devices, Researchers Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "His associates said he was planning a political nonprofit group called Citizens of the American Republic that would spend between $25 million and $30 million \u2014 though some advisers predicted a budget as large as $100 million \u2014 to seed the primary campaigns. Half the budget was slated to be spent on voter mobilization efforts on the ground in targeted districts for months leading up to elections, with the other half going toward advertising, according to people familiar with the plan. While Mr. Bannon publicly bashed the Republican donor class, he spent months quietly courting some of the deepest pockets on the right.\n\nMr. Bannon discussed his plans in grandiose, but vague, terms in a series of meetings with donors, including the Las Vegas casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson; a Chicago Cubs owner, Todd Ricketts; and a Home Depot founder, Bernard Marcus.\n\nWhile Mr. Bannon boasted that he was turning donors against Mr. McConnell, some of the donors who talked to Mr. Bannon say he appeared to lack the organization to effectively raise and spend their money. For instance, they said Mr. Bannon did not have staff follow up to collect donations after meetings \u2014 a common step in political fund-raising. Other donors, they said, resented that word of their conversations with Mr. Bannon seemed to leak to the news media in what they regarded as a presumptuous effort to use them to exaggerate his support.\n\nAfter reports of Mr. Bannon\u2019s meetings with Mr. Adelson, a representative for the Las Vegas billionaire, Andy Abboud, issued a rare statement pledging loyalty to Mr. McConnell and declaring, \u201cThe Adelsons will not be supporting Steve Bannon\u2019s efforts.\u201d Mr. Abboud added, \u201cFor anyone to infer anything otherwise is wrong.\u201d\n\nThe loss of the Mercer family\u2019s support will be particularly hard for Mr. Bannon to overcome. The Mercers began drifting from Mr. Bannon months ago amid concerns about how the controversy he was generating was affecting the family, according to family associates. The Mercers were upset further when they learned that Mr. Bannon had privately boasted that they would back him if he ran for president, according to one family associate.\n\nThe family has pumped tens of millions of dollars into businesses and groups that formed the platform from which Mr. Bannon has waged his populist antiestablishment crusade. Besides their share of Breitbart, they are invested in the political data firm Cambridge Analytica, where Mr. Bannon sat on the board, and the investigative nonprofit group Government Accountability Institute, which Mr. Bannon co-founded.", "title": "Led by the Mercers, Bannon\u2019s Allies Abandon Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Both men have campaigned in outbursts of anger and indignation, setting a tone for the contest that is largely in line with the national mood.\n\n\u201cYou have a sentiment in the country in which people want to throw things overboard,\u201d said Monica de Bolle, a Brazil expert at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.\n\nShe compared the high stakes of this year\u2019s campaign to the 1989 election, Brazil\u2019s first direct vote for president after more than two decades of military dictatorship. But in 1989, Ms. de Bolle added, there was a sense of renewal. \u201cNow, people want to destroy,\u201d she said.\n\nBrazilians have had plenty of reason to sour on their political system in recent years.\n\nIn 2014, a routine money laundering probe that became known as Lava Jato, or Car Wash, exposed vast kickback schemes that tarred nearly all the large political parties and crippled pillars of the economy, including the state-owned oil company Petrobras, the construction giant Odebrecht and JBS, the world\u2019s largest meatpacker.\n\nAs magnates began going to prison, a fate that several veteran politicians implicated in the scandal feared, a coalition of lawmakers in December 2015 set in motion a plan to impeach Ms. Rousseff for tapping into central bank funds to conceal budget shortfalls. Ms. Rousseff decried her removal from office in August 2016 as a \u201ccoup,\u201d masterminded by center-right politicians who had failed to attain power through the ballot box.\n\nThe political whiplash of the past few years has made Brazilians more discontented with democracy than any other Latin American population, according to a 2017 poll conducted by Latinobar\u00f3metro. The survey found that only 13 percent of Brazilians were satisfied with democracy, and that 97 percent felt their government catered to a small, powerful elite.\n\n\u201cBrazilian society is in a critical state,\u201d said Marta Lagos, the head of Latinobar\u00f3metro. \u201cPeople feel abandoned by institutions.\u201d", "title": "Leftist Lion and Far-Right Provocateur Vie for Brazil Presidency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLegal Path for \u2018Dreamers\u2019? These People Say No\u201d (front page, Jan. 26):\n\nAs even some opponents of granting protections for Dreamers acknowledge, the situation facing undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children is complex and wrenching. I know about this predicament firsthand, because I am one of the millions formerly without legal status who were granted a path to citizenship under the law signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1986.\n\nToday, I proudly represent New York City and its values of inclusion, fairness and openness to the world, the latest step in a career devoted to the public. I am joined by countless others who have dedicated their lives, in most cases quietly, to giving back to this country that has given us so much.\n\nPrecisely because of the difficulties involved in parsing the merits of individual circumstances, there is only one just and compassionate way to resolve the question of the Dreamers. That is to provide legal status to those who arrived here without a choice in the matter, and now want nothing more than the opportunity to pursue their own American dream and contribute to this great country.\n\nPENNY ABEYWARDENA, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is commissioner of the New York City Mayor\u2019s Office for International Affairs.", "title": "Opinion | Legal Status for \u2018Dreamers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The Upper East Side apartment of Lella and Massimo Vignelli, the influential design team whose understated work endures in their adoptive home of New York, will list for $6.5 million.\n\nThe roughly 3,900-square-foot duplex co-op, on the sixth and seventh floors of a 1907 Italian Renaissance-style mid-rise, has three bedrooms, three and a half bathrooms and a nearly 20-foot-tall living room with a towering leaded glass window. The maintenance fee is $6,787 a month.\n\nPhoto\n\nBought in 1978 for around $250,000, it was the Italian-born couple\u2019s first and primary home in New York, said their son, Luca Vignelli, 55, a photographer who lived there during high school and college. The couple, who were prolific in a range of disciplines, including architecture and graphic and industrial design, had moved to New York in 1965 to pursue those interests.\n\nMr. Vignelli, who died in 2014 at the age of 83, was a founder of the design firm Unimark International, one of the first to emphasize corporate identity. He is credited with iconic branding for companies like Bloomingdale\u2019s (the big brown bag and logo), Ford and American Airlines. But perhaps his best known mark on New York is the 1972 \u201cdiagram\u201d of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority subway system, which earned praise from aesthetes and bemusement from some straphangers. (Central Park was rendered gray, not green, and the style was angular and clean, like an engineer\u2019s schematic.) It was replaced with a more conventional design in 1979, but the M.T.A. still uses a version of the map on its Weekender app.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe couple frequently collaborated, and together founded Vignelli Associates, which focused on graphics, interior design and corporate identity. They also designed the interior of St. Peter\u2019s Lutheran Church in Manhattan and created signature designs for modernist brands like Poltrona Frau.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut it was Mrs. Vignelli, a licensed architect who died in 2016 at the age of 82, who specialized in three-dimensional design, her son said. She led Vignelli Designs, creating products like furniture and tableware.", "title": "Lella and Massimo Vignelli\u2019s Home Seeks a Like-Minded Buyer", "authors": ["Stefanos Chen"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLena Hall, the Tony Award-winning actress and cabaret singer, will soon embark on an ambitious project to pay homage to her favorite musicians and bands by releasing a new EP album on the first Friday of every month in 2018, as well as a music video every week.\n\nThe project, called \u201cObsessed,\u201d begins Jan. 5 with songs from John Cameron Mitchell and Stephen Trask\u2019s rock musical, \u201cHedwig and the Angry Inch,\u201d which she starred in on Broadway alongside Neil Patrick Harris in 2014. She went on to win the Tony for best featured actress in a musical. On Friday, she will also release two music videos.\n\nVideo\n\nMs. Hall\u2019s tentative schedule for the rest of the year includes a diverse slate of tributes: to Peter Gabriel and Elton John, for example, as well as Beck and Pink. Also on the roster are Nirvana, Jack White and Radiohead.\n\nToward the end of the year, she will record songs by the Cranberries and Muse, as well as David Bowie and Chris Cornell, of Soundgarden and Audioslave.\n\nSKB Records (Sh-K-Boom/Ghostlight), a heavyweight label in the world of Broadway cast recordings, will produce Ms. Hall\u2019s EPs. Her previous album, \u201cSin & Salvation: Live at the Carlyle,\u201d was produced independently.", "title": "Lena Hall Plans an Ambitious Tribute to Her Favorite Musicians", "authors": ["Joshua Barone"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 High in the mountains of a small southern African kingdom, miners have unearthed one of the largest diamonds ever found, a glittering giant weighing 910 carats, or 6.4 ounces, and probably worth tens of millions of dollars.\n\nThe stone, found in the Letseng mine in Lesotho, is the fifth-largest gem-quality diamond ever found, and the largest in Lesotho\u2019s history. It weighs more than a regulation baseball (about 5 ounces), and more than half as much as the average male human heart (about 10 ounces).\n\nGem Diamonds, the London-based company that owns a majority stake in the mine and that announced the find on Monday, described the diamond as being of extremely high quality.\n\nIt said the stone is a D color, Type IIa diamond, meaning it is colorless and very radiant, without any yellow tint or impurities like nitrogen that absorb light and decrease luster.", "title": "Lesotho Diamond Weighs More Than a Baseball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Businesses die every day in New York, but all deaths are not equal. Some rend the very fabric of a city that fancies itself, quite reasonably, the nation\u2019s cultural tastemaker. So there is reason to mourn the passing of two movie houses in Manhattan that believed in the capacity of films that aren\u2019t dominated by car explosions, light sabers and computer-generated gimcrackery to more faithfully reflect the human spirit.\n\nLast Sunday the Sunshine Cinema, dedicated to independent and foreign films, shut its doors after a 16-year run on Houston Street (that\u2019s HOW-stin, people, not HEW-stin). A developer plans to demolish it and put up \u2026 something. Whatever it is, it\u2019s bound to be less soul-satisfying.\n\nThis Sunday brings the end to an older theater, Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, which has been around since 1981, in a worn area one flight below the street at Broadway and 62nd Street. The Lincoln Plaza faithful \u2014 who tend to be, shall we say, not young \u2014 aren\u2019t just hanging crepe these days. They are practically ready to call in grief counselors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCall it an art house if you must, a term bound to scare off some people. It\u2019s where devoted audiences have long flocked to see works of intelligence, many of them imports, because not all things great are American. On the final day at the theater, its six screens have films by Italian, Lebanese, Austrian, English and Scottish directors. There is also one film by a not-so-typical American named Woody Allen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat happened to this theater is a landlord-tenant story so familiar to New Yorkers that it\u2019s trite. The lease expired, and the building owner, Milstein Properties, didn\u2019t renew it. Structural work is needed around the building, Milstein said. It has promised that once the job is done, a new cinema will be birthed in the old Lincoln Plaza space. We\u2019ll see. For now, it\u2019s probably not a bad idea to bear in mind an old line about verbal agreements and how they\u2019re not worth the paper they\u2019re written on.", "title": "Less Chance to Get Together in the Dark", "authors": ["Clyde Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nThe word \u201cselect\u201d glowed on the sign identifying the bus as the M34. I did not know what that meant, so I ignored it and got on when the door opened, pulling my overnight bag behind me. I was going to Penn Station.\n\nWith an older person\u2019s prerogative, I took a seat near the front of the bus and began to fuss around in my purse in search of my MetroCard. Once I\u2019d found it, I lurched to the front to pay my fare.\n\nThe driver explained what \u201cselect\u201d meant: that you pay at the blue box at the bus stop before boarding.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sorry,\u201d said. \u201cI made a mistake. Can I pay when I get off?\u201d\n\nThe problem with that, the driver said, was that if an inspector got on and asked me for a receipt, I could be fined for not having one.", "title": "Lesson in Select Bus Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "President Johnson faced a fiendish tangle of problems: He had to restrain Seoul and Pyongyang from locking horns in a war that could quickly engulf thousands of American troops in South Korea, dissuade President Park from withdrawing crack South Korean troops fighting in Vietnam to reinforce his vulnerable home front, and get the captive Pueblo sailors back before the Communists executed them.\n\nHe began by rattling his saber as loudly as possible, both to intimidate the North and reassure the South. He rushed the aircraft carrier Enterprise and 25 other warships into the Sea of Japan, within easy range of North Korea, and 360 combat aircraft to bases in and near South Korea.\n\nThe Pentagon prepared plans to hit the North with nuclear weapons if it invaded the South. Under one scheme, eerily code-named Operation Freedom Drop, B-52s would incinerate Communist troops and armor with atomic bombs. Another plan envisioned destruction of the entire North Korean air force \u2014 nearly 500 aircraft \u2014 with round-the-clock airstrikes.\n\nBut Johnson chose not to bloody his saber, and thereby exposed himself to charges of weakness. (An outraged New Jersey man sent him a one-word telegram \u2014 \u201cCoward\u201d \u2014 and a Milwaukee newspaper sarcastically suggested that America\u2019s national symbol be changed from an eagle to a chicken.)\n\nThe president believed the wiser course was a diplomatic one. His United Nations ambassador called for debate on the Pueblo in the Security Council, creating a rationale for delaying military action.
