To hold the South Korean president in check, Johnson gave him a cornucopia of military equipment, including two Navy destroyers.\n\nIn February, United States and North Korean negotiators began meeting secretly at Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone. The talks dragged on for months as the North Koreans insisted on an American apology for the Pueblo\u2019s \u201cespionage\u201d in their territorial waters. (Washington said the ship was on a legitimate military mission in international waters.) The Americans offered various alternatives short of a formal apology, but the Communists stuck to their demand.\n\nThe North Koreans flung insults and the chief American negotiator, a cigar-puffing Navy admiral, contemptuously blew smoke rings at them.", "title": "Opinion | Lessons From a Spy Ship\u2019s Seizure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Last year, I received an email from my dad, under a mildly worrisome subject line: \u201cMystery critter ???\u201d There was no body text, but attached was a 10-second video clip, shot in the eerie grays of infrared night vision. It showed a furry creature, about the size of a Pomeranian, charging away from the camera and down a driveway. Midway through the video, the animal stops abruptly, turns slightly and stares back \u2014 if not directly at the camera, near enough that its retinas catch the light and, for a moment, glow. Then it slouches off, away from the camera and into the darkness. Watching it again, I noticed that the driveway looked oddly familiar \u2014 it was my childhood home.\n\nThere were soon more emails with more videos attached. The next had a fox \u2014 or the back half of a fox \u2014 making a rapid exit offscreen. The one after that showed a possum plodding into and through some hedges. By the time my dad moved the cameras into the backyard, he had captured another possum, or maybe the same possum, plus more foxes, a rabbit and a pair of coyotes. He had also solved the case of the mystery critter. It was a raccoon rendered unrecognizable by the loss of its tail.\n\nMy parents live in the foothills of Santa Barbara, and for years they had been talking about wanting to set up some camera traps, just to see what sorts of animals were prowling around the house. But my dad had always thought the cameras were a little too expensive and complicated. Still, they pined. For the past 30 years, my parents\u2019 primary hobby has been exploring and settling their backyard, weeding and gardening it aggressively and making note of all the paw prints and scratch marks they encountered as they did so. When I was growing up, this was where I built forts and caught lizards, dug up anthills and found quite a few skulls, bleached and buried, of long-dead rodents (and once, a pet cat).\n\nThis sort of terrain, between the settled and the unsettled land, is known as the wildland-urban interface, or WUI. Each decade, the interface is carefully mapped by the Forest Service as part of its fire-safety precautions. The last effort was in 2010, and it found that one in three people in the United States lives in the WUI, and that it\u2019s among the fastest-growing residential regions in the country: At the time, it covered 10 percent of the map. The WUI runs through the fringes of suburbs and exurbs, and in the gaps they never quite fill, but it also creeps into our metropolises. California has more people living in the WUI than any other state. In Los Angeles, I can see it from my apartment in two different spots: right in the middle of the city where the Santa Monica Mountains run, and again to the east along the San Gabriels.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout a year ago, an acquaintance recommended that my dad get the Bushnell Trophy Cam HD Essential E2. With eight AA batteries and an SD memory card (not included), the camera \u2014 in a third of a second upon detecting motion \u2014 could power on, capture up to a minute of footage and store it. It was simple and rugged: You could leave it alone for a year, and it would keep going. It owed its hardiness to the fact that it was made for sportsmen, not biologists. \u201cJust hang it and hunt!\u201d the website boasted. It cost around $150. My dad bought two.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe first pointed them toward a barren patch of hill where he had noticed a particular pile of scat, which always appeared in the same spot. He attached one camera to an old bench, and he tied the other to the trunk of an olive tree. After leaving them only a night, he checked. Most of the time, the camera misfires, capturing not critters but other, more mundane but still ghostly movement \u2014 usually branches bobbing in a silent wind. But this first night, right in front of the bench, a fox arrived. It trotted precisely to the center of the sightline and squatted, briefly, in the exact scat spot. \u201cCan you believe it?\u201d he said, queuing up the video to play for me again.\n\nI could not, yet there it was, plain to see. For me, the pleasure in watching these videos was that they would never be entirely believable, that the images would always appear to be on the brink of the imaginary. Rather than making the world more knowable, they seem to make it more extraordinary, filled with more life and movement than seems possible in the dead of night. They\u2019ve taken the familiar \u2014 a backyard I know better than any other \u2014 and made it strange, turned it into a place crawling with mystery. It serves as a reminder: In the WUI, the land is still part wild. Wilder than we might care to admit until it\u2019s too late.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Bushnell Trophy Cam", "authors": ["Ryan Bradley", "Letter Of Recommendation"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Floating, Lilly realized, helped to peel back the brain\u2019s learned layers to its elemental core and reprogram it. \u201cSuddenly all of the stimulation of holding one upright against gravity disappears,\u201d he wrote. \u201cOne\u2019s cerebellum is now freed for uses other than balancing the body.\u201d It seems I had my cause and effect reversed: Rather than trying to quiet my brain in order to float, I could use floating to achieve a sort of Zen stillness. Inner peace, divined by salt water.\n\nAfter childhood, I gave little thought to floating until last year, while on a trip to Israel. My 87-year-old Saba Meir \u2014 saba is Hebrew for grandfather \u2014 surprised me with a request to visit the Dead Sea. It was on the opposite side of the country, and he hadn\u2019t floated in its famously salty water for 30 years.\n\nOver our four-hour drive to the Dead Sea, I thought about all that he was losing to age and Parkinson\u2019s disease. Since the last trip, he had deteriorated visibly; I went to Israel only every two years or so, which meant my mental image of his aging felt accelerated, like a time-lapse video. At home in his apartment, he could get through the day without help. But in unfamiliar places, he suddenly appeared frail and confused, and my partner and I fell into chaperone mode. In the visitors\u2019 center bathroom, after an arm-in-arm walk down the corridor, he hesitated at the urinal before asking me for help with his belt buckle. I felt a rush of parental protectiveness when a middle-aged man walked in on us.\n\nIn the hurry to get to the beach before closing, stress signals caromed through my brain, refusing to coalesce into coherent thoughts. Down at the water, some older sunbathers had dragged in the resort\u2019s plastic lawn chairs so they could sit waist-deep, and we followed their lead. Saba, my partner and I waded in, the current tugging on our flip-flops, me holding Saba\u2019s arm, him gripping the chair. With great negotiation, we got him situated, his feet floating upward as he stiffly tried to recline.\n\nMy own floating technique was no better now than it was when I was a child. My mind reeled more than ever, hot with anxiety from a day of caregiving. My eyes darted from Saba to the water; I was too preoccupied with his safety to appreciate the seascape.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Floating", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe last time I went to trivia night at a bar, the friend who invited me set expectations unreasonably high. He announced proudly to our teammates, most of whom I\u2019d never met, that I worked as a fact-checker for a magazine, the implication being that I was a repository of data. As it happened, my performance was subpar \u2014 until we arrived at the clincher, a double-or-nothing bonus round. \u201cWhy did a porn-production studio offer a British woman $1 million to appear in one of their films?\u201d I bolted to attention. I had read about said British woman that very afternoon, while browsing The Daily Mail instead of attending to my fact-checking duties! \u201cShe had two vaginas,\u201d I whispered excitedly. When we won, my friend\u2019s friends \u2014 now, dare I say, my own \u2014 cheered with gusto.\n\nThe truth about being a fact-checker is that you\u2019re not supposed to rely on what you know. That\u2019s usually where the mistakes are made \u2014 in assumptions, in guesses based on faded memories and self-affirming bluster. A good fact-checker is incredibly stringent and willing to look something up, and then look it up again, and then call someone to confirm that they\u2019ve looked it up correctly, and someone else to confirm that they\u2019ve understood it. Being adept at this process is its own skill, and I consider it one of mine. But when it comes to intellectual capital, what I\u2019m most impressed by \u2014 in myself and in other people \u2014 are the random bits of information we manage to retain and retrieve from our own crowded brains, evidence of lives spent reading, watching, listening and discussing. Proof that we\u2019ve been curious, awake and observant, and that we\u2019re richer and more complicated for it.\n\nLife doesn\u2019t present us with many opportunities to put to use the facts that we know for no other reason than that we know them. And so last year, when two of my smartest, most interesting, most encyclopedic friends revealed that they were members of an online trivia league, I wanted in. No, it was not HQ, the live-video, cash-prize trivia app that has taken the internet by storm in the last few months.\n\nPhoto\n\nMy friends\u2019 trivia league, which is now my own, is called Learned League. It predates HQ by about 18 years, and you can tell \u2014 visiting the desktop-only, confusing-to-navigate website on which it lives is a little like time-traveling to Y2K. Text is small and dense; there are no graphics beyond a generic-looking logo and the tiny flags that players are required to use as avatars. More important, there\u2019s basically nothing at stake: There are no prizes of any kind, and when you join (by referral only, for a yearly fee of $30), you\u2019re placed into a group of about 20 random competitors, identified by only their last names and first initials, so you can\u2019t even really play against your friends \u2014 although everyone, across every \u201crundle,\u201d as the groups are called, answers the same six questions each day of each 25-day quarterly season, and anyone is free to look up anyone else\u2019s statistics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe only thing stopping you from cheating is the honor code, but there\u2019s no point in cheating, because the only point of Learned League is to test your own knowledge. And test your knowledge it does: Most of the questions \u2014 written by the league\u2019s trivia-obsessed founder, Shayne Bushfield, who in his capacity as \u201ccommissioner\u201d uses the moniker \u201cThorsten A. Integrity\u201d \u2014 are extremely challenging and often bewilderingly worded. \u201cIdentify the subatomic particle of the baryon family, believed to be composed of two up quarks and one down quark, which has a mass of 1.672x10-24 grams and a positive electric charge of 1.602x10-19 coulombs\u201d or \u201cWhat was the name given to the ecclesiastical court established by the Roman Catholic Church, beginning with Pope Gregory IX in 1231, whose jurisdiction was the prosecution of heresy?\u201d\n\nI didn\u2019t know the answers to either of those questions, and I can\u2019t remember them now. I am very, very bad at Learned League, consistently finishing seasons in the bottom quarter of my rundle. But every so often, I get one right, and the feeling is nothing short of euphoric. One about a short-lived television show that happens to have been created and written by a friend of mine and her husband. One about maple syrup, in which I happen to be something of an expert. One about \u201cThe Decameron,\u201d by Boccaccio, which I was required to read in college and hadn\u2019t thought of since. Sometimes it feels like pure magic: On a day I had idly studied my map-of-the-night-sky shower curtain while brushing my teeth, I was stunned to find that one of Thorsten\u2019s questions was, \u201cBetelgeuse, Rigel and Bellatrix are the Alpha, Beta and Gamma stars of what constellation?\u201d (Answer: Orion.) Trivia becomes motivation to pay closer attention to everything, just in case.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Learned League", "authors": ["Hannah Goldfield", "Letter Of Recommendation"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine having no talent. Imagine being no good at all at something and doing it anyway. Then, after nine years, failing at it and giving it up in disgust and moving to Englewood, N.J., and selling aluminum siding. And then, years later, trying the thing again, though it wrecks your marriage, and failing again. And eventually making a meticulous study of the thing and figuring out that, by eliminating every extraneous element, you could isolate what makes it work and just do that. And then, after becoming better at it than anyone who had ever done it, realizing that maybe you didn\u2019t need the talent. That maybe its absence was a gift.\n\nThese were the stations on the via dolorosa of Jacob Cohen, a.k.a. Rodney Dangerfield, whose comedy I hold above all others\u2019. At his peak \u2014 look on YouTube for any set he did between 1976 and 1990 \u2014 he was the funniest entertainer ever. That peak was long in coming; by the time he perfected his act, he was nearly 60. But everything about Dangerfield was weird. While other comedians of that era made their names in television and film, Dangerfield made his with stand-up. It was a stand-up as dated as he was: He stood on stage stock-still in a rumpled black suit and shiny red tie and told a succession of diamond-hard one-liners.\n\nThe one-liners were impeccable, unimprovable. Dangerfield spent years on them; he once told an interviewer that it took him three months to work up six minutes of material for a talk-show appearance. If there\u2019s art about life and art about art, Dangerfield\u2019s comedy was the latter \u2014 he was the supreme formalist. Lacking inborn ability, he studied the moving parts of a joke with an engineer\u2019s rigor. And so Dangerfield, who told audiences that as a child he was so ugly that his mother fed him with a slingshot, became the leading semiotician of postwar American comedy. How someone can watch him with anything short of wonder is beyond me.\n\n\u201cTo be a comedian,\u201d he said, \u201cyou have to get onstage and find out if you\u2019re funny.\u201d He wasn\u2019t. During his first career, performing as Jack Roy, he was a singing waiter, used props, tried impressions. Even after his second coming \u2014 using a stage name devised by a club owner as a gag \u2014 and becoming a regular on \u201cThe Ed Sullivan Show,\u201d he could be miserable. In a YouTube clip of him performing on \u201cSullivan\u201d in 1969, Dangerfield\u2019s face is the unsettling bluish-pink of raw chicken. The jokes \u2014 about getting directions, his wife\u2019s driving, their apartment \u2014 keep bombing. The setups are too long; the delivery is too slow; the punch lines are so lame that you can hear the scattered laughter of distinct individuals. Even worse, he panders. \u201cI\u2019ll tell you, it\u2019s nice to hear you laugh,\u201d he says at one point. It\u2019s almost unseemly.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Rodney Dangerfield", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Handel\u2019s Masterpiece\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his review of \u201cMessiah\u201d by Jonathan Keates (Dec. 24), Leon Botstein notes that audiences are \u201cbrought to their feet by the \u2018Hallelujah\u2019 chorus.\u201d For the origin of that tradition, I refer interested readers to a Dec. 19, 2009, Boston Globe article by Matthew Guerrieri: \u201cRoyal example, religious devotion, reassuring ritual, rousing musicality \u2014 take your pick. Or don\u2019t: Remaining seated during the \u2018Hallelujah\u2019 chorus ranks as one of the more effortless demonstrations of anti-authoritarian dissent.\u201d\n\nJOEL SOLONCHE\n\nBLOOMING GROVE, N.Y.\n\nThe Story of the Jews\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn reviewing Simon Schama\u2019s \u201cThe Story of the Jews, Volume 2, Belonging: 1492-1900\u201d (Dec. 24), Roger Cohen writes that Schama makes \u201can eloquent and a far-reaching case for why Jews needed a small piece of earth they could call home.\u201d Cohen describes the heavy price paid by the Palestinian people but holds fast to the belief that the cost in systematic injustice and the corrosive effect on Israeli society \u201cwas not inevitable.\u201d Cohen is unwilling to see that the price exacted for that \u201csmall piece of earth\u201d is the inevitable outcome. Zionism is understandable as a 19th-century response to millenniums of persecution. But as a project of colonial dispossession, it is neither sustainable nor defensible in the 21st century. The only hope for a decent future for both Palestinians and Jews is one that envisions a state that does not privilege one people over another.\n\nMARK BRAVERMAN\n\nPORTLAND, ORE.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRoger Cohen claims that the establishment of Israel and the occupation of the West Bank has resulted in \u201cthe exile\u201d of the Palestinians. In 1947, when the United Nations voted to approve the establishment of a Jewish state, Palestinian Arabs and existing Arab countries refused to recognize the right of Israel to exist and refused to accept the territory allocated for the Palestinian Arabs\u2019 own independent nation. Palestinian Arabs have repeatedly launched wars against Israel. When Cohen blames Israel, and the occupation of the West Bank, for ongoing bellicosity, he ignores the ugly truth of what is keeping the occupation necessary.\n\nROSALIND FELDMAN\n\nROCKVILLE, MD.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI commend Roger Cohen for his appreciation of Simon Schama\u2019s book, but his review should have stopped in 1900, when Schama does. Any comments on what happened after that belong on an op-ed page and not in a review.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Sports Editor:\n\nRe \u201cGlory to Georgia, in a Northern Accent,\u201d Jan. 8: You reported that the \u201cBattle Hymn of the Republic\u201d originally implored, \u201cLet us die to make men free.\u201d But it\u2019s important to note that Americans no longer buy that counterproductive martial fatalism. As Gen. George S. Patton famously put it: \u201cNo bastard ever won a war by dying for his country. You won it by making the other poor dumb bastard die for his country.\u201d That\u2019s why singers of the \u201cBattle Hymn\u201d now frequently rise up to healthy revisionism: \u201cLet us live to make men free.\u201d\n\nSteven T. Corneliussen\n\nPoquoson, Va.\n\nLessons From Figure Skating\n\nTo the Sports Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNathan Chen Leads Olympic Figure Skating Team; Ross Miner Is Bumped,\u201d Jan. 7: At a moment when Tonya Harding, triple Axels, and the sport\u2019s elitism permeate popular discourse, Jer\u00e9 Longman\u2019s poignant piece seems timely indeed.\n\nAs a longtime competitive figure skater and a university English professor, I find Longman\u2019s article relevant to one of my current college courses, \u201cAmerican Sports Stories,\u201d which looks to literature and culture to reflect upon the relationship between art and sport.\n\nLongman makes the persuasive point that, while figure skating is not without bias, the current International Judging System strives for the \u201cright balance between athleticism and artistry.\u201d Similarly, humanities professors work to design rubrics that quantify more subjective disciplines like literature and writing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLongman\u2019s article reinforces the valuable life lessons that can emerge from the world of figure skating. These lessons enhance my work to prepare students for a 21st century world, which, despite its increasing reliance on numbers, is largely unquantifiable.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Julie Manet\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs the translator and editor of the recent publication \u201cGrowing Up With the Impressionists: The Diary of Julie Manet,\u201d I am bemused, to say the least, by your review by Nancy Kline (Dec. 10), which was published online under the headline \u201cGreat Art, Repugnant Politics.\u201d Julie\u2019s diary, which she wrote between the ages of 14 and 20, is a seminal text on the period. My new translation, with an introduction and over 400 footnotes, gives a personal view of the last years of the 19th century through the eyes of Berthe Morisot\u2019s daughter.\n\nThe Dreyfus Affair material is essential for many reasons, the least being to gauge how politically ambiguous Julie Manet\u2019s circle was at that time. We also see how impressionable young people could be (as they still are!) regarding their parents\u2019 or mentors\u2019 views and we are able to observe how the affair seeped into the fabric of everyday life during these troubled years.\n\nJANE ROBERTS\n\nPARIS\n\nA Revealing Photograph?\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nJody Williams\u2019s review of \u201cAnnie Leibovitz: Portraits 2005-2016\u201d (Dec. 3) neglected to mention a troubling portrait. This photograph was described in The New York Times in 2006: \u201cThere\u2019s Donald Trump, seen as the proud possessor of a fancy car, a private jet and a beautiful young wife also heavy with child.\u201d He sits in a $600,000 car while his pregnant wife descends the stairs in spike heels and a gold bikini. Does this photo summarize his current political battles? Is his tax plan just a way to secure the right of every rich man to freedom from any taxes that might impair his ability to live like the Donald, periodically trading in the old car, jet and wife for a newer model?\n\nJANET BUSH HANDY\n\nBEL AIR, MD.\n\nGreeks and Romans\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nReviewing Emily Wilson\u2019s new translation of Homer\u2019s \u201cThe Odyssey\u201d (Dec. 10), Gregory Hays appreciates Wilson\u2019s gloss that the slave women slain by Telemachus were only doing \u201cthe things the suitors made them do with them.\u201d Actually, not. Of the 50 such women, only 12 shamelessly snapped their fingers at Penelope and \u201cslept with the suitors.\u201d It is they who were singled out for execution, while the others were exonerated.\n\nWADE RICHARDSON\n\nLADYSMITH, BRITISH COLUMBIA\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThank you Gregory Hays for your review of Emily Wilson\u2019s translation of \u201cThe Odyssey\u201d and thank you Denis Feeney for your review of David Ferry\u2019s translation of \u201cThe Aeneid\u201d (Dec. 10). With both books, we have translators critiquing translators, which is a big help for old salts deciding if they want to sign ship\u2019s papers or for landlubbers who wonder if they are seaworthy. When it comes to the classics, though, no one needs permission to come aboard. I plan on signing up for both voyages.\n\nNEAL WHITMAN\n\nPACIFIC GROVE, CALIF.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Holy Days\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nStudies have shown that our world is becoming less religious and that more people no longer believe in God. Your Dec. 24 issue reviewed books concerning various aspects of religion, but there was no representation of the shift toward a secular society. Atheists have little faith in the supernatural, but we would hate to think our faith in The New York Times is in peril.\n\nDENNIS B. APPLETON\n\nMADISON, WIS.\n\nVietnam\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nJeff Shesol\u2019s review of \u201cPlaying With Fire,\u201d by Lawrence O\u2019Donnell (Jan. 7), speculates that Senator Eugene McCarthy\u2019s quest for the 1968 presidential nomination may have prolonged the conflict in Vietnam by widening divisions in the Democratic Party and thereby helped elect Richard Nixon, who escalated the American military intervention in Southeast Asia. While accurate about Nixon\u2019s escalation strategy, Shesol overlooks or ignores the fact that the vice president and Democratic nominee, Hubert Humphrey, had supported military escalation in Vietnam for years and thus in all likelihood would have prolonged the war as well. One of the reasons Humphrey\u2019s presidential campaign faltered was that young voters did not trust him on the war issue.\n\nLARRY D. WOODS\n\nNASHVILLE\n\nHoliday Handel\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nReaders of Leon Botstein\u2019s review of Jonathan Keates\u2019s \u201cMessiah\u201d (Dec. 24) should know that Handel doesn\u2019t need to be appreciated only on Christmas or Easter. \u201cSee the Conquering Hero,\u201d from his oratorio \u201cJudas Maccabaeus,\u201d is now a Hanukkah song for children called \u201cHava Narima.\u201d It sounds great in Hebrew.\n\nZALMAN SHOVAL\n\nTEL AVIV\n\nListening to Gibbon\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nDaniel Mendelsohn (By the Book, Jan. 7) is kidding himself if he thinks he\u2019s getting the whole enchantment of \u201cThe Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire\u201d by listening to it on tape. If, as I suspect, it doesn\u2019t include the footnotes, he\u2019s missing out on some of the wittiest and most malicious delights of Gibbon\u2019s book.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mrs. Robinson\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI enjoyed reading Lisa Schwarzbaum\u2019s review of \u201cSeduced by Mrs. Robinson\u201d (Jan. 7), although I always found Benjamin annoying and hardly representative of my generation. However, the legs in the photograph belonged to Linda Gray of \u201cDallas\u201d fame. It was a publicity shot, not a frame from the film. I don\u2019t know why Anne Bancroft didn\u2019t pose. She had lovely legs.\n\nHENRY HARP BLAUKOPF\n\nNEW YORK\n\nScience and the Humanities\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI\u2019m disappointed in Peter Godfrey-Smith\u2019s review of Edward O. Wilson\u2019s \u201cThe Origins of Creativity\u201d (Jan. 14). \u201cIs there a problem with the humanities that makes these meetings urgent?\u201d Godfrey-Smith asks. Yes, there is. To quote Wilson, the humanities \u201care rootless in their explanations of causation.\u201d To account for racism, for instance, humanities scholars propose various theories of \u201cothering,\u201d the practice of labeling and excluding persons who don\u2019t fit the norms of a particular social group.\n\nIt\u2019s essential to consider such practices in their specific cultural contexts, but evolutionary biology and neuroscience can yield insights into their cognitive underpinnings, contributing to a primary goal of the humanities, self-understanding. Whatever the flaws of Wilson\u2019s book, I wish Godfrey-Smith had consulted other humanities scholars before assuming they would be equally dismissive of Wilson\u2019s hope for new alliances between sciences and the humanities.\n\nKATHLEEN R. HART\n\nPOUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.\n\n\u2018Windfall\u2019\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRobert D. Kaplan\u2019s review of \u201cWindfall: How the New Energy Abundance Upends Global Politics and Strengthens American Power\u201d (Dec. 31) fails to mention the role of the oil and gas sectors in causing climate change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe review also omits mention of renewable energy, another decentralized source of power, in both senses of the word. Some American leaders are shutting down coal plants, rejecting fracking and instead investing in offshore wind and other clean energy initiatives. It seems that, like President Trump, \u201cWindfall\u201d is looking at the sources of American power through a rearview mirror.\n\nSTEPHANIE DOBA\n\nBROOKLYN, N.Y.\n\nCulture Wars\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his latest salvo in the culture wars (By the Book, Jan. 14), Niall Ferguson slays an impressive number of straw creatures. Still, a casual reader might be confused. What is this \u201cloathsome coastal cognitive elite\u201d to which he \u2014 a man who has taught at Stanford and Harvard and whose nightstand reading surely impresses his colleagues but just as surely would pose a mighty challenge to many of the \u201cmiddle Americans\u201d he so deeply understands \u2014 refers?", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Fox News pounced on the viral tweet as evidence of how easily \u201cTrump trashers\u201d could be fooled into believing anything negative about the president. Farhad Manjoo, a New York Times columnist, admonished people for sharing fake screenshots, saying \u201cthe jokes just don\u2019t work in a partisan-echo-chamber-feed world.\u201d\n\nJennifer Stromer-Galley, the former president of the Association of Internet Researchers and a professor at Syracuse University, said the gorilla channel meme had spread thanks to people\u2019s willingness to suspend disbelief and their susceptibility to confirmation bias \u2014 the same reasons that fake news accounts are able to take hold, she said.\n\n\u201cThis is a bit more harmless, but it\u2019s part of a larger challenge,\u201d she said in an interview on Saturday. \u201cIt does raise questions for how we try to empower the public to better sort out what\u2019s true from fiction.\u201d\n\nIn an email, Mr. Ward wrote that he has been doing fake screenshots on Twitter for a long time, and he always tried \u201cto make them ridiculous enough that it\u2019s clear they\u2019re jokes.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut there\u2019s always at least a few people who think the joke is real,\u201d he continued. \u201cI\u2019m not sure this says anything about the state of society. I think it\u2019s just that people assess what they\u2019re reading in the context it\u2019s presented in, so some people won\u2019t realize they\u2019re looking at a joke unless you explicitly say \u2018this is a joke.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn defense of those who fell for the gorilla channel gag, art \u2014 or in this case, Twitter jokes \u2014 might imitate life. A 1997 New Yorker profile of Mr. Trump described a scene aboard his jet as he flew to Mar-a-Lago, with Mr. Trump watching the 1988 martial arts film \u201cBloodsport\u201d and tasking his son Eric with fast-forwarding to the fight scenes.\n\nThe gorilla channel tweet is certainly not the first joke post about Mr. Trump to generate partisan debate. A 2015 tweet purporting to show Mr. Trump attacking the rock band Pavement, for example, sent some potential voters into crisis about whether they could support a candidate who didn\u2019t appreciate \u201990s-era indie rock.", "title": "Let\u2019s Talk About the Gorilla Channel for One More Day", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf they can\u2019t, I will revisit this issue!\u201d he said.\n\nMaybe he forgot. This is a man who twice tried to walk out of executive order signing ceremonies without signing the executive order. Who once testified that he couldn\u2019t remember having told a reporter he had one of the world\u2019s great memories.\n\nIt is stupendously important that Washington deal with DACA now. The nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute predicts that otherwise, beginning this spring, an average of 915 young people a day will lose protection from deportation.\n\nOn one bright evening last fall it appeared that Trump had worked out a deal with the Democratic leaders: fix the Dreamer problem and spend a lot more money on border patrols.\n\nDo you think it was a good plan? The Border Patrol is already huge. And the agents have less and less to do. During the last fiscal year, they made 310,531 arrests, down 25 percent from the year before, and the lowest level since 1971.\n\nHow do you feel about hiring more of them?\n\nA) What the hell, if it gets us through the problem.\n\nB) No way, I\u2019m a deficit hawk.\n\nC) Do you think the president has dementia? I have read many convincing pieces on this subject recently.\n\nHey, C is off the table. It would cost an estimated $21.6 billion, ruin farms, kill off wildlife and look like hell. Otherwise, no problem.\n\nTrump has had eight prototypes of his dream barrier constructed just to show the country what it\u2019s been missing. Some are gray, some are brown, some are kind of blue. Some are 30 feet tall. They\u2019re right on the border near San Diego.", "title": "Opinion | Let\u2019s Try to Get Past Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "MONROVIA, Liberia \u2014 Just days before the end of her 12-year tenure as Liberia\u2019s head of state, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has been expelled by senior members of her political party, who accused her of supporting the opposition candidate and now president-elect, George Weah, in his recent election campaign.\n\nA statement from the Unity Party, released late Saturday, said that Mrs. Sirleaf, Africa\u2019s first female democratically elected head of state, had been expelled because of \u201cseveral violations and other acts inimical to the existence of the party.\u201d\n\nAmong them was her failure to support her vice president, Joseph Boakai, in the election.\n\nMr. Weah will be sworn into office on Jan. 22, the first peaceful democratic transfer of power in the country since 1944.\n\nThe Unity Party\u2019s spokesman, Mohammed Ali, accused Mrs. Sirleaf of using state resources to fund Mr. Weah\u2019s campaign and said that evidence would be disclosed to the public at a later date.", "title": "Liberia President\u2019s Ouster by Party May Raise Questions Over Her Legacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Despite the recent political tumult, Liberians were euphoric on Monday at the prospect of change and the chance to leave behind the rocky history of politics in a nation founded in the early 19th century by freed American slaves. Two of its past presidents were assassinated, and the nation has endured two civil wars that left scores dead.\n\nMr. Weah\u2019s rise to the presidency resonated with the poorest citizens in a country where more than half of the population lives below the poverty line. Mr. Weah himself came from poverty. During his teenage years in the 1980s, he shared a bedroom with 10 other boys in West Point, Monrovia\u2019s largest slum.\n\nSupport for him in West Point is evident in a painting of the former soccer star, bespectacled and solemn looking, that hangs outside a corner shop. \u201cLiberia\u2019s Hope\u201d is written underneath. People have nicknamed him King George.\n\nWest Point has long been a political stronghold for Mr. Weah. With poor infrastructure and sanitation, regular outbursts of mob violence and rural migrants searching for opportunity, it is a microcosm of the challenges throughout the country that await the new president.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Weah rode a wave of disappointment into office, propelled by voters upset that Mrs. Sirleaf\u2019s government never managed to tackle endemic poverty or successfully fight corruption.\n\nHis challenges are formidable. He must govern a nation with a broken education system, high levels of unemployment and an economy hit hard by falling rubber and iron ore prices.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Weah must also maintain security and stability in a postwar society without the support of peacekeepers. The United Nations mission in Liberia is sending the last of its troops back home.\n\nLike his predecessor, Mr. Weah has vowed to fight corruption. He has pledged to promote free education and health care, while also providing tax breaks for investors.\n\nBut his critics say he is too inexperienced to address the mammoth problems the nation faces. His political experience consists of three years as senator and a limited stint as an ambassador for a reconciliation initiative.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe economy is doing very badly and will be a big challenge for him to turn it around,\u201d said Silas Kpanan\u2019Ayoung Siakor, an environmental activist.\n\nAnd he must operate in the shadow of Mrs. Sirleaf, who despite being criticized for nepotism and failing to address endemic corruption, is often credited with Liberia\u2019s postwar turnaround.\n\n\u201cShe took over at a time when things were so bad and she had so much money flowing in that she was able to show progress very quickly,\u201d Mr. Siakor said.\n\nMr. Weah is not expected to enjoy the same levels of foreign donations, and he has focused on Liberia\u2019s business potential, saying he wants to relax constraints on companies in hopes of creating jobs.\n\nFaith Caranda, 18, who is finishing high school, said she hoped his first priority would be improving access to education.\n\n\u201cA lot of my friends don\u2019t have money to go to school, so they sit down doing nothing,\u201d said Ms. Caranda, who hopes to study medicine. \u201cI know he will bring change in our country.\u201d", "title": "Liberia Swears In George Weah, Its Soccer Star President", "authors": ["Clair Macdougall"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "No longer fearing reprisals for opposing the president, politicians have newfound influence. Lawmakers have taken to holding legislative items hostage, making material demands when the time comes to pass budgets, allocate money for schools, confirm political appointees or enact laws.\n\nHer leverage limited by the tools of democratic governance, Ms. Sirleaf used \u201ccash violence,\u201d in Liberian slang, or the persuasive powers of the purse, to bring political competitors to her side. She gave or withheld government positions and contracts, and used off-the-book inducements.\n\nSuch structural problems resist easy fixes and the odds rarely favor reformers, but at certain moments \u2014 such as during political transitions \u2014 narrow windows of opportunity open. Mr. Weah is in such a moment, because Liberia, while still fragile, has passed through the period when restoring stability had to be an absolute priority. He can now turn to smaller technical fixes that did not even appear on Ms. Sirleaf\u2019s radar.\n\nFor starters, Mr. Weah could set new expectations for greater accountability by promptly issuing an executive order asking all government ministries and agencies to publish their monthly expenditures. It\u2019s a simple step, but it could have an outsized impact on combating government fraud by opening spending to public scrutiny.\n\nMr. Weah should instruct the finance ministry to allocate funds only to government entities with an approved procurement plan. Government contracts for goods and services \u2014 which, officials have told me, can account for up to 50 percent of the total budget \u2014 offer easy opportunities for graft. Just 41 percent of government entities currently have such plans even though those are required by law. Tying funding to compliance would change this practice is no time.\n\nThe new president should also ask the General Auditing Commission to examine the legislature\u2019s 2018 expenditures and legislators\u2019 assets. Remarkably, the National Assembly has never had to account for its spending despite persistent allegations of corruption. Giving legislators a full year\u2019s warning would allow them to correct any problematic behavior; past practices should be ignored, as looking into them would be a political nonstarter. Calling for oversight of this kind would have been too contentious in the past, but the new Speaker of the House \u2014 the third-highest position in the country \u2014 is an ally of Mr. Weah\u2019s and has previously said he would support such a move.\n\nMr. Weah faces a moment of consequence and a rare opportunity to build on Ms. Sirleaf\u2019s successes. She brought Liberia back from the dead. Now it\u2019s his turn to nurture the country\u2019s fledgling institutions by taking on its coercive, corrupt political culture.", "title": "Opinion | Liberia\u2019s Next Fight?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTRIPOLI, Libya \u2014 The Libyan Navy said on Wednesday that its Coast Guard had rescued at least 279 migrants off the coast of Libya, but that about 100 more were missing and feared dead.\n\nThe migrants, mostly Africans, had been packed into several vessels hoping to cross the Mediterranean and reach southern Europe. The missing appeared to have all been in the same dinghy, whose remnants were found near the city of Khoms, the navy said.\n\nSearch-and-rescue efforts continued for more than 12 hours in rough conditions, the navy said. All of the survivors, including 19 women and 17 children, were taken to a naval base in the capital, Tripoli, and were later handed over to Libya\u2019s anti-migration authority.\n\nThe United Nations migration agency estimates that more than 3,100 migrants died while trying to cross the Mediterranean in 2017, a number attributed to smugglers\u2019 use of small dinghies and other poor-quality vessels.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLibya descended into chaos after the 2011 uprising that toppled and killed the longtime dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The country has since become part of a common route to Europe for those fleeing poverty and conflict.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Contagious colleagues at work. Time-draining hospital visits.\n\nThousands of Americans nationwide are grappling with what officials say is turning out to be the worst flu season in nearly a decade. And New Yorkers are falling ill, too.\n\nOn the third week of January, there were 7,779 confirmed influenza cases and 1,759 people hospitalized in New York, the highest weekly numbers since the state began reporting them in 2004, according to the New York State Department of Health. In New York City, the flu has sent 3,015 people to the hospital since the season began in October, a 33 percent increase from this time last year.\n\nThe uptick has crowded emergency rooms across the state, forcing some hospitals to temporarily divert ambulances and hire more staff. Officials are urging New Yorkers to get vaccinated and some have called on the federal government to ratchet up its efforts in New York.\n\nThis flu season is \u201cpossibly tracking to be more severe than the 2014-2015 season, which was characterized as moderately severe,\u201d Brad Hutton, the deputy commissioner of public health at the state Department of Health, said. \u201cWe\u2019re moving toward it being a severe flu season.\u201d", "title": "Like Fevers, the Number of Flu Patients Is Rising", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "TUESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 We have new people joining us all the time, so this is a friendly reminder that when you see circled squares or shaded squares in a crossword grid, it is an important part of the theme. There are two ways to figure out the theme: You can solve the revealer so that you have a hint as to what might be contained in the circled or shaded squares, or you can solve as many of the circled or shaded squares as you need to in order to figure out the revealer. I prefer the latter because it\u2019s almost like hearing the punch line of a joke, but you do you. Solve the way you need to in order to appreciate the puzzle.\n\nEmily Carroll returns in her third time at bat in The New York Times Crossword and at first, I thought she was demolishing houses. That\u2019s one of the nice things about having the revealer toward the bottom of the grid. I have no statistical evidence of this, but I would bet that even if solvers don\u2019t necessarily start at 1A, most of us solve from top to bottom in some way. It\u2019s the way we read, so it would make sense. Putting the revealer at the bottom serves as that punch line, and it\u2019s an effective way to pull the theme together or at least send the solver off with a smile.\n\nMs. Carroll\u2019s puzzle is early week, so it wasn\u2019t terribly difficult to figure out the real theme to the puzzle, but I did get a good laugh out of the revealer. And that reminds me \u2014 it\u2019s time to take the Extremely Spunky Border terrier for a walk.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nFour styles of houses are broken in Ms. Carroll\u2019s puzzle, but her theme has nothing to do with demolition. When we finally get to the revealer at 57A \u2014 HOUSEBROKEN, clued as \u201cLike most pet dogs \u2026 or a hint to this puzzle\u2019s circled letters\u201d \u2014 we realize that Ms. Carroll has been playing with us. It\u2019s not the houses that are broken. It\u2019s the unscheduled elimination habits in our pets.", "title": "Like Most Pet Dogs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Mr. Mark measured up at 6-6.", "title": "Lindsey Housman, Steven Mark", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Wall Street is putting a trading axiom to the test. Investment banks often say that underwriting debt and equity issues for companies brings in trading activity, and vice versa. The latest results from the country\u2019s five big players \u2014 Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley \u2014 show that that\u2019s not necessarily the case.\n\nGoldman, which reported earnings on Wednesday, has over the past five years done a fine job bulking up the business of helping companies issue debt. The division raked in just shy of $3 billion last year, a 24 percent increase over 2013.\n\nIts traders, though, have not been as successful. A 38 percent drop in fixed-income, currency and commodity trading revenue over the same five-year period made Goldman the worst performer of the five banks. On average, the five endured an 11.4 percent decline.\n\nTrading revenue at Citigroup and JPMorgan declined too, albeit by a smaller percent, even as underwriting grew. Bank of America managed a slight increase in trading despite a small drop in underwriting.", "title": "Link Between Underwriting and Trading Is Put to the Test", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday, Joyce Arthur, executive director of the Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada, said the policy had been meant to ensure that the government would not be funding groups that undermine human rights. But she said the lack of clarity had allowed the policy to be hijacked by conservative groups pressing their own ideological agendas.\n\n\u201cIt was a no-brainer requirement,\u201d she said by phone from Vancouver. \u201cBut the wording needs clarification so the issue doesn\u2019t get misunderstood. Unfortunately, it has become a big distraction.\u201d\n\nThe Conservative opposition leader Andrew Scheer accused Mr. Trudeau this month of using the requirement to impose his own views on Canadians. Speaking at a meeting hosted by the Mississauga Board of Trade, he said community groups were expressing alarm that they would be unable to employ youths and provide services because of their beliefs. Among the groups affected was the Southern Alberta Bible Camp, which told CBC News, the Canadian broadcaster, that it would lose about $40,000 for six summer counselor positions.\n\nMr. Trudeau, who has sought to balance his own Roman Catholic religious views with his commitment to abortion rights, has called the reaction to the policy a \u201ckerfuffle.\u201d\n\nBoth he and the employment minister, Patty Hajdu, have stressed that the policy was not intended to target religious groups.\n\nSpeaking at a town-hall meeting in Hamilton, Ontario, last week, Mr. Trudeau affirmed that Canadians were entitled to their beliefs. And that\u2019s where we stand on that.\u201d\n\nIn 1988, Canada\u2019s Supreme Court struck down the country\u2019s then restrictive abortion law, which allowed only abortions approved by hospital committees. It\u2019s a fitting tie-in. During one recent season, her tag line during the show\u2019s title sequence was \u201cLife isn\u2019t all diamonds and ros\u00e9. But it should be.\u201d\n\nShe also uses her platform to champion causes important to her, like gay and lesbian equality, AIDS awareness and animal rights (she has seven dogs, two miniature ponies and eight swans). Last year she opened Vanderpump Dogs in Los Angeles, a rescue and shelter tricked out with luxurious trappings like velvet sofas and chandeliers.\n\nMs. Vanderpump ordered tea at the Plaza, but on the show she\u2019s best known for spilling it, aided by her quick wit and way with a bon mot. Upon seeing the hotel had yet to take down its Christmas trees a week into January, for example, she said, \u201cI liken Christmas decorations being up too long to watching a porno after an orgasm. It\u2019s just not the same.\u201d\n\nShe has honed a television persona charismatic enough to demand ample screen time without resorting to confrontational theatrics. \u201cI\u2019ve been accused of being cold or removed, but I think that\u2019s because I wasn\u2019t as volatile or I don\u2019t have a knee-jerk reaction,\u201d she said, her hands glistening with jewels and her lips glossy and pink like a glazed French confection.\n\nShe remembers the first time she watched two co-stars verbally spar during filming. \u201cI sat there and thought, I don\u2019t think I\u2019ve ever seen anything quite like this in my life,\u201d she said. \u201cAfter we stopped filming, I went to the elevator and thought, Oh God, I don\u2019t think I can do this. I phoned my husband and said, \u2018That was bizarre.\u2019\u201d\n\nShe paused and added: \u201cBut that was eight years ago.\u201d\n\nSince then, she has found herself at the center of plenty of arguments, broadcast for public consumption. And she hasn\u2019t made it out unscathed, either. At times she has been portrayed by her co-stars as outwardly warm but secretly Machiavellian. When a reporter suggested that maybe they\u2019re jealous of her position as the show\u2019s de facto star, she was too savvy to take the bait, perhaps proving her co-stars\u2019 point.", "title": "Lisa Vanderpump of \u2018Real Housewives\u2019 Sips Her Tea. And Spills Some, Too.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Ian Kerner, a psychotherapist and sexuality counselor, helps the Sugars answer a letter from a woman who calls herself \u201cFed Up With Fantasy.\u201d She writes, \u201cEver since I started being a sexual being I\u2019ve had terrible fantasies. Incest of every kind. Teachers having sex with their underage students. Gangbangs in public bathrooms. I cannot get turned on without thinking of these story lines.\u201d\n\n\u201cDid something bad happen to me that I have repressed so much I don\u2019t even have a hint of it?\u201d she asks. \u201cAnd how do I make it stop?\u201d\n\nDr. Kerner and the Sugars explore where dark fantasies come from and offer \u201cFed Up With Fantasy\u201d ways she can share them with her boyfriend. Dr. Kerner specializes in sex therapy and couples therapy. He\u2019s also the New York Times best-selling author of \u201cShe Comes First: The Thinking Man\u2019s Guide to Pleasuring a Woman.\u201d", "title": "Listen to \u2018Dear Sugars\u2019: Dark Fantasies Part 1 \u2014 With Dr. Ian Kerner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "How do I listen?\n\nIf you don\u2019t see an audio player on this page or to subscribe to \u201cDear Sugars\u201d for free, follow the instructions below.\n\nOn your iPhone or iPad:\n\nOpen the preloaded app called Podcasts; it has a purple icon. The company specialized in so-called artist presales, or selling batches of advance tickets \u2014 often around 8 percent of the inventory for a show \u2014 to fans. Presales serve, in part, as a way to thwart scalpers.\n\nSongkick contended that Live Nation was interfering in its business by blocking its access to presale tickets and by demanding fees on the sale of tickets that Songkick handled. But Live Nation, which countersued, argued that its contracts with venues gave it the right to determine how those tickets should be sold. Songkick\u2019s suit also accused Live Nation of threatening artists not to do business with Songkick.\n\nThe case was also punctuated by accusations of corporate espionage by Ticketmaster, and had voluminous court filings showing sometimes embarrassing internal communications among top Live Nation executives.", "title": "Live Nation Settles Suit With Ticketing Start-Up, Buying Its Assets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "LIVERPOOL, England \u2014 As Liverpool\u2019s players drifted back into position, fresh from celebrating the goal by Roberto Firmino that had restored their lead against Manchester City, J\u00fcrgen Klopp beckoned halfway across the field to his midfielder, Emre Can.\n\nThe chances of Klopp\u2019s being heard at that distance were slim. Anfield was in tumult, everyone\u2019s ears still ringing from the roar that had greeted the goal, the noise gathering strength as it washed down the stands. So Klopp, the Liverpool manager, had to resort to elaborate mime: turning to his left and pushing, then pointing at Can and lifting an imaginary weight onto his shoulders.\n\nCan got the message and relayed it. He turned to his teammates, just before Manchester City kicked off, and urged them to attack. Liverpool had the Premier League\u2019s unbeaten, previously untouchable, leader on the ropes. Klopp, through his chosen lieutenant, wanted his players to know that they must not ease up, not let this opportunity pass. Now was the time to go for the kill.", "title": "Liverpool Beats Manchester City but Barely Dents Its Invincible Aura", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "A top-floor unit on Driggs Avenue, renting for $3,000, was above a pizza place, but the apartment had high ceilings, exposed brick, a skylight and two similar-size bedrooms. Mr. Hutchinson and Mr. Solomon were interested. \u201cThere was an immediate reaction that we knew we were going to live here,\u201d Mr. Solomon said.\n\nStill, Williamsburg seemed so promising that they thought they might see something they liked even more.\n\nOn Bedford Avenue, they looked at a large two-bedroom railroad apartment that occupied a whole floor and included a dining room, for $3,100. But the layout seemed odd \u2014 one bedroom had two doors, one to the hallway and the other to the second bedroom \u2014 and the interior was rundown, with creaky floors.\n\nAnother apartment, on Graham Avenue, was within their budget at $2,850, but one bedroom was especially small. \u201cIt was an unfair distribution of size,\u201d Mr. Solomon said. Also, the apartment was above a deli and didn\u2019t feel homey.\n\nThey knew they wanted the apartment on Driggs, and Mr. Henwood suggested they not hesitate any longer. Mr. Hutchinson and Mr. Solomon used their parents as guarantors, paying a broker\u2019s fee of 15 percent of a year\u2019s rent, or $5,400. They moved in just before the school year started, in August.\n\nTheir apartment is comfortable and spacious, furnished primarily with hand-me-downs from Mr. Hutchinson\u2019s mother, as well as items from Ikea.", "title": "Living Way Off Campus, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The intent of the text messages would be to give real-time financial counseling, according to a solicitation document issued by the Education Department. The service would provide \u201cthe student loan customer with specific understanding of long-term dollars and cents ramification of making purchases using their student loan funds,\u201d the document states.\n\nThe program is part of the department\u2019s broader plan to modernize the system it uses to oversee 42 million borrowers annually. The card, for instance, would be a feature within the myStudentAid mobile app, which would allow students and their parents to complete federal aid applications from a phone and gain access to information about their loans, among other things, according to the document, which was prepared to solicit bids from banks and financial services providers.\n\nThe card industry has a long history of exploiting students on campus, charging fees at every turn. Higher One, in a particularly egregious example, aggressively marketed debit accounts littered with fees to college students \u2014 and was ordered to pay millions of dollars in restitution for deceptive marketing and improper disclosures.\n\nThose kinds of practices led the Obama administration to issue, in 2015, stronger regulations that limited the fees companies could charge, among other protections.\n\nThe solicitation lists several fees that cannot be charged to students, including those for annual membership, activation and account maintenance. It would allow up to three free withdrawals from out-of-network automated teller machines before fees kicked in.\n\nConsumer advocates and some Democratic senators, however, have voiced concerns beyond fees, including how students\u2019 spending patterns and other data would be used \u2014 and whether their spending could be restricted to certain categories. The solicitation document says the card will come with the ability to restrict its use to certain types of products and merchants, but the department said spending, while monitored, would not be restricted.\n\n\u201cWhile we support efforts to improve the financial aid distribution process, we have serious concerns about your proposal given the poor track record of such cards in the past,\u201d Senator Richard J. Durbin, a Democrat from Illinois, and four other senators wrote in a letter to Wayne Johnson, chief operating officer of the Federal Student Aid Office. They asked him to answer 19 questions by Jan. 30.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the absence of strict oversight and safeguards,\u201d they wrote, \u201cthese card programs can leave students and taxpayers vulnerable to exploitation.\u201d\n\nAnd while the solicitation from the Office of Federal Student Aid, known as F.S.A., lays out several restrictions for the financial services providers that will ultimately run the program, it also explicitly states how they stand to benefit: The payment card, the document reads, \u201cwill be the first step in exploring a new, meaningful way to build a stronger, lifetime relationship with F.S.A.\u2019s customers.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat language set off alarms for consumer advocates, who said the department was offering banks and card issuers an opportunity to lure in customers while they were young, while pushing the boundaries of what a federal student aid office should be.\n\n\u201cThat is incredibly problematic,\u201d said Colleen Campbell, the associate director for postsecondary education at the Center for American Progress, a liberal research group. \u201cStudents will be sharing all of their data with a company that is open to marketing other products to them.\u201d\n\nThe financial services providers in the program will need to receive permission from students to cross-market any other products. But how exactly will that work?\n\nDr. Johnson \u2014 a former chief executive officer of First Performance, a card payments company \u2014 said students wouldn\u2019t be asked to provide a one-time blanket permission to be sent solicitations, but instead would be asked case by case. So they might be asked if they were interested in a list of products of services and wouldn\u2019t receive more information unless they agreed.\n\nThe mantra is \u201ccustomer first, student first, protection first,\u201d Dr. Johnson said in an interview. \u201cAnd, oh, by the way, super cool stuff,\u201d he added, referring to the card\u2019s benefits.\n\nThe card is expected to incorporate several features. A student\u2019s parents would be able to load more money into another bucket on the card, and students would be able to make peer-to-peer payments. The program\u2019s developers also hope to incorporate budget options, enabling students to manage their spending.\n\nA student, for instance, might set a $200 monthly budget for groceries; when the student reached $190, he or she would be alerted with a text message saying the self-imposed limit was near.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe department said students at schools in the program would still be able to receive their money through existing methods \u2014 paper checks and direct deposit into their bank account or onto another prepaid card \u2014 if their schools offered those options.\n\nSeveral federal agencies already disburse benefits through prepaid cards, including the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Social Security Administration.\n\nDebbie Schwartz, a former marketing executive for a financial services firm and founder of a service called Road2College, said that even if the government kept fees and abuses in check, access to students\u2019 spending patterns and other data would be a boon to financial services providers.\n\nThat information, according the Education Department, will be owned by the providers, though how they use it will be restricted by the department.\n\n\u201cThe fact that they are giving the financial services companies the opportunity to get something into a student\u2019s hand backed by the federal government,\u201d Ms. Schwartz said, \u201cis a privilege.\u201d", "title": "Loan Program Plans to Offer Students Prepaid Bank Cards", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Mar-a-Lago, the Trump-owned private club where the president spends much of his time, charged up to $750 per person to spend New Year\u2019s Eve with him.\n\nAs we have noted, this all began with the festivities surrounding the inauguration, which were bankrolled by coal, oil, gas, chemical, technology and pharmaceutical companies that forked over a big chunk of the record $107 million raised for the inaugural events. Organizers aren\u2019t saying how much was spent and what was done with the leftover money \u2014 likely tens of millions of dollars \u2014 which they said would go to charity, USA Today reported on Thursday.\n\nBut what is clear is that Mr. Trump and Republicans in Congress have been doing corporate interests\u2019 bidding ever since.\n\nThe Trump transition\u2019s \u201cbeachhead teams,\u201d which essentially took control of federal departments and other agencies without needing Senate approval, bristled with lobbyists, some working inside the same agencies regulating their former industries. Cartoonishly self-interested cabinet members and senior advisers were drawn from the corporate elite Mr. Trump derided on the campaign trail. \u201cI\u2019m going to fight for every person in this country who believes government should serve the people \u2014 not the donors and special interests,\u201d Mr. Trump promised. Not so much.\n\nInstead, Mr. Trump got to work serving those special interests, signing executive orders gutting environmental, health and safety rules, sometimes as his industry masters looked on. Interested more in media attention than in governing, Mr. Trump stages televised meetings where he glowers \u201cApprentice\u201d-style and demands that Congress send him legislation to sign. What a perfect scenario for big Republican donors. They help write perks for their industries into the bill, then congressional leaders push it under the pen of a president who signs pretty much anything. Take the December tax \u201creform.\u201d It shortchanges low-income people, working families and the elderly to grant a big payday to multinational corporations, hedge funds, and the Trump family businesses. Mr. Trump doesn\u2019t seem to read legislation or much else, but there\u2019s no doubt that last part caught his eye.\n\nMr. Trump has become such a Washington creature that he\u2019s rooting for a return to earmarks, that opaque process in which legislators direct federal spending to their home districts and pet projects, like Republican Representative Don Young of Alaska\u2019s failed \u201cbridge to nowhere,\u201d a plan to waste more than $300 million on a mammoth bridge to an Alaska island of 50 inhabitants.", "title": "Opinion | Lobbyists Romp in Trump\u2019s Washington", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNow with that said, buckle up,\u201d Mr. Paul adds, cursing for effect.\n\nAs the video proceeds, Mr. Paul describes the reputation of the Aokigahara forest, which has become well-known in the past decade as a destination for people looking to kill themselves.\n\nIn 2016 alone, three North American films were set in the forest, which lies at the base of Mount Fuji, a sacred site in Japan.\n\nLocal folk tales have also fueled talk about the paranormal within the forest, a subject that Mr. Paul eagerly latches onto as he and his companions begin their trek with a guide.\n\nIn the next scene, they come across the body. The face is blurred; the rest is left visible. Mr. Paul and the others react in shock and Mr. Paul urges the guide to call the police.\n\n\u201cYo, are you alive?\u201d he shouts toward the body.\n\nAs a camera pans over the body, which Mr. Paul later says is only about 100 yards away from the parking lot, he describes its condition, and speculates that the death was recent. He apologizes to his viewers and says that suicide, depression and mental illness are not a joke.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
