View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs the group leaves the area where the body was found, Mr. Paul, who has television experience and has trained with comedy troupes, begins to engage in the kinds of behavior most familiar to his viewers: exaggerated reaction shots and nervous laughter. The tone soon becomes more antic as Mr. Paul and the others appear to try to lighten the mood.\n\nToward the end of the video, Mr. Paul says that his smiling and laughing \u201cis not a portrayal of how I feel about the circumstances,\u201d describing it as his coping mechanism.\n\nThe video, which was posted on Sunday, quickly received pushback online, as people reacted to Mr. Paul\u2019s decision to show the body and his capering afterward. Some shared numbers for suicide hotlines and told stories about their own struggles with mental illness.\n\nYouTube said in a statement that the video had violated its policies, which prohibit \u201cviolent or gory content posted in a shocking, sensational or disrespectful manner.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur hearts go out to the family of the person featured in the video,\u201d the statement said.\n\nMr. Paul\u2019s YouTube channel has more than 15 million subscribers, making him even more popular than his younger brother, Jake, who may be more well-known to those who do not regularly watch vlogs thanks to his own brushes with controversy.\n\nYouTube stars are often incentivized to post increasingly eye-catching footage in a bid for subscribers, who are attracted to more outlandish clips. After Jake Paul drew the attention of mainstream news outlets over the summer for, essentially, annoying his neighbors on camera, he posted another video in which he tried to convince people that he had been arrested, upping the ante after the surge of press.\n\nThe brothers\u2019 audiences are largely made up of younger people. Toward the end of the Japan video, Logan Paul runs into a young fan in the parking lot who is with an older chaperone.\n\n\u201cI have one piece of advice,\u201d he tells them, smiling and pointing to where the body is. \u201cDon\u2019t go over there.\u201d", "title": "Logan Paul, YouTube Star, Says Posting Video of Dead Body Was \u2018Misguided\u2019", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The new year has brought new questions about the long-term future of London Fashion Week Men\u2019s, where the latest round of shows began on Saturday. The now-conspicuous absence of big-league names on the schedule, as more and more brands opt to show mixed-gender collections during the women\u2019s wear season or reconsider their spending on the traditional show format, has led to a dwindling numbers of foreign buyers, media representatives and photographers at the twice-yearly event. And this season has been no exception.\n\nAt times the calendar, with a few Savile Row stalwarts but also emphatic offerings from emerging designers heavy on the styling and outrageous statements but ultimately light on creative or commercial finesse, felt peripheral to the wider international fashion ecosystem. Yet it also fizzed with displays of energy, ideas and talent that underscored why the British men\u2019s wear scene should not be discounted. Here, some of the best shows that defiantly flew the flag for the future:", "title": "London Men\u2019s Wear Shows Reflect on Race and Masculinity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In a filmed introduction to \u201cThis Is Cinerama\u201d (1952), the broadcaster Lowell Thomas didn\u2019t simply explain the wide-screen format that viewers were about to see. He narrated a history of art, from cave painting to the Sistine Chapel to early movies. Cinerama, he promised, would be the next step in that evolution: \u201can entirely new medium, which we believe is going to revolutionize the technique of motion picture storytelling.\u201d\n\nHis prediction proved only partly true. Cinerama, in its original form, lasted only about a decade, but it paved the way for enduring wide-screen formats. On Sunday, on what the Museum of Modern Art is calling Cinerama Day, Cinerama will return to New York, the city where it was unveiled.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Cinerama films are hardly the rarest or most artistically accomplished movies in MoMA\u2019s annual To Save and Project series, which also includes films from the innovative 1930s studio director William K. Howard and the American premiere of \u201cEight Hours Don\u2019t Make a Day,\u201d a television mini-series from Rainer Werner Fassbinder.\n\nBut the Cinerama movies highlight some of the questions facing modern film preservation. Is it worth restoring films that can\u2019t be seen properly? Only three theaters on Earth \u2014 in Los Angeles, Seattle and Bradford, England \u2014 can still screen the first form of Cinerama, which required three projectors running simultaneously, each aimed at a different part of an enormous screen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd assuming that you don\u2019t care to travel, what\u2019s the best way to see these movies? The two titles showing Sunday, \u201cThis Is Cinerama\u201d and \u201cWindjammer: The Voyage of the Christian Radich\u201d \u2014 the lone picture made in a competing but similar format, Cinemiracle \u2014 will screen in new digital restorations that take pains to approximate the look and feel of what moviegoers saw in the 1950s. But they aren\u2019t quite the genuine article.", "title": "Long Before Imax, the Curious Tale of Cinerama", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "AOKIGAHARA FOREST, Japan \u2014 Long before the YouTube star Logan Paul brought renewed notoriety to this primeval forest at the foot of Mount Fuji by posting a video of a body hanging from a tree, local officials fought to reverse Aokigahara\u2019s bleak reputation as one of Japan\u2019s top suicide destinations.\n\nThe forest looms large in the national consciousness, emblematic of a persistent suicide problem in Japan, which has one of the highest suicide rates of developed countries despite improvements in recent years.\n\nAt Aokigahara, signs at the foot of walking paths promote a suicide hotline. \u201cLife is a precious thing that your parents gave to you,\u201d the signs read. Another offers a number for help with debt. Locals patrol the forest, talking to people who are alone or show signs of depression or suicidal plans.\n\nAlthough officials believe such measures have helped to reduce the number of suicides committed in the forest to about 30 a year, down from 100 a decade ago, they worry that the fresh publicity could attract more of the hopeless.", "title": "Long Before Video, Japanese Fought Suicide in the \u2018Sea of Trees\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Recently discovered artifacts of colonial America\u2019s artisanal history will be unveiled to the public on Thursday at the New York Ceramics and Glass Fair.\n\nAfter being found buried in a privy shaft in the Old City district of Philadelphia, over 10 pieces of slipware pottery from the 18th century will displayed in a show called \u201cBuried Treasure: New Discoveries in Philadelphia Slipware from the Collection of the Museum of the American Revolution.\u201d\n\nThe ceramics were uncovered during an excavation of the grounds of the new Museum of the American Revolution in Philadelphia. Archaeologists from the Commonwealth Heritage Group recovered almost 85,000 artifacts from the site between 2014 and 2016.", "title": "Long Buried Colonial Pottery to Make Its Modern Debut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Rubinstein is one of four women who spoke on the record, describing unwanted sexual contact by Mr. Edelstein since his arrival in 2002 at Long Wharf, a respected nonprofit theater in New Haven that has had several productions mounted on Broadway. Six other former employees, women and men, described frequent sexually explicit remarks in the workplace by Mr. Edelstein, a prominent figure in American theater circles.\n\nLong Wharf officials, after receiving questions from The New York Times, said Monday that Mr. Edelstein had been put on administrative leave, effective immediately. The staff was summoned to a meeting Monday and the board to a meeting on Tuesday.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThese allegations are deeply upsetting,\u201d said Laura Pappano, the chairwoman of the Long Wharf board of trustees. \u201cWe simply cannot and will not tolerate behavioral misconduct in the theater workplace.\u201d\n\nMr. Edelstein did not respond to a request for comment. Ms. Pappano responded on the theater\u2019s behalf to the questions from The Times, which were also emailed to Mr. Edelstein; the theater\u2019s managing director, Joshua Borenstein; and its spokesman, Steven Scarpa.\n\nThis article is based on interviews with 24 current and former Long Wharf employees and collaborators. Most of them said that Mr. Edelstein is prone to sexually explicit language in the workplace. And several former employees said some administrators and board members have been aware of concerns about Mr. Edelstein\u2019s behavior for years \u2014 a claim that theater leaders called \u201cmisleading.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe theater is complicit in this behavior,\u201d said Meghan Kane, a former assistant director of production at Long Wharf. \u201cThere are other administrators that know about his inappropriate behavior; there are board members.\u201d She added, \u201cIt\u2019s not just about one person \u2014 it\u2019s about an entire company of people.\u201d\n\nMs. Kane said she was stunned when, in 2011, Mr. Edelstein commented on her body during a routine meeting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI had a breast-reduction surgery when I was there, and one of the most horrifying situations I was in was him saying, \u2018Why did you cut off the most beautiful two things about you?\u2019 in front of a big room,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Pappano said the suggestion that Mr. Edelstein\u2019s conduct was reported to administrators and board members was an \u201covergeneralization.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe theater and its board immediately addressed the incidents it knew about,\u201d said Ms. Pappano, who is also a freelance journalist who has regularly contributed work to The Times.\n\n\u201cIt is misleading and unfair to imply it did not respond to occurrences that were never reported and of which it had no notice,\u201d she said. \u201cWe know of no instance in which a report was made and not acted upon.\u201d She said the theater had not received any complaints of sexual misconduct since Ms. Rubinstein\u2019s in 2006.\n\nIn interviews, several women described sexual misconduct and crude remarks by Mr. Edelstein. Halley Feiffer, a playwright and actress, said she was groped by him in 2008, when she was performing in a revival he directed of \u201cSome Americans Abroad,\u201d a comedy by Richard Nelson, at Second Stage, an Off Broadway theater.\n\n\u201cWe were at an opening night party, and I walked by him and he grabbed my butt,\u201d Ms. Feiffer said. \u201cI remember thinking that I must have made it up, or that\u2019s my fault for walking so close to him, and then thinking I have to be really careful around him, but he runs a theater and I want to be a playwright and I want him to produce my plays one day, so that\u2019s why I never said anything or did anything \u2014 I wanted to be in his good graces because he\u2019s powerful.\u201d\n\nAnnie DiMartino, the former head of the Long Wharf education department, said that in 2010, \u201cwe were sitting at a holiday party \u2014 and once Gordon has some drinks he becomes very loose \u2014 and he grabbed my hand and placed it on his crotch under the table.\u201d\n\nLaura Collins-Hughes, now a freelance theater critic at The Times, said that in 2003, when she was attending a Long Wharf gala as the arts editor for The New Haven Register, \u201che kissed me on the lips, and his lips were wet, and it was lingering and disgusting.\u201d She did not report the incident to the theater.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLong Wharf is among the nation\u2019s important regional theaters, a distinction recognized in 1978, when it became one of the first regional theaters honored with a special Tony Award for its work. It regularly develops new work and has credits on 19 Broadway productions, including this season\u2019s \u201cMeteor Shower,\u201d a comedy by Steve Martin starring Amy Schumer that closed Jan. 21.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Edelstein received $235,000 in compensation in the 2016 fiscal year, according to an I.R.S. filing. He has directed three plays on Broadway, including most recently a 2012 production of the Athol Fugard drama \u201cThe Road to Mecca.\u201d\n\nIn 2004, the theater\u2019s props supervisor, Jackie Farrelly, filed a discrimination complaint with the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities, objecting after Mr. Edelstein had used the word \u201cskanky\u201d to refer to an actress who irritated him. In 2005, the theater\u2019s administrators signed an agreement denying any injury to Ms. Farrelly but agreeing to make a $500 donation to the Connecticut Women\u2019s Education and Legal Fund, and Mr. Edelstein signed a letter to Ms. Farrelly that said, in its entirety, \u201cI apologize that my using the word \u2018skanky\u2019 caused you discomfort or that you found it offensive,\u201d according to documents viewed by The Times.\n\nDeb Clapp, a former Long Wharf general manager who is now the executive director of the League of Chicago Theaters, gave Ms. Farrelly the money to file the complaint.\n\n\u201cI told her I thought she should do that because no one had done it in the past, and I thought it would be a way to document the behavior that was making women uncomfortable,\u201d Ms. Clapp said.\n\nA former assistant and a former audio supervisor at Long Wharf, both of them lesbians, said Mr. Edelstein also made a habit of inquiring about their sex lives.\n\n\u201cIf I had a dollar for every time he propositioned me and my partner at the time, I would be a very rich woman,\u201d said Corrine Livingston, the former audio supervisor. \u201cHe would make sexual comments all the time. He would talk about wanting to have threesomes and hook up.\u201d\n\nMs. Livingston said she finally complained in 2013, when, while discussing circumcision and eunuchs at a tech rehearsal, Mr. Edelstein \u201cslapped me on the shoulder and asked me when I got my balls cut off.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd, according to two former employees, when Albertus Magnus College, a Catholic liberal arts school in New Haven founded by the Dominican Sisters of Peace, announced that it was giving a 2017 honorary degree to Mr. Edelstein, he twice blurted out, in an effort at humor that some employees found unfunny, \u201cI had sex with all the nuns.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Pappano confirmed the incident but said the board had acted. \u201cAfter it was reported that Mr. Edelstein joked about having sex with nuns, he was reprimanded by representatives of the Board of Trustees and told that such behavior was out of line and would not be tolerated,\u201d she said.\n\nSome theater officials were made aware of concerns from other women. Ms. DiMartino, the former education department head, said she had told the theater\u2019s spokesman, Mr. Scarpa, the night Mr. Edelstein placed her hand on his crotch. (Ms. DiMartino and Mr. Scarpa were dating at the time.)\n\nMs. Rubinstein said she spoke about Mr. Edelstein\u2019s behavior toward her with Mr. Borenstein, then the theater\u2019s general manager, as well as members of the board. Joan Channick, who was the managing director at Long Wharf from 2006 to 2008 and is now a theater management professor at Yale, recalled that before she accepted the Long Wharf job, the leaders of the search committee and the theater board called to disclose to her that \u201csomething inappropriate of a sexual nature\u201d had happened between Mr. Edelstein and Ms. Rubinstein.\n\n\u201cGordon was apologetic and regretful, and we talked about the fact that this kind of behavior could not happen again,\u201d Ms. Channick said. She said there were no new complaints against him during her time at the theater.\n\nIn 2007, Ms. Rubinstein left Long Wharf \u2014 she was unhappy that Mr. Edelstein had reassigned a play slot she was expecting to oversee, an act she viewed as retaliation. She moved to San Diego, where she now teaches acting and directing at the University of California, San Diego. In an exit interview with Ms. Channick, she said \u201cshe felt that she had no choice but to leave,\u201d Ms. Channick recalled.\n\nMs. Pappano defended the theater\u2019s handling of Ms. Rubinstein\u2019s complaint, citing steps including mandatory counseling sessions for Mr. Edelstein.\n\n\u201cFrom the moment Kim Rubinstein approached Josh Borenstein with allegations of sexual harassment in May 2006, Mr. Borenstein took the charges extremely seriously,\u201d Ms. Pappano said. \u201cHe met with her on six occasions. Ms. Rubinstein relayed to Mr. Borenstein that she had had a consensual affair with Mr. Edelstein in the past. She reported to Mr. Borenstein that she initially encouraged Mr. Edelstein\u2019s advances. The lurid account you now offer differs materially and in tone with the allegations she brought to Long Wharf 11 years ago.\u201d\n\nMs. Rubinstein disputed that characterization, saying that although she had slept with Mr. Edelstein once years before working at the theater, their relationship at the theater was never consensual and she never encouraged Mr. Edelstein\u2019s advances. \u201cThat is absolutely not true and makes me so mad and upset,\u201d she said.", "title": "Long Wharf Theater Leader Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The board of trustees of Long Wharf Theater on Tuesday evening fired the longtime artistic director Gordon Edelstein over accusations of sexual misconduct.\n\nThe board of the New Haven theater acted one day after The New York Times published an article detailing the allegations by multiple women, four of whom accused Mr. Edelstein of groping or other forms of unwanted touching. Several former employees also said Mr. Edelstein frequently used sexually explicit language toward and about women in the workplace.\n\n\u201cThe board of trustees voted to terminate Gordon Edelstein, effective immediately,\u201d Laura Pappano, the board chairwoman, said in an interview. She said Mr. Edelstein had been barred from the theater\u2019s premises as of Monday.\n\nMs. Pappano said that board would hire an independent agency to conduct a review of the theater\u2019s procedures for reporting misconduct, and that \u201cimplicit in that\u201d is a desire to understand what went wrong during Mr. Edelstein\u2019s tenure. \u201cWe want to do better,\u201d she said. \u201cAll of this reporting has brought to our attention things that we did not know about, and we feel strongly that going forward we want to know.\u201d", "title": "Long Wharf Theater\u2019s Artistic Director Fired Over Sexual Misconduct Accusations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "A novel that unpacks a supposedly troubled period in Picasso\u2019s life, \u201cCooking for Picasso\u201d describes the fictional relationship and mutual inspiration between a young cook and the artist in the South of France in 1936. Mr. Haralabides, who is a native of Greece, owns Rebuild Workshop, a design-build firm that specializes in brownstones. He viewed a renovation project with gusto.\n\n\u201cIf we put some money in and fix it, we will have a great house,\u201d he said. He and Ms. Chou had a budget, for everything, of about $2 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey wanted a \u201cdiamond in the rough, and that\u2019s hard to find in brownstone Brooklyn these days,\u201d said their agent, Kirsten Syrett, who works as a team with Sarah Chamberlin. (They were at Halstead Property then, and are now at Compass.)\n\nMr. Haralabides and Ms. Chou, finding little they could afford, decided to partner with their friends, another couple also searching for a Brooklyn home. One prospect was a charming but decrepit \u2014 it lacked running water \u2014 three-family house on Sixth Avenue in Park Slope, an estate sale asking $2.3 million.\n\nThe idea for both families to purchase something together was short-lived; both wanted the top floor and the garden. \u201cWe were going to flip a coin,\u201d Ms. Chou said. \u201cWe saw obstacles brewing.\u201d Nobody wanted to risk their friendship if the deal soured.\n\nMr. Haralabides and Ms. Chou\u2019s friends ended up buying a condominium in Clinton Hill. The Park Slope house \u2014 too expensive to go it alone \u2014 later sold for $2.2 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt around the same time, Mr. Haralabides and Ms. Chou saw a small two-family \u2014 just 15 feet wide \u2014 on busy Ninth Street in Park Slope, asking $1.5 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt faced a 24-hour CVS Pharmacy. In their price range \u201cthey weren\u2019t going to get a beautiful tree-lined block,\u201d Ms. Syrett said.\n\nThe couple were less bothered by the traffic than with the unappealing view. The house was in terrible condition, which for them was a plus.\n\n\u201cThe termites had chewed through the plaster,\u201d Ms. Syrett said. \u201cIt was like lace. They were fearless,\u201d she said of the couple.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Haralabides and Ms. Chou offered the asking price, but were outbid by a buyer offering $1.55 million.\n\nWeary of continuing their search, they briefly considered a just-renovated Prospect Heights two-family for $2.3 million, where they could move right in.\n\nThis idea, too, was short-lived. \u201cWe wanted to take advantage of our skills and our vision,\u201d Mr. Haralabides said. He also worried about the quality of construction in a house redone by somebody else. Besides, \u201cif we bought something like that, I would miss all the fun,\u201d he said.\n\nAn unappealing listing appeared on Eighth Avenue in Park Slope \u2014 a modest three-family rowhouse for $1.6 million. At one point, the stoop had been removed, and a front extension built, which had been home to a deli.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. They increased their bid to $1.67 million, matching the other offer.\n\nThe house, in the Park Slope Historic District Extension, was just 16 feet wide. \u201cWe did quick sketches to see how many rooms we could fit inside,\u201d Mr. Haralabides said. \u201cTo put three bedrooms and two bathrooms, it is a little bit like a Swiss watch. Everything is small.\u201d\n\nThey bought the house last spring, using all of their savings and borrowing from their retirement funds, and set to work. \u201cDemolition is an understatement,\u201d Mr. Haralabides said. \u201dWe left brick and some of the joists.\u201d\n\nThey chose two small bathrooms over one large one, and added noise insulation between rooms, ceilings and floors. \u201cIt costs very little, but developers don\u2019t do it,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is hard to fix once you move in.\u201d\n\nThe house, which includes a rental unit on the ground floor, is now nearly completed. The family arrived in late December and immediately installed baby gates for Olivia, who is eager to explore the stairs.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very rewarding to go through all this effort,\u201d Mr. Haralabides said.", "title": "Looking for a Fixer-Upper in Park Slope", "authors": ["Joyce Cohen", "The Hunt"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The seizures marked the latest action in an effort by the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to repatriate looted antiquities discovered in New York City to their countries of origin.\n\nImage Mr. Steinhardt Credit Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press\n\nOver the last year, Mr. Vance has roiled the city\u2019s rarefied art world, seizing work from major museums, auction houses and private collections. In recent months, he has returned three ancient statues to Lebanon, a mosaic from one of Caligula\u2019s ships to Italy, and a second-century Buddhist sculpture to Pakistan.\n\nLast month, Mr. Vance formed an antiquities-trafficking bureau to continue the work, putting it under the leadership of Matthew Bogdanos, an assistant district attorney who is a classics scholar and has headed most of the investigations.\n\nBut the district attorney\u2019s aggressive efforts have drawn criticism from collectors, who have argued such disputes over the provenance of ancient pieces would be better handled in a civil courts. Mr. Vance has been using a state law that allows prosecutors to return stolen property to its owner, though so far he has not brought charges against anyone for possessing the works.\n\nAmong the pieces seized on Friday from Mr. Steinhardt was a Greek white-ground attic lekythos \u2014 or oil vessel \u2014 from the fifth century B.C., depicting a funeral scene with the figures of a woman and a youth, according to the search warrant. It is worth at least $380,000.\n\nAlso seized were Proto-Corinthian figures from the seventh century B.C., depicting an owl and a duck, together worth about $250,000. The other pieces included an Apulian terra-cotta flask in the shape of an African head from the fourth century B.C.; an Ionian sculpture of a ram\u2019s head from the sixth century; and an attic aryballos, a vessel for oil or perfume, from the early fifth century. The objects were all bought in the last 12 years for a total cost of $1.1 million, according to the warrants.", "title": "Looted Antiques Seized From Billionaire\u2019s Home, Prosecutors Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Lorell Marie Guerrero and Luis Alberto Gonzalez were married Jan. 27 at Estancia Culinaria, an events space on an avocado farm in Redland, Fla. He graduated with distinction from the University of Florida.", "title": "Lorell Guerrero, Luis Gonzalez", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "TANC\u00cdTARO, Mexico \u2014 The road to this agricultural town winds through the slums and cartel-controlled territory of Michoac\u00e1n, ground zero for Mexico\u2019s drug war, before arriving at a sight so strange it can seem like a mirage.\n\nFifteen-foot stone turrets are staffed by men whose green uniforms belong to no official force. Beyond them, a statue of an avocado bears the inscription \u201cavocado capital of the world.\u201d And beyond the statue is Tanc\u00edtaro, an island of safety and stability amid the most violent period in Mexico\u2019s history.\n\nLocal orchard owners, who export over $1 million in avocados per day, mostly to the United States, underwrite what has effectively become an independent city-state. Self-policing and self-governing, it is a sanctuary from drug cartels as well as from the Mexican state.\n\nBut beneath the calm is a town under tightfisted control, enforced by militias accountable only to their paymasters. Drug addiction and suicide are soaring, locals say, as the social contract strains.", "title": "Losing Faith in the State, Some Mexican Towns Quietly Break Away", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nIn the first season of our video series, Conception, we chronicled what it\u2019s like to become a mother.\n\nDrawing on more than 1,300 responses to a call-out, we told six intimate stories about women with experiences ranging from postpartum depression to the beauty of raising a child you didn\u2019t quite expect. Now, we\u2019re asking you to help us envision the next iteration of the series.\n\nIn season two, we\u2019ll explore parenting in 2018.\n\nRaising a child in the context of today\u2019s political, social and economic climate is wrought with a new set of challenges. We\u2019re looking to hear from all types of parents \u2014 from all over the world and all points on the political spectrum \u2014 with unique perspectives about how those challenges have influenced their approach.\n\nWe\u2019d like to hear about the issues that are affecting your families, biological or otherwise, including but not limited to: race, immigration, international conflicts or war, the ongoing gun debate, the opioid crisis, mental health, maternal health, gender identity, social media, sexual violence and the #MeToo era, the changing nature of work, infertility, incarceration and income inequality. We\u2019re also interested in stories from those who have chosen not to become parents.\n\nWe invite you to share your story by clicking on the form below.\n\n\n\nThe project will be an animated, audio-driven exploration.", "title": "What\u2019s It Like to Raise a Child in 2018? We Want to Hear From You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "BJ\u2019s Wholesale Club, another rival, encouraged Sam\u2019s Club customers to join its program, noting in a statement that there was \u201can immediate increase\u201d in new memberships after the Sam\u2019s Club closings. BJ\u2019s, which has 215 clubs in 16 states, also said that it has \u201chad numerous inquiries from Sam\u2019s Club employees\u201d about obtaining jobs.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Walmart said it would raise its minimum starting wage to $11 an hour from $9 while also expanding maternity and family leave benefits and offering bonuses of up to $1,000. But the glow of that announcement faded just hours later, when the Sam\u2019s Club closings were revealed not by an announcement from Walmart but rather through social media posts from confused and increasingly irate customers and employees.\n\nWalmart was accused of using its pay announcement as a shield to cover up the shutdowns.\n\nThe abruptness of the closings contributed to consumer frustration. Typically, companies warn investors and shoppers \u2014 and employees \u2014 that they will be closing stores far in advance. In an interview on Thursday, John Furner, the chief executive of Sam\u2019s Club, did not go into detail about the reasons for the unusually sudden move.\n\n\u201cThere were a few locations where we felt there was no easy way to keep them open,\u201d he said, adding that some of the stores will remain open for a few weeks.\n\nMr. Furner said that Sam\u2019s Club wanted to inform its employees of the closures before notifying the public. But many of the thousands of workers who will be affected were unaware when they showed up to locked stores on Thursday.\n\nNot all employees at the affected stores will be out of a job. Walmart hopes to find positions for displaced workers at other Sam\u2019s Club locations. Up to a dozen stores will be retrofitted into e-commerce fulfillment centers.\n\n\u201cWe made a deliberate decision to prioritize employees,\u201d Mr. Furner said. \u201cI am not going to second-guess and change my mind at this point.\u201d", "title": "Loyal Sam\u2019s Club Members Lament the Loss of a Trusted Friend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLupita Nyong\u2019o, the Academy Award-winning actress and voice of Maz Kanata in \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens,\u201d will write her debut children\u2019s book \u201cSulwe\u201d for Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers next January. The picture book is aimed at readers between the ages of 5 and 7. An illustrator has not yet been announced.\n\n\u201cSulwe,\u201d which means \u201cstar\u201d in Ms. Nyong\u2019o\u2019s native language, Luo, is the story of a 5-year-old girl growing up in Kenya. In the book, Sulwe has the darkest skin color in her family, a fact that makes her uncomfortable and determined to find a way to lighten her skin. As the story unfolds Sulwe embarks on a whimsical adventure in the night sky that, coupled with advice from her mother, helps her see beauty differently.\n\nFor Ms. Nyong\u2019o, the decision to touch on these heavy and often difficult themes in a children\u2019s book was obvious. The story plants seeds in a child\u2019s mind, allowing for later access to lessons that children \u201cdon\u2019t necessarily recognize when they are reading the books,\u201d said Ms. Nyong\u2019o in an interview. When thinking about her own journey into acceptance and self-love, Ms. Nyong\u2019o cited reading with her mother as critical to her development.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLike Sulwe, Ms. Nyong\u2019o struggled with her complexion and self-image as a child. Growing up, she remembers becoming more aware of herself in grade school and caring about the opinions of others. It was around that time that she also noticed the language people outside of her family used to describe her \u201cbrown and pretty,\u201d lighter skinned sister.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Nyong\u2019o candidly acknowledged being self-conscious of her darker skin in an unforgettable speech in 2014. She then used her remarks to deliver a powerful message about the importance of race and representation in Hollywood and beyond. She also addressed a young fan who decided against lightening her skin after witnessing Ms. Nyong\u2019o\u2019s success as an actress.", "title": "Lupita Nyong\u2019o to Publish a Children\u2019s Book", "authors": ["Lovia Gyarkye"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "New York City Transit officials reportedly pressured staff members to expand the number of subway delays that could be attributed to Con Edison power issues in advance of a public event where Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo placed responsibility on the utility company to improve subway reliability.\n\nThe inflated numbers were reported in The Daily News, which obtained internal emails between Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials and Mr. Cuomo\u2019s press office from July 25 to Aug. 9. The emails reportedly show that transit officials broadened the definition of power-related delays to include circuit failures and other incidents, like when a person was on the track and the power was intentionally shut off. The New York Times has not seen the emails, but transit officials have not disputed their authenticity.\n\nUnder the broader definition, Mr. Cuomo, during the Association for a Better New York breakfast on July 27, was able to say there had been 32,000 power-related delays in the previous 12 months. The actual number was closer to 8,000, The Daily News reported.\n\n\u201cThe M.T.A. doesn\u2019t control the power, Con Edison does,\u201d Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, said at the breakfast. \u201cCon Edison has a duty to safely, prudently and effectively provide electricity that powers the subway system.\u201d", "title": "M.T.A. May Have Inflated Number of Subway Power Delays", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 Mac Knight, a daily commenter on Wordplay and friend, died Jan. 28 after a 10 year battle with multiple myeloma. He was 65.\n\nImage Credit Courtesy of the Knight family\n\nA retired fire battalion chief who lived in Washington State, Mac loved his wife, Merrilee, his sons, Micheal, Matthew and Martin, his grandchildren, reading, crosswords, photography and probably much more, knowing him.\n\nWe got to know each other a bit through Facebook, and I truly admired his love for his family, his intellectual curiosity and his supportiveness.\n\nThroughout his illness, he made every effort to post a daily positive thought on Wordplay, and he will be missed.", "title": "Mac Knight, 1952 \u2014 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "CALAIS, France \u2014 President Emmanuel Macron of France on Tuesday came to Calais, the port city at the center of France\u2019s migrant problem, to defend his policies as a mix of benevolence and firmness against critics who have accused him of inhumanity.\n\nWith France receiving a record number of asylum claims \u2014 100,000 last year \u2014 Mr. Macron has been under increasing fire, especially from the left, for betraying France\u2019s values.\n\nHis interior minister has been criticized for promoting searches of illegal migrants in emergency shelters and stepping up deportations. Police have been accused of ripping blankets away from freezing migrants.\n\nEven members of Mr. Macron\u2019s own cultlike political movement, La R\u00e9publique en Marche, have expressed uneasiness with their leader for the first time.", "title": "Macron Defends Migration Policy in France, Walking a Fine Line", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Macron imbibed from his mentor, the late philosopher Paul Ricoeur, a belief in the transforming power of the individual will. As proof, the young president can point to his own quick rise to the top, a stunning success that undergirds many of his pronouncements.\n\nSimilarly, the changes he has pushed through so far \u2014 like his lightening of the mammoth French labor code, with barely a whimper from the opposition \u2014 only buttress the narrative of individual determination, which he now hopes to infuse in his fellow citizens.\n\nIt is an unusual position for a French politician, who for generations have emphasized the protective power of the state \u2014 and the proof of any success will come only with a significant drop in the stubborn 10-percent jobless rate, elusive so far. But already surveys show higher levels of confidence among business executives than have been seen in many years.\n\nThat is so even though Mr. Macron\u2019s cadre of technocrats are \u201cincredibly far from an electorate that demands protection,\u201d Mr. Perrineau, the political scientist, said in the Le Un interview. Yet Mr. Macron\u2019s poll numbers are climbing again, after a summer trough.\n\nBut there are challenges ahead. Mr. Macron may not be so lucky with his next intended shock to the French system, a change to the country\u2019s generous unemployment compensation system, scheduled to be negotiated beginning next week.\n\nAlready opposition politicians have reacted furiously to a leaked government document that merely spells out what Mr. Macron promised during his campaign: tighter controls over those seeking compensation, including sanctions and cutoffs for those who refuse more than two \u201cdecent\u201d job offers.\n\nThe unions are also unhappy about another Macron promise that appears likely to be on the table in the upcoming negotiations, a vow to make unemployment insurance \u201cuniversal,\u201d opening it up to independent workers, shopkeepers, artisans and others.", "title": "Macron Opens Year Pulling No Punches With Journalists, or Anyone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Old Forester, the bourbon brand, has introduced a collection of cocktail components meant for the perfect old-fashioned. Jackie Zykan, the company\u2019s master taster, helped create the three kinds of bitters ($11.50 each), in cherry-tobacco, cinnamon-black tea and citrus flavors; two syrups ($8.50 each), Demerara and citrus; and a tincture of smoked sea salt and black pepper ($7.50). All are suited for an old-fashioned or other cocktails. They\u2019re made by Bourbon Barrel Foods, a Louisville company known for its condiments: Old Forester Cocktail Provisions, store.oldforester.com and bourbonbarrelfoods.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Made for the Perfect Drink", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "SHANGHAI \u2014 One new drug promises to stop cancer from spreading to other organs. Another would treat blood cancer. A third would use the body\u2019s immune system to kill tumors.\n\nAll three show encouraging results, and need just one more step to be approved for use in the United States. The drugs have something else in common: They were created in China.\n\nFor years, China\u2019s drug industry concentrated on replicating Western medicines. Getting new drugs approved was a frustrating and time-consuming process. Companies thought plowing millions of dollars into research and development was risky and stuck to safer revenue streams.\n\nThe country is now pushing to play a bigger role in the global drug industry. Millions of people in China have cancer or diabetes, and the government has made pharmaceutical innovation a national priority. Officials have promised to speed up drug approvals, and to reverse a brain drain by luring scientists back home. The authorities are providing land, grants and tax breaks, and investing in research.", "title": "Made in China: New and Potentially Lifesaving Drugs", "authors": ["Sui-Lee Wee"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDOGS AT THE PERIMETER\n\nBy Madeleine Thien\n\n253 pp. W.W. Norton. Paper, $15.95.\n\nBorders are porous in Madeleine Thien\u2019s novel \u201cDogs at the Perimeter,\u201d both in the world and in the mind. The narrator is a neurological researcher whose carefully compartmentalized memories of her childhood in Cambodia living under the Khmer Rouge \u2014 the communist guerrillas whose reign of terror in the 1970s left an estimated 1.7 million dead \u2014 start to leak into her present day after a colleague disappears in search of a brother lost, like hers, in her home country. Timelines converge; suddenly nothing separates the woman in a lab in Montreal, sharing with her son the beauty of a neuron \u201clithe as a starburst,\u201d from the 8-year-old girl gazing up at a swarm of airplanes over Phnom Penh as the guerrillas close in.\n\nTo navigate the slippage in her mind, she turns to case studies of brain damage \u2014 a patient who \u201cceases to recognize faces, including her own,\u201d and a sufferer of asomatognosia, unable to detect the physical boundaries of her body while \u201cher thoughts continued, anchored to nothing.\u201d She recalls how, as a child in Phnom Penh, she gave all her dolls the same name: Vesna, after Vesna Vulovic, a Serbian flight attendant who survived a jetliner explosion in 1972, falling 33,000 feet over what was then Czechoslovakia . She even tapes a picture of Vesna \u2014 \u201clike a drop of rain or a very tiny bird, someone whom the gods had overlooked\u201d \u2014 to her wall when she arrives in Canada as a refugee, \u201cashamed that I had lived.\u201d\n\nHer own name, the name her parents gave her, is never revealed. Early on, a Khmer Rouge soldier urges her to \u201cbecome someone else\u201d and calls her Mei, an act of both erasure and protection, freeing her from the crimes of her educated parents. (\u201cFamilies are a disease of the past,\u201d says the Angkar, the Khmer Rouge leadership.) Later, in a foster home in Canada, she is reborn again as Janie. Both names hover over her awkwardly, like aliases. Once, \u201cin the temple schools, a new name had been a rite of passage, a bridge from one shore of life to the next,\u201d she muses. Now, \u201cnames were empty syllables, signifying nothing, lost as easily as a suit of clothes, a brother or a sister, an entire world.\u201d\n\nThe revision of history and the dismantling of the self under communism were central themes in Thien\u2019s 2016 novel of the Cultural Revolution, \u201cDo Not Say We Have Nothing,\u201d which was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize. \u201cDogs at the Perimeter,\u201d first published in Canada in 2011, reads like a seed of the later novel: contrapuntal and elegiac in tone, with a white heat beneath. Where \u201cDo Not Say We Have Nothing\u201d is symphonic and expansive, \u201cDogs at the Perimeter\u201d turns inward, to the workings of a mind in flight from itself.\n\nSuch are Thien\u2019s gifts that she can write lyrically about horror without stripping it of force. When bombs fall on Phnom Penh, Janie registers her brother\u2019s screaming as \u201ca wide emptiness, a pressure in the air blinding me, and in the darkness I hear a strange, familiar ticking \u2014 insects, the typewriter, a clock counting time.\u201d The hollowed-out bodies of refugees evoke \u201can exhumed cemetery.\u201d A dying friend appears insubstantial, \u201cas if the sea inside her had evaporated.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA curious fact about the Khmer Rouge: Although they condemned anyone who could read or write \u2014 eyeglasses were evidence enough \u2014 they kept thousands of pages of files, and every citizen was required to write a record of his or her life, naming and implicating family and friends. In the end, these memoirs were used as confessions, of crimes real or imagined. (\u201cIf you act correctly, you are the enemy, if you act incorrectly, you are the enemy,\u201d an officer says.) Janie\u2019s little brother, anointed at age 9 as an interrogator, listens as a tortured prisoner admits to being a spy and describes an America he\u2019s never seen, where people \u201clived on airplanes or underground, leaving the surface of the country empty as a sheet.\u201d The lesson still haunts Janie: \u201cthat the story of one\u2019s own life could not be trusted, that it could destroy you and all the people you loved.\u201d\n\nFour decades later, she must find another way to live with the past, to make room for her ghosts. Midway through the novel, she turns to the case of Lev Zasetsky, a Russian soldier who survived a shot to the head during the World War II Battle of Smolensk. Despite losing the ability to process language, he managed to keep a diary that eventually surpassed 3,000 pages. \u201cEach sentence required that he hunt through the disintegrated rooms of his memory, fumble blindly for words, the simplest words, hoarding them like gold dust until he had enough to construct a sentence,\u201d Thien writes. Zasetsky\u2019s doctor saw the diary as a way for his patient to not simply remember his life, but \u201cmake a wholeness of it.\u201d For Janie, the hope is the same.", "title": "Madeleine Thien\u2019s New Novel of Communist Occupation Turns Inward", "authors": ["Ligaya Mishan", "Madeleine Thien"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "In the quarterfinals, Keys will face Angelique Kerber, the former No. 1-ranked player and the 2016 Australian Open champion, in what should be a compelling contrast in styles: Keys\u2019s punching power against Kerber\u2019s counterpunching athleticism.\n\nKerber, seeded 21st but undefeated this season after winning the title in Sydney, was close to a surprise defeat on Monday before prevailing, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2, against Hsieh Su-wei, the 88th-ranked Taiwanese veteran with an unconventional game.\n\nHsieh, 32, had already upset No. 3-seeded Garbi\u00f1e Muguruza and No. 26-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska with her clever tactics, great defense, abrupt changes of rhythm and tightly angled shots struck double-handed off both sides.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why the tennis is so interesting, because all the girls have different timing, different game,\u201d Hsieh said. \u201cWestern style. Chinese style. One-hand. Double-handed. That\u2019s why it makes tennis so fun.\u201d\n\nShe was one game away from bamboozling Kerber, too, but after Hsieh took a 6-4, 5-4 lead, Kerber held serve to 5-5 and got the better of a series of grueling, extended exchanges: howling with release as she crouched low to hit a forehand winner down the line to break Hsieh\u2019s serve in the next game, taking command of the set and the momentum.\n\n\u201cI was running everywhere and she always had the answer,\u201d Kerber said on the court after closing out her ninth straight victory (13 if you count the Hopman Cup team event). \u201cWe will see a lot in 2018 from her, that\u2019s for sure.\u201d\n\nAsked about Kerber\u2019s comment, Hsieh moved two fingers across her field of vision, \u00e0 la John Travolta dancing in \u201cPulp Fiction.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m coming,\u201d she said with a smile. \u201cSo I will keep trying. Thank you.\u201d\n\nHsieh, who has won 19 doubles titles on the tour, had not reached the fourth round of a Grand Slam singles tournament since the Australian Open in 2008.\n\nShe calls her style \u201cSu-wei style\u201d or \u201cfreestyle.\u201d\n\n\u201cLike today, I go on the court, and if I don\u2019t have a plan, then I do whatever I can,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen the ball comes, I decide at the last moment where to hit. So sometimes the girls say, \u2018Oh I don\u2019t know where she hit.\u2019 But sometimes I don\u2019t know where I hit, too.\u201d\n\nGarcia, a 24-year-old from France who propelled herself into the top 10 late last season with a series of attack-minded victories in Asia, winning two tournaments in China and reaching the semifinals of the WTA\u2019s year-end championships in Singapore.\n\nPhoto\n\nA back problem forced her to retire during her first tournament of this year in Brisbane, Australia, but Garcia looked fit and confident heading into Monday\u2019s duel. She opened the match by stepping inside the baseline to return aggressively, breaking Keys\u2019s intimidating serve in the first game.\n\nBut the 17th-seeded Keys bounced back to break Garcia, and then proceeded to play one of her finest matches in a major tournament.\n\nKeys, 22, reached her first major final at the United States Open last September but struggled to handle the moment, making errors in bunches and losing, 6-3, 6-0, to her compatriot and friend Sloane Stephens.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPretty much the week to 10 days after was really tough,\u201d Keys said. \u201cI mean, my sleep schedule was totally messed up. I was just really tired from all the late, emotional matches that I had. And then to have such a great two weeks and then have it end the way that it did, it was really devastating for me. So it definitely took some time to get over.\u201d\n\nStephens has yet to win another match since that victory, and Keys played only one more match in 2017, losing to Varvara Lepchenko in the opening round in Wuhan, China, before deciding to end her season early to focus on getting her postoperative wrist in ideal shape to start 2018.\n\nBut she also used her relatively long off-season to work on her conditioning, and it showed in the form of improved footwork, lateral speed and quickness against Garcia, who repeatedly tried to attack her traditional weaknesses without success.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a sharpness about her,\u201d said Sam Smith, the former British player, who is a television analyst for Seven Network in Australia. \u201cShe\u2019s getting to the ball a fraction faster, and the setup is more precise. Hence she is making fewer unforced errors.\u201d\n\nKeys still made 21 on Monday, but she also hit 32 winners, including nine aces, and managed to win the majority of the rallies, no matter what the length of the exchange.\n\nShe said she was playing \u201creally smart,\u201d but when asked if this was a new step for her, her answer was polite but clear.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think so,\u201d she said smiling. \u201cI think I played pretty smart to get to the finals of the U.S. Open and win some titles. Hopefully it\u2019s just a little bit more consistently that way.\u201d\n\nKeys has had world-class power from the baseline since her midteens. It comes naturally, and it can be a double-edged sword as her flat strokes often leave her little margin for error.\n\nBut Smith believes that Keys, under the guidance of her coach, Lindsay Davenport, is able to hit with more topspin on the backhand side now, creating more clearance when Keys needs it.\n\n\u201cEach shot used to be an individual event,\u201d Smith said. \u201cBut Lindsay Davenport has taught her how to play tennis.\u201d\n\nKeys, identified long ago as a potential champion, has had no shortage of guidance during her career. Her ability to control her nerves as well as her power will be decisive as she chases her first Grand Slam title.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBigger challenges await in the second week here, but she has yet to lose a set in four matches, or be pushed to a tiebreaker.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really excited,\u201d said Keys, the last American woman in the singles tournament. \u201cI think I\u2019m playing well and especially in tight moments, handling my emotions well.\u201d\n\nAlso on Monday, Simona Halep cruised past Naomi Osaka, 6-3, 6-2. In the quarterfinals, Halep will face sixth-seeded Karolina Pliskova, who defeated Barbora Strycova, 6-7 (5), 6-3, 6-2, in an all-Czech affair.", "title": "Madison Keys Surges Into Australian Open Quarterfinals", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "MEDELL\u00cdN, Colombia \u2014 President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro of Venezuela ordered a temporary shutdown of air and maritime traffic with three Caribbean neighbors on Friday, accusing smugglers there of seeking to plunder his country.\n\nIn a televised address, Mr. Maduro said he had halted all flights and ship traffic to Aruba, Bonaire and Cura\u00e7ao for 72 hours. He accused the three countries of running black markets by siphoning everything from copper to food before selling the items.\n\n\u201cThey take away gold from this country illegally, and make it legal to sell there; they take away coltan, they take away diamonds, they take away all food products,\u201d Mr. Maduro said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to take a measure like this one, but I am ready to take even more radical measures.\u201d\n\nThe Caribbean islands, which are short distances from Venezuela\u2019s northern coast, have long hosted black markets for Venezuelan contraband, trading everything from illegally mined minerals to narcotics. The countries, however, have become better known under Mr. Maduro\u2019s presidency as the landing site of boats of hungry Venezuelans fleeing their country\u2019s food shortages.", "title": "Maduro Cuts Off Venezuela\u2019s Air and Sea Traffic With 3 Island Neighbors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSnap, crackle or pop?\n\nNature keeps coming up with new and baffling ways to blow things up.\n\nAstronomers have been baffled lately by the mysterious pulses of cosmic energy known as fast radio bursts that seem to pepper the cosmos. In a few unpredictable milliseconds, they typically emit as much energy as the sun does in a day. About 30 of these objects have been discovered deep in space since the first was detected in 2007, all but one burping out a cataclysmic radio pulse exactly once and then disappearing into the night.\n\nOnly one burster, known as FRB121102, after the date it was discovered (Nov. 2, 2012), has repeated itself, hundreds of times now.\n\nThat allowed Shami Chatterjee of Cornell and his colleagues to track it to a galaxy 3 billion light years away. But that only deepened the mystery of the powers of these objects, and why none are closer to us.\n\nAmong the more out-there explanations proffered was that they are lasers propelling alien interstellar spacecraft. That is a scheme that Earthlings themselves are considering to launch a fleet of miniature space probes to Alpha Centauri later this century.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlas for E.T., new observations have now debunked alien technology as the explanation for at least one source of a burst, according to a new paper in Nature by Jason Hessels of the University of Amsterdam and a multinational crew of radio astronomers.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs monitored by the mighty 300-meter-diameter radio telescope at Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico and abetted by measurements at the Green Bank Telescope in Green Bank, W.Va., the signals from the repeating burster FRB110212, bore the marks of having been produced in a magnetic field at least thousands of times more powerful than normally seen in space.", "title": "Magnetic Secrets of Mysterious Radio Bursts in a Faraway Galaxy", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye", "Out There"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In the Czech Republic, President Milos Zeman came first in the first round of presidential elections but failed to pass the 50-percent threshold that would have saved him from having to compete in a runoff.\n\nThat vote, in two weeks, will decide whether the country continues to be drawn toward Russia and China under Mr. Zeman\u2019s leadership or moves back more fully into the embrace of the E.U. under Jiri Drahos, above left, Mr. Zeman\u2019s challenger.\n\nAnalysts predict a tight race.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The United States and the E.U. have warned Kosovo against attempts by former guerrillas turned politicians to halt a special war crimes court before it has even begun work.\n\nThe court is viewed by many as a vital prerequisite for reconciliation in the aftermath of the bloody Balkan wars of the 1990s.\n\nBut critics expect that when Parliament reconvenes this week, some lawmakers will try to undermine it to protect prominent war veterans.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Male models and assistants are accusing the fashion photographers Bruce Weber and Mario Testino of sexual misconduct. (Here\u2019s a look at some players to watch.)\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe headquarters for the U.S. military has always stood out.\n\nThe Pentagon building was already in use when it was dedicated 75 years ago today, at the height of World War II.\n\nBuilt just across the Potomac River from Washington in less than two years, the Pentagon was home to 22,000 workers by the end of 1942.\n\nIt remains one of the world\u2019s largest office buildings, with more than six million square feet of floor space.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe distinctive design came from the shape of the first proposed site, which was hemmed in by streets on five sides. When President Franklin Roosevelt decided on a different location, the shape stayed, but the sides were made even.\n\nThe first architectural reviews were not glowing, but they improved over time.\n\n\u201cCalled too big, too barren and too expensive when it was completed for $83 million in 1943, the Pentagon is a thriving, functional success in 1968,\u201d The Times wrote in a report for the 25th anniversary of the building, which it extolled as a place of community:\n\n\u201cEveryman, or Littleman, triumphed over all. Thousands of secretaries and office workers have turned the Pentagon into a cluttered, cosy, home-away-from-home.\u201d\n\nSarah Anderson contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. Fewer than 1,000 people live in Jackman, according to the 2010 census. There are more than 2,500 five-star ratings on our best recipe for pizza dough (above), but I\u2019m here this morning with a couple of notes about it all the same. (Some night soon you can use the result to make a plain pizza pie, or a pizza that is green and white.)\n\nThe first is, if you can, use a stand mixer to knead the dough, instead of working by hand. The work goes faster and leads to a more beautiful, textured dough. The second is, make a double batch. This is dough that stores well in the refrigerator, picking up good flavor along the way, particularly if you invest in some stackable pizza proofing pans to store it.\n\nYes, you\u2019ll be that guy. But you\u2019ll also be able to make four incredible pizzas on a Wednesday night in your own home with a lot less hassle than the other guy. Just brush up on your skills with our special guide: How to Make Pizza.\n\nSo that\u2019s like 20 minutes of work this evening against a whole night of pleasure later in the week. Make the dough and square everything away, and then you can make this dead-simple recipe for stir-fried pork and pineapple for dinner. (Feel free to sub in shiitakes or another mushroom for the black fungus, though, of course, it\u2019s great to say, \u201cblack fungus.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr, if you eschew pizza made at home and have a little extra time because you didn\u2019t make dough, cook this fine recipe for sesame-braised chicken in a pot. And maybe bake this recipe for chocolate dump-it cake after you eat. You must love something, after all.", "title": "Make the Best Pizza", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Mark Bittman", "Amanda Hesser", "Nigella Lawson", "Kim Severson"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are ready to show America how this can and will be done,\u201d Mr. Bevin said at a news conference in Frankfort. And yet Kentucky\u2019s approach to Medicaid draws from a well-worn playbook, one from which both Republicans and Democrats have drawn to trim the social safety net over the years.\n\nKentucky was an eager participant in the last big so-called entitlement reform, visited upon the nation\u2019s poor just over two decades ago. Under that 1996 program directed at welfare benefits, the entitlement to federal assistance was replaced by a hodgepodge of programs managed by the states and financed by a fixed dollop of federal cash. Work requirements became the norm. And people got less help.\n\nThe number of families in poverty in Kentucky has budged little since then, declining to 116,000 from 132,000. But the number of families getting cash assistance has fallen by two-thirds. Today, the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program covers only one of five poor families in the state. For a single mother with two children, it provides $262 a month \u2014 a third less than it did two decades ago, adjusted for inflation.\n\nAnd Kentucky is hardly the stingiest state. In 15 states, antipoverty cash benefits reach fewer than 10 percent of the families with children in poverty. In all of them, the change was sold as a way to encourage poor Americans to get off their backsides, get a job and prosper on their own \u2014 free of the clutches of the welfare state. Yet though it pushed many poor families into employment, it failed at mitigating their distress: Rarely do such families\u2019 breadwinners earn enough to move out of poverty.\n\nThe problem with the latest twist in Republicans\u2019 effort to pare the social safety net is that removing the poor\u2019s health insurance may not just make their life more difficult.\n\nIt might kill them.\n\nIt is well known by now that health insurance saves lives. A review of recent research in the Annals of Internal Medicine concluded that the odds of dying for non-elderly adults are between 3 and 41 percent higher for the uninsured than for the insured.\n\nWork by Katherine Baicker, now at the University of Chicago, with Benjamin Sommers and Arnold Epstein at Harvard found that Medicaid expansions in the past significantly reduced mortality. Their research, they concluded, \u201csuggests that 176 additional adults would need to be covered by Medicaid in order to prevent one death per year.\u201d", "title": "Making Medicaid a Tool for Moral Education May Let Some Die", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "She still welcomes strangers to her apartment in Brooklyn.\n\nMs. Carrier, who has lupus, said her caregiving inclinations were deeply intertwined with her lifelong struggles with illness, mental and physical, as well as the deaths of many relatives to whom she tended.\n\nAfter she gave birth to her only child at age 17, painful memories from Ms. Carrier\u2019s childhood surfaced. She realized that she had suppressed traumatic events and sought counseling.\n\n\u201cI had my daughter, so I needed to put my life in a better place,\u201d said Ms. Carrier, who remains close with her daughter and granddaughter.\n\nIn the following years, Ms. Carrier balanced motherhood and caring for ailing relatives with a career in advertising and work as an insurance coding supervisor until she was crippled by the loss of her brother. Just 22, he was hit by a drunken driver in 1977 and died from a heart attack shortly after. When she tried to return to work, she found it difficult to concentrate.\n\n\u201cI was here, but I wasn\u2019t here,\u201d Ms. Carrier said tearfully. \u201cI just couldn\u2019t handle it. Me and my brother were real close.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1983, she began working as a ticket collector for Conrail, now Metro-North. Ms. Carrier rose through the ranks to become one of the first black female conductors. A few years later, she was ready to move on. And in 1988, she founded a soup kitchen in the Bronx with a friend and that friend\u2019s mother, funded entirely by the three of them. In cooperation with a Union American Methodist Episcopal church in the Bronx, they fed 200 or more people every day. Ms. Carrier also worked on and off as a home attendant from 1984 to 2007, stopping because of her knee replacement and growing complications from lupus.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the decades since her brother\u2019s death, Ms. Carrier has served as the primary caregiver for members of her immediate family in their final years. Her mother succumbed to leukemia in 1983. Her sister died of liver cancer in 2010. Five years later, her husband, whom she had lived with for over 20 years, died at age 64.\n\n\u201cMy father just passed away in February,\u201d Ms. Carrier said in an interview last month. \u201cNow it\u2019s just me.\u201d\n\nOver the last three years, Ms. Carrier has sought mental health help from the Service Program for Older People, a mental health treatment program that is a partner of FPWA, one of the eight organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The service program has helped her cope with her many losses and address her traumatic memories.\n\nShe offered advice to other women: \u201cDon\u2019t be afraid to get help, because when you let your guard down a little bit, you\u2019ll see there is somebody there for you.\u201d\n\nHer health makes it difficult for her to leave Brooklyn, but once a week, Ms. Carrier, who each month receives $357 in Supplemental Security Income and $192 in Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits, makes her way to the agency\u2019s Upper West Side office for a therapy session.\n\nIn late September, Ms. Carrier received a $1,000 grant from FPWA to furnish her living room with two end tables, a pair of lamps and a love seat to replace the couch her husband had brought home.\n\n\u201cI feel comfortable sitting in my living room now,\u201d Ms. Carrier said. \u201cWhen you have what you want in your home, and not what somebody just gave you, you have more pride in it.\u201d\n\nMs. Carrier chose her new furniture from a catalog at a store, where a manager looked on as she turned page after page.\n\n\u201cThe man laughed at me. He said I sat there for 3\u00bd hours picking out furniture,\u201d Ms. Carrier said, but she would not be rushed. Choosing it herself was what made this furniture, and by extension the apartment around it, hers.", "title": "Making a Home Her Own, and a Refuge for Others", "authors": ["Sheli Paige Frank", "The Neediest Cases Fund"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe shuts the door and locks it. {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Emergency shelters are not permitted in residences, Laura Valdez, the assistant city manager, said Friday. \u201cHe has a big heart, and it\u2019s very admirable, but there are other shelters that are in place that are lawful,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd we have a relationship with them to provide a safe space.\u201d\n\nJeff Rowes, a senior lawyer who focuses on private property rights and free speech at the Institute for Justice, a public interest law firm, said he believed the city may have overstepped its bounds.\n\n\u201cBoth Greg and the homeless people he helps have a constitutional right to be free of government interference that endangers their lives,\u201d he said on Friday.\n\nMr. Rowes, who has been in contact with Mr. Schiller, said Mr. Schiller constitutionally may have a \u201cright to rescue,\u201d in that he has a right to offer lifesaving services to people in danger, and that he should not be subject to \u201cirrational zoning.\u201d\n\nBlindly enforcing rules in a way that is divorced from real-time problems is unacceptable, Mr. Rowes said. \u201cAbuse of zoning and code enforcement is a plague, particularly a plague on low-income people,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Schiller was opening his home only in emergency situations, Mr. Rowes said, adding, \u201cHe\u2019s not trying to run a clandestine homeless shelter 24/7.\u201d\n\nElgin, a city of about 110,000, has three lawful shelters, two of which work together to offer 24-hour service year-round.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral warming centers become available during extreme cold and there is also an emergency shelter operated by the nonprofit Matthew 25:40. It only opens when the temperature drops to 15 degrees or lower, Tammy Wheatly, the shelter\u2019s executive director, said Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the nights that Mr. Schiller opened his home, the temperatures were above 15 degrees but still below freezing.\n\n\u201cWe have shelters, but they\u2019re not always open,\u201d Mr. Schiller told AM 560. \u201cAll I\u2019m doing is trying to fill a gap in the wintertime.\u201d\n\nMr. Schiller, the managing director of the Light in the Darkness Ministry, was a founding member of Matthew 25:40. He resigned in November 2016 amid conflict with the organization. \u201cHe had a my-way-or-the-highway attitude and refused to seek approval or input from the board,\u201d Ms. Wheatly said.\n\nMr. Schiller did not respond to a call seeking comment on Friday.\n\nTraditional shelters require those seeking housing to meet certain requirement, but they are not that stringent, said Sarah J. Ponitz, the executive director of PADS of Elgin, the overnight shelter that operates all year.\n\nThese individuals need some type of photo identification, but it doesn\u2019t have to be state issued, she said. They also have to have some type of community connection to prove they are in the shelter\u2019s service area. Almost no one is turned away, regardless of substance abuse or mental health issues, Ms. Ponitz said.\n\nMs. Ponitz said there were many reasons, some complex, as to why homeless people might opt to go to a private home instead of a lawful shelter. Some don\u2019t feel that they need help, she said, and some want to drink or use drugs, which are not permitted in shelters.\n\nPADS is rarely at capacity, Ms. Ponitz said. \u201cIt\u2019s unfair to say there\u2019s nowhere else to go,\u201d she said.\n\nThis is not the first time Mr. Schiller has been ordered to close a makeshift shelter at his home. He opened his garage to homeless people last winter, he told AM 560. He set up propane heaters and cracked open the garage door, but had to call emergency services after one man with a heart condition fell ill. Emergency medical technicians reported him for violating zoning code, he said.\n\nThe city was tipped off to the recent situation by an anonymous complaint, Ms. Valdez said. Mr. Schiller said it wasn\u2019t filed by his neighbors, who he said supported his efforts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe believe that the complaint came from someone who has a personal ax to grind with me that doesn\u2019t live near here,\u201d he said.", "title": "Man Who Sheltered Homeless People in His Basement Stops After City Order", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "A man and his teenage daughter were killed by a fire on Sunday in a public housing complex in the Bronx, the police said. Is Apple also slowing down older iPads? If so, will it replace batteries at a reduced rate?\n\nA. In response to accusations that it intentionally hindered older products, Apple\u2019s public explanation and apology says that only certain iPhone models were affected by the software updates designed to prevent the battery from conking out unexpectedly. In fact, Apple\u2019s mea culpa states, \u201cThis power management feature is specific to iPhone and does not apply to any other Apple products.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cpower management\u201d tool was first introduced in early 2017 with iOS 10.2.1 for iPhones. Longer times for apps to start up, lowered audio volume and screen brightness, a disabled camera flash and jerkier frame rates are signs of the performance reduction in action. Apple said only the iPhone 6, iPhone 6 Plus, iPhone 6s, iPhone 6s Plus, and iPhone SE models were included at first, but it added the iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus with the iOS 11.2 update in December.\n\nTo make amends, Apple is replacing batteries in older iPhones for $29 (instead of the usual $79) until the end of the year; new batteries typically let the phone avoid the power-management throttle kicking in. However, Apple\u2019s price for an out-of-warranty iPad battery replacement is still $99; third-party repair services can cost less but it\u2019s worth researching the provider\u2019s reputation first.", "title": "Managing an iPad\u2019s Battery Use", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia told colleagues on Tuesday that he intended to run for re-election this year after all, ending an anxiety-making flirtation with retirement and easing Democratic fears that the most conservative Democrat in the Senate was about to effectively hand his seat to a Republican.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Manchin said he repeatedly expressed his frustration to Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, and other colleagues, telling them that \u201cthis place sucks,\u201d before finally signaling Tuesday morning to Mr. Schumer\u2019s aides that he would file his re-election paperwork before West Virginia\u2019s deadline on Saturday.\n\n\u201cI was very vocal,\u201d Mr. Manchin said, adding, \u201cthey read between the lines.\u201d\n\nEven as Democrats won a reprieve, Mr. Manchin\u2019s discontent illustrated the divisions in their party between those from states that President Trump easily carried and the more liberal bloc of senators, at least a half-dozen of whom are positioning themselves for possible White House runs. The rift contributed to the government shutdown over the weekend and the Monday decision by a group of moderates to force the government\u2019s reopening.\n\nIt also will have to be bridged if Democrats have any hope of regaining the Senate in November, when they must defend 10 seats in states that Mr. Trump won, while winning Republican-held seats in difficult states like Tennessee, Nevada and Arizona.", "title": "Manchin Will Seek Re-election but Sends Democrats a Stern Warning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The Manhattan real estate market missed a beat in the fourth quarter of 2017, but remained strong overall, despite looming property tax changes and a softening luxury market, according to recent industry reports.\n\nThe average sales price fell to $1,897,503 in the fourth quarter, the first time it has fallen below $2 million in almost two years, noted a new report from Douglas Elliman. There were 2,514 closed sales, down 12 percent from a year earlier, making it the slowest fourth quarter in six years, the report said.\n\nThe last quarter is typically the slowest of the year, but in 2017 two factors exacerbated that, said Jonathan J. Miller, president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel, which prepared the report.\n\nFirst, the so-called legacy pipeline \u2014 contracts on pricey new apartments that have taken years to close \u2014 is drying up. These deals, many of them signed around 2014 for under-construction condos, inflated the average sales price for the last few years, Mr. Miller said, but that effect is now fading.", "title": "Manhattan Market Blinks Ahead of Tax Overhaul", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Tennessee appeared to come into the game at a disadvantage because its starting running back, DeMarco Murray, was out with a knee injury.
