But Kelce had to sit out the second half after sustaining a concussion in the second quarter, and the Chiefs never recovered.\n\nEven Kareem Hunt, Kansas City\u2019s dynamic rookie running back, who had come out of nowhere to lead the N.F.L. in rushing this season, seemed unable to do anything in the second half. He finished the game with 11 carries for 42 yards and a touchdown.\n\nWith the loss, the Chiefs remained stuck on just one playoff victory since the team\u2019s run to the A.F.C. championship game behind quarterback Joe Montana after the 1993 season. Smith\u2019s future with the team will certainly be debated, as fans had already been clamoring for a switch to Patrick Mahomes, the quarterback whom the team took with the 10th overall pick in the draft last spring.\n\nDepending on the results of Sunday\u2019s game between the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Buffalo Bills, the Titans will face either New England or Pittsburgh in the divisional round next, with a chance to reach the conference championship game for the first time since after the 2002 season.", "title": "Marcus Mariota, With a Play for the Ages, Leads the Titans Past the Chiefs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "When you leave Marfa, it\u2019s a deep dive into the rural framework of Texas. Back to the grasses and the yucca. The uninterrupted sky. A whole lot of space to fill. And what a sky it was! It had been so fickle, now finally we saw glimmers of bright blue patches above the long dark ribbon of a road ahead. Look at that road! With nothing on it!\n\n\u201cThis would be a good time to stand in the middle of the road,\u201d Beth said. And she was the family therapist. The reasonable one! It was a spur of the moment suggestion. No reasoning behind it. We might be getting older, but in Texas, in the desert, you can still pull over, jump in the middle of the road and not a soul will know about it.\n\nWe hopped out of the car and screamed our heads off, drunk with all of the space. And it was exhilarating! When my kids were little, I told them not to run into the street about 100 times. (Maybe more?) Here we were, four women in our mid-40s. It went against all of our instincts as responsible adults, and we let those instincts go into the wind that night.\n\nThe sun was quickly dropping into the desert so, after our \u201cI\u2019m the queen of the road\u201d stunt, we got back in the S.U.V. and I revved up to 80 again. In my path were two large black crows, snacking on roadkill. I slowed down a bit so they\u2019d have time to ascend, but one got caught by the wind and it swooped down with a sharp force. My car plunged into it, everyone screamed and the bird propelled into my windshield. I did what any sane person would do when something large is coming at you: I ducked, yet my hands remained steady on the wheel.\n\nFor whatever reason \u2014 maybe it was the desolate road, maybe it was how fast I was driving, or my desert head space \u2014 but my instinct was to simply duck, not to swerve. I\u2019m a good driver. I can take a highway or a city street. But this was not a normal reflex. I\u2019m telling you, I didn\u2019t move that wheel. I\u2019m going to chalk it up to adrenaline. Something raced inside of me that said \u201cGet your head down. Now.\u201d", "title": "Marfa Road Trip: Thelma and Louise, With a Happier Ending", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "You went from zero to hockey?\n\nIn hindsight I was just running on the ice in skates. But you have so much padding on. I didn\u2019t know how to stop or anything, so I\u2019d just spring on the ice and then hit another player, or a barricade, or the ice to stop. That was pretty much the extent of my ice skating knowledge until the movie came around and I started training. And that\u2019s when I put on figure-skating skates, which are very different [from] ice hockey skates, I found out.\n\nDid you do dance or gymnastics growing up?\n\nI did ballet for from 5 to 15 [years old]. That helped a lot actually. It was just the actual ice part of it that was scary. I had to look like a very proficient skater. The first time I went to do a high kick on the ice I just flew backwards and winded myself. Fortunately we had an amazing skate choreographer, Sarah Kawahara. She actually choreographed for Nancy [Kerrigan] a bit back in the day. I kept apologizing, \u201cOh, I\u2019m sorry you\u2019re stuck with me,\u201d like, \u201cThis must be very frustrating.\u201d\n\nHad you heard of Tonya Harding growing up?\n\nI was 4 at the time, so I totally missed it. But once I delved into the story I was fascinated. I kind of understood why everyone was so enthralled by it at the time. There\u2019s always been an appetite for scandal, but this was an event that escalated and snowballed into this global phenomenon. Pinning two women against each other, categorizing people into neat little sound bites and splashy headlines. I think it would have been particularly traumatic to go through that coming from the upbringing she had, not being surrounded by a support network, not having the financial resources to protect herself.\n\nShe was the villain.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t fair on Nancy either. She was painted like this prissy ice queen. She came from a blue-collar family. And at the end of the day both of them are athletes. Everyone\u2019s commenting on their looks. No, it\u2019s not about their looks. They\u2019re athletes; they\u2019re not models.\n\nBut it did matter in the skating world.\n\nIt did matter, and a big part of our story is that Tonya didn\u2019t fit in. She wasn\u2019t the image the skating world wanted as the face of American figure skating. She was always seeking validation, always seeking affection and love, whether it was from her mom, her husband, the media, the public, the skating association, the other skaters, whoever it was. Before hitting the first serve of the match, he bounced the ball more than two dozen times.\n\nCilic\u2019s fidgeting presaged a poor start. He quickly fell behind after he finally put the ball in play; his opponent, Kyle Edmund, won three of the first four points to earn two immediate break opportunities.\n\nBut after the initial scare, the sixth-seeded Cilic found his groove. He hammered three consecutive service winners and never looked back, beating Edmund, 6-2, 7-6 (4), 6-2, in 2 hours 18 minutes.\n\nEdmund failed to generate any further break point opportunities in the match, while Cilic broke serve four times. Cilic dominated with his first serve, winning 90 percent of those points on his way to becoming the first Croat, man or woman, to reach an Australian Open singles final. She graduated from the University of Southern Mississippi in Hattiesburg and received a Ph.D. in pharmaceutical sciences from the University of Maryland, Baltimore.\n\nShe is a daughter of VieAnna F. Brown of Hattiesburg.\n\nDr. Hewitt, 47, is a researcher and policy consultant for environmental management and related public health issues in Philadelphia and a lecturer in biology at the University of Pennsylvania. Turner.\n\nThe couple met in 2013 through a mutual friend at Penn, where the bride was a researcher at the medical school.", "title": "Marishka Brown, David Hewitt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "With 32 studio albums and countless compilations, reissues, live recordings and non-LP singles to their name, the British post-punk band the Fall created one of the most daunting catalogs in rock. The only constant in the group\u2019s constantly changing lineup was the man at the center: Mark E. Smith.\n\nMr. Smith, the Fall\u2019s main songwriter and vocalist, died Wednesday morning at 60. His death was confirmed by Pam Vander, the band\u2019s manager, who said in a statement that the musician had died at his home.\n\nOver the band\u2019s nearly five-decade career, Mr. Smith unspooled caustic rants that could seem inscrutable until certain repeated phrases became mantras. (Think equal parts Lou Reed, \u201cFinnegans Wake\u201d and the lovable crank at the corner of the bar.) The music behind him could drone or pound, pull in \u201960s garage, rockabilly or reggae \u2014 whatever Mr. Smith was into, really \u2014 and still sound instantly like the Fall. Here are 12 of his best songs.", "title": "Mark E. Smith of the Fall: Listen to 12 Essential Tracks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Although some of the band\u2019s albums reached the British Top 40, the Fall did not seek pop acceptance. A well-chosen 2004 compilation album was titled \u201c50,000 Fall Fans Can\u2019t Be Wrong.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the astringent sound and attitude of the Fall\u2019s early albums, with bottom-scraping bass lines under clattery, unswerving drumbeats and dissonant guitar, became a cornerstone of post-punk, echoing through bands like Sonic Youth, Pavement and Protomartyr. And the Fall found and built a loyal audience that welcomed the music\u2019s corrosive intent while it parsed the spite, mockery, allusions and non sequiturs in Mr. Smith\u2019s lyrics.\n\nOn Twitter, Cedric Bixler-Zavala of the Texas post-punk band At the Drive-In called Mr. Smith \u201cone of the pillars of influence for me as lyricist and troublemaker.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThrough the Fall\u2019s studio albums and an avalanche of live recordings, the band\u2019s style changed often, as Mr. Smith, its founder and only constant, hired and often fired more than five dozen musicians.\n\nAt various points in the band\u2019s four-decade career, the Fall might sound like punk, hard rock, psychedelia, funk, blues-rock, jazz-rock, electropop or sheer noise. \u201cIf it\u2019s me and your granny on bongos, it\u2019s the Fall,\u201d Mr. Smith once declared. The BBC disc jockey John Peel, an early and steadfast supporter, said of the Fall that \u201cthey are always different, they are always the same.\u201d\n\nThrough it all, Mr. Smith maintained his role as a brain-twisting wordsmith, a contentious bandleader and a perpetual irritant. In a 2017 interview with The Guardian, he boasted: \u201cPeople still cross the road from me; I\u2019ve still got that. I can clear a pub when I want to. It\u2019s a talent.\u201d\n\nMark Edward Smith was born in Salford, near Manchester, on March 5, 1957, and grew up in nearby Prestwich. After dropping out of school at 16, he was working as a shipping clerk and studying literature at night school when he saw the Sex Pistols in a sparsely attended show at the Lesser Free Trade Hall in Manchester. He soon started his own band with friends. The Fall was named after an Albert Camus novel.\n\n\u201cWhen I formed the group,\u201d Mr. Smith wrote in his 2008 autobiography, \u201cRenegade: The Lives and Tales of Mark E. Smith,\u201d \u201cit was because of sounds; of wanting to make something; combining primitive music with intelligent lyrics.\u201d\n\nThe Fall released its first EP, \u201cBingo-Master\u2019s Break-Out!,\u201d in 1978, and its debut album, \u201cLive at the Witch Trials,\u201d in 1979. Manchester was a center of post-punk innovation at the turn of the 1980s, with bands like Joy Division, the Durutti Column and the Smiths. But the Fall \u2014 although less popular and more abrasive \u2014 would outlast them all.\n\nThe Fall\u2019s closest approach to the rock mainstream, with songs featuring clear-cut beats, riffs and choruses, came in the 1980s, when the band\u2019s guitarists (and Mr. Smith\u2019s songwriting collaborators) were Craig Scanlon, who was in the Fall from 1979 to 1995, and Brix Smith, who was Mr. Smith\u2019s wife from 1983 to 1989, her initial tenure with the band, and rejoined for two 1990s albums.\n\nHer departure was followed by decades of fluctuations in the band\u2019s music, by turns obnoxious and illuminating. Mr. Smith also recorded outside the Fall with Gorillaz and Elastica, and he made an album in 2007 with the German electronic duo Mouse on Mars under the group name Von S\u00fcdenfed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Fall toured constantly through its four decades, playing sets that could be spellbinding or desultory. A notorious 1998 performance at Brownie\u2019s in the East Village included fistfights among the musicians.\n\nFor the Fall\u2019s final half-dozen albums, the lineup remained largely stable. From 2002 to 2016 the band included Elena Poulou, whom Mr. Smith married in 2001, on keyboards. They divorced in 2016.\n\nIn addition to Ms. Vander, Mr. Smith is survived by his mother, Irene, and three sisters, Caroline, Barbara and Susanne.\n\nMr. Smith garnered multiple reputations: as a drinker and a brawler, as a contrarian and an insult-slinger (particularly against politicians, institutions and other musicians), and as an artist and an experimenter. In concert, he disdained looking back or playing longtime fan favorites. The Fall\u2019s live sets usually drew only on the band\u2019s most recent recordings and even newer songs.\n\nIn his autobiography, Mr. Smith put it bluntly: \u201cThe Fall are about the present, and that\u2019s it.\u201d", "title": "Mark E. Smith, Uncompromising Leader of the Fall, Dies at 60", "authors": ["Jon Pareles"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMark Salling, who played Noah Puckerman on the television show \u201cGlee,\u201d was found dead on Tuesday in the Tujunga area of Los Angeles, according to the Los Angeles County medical examiner-coroner\u2019s office. The cause of death was an apparent suicide, The Associated Press reported. It comes just weeks after Mr. Salling pleaded guilty to federal charges of being in possession of child pornography. A sentencing hearing was scheduled for March 7.\n\nMr. Salling was 35. The 25,000 images were on Mr. Salling\u2019s laptop, hard drive and a flash drive, according to the Justice Department, which also said that law enforcement authorities had been tipped off by Mr. Salling\u2019s girlfriend.\n\n\u201cMark was a gentle and loving person, a person of great creativity, who was doing his best to atone for some serious mistakes and errors of judgment,\u201d Michael J. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI went to a place called the Jingle Mill,\u201d she said in a 1980 interview with The Times, \u201cwhere I did five commercials an hour for $10.\u201d\n\nIn 1965 her stature in that niche profession improved considerably when she was chosen to sing a jingle for Campbell\u2019s Soup, and for decades afterward articles about her would have headlines like \u201cMarlene VerPlanck Is Mmm, Mmm Good.\u201d\n\nAnother assignment was for Michelob. Though she recorded that beer\u2019s jingle only once, the job rewarded her for years.\n\n\u201cWhen I sang \u2018Weekends were made for Michelob,\u2019 they asked me to add a \u2018Yeah\u2019 at the end,\u201d she told The Boston Herald in 1997. \u201cAnd then they tacked that \u2018Yeah\u2019 of mine onto every Michelob commercial for seven years. Even when Brook Benton and Vic Damone sang the jingle, it was my \u2018Yeah\u2019 at the end. It became a very nice annuity.\u201d\n\nMs. VerPlanck also recorded as a backup singer for artists as diverse as Perry Como and the rock group Kiss. For Frank Sinatra\u2019s ambitious 1980 album, \u201cTrilogy,\u201d she had the job of recruiting 16 other singers for some of the sessions.\n\nBy then, Ms. VerPlanck had established herself on the cabaret scene. The jazz guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli, whom she knew from her studio work, arranged her New York nightclub debut in 1972 at Soerabaja on the Upper East Side, where he backed her.\n\n\u201cHis guitar is all she has in the way of support,\u201d Mr. Wilson wrote in reviewing that performance, \u201cwhich leaves her very much on her own. She is attempting the most naked kind of singing \u2014 a situation in which nothing can be covered up or faked. And Miss VerPlanck is more than equal to it.\u201d", "title": "Marlene VerPlanck, Singer of Jazz and Jingles, Dies at 84", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Marriott International, the hotel chain, wants to be clear on this point: It does not support separatist elements in China.\n\nMarriott is best known for its hospitality, not fomenting rebellion in the countries where it does business. Nevertheless, it apologized to the Chinese government on Thursday for the way it worded a customer survey \u2014 wording that has spurred intense online criticism and a government investigation.\n\nThe problem: The survey listed Tibet, a region of China, and Taiwan, an island it claims as its own, as separate countries, according to Chinese media reports. It also listed Hong Kong and Macau \u2014 territories that are ruled by China \u2014 as separate, according to the reports.\n\nThe error is a common one, and easy to make, among companies that do business there. A simple website drop-down menu labeled \u201ccountries\u201d can inadvertently bestow the nation label on places like Taiwan and Hong Kong.", "title": "Marriott to China: We Do Not Support Separatists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Consistency was a problem for Kostyuk on Wednesday, but she was able to beat another wild card, Olivia Rogowska, an Australian ranked No. 168 in the world, 6-3, 7-5.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t feel like she was 15 at all,\u201d Rogowska said. \u201cPower of her shots was up there. Her mother, Talina Beiko, also took up coaching after a professional career, which compelled Kostyuk to spend time on the court.\n\n\u201cI wanted to see her a lot, so I was practicing,\u201d Kostyuk said in an interview with WTA Insider.\n\nBeiko received a coaching violation during the match, a penalty that annoyed Kostyuk because she did not see whatever signal her mother was sending her.\n\n\u201cI was so mad,\u201d Kostyuk said, smiling. \u201cBut actually when I\u2019m mad, it\u2019s helping.\u201d\n\nWTA rules dictate that 15-year-olds are limited to 10 tournaments, but her top-five finish in the junior rankings last year allows her to play in an additional two competitions.\n\nThere will be time for her to contemplate her future schedule, but for now there is a more pressing issue: She will face fourth-seeded Elina Svitolina, the best women\u2019s player Ukraine has produced, on Friday in the third round.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Now healthy again, she beat Venus Williams in the first round on Monday before falling, 6-1, 6-3, to the qualifier Luksika Kumkhum on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cNow I\u2019m a veteran,\u201d Bencic, 20, said with a laugh.\n\nBencic first watched Kostyuk play on Wednesday, and she was impressed. \u201cI hope for her that she continues like that, and keeps enjoying all of this, and remembers the feeling how it is when you\u2019re excited the first time, first Grand Slam, and to keep it this way,\u201d Bencic said.\n\nBencic, who speaks from experience, said the most difficult thing for a highly praised teenager to deal with is the expectation of becoming an immediate champion.\n\n\u201cYou get really hyped, a lot, when you win one, two matches,\u201d Bencic said. \u201cEverybody focuses on you, there\u2019s attention \u2014 and suddenly you\u2019re the one who has to win. Which, it actually shouldn\u2019t be like that. I think that\u2019s the toughest part.\u201d", "title": "Marta Kostyuk, 15, Reaches 3rd Round of Australian Open", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "That character was a place for me to just give everything that I was dealing with to. I was dealing with my own personal pain. I was really suffering. This was the place to just rest all this pain, and rest all of this confusion, but still at the same time trying to be a strong woman.\n\nVideo\n\nYou\u2019re a glamour icon. You had to strip down everything for this role. No makeup, no wigs. Did that make you feel extra vulnerable?\n\nThe first couple of days it was hard, because I didn\u2019t realize I was depending on so many things to make me feel beautiful. So when Dee was, like, \u201cNo, we want your all-natural hair,\u201d and I said, \u201cNo, well, can we do a lace front? Can she have wavy hair?\u201d I didn\u2019t want my own textured hair. Because it\u2019s not the nicest textured hair. And I didn\u2019t really want that to be seen. Those are the things I didn\u2019t even realize that I was so insecure about. I didn\u2019t realize I was so vain. I didn\u2019t realize I was not that deep.\n\nThat\u2019s not really fair to say, though.\n\nBut it taught me a lesson. It taught me to love myself deeper. Because once I just exposed and let Florence live, I just went against the fear. It filled me up with a newfound love and a newfound confidence. It was tough at first. It was tough because I was really trying to get rid of Mary J. Blige, who was used to wigs and weaves and makeup.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat was your reaction when you saw the first daily of you as Florence?\n\nI couldn\u2019t believe it. I was not looking at myself; I was looking at a character. When I saw it at Sundance, I just broke down and cried.\n\nWhy?\n\n\n\nJust to see that character and how strong she was and how much pain she was dealing with at the same time. Every other movie I\u2019ve been in, I\u2019ve seen myself. \u201cRock of Ages,\u201d I see Mary J. Blige. \u201cPrison Song,\u201d I saw Mary J. Blige. But I didn\u2019t see myself [in \u201cMudbound\u201d], which was creepy. I was, like, \u201cWho is that?\u201d Yeah, so mission accomplished.\n\nCan you speak a bit about this moment, with people calling out alleged abusers?\n\nI\u2019m really proud of the moment. I\u2019m happy for the people being set free. There\u2019s a lot of women that have been suffering with this huge secret for years, and they\u2019re speaking, and they\u2019re helping other women feel empowered. Because this thing has caused women to feel less than. I know that feeling of having secrets that hold you and cause you to feel inferior or insecure and not equal.\n\nHas it happened to you?\n\nNot in the music industry, but from the time I was 5 up until almost adulthood I\u2019ve had those exact kinds of things happen to me. It\u2019s tough being a little girl, and it\u2019s tough being a teenager, and it\u2019s tough being a woman. By the time I got to the music business I was completely in a state of mind of \u201cI\u2019m not having it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHarassment or abuse or \u2026?\n\nEverything. A lot of things that happened to me I wasn\u2019t able to tell my parents until I was a grown woman. I stand with those women, and I\u2019m happy for them, because they\u2019re being set free mentally and spiritually.\n\nHas \u201cMudbound\u201d opened other doors acting-wise?\n\nA lot of scripts are coming in. People want to work with me. And it doesn\u2019t change anything. I\u2019m still going to work hard. I\u2019m still going to get whatever coach I need to bring whatever character to life. So many beautiful things are happening.\n\nIs faith helping you as well with this?\n\nOf course. If it wasn\u2019t for faith, if it wasn\u2019t for God, I\u2019d be dead, seriously. From 2016 to now, this is all God. This is all a blessing. There\u2019s so many things that are being completely pruned and wiped away to prepare me for this.", "title": "Mary J. Blige Dealt With \u2018Personal Pain\u2019 in \u2018Mudbound\u2019", "authors": ["Cara Buckley", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nYour book \u201cThe Future Is History\u201d traces the lives of intellectuals following the fall of the Soviet Union and the rise of Vladimir Putin. What do you make of the political climate in the United States, which feels particularly hostile to intellectuals and experts right now? The basic idea of the book \u2014 that a people robbed of the tools of self-understanding find themselves at a dead end \u2014 actually has relevance to this country. Not that I think Americans are at a dead end, but we should be cognizant of that danger.\n\nSo I can imagine you weren\u2019t enamored of the term \u201calternative facts.\u201d I get really nervous when impossible phrases are created. In academic circles, the idea of fixed facts has been problematized for a long time, so that in itself doesn\u2019t disturb me. The postmodern project was to get a better understanding of facts by questioning whether we can have them. Now we\u2019re confronted with a nihilistic project of just saying there\u2019s no such thing as facts.\n\nGessen\u2019s most recent book, \u201cThe Future Is History: How Totalitarianism Reclaimed Russia,\u201d won the 2017 National Book Award for nonfiction. Age: 50 Occupation: Journalist Hometown: Moscow Her top 5 queer-mentor heroes and (some of) their books: 1. Joan Nestle, \u201cA Restricted Country\u201d 2. Samuel R. Delany, \u201cThe Motion of Light in Water\u201d 3. Dennis Altman, \u201cHomosexual: Oppression and Liberation\u201d 4. Martin Duberman, who taught her 5. Richard Rouilard, who edited her\n\nBased on what you know about the Russian government, do you believe there\u2019s going to be evidence of collusion between this president and the Russian government? I have doubts that the investigation will be able to produce definitive evidence of sustained coordination between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. It\u2019s a lot of wheeling and dealing, a lot of freelancers and subcontractors \u2014 it\u2019s really mostly people trying to make money. There\u2019s no strategy. Will they be able to show that the government funding was for hacking the Democratic National Committee? I don\u2019t think so. I don\u2019t think that Donald Trump is capable of holding a thought for more than three seconds, so how can we possibly imagine that he actually had some sort of sustained relationship that had an articulated strategy behind it?\n\nSo much has been made of Trump\u2019s affinity and respect for Putin. What do you think Putin thinks of Trump? I think that he feels disappointed. Putin really assumed that once Trump \u2014 who had such clear admiration for him \u2014 was elected, it would be convenient for Trump to change the relationship with Russia profoundly and instantly. On a larger scale, I think that it\u2019s very difficult for Putin to deal with an unpredictable interlocutor, because he has always been the madman on the international stage. Weirdly, I think it would have been easier for Putin to deal with Hillary Clinton, who would have been tough but very consistent.\n\nIn your essay \u201cAutocracy: Rules for Survival,\u201d your third rule was that institutions will not save you. What do you make of United States institutions in the last year? A lot of what we think of as democratic institutions are informal ones, like the White House press briefing. There is no law that guarantees press access to the White House. Communication was lessening during the Obama years. There was every reason to suspect that Trump was going to create an adversarial relationship and that people were going to be faced with the impossible dilemma between sort-of-complicity and access.\n\nAt the same time, there\u2019s a strong pushback to that: It feels like a big news story drops every weekend. The question is how sustained and effective this pushback can be over the course of four or eight years. Institutions function in relationship to one another, so when you have an institution that is being destroyed, the system begins to tear. A great example of that is the travel ban \u2014 the reason the judiciary was able to act so quickly was that civil society, which is also an institution, had sprung into action. The whole democracy depends on its existence. We\u2019re seeing civil society fatigue with the different iterations of the travel ban, which is basically the exact same travel ban all over again, and that\u2019s what I\u2019m really worried about. Gradually, the fatigue is starting to stick.", "title": "Masha Gessen Is Worried About Outrage Fatigue", "authors": ["Audie Cornish"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mathilde Krim, who crusaded against the scourge of AIDS with appeals to conscience that raised funds and international awareness of a disease that has killed more than 39 million people worldwide, died on Monday at her home in Kings Point, N.Y. She was 91.\n\nHer death was confirmed by Bennah Serfaty, a spokeswoman for amfAR, the Foundation for AIDS Research, of which Dr. Krim was the founding chairwoman.\n\nWhen the nation learned in the early 1980s that the virus that causes AIDS had begun its terrifying attack upon the human immune system, Dr. Krim, a geneticist and virologist with wide experience in cancer research and a passion for causes, plunged into a fight not only against the virus but also for the civil rights of people who had it.\n\nOver the next several decades, she became America\u2019s foremost warrior in the battle against superstitions, fears and prejudices that have stigmatized many people with AIDS, subjecting them to rejection and discrimination. There is still no cure for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, which has become pandemic, although antiretroviral medication can slow the disease and may lead to near-normal life expectancy with prompt diagnosis and treatment.", "title": "Mathilde Krim, Mobilizing Force in an AIDS Crusade, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Maura Jacobson, who for 31 years made crossword puzzles for New York magazine that were beloved by aficionados for their pun-filled wit, died on Dec. 25 in White Plains. She was 91.\n\nHer death was confirmed by her husband, Dr. Jerome Jacobson.\n\nMs. Jacobson owed her career, in a way, to a traffic accident. She had dabbled in puzzle making, sending some to Margaret Farrar, the crossword puzzle editor at The New York Times, but had let the hobby lapse. Then, in 1971, she was seriously injured in an auto accident. It kept her off her feet for a year, she said.\n\n\u201cMargaret Farrar sent me grids and said, \u2018Stay well and keep working,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Jacobson recalled years later. So she began putting more effort into the craft, and by 1978 was making puzzles for a listings magazine called Cue. In 1980, New York bought Cue, and Ms. Jacobson and her puzzles were part of the package.\n\nIn a 2011 article commemorating her retirement, the magazine said she had created more than 1,400 puzzles for New York. In the universe of cruciverbalists \u2014 people good at making or solving crosswords \u2014 Ms. Jacobson was a superstar. When her name would be announced at the annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, the hall would burst into applause.", "title": "Maura Jacobson, Creator of Witty Crosswords, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Maurice Peress, a conductor who worked closely with both Leonard Bernstein and Duke Ellington, and whose twin passions for jazz and classical music were reflected in his penchant for reconstructing important concerts from the past, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.\n\nHis son, Paul, said the cause was leukemia.\n\nMr. Peress spent the last 33 years conducting the student orchestra at the Queens College Aaron Copland School of Music, where he established a master\u2019s degree in conducting. But before settling into that role he led major orchestras, conducted the premieres of important works by Bernstein and others, and helped Ellington orchestrate some of his signature compositions.\n\nMr. Peress (pronounced PER-ess) also examined the historical underpinnings of American music, most notably in his book \u201cDvorak to Duke Ellington: A Conductor Explores America\u2019s Music and Its African American Roots,\u201d published in 2004.\n\nAntonin Dvorak, the Czech composer, spent three years in the United States beginning in 1892, urging the development of an American musical tradition and famously saying, \u201cIn the Negro melodies of America I discover all that is needed for a great and noble school of music.\u201d", "title": "Maurice Peress, Conductor Who Worked With Ellington, Dies at 87", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Yet the reality is that, unless the president is properly evaluated, we have no real evidence to know with certainty if he has a mental disorder. And even if we did, we lack a clear constitutional standard for what severity of impairment would render him unfit to serve. History has shown us that former presidents have suffered conditions hampering their mental function while still in office, including Ronald Reagan, Calvin Coolidge and Woodrow Wilson. Consider the case of Reagan: He was eventually diagnosed with Alzheimer\u2019s, but if he was beginning to show symptoms in his second term, as some believe he was, that did not preclude him from finishing his term.\n\nThe experiences of those presidents provide convincing evidence that, even if there weren\u2019t a tsunami of speculation about Mr. Trump\u2019s mental condition now, Congress should consider adopting policies to standardize, and to expand as needed, the scope of presidential medical exams to include neuropsychiatric assessments.\n\nAs I have written, disorders such as psychosis, dementia, depression and addiction commonly occur in people in the age range of presidents \u2014 and any of those, when severe enough, could damage a president\u2019s ability to discharge his or her duties. The 25th Amendment provides a process for transferring power from presidents deemed incompetent. However, we still lack a defined process for applying the 25th Amendment to a president who will not voluntarily submit to an examination to evaluate mental competence. We also lack clear criteria for what behavior warrants an intervention and transfer of power to the vice president.\n\nThe 25th Amendment has been invoked only a handful of times since its ratification in 1967. But except during the Watergate scandal, these incidents mainly involved giving vice presidents the power of the presidency while the president was undergoing medical procedures that included general anesthesia.\n\nThere is another problem with the current debate over Mr. Trump\u2019s mental condition: It assumes his behavior isn\u2019t voluntary, and that his shocking or \u201cunpresidential\u201d conduct is a symptom of mental illness. This kind of thinking contributes to the stigmatization of mental illness. It\u2019s entirely possible that he simply has certain personal qualities we don\u2019t find ideal in a leader, like being a narcissistic bully who lacks basic civility and common courtesies. That he is, in a word, a jerk. But that alone does not make him mentally unfit to serve.", "title": "Opinion | Maybe Trump Is Not Mentally Ill. Maybe He\u2019s Just a Jerk.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "By 3:15 p.m. on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s team \u2014 Joseph J. The city, Mr. Lhota pointed out, has final veto power over the transit portion of the M.T.A.\u2019s capital plan. \u201cThey have the ultimate leverage,\u201d he said, \u201cthe ability to say no.\u201d\n\nAt a news conference on Tuesday in the Bronx, Mr. de Blasio weighed in on the latest skirmish. \u201cWe\u2019re going to continue to make the point that we don\u2019t like the direction the M.T.A. is taking, and we\u2019re going to be speaking up about it,\u201d he said. \u201cThe countdown clocks and the Wi-Fi and painting, having lights on bridges \u2014 all that stuff doesn\u2019t matter compared to your subway actually arriving where it\u2019s supposed to arrive on time.\u201d\n\nThe governor\u2019s office declined to comment on the interactions between the two men.\n\nThe bad blood between the governor and the mayor has included disputes over prekindergarten financing to a renegade deer apprehended in a Harlem building complex. But their protracted battle over the subway seems to have eclipsed all the others, even as riders complain that they have yet to see the kind of improvements Mr. Cuomo promised after he declared state of emergency on the subway last year.\n\nAnd the schism over the station overhauls is but a piece of the mayor\u2019s differing vision on the subway. The governor\u2019s proposal to allow special tax districts on developments near the subway as a way to help pay for the system is too broad in scope, according to the mayor\u2019s aides, and was done without consulting the city. During an appearance on a morning talk show on Wednesday, the mayor touted his plan to tax the richest New Yorkers, a so-called \u201cMillionaires Tax,\u201d to fund the subway, as more fair that Mr. Cuomo\u2019s notion to pay for it through congestion pricing, charging drivers a fee to enter Manhattan\u2019s business districts.\n\nOn Wednesday, the full M.T.A. board met at the agency\u2019s headquarters in Lower Manhattan, and both camps came prepared. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThe key to a legitimate Russia investigation has always been Republicans not named Donald Trump.\n\nIn Congress, Republicans \u2014 and only Republicans \u2014 have the power to make clear that Trump\u2019s presidency is effectively over if he fires Robert Mueller, the special counsel. At the Justice Department, Republicans can refuse to carry out any order to fire Mueller and create a firestorm if Trump subsequently fires them. And at the White House, Republicans serving under Trump can explain to him that he would create a true constitutional crisis if he tried to subvert the rule of law.\n\nWe now know \u2014 thanks to Michael Schmidt and Maggie Haberman of The Times \u2014 that Trump did try to subvert the rule of law. In June, he issued an order to fire Mueller, with three silly justifications (including the fact Mueller once quit Trump National Golf Club in Sterling, Va.).\n\nBut the White House counsel, Donald McGahn (pronounced \u201cMcGann\u201d), refused to send the order to the Justice Department, which would have had to carry out any firing. He pleaded guilty to molestation charges in November and will be sentenced later this month. He has already received a 60-year sentence for child pornography.\n\nDr. Nassar has been accused of molesting gymnasts at the Karolyi Ranch, the national training center for the United States women\u2019s gymnastics team north of Houston, as well as in his home and at other workplaces.\n\nU.S.A. Gymnastics said this week that it would not fine Ms. Maroney if she spoke up about the abuse, despite the nondisclosure agreement that she signed in 2016.\n\nUnder that agreement, Ms. Maroney would have had to pay more than $100,000 if she chose to speak out, according to a lawsuit filed last month by Ms. Maroney against the United States Olympic Committee, U.S.A.
