Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe New Hampshire Log Cabin Republicans, a conservative gay and lesbian group, said on Tuesday that it was \u201cdeeply disappointed\u201d that the measure failed.\n\n\u201cThe American Psychological Association, the American Psychiatric Association and the American Medical Association have all denounced reparative, or conversion, therapy as ineffective and potentially harmful,\u201d the group said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConversion therapy, which can include support groups and other types of interventions, aims to suppress same-sex attraction and change one\u2019s sexual orientation.\n\nAt least nine states \u2014 Nevada, Connecticut, California, New Jersey, New Mexico, Vermont, Rhode Island, Oregon and Illinois \u2014 have taken steps to prevent mental health professionals from trying to change a minor\u2019s sexual orientation, according to the National Center for Lesbian Rights and others who track legislation.\n\nOther states, however, have struggled to pass similar laws. Last year, a Colorado Senate committee killed a bill that would have banned conversion therapy for minors, the third year in a row it had done so, The Gazette reported. Similar bills also failed to advance in Maryland and Virginia.\n\nThe treatment promotes feelings of inadequacy and self-hate, Clinton W. Anderson, director of the sexual orientation and gender diversity office at the American Psychological Association, said in a phone interview. Even if someone agrees to behave differently, he added, it doesn\u2019t change who they inherently are.\n\n\u201cPeople have a lot of control over their behavior,\u201d Dr. Anderson said. \u201cBut that doesn\u2019t mean that their underlying deeply seated pattern of what we would call sexual orientation has changed.\u201d\n\nThe A.P.A. doesn\u2019t consider it a problem for a minor to have a same-sex crush, Dr. Anderson said, and when emerging sexuality is subjected to such external interventions, there can be damaging consequences.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very different when you\u2019re talking about a child because they\u2019re still developing,\u201d he added. \u201cWhat\u2019s that going to do to people? Are they going to look back in 20 years and think, \u2018Oh my God, that was abusive to me.\u2019\u201d\n\nJennifer Horn, co-chair of New Hampshire Log Cabin Republicans, is calling on lawmakers to go back to the drawing board.\n\n\u201cWe respect the fact that there are a lot of folks out there that feel like there\u2019s a problem with the language in the bill,\u201d she told WMUR. \u201cIf that\u2019s the case, we\u2019d really like to see Republicans step up and lead on getting the language right.\u201d", "title": "Measure to Ban Discredited \u2018Conversion Therapy\u2019 Fails in New Hampshire", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIs a Free Press Mr. Duterte\u2019s Next Victim?\u201d (editorial, Jan. 17):\n\nThe Philippine Constitution dictates that mass media entities must be wholly owned and managed by Filipinos. The Securities and Exchange Commission of the Philippines is mandated, among others, to ensure that media businesses are faithfully observing this constitutional provision.\n\nThe commission\u2019s chairwoman, Teresita Herbosa, who said she would defend \u201cto the hilt\u201d the commission\u2019s decision to revoke the online news site Rappler\u2019s license, is known to me as a person of unimpeachable character. She is highly respected within legal and policy circles for her commitment to the rule of law and to the public interest.\n\nEfforts to impute political motivation to this case do a great disservice to Ms. Herbosa and the institution she leads.\n\nThe commission\u2019s decision is about upholding the law. It has no bearing on the state of press freedom in the Philippines, where thousands of broadcast stations and newspapers continue to operate unhampered.", "title": "Opinion | Media Case in the Philippines", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "While the search for new treatments and cures is advancing at breakneck speed, ideas about how to help patients pay for them lag far behind. And Republicans who sometimes laud the N.I.H. as the National Institutes of Hope also support dismantling the Affordable Care Act, which could limit access to the new treatments.\n\n\u201cIf we are spending billions to incentivize the development of new drugs, I think we also have to ensure that patients can afford those drugs,\u201d said Representative Jan Schakowsky, Democrat of Illinois. \u201cIt is almost cruel to find a cure and then have it priced so high that a patient can\u2019t afford it.\u201d\n\nThe challenges facing patients and policymakers were illustrated this past week when a Philadelphia company said it would charge $850,000 for a new gene therapy to treat a rare inherited form of blindness. (The company, Spark Therapeutics, said it would pay rebates to certain insurers if the medicine, given in a one-time injection, did not work as promised.)\n\nMembers of Congress have friends, relatives and constituents who suffer from cancer, Alzheimer\u2019s and other diseases, but lawmakers may have less interaction with people who are uninsured and unable to afford doctor visits or prescription drugs.\n\n\u201cSadly,\u201d said R. Alta Charo, a professor of law and bioethics at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, \u201cthe cynic in me says it\u2019s because of the prevalence of selfishness. We all want to know there\u2019s something out there that will cure us if we need it, but many of us are quite reluctant to pay for somebody else to get cured when they need it.\u201d\n\nSherri J. Bale, a geneticist who worked at the N.I.H. for 16 years before founding GeneDx, a genetic testing company in Gaithersburg, Md., said: \u201cGene therapy has fabulous promise. We will soon be able to treat and even cure people with genetic diseases where we previously had nothing at all to offer them. But where are they supposed to get the money to pay for these treatments \u2014 thousands of dollars a month?\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat good is the research if all you do is treat people in a clinical trial and publish a few papers?\u201d Ms. Bale asked. \u201cI\u2019m afraid that patients will be left in the lurch.\u201d", "title": "Medical Research? Congress Cheers. Medical Care? Congress Brawls.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "For the 34 years Medieval Times has been in business, that monarch has been a man. But the show, which draws an estimated 2.5 million customers each year, is replacing all of its kings with queens. And its peculiar brand of dinner theater \u2014 a sort of G-rated \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d \u2014 is taking on an unlikely resonance amid the national jousting over gender equality provoked by the #MeToo and #TimesUp movements.\n\nThe new production, with a woman wearing the crown, had its debut here last fall, then opened at the castle in suburban Chicago. It was rolled out in Lyndhurst, N.J., on Jan. 11. By year\u2019s end, a queen will reign in all nine of the castles in North America.\n\nIn the show\u2019s old plot, the king had to fight off a challenger from another realm using a knight who bested five others in a tournament. In the new script, the queen has taken over for her late father (presumably the king from the previous show). She presides over a tournament to find the best knight in the land; drama ensues when a knight who has been acting dishonorably challenges her authority.\n\nLeigh Cordner, a former Marine who left his job as an FM disc jockey 30 years ago to join Medieval Times, directs the show. He started rewriting it a year and half before the sexual harassment accusations against the movie producer Harvey Weinstein, the chef Mario Batali and a host of other men started a national conversation.\n\n\u201cThe fact that a woman is sitting on the throne in our show at the same time the gender equality movement hit is a coincidence,\u201d he said. Mr. Cordner was simply responding to audience members who kept asking why women played nothing but princesses. (On the other hand, the show still refers to its waitresses as wenches.)", "title": "Medieval Times Goes Modern, Replacing Its Kings With Queens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nName Jaimie Wilson\n\nAge 22\n\nHometown Howell, Mich.\n\nNow Lives In a two-bedroom apartment in the East Village of Manhattan that he shares with a roommate.\n\nClaim to Fame Mr. Wilson is a budding folk-pop musician and baby-faced model who appears on the most recent cover of Candy magazine, as well as in advertisements for the skimpy men\u2019s underwear brand 2(x)ist. He is also something of an L.G.B.T. activist by being a plainly outspoken transgender man to his hundreds of thousands of followers on Facebook and Instagram. \u201cMusic has the power to bring people outside of the community into the community,\u201d he said.\n\nBig Break In March, about one year after he began transitioning, Mr. Wilson posted before-and-after photos (some shirtless) on Facebook that racked up 13 million views. The actress Ruby Rose commented that he was \u201clooking like a young Channing Tatum.\u201d The rapper Lil Wayne wrote, \u201cWow.\u201d \u201cPeople didn\u2019t start listening to my music until after my transition, which is funny because I had to really practice to regain my singing voice because my vocal cords had changed so drastically,\u201d Mr. Wilson said.\n\nLatest Project In 2015, he started a clothing swap program in Michigan for transitioning men and women called T Is for Trans. But like most New Yorkers with small closets, he had to close up shop when he moved to the city. He still does the occasional giveaway of chest binders (compression garments that reduce the appearance of female breasts) through Instagram Stories. \u201cClothing is the last thing you want to think about when you\u2019re spending most of your money on hormones and top surgery funds,\u201d he said.\n\nNext Thing In February he will release his first EP, funded on Kickstarter, \u201cLife Is a Journey.\u201d After playing at last year\u2019s Sziget Festival in Budapest alongside Pink and the Chainsmokers, he plans to make his first official music video and continue hitting the road. \u201cIn the future, I want to be one of those people where other artists might say, \u2018I got to headline with Jaimie Wilson.\u2019\u201d\n\nPretty Hurts While he has received an outpouring of support about his trans identity, there are plenty of detractors both online and off. \u201cI had people tell me I can\u2019t be transgender because I was such a pretty girl or because I didn\u2019t show the signs,\u201d he said. \u201cI want to show other people out there that despite what you look like or how people view you, you can do whatever you want.\u201d", "title": "Meet Jaimie Wilson, a Transgender Activist With Guitar in Hand", "authors": ["Alex Hawgood", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Long before the Google Arts and Culture app, which became the most downloaded mobile app over the weekend, art aficionados, dabblers, narcissists and soul searchers pondering a cosmic connection to distant humans have been searching for their art twins, a long-gone, sometimes fictional or unknown doppelg\u00e4nger encased in oil, sculpture or ceramics.\n\nSome set out specifically to find their twin, in an engaging pastime that gives museum visits a new focus. Others, like the Duffins, have stumbled on theirs as they wander.\n\nAs anyone who regularly looks at a social media feed knows by now, millions more need never leave home or cross a border to find that uniquely familiar face on some obscure etching. They just upload a selfie and let technology do the sleuthing.\n\nThe app was available in 2015, but its arts matching feature was introduced in mid-December. Its popularity has quickly surged, and Instagram, Twitter and YouTube users have widely shared photos of both their art twins and those of celebrities, from William Shatner to Taylor Swift. Google estimates more than 20 million selfies have been uploaded using the new feature.\n\nDr. Duffin said he was amused by his moment with the unknown soldier, described by the museum as probably a more mythological than human figure. But the resemblance had an impact on his life after he posted the photograph on Twitter, where it was widely shared without identifying him by name.\n\n\u201cA month later, all of a sudden, it started to get a lot of play in the press,\u201d Dr. Duffin, a professor of music at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, said in an interview. \u201cI would get email messages from people I had not heard from in years who knew immediately it was me.\u201d\n\nWith people seeking selfies that make a connection going back in time, museums are using the opportunity to engage with visitors.\n\nPhoto\n\nLeslie C. Denk, the director of external affairs for the Norton Simon Museum, said the museum had noticed some visitors posting photographs of themselves posing like works of art, particularly alongside sculptures by Auguste Rodin and Aristide Maillol.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cArt has the power to transport us through time, and so I think it\u2019s a joy to recognize ourselves, a friend or even a pet, in an artwork from centuries ago,\u201d she said.\n\nArt-twinning happens so often in the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston that it hosts a fan favorite every week on Instagram. The most popular piece to pose with is \u201cLittle Fourteen-Year-Old Dancer,\u201d a sculpture by Edgar Degas.\n\n\u201cIn our galleries, visitors frequently seek out their museum doppelg\u00e4nger or attempt to mimic works of art \u2014 usually as they search for the perfect Instagram shot,\u201d said Katie Getchell, the deputy director and chief brand officer at the Boston museum.\n\nAt the Brooklyn Museum, selfies with artworks are also popular. \u201cThe success of Google\u2019s project comes as no surprise to me, or probably to anyone else who works in a museum,\u201d said Brooke Baldeschwiler, the museum\u2019s senior manager of digital communications. \u201cIt\u2019s really simple. People love to see themselves in art.\u201d\n\nIf human beings are obsessed with selfies, then the Google Arts and Culture app is the addiction\u2019s enabler for the art world. It does have its critics. Some people just find facial recognition software creepy, and the app is not available in Texas and Illinois, which have some of the country\u2019s strictest laws about the collection of biometric data, including selfies. The app also has mixed results, particularly when it comes to race, gender and age.\n\n\u201cMy grandmother got Ronald Reagan\u2019s presidential portrait,\u201d said Patrick Lenihan, a spokesman for Google.\n\nA photo posted by (@joshgad) on Jan 17, 2017 at 7:30am PST\n\nFar from the virtual realm, Greco-Roman antiquities, Egyptian funerary portraits and the contemporary people who resemble them are being brought together in an exhibit in Canada called \u201cMy 2,000-Year-Old Double.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Mus\u00e9e de la Civilisation in Quebec City has narrowed down thousands of selfies to a few dozen people who resemble the artworks, arranging for them to be photographed in Montreal by Fran\u00e7ois Brunelle, whose previous projects include documenting people who look alike but are not twins.\n\nWesley Rowell, 57, who works in New York City, was one of them.\n\nHe will appear alongside his art twin, a sculpture of an unidentified man from the third century B.C.\n\n\u201cTo think about the lives, the generations, between him and me in New York City, is kind of bizarre,\u201d Mr. Rowell said. \u201cI keep going back to that human need, to feel like I am connected to everything that was before me.\u201d\n\nAmanda Bullis, 29, an actor who lives in Jersey City, was chosen for her similarity to a face carved onto a vessel, dating between 300 and 201 B.C.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Bullis sat for hours for hair and makeup. \u201cIn that moment I was able to embody her,\u201d she said, adding that it made her think about her ancestry. \u201cI just found it interesting that I am part of a larger humanity that has been evolving and changing, but largely the same, over thousands of years.\u201d\n\nDr. Duffin, the Ohio professor, said he did not think much more about his art twin after he posed with the painting in California. He is accustomed, he added, to being mistaken for another bearded fellow.\n\nStrangers often ask him, \u201cHas anyone ever told you that you look like Santa Claus?\u201d he said. \u201cAnd my answer is, \u2018Not since yesterday.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Meet Your Art Twin: A 400-Year-Old With an Oily Complexion", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s what you need to know about the device.\n\nThe Highlights\n\nThe signature feature of the Mate 10 Pro is the processor, which has a dedicated part of its silicon specifically designed for artificial intelligence.\n\nThis allows the phone to crunch algorithms and do things like automatically recognize an object so that the camera can be adjusted to focus quickly and let in the right amount of light. Huawei also says A.I. allows the phone to maximize its performance: Periodically, it will automatically do maintenance, like clearing out old system files that might otherwise slow down the phone.\n\nThe camera is notable as well. Huawei teamed up with Leica, a popular camera maker, to develop the phone\u2019s dual-lens setup. Like phones from Apple and Samsung, the Mate 10 Pro\u2019s camera can create a so-called bokeh effect, where the two cameras work together to show the picture\u2019s main subject in sharp focus while gently blurring the background.\n\nLike other modern smartphones, the Mate 10 Pro is water and dust resistant. But it also has an extra-large battery that Huawei says will last longer than that in many other phones. That\u2019s partly because of its A.I. processor, which examines how the battery is being used and changes resource allocation to prolong its life.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Mate 10 Pro also ships with a screen protector applied to its display, and inside the box there is a plastic protective case. These are thoughtful additions. The case absorbs the impact of drops, and the screen protector helps prevent scratches, which weaken the structural integrity of a display.\n\nPros and Cons\n\nIn my tests, the two best features of the Mate 10 Pro were the camera and battery. The least impressive was the display.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut let\u2019s start with the good stuff. In side-by-side comparisons with an iPhone X and Samsung\u2019s Galaxy S8+, the Mate 10 Pro came in second to Apple\u2019s offering in photo quality. All took nice photos, but the colors in the Galaxy S8+\u2019s pictures looked oversaturated, and while the Mate 10 Pro\u2019s photos appeared rich and clear, the shadow details looked better on the iPhone X.\n\nAs for the bokeh effect, also known as portrait mode, the Mate 10 Pro excelled at separating the subject from the background compared with the Galaxy S8+, but I still preferred the iPhone X because it did a better job at lighting up a person\u2019s face.\n\nThere was one area where the Mate 10 Pro was the clear winner: the battery. In my tests browsing the web over a cellular connection, Huawei\u2019s phone had roughly two hours more juice than Samsung\u2019s Galaxy Note 8 and the iPhone X.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe display \u2014 the biggest downside of the Mate 10 Pro \u2014 had a lower resolution than the Note 8, the Galaxy S8+ and the iPhone X, meaning some graphics and text looked more pixelated. Over all, text appeared crisper and websites more vibrant on the iPhone X and Samsung Galaxy screens than they did on the Mate 10 Pro\u2019s display.\n\nBottom Line\n\nThe Mate 10 Pro is an impressive smartphone, but you probably aren\u2019t going to buy it even if you get your hands on it. The lower-resolution display is a major negative, as is the lack of carrier support.\n\nHuawei said that to get technical support for the Mate 10 Pro, you can call its hotline, and for repairs, you can ship your device to a center in Texas. That\u2019s still not ideal compared with the ease of strolling into an Apple store or your carrier\u2019s nearest location.\n\nPrivacy and trust are also important. In 2012, the House Intelligence Committee concluded that Huawei and ZTE, another Chinese telecommunications company, were a national security threat because of their attempts to extract sensitive data from American companies. And in 2016, security researchers discovered preinstalled software on some Huawei and ZTE phones that included a back door that sent all of a device\u2019s text messages to China every 72 hours. That feature was not intended for American phones, according to the company that made the software. But American lawmakers have been wary of Huawei.\n\nMost important, you will have to decide whether you trust Huawei. The onus is on you to carefully read Huawei\u2019s privacy policy and determine if you feel confident using this phone. In a statement, Huawei said that privacy and security were top priorities and that it complied with stringent privacy frameworks and regulations.\n\nAt CES, Huawei\u2019s Mr. Yu described how the company had previously overcome trust hurdles \u2014 including at home in China, where Huawei\u2019s smartphones were initially distrusted by Chinese carriers because the company was a newcomer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was very hard,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we won the trust of the Chinese carriers, we won the trust of the developing market and we also won the global carriers, all the European and Japanese carriers. Over the last 30 years, we\u2019ve proven our quality.\u201d", "title": "Meet the $800 Smartphone That You Probably Won\u2019t Buy", "authors": ["Brian X. Chen", "Tech Fix"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The Rundfunkchor Berlin (Berlin Radio Choir) belongs to the city\u2019s lively family of public radio ensembles, known as ROC Berlin. In recent years, the Rundfunkchor has become something of a house choir for the Berlin Philharmonic, and won acclaim for its prominent role alongside that orchestra in Peter Sellars\u2019s well-traveled staging of Bach\u2019s \u201cSt. Matthew Passion\u201d from 2010.\n\nSince 2015, the group has been steered by the 39-year-old Dutchman Gijs Leenaars, who previously led the Netherlands Radio Choir. \u201cClassical music is always under threat in Holland,\u201d he said in an interview, referring to drastic cuts to the country\u2019s cultural budget since 2011. \u201cIn this town,\u201d he continued, speaking of Berlin, \u201cculture has such a different position from what it means in my country. Not a day goes by when I don\u2019t notice it.\u201d\n\nThe Rundfunkchor regularly works with the city\u2019s orchestras but also develops its own projects, like an immersive version of Brahms\u2019s \u201cA German Requiem\u201d that came to New York for Lincoln Center\u2019s White Light Festival in 2016. In October, the ensemble opened the season with another striking production: A collaboration with the director and designer Robert Wilson, \u201cLuther: Dancing With the Gods\u201d explored the 500th anniversary of the Reformation with music by Bach, Knut Nystedt and Steve Reich backgrounding dramatic scenes.\n\n\u201cKirill who?\u201d some asked in the summer of 2015, when the Berlin Philharmonic selected a new chief conductor to succeed Simon Rattle. The Russian maestro Kirill Petrenko is held in high esteem throughout Europe, but he is far less known (and seen) outside of it. New York audiences will have the rare opportunity to experience his work in late March during a guest performance of the Bavarian State Opera, which he has led since 2013. On the program of his Carnegie Hall debut is \u201cDer Rosenkavalier\u201d by Strauss \u2014 for whom, along with Wagner, the conductor is especially revered.\n\nFor the 45-year-old Mr. Petrenko, who arrives in Berlin in the summer of 2019, the new job is something of a homecoming: Between 2002 and 2007, he was the general music director at the Komische Oper. But in part because of his reputation as an opera conductor, the philharmonic\u2019s decision caught many by surprise. Last March, he made his first appearance with the orchestra since his appointment in a program that included a smoldering performance of Tchaikovsky\u2019s Sixth Symphony.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis orchestra has a burning ardor, which must sometimes be held in check in order to let it out at the right moment,\u201d the soft-spoken Mr. Petrenko told the cellist Olaf Maninger in a conversation taped for the orchestra\u2019s Digital Concert Hall platform. \u201cIf you know what potential this orchestra has, then as a conductor you want to acknowledge it,\u201d he added with a smile.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf all these new leaders, Vladimir Jurowski, 45, the newly minted chief conductor of the Rundfunk-Sinfonieorchester Berlin (RSB), probably has the busiest international schedule: Since 2007, this fiery Russian has led the London Philharmonic Orchestra. He has another directorship in Moscow, conducts all over Europe and is the only conductor on this list to have significant experience with American orchestras.\n\nNor is he a stranger to Berlin. After studying at the Hanns Eisler conservatory there, he was a conductor at the Komische Oper from 1997 to 2001. And like Mr. Petrenko, Mr. Jurowski is an opera specialist. He spent a dozen years leading Glyndebourne (Mr. Ticciati is his successor) and won praise for performances of Strauss\u2019s \u201cDie Frau ohne Schatten\u201d at the Metropolitan Opera in 2013 and Berg\u2019s \u201cWozzeck\u201d at last summer\u2019s Salzburg Festival.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPerhaps this affinity for opera has shaped Mr. Jurowski\u2019s flair for the dramatic. So far his first season at the RBS \u2014 the oldest of Berlin\u2019s radio orchestras, founded in 1923 \u2014 included a thunderous performance of Mahler\u2019s \u201cResurrection\u201d Symphony (featuring the Rundfunkchor), as well as that composer\u2019s rarely heard orchestrations of Beethoven\u2019s Third and Fifth Symphonies. Mr. Juwoski \u201ccountered megalomania with a depth and tonal vastness that make many recordings look pale,\u201d the Berlin newspaper Tagesspiegel wrote.\n\nAnyone following classical music in Berlin is aware of the flowering of the Komische Oper, the most rebellious and unconventional of the city\u2019s three opera houses, under its artistic director, Barrie Kosky. Next season the company welcomes Ainars Rubikis, a 39-year-old Latvian, as its general music director, a post once occupied by Kurt Masur (and by Mr. Petrenko).\n\nAfter winning conducting competitions in Bamberg, Germany, in 2010, and Salzburg, Austria, in 2011, Mr. Rubikis was the music director of the Novosibirsk Opera and Ballet Theater in Russia from 2012 to 2014. This summer, he will make an early debut as the Komische\u2019s director with Mr. Kosky\u2019s production of Shostakovich\u2019s \u201cThe Nose.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNor is he Mr. Kosky\u2019s only youthful find. The house\u2019s new Kapellmeister (or, roughly, house conductor) Jordan de Souza, 29, opened the season with a gripping performance of Debussy\u2019s \u201cPell\u00e9as et M\u00e9lisande.\u201d\n\nMatthias Schulz, 40, the incoming general manager, or intendant, of the Staatsoper Unter den Linden, is the only native German among Berlin\u2019s crop of young musical leaders. From 2012 to 2016, he led the International Mozarteum Foundation in Salzburg, and he is expected to draw on his background in both music (he is a classically trained pianist) and finance (he studied economics in his native Munich) as the manager of Berlin\u2019s oldest opera company. Unlike past intendants, however, Mr. Schulz will not stage operas for the company, which has just moved back to its historic home following a seven-year renovation.\n\nAccording to Mr. Barenboim, the music director since 1992, the Staatsoper is now making an effort to attract individual and corporate sponsorship in a country lacking a strong tradition of private philanthropy.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve worked in Europe, in Paris, here and in Chicago. I know both systems,\u201d Mr. Barenboim said. \u201cIn Chicago, it\u2019s zero public money, and in Berlin it\u2019s practically zero private money. And neither system can work in the world in the 21st century. It needs a mixture.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Barenboim called Mr. Schulz\u2019s appointment, which was suggested by the outgoing general manager, J\u00fcrgen Flimm, a \u201cvery smooth transition.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s very open-minded,\u201d Mr. Barenboim added. \u201cWe will continue to do new operas, to commission new pieces. We are attempting to start every season with something unusual.\u201d\n\n\u201cI want to show that artistic passion does not exclude economic sense,\u201d Mr. Schulz said. For Berlin, a city that is a financial drain on Europe\u2019s most successful economy, as well as a cultural mecca whose former mayor proudly proclaimed it \u201cpoor but sexy,\u201d this proposal sounds both astute and, well, mature.", "title": "Meet the New Generation Leading Berlin\u2019s Classical Scene", "authors": ["A. J. Goldmann"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Why would travelers ever plan a vacation on their own when their money will go a lot further with the help of a travel agent? At a time when booking trips online seems to be the norm, it\u2019s a message that several travel networks, each with their own group of travel agents, are increasingly pushing.\n\nWith more than 16,000 agents globally, Virtuoso is one of the largest networks. That scale can benefit the traveler: Book a trip with a Virtuoso agent, said Albert Herrera, the company\u2019s senior vice president of global product partnerships, and you will get hotel perks such as free breakfast, room upgrades and spa treatments; these extras are worth up to $450 a property. \u201cIf you\u2019re staying at three hotels on one trip, you\u2019re looking at more than $1,300 of amenities that you\u2019re not paying for,\u201d he said.\n\nSignature Travel Network has more than 7,000 agents. Ignacio Maza, the company\u2019s executive vice president, said that the network\u2019s agents can get clients benefits valued at up to $500 at hotels; on cruises, more than $1,000.\n\nSmaller networks also offer amenities for their clients: Andrew Harper Travel, for example, began in the 1970s as a hotel review company but expanded around 15 years ago to offer travel planning services; currently, the company has around 20 agents.", "title": "Meet the New Travel Agents (a.k.a. Travel Networks)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWHO The Stereotypes are Jonathan Yip, Ray Romulus, Jeremy Reeves and Ray Charles McCullough II (known as Charm).\n\nWHY THEY MATTER This production and songwriting team, based in Los Angeles, barely kept its head above choppy industry waters for years before reconnecting with an early collaborator: Bruno Mars. The Stereotypes contributed to four of the funk and soul throwback singles from Mr. Mars\u2019s 2016 album, \u201c24K Magic,\u201d including the multiplatinum title track; \u201cThat\u2019s What I Like,\u201d which hit No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100; and \u201cFinesse,\u201d which shot to No. 3 this month, thanks to a remix with Cardi B. At the Grammy Awards on Sunday, the Stereotypes are up for three awards \u2014 producer of the year (nonclassical), song of the year and best R&B song (both for \u201cThat\u2019s What I Like\u201d) \u2014 while Mr. Mars is nominated for six trophies in all, including album of the year.\n\nWHERE THEY CAME FROM The Stereotypes scored its first hit \u2014 \u201cDamaged,\u201d by Danity Kane, a girl group molded by Diddy on the MTV series \u201cMaking the Band 3\u201d \u2014 a decade ago, or at least two lifetimes in contemporary pop years. Not long after came the lean times.\n\nMr. Reeves, 35, was working at Guitar Center when he initially cold-pitched his beats to Mr. Yip, then an administrator at Interscope Records; Mr. Romulus, an aspiring music executive who once served as Jermaine Dupri\u2019s personal assistant, also worked at a record label. But the trio coalesced as musicians in 2007, working out of a spare bedroom in Mr. Yip\u2019s condo on the west side of Los Angeles. \u201cWe treated our job like a 9 to 5,\u201d Mr. Yip said in a phone interview \u2014 out of necessity. \u201cOur neighbors weren\u2019t happy with us, so we had to end around 6, at the latest.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Romulus recalled intensive bonding sessions as the three men learned one another\u2019s strengths and sonic leanings, with \u201990s pop R&B as a center point. \u201cWe would do more than just music \u2014 hit the gym together, go get lunch, literally anything to build morale,\u201d he said. (Charm, 31, joined the group in 2012.)\n\nThe Danity Kane track opened doors (and allowed the Stereotypes access to a real studio), leading to songs with Justin Bieber, Ne-Yo and Far East Movement. And at the collaborative sessions where pop hits are mined, the Stereotypes encountered the Smeezingtons, a songwriting team led by a prefame Mr. Mars.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLOSING TOUCH Though the Stereotypes and the Smeezingtons worked together on songs for Natasha Bedingfield and Travie McCoy, their paths diverged as the Stereotypes hit a slow patch, and as Mr. Mars became the kind of headlining artist who could play the Super Bowl halftime show twice in three years.", "title": "Meet the Stereotypes, the Guys Who Help Give Bruno Mars His Bounce", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "As far as Emily Cochrane is concerned, there is no Joe Biden. For Ms. Cochrane, per Times style, there is only Joseph R. Biden Jr. Ditto Michael T. Flynn, Eric H. Holder Jr., Roy S. Moore, Robert S. Mueller III, Christopher A. Wray, Michael E. Horowitz, and Donald J. Trump. The comedian Gilbert Gottfried had an old bit where he\u2019d wander into the land of the three-name people, then escape to the land of the one-named people, before finally finding himself in the land of the people with initials in their names. Ms. Cochrane would have felt right at home. \u201cThe New York Times has a very specific style in terms of people who use middle initials,\u201d she said.\n\nMiddle initials are just the beginning. As the Washington bureau\u2019s fact-checker, Ms. Cochrane reads stories generated among the 50 reporters based there; as they and editors cobble pieces together, she looks over their shoulders to confirm names, dates, quotes and other factual points across the dozen or more articles the bureau publishes each day.\n\nFact-checkers, as the name implies, validate the information in stories written by colleagues. Their duties can include re-crunching arithmetic in search of errant decimals, verifying the spelling of names and ensuring Republican politicians are not called Democrats, or vice versa (a grievous error in these partisan times). Although common at magazines, where there is generally more time to review a story, in the fast-paced world of newspapers fact-checkers are so rare as to be virtually nonexistent. Peter Baker, The Times\u2019s chief White House correspondent, said that he had never before in his 30-year career come across a full-time newspaper fact-checker. (He added that copy editors do often catch mistakes.)\n\nReporters, both at The Times and elsewhere, are expected to check their own work. Stories already go through \u201ctwo very distinct, strong layers of editing,\u201d said Thom Shanker, the assistant Washington editor. \u201cIn this environment, where everything we do is being scrutinized so carefully,\u201d Mr. Shanker said, the addition of a fact-checker constituted \u201cone more layer of safety for us.\u201d", "title": "Meet the Washington Bureau\u2019s Fact-Checkers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was the 1990s, and I was doing stand-up comedy.\n\nI left the Comic Strip late one night and headed home. When I got to my block, I realized that I had forgotten to buy cat food. I saw that a store was open and went in to buy a box of Tender Vittles.\n\nAs I walked out, I saw a man standing alone looking at the fruit. As I got closer, I realized who he was.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re Bill Murray,\u201d I said.\n\nHe looked over and smiled, but he didn\u2019t say anything.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a big fan and I do stand-up,\u201d I added.\n\n\u201cYou do?\u201d he said.\n\nI nodded.\n\nHe grabbed the shopping bag I was holding, looked inside and saw the cat food.", "title": "Meeting Bill Murray", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI ran into Coretta Scott King at La Guardia Airport. It was a year or two after Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s death.\n\nI was a driver for an airfreight company based in Queens and was at the airport to retrieve an incoming package and expedite it to its destination in Manhattan. Mrs. King was waiting for a departing flight. She had what appeared to be a couple of her daughters in tow.\n\nFeeling that I had to say something, I walked up and stammered a couple of thoughts meant to convey my appreciation for her work and Dr. King\u2019s. I sensed immediately that it sounded pretty lame.\n\nMrs. King didn\u2019t think so. She seemed to absorb me for a second, and then she thanked and blessed me in such a sincere, powerful and just plain nice way that it left me with a transcendent and unforgettable feeling of human kindness.", "title": "Meeting Coretta Scott King", "authors": ["Joe Schub", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "The most important part of the apology was its specificity. He gave a complete account of what he did. Not the salacious details that people focus on \u2014 was it in a bar? what time? who was there? \u2014 but the ugly little realities. He knew that I didn\u2019t welcome his advances. He did it anyway. He treated me differently than he treated the male writers. And when people confronted him about it, he lied.\n\nWe both know what happened, but these were the parts of the story that only he could confirm for me. Whenever I talked to friends about it afterward, they would of course say, \u201cIt wasn\u2019t your fault. You didn\u2019t do anything wrong.\u201d And I know that\u2019s true. But some small part of me would always think, \u201cYou weren\u2019t there.\u201d\n\nThe irony is, Dan was the only person who could wipe those doubts from my head. That\u2019s why I was able to accept his apology. Because I felt vindicated, to others but more importantly to myself.\n\nWas this something you were expecting?\n\nUnfortunately, Dan is not the only person who has sexually harassed me. I was groped by a producer at a party a couple years ago, after which I made an anonymous complaint to HR. As far as I know he was never personally disciplined.\n\nSo, no. Dan wasn\u2019t in the forefront of my mind. But before the holidays, I saw him tweeting about how he had been a bad person in the past, and how he was trying to do better. And all these people were congratulating him for being so brave and honest. And I thought, \u201cNo way does he get to skip past confession and go straight to absolution.\u201d So I asked him to be specific.\n\nHow would you want people to view him from here on out?\n\nI think of Dan as a work in progress. That\u2019s how I think of myself, too. It\u2019s dangerous to think of yourself as a hero and someone else as a villain. It gets in the way of empathy. We should be tearing down walls, not putting them up.", "title": "Megan Ganz on Dan Harmon\u2019s Apology: \u2018I Felt Vindicated\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "In an unusual broadside during NBC\u2019s morning hours on Monday, Megyn Kelly blasted Jane Fonda, the 80-year-old Hollywood eminence who has been critical of the NBC host in recent months.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t even 10 a.m.\n\n\u201cWhen she first complained publicly after the program \u2014 and repeatedly \u2014 I chose to say nothing, as my general philosophy is what other people think of me is none of my business,\u201d Ms. Kelly said, giving NBC viewers a glimpse of her old Fox News persona. \u201cHowever, Fonda was at it again last week, including right here on NBC, and then again elsewhere. So it\u2019s time to address the \u2018poor me\u2019 routine.\u201d\n\nThe Kelly-Fonda skirmish began in September, when Ms. Kelly asked about her use of plastic surgery in the first week of \u201cMegyn Kelly Today.\u201d Ms. Fonda seemed thrown by the question, and the clip of the interview went viral, becoming symbolic of Ms. Kelly\u2019s rocky transition from hard-hitting cable news prime time anchor to sunny morning host.\n\nMs. Fonda has brought up the interview twice in the last week \u2014 during a \u201cToday\u201d appearance with co-anchors Savannah Guthrie and Hoda Kotb, and in a Variety interview over the weekend.", "title": "Megyn Kelly vs. Jane Fonda: The Rematch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Nearly a year into her tenure as first lady \u2014 and after a week of intense scrutiny prompted by a new book that claims she had dreaded life in the White House \u2014 Melania Trump has hired a director of policy to advance her nascent platform.\n\nFor months, Mrs. Trump\u2019s East Wing had searched for a policy director who could further an agenda that has been broadly defined as helping children. On Thursday, the White House announced the first lady\u2019s choice: Reagan Thompson, 27, who had previously served as an executive assistant on the National Security Council.\n\nBefore working for the N.S.C., Ms. Thompson was a communications and policy adviser for Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, when he was a hard-line Republican congressman.\n\nIt is unclear how Ms. Thompson\u2019s background in serving Mr. Pompeo \u2014 she has described her duties with him as \u201cworking on issues for the intelligence and Benghazi committees and on Iran, Guant\u00e1namo and Asia\u201d \u2014 may help her in her new role.", "title": "Melania Trump Hires Policy Director Amid Scrutiny From New Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Quiet Radicalism of Melania Trump,\u201d by Kate Andersen Brower (Sunday Review, Jan. 28):\n\nIt seems to me that radicalism (not unlike obstruction of justice) hinges in large part on the presence or absence of intent. Melania Trump may well be essentially silent and refuse to travel with her husband or participate in other traditional wifely duties, but acting passively out of misery, dejection or hurt is not the same as forging a new path to redefine a White House role.\n\nELLEN GREENFIELD, BROOKLYN\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nKate Andersen Brower writes, \u201cMaybe Mrs. Trump is more like Michelle Obama than people think.\u201d Please never equate Melania Trump with Mrs. Obama. I suspect that one married for wealth and a gilded palace, and one married for love and a partnership to build a dream upon.\n\nIf Mrs. Trump changes the nature of the first lady\u2019s role, it\u2019s by default only. She does nothing to advance any cause and has only supported the president\u2019s ego, narcissism and repugnant behavior. There is no radicalism there \u2014 perhaps defiance, and likely just exhaustion from being married to a serial philandering misogynist.\n\nMYRA PAIGE\n\nSANTA BARBARA, CALIF.", "title": "Opinion | Melania Trump Is No Radical", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s possible she just liked the color, and what it symbolizes about new beginnings (also, of course, purity, but that takes us back to the idea something else might be going on). It\u2019s possible she had no idea that Maria Grazia Chiuri, the artistic director of Christian Dior, made waves in her first collection with a best-selling T-shirt announcing \u201cwe should all be feminists.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s possible.\n\nBut given that clothes became a symbolic dividing line during this State of the Union like seemingly never before \u2014 the members of the Congressional Black Caucus also expressed their point of view through their attire, with some wearing kente cloth and black outfits in reference to, and repudiation of, the president\u2019s denigrating comment about Africa and Haiti this month \u2014 it\u2019s hard to believe that the potential (and, indeed, probable) interpretations of her choice escaped the first lady.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEspecially because during her husband\u2019s address last year, Mrs. Trump came under fire very quickly for her choice of what was seen as a let-them-eat-cake black sequined Michael Kors suit, so she must know how much what she wears to this particular event matters. Especially because she has proved, over the last few months, perfectly cognizant of the way dress can be used as an implicit form of messaging, wearing red Dior for her trip to France for Bastille Day, and Dolce & Gabbana to the G-7 in Sicily.\n\nAnd especially given the almost elated reception that greeted her decision to wear a bright pink pussy bow blouse for an appearance during the campaign after her husband\u2019s previous public sexual shaming, the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape in which he made vulgar remarks about women. If she has paid any attention at all to public reaction (or if her team has), she cannot be ignorant of the fact that when she seems to use clothing as a subversive tool to suggest what she presumably cannot say, it provokes a groundswell of support.\n\nThough it was unclear at the time whether Mrs. Trump really understood the implications of that blouse choice, wearing a white suit to the State of the Union indicates that, indeed, she did. That when it comes to what she wears and what she means by it, she chooses her moments. Sometimes, such as at the Easter egg roll, it\u2019s just about a pretty dress. But other times, as this time, her fashion is accessorized with a pointed subtext.\n\nAt the very least, it\u2019s dangled as a tease to those who would like to think it could mean more.\n\nBut taken together with the wardrobe choices of the Democrats and the Republicans, the first lady\u2019s white suit was the final piece of what appeared to be an unprecedentedly politicized use of dress during a State of the Union. Indeed, Ivanka Trump, in understated plaid Oscar de la Renta, was one of the rare people in the room who didn\u2019t seem to be using her clothes to communicate anything other than taking a back seat. The audience was theoretically supposed to be silent \u2014 the president was talking \u2014 but their clothes spoke for them. And they did it at a time when millions of viewers across the country were watching, and could read the message in the material. Why wait for the official rebuttals? They can start white now.", "title": "Melania Trump and the Case of the White Pantsuit", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman", "On The Runway"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Americans are usually eager to see what the first lady will be wearing to the president\u2019s State of the Union address, how she will greet attendees and which guests she has invited to sit near her to watch the speech.\n\nRarely is there a question about whether she will show up at all.\n\nIn the end \u2014 spoiler alert \u2014 Melania Trump attended President Trump\u2019s first such address on Tuesday night. She entered to a loud round of applause. Fresh from Palm Beach, she sported a tan. She flashed a wide smile.\n\nAnd, for the record, she wore Dior.\n\nIt was a high-profile resurfacing for a notoriously private first lady who in recent weeks has stayed largely out of sight. Her recent absence from public life was said to have been caused, in part, by anger over reports that the porn star Stormy Daniels was paid $130,000 just before the 2016 election to keep quiet about an affair she had had a decade earlier with Mr. Trump.", "title": "Melania Trump, Again on Her Own, Emerges at State of the Union Speech", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The uncertainty over Mrs. Trump\u2019s appearance was in contrast to her willingness to show up and support Mr. Trump in the past. He has long been able to rely on his wife to step in to rationalize his behavior, dismiss his accusers or hit back against naysayers.\n\nIn 2011, Mrs. Trump appeared on TV to support her husband\u2019s attempts to pressure President Barack Obama into making his birth certificate public. In 2016, she again appeared on camera to dismiss an \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d recording from 2005 \u2014 in which Mr. Trump bragged about grabbing women\u2019s genitals \u2014 as \u201cboy talk.\u201d Mrs. Trump has also defended her husband against claims brought by multiple women that he sexually assaulted them.\n\n\u201cI believe my husband, I believe my husband \u2014 it was all organized from the opposition,\u201d Mrs. Trump told CNN\u2019s Anderson Cooper weeks before the 2016 election.\n\nAfter the story about Ms. Daniels, there was no such pushback from the East Wing, and little in the way of public statements. After days of swirling rumors and repeated refusals to comment on Mrs. Trump\u2019s whereabouts after canceling her trip to Davos, Switzerland, with the president, the first lady\u2019s spokeswoman seemed to have had enough.\n\n\u201cThe laundry list of salacious & flat-out false reporting about Mrs. Trump by tabloid publications & TV shows has seeped into \u2018main stream media\u2019 reporting,\u201d Ms. Grisham wrote on Twitter on Sunday. \u201cShe is focused on her family & role as FLOTUS \u2014 not the unrealistic scenarios being peddled daily by the fake news.\u201d\n\nA year into her husband\u2019s presidency and her own tenure as first lady, Mrs. Trump finds herself in an unusual position \u2014 and perhaps at a disadvantage. There are few things Mrs. Trump can share about herself without it being dissected \u2014 often negatively. When she revealed the tidbit that her favorite TV show was \u201cHow to Get Away With Murder,\u201d for example, the show\u2019s star, Viola Davis, did not dispute a joke that the first lady was \u201ca captive in her own home.\u201d\n\nThe polarizing nature of her husband\u2019s presidency has also isolated Mrs. Trump from her predecessors. She is not part of a small group of first ladies, including Michelle Obama and Laura Bush, who have developed a bond based on knowing what it is like to be constantly scrutinized, with their popularity linked to their husbands\u2019.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFirst ladies from Jackie Kennedy to Hillary Clinton to Laura Bush have stood by their husbands at the lowest points in their presidency,\u201d Kate Andersen Brower, an author of \u201cFirst Women: The Grace and Power of America\u2019s Modern First Ladies,\u201d said in an interview. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing a different example with Melania of a woman who has maybe had too much.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMrs. Trump\u2019s trip on Thursday to the Holocaust Memorial Museum was, coincidentally or not, in the same direction as Joint Base Andrews, where she was headed to leave for a whirlwind trip to Palm Beach, Fla. While Mr. Trump was still at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, Mrs. Trump went to Mar-a-Lago, the president\u2019s Florida estate. On Friday, onlookers at the resort were directed by the Secret Service to move their vehicles to ensure a wide berth for Mrs. Trump, who needed a secure path from her residence to the spa.\n\nAttendees at a safari-themed fund-raiser held at the resort on Friday had hoped for an impromptu visit by the first lady, but were told Mrs. Trump had left just before the event began. In her stead, guests had to be satisfied with a giant portrait of the first lady, which failed to quickly sell at auction. (A portrait of Mr. Trump sold for $17,500.)\n\n\u201cShe had to leave just as we were starting,\u201d said Terry Bomar, the event\u2019s organizer. \u201cThe Secret Service made everybody stand inside as she was coming out.\u201d\n\nThe roughly two-hour trip from Joint Base Andrews to Palm Beach International Airport cost $16,168 per hour, which means that the first lady\u2019s short trip aboard a C-32A plane cost taxpayers around $64,600, according to figures kept by the Department of Defense.\n\nThis month, the East Wing has worked to swat down all manner of rumors about Mrs. Trump\u2019s whereabouts and psyche, beginning with \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d a book by Michael Wolff that described Mrs. Trump as a first-lady-to-be who had not supported Mr. Trump\u2019s candidacy and cried on election night. Mrs. Trump, who is known to instruct her aides to publicly hit back at reports on her behalf, had them emphatically deny Mr. Wolff\u2019s account.\n\nAfter \u201cFire & Fury,\u201d two people close to Mrs. Trump stepped forward to defend her relationship with the president. One of them, Hilary Geary Ross, the wife of the commerce secretary Wilbur Ross, said in an interview in early January \u2014 days before the news of Ms. Daniels broke \u2014 that the Trumps enjoyed a \u201ccozy\u201d relationship.\n\n\u201cThey seem like a cozy, happily married couple,\u201d Ms. Ross said. \u201cYou can see they\u2019ve got the chemistry with each other. You can see it and you can feel it.\u201d\n\nThere was no similar pushback from the East Wing in light of the news about Ms. Daniels. And Ms. Ross did not respond to a request to comment further on Monday.\n\nFor her part, Mrs. Trump\u2019s only public comments in the past few weeks have been limited to tweets and a statement delivered just after her visit to the Holocaust Memorial Museum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy thoughts and prayers are with the people whose lives and families were broken by the horrors of the Holocaust,\u201d Mrs. Trump said in a statement. \u201cYet it is also through our shared humanity that we come together now in commemoration, strength and love. Take the common phrase HONEY COMB, slap AT on the end, and you have the reason someone is sleeping on the couch tonight.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n1A: I love clues that feel like noncrossword puzzle clues, but it took me a few crossings to get this one for some reason. ASPS are \u201cmenaces,\u201d as the clues says, and if you add a W at the front, you have WASPS, another type of menace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n8A: The following is an opinion from a nerd: DR. WHO is wrong, and it will always be wrong. You can Google DR. WHO until Strax returns to the planet Sontar, but you will always see it referred to as \u201cDoctor Who,\u201d and the titular character referred to as \u201cThe Doctor\u201d (as opposed to \u201cDr. Who\u201d). There is no \u2018informal\u2019 sense. And I will nerd-fight anyone who says that there is.", "title": "Member of a Crossword Zoo", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "In a phone interview on Monday night, Ms. Woodson said she was in disbelief watching the video, which was posted on the church\u2019s YouTube page.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s disgusting,\u201d Ms. Woodson said through tears.\n\nShe said that the episode had not been \u201cdealt with\u201d because it had never been reported to law enforcement authorities. On Monday, she said she reported it that day, speaking with a detective in the Montgomery County Sheriff\u2019s Department, which is just north of Houston. A sheriff\u2019s department spokesman did not return a phone call and an email seeking comment on Monday.\n\nIt is not clear whether the case could be investigated.
