Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI just hope that by me coming forward that I would give courage to one other person,\u201d Ms. Woodson said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter if I was his only victim. What matters is that this was a big problem and continues to go on.\u201d\n\nMs. Woodson said she decided to come forward with her story after glancing at the front page of USA Today in December. On the cover of the newspaper was an article about the dismissal of Matt Lauer, the anchor of NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d who was fired after a former colleague accused him of inappropriate sexual behavior.\n\nLater the same day, she said, she sent an email to Mr. Savage at his church. \u201cDo you remember that night that you were supposed to drive me home from church and instead drove me to a deserted back road and sexually assaulted me?\u201d she said she wrote to him.\n\nMs. Woodson thought he would respond. She thought he might apologize. More than a month later, when there was still no reply, she decided to go public with her story. Writing on a website about cases of sexual abuse, Ms. Woodson recounted that night in 1998 and how, she said, he asked her to unbutton her shirt so he could touch her chest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Woodson wrote that after five minutes together in the parked truck, Mr. Savage ran out of the truck to the other side, got on his knees and begged her not to tell anyone about what had happened. \u201cYou have to take this to the grave with you,\u201d she said he told her.\n\nShe said that Larry Cotton, an associate pastor of the church, The Woodlands Parkway Baptist Church, urged her to stay quiet when she told him what had happened. Instead of telling her to inform the authorities, he told her that the church would address the episode internally.\n\nMr. Cotton later left that church and became a director at a church in Austin, Tex. On Tuesday, the Austin Stone Community Church said that it placed Mr. Cotton on leave last Friday while it investigates \u201chis qualification for his current role of leadership.\u201d Mr. Cotton could not be reached for comment on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nAfter Ms. Woodson told Mr. Cotton about her story in 1998, she said the church sent Mr. Savage to apologize to her mother. But he never told her mother explicitly what had happened, leaving the impression that they had only kissed. In Sunday\u2019s service, Mr. Savage said that at the time he handled the situation in a \u201cbiblical way\u201d and resigned from the church and returned to his hometown, Memphis.\n\nMr. Savage did not return a call seeking comment on Monday evening. On Monday afternoon, the Christian publishing company Bethany House said it had canceled the July publication of his book \u201cThe Ridiculously Good Marriage.\u201d", "title": "Memphis Pastor Admits \u2018Sexual Incident\u2019 With High School Student 20 Years Ago", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The sweeping scale of \u201cIliad\u201d and \u201cOdyssey,\u201d which recount the Trojan War and Ulysses\u2019 subsequent, decade-long journey home, are obvious obstacles for theater directors, and few adaptations have seen the light of day. Boldly, Ms. Bayle uses just five actors, who all take turns playing male and female roles. The charismatic Charlotte van Bervessel\u00e8s set the tone with a sharply drawn Achilles in \u201cIliade\u201d; Helen and Andromache, two female archetypes in Greek mythology, are played by men.\n\nAlong the way, Ms. Bayle toys with the audience\u2019s expectations, and she does so in a straightforward manner, without playing the gender swaps for laughs. Nor do they compromise her adaptation of the text, which juggles between modernized dialogue and precise translations of Homer\u2019s lyrical verse. In lieu of props, red paint signals the blood being shed, and glitter the characters\u2019 armor. The spare sets proved limiting for some of Ulysses\u2019 fantastical encounters, but \u201cIliade\u201d and \u201cOdyss\u00e9e\u201d are winning examples of forward-looking storytelling.\n\nWhile Ms. Stavisky\u2019s \u201cTableau d\u2019une execution,\u201d a staging of Howard Barker\u2019s 1984 play \u201cScenes from an Execution,\u201d is more conventional in its form, its heroine Galactia, an uncompromising, freethinking painter in Renaissance Venice, remains a startling creation. She responds to a public commission with a savage painting that offends Venice\u2019s ruler, the Doge \u2014 until local officials find a way to harness its power to their advantage.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is a subtle tale of power relations, and Ms. Stavisky, the director of the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre des C\u00e9lestins in Lyon, channeled it into an elegant production, performed at the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre du Rond-Point here in Paris. Franck Th\u00e9venon\u2019s painterly lighting enhanced the semirealistic sets. Yards of red fabric draped across the stage stood for Galactia\u2019s elusive masterpiece, a wise choice that left the cast free to fill the space.\n\nThe role of Galactia was originally written for Glenda Jackson, and requires a rare mix of fearlessness and maturity. In Paris, Christiane Cohendy, an award-winning actress whose career stretches five decades, was brilliantly oblivious to other people\u2019s expectations throughout, with a mordant edge. Galactia is punished for her transgression, but only temporarily: The twists and turns paint a compellingly nuanced picture of a conservative society, and Ms. Cohendy\u2019s portrayal is attuned to the audacity and cost of a woman\u2019s artistic ambitions in it.\n\nFemale directors do not necessarily bring feel-good feminism to the stage, however, and other plays explored more unsettling territory. \u201cLa Maladie de la mort,\u201d Marguerite Duras\u2019s 1982 novella, is especially intriguing material in the hands of Ms. Mitchell, an outspoken feminist who once called Shakespeare\u2019s gender politics \u201cexecrable.\u201d Ms. Duras, one of the most distinctive voices in 20th-century French fiction, operated on the essentialist premise that men and women are fundamentally unalike, and some of her works have rapidly acquired a dated feel in that regard.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cLa Maladie de la mort\u201d (\u201cThe Malady of Death\u201d) shows the sort of relationship that fascinates Ms. Duras: A man pays a woman to spend nights with him in order to learn \u201chow to love.\u201d Along the way, there is talk of submission and violent penetration, and we are told that her body \u201ccalls for strangling, for rape.\u201d If you\u2019re inclined to follow Ms. Duras\u2019s reasoning, the woman\u2019s passive assent is a form of mercy: The man is marked by the \u201cmalady of death,\u201d and therefore doomed.\n\nMs. Duras left instructions at the end of the novella for a potential theater adaptation, but Ms. Mitchell doesn\u2019t follow them in her new production at the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre des Bouffes du Nord (part of the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre de la Ville\u2019s season). While the strong stamp she puts on the texts she works with hasn\u2019t always been popular in her native Britain, she is right at home in France, where director-dominated theater is the norm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Mitchell\u2019s is a shrewd reading of \u201cLa Maladie de la mort,\u201d billed here as a \u201clive cinema performance.\u201d In the lead roles, Laetitia Dosch and Nick Fletcher move around the sets \u2014 a hotel room, and the corridor outside it \u2014 with a crew of cameramen and technicians, while a narrator fills in the blanks. The film, occasionally interspersed with prerecorded footage, is shown on a screen above the stage.\n\nThe overall effect is to radically remove anything erotic from Ms. Duras\u2019s text. The sex scenes are obviously faked for the cameras; close-ups linger on Ms. Dosch\u2019s expressive face as she reacts to the man\u2019s demands with a mixture of disgust and practicality. She clearly plays along for the money \u2014 her life outside the hotel room is hinted at repeatedly, and a son introduced by Ms. Mitchell near the end. In that sense, Ms. Duras\u2019s ambiguous heroine gains depth and agency, and the production rejuvenates \u201cLa Maladie de la mort\u201d in the process.\n\nMs. Duras famously grew up in French Indochina, but aside from her, few French artists have grappled with the legacy of France\u2019s colonial rule over this region of Vietnam. Enter Ms. Guiela Nguyen, who wrote and directed \u201cSaigon,\u201d currently installed at the Od\u00e9on-Th\u00e9\u00e2tre de l\u2019Europe, where she is an associate artist.\n\nThis poignant saga follows interconnected characters from Vietnam in 1956, as the last French troops prepare to depart, to Paris in 1996. Performed in a mix of French and Vietnamese, it makes plain the intimate pain wrought by colonial arrogance, culture clashes and exile.\n\nAs Marie-Antoinette, the cook who runs the Saigon and Paris restaurants in which the story unfolds, the diminutive Anh-Tran Nghia gives an especially mighty performance. \u201cThat\u2019s how stories are told in Vietnam \u2014 with a lot of tears,\u201d Ms. Guiela Nguyen concludes wistfully. More of these hidden stories remain to be unearthed, and women may well take the lead.", "title": "Men Dominate French Theater, but Talented Women Abound", "authors": ["Laura Cappelle"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "COOBER PEDY, Australia \u2014 For anyone driving through South Australia\u2019s outback, it does not take long to see why patrol officers like Alan Walton are needed to keep the country\u2019s 3,500-mile-long dingo fence in order.\n\nEarly into a recent workday, Mr. Walton watched as a kangaroo \u2014 perhaps driven by the potential for greener pastures or a mate on the other side \u2014 slammed full-throttle into the fence, bouncing off like a boxer hitting the ropes.\n\nWithin minutes, Mr. Walton, 54, crawled his pickup truck, known locally as a ute, past the battered section of the fence. This time, the barrier was not breached. Other times, Mr. Walton has had to patch holes in the wire, stabilize a post or untangle an offending kangaroo.\n\nThe idea of the dingo fence is simple: to keep feral dogs and dingoes on one side of the wire and vulnerable sheep farms on the other. First built by settlers in the 19th century, the fence has a storied presence in the outback.", "title": "Mending Fences in the War Between Dingoes and Sheep", "authors": ["Serena Solomon"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Puffer jackets are practically ubiquitous this time of year \u2014 but, at least on the streets of New York, they are most commonly spotted in neutral tones. On the recent men\u2019s runways in Europe, they got a welcome upgrade: at Astrid Anderson in London and Prada in Milan, the winter staple made a bright return in fearless colors that recall the heyday of \u201990s American sportswear. Here, six versions of the quilted jacket you can buy now.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto", "title": "Men\u2019s Puffer Jackets Get a Bright Upgrade", "authors": ["Kelly Harris", "Market Report"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 The leaders of Germany\u2019s main establishment political parties emerged from overnight talks Friday morning with the outline of a possible coalition deal, bringing Europe\u2019s biggest economy one step closer to forming another government led by Chancellor Angela Merkel.\n\nBut many obstacles remain, not least a vote by members of one of the three parties, many of whom are less than thrilled to see the potential repeat of a coalition that has seen their vote share drop to postwar lows.\n\nThe marathon negotiation session, which went on for nearly 24 hours, was the final round in six days of preliminary talks among Ms. Merkel of the center-right Christian Democrats; Horst Seehofer of their conservative Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union; and Martin Schulz of the center-left Social Democrats \u2014 the three parties that have governed Germany together in a \u201cgrand coalition\u201d since late 2013.\n\nAll three lost votes and seats in the Sept. 24 elections, making the Social Democrats, in particular, reluctant to resume that arrangement. But the success of the populist Alternative for Germany, which became the first far-right party to win seats in Parliament since World War II, made it impossible for Ms. Merkel to command a majority without the support either of the Social Democrats or of a disparate group of minor parties.", "title": "Merkel Takes Step Toward New Government for Germany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBERLIN \u2014 Six days of meetings, three parties and a news blackout: If all goes well in meetings that start this weekend, that\u2019s the combination that could give Germany a new government by March.\n\nThat\u2019s the best-case situation, as leaders of Chancellor Angela Merkel\u2019s conservative Christian Democrats, their Bavaria-only sister party, the Christian Social Union, and their previous partners, the Social Democrats, sit down on Sunday for a new round of talks intended to hammer out the basis of a new government.\n\nMore than three months after the Sept. 24 election that left Ms. Merkel and her party weakened, the chancellor is under pressure and taking no chances. The goal is to hold \u201ctight and productive\u201d talks in a spirit of trust and optimism \u2014 the news blackout is aimed at preventing a repeat of a breakdown last November, when the Free Democrats walked out on the chancellor.\n\nYet each side has its doubts, especially the Social Democrats, whose supporters remain unconvinced that a third government with the party that was previously its main rival is in its best interest. Here is a look at some of the issues that could prove to be the most divisive.\n\nPhoto\n\nImmigration and Refugees\n\nThe huge influx of migrants has emerged as a polarizing issue in Germany and contributed to the drop of 14 percentage points in support overall for the negotiating parties. Many of those voters switched to the far-right Alternative for Germany, which campaigned on an anti-immigrant platform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nImmigration remains one of the biggest sticking points in the talks. Conservatives and Social Democrats are split over the number of people who should be allowed to enter the country and to apply for protection on humanitarian grounds. Ms. Merkel and the Bavarians are holding to a limit of 200,000 applications, but the Social Democrats are opposed to any restrictions.", "title": "Merkel and Other German Leaders Try, Again, to Form a Government", "authors": ["Melissa Eddy"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe second season of \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d is getting bigger.\n\nMeryl Streep has been cast in the Emmy-winning HBO series, the network said Wednesday, joining Nicole Kidman and Reese Witherspoon as television continues to attract major stars.\n\nMs. Streep, who received her 21st Oscar nomination this week for \u201cThe Post,\u201d has not done much TV work over the years, though she has won three Emmys, including one last year for outstanding narrator for the Netflix documentary \u201cFive Came Back.\u201d\n\nIn \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d Ms. Streep\u2019s character comes to the show\u2019s beachside California town \u201csearching for answers\u201d following the death of her son, Perry, played by Alexander Skarsgard. Her character is the mother-in-law of Ms. Kidman\u2019s character.\n\nThough HBO hasn\u2019t announced the rest of the cast, the network said it expected that most of the actors from the first season would return. TV Line reported this week that even Mr. Skarsgard was expected to return in some way.\n\nThe next season will based on a story by Liane Moriarty, whose book inspired the first season. HBO has not said when it expects the show to return but the earliest it could be on the air would be 2019.", "title": "Meryl Streep Joins the Cast of \u2018Big Little Lies\u2019", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "HANKS There was a reference to her.\n\n(To Mr. Hanks) Especially you stepping into a role that was iconically done. How do you go about that differently?\n\nHANKS I viewed this as the story of the week that Katharine Graham became Katharine Graham. In which case I had the juicy aspect of playing the only ally she had. You know, philosophically, the relationship that they had was based on so much stuff. You might as well just call it love, respect, empathy, understanding, professional moxie.\n\nSTREEP Mutual admiration.\n\nHANKS It\u2019s also cantankerous, like when he said, \u201cKatharine, get your finger out of my eye.\u201d From the moment we both read it and said, \u201cOh, I\u2019m not going to let this pass me by,\u201d it grew into the specifics of what the Pentagon Papers were. It actually bolstered the story of the week that Katharine Graham became Katharine Graham.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe was filled with such self-doubt. And it dogged her her whole life. She felt like she was in a holding pattern until her son came of age and became the publisher. Where do you think she found that mettle to say, \u201cLet\u2019s do it, let\u2019s publish\u201d? Her advisers were against it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSTREEP Where do the hardest things come from? They come from deep. Usually they come from your parents. Her father was a formidable figure, and her mother was even more terrifyingly important in her life. Absent, but the absence was important. Katharine Graham was someone who was a product of her time. It was the whole culture that undermined all women, especially women that should\u2019ve had the most agency of all \u2014 highly educated wealthy women who had every opportunity to step into important places in life but they sat back. The more I read about her, the more I thought, \u201cWho do you think you are trying to be \u2014 Katharine Graham?\u201d She was so thoughtful, deep-principled and wily in that way that women had to be when they were only the second tier of a society.\n\nHANKS There was that moment where the men stayed and talked about policy and current events, and the women went in the other room.\n\nI didn\u2019t know that still happened in the early \u201970s.\n\nSTREEP You have to remember that I was in graduate school when I was first allowed to get a credit card without a male family member signing for me.\n\nThe film is a model for men and women working together respectfully, which, who would have thunk it, is what we need, that good example.\n\nSTREEP Yeah, but just think if I had been the managing editor of The Washington Post and you had been my publisher. If I said, \u201cGet your finger out of my eye.\u201d\n\nHANKS You would\u2019ve been a bitch.\n\nSTREEP I would\u2019ve been fired. And that\u2019s what I mean about the imbalance. There\u2019s a tolerance for a certain kind of thing. I think women also have to step up and get able to do that.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere are echoes of Nixon in what we\u2019re hearing now from the White House, with the difference being that the person in the White House is saying that real reporting is \u201cfake news.\u201d Was it gratifying to do a movie set when people actually believed things?\n\nHANKS The assault on the First Amendment under the Nixon administration was old school, a D-Day version of \u201cLet\u2019s stop this story because it\u2019s national security and they\u2019re traitors if they print it. Because if they dare print it, they\u2019ll find out that we lied. And if they know that we\u2019re lying, we can\u2019t do our jobs.\u201d What\u2019s happening now is this guerrilla war that is going on against the First Amendment. This idea now that has actually been verbalized by various people high up in the current administration, that there is such a thing as [an] \u201calternative fact.\u201d It gives validation to what is patently false, that the purveyors know is a lie, and worse, know that it is completely unconfirmed and is scurrilous. And in that realm comes some degree of the same message: \u201cDon\u2019t let them find out the truth, because if so we can\u2019t stay in power.\u201d All of this stuff that was going on was not lost on any of us.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow do we rebuild faith in these institutions?\n\nHANKS Well, I think it\u2019s a marathon. It\u2019s the long haul. Eventually I think the truth does come out.\n\nAt The New York Times, colleagues feel that this is a New York Times story. They broke the Pentagon Papers. What are your thoughts on that?\n\nHANKS I read an article before we even started shooting, which was \u201cHow dare they do this movie about The Washington Post when it was us?\u201d We\u2019re all reacting off what The New York Times did. They did not have Katharine Graham. They did not have that side of it. The Times gets all the props in the world. Have [your colleagues] rest assured that they get props.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI\u2019ve got to shift conversation to the news these days, sexual harassment. One thing that struck me after the Harvey Weinstein accusations broke was people were saying, \u201cWhat is Meryl going to say?\u201d They were waiting for you.\n\nSTREEP I know. I found out about this on a Friday and went home deep into my own life. And then somebody told me that on \u201cMorning Joe\u201d they were screaming that I haven\u2019t responded yet. I don\u2019t have a Twitter thing or \u2013 handle, whatever. And I don\u2019t have Facebook. I really had to think. Because it really underlined my own sense of cluelessness, and also how evil, deeply evil, and duplicitous, a person he was, yet such a champion of really great work.\n\nYou make movies. You think you know everything about everybody. So much gossip. You don\u2019t know anything. People are so inscrutable on a certain level. And it\u2019s a shock. Some of my favorite people have been brought down by this, and he\u2019s not one of them.\n\nWhat do you make of the fact, though, that people are waiting for you to speak?\n\nSTREEP I don\u2019t want to hear about the silence of me. I want to hear about the silence of Melania Trump. I want to hear from her. She has so much that\u2019s valuable to say. And so does Ivanka. I want her to speak now.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat have you experienced over the years and how have you dealt with it?\n\nSTREEP I have experienced things, mostly when I was young and pretty. Nobody comes on to me [now]. So I wouldn\u2019t have had that more recently. But back in the day, when everybody was doing cocaine, there was a lot of [expletive] behavior that was inexcusable. But now that people are older, and more sober, there has to be forgiveness, and that\u2019s the way I feel about it.\n\nDo you want to go into specifics?\n\nSTREEP No, no, I don\u2019t. I mean, I was really beaten up, but I don\u2019t want to ruin somebody\u2019s mature life. I just don\u2019t. I do think if the world is going to go on, we have to find out a way to work together, and know that it\u2019s better for men if they respect us deeply as equals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGoing back to your early days, people are wondering if you had problems with Dustin Hoffman, and your thoughts on the talk around him, to put it euphemistically. Did he slap you?\n\nSTREEP That was when we were making \u201cKramer vs. Kramer.\u201d This is tricky because when you\u2019re an actor, you\u2019re in a scene, you have to feel free. I\u2019m sure that I have inadvertently hurt people in physical scenes. But there\u2019s a certain amount of forgiveness in that. But this was my first movie, and it was my first take in my first movie, and he just slapped me. And you see it in the movie. It was overstepping. But I think those things are being corrected in this moment. And they\u2019re not politically corrected; they\u2019re fixed. They will be fixed, because people won\u2019t accept it anymore. So that\u2019s a good thing.\n\n(To Hanks) What do you make of this #MeToo moment?\n\nHANKS I know that I have participated in crude humor worthy of a baseball locker room on a set. And that\u2019s bad words, and a degree of stupid sexuality in the confines of the circus. I was asked by Diane Rehm on NPR if I had ever been aware of this type of sexual predatory behavior. And I said: \u201cWell, it\u2019s easy to say no. I mean, I\u2019m oblivious to an awful lot of this. But I\u2019d be a fool to say that it\u2019s never happened on some job I\u2019ve had, because I\u2019m not in every office.\u201d But four days after the Harvey Weinstein stuff broke someone wrote, \u201cWho says it\u2019s too late to learn new behavior?\u201d There\u2019s no reason not to view this as a reckoning that is going to make us a better society.\n\nSTREEP There shouldn\u2019t be the idea of a locker room. The payload is unloaded on women, because that\u2019s the last group it\u2019s kind of O.K. to demean, degrade.\n\nDid either of you feel \u2014 \u201ccomplicit\u201d is a tough word, but that you might have put on blinders?\n\nSTREEP Well, honestly for me in terms of Harvey, I really didn\u2019t know. I did think he was having girlfriends. But when I heard rumors about actresses, I thought that that was a way of denigrating the actress and her ability to get the job. That really raised my hackles. I didn\u2019t know that he was in any way abusing people. He never asked me to a hotel room. I don\u2019t know how his life was conducted without people intimately knowing about it.\n\nHANKS I would claim that I was never knowingly complicit, but that doesn\u2019t mean I wasn\u2019t oblivious. You know what\u2019s oddly liberating about this is that we would go off and make movies that have absolutely nothing to do with any of these topics, but journalists bring them up, you know?\n\nSTREEP But that\u2019s because we have the pulpit. You don\u2019t know that when you go to drama school. You take out those loans, you think, \u201cWell, maybe I can pay those back.\u201d You don\u2019t think somebody\u2019s going to ask you to make a speech in front of the Committee to Protect Journalists.\n\nHANKS Or whether Social Security should be privatized.\n\nDo you think it\u2019s out of place?\n\nHANKS No, not on this movie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSTREEP It\u2019s great to be asked to step up because you know what, everybody should.\n\nHANKS And this movie \u2014 this is what this entire film deals with. We made this movie about 1971, but it really is about 2017. There\u2019s no reason not to get involved in what this overpowering discussion is about.\n\nYou\u2019re both beheld as icons. The Washington Post review said, \u201cIcons playing icons.\u201d\n\nHANKS Oh dear.\n\nSTREEP Uh oh.\n\nHANKS Oh my.\n\nSTREEP Good thing we don\u2019t read the reviews.\n\nHANKS Here comes hubris right up the track to take us down.\n\nBut you\u2019d never worked together before. Had it come close?\n\nHANKS I will say that I\u2019ve never been actively involved in something that, quite frankly, warranted Meryl to be in the movie.", "title": "Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks on the #MeToo Moment and \u2018The Post\u2019", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "BARCELONA, Spain \u2014 Lionel Messi scored twice in the span of three minutes during a 5-0 win over Celta Vigo on Thursday that sent Barcelona through to the quarterfinals of the Copa del Rey.\n\nMessi, who also created Barcelona\u2019s third goal for Jordi Alba, set his team on its way to a 6-1 aggregate victory with his 21st and 22nd goals in all competitions this season.\n\nAlba had provided the assists for Messi\u2019s strikes in the 13th and 15th minutes, and Messi returned the favor by setting up Alba in the 28th.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez made it 4-0 before halftime, and Ivan Rakitic headed in a corner kick by Dembele in the final minutes to complete the rout.", "title": "Messi\u2019s 2 Goals Help Barcelona Advance in Copa del Rey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Metropolitan Opera fired the veteran British stage director John Copley this week after receiving a complaint about what the company described as \u201cinappropriate behavior in the rehearsal room.\u201d\n\nMr. Copley, 84, has been one of the opera world\u2019s foremost directors for decades. He was at the Met directing a revival of his 1990 production of Rossini\u2019s \u201cSemiramide\u201d when a member of the chorus reported that Mr. Copley had made him uncomfortable at a rehearsal on Friday with a sexually charged remark, according to two people familiar with the complaint.\n\nThe Met said in a statement that \u201cfollowing a complaint from a chorister about inappropriate behavior in the rehearsal room that was received on Monday, Jan. 29, John Copley is no longer directing the revival of \u2018Semiramide\u2019 that will open on Feb. 19.\u201d\n\nWilliam Guerri, Mr. Copley\u2019s manager at Columbia Artists, could not immediately be reached for comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe news of the firing stunned the opera world, and a number of prominent British critics and singers who have worked with him complained on social media that it seemed like an overreaction.\n\nMr. Copley\u2019s dismissal came as the Met has been investigating accusations against its former music director, James Levine, whom it suspended in December after The New York Times reported the accounts of four men who said that he had sexually abused them decades ago, when the men were teenagers or his students. Mr. Levine has denied the accusations.\n\nQuestions have been raised about what Met officials knew about Mr. Levine\u2019s suspected behavior, given that he had been with the company for more than four decades and that rumors about his private life had swirled for nearly that long. In the case of Mr. Copley, the company acted swiftly after receiving a complaint.", "title": "Met Opera Fires Stage Director, Citing \u2018Inappropriate Behavior\u2019", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "After another season of many injuries and criticism of how they handle players\u2019 health, the Mets have hired a specialist to address the concerns by revamping their medical and training procedures.\n\nThe specialist, Jim Cavallini, a former fitness expert at EXOS \u2014 a private company that works with elite athletes and the military and uses advanced medical analytics \u2014 will be the team\u2019s first-ever director of high performance, according to several people familiar with the move. They were not allowed to talk publicly about the hiring because the team had not yet announced it.\n\nCavallini, among other measures, is expected to bring the Mets in line with several other teams and leagues by using biometrics \u2014 the gathering of a range of data from players\u2019 bodies \u2014 and training technology to improve players\u2019 health and performance.\n\nHis position was created in response to a rash of injuries last season in which the Mets\u2019 communication, medical care and oversight of training were called into question by players, fans, agents and commentators.", "title": "Mets, Playing Catch Up, Hire Specialist to Avert Injuries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The arrest has rattled officials in Mexico City, where the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, presides over the federal government. Mr. Guti\u00e9rrez was a top financial aide to the former president of the party, Manlio Fabio Beltrones, a major power broker who has also been described as the mastermind of the embezzlement scheme, according to the documents reviewed by The Times.\n\nThe investigation has the potential to derail the party\u2019s ambitions to maintain power in this year\u2019s presidential elections. Corruption and impunity have been stains on the legacy of Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto, who is suffering some of the worst approval ratings in a quarter century. As the nation hurtles toward elections this summer, analysts say the PRI is growing desperate to keep a lid on any potential corruption scandals.\n\nIt is in this environment that Mr. Corral, a governor who hails from an opposition party, has set out on his crusade against corruption. Now, the governor appears to be gambling with his state\u2019s finances to preserve his investigation.\n\n\u201cThere is a clear intention to financially strangle the state,\u201d Mr. Corral said.\n\nOn Monday, the governor cried foul publicly, claiming that the federal government had reneged on its commitment to Chihuahua. According to documents reviewed by The Times, the federal Ministry of Finance signed four agreements in December with officials in Chihuahua promising to transfer roughly $5 million to the state by the end of the month.\n\nAs the year\u2019s end drew near, Mr. Corral said, the money had not arrived. To date, only one of the agreed payments, for roughly $1 million, has been sent, state officials said.\n\nBut when Mr. Corral called to inquire about the missing funds, he said, he was told a meeting in person was required to resolve the matter.\n\nPressed for time, and with state salaries to pay, Mr. Corral said he had been forced to take a bank loan to cover the shortfall, a costly expenditure for a state with ailing finances. Several days passed before Mr. Corral said he was able to sit down with the minister of finance, Jos\u00e9 Antonio Gonz\u00e1lez Anaya.", "title": "Mexican Governor Says His State Is Being Punished for Corruption Inquiry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Just like in any sports movie worth its salt, the montage told the story best.\n\nIn early May 2017, Michael Eisner arrived at the Guildhall in Portsmouth, England, to face 1,500 fans of the city\u2019s soccer team. His task was a delicate one: to persuade at least 75 percent of them to sell their beloved club, Portsmouth F.C., to \u201can ancient Hollywood executive\u201d and his sons.\n\nThere would be, he knew, a degree of skepticism. Portsmouth\u2019s previous experience with foreign owners suggested they brought nothing but trouble. First under Russian-Israeli, and then Emirati, Saudi and Nepali ownership, the century-old club had sunk all the way from the Premier League to League Two, English soccer\u2019s fourth tier. It had flirted with oblivion; only a consortium comprising some 3,000 local fans, reaching into their own pockets, had saved it from extinction.\n\nFacing those fan-owners, Eisner realized he had a tough sell. He knew it would not be enough to turn up to the Guildhall and \u201csit on a stool and pontificate.\u201d A naval base on England\u2019s south coast, Portsmouth is a tough, tight-knit sort of a place; being lectured by a mogul who had just jetted in from California with no prior knowledge of or investment in soccer would not go over well.", "title": "Michael Eisner Sketches a Happy Ending for Portsmouth F.C.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wolff countered by saying that he had absolutely spoken to the president and had done so after the inauguration.\n\n\u201cWhether he realized it was an interview or not, I don\u2019t know, but it certainly was not off the record,\u201d he said.\n\nHe said that, cumulatively, he had spent about three hours with the president during the campaign and in the White House.\n\n\u201cWhat was I doing there if he didn\u2019t want me to be there?\u201d he said.\n\nExcerpts from \u201cFire and Fury\u201d began to appear online earlier this week, leading to a break between Mr. Trump and his onetime chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, who is quoted in the book calling Donald Trump Jr.\u2019s actions during the campaign \u201ctreasonous\u201d and \u201cunpatriotic\u201d and insulting Ivanka Trump.\n\nMr. Wolff characterized the book as an investigation of what it was like to work with Mr. Trump. He wrote that the president\u2019s associates called him a \u201cmoron\u201d and an \u201cidiot,\u201d and almost unanimously described him as being \u201clike a child.\u201d", "title": "Michael Wolff Says Trump Has Less Credibility Than \u2018Anyone Who Has Ever Walked on Earth\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "On Thursday, Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers threatened to sue Mr. Wolff\u2019s publisher, Henry Holt, if it did not halt the book\u2019s release and apologize for its contents \u2014 an extraordinary attempt by a sitting president to stifle critical coverage. Henry Holt responded by moving up the book\u2019s release by four days. Mr. Wolff may be looking at his first No. 1 best seller.\n\nEven for the brazenly confident Mr. Wolff, a status-mad needler with a habit of being ejected from expensive restaurants, this is a new level of notoriety. He is accustomed to angering the Manhattan power elite, not the leader of the free world. \u201cIt\u2019s almost a natural evolution of Michael Wolff, that one day the president would be talking about him from the White House,\u201d said Janice Min, the former editor of The Hollywood Reporter, where Mr. Wolff is a columnist.\n\nHis acidic portrayal of Mr. Trump as a president in over his head, disdained by aides who are astounded by his lack of fitness for the job, has dominated headlines and social media for days, along with his purportedly verbatim quotes from figures like Mr. Bannon and Mr. Murdoch dismissing Mr. Trump as a fool.\n\nBut Mr. Wolff has picked up as many foes as fans during his years as a slashing columnist \u2014 perhaps more, even \u2014 and critics have raised questions about the veracity of his reporting, saying that he has a history of being casual with his facts.\n\n\u201cHistorically, one of the problems with Wolff\u2019s omniscience is that while he may know all, he gets some of it wrong,\u201d David Carr, the late New York Times media columnist, wrote in 2008, reviewing a Wolff book that, he pointed out, contained errors.", "title": "Michael Wolff, From Local Media Scourge to National Newsmaker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe interviews and processing of green cards is extraordinarily slow and challenging,\u201d said Sara Curran, a migration expert and the director of the Center for Studies in Demography and Ecology at the University of Washington.\n\nThat is especially true for those who are living in the country illegally.\n\n\u201cNot only could you put yourself at risk, but if you don\u2019t have a good enough attorney, then it\u2019s pretty hard to get through the system without being caught up by a technicality,\u201d Ms. Curran said.\n\nMr. Garcia was ordered removed by an immigration judge in 2006, said Khaalid Walls, a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, in a statement on Tuesday. Mr. Garcia appealed the ruling, Mr. Walls said, and was told he could voluntarily leave.\n\n\u201cAfter he failed to depart within the timeline of the agreement, he became subject to a final order of removal in 2009,\u201d the statement said. \u201cICE exercised prosecutorial discretion on multiple prior occasions in Mr. Garcia-Martinez\u2019s case in 2011, 2012 and 2014.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Garcia\u2019s deportation was continually delayed during his annual meetings with immigration officials, Ms. Garcia said.\n\n\u201cThey knew we were trying to fix his status,\u201d Ms. Garcia said.\n\nThis year, however, was different.\n\n\u201cThe officer told us because of the new Trump administration, because he had an order of supervision and an order of deportation, he had to leave,\u201d Ms. Garcia said.\n\nIn fiscal year 2017, which ended on Sept. 30, ICE removed 226,119 unauthorized immigrants, which is nearly 6 percent fewer than the number deported in 2016 under President Barack Obama, and 45 percent fewer than in 2012, when Mr. Obama deported an unpredecented 409,849 people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe number of unauthorized immigrants arrested, however, has risen during the Trump administration. In fiscal year 2017, ICE conducted 143,470 immigration-related arrests, 30 percent more than in 2016.\n\nMr. Obama created the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, in 2012 to protect \u201cDreamers\u201d \u2014 young immigrants who, like Mr. Garcia, were brought to the country illegally as children. The program does not apply to Mr. Garcia, however, because of its age limit.\n\nWith the program, Mr. Obama was aiming to \u201cappease his fairly well-mobilized DACA community \u2014 mobilized in part because of the crackdown he initiated,\u201d Ms. Curran said.\n\nMr. Trump said in September that he wanted to end DACA, and critics of that decision sued his administration. Last week, a federal judge ordered the government to accept renewal requests for the program, but the legal battle continues.\n\nMs. Garcia said her husband had asked the immigration officials to wait until new DACA legislation passed, with the hope that the age limit might be modified, but the request was denied.\n\n\u201cAs ICE Deputy Director Thomas Homan has made clear, ICE does not exempt classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement,\u201d Mr. Walls said in the statement.\n\nMr. Garcia is still pursuing a green card, his wife said. But it could take up to 18 months to arrange a visit with the consulate in Mexico.\n\nShe urged others to be sympathetic toward the issue of immigration.\n\n\u201cGet to know the facts before you make a judgment,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd realize that children are being affected emotionally, psychologically.\u201d", "title": "Michigan Father Deported After Living in U.S. for 30 Years", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Lou Anna K. Nassar, a former university doctor who was accused of molesting scores of female athletes.\n\nThe trustee, Mitch Lyons, broke ranks with the eight-person board one day after it issued a statement declaring its support for the president, Lou Anna K. Simon, who was appointed in 2005.\n\nIn his statement, Mr. Lyons said he had been \u201cvery troubled\u201d since the board\u2019s remarks. He said that although he agreed with the board\u2019s request for the state\u2019s attorney general to review the situation, he believed that the public had \u201clost confidence\u201d in Dr. Simon \u2014 and that the loss was \u201cirreparable.\u201d\n\nNoting that he did not think Dr. Simon \u201cknowingly engaged in any cover-up or criminal wrongdoing,\u201d Mr. Lyons said the university\u2019s institutional accountability had nonetheless been compromised.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t feel that President Simon can survive the public outcry that has been generated by this tragedy,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cI feel that our best recourse is for President Simon to resign immediately in order to allow the healing process to begin.\"", "title": "Michigan State Trustee Asks President to Resign Over Nassar Scandal", "authors": ["Matt Stevens", "Jason M. Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director, spent the weekend managing the shutdown of the federal government. On Tuesday, he turned his attention back to his secondary job running the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a government agency he would probably shut down if he could.\n\nIn a 1,118 word mission statement that was sent to the bureau\u2019s staff on Tuesday, Mr. Mulvaney, the acting director, outlined a vision for an agency that enforces financial regulations and consumer protections with \u201chumility and prudence\u201d and that will no longer \u201cpush the envelope\u201d when it comes to jurisdiction and scope. Mr. Mulvaney insisted that he would not shutter the bureau, if only because doing so would be against the law.\n\n\u201cWhen I arrived at C.F.P.B., I told folks that despite what they might have heard, I had no intention of shutting down the Bureau,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney wrote. \u201cIndeed, the law doesn\u2019t allow that, and as members of the Executive Branch we are charged with faithfully executing the laws.\u201d\n\nThe consumer bureau, which was created by the 2010 Dodd-Frank law, has been an ongoing target of Republican lawmakers, who complain that its mandate is too broad, that it has too much power and that its director is unaccountable. The agency is loathed by Republicans because its authority is intended to be independent of the White House and Congress.", "title": "Mick Mulvaney Calls for \u2018Humility\u2019 from Consumer Financial Protection Bureau", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nI\u2019ve never been great with deadlines.\n\nIt\u2019s a flaw I\u2019m keenly aware of, and one I actively try to counter. But despite my best efforts, it\u2019s forever lingering in the background, an insatiable little gremlin that devours my productivity. It is definitely one of my things.\n\nYet of the countless articles, books and so-called lifehacks about productivity I\u2019ve read (or written!), the only \u201ctrick\u201d that has ever truly and consistently worked is both the simplest and the most difficult to master: just getting started.\n\nEnter micro-progress.\n\nPardon the gimmicky phrase, but the idea goes like this: For any task you have to complete, break it down into the smallest possible units of progress and attack them one at a time.", "title": "Micro-Progress and the Magic of Just Getting Started", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 Microsoft has spent years adjusting its business to reflect a shift from traditional software sales to cloud computing services delivered over the internet.\n\nIt is a bet that continues to pay off for the company \u2014 as was evident in its quarterly earnings released Wednesday.\n\nThe report was blemished by a charge of $13.8 billion related to recent changes in tax law in the United States, which caused Microsoft to report a net loss. But putting aside the tax-related charge, which was widely expected and will probably impact other tech companies, Microsoft\u2019s business showed the kind of growth that has attracted investors in recent years.\n\nThe portion of Microsoft\u2019s cloud business that involves selling to companies \u2014 called commercial cloud \u2014 grew 56 percent, to $5.3 billion, in the quarter that ended on Dec. 31. Like many legacy software companies that cater to the huge corporate computing market, Microsoft was caught off guard by the emergence of cloud computing in the form of online storage and computing services offered by the internet retailer Amazon.", "title": "Microsoft Sales Lifted by Cloud Computing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Having migraine headaches increases the risk for cardiovascular diseases, a new study has found.\n\nUsing the Danish National Patient Registry, researchers matched 51,032 people with migraines, 71 percent of them women, with 510,320 people in the general population without migraines. The subjects were, on average, age 35 at the start of the study, and researchers followed them for 19 years.\n\nThe absolute risk for cardiovascular disease was small, unsurprising in a group this young. Nevertheless, after adjustment for other variables, over the course of the study people with migraines had a 49 percent increased chance of heart attack, and roughly double the risk of stroke. They also had a 59 percent increased risk of a blood clot in their veins. These risks were even higher in the first year after a migraine diagnosis.\n\nThe observational study, in BMJ, found no association of migraine with peripheral artery disease or heart failure.\n\n\u201cWe now have accumulating evidence that migraine is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. It\u2019s important to take it into consideration,\u201d said the lead author, Dr. Kasper Adelborg, a postdoctoral researcher at Aarhus University. \u201cAnd it\u2019s important to find out if the agents that prevent migraine could also reduce the burden of cardiovascular disease.\u201d", "title": "Migraines Increase the Risk of Heart Attacks and Strokes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "MONTREAL \u2014 After fleeing to Montreal from Long Island, Marlise Beauville felt, she said, as if she had reached the Promised Land.\n\nShe entered the country last summer without immigration papers, yet received a work permit, a monthly stipend of 600 Canadian dollars, or $480, free health care and free French lessons. The weather has become bone-cold chilly but her Canadian neighbors are warm.\n\nThough it is not clear that she will be able to stay, she is hunkering down, adamant that limbo in Canada is better than returning to Haiti, where she fears that the family of her dead husband will kill her. \u201cI won\u2019t \u2014 I can\u2019t \u2014 go back to Haiti,\u201d said Ms. Beauville, a caregiver from Anse-\u00e0-Veau, Haiti, who was visiting a Haitian community center here the other day.\n\nMs. Beauville was one of a surge of thousands of Haitian migrants who crossed over the border from the United States to Quebec last summer, spurred by a May announcement by the Trump administration that Haitians could lose their temporary protected status in the United States, granted after the 2010 earthquake that devastated their country.", "title": "Migrants Fleeing to Canada Learn Even a Liberal Nation Has Limits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Like Roosevelt, the environmentalist John Muir was left at a loss for words by the canyon\u2019s beauty, writing in 1902 that no artist could do justice to its colors: \u201cAnd if paint is of no effect, what hope lies in pen-work? though some remain skeptical.\n\nWhen Mr. Pence announced his first trip to the Middle East, he initially hoped to draw attention to the persecution of Christians in the region, as well as nudge Israelis and Palestinians toward peace.\n\nThings didn\u2019t go as planned.\n\nMr. Pence wrapped up the trip to Israel, Egypt and Jordan on Tuesday, having been rebuffed by top Christian leaders in those countries in protest over Mr. Trump\u2019s decision last month to break with decades of American policy \u2014 and recognize Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital.\n\nIt\u2019s still mysterious Neither did Mr. Pence sit down with other Palestinian leaders, any Israeli-Arab citizens, or Israeli opposition members.", "title": "Opinion | Mike Pence\u2019s Self-Serving Trip to the Holy Land", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Yet the contrast between their minimalist industrial austerity (they were made from lining fabric) and the opulence and ornamentation that characterized so much design in the Reagan years signaled the arrival of an intriguing talent, and of a designer whose intelligence has shone like a beacon ever since in a field in which brain power is not exactly in abundant supply.\n\nDonatella Versace also kept her eye on the rearview mirror, mentally rummaging through the motifs of a design house created in the \u201980s by her brother, looking for elements to recast for a social media age. It made sense because in many ways Versace was the quintessential Instagram label avant la lettre.\n\nHere, she invoked the whole canonical Versace shebang as if intentionally for an iPhone cascade. There were neo-Roman \u201cAmore e Psiche\u201d and \u201cSipario\u201d housewares prints. There was the garishly gilded Leonard\u2019s of Great Neck palette. There was, as always, exuberant styling, pairing kilts with thigh-high boots, adding caterpillar fringe to hoodies, sticking on logo pins, deploying Versace tartans and adding interlocking chains to the soles of a new molded sneaker introduced for an audience that notably included the hip-hop artist Tauheed Epps.", "title": "Milan Is Still Making It New", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration must give lawyers with the American Civil Liberties Union 72 hours notice before transferring a United States citizen imprisoned in Iraq as an enemy combatant for more than four months, a federal judge has ruled.\n\nThe man, whose name has not been released, was captured by a Syrian militia in September and turned over to American forces as a suspected Islamic State fighter, raising a dilemma about what to do with him. He is said to have been born in the United States to visiting Saudi parents, making him an American citizen, but raised in Saudi Arabia, where he apparently also is a citizen.\n\nAfter law enforcement officials concluded that they had insufficient courtroom-admissible evidence to bring criminal charges against the man, Trump administration officials in December decided to try to transfer him to Saudi custody, according to officials familiar with deliberations.\n\nBut the eight-page ruling late on Tuesday by the judge, Tanya Chutkan of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, ensures that if such a diplomatic deal is reached, the man could fight his transfer in court.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAbsent a showing that the government \u2014 for international relations reasons or otherwise \u2014 needs to transfer petitioner now, the court does not find that the government\u2019s interests outweigh the petitioner\u2019s right to challenge his detention without fear of his transfer to another country,\u201d she wrote.", "title": "Military Ordered to Notify A.C.L.U. Before Transferring American ISIS Suspect", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Across the military, officers and troops are quietly preparing for a war they hope will not come.\n\nAt Fort Bragg in North Carolina last month, a mix of 48 Apache gunships and Chinook cargo helicopters took off in an exercise that practiced moving troops and equipment under live artillery fire to assault targets. Two days later, in the skies above Nevada, 119 soldiers from the Army\u2019s 82nd Airborne Division parachuted out of C-17 military cargo planes under cover of darkness in an exercise that simulated a foreign invasion.\n\nNext month, at Army posts across the United States, more than 1,000 reserve soldiers will practice how to set up so-called mobilization centers that move military forces overseas in a hurry. And beginning next month with the Winter Olympics in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang, the Pentagon plans to send more Special Operations troops to the Korean Peninsula, an initial step toward what some officials said ultimately could be the formation of a Korea-based task force similar to the types that are fighting in Iraq and Syria. Others said the plan was strictly related to counterterrorism efforts.\n\nIn the world of the American military, where contingency planning is a mantra drummed into the psyche of every officer, the moves are ostensibly part of standard Defense Department training and troop rotations. But the scope and timing of the exercises suggest a renewed focus on getting the country\u2019s military prepared for what could be on the horizon with North Korea.", "title": "Military Quietly Prepares for a Last Resort: War With North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The United States is switching its priority to countering Chinese and Russian military might after almost two decades of focusing on the fight against terrorism, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said Friday, unveiling a national defense strategy that Pentagon officials say will provide a blueprint for years to come.\n\nThe new strategy echoes \u2014 on paper, if not in tone \u2014 a national security blueprint offered last month in which President Trump described rising threats to the United States from an emboldened Russia and China, as well as from what was described as rogue governments like North Korea and Iran.\n\nBut where Mr. Trump struck a campaign tone during the unveiling of his national security strategy, with references to building a wall along the southern border with Mexico, Mr. Mattis took a more sober route by sticking to the more traditional intellectual framework that has accompanied foreign policy doctrines of past administrations.\n\nDrawing inspiration from Winston Churchill, who once said that the only thing harder than fighting with allies is fighting without them, Mr. Mattis said that the United States must strengthen its alliances with other powers.", "title": "Military Shifts Focus to Threats by Russia and China, Not Terrorism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "In September, during New York Fashion Week, the artist Maia Ruth Lee walked the runway at Eckhaus Latta in a blush cardigan dress, its middle buttons undone around her 35-week pregnant belly, her navel a button punctuating the look. It was splendid, stylish and rare.\n\nA month later, Hatch, a modern maternity label founded in 2011 by Ariane Goldman, opened its first brick-and-mortar store, on Bleecker Street. Hatch makes \u201cclothing for before, during and after\u201d pregnancy, an assertion that, along with the Eckhaus Latta casting, feels like a shiver in a water glass, a sign of rumblings around the aesthetic ownership of pregnancy.\n\nTo go to Hatch unpregnant is apparently welcome and can be fruitful (Ms. Goldman told Vogue.com in October that a quarter of her customers aren\u2019t pregnant), but to explore it through the eyes of an expecting mother, I brought along Marz Lovejoy, 26, a musician, model and artist who is six months along.\n\n\u201cI have from the jump been really outspoken about how society has this fear of pregnant women,\u201d she told me. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to treat me like I\u2019m weak. I\u2019m actually stronger, there\u2019s two of me right now.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt may have just been the spitty, wet weather, but Hatch actually feels like a womb. The store is decorated in soft tones, with seating so cozy and touchable that it would invite a baby to reach up and stand for the first time. Hilary Koyfman, formerly of CDR Interiors, the design firm who did the d\u00e9cor for the women\u2019s social club the Wing, designed the space, and I noticed later that day that the wallpaper in the beauty area in back is the same as in the Wing SoHo\u2019s beauty room and, surreally, that it\u2019s also on the walls at the Real Real store on Wooster Street.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe pattern, called Coven, shows stark-white women (at the Wing not all of the women are white) heavily outlined, blindfolded and naked, frozen in balletic handholds. We thank him for all of his contributions and wish him the best.\u201d\n\nKidd, who is a 2018 nominee for the Basketball Hall of Fame as a result of his highly successful 19-year career as a player \u2014 mostly with the Dallas Mavericks and the Nets \u2014 negotiated a strong personnel role with the Bucks when he left the Nets after a one-year coaching stint. Firefighters responded almost immediately and quickly brought the blaze under control.\n\nA tweet from the Fire Department indicated that the fire was in the building\u2019s heating, ventilation and air conditioning system.\n\nTrump Tower has two roofs, a low roof that houses mechanical equipment and a higher roof that covers the equipment. A fire official said that there was no fire in the building and that firefighters were able to extinguish it using water despite the cold weather.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere were three minor injuries: A firefighter was hurt by falling debris and two civilians were injured.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The change was intended to curb first-round retirements because of pre-existing injuries or ailments. After four players accepted the offer at this tournament, it was hailed as a success.\n\nA week later, however, the harsher side of the rule was implemented for the first time: Zverev, the only man or woman to retire from a first-round singles match, was fined roughly $36,000 after he quit midway through his second set against Hyeon Chung after 48 minutes, trailing by 2-6, 1-4.\n\nThe rule states, \u201cAny player who competes in the First Round Main Draw and retires or performs below professional standards, may be subject to a fine up to First Round Prize Money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBill Babcock, the director of the Grand Slam Board, said that investigations would precede any penalty for performances considered below those standards. He declined to comment on Zverev\u2019s penalty because the player has appealed his punishment.", "title": "Mischa Zverev Is Fined After First-Round Retirement", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The move is in step with the award industry\u2019s recent efforts to be more inclusive. \u201cNow, it\u2019s gender-neutral, and the ambassador could be a woman, a man, a transgender,\u201d said Anke Hofmann, vice president of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which bestows the Golden Globes. Ms. Hofmann added that the group had been contemplating the name change, and adding more philanthropic duties, for a while.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tradition of naming a Miss Golden Globe dates back to 1963. Starting in 1971, the H.F.P.A. began naming the daughter (though occasionally the son) of a celebrity to the title, as a way to showcase an up-and-comer to further the Hollywood legacy. Their duties are largely ceremonial, and consist mainly of holding trophies backstage and herding winners offstage.\n\nThis being Hollywood, there is fierce competition and campaigning by proud A-list parents for the role. The foreign press association was vague about the selection process, except to say that its board votes on which candidates are presented to the president, who makes the final pick.\n\nGreer Grammer, the daughter of Kelsey Grammer, first interviewed for the 2011 awards but lost out to Gia Mantegna. Three years later, Ms. Grammer expressed interest again and was told that she was chosen to be 2015 Miss Golden Globe.\n\nPhoto\n\nConversely, Corinne Foxx, daughter of Jamie Foxx, did not realize she was in the running to be the 2016 Miss Golden Globe 2016 until a call came \u201cout of the blue,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s an enormous amount of anticipation to see who gets to do it,\u201d said Krista Smith, the executive West Coast editor of Vanity Fair. \u201cIt\u2019s a gesture toward the new generation.\u201d\n\nThe tradition\u2019s track record of picking future stars is mixed, though there are notable exceptions.\n\n\u201cI think the H.F.P.A. looked at their crystal ball and thought I had a good shot,\u201d said Joely Fisher, the daughter of Connie Stevens and Eddie Fisher, who was Miss Golden Globe in 1992. Ms. Fisher went on to be nominated for a Golden Globe for her role on the TV show \u201cEllen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther former honorees have returned to the stage as winners. Melanie Griffith (1975) nabbed an award for \u201cWorking Girl\u201d 14 years later; Laura Dern (1982) has racked up three wins and is nominated this year for \u201cBig Little Lies.\u201d\n\nNowadays, a thriving social media presence is perhaps as important as acting chops. \u201cWe are keeping the tradition of a next-generation actor, who is also very involved with social media,\u201d Ms. Hofmann said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Garcia Johnson has 248,000 followers on Instagram, where she includes a link to a GoFundMe page for the legal defense fund for Time\u2019s Up, a new initiative for combating sexual harassment in Hollywood.\n\n\u201cI hope that one of the reasons why I was chosen is because I do speak out on issues that some people are afraid to speak out on,\u201d Ms. Garcia Johnson said. (For the record, she would not reveal what she planned to wear tonight.)\n\nThe title comes with perks besides the exposure and after-party invitations, Ms. Foxx said that she landed modeling campaigns after her appearance at the Globes, and the Stallone sisters have appeared on the covers on The Hollywood Reporter and Harper by Harper\u2019s Bazaar magazines.\n\nStill, the job itself has some decidedly unglamorous downsides. For much of the three-hour ceremony, when no awards are being presented, honorees are confined to a chair offstage, where production assistants are on hand to offer water and snacks.\n\nAnd some winners don\u2019t take kindly to being hustled offstage by a celebrity offspring they probably don\u2019t recognize. \u201cPrince wanted nothing to do with me or my instructions,\u201d Ms. Grammer said. \u201cHe looked at me like, \u2018Who the hell are you?\u2019\u201d\n\nIf that should happen this year, Ms. Garcia Johnson can shoot back, \u201cI\u2019m the ambassador. Please follow me.\u201d", "title": "Miss Golden Globe Is No More. Long Live the Golden Globe Ambassador.", "authors": ["Monica Corcoran Harel"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Lawmakers have said that Mr. Greitens came off as smug at times and was quick to tout successes as his own. He added that Mr. Greitens was paying him personally and that \u201chis goal is to begin the process of making amends with people who may feel impacted by the lapse in his conduct that he has acknowledged.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Greitens has admitted to the affair, he denied that he had threatened to release a compromising photo of the woman if she told anyone, an allegation made by the woman\u2019s former husband in a report that aired on KMOV, a St. Louis television station. The ex-husband leaked a recording of the woman in which she brought up the photo.\n\nThe woman, who has not been publicly identified and did not respond to requests for comment, requested privacy in a statement by her lawyer on Friday.\n\n\u201cIt is very disappointing that her ex-husband betrayed her confidence by secretly, and without her knowledge, recording a private and deeply personal conversation and then subsequently released the recording to the media without her consent,\u201d said the statement from her law firm, Knight & Simpson.\n\nSome Democrats have called on Mr. Greitens to resign. Turkey, which has been furious over American support for the Kurds, is a NATO ally, while the Kurds have been critical American partners in the war against the Islamic State.\n\nFor its part, the White House disavowed a plan by the American military to create a Kurdish-led force in northeastern Syria, which Turkey has vehemently opposed. I\u2019ve really liked what he\u2019s done for the economy.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Sundar Pichai of Google said about taxes: \u201cWe are happy to pay a higher amount, whatever the world agrees on as the right framework. It\u2019s not an issue about the amount of tax we pay, as much as how you divide it among various countries.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Jack Ma of Alibaba said on a panel: \u201cI think globalization cannot be stopped. Nobody can stop globalization. Nobody can stop trade. And I believe, if trade stops, war starts.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Raymond Nolte of SkyBridge Capital said, \u201cIf you take away Trump\u2019s Twitter ridiculousness, it\u2019s actually been a pretty good year for the business community.\u201d\n\nMore from the World Economic Forum\n\n\u2022 European leaders like Emmanuel Macron (who reportedly persuaded Mr. Trump to come) and Angela Merkel forcefully defended international cooperation and globalization. Shari Redstone, who along with her father, Sumner Redstone, controls the two companies, tried to merge them in 2016. Those efforts faltered over the concerns of CBS\u2019 directors and CBS\u2019s chief executive, Les Moonves. But Walt Disney\u2019s deal for much of 21st Century Fox late last year has sparked much strategic rethinking across the industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne celebrity business mogul won\u2019t run for president\n\nIt is, of course, Oprah.\n\nHere\u2019s what she told InStyle magazine:\n\nIt\u2019s not something that interests me. I don\u2019t have the DNA for it. Gayle\u2014who knows me as well as I know myself practically\u2014has been calling me regularly and texting me things, like a woman in the airport saying, \u201cWhen\u2019s Oprah going to run?\u201d So Gayle sends me these things, and then she\u2019ll go, \u201cI know, I know, I know! It wouldn\u2019t be good for you\u2014it would be good for everyone else.\u201d I met with someone the other day who said that they would help me with a campaign. That\u2019s not for me.\n\nCompletely coincidentally, we\u2019re sure, shares in Weight Watchers International were down 3 percent this morning:\n\n#MeToo meets corporate governance\n\nFrom a client memo by David Katz and Laura McIntosh of the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz:\n\nA recent study indicates that the topic would be new for most public company boards, notwithstanding the fact that it relates to key elements of board-level governance: company culture, tone-at-the-top, risk management, and crisis management. Sexual misconduct in the workplace can take a devastating human toll. Moreover, the issue implicates gender equality and gender diversity concerns more broadly, and boards that include a meaningful proportion of female directors should be better positioned to address sexual harassment and gender equality issues.\n\nAmong the best ways to better address the issue at a company: having more women on corporate boards and in senior management positions.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nThe race is on to become the first United States company valued at $1 trillion.\n\nShares of the biggest American technology companies have continued to surge in 2018. The S&P 500 technology sector is up 7.6 percent to start 2018. Amazon.com has risen 17 percent, Alphabet is up 12 percent, and Microsoft has climbed 8.4 percent, writes MoneyBeat\u2019s Ben Eisen. Meanwhile, Apple has lagged a bit in 2018, up just 1.8 percent.\n\nIf the rally persists, then the four biggest companies in the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index could all soon be flirting with the $1 trillion mark.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nApple: $884 billion.\n\nAlphabet: $814 billion\n\nMicrosoft: $713 billion\n\nAmazon: $656 billion\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen will things look up for G.E.?\n\nBad enough that the embattled industrial giant had to announce that GE Capital would suspend dividends to the group, after a $6.2 billion charge tied to its reinsurance operations.\n\nNow the S.E.C. is taking a look, and questions are being raised about the conglomerate\u2019s famously opaque accounting. (NY Post)\n\n\u2022 RPX, a manager of patent-related issues, is considering selling itself and has drawn interest from investment firms, according to unnamed sources. (Reuters)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe downside of the U.S. oil boom\n\nFrom Javier Blas, in Bloomberg Businessweek\u2019s latest cover story:\n\nIt sounds good, but be careful what you wish for. The last three years have been the hottest since record-keeping began in the 19th century, and there\u2019s little room in Trump\u2019s plan for energy sources that treat the planet kindly. Governors of coastal states have already pointed out that an offshore spill could devastate tourism \u2014 another trillion-dollar industry \u2014 not to mention wreck fragile littoral environments. Florida has already applied for a waiver from such drilling. More supply could lower prices, in turn discouraging investments in renewables such as solar and wind. Those tend to spike when oil prices rise, so enthusiasm for nonpolluting, nonwarming energies of the future could wane. For now, though, the petroleum train is chugging. And you can thank the resilience of the U.S. shale industry for it.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 The Presidents Club Charitable Trust has shut down after the FT revealed that participants at its annual men-only dinner groped, harassed and propositioned young women serving them. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Mnuchin Takes on the Dollar at Davos: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHow to Get New York Moving Again,\u201d by David Leonhardt (column, Jan. 8):\n\nMobility in New York City is a mess, and congestion pricing alone cannot solve this issue. The goal is not to get people moving again in cars, but to do everything possible to get them moving without cars.\n\nNew York must increase the size and quantity of bike lanes to make it easier for people to get around. Dockless bike-share programs are crucial for this. Charging for driving is not enough, and New York needs to eliminate all free on-street parking as a further way to get cars off the road. Charging drop-off fees for ride-sharing services is critical to get people out of cars.\n\nAnd, of course, New York needs a revitalized public transit system, with particular focus on improving the aging and neglected subways. Every person who is out of a vehicle will contribute to a more livable and enjoyable urban environment.\n\nGLEN MEYEROWITZ, WACO, TEX.", "title": "Opinion | Mobility Is a Mess in New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "On this week\u2019s podcast, we celebrate our 100th episode with excerpts from powerful episodes and listeners\u2019 stories of empathy.\n\nModern Love Modern Love: The Podcast | Episode 100 This week, Modern Love: The Podcast celebrates its 100th episode with listeners\u2019 favorite soundbites and reflections from the Modern Love editor Daniel Jones. Audio\n\nWe asked listeners to talk about the readings that resonated with them, and to share their own tales of love and loss. After their stories, stick around for reflections from the Modern Love editor Daniel Jones.", "title": "Modern Love Podcast: 100 Episodes Later", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Modern Love"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "On this week\u2019s podcast, Andrea Martin (\u201cGreat News\u201d) reads \u201cA Dose of Empathy From My Syrian Doctor,\u201d about a woman who doesn\u2019t fall in love with her physician, but comes to depend on him for more than basic care.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe author, Randi Davenport, is a novelist who suffers from an incurable motor neuron disease.
