It\u2019s now become a showcase of sorts for the restrained, provenance-infused modernism that Brechbuehler, 39, and Highsmith, 35, have espoused since founding their interior, building and lighting firm with fellow Rhode Island School of Design alum Ryan Mahoney almost a decade ago. In recent years, Workstead has been turning its attention increasingly southward \u2014 in 2016, they finished the transformation of a midcentury-era Charleston government building into the majestic Dewberry Hotel, complete with a Rubenesque brass cocktail bar and cypress-clad spa.\n\nThe firm\u2019s nearby Workstead House, as it\u2019s now known, doubles as a pied-\u00e0-terre for its owner and an events space for the couple who designed it, whose own second home is also in town. \u201cWe immediately fell in love with the grandness of the space,\u201d Brechbuehler says of the five-bedroom manor, which was built as a private residence in 1853, later served as a warehouse for Civil War contraband and then belonged to George A. Trenholm, a 19th-century politician who was reported to be the author Margaret Mitchell\u2019s muse for Rhett Butler in \u201cGone With The Wind.\u201d\n\nWhat daunted other buyers \u2014 namely that all 5,600 square feet of the site, which comes with its own carriage house, needed to be totally reworked \u2014 Brechbuehler and Highsmith relished. After installing new plumbing and wiring throughout, they forensically restored the original doors, windows, stairwell and heart-pine flooring with the help of local craftspeople. Once the interior architecture was complete, they painted most of the rooms a honeyed-stone hue (Farrow & Ball\u2019s Savage Ground) and began filling the space with brass lighting, cabinetry and furniture of their own design, sparely adding antiques and art objects found on their travels (the elegant 19th-century oil painting by Franklin Tuttle in the parlor is the result of a particularly fruitful trip to Savannah). \u201cWe detest the idea of the \u2018instant house,\u2019\u201d Highsmith says. \u201cIt\u2019s all about the ritual involved in giving a space real personality, which takes time.\u201d And with the carriage house still to complete, they\u2019re in no rush \u2014 if anything, it\u2019s a chance to trade the bleakness of another Brooklyn winter for some much-needed Southern heat.", "title": "Modernizing a Southern Home Without Losing Its Charm", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Modi is following a similar path in India, as he looks to nurture growth in his sprawling economy and to create jobs.\n\nLast month, India\u2019s government imposed stiff tariffs on imports of cellphones, video cameras and televisions. The move put heavy pressure on Apple, which ships most of the iPhones it sells in India from China, to do more manufacturing in India.\n\nMr. Modi\u2019s government is also considering a recommendation by India\u2019s Directorate General of Safeguards, Customs and Central Excise that the country impose 70 percent tariffs on imported solar panels. Such a move would appear to conflict with Mr. Modi\u2019s call here for international action on climate change. Introducing such stiff tariffs could well encourage the production of more solar panels in India, but it could also make solar power far more expensive for Indian consumers and, in turn, hurt the fight against climate change.\n\nAt 70 percent, the tariffs that India is considering on imported solar panels would be more than double those that the Trump administration said on Monday it would impose on such panels. Mr. Modi did not indicate in his speech what his government might decide on the issue.\n\nThe Trump administration faces a dilemma of its own over whether to follow India\u2019s lead in placing tariffs on consumer electronics. Mr. Trump\u2019s trade advisers are considering whether to limit imports of such goods from China amid a broader dispute over whether Chinese companies are systematically violating American intellectual property.\n\nMark Wu, a former trade negotiator for the United States who is now an assistant professor of trade law at Harvard University and who attended Mr. Modi\u2019s speech, said India faced a challenge in terms of imports: attracting foreign manufacturers without appearing to violate international trade norms.\n\n\u201cWhile the prime minister articulated all the right messages on globalization at Davos, his government remains firmly committed to a strategy of leveraging its market size to drive industrial policies to spur greater high-tech manufacturing in India,\u201d Mr. Wu said. \u201cThis is bound to cause greater trade frictions ahead.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his speech, Mr. Modi echoed many of the pro-globalization themes expressed here last year by Mr. Xi, the leader of the country with the highest import tariffs of any large economy besides India.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough he did not mention China, Mr. Modi extolled India as a model of political openness and economic growth. \u201cWe Indians very well understand the importance of a democratic environment and freedoms,\u201d he said.\n\nChina has begun to push hard in recent months to address its environmental problems, replacing coal-fired heating systems with natural gas where possible and closing factories that are heavy polluters. Pollution in India, which is at least a decade behind China in raising its citizens\u2019 standard of living, continues to increase.\n\nA ranking of countries on pollution and ecosystem protection released here on Tuesday showed India falling to 177 out of 180, down from 156 two years ago. By comparison, China was No. 120 on the list, which was compiled by Yale\u2019s Center for Environmental Law and Policy.\n\n\u201cThey are driving economic growth, but not paying attention to what I would call the parallel challenge of sustainable development: avoiding environmental degradation,\u201d Daniel Esty, the center\u2019s director, said of India.\n\nAs in the United States, industrial policies in India meant to foster domestic manufacturing can collide with a push by environmentalists and clean-energy electric utilities for solar panels, even imported ones, to be deployed as widely and as cheaply as possible. Among the other people attending Mr. Modi\u2019s speech was Sumant Sinha, chairman and chief executive of ReNew Power Ventures, a company based on the outskirts of New Delhi that builds clean energy projects.\n\nMr. Sinha said he admired Mr. Modi\u2019s efforts to make it easier for foreign and domestic companies alike to do business in India. But he said he also worried that if the recommendation for 70 percent tariffs on imported solar panels were adopted, solar energy could become unaffordable for many Indians.\n\n\u201cThe person buying the power would like the cost of the power to be as low as possible,\u201d he said.\n\nDevendra Fadnavis, the chief minister of Maharashtra, the vast Indian state that includes Mumbai and big manufacturing cities like Pune, also attended Mr. Modi\u2019s speech. He said that he saw growing interest among companies from outside India to manufacture in the country. Foxconn, the giant Taiwanese manufacturer that produces the bulk of Apple\u2019s consumer electronics, is in negotiations with Maharashtra officials to set up a large factory there.\n\nMaharashtra has offered Foxconn land at a major Mumbai port as a way of addressing the company\u2019s concerns about transportation links, Mr. Fadnavis said. But he also offered a strong defense of India\u2019s tariffs on imports, saying that the country\u2019s large number of poor farmers made it important to proceed carefully.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe want to open the door,\u201d he said. \u201cOn the other hand, we want to protect our domestic concerns, like food security and the farmers.\u201d", "title": "Modi, in Davos, Praises Globalization Without Noting India\u2019s Trade Barriers", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The list, titled \u201cShitty Media Men,\u201d had real consequences, not only for several men named on the list who eventually lost their jobs, but also for Ms. Donegan. In her essay, she wrote that she lost friends and a job after the list was published. (It was not clear what job she meant. On Thursday, The New Republic, the magazine where Ms. Donegan had worked last year, said she did not leave her job there because of the spreadsheet.)\n\nThe list also became a source of rabid debate in media circles.\n\nAnd this week, writers and editors warned on Twitter that Harper\u2019s Magazine planned to name the list\u2019s creator in an article in the March issue. The writer of the essay, Katie Roiphe, told The New York Times on Wednesday that she did not know who created it and would not out anyone in the essay.\n\nBut Ms. Donegan wrote that Ms. Roiphe sent her an email in December asking her thoughts about the feminist moment. She declined to comment, Ms. Donegan said, but then heard from Harper\u2019s again this week when a fact checker emailed to say that Ms. Roiphe planned to name her in the magazine essay.\n\nThe outrage aimed at Harper\u2019s on Twitter \u201cmade it seem inevitable that my identity would be exposed even before the Roiphe piece ran,\u201d Ms. Donegan wrote. \u201cAll of this was terrifying. I still don\u2019t know what kind of future awaits me now that I\u2019ve stopped hiding.\u201d\n\nSoon after Ms. Donegan\u2019s story was published late Wednesday, readers \u2014 many of them also women working in media \u2014 flooded Twitter, mostly to thank her for what they said was a show of courage and to praise her essay of nearly 2,900 words.", "title": "Moira Donegan Says She Created List of Men in Media Accused of Misconduct", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI am 17. Since I was a baby, my mother has taken me to church with her on Sunday mornings. Recently, I\u2019ve felt less religious and less interested in going than I used to. But when I bring this up with her, it always ends in a screaming match (especially on Sunday mornings). She believes I must go. We get along fairly well otherwise. Is there a better way to broach this subject, or should I simply endure the weekly ritual until I go to college?\n\nSARA\n\nIn one of the great understatements in (boxing) history, Floyd Mayweather Jr. once said, \u201cSelf-preservation is an important thing to me.\u201d So it should be to all of us. You are probably financially dependent on your mother \u2014 and will be, to some extent, when you go to college. Nothing in your letter suggests a dire backdrop, but many young people are cut off by their parents for warring over hot topics such as religion or sexuality. Keep that (and your best interests) in mind.\n\nI applaud your mom for wanting a regular spiritual component in your life. But that needn\u2019t be church (in my irrelevant opinion) for one disinclined and on the cusp of adulthood. Suggest a weekly commitment to serving those in need \u2014 at a soup kitchen or homeless shelter, maybe \u2014 in lieu of church. She may go for a switcheroo with a moral and compassionate flavor. (Or she may want you sitting in the pew next to her.) Bring it up quietly at dinner some Tuesday night and see how it goes.\n\nVegansplaining\n\nI am a passionate vegan for many reasons. But contrary to popular opinion, I do not speak about them. Still, when asked if I am vegan, I suffer an instant barrage of unsolicited opinions \u2014 from \u201cYou\u2019re going to die of malnutrition\u201d to \u201cStop being a snowflake; animals don\u2019t have feelings.\u201d This offends me. These conversations aren\u2019t about me explaining my choices, but others imposing their (often incorrect) views on me. I am a peace-loving person, but I would like a saucy comeback. Can you oblige?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nABIGAIL\n\nWith pleasure! Unsolicited opinions are the worst. They are usually about the red-hot needs of opinion spouters, not their recipients. And frequently they are infantilizing: \u201cYou are incompetent to walk this green earth until I tell you how.\u201d This also goes for the new (to me, anyway), aggressive cousin of unsolicited opinions, when someone says, apropos of some personal choice, \u201cWould you like to know what I think?\u201d (No, not really.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe next time a meddler asks (then tells) about your diet or use of animal products, say, \u201cRemember that time I asked you about my veganism? Funny, me neither.\u201d That should do the trick. And if this tack is insufficiently \u201cpeace-loving,\u201d try: \u201cI\u2019m good with my choice, but thanks for your concern.\u201d Then pivot. Easy, right?", "title": "Mom, I Love You, but I Can\u2019t Keep Going to Church", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Social Q S"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "It was a sportsmanlike, old-school finish to a winner-slapping, new-school duel. And it seems about time for Dimitrov to take those words to heart in a major tournament.\n\nFor all his evident ability and athleticism, he has yet to reach a Grand Slam singles final. For all the miles he has traveled and high-profile mentors he has consulted in his journey to excellence that began in his native Bulgaria, he has not yet had the psychic payoff he seeks in an era dominated by Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic.\n\nBut momentum is building. Dimitrov won his most prestigious title at the end of last season: the ATP Tour World Finals in London. And though he struggled in the early rounds of this tournament with his one-handed backhand and second serve, hitting 29 double faults in his first three matches, he was much more precise and resolute against the prodigiously unpredictable Kyrgios.\n\n\u201cThat match was incredibly intense, and I think the best man won,\u201d said Patrick Mouratoglou, the coach of Serena Williams, as he stood in a corridor in Rod Laver Arena in the aftermath.\n\nMouratoglou once advised Dimitrov when he trained as a teenager at Mouratoglou\u2019s French academy. Mouratoglou, ever the talent scout, spotted Dimitrov at the prestigious junior tournament, Les Petits As, in Tarbes, France.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe is more solid here now,\u201d Mouratoglou said, tapping his temple. \u201cMuch more stable.\n\n\u201cHe works a lot, is quite consistent in his habits and has created a very solid base for himself. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s the same thing on the other side of the net. In the important moments, that plays a role.\u201d\n\nMouratoglou was referring to Kyrgios, a 22-year-old Australian who continues to resist hiring a full-time coach after working intermittently with the former French star Sebastien Grosjean last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMatt Reid, Kyrgios\u2019s friend and doubles partner here, has been playing the coaching role at the Australian Open, and Kyrgios is also in close contact with Lleyton Hewitt, the Australian Davis Cup captain, who is, after coming briefly out of retirement, into the quarterfinals of men\u2019s doubles with Sam Groth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKyrgios continues to train and play his way, which seldom means the most consistent way.\n\n\u201cHis personality is so different to many of us who have played the game before,\u201d said Hewitt, an analyst for Australia\u2019s Seven Network during Sunday night\u2019s match. \u201cYou see him sometimes talking to himself under his breath between first and second serves. I wouldn\u2019t have been able to personally concentrate.\u201d\n\nYou saw Kyrgios doing a whole lot more than that on Sunday: bantering with his box, complaining loudly about having a racket with the wrong string tension, turning routine shots into more difficult ones and difficult shots into routine ones.\n\nBut Kyrgios, who beat Dimitrov on his way to the Brisbane title a few weeks ago, looked much more settled than he did last January. In winning three matches at the Australian Open, he has already won more Grand Slam singles matches in 2018 than he won in all of 2017.\n\n\u201cI lost tonight to one of the best players in the world, went down swinging,\u201d Kyrgios said. \u201cObviously I feel a lot better this time around. Last year I really didn\u2019t know what I was going to do after the Australian Open. I feel like I have more of a vision and a goal for this year. I think I\u2019m in a good head space.\u201d\n\nIf so, that bodes ill for the opposition, even if Kyrgios wished no ill on the friend who had to dig so deep to beat him in the fourth round.\n\n\u201cSometimes I think he lacks a bit of belief,\u201d Kyrgios said of Dimitrov. \u201cBut I think he\u2019s got the game, and he\u2019s proved to everyone that he can win one of these Slams. So I just told him to believe in himself and hopefully he can go all the way.\u201d\n\nTo advance, Dimitrov will need to defeat Kyle Edmund, the unseeded British surprise, in the quarterfinals and then either Nadal or Marin Cilic in the semifinals. Dimitrov lost to Nadal in a classic semifinal here last year that lasted nearly five hours. He could face Federer or Djokovic in the final.\n\nThat sounds like quite a challenge, but if Dimitrov can shore up his serve and replicate the blend of offense and defense he showed on Sunday night, he has a chance.\n\nWell after midnight, I asked him what he learned about himself in the match.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a fair question,\u201d he said. \u201cI learned that I can, you know, switch to another gear when I really need it.\u201d", "title": "Momentum Builds Toward Grigor Dimitrov\u2019s Grand Slam Breakthrough", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Other deals under review include the sale of SkyBridge Capital \u2014 an investment firm founded by Anthony Scaramucci, an ally of Mr. Trump \u2014 to an arm of HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate.\n\nThe collapse of the deal offers the latest sign of a shift \u2014 one that began during the end of the Obama administration \u2014 over how Washington treats Chinese acquisitions of American assets.\n\nMr. Trump and other politicians have long criticized Chinese trade practices and their impact on traditional, heavy industries in the United States, such as steel. But officials and lawmakers of both parties have grown increasingly concerned with Chinese purchases in high-tech areas, like semiconductors and artificial intelligence. China \u2014 a country that has grown by leaps and bounds in expertise in recent years \u2014 has aggressively funded development of next-generation technology in ways that have alarmed some foreign governments and businesses.\n\nThat has led to calls to tighten reviews of Chinese purchases of American assets. Chinese investment surged to more than $130 billion in 2017 from just $21.5 billion in 2012, according to Rhodium Group, a research firm. In 2018, bankers say they expect another big year of investment, targeted more at sectors considered important to future economic growth like high technology and renewable energy.\n\nLawmakers from both parties have introduced legislation calling for greater scrutiny of Chinese investments in the United States. They are pushing for an expansion of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius, the multiagency panel that reviews foreign deals for potential threats to national security and that rejected the MoneyGram-Ant Financial plan.\n\nIn 2016, American concerns over China\u2019s interest in microchips scotched some Chinese purchases, and last year Mr. Trump blocked the purchase of Lattice Semiconductors by a group with links to China.\n\nThe deal\u2019s demise also illustrates rising concerns in both the United States and China over sensitive personal data. In buying a large-scale money-transfer company like MoneyGram, Ant Financial would have had access to a large number of records of financial flows within the United States. That fact, combined with close ties to China\u2019s government, could have created security problems. For example, the flow of funds could point to possible espionage targets in the United States military who face financial difficulties.", "title": "MoneyGram and Ant Financial Call Off Merger, Citing Regulatory Concerns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIn Diesel Study, Real Monkeys, but Rigged VW\u201d (front page, Jan. 26):\n\nIt\u2019s not the worst example of animals made to suffer for the sake of corporate greed. Smoking experiments inflicted on primates by tobacco companies probably take the prize for that. But Volkswagen has shamed itself just the same by sponsoring air-pollution research using auto exhaust fumes and monkeys.\n\nThe aim of both laboratory outrages was to mislead people into thinking that breathing something harmful wasn\u2019t really so bad.\n\nOnly thanks to a lawsuit and The Times do we now learn about this misguided experiment aimed at reassuring consumers about the low-polluting advantages of diesel cars. Except that the test car, as in other Volkswagens, was rigged to perform better in tests than on the highway \u2014 small consolation to the monkeys, I\u2019d say.\n\nI believe that the company should apologize, swear off all future animal tests and pour significant funding into real research that won\u2019t cause animal suffering.", "title": "Opinion | Monkeys and Volkswagen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Bullock and some public interest advocates who have advised him argue that the state has wide latitude to set conditions to any contracts with the government \u2014 one of the biggest customers in most cities and states \u2014 to get around the F.C.C.\u2019s restrictions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf you want to do business with Montana, there are standards on net neutrality you will have to follow,\u201d Mr. Bullock said.\n\nThe idea is similar to bills in New York and Rhode Island that are also trying to use government contracts to regulate the practices of internet service providers. Those efforts are proceeding slowly, along with multiple lawsuits filed last week by more than 20 state attorneys general and public interest groups.\n\nBroadband providers say they will have difficulty following different state laws related to net neutrality. Various trade groups said they were watching Montana\u2019s action and other state bills and were considering lawsuits.\n\n\u201cFollowing patchwork of legislation or regulation is costly and makes it even harder to invest in networks,\u201d said Matt Polka, president of the American Cable Association, a lobbying group for small- and midsize broadband providers.\n\nMr. Bullock, a Democrat, said the executive order was the fastest and surest way to bring back net neutrality rules and to head off any decisions by internet service providers to begin throttling or charging websites more to reach consumers.\n\n\u201cThere is a long history of government using its procurement power to get companies to adopt requirements, and this is no different,\u201d said Travis LeBlanc, an enforcement chief for the F.C.C. during the Obama administration. \u201cThis action by Governor Bullock will provide immediate relief.\u201d\n\nThough the order applies only to Montana, it could have a spillover effect, as seen with auto emissions rules and cybersecurity notification laws that began in a few states but eventually became national standards.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is simple plug and play for other states to do as well,\u201d Mr. Bullock said.", "title": "Montana Governor Signs Order to Force Net Neutrality", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The legendary Memphis newspaper editor Ida B. Wells was targeted for assassination \u2014 and driven into exile \u2014 for exposing the lies that were routinely used to justify hanging, dismembering and burning alive African-Americans in the Jim Crow South.\n\nWhites were particularly outraged when Wells said in an incendiary editorial, \u201cNobody in this section of the country believes the old threadbare lie that Negro men rape white women\u201d \u2014 implying that rape accusations that preceded lynchings arose from the discovery of consensual sex between black men and white women.\n\nBy the time Wells took refuge in the North in 1892, white Southerners had made racial terrorism a fact of life and embarked on a propaganda campaign that romanticized slavery, idealized the Confederate past and held that white supremacy would restore lost Southern greatness. The Confederate monuments that sprang up in public spaces across the South \u2014 and that still stand today \u2014 were an essential part of that campaign.\n\nThe Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson were popular choices for veneration. But Wells\u2019s beloved city of Memphis set its sights on Tennessee\u2019s native son, the Civil War general and Ku Klux Klan founder Nathan Bedford Forrest. A monument of Forrest astride his horse towered over a public park in the city for more than a century until shortly before Christmas, when the city overcame state opposition to finally dismantle it.", "title": "Opinion | Monuments to White Supremacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "TECHNOLOGY\n\nIs Big Blue Bouncing Back?\n\nIBM\u2019s revenue, which has fallen for 22 consecutive quarters, will be the focus of attention when the big technology company reports its financial results on Thursday. Analysts say the decline may well have stopped in the most recent quarter, as the company navigates a challenging shift to new businesses like cloud computing and artificial intelligence. If so, does it signal a true turnaround \u2014 or is it merely a blip helped by strong sales of a new line of mainframe computers? Steve Lohr\n\nECONOMY\n\nLooking for Signs of a Shift in China\n\nChina could post flat or modestly higher growth figures when it reports its fourth-quarter and full-year economic results for 2017 on Thursday. That would not surprise China watchers, who have noted that the country\u2019s headline economic figures have become implausibly stable in recent years. There may also be indications of what is to come this year. Now that an important leadership meeting has been completed, China may begin to shift its emphasis toward fixing some of its intractable financial, environmental and social problems and to temper its focus on growth. Carlos Tejada\n\nAssessing the Outlook for Europe\n\nWhy have wages in Europe barely budged despite vigorous economic growth? What should the region\u2019s priorities be now that the debt crisis seems to have passed? And what to think when it comes to inflation? Those are among the topics that a roster of prominent economists and policymakers will discuss on Thursday at a conference in Frankfurt that will be hosted by the International Monetary Fund and the Bundesbank, Germany\u2019s central bank. Speakers include Christine Lagarde, the fund\u2019s managing director, and Jens Weidmann, the Bundesbank president. Jack Ewing\n\nA Fresh Snapshot of Consumer Sentiment\n\nThe University of Michigan is set to release its monthly survey of consumer sentiment on Friday. Consumer confidence was strong in 2017, although it dropped over the year\u2019s final three months, to 95.9 in December. With the stock market booming, the jobless rate low and a new tax law in place, analysts expect the figure for January to inch up to 97. For comparison, the consumer sentiment index has averaged 86.2 since the early 1950s, peaking at 111.3 in February 2000 and bottoming out at 51.7 in May 1980. Patricia Cohen\n\nMOVIES\n\nA Sundance Without Harvey Weinstein\n\nWhat is the Sundance Film Festival without Harvey Weinstein? The movie industry is about to find out. On Thursday, the festival begins its 34th year in Park City, Utah, with 121 feature-length movies on the calendar, 53 from first-time filmmakers. Sundance prides itself on discovering striking new voices, but it is also about cold, hard commerce. On that front, this will be the first festival in roughly 30 years where Mr. Weinstein will not be among the shoppers. Fox Searchlight may be hesitant to write big checks after its last two Sundance acquisitions, \u201cThe Birth of a Nation\u201d and \u201cPatti Cake$,\u201d flopped. Other traditional bidders like Lionsgate and CBS Films have cut way back on Sundance purchases. That leaves Netflix and Amazon, which have come to dominate the festival, buying films like \u201cThe Big Sick\u201d and \u201cMudbound\u201d for $12 million a pop. But their rivalry is driving up prices in a way that may be unsustainable. Brooks Barnes", "title": "More Bank Earnings, China\u2019s Growth and Sundance Without Weinstein", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Another parent, whose son is a student at an Ivy League college, said: \u201cHe\u2019s not striving to meet our standards, they\u2019re his own.\u201d The father, whom I cannot name because he is my patient, said: \u201cI keep reminding him that perfect is the enemy of good, and he says, \u2018Yeah, but good\u2019s not enough to get into med school.\u2019\u201d\n\nHannah Miller, a Columbia graduate student, is candid about her perfectionism. \u201cWhen it\u2019s not out of control, it\u2019s a good thing to have. When it overwhelms me, which is less often than it did when I was an undergraduate, I have to force myself to step back and make an accurate assessment of how important the task is and consider it thoughtfully rather than emotionally \u2014 like, how good does it have to be?\u201d\n\nWhen she finds herself procrastinating until a deadline, she repeats a maxim favored by a high school teacher: Do the best that you can in the time that you have.\n\nMs. Miller said that when she\u2019s stressed and anxious she turns to her close friends for comfort and support, and also to her mother, whose perfectionism, like her own, is mostly self-prescribed. Mother and daughter share a kind of presentational perfectionism, especially about public speaking. Ms. Miller said that her mother \u201cgets over it the same way she tells me to: Prepare thoroughly and it will carry you through.\u201d\n\nIf you are a parent concerned about perfectionist tendencies in your child, the questions posed by the Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale, used in the study, may be informative. Among its 44 items, scaled from 1 (disagree) to 7 (agree), are statements like these: When I am working on something, I can\u2019t relax unless it\u2019s perfect; The people around me expect me to succeed at everything I do; The better I do, the better I am expected to do. The scale is not a clinical instrument, but the questions might be a good starting point for discussion.\n\nIt\u2019s hard to tell how much social media is affecting your child\u2019s self-image; many feel enormous pressure to be perfect off line, too. And it\u2019s difficult to know what, if anything, parents can do about it, beyond offering empathy, reassurance and emotional support.\n\nIf they\u2019ve been here before, remind them that perfect wasn\u2019t the goal; good enough was, and it did the trick. (\u201cRemember the way you felt before your SATs, and how well you did?\u201d) Make sure it\u2019s their perfectionism you\u2019re worried about, not yours. And stay in touch without hovering. If they seem really anxious for more than a week, suggest they seek counseling, or contact the school to ask whether the department of student life might sponsor a program about perfectionism.\n\nAnd meanwhile, send care packages. It\u2019s fine if they\u2019re not perfect \u2014 they will still brighten your student\u2019s day.", "title": "More College Students Seem to Be Majoring in Perfectionism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "In an emailed statement on Wednesday, he said: \u201cThis is not breaking news. She told Mr. Weisberg that she and Mr. Trump began an affair at a 2006 celebrity golf tournament and that Mr. Trump said he could cast her on \u201cThe Apprentice.\u201d One difference: Slate says that their relationship lasted about a year.\n\nAny communication between Ms. Clifford and Mr. Cohen in October 2016 would have happened at a tumultuous time for Mr. Trump. And his fidelity was called into question when Karen McDougal, a former Playboy model, claimed she had had sex with him in 2006.\n\nHis campaign was further threatened when an \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d segment was released in October. In it, he spoke about women in extraordinarily vulgar terms.", "title": "More Details Emerge About Trump\u2019s Relationship With Porn Star", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "But it wasn\u2019t clear until this study that the shift was so dramatic and happening in such a large population across time, she said.\n\n\u201cThis is the first paper that\u2019s shown this multigenerational effect,\u201d influencing the gender of juveniles, older adolescents and adults, Dr. Wyneken said.\n\nIt takes 35 to 40 years for a green sea turtle to reach sexual maturity, she said.\n\n\u201cThese animals are teenagers for an awfully long time,\u201d Dr. Wyneken said. \u201cWe won\u2019t see the effects of what\u2019s happening today for several decades.\u201d\n\nDavid Owens, a professor emeritus from the College of Charleston in South Carolina, was not involved in the new study, but said he\u2019s dreamed of doing such research for years. He praised the way the study team \u2014 which included a wide range of expertise \u2014 was able to link temperature with turtle gender.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had little pieces of this story come out before, but this is the first time anyone\u2019s been able to orchestrate the whole story to bring in global climate change along with feminization,\u201d Dr. Owens said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd if the green sea turtles of Australia are seeing this shift, the same thing is probably happening to many other sea turtles and other animals whose gender is determined by temperature, he said.\n\nSea turtles tend to lay their eggs on the same beaches where they were hatchlings decades earlier, so they can\u2019t quickly adapt to warming temperatures, Dr. Owens said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s possible that they could lay their eggs earlier in the season, instead of waiting for the hottest weeks of the year, but Dr. Jensen said there\u2019s no evidence to suggest that such a shift has or could occur.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSea turtles are the \u201clawn mowers of the ocean,\u201d according to Camryn Allen, an author of the new study and a marine biological researcher with the Joint Institute for Marine and Atmospheric Research \u2014 University of Hawaii and located at NOAA in Hawaii. The turtles maintain coral reefs and are nutrient transporters. If they are lost, other species that depend on the same habitat will also be harmed.\n\n\u201cSea turtles are sentinels,\u201d Dr. Allen said. \u201cThey\u2019re telling us something is going on in the oceans and we need to pay attention.\u201d\n\nBoth she and Dr. Jensen said they do not yet see the problem as urgent, because there are enough adult males to sustain the population. Highlighting the problem now will give researchers time to learn more about factors affecting the animals.\n\nDr. Allen said the government of Australia has already started to take steps toward helping sea turtles, such as funding the Raine Island Recovery Project to study and support the local turtle population.\n\nThe group conducted its research over 16 days in July 2014, plying small boats around the Howick Group of islands in the north Great Barrier Reef \u2014 \u201can absolutely magical place,\u201d according to Dr. Jensen. They captured 411 foraging turtles, one at a time, drawing blood to measure gender hormones and taking skin samples for DNA. The genetic analysis allowed them to determine whether the turtle had been born in the northern or southern parts of the reef, which are separated by about 1,200 miles.\n\nDr. Allen said the reasons for the gender bias were still a mystery. \u201cThe exact mechanism is not well understood,\u201d she said. \u201cBut we do know they don\u2019t have sex chromosomes like humans do.\u201d\n\nTurtles born in the cooler south were only biased 65 to 69 percent female, the study showed. Researchers still don\u2019t know the ideal ratio, or how many males to females it takes to effectively sustain the population, Dr. Jensen said.\n\nWithout the new study, he said, scientists might not have recognized the gender skewing in the north for decades \u2014 perhaps missing the window to make a difference.\n\n\u201cThe result is definitely alarming,\u201d Dr. Jensen said. \u201cBut now we know and can focus our research on the right questions and start thinking about what can be done. So I\u2019m hopeful as well.\u201d", "title": "More Female Sea Turtles Born as Temperatures Rise", "authors": ["Karen Weintraub"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The spectacle of more than 150 young women telling their stories of sexual abuse before a court, the world, and the perpetrator himself seemed straight from the movies, a cathartic ending to a dark, yearslong drama that had been all too real.\n\nIt is rare, perhaps unprecedented, for so many victims to stand in court and, with the encouragement of a judge, to describe aloud for days the abuse they endured. Therapists said that the chance to testify at the sentencing hearing of Dr. Lawrence B. Nassar was worth taking for those who felt ready to do so.\n\nThe women were taken at their word; they were part of group, bonded by shared experience; and they saw justice done before their eyes\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t think of a better scenario,\u201d said Elaine Ducharme, a psychologist in Glastonbury, Conn., who specializes in treating trauma from sexual abuse and other violations. \u201cTo have the judge hear them, to allow their stories to influence her decisions, and all without putting them through the trauma of an actual trial. Most of them are likely to have felt tremendous relief.\u201d", "title": "More Than 150 Women Described Sexual Abuse by Lawrence Nassar. Will Their Testimony Help Them Heal?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix weeks after firing the former congressman Harold E. Ford Jr. for unspecified misconduct, Morgan Stanley clarified Monday that the misconduct was not sexual in nature.\n\n\u201cThe press has reported that Mr. Ford was terminated for sexual misconduct,\u201d the bank said in a statement. \u201cHe was not. We have not received any internal allegations of sexual harassment or misconduct involving him either before or after his separation became public.\u201d\n\nThe statement is part of a legal settlement that Mr. Ford reached over the weekend with Morgan Stanley, according to a person who was briefed on the resolution but was not authorized to speak publicly. Through a spokesman, Mr. Ford declined to comment.\n\nBefore his firing last month, Mr. Ford had spent seven years at Morgan Stanley recruiting clients. He joined the investment banking industry after losing a United States Senate race in Tennessee as the Democratic nominee in 2006.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ford, 47, was fired after a female journalist told Morgan Stanley that he had harassed her at a dinner in 2014. Five months later, Moroccan soccer officials have provided scant detail about how they propose to stage the world\u2019s biggest sporting event.\n\nWith five months to go before FIFA selects the 2026 host, Morocco only last week named a chairman of its bid committee. As yet the bid has no logo to paste on billboards, no slogan to trumpet in news releases, no flashy stadium plan to share with potential voters. It doesn\u2019t even have a website. In the past, bid committees have had all of these basic features in place more than a year ahead of a selection vote, and bid leaders would have long ago commenced globe-trotting campaign trips to attempt to secure support, sharing an outline of a bid\u2019s plans for matches, transportation and accommodations along the way.\n\nLast week, numerous local soccer officials recoiled when asked to comment on the plans and declined to discuss the bid on the record. On the city\u2019s labyrinthine streets, some merchants, like the fish-seller and self-described soccer fan Abdulrahman Koudri, said they had no idea Morocco was even trying to secure what would be the biggest sporting event ever held on the African continent.", "title": "Morocco Wants to Host the World Cup. Just Don\u2019t Ask for Any Details.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Star of David may look the same upside-down as it does right-side-up, but the same can\u2019t be said of a painting by the American Color Field artist Morris Louis that implements the Jewish symbol, and for years has potentially been viewed in flipped-over form.\n\nThe work, now on display with the title \u201cMan Reaching for a Star\u201d in an exhibition at the Jewish Museum, was until recently referred to as \u201cUntitled (Jewish Star).\u201d The painting had been displayed in the museum under its previous title twice before, once in 1997 and again in an exhibition that ran for several years beginning in 2003. But during preparations for the current exhibition \u201cScenes From the Collection,\u201d curators decided that a set of red chalk arrows drawn on the back of the work suggest that the orientation had been 180 degrees off.\n\n\u201cWe got into this fascinating discussion, looking at this painting anew,\u201d Claudia J. Nahson, a curator at the museum, said in a phone interview. Another curator, Stephen Brown, described a group standing around the painting in the museum\u2019s storeroom, considering how the piece was originally intended to be shown.\n\nThe new orientation reveals what appears to be the abstract figure of a man reaching for the star, an image that carries weight for a painting that has been interpreted as a response to Nazi book burnings in the 1930s and to McCarthy-era efforts to suppress public figures perceived as Communist or leftist.\n\nAfter further research, the curators discovered a brochure from a 1953 exhibition in Washington, D.C., that referred to a Louis painting called \u201cMan Reaching for a Star.\u201d Though the brochure did not include photographs, they determined that the painting was likely the same one as \u201cUntitled (Jewish Star).\u201d\n\nMr. Brown points out that the correct way to display abstract art is often debated, or considered open for interpretation. \u201cIt\u2019s often difficult to know which way up the painting should be,\u201d he said.", "title": "Morris Louis Painting Shown at Jewish Museum, This Time Right-Side-Up", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "In 1950, amid the Korean War, Spider morphed into Beetle Bailey in an Army uniform. Mr. Walker\u2019s comic strip substituted barracks buddies for dorm mates, sergeants and generals for professors, and the military bureaucracy for academic pronouncements.\n\nIn the first sketches showing Beetle Bailey in uniform, this time with an Army cap covering his eyes, he took an aptitude test and asked what his specialty would be.\n\n\u201cNot engineering. \u2026 Not cooking. \u2026 Not driving. \u2026\u201d the Army tester told him.\n\n\u201cYou have one outstanding ability! Avoiding work!\u201d\n\nAnd so it went through the Korean War, the Vietnam War and wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, even though \u201cBeetle Bailey\u201d seldom became topical.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe main character\u2019s war was with the Army itself, and though he was never promoted beyond private, he bested the likes of the tough but ultimately endearing Sarge (officially Orville P. Snorkel) and the bumbling Camp Swampy commander, Gen. Amos T. Halftrack.\n\nThe newspaper Stars and Stripes, published for members of the armed forces, banned \u201cBeetle Bailey\u201d from its Tokyo edition in 1954, evidently a result of the military\u2019s concern that discipline would lag after the end of the Korean War and that the comic strip might inspire disrespect for officers.\n\nThe ban, reported in the press with no small degree of ridicule and continuing for about a decade, as Mr. Walker recalled it, served only to boost the comic strip\u2019s profile, and it was eventually syndicated in some 1,800 newspapers around the world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrian Walker said that the strip will continue, and that he and his brother Greg had been working on it with their father for decades.\n\nAddison Morton Walker was born on Sept. 3, 1923, in El Dorado, Kan., and grew up in Kansas City, Mo., where his father, Robin, was an architect and his mother, the former Carolyn Richards, worked as a newspaper illustrator. He drew for his student newspaper while in elementary school, began selling cartoons to magazines at 14 and became the chief editorial designer for Hallmark greeting cards at 18. He continued his sketching while in the Army in Italy, working in intelligence and later commanding a camp holding German prisoners of war.\n\nHe graduated from the University of Missouri in 1948, edited fan and humor magazines for Dell Publishing and sold cartoons of his own to leading magazines before a Saturday Evening Post editor named John Bailey urged him to create a cartoon series revolving around his fraternity brothers from college. Mr. Walker later gave the character deriving from Spider the surname Bailey to honor the editor who inspired his college-themed cartoons.\n\nMr. Walker modeled the character after a high school and college buddy who was tall and thin and often got into trouble innocently. The overweight, snaggletoothed Sarge was based on a sergeant Mr. Walker once encountered. The cast at Camp Swampy also included Sarge\u2019s uniformed canine sidekick Otto and General Halftrack\u2019s sexy secretary Miss Buxley.\n\nMr. Walker had long been urged to include a black character, but felt he would draw complaints if he made the figure an oddball like the others at Camp Swampy. He decided to create an officer with an Afro who liked wild clothing, introducing Lt. Jack Flap in the early 1970s.\n\n\u201cThere was an initial fuss from people who either thought I was propagandizing or ridiculing blacks,\u201d Mr. Walker remembered. \u201cStars and Stripes banned me again and Senator Proxmire had to convince them to reinstate me,\u201d he continued, referring to William Proxmire of Wisconsin.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe later added an Asian-American character, Corporal Yo, and a high-tech warrant officer, Chip Gizmo.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s always changes,\u201d Greg Walker told CBS News in 2015. \u201cEverybody\u2019s got a cellphone now, and computers and all that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Walker received the National Cartoonists Society\u2019s award for outstanding cartoonist of the year for 1953. He was invited to the Pentagon in 2000 to receive the Secretary of the Army\u2019s highest award to a civilian, the Distinguished Civilian Service citation. A life-size statue of Beetle Bailey, cast in bronze, stands outside the alumni center at the University of Missouri.\n\nMr. Walker worked with his associates Jerry Dumas, Bob Gustafson and Bud Jones as well as several of his children in creating gag ideas. In addition to \u201cBeetle Bailey\u201d he created \u201cHi and Lois,\u201d with Dik Browne, based on Mr. Walker\u2019s family members\u2019 lives; \u201cBoner\u2019s Ark,\u201d featuring quirky animals and their search for dry land; and \u201cSam\u2019s Strip,\u201d about a comic strip character running his own comic strip. He founded \u201cSam\u2019s Strip\u201d with Mr. Dumas, who later took over and renamed it \u201cSam and Silo.\u201d\n\nWorking from a home and studio in Stamford that once belonged to Gutzon Borglum, the Mount Rushmore sculptor, Mr. Walker was also a comic strip historian and preservationist. In 1974, he opened the International Museum of Cartoon Art in Greenwich, Conn. Its extensive collection of drawings and books, including creations of Walt Disney, Charles Schulz, Walt Kelly and Rube Goldberg, was later housed in Rye Brook, N.Y., and in Boca Raton, Fla., and is now at Ohio State University in Columbus as part of the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum.\n\nBesides his sons Brian and Greg, survivors include his second wife, Catherine Carty; two stepchildren, Priscilla Prentice and Whitney Prentice; and his children Polly, Margie, Neal and Roger from his marriage to his first wife, the former Jean Suffill, which ended in divorce.\n\n\u201cBeetle Bailey\u201d used the Army as its setting, but its popularity derived from everyday life and the universal battles against authority figures and mindless bureaucracy.\n\n\u201cIt deals primarily with working, playing, eating and sleeping,\u201d Mr. Dumas, who began working with Mr. Walker in the 1950s, told The New York Times in 2000. \u201cThat means it can be understood and related to by people all over the world.\u201d\n\nWhen the Defense Department congratulated Mr. Walker on his 80th birthday, he said: \u201cHuman frailty is what humor is all about. People like to see the foibles of mankind. And they relate to the little guy, the one on the bottom.\u201d", "title": "Mort Walker, Creator of \u2018Beetle Bailey\u2019 Comic Strip, Dies at 94", "authors": ["Richard Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a moment in Mort Walker\u2019s \u201cBeetle Bailey,\u201d from decades ago, when the innocent Zero asks the intellectual Plato why he owns so many books. Plato explains proudly that \u201call the wisdom of the ages\u201d can be found between their covers. Zero responds, \u201cWhat happens if a couple of pages get stuck together?\u201d\n\nMort\u2019s own answer might have been, \u201cWell, we\u2019ll always have comic strips.\u201d Millions of people knew Mort, who died last week at the age of 94, as one of the pre-eminent cartoonists of his era \u2014 and one of the central figures among the remarkable group of artists (my father, John Cullen Murphy, the longtime illustrator of \u201cPrince Valiant,\u201d was another) who populated southwestern Connecticut in the peak years of the American century.\n\nBut in his way, and without putting on airs, Mort was also a historian.\n\n\u201cBeetle Bailey,\u201d the strip for which he was most widely known \u2014 though he created several others, including \u201cHi and Lois\u201d \u2014 was slyly but gently subversive, in a manner that wears well in America. \u201cBeetle\u201d was built around a cast of misfits at a military base, Camp Swampy, and Army humor, as Mort often said, writes itself. He told me once that when he was stationed in occupied Italy during World War II, he was ordered to run over watches, radios and other equipment with a tank in order to avoid the paperwork that would have been required to send the stuff back home.", "title": "Opinion | Mort Walker, Historian", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 For anyone who braves the Russian winter, overcast skies and short, dark days are a depressing reality.\n\nBut even those bleak expectations were shattered in December, when Moscow was shrouded in an unrelenting cloud cover for all but six minutes.\n\nIt was the darkest December in the capital since the city began recording the data, the previous worst having come in 2000, when the sun checked in for a meager three hours.\n\nThe average amount of sunlight for December \u2014 18 hours \u2014 is hardly anything to write home about.\n\n\u201cWhen they hear about this, many people say, \u2018It\u2019s clear now why I was depressed,\u2019 \u201d said Roman Vilfand, the director of Russia\u2019s Weather Service, according to the news agency Tass.", "title": "Moscow Got 6 Minutes of Sunlight in December", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 A Moscow movie theater that bucked an official ban on showing \u201cThe Death of Stalin,\u201d a British black comedy about the Soviet dictator\u2019s death, has halted screenings after a police raid on Friday.\n\nIn a Facebook post, Pioner Cinema wrote that the 2017 film, by the director Armando Iannucci, which had been playing to sold-out crowds, had been pulled as of Saturday \u201cdue to circumstances beyond our control\u201d and directed further queries to Russia\u2019s Ministry of Culture, which had quashed it. The post was accompanied by an image of graffiti reading \u201cFree Speech Conditions Apply\u201d by a well-known street artist.\n\nAlexander Mamut, a billionaire known for cutting-edge cultural projects, owns the art house cinema as well as two major Russian movie theater chains, leading to speculation that \u201cThe Death of Stalin\u201d standoff indicates conflict among Russia\u2019s elites.\n\nOla Cichowlas, an AFP journalist, tweeted photographs of the raid. As of Saturday, it was not clear which law enforcement agency was behind it. An official of the Moscow branch of the Investigative Committee, Russia\u2019s equivalent of the F.B.I., told the Tass news agency, that it had nothing to do with the raid.", "title": "Moscow Raid on Movie Theater Closes \u2018The Death of Stalin\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump has repeatedly expressed support for legalizing DACA recipients \u2014 on Wednesday, he said he was open to granting them a path to citizenship \u201cat some point in the future, over a period of 10 to 12 years.\u201d But he, too, has felt the pull from people in his administration who objected to the program, which was created by former President Barack Obama in 2012.\n\nIn announcing the end of DACA last September, Attorney General Jeff Sessions called it a \u201cunilateral executive amnesty\u201d that had encouraged more illegal immigration and \u201cdenied jobs to hundreds of thousands of Americans by allowing those same jobs to go to illegal aliens.\u201d\n\nLars Larson, a syndicated conservative talk-show host based in Portland, Ore., said that 10 to 15 percent of his callers consider DACA recipients lawbreakers and want to give them \u201cnothing at all.\u201d\n\n\u201cI point out that philosophically, I agree with them, but practically this needs to be resolved,\u201d he said, by granting permission to stay only in exchange for tougher enforcement measures. \u201cShow us that you are bringing something of value.\u201d\n\nIn interviews, voters who oppose legalization said that they felt the government was being held hostage by sympathizers of the young immigrants. Most were resigned to the possibility that a deal could happen, and said that they could live with it if conservatives came away with significant new immigration controls.\n\nStill, several invoked the law signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1986, which granted 2.7 million people amnesty while tightening security at the Mexican border and adding strict penalties for employers who hired undocumented workers. Though it promised to reduce illegal immigration, the number of undocumented people has grown since then to an estimated 11 million.", "title": "Most Americans Want Legal Status for \u2018Dreamers.\u2019 These People Don\u2019t.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Utah was the only state to get an A-plus. The state requires students to take a state-administered test at the end of the course, and recently mandated that the class cover the cost of college and student loans.\n\n\u201cThe timing couldn\u2019t be better,\u201d said Travis Cook, a financial literacy specialist with the Utah State Board of Education, noting that student debt nationally is mushrooming.\n\nThe report card, an update of an assessment done in 2015, is based on the premise that all high school students should, at a minimum, be required to take a course that includes personal finance topics, even if the topics are just a \u201cmodest\u201d part of the overall course.\n\nInterest in financial literacy has risen since the 2008 financial crisis, but there is some disagreement on how best to teach it. A study published in 2015 suggested that additional math instruction for students might be more helpful than traditional personal finance instruction.\n\nThe authors of a separate study, done in 2015 and funded by the Finra Investor Education Foundation, noted that past research had found, \u201cat best, mixed evidence\u201d that financial education improved financial well-being. Still, after comparing three states that adopted mandatory personal finance instruction with neighboring states that did not, the study found reason for optimism.\n\n\u201cWe find that if a rigorous financial education program is carefully implemented,\u201d the report concluded, \u201cit can improve the credit scores and lower the probability of delinquency for young adults.\u201d\n\nLauren Willis, a professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles who has argued for stronger consumer financial protections, said she saw more promise in \u201cconsumer self-defense classes,\u201d which focus on \u201cspotting and avoiding scams, spotting manipulative advertising, and the like.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProfessor Willis is advising the FoolProof Foundation, a Florida nonprofit group that creates free courses that teach high school students (and now middle school students) the importance of a \u201chealthy skepticism\u201d when evaluating various forms of debt. FoolProof\u2019s online lessons emphasize, for instance, that credit cards are a \u201cwildly expensive\u201d way to borrow and can build \u201clifetime debt.\u201d\n\nMr. Pelletier said there were other options for schools that wanted free or low-cost financial literacy classes that weren\u2019t sponsored by banks. He cited, as two examples, Next Gen Personal Finance, a nonprofit group based in Palo Alto, Calif., that offers free online classes and teacher training, as well as offerings from the National Endowment for Financial Education.\n\nHere are some questions and answers about financial literacy education:\n\nWhat if my child\u2019s school doesn\u2019t offer personal finance instruction?\n\nLaura Levine, chief executive of the JumpStart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy, an advocate for financial education for young people, encourages parents to talk to their child\u2019s teachers and principals and to school board members about offering the subject. \u201cWe as parents have voices,\u201d she said.\n\nThe coalition\u2019s website includes a clearinghouse of instructional material for teachers, often free. Some programs are sponsored by financial institutions, Ms. Levine said, but the coalition requires that the material be presented in a \u201cbalanced\u201d way.\n\nAlso, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau recently developed a guide for advancing financial education.\n\nWhat should a high school financial literacy class cover?\n\nBoth the JumpStart Coalition and the Council for Economic Education recommend standards for kindergarten through grade 12, with detailed benchmarks for each grade.\n\nFor instance, the council recommends that schools cover earning income, buying goods and services, saving, using credit, investing and looking at insurance. In high school, the \u201csaving\u201d topic should include how much a student would need to save to buy a car, and explore how inflation affects the purchasing power of savings.\n\nShouldn\u2019t children learn about money at home?\n\nIdeally, Mr. Pelletier said, children would begin learning about financial concepts from their parents, but that\u2019s not necessarily happening. A T. Rowe Price survey last year found that more than two-thirds of parents were reluctant to discuss money topics with their children.\n\nParents may be hesitant because they have made poor decisions themselves in the past, Ms. Levine said. Still, she said, parents should try to talk about spending and budgeting \u2014 starting, perhaps, by explaining why the family made a certain budget decision. Or, she suggested, parents could research, together with their children, information about setting savings goals. The coalition offers tips and online tools on its website.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe encourage parents to talk to their kids about money,\u201d Ms. Levine said.", "title": "Most States Don\u2019t Require Specific Financial Literacy Classes", "authors": ["Ann Carrns", "Your Money Adviser"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen the hotel chain Motel 6 acknowledged in September that two of its Arizona motels had helped the government detain and deport some guests, the company said that the practice had been \u201cimplemented at the local level.\u201d\n\nBut a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by Washington State suggests that it may have been more widespread.\n\nThe suit, filed in King County Superior Court in Seattle, alleges that hotel employees in that state routinely gave immigration agents personal information about guests, including their names, birth dates and license plate numbers. At least 9,000 names were turned over, according to the suit, though only six were known to have been detained.\n\nWashington\u2019s attorney general, Robert W. Ferguson, said that he began an inquiry after reading reports about the activity in Arizona, which prompted widespread condemnation and calls to boycott the hotel chain. One of those articles quoted an immigration lawyer who said he had heard about the same thing happening in Washington.\n\n\u201cMotel 6 implied this was a local problem,\u201d Mr. Ferguson said in a statement. \u201cWe have found that is not true. Washingtonians have a right to privacy, and protection from discrimination. I will hold Motel 6 accountable and uncover the whole story of their disturbing conduct.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs part of Mr. Ferguson\u2019s investigation, Motel 6 initially provided information about 11 of its 26 locations in Washington, six of which, the company said, had been assisting immigration agents. As the inquiry continues, the number of names turned over, and people detained as a result, will most likely go up, Mr. Ferguson said.", "title": "Motel 6 Gave Guest Lists to Immigration Agents in Washington State, Lawsuit Says", "authors": ["Caitlin Dickerson"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Evelyn Rodriguez, whose daughter Kayla Cuevas was killed by MS-13 gang members on Long Island in 2016, says she will be in the audience as a guest of the White House when President Trump gives his State of the Union address on Tuesday.\n\nShe has also been invited to the White House before the address to meet with the president.\n\nThe murders of Kayla, 16, and her friend Nisa Mickens, 15, two American-born teenagers who were killed in a suburban cul-de-sac, became a flash point for the administration\u2019s crackdown on illegal immigrants. Ms. Rodriguez, 49, was honored to be invited, but said, for her, it was not about immigration.\n\n\u201cI want him to ensure that we\u2019re going to get the proper funding for the resources for our kids,\u201d she said in an interview on Sunday from her Brentwood, Long Island, home before boarding a plane to Washington. \u201cI\u2019m not here for anybody\u2019s political gain,\u201d Ms. Rodriguez added. \u201cI just want what\u2019s right to be done. Everybody should put their political agenda aside and think about what\u2019s going on in our country.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, and the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, in visits to the area last year, said the spate of MS-13 gang violence \u2014 17 killings in Suffolk County in a 17-month span \u2014 was because of the recent increase in illegal immigration of young people from Central America.
