Officer", "authors": ["Adam Goldman", "Matt Apuzzo"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "3. Toronto Raptors (29-12)\n\nThe Raptors generated little excitement entering the season, but that\u2019s largely because few envisioned the transformation in DeMar DeRozan\u2019s game, which features more 3-pointers and a greater commitment to the pass, or the formation of a younger, better bench, which has helped fuel a 58-win pace. Although no one is picking the Raptors to win the Eastern Conference just yet, this certainly looks like the best team in Toronto\u2019s history.\n\n4. Houston Rockets (30-11)\n\nA spate of recent injuries has stunted James Harden\u2019s Most Valuable Player Award campaign and, of greater consequence, made it a bit harder to justify a top-five spot for the Rockets even after their gaudy 25-4 start. But the additions of the defensive aces Luc Mbah a Moute and P. J. Tucker, in support of the All-Star newcomer Chris Paul, make Houston perhaps the most dangerous threat to Golden State in either conference \u2014 provided everyone gets healthy.\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Cleveland Cavaliers (26-16)\n\nThe Cavaliers are an abysmal 29th in defensive efficiency. They have played the N.B.A.\u2019s second-easiest schedule thus far. And only recently has the key figure acquired in the Kyrie Irving trade, Isaiah Thomas, come back from injury. Yet such is the leaguewide respect for LeBron James, in his 15th season, that Cleveland remains a huge favorite to reach a fourth successive N.B.A. finals \u2014 even when so much statistical evidence suggests we shouldn\u2019t treat the creaky Cavs as such a shoo-in.\n\n6. Minnesota Timberwolves (28-16)\n\nIt\u2019s only a matter of time before the longest playoff drought in N.B.A. history, now spanning 13 seasons, is officially over. Jimmy Butler\u2019s M.V.P.-worthy impact at both ends has been so instant and dramatic that the Wolves, who didn\u2019t even reach the postseason in Kevin Garnett\u2019s last three seasons in Minnesota, are on a 52-win pace \u2014 despite the inevitable news media fixation on how much Coach Tom Thibodeau relies on his starters.\n\n7. Oklahoma City Thunder (23-20)\n\nIt took longer than the Thunder hoped, but Russell Westbrook, Paul George and Carmelo Anthony are figuring it out, looking more and more like a group built for the postseason. Despite a worrisome 8-12 start, Oklahoma City is up to fourth in the league in defensive efficiency and 12th in offensive efficiency. Only two teams at present \u2014 Golden State and Toronto \u2014 rank in the top 10 of both categories, which is typically a trusty measure of elite status.\n\n8. San Antonio Spurs (29-15)\n\nA partial tear in Kawhi Leonard\u2019s left shoulder \u2014 not long after a lingering quadriceps ailment cost him the season\u2019s first 27 games \u2014 sounds ominous and caused this uncharacteristic plummet to the back of the top 10. But you know the rules by now: Never write off or assume anything with the Gregg Popovich-coached Spurs. Especially when Manu Ginobili remains a crunchtime wizard at age 40 and when the long-quiet Leonard is the star of a new (and fun) \u201cI was hacked\u201d Foot Locker commercial.\n\n9. Washington Wizards (25-18)\n\nThe Committee came into the season firmly believing that the inevitable focus on Cleveland and Boston would benefit the Wizards as much as the Raptors. Things haven\u2019t worked out as planned; Washington\u2019s 13-10 mark against sub-.500 teams is the second-worst among the East\u2019s top eight. The reality, though, is that a top-four seeding remains up for grabs and John Wall (only 39th in player efficiency rating) has another gear to rediscover in the second half.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n10. Milwaukee Bucks (22-19)\n\nIt\u2019s an open secret that the Bucks, after acquiring Eric Bledsoe from Phoenix to pair Bledsoe\u2019s athleticism with the frontcourt sensation Giannis Antetokounmpo, are trying to pull off a trade for DeAndre Jordan to address a need for more rim protection. But Jabari Parker will soon be back from injury, which almost guarantees a needed boost to Milwaukee\u2019s meek second unit.\n\n11. Miami Heat (24-17)\n\nOld-school thinkers will tell you that the Heat\u2019s 9-2 record in games decided by 3 or fewer points is tied to Erik Spoelstra\u2019s coaching acumen. New-schoolers attribute the outcome of close games to randomness as much as anything. On whichever side you fall, Miami is once again among the most fascinating teams in the league, having surged to seven games over .500 despite a negative per-game point differential (-1.0).\n\n12. Denver Nuggets (22-21)\n\nSigning Paul Millsap was a triumph for a franchise not known for its off-season splashes. But the Nuggets\u2019 passable 13-14 record since losing Millsap to a wrist injury is also a coup of sorts, given that they\u2019re hanging in the West playoff hunt even with Nikola Jokic going through a rough patch as opposed to taking the widely anticipated next step. Millsap\u2019s absence has also created an opportunity for Trey Lyles, whose promise as a versatile modern forward suggests Denver actually did get something out of the Donovan Mitchell trade on draft night.\n\n13. Portland Trail Blazers (22-20)\n\nThe West features only four teams on a 50-win pace entering the second half, which gives the Blazers a real shot to finish as high as fifth despite the fact that, as constructed, they appear to have a limited ceiling. Portland continues to lack a dependable third scoring option in support of Damian Lillard and C. J. McCollum and still has holes in the frontcourt after the initial success Jusuf Nurkic found when he joined the Blazers.\n\n14. Indiana Pacers (22-20)\n\nNo. 8 in the East? No. 8 in offensive efficiency? A record of 22-15 when Victor Oladipo is in uniform? If you claim to have predicted any of that \u2026 stop fibbing. The Pacers enter the season\u2019s second half as the undisputed No. 1 team in the Biggest Surprise of the Season rankings, hushing Indiana\u2019s many critics of the Paul George trade, which brought back the former Indiana University star Oladipo, Domantas Sabonis and no future draft picks.\n\n15. Detroit Pistons (22-19)\n\nThe Pistons are openly pursuing roster upgrades via trade, preferring to focus on the promise they see in their highs to date \u2014 wins over the West\u2019s top teams (Golden State, Houston and Minnesota twice) \u2014 as opposed to their various lows (Reggie Jackson\u2019s ankle injury, an 0-7 start to the month of December and a recent 3-10 funk on the road). Which isn\u2019t surprising when the coach (Stan Van Gundy) runs the front office, too.\n\n16. New Orleans Pelicans (21-20)\n\nThe big men Anthony Davis and DeMarcus Cousins have proven their compatibility. Consistency, though, remains an issue for New Orleans, which has stumbled every time it seems poised to go on a run that could lift it out of the lower reaches of the West\u2019s playoff chase. Of course, if the Pelicans stay where they are, we could see Golden State versus New Orleans in the first round of the playoffs, which would be a fascinating contrast in styles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n17. Philadelphia 76ers (19-20)\n\nThe Committee can think of no better ambassador to have dispatched to London for the league\u2019s annual regular-season game there than Joel Embiid \u2014 Philadelphia\u2019s one-man party. The Sixers are still young and inconsistent, and might pay for their 1-5 record in games decided by 3 or fewer points when it comes to making the playoffs, but few tandems in circulation are as must-see as Embiid and his sidekick Ben Simmons, who ranks as the current rookie of the year favorite.\n\n18. Los Angeles Clippers (21-21)\n\nThe Clippers have had too many injuries in the wake of Chris Paul\u2019s departure to come down hard on Coach Doc Rivers for the team\u2019s struggles to stay in the West\u2019s top eight. But the club\u2019s deep-pocketed owner, Steve Ballmer, wants to win so badly that Rivers\u2019s future remains a subject of great curiosity \u2014 in addition to DeAndre Jordan\u2019s and that of the veteran guard Lou Williams amid Williams\u2019 unexpectedly potent season.\n\nPhoto\n\n19. Knicks (19-23)\n\nThe Knicks took considerable grief for signing Tim Hardaway Jr. to a four-year, $71 million contract, but how much did they miss the injured Hardaway over the past 20 games? Answer: Kristaps Porzingis\u2019s recent admission about being \u201cso tired\u201d should tell you all you need to know. Enes Kanter and Michael Beasley have been pleasant surprises, but we\u2019re about to find out whether a Knicks star can freely admit fatigue to the New York tabloids and survive.\n\n20. Chicago Bulls (16-27)\n\nNikola Mirotic went from practice-floor fight casualty to prized trade commodity. Kris Dunn is looking increasingly worthy of the No. 5 pick in the draft. And Zach LaVine is back on the floor well ahead of schedule. But the most promising development in Chicago, after a 3-20 start, just might be Dirk Nowitzki\u2019s claim that the rookie big man Lauri Markkanen is \u201cgoing to be great for a long time\u201d and has \u201cthe same upside as\u201d Porzingis.\n\n21. Utah Jazz (17-25)\n\nThe good: The rookie guard Donovan Mitchell, last June\u2019s 13th overall pick, has shown real steal-of-the-draft potential in trying to fill the void created by Gordon Hayward\u2019s departure. The bad: A lack of consistent scoring apart from Mitchell and multiple injuries to the team\u2019s defensive anchor, Rudy Gobert, have led to a 4-18 mark on the road. Is a trade for Chicago\u2019s Mirotic enough to put Utah back on a playoff path? Debatable.\n\n22. Nets (16-27)\n\nThe Nets elicit virtually the same reaction from every coach or executive the Committee encounters: \u201cThey play so annoyingly hard.\u201d Brooklyn has developed Caris LeVert and Spencer Dinwiddie nicely, acquired the former No. 3 overall pick Jahlil Okafor in an opportunistic trade and appears determined to drain as much value as it can out of its first-round pick \u2014 which, remember, now belongs to Cleveland as part of the Kyrie Irving trade.\n\n23. Dallas Mavericks (15-29)\n\nAs excited as the Mavericks are about the rookie guard Dennis Smith Jr., they need another top draft pick in June (and some long-awaited success in free agency in July) to return to the usual standards of playoff contention they\u2019ve known throughout Dirk Nowitzki\u2019s career. Nowitzki still has his moments as a shooter (and screener) in Year 20, and the plucky J. J. Barea has been more efficient than ever at age 33, but Smith has to get a lot more serious about defense to become the impact player Dallas envisions.\n\nPhoto\n\n24. Los Angeles Lakers (15-27)\n\nPulling LaVar Ball aside and privately threatening to trade his son if he keeps squawking is unlikely to have much impact when everyone knows the list of teams willing to trade for Lonzo Ball and inherit the circus surrounding him is nonexistent. While Kyle Kuzma has looked like a draft steal to rival Donovan Mitchell, and Brandon Ingram quietly continues to make real strides, it\u2019s hard to notice anything else in Lakerland when the daily Ball soap opera is so suffocating. (To his credit, though, Lonzo Ball has been a steadying force through the latest controversy and a subsequent four-game winning streak.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n25. Charlotte Hornets (16-25)\n\nThe Michael Jordan-owned Hornets are going nowhere. Yet we advise you to track them at least through the Feb. 8 trade deadline because Charlotte will probably be forced to consider dealing Kemba Walker. If Walker stays, Jordan risks losing his best player without compensation in the summer of 2019 \u2014 or, perhaps worse, paying big bucks to hang on to him instead of starting an overdue tear-down of a pricey but mediocre roster.\n\n26. Phoenix Suns (16-27)\n\nAlthough the standings remain unpleasant reading, Jay Triano does appear to have made a difference in terms of accountability and structure since taking over as coach for Earl Watson four games into the season. But the Suns\u2019 future hinges on Marquese Chriss, Josh Jackson and Dragan Bender either improving to a level closer to Devin Booker\u2019s or becoming attractive enough for the Suns to package in a trade for an established star.\n\n27. Memphis Grizzlies (13-28)\n\nHarsh as it sounds, Memphis is going to have a hard time getting anyone beyond city limits to tune in when 1) Mike Conley is out injured and 2) management continues to treat Marc Gasol as untouchable while the trade deadline nears. As emotional as it would be for the locals to see Gasol follow his fellow grit-and-grind founding fathers Zach Randolph and Tony Allen out of town, where is this team going if it keeps the Spaniard?\n\n28. Sacramento Kings (13-28)\n\nVivek Ranadive, the Kings\u2019 owner, yearns to host playoff games in his new Golden 1 Center, but that\u2019s well out of reach for the moment. This season has to be about development for the Kings\u2019 recent marquee draft picks, most notably Buddy Hield, Skal Labissiere and the rookie De\u2019Aaron Fox. The big question for the second half is how long before Coach Dave Joerger goes all-in with the kids ahead of Zach Randolph, George Hill and Vince Carter.\n\n29. Atlanta Hawks (11-31)\n\nPerhaps no team in the league is more focused on the future than the Hawks, who (unlike Orlando) planned to be this bad and have entrusted their new general manager, Travis Schlenk, with reshaping the roster completely after a run of 10 seasons in the playoffs \u2014 but only one trip to the conference finals in that span. Don\u2019t be surprised if Atlanta remains in overhaul mode next season as well.\n\n30. Orlando Magic (12-31)\n\nIt might go down as one of the great unsolved mysteries of our time: How did this Magic team start 8-4? Orlando has since gone a ghastly 4-27, which will most likely lead to a fire sale at next month\u2019s trade deadline. Rival executives expect Jeff Weltman, Orlando\u2019s new team president, to aggressively hunt for new homes for the likes of Evan Fournier, Elfrid Payton and Mario Hezonja, given that Nikola Vucevic\u2019s broken finger is likely to preclude dealing the center.", "title": "N.B.A. Power Rankings: Warriors on Top at Midseason", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In a first for a major American professional sports league, the N.B.A. on Wednesday formally asked for new laws that would legalize sports gambling nationwide.\n\n\u201cOur conclusion is that the time has come for a different approach,\u201d Dan Spillane, associate counsel for the league, said in prepared remarks to a New York Senate committee on gambling.\n\nSpillane urged the state to pass a \u201ccomprehensive sports betting bill that would serve as a model for a 50-state solution.\u201d Currently, sports betting is legal in only four states \u2014 most prominently in Nevada \u2014 because of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act, or Paspa, passed in 1992 with the N.B.A.\u2019s support.\n\nIn 2007, Tim Donaghy, an N.B.A. referee, pleaded guilty to betting on games he officiated, which seemed to have a galvanizing effect on the league. David Stern, then the N.B.A.\u2019s commissioner, later said that legalized betting would help the league better track potential Donaghys. His successor, Adam Silver, called for legalized sports betting in an opinion piece in The New York Times over three years ago.", "title": "N.B.A. Pushes for Legal Sports Gambling Nationwide and a Cut of the Bets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Critics contended that the N.C.A.A. had overstepped its bounds with those penalties. Emails made public because of a lawsuit two years later appeared to show N.C.A.A. officials questioning whether their institution had the authority to issue such penalties on a university, even one where several high-ranking officials later received jail time for their roles in covering up Mr. Sandusky\u2019s abuse.\n\nIn one email, an N.C.A.A. official referred to the consent decree between the association and Penn State as a \u201cbluff\u201d and urged a settlement because the N.C.A.A.\u2019s chances of proving a violation of its bylaws before a Committee on Infractions might prove difficult.\n\nLast year, an N.C.A.A. Committee on Infractions demonstrated just how narrow those bylaws can be when it declined to penalize the University of North Carolina over a scandal in which scores of dubious classes were taken disproportionally by football and men\u2019s basketball players. Through gritted teeth, the committee said it could not find an N.C.A.A. violation because the classes had been available to all students.\n\nThe Nassar case has drawn comparisons to the Sandusky case, raising questions about how university officials responded to warning signs about federal crimes being committed on their campus and about whether they tried to protect someone who was considered valuable to the athletics program. Championship game for a chance to play in Super Bowl LII, which will be held in Minnesota\u2019s U.S. Bank Stadium on Feb. 4. Here is what you can expect in the conference championship:\n\nNo. 2 Minnesota at No. 1 Philadelphia\n\n6:40 p.m. Eastern, Fox\n\nLine: Minnesota by 3\n\nThe Vikings\u2019 season was basically over. There were 10 seconds left in their divisional round matchup against New Orleans, they were at their own 39-yard line, they had no timeouts remaining and they were down by a point. A 61-yard touchdown pass from Case Keenum to Stefon Diggs changed everything, and brought back the possibility of a team playing at home in the Super Bowl for the first time in N.F.L. history.\n\n\u2014-\n\nA.F.C. Championship Game Prediction: Patriots or Jaguars?\n\n\u2014-\n\nIt is hard to say how the Vikings (13-3) will react to being brought back from the dead, but it seems like it is bad news for the Eagles (13-3), who had been trying to turn their upset win over Atlanta into something resembling momentum.\n\nWhen they are not winning games with thrilling 61-yard touchdown passes, the Vikings are really not all that dissimilar to the Jacksonville Jaguars. Keenum is a low-risk, moderate-reward style of quarterback, the team relies on its receivers to take care of the bulk of the work after the catch rather than before it, and they punish teams with a defense that is strong on each level.\n\nPhoto\n\nEverson Griffen and Linval Joseph wreak havoc on the defensive line, but the crown jewel of Minnesota\u2019s defense is its secondary, where Xavier Rhodes and Andrew Sendejo are top-notch but Harrison Smith is a nearly singular talent. A Pro Bowl safety, Smith was rated by Pro Football Focus as not just the best player at his position in the game, but the top player at any position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPhiladelphia, up until Carson Wentz\u2019s injury, could nearly match the Vikings unit for unit. They have a devastating pass-rush led by Fletcher Cox, a three-headed beast of a running game, and they were a top-five team in both points scored and fewest points allowed. But regardless of how happy they were to turn their underdog status against Atlanta into motivation for a win, their play hardly inspired confidence. Nick Foles dinked and dunked his way to a high completion percentage, and the key play of Philadelphia\u2019s victory required one of the greatest wide receivers who ever played the game \u2014 Julio Jones \u2014 not to catch a ball thrown to him in the end zone.\n\nUnless Foles can somehow locate the explosiveness he showed in 2013, it is hard to believe the Vikings\u2019 path to the Super Bowl is not clear.", "title": "N.F.C. Championship Game Prediction: Eagles or Vikings?", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Philadelphia had already secured home-field advantage before being shut out in Week 17 against Dallas, so an uninspired performance on that day can be excused. But to understand how little ball movement the Eagles generated under Foles, an instructive statistic is his adjusted yards per attempt, which accounts for the effect of interceptions. Among the 46 quarterbacks who attempted 50 or more passes this season, Foles\u2019s adjusted average of 5.42 yards per attempt ranked 38th. His average was not only worse than that of every quarterback in the playoffs, but he also found himself ranked lower than players like Tom Savage, C.J. Beathard and Trevor Siemian, each of whom lost their starting jobs despite playing for non-contenders.\n\nCoach Doug Pederson has tried to remain upbeat about Philadelphia\u2019s ability to win without Wentz, and told reporters that getting a chance to go over film of Foles\u2019s more successful stints in the past had given the team a blueprint for success.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMy message to Nick is, \u2018Listen, you have a great opportunity. Just go be Nick. Go play. Let\u2019s go execute the offense,\u2019\u201d Pederson said.\n\nFor Foles, that most likely means focusing on film from the 2013 season, when he burst onto the scene as an ideal fit with Coach Chip Kelly\u2019s offense in Philadelphia. In 10 starts that year, Foles went 8-2, leading the N.F.L. with 10.54 adjusted yards per attempt. He threw 27 touchdowns against just two interceptions, earning a Pro Bowl appearance and making people quickly forget Michael Vick, who had been ineffective earlier that season before a hamstring injury sent him to the bench.\n\nFoles followed up his strong 2013 regular season with a decent showing in the playoffs \u2014 he threw for 195 yards and two touchdowns in a wild-card round loss to the New Orleans Saints \u2014 and he was 6-2 as a starter in 2014 before a broken collarbone ended his season.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. A few weeks of practice with the first-team offense could help shake off some rust, and he could emerge as a player capable of leading them in the playoffs. Or, even if he continues to struggle, Philadelphia could ride a great performance by its defense and its rushing attack and win in spite of him.\n\nIt is not that a healthy amount of skepticism is unwarranted based on Foles\u2019s play thus far, but some Eagles, including starting right tackle Lane Johnson, consider their underdog status to be a huge motivational advantage.\n\n\u201cI think everybody perceives us as being the weakest and that is fine,\u201d Johnson told reporters this week. \u201cI think that is good. Here is a look at the first weekend of the playoffs, and who we think will win:\n\nA.F.C. Wild-Card Round\n\nNo. 6 Bills (9-7) at No. 3 Jaguars (10-6) Sunday, 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS\n\nThe Bills appeared to have torpedoed their playoff chances when they benched quarterback Tyrod Taylor at the start of Week 11, taking a loss that looked as if it would keep Buffalo out of the playoffs for an 18th consecutive season. But a last-minute victory by Cincinnati over Baltimore on Sunday shook up the A.F.C. standings and sent the Bills to the postseason for the first time since Doug Flutie was their quarterback.\n\nFor their trouble, the Bills will face a Jacksonville team that is superior in virtually every aspect of the game.\n\nThe Jaguars ended a nine-season playoff drought by building perhaps the N.F.L.\u2019s most fearsome defense. It was paired with an offense that scared absolutely no one, yet Jacksonville somehow finished in the top 10 in both total yards and points per game.\n\nThe Bills\u2019 best hope for an upset rests in Blake Bortles\u2019s reverting to his mistake-ridden past. But Jacksonville\u2019s defense is so suffocating that Buffalo\u2019s return to the playoffs seems destined to be short-lived. Pick: Jaguars", "title": "N.F.L. Wild-Card Picks: Rams Over Falcons, Chiefs Over Titans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "But that fell far short of the \u00a34 billion in additional funding that Simon Stevens, the chief executive of the service in England, requested last year, warning that services would come under unprecedented pressure during the winter.\n\n\u201cThe N.H.S. waiting list will grow to five million people by 2021,\u201d Mr. Stevens said in an impassioned speech to health care leaders in November. \u201cThat is one million more people, equivalent to one in 10 of us, the highest number ever.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s more, he said, \u201cafter seven years of understandable but unprecedented constraint on the current budget, the N.H.S. can no longer do everything that is being asked of it.\u201d\n\nOver the past week, hospitals have increasingly declared \u201cblack alerts,\u201d an admission that they are unable to cope with demand, the health service confirmed, without releasing numbers. Most hospitals have been unable to meet emergency-ward targets of seeing patients within four hours because of a shortage of beds and staff.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May denied that the National Health Service was facing a crisis. \u201cThe N.H.S. has been better prepared for this winter than ever before, we have put extra funding in,\u201d she said on Wednesday. \u201cThere are more beds available across the system. We\u2019ve reduced the number of delayed discharges of elderly people who would otherwise have been in N.H.S. beds rather than in social care,\u201d she added, referring to state-funded care.\n\nBut the scenes unfolding across hospitals in Britain paint a different picture.\n\nTuesday night, the emergency ward at Kingston Hospital in southwestern London looked more like an airport lounge than a hospital, with patients sprawled out in the waiting room.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no real system or order; it\u2019s a jungle in here,\u201d said Nancy Harper, who had accompanied her 87-year-old grandmother, who was lying down and complaining of excruciating pain in her lower back.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been more than five hours,\u201d Ms. Harper said. \u201cWe get to the front of the queue and then someone more ill comes in and we get pushed back. It\u2019s outrageous.\u201d\n\nOther patients said they had been turned away and referred to a pharmacy or general practitioner because their cases were not deemed urgent enough.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t even think I was seen by a nurse,\u201d said Ali Elamine, who complained of acute ear pain. \u201cSome helper just took my temperature, said it was normal and told me to go to my local G.P. in the morning.\u201d\n\nMany hospitals have asked that patients seek help from emergency rooms only for urgent or life-threatening matters.\n\nMore than nine million people at emergency wards in the 2016-17 fiscal year were sent home after receiving only guidance that in many cases could have been obtained from a pharmacist, the health service said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nAnd Jane Cummings, the chief nursing officer for N.H.S. England, said that millions of patients had missed hospital appointments last year, at a cost of almost \u00a31 billion.\n\n\u201cWith the N.H.S. coming under pressure as never before, we are asking patients and the public to use the health service responsibly,\u201d she said, \u201cto help ensure that care is readily available for everyone who needs it.\u201d\n\nDr. Anu Mitra, an emergency physician at Imperial College Healthcare N.H.S. Trust, said that 70 years ago, as the country was recovering from the devastation of war, the health service had been the country\u2019s \u201cgreatest gift.\u201d But \u201cawful days like today\u201d are a result of a systematic dismantling of the system eight years in the making.\n\n\u201cTwo years ago I\u2019d have point blank refused to examine a corridor patient until they were in a cubicle,\u201d Dr. Mitra said on Twitter early Wednesday. \u201cOn days like this it\u2019s unavoidable, I\u2019m ashamed to say.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe extraordinarily high pressure has led to resignations. In December, Bob Kerslake, the chairman of the board at King\u2019s College hospital in London, quit in protest over what he viewed as the government\u2019s insufficient funding of health services.\n\n\u201cWe desperately need a fundamental rethink,\u201d he wrote in an opinion piece in The Guardian.\n\nHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologized to patients on Wednesday for the postponement of thousands of nonurgent operations. \u201cIt is absolutely not what I want,\u201d he told Sky News. \u201cThere are real pressures, no doubt about it. This is the busiest week of the year for the N.H.S.\u201d\n\nPatients have accused hospitals of putting them at risk.\n\n\u201cI learned about the new set of deferrals from the news, but if I receive a notification, it will be the third time my operation is postponed,\u201d Graham Groves, a construction worker, said as he sat in a cafe at St. Mary\u2019s Hospital on Wednesday. \u201cThis is a disgrace. We injure ourselves while working to pay our taxes, and the government just leaves us to suffer.\u201d", "title": "N.H.S. Overwhelmed in Britain, Leaving Patients to Wait", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a fight brewing in California that has enormous consequences for the state\u2019s climate policies. But it\u2019s not about electric cars or renewable energy, it\u2019s a battle over affordable housing.\n\nHere\u2019s the back story: San Francisco\u2019s state senator, Scott Wiener, introduced a bill this month that would abolish a variety of local zoning restrictions around transit hubs in cities like San Francisco, Oakland, Los Angeles and San Diego. It would essentially make it much easier to build thousands of new midrise housing units near bus stops and train stations.\n\nTo call this bill contentious would be an understatement. Cities and towns have long been protective of their ability to control local development through zoning codes. Opponents of Mr. Wiener\u2019s bill have warned that allowing unregulated development could destroy the character of their neighborhoods or displace vulnerable communities. \u201cI would have a neighborhood with little 1920s, \u201930s and \u201940s single-family homes look like Dubai 10 years later,\u201d Paul Koretz, a Los Angeles city councilman, told The Los Angeles Times.\n\nMr. Wiener has disputed those concerns and argues that California\u2019s high housing costs call for bold action. Cities have made it too hard to increase density in urban areas, he says, which drives up housing prices and pushes people into the suburbs, forcing longer commutes.\n\nIt\u2019s too early to predict how this debate will play out. But many analysts agree that California needs to rethink its land-use policies to meet its ambitious goals on climate change.", "title": "NASA Ranks 2017 as the Second-Warmest Year on Record", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Bank of Japan expected to maintain the status quo.\n\nThe Bank of Japan will announce its monetary policy decision on Tuesday, and is expected to maintain its fiscal stimulus policies. With no change in policy expected, analysts will instead be looking at comments from the bank\u2019s governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, for signs about when the current stimulus is likely to reduced \u2014 a step that its counterparts in the United States and Europe have begun to take. Zach Wichter\n\nMANUFACTURING\n\nThe question for General Electric: What\u2019s next?\n\nWhen General Electric reports its fourth-quarter results on Wednesday, the numbers from the recent past will matter far less than clarifying what lies ahead. Last week, G.E. announced a surprising $6.2 billion charge to pay for lingering problems in its finance unit. The new chief executive John Flannery suggested that the setback might accelerate his plan for paring back the struggling industrial giant. Steve Lohr\n\nECONOMY\n\nEurope\u2019s Central Bank may offer clues on future of stimulus.\n\nThe surprising strength of the eurozone economy has raised questions about whether the European Central Bank will cut back its stimulus measures sooner than expected. As a result, Mario Draghi, the central bank\u2019s president, is likely to be grilled about the central bank\u2019s intentions on Thursday after a meeting of the Governing Council. In January, the central bank cut its money printing program in half, and has said it will keep up the stimulus at least through September. But statements by some members of the Governing Council have fed speculation that the program could end abruptly after that, setting the stage for interest rate increases in 2019. Jack Ewing\n\nTRADE\n\nDecisions expected on jets and solar products.\n\nThe White House faces a Friday deadline for a decision on whether to impose tariffs on foreign solar panels. American makers of the products say they have been devastated by cheap products from China, while others in the solar industry warn that restrictions on imports could raise the price of solar power and make the sector less competitive. The United States International Trade Commission will also cast its final vote on Thursday on a trade case that Boeing brought against the Canadian aircraft maker Bombardier. The trade case is a common one but in this instance it has been heavily politicized; the Canadian prime minister, Justin Trudeau, and Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain both weighed in on behalf of factories in their countries that help produce Bombardier jets or parts for them. Ana Swanson\n\nGrowth estimate may show strength of economy in Trump\u2019s first year.\n\nThe Commerce Department will release its initial estimate for economic growth for the final quarter of 2017 on Friday morning, and offer a preview of how much the economy grew in President Trump\u2019s first year in office. Both the second and third quarters of 2017 boasted gains of more than 3 percent on an annual basis. If that happens again, it would be the first time since before the recession that the economy registered three consecutive quarters of 3 percent annual growth. At the moment, most analysts don\u2019t expect that to happen. Wall Street is forecasting a 2.9 percent annual growth rate, adjusted for inflation, for the final three months of 2017. In any case, the meager growth rate of 1.2 percent for the first quarter of 2017 is almost certain to keep the full year\u2019s rate below 3 percent. Patricia Cohen", "title": "Nafta Talks Resume and Trump Plans to Speak at Davos Economic Forum", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Alderman\u2019s earlier works also found receptive audiences. Her 2006 novel, \u201cDisobedience,\u201d about the fallout when an Orthodox Jewish woman revives a romance with another woman, was adapted for the screen. The film version, released last fall, was produced by and stars Rachel Weisz.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Alderman is, not surprisingly, given to pondering the alarms her works and others have raised. When she reviewed Leni Zumas\u2019s \u201cRed Clocks,\u201d which posits a near future in which abortion is illegal again, Ms. Alderman warned: \u201cThis imagined dystopia is terrible, but the reality would be far worse.\u201d\n\nSpeaking by telephone from her home in London, Ms. Alderman discussed the upside of power and its underbelly; the sources of her own energy; and her seemingly preternatural facility for seeing into the future. Our conversation has been edited.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYour book, which reads at the outset like a particularly satisfying revenge fantasy, seems prescient. Are the social and sexual upheavals that gave rise to the #MeToo movement something you could have seen coming?\n\nI think I am probably part of that wave, rather than having known it was coming. Some of the news has sort of caught up to the book in this very strange way. Both have been part of a growing anger over the past decade, which, to me, related to the increasing visibility of certain kinds of misogyny.\n\nWhen I was a teenager in the 1990s, it was a common thing among young women to say that feminism\u2019s battles are won. Now I think it\u2019s very horrifically obvious that that is not the case. I think the internet is a big part of that awareness. You can look at men\u2019s forums, where men talk about how much they hate women, want to rape them, overpower them. You can read their rants. I was probably responding to the same thing that #MeToo is responding to. A lot of things have become visible now, things that we need to address.\n\nYour tale overall is an invitation to explore the darker, more corrosive side of power, the rise of female dictators and thrill killers asserting their authority in an increasingly lawless universe. But there is no hint of that in earlier chapters, in which you portray the reversal of gender roles in a positive, even enviable, light.\n\nI hoped at least at the outset it would be good for women to feel or imagine what it would be like to be in a position of control. It\u2019s always nice to have a little peek and see how society would look from the other side.\n\nBut finally, you have to ask, are women better than men? They\u2019re not. People are people. You don\u2019t have to think that all men are horrible to know there are some men who abuse their strength. Why wouldn\u2019t the same hold true for women? There is a small minority of sadists in the world who muck it up for the rest of us.\n\nSome of your female characters are menaced, raped, forced into sexual slavery. Did you write to avenge them?\n\nI don\u2019t know if I would exactly say avenge. The book was a thought experiment. I was writing it in 2014 and 2015, and I really didn\u2019t know at the start what the end would be. I just wanted to think it through for myself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut I do think revenge is a perfectly reasonable feeling for some characters. Just look at the news; think of the Turpins, charged with abusing their children and holding them captive. My God \u2014 that teenage girl who managed to find a phone in that situation and call for help, she is my hero.\n\nThere are women today being trafficked as sex slaves. If I could give them the power to execute their captors at will, I probably would.\n\nStill, much of the menace and violence perpetrated by women in \u201cThe Power\u201d seems gratuitous. What are your readers supposed to take from that?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI\u2019m Jewish. You can get stuck imagining yourself in a particular historical position that people like you have been in \u2014 in my case imagining myself as a Holocaust victim. But for me the larger question about the Holocaust is not, How do you avoid being a victim? It is, How do you avoid being a Nazi?\n\nSo potentially we all are oppressors?\n\nDo you think that you are so exceptional that if you had been born a German in the 1930s, you would have understood immediately that Lebensraum was a lie? That you would have tried to assassinate Hitler? Do you believe that your ethics are so exceptional that you would immediately have rebelled?\n\nIf you and I lived in a world where women were dominant, would you be telling yourself: This is very unjust; I will fight for the rights of men?\n\nIf we lived in the world of the power, I don\u2019t think I would be magically excluded from the way the world operates. I don\u2019t think I can say I would have been the enlightened person. With or without the power, I behave the way the system teaches me to behave.\n\nYou tell your story through the eyes of four characters: Allie, who becomes a self-anointed prophet; Margot, who represents the state; Roxy, a London crime lord\u2019s daughter gifted with preternatural strength; and Tunde, the only male character, who travels the world photographing and documenting the evolution of the power and learning eventually to fear its abuses. Who in your mind is the real protagonist, the one you most relate to?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI identify with Tunde. Tunde starts out as very confident, and the world slowly teaches him the reasons that perhaps he should not have been that confident. His story is the story about how a man in a world run by women learns how women have felt in a world run by men, living among wandering sadists, people who turn violent just because they can. Tunde is a writer, like me. He is also the nicest character in the book (laughs deprecatingly).\n\nYour portrayal of the Moldovan dictator Tatiana Moskalev is strikingly familiar. You introduce her as an ex-gymnast who \u201calmost competed in the Olympics\u201d: a woman as gilded as her palace, \u201cbronze highlights in her hair, glitter on the curve of her cheeks.\u201d Did you have a role model in mind?\n\nI asked myself, What is a female version of Putin? I was also thinking of Berlusconi, or a slightly ridiculous, hyper-macho dictator who really enjoys showing off his sexuality. All these slightly oily characters were somewhere in my mind.\n\nAn unsavory minor character called Weinstein makes a brief appearance. Was that pure chance?\n\nYes, people have reminded me that I wrote about Weinstein; he\u2019s the odious, treacherous guy who betrays Roxy\u2019s father. In hindsight, it was kind of eerie that I gave him that name. Am I psychic? Well, maybe.\n\nMargaret Atwood, who I was lucky enough to have as a mentor while I was writing this book, has this psychic quality to her (laughs slyly). Maybe she taught me her slightly witchy ways.\n\nWhat is the source of your own power?\n\nMy parents, God bless them, have given me an amazing education. And the support of other women has been absolutely vital to me.\n\nI rely on the women\u2019s movement over the past 150 years more than on any utility that may be in my home. I tell myself I can do better with the women\u2019s movement and without running water, than with running water and electricity and no women\u2019s movement.\n\nThere is this thing in the book where young women who have the power can wake it up in older women. This has been very central to me. We should have a certain humility in the face of the righteous anger of younger women who look at the world they grew up in and say, \u201cNo, we\u2019re not going to accept that.\u201d", "title": "Naomi Alderman on the World That Yielded \u2018The Power\u2019", "authors": ["Ruth La Ferla"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The search for the real Rosie is the story of one scholar\u2019s six-year intellectual treasure hunt. It is also the story of the construction \u2014 and deconstruction \u2014 of an American legend.\n\n\u201cIt turns out that almost everything we think about Rosie the Riveter is wrong,\u201d that scholar, James J. Kimble, told The Omaha World-Herald in 2016. \u201cWrong. Wrong. Wrong. Wrong. Wrong.\u201d\n\nFor Dr. Kimble, the quest for Rosie, which began in earnest in 2010, \u201cbecame an obsession,\u201d as he explained in an interview for this obituary in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis research ultimately homed in on Mrs. Fraley, who had worked in a Navy machine shop during World War II. It also ruled out the best-known incumbent, Geraldine Hoff Doyle, a Michigan woman whose innocent assertion that she was Rosie was long accepted.\n\nOn Mrs. Doyle\u2019s death in 2010, her claim was promulgated further through obituaries, including one in The New York Times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Kimble, an associate professor of communication and the arts at Seton Hall University in New Jersey, reported his findings in \u201cRosie\u2019s Secret Identity,\u201d a 2016 article in the journal Rhetoric & Public Affairs.\n\nThe article brought journalists to Mrs. Fraley\u2019s door at long last.\n\n\u201cThe women of this country these days need some icons,\u201d Mrs. Fraley said in the People magazine interview. \u201cIf they think I\u2019m one, I\u2019m happy.\u201d\n\nThe confusion over Rosie\u2019s identity stems partly from the fact that the name Rosie the Riveter has been applied to more than one cultural artifact.\n\nThe first was a wartime song of that name, by Redd Evans and John Jacob Loeb. It told of a munitions worker who \u201ckeeps a sharp lookout for sabotage / Sitting up there on the fuselage.\u201d Recorded by the bandleader Kay Kyser and others, it became a hit.\n\nThe \u201cRosie\u201d behind that song is well known: Rosalind P. Walter, a Long Island woman who was a riveter on Corsair fighter planes and is now a philanthropist, most notably a benefactor of public television.\n\nAnother Rosie sprang from Norman Rockwell, whose Saturday Evening Post cover of May 29, 1943, depicts a muscular woman in overalls (the name Rosie can be seen on her lunchbox), with a rivet gun on her lap and \u201cMein Kampf\u201d crushed gleefully underfoot.\n\nRockwell\u2019s model is known to have been a Vermont woman, Mary Doyle Keefe, who died in 2015.\n\nBut in between those two Rosies lay the object of contention: a wartime industrial poster displayed briefly in Westinghouse Electric Corporation plants in 1943.\n\nRendered in bold graphics and bright primary colors by the Pittsburgh artist J. Howard Miller, it depicts a young woman, clad in a work shirt and polka-dot bandanna. Flexing her arm, she declares, \u201cWe Can Do It!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n(In 2017, The New Yorker published an updated Rosie, by Abigail Gray Swartz, on its cover of Feb. 6. It depicted a brown-skinned woman, sporting a pink knitted cap like those worn in recent women\u2019s marches, striking a similar pose.)\n\nMr. Miller\u2019s poster was never meant for public display. It was intended only to deter absenteeism and strikes among Westinghouse employees in wartime.\n\nFor decades his poster remained all but forgotten. Then, in the early 1980s, a copy came to light \u2014 most likely from the National Archives in Washington. It quickly became a feminist symbol, and the name Rosie the Riveter was applied retrospectively to the woman it portrayed.\n\nThis newly anointed Rosie soon came to be considered the platonic form. It became ubiquitous on T-shirts, coffee mugs, posters and other memorabilia.\n\nThe image piqued the attention of women who had done wartime work. Several identified themselves as having been its inspiration.\n\nThe most plausible claim seemed to be that of Geraldine Doyle, who in 1942 worked briefly as a metal presser in a Michigan plant. Her claim centered in particular on a 1942 newspaper photograph.\n\nDistributed by the Acme photo agency, the photograph showed a young woman, her hair in a polka-dot bandanna, at an industrial lathe. It was published widely in the spring and summer of 1942, though rarely with a caption identifying the woman or the factory.\n\nIn 1984, Mrs. Doyle saw a reprint of that photo in Modern Maturity magazine. She thought it resembled her younger self.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTen years later, she came across the Miller poster, featured on the March 1994 cover of Smithsonian magazine. That image, she thought, resembled the woman at the lathe \u2014 and therefore resembled her.\n\nBy the end of the 1990s, the news media was identifying Mrs. Doyle as the inspiration for Mr. Miller\u2019s Rosie. There the matter would very likely have rested, had it not been for Dr. Kimble\u2019s curiosity.\n\nIt was not Mrs. Doyle\u2019s claim per se that he found suspect: As he emphasized in the Times interview, she had made it in good faith.\n\nWhat nettled him was the news media\u2019s unquestioning reiteration of that claim. He embarked on a six-year odyssey to identify the woman at the lathe, and to determine whether that image had influenced Mr. Miller\u2019s poster.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the end, his detective work disclosed that the lathe worker was Naomi Parker Fraley.\n\nThe third of eight children of Joseph Parker, a mining engineer, and the former Esther Leis, a homemaker, Naomi Fern Parker was born in Tulsa, Okla., on Aug. 26, 1921. The family moved wherever Mr. Parker\u2019s work took him, living in New York, Missouri, Texas, Washington, Utah and California, where they settled in Alameda, near San Francisco.\n\nAfter the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the 20-year-old Naomi and her 18-year-old sister, Ada, went to work at the Naval Air Station in Alameda. They were assigned to the machine shop, where their duties included drilling, patching airplane wings and, fittingly, riveting.\n\nIt was there that the Acme photographer captured Naomi Parker, her hair tied in a bandanna for safety, at her lathe. She clipped the photo from the newspaper and kept it for decades.\n\nAfter the war, she worked as a waitress at the Doll House, a restaurant in Palm Springs, Calif., popular with Hollywood stars. She married and had a family.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYears later, Mrs. Fraley encountered the Miller poster. \u201cI did think it looked like me,\u201d she told People, though she did not then connect it with the newspaper photo.\n\nIn 2011, Mrs. Fraley and her sister attended a reunion of female war workers at the Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park in Richmond, Calif. There, prominently displayed, was a photo of the woman at the lathe \u2014 captioned as Geraldine Doyle.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t believe it,\u201d Ms. Fraley told The Oakland Tribune in 2016. \u201cI knew it was actually me in the photo.\u201d\n\nShe wrote to the National Park Service, which administers the site. In reply, she received a letter asking for her help in determining \u201cthe true identity of the woman in the photograph.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs one might imagine,\u201d Dr. Kimble wrote in 2016, Mrs. Fraley \u201cwas none too pleased to find that her identity was under dispute.\u201d\n\nAs he searched for the woman at the lathe, Dr. Kimble scoured the internet, books, old newspapers and photo archives for a captioned copy of the image.\n\nAt last he found a copy from a vintage-photo dealer. It carried the photographer\u2019s original caption, with the date \u2014 March 24, 1942 \u2014 and the location, Alameda.\n\nBest of all was this line:\n\n\u201cPretty Naomi Parker looks like she might catch her nose in the turret lathe she is operating.\u201d\n\nDr. Kimble located Mrs. Fraley and her sister, Ada Wyn Parker Loy, then living together in Cottonwood, Calif. He visited them in 2015, whereupon Mrs. Fraley produced the cherished newspaper photo she had saved all those years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere is no question that she is the \u2018lathe woman\u2019 in the photograph,\u201d Dr. Kimble said.\n\nAn essential question remained: Did that photograph influence Mr. Miller\u2019s poster?\n\nAs Dr. Kimble emphasized, the connection is not conclusive: Mr. Miller left no heirs, and his personal papers are silent on the subject. But there is, he said, suggestive circumstantial evidence.\n\n\u201cThe timing is pretty good,\u201d he explained. \u201cThe poster appears in Westinghouse factories in February 1943. Presumably they\u2019re created weeks, possibly months, ahead of time. So I imagine Miller\u2019s working on it in the summer and fall of 1942.\u201d\n\nAs Dr. Kimble also learned, the lathe photo was published in The Pittsburgh Press, in Mr. Miller\u2019s hometown, on July 5, 1942. \u201cSo Miller very easily could have seen it,\u201d he said.\n\nThen there is the telltale polka-dot head scarf, and Mrs. Fraley\u2019s resemblance to the Rosie of the poster. \u201cWe can rule her in as a good candidate for having inspired the poster,\u201d Dr. Kimble said.\n\nMrs. Fraley\u2019s first marriage, to Joseph Blankenship, ended in divorce; her second, to John Muhlig, ended with his death in 1971. Her third husband, Charles Fraley, whom she married in 1979, died in 1998.\n\nHer survivors include a son, Joseph Blankenship; four stepsons, Ernest, Daniel, John and Michael Fraley; two stepdaughters, Patricia Hood and Ann Fraley; two sisters, Mrs. Loy and Althea Hill; three grandchildren; three great-grandchildren; and many step-grandchildren and step-great-grandchildren.\n\nHer death was confirmed by her daughter-in-law, Marnie Blankenship.\n\nIf Dr. Kimble exercised all due scholarly caution in identifying Mrs. Fraley as the inspiration for \u201cWe Can Do It!,\u201d her views on the subject were unequivocal.\n\nInterviewing Mrs. Fraley in 2016, The World-Herald asked her how it felt to be known publicly as Rosie the Riveter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cVictory!\u201d she cried. \u201cVictory! Victory!\u201d", "title": "Naomi Parker Fraley, the Real Rosie the Riveter, Dies at 96", "authors": ["Margalit Fox"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Also Friday, the remaining members of the U.S.A. Gymnastics board embraced a demand from the United States Olympic Committee for everyone to resign. Three members had already stepped aside this week.\n\n\u201cU.S.A. Gymnastics will comply with the U.S.O.C. requirements,\u201d Leslie King, a spokeswoman, said in an emailed statement, referring to a letter from the Olympic committee.\n\nAnd the House Energy and Commerce Committee announced it would investigate Michigan State, the U.S.O.C. and U.S.A. Gymnastics, along with U.S.A. Swimming and U.S.A. Taekwondo, in relation to sexual abuses alleged in those sports.\n\nDr. Nassar was sentenced on Wednesday to decades in jail, on top of decades he had already received on federal child pornography charges, for sexually abusing seven girls. His sentencing hearing over the prior week included statements from more than 150 of his accusers and family members.\n\nAt the first public meeting since Ms. Simon\u2019s resignation Wednesday, the university\u2019s board of trustees appointed Bill Beekman, the university vice president and board secretary, as the acting president and announced a nationwide search for Ms. Simon\u2019s permanent replacement. It also reiterated its support for an investigation by the state\u2019s attorney general, Bill Schuette.\n\n\u201cI call on it to be completed expeditiously,\u201d said the board chairman Brian Breslin, \u201cand call on him to appoint an independent third party to promote bipartisan acceptance of the result.\u201d\n\nFriday\u2019s board meeting contained statements of regret by trustees, nearly all of whom had stood behind Ms. Simon just one week ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo all of the victims, we failed you,\u201d said Brian Mosallam, a trustee. \u201cFor all current M.S.U. students, alumni and faculty, we failed you. This board has come across as tone-deaf, emotionless and lacking in compassion.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
