View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJoel Ferguson, another trustee, testily addressed the firestorm he ignited earlier this week when he publicly dismissed the scandal as \u201cthis Nassar thing.\u201d He apologized to his fellow board members for putting \u201ca target on their back,\u201d later clarifying, \u201cI said I was sorry.\u201d\n\nThe trouble at Michigan State appears to go beyond Dr. Nassar, who was a university employee for decades and the physician to two women\u2019s varsity teams. An ESPN investigation Friday described a pattern in which sexual assault complaints involving prominent athletes, including more than a dozen on the football team and a few in the celebrated men\u2019s basketball program, were handled by the athletic department rather than through regular university channels.\n\nMichigan State insufficiently complied with federal officials monitoring the university under Title IX, the gender-equity law, the report found.\n\nThe report also said that ESPN shared the main findings of its reporting on Wednesday and requested interviews with multiple administrators and athletic officials, including Mr. Hollis, indicating that the report may have helped prompt his resignation. Mr. Hollis had been Michigan State\u2019s athletic director since 2008, and was considered one of the best in the country.\n\n\u201cMark Hollis is a very good man, and I don\u2019t know why he chose to quit,\u201d Mr. Breslin, the board chairman, told reporters after Friday\u2019s meeting.\n\nDan Gavitt, the senior vice president of basketball for the N.C.A.A., said Hollis has been an innovative leader for men\u2019s college basketball. \u201cMark is a supportive friend and colleague to all of us involved with the sport, who always kept the experience around the game and for fans a top priority,\u201d Mr. Gavitt said.\n\nMr. Hollis received his undergraduate degree from Michigan State in 1985 and had worked in its athletic department since 1995. After he ascended to his current position, which a university spokesman confirmed he will depart next Wednesday, annual department revenue jumped to $123 million from $81 million, per USA Today\u2019s financial database.\n\nIn the high-profile sports of football and men\u2019s basketball, Mr. Hollis was credited with keeping Michigan State extremely competitive even next to more nationally recognized rivals such as Ohio State and the University of Michigan. Since 2008, the Spartans have won or shared three Big Ten football championships and reached three Final Fours in men\u2019s basketball. The basketball team is currently ranked No. 6 in the country and is seen as a national title contender.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hollis served on the men\u2019s basketball tournament selection committee \u2014 he was the chairman last year \u2014 and he was known for helping to advance eye-catching events, including basketball games in the center of indoor football stadiums, hockey games in outdoor football stadiums and, twice, basketball games on an aircraft carrier.\n\nLast year, Mr. Hollis oversaw the suspension and then dismissal of four football players accused of and then charged with sexual assault. At a June news conference addressing those incidents, he called Michigan State \u201cmy home,\u201d noting that he and his wife had met there as students and that their three children had attended or planned to attend the university.\n\n\u201cI expect my home to be safe,\u201d he said, adding: \u201cLike any home, its safety requires shared responsibility and accountability. As athletic director, I am responsible to make tomorrow better than today.\u201d", "title": "Nassar Case Topples U.S.A. Gymnastics Board and M.S.U. Athletic Director", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "But Ms. Portman managed to deliver a line that instantly landed among the awards show\u2019s most memorable.\n\nOn stage to present the award for best director, Mr. Howard began with a relatively standard introduction.\n\nMs. Portman added, without a smile: \u201cAnd here are the all-male nominees.\u201d\n\nIndeed, the category featured five men: Guillermo del Toro for \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d Martin McDonagh for \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d Christopher Nolan for \u201cDunkirk,\u201d Ridley Scott for \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d and Steven Spielberg for \u201cThe Post.\u201d", "title": "Natalie Portman Presents Best Director: \u2018Here Are the All-Male Nominees\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "For others, the reliance on the quad has effectively reduced figure skating to a math test. There is a proposal by international skating officials to reduce the numerical value of quad jumps after these Olympics in an attempt to restore more balance between skating\u2019s athleticism and artistry.\n\nThe American skating legend Dick Button, the 1948 and 1952 Olympic champion, said, \u201cI don\u2019t even enjoy watching skating today because it\u2019s all about quadruple jumps.\u201d\n\nThe winner of the 2018 Olympics, he said with resignation on a recent teleconference call, will be the skater who performs \u201cthe best and the most quadruple jumps, period, end of subject.\u201d\n\nButton, always frank as a commentator, might seem bitterly nostalgic and hypocritical to some, given that he was essentially the Nathan Chen of the mid-20th century. Button pushed the technical envelope and is credited with being the first man to perform a double Axel \u2014 the only style of jump where skaters take off in a forward position. He is also credited as being the first to perform any jump requiring three revolutions.\n\nYet Button\u2019s wariness about the quad might resonate with sports fans in general. He noted that skaters still receive points even if they fall on a quad jump, leading to more attempts and infecting some competitions with inelegant spills on the ice.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re a pole vault jumper and you knock the pole off its supports, do you get points for it?\u201d Button said.\n\nIn fairness, Chen has worked diligently to improve his artistry and skating skills, as well. He understands that the quad alone will not bring him a gold medal. And Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, the reigning Olympic champion, performs with deftness, creativity and emotion that may be unmatched by any previous skater. But Hanyu is recovering from a serious ankle injury sustained, in part, because of his attempt to keep up with Chen\u2019s mastery of the quad. Hanyu\u2019s Olympic prospects are uncertain.", "title": "Nathan Chen Has Taken the Quad to a New Level. Is It Good for Figure Skating?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "On Saturday, Rippon seemed to be affected by nerves as his jumping skills faltered in his long program. He fell on a quad Lutz and managed only single rotations on a planned triple Salchow and triple Lutz.\n\nIn the autumn, though, he took second place at two competitions on the international Grand Prix circuit \u2014 NHK Trophy in Osaka, Japan, and Skate America in Lake Placid, N.Y. \u2014 and he finished fifth at the Grand Prix final in December in Nagoya, Japan.\n\nMiner, who skated brilliantly on Saturday but has had a journeyman career, finished sixth at Skate America in his only major international competition of the season. He is ranked 26th in the current International Skating Union rankings, while Rippon is fifth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRippon, usually a polished, artistic performer, will most likely be considered for the long program in the Games\u2019 team competition, in which the Americans are expected to compete for a bronze behind the favorites Russia and Canada, before he competes in the singles event.\n\nThe Olympic selection committee voted 11-1 in favor of Rippon over Miner, Auxier said.\n\nWhile Miner skated an \u201camazing, lights-out performance\u201d on Saturday, Auxier said, the selection committee was not sure that he could perform at the Olympics \u201cto the extent that there was a possibility for a medal.\u201d\n\nRippon said that he and Miner had exchanged gracious text messages, but there was much debate about the selection. Those favoring Miner noted that he was peaking at the right moment and that the current selection system devalues the national championships too much.\n\nMiner\u2019s coach, Mark Mitchell, delivered especially pointed criticism, saying figure skating should choose its Olympic team as track and field does \u2014 by taking those who perform best at the championships.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a competition, after all,\u201d Mitchell said.\n\nHe accused U.S. Figure Skating of using ill-defined criteria to pick a team based on its preference.\n\n\u201cWhen they don\u2019t like the results, they manipulate the system to get who they wanted to be there,\u201d he said.", "title": "Nathan Chen Leads Olympic Figure Skating Team; Ross Miner Is Bumped", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Chen, the only undefeated male skater in the world this season, is considered the Americans\u2019 best hope for an Olympic medal. Now, the United States Figure Skating selection committee will consider each skater\u2019s body of work to pick the three men who will represent the country in South Korea.\n\nVincent Zhou, another prodigious jumper, placed third.\n\nMiner, 26, skated a nearly flawless routine to a Queen medley and had the SAP Center crowd rocking and clapping along. He pumped his right fist after a double Axel that made for a clean, lighthearted program. Miner earned a standing ovation and beamed while putting his hand to his heart in appreciation. He scored 185.60 for a 274.51 total.\n\n\u201cI had one of the most fun nights I\u2019ve ever had on the ice,\u201d Miner said. \u201cThat\u2019s what I do in training at home, and it was such a good feeling to put it out there at the big game and show what I\u2019m capable of. That\u2019s what I do all the time.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nZhou, a 17-year-old skating in his hometown to \u201cMoulin Rouge,\u201d attempted five quads and completed four in his technically difficult program \u2014 one quad was in combination with a triple \u2014 for a score of 273.83.\n\nThe 2017 silver medalist at nationals, Zhou calmed himself moments before he began by shutting his eyes, then opening them with a deep breath. He skated with ease and confidence to nail his first four quadruple jumps before falling on a quad toe loop in the second half of his performance.\n\nAdam Rippon, who was second out of the short program and chasing his first Olympics at age 28, fell on his quad Lutz but recovered. He then popped his planned triple Salchow and triple Lutz into singles for fourth place with a score of 268.34.\n\nRippon has worked tirelessly on his fitness in the past year after a foot injury, seeking to pull off the big jumps that the youngsters have mastered. Skating a year to the day since breaking his left foot while gearing up to defend his 2016 national title \u2014 he didn\u2019t get to compete \u2014 Rippon may have complicated things for the Olympic selection committee.\n\n\u201cFor what I did today, I take full responsibility,\u201d Rippon said. \u201cI felt really good this whole week, and I think over the past few years I\u2019ve had one bad skate, not even a competition.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cI knew there was a criteria to be selected for the Olympic team. I feel like I have better criteria than second and third place here, but with that being said, Vincent and Ross skated very well tonight. No matter what the selection is, I will be 100 percent O.K.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrown, a 2014 team bronze medalist at the Sochi Olympics, finished sixth. He went into Saturday third after a 93.23 in the short program and finished at 253.68. Brown shortened his quad toe loop rotation to start his free skate and fell before coming back strong with some entertaining, graceful footwork.", "title": "Nathan Chen Soars on 5 Quads and Skates Away With the U.S. Crown", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Games are meant to resolve matters, with the finality of a score. That is not the case for the biggest sports story of the year. Good luck figuring out who won and who lost.\n\nHow is success measured in protests and counterprotests? Is it mere heightened awareness, or do we need to point to concrete change? Is the goal to create division or cohesion, disruption or appeasement?\n\n(Let\u2019s step back: Do you even remember what the protests are \u2014 or were supposed to be \u2014 about? Answer: racial inequality and police brutality, according to Kaepernick, who sat, and later knelt, for pregame national anthems in 2016, and whose last game came on New Year\u2019s Day a year ago.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe 2017 season really began in the spring, as Kaepernick, 29, with a sterling reputation as a teammate and with a Super Bowl on his r\u00e9sum\u00e9, waited to be signed. It never happened. He has since watched more than 40 other quarterbacks be pulled from football\u2019s unemployment rolls instead.\n\nOnce the preseason started, Malcolm Jenkins of the Philadelphia Eagles raised a fist as his teammate Chris Long put his hand on Jenkins\u2019s back. It was widely considered the first time a white N.F.L. player took part in the protests but mostly started a season-long discussion about what constitutes \u201ctook part.\u201d\n\nIn Cleveland, more than a dozen Browns players knelt in front of the water coolers, offending many, including the local police union, which said it would not participate in flag ceremonies at future games if such conduct continued. It did not, and when the regular season began a few weeks later, the players ran onto the field with police officers, emergency medical workers and military personnel, everyone locking arms in some sort of chain of unity. (It will be remembered by some as the season\u2019s high point. The Browns went 0-16.)\n\nIt all felt only vaguely related to Kaepernick\u2019s unceremonious protests of 2016, which had required three games before anyone noticed. Trying to discern meaning in this season\u2019s protests was as bewildering as defining a catch in the N.F.L. these days.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAh, but this was 2017, when confusion was merely the first stage of good grief. Just as the regular season began, the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, was asked if Kaepernick was good enough to play in the league.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not a football expert,\u201d said Goodell, who later signed a five-year contract extension worth roughly $100 million, despite his lack of football expertise.\n\nOnly a few players protested during the first two weeks of the regular season, with more of them standing with a raised fist than kneeling or sitting. But things changed dramatically on a Friday in September. \u201cWouldn\u2019t you love to see one of these N.F.L. owners, when somebody disrespects our flag, to say, \u2018Get that son of a bitch off the field right now \u2014 out!\u2019\u201d President Trump told a rally of supporters in Alabama. \u201c\u2018He\u2019s fired. He\u2019s fired!\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was the verbal equivalent of starting a barroom brawl. Goodell and many team owners responded, mostly through tepid, prepared statements. Players, unrestrained, took to social media. Trump continued.\n\n\u201cIf a player wants the privilege of making millions of dollars in the NFL, or other leagues, he or she should not be allowed to disrespect our Great American Flag (or Country) and should stand for the National Anthem,\u201d Trump wrote on Twitter, part of a series of rhetorical bar stools he lobbed for most of a week. \u201cIf not, YOU\u2019RE FIRED. Find something else to do!\u201d\n\nAt least 100 N.F.L. players knelt for the anthem that weekend. The Seattle Seahawks and the Tennessee Titans broke league rules by staying inside during the anthem; the Titans missed the singer Meghan Linsey taking a knee at the end of her rendition. Alejandro Villanueva of the Pittsburgh Steelers came out of the stadium tunnel, barely, while his teammates stayed behind, a miscommunication that thrust them into the fray and made Villanueva an accidental hero among people opposed to the protests.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAaron Rodgers posted an Instagram photo of himself kneeling during warm-ups, which Tom Brady liked, but both stood for the anthem. Their teams, like many others, linked arms.\n\nThe protests became a sporting form of interpretive dance. What does it mean to take a knee? Is it different from sitting? What about locking arms? Raising a fist? Putting your hand on someone\u2019s shoulder? When LeSean McCoy of the Buffalo Bills stretched during the anthem, people did mental calisthenics to discern what it meant.\n\nThings got weird. The Dallas Cowboys and the team\u2019s owner, Jerry Jones, who had threatened his players against kneeling, knelt and linked arms on the field. Then they all stood before the anthem started \u2014 a flourish no one quite understood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFans booed. The president wrote on Twitter the next morning that the booing was the loudest he had ever heard. \u201cGreat anger,\u201d he wrote.\n\nEveryone, it seemed, found a reason to take some kind of stand. With the goal unclear \u2014 to force all players to stand at attention while we rush to the restroom or the beer line? \u2014 there was a lot of ruckus and noise, and little discussion or decorum.\n\nHigh school athletes, cheerleaders, marching bands, police officers, city councils, rock stars, even a football team of 8-year-olds and a band playing the anthem for an Oakland A\u2019s game knelt. Some marched to the N.F.L. offices or to the gates of stadiums in shows of solidarity.\n\nConversely, some burned their season tickets or team jerseys and vowed never to watch the N.F.L. again. A Missouri bar owner used the jerseys of two well-known protesting players as doormats to spell out \u201cLynch Kaepernick.\u201d Plenty, including the president, blamed or credited the controversy for the N.F.L.\u2019s fading television ratings (which were on a slide before the protests).\n\nIn early October, Vice President Mike Pence showed up to an Indianapolis Colts game and left abruptly (in what some called a stunt at Trump\u2019s request) when players from the visiting San Francisco 49ers \u2014 Kaepernick\u2019s former team \u2014 knelt for the anthem.\n\nThe N.F.L. and Goodell, longtime practitioners in the status quo, tiptoed the fence, to no one\u2019s satisfaction, waiting for the whole thing to fade away, which it kind of did. They responded primarily with meetings, including with protesting players. There were offers to spend more money on charitable causes, but people could not agree on that, either. There was talk that the N.F.L. might just keep players in the locker room during the anthem next season.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s almost as bad as kneeling!\u201d the president said on Twitter in November, his ire temporarily resurrected.\n\nBy then, though, the number of players kneeling or sitting for the anthem had shrunk back to early-season levels, a protest movement hard to sustain without a clear, vocal leader and goals. In places like Seattle and San Francisco, where the majority of protesters played, anthem rituals became routine, barely noticed. Even the television networks turned their cameras away, having moved on.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, at season\u2019s end, the top sports story of 2017 already feels like something that has come and gone \u2014 or is going, at least, perhaps just smoldering until it flares again. Oppression, by any measure, hasn\u2019t ended, or perhaps even slowed. Police brutality against people of color remains a major issue. Those were not things that would go away quickly, if ever.\n\nSo were the protests a success? Or does something else have to happen? How will history judge the N.F.L. season of 2017?\n\nSunday\u2019s games will not be a memorable part of the story. Nine members of the Seahawks sat, as they had most of the season, while another knelt with a teammate\u2019s hand on his shoulder. Four 49ers knelt. Six other teams had at least one player take part, the reports said, judging by their posture.\n\nWhen the anthems and the television commercials ended, the games and cheers began, as if nothing had happened. The sideline posturing of 2017 came to a close. Fitting for football, it will take a long review to determine just what it was that we think we saw.", "title": "National Anthem Protests Sidelined by Ambiguity", "authors": ["John Branch", "On Pro Football"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Efforts to establish \u201cnorms of behavior\u201d got a promising start, but are now falling apart. No one can even agree on when an act of aggression in cyberspace amounts to an act of war. The Pentagon, in its first nuclear strategy review since President Trump took office, is even proposing to use the threat of unleashing nuclear weapons against a country or group that delivered a devastating cyberattack against the critical infrastructure of the United States or its allies. But that doesn\u2019t help with the problem of everyday attacks.\n\nThe most talented state sponsors of attacks \u2014 mostly Russia, China, Iran and North Korea \u2014 have carefully calibrated their operations in cyberspace to achieve their strategic aims while avoiding a real shooting war. So far they have succeeded. While there have been indictments of Iranian and Chinese hackers in major strikes on the United States, they have never seen the inside of an American courtroom.\n\nNorth Korea has been a case study in how a nation learns to make use of its cyberweapons for disruption, revenge or profit, without fear of serious retaliation. It has learned how to station hackers around the world \u2014 in China, Malaysia, Thailand and elsewhere \u2014 and has gotten away with bolder and bolder attacks, from Wannacry to its raid on Bangladesh\u2019s central bank, which nearly resulted in the theft of a billion dollars. (The transfers were halted after $81 million had passed through the Swift system, the international clearinghouse for transactions, after someone at the New York Fed discovered a spelling error \u2014 the word \u201cfandation\u201d for \u201cfoundation\u201d \u2014 and stopped the heist. )\n\nAs James Lewis of the Center for Strategic and International Studies put it recently, \u201cNorth Korea is both cautious and cunning in its use of force, including cyberattack.\u201d But he added: \u201cThe North has been successful only against poorly protected targets, of which there are many, suggesting that there is a relatively low ceiling for its cyberattack capabilities.\u201d\n\nIn fact, the explosion of state-sponsored, sophisticated cyberattacks over the past seven or eight years has been fueled, in large part, by the expansion of poorly protected targets. Yes, banks and major utilities have, for the large part, tightened their defenses, and tens of billions of dollars have been made by companies promising all kinds of cyber protections, from the most basic programs loaded on your laptop to sophisticated systems designed to anticipate future action, or watch for variations in the normal behavior of users.\n\nBut none of that has prevented cyberspace from becoming what President Barack Obama termed the \u201cWild, Wild West,\u201d a territory of anarchy, where adversaries take free shots at one another. In the past five years, these attacks have become the cheapest way for nations to undercut one another in the name of bigger strategic goals.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet the world has been unable to decide what constitutes fair game, and what should be off limits. For years officials talked about their fear of a \u201ccyber Pearl Harbor,\u201d a devastating strike against the power grid that would turn out the lights from Boston to Washington, or London to Rome. That has not happened, save for limited strikes in Ukraine, widely attributed to Russian hackers, that seemed intended to send a message that they could attack critical infrastructure at any time. Countries have sensed what would happen if they went too far.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, cyberattacks have taken a far more subtle turn. The Russian-led attacks on the 2016 American election \u2014 and similar efforts in France and Germany last year \u2014 are prime examples. While United Nations experts had been struggling to come up with \u201cnorms of behavior\u201d in cyberspace, a consensus about what was off-limits \u2014 like attacks on power grids or safety systems, for example \u2014 few were thinking about the use of the technology to influence elections.\n\nIn fact, the election systems in the United States \u2014 the foundation of American democracy \u2014 were never on the list of \u201ccritical infrastructure\u201d until Mr. Obama\u2019s Homeland Security secretary, Jeh Johnson, added them in the last days of the administration. By then it was too late.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInfrastructure is only part of the problem. The evidence that has poured out of the United States after more than a year of congressional investigations has left no doubt that Russian hackers \u2014 working largely on behalf of two of Moscow\u2019s spy services, the SVR and the GRU \u2014 did far more than use cyber tools to break into the Democratic National Committee and the accounts of key players in Hillary Clinton\u2019s campaign.\n\nThe sophisticated use of \u201cbots\u201d to target key demographic groups with Twitter messages, Facebook ads and just ordinary-looking social media exchanges made it clear that we have entered a new world, in which states marry some of the oldest propaganda techniques with the newest ways to disseminate a divisive message.\n\nYet thinking about how to regulate that kind of activity is tying the West in knots. President Emmanuel Macron in France is proposing that government authorities be able to take down \u201cfake news\u201d during elections, declaring in his New Year\u2019s speech that \u201cif we want to protect liberal democracies, we must be strong and have clear rules.\u201d\n\nYet those rules clearly could not survive in the United States, where First Amendment protections would prohibit the government from stepping in and declaring what is fake and what is not.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s own declarations about what constitutes \u201cfake news\u201d \u2014 including articles about the Russian election activity \u2014 underscore the dangers of putting that power into government hands.\n\nThere are other complications. After the election hacks in the United States, many called for \u201creal identities\u201d on the internet, so the world would know exactly who is tweeting or posting. Sensible as it may sound, it would also be a boon to the Russians, the Chinese and any authoritarian government looking to crack down on dissent. In short, the best way to solve the problem of election meddling and anonymous attacks would be a dictator\u2019s dream.\n\nThere have been a few successes in setting norms of behavior, particularly when it comes to banning child pornography or cracking down on intellectual property theft. But those are the easiest issues on which to agree.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States, for example, would never support rules that banned espionage. And what about rules prohibiting the placement of \u201cimplants\u201d in foreign computer networks, so that in the future they could monitor activity or plant malware to bring a network down?\n\nAmerican and European officials raise the alarm whenever they find such implants in their electrical grids. But they also quietly place them in hundreds of thousands of foreign networks. That is how Presidents Bush and Obama got inside Iran\u2019s nuclear enrichment site at Natanz, with the Stuxnet code.\n\nIt is a power that the United States and its allies, have no intention of giving up.", "title": "Nations Seek the Elusive Cure for Cyberattacks", "authors": ["David E. Sanger"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 As soon as I solved Paolo Pasco\u2019s smooth Monday puzzle, I was reminded of this one by Howard Barkin, although it tackles the theme from a different perspective.\n\nThat\u2019s a puzzle maker for you: There are only so many ways to describe the theme concept in a grid, but leave it to a constructor to visualize a unique set.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nWe\u2019re watching a word erode today, and the object that is eroding is a STONE (Well, it\u2019s actually the actress EMMA STONE at 18A, and I sincerely hope she doesn\u2019t wear away. I like her.)\n\nMr. Pasco has developed a set whose last word takes one letter away from a side of the word STONE with each iteration. For example, we have EMMA STONE, followed by QUARTER TONE at 24A. The next letter to go is the \u201cE\u201d at 37A, where the answer is METRIC TON. The there is I MEAN COME ON at 54A, and all we have left at 61A is the small pebble of a STANDING O.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPouring like water over I MEAN COME ON is our revealer, \u201cNatural process illustrated by the last words of 18-, 24-, 37-, 54- and 61-Across,\u201d or EROSION.", "title": "Natural Process", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The announcement of a hearing and of court-martial charges \u201cis not intended to and does not reflect a determination of guilt or innocence related to any offenses,\u201d the statement said.\n\nImage Cmdr. Alfredo J. Sanchez Credit Us Navy, via Reuters\n\nA chief petty officer from the John S. McCain has already been referred to court-martial on suspicion of dereliction of duty; eight other crew members, four from each ship, face administrative actions.\n\nVice Adm. Joseph P. Aucoin, the head of the Seventh Fleet, the Navy\u2019s largest overseas, and other senior officers were also relieved last year after the collisions.\n\nIn November, the Navy released reports about the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and a commercial ship that killed seven sailors off Japan and the Aug. 21 collision between the John S. McCain and another commercial vessel that left 10 dead near Singapore.\n\nThe Navy concluded that both collisions resulted from a chain of errors, missed warnings and poor training.", "title": "Navy Seeks to Prosecute Top Officers for Crashes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The protests, which began on Monday, have been largely aimed at a series of austerity measures and tax increases that went into effect on Jan. 1 and have quickly rippled through the economy, which is plagued by high inflation and high unemployment.\n\nAlthough the protests appeared to be ebbing on Friday, there were calls for new political agitation on Sunday \u2014 the seventh anniversary of Mr. Ben Ali\u2019s overthrow.\n\nThe police remained out in force in Tunis. There were several scuffles. Mayssa Oueslati, a woman from Tunis, shoved a police officer, telling him to leave her alone. She said he had told her, \u201cWe know you from before \u2014 be careful.\u201d\n\nShe said the police were practicing familiar tactics of intimidation: \u201cWe know their ways, how they watch us when we go in a cafe or just protest. There is a gap between policemen and the youth. You can see it in how they treat soccer fans in stadiums, not just with protesters.\u201d\n\nSeveral of the protesters marched on Friday under the slogan \u201cWhat Are We Waiting For?\u201d\n\nAmna Guellali, a Tunisia researcher at Human Rights Watch, said the number of police officers was very high compared to the number of protesters, and expressed concern about whether the protesters had adequate freedom of movement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a news release, Reporters Without Borders said that journalists covering the protests had been intimidated, including a French reporter who was taken from his home and escorted to a police precinct for questioning. The police asked him for the contacts of journalists in Tebourba, a site of protests. (The reporter refused, and was released.)\n\nOne death has been attributed to the protests, that of Khomsi el-Yerfeni, who died Monday in Tebourba. Onlookers said that he might have been struck by a police car, but the authorities said that he was not hit and that he had suffered from chronic shortness of breath. An autopsy has been conducted but not yet released.\n\nWith its relatively stable democracy, Tunisia has been a rare success story following the Arab Spring uprisings that began here in 2010 and soon spread to Egypt, Libya, Syria, Yemen, Bahrain and other nations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe International Crisis Group, an organization committed to preventing and resolving deadly conflicts, warned in a report on Thursday that the achievements of Tunisia\u2019s revolution risked being overshadowed by political tensions and a nostalgia for strong, centralized government.\n\nThe group added: \u201cTunisia has a special responsibility to stand up to this tendency, to avoid new jihadist violence, to prevent a return to political polarization and to sustain its role as the sole Arab state sticking to a peaceful, more democratic course since the 2011 Arab Uprisings.\u201d\n\nThe group urged the strengthening of Tunisia\u2019s political institutions, the creation of a constitutional court and the establishment of independent oversight bodies and called for long-delayed local elections to be held this year.\n\nBut the unrest in Tunisia has both political and economic dimensions. While a group of Tunisian organizations were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2015 for helping to manage the country\u2019s transition to democracy, reviving the economy has been far more difficult.\n\nThere are also big regional differences. In towns like Thala, the dominant concerns are the economic despair of young people grappling with high inflation and a lack of jobs; in the more affluent capital, Tunis, young protesters have been focusing on reforms in governing.", "title": "Nearly 800 Arrested in Economic Protests in Tunisia", "authors": ["Lilia Blaise"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNeha Chavi Goel and Alexander Michael Bolano are to be married Jan. 14, at the Hyatt Regency Indian Wells in Indian Wells, Calif. Boucher, 58, of Bowling Green, Ky., was charged on Friday with assaulting a member of Congress resulting in personal injury, the United States attorney for the Southern District of Indiana, Josh J. Minkler, said in a news release.\n\nMr. Boucher has signed a plea agreement and will plead guilty, but no date has been set for his court appearance, his lawyer, Matthew J. Baker, said in a phone interview. Federal prosecutors will seek a prison sentence of up to 21 months, Mr. Baker said, adding that he would seek probation for his client. The charge carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.\n\nThe episode happened on Nov. 3, 2017, when Mr. Paul was mowing his yard while wearing headphones, officials said.", "title": "Neighbor to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge in Attack on Rand Paul, Lawyer Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The singer Neil Diamond on Monday announced his retirement from touring, after a recent diagnosis of Parkinson\u2019s disease.\n\nConcert dates in Australia and New Zealand that were set for March and April as part of Mr. Diamond\u2019s 50th anniversary tour have been canceled.\n\n\u201cIt is with great reluctance and disappointment that I announce my retirement from concert touring,\u201d Mr. Diamond said in a statement on his website. \u201cI have been so honored to bring my shows to the public for the past 50 years.\u201d", "title": "Neil Diamond Retires From Touring After Parkinson\u2019s Diagnosis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The case against Mr. Russell, who was a member of the Florida National Guard, dates back to May 19, when police officers responded to the shooting at his Tampa apartment, according to a police affidavit. There, they found the bodies of Jeremy Himmelman, 22, and Andrew Oneschuk, 18.\n\nAccording to the affidavit, Mr. Arthurs admitted to shooting both men, telling the authorities that all four of them had belonged to the neo-Nazi group. (Mr. Himmelman\u2019s sister told The Tampa Bay Times that neither her brother nor Mr. Oneschuk had belonged to the group.)\n\nIn the garage, the police found the explosive compound hexamethylene triperoxide diamine and other related materials, including \u201cmultiple pounds\u201d of ammonium nitrate, nitromethane, empty shell casings, fuses and electric matches, according to the Justice Department.\n\nMr. Russell was arrested on May 20 and pleaded guilty in September to possessing an unregistered destructive device and unlawfully storing explosive material.\n\nHe admitted to making the compound, telling the authorities that he used it to boost homemade rockets and balloons, according to an F.B.I. court filing. But an explosives expert with the agency said that the material was \u201ctoo energetic and volatile\u201d for those uses.", "title": "Neo-Nazi Leader in Florida Sentenced to 5 Years Over Homemade Explosives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Advocates for Palestinian rights and for a two-state solution had worried that the measure would help create what some said would be Israel\u2019s first \u201cBantustans\u201d on the border between Jerusalem and the West Bank \u2014 overcrowded communities left to fend for themselves without any political power, either in Israel or under the Palestinian Authority. The reference was to the apartheid South Africa territories.\n\nIn dropping the measure, the right wing had precisely the opposite goal: It wants to block a two-state solution by keeping Jerusalem intact and ensuring that parts of it will never be turned over to the Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem for their capital.\n\nNaftali Bennett, the education minister who leads the right-wing Jewish Home party, said he had changed his stance on the municipal-boundaries language after aggressive lobbying by activists, including David Be\u2019eri, who has led efforts to acquire property from Arabs in East Jerusalem and lease it to Jews.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Bennett said the activists had sketched out a plausible chain of events: Under the language they objected to, if a left-wing government were to gain power, it could redraw the Jerusalem map to create a new municipality in East Jerusalem \u2014 perhaps named \u201cAl Quds,\u201d he said, the Arabic name for Jerusalem.\n\n\u201cNow, it\u2019s only a municipal boundary,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the whole world gets used to it \u2014 that there\u2019s something else that\u2019s Al Quds. And very quickly, the perception would be that Al Quds is not Jerusalem. And then, to do the diplomatic move of severing it and handing it to the P.A. would be much easier.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd who would\u2019ve been the ones who allowed that?\u201d Mr. Bennett added. \u201cThe right wing. They\u2019d say, \u2018You\u2019re the guys who legislated this.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Bennett was a co-sponsor of the bill that contained the language allowing the Jerusalem map to be redrawn, but he was responsible for a different part of it, which raised the threshold for ratifying any peace deal involving ceding parts of Jerusalem. It requires 80 votes out of 120 in the Knesset, a forbidding supermajority.\n\nThat part of the bill was enacted, prompting howls from the left and a broadside from the Palestinian Authority, whose top spokesman said Tuesday that it amounted to \u201cdeclaring war on the Palestinian people and their political and religious identity.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe measure on redrawing the Jerusalem city map, by contrast, would have affected only a few areas, like Kufr Aqab and the Shuafat refugee camp, that have been largely abandoned by the city because of concerns for the safety of its employees outside the security barrier. This has turned them into teeming boomtowns of illegal construction, where estimates say the population has soared to between 70,000 to 150,000 people.\n\nHagai Agmon-Snir, director of the nonpartisan Jerusalem Intercultural Center, said the possibility of excising those areas from the city had set off alarm bells across the political spectrum. \u201cThere\u2019s a consensus among all Jerusalem activists, right and left, that this is not a good idea, because it\u2019s not stable,\u201d Mr. Agmon-Snir said.\n\nCreating a new local governing body would take years, and in the meantime, the Jerusalem municipality \u201cwill not invest a cent there,\u201d he said. Before any new local government could get up and running, he said, \u201cKufr Aqab and Shuafat are sure to collapse.\u201d\n\nYet the idea\u2019s main proponent, Ze\u2019ev Elkin, a Likud member who is minister of Jerusalem affairs, insisted through a spokeswoman that he would continue to pursue it. The bill that was passed requires the prime minister to gain approval in the Knesset, Israel\u2019s Parliament, for any map changes.\n\nLeft-wing groups hardly crowed about the mixed result.\n\n\u201cThe idea was in the air, it was almost realized, and I don\u2019t think it will go away so quickly,\u201d said Aviv Tatarsky of Ir Amim, a Jerusalem advocacy group that fought against the entire bill. \u201cThe peace camp and the Palestinians cannot rely on the good will of the Jewish Home party.\u201d\n\nAnd Ronit Sela, a specialist on human rights in the occupied territories for the Association for Civil Rights in Israel, said she was mystified by the last-minute change in the legislation, but welcomed the chance to lobby against Mr. Elkin\u2019s idea another day.\n\n\u201cWe are up for fighting it,\u201d she said, \u201cand if it\u2019s in the Knesset we have more tools and it\u2019s a longer decision-making process, than if the government just did this and radically changed the lives of so many people.\u201d", "title": "Netanyahu Allies Rethink Remapping of Jerusalem", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew this week:\n\nPRAY ME STAY EAGER By Ellen Dor\u00e9 Watson. (Alice James Books, paper, $15.95.) On the evidence of this exuberant poetry collection, her fifth, Watson (who directs the Poetry Center at Smith College) has stayed eager indeed. One poem describes frogs \u201cgoing nutso down in that sinkhole / pond,\u201d and closes, \u201cthey could care / less whether I thank or curse them / for their farty calls speaking sex.\u201d WILD IS THE WIND By Carl Phillips. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The love poems in Phillips\u2019s 14th collection embrace the paradox of desire and stability, with his customary long lines and discursive, inquisitive voice. BULLETS INTO BELLS: POETS AND CITIZENS RESPOND TO GUN VIOLENCE Edited by Brian Clements, Alexandra Teague and Dean Rader. (Beacon Press, paper, $15.) Clements conceived of this anthology, made up of poems about gun violence and responses from affected readers, after his wife, a teacher, survived the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. Contributing poets include Natasha Trethewey, Ada Lim\u00f3n and Ocean Vuong \u2014 as well as Clements himself, whose poem \u201c22\u201d concludes with the events of that day and ends, despairingly, \u201cAfter that, a lot of other things happened, / but it doesn\u2019t really matter what.\u201d COLLECTED POEMS By Galway Kinnell. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $35.) Kinnell, who died in 2014, was a towering figure in American poetry, publishing 10 collections over 65 years; in 1982, his \u201cSelected Poems\u201d won both a Pulitzer and a National Book Award. This is the first volume to gather all of his work in one place.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cThere would have been no \u2018The Da Vinci Code\u2019 without Elaine Pagels\u2019s THE GNOSTIC GOSPELS, her calmly dazzling 1979 reading of a long-hidden trove of early Christian texts. Uncovered in the 1940s, these blockbuster documents kaleidoscopically broadened our sense of what Christianity was and is. As Pagels explains with graceful care, what has come down to us as the religion\u2019s fundamental tenets \u2014 regarding the reality of Jesus\u2019 resurrection, the nature of his martyrdom, the status of women, even monotheism itself \u2014 were not foregone conclusions but the victors in fierce (indeed, deadly) struggles for social and political authority. It\u2019s always a lot of chaotic battles that got us to the place we are; this is true of the canon in classical music, too, which is why it\u2019s been fun, as I belatedly read Pagels, to also thumb through Nicolas Slonimsky\u2019s hilarious LEXICON OF MUSICAL INVECTIVE, a compendium of all the bad reviews that great works \u2014 we\u2019re talking Beethoven\u2019s Ninth, etc. \u2014 got when they were new. In both books, history is shown in the messy process of forming.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Zachary Woolfe, classical music editor\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew this week:\n\nCATNIP By Michael Korda. (Countryman Press, $14.95.) Korda, a presidential biographer, has always loved doodling. When his wife, Margaret, was diagnosed with a brain tumor in 2016, he started producing a sketch a day for her \u2014 featuring one of their cats, Ruby, Kit Kat or Tiz Whiz \u2014 silly, whimsical drawings he never imagined would be collected like this after her death. JANE ON THE BRAIN By Wendy Jones. (Pegasus Books, $27.95.) A psychotherapist and an English professor, Jones wears both hats simultaneously to describe why Jane Austen\u2019s novels appeal to the human brain, which craves sociability. MODERN LOSS Edited by Rebecca Soffer and Gabrielle Birkner. (Harper Wave, $24.99.) Love is not the only human experience so common it is endlessly fascinating in its permutations \u2014 so is loss. Soffer and Birkner, who both had parents die tragically when they were young, understand this. First with a website, and now this book, they have collected moving, emotional and oftentimes funny essays about how grief can enter and change your life. EAT LIKE WALT By Marcy Carriker Smothers. (Disney Editions, $35.) The corn dogs and banana splits at Disneyland are part of its kitschy appeal. But how did that particular American cuisine get there? Like all else at the park, Walt Disney is in the details. This strangely fascinating book lays out his thinking as well as some recipes \u2014 from Adventureland\u2019s \u201cPineapple Polynesian Ribs\u201d to Main Street, U.S.A.\u2019s \u201cPotato Salad.\u201d A GOOD COMB By Muriel Spark. (New Directions, $11.95.) A collection of the author\u2019s sayings and aphorisms, which includes such gems as, \u201cIt is impossible to persuade a man who does not disagree, but smiles.\u201d\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cWith modern workplace culture being interrogated anew, I\u2019m plunging back into THE GIRLS IN THE OFFICE, by Jack Olsen: a fascinating if lamentably out-of-print 1972 collection of interviews with 15 pseudonymous female employees of a Manhattan organization referred to simply as the Company. With its frequent alcoholic \u2018pours\u2019 this Company suspiciously resembles the old Time Inc., for which Olsen was once Midwest bureau chief. The colorful, forthcoming subjects include the 20-something Bettye McCluin (\u2018overskilled, sexy, aloof\u2019) and the \u2018fading jet set cosmopolite\u2019 Callia Bartucci. A prolific writer and father of seven who died in bed at 77 with a magazine on his chest, the author specialized in true crime. His oral history \u2014 a genre practiced with more transparency by Studs Terkel and Jean Stein \u2014 favors lurid detail and despair, like a nihilistic sequel to the Rona Jaffe novel \u2018The Best of Everything.\u2019 But it serves as powerful documentation of an era when women were institutionally subordinate, squabbling over the terms of their own liberation. How much has changed \u2026 and how little.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Alexandra Jacobs, features editor\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "New this week:\n\nWHEN TO JUMP: IF THE JOB YOU HAVE ISN\u2019T THE LIFE YOU WANT By Mike Lewis. Read by the author and various contributors. (Macmillan Audio.) Sheryl Sandberg narrates the foreword to this first manifesto of the growing community of \u201cjumpers,\u201d people who are leaving behind unsatisfying careers to chase after their true passions. THE LARGESSE OF THE SEA MAIDEN By Denis Johnson. Read by Nick Offerman, Michael Shannon, Dermot Mulroney, Will Patton and Liev Schreiber. (Random House Audio.) Five short stories are read by five noteworthy actors in a tribute to the enduring influence of this writer\u2019s work in all its darkness and sublimity, before his death last year at age 67. BETTY BEFORE X By Ilyasah Shabazz with Ren\u00e9e Watson. Read by the author. (Macmillan Audio.) In a book intended for young audiences, the daughter of Malcolm X fictionalizes her mother\u2019s young life and the story of her attempt to overcome a difficult upbringing and a 1940s America riven with racial tension. TOGETHER WE RISE: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE PROTEST HEARD AROUND THE WORLD By the Women\u2019s March Organizers and Cond\u00e9 Nast. Read by Ashley Judd, Melanie L. Campbell, Cindi Leive et al. (HarperAudio.) In a series of essays that have only grown in relevance, some of the most vociferous advocates of last year\u2019s women\u2019s march offer an urgent call to arms for gender equality today. SPIN By Neil Fishman and Harvey Edelman. Read by Jim Dale et al. (HarperAudio.) Two Broadway songwriters deliver the first original audiobook musical, based on the Brothers Grimm fairy tale \u201cRumpelstiltskin.\u201d\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know as much about affluent people as we think we do. Caricatures abound, but the socioeconomically lucky don\u2019t often offer themselves up for study. That all changed with Rachel Sherman\u2019s UNEASY STREET. Nominally a sociologist, Sherman has written what is really a psychological study, and I\u2019ve found myself returning to it frequently to remind myself of uncomfortable questions that lurk just below the surface of the lives of people who have much more than average. For instance, every consumer choice is its own expression of values. So what do our biggest ones say about what we stand for? How do impressionable children view them? And why are so many of us so eager to embrace social class labels with the word \u2018middle\u2019 in them when we\u2019re nowhere near the median? The voyeurism here is minimal; the judgment nearly nonexistent. But with each reading, I\u2019m a little more unsettled, in the best possible way.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Ron Lieber, \u201cYour Money\u201d columnist", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "New this week:\n\nTHE MAN WHO MADE THE MOVIES By Vanda Krefft. (Harper, $40.) Krefft has written the first major biography of William Fox, the movie mogul whose life story is the archetypical rags-to-riches tale \u2014 a boy who worked in a sweatshop on the Lower East Side eventually creates an entertainment empire. PHONE By Will Self. (Grove Press, $27.) The final novel in Self\u2019s massive Umbrella Trilogy exploring technology and psychopathology, this book is set in London and Iraq and tells the story of two men, a psychiatrist losing his own mind and a mysterious MI-6 agent. MY TWENTIETH CENTURY EVENING AND OTHER SMALL BREAKTHROUGHS: THE NOBEL LECTURE By Kazuo Ishiguro. (Knopf, $16.95.) This is the lecture that the most recent Nobel laureate gave in Sweden in early December, looking at his own evolution as a writer and his thoughts on what a new generation of authors must do to keep literature relevant to our lives. IN DAYS TO COME By Avraham Burg. (Nation Books, $28.) The former speaker of Israel\u2019s Knesset gives his own take on his country\u2019s history and the quagmire it now finds itself in as Zionism and Jewish identity evolve to meet the new realities of the 21st century. TELL ME MORE By Kelly Corrigan. (Random House, $26.) Corrigan unpacks 12 essential phrases, from \u201cI don\u2019t know\u201d to \u201cI love you,\u201d that, as she puts it, \u201cturn the wheel of life.\u201d\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cThe last time I read PERSONAL HISTORY by Katharine Graham was in 2015, after almost nine years of working for The Washington Post, her newspaper. What struck me most then, though, was her description of her young adulthood in the nation\u2019s capital, and the \u2018legions of young men in Washington who grouped together to live in houses.\u2019 Katharine Meyer and Philip L. Graham met at a group-house party in D.C.! I had suffered through so many myself, and mostly what I got were in-person recitations of funny things people had said on Twitter. I\u2019m reading her book for a third time now, after being predictably charmed by the new movie \u2018The Post.\u2019 It is remarkable to watch Meryl Streep, as Graham, decide to publish the Pentagon Papers, then read that decision rendered in Graham\u2019s own words. By the time you reach that point in the book, she has talked candidly about pregnancy loss, personal friendships with several presidents, her husband\u2019s suicide \u2014 and the way she made history in a job she was never really expected to have. Maybe that would have been too long a movie, but it\u2019s worth treating yourself to the source material.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Rachel Dry, editor of Sunday Review\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew this week:\n\nSO YOU WANT TO TALK ABOUT RACE By Ijeoma Oluo. (Seal Press, $27.) Oluo takes on the thorniest questions surrounding race, from police brutality to who can use the \u201cN\u201d word. One chapter even has this intriguing heading: \u201cI Just Got Called a Racist, What Do I Do Now?\u201d ANGELITOS By Ilan Stavans and Santiago Cohen. (Mad Creek Books, $17.95.) This graphic novel has a simple, gritty style. It tells the story of Padre Chinchachoma, a Catholic priest known on the streets of Mexico City as a protector of homeless children who raised the ire of the local police and was suspected of sexual abuse. CULTURE AS WEAPON By Nato Thompson. (Melville House, $24.99.) Thompson is an art curator and activist who has a problem with the way that corporations have co-opted the realm of culture to ensure profits, shape public opinion and control dissent. IT OCCURS TO ME THAT I AM AMERICA Edited by Jonathan Santlofer. (Touchstone, $30.) Timed to the first anniversary of Donald Trump\u2019s inauguration, this collection packs in an impressive array of fiction writers and illustrators. The likes of Joyce Carol Oates, Neil Gaiman and Art Spiegelman assert their own visions for a democratic society. NIKOLAI GOGOL By Vladimir Nabokov. (New Directions, $16.95.) In Nabokov\u2019s classic biography of the Russian novelist, newly reissued, he begins with Gogol\u2019s death and works back to his birth. Nabokov is particularly good at capturing the humorist in Gogol, a writer often misinterpreted as a kind of Russian Dickens.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cWhen machines eventually think and feel, can we still own them? And if we can, is it then logical that we can enslave people too? A new novel by Annalee Newitz, AUTONOMOUS, tracks the eventual collision of a mercenary, who is falling for his killer robot, and a murdering pharma-copyright pirate, who is falling for a rescued slave. Much of the book is taken up with a scary plot about drug copyright, which turns out to be about who owns our chemical brains. But the larger point about living in this world \u2014 life after \u2018the slow-motion disaster of capitalism converting every living thing and idea into property\u2019 \u2014 means it has become impossible to recognize the difference between coercion and freedom. It\u2019s normal to read about characters who are mystified about why they can\u2019t connect. It\u2019s much scarier to read about people who can\u2019t recognize that they\u2019re predators. Timely!\u201d\n\n\u2014 Choire Sicha, Styles Editor\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The author of a definitive book on the hot dog is now covering a much bigger topic. Bruce Kraig, a professor emeritus of history at Roosevelt University in Chicago, surveys the food of America from prehistory to the present in \u201cA Rich and Fertile Land.\u201d Geology, geography, meteorology, agriculture, industrialization, politics, technology and taste are all included, and Mexico and Canada are mentioned when relevant. What could have been a dry treatise is enlivened by individual stories drawn from diaries and other first-person accounts, and by occasional illustrations: \u201cA Rich and Fertile Land: A History of Food in America\u201d by Bruce Kraig (Reaktion Books, $39).", "title": "New Book on the History of American Food", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Planning to travel abroad this year?\n\nThe State Department has new advisories at Travel.state.gov that rank every country on a scale of one to four to help travelers make informed decisions about their personal safety. The agency introduced the rankings this month to replace its longstanding system of warnings and alerts, which many travelers found difficult to grasp.\n\n\u201cFrankly, I personally was tired of explaining the difference between a travel warning and a travel alert even to some of my colleagues,\u201d Michelle Bernier-Toth, the Bureau of Consular Affairs acting deputy assistant secretary for overseas citizens services, said during a conference call about the rankings.\n\nMany people weren\u2019t sure what di fferentiated travel warnings from alerts, and what they were supposed to do when either was issued. Under the new ranking system, the lower the number, the lower the risk, with Level 1 being \u201cexercise normal precautions,\u201d Level 2 being \u201cexercise increased caution,\u201d Level 3 being \u201c reconsider travel\u201d because of serious risks to safety and security, and Level 4 being \u201cdo not travel\u201d because of the greater likelihood of life-threatening risks and the United States government\u2019s limited ability to provide help.\n\nUpon first blush, the rankings may seem like laws. For instance, if you search for a country and it\u2019s a Level 4, as Afghanistan is, it has a bright red heading and the words \u201cDo not travel.\u201d But the State Department does not bar private citizens from traveling to a particular country \u2014 even one that it advises they not visit. (In the case of North Korea, however, there is a general travel restriction on the use of a United States passport.) The rankings, even those that are Level 4, are recommendations, not rules.", "title": "New Country Rankings Aim to Help Travelers Choose Safe Destinations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The British artist Damien Hirst will exhibit new works from his series of spot paintings at a stately home in Britain.\n\nThe exhibition, titled \u201cColour Space,\u201d will open in March at Houghton Hall in Norfolk, in the southeast of England; the mansion was built in the 1720s for Britain\u2019s first prime minister, Robert Walpole.\n\nRoughly 50 of Mr. Hirst\u2019s new works will go on display in the state rooms of a building that once housed a world-class collection of European old master paintings.\n\n\u201cI originally wanted the Spots to look like they were painted by a human trying to paint like a machine,\u201d Mr. Hirst said in a statement. \u201c\u2018Colour Space\u2019 is going back to the human element, so instead you have the fallibility of the human hand in the drips and inconsistencies.\u201d", "title": "New Damien Hirst Paintings to Be Exhibited in Stately British Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "At this time of year, baseball fans keep an eye on the calendar, counting the days until pitchers and catchers report for spring training. An equivalent exercise for followers of New York government is tracking the trial dates for politicians accused of first-degree possession of sticky fingers.\n\nThe state and its capital have long been playgrounds for the ethically challenged, but this year is a \u201cscandal-palooza\u201d of criminal cases, to borrow from Blair Horner, executive director of the New York Public Interest Research Group. So mark your calendars for these corruption trials. You can\u2019t tell the players without a scorecard:\n\nFebruary: George Maziarz, a former state senator. March: Edward Mangano, a former Nassau County executive. April: former Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, retried, having been denied a review of his case last week by the United States Supreme Court. May: Alain Kaloyeros, a former state university executive. June: Dean Skelos, former State Senate majority leader, also a retrial. July: Assemblywoman Pamela Harris of Brooklyn, indicted this month on charges that include profiteering from Hurricane Sandy by falsely claiming it displaced her from her home.\n\nBut first up is Joseph Percoco, long a loyal aide and friend to Gov. Andrew Cuomo. He and three others go on trial Monday in federal court in Manhattan, charged with pocketing bribes from companies looking for state contracts. It\u2019s alleged that in emails Mr. Percoco referred to the money as \u201cziti,\u201d a term of art gleaned from \u201cThe Sopranos.\u201d With those contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars, an awful lot of ziti was at stake.", "title": "Opinion | New Directory to Lawmakers: The Court Calendar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 People from all walks of life sit down every day (Maybe some of you stand. Who am I to judge?) and solve puzzles to help satisfy that need to put the world in order and test their gray matter.\n\nOne not-so-well-kept secret on the puzzle-making side of the business is that your favorite puzzle makers may have learned their trade from a more experienced constructor (Full disclosure: I owe my career to Nancy Salomon, who was incredibly patient with me as I learned the ropes.) Mentors are published constructors who give generously of their time and teach new constructors how to polish a theme, what good fill looks like and how to write clues. They are continually giving back to the puzzle community. We stand on their shoulders.\n\nNow, two puzzle makers, along with a group of constructors who are generously volunteering their time, would like to help diversify the pool of constructors who contribute to newspapers and magazines. Will Nediger, a 28-year-old professional puzzle maker from London, Ontario, and Erik Agard, a constructor from Gaithersburg, Maryland who makes puzzle for a variety of venues including the Indie 500 Crossword Tournament, have teamed up to encourage more women and people of color to learn the art of crossword puzzle construction.\n\nMr. Nediger and Mr. Agard have created a public group on Facebook called the \u201cPuzzle Collaboration Directory,\u201d an online resource that will match aspiring puzzle makers with experienced constructors to help them learn the craft. While anyone is welcome to join and find a published constructor, the focus is on diversifying the rotation normally seen in newspaper and magazine puzzles.", "title": "New Facebook Group Helps Aspiring Constructors Learn the Art of Puzzle Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The bigger picture\n\nThe onetime engine of Wall Street\u2019s enviable performance, fixed-income trading, is still sputtering, thanks to new regulations, disruptive technologies and calmer markets.\n\nMore from Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly in the NYT:\n\nFive years ago, fixed-income trading \u2014 so called because its keystone product, bonds, typically provides a fixed payout \u2014 generated nearly $103 billion in income for the top 12 investment banks, according to Coalition, a London research firm. By 2016, that had fallen to less than $76 billion \u2014 down $27 billion from the peak.\n\nJPMorgan takes hit tied to Steinhoff\u2019s woes.\n\nTucked into JPMorgan's earnings this morning was a $143 million mark-to-market loss the bank disclosed on a \u201cmargin loan to a single client.\u201d\n\nThat client is Steinhoff International Holdings, according to reports.\n\nEarly last month the giant South African retailer, which owns American mattress maker Sleepy\u2019s, said it had discovered accounting irregularities. Its shares tumbled 78 percent on the news.\n\nHow does this effect J.P. Morgan? The bank was not among the initial group of lenders on the margin loan \u201cto an entity controlled by Steinhoff\u2019s then chairman Christo Wiese to purchase additional shares in the company in the fall of 2016.\u201d But, as the WSJ reports, \u201closses from the margin loan were expected to have been spread among a wider group of banks.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe borrowing entity pledged 628 million Steinhoff shares as collateral on the loan, according to a company statement at the time. After the share price collapse, however, that collateral has little value relative to the debt.\u201d\n\nU.S. Supreme Court will hear a challenge to S.E.C.\u2019s in-house judges.\n\nHow often does the Supreme Court agree to review a decision in which the two sides agree the lower court was wrong?\n\nThat odd situation will play out in Lucia v. Securities and Exchange Commission in which the justices will consider whether administrative law judges used by the S.E.C. are \u201cofficers\u201d under the Constitution Appointments Clause. If they are, then they can only be put in office by the president, a head of a department, or the judiciary.\n\nThis obscure provision burst on the scene about two years ago when defendants challenged how the S.E.C. picked its in-house judges [link below].\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe S.E.C. became more aggressive in pursuing administrative cases in the wake of the Dodd-Frank Act. The law expanded the S.E.C.\u2019s authority to bring most cases in its administrative court rather than going into a federal district court, depriving defendants of discovery rights and a jury to decide the case.\n\nDefendants argued the judges are not mere employees but \u201cofficers\u201d so the proceeding was unconstitutional. Needless to say, the S.E.C. disagreed and argued before the appeals courts that there was no issue regarding their constitutional status.\n\nThe S.E.C. won the case before the federal appeals court in Washington, D.C. but lost in the Tenth Circuit. Then the Justice Department flipped the script. In late November, the solicitor general\u2019s office filed a brief [link below] with the Supreme Court stating that the judges had not been properly appointed because they are \u201cofficers\u201d under the Constitution.\n\nThe key issue is whether other agencies beyond the S.E.C. that use in-house judges will also have to change how they are appointed. The impact of the decision could be significant if previously decided cases will have to be reheard before a properly appointed judge, creating a mess that could take years to sort out.\n\n-- Peter J. Henning\n\nPhoto\n\nBlackRock is now a $6 trillion firm.\n\nContinuing to cash in on the boom in exchange-traded funds, the world\u2019s largest money manager ended 2017 with $6.3 trillion under management up 22 percent for the year.\n\nBlackRock reported adjusted net earnings of $3.7 billion for the year on Friday, up 16 percent for the year and easily beating analyst expectations. The firm also reported a $1.2 billion tax benefit for the fourth quarter, resulting from the recent tax cut package. Including the tax benefit, earnings were up 59 percent for the year.\n\nBlackRock has been one of the main beneficiaries of the current bull market. Money has flowed over the past nine years into passive investment funds that track a wide variety of indexes and strategies at minimal cost.\n\nOf the $367 billion in net inflows that BlackRock took in last year, $245 billion came via the firm\u2019s iShares suite of E.T.F.s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIncreasingly investors are using E.T.F.\u2019s to make bets on the stock and bond markets as opposed to buying the individual securities themselves.\n\n\u2014 Landon Thomas Jr.\n\nT. Boone Pickens Calls it Quits.\n\nThe famous oilman and investment manager is shutting his energy-focused hedge fund as his health declines, the WSJ reports.\n\nMr. Pickens wrote in a letter that he plans to publish soon and was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal:\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s no secret the past year has not been good to me, from a health perspective or a financial one. If you are lucky enough to make it to 89 years of age like I have, those things tend to put life in perspective.\u201d \u201cTrading oil is not as intriguing to me as it once was.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nC.E.O.s hoping for an immigration deal will have to keep waiting\n\nYesterday morning, six senators looked near a bipartisan deal on how to protect the class of young unauthorized immigrants known as Dreamers. That would have pleased the 142 business leaders who had pleaded for one.\n\nThen \u201cshithole\u201d happened.\n\nLeaving aside the controversy over the vulgarity, President Trump\u2019s reported remarks \u2014 which he says weren\u2019t quite like that \u2014 exposed his skepticism about the contours of a proposal presented to him by the senators Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, and Dick Durbin, Democrat of Illinois.\n\nDemocrats want a clean bill to protect the immigrants, but Mr. Trump questioned why immigrants from Haiti and parts of Africa should be protected too.\n\nOther Republicans expressed skepticism as well. Senator John Cornyn of Texas said, \u201cWe need to have more than six votes for a proposal.\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Inside the fractious relationship between the president and his party. (Time)\n\n\u2022 Steven Mnuchin defended Mr. Trump\u2019s planned visit to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, with the improbable assertion that it isn\u2019t \u201ca hangout for globalists.\u201d (Axios)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 How Mr. Mnuchin is expanding his influence within the administration, to colleagues\u2019 consternation. (Politico)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe small print on Walmart\u2019s tax gesture\n\nThe retail giant initially won praise for announcing that it was raising hourly wages to $11, expanding parental leave benefits and offering U.S. employees bonuses of up to $1,000.\n\nBut then:\n\n\u2022 People calculated how much \u2014 or little \u2014 it would all cost. The $300 million bill for the new hourly rate amounts to \u201cjust 0.3 percent of the company\u2019s sales and administration costs.\u201d One analyst calculated Walmart\u2019s overall tax savings at about $2.2 billion.\n\n\u2022 Critics pointed out that Walmart would probably have had to raise wages anyway, given the tight labor market and competition from rivals like Target.\n\n\u2022 Walmart said it was closing 63 Sam\u2019s Club stores, and trying to find jobs for affected employees.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them.
