View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe tax flyaround\n\n\u2022 Fiat Chrysler announced $2,000 bonuses for about 60,000 workers and plans to move some truck production to Michigan from Mexico. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Delta said yesterday that the tax changes would help it in two ways: via a lower corporate rate, and via other businesses spending some of their savings on travel. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 Bill Dudley, the New York Fed\u2019s president, said the cuts would probably prompt rate increases. (FT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The Treasury Department is encouraging companies to incorporate the new, lower withholding rates as soon as possible, so benefits will show sooner. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Companies like Apple whose fiscal years don\u2019t match the calendar year could use a loophole for even bigger gains. (Bloomberg)\n\nAll eyes are on Dropbox\u2019s I.P.O.\n\nWith its confidential filing with the S.E.C., the online file storage company will be the latest Silicon Valley unicorn to attempt a transition to the public markets \u2014 by spring, it hopes.\n\nOne big question: What will Dropbox be valued at? Private market investors reckoned $10 billion. And can it command a higher valuation than its rival Box?\n\nWhat\u2019s next: Dropbox has already hired Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase as underwriters, and will appoint more. It will then work on formalizing its prospectus and arrange meetings with analysts and, eventually, prospective investors.\n\nThe other big question: Will Dropbox be more like Stitch Fix (up 66 percent since its I.P.O.) or Snap (down 40 percent)?\n\nPhoto\n\nPublishers worry about Facebook\u2019s latest shift\n\nWhat to expect: More status updates by family or photos of your friend\u2019s Bernese mountain dog. And fewer posts by publishers.\n\nWhat publishers fear, as expressed by Jason Kint of Digital Content Next to Sydney Ember and Sapna Maheshwari of the NYT:\n\n\u201cIf this change is as significant as they describe it, news organizations will go out of business or succeed based on a change that they didn\u2019t necessarily have input on,\u201d Mr. Kint said. \u201cIt reads as something that will drive up engagement and probably push away policy risk, because they\u2019re not allowing news properties to have the same sort of presence in their feeds.\u201d\n\nMark Zuckerberg acknowledged that could hit Facebook\u2019s business in the short term. Its shares were down 2.6 percent in premarket trading this morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bigger point\n\nThe company and Mr. Zuckerberg are considering how to reshape their products in the face of an array of critics, from Congress and other governments to user privacy advocates. \u201cWe want to make sure that our products are not just fun, but are good for people,\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg told Mike Isaac of the NYT.\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind Harold Ford\u2019s ouster from Morgan Stanley\n\nBeing accused of harassing a female journalist \u2014 Lauren Tara LaCapra of Reuters said he tried to pull her into an elevator to go to a cocktail lounge \u2014 helped hasten a downfall years in the making.\n\nWhat Morgan Stanley officials felt, according to Kate Kelly and Andrew in the NYT:\n\nEven though the harassment charge was never corroborated, they said, the bank found evidence that Mr. Ford had misled executives about some of his behavior, which itself constituted cause to remove him. And they say Mr. Ford already had received a final written warning about abuse of his expense account and other conduct.\n\nMr. Ford and his lawyers argue otherwise and said Ms. LaCapra\u2019s account was false.\n\nWhere is Wall Street\u2019s #MeToo moment?\n\nKeep waiting. More than most industries, finance can force cases into arbitration. And there\u2019s the money, as the wealth manager Jennifer Hatch told Max Abelson of Bloomberg:\n\n\u201cPeople spend their entire educational and professional career trying to get to this pot of gold, and some guy dropping his drawers is not going to get in the way of that,\u201d she says.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 DFJ has apologized for an event hosted by a co-founder, Steve Jurvetson, that a book by the Bloomberg reporter Emily Chang described as featuring rampant sex and drug use. (Recode)\n\n\u2022 Daniel Ek, the C.E.O. of Spotify, has backed the #MeToo movement, saying his company had a lot to do on gender bias. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 University students and faculty worldwide have been describing harassment in an anonymous crowdsourced spreadsheet. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nBitcoin newbies start worrying about taxes\n\nTax professionals are getting more questions from Bitcoin sellers, and the I.R.S. is also showing interest.\n\nMore from Brian Fung of the WaPo:\n\nIn a recent court battle, the I.R.S. forced Coinbase, one of the largest U.S.-based exchanges where consumers can buy bitcoin for dollars, to provide taxpayer information on more than 14,000 customers. The I.R.S. did not single out any customer for suspicion in the suit but did say it believed gains from virtual currency \u201care underreported.\u201d\n\nThe digital money flyaround\n\n\u2022 Shares in the money-transfer services provider MoneyGram rose after it said it was testing Ripple\u2019s XRP. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "New Facebook Should Benefit Investors Long Term: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Many more stroke victims than previously thought can be saved from disability or death if doctors remove blood clots that are choking off circulation to the brain, a new study has shown.\n\n\u201cThese striking results will have an immediate impact and save people from lifelong disability or death,\u201d Dr. Walter J. Koroshetz, director of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, said in a statement. \u201cI really cannot overstate the size of this effect.\u201d\n\nThe key finding is that there is often more time than doctors realized in which brain cells can still be rescued by a procedure to remove the clot. Traditional guidelines have set a limit of six hours after stroke symptoms begin, and said after that it would be too late to help.\n\nThe study showed that the time window could be expanded to 16 hours. However, the findings do not apply to every stroke victim. The researchers used a special type of brain imaging to identify the patients who still had live brain tissue that could be saved if the blood supply was restored. Only about half the patients who were screened qualified for treatment, known as thrombectomy, which uses a mechanical device to pull clots out of a blood vessel.", "title": "New Findings Could Save Lives of More Stroke Patients", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "It has taken longer than expected to get building permits. It has taken longer to negotiate rates with nonprofits paid to operate the shelters. It has taken longer to find locations for shelters. It has taken countless hours in court and at community meetings to try to change public perceptions that homeless people are nuisances, that shelters are blight and that the government is unfair and opaque.\n\nIn interviews, Steven Banks, the city\u2019s commissioner of social services, said he was confident that the city would be closer to its goal in the spring and would be well on track by 2019. \u201cThe pace has picked up in the last month,\u201d he said. But he acknowledged that 2017 had been a reality check.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a reason why nobody tried to do this before,\u201d Mr. Banks said. \u201cIf it was easy to do, the shelter system wouldn\u2019t have developed in a haphazard way over three and a half decades. We set an ambitious goal to keep commitments to providing better client services and more community engagement. We\u2019re confident that at the end of the five-year plan, we will get to the 90 shelters.\u201d\n\nOn Monday night, thousands of volunteers fanned out to streets, parks and subways for the Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, the city\u2019s annual census of unsheltered homeless people. Its 10 rooms occupy a former 18th-century house in the historic San Marcos neighborhood with a bar on the roof and the city\u2019s acclaimed Nuema restaurant on the premises. Rooms from $459; illaexperiencehotel.com.\n\nUNITED STATES\n\nTiny Urban Escapes, Indianapolis\n\nThis summer, two shipping containers that have been remodeled with glass walls will open on four acres of private land adjacent to Eagle Creek Park in Indianapolis as getaway cabins called Tiny Urban Escapes. Poised to draw nature-loving city-dwellers, the 160-square-foot rooms will each come with two bikes for exploring the nearby trails. Rooms from $179; tinyurbanescapes.com.\n\nThe Source Hotel, Denver\n\nComing this spring to the Source food market in Denver\u2019s booming River North Art District, the Source Hotel will have its own microbrewery from New Belgium Brewing in Fort Collins and a rooftop space called the Woods after the 50 oak barrels stationed there to age its craft beer. Guests of the 100-room hotel will get a brew at check-in. Besides drinking, there will be a cantilevered pool and a barbecue restaurant. Rooms from $250; thesourcehotel.com.\n\nSheldon Chalet, Denali National Park, Alaska\n\nOne might argue that any shelter in the Alaska wilderness is a luxury. But travelers to the Denali region will have a true luxury lodging option when the Sheldon Chalet opens in February. The five-bedroom lodge, 10 miles from Denali in a summit-ringed basin known as the Don Sheldon Amphitheater, promises running water and fine dining along with aurora viewing, skiing and guided glacier trekking. Rooms from $2,300; sheldonchalet.com.\n\nRosewood Miramar Beach Montecito, Montecito, Calif.\n\nLong closed and its future in limbo, the landmark Miramar By the Sea Hotel has been redeveloped and will open in summer as the Rosewood Miramar Beach Montecito in the affluent Montecito enclave near Santa Barbara. The 16-acre property, which its owners say has the only private beach in Southern California, encompasses some 161 rooms (many in cottages and bungalows), two swimming pools, six restaurants and bars, and a spa. (Because of the Jan. 9 mudslide, Highway 101 near the resort is closed. The hotel itself was not in its path and it remains on track to begin operations in the summer.) Rooms from $825; rosewoodhotels.com.\n\nPark MGM and NoMad Las Vegas\n\nIn the first half of 2018 on the Las Vegas Strip, MGM Resorts International aims to replace the mundane Monte Carlo Resort and Casino with two flashier hotels in one tower: the 2,700-room Park MGM with an Eataly food market and the relatively boutique 292-room NoMad Las Vegas from the Sydell Group. With the latter comes a NoMad restaurant from the chef Daniel Humm and the restaurateur Will Guidara. Rates to be determined; parkmgm.com.\n\nVIETNAM\n\nAzerai Can Tho, Can Tho\n\nThe hotelier Adrian Zecha, who created Aman resorts, founded a new hotel group called Azerai that made its debut in Luang Prabang, Laos, in 2017. Its second property, Azerai Can Tho, is slated to open by year- end on the Hau River, a Mekong tributary, in Vietnam\u2019s fourth-largest city. The 60-room resort features a spa, tennis court and two restaurants. Excursions include visits to the city\u2019s famous floating markets, bike trips and sampan boat tours. Rooms from $250; azerai.com.", "title": "New Hotels to Check Out in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Having new antibiotics in development was important, but so were measures to encourage prudent use of existing drugs.\n\nFor example, Dr. Iyer said, Glaxo stopped tying sales agents\u2019 bonuses to the volumes they sold and rewarded them for customer service, technical knowledge and how well they help doctors prescribe judiciously.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJohnson & Johnson was recognized for its \u201cstewardship\u201d of one of its best new antibiotics, bedaquiline. Instead of selling it to any customer for any human or animal use, the company restricted it to treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis, which kills about 250,000 people a year.\n\nCompanies were also rated for clean manufacturing \u2014 particularly whether they discharged antibiotic-laden wastewater into rivers or lakes.\n\nResearch to create the benchmark index was paid for by the British and Dutch governments. The Netherlands-based foundation that issued it is best-known for its biennial Access to Medicines Index, which rates pharmaceutical companies on how they do at making their products available to poor countries.\n\nGlaxo has also topped that index ever since it was first issued in 2008.\n\nDrug companies have 28 new antibiotics in late stages of development, but only nine are markedly different from existing ones, Dr. Iyer said.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a problem,\u201d she said. \u201cWe definitely need to strengthen the pipeline.\u201d", "title": "New Index Rates Drug Companies in Fight Against \u2018Superbugs\u2019", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Yet in the past, politicians have sometimes shied away from carbon pricing for fear that it would raise electricity or gasoline prices for voters who rely heavily on fossil fuels and have few alternatives. When Mr. Christie withdrew New Jersey from R.G.G.I. in 2012, he said the program \u201cdoes nothing more than tax electricity, tax our citizens, tax our businesses, with no discernible or measurable impact upon our environment.\u201d\n\nIn the Northeast, at least, those fears have not been borne out so far. In part because of a glut of cheap natural gas from fracking, as well as the recent boom in wind and solar power, utilities in the R.G.G.I. program have found it relatively easy to retire their dirtiest coal plants and cut pollution at minimal cost. Emissions from electricity in R.G.G.I. states have fallen 40 percent since 2009 \u2014 faster than in the rest of the country \u2014 while electricity prices have declined 3.9 percent. (Regulators recently tightened the program\u2019s cap to aim for an additional 30 percent cut in power-plant emissions by 2030.)\n\nSome policymakers are also seeking to minimize any backlash from carbon pricing by taking the revenue raised and investing it directly into efficiency measures that can lower household electricity bills or fossil-fuel alternatives, like electric vehicles. Jesse Jenkins, an energy researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, notes that these investments may end up having a greater impact than the carbon prices themselves, since \u201creal-world carbon prices routinely fall well below what economists typically have in mind.\u201d\n\nMr. Inslee has opted for that strategy in pushing a carbon tax in Washington after a similar proposal failed at the ballot in 2016. The tax, he said in his State of the State speech, \u201cwill allow us to reinvest in all the things that drive down emissions. We can build more solar panels. We can put more electric cars on the road. We can help more Washingtonians purchase energy-saving insulation for their homes and businesses.\u201d\n\nAs long as interest in carbon pricing remains confined to a handful of Democratic-led states, it will have only a partial effect on overall emissions in the United States. Taken together, the states that either have or are considering carbon pricing accounted for roughly 21 percent of America\u2019s carbon dioxide emissions in 2015.\n\nStill, Robert Stavins, an energy economist at Harvard University, notes that state-level momentum on carbon pricing could send a message that the United States has not abandoned efforts to address global warming, even as the Trump administration disavows the Paris climate agreement.", "title": "New Jersey Embraces an Idea It Once Rejected: Make Utilities Pay to Emit Carbon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. O\u2019Scanlon said that he frequently pumps his own gas, ignoring the Retail Gasoline Dispensing Safety Act of 1949, the statute that first forbade civilians from putting their grubby hands on the nozzle.\n\n\u201cI break the law in New Jersey on a regular basis,\u201d he said. \u201cSomeone can come to my door and cuff me if they want.\u201d\n\nTwo years ago in the Assembly, Mr. O\u2019Scanlon was one of several legislators to sponsor a bill allowing self-service stations. It stalled.\n\nOne prominent opponent of the idea is the president of the State Senate, Stephen M. Sweeney, a Democrat, who remains immovable. In an emailed statement Friday, Mr. Sweeney said that he saw no good reason to change a system that worked.\n\n\u201cWhen we have winters like the one this year, I don\u2019t see many men and women who want to pump their own gas,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s something that makes New Jersey a little more unique and the people of New Jersey like it that way.\u201d\n\nPolling and interviews suggest that the state\u2019s natives agree. The actor Bobby Cannavale, who grew up in the state, said that it never bothers him, though he does forget every time he leaves and comes back, and has to be ushered back into his car by the attendant. He added that he sometimes gets nervous for a split second that he\u2019ll never get his credit card back.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re sitting in your car just handing a guy your credit card,\u201d he said. \u201cHe can hand it to another guy in another car and you\u2019re done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChris Christie proposed self-serve gas during his gubernatorial campaign in 2009, but dropped the proposal because the negative response from the public was so ferocious. At a town hall-style meeting in 2016, he said that it was a gender issue, citing a poll that indicated that 78 percent of women in the state were only too happy to stay in their cars.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAshley Koning, the director of the Eagleton Center for Public Interest Polling at Rutgers University, said in an interview that the idea of pumping one\u2019s own gas had never been broadly favorable in New Jersey.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of one of the third rails of state politics,\u201d she said, noting that women and older people in particular enjoyed the service.\n\nA December 2015 Rutgers-Eagleton poll found that almost three-quarters of the state\u2019s residents preferred to have gas pumped for them, and that 84 percent of women preferred the service.\n\nAnd when she takes off her polling hat, Ms. Koning said, she is one of those women.\n\n\u201cAs a Jersey Girl, I\u2019m definitely not for it,\u201d she said. \u201cJersey is very proud and one of the things it\u2019s proud of is not having to pump its own gas.\u201d\n\nSome pollsters have stopped asking the question altogether. Krista Jenkins, the director of Fairleigh Dickinson University\u2019s polling unit, said that it had not come up since 2012 because \u201cit hasn\u2019t really been that much of a debate.\u201d\n\nIn that year, the university found that 63 percent of voters supported the law and only 23 percent opposed it, with a similarly exaggerated gender gap.\n\nMs. Jenkins grew up in Southern California, and pumped her own gas.\n\n\u201cBut,\u201d she said, \u201cin the dead of winter when you don\u2019t have to get out of your car, it\u2019s a lovely feature of living in the state.\u201d\n\nThe response of some Oregon residents to that state\u2019s loosening of restrictions may not encourage change in Jersey. A widely shared tweet highlighted comments on a local news story from Medford, in Jackson County, Oregon. Among residents\u2019 concerns were \u201csmelling of gas when I get it on my hands or clothes\u201d and the potential health effects of breathing in small amounts over time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew Jersey legislators cited safety concerns when they passed the original law that barred residents from pumping gas almost 70 years ago. But when gas station owners challenged the ban in 1951, the state\u2019s Supreme Court ruled that self-serve was indeed \u201cdangerous in use.\u201d And the ban held up, despite attempts to fight it in the 1980s.\n\nIn the rest of the country, self-service stations became the norm. Safer unleaded gasoline became more common, thanks to federal regulations, as did pumps that accepted credit cards. In most of the United States, that spelled the end of an era when attendants offered to wipe your windshield and check your oil while the tank filled up and you fumbled for a tip.\n\nMr. O\u2019Scanlon is undeterred by the dual weights of history and public opinion. He said that he may bring a new proposal this year, just to keep the conversation alive. He said that economic arguments about jobs and safety are absurd, given that drivers in other states have been pumping their own gas for decades and lived to tell the tale.\n\n\u201cThe only thing you could argue is that New Jerseyans are more flammable than people in the other 49 states,\u201d he said. \u201cBecause we eat so much oily pizza, funnel cake and fries, maybe you could make that argument. Otherwise, it\u2019s simply ridiculous.\u201d", "title": "New Jersey Is Last State to Insist at Gas Stations: Don\u2019t Touch That Pump", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA teenager in New Jersey was taken into police custody after his parents, sister and a family acquaintance were found dead inside the family\u2019s home late on Sunday, the Monmouth County prosecutor said in a statement on Monday.\n\nThe statement said that it \u201cappears\u201d that the teenager, 16, had used a semiautomatic rifle to kill his father, Steven Kologi, 44; mother, Linda Kologi, 42; sister, Brittany Kologi, 18; and an acquaintance, Mary Schultz, 70, at 11:43 p.m., the prosecutor, Christopher J. Gramiccioni, said.\n\nThe police went to the home in Long Branch, a seaside New Jersey town of about 30,000 people, after a 911 call reporting a shooting. The Associated Press quoted Mr. Gramiccioni as saying that the teenager was expected to face four counts of murder and other charges.\n\nThere was no immediate information about a motive, but the statement described the shooting as an isolated domestic incident. Calls and emails to the prosecutor\u2019s office early on Monday were not immediately returned, and the teenager was not named.\n\nThe prosecutor said the teenager\u2019s grandfather and brother were not targeted and left the home unharmed, according to The A.P.", "title": "New Jersey Teenager in Custody After 4 Are Found Shot to Death in Home", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "For weeks, the police here have coordinated with officials at Waze, Google Maps and Apple Maps so that the apps no longer include the 60 affected streets when directing motorists around traffic tie-ups. In his office at police headquarters, Chief Rowe proudly displayed a screen shot on his phone from 9 a.m. It showed a field of red dots on Apple Maps, indicating closed streets across the borough.\n\nPhoto\n\nAcross the United States, navigation apps have diverted traffic from congested highways onto quiet residential streets, creating headaches for small towns. But Leonia, a 1.5-square-mile borough near the George Washington Bridge, may be ground zero for the phenomenon.\n\nWith three exits from the New Jersey Turnpike, Leonia offers tantalizing shortcuts through the community, whose suburban streets of Tudors and split-level homes make the borough feel a world away from one of the busiest bridges in the country and one of the biggest cities in the world.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re in a very unique situation,\u201d Chief Rowe said. \u201cIt\u2019s the perfect storm of traffic.\u201d\n\nResidents have complained that they sometimes cannot pull out of their driveways because their road has bumper-to-bumper traffic. The new ban on nonresident cars applies to 60 streets in the borough and runs from 6 a.m. to 10 a.m., and 4 p.m. to 9 p.m., seven days a week. But those employed in the borough can also apply for the yellow vehicle tags.\n\nOn Monday, some residents here expressed relief that local officials had moved to reclaim the borough\u2019s bygone suburban serenity. \u201cIt\u2019s going to be good for Leonia,\u201d said Kathy Bianchi, a retiree who lives on Glenwood Avenue, which sees traffic both from a local school and overflow traffic from nearby highways.\n\nBut Mrs. Bianchi said she had received pushback from people in neighboring towns. \u201cOne of my spin partners said, \u2018Well, if you\u2019re not going to let me come through Leonia, I won\u2019t let you come through my town,\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201cHe wasn\u2019t kidding.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndeed, when Leonia\u2019s council voted in favor of the ordinance last month, some commuters from outside the area lashed out at the borough, while others questioned the measure\u2019s legality. (Borough officials say the ordinance should pass legal muster, pointing to former court cases that upheld similar restrictions around the country.)\n\nPhoto\n\nEven some Leonia residents questioned the legal footing of the ban, however. Scott Greenberg, a video editor who commutes to and from his job in Stamford, Conn., said he would resent being told to keep out of other towns. \u201cI\u2019m not sure it\u2019s constitutionally viable,\u201d he said. \u201cI think we are using the guise of safety and getting ambulances through the town to justify the ban.\u201d\n\nBut Chief Rowe said that safety was a main impetus for the new ordinance, pointing to the death in 2014 of a 60-year-old woman who was hit by a school bus. Although the accident was not directly related to traffic congestion, Mr. Rowe believed it was a factor.\n\n\u201cWe had 90-minute delays on the George Washington Bridge that day,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen people are stuck in traffic for a long period, their nerves become frayed and their attention span is altered.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChief Rowe said that the police department would soon decide when to begin enforcing the ban. The first Monday of February, the 5th, was a likely date for officers to begin handing out summonses that carry a $200 fine. But he wanted to give as many people as possible, especially commuters from nearby towns, the opportunity to get into a new routine.\n\n\u201cFor some people, that\u2019s the way they have traveled for many years \u2014 it\u2019s muscle memory,\u201d he acknowledged. \u201cWe will do everything to keep it fair. This is not a revenue-raising scheme by any means. If we feel that the education phase needs to be extended, up to a month, we will certainly do that.\u201d\n\nThe focus of the education campaign was near the train station, where vehicles are no longer allowed to make a right turn from Fort Lee Road onto Station Parkway. Instead, they must drive another block to Grand Avenue, one of three county or state roads in Leonia that will remain open to all cars at all times.\n\nChief Rowe said that most of the drivers who ignored the sign and made the turn seemed genuinely unaware of the change. \u201cNone of my officers reported any negative encounters,\u201d he said. \u201cNo one was rude. And obviously the people we saw who were residents gave us the thumbs up.\u201d", "title": "New Jersey Town Aims to Keep App-Guided Outsiders Off Its Streets", "authors": ["Lisa W. Foderaro"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "NEWARK \u2014 The boardroom at the headquarters of New Jersey Transit here does not often fill with spontaneous applause. But it did on Monday morning \u2014 not for an action the agency\u2019s board took, but for one it put off.\n\nAfter the board took the unusual step of rescheduling its monthly meeting for Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday, a state and federal holiday, a crowd of Hoboken residents showed up to protest. The residents wanted to stop New Jersey Transit from helping a privately owned ferry company turn a site on the Hoboken waterfront into a maintenance facility for its fleet.\n\nHoboken officials had started moving toward seizing the property with plans for transforming it into a public park. To preserve it for industrial use, the ferry company, New York Waterway, asked New Jersey Transit to buy the site and lease it back to the company.\n\nOver the objections of Hoboken\u2019s new mayor, Ravinder S. Bhalla, and his predecessor, Dawn Zimmer, the agency\u2019s board had been scheduled to vote on the purchase last Wednesday. But the meeting was postponed because the board did not have a quorum of four members. The board then rescheduled the meeting for Monday, even though state and federal government agencies were closed.", "title": "New Jersey Transit Delays Vote on Contested Site on Hoboken Waterfront", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe longer I went without a \u2018BM,\u2019 the longer I could hold onto my Sick Girl identity, and the more of a quest I could generate for you,\u201d Brandeis writes in a passage addressed to her mother. \u201cYou seemed a little lost without the constant demands of my illness. \u2026 I started to spritz Love\u2019s Baby Soft every time I pooped to mask the smell.\u201d\n\nWhen Brandeis finally \u201ctraded in the \u2018sick girl\u2019 mantle,\u201d her sister Elizabeth picks up right where she leaves off and begins projectile vomiting at the dinner table \u201clike something from \u2018The Exorcist.\u2019\u201d Elizabeth eventually lands in a hospital with a feeding tube up her nose, but a mere eating disorder is too prosaic for Arlene, who accuses the doctors of trying to kill her daughter. Years later, Arlene files a lawsuit against the doctors, but Elizabeth, summoned home from college for testimony, is still too loyal to her mother to tell the truth and admit she was making herself throw up.\n\n\u201cShe doesn\u2019t want anything to disrupt her own story line,\u201d Brandeis writes of Arlene, \u201cthe story of herself as the heroic crusader, the warrior martyr of a mother who stood up to the big bad medical establishment and saved her blameless girls.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the course of 16 years, Brandeis writes, the family entertained explanations for Arlene\u2019s delusions that ranged from borderline personality disorder to schizophrenia to mismanaged diabetes to a brain lesion. During much of that time, Arlene was working on a documentary film about her medical journey, one for which she routinely sought out her daughters\u2019 help and participation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe film was clearly a vanity project, though Brandeis is careful to give it its due. As such, she incorporates transcripts and scene descriptions into her book, even giving it the same title her mother was using for the film. Borrowing the title works as a homage; not to mention that \u201cThe Art of Misdiagnosis\u201d is a terrific title. But the shifts between first-person narration, film transcripts and letters addressed to her mother cause the book to buckle somewhat under the weight of its own confusions. Brandeis may have finally disrupted her mother\u2019s story line, but that\u2019s a separate matter from finding her own.\n\nIf the death at the center of Brandeis\u2019s memoir stirred up more emotional detritus than she could possibly sort through in one book, Thomas Mira y Lopez may have faced the opposite problem. Framed around his father\u2019s death following a massive seizure in 2006, THE BOOK OF RESTING PLACES: A Personal History of Where We Lay the Dead (Counterpoint, $26) is both a grief memoir and a travelogue through the afterlife \u2014 at least as it\u2019s experienced by those left behind. In a series of 10 linked essays, Mira y Lopez treks across various landscapes \u2014 some real, some psychological \u2014 with an eye toward discovering what connects particular places to particular rituals or relics surrounding the dead.\n\nAt a construction site that once was Tucson\u2019s National Cemetery, the author observes, astutely, that a cemetery serves a \u201ccivic function\u201d but is more than just functional, in that \u201cit disposes of the dead, yet also provides them a home. It\u2019s built of the dead, but also for the living.\u201d In Rome, where he was studying at the time his father had the seizure, Mira y Lopez visits the Catacombs of Priscilla and wonders why he does not immediately return home. \u201cThe tour guides told us about the walls,\u201d he writes, \u201cthe soft volcanic tufa the Romans initially believed bees nested within. \u2026 I thought of the rehab ahead, of how my father\u2019s body and mind would be permanently changed.\u201d Later in the book, another kind of death comes in the form of a friend, or at least a friendly acquaintance, whom the author must distance himself from when he discovers the man to be a raging bigot.\n\nMira y Lopez, who holds an M.F.A. in creative nonfiction from the University of Arizona, is a gifted writer. His ear for language and his ability to take ownership of ideas by finding the poetry in them rather than falling into didacticism \u2014 \u201cA ghost is a manifestation of guilt,\u201d he writes, \u201ca forgiveness demanded, a memory contested\u201d \u2014 is the kind of thing that cannot be taught. Nonetheless, \u201cThe Book of Resting Places\u201d feels a lot like an M.F.A. thesis project stretched too thin in order to become a book. His father\u2019s death having amounted to a rather narrow premise, there is a sense here of the author combing through every experience he\u2019s had in recent years in search of thematically relevant material.\n\nNot that the impulse to look outward rather than inward isn\u2019t laudable. It\u2019s refreshing to encounter a young writer who\u2019s chosen to do some fieldwork rather than indulging a deep dive into his own limited personal history. But Mira y Lopez has the kind of talent that can be as much a burden as a blessing. Though it will probably be embraced by graduate school creative writing types, many of whom struggle daily with imposing deep meaning on what is exasperatingly mundane, \u201cThe Book of Resting Places\u201d occupies that awkward literary sphere of books that seem on the surface to be more interesting than they actually are.\n\nI actually sort of mean that as a compliment. Sure, Mira y Lopez relies too much on rigged-up profundities and allusions to Greek myth, but the dirty secret of completing a book is sometimes you have to shift your goal from writing a masterpiece to merely pulling things off. To that end, I have to begrudgingly hand it to the poet Beth Ann Fennelly, whose book of micro-memoirs is nothing if not a lesson in sticking to your aesthetic guns. HEATING & COOLING: 52 Micro-Memoirs (Norton, $22.95) contains essays that are sometimes as short as 10 words \u2014 \u201cSwapped the rosary on my bedpost for Mardi Gras beads\u201d (that\u2019s the whole thing) \u2014 but add up to a surprisingly maximalist portrait of a life.\n\nFennelly writes about the tedium of conversations on airplanes, the unshakeability of a Catholic upbringing, the fact that she has an enormous bladder and can go for hours without urinating. In the title essay, Fennelly calls an air-conditioning repairman and, told that her ceiling must come down, wrestles with the \u201cnumerous subjects of which I\u2019m ignorant.\u201d It\u2019s meant to be a reckoning with her perception of herself as a feminist but, as she does again and again in this tiny book, she\u2019s really just owning up to the fruitlessness of trying to find meaning in every moment. And if the book feels familiar in places (\u201cMommy Wants a Glass of Chardonnay\u201d is both a title and trope here), it\u2019s also a testament to the power of not unpacking at all but instead living out of a very small suitcase.", "title": "New Memoirs Try to Get the Balance Right", "authors": ["Meghan Daum"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDetermined to avoid a repeat of the envelope snafu that resulted in a stunning Oscar best picture mix-up last year, new rules have been adopted by PwC, the accounting firm that tabulates votes for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.\n\nThe changes, which were first reported Monday by The Associated Press and have been confirmed by the academy and PwC, include having presenters ensure before going onstage that they have the correct envelope in hand; this will be confirmed beforehand by stage managers, too.\n\nLast year, one of the two PwC representatives attending the Oscars mistakenly handed Warren Beatty, who was presenting the best picture award with Faye Dunaway, the backup envelope for best actress, which had moments earlier gone to Emma Stone for \u201cLa La Land.\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Beatty opened the envelope onstage, he hesitated, and Ms. Dunaway, thinking he was monkeying around, ended up reading out \u201cLa La Land.\u201d In fact, \u201cMoonlight\u201d had won, but long moments passed before the bewildering mistake, and the correct winner, were revealed.\n\nLast year\u2019s PwC accountants, Brian Cullinan and Martha Ruiz, have been replaced by Rick Rosas, a longtime PwC accountant who handled the Oscars envelopes for 14 years, and his colleague Kimberly Bourdon. (Both Mr. Cullinan and Ms Ruiz still work at PwC.) A third PwC accountant, who also will have memorized the winners\u2019 list, will sit in the control room with the producers of the show. All three accountants will also attend rehearsals, and practice what to do if there\u2019s another mistake.\n\nPerhaps the most drastic change of all: the PwC accountants won\u2019t be allowed to use their cellphones or be on social media during the ceremony. Last year, just before handing Mr. Beatty the wrong envelope, Mr. Cullinan tweeted out a photo of a jubilant Ms. Stone.\n\nOscar nominations will be announced Tuesday; the ceremony will be held March 4.", "title": "New Oscar Rules Aim to Avoid Another Envelope Mix-up", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "She and Senator Patrick J. It was impossible to look away.\n\nWhich was the point.\n\nThe brief disruption to Seton Hall\u2019s pregame preparation was a form of old-school gamesmanship with a new-school twist. \u201cTheir players were looking up at the video board, and we thought, \u2018Wow this is making a little bit of difference,\u2019\u201d said Mike Greengarten, Rutgers\u2019s assistant director of marketing, who played a role in having the video shown. \u201c\u2018It\u2019s getting in their head a little bit.\u2019\u201d", "title": "New Pregame Trickery: Distract the Visiting Team With Bad YouTube Videos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe politics gets in the way of that sometimes,\u201d he said.\n\nEric F. That ban limits most forms of immigration from some of the same countries, but it does not apply to refugees, who have been dealt with separately.\n\nPresident Trump set a ceiling of 45,000 refugee admissions for the fiscal year, compared with the 85,000 set by President Barack Obama the year before amid an unabated refugee crisis worldwide, including civil war in Syria and conflict in other countries. Last year, hundreds of thousands of Muslims fled Myanmar to Bangladesh, where they are parked in camps.\n\nThe government is on pace to let in much fewer than 45,000 refugees. About 6,000 have been admitted since the fiscal year began on Oct. 1, and only 791 were Muslims, according to the International Rescue Committee. In the previous fiscal year, 14,496 Muslims were admitted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Muslims are not the only ones affected by the slowdown. And some refugees who were admitted in previous years have been unable to reunite with family members still stuck in refugee camps abroad.\n\nThe number of admissions could rise now that the government has reopened the door for people from the 11 countries, although officials noted that 45,000 refugees was a ceiling, not a target, and that there would be a \u201clag time\u201d as agencies put the new security measures in place.\n\nOfficials said the new measures would involve more \u201cin-depth\u201d interviews and \u201cdeep-dive\u201d background checks, but they declined to be more specific. \u201cWe won\u2019t give our playbook to our enemies,\u201d one administration official said on a conference call with reporters.\n\nWith existing security checks, it can take two years for a refugee to be approved for admission to the United States. The vetting includes several interviews of family members, often together and apart; background checks; fingerprinting; and iris scans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics of the administration\u2019s new rules noted that no refugees have carried out a terrorist attack on American soil.\n\n\u201cBy instituting a risk-based analysis to determine refugee admissions, the administration is essentially implementing a Muslim refugee ban without saying it, despite the number of security screenings already in place,\u201d said Kevin Appleby, senior director for international migration policy at the Center for Migration Studies.\n\nBut Ira Mehlman, the media director for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a group that favors restricting immigration, said the administration was right to scrutinize refugees more closely.\n\n\u201cThe obligation of the government is to ensure that people let in have been thoroughly vetted,\u201d he said, adding that most people are not endangered by waiting longer for processing.\n\n\u201cGiven that these countries have little infrastructure and accurate record-keeping, the vetting process is going to be somewhat more difficult.\u201d", "title": "New Scrutiny Coming for Refugees From 11 \u201cHigh-Risk\u201d Nations", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018You do it too, writer, do not be shy.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cAfterglow (a dog memoir)\u201d (Grove Press, 2017, Page 191), by Eileen Myles, the author of 20 books of poetry and prose.\n\nCertain writers make you want to write. Something about the motion of their sentences lures your mind so close to theirs that, without even trying, in the absolutely normal course of reading, you absorb some of their creative energy. It\u2019s the literary equivalent of an estuary: A river flows into an ocean, and the ocean flows right back into the river, and the mixing of salt water and fresh water creates a magic zone of abundant life where young fish gather and hover and feast and grow.\n\nEileen Myles is an estuary of a writer. The voice on the page is so fluid and expressive and unembarrassed that it makes you want to join it. Myles\u2019s sentences tilt and wobble like a living mind: \u201cYet this inbetweenness, this aloneness, hear it now, is holy.\u201d The energy breathes from writer to reader and back again. To read this prose is practically to write your own first draft.\n\nThis impulse is made explicit near the end of Myles\u2019s new book, in a footnote: \u201cYou do it too, writer, do not be shy.\u201d Myles encourages the reader, as casually as you might urge a small child to try to skip a rock, to write a book like this one: a memoir of a dearly departed dog. As if shyness is the only thing that might stand in the way of someone writing a book.", "title": "New Sentences: From Eileen Myles\u2019s \u2018Afterglow\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u2018Mum says fifty-six bad words on the phone to Jamaica.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From the poem \u201ckid,\u201d by Yrsa Daley-Ward, as it appears in the collection \u201cBone\u201d (Penguin Books, 2017, Page 119). Daley-Ward, who is also an actor, was born in England to a Jamaican mother and Nigerian father.\n\nSome of the earliest known human writing was, basically, counting. On clay tablets, with little styluses, ancient Sumerian merchants tallied lists of goods: barley, cattle, wheat, wine. Imagine the power of it. One minute you\u2019re living in a world of uncontainable profusion. Men and beasts jostle in the dirty markets; ships bob and crash at the dock; the storehouses overflow with infinities of goods. All around that swarms a further scampering abundance \u2014 kids, cats, rats, ants, the drops of water that make up the river, the atoms that make up the drops.\n\nThe next minute you\u2019re holding that profusion in your hand, as solidly as you would hold a rock or an apple: an inventory of the world. The abundance has been brought under control. That reduction is profound. Meditation often involves the simple counting of breaths.\n\nIn Yrsa Daley-Ward\u2019s poem \u201ckid,\u201d the speaker is living in domestic chaos. Everyone seems to be angry. Her brother is in the hospital, and no one will tell her why or for how long.\n\nAnd so she counts. She counts the number of times the pastor refers to hell in his sermon, the white socks and black shoes in church, how many months her brother has been away, the number of roses on the wallpaper of her new room. She counts the number of times she can fit the word \u201clonely\u201d onto a single sheet of A4 paper. She counts the number of times her mother swears on a phone call to Jamaica. Her mother doesn\u2019t appreciate this (\u201cShe is not impressed when you tell her so\u201d), but that doesn\u2019t matter. The counting itself is the point. And the power of the counting belongs to the child. It allows her to reduce the chaos, label it and hold it in her mind.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Bone,\u2019 by Yrsa Daley-Ward", "authors": ["Sam Anderson", "New Sentences"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018At Christmas and on my birthday I was given handsome presents as if they were punishments.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cThe Juniper Tree\u201d (NYRB Classics, 2018, Page 10), by Barbara Comyns. \u201cThe Juniper Tree\u201d was the English writer\u2019s ninth book, originally published in 1985 by Methuen.\n\nSometimes a sentence has such a powerful structure it can become a kind of parlor game. This one rolls along happily for 15 words, parceling out a perfectly logical string of information \u2014 Christmas, birthday, presents \u2014 until suddenly that very last word snaps like the end of a whip, reversing the meaning of everything. Presents become punishments. Celebrations become rebukes. Holidays become theaters of quiet savagery.\n\nAfter I read this sentence many times in a row, smiling every time, eventually its structure detached from its words: \u201cAt X and on Y, I Z as if not-Z.\u201d That formula got stuck in my head like a little musical phrase. I started to fill it in with other words.\n\nAt lunch and at dinner I ate fresh fruits as if they were vegetables.\n\nOn the beach and by the pool I wore my Speedo as if it were a tuxedo.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018The Juniper Tree,\u2019 by Barbara Comyns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018I hope you will understand that back there we were talking about the drama of good and evil, and about how, sad to say, there was no communication between the two, and how a single decisive detail in the world is, sad to say, enough to make the whole world intolerable.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cUniversal Theseus,\u201d a story in the new collection \u201cThe World Goes On\u201d (New Directions, 2017), by the Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai. The collection was translated by George Szirtes, Ottilie Mulzet and John Batki.\n\nThe Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai does many fascinating things with his prose, and one of the most striking is the thing you see above: Starting a sentence hopefully, trying to say this or that, and then traveling inexorably, one clause after another, to the bleak and totalizing conclusion that all is lost, nothing is real, the world is intolerable.\n\nLike Beckett, it\u2019s much funnier than you\u2019d think. It\u2019s as though there\u2019s a black hole hiding behind the pages: No matter how innocently a sentence begins, no matter how elliptical its orbit, the laws of gravity will inevitably pull it back into the void. It will end where it was always fated to end, where everything is fated to end, in a pointless vacuum.\n\nThe speaker of the sentence here is being forced to give a series of lectures to a mysterious audience. In one he describes self-pity: \u201cNo one is harming you, you are fine, you sit in silence, alone in a desolate park after the rain, or in a cozy room abroad, before dawn or as darkness falls, and this self-pity ambushes and takes you by the rudest surprise, devouring and inevitable, because this is when you realize, without understanding it, that nothing exists.\u201d", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018The World Goes On,\u2019 by Laszlo Krasznahorkai", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe new shingles vaccine is expensive, but worth it, according to a new analysis in JAMA Internal Medicine.\n\nShingles is a painful and sometimes debilitating nerve inflammation and blistering skin rash caused by the same virus that causes chickenpox. Anyone who has had chickenpox is susceptible to it many years later.\n\nThe old vaccine, Zostavax, is about 50 percent effective. The new one, Shingrix, provides 90 percent protection. It is given in two shots at $140 each, and it is recommended for people 50 and older. It will probably soon be covered by Medicare Part D and other insurers.\n\nUsing data from randomized trials, researchers calculated that using the new vaccine would save money over the long term, based on statistical measures that quantify the cost effectiveness of health care measures.\n\n\u201cOur findings are subject to the proposed price \u2014 $280,\u201d said the lead author, Phuc Le, an assistant professor at the Cleveland Clinic. \u201cAny price change in the future may change the calculation.\u201d\n\nThe age of the recipient and failure to get the second shot could change the cost effectiveness. But even allowing for such variables, if the new vaccine cost $350 for two doses, it would still be more cost effective than the old one.", "title": "New Shingles Vaccine Is Cost Effective", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ahead of the soccer game, there was another small sign of change: the country\u2019s first car showroom dedicated to female customers was opened.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut for the soccer game, a former Saudi sports journalist shared a photo of female ushers preparing to greet the female fans and their families.\n\nWomen cheered as an announcer read the names of the players, and as the teams faced off.\n\nSoccer is very popular in Saudi Arabia, with many fans of international and local leagues, but female enthusiasts long had to content themselves with watching their favorite teams on television.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany women excited about the new ability to watch live games \u2014 as well as men opposed to this \u2014 took to social media on Friday, writing under the Arabic hash tags #FamiliesEnteringStadiums and #ThePeopleWelcomeWomenEnteringStadiums.\n\n\u201cThis is more than women\u2019s rights,\u201d Fatimah S. Baeshen, a spokeswoman for the Saudi Embassy in Washington, said in a Twitter post, adding, \u201cI\u2019m rooting for the ladies.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI do not see that letting women enter stadiums is wrong or forbidden,\u201d Manayer al-Qahtani also wrote on Twitter. \u201cTo the contrary, it does not go against religion nor against the customs and traditions. Many girls follow soccer and we gather at game time. It is a legal right for us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut some people used the hash tag to criticize the event, writing that the place of women is in their homes, focusing on their children and preserving their faith, and not at a stadium where male crowds may curse and get rowdy.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe kingdom\u2019s stadium had not been built with women in mind, so modifications were made so that they could attend matches. The government\u2019s General Sports Authority said this week that three stadiums had so far been modified to accommodate women through the addition of private sections for women and their male relatives, female bathrooms and even prayer areas.\n\nAlthough tickets were only 20 riyals ($5.33), the family section for Friday\u2019s match was less than half full. But anticipation for the game was high on social media. People shared photos of female fans preparing to enter the stadium.\n\nIt was a far cry from 2015, when a Saudi woman who tried to attend a soccer game in Jidda was arrested after she was spotted by security officers wearing pants, a long-sleeve top, a hat and sunglasses to avoid detection, local news outlets reported.\n\nWomen will also attend a game on Saturday in the national stadium in the capital, Riyadh, as well as a game on Thursday in the city of Dammam.\n\nOn Friday, Al-Ahli trounced Al-Batin 5-0 in the Premier League match, according to the Saudi Gazette.\n\nReema bint Bandar Al Saud, a member of the royal family, attended the match and said on Twitter:\n\n\u201cToday, you brought happiness to every Saudi family and woman who attended the first game. This is a historic moment for the Kingdom.\u201d", "title": "New Sound at Saudi Soccer Game: Women Cheering From the Stands", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Named after Charles Dana Gibson, the magazine\u2019s former editor, and Henry Luce, its former publisher, the bar pays tribute to the glory days of the famed photojournalistic periodical, in a space where Norman Rockwell and editors once lounged. While the bar does a commendable job of evoking the past, it feels more like an after-work or pre-dinner spot, rather than somewhere one would seek out.\n\nTHE PLACE\n\nThe bar is on a dingy stretch of West 31st Street, lined with hole-in-the-wall shops selling discount jewelry, body oils and janky phone accessories. Inside, a marble bar fronts a dimly lit lounge that suggests a midcentury gentlemen\u2019s club, replete with blue banquettes, brass picture lights and wood paneling. Still, the illusion seems somewhat incomplete at times. \u201cWith such rich history, you want them to commit more to that in the design,\u201d said one patron, pointing to an empty wall. \u201cYou want them to make that history feel more tangible.\u201d", "title": "New Speakeasy Memorializes an Old-School Journalist Haunt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re telling me that the king of a third world country runs around in a bulletproof catsuit?\u201d a C.I.A. agent (played by Martin Freeman) asks a black-market gun runner (Andy Serkis) in a TV spot for Marvel\u2019s \u201cBlack Panther\u201d that was broadcast during the college football national championship on Monday night. Then hunch over your keyboard for 12 hours a day. When you notice your back hurts, sink deeper into your office chair and accept your early-onset arthritis. This is your life now.\n\nNew Year\u2019s Resolution: Make healthy dinners with nary a carbohydrate in sight!\n\nNew Year\u2019s Reality: Spend two hours poring over old Mark Bittman easy weeknight recipes.
