Schneiderman, on Saturday opened an investigation into a company that sold millions of fake followers on social media platforms, some of them copying real users\u2019 personal information.\n\nThe company, Devumi, and its sale of automated followers to a swath of celebrities, sports stars, journalists and politicians, was detailed in a New York Times article published earlier on Saturday. While based in Florida, Devumi claims on its website to be based in New York City.\n\nAt least 55,000 of its \u201cbot\u201d accounts used names, pictures, hometowns and other details taken from people on Twitter. The real users hailed from every U.S. state, including New York, and dozens of countries, a Times analysis found.\n\n\u201cImpersonation and deception are illegal under New York law,\u201d Mr. Schneiderman wrote on Twitter. \u201cWe\u2019re opening an investigation into Devumi and its apparent sale of bots using stolen identities.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe investigation is the latest in a series of federal and state inquiries into the commercial and political abuse of fake accounts on social media. Tens of millions of fake accounts have been deployed to defraud businesses, influence political debates online and attract customers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSocial media companies, including Twitter and Facebook, have drawn intense scrutiny for not taking greater steps to weed them out. Many of the accounts identified by The Times appear to violate Twitter\u2019s own policies, but remained active on the social media platform for years, each retweeting and promoting Devumi customers.", "title": "New York Attorney General to Investigate Firm That Sells Fake Followers", "authors": ["Nicholas Confessore"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "In announcing both suits, Mr. de Blasio and his staff likened the efforts to litigation targeting tobacco companies, and suggested that the goals were similar: compensation for city spending to address problems caused by the company\u2019s products, and a change in future corporate behavior.\n\nThe city\u2019s top lawyer, Zachary W. Carter, acknowledged that the city would look to take legal action in cases \u201cwhen the target is an industry that\u2019s causing harm.\u201d But he rejected the notion that the two suits represented any new initiative in city government. \u201cThat really is a coincidence of timing,\u201d he said.\n\nIndeed, in 2000, under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city sued gun manufacturers and distributors, claiming they failed to properly monitor sales to keep guns out of the hands of criminals. The lawsuit was eventually dismissed.\n\nMayor Michael R. Bloomberg had more luck with a 2006 lawsuit that focused on dealerships in the South that had sold guns used in New York City crimes. Most of the dealers settled.\n\nNew York is far from the first to take drug companies to court over the opioid crisis. Chicago did so in 2014 and its case is continuing; city lawyers there have received 10 million pages of documents and conducted hundreds of interviews, according to a spokesman for the Chicago law department, Bill McCaffery.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the years since, many municipalities have joined a growing legal movement among local leaders seeking to halt the cycle in which opioid analgesics \u2014 legal prescriptions \u2014 lead to dependence and death, either from the drugs themselves or after users begin to use illegal opiates such as heroin. Philadelphia and Delaware each filed lawsuits in recent days. A lawsuit filed by Oklahoma is expected to go to trial later this year.\n\nIn New York State, more than a dozen counties filed suit last year, represented by the law firm Simmons Hanly Conroy that is based in Alton, Ill. The firm, which is representing localities in about 200 cases around the country, is representing New York City in its suit.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a new case getting filed every day,\u201d Paul J. Hanly Jr., who leads the law firm\u2019s New York office, said of the national trend. \u201cWe could be in a situation a year from now when there are a thousand or two thousand cases.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs opioids and heroin have claimed an increasing number of lives, New York City has been slow to respond to the crisis. Last year Mr. de Blasio announced a plan to reduce opioid deaths through a combination of outreach, treatment and law enforcement.\n\nThough the final tally of overdose deaths from 2017 was not yet available, Mr. de Blasio said that more people died last year in New York City from a drug overdose, most involving an opioid, than the combined deaths from car accidents and homicides.\n\nThe lawsuit, filed Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, alleges that the opioid crisis was caused by the deceptive marketing of drugmakers, and by distributors bringing large amounts of prescription painkillers into the New York market. All of this has caused the city to spend millions of dollars on substance abuse treatment programs, hospital services, emergency medical services and law enforcement.\n\nThe manufacturers named in the lawsuit include Purdue Pharma, Teva, Cephalon, Johnson & Johnson, Janssen, Endo, Allergan, Watson and various subsidiaries. The distributors include McKesson, Cardinal Health and AmerisourceBergen.\n\n\u201cWe maintain that the allegations made in these lawsuits against our company are baseless and unsubstantiated,\u201d a spokeswoman for Janssen Pharmaceuticals, Sarah Freeman, said in a statement. \u201cOur actions in the marketing and promotion of our opioid pain medicines were appropriate and responsible.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for Purdue Pharma, John Puskar, said the company was \u201cdeeply troubled by the prescription and illicit opioid abuse crisis, and are dedicated to being part of the solution,\u201d and added that it \u201cvigorously\u201d denied the city\u2019s allegations.", "title": "New York City Sues Drug Companies Over Opioid Crisis", "authors": ["J. David Goodman", "William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAnother Day of Reckoning for Big Oil\u201d (editorial, Jan. 16):\n\nIf there\u2019s one thing the petroleum industry understands, it\u2019s money. Both lawsuits and the global divestment movement can hit Big Oil where it hurts most.\n\nI applaud New York City\u2019s lawsuit seeking damages for the cost of efforts to address climate change and its decision to divest city pension funds. The petroleum industry\u2019s decades-long campaign of cover-ups and disinformation is public knowledge. Like Big Tobacco, it will have to pay for the harm done and the long-deferred social and environmental costs of production and use of its product.\n\nI hope New York\u2019s effort succeeds where others failed. I hope it starts an avalanche of similar efforts. The dying coal industry should take note, because it is also part of the problem.\n\nDollars can\u2019t fix everything. But dollars can compensate some losses and propel us toward a green-energy economy, a healthy environment and a sustainable future.", "title": "Opinion | New York City\u2019s Attack on Fossil Fuel Companies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The city\u2019s numbers are in stark contrast to a nationwide increase in traffic deaths, many of which were the result of factors such as drivers texting, according to data compiled by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.\n\nBut while New York\u2019s streets have become less deadly for pedestrians, they still remain perilous for others. In 2017, 23 bicyclists, 33 motorcyclists and 57 people in vehicles who were involved in collisions were killed, all slightly above the tallies in 2016. City officials said the small numbers make drawing conclusions about the reason for the increase a challenge, though they stressed that it further illustrates the need for continued work on making streets safer.\n\nOfficials noted that although the number of cyclists in the city has doubled since 2006, the number of deaths has remained relatively static, at between 12 and 24 per year, according to a study released last summer by several city agencies.\n\nEric McClure, the executive director of StreetsPAC, a political action organization, said more improvements, like lanes that separate bikers from drivers, may be needed to help prevent deaths. \u201cIf you\u2019re going to continue to encourage people to bike, then the infrastructure needs to be there to accommodate them,\u201d he said.\n\nThe progress also played out somewhat unevenly across the city: Queens, long a hot spot of dangerous thoroughfares threading through residential neighborhoods, had the fewest number of traffic fatalities it has ever recorded \u2014 59. But in Brooklyn, the number was up: there were 57 traffic fatalities in 2017, compared with 51, its record low, the year before.", "title": "New York City\u2019s Pedestrian Deaths Hit Lowest Level Since 1910", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "At his trial, prosecutors suggested that Detective Desormeau had decided that making lots of arrests was the route to glory in the New York Police Department, which was why he decided to falsify evidence.\n\nHe and his partner, who was also on trial, \u201cwere only interested in advancing their careers by getting high arrest statistics and getting promoted,\u201d an assistant district attorney, Yvonne Francis, told the jury at the trial\u2019s outset last week.\n\nDetective Desormeau and his partner, Detective Sasha Neve, still face charges related to false statements in Manhattan in a separate case, in which prosecutors have accused them of lying about the circumstances of a gun arrest, also from 2014.\n\nDetective Desormeau offered little visible reaction to his verdict, other than lowering his head. Detective Neve, who was tried alongside him, was found guilty of official misconduct, a lesser charge. But the judge overseeing the case, Michael B. Aloise of State Supreme Court, immediately struck down her conviction, saying there was insufficient evidence. Detective Neve grew tearful with relief.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs both detectives left the courtroom, other officers from their old unit, the Queens gang squad, patted their backs in support. The officers have packed the tiny courtroom over the last week; one officer was overheard describing the case as a \u201cwitch hunt.\u201d\n\nThat was a theme that Detective Desormeau\u2019s lawyer, John Arlia, tried to develop on Tuesday during closing statements. \u201cWe can\u2019t have people being indicted for perjury for just a little white lie,\u201d Mr. Arlia said. At another point, he claimed that the district attorney\u2019s position was so exacting that \u201ceverybody is going to be here for perjury if that\u2019s the case.\u201d\n\nProsecutors described the two detectives as having little compunction about covering up an illegal search with a false cover story so that a case would not be thrown out in court for constitutional violations. This type of perjury \u2014 in which officers embellish or invent allegations of suspicious behavior to justify illegal searches, often of black men \u2014 has long plagued the criminal justice system, though it is rarely exposed and, even in those instances, rarely punished.\n\nThe fact that two detectives were charged with falsifying the circumstances of not just one but two arrests they made as partners is extremely unusual. And it raises the question about how often plainclothes officers and detectives, who conduct a disproportionate number of street stops and vehicle searches, offer false narratives about arrests.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the trial in the Queens case offered little exploration of the larger question. Instead the testimony remained focused only on what happened inside a small Caribbean restaurant called Yogi\u2019s, and on what might have happened on the street out front.\n\nYogi\u2019s is where the man whose rights were violated when he was accused of dealing drugs has spent much of his time in recent years, playing pool on the single coin-operated pool table in the center of the restaurant.\n\nThe man, Roosevelt McCoy, 48, was not a sympathetic character: He has spent much of his life in prison for crimes that include killing two men. The jury watched Mr. McCoy shoot a couple of games of pool that were captured on the restaurant\u2019s security camera. His last game ended abruptly with a few balls still on the table, when the two detectives entered the restaurant and ordered him to go outside.", "title": "New York Detective Guilty of Lying About Drug Arrest", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein", "John Surico"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "The crash left craters of anguish and grief in New York and Florida.\n\nIn a phone interview, Rabbi Jacob Luski of Congregation B\u2019nai Israel of St. Petersburg, Fla., said that a relative of the Weiss family had confirmed the deaths of Mitchell Weiss, 52; his wife, Leslie L. Weiss, 50; their daughter, Hannah M. Weiss, 19; and their son, Ari M. Weiss, 16.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey were together and they all perished,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is a terrible tragedy and it is a devastating loss to their families and to our congregation.\u201d\n\nA sister of Mr. Steinberg confirmed Sunday night in a Facebook post that her brother and his family had died in the crash. A relative who answered the phone at Mr. Steinberg\u2019s parents\u2019 home in Florida confirmed that the Steinbergs lived in Scarsdale, a suburb north of New York City, with their sons William, Zachary and Matthew.\n\n\u201cThey were the kind of people you would like to have many of,\u201d the relative said before saying she had to hang up. \u201cThey always did everything as a family.\u201d\n\nLyn Kaller, a close friend of Ms. Steinberg who also lives in Scarsdale, said she learned of the plane crash in a text message from a rabbi in Costa Rica on Sunday afternoon. \u201cSomething happened to the Steinbergs,\u201d the rabbi wrote.\n\nMs. Kaller said she immediately called the man, who told her that the plane the family was on had crashed after takeoff, but she did not believe him until her son found a news story online about the accident.\n\nIn the hours after the crash, Ms. Kaller said that an official with a United States consulate in Costa Rica also contacted her about the crash. The Steinbergs had many friends in Scarsdale, she said, so why the rabbi and government official contacted her had become another mystery in Sunday\u2019s tragedy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Steinberg worked in investment banking, and Ms. Steinberg volunteered at many nonprofits, Ms. Kaller said. She said she met Ms. Steinberg about 14 years ago when Matthew Steinberg and her son, Noah, attended nursery school at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale.\n\nPhoto\n\nMatthew was an eighth-grader at a private school, William attended the University of Pennsylvania and Zachary was at Johns Hopkins University, Ms. Kaller said. She said that their parents made an effort to expose them to cultures all over the world. It was a trip to Asia in a previous year, and the latest was the vacation to Costa Rica.\n\n\u201cIrene and Bruce felt very strongly about providing that kind of culture and enrichment for their children,\u201d she said in an interview.\n\nAviation and security officials in Costa Rica told local news media on Sunday that the cause of the crash was unknown but that the Nature Air plane encountered inclement weather on Sunday when it first tried to land in Punta Islita to pick up the American passengers. The plane returned to another airport before it eventually landed in Punta Islita around 11 a.m., the country\u2019s civil aviation director told the newspaper El Mundo.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter the pilots picked up the American passengers, the plane took off for San Jos\u00e9, the capital, which is about 140 miles east, the authorities said. Photos posted by government officials on Facebook show that the Cessna plane crashed several hundred yards from the end of a runway at Punta Islita Airport.\n\nLaura Chinchilla, the president of Costa Rica from 2010 to 2014, said on Twitter that her cousin was one of the crew members killed in the crash.\n\nCosta Rica, particularly its pristine beaches and mountains on the Pacific coast, is popular with North American and European tourists. More tourists visit Costa Rica from America than any other country. Eco-tourism is a major draw, and Nature Air bills itself as the first carbon-neutral airline in the world.\n\nIn September, an American and another passenger on a Nature Air flight died when a single-engine Cessna crashed in a river in Guanacaste. Another American on the flight was injured.", "title": "New York Family of 5 Among 10 Americans Killed in Costa Rica Plane Crash", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "God and the Devil were fighting for a man\u2019s soul \u2014 for all of humanity, really. Angels and miscreants got in on the action, pushing and pulling, the Devil stretching out his hand and zapping everyone; God responded in kind. In the middle of the scrum, arms yanked in opposite directions, stood Jerry Springer. Well, a guy playing Jerry Springer at least.\n\nGod and the Devil are presumably doing battle elsewhere in the world, too, and this Jerry was the Broadway actor Terrence Mann, in the thick of rehearsing a scene from \u201cJerry Springer \u2014 The Opera.\u201d The show, a London sensation in 2003 that toured Europe and has been mounted by a handful of regional American theaters, has not had an honest-to-goodness run in New York until now. The New Group production begins previews Jan. 23, Off Broadway at the Pershing Square Signature Theater.\n\n\u201cThe Jerry Springer Show\u201d \u2014 the TV series, not the opera \u2014 had its premiere in 1991 and was part of the heyday, or nadir, depending on your perspective, of daytime talk. These were the days of \u201cDonahue,\u201d \u201cThe Oprah Winfrey Show,\u201d \u201cGeraldo,\u201d \u201cThe Jenny Jones Show,\u201d \u201cRicki Lake,\u201d \u201cThe Richard Bey Show,\u201d \u201cThe Montel Williams Show\u201d and the somehow-still-running \u201cMaury.\u201d\n\nWhile every show had its own brand of scandalousness, \u201cJerry\u201d became the juiciest, the tawdriest, the ultimate lowbrow modern-day freak show. \u201cTalking Trash\u201d announced a 1998 Time magazine article. The host appeared on the cover of Rolling Stone with the headline \u201cSex, Sin & the Death of All We Hold Sacred.\u201d", "title": "New York Has Its \u2018Jerry Springer\u2019 Moment, With Arias and Dancing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Consider the following: The first phase of the Second Avenue subway, completed at the end of 2016, cost $2.5 billion per mile; and the extension of the No. 7 line to Hudson Yards, finished the year before, cost $1.5 billion per mile. By contrast, Paris, a dense and historic city with strong labor unions, is building a line extension similar to the Second Avenue project for just $450 million a mile, which is roughly comparable to the average cost for subway projects around the world. Several transit experts have pointed out these cost discrepancies in recent years.\n\nThe M.T.A. chairman, Joe Lhota, acknowledged to The Times that excessive costs have \u201cbeen a problem,\u201d but he says New York has unique challenges, like aging utilities and high density, that contribute to high costs. That is not credible, since Paris and London are older than New York and have done a much better job improving and expanding their transit systems in recent years.\n\nStill, Mr. Lhota, whom Gov. Andrew Cuomo appointed last year, says the M.T.A. is working to bring down costs. To be successful, he will need help from Mr. Cuomo, who has been friendly with the labor unions whose members operate cranes and dig tunnels, and with the contractors doing the work. The unions and the construction companies are big campaign contributors and have a strong financial incentive to preserve the status quo.\n\nMr. Cuomo, in turn, will have to stir the Legislature, which has, regrettably, taken little interest in overseeing and improving the M.T.A. Besides annual hearings about the M.T.A.\u2019s budget, the State Assembly and the Senate conducted just two oversight hearings on the M.T.A. between 2015 and last year, according to Reinvent Albany, a public interest group. Last year, as the subways were plagued by delays and derailments, the Assembly held just one oversight hearing, about the impact of the track work Amtrak was doing at Penn Station. The Senate did not bother with even that. By contrast, the New York City Council, which has little sway over the M.T.A., has held nine oversight hearings in the past three years.\n\nIt\u2019s not as if the Legislature has no power. It held important hearings in 2016 about water contamination in Hoosick Falls and elsewhere. Those hearings helped shine a light on how a toxic chemical got into groundwater, and state officials were pressed to explain why they did not respond more quickly.", "title": "Opinion | New York Leaders Are Failing Its Subway Riders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Anti-football legislation, even at the state level, faces an uphill battle. Despite the decline in youth football participation over the past decade, the sport remains the most popular in the country by many measures. More than a million boys play high school football nationally each year \u2014 more than baseball and basketball combined \u2014 and football is often the only sport that produces a profit for major college athletic programs.\n\nThe N.F.L. also remains immensely influential, despite a recent decline in television ratings and mounting worries about the long-term health of players subjected to years of head hits. It is the largest sports league in the country, with $14 billion in revenue, and its games draw more viewers than nearly everything else on broadcast television.\n\nThe reintroduction of the New York bill comes as research increasingly shows a correlation between long-term brain disease and the age at which children begin playing tackle football. Last week, a study published in the journal, Brain, showed evidence of the degenerative brain disease, chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., in teenage athletes who sustained head impact injuries.\n\nDoctors note that head hits absorbed by young players are more damaging because their brains are not fully developed, and are less capable of fully repairing themselves. Younger players also have weaker neck muscles, and therefore are less capable of bracing for impact and supporting the weight of a football helmet.\n\n\u201cSome of my colleagues quibble that the science has not determined which age is the right age, but they don\u2019t seem to realize that health experts set age minimums for all sorts of activities like drinking, smoking and driving, and the science is never purely black and white,\u201d said Dr. Robert Cantu, the co-founder and medical director of the Concussion Legacy Foundation, who has studied head trauma in children for years.", "title": "New York Legislator Renews Effort to Bar Tackle Football for Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis footage has serious implications not only for the safety and due process rights of police officers, but for the privacy and rights of members of the public, as well,\u201d he said. He accused Mayor Bill de Blasio and the Police Department of showing \"reckless disregard\u201d for those concerns and for state law.\n\nThe issue of what the public is permitted to see runs through the national debate over body cameras, as police departments, officers\u2019 unions, lawmakers and watchdog organizations wrestle over what makes for the best policy.\n\nThe 50-a statute was intended to protect officers from exploitation and abuse. The city\u2019s interpretation has expanded under Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat elected on promises of police reform, and the state\u2019s highest court has affirmed the broader interpretation.\n\nThe Police Department has cited the 50-a statute as the reason for refusing to turn over body camera video to journalists who have requested it under the state Freedom of Information Law. But in statements confirming that the city was reviewing the lawsuit, officials stood by the decision to release some videos to the public.\n\n\u201cThe mayor and the police commissioner have spoken to the need for increasing transparency into the way our city is policed,\u201d Austin Finan, a spokesman for Mr. de Blasio, said. \u201cThe release of body camera footage, when possible, is an important extension of that commitment.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRobert J. Freeman, the executive director of the state Committee on Open Government, who has called for the 50-a statute to be amended or repealed, said the lawsuit was an attempt by the union to further shield police officers from public accountability.\n\n\u201cYou have this myth that the disclosure of information relating to the performance of the duties of a public employee in some way relates to that person\u2019s personal privacy,\u201d he said. \u201cNot so. Not so. The record that indicates my salary is about me, but it\u2019s not personal. It\u2019s about me as a public employee.\u201d\n\nThe police union, like others in Boston and Seattle, has resisted body cameras for its officers. Officials considered taking legal action against the city during contract negotiations last year until the city agreed to give a raise for officers who would be required to wear them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile the police union would rather not see the videos released at all, prosecutors prefer that decision to be made after they have completed investigations and decided if criminal charges are warranted. And police-reform advocates have pushed for a standardized process that would allow more videos to be made public.\n\nDarius Charney, the lead lawyer in a 2008 lawsuit that challenged the Police Department\u2019s stop-and-frisk tactics and led to a court-ordered body camera pilot, said the videos should be considered official reports, no different from what officers file each time they conduct a stop, arrest or other enforcement action.\n\nRichard M. Aborn, the president of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City, a criminal justice policy nonprofit, said that whether the statute applies to body camera video may depend on whether the Police Department plans to use it to evaluate officers\u2019 performances or make disciplinary decisions.\n\n\u201cWhat is crystal clear is the right of the public to see these videos and hear reports from the government about what happened in these shootings is paramount, and the courts have got to find a way to expeditiously resolve any dispute and allow the dissemination of this information,\u201d he said. \u201cSo to me, this is about speed.\u201d\n\nGetting video released quickly, or explaining why it is being withheld, is crucial to quelling public skepticism, he said.", "title": "New York Police Union Sues to Stop Release of Body Camera Videos", "authors": ["Ashley Southall"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI am very keen to introduce new, very customer-friendly, high amenity, very reliable rolling-stock into the New York system,\u201d said Andy Byford, the former chief executive of the Toronto Transit Commission who this week became the president of New York City Transit, which operates the subway and buses. \u201cWe are determined to modernize the New York City subway, that\u2019s one of the prime reasons I\u2019ve come, and I\u2019m determined to push on with that.\u201d\n\nWhile the constant failures of the subway\u2019s antiquated signal system and issues like packed rush-hour platforms have contributed to its dismal on-time performance, car breakdowns are also a major factor. Part of the intention behind the enormous and sped-up purchase of shiny new cars is the seemingly straightforward premise that newer cars will break down less. But, in fact, both older and newer cars have been breaking down more often, according to a recent state comptroller report, which is reflected in a sharp drop in what is known as \u201cmean distance between failures,\u201d a metric the M.T.A. uses to measure performance.\n\nAs a result, one of the most striking changes will be invisible to commuters: R211 cars will be equipped with monitoring computers that will relay information in real-time about its performance \u2014 a health check of sorts \u2014 so that an ailing train can be diagnosed even before it has been hauled back to the repair shop.\n\nTo further tackle the issue, the contract stipulates that the Kawasaki cars adhere to specific reliability requirements, as a warranty. The level of performance that the cars\u2019 critical systems \u2014 such as doors and brakes, some of the largest contributors to delays \u2014 are required to demonstrate, based in part in how many miles they travel before breaking down, is more than double that of past contracts, according to the agency. If they fail to meet those levels, Kawasaki itself must shoulder the cost of any repairs, instead of the authority.\n\nThe Riders Alliance, an advocacy group, praised the introduction of gangway cars, which have been slow to catch on in America. Toronto in 2011 became the first North American city to adopt them and now more than 80 such trains run on one of its lines. In New York City, the open gangway train are expected to fit 1,785 people, 55 more than an equivalent regular train.", "title": "New York Set to Acquire the Next Generation of Subway Cars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 So why is it that the State of New York can tell the City of New York what to do with its streets?\n\nThe question is a natural one in light of a proposal unveiled on Friday to charge drivers who enter Midtown and Lower Manhattan, a congestion pricing plan that would raise money for mass transit.\n\nThe answer lies in Article IX of the New York Constitution, which outlines the state\u2019s responsibilities and powers over its local governments, including their very creation. Leverage over local affairs was codified in a 1929 case, Adler v. Deegan, which found so long as there was \u201csubstantial\u201d state interest, the Legislature could act on matters of \u201cproperty, affairs or government,\u201d an opinion \u2014 written by the jurist Benjamin Cardozo \u2014 that has been widely construed.\n\nAnd while the issue of home rule \u2014 the ability of local governments to manage their own affairs \u2014 still generates lawsuits and calls for constitutional reform, the state\u2019s authority has been upheld by the state\u2019s highest court, the Court of Appeals. And its influence has been flexed repeatedly over New York City, with the Legislature overruling the city on issues like fees for plastic bags, and granting miserly extensions of mayoral control of the city\u2019s schools.", "title": "New York State, Not the City, Will Decide Congestion Pricing. Here\u2019s Why.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe goal is to shift some of the preconceptions that people have around classical music, some of the negative stigma around the concert experience,\u201d he said.\n\nOf course, taking classical music out of the concert hall has been done before in the city. Over the years, string quartets, pianists and other musicians have played classical music in these and other unconventional venues around town:\n\n\u2022 On subway platforms\n\n\u2022 On a coal barge by the Brooklyn Bridge\n\n\u2022 At the Bronx Zoo\n\n\u2022 At Madame Tussauds in Times Square\n\n\u2022 In the Arms and Armor Court at the Met\n\n\u2022 At homeless shelters and soup kitchens\n\n\u2022 In the Hall of Saurischian Dinosaurs at the American Museum of Natural History\n\nThe Thursday evening crypt concert is sold out, but you can join the mailing list for tickets to the next performance, in March, which will go on sale Friday morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nChilly, but lovely.\n\nSunny skies and a high around 35 \u2014 a lucky break for early risers who got to see the super blue blood moon this morning just before 6 a.m.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Kevin Corbett, a top executive at a global construction and engineering firm, will become the next executive director of the struggling New Jersey Transit. The Zamboni and tractors with ice scrapers were invented, replacing horse-drawn ice-cleaners, in the first half of the 20th century. The beloved Rink at Rockefeller Center opened in 1936.\n\nNew York on Ice: Skating in the City, a new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, explores these developments and more. Tonight, skating experts look forward, not back, exploring the future of skating in the city.\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 8:05 a.m.\n\nGood morning on this slightly mild Monday.\n\nIf the weather this month has seemed a little extreme, it\u2019s not your imagination.\n\nLet\u2019s review.\n\nNew York City kicked off 2018 with its coldest New Year\u2019s Eve in more than half a century.\n\nA new weather disaster phrase entered the lexicon with the \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d of Jan. 4, which covered the city in 9.8 inches of snow, a record for the date.\n\nIt arrived, rather inconveniently, during a two-week streak where the temperature never broke 32 degrees.", "title": "New York Today: A Month of Weird Weather", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "What to eat. Tacos. Let\u2019s be honest: It\u2019s hard to find a good taco in New York. Our saving grace is Sunset Park. Here the best tacos are simple: warm tortillas stuffed with braised or grilled meat and finished with minced raw onion and fresh cilantro. At Tacos el Bronco, try the tacos campechanos, tender flank steak with crispy fried chorizo, and the tacos al pastor made with spiced beef and sweet roasted pineapple. If you\u2019re feeling adventurous, try the seasoned beef tongue tacos at nearby Tacos Matamoros.\n\nWhat to drink. Vietnamese coffee. After strolling past the vegetable sellers, Chinese banquet halls and toy stores on Eighth Avenue, stop into Ba Xuyen for a strong cup of Vietnamese coffee. The secret to this dessert-like drink is a few generous spoonfuls of condensed milk, or at nearby Thanh Da II, a touch of cream.\n\nWhat to do. Explore Industry City. The converted warehouses of this 30-acre industrial park now house outlets, studio spaces, outdoor play areas and a large food hall. During the winter, it\u2019s home to Brooklyn Flea and Smorgasburg, the popular food vendor market. While you\u2019re there, try local craft vodka on a tour of the Industry City Distillery, or learn how to make Japanese street food or French pastries at a cooking class at the Brooklyn Kitchen.\n\nHow to get there: Take the Rockaway or South Brooklyn ferry routes. Travel time from Wall Street/Pier 11 is about 15 to 30 minutes, depending on the route.\n\nLooking for more vacation ideas for the year ahead? The New York Times Travel Show brings three days of travel ideas, globe-trotting tips and advice from travel experts to the Javits Center in Midtown this Friday through Sunday.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nWe hope you haven\u2019t lost your umbrella: We\u2019re expecting showers \u2014 and possibly a thunderstorm \u2014 today.\n\nIt\u2019s going to be windy, too, so the rain may come at you sideways. The high, at least, is 57.\n\nThe sun should come out tomorrow.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 The New Jersey town of Leonia has banned all nonresident traffic routed during rush hours into its neighborhood via traffic navigation apps like Waze and Google Maps. Here\u2019s what a few had to say.\n\n\u201cI strongly believe that we already have too many bike lanes. I have never seen more than two bikes in a bike lane. Frequently they are empty. I find many bicycles running red lights, on sidewalks and going in the wrong direction. In addition, I feel like the bike lanes are ageist. Bicycles are used exclusively by younger people, not seniors and definitely not the disabled.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Helene Polonsky, 65, Murray Hill\n\n\u201cPeople tend to complain about cyclist behavior, but it\u2019s important to point out that nearly all of the cyclists who were killed in 2017 were obeying the law when they died. A crosstown bike lane might have saved Dan Hanegby, who was killed by a bus driver who allegedly passed him too closely. I\u2019m thankful that the Department of Transportation is finally solving the problem of safe crosstown travel for New Yorkers on bikes.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Doug Gordon, 44, Park Slope, Brooklyn\n\n\u201cI live on the street with the proposed protected bike lanes. Although I\u2019m an avid Citi Biker and pro-safety, I know that the extra width on my block is super critical to allow fire trucks to pass traffic when they get called out. I\u2019m not looking forward to the blasting horns I will now hear because there is no \u2018passing lane.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u2014 Allison Robin, 35, Murray Hill\n\n\u201cIf people are really complaining about the loss of a few parking spaces, one might ask why that is an efficient use of public space. About 25 percent of Manhattan households own cars. Why does the city provide public space, free of charge, for storage of private property that is, for most people, a discretionary expenditure?\u201d\n\n\u2014 Jeremy M. Posner, 42, Upper East Side\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? To see how the snowscape was holding up, we stopped by the park this week. On an empty roadway, a group of 12-foot piles of snow sat glistening in the sun, protected by police-style barricades. It was the only snow around, and it wasn\u2019t very fluffy.\n\n\u201cIt has a hard icy surface from the rain, but that\u2019s covering the powder underneath,\u201d Mr. Sama said. On Friday, he added, a snow groomer will break up what\u2019s left and shape it into hills of white. Ideally.\n\nIf the snow doesn\u2019t last until the weekend, the Parks Department has a backup plan \u2014 winter-themed activities that don\u2019t require snow: \u201carctic golf,\u201d a version of miniature golf where ice sculptures replace the windmills, and \u201carctic bowling,\u201d regular bowling but outdoors.\n\nWith sunny skies and a predicted high near 50, the Parks Department is also breaking out other warm-weather activities \u2014 dodge ball and shuffleboard \u2014 just in case.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nRock your shades, it\u2019s a brilliant day.\n\nBut don\u2019t get too comfortable. It\u2019s cooler than yesterday \u2014 the high is 39 \u2014 and you\u2019ll want to take a warm coat.\n\nLeave the umbrella at home.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Grandma the clown, a revered star of the Big Apple Circus, resigned after it was revealed that he pressured a 16-year-old aerialist into posing for pornographic photos. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 An appeals court freed a man who had been found guilty on marijuana charges after a series of mishaps and court mishandlings caused him to have to wait seven years for his trial to begin. [New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Mayor Bill de Blasio set a target of opening up 20 of his 90 homeless shelters that were laid out in his \u201cvision\u201d plan before the end of 2017. Only 10 have opened. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Opening statements were made in the federal corruption trial of Joseph Percoco, a former friend and adviser to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 New York City has sued Big Pharma drug companies over the opioid crisis, joining a national campaign to hold those companies responsible for costs related to the epidemic. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey signed an executive order aimed at loosening the state\u2019s restrictive medical marijuana policies. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The Brooklyn district attorney, Eric Gonzalez, has formed a committee of more than 50 criminal justice experts in hopes of sustaining his predecessor\u2019s legacy of reform. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In \u201cAbout New York,\u201d the columnist Jim Dwyer contemplates how the feud between the governor and the mayor is holding New York City back. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Wyatt Tee Walker, a Harlem leader and chief of staff to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died at 88. Even through its multiple iterations, from Off Broadway to Broadway and back, it has charmed our critic Ben Brantley, who wrote that \u201cpretty much anyone who remembers arriving in New York, fresh from school, without a trust fund or a sugar daddy (or momma), will find grounds for identifying with those rudderless figures onstage.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cBright Colors and Bold Patterns\u201d reopened at the end of last year at the SoHo Playhouse. \u201cPlays do not get much gayer than \u2018Bright Colors,\u2019\u201d our critic wrote. \u201cSet poolside, this 80-minute evening is essentially an audience with Gerry, who suffers from a serious case of ADHD, throws back cocktails as if they were cleansing juices, possesses a voluminous knowledge of pop culture (who is Shannon Elizabeth, anyway?), wields an acerbic wit that could flay you at 50 paces and has no off button.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cDrunk Shakespeare.\u201d The conceit here is simple: A truncated version of a Shakespeare classic is performed while one cast member takes shots. Our critic wrote that what sets \u201cDrunk Shakespeare\u201d apart from other productions where actors are impaired \u201cis that alcohol isn\u2019t the main character. It\u2019s more like an enabler, allowing the actors (sober and drunk) to take all sorts of liberties with Shakespeare, but skillfully.\u201d\n\nYou can see a list of the other discounted Off Broadway productions and read our reviews here.\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? There, in 1958, while signing copies of his book \u201cStride Toward Freedom: The Montgomery Story,\u201d he was stabbed by a woman with a seven-inch steel letter opener.\n\nWhen asked, the current tenants \u2014 Apollo Beauty Land, Platinum Jewelry of Harlem and Dr. Jay\u2019s Ladies \u2014 said they didn\u2019t know of their building\u2019s association with racial justice.\n\nThey did a few blocks north at Harlem Hospital Center, where King was taken after the attempted assassination.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re particularly proud of the integral role we played in the civil rights movement,\u201d said Sylvia L. White, the hospital\u2019s deputy executive director. \u201cHe said it himself, without us, there would be no march on Washington.\u201d\n\nMs. White gave us a tour of the Martin Luther King Jr. Pavilion (18 floors where doctors work with the hospital\u2019s most severe cases) and showed us a mural by the artist Darryl Downes that depicts, in dreamy green and aquamarine, the surgeons at work on King.\n\nThe room where he slept, the bed in which he recovered and the steps from which he can be seen smiling and waving in a photo after his recovery were all lost to history. The building was demolished in 2004 during a renovation of the hospital campus.\n\nWe ended our tour at the memorial to King by William Tarr in Lincoln Square, close to where, in 1967, he led one of the nation\u2019s largest anti-Vietnam War demonstrations. Less than a year later he was shot and killed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the steel cube are quotes from King, including this one:\n\n\u201cLet us be dissatisfied until every man can have food and material necessities for his body, culture and education for his mind, freedom and human dignity for his sprit.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nIt\u2019s going to rain today, and it could be very heavy at times, so bring an umbrella and a pair of dry socks.\n\nOn the flip side, it will be warm. The high could reach 60.\n\nSaturday is looking wet as well, but dropping temperatures means it could come in the form of freezing rain and sleet. Sunday will be sunny, ushering in a stretch of cold similar to the beginning of this year.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 One of Chris Christie\u2019s last acts as governor may be a push for New Jersey Transit to purchase the last industrial site on the Hoboken waterfront, over objections from the city\u2019s mayor. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 An accusation against the powerful New York senator Jeffrey D. Klein is Albany\u2019s biggest sexual harassment scandal in years, but there may be few options to investigate. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The former director of financial aid at Columbia University is accused of taking kickbacks from graduate students. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The City Council speaker accused police officers and federal agents of acting violently at an immigration protest at which two council members were arrested. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In \u201cAbout New York,\u201d the columnist Jim Dwyer explores how Mayor Bill de Blasio declared himself a foe of climate change, despite travel habits that undermine his rhetoric. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 New York\u2019s prison system is testing a policy that would require all packages for inmates to be ordered through a handful of state-approved vendors. [New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The president of the University of Rochester stepped down just hours before an outside investigation cleared him of charges that he covered up a sexual harassment scandal involving a prominent professor. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A Brooklyn judge threw out a guilty verdict in a 1997 murder case that the physically aggressive former detective Louis Scarcella worked on. The prisoner argued that Mr. Scarcella choked and hit him to coerce a confession. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The number of students taking the SAT at New York City public schools increased significantly last year, after the city offered the test for free and during the school day in an effort to close a racial gap. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The real estate prices in Brooklyn continue to climb, even as the surrounding areas stumble. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Mayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s monuments commission decided to allow a Christopher Columbus statue to remain in place, but markings will be added to honor indigenous people. [New York Daily News]\n\n\u2022 A New Jersey resident was stripped of his citizenship after the Justice Department learned he had entered the country under a false name. [NBC New York]\n\n\u2022 The suspect in the Port Authority bombing case pleaded not guilty \u201cat this moment\u201d in Manhattan federal court. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the coming days, here are some suggestions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVisit the exhibition \u201cKing in New York,\u201d about King\u2019s time in New York, at the Museum of the City of New York on the Upper East Side. Opens tomorrow at 10 a.m. [$18]\n\nMake a quilt out of donated fabric in honor of King\u2019s visit to Gee\u2019s Bend Community in rural Alabama and the establishment of the Freedom Quilting Bee at Wave Hill in the Bronx. Saturday at 10 a.m. [Free]\n\nAttend a musical tribute to King at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights. Sunday at 3 p.m. [Free]\n\nListen in on conversations with politicians, activists and journalists from WNYC at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day Celebration at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Sunday at 3 p.m. [Free]\n\nHear musical performances and talks with activists and civic leaders at the city\u2019s largest tribute to King at BAM in Downtown Brooklyn. Monday beginning at 10:30 a.m. [Free]\n\nJoin a gospel celebration in honor of King by the Harlem Gospel Choir at B.B. King Blues Club and Grill in Times Square. Monday at 12:30 p.m. [$30]\n\nThere will be no New York Today on Monday in observance of Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday. We\u2019ll be back on Tuesday. Have a great weekend!\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Brands like Athleta and Lululemon offer in-store classes in yoga, Pilates, boot camp, barre and more. If assuming a lotus pose while surrounded by merchandise throws off your chi, center yourself with a reminder that these classes are free \u2014 as long as you don\u2019t shop on your way out.\n\nShape Up NYC. Maybe you avoid working out because you think it\u2019s just \u2026 so \u2026 boring. In that case, you might try bringing a friend who makes you laugh to one of the more unusual Shape Up NYC classes offered by the parks department, like belly dancing, hip-hop aerobics or line dancing. The parks department offers 250 classes a week in every borough, all free. Still not enough mental stimulation? Try a bilingual yoga class and learn how to do a perro invertido.", "title": "New York Today: Getting Fit for Free", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "How do you avoid burnout?\n\nI don\u2019t know. I\u2019m very tired (laughs). But we\u2019re all very tired. I think that the demands of reporters now are very different. The only way to avoid burnout is to take cues from your body and your brain. If you\u2019re making mistakes in your copy, take a few extra minutes and look it over a few extra times. Double-check yourself. That doesn\u2019t really deal with the feeling of \u201cI can\u2019t keep doing this,\u201d but if you need to take a break, take a break.\n\nWhat\u2019s something that newcomers to the industry might not understand about your job?\n\nThere\u2019s a difference between letting your sources take advantage of you and having good sources.\n\nWhat are the most important qualities in a journalist today?\n\nNot being afraid. A lot of times people are afraid of writing something because someone will get mad or they\u2019ll lose access. That can never be a concern. Ever. That was true 50 years ago, and even more so now because the culture of bullying reporters has become more intense.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nThe sun is out, but zip up your jacket: Today\u2019s high is only 34.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Harendra Singh, a restaurateur and campaign donor to Mayor Bill de Blasio, secretly pleaded guilty in federal court to trying to bribe the mayor to win favorable lease terms. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A new bureau of the Bronx district attorney\u2019s office, located inside the Rikers Island jail complex, has changed the way prosecutors investigate crimes by inmates and visitors. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A federal judge acquitted Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his co-defendant of seven bribery and mail fraud charges, leaving them to face 11 charges at retrial. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The owner of the $65 million animal transit facility at Kennedy International Airport known as Ark claims he is incurring massive operational losses and has sued the Port Authority. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Mayor Bill de Blasio won the latest battle in his feud against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority put off a vote on the governor\u2019s plan to add amenities to 33 subway stations. [New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 After the F.B.I. raided the home of Joseph Percoco, the first call he made was to his ally and close friend: the governor. But we\u2019re always using public transportation and going to the gym \u2014 places where we\u2019re in close contact with people who are sick.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: Messy Weather and Flu Facts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "During bigger snowstorms, he added, temperatures tend to rise closer to freezing. So in New York, at least, \u201cyou don\u2019t tend to see that big a snowstorm in the single digits.\u201d\n\n(Case in point: During the blizzard in January 2016, one of the largest snowfalls ever recorded in New York City, temperatures were generally in the 20s.)\n\nSo what ingredients are needed to cook up a perfect storm?\n\n\u201cIn order to get snow of significance,\u201d Mr. Homenuk said, \u201cthe main things you need are cold enough temperatures, lift in the atmosphere and moisture.\u201d\n\nLater this week, when temperatures are expected to climb closer to 30, we may see some flurries. We\u2019re in the clear for snow today and tomorrow, but it may feel as bone-chilling as 0 degrees as you head out for the day.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure people will be asking when it\u2019s going to end,\u201d Mr. Homenuk said of this cold spell. \u201cWe can probably look at the second week of January when things will start to improve \u2014 when our confidence will go up that when you walk outside, it\u2019s going to be much less unpleasant than it is right now.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Mayor Bill de Blasio was sworn in for his second and last term on Monday. Most recently, when the park held a trial run last summer, the city\u2019s Department of Transportation found that closing the roadways to cars caused little to no incremental delays, further making a case for the change to be permanent.\n\n\u201cAs Brooklyn\u2019s backyard,\u201d said Sue Donoghue, president of the Prospect Park Alliance, \u201cit is important to do all we can to ensure the park is a safe and tranquil destination for the millions of visitors who depend upon it for recreation and relaxation.\u201d\n\nFollowing implementation today, the department plans to monitor traffic patterns in the area and adjust traffic signals if necessary.\n\nNow all we need is some warmer weather so we can actually enjoy it.\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? We checked in with our White House correspondent Michael D. Shear about what to expect.\n\nThe big ones, for New York City residents, are infrastructure and immigration, Mr. Shear told us.\n\nInfrastructure\n\n\u201cWhat Mr. Trump is going to do is highlight this idea of a trillion-dollar infrastructure package that he wants to pursue with Congress that would marry up federal government money with private money and state money to help fix crumbling infrastructure,\u201d Mr. Shear said.", "title": "New York Today: Our State of the Union", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 11:14 a.m.\n\n\n\nGood morning on this bright Thursday.\n\nHere\u2019s something you might not expect to find at a farmers\u2019 market or street parade: philosophy.\n\nFor nearly two years, Ian Olasov, a doctoral candidate in philosophy at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and the founder of Brooklyn Public Philosophers, has set up an \u201cAsk-a-Philosopher\u201d booth in places like Union Square. There, he and fellow philosophers help passers-by with questions tougher than how to get where they are going.\n\nThe most common question they get (not surprisingly, he said) concerns the meaning of life.\n\n\u201cBut there are other questions of pressing popular concern that people might not recognize as philosophical,\u201d said Mr. Olasov, 31. \u201c\u2018What does it mean to say that race or gender are socially constructed?\u2019 \u2018What is money?\u2019 \u2018What makes Bitcoin money?\u2019\u201d\n\nDuring this volatile time in our country, the conversation has also shifted considerably, he added.\n\n\u201cOne thing that strikes me is how much public talk there is about how we can \u2018know\u2019 things or how the institutions that create and disseminate knowledge should be organized \u2014 like the press,\u201d Mr. Olasov told us. \u201cOr the role of experts in a democracy. Or what makes scientific institutions trustworthy?\u201d", "title": "New York Today: Street Philosophy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning on this thawing Monday.\n\nAlexa du Pont Bell arrived in New York City in 2000 in a seemingly financially secure position for a 22-year-old: She had a degree from Harvard and a position as an investment banker.\n\nBut while she spent her days thinking about complex issues like fund-raising and equity, her personal finances began to fray. She missed payments on her credit card, was threatened with collections, and was spending a lot on rent, college loans and eating out.\n\n\u201cWhere would I have learned personal finance?\u201d she said. \u201cUnless you get it from your family, there\u2019s no time where a teacher sits down and explains very basic financial principles,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter Ms. Bell got her own finances sorted out, she helped found Cents Ability, a nonprofit that teaches financial literacy to thousands of high school students across New York City. We recently sat down with Ms. Bell as part of our series about the people and inspirations behind local philanthropies.", "title": "New York Today: Teaching Teens the Financial Ropes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s it like going out to dinner with you?\n\nMr. Wells: \u201cIt can be like a job. I tell you what to do, and I may end up eating at strange hours in weird corners of the city. It doesn\u2019t work out that well to have people who think they\u2019re just going out for fun.\u201d\n\nMs. Goldfield: \u201cI really need to focus on the food and on my surroundings. Sometimes I\u2019ll just check out of the conversation, which can drive people crazy.\u201d\n\nYou make reservations under different names. Does that matter, when anyone can Google you and see what you look like?\n\nMr. Wells: \u201cThe real merit in anonymous reviewing is showing up as a regular civilian even if they recognize you at the door, so that you\u2019re not telegraphing that you expect to be treated as a representative of the newspaper.\u201d\n\nMs. Goldfield: \u201cI think the idea of special treatment for a critic is, to some degree, a thing of the past. Service has just gotten better across the board. Part of that is an emphasis on hospitality and part is also symptomatic of the Yelp era.\u201d\n\nWhat makes a good meal?\n\nMr. Wells: \u201cThe most satisfying meals that I have are the ones that the chef isn\u2019t trying to make a huge impression but is just trying to make the food really good. You would think that making the food really good is the baseline, but beyond that a lot of ego and flag planting can creep in and it\u2019s not always to the benefit of the diner.\u201d\n\nMs. Goldfield: \u201cReally good, really unpretentious cooking. I\u2019m averse to preciousness. I like to feel like what I\u2019m eating looks like food and marries flavors in a thoughtful rather than showy way.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCurrent favorite food?\n\nMr. Wells: \u201cThings with crust, like tarts and savory pies.\u201d\n\nMs. Goldfield: \u201cI love mapo tofu, but there\u2019s almost nothing I find so satisfying as really good bread and butter.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nBy the time you\u2019re done commuting today, a meal at a cozy, candlelit restaurant will really hit the spot.\n\nIt could rain throughout the day and we\u2019re not expecting much in the way of sun. Andrew M. Cuomo will deliver the annual State of the State address in Albany.\n\nThe stakes are higher this year for the governor, a Democrat in his second term \u2014 he\u2019s up for re-election in November and may have presidential ambitions for 2020.\n\nThough Mr. Cuomo has been lauded for progressive victories \u2014 like tuition-free college, the legalization of same-sex marriage, a higher minimum wage and paid family leave \u2014 he has also faced troubles in office. He has been blamed (and blamed some more) for New York City\u2019s transit crisis. He has also been criticized for his response to sexual harassment allegations against one former senior aide, and for his ties to another aide who will go on trial this month to face corruption charges.", "title": "New York Today: The State of Our State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Green birdwings from Papua New Guinea and Australia, the most exotic of the museum\u2019s collection, basked on nectar plants. Atlas moths from Asia, the largest in the display, dozed peacefully on flowers. Morpho butterflies and Ulysses swallowtails flashed electric blue as they fed on juice from oranges and bananas.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe wondered: How are these butterflies \u2014 thousands of them \u2014 transported across oceans?\n\nFaraway farms raise the caterpillars until they pupate, or become a chrysalis. This is the ideal time to ship the soon-to-be butterflies because they don\u2019t eat or drink during this stage. The farmers collect the chrysalides, wrap them in soft cotton, foam or toilet tissue, place them in boxes, and send them (DHL Express or FedEx) from their skies to ours.\n\nWhen Ms. Davies receives the parcels \u2014 each packed delicately with about 100 chrysalides \u2014 she and her team open them inside the museum\u2019s quarantine lab. They check the specimens carefully, like doctors examining their patients, and nurture the healthy ones until the butterflies emerge and can be released in the conservatory to mingle with New Yorkers.\n\n\u201cThey particularly like to land on people when you get quite sweaty, because they like to take in salts from sweat,\u201d Ms. Davies said. \u201cThey love bald men\u2019s heads. They\u2019re looking for a perch, and some of them like legs because they think it\u2019s a tree trunk.\u201d\n\n\u201cSo if you\u2019d like to come in and just stand here and sweat and feed the butterflies,\u201d she added, \u201cthey\u2019d love it.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nNot a bad time to visit a tropical bubble.\n\nTemperatures will hover around freezing today and tomorrow, and we may see some flurries on both days.\n\nOh, and things aren\u2019t warming up anytime soon.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 A lawyer told a jury that his client had murdered three people, against the client\u2019s request. Now, the Supreme Court will hear arguments as to whether what he did was constitutional. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Some preservationists are upset that only the exterior of the office building at 550 Madison Avenue might become an official landmark and not the interior. [New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Jumaane D. Williams, a city councilman from Brooklyn, said he was opening an exploratory committee to unseat the current lieutenant governor. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Despite accusations from a former staffer that he made unwanted advances toward her, Senator Jeffrey D. Klein has resisted calls for his resignation. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 After the board of New Jersey Transit rescheduled its monthly meeting for Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday, a crowd of Hoboken residents showed up to protest. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Music therapy is becoming more prevalent in nursing homes and hospices across the city, where it has been shown to improve a patient\u2019s quality of life. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A debate over how to curb wolflike coyotes, or \u201ccoywolves,\u201d continues to intensify in the rural New York community of Clarkstown. Wade.\n\nThe ruling, one of the most prominent Supreme Court decisions in our country\u2019s history, legalized abortion in the United States on Jan. 22, 1973.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n(\u201cRoe,\u201d the anonymous plaintiff in the case, was Norma McCorvey of Texas, who was trying to get an abortion there. The defendant, \u201cWade,\u201d was Henry Wade, then the Dallas County district attorney, who supported a Texas law forbidding abortion unless it would save the mother\u2019s life.)\n\nBut the landmark ruling has always incited heated debate.\n\nIn New York, amid worries that the Supreme Court could soon try and overturn the ruling, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has proposed writing Roe v. Wade into our state constitution to guarantee that these rights and protections remain in place.\n\nYou can learn more about the past, present and future of Roe v. Wade tonight at the Brooklyn Historical Society, when reproductive rights experts will lead the discussion \u201c45 Years after \u2018Roe v. Wade.\u2019\u201d\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day?
