Title From James Madison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "It is hard for Abby Schauer to talk about what happened at U.N.D. Growing up in Grand Forks, she dreamed of wearing the Kelly green and white of the team formerly known as the Fighting Sioux. Her parents had men\u2019s and women\u2019s hockey season tickets.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been going to games for as long as I can remember,\u201d she said.\n\nIn high school, Schauer seemed on her way. She made all-state as a freshman forward for the KnightRiders, a team drawn from the two Grand Forks high schools. (The nickname combines Grand Forks Central Knights and Red River Roughriders.) Seeking tougher competition to prepare for Division I, Schauer left two years ago to play Tier 1 hockey for the Northern Cyclones, based in New Hampshire. The news of U.N.D.\u2019s decision broke her heart.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRecently, while the Schauers packed for a move to another house in Grand Forks, her mother, Sally, discovered Abby\u2019s thick journal from first grade. It contained a crayon drawing Abby made of herself playing hockey, with a haunting caption using creative spelling: \u201cWhen I grow up I will play college hockey and then go pro. I will play for the Sioux and be the goaly. I will lead them to the championship.\u201d\n\nLast month, Schauer pinned it to her Twitter account and tagged U.N.D.\u2019s president, Mark Kennedy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard. It\u2019s sad,\u201d said Schauer, a junior, who is now playing Tier 1 with the Madison Capitols in Wisconsin. \u201cI left here so I could play college hockey in my hometown. I sacrificed my high school years so I could play here. It was my goal.\u201d\n\nU.N.D. dropped women\u2019s hockey, baseball, men\u2019s golf, and men\u2019s and women\u2019s swimming in a two-year wave of athletics budget cuts brought on by a state revenue shortfall. Men\u2019s golf was reinstated with outside financing. Most worrisome for women\u2019s hockey boosters, North Dakota is the third Division I member to shutter its women\u2019s program since 2011; Wayne State and Niagara are the others.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBut it\u2019s especially troublesome here in a cradle of the game. College hockey players are rock stars in Grand Forks, unable to go to the grocery store without being recognized. Miller, the KnightRiders\u2019 assistant, said girls\u2019 teams had regularly attended U.N.D. women\u2019s games at opulent Ralph Engelstad Arena, known locally as the Ralph. Players were often asked for and gladly signed autographs, and conducted clinics.\n\n\u201cFor our youth girls\u2019 team, skating side by side with those girls was exceptional,\u201d Miller said. \u201cNow we don\u2019t have that anymore. You don\u2019t have those positive female role models to look up to. It\u2019s a huge loss in the community.\u201d\n\nThe KnightRiders drew about 200 fans for a recent Saturday afternoon game with Jamestown at Eagles Arena, a small municipal rink with a jungle gym next to the trophy case. The night before, more than 2,000 packed into Purpur Arena, named for Fido, to watch the city\u2019s undefeated boys\u2019 hockey teams, Grand Forks Central and Red River, play to a 2-2 tie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKilgore, the Lamoureux sisters\u2019 bantam coach, wonders if girls can adjust their aspirations to be KnightRiders instead of Fighting Hawks, and whether that will be enough to keep girls\u2019 hockey relevant in a vibrant hockey state.", "title": "North Dakota\u2019s Loss of Division I Women\u2019s Hockey Leaves a Void", "authors": ["Pat Borzi"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "There \u201care dishonest things seriously chilling the dramatic atmosphere for the north-south reconciliation created by the great magnanimity and the initiative steps taken\u201d by the North, the news agency said, urging the South Korean authorities to address the problem.\n\nIn an apparent move to soothe Pyongyang, South Korean officials appealed on Saturday to local news outlets, asking them not to carry speculative articles or dwell too much on controversial aspects of the North\u2019s participation in the Games.\n\nAlso on Saturday, the International Olympic Committee announced that 22 North Korean athletes, as well as 24 coaches and 21 media representatives, would be allowed to take part in the Games. The athletes will compete in women\u2019s ice hockey, figure skating, short-track speedskating, cross-country skiing and Alpine skiing. The two countries had already agreed on Wednesday to form the unified hockey team, the first inter-Korean team ever fielded at the Olympics.\n\nThe Koreas have also agreed that their delegations will march together during the opening ceremony. The International Olympic Committee said on Saturday that the countries would be led into the main stadium by two athletes carrying a flag symbolizing a unified Korea. When the combined hockey team plays, \u201cArirang,\u201d a folk song popular on both sides of the border, will play in place of either country\u2019s national anthem.\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who lobbied for the North\u2019s participation in the Games well before Pyongyang agreed to it this month, has said it will help ease the tensions that have built up on the peninsula during the past year over the North\u2019s nuclear and missile tests. But Mr. Moon\u2019s critics, including much of South Korea\u2019s generally conservative news media, have argued that the North will use the Olympics as a propaganda opportunity, to try to weaken international resolve over enforcing sanctions against the North for its nuclear program.\n\nSouth Korean officials have insisted they would ensure that the North Korean delegates kept political propaganda out of their activities in the South. But the musicians and other performers being sent by Pyongyang, like any North Korean artist allowed to appear overseas, will have been well-trained in propagandizing for the country\u2019s authoritarian regime.\n\nNorth Korea had announced that its advance team would be headed by Hyon Song-wol, a singer who leads the Moranbong Band, said to be a favorite of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un. Under Mr. Kim\u2019s rule, the band has enlivened the North\u2019s propaganda-heavy pop music scene, sporting short skirts and performing American pop standards like \u201cMy Way\u201d and the \u201cRocky\u201d theme song.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Hyon herself has received outsize media attention in South Korea, where some news outlets have speculated \u2014 with no apparent evidence \u2014 that she was once Mr. Kim\u2019s girlfriend, a theory dismissed by North Korea analysts in the South. Mr. Kim\u2019s wife, Ri Sol-ju, is herself a former member of a pop band.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen reports linking Ms. Hyon to Mr. Kim first emerged years ago, North Korea called them \u201can unpardonable hideous provocation hurting the dignity of the supreme leadership.\u201d Some South Korean news outlets have continued to refer to Ms. Hyon in recent days as Mr. Kim\u2019s former girlfriend, and some analysts said on Saturday that the advance team\u2019s visit might have been canceled in protest.\n\nMs. Hyon was at the border village of Panmunjom for talks on Monday, when North Korea agreed to send a 140-member arts troupe to the South for concerts in Seoul and Gangneung, an Olympic venue on the east coast, during the Winter Games. Ms. Hyon was widely expected to lead the troupe.\n\nShe first gained international attention in 2013, when news reports in South Korea and Japan claimed that she had been executed on Mr. Kim\u2019s orders. But she later appeared in public wearing an army colonel\u2019s insignia and thanking Mr. Kim for his \u201cheavenly trust and warm care\u201d of the Moranbong Band. In October, Ms. Hyon was elected to the ruling Workers\u2019 Party\u2019s Central Committee as an alternate member.\n\nIn 2015, Ms. Hyon led the Moranbong Band to Beijing for a performance meant as a gesture of friendship between the two countries\u2019 Communist governments. But just hours before the performance was to begin, the band packed up and returned home.\n\nNeither government has explained what happened. But South Korean intelligence officials have since told lawmakers in Seoul that Ms. Hyon was enraged when the Chinese authorities tried to interfere with her program, which was steeped with propaganda touting Mr. Kim and his leadership.\n\nRelations between North Korea and China have become increasingly strained in recent years, as Mr. Kim has defied not only Washington but also Beijing by accelerating his country\u2019s nuclear and missile tests.", "title": "North Korea Agrees, Again, to Pre-Olympic Visit to South Korea", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 North Korea on Monday canceled a joint cultural event it had planned to hold with South Korea early next month, blaming \u201cinsulting\u201d South Korean news media coverage of its participation in the Winter Olympics, South Korean officials said.\n\nWhen the two Koreas agreed this month that the North would send a delegation to the Olympics being held in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang, they also agreed to hold a joint pre-Olympic cultural performance in the North\u2019s Mount Kumgang resort on Feb. 4.\n\nBut it informed the South on Monday night that it was canceling that program. South Korea had planned to send K-pop bands and other musicians to perform alongside North Korean art troupes at Mount Kumgang.\n\nThe North\u2019s sudden decision did not affect its plan to send 22 athletes to the Games or its separate plan to send an art troupe, consisting of a pop orchestra and dancers, to the South to perform before and during the Olympics, which begin on Feb. 8. Still, it showed the unpredictability of the North Korean government.", "title": "North Korea Cancels Pre-Olympic Event, Blaming South Korean Media", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea has agreed to send a team to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea next month.\n\nWhile the decision may help defuse nuclear tension with the West, in terms of sports, it is unlikely to bring the emergence of a hidden-away North Korea version of Shaun White or Yuzuru Hanyu.\n\nIt is not known how many North Koreans will wind up participating. But the athletes who do are not likely to shake up the medal table.\n\nSo far, North Korea has qualified only two athletes for the Games, the figure skating pair of Ryom Tae-ok and Kim Ju-sik. They missed a deadline to apply for a spot, but that is expected to be overlooked. The International Olympic Committee has also indicated a willingness to grant some wild-card entries to other North Korean athletes.\n\nRyom and Kim were 15th at the last world championships, and few expect them to improve much on that performance at the Games.", "title": "North Korea Is in Winter Olympics Without Any Star Athletes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Olympic ideal has long been tarnished by scandal and prohibitive costs that make the Games unaffordable to many cities. But the I.O.C., since its founding in the 19th century, has prided itself on the Olympics serving as essentially a peace movement. They are meant to show that the world\u2019s nations and athletes can come together and, if only for a brief period, the chance of conflict can be lessened.\n\nFor those who still subscribe to that ideal, hopes soared Tuesday. \u201cThis is going to put a positive vibe into those Games,\u201d Mr. Marcotte said.\n\nThere is, too, a widely-expressed hope among South Korean officials and international sports officials and athletes that North Korea\u2019s unpredictable leader, Kim Jong-un, will be less likely to behave provocatively during the Olympics if his country\u2019s athletes are participating.\n\nLast week, the North Korean ruler boasted that the United States was within range of a nuclear arsenal he could operate with a button on his desk. President Donald J. Trump responded on Twitter by bragging about the nuclear capabilities of the United States and the size of his button.\n\nThe jousting evoked somber Olympic memories from three decades ago. Ten months before the 1988 Summer Games were held in Seoul, the South Korean capital, North Korean agents placed a bomb aboard a Korean Air flight and killed all 115 aboard in what South Korean officials said was an attempt to undermine those Olympics. North Korea boycotted those Games.\n\nAt the last major international sporting event held in South Korea, soccer\u2019s 2002 World Cup, North Korea provoked a naval skirmish with the South on the day that South Korea played a match for third place.\n\nBut, on various fields of play, the two countries have been on convivial terms lately. Last year, North Korea sent its women\u2019s national hockey team to play in South Korea, and South Korea sent its women\u2019s soccer team to play in North Korea. North Korea also sent a taekwondo team to the South.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two nations marched together in the opening ceremony at the 2000 and 2004 Summer Olympics. South Korean officials have held open that possibility for the Winter Games.\n\nSouth Korean officials have also strenuously sought to play down security concerns ahead of the 2018 Games, which will be held in Pyeongchang, South Korea, only about 40 miles from the Demilitarized Zone that separates North and South.\n\n\u201cThese worries are understandable,\u201d Choi Moon-soon, governor of the South Korean province where the Olympics will take place, told reporters last year. But, referring to North Korea, he added, \u201cIf they participate in the event, that threat disappears.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is not known whether Kim Jong-un had any plans to disrupt the Pyeongchang Games, but Olympic insiders have said the presence of North Korean athletes would allow them to rest more easily.\n\nLast week, at the United States figure skating championships, David Raith, executive director of U.S. Figure Skating, said he welcomed North Korea\u2019s presence at the Olympics.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hoping they\u2019re there,\u201d Mr. Raith said. \u201cIt would be the safest place in the world.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNorth Korea missed a deadline in late October to officially enter its pairs team into the Olympics. And it does not yet appear to have made such a request, Alexander Lakernik, a Russian who is vice president of the International Skating Union, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday.\n\nBut adding the North Koreans to the Olympic pairs competition would be a simple procedure. And the I.O.C. has said it would keep the doors open to North Korea\u2019s participation for as long as possible. The Olympic committee has also broached the idea of offering North Korea wild-card entries in some Nordic skiing sports and short-track speedskating.\n\nDiscussions have been underway about the pairs team, Mr. Lakernik said, and given the special circumstances, \u201cthere could be an exception made; but first we need an application.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile North Korea has won 16 gold medals in the Summer Games, in such sports as weight lifting, wrestling and boxing, it is not a power in the more expensive winter sports. North Korea did not participate in the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia. Its officials have recently complained that tightened sanctions against the country have made it difficult to obtain some sports equipment.\n\nIn general, North Korea has not appeared to follow the model of the former Soviet Union and East Germany, which were both winter sports powers and used gold medals for propaganda purposes. But experts see participation in these Games as an attempt by Mr. Kim to get sanctions eased and to reduce the chances of American military action.\n\n\u201cSports diplomacy is a sexy affair,\u201d said Lee Sung-yoon, a Korea expert at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. \u201cPyongyang has all the reason to jazz up the Winter Olympiad and be the center of attention.\u201d\n\nPurely in skating terms, Mr. Marcotte, the coach said, the North Koreans appear to be mirroring the Chinese model of attempting to build pairs teams to an elite international level.\n\nAt the 2006 and 2010 Winter Olympics, Chinese pairs won two of the three available medals and are among the favorites to win gold at the 2018 Games. Ryom and Kim possess some of the dynamism seen in Chinese pairs and also some of the classic, balletic style of Russian skaters. There is Western influence in their routines as well. They perform their short program to an instrumental version of the Beatles\u2019 \u201cA Day in the Life.\u201d\n\nWhile qualifying for the 2018 Games at a competition in Germany in September, the skaters spoke several times with reporters and seemed relatively open. Both Ryom and Kim are listed as students. Both live in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, where loyalists to the Kim Jong-un regime are permitted to reside.\n\n\u201cI want to continue to improve until I become world champion,\u201d Ryom said at the time.\n\nOne subject was off limits: the Olympics, because no decision had yet been made about North Korea\u2019s participation.\n\nAnd there seemed to be every attempt to avoid politics.\n\nNeither skater, for instance, wore pins commonly worn by North Koreans that depict Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il, Kim Jong-un\u2019s grandfather and father, who preceded him as the country\u2019s dynastic rulers. And both skaters neglected to praise Kim Jong-un for their success, another common practice for North Korean athletes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Marcotte, the coach, said that all his interactions with the skaters had been about \u201csports, sports, sports.\u201d\n\nAnd while their performance at the Olympics would carry broader meaning for many, he said, the skaters would most likely feel only the pressure that every skater feels \u2014 to perform at their best.\n\n\u201cThey want to show the world that they\u2019re a good team,\u201d Mr. Marcotte said.", "title": "North Korea Makes Peace With the Olympics", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman", "On Olympics"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, spent 2017 rattling the world with nuclear and long-range missile tests and has promised more provocations in 2018. So it was a surprise when he deftly seized on the Winter Olympics on Tuesday to turn toward diplomacy with Seoul, playing the part of the statesman even while seeking fractures in the seven-decade alliance between South Korea and the United States.\n\nAfter his outreach to Seoul on New Year\u2019s Day, Mr. Kim agreed to send a team to compete in the Olympics next month when the Winter Games open in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang. That was followed by an announcement about resumption of military-to-military talks between the two countries \u2014 without the United States.\n\nAll this is a relief to South Korea\u2019s leader, President Moon Jae-in, who feared the North would find a way \u2014 missile launches, terrorism, a nuclear test \u2014 to cast a pall over a sports event meant to highlight the South\u2019s emergence as one of the world\u2019s most dynamic economies.\n\nFew in Seoul or Washington believe Mr. Kim, though an avid sports fan, is motivated solely by the Olympic spirit. The Winter Games also present him with an ideal opportunity to throw a wrench in President Trump\u2019s threats of military action if the North does not agree to give up its nuclear program.", "title": "North Korea Moves Toward D\u00e9tente With Seoul", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 Michael Wolff\u2019s book about the Trump administration has been getting mixed reviews from critics and others, but it\u2019s finding fulsome praise in one corner: North Korean state media, which says the book\u2019s popularity \u201cforetells Trump\u2019s political demise.\u201d\n\nThe book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d has apparently made its way to the so-called hermit kingdom, giving more ammunition to a North Korean government already in a raging propaganda war with President Trump.\n\n\u201cThe anti-Trump book is sweeping all over the world so Trump is being massively humiliated worldwide,\u201d said a commentary in the country\u2019s Rodong Sinmun newspaper, which is run by the ruling Workers\u2019 Party.\n\nThe book has sold so well in the United States \u2014 29,000 hardcover copies the first weekend \u2014 that retailers are having trouble keeping it in stock, and digital and audio sales have topped 350,000. Pirated copies of the book are already circulating online in Asia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRodong Sinmun said those sales figures were no surprise, given the worldwide enmity toward Mr. Trump, who has belittled the country\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, as \u201cLittle Rocket Man\u201d and suggested that the dictator\u2019s \u201cnuclear button\u201d is too small.", "title": "North Korea Praises \u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 Book on Trump Administration", "authors": ["Gerry Mullany"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 North Korea reopened a border hotline with South Korea on Wednesday, restoring a channel of direct dialogue and signaling a possible thaw in relations between the two Koreas after years of hair-trigger tensions.\n\nThe return of the telephone hotline at the village of Panmunjom, which straddles the Demilitarized Zone, the world\u2019s most heavily guarded border, came two days after North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, made a rare overture to the South.\n\nIn his New Year\u2019s Day speech, Mr. Kim continued his nuclear threat against Washington, saying he had a \u201cnuclear button\u201d ready to launch a weapon against any target in the United States. But he also proposed negotiations with South Korea to discuss easing military tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula and his country\u2019s possible participation in the Winter Olympics, which are being held in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang next month.\n\nThe fast-moving political developments have given new hope for a warming of ties between the two longstanding enemies.", "title": "North Korea Reopens Border Hotline With South", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Pyongyang\u2019s statement on Tuesday did not mention a parade, but it said that the North would \u201csignificantly mark\u201d the new Army Building Day with \u201cdiverse events\u201d every year.\n\nThe South Korean Defense Ministry said on Tuesday that it was closely monitoring signs that the North might be planning a parade.\n\nIf held, a military parade would be the North\u2019s first since Mr. Kim claimed on New Year\u2019s Day that the country had finished building a nuclear force, including missiles capable of reaching the mainland United States. Rolling out the country\u2019s new intercontinental ballistic missiles, or ICBMs, during a parade would keep the North\u2019s nuclear threat in the spotlight amid the celebrations surrounding the Games, analysts said.\n\n\u201cIt can keep its people from looking enviously at the Olympics in the South, rallying the loyalty of its people and officials by reminding them that although the North may lag behind the South economically, it is ahead of South Korea militarily,\u201d said Cheong Seong-chang, a senior analyst at the Sejong Institute in South Korea.\n\nNorth Korea, which before this month had not expressed interest in joining the Olympics in the city of Pyeongchang, plans to send 22 athletes, along with hundreds of musicians, dancers and cheerleaders. The two Koreas have agreed that their athletes will march together at the opening ceremony with a single flag symbolizing a unified Korea. They will also field the first unified Korean team in the Olympics, a women\u2019s ice hockey team.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Tuesday, a team of South Korean officials went to the North for logistical preparations at tourist and ski resorts where the two sides have agreed to hold pre-Olympic cultural events and train non-Olympic skiers together. A team of North Korean officials finished a similar trip to the South on Monday, to review potential venues for performances by North Korean artists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPresident Moon Jae-in and other South Koreans have welcomed the North\u2019s participation in the Games as an opportunity to ease the tensions that have built up over the last year over Pyongyang\u2019s nuclear weapons program. But that sentiment is far from unanimous in the South, where others see it as a bid by Mr. Kim to weaken international unity on sanctions against the North, and to turn the Games into what conservative critics are disdainfully calling the \u201cPyongyang Olympics.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s office addressed the criticism on Tuesday, calling for the nation to unite in favor of a successful Games. \u201cWe don\u2019t understand why they label the Games the \u2018Pyongyang Olympics,\u2019\u201d Park Soo-hyun, a presidential spokesman, said in a televised statement. Rather, he said, they should be called the Pyeonghwa, or peace, Olympics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNorth Korea also lashed out, calling the Games\u2019 conservative critics in the South \u201chuman scum\u201d and accusing them of \u201cunpardonable atrocities.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf these traitors and psychopaths defaming the dignified Korean nation are allowed to go scot free, the national reconciliation, unity and the building of a reunified powerful country will be delayed so much,\u201d said a statement carried by the Korean Central News Agency.\n\nJapan\u2019s foreign minister, Taro Kono, said on Tuesday that the talks with North Korea over the Olympics would not lead to a softening of international resolve against Pyongyang\u2019s nuclear program. He said the North had a track record of engaging in dialogue only to disregard any agreements and continue its pursuit of nuclear arms.\n\n\u201cSo you cannot talk them out of it,\u201d Mr. Kono said in an interview. \u201cYou just have to put the pressure on them so that they just see there is no bright future on the current course.\u201d", "title": "North Korea Signals It Might Hold Military Parade on Eve of Olympics", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 North Korea agreed on Tuesday to send athletes to February\u2019s Winter Olympics in South Korea, a symbolic breakthrough after months of escalating tensions over the North\u2019s rapidly advancing nuclear and missile programs.\n\nIn talks held at the border village of Panmunjom, North Korean negotiators quickly accepted South Korea\u2019s request to send a large delegation to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, next month, according to South Korean news reports. In addition to the athletes, the North will send a cheering squad and a performance-art troupe.\n\nThe event will be the first time North Korea has participated in the Winter Games in eight years. The country has competed in every Summer Olympics since 1972, except the 1984 Games in Los Angeles and the 1988 Games in Seoul, both of which it boycotted.\n\nIn fact, the North\u2019s attendance will be a historic development in inter-Korean sports exchanges.\n\nThe North not only shunned the 1988 Seoul Olympics but also tried to disrupt them after talks on co-hosting them fell apart. Its agents planted a bomb on a Korean Air passenger plane in 1987 in a terrorist attack that the South said was aimed at sabotaging the 1988 Olympics. All 115 people on board were killed.", "title": "North Korea to Send Olympic Athletes to South Korea, in Breakthrough", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Wall is the Wall, it has never changed or evolved from the first day I conceived of it,\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 China\u2019s economy grew 6.9 percent last year, its first acceleration in seven years as exports, construction and consumer spending all climbed strongly.\n\nAt least, as our Shanghai bureau chief points out, that\u2019s what the government says.\n\nIn reality, the pace of growth in the world\u2019s second largest economy is anybody\u2019s guess. Various signals suggest China\u2019s growth did speed up last year, but its official figures are at times implausibly smooth and steady.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Earth\u2019s long-term warming trend continued in 2017, with NASA declaring it the second warmest year on record, even without El Ni\u00f1o, which helped make 2016 the hottest recorded yet.\n\nOverall, as this interactive graphic shows, global temperatures have increased more than 1 degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit) since the late 19th century. To avoid the worst consequences of climate change, scientists warn that temperatures must not increase more than 2 degrees Celsius.\n\nClimate change is being felt in geopolitics, too. A water crisis \u2014 whether caused by nature, human mismanagement, or both \u2014 can be an early warning signal of conflict. Iran is the latest example.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 And Novak Djokovic defeated Ga\u00ebl Monfils in a scorcher at the Australian Open.\n\nThe temperature on the court felt like 68 degrees Celsius (154 Fahrenheit), according to Australian television, and Mr. Djokovic called the conditions \u201cbrutal.\u201d Here\u2019s our full coverage of the tournament in Melbourne.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd the results are in for another epic challenge. A seismologist scrutinized hundreds of strong earthquakes over four centuries and found no relationship to lunar cycles.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nLong before the world got hooked on \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d \u201cI Love Lucy\u201d was almost unprecedented in popularity \u2014 and daring in content for the time.\n\n\n\nLucy was one of the first pregnant characters shown on U.S. television, and 44 million viewers tuned to CBS 65 years ago today to see Lucille Ball\u2019s character become a mother.\n\n(Lucy gave birth to Ricky on the air the same night, it turns out, that Ms. Ball gave birth to her second child.)\n\nAudience numbers like that episode\u2019s have since been far surpassed \u2014 the Super Bowl, for instance, has drawn more than 100 million viewers for each of the past eight years. But almost 72 percent of TVs in the U.S. were tuned in to \u201cI Love Lucy\u201d that day, an astonishing feat.\n\nAccording to Nielsen\u2019s, the final episode of \u201cM*A*S*H,\u201d in 1983, had the highest rating of any fictional show in U.S. history, 125 million. But few shows can rival the positive response that the \u201cI Love Lucy\u201d birth episode, and the arrival of Ms. Ball\u2019s second child, elicited.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOne million viewers responded with congratulatory telephone calls, telegrams, letters or gifts,\u201d The Times noted in Ms. Ball\u2019s obituary in 1989.\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. He denied accusations of sexual harassment and of physical and verbal abuse.\n\n\u2022 In college football, Alabama will face Georgia in the national championship game in Atlanta on Monday.\n\nIn the semifinals, the Crimson Tide defeated the Clemson Tigers in the Sugar Bowl, and the Bulldogs beat the Oklahoma Sooners at the Rose Bowl.\n\n\u2022 The three most popular movies at theaters in North America in 2017 \u2014 \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi,\u201d \u201cBeauty and the Beast\u201d and \u201cWonder Woman\u201d \u2014 were driven by female characters. That hasn\u2019t happened in at least 37 years.\n\nPhoto\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Our bloopers in 360\n\nWe begin the year with an ending: our final daily 360 video.\n\nWe\u2019ve made 435 videos in 426 days. Here are some of the moments that didn\u2019t make the cut.\n\nVideo\n\n\u2022 In memoriam\n\nSue Grafton, a best-selling mystery writer, was primarily known for her so-called alphabet novels, starting with \u201cA Is for Alibi\u201d in 1982 and ending in August with \u201cY Is for Yesterday.\u201d She was 77.\n\nRecy Taylor was abducted and raped by six white men in Alabama in 1944, a crime that became an early catalyst for the civil rights movement. The case never went to trial, but renewed attention decades later prompted an apology in 2011 to Mrs. Taylor by the Alabama Legislature. She was 97.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIf you want to catch a cat you have to stay up all night \u2014 that\u2019s just the name of the game.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Jennifer Petruska, a resident of Santa Rosa, Calif., and a self-described insomniac, who spends her nights tracking and trapping pet cats who went into hiding during recent wildfires.\n\nBack Story\n\nWe begin today on a high kick.\n\nThe Rockettes closed their annual holiday season run on Monday, their 85th year at Radio City Music Hall in New York. But their famous kicklines are only a part of the storied history of one of New York\u2019s cultural cornerstones.\n\nPhoto\n\nOpened on Dec. 27, 1932, Radio City was \u201cthe largest temple of entertainment of its kind in the world,\u201d The Times (somewhat breathlessly) proclaimed.\n\nIt was part of John D. Rockefeller Jr.\u2019s plan to revive New York during the Great Depression: by building a \u201ccity within a city\u201d that would provide jobs for New Yorkers and convert a neighborhood known as \u201cthe speakeasy belt\u201d into a commercial hub.\n\nRockefeller teamed up with the Radio Corporation of America to develop the 6,200-seat theater, and the building\u2019s design became a beacon of the Art Deco form.\n\nThe theater has hosted events like the MTV Video Music Awards and more than 700 movie premieres, including \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird,\u201d starring Gregory Peck, a former Radio City usher.\n\nMayor-elect John O\u2019Brien declared the music hall \u201cthe greatest achievement of the theatrical world,\u201d marking \u201ca new era in the history of New York.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. But the last breakthroughs happened much faster than they had expected.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 In India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi\u2019s popularity is eroding as the once-roaring economy cools down.\n\nEconomists agree that two of Mr. Modi\u2019s biggest policy gambles \u2014 abruptly voiding most of the nation\u2019s currency and imposing a sweeping new sales tax \u2014 have slowed India\u2019s meteoric growth.\n\nNow that his economic strategy is losing its sheen, Mr. Modi may lean even more heavily on Hindu nationalism, a risky gambit as social tensions simmer, especially between Hindus and Muslims and among castes.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 President Trump\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital is seen by many as the death knell for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nAnd even the Palestine Liberation Organization is asking if that might not be such a bad idea. But Israeli and Palestinian visions of what that single state would look like are mutually exclusive.\n\nSeparately, the financial ties between Israel and Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law, continue to deepen, even with Mr. Kushner\u2019s diplomatic role in the Middle East.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 At almost twice the length of the U.S.-Mexico border, Australia\u2019s dingo fence is the longest in the world.\n\nThe idea is simple: to keep feral dogs and dingoes from getting to sheep farms on the other side of the wire.\n\nBut new research has raised questions about the fence\u2019s environmental impact, and new technology threatens to upend its traditional means of maintenance.\n\nMeanwhile, Sydney recorded its highest temperatures since 1939, with western areas hitting 117 degrees Fahrenheit, or 47 Celsius.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The Golden Globes are Sunday night, the first major Hollywood gathering since the explosive revelations last year of sexual assault and harassment. Now, a writer for The Times Magazine says, it must be rebuilt if the city is to survive, regardless of the cost.\n\n\u2022 A crimp in colleges\u2019 revenue\n\nMany U.S. universities that had put the 2008 recession behind them are making new rounds of budget cuts, in large part because they have fewer international students, who generally pay more in tuition.\n\nChanging conditions abroad and tougher immigration policies in the U.S. have contributed to the decline, college administrators say.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam\n\nThomas Monson, the president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, enlarged the ranks of female missionaries but rebuffed demands to ordain women as priests. The Mormon leader also refused to alter the church\u2019s position on same-sex marriage. He was 90.\n\nJohn Portman, an architect and developer, revolutionized hotel designs with soaring futuristic atriums and transformed cityscapes around the world. He was 93.\n\nRick Hall, a music producer, turned small-town Alabama into a crucible of soul, country, pop and rock with his studio in Muscle Shoals. He was 85.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nBack from vacation, Stephen Colbert returned to one of his favorite targets: President Trump.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cI was an amateur boxer in my youth, and I\u2019ve brought that fighting spirit with me to Washington. But every good fighter knows when to hang up the gloves. And for me, that time is soon approaching.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, who announced he would not seek an eighth term.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cCharlie Brown, Snoopy, Linus, Lucy \u2026 how can I ever forget them?\u201d\n\nThose were Charles M. Schulz\u2019s parting words in the final daily \u201cPeanuts\u201d comic strip, which ran 18 years ago today.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey recalled a slightly less sentimental line from the strip\u2019s debut, nearly 50 years earlier, in which a carefree Charlie Brown strolls by a pair of children.\n\n\u201cGood ol\u2019 Charlie Brown,\u201d one says. \u201cHow I hate him!\u201d\n\nThat juxtaposition of earnestness and wry humor made \u201cPeanuts\u201d a pop-culture mainstay for half a century, appearing in 75 countries and 21 languages at its peak.\n\nMr. Schulz insisted on producing every aspect of the comic, making himself inseparable from his characters.\n\n\u201cI want it to be my words in everything I do,\u201d he told The Times in 1967. \u201cI\u2019ve thought of it \u2014 hiring someone to help. Sometimes I think it would be nice. But then \u2014 what would be the point?\u201d\n\nWhen colon cancer forced Mr. Schulz to end the daily strip in 2000, at age 77, The Times invoked a dismal Charlie Brown, mourning the end of the baseball season: \u201cThere\u2019s a dreariness in the air that depresses me.\u201d\n\nMr. Schulz died a month later, but all 17,897 \u201cPeanuts\u201d strips were anthologized over the next two decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDan Sanchez contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. Read our profile of Ms. Laurio, above.\n\n\u2022 China\u2019s \u201cLos Alamos\u201d: Our correspondent visited the ruins of a city where Beijing once built a nuclear arsenal to defend Mao Zedong\u2019s revolution.\n\n\u2022 And up and away: A travel writer got a bird\u2019s-eye view of falconry while hot-air ballooning above Dubai.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nToday marks a big step for equality in the entertainment industry.\n\nMinnie Mouse is set to finally receive a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, 90 years after she was introduced and nearly 40 years after her longtime love interest, Mickey, received one in 1978, above.\n\nFirst voiced by Walt Disney himself, the characters made their debut in the 1928 animated short \u201cSteamboat Willie.\u201d\n\nMinnie went on to appear in more than 60 cartoon shorts, primarily in the 1930s, before becoming a perennial presence on television and at Disney\u2019s theme parks around the world.\n\nOriginally drawn wearing a pillbox hat, Minnie later sported a polka-dot bow on her head that matched her dress. \u201cMinnie: Style Icon,\u201d an exhibition at London Fashion Week in 2015, traced her influence over the decades.\n\nBut she has always dwelt in Mickey\u2019s shadow, the damsel to his leading man. In a 1934 essay titled \u201cMickey and Minnie,\u201d the British novelist E. M. Forster lamented: \u201cAbout Minnie too little has been said, and her name at the top of this article is an act of homage which ought to have been paid long ago.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother act of homage will come today in Hollywood, when she is honored with the 2,627th star on the Walk of Fame.\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.\n\nGood luck today.", "title": "North Korea, Syria, Women\u2019s Marches: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Mike Ives", "Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "After he recovered, he began going to markets and train stations on his crutches, begging and pilfering food.\n\nBut he said he never thought of deserting North Korea until 2000, when he made his way illegally to China. There, he was given food in churches and saw that \u201canimals in China were fed better than North Koreans.\u201d A month later, when he returned home with some food for his family, the secret police caught him and beat him for 20 days, he said.\n\n\u201cIt was not the beating that really hurt me,\u201d he said. \u201cOne of them said: \u2018You cripple, begging in China before foreign cameras! You are an embarrassment for the leader and the country.\u2019\n\n\u201cIt was then that I realized I had no future in North Korea.\u201d\n\nLater, he got in touch with a friend from his hometown who had made it to South Korea. He spoke to him on a cellphone that picked up Chinese signals near the border, and learned how much better conditions were in the other Korea. \u201cThey don\u2019t beat the handicapped in the South,\u201d he said his friend told him.\n\n\u201cI had never seen people with Down syndrome until I came to South Korea,\u201d Mr. Ji said. \u201cIn the North, they gather such people and keep them from public view.\u201d\n\nIn April 2006, Mr. Ji crossed the Tumen River into China one last time, nearly drowning when he lost his balance in a river swollen with snowmelt. His younger brother, who was fleeing the North with him, pulled him out.\n\nIn China, the brothers split up. Mr. Ji feared he would be a burden for his younger brother on the risky and difficult journey to South Korea.", "title": "North Korean Defector, Honored by Trump, Has a Remarkable Escape Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The art troupe would be larger than the previous six that North Korea has sent to South Korea since 1985. The North last sent such a group in 2002, when 30 North Korean singers and dancers performed in Seoul to celebrate Korea\u2019s liberation from Japanese colonial rule in 1945.\n\nScenes of young North Korean artists performing for South Korean audiences could have huge implications. They could be moments of rare inter-Korean reconciliation after a year of high tensions over the North\u2019s nuclear and long-range missile tests.\n\nPhoto\n\nOr the event could be a source of bitter controversy in the South, depending on what songs the North Korean artists perform.\n\nTo avoid having the orchestra performances become a political controversy, South Korean negotiators are expected to insist that the North Korean artists not sing songs or use stage props that would surely cause ire among South Koreans, including any references to, or images of, North Korean missiles.\n\nDuring the talks on Monday, the North promised to play traditional Korean folk songs that \u201cfit the mood for unification and are well known on both sides,\u201d as well as classical music, said the chief South Korean delegate, Lee Woo-sung. Mr. Lee said more discussions were expected to work out other details of North Korean performances.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
