Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe South Korean government said it hoped that the North Korean orchestra would \u201ccontribute to improving relations and recovering the cultural homogeneity.\u201d Both sides have not decided whether the North Koreans will hold any joint concerts with a South Korean orchestra.\n\nAfter years of denouncing the South as an American stooge, Mr. Kim, the North Korean leader, used his New Year\u2019s Day speech to propose a dialogue to discuss his country\u2019s participation in the Winter Olympics being held in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang beginning Feb. 7.\n\nSouth Korea quickly embraced the idea as a way to calm tensions and dispel fears of a possible war on the divided peninsula spurred by the North\u2019s nuclear and missile tests and President Trump\u2019s frequent threats to destroy the North should it pose harm to the Americans and their allies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn border talks held at Panmunjom last week, the two sides agreed that North Korea would send athletes and cheerleaders, as well as an art troupe, journalists and a taekwondo demonstration team. Working-level negotiators met at Panmunjom on Monday to sort out the details.\n\nThe South Korean government also said that the two Koreas had agreed in principle to field a joint women\u2019s ice hockey team. The International Olympic Committee is scheduled to discuss the proposal when it brings together Olympic officials from both Koreas in Switzerland on Saturday to discuss the North\u2019s last-minute decision to join the Olympics.\n\nIf approved, it would be the Koreas\u2019 first unified Olympic team ever and the first joint Korean team in an international sporting event since the two Koreas competed together in an international table tennis championship and a youth soccer tournament in 1991.", "title": "North Korean Orchestra Plans to Perform in South Korea During Winter Olympics", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 Barbed-wire steel gates on the heavily fortified border between North and South Korea swung open for the first time in two years on Sunday, allowing in an advance team of officials from the North, led by one of its most celebrated singers, to help plan for next month\u2019s Winter Olympics.\n\nThe visit by the seven-member North Korean delegation has been heralded as a thawing of tensions following a series of missile and nuclear tests by the North. The group will spend two days in South Korea to help prepare for cultural performances by North Korean singers, dancers and pop orchestra musicians during the Winter Olympics, which will be held in the South Korean mountain town of Pyeongchang.\n\nIn South Korean media, it was the North Korean singer, Hyon Song-wol, who stole the show. Nicknamed the \u201cgirl on a steed\u201d by South Koreans after her most popular song, Ms. Hyon was greeted with a media frenzy that South Korea usually reserves for one of its own K-pop stars.\n\nSouth Korean television crews tagged along, feeding live broadcasts, as a bus carrying Ms. Hyon\u2019s delegation and a police escort sped down the inter-Korean highway linking the two nations, which was temporarily reopened for their visit.", "title": "North Korean Pop Singer Leads Pre-Olympic Delegation to South", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 President Moon Jae-in of South Korea said on Friday that he would take a tougher line with North Korea than his progressive predecessors, vowing to strengthen the military even as the two Koreas agreed to start high-level talks next week.\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t be weak-kneed or just focus on dialogue, as we did in the past,\u201d Mr. Moon told leaders of the Korean Senior Citizens Association. \u201cI will push for dialogue and pursue peace, but will do so based on a strong national defense capability.\u201d\n\nIn inviting members of the association to the presidential residence, Mr. Moon was trying to lessen fears among older and conservative South Koreans that he might be conceding too much to the North as he doggedly champions talks. Such concerns have persisted even as Mr. Moon has moved to build more powerful missiles and get new weapons from the United States to counter the North\u2019s growing nuclear threat.\n\nConservative South Koreans remain deeply skeptical of the so-called Sunshine Policy of two previous progressive leaders, Kim Dae-jung and Roh Moo-hyun, who encouraged trade with the North and allowed large investment and aid shipments there in a belief that such largess would help North Korea open up and denuclearize.", "title": "North and South Korea Agree to Border Talks Next Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump has threatened the North with \u201cfire and fury like the world has never seen\u201d should it put the security of Americans and their allies at risk. Mr. Kim has called Mr. Trump a lunatic.\n\nThe Olympics agreement could help President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who has been pushing for dialogue and reconciliation with the North.\n\nFew expect that the breakthrough will lead to a quick breakthrough in the decades-old standoff over the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program. But it provided a welcome reprieve for South Koreans who have grown both alarmed and weary over the tensions and talks of possible war in the peninsula.\n\nThe news was welcomed by top officials at the United Nations, where Secretary General Ant\u00f3nio Guterres has said he plans to attend the opening ceremonies. The president of the General Assembly, Miroslav Lajcak of Slovakia, said on Twitter: \u201cHeartened by reports that Koreans from DPRK & RoK will march together in @Olympics opening ceremony.\u201d\n\nThe two countries also agreed on Wednesday that their skiing teams would train together in the Masikryong ski resort in North Korea. The resort, a showpiece project of the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, was opened in 2013.\n\nSouth Korean officials said on Wednesday that the North\u2019s delegation would include at least 550 people, including about 150 to the Paralympic Games in March. But the joint news statement said that the final number would be determined in Switzerland on Saturday, when the International Olympic Committee is to bring together North and South Korean officials. The plan is for the North\u2019s athletes to enter the South over a land border on Feb. 1.\n\nVideo\n\nSo far, the only North Korean athletes to qualify for the Pyeongchang Games are a pairs figure skating team. North Korea missed an Oct. 31 deadline to accept invitations from South Korea and the International Olympic Committee to join the Games. But the international body has said it remains willing to consider wild-card entries for North Korean athletes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA unified team of any kind at the Olympics would be a milestone for the Koreas, which have been bitter rivals in international sports as well as diplomacy and armed conflict, but which also have a history of trying to use sports as an avenue for reconciliation.\n\nMr. Moon proposed in June that the two Koreas form a unified team for the Pyeongchang Games, but the suggestion was not taken seriously until the Mr. Kim used his New Year\u2019s Day speech to propose dialogue with the South and to discuss his country\u2019s participation in the Olympics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat proposal led to a series of talks in Panmunjom between the two Korean governments. In an earlier round of negotiations, the North agreed to send a 140-member orchestra to play in the South during the Olympics.\n\nThe prospect of fostering inter-Korean reconciliation through sports and other channels has strong appeal in South Korea, so much so that successive governments have tried to negotiate sending a unified team to the Olympics.\n\nSuch efforts have sometimes led to breakthroughs. In 2000, the year of the first inter-Korean summit meeting, the countries\u2019 delegations marched together at the opening ceremony of the Sydney Olympics. They have marched together nine times, including in Athens in 2004, carrying a blue-and-white flag representing a united Korea, and at the 2006 Winter Olympics. The two Koreas last marched together in the Asian Winter Games of 2007.\n\nBut forming a joint Olympic team proved elusive. Past negotiations faltered over such details as whether a joint team would have an equal number of players from each country, who would choose the coaches and where the athletes would train.\n\nSouth Korean athletes, who have far more resources and Olympic experience than their counterparts from the North, have balked in the past at the idea of sacrificing their hard-earned prospects for the sake of parity with North Korea in a united team. South Korean news outlets have reported that the South asked the International Olympic Committee to allow a unified hockey team to have an expanded roster, so that none of the South Korean players would have to bow out of the Games.\n\nSouth Korea first sought to use sports to ease military tensions with the North back in the 1960s, proposing joint teams for international athletic events. But sports diplomacy has never led to a lasting political thaw on the Korean Peninsula, which has remained technically in a state of war since the 1950-53 Korean War was halted with a truce.\n\nThe two Koreas negotiated sharing some of the 1988 Seoul Olympics after South Korea won the right to play host to the Games. But the talks collapsed and the North bombed a South Korean passenger jet in 1987 in an attempt to disrupt the games in the South.\n\nInter-Korean sports and other exchanges increased between 1998 and 2008, when the leaders of the South were pushing their so-called Sunshine Policy of seeking reconciliation and easing political tensions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that period of d\u00e9tente, which gained momentum with the historic inter-Korean summit in 2000, unraveled as conservatives took power in the South in 2008. They withdrew from projects like a joint factory park in the North Korean town of Kaesong in response to the North\u2019s nuclear weapons pursuit and other acts the South considered provocative.", "title": "North and South Korean Teams to March as One at Olympics", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "OSLO \u2014 Norway\u2019s ruthlessly successful Alpine ski team is preparing for next month\u2019s Winter Olympics with a punishing training regimen of slaloms, weights and ice baths. So you would think that choosing what knitted woolly sweater to wear would be the easy bit.\n\nDesigned at a time when public interest in Viking culture is experiencing a renaissance, the theme for Norway\u2019s Alpine ski team uniforms this season is \u201cthe Attacking Viking,\u201d a homage to the team\u2019s nickname. But the sweater features a symbol known as the Tyr rune, which neo-Nazis want to claim as their own.\n\nThere is little evidence that the rune originally had any symbolic significance beyond its sound value, but the letter shares the name of a Norse deity popularly understood as the god of war, Tyr. Nowadays, most runologists consider it a letter no more mysterious than the letter T.\n\nEven so, the presence of the Tyr rune on the team\u2019s sweater design was enough to raise alarms. Norway\u2019s security police have warned of the rise of a small but politically extreme and potentially violent group called the Nordic Resistance Movement, which uses the Tyr rune in its branding.", "title": "Norway Ski Team\u2019s Sweater Gets Tangled in a Neo-Nazi Uproar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was on the M104 going up Broadway when a woman got on and sat down next to me. After a while, she answered her cellphone.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m on the bus right now,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d she said after a pause.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d she said, looking at me. \u201cHe answers that description.\u201d\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d she said after another pause. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t answer that description.\u201d\n\nI looked at her after she ended the call.\n\n\u201cMy friend asked me if I was sitting next to a man,\u201d she said. \u201cThen she asked me if he was well dressed and good looking. Finally, she asked me if he was 68.\u201d\n\nWe both laughed.\n\nThe bus stopped at 97th Street.\n\n\u201cBetter luck next time,\u201d I said as we got both off.", "title": "Not Quite Fitting the Description", "authors": ["Morton Lebow", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In this week\u2019s issue, Charles McGrath interviews Philip Roth about his career and America\u2019s strange political moment. In 1959, William Peden reviewed \u201cGoodbye, Columbus,\u201d Roth\u2019s first book and the one that would establish the young writer from Newark. Read an excerpt below:\n\nSome years ago, in the vanguard of the Southern literary renascence, Ellen Glasgow commented that what the South needed was \u201cblood and irony.\u201d The same might be said of some recent writers who have concerned themselves with depicting the role of the Jew in American society, which is the subject of Philip Roth\u2019s collection of short stories and a novella. An English instructor at the University of Chicago, 26-year-old Mr. Roth has published fiction in Harper\u2019s, The Paris Review, The New Yorker and other periodicals. \u201cGoodbye, Columbus,\u201d a Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship Award, is his first book, and an impressive one. There is blood here and vigor, love and hate, irony and compassion.\n\nMr. Roth\u2019s novella is a somewhat incongruous mingling of conventional boy-meets-girl material and portrait-of-the-intellectual-as-a-young-man, narrated with an occasional fondness for clinical detail reminiscent of Edmund Wilson\u2019s \u201cThe Princess With the Golden Hair.\u201d Young Neil Klugman meets beautiful, wealthy Brenda Patimkin, a Radcliffe undergraduate. Neil pursues Brenda with the determination of a well-trained bird dog, and soon catches her. After a summer love affair, he rejects Brenda and the nouveau-riche Patimkins with the smug self-righteousness of Joyce\u2019s Stephen Dedalus.\n\nSuch a summary, however, does justice neither to the author nor to his people; out of such hackneyed materials Mr. Roth has written a perceptive, often witty and frequently moving piece of fiction. He is a good story-teller, a shrewd appraiser of character and a keen recorder of an indecisive generation.\n\nMost of Mr. Roth\u2019s protagonists are, like Neil Klugman, adrift in a limbo between past and present. The author seems to know his people inside and out, whether he writes of a boy arguing the Virgin Birth with an exasperated rabbi, (\u201cThe Conversion of the Jews\u201d), or, in \u201cEli, the Fanatic,\u201d of a young Jewish lawyer trying to explain suburban mores to the leader of a rabbinical orphanage, or, in \u201cEpstein,\u201d of the ludicrous yet pitiable aftermath of an aging man\u2019s search for love. These stories, though concerned with universal, archetypal experiences, are somewhat transmuted into that which is at once strange and familiar. \u201cI\u2019m a Jew,\u201d one character says. \u201cI am different. Better, maybe not. But different.\u201d", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s cover considers the historical influence of books and literature. But with so many books, there\u2019s never enough time. In 1984, the Book Review asked a handful of writers, including Jean Strouse and Eudora Welty, about some of the \u201cgreat books\u201d they never finished. Read an excerpt below.\n\nJean Strouse, author of \u201cAlice James: A Biography.\u201d The book I\u2019ve often hauled along to beaches and mountains and have never managed to make much headway in is James Joyce\u2019s \u201cFinnegans Wake.\u201d I can\u2019t even say something clever about it now because I haven\u2019t ever got past page 20. I do remember the first time I heard its name. I was 15. My family lived in West Los Angeles, and I spent a lot of time that year browsing in local bookstores with a friend who seemed very sophisticated. In those bookstores I was drawn as if by pheromone to New Directions paperbacks \u2014 they had about them irresistible intimations of New York coffeehouses, French cigarettes, bare mattresses on cold floors and major depression. One day my learned friend pulled a volume called \u201cFinnegans Wake\u201d off the shelf and asked if I\u2019d read it. I tried to look knowing as I shook my head and temporized \u2014 \u201cNot yet\u201d \u2014 wondering why he of all people would be interested in a fat book about sailing.\n\nEudora Welty, author of \u201cOne Writer\u2019s Beginnings.\u201d It doesn\u2019t enter my mind not to finish reading a book I\u2019ve once started, whether it\u2019s a classic or any other kind. I persist and might do so out of habit alone, but the act of reading is itself vital to me and carries me along \u2014 it sparks its own hope and curiosity. Certainly disappointment comes along in the course of reading many a book, but this isn\u2019t fatal \u2014 if I may limit this to the reading of fiction. And then I should add that contemporary fiction keeps its hold on me till the end because of my sympathy as a writer for another writer\u2019s welfare. I once literally threw away a new novel I\u2019d brought along to read on a voyage to Europe, but not without finishing it first. Had I chucked that novel into the Atlantic without having read the whole of it through, I could have thought, \u201cThere but for the grace of God go I.\u201d", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s issue includes a review of a new book about Ezra Pound\u2019s 12-year stay at a federal psychiatric center. In 1922, long before his commitment, Richard Le Gallienne reflected on the polarizing poet and his collection, \u201cPoems 1918-21, Including Three Portraits and Four Cantos.\u201d Read an excerpt below:\n\nWhatever Mr. Ezra Pound\u2019s merits or frailties, no one who knows his work at all will deny him a sense of humor, a gift which he does not seem to have communicated either to his admirers, his non-admirers or even to his publishers \u2014 might properly report that on the \u201cjacket\u201d of a volume humor is out of place. There, of all places in the world, your author must be taken with the seriousness funeral. So that, after all, it is quite natural that on his own \u201cjacket\u201d Mr. Pound should figure as \u201cthe great international literary figure that he is.\u201d I think that Mr. Pound will smile at this description, though I may be doing him a wrong, for a man\u2019s sense of humor seldom extends to the recognition of the limitations of his own greatness. Mr. Pound, however, is not responsible for the lack of humor which seems to attend upon the mere mention of his name, with his admirers taking the form of abject ecstasy beneath his feet \u2014 after all, forgivable, as being constructive, tending, that is, toward that high appreciation of his work which is its just due; with his non-admirers taking the form of a foaming anger, blindly destructive and robbing the non-admirer himself of the benefit he might otherwise enjoy in open-mindedly approaching a writer whose work has so much rare pleasure to give us, vitalized as it is with beauty and romance \u2014 particularly with the romance of an enviable learning. I don\u2019t think Mr. Pound bothers a great deal either about his admirers or his non-admirers, though after the manner of his chief master, Robert Browning, he occasionally makes private fun in flouting the latter \u2014 \u201cyou British public \u2014 you who like me not\u201d \u2014 with his:\n\nNon-esteem of self-styled \u201chis betters\u201d Leading, as he well knew, To his final Exclusion from the world of letters.\n\nLike all serious artists, he writes primarily to amuse and please himself, knowing far better than his non-admirers his real \u201cletters,\u201d and bringing to them the homage of profound knowledge and creative imitation.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s cover reviews reflect on the state of the American Republic. In 1942, following a period of intense change and turmoil, Allan Nevins reviewed Henry Hazlitt\u2019s \u201cA New Constitution Now,\u201d which argued for a radical reconstruction of the nation. Read an excerpt below.\n\nThe American Republic plainly confronts a new era. The nation which emerges from the stormy events of our time \u2014 the Great Depression, the New Deal and the Second World War \u2014 will have undergone a drastic alteration. In many respects its economy, its social outlook and its political preconceptions will be completely transformed. To meet these changes in our ideas, activities and institutions the structure of our government will necessarily have to be modified. But should this modification be slow and moderate or rapid and profound? To this question, which we must all face, Mr. Hazlitt gives a bold and emphatic answer. He advocates a far-reaching reconstruction of our governmental system, and he calls for a new method of constitutional revision which will bring such reconstruction within easy reach. The boldness and thoroughness of Mr. Hazlitt\u2019s prescription are refreshing qualities.\n\nFor with Mr. Hazlitt the question is not whether we would gain by the change; the question is whether we can safely defer making it. Like the older writers, he thinks that the Presidential or balance-of-power system, with its rigidity, its frequent stalling, its elevation of second-rate men to power and its long interludes in which no real policymaking is attempted, was tolerable so long as the United States was half-empty, prosperous and well protected by broad oceans. But these happy conditions no longer exist. The nation is crowded, it is beset by fierce industrial and social problems, and its isolation has disappeared forever. It may be remembered that Bryce, in the eloquent closing pages of his \u201cAmerican Commonwealth,\u201d predicted that the United States would yet pass into the \u201cshadow belt,\u201d that, like the fog belt of the Grand Banks, had closed upon older ships of state. We are now in that shadow zone, dark, chilling and perilous. The nation will have to make its way henceforth amid omnipresent difficulties and recurrent crises; it needs, so Mr. Hazlitt intimates, an efficient coordination, a power of instant mobilization, which only the parliamentary system can consistently furnish.\n\nIn short, Mr. Hazlitt bids us drift no longer under the spell of our old Constitution worship but remodel our government with unflinching courage.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Many of the products featured at Colette have come along too: OnePlus 5T Android cellphones (\u20ac559), for example, an early best-seller since Nous opened, or rolling papers from Devambez for the stoner antiquarian of means (32 rolling papers and 32 paper tips, \u20ac85). (Maison Devambez is better known as a supplier of fine stationery and the like.) As Colette had a selection of magazines, so does Nous, as well as the Mizensir candles the store used to stock. Colette customers \u2014 Mr. Chapelle said many have already been by \u2014 might even recognize some of Colette\u2019s security guards at the door.\n\nBut Nous has less whimsy than Colette had, and less fashion, too. \u201cWe\u2019re more into streetwear,\u201d Mr. Chapelle said, taking a break from some notes scrawled, still, on a Colette pad, and a sleeker, harder edge and sound. (On the soundtrack: the English rapper J Hus and Drake.) The mix skews toward men\u2019s wear, though there are some women\u2019s pieces, and more to come.\n\n\u201cThis is not something that we wanted, to be the inheritors of Colette,\u201d Mr. Chapelle said. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to have that name on our shoulders.\u201d In fact, he added, \u201cThere would be no reason to do it if there was Colette.\u201d\n\nBut there isn\u2019t Colette, even if there is blessed memory, so Nous has sprung up on Rue Cambon, not far from its predecessor, and just down the block from the famous apartment (and shop) of Chanel. Mr. Chapelle recounted that a group from Chanel had already come in, lured by the sight of trompe l\u2019oeil art piece \u2014 of a Pharrell Williams sneaker designed in collaboration with Chanel and Adidas \u2014 carved from a single block of wood. For \u20ac5,000, Nous offers shoppers the opportunity to commission their own wooden sneaker, of any make and model.", "title": "Nous, a New Store, Picks Up Where Dearly Departed Colette Left Off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor sure, you know, we took risk,\u201d Monfils said, talking about health risks, not forehands down the line.\n\nBut Monfils, like so many others around the grounds on Thursday, managed to reach the finish even if Djokovic ended up the winner for the 15th time in their 15 matches, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1, 6-3.\n\nThere was a time, increasingly long ago, when Djokovic might have been the more vulnerable man on such a scorcher. Early in his career, before he changed his diet and underwent sinus surgery, he was the one who frequently wilted in the heat.\n\nDjokovic acknowledged the school of thought that tennis players train to be able to sustain these kinds of conditions and should be rewarded. Jim Courier, when he won the 1993 Australian Open over Stefan Edberg on a torrid afternoon before there was an official heat policy, said he actually threatened not to play if officials closed the roof.\n\n\u201cI was never a big fan of playing in the heat, but I knew that it was advantageous for me versus some opponents,\u201d Courier said on Thursday. \u201cIt was a matter of hating it less than my opponent.\u201d\n\nBut Courier likes that the tournament referee has an official policy to work with now along with some latitude if common sense becomes a better guide. Djokovic made it clear that there was a limit to what players should be asked to suffer \u2014 a balance between needing to be fit and avoiding health risks.\n\nWas that limit reached on Thursday?\n\n\u201cIt was right at the limit,\u201d he said before alluding to the business decisions made to guarantee that the show goes on. \u201cOur sport has become an industry, like most of the other global sports. It\u2019s more business than a sport. At times I mind that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAustralian Open officials would argue that competitive fairness is also a factor. Close the roofs and the stars on the show courts get to play under cover while hoi polloi have to wait or play in the heat when play is again authorized.\n\nBut there should be no debate that Djokovic\u2019s victory on Thursday was a tribute to his fitness in his first tournament after an extended injury break. It also was a tribute to his will, which was in question for the second half of 2016 and the first half of 2017. That was before his still-unspecified right elbow injury forced him to spend four months without a racket in his hand and six months off the tour.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNovak looks good to me,\u201d Roger Federer said after beating Jan-Lennard Struff, 6-4, 6-4, 7-6 (4), in the comparative chill of the evening session to set up a third-round match with Richard Gasquet. \u201cIt was more a battle of the weather today, so it\u2019s difficult to judge exactly because it was not normal conditions; not easy to see if Novak\u2019s changed something tactically.\n\n\u201cBut what I see is a strong Novak who knew how to manage the weather and find solutions in the toughest second round of the tournament, in my view. There were others, but Ga\u00ebl, with his abilities and having just won Doha, it was a real test, and Novak passed it after starting poorly, very poorly, to be honest.\u201d\n\nIt is hard to remember a shakier start for Djokovic, who double-faulted on the first two points and twice more in his second service game, spraying backhands and forehands into all the wrong places as he fell behind, 0-3.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNervous start,\u201d said Djokovic, whose revamped serve is designed to protect his elbow. \u201cI wasn\u2019t really comfortable at the very beginning. I can\u2019t blame conditions for my double faults. I mean, it\u2019s still that motion I\u2019m kind of getting used to. Being rusty at the beginning is something that you can also expect. I just have to accept it, embrace it.\u201d\n\nIt was soon back to 3-3, however, and though Monfils, taking uncharacteristic risks to shorten the points and the suffering, managed to win the set, he was soon just trying to manage. He pleaded to have more than 25 seconds between points and poured water over his head without bothering to drink it.\n\nAt least there were no hallucinations of the sort the Canadian player Frank Dancevic experienced in the extreme heat wave at the 2014 Australian Open. He had visions of Snoopy shortly before fainting midmatch in the first round and then going on to defeat.\n\n\u201cUntil somebody dies, they\u2019re going to keep playing matches in this heat,\u201d Dancevic said then.\n\nThe heat policy here was designed with considerable medical input, and as much as Melbourne Park felt like a Finnish sauna on Thursday, there were no retirements in any singles match.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt can certainly get hotter, and it may on Friday with temperatures forecast to rise above 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit).\n\n\u201cGood luck for the guys,\u201d Monfils said. \u201cHonestly, good luck for the guys.\u201d\n\nThe men have been talking about much more than the weather here this year. With his return to the circuit, Djokovic, the president of the ATP Player Council, has also been initiating discussions on prize money hikes and the merits of unionization.\n\nFederer, a former president of the council, played a pivotal role in persuading the Grand Slam tournaments to raise prize money in the early 2010s. He was in attendance at the mandatory players meeting last Friday in Melbourne where Djokovic broached some of these topics.\n\nFederer was asked very late on Thursday night whether he believed the Grand Slams were devoting a sufficient percentage of their revenue to prize money.\n\nHe looked a touch world-weary as he answered.\n\n\u201cThey could definitely pay more, no doubt about it,\u201d he said. \u201cThey know that. We\u2019re not partners. We\u2019re just players. It\u2019s always hard to rally. We had a good agreement, in my opinion. That made the Grand Slams happy, the players pretty happy. Seems like that has run its course.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThe moment that happens, there\u2019s not the same increases anymore, so players have to rally, get back together again, put in the effort. The Grand Slams know that. They will only react when we do so. We\u2019re ready to do it. It\u2019s going to be the same process over and over again. It\u2019s a bit boring, to be honest, always having to ask for stuff. If you look at the revenue, the sharing process, it\u2019s not quite where it\u2019s supposed to be.\u201d\n\nHe also said he was encouraged that the players were communicating with one another again. \u201cWhen the players don\u2019t talk, nothing gets done,\u201d he said.\n\nIt was a day for cold water at Melbourne Park, but if ATP or Grand Slam officials had hoped that Federer, the elder statesman, would throw plenty of it on Djokovic\u2019s activism, they were disappointed.\n\nBoring does not quite seem the best word to describe the situation. Or this tournament.\n\nBring on the heat.", "title": "Novak Djokovic Passes Heat Test at the Australian Open", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "That question mark hardly applies to Djokovic alone in this injury-riddled phase in men\u2019s tennis. His next opponent in Melbourne, the Frenchman Ga\u00ebl Monfils, is also coming back from an extended layoff. So is one of Djokovic\u2019s biggest rivals, Stan Wawrinka, the Swiss star who also had not played an official match since Wimbledon and is still in contention in Djokovic\u2019s quarter of the draw after winning his first-round encounter on Tuesday with Ricardas Berankis.\n\n\u201cI still have some pain,\u201d said Wawrinka, who underwent two operations to repair cartilage in his left knee last summer. \u201cIt depends on the way I\u2019m moving, how I push on it. In general, it\u2019s going the right direction. That\u2019s the best news.\u201d\n\nThat Wawrinka is 32 years old, Monfils 31 and Djokovic 30 only makes the outcome more uncertain, even if Federer, now 36, continues to seem immune to the passage of time and zipped through his opening match at Melbourne Park on Tuesday night, a 6-3, 6-4, 6-3 defeat of Aljaz Bedene.\n\nStill, it seems best to enjoy the spectacle and Federer\u2019s leaping, no-look overheads while they last. It is all just a bad back away from turning into nostalgia.\n\nFederer knows this, and he drank it all in as he returned to Rod Laver Arena, where he experienced one of the biggest buzzes of his long career last year by defeating his friendly archrival Rafael Nadal in a five-set thriller of a final.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s big emotions to be back out there,\u201d Federer said. \u201cWhen I returned for the first time to train, you remember where the ball more or less bounced and what side of the court you were on. You relive those moments, and when I saw the people and the full stadium when I went on court tonight, I really celebrate it as a player to be able to be in good health and to come back again.\u201d\n\nDjokovic also seemed intent on savoring what was no longer routine at the tournament where he has won a record-tying six singles titles, the most recent in 2016 when he was on his way to winning four straight Grand Slam titles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWell, I did have various emotions, mostly good ones: excitement, joy, gratitude for being able to have an opportunity to compete,\u201d Djokovic said on Tuesday. \u201cBut I did feel nerves, and I did feel a bit skeptical whether I\u2019m going to be able to continue playing as well as I have the last couple weeks in the practice sessions. But I thought I controlled it well.\u201d\n\nHe has not made his life simpler by reportedly deciding to use the forum of the ATP player meeting last Friday in Melbourne to discuss the possibilities of unionizing and applying greater pressure on tournaments to devote a greater percentage of their revenue to prize money.\n\nFor now the ATP Tour remains an organization that represents both the players and the tournaments. Britain\u2019s Daily Mail reported that Djokovic, the president of the ATP player council, had asked non-players to leave the meeting room at the Sofitel hotel in order for the players to deliberate in private.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve taken things out of the context,\u201d Djokovic said on Tuesday at a news conference packed with reporters. \u201cI saw that you\u2019ve portrayed me as someone who is very greedy, asks for more money and wants to boycott. But I respect your, you know, freedom and decisions to do that. But not much of what you have wrote is true.\u201d\n\nDjokovic said there was no discussion on his part of a future Australian Open boycott and no push to unionize, just an exchange of ideas.\n\n\u201cIt was subjects that we never get a chance to talk about in such a large group,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s all it was. Never have I intentionally thrown anybody out of the room. Everything was done in a very normal, polite way.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany players have declined to discuss the meeting during the first two days of the Australian Open, often citing the desire to focus on their matches. But others, including Djokovic\u2019s Serbian compatriot Victor Troicki, have expressed interest in a union as a way of increasing the players\u2019 bargaining power and capacity to make change.\n\nATP executives remain on alert, and some privately expressed dismay at not being informed in advance of Djokovic\u2019s desire to create a players-only discussion during a general meeting.\n\nWhat is clear is that Djokovic, with the longest layoff of his career, has had an unusual amount of downtime to consider the bigger picture in his faction-ridden sport.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also has made several changes in his extended layoff. He added the newly retired Czech player Radek Stepanek to a coaching team that already included Andre Agassi.\n\nDjokovic said he also made modifications to his racket without specifying precisely what they were. He has changed shoe models and manufacturers, too, explaining that he was searching for the ideal fit for his playing style, which includes plenty of sliding on hard courts.\n\n\u201cThat was a big step for me, and I needed to be 100 percent sure before actually doing it,\u201d he told Serbian reporters of the shoe decision. \u201cI knew this break that I\u2019ve had is ideal for that sort of thing.\u201d\n\nPerhaps most importantly he has abbreviated his service motion in an attempt to relieve pressure on his right elbow. He no longer drops his racket head nearly as low in the take-back.\n\nIt worked well on Tuesday, and his average first-serve speed of 116 miles per hour was similar to his numbers here in 2016. But what was potentially disquieting was that he lost velocity on his serve on Tuesday as the match progressed. In 2016, according to data provided by Tennis Australia\u2019s Game Insight Group, his average speed remained much more stable or even increased in his final six matches.\n\nMachar Reid, innovation catalyst at Tennis Australia who did his doctoral thesis on the serve, said that there was also some evidence to suggest that an abbreviated service motion might create more load on the shoulder.\n\nBut Djokovic, at least on Tuesday, sounded encouraged. \u201cI\u2019m very happy with the second serve; first serve was kind of up and down,\u201d he said. \u201cAll in all, I\u2019m quite pleased. I know that it\u2019s going to take a little bit of time for me to kind of work my way in and get used to the specific changes that I\u2019ve made in my service motion. It wasn\u2019t ideal, but it was still good. I\u2019m looking forward to work on it more.\u201d\n\nNext under-pressure opportunity: Thursday in the heat against Monfils, who is 0-14 against Djokovic. Despite winning the title in Doha, Qatar, to start the year, Monfils is deeply resistant to the theory that Djokovic\u2019s layoff presents the best opportunity to finally get on the board.\n\n\u201cLook, I\u2019m not playing as well as when I\u2019m in form,\u201d Monfils said. \u201cAnd already when I am in form, I have trouble beating him, so imagine the situation now. We keep talking about him, him, him. We\u2019ve got to stop. The guy is a champion. He\u2019s back, and if he\u2019s back, that means he\u2019s ready to compete.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt remains much less likely, however, that he is ready to steal a page from Federer\u2019s 2017 storybook and win the Australian Open after a six-month layoff.", "title": "Novak Djokovic Wins After an Injury Layoff, but Questions Remain", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Christie will probably never shake free of the scandal known as Bridgegate, the 2013 plot by some of his underlings to shut down lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge to make life miserable for the Democratic mayor of Fort Lee and his constituents. In recent weeks, for the umpteenth time, the governor insisted he had nothing to do with that outrage. \u201cIt\u2019s insulting to me that people think I would participate in something like that,\u201d he told Times reporters in an interview before the new year.\n\nHe simply doesn\u2019t get it. Those minions would never have dared to gleefully inflict pain on a municipality if they believed for a second that doing so would displease the boss. That they thought the traffic nightmare they created would tickle Mr. Christie says as much about him as it does about them.\n\nEnduring memories of his tenure will be of those traffic jams, of the governor happily sunning himself last July on a beach that was closed to the public during a budget dispute, of Mr. Christie standing almost worshipfully behind Mr. Trump during the 2016 campaign like a footman out of \u201cDownton Abbey.\u201d\n\nBeing so dutiful brought him no reward in the form of a top administration post. But this isn\u2019t that day.", "title": "Opinion | Now Chris Christie Is Just a Bad Memory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Over the course of each year, people have many kinds of interactions and experience many kinds of mistreatment. But there is something unique about positive or negative touch. Emotional touch alters the heart and soul in ways that are mostly unconscious. It can take a lifetime of analysis to get even a glimpse of understanding.\n\nFor this reason, cultures all around the world have treated emotional touching as something apart. The Greeks labeled the drive to touch with the word \u201ceros,\u201d and they meant something vaster and deeper than just sexual pleasure. \u201cAnimals have sex and human beings have eros, and no accurate science is possible without making this distinction,\u201d Allan Bloom observed.\n\nThe Abrahamic religions also treat sex as something sacred and beautiful when enveloped in loving and covenantal protections, and as something disordered and potentially peace-destroying when not.\n\nOver the past 100 years or so, advanced thinkers across the West have worked to take the shame out of sex, surely a good thing. But they\u2019ve also disenchanted it. As Elizabeth Bruenig wrote in The Washington Post this week, \u201cOne of the principal outcomes of the sexual revolution was to establish that sex is just like any other social interaction \u2014 nothing taboo or sacred about it.\u201d Sex is seen as a shallow physical and social thing, not a heart and soul altering thing.\n\nOne unintended effect of this disenchantment is that it becomes easy to underestimate the risks inherent in any encounter. The woman who talked in an online article about her date with Aziz Ansari is being criticized because what happened to her was not like what happened to the victims of Harvey Weinstein and Louis C.K. There was no workplace power dynamic and no clear violation of consent. The assumption seems to be that as long as there\u2019s consent between adults, everything else is kosher.", "title": "Opinion | Now Is the Time to Talk About the Power of Touch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNobody wants to be seen with me right now,\u201d the performer, known as Stormy Daniels, said in a brief interview, laughing softly behind an assemblage of nude pictures of herself. That plan is simply a recommendation to the governor, who can reject any or all of it. As a result, it is widely seen as merely a starting point for months of negotiations to forge a politically palatable agreement that could turn congestion pricing into a reality.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got a big fight ahead in Albany,\u201d said Alec J. Slatky, the government relations liaison for AAA Northeast, which will push for lower bridge tolls and money for roads and bridges. \u201cWe\u2019re going to make sure the legislators get the perspective of the drivers who are going to be funding this plan if it passes.\u201d\n\nGene Russianoff, an attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a transportation advocacy group, said that such horse-trading was a normal part of how policy gets made in New York. \u201cIf you think you have a good idea, you\u2019re not going to sit back and twiddle your thumbs,\u201d he said.\n\nHe pointed to former Gov. Bloomberg faltered in Albany before coming to a vote.", "title": "Now the Real Work Begins on a Manhattan Congestion Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe number of New York City public school students taking the SATs shot up last year, after the city offered the test free during the school day.\n\nThe city\u2019s education department said that 61,800 high school juniors took the test last year, a 51 percent increase from the year before.\n\nWith its program, which gave all juniors the chance to take the free test last spring, New York City has become part of a movement to widen the pool of students taking the SAT or its competitor, the ACT. Kentucky and Wisconsin offer the ACT to all juniors in high school. The idea is that by making these tests a default, more students will participate. Traditionally, students would pay for the test and take it on a weekend.\n\n\u201cFor too many of our kids, the SAT, which they need to go to college, was something they had never even heard of,\u201d said the schools chancellor, Carmen Fari\u00f1a, standing in The Hamilton Grange School, a middle school in Manhattan, wearing a gray and purple New York University sweatshirt. \u201cWe should not be making this difficult. We should be making this as easy as possible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPhil Weinberg, the deputy chancellor whom Ms. Fari\u00f1a credited as the person responsible for the initiative, said the city paid about $2.2 million to make the SAT free to every student who wanted to take it \u2014 Ms. Fari\u00f1a said that even some students at the Rikers Island jail complex participated last year. Students signing up for the SAT themselves would pay $46, though those from low-income families can get the fee waived; the city pays a discounted rate of $36, a department spokesman said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Fari\u00f1a described the initiative as one way to help close the pernicious achievement gap between black and Hispanic students and their white and Asian peers. Last year, the participation gap on the college tests between those groups narrowed. Nearly 75 percent of black juniors took the SAT last year, the city said, up from 47 percent the year before. Eighty-three percent of white juniors took the test last year as did 89 percent of Asian juniors.\n\nBut there remained a divide in how they performed. Black juniors scored an average 449 points on the math, 100 points lower than their white peers. Wow,\u201d Mr. Letterman announced in a trailer.", "title": "Obama Announced as First Guest on New Letterman Talk Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nType 2 diabetes is almost twice as common in African-Americans as it is in whites. Obesity, rather than racial factors, is to blame, a new study in JAMA reports.\n\nResearchers began with 4,251 black and white men and women ages 18 to 30 who were not diabetic. They then followed up with periodic interviews and health examinations over an average of 25 years. Compared to whites, black men were 67 percent more likely, and black women almost three times as likely, to develop diabetes.\n\nWhen they controlled for a long list of modifiable risk factors \u2014 fasting glucose, body mass index, waist circumference, blood pressure, blood lipids, location of residence, socioeconomic status and more \u2014 the difference in diabetes incidence between the races disappeared. The key cause, the researchers determined, is obesity, which is tied to all of these risk factors.\n\n\u201cThe benefit of capturing these behaviors over time is that we can study how the accumulation of unhealthy risk factors contributes to the development of diabetes,\u201d said the senior author, Mercedes R. Carnethon, an associate professor of preventive medicine at Northwestern University. \u201cModifiable risk factors matter. The answer is simple, but the strategy to achieve change is complicated.\u201d", "title": "Obesity Is the Main Contributor to Diabetes in Blacks and Whites", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump gave firm instructions in March to the White House\u2019s top lawyer: stop the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, from recusing himself in the Justice Department\u2019s investigation into whether Mr. Trump\u2019s associates had helped a Russian campaign to disrupt the 2016 election.\n\nPublic pressure was building for Mr. Sessions, who had been a senior member of the Trump campaign, to step aside. But the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, carried out the president\u2019s orders and lobbied Mr. Sessions to remain in charge of the inquiry, according to two people with knowledge of the episode.\n\nMr. McGahn was unsuccessful, and the president erupted in anger in front of numerous White House officials, saying he needed his attorney general to protect him. He was 90.\n\nHis death was announced by the Norwegian government, which said the cause was prostate cancer.\n\nMr. Nordli, a career Labor Party politician who was prime minister from 1976 to 1981, supported full-employment programs and increased social welfare services while presiding over the expansion of Norway\u2019s offshore oil production. In 1977, a blowout of a well disgorged tens of thousands of gallons of oil into the North Sea.\n\nBut it was his actions as a staunch supporter of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and as an advocate of heightened military security in Europe that largely alienated him from his party\u2019s left wing. Opponents said his decision to let the United States store heavy weapons near the Soviet border would only increase tensions with Moscow.\n\nHe resigned in 1981, citing health problems. Doctors had advised him to take a two-month break from politics, he said at the time, but he concluded that resignation would better serve his party\u2019s interests.", "title": "Odvar Nordli, a Cold War Leader of Norway, Dies at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The people who are most disturbed by such theological contortions are earnest evangelicals who fear the disgrace of their religion. Trump\u2019s religious champions, Michael Gerson writes in The Washington Post, are \u201cassociating evangelicalism with bigotry, selfishness and deception. They are playing a grubby political game for the highest of stakes: the reputation of their faith.\u201d\n\nI sympathize with his distress. But the politicized sectors of conservative evangelicalism have been associated with bigotry, selfishness and deception for a long time. Trump has simply revealed the movement\u2019s priorities. It values the preservation of traditional racial and sexual hierarchies over fuzzier notions of wholesomeness.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve resisted throughout my career the notion that evangelicals are racist, I really have,\u201d Balmer told me. \u201cBut I think the 2016 election demonstrated that the religious right was circling back to the founding principles of the movement. What happened in 2016 is that the religious right dropped all pretense that theirs was a movement about family values.\u201d\n\nThis is one reason I find it hard to take seriously religious conservatives who say they are being persecuted for their defense of traditional marriage. People who are sympathetic to Christian, conservative Trump supporters \u2014 even if they don\u2019t support Trump themselves \u2014 will say that they\u2019ve been backed into a corner by the expansion of civil rights laws and policies protecting gay people. As they see it, liberals not only won the culture war on gay marriage but now are also demanding that private redoubts of resistance be brought into line.\n\nReferring to the Supreme Court\u2019s 2015 gay-marriage decision, Rod Dreher, a social-conservative Trump critic, wrote, \u201cPost-Obergefell, Christians who hold to the biblical teaching about sex and marriage have the same status in culture, and increasingly in law, as racists.\u201d\n\nDreher obviously thinks they deserve much better. He sees a fundamental difference between Christians who thought their religious freedom was trampled by desegregation and Christians who think their religious freedom is trampled when their business and charities have to serve gay people.\n\nBut it seems absurd to ask secular people to respect the religious right\u2019s beliefs about sex and marriage \u2014 and thus tolerate a degree of anti-gay discrimination \u2014 while the movement\u2019s leaders treat their own sexual standards as flexible and conditional. Christian conservatives may believe strongly in their own righteousness. But from the outside, it looks as if their movement was never really about morality at all.", "title": "Opinion | Of Course the Christian Right Supports Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPolice officers in the Bronx fatally shot a man who was holding a knife and chasing his landlord in the street on Monday evening, the authorities said.\n\nThe landlord called the police at about 7:40 p.m. to report that one of his tenants had a knife and was threatening him outside his apartment in the Belmont neighborhood of the Bronx. When the first two officers arrived, they found the tenant, a 52-year-old man, running after his landlord in the 2100 block of Prospect Avenue, at 180th Street.\n\nThe officers, who are partners, came about 10 feet from the man and ordered him at least five times to drop the knife, Rodney Harrison, the New York Police Department\u2019s chief of patrol, said at a news conference Monday night. The man did not drop the knife, and when he turned toward the officers, both fired their weapons, Chief Harrison said.\n\nThe man was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. It was unclear how many times he had been shot. His name has not been released. The landlord was not harmed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe police said they had recovered a partly serrated knife with a black handle from the scene.\n\nBoth officers, who are assigned to the 48th Precinct, had the episode captured on their body cameras, Chief Harrison said.
