Baxley, said he was surprised to see officers invoke it, and even a lawyer for one of the officers who claimed Stand Your Ground said the law should be changed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe police are already authorized to use force when they perceive danger, and even in highly disputed cases they usually avoid facing charges.\n\nStand Your Ground gives them an additional chance to do so, if they can persuade a judge. \u201cA police officer has full immunity under the law if he uses deadly force appropriately,\u201d said David I. Schoen, a lawyer for the family of one of the police shooting victims. \u201cYou can\u2019t also give him Stand Your Ground.\u201d\n\nLast week, lawyers notified the court that Nouman K. Raja, a former Palm Beach Gardens police officer, intended to seek Stand Your Ground protection in the 2015 killing of Corey Jones, a 31-year-old musician and housing inspector. Mr. Jones was waiting on the side of the road in a broken-down car when Mr. Raja, in plain clothes and an unmarked vehicle, approached him in the middle of the night without identifying himself.\n\nMr. Jones had a new gun which he bought because he frequently carried cash on his way home from gigs. The officer claimed Mr. Jones pointed it at him, but prosecutors say Mr. Raja fired at Mr. Jones six times even as he fled, hitting him three times.\n\nThe encounter was recorded by the roadside assistance service Mr. Jones had called for help.\n\nMr. Raja, a rookie in the department, was fired. His Stand Your Ground hearing has been scheduled for March, when prosecutors must present a mini-trial before the judge, who will decide whether to dismiss the charges.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe hearing gives defendants a chance to beat the charges before trial. Prosecutors have argued that officers already have immunity for lawful shootings under a different law that specifically addresses law enforcement.\n\nIn a court motion, the Florida attorney general\u2019s office said police officers should not be allowed to get protection from both laws. Victims\u2019 families have also objected.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s very sad that police officers are taking advantage of that law, especially when they are in the wrong,\u201d said Mr. Jones\u2019s father, Clinton Jones Sr. \u201cI think it\u2019s a disgrace to the police department.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBenjamin L. Crump, the family\u2019s lawyer, said the case \u201crisks a terrible precedent.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo extend it to police officers on the street gives them a license to kill just by saying they felt fear \u2014 no standards, no objective check and balance,\u201d Mr. Crump said.\n\nMr. Raja\u2019s lawyer, Richard Lubin, declined to comment while the case is pending.\n\nHe was not the first to try the defense. A judge granted the Stand Your Ground claim of Mr. Schwartzreich\u2019s client, Broward Sheriff\u2019s Deputy Peter Peraza, in the 2013 killing of Jermaine McBean. Mr. McBean, 33, was walking down the street, wearing earbuds and with an air rifle propped on his shoulders, when Mr. Peraza ordered him from behind to drop it.\n\nThe officer claimed that Mr. McBean pointed the air rifle at him, although witnesses disputed his account. After a hearing, a judge ruled in Mr. Peraza\u2019s favor and dismissed the case.\n\nThe Fourth District Court of Appeal upheld the ruling, but because the decision was in direct conflict with another appeals court ruling, the case is headed to the Florida Supreme Court.\n\nIn 2012, the Second District Court of Appeal rejected an officer\u2019s use of the law to avoid trial for stomping on a 63-year-old man. Juan Caamano, a former police officer in Haines City, south of Orlando, instead went to trial and was acquitted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast summer, two Miami police officers successfully invoked Stand Your Ground immunity when they were sued for damages in the beating of a man in a wheelchair.\n\nEven Mr. Caamano\u2019s lawyer said police officers should not be allowed to invoke Stand Your Ground.\n\nLocal judges often have ties to law enforcement or are reluctant to rule against police officers for political reasons, the lawyer, Lawrence H. Collins, said.\n\n\u201cWhat it does in the case of police officers is it puts a decision of whether an action was justified in the hands of a judge rather than a jury,\u201d he said. \u201cThe law needs to be changed. You don\u2019t want that decision in the hands of a judge.\u201d", "title": "Officers in Florida Shootings Say They Can Stand Their Ground, Too", "authors": ["Frances Robles"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The administrative services agency was at the center of several cases that drew scrutiny from federal investigators, including that of Mr. Singh and another case involving the procurement of mint-scented trash bags meant to repel rats. Investigators ultimately brought no charges.\n\nMs. Turnbull, a veteran civil servant, was in charge of the Office of Citywide Procurement in 2015, when the city signed a contract to buy millions of dollars of the mint-scented bags for the Parks Department. The purchase occurred after the owner of the company that made the bags, Joseph Dussich, contributed $100,000 to a nonprofit group established by the mayor to support his agenda.\n\nPhoto\n\nA year later, federal investigators started asking questions, and in July 2016, Ms. Turnbull was told that lawyers for Mr. de Blasio wanted to speak with the employees involved in the trash bag contract, according to the lawsuit.\n\nOne of those employees, it said, was a subordinate of Ms. Turnbull\u2019s who acted as a contracting officer.\n\nAccording to the lawsuit, some time after he met with lawyers for the mayor, the contracting officer informed Ms. Turnbull that he had a job offer from another city agency and wanted a substantial raise to remain at the administrative services department. In September 2016, Ms. Turnbull said she was instructed by a senior official to offer the supervisor a large raise; she objected, saying that it violated city guidelines for employee pay increases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe agency\u2019s commissioner, Lisette Camilo, nonetheless quickly approved the raise, increasing the contracting officer\u2019s pay to $132,500, an increase of nearly 20 percent, the lawsuit says.\n\nThe court papers said that Ms. Turnbull persisted in raising objections to Ms. Camilo and another senior official, telling them that the pay increase appeared to be \u201ca quid pro quo reward to him\u201d for somehow \u201cprotecting\u201d the de Blasio administration during the federal probe.\n\nThen in February 2017 Ms. Turnbull was demoted to the job of procurement analyst and her salary cut to $91,169 from $199,000, according to the lawsuit.\n\nSamuel O. Maduegbuna, a lawyer for Ms. Turnbull, said he had no direct evidence that the supervisor protected the mayor during the trash bag investigation, but said there is strong circumstantial evidence, characterizing the timing of the raise as \u201cvery suspicious.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKimberly Joyce, a spokeswoman for the city\u2019s law department, said in a written statement, \u201cThis raise was based on merit, something these claims lack.\u201d", "title": "Official Sues City Claiming Retaliation Tied to Inquiry of Mayor", "authors": ["William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "We thought a lot about the No. 1 choice \u2014 ultimately selecting New Orleans, on the occasion of its 300th birthday (see the item by yours truly, the project\u2019s coordinating editor) \u2014 and tried to make sure there was a little something for every type of traveler through the rest of the list, providing a geographic and thematic mix.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo what about that 52 Places Traveler? It\u2019s an idea that has been percolating for the last couple of years, but always seemed too daunting to pull off. This year, we finally posted the job. We expected a passionate response from a group of inveterate travelers \u2014 but I can\u2019t say we expected 13,000 submissions.\n\nA team of four, including myself, divided up the applications and took at least a glancing look at all of them, diving into the ones we thought showed the most promise. Over many multi-hour sessions, we narrowed the list to 139 people \u2014 including a father-daughter team and Buzz Bissinger, the author of \u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d \u2014 and asked each to send a video introduction, as well as a sample video story from the road for posting to Instagram.\n\nWe narrowed the list further, to six finalists. One is an editor at a major travel magazine. Another works as a breaking news videographer for a TV network. Another is a lawyer-turned-journalist. (Mr. Bissinger, sadly, did not make the cut, though his submission video was as compelling as one would expect.)\n\nA team of folks from around the newsroom \u2014 representing the Travel section, the video department and the photo department \u2014 met with those applicants either in person or by video chat. All were impressive \u2014 indeed, any one of them could have done the job.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut in the end, we decided on Jada Yuan. Jada is not a professional travel journalist, but she possesses some of those skills. As a writer at New York magazine for the last decade, she has profiled plenty of celebrities, but she has also parachuted into film festivals and presidential conventions \u2014 each time having to find her footing in a new place. She knows how to locate interesting people to talk to. And she knows how to insert herself into a piece in a way that is both personal and insightful (take, for example, her article for Cosmopolitan magazine on trying to date in six U.S. cities).\n\nWe\u2019re trying to connect Jada with a few of the applicants who made the first cut. Jamie Lafferty, a travel writer from Glasgow (No. 10 on the places list) has kindly offered to be her guide to his hometown, and we\u2019re going to take him up on that. We\u2019re hoping that other applicants will do the same.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJada starts her journey around the world in New Orleans in less than two weeks. She won\u2019t be doing the list sequentially \u2014 that would be, well, insane (try getting from No. 6 rural Chile to No. 7 South Korea, for example). So after New Orleans, she heads to a few other cities in the southern United States, then farther south to the Caribbean and Latin America. We can\u2019t wait to tag along with her.", "title": "Oh, the 52 Places She\u2019ll Go", "authors": ["Dan Saltzstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "An Ohio teacher who told a black eighth grader that his friends would \u201clynch\u201d him if he didn\u2019t finish his work has been put on leave, the school district said, calling the student a \u201chero\u201d for standing up to her.\n\nThe 13-year-old student, Nathan Bell, was chatting with his friends at Mason Middle School in Mason, Ohio, about 25 miles north of Cincinnati, on Dec. 4 when his social studies teacher became frustrated, his mother, Tanisha Agee-Bell, said in a phone interview on Sunday.\n\nThe teacher told Nathan, who was the only black student in the class, that \u201cif he didn\u2019t get back on task, then his friends were going to form an angry mob and lynch him,\u201d Ms. Agee-Bell said. Nathan responded that her comment was racist, and the teacher, Renee Thole, \u201ckept asking him why,\u201d Ms. Agee-Bell said.\n\n\u201cHer job is to teach American history to eighth graders,\u201d Ms. Agee-Bell said. \u201cHow can you teach American history and you don\u2019t understand the impact of your words to your students, given our nation\u2019s history?\u201d", "title": "Ohio Teacher Put on Leave After Lynching Remark to Black Student", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "This year, the United States is expected to surpass Saudi Arabia and to rival Russia as the world\u2019s leader, with record output of over 10 million barrels a day, according to the International Energy Agency.\n\n\u201cThis is a 180-degree turn for the United States and the impacts are being felt around the world,\u201d said Daniel Yergin, the economic historian and author of \u201cThe Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power.\u201d \u201cThis not only contributes to U.S. energy security but also contributes to world energy security by bringing new supplies to the world.\u201d\n\nCatching Up Forecasts show that the United States could surpass Saudi Arabia as an oil producer this year, with output exceeding 10 million barrels a day. 12 million barrels a day Russia 10 Saudi Arabia United States 8 Crude oil production 6 Iraq 4 Canada Brazil 2 0 \u201912 \u201913 \u201914 \u201915 \u201916 \u201917\n\nAt the same time, the United States is becoming a major exporter of natural gas, another outgrowth of the shale revolution, undercutting Russian energy dominance over Eastern Europe.\n\nThe improving energy picture comes as the Trump administration is attempting to increase offshore drilling and loosen other regulations on fossil fuel development. But just as the surge in oil and gas production in shale fields during the Barack Obama administration had little to do with Washington, the current rise is the result of private companies responding to global markets.\n\nShale fields can be developed relatively quickly and at modest costs relative to the giant projects, whether on land or offshore, that were once favored by big oil companies. That makes it easier to turn investment spigots on or off to adjust to market fluctuations. Companies like Exxon Mobil and Chevron are putting increasing amounts of capital in shale fields, particularly in West Texas and New Mexico.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe results go far beyond the economic, offering Washington strategic weapons once unthinkable. The United States and its allies now have a supply cushion at a time when political turmoil in Venezuela, Libya and Nigeria is threatening to interrupt flows to markets.\n\nOnly a few years ago, such threats \u2014 along with a recent pipeline failure in the North Sea and storms in the Gulf of Mexico \u2014 would have sent the price of crude soaring. Instead, the rise has been muted, and gasoline at the pump remains below $2.60 a gallon across most of the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new energy power also relieves pressure on Washington to act militarily if tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia break out into war. And it gives Washington the leeway to apply sanctions on other producers \u2014 as it has in Russia, and may in Iran or Venezuela \u2014 with far less risk to the global economy.\n\nIt is a striking contrast to the 1970s, when Arab oil boycotts forced motorists to line up for blocks to fill their tanks and the economy went into a tailspin. Even more recently, during the presidency of George W. Bush, domestic oil output was declining so rapidly that the country set a course to replace oil with biofuels like ethanol.\n\nMany environmentalists argue that by increasing oil and gas supplies and lowering prices for consumers, shale drilling is extending the life of fossil fuels to the detriment of the environment and the development of cleaner energy.\n\nThe shale drilling revolution has remade the global energy market, with imports from members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries plunging by 20 percent from late 2016 to late 2017. At the same time, exports rose by hundreds of thousands of barrels a day.\n\nNothing like the current situation was foreseen in late 2014, when rising domestic production began weighing on global oil prices.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn response, Saudi Arabia led OPEC in a new direction. Instead of throttling back to support prices as the cartel had done so often, it left the market alone and even increased production for a time.\n\nPrices fell below $40 a barrel, as the Saudis and their allies hoped to drive American operations out of business by making shale drilling uneconomical. American exploration quickly dropped, but the price squeeze made companies more innovative in the use of drilling technologies, robotics and sensors to maximize output and reduce costs.\n\nWhile scores of smaller companies went out of business, the survivors lengthened horizontal wells to yield more oil, and used clever hedging and drilling strategies to maximize profits even when prices slumped.\n\nThe response surprised the global oil community. OPEC, Russia and allied producing countries changed course and began cutting back again in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOPEC missed the point,\u201d said Ren\u00e9 Ortiz, a former OPEC secretary general and former Ecuadorean energy minister. \u201cThey thought they could recover the U.S. market by bringing the prices down. Now the U.S. has gained the leading position in the world oil market regardless of what OPEC does.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis displacement of Saudi oil, Nigerian oil, Libyan oil and Venezuelan oil,\u201d Mr. Ortiz concluded, \u201cwas never anticipated.\u201d\n\nA week ago, OPEC leaders met in Oman to discuss a probable extension of production cuts into 2019 to support prices. Their biggest obstacle is the United States.\n\nTechnological advances unlocking oil from tight rocks like shale has led to a drilling frenzy enabling a doubling of output in a decade, transforming unlikely places like North Dakota and New Mexico into world class petroleum hubs. Pipelines are being built across Texas to serve ports where oil can be pumped onto tankers headed for China, India and other markets.\n\nDomestic production last year averaged 9.3 million barrels a day, and the Energy Department projects that the figure will climb to 10.3 million barrels a day this year, surpassing the record set in 1970. In the meantime, since a 40-year export ban was lifted in 2015, exports of American oil have risen to roughly two million barrels a day \u2014 more than many OPEC members.\n\nThe department projects an additional increase in domestic production of 500,000 barrels a day in 2019.\n\nConcerns over climate change as well as the growing popularity of electric cars and the eventual aging of the best shale fields will probably curb production and demand over the next few decades. But in the short term, the boom has changed the landscape.\n\nThe Energy Department projects that the recent surge will hold the price of Brent crude, the global benchmark, to $60 a barrel in 2018 and $61 a barrel in 2019 \u2014 a modest increase from $54 last year. (The Brent price rose above $70 a barrel this month, but few analysts see a return to $100-a-barrel oil.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe emerging order in the energy realm is a stable balance of power. Saudi Arabia, which essentially runs OPEC, has put a floor under the oil price \u2014 probably around $50 a barrel \u2014 with its limits on output and exports over the last four years. But now the United States, by the sheer force of its production, the supremacy of its technology, and an unmatched pipeline, refinery and storage structure, has put a ceiling to the price.\n\nExperts note that when oil climbs to $60 a barrel and higher, as it has lately, a drilling rush commences \u2014 the national rig count has climbed by over a third in the last year \u2014 promising to refill domestic and even global energy inventories. Only a major war or other disruption is likely to send prices soaring.\n\n\u201cWe have all suffered these depressed prices over the last two years and we are excited to see the new prices and we will respond accordingly,\u201d said Harald Jordan, vice president for engineering at Peak Energy, a Colorado-based producer. \u201cYou will see rig activity continue to increase.\u201d", "title": "Oil Boom Gives the U.S. a New Edge in Energy and Diplomacy", "authors": ["Clifford Krauss"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Political risks elsewhere are also helping to push prices higher, including long-running tensions between Iraq\u2019s government in Baghdad and the autonomous Kurdish enclave in the north, and the collapse of Venezuela\u2019s oil industry. Both countries are major suppliers of crude \u2014 Iraq produces 4.5 million barrels of oil, and Venezuela adds around 1.8 million barrels \u2014 and any disruptions there could have a significant impact on global markets.\n\nThere are also factors mitigating a relentless rise in prices, though.\n\nFor one, the higher prices would most likely lead to increased investment and exploration for oil and, eventually, more production. This is especially true of smaller producers in the United States, whose output is already growing.\n\nThere is skepticism over whether drillers in Texas and elsewhere can increase output fast enough to create another glut. \u201cThere is a natural limit to what shale can do,\u201d said Antoine Rostand, president of Kayrros, a market research firm. \u201cTrees don\u2019t grow to the sky.\u201d\n\nBut these so-called swing producers have been crucial to previous price declines.\n\nThe International Energy Agency, in an Oil Market Report published in December, noted that new supplies coming onto the market, particularly from the United States, might still exceed growth in demand in the first half of the year.\n\nOn the whole, the oil industry appears to be well down the road of having adjusted to the steep price falls that began in 2014 and saw oil dipping to the $30-a-barrel range.\n\nAmong the shifts: OPEC has taken a more active role in managing global energy markets, with Russia \u2014 which is not a member \u2014 unofficially replacing weakened or uncooperative cartel members like Iran, Nigeria and Venezuela.\n\nOil companies have also reshaped themselves, sharply increasing efficiency and reducing costs to a point where they are profitable at current levels, or even lower ones. They have cut huge numbers of jobs, simplified the designs of their exploration infrastructure and embraced new technologies. Indeed, the availability of supplies at those lower costs may be the best bet for keeping recent price rises under control.", "title": "Oil Price Briefly Reaches $70 as Buoyant Global Economy Bolsters Demand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Oklahoma Coach Lon Kruger offered sympathy for those who did not see his star player coming: \u201cI don\u2019t know that anyone could have forecast this,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cFor him to explode like he did through the first 10 games is unheard-of.\u201d\n\nUnlike so many of his peers, Young was patient. Other players committed to the Jayhawks and the Wildcats before he made his decision, making Oklahoma a more palatable option. His hometown ties did not hurt. And perhaps above all, Young desired the kind of experience and playing time as a freshman that Kansas and Kentucky, with their star-clogged rosters, might not have permitted him.\n\n\u201cHad he chosen Kansas or Kentucky or Duke, he would have come into the season with more buzz,\u201d said the ESPN analyst Fran Fraschilla, a former coach who has known Young since the latter was a middle-schooler (Duke also offered Young a scholarship).\n\nAt the same time, Fraschilla added, had Young, who attended Norman North High School, left home, he most likely would not be playing nearly 34 minutes per game. That kind of on-court time has largely enabled Young\u2019s leap in esteem and drawn comparisons to Buddy Hield, the marksman who split major national player of the year honors two seasons ago while playing at Oklahoma for Kruger. Other coaches, whether due to their personal style or roster construction, may have limited his minutes or been less forgiving of his sky-high usage rate and 95 turnovers.\n\n\u201cHe picked a school where they had the exact need for his strengths and the coach who\u2019d already proven he was willing to turn the reins over, put the blinders on a little bit to the turnovers, and the bad shots at times, in order to cultivate this young man\u2019s brilliance,\u201d Fraschilla said.", "title": "Oklahoma\u2019s Trae Young, the Superstar Nobody Saw Coming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 The Old Vic theater here has begun an initiative to address inappropriate behavior following allegations of misconduct by the actor Kevin Spacey during his time as the theater\u2019s artistic director.\n\nThe plan, known as the Guardians Programme, is an alternate channel for employees to report instances of harassment outside of the formal structure of management and human resources.\n\n\u201cWe want everyone to have a way to share their concerns with someone outside of the \u2018regular\u2019 reporting line,\u201d Kate Varah, executive director at the Old Vic, said in a statement. \u201cOur Guardians will actively listen and support, offering confidential advice on options, with discretion and empathy.\u201d\n\nThe Old Vic\u2019s program comes as a report published by the British theater magazine The Stage found that one in three theater professionals and students among its registered users polled said they had experienced sexual harassment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe report, which was answered by 1,050 theater workers including performers, backstage workers, front-of-house staff and management, {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Kosovo government condemned the killing, which it said \u201cchallenges the rule of law and any attempt to establish order throughout the entire territory of Kosovo.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, Hashim Thaci, president of Kosovo, said, \u201cI call on the law enforcement authorities to expose the circumstances of his assassination as soon as possible and the perpetrators of the crime come to justice.\u201d\n\nIn Brussels, after the assassination, a Serb delegation walked out of talks on Tuesday on normalizing relations between Kosovo and Serbia. The European Union has served as a mediator as both Serbia and Kosovo seek to join the 28-nation bloc. But recognizing Kosovo\u2019s independence is a condition for Serbia\u2019s membership in the bloc.\n\nSerbia considers Kosovo the cradle of the Serbian nation and of its Christian Orthodox faith and refuses to recognize its former province as an independent state, a stance backed by Russia.\n\nPhoto\n\nSerbia had ruled the predominantly ethnic Albanian province since the late 1980s, when its former strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, revoked Kosovo\u2019s autonomy. Serb forces were driven out in 1999, after an American-led NATO bombing campaign. Kosovo declared independence in February 2008, with the overwhelming backing of Western countries like the United States and most members of the European Union.\n\nHowever, the ethnic Albanian-dominated government in the capital, Pristina, has failed to bring under its control the predominantly Serb parts of the country north of the Ibar River, including Mitrovica. The city is divided by the Ibar, with Albanians in the southern part and Serbs in the north, where Mr. Ivanovic was killed. When the war ended, NATO troops under French command allowed the city to be partitioned at the river, with the Serbs controlling the northern sector and maintaining close ties to Belgrade.\n\nMr. Ivanovic had no shortage of enemies, and someone set fire to his car outside his house in July 2017, after which some of his allies urged him to leave the country. In addition to being at the center of political tensions, he was an outspoken critic of Kosovo\u2019s drug gangs and the authorities who he said allowed traffickers to operate with impunity.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis is one of several ethnic Serb parties in Kosovo, but unlike its major rivals, it is less subservient to Belgrade, and willing to recognize and work with the ethnic Albanian authorities. Under a previous administration in Belgrade, he served as chief of Serbia\u2019s Ministry for Kosovo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe had a small party but a huge reputation,\u201d said Dusan Reljic, a southeast Europe specialist at German Institute for International Affairs and Security, who knew Mr. Ivanovic. \u201cIf you were looking for someone who could build bridges, it would be him, which is why neither the government in Pristina nor the government in Belgrade liked him.\u201d\n\n\u201cOliver knew he wasn\u2019t safe,\u201d Mr. Reljic added.\n\nA doctor who treated Mr. Ivanovic said he had been shot five times in the upper body. The police responded by blockading the Serb-majority northern part of the city as they searched for the gunman.\n\nIn 2014, a special European Union court set up to deal with Kosovo charged Mr. Ivanovic with involvement in the expulsion and killing of Albanian civilians. He was convicted in 2016 on one count, but an appeals court overturned that verdict last year and ordered a new trial.\n\nInternational representatives in Kosovo condemned the killing on Tuesday, and called for a full investigation.\n\nTensions have escalated in Kosovo as the nation of 1.8 million prepares to celebrate the 10th anniversary of its statehood. Last week, the State Department warned Americans to exercise caution if traveling to the country, citing an increased threat of terrorism, particularly in Serb-dominated enclaves, including northern Mitrovica.\n\nMr. Ivanovic, who was married and had three children, was one of the main leaders of the Serbs in northern Mitrovica but later came to support better relations with ethnic Albanians, including the government in Pristina.\n\nMarko Duric, the director of Serbia\u2019s Ministry for Kosovo, said that whoever killed Mr. Ivanovic had aimed to destabilize the region. \u201cThe goal is to provoke chaos and to push Serbs in Kosovo and Serbia into the hell of fighting,\u201d he told reporters in Brussels.", "title": "Oliver Ivanovic, Moderate Kosovo Serb Leader, Is Killed", "authors": ["Barbara Surk", "Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "If \u201cRoots\u201d did not make Ms. Cole a star, she nonetheless continued to work for decades. She had roles in the mini-series \u201cBackstairs at the White House,\u201d which earned her an Emmy nomination; another mini-series, \u201cThe Women of Brewster Place,\u201d produced by and starring Oprah Winfrey; the movie \u201cFirst Sunday,\u201d starring Tracy Morgan; and numerous theater productions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBackstairs,\u201d seen on NBC in 1979, was a behind-the-scenes look at the White House as told by the people who worked there, based on a best-selling memoir. Ms. Cole played the role of the first black maid to be employed on \u201cthe presidential floor.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe wonderful thing about \u2018Backstairs\u2019 is that it offers a challenging role for an actress, not a black actress,\u201d Ms. Cole told The Philadelphia Inquirer in 1979. \u201cIf only people would stop thinking in terms of black and white, and think only of who\u2019s the best in terms of ability!\u201d\n\nIn 2016 Ms. Cole appeared in a production of the 1995 play \u201cHaving Our Say: The Delany Sisters\u2019 First 100 Years\u201d at the Long Wharf Theater and Hartford Stage in Connecticut. The play, written by Emily Mann and based on the book of the same name, explored the bond between two elderly sisters who grew up in the Jim Crow era. Ms. Cole played Sadie Delany, who became a high school teacher; Brenda Pressley played Bessie Delany, who became a dentist.\n\n\u201cThis is the sort of theater that feeds you,\u201d Ms. Cole told The Harford Courant at the time.\n\nMs. Pressley, who had known Ms. Cole since the 1990s, described her in a phone interview as eccentric, spiritual and devoted to her craft.\n\n\u201cShe demanded her time to really sink down into every moment that she wanted to convey,\u201d Ms. Pressley said.\n\nMs. Pressley and Ms. Cole prepared meals onstage as part of the play. But offstage, Ms. Pressley said, Ms. Cole avoided the kitchen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNo darling, I don\u2019t cook,\u201d she recalled her saying. \u201cIn my oven I have books.\u201d\n\nJade King Carroll, the director of that production, said in a phone interview that Ms. Cole \u201clived inside roles,\u201d recalling that she would eat one clove of garlic a day because that\u2019s what her character did.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe same year Ms. Cole appeared in \u201cHaving Our Say,\u201d a new version of \u201cRoots\u201d that was shown on the History Channel. Ms. Cole told ABC News at the time that it was a story every generation should know.\n\n\u201cWe need to have these voices out here,\u201d she said. \u201cWe need to know where we come from. We need to know how we got here.\u201d\n\nOlivia Carlena Cole was born on Nov. 26, 1942, in Memphis. Her mother, the former Arvelia Cage, was a tennis player and instructor who was inducted into the United States Tennis Association Eastern Tennis Hall of Fame in 1997. Her father, William Calvin Cole, worked for Grumman Aircraft. Her parents divorced after moving to New York City.\n\nNo immediate family members survive.\n\nMs. Cole graduated from Hunter College High School in Manhattan in 1960, studied drama at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and earned a scholarship to attend the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, where she graduated with honors in 1964. Upon returning to the United States, she earned a master\u2019s degree in theater arts in 1967 from the University of Minnesota. She minored in Scandinavian studies.\n\nHer marriage to the actor Richard Venture ended in divorce. He died in December.\n\nMs. Cole lived in San Miguel de Allende, a city with a large artistic community filled with expatriates and retirees, for the last 35 years.\n\nShe created a Shakespeare club there, holding readings of Shakespeare\u2019s 37 plays for three decades.\n\n\u201cShe once told me that she thought she had done her best work in the Shakespeare group, just because she was learning so much,\u201d Wendy Sievert, a close friend, said.\n\nMs. Cole lived alone in Mexico, but her friends said she had a vibrant social life.\n\n\u201cYou walk down the street with her, 15 people would say hello,\u201d Ms. Sievert said. \u201cI think she knew everyone in town.\u201d", "title": "Olivia Cole, Award-Winning \u2018Roots\u2019 Actress, Is Dead at 75", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Olivia Wilde, 33, is known for her work as an actress, but these days she is trying on multiple roles. Recently she was the executive producer of \u201cFear Us Women,\u201d a documentary that follows a volunteer soldier in the YPJ, an all-female Kurdish army. Also keeping her busy: acting in and producing the crime drama \u201cA Vigilante,\u201d out later this year, and touting True Botanicals, a skin care line for which she serves as a brand ambassador. Born in Manhattan, raised in Washington, D.C., and now living in Brooklyn, Ms. Wilde uses her days off to pop into the Brooklyn Museum for First Saturdays or to do hip-hop yoga in Union Square. Find out more about her wellness and beauty routine, below.\n\nSkin Care\n\nI do enjoy the ritual of my morning. It helps me wake up psychologically as much as physically. I wash with True Botanicals Hydrating Cleanser \u2014 it\u2019s really gentle. Then I spritz on some of the Nutrient Mist. Of all the True Botanicals products, it\u2019s one of my favorites. It always smells amazing. I use the brand\u2019s face oils, too. If I\u2019m having breakouts, I use the one they have for clearing up skin, and then the tinted SPF. If I\u2019m running around, I like Ursa Major Essential Face Wipes because they clean and moisturize at the same time.\n\nI\u2019ve been on a search for natural deodorants that actually work. I have two I feel I can rely on: Soapwalla and Agent Nateur.\n\nAnother thing I\u2019m a huge believer in, in terms of body care: I\u2019ve been using this body lotion that has CBD from marijuana. It\u2019s called Lord Jones, and I discovered it through my friends in L.A. Recently I did a play on Broadway for six months, and my body was wrecked. My neck was really tight. The CBD has relaxing benefits, and the idea is to avoid using too many painkillers.\n\nSlide Show\n\nMakeup\n\nI really like the Glossier Stretch Concealer. It has nice coverage, but it\u2019s not cake-y and blends really easily. Then I do a tiny bit of eyeliner. I\u2019m always looking for natural makeup that works, and I finally found a natural eyeliner I like. It\u2019s the W3ll People Expressionist liner, and it stays on. That\u2019s my litmus test. I have Kjaer Weis cream blush, and I do my eyebrows with the Kjaer Weis eyebrow powder and brush. I also like pencils. The Marc Jacobs eyebrow pencil is really thin and can mimic natural hairs. You don\u2019t want that painted-on look.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMascara, I bounce around. I don\u2019t have a fave. Lately I have eyelash extensions. I\u2019m wrangling two kids, two dogs and a job. If there\u2019s a step I can skip, that\u2019s great.", "title": "Olivia Wilde Doesn\u2019t Do a Painted-on Face", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "A survey last year by the government-run Korea Institute for National Unification in Seoul found that far more South Koreans in their 20s now oppose reunification \u2014 71.2 percent \u2014 than support it. Across the population, support has dropped to 57.8 percent from 69.3 percent just four years ago.\n\n\u201cEspecially men in their 20s, about half of them, consider North Korea an outright enemy,\u201d said Kim Ji-yoon, a research fellow at the Asan Institute for Policy Studies in Seoul who has been tracking attitudes toward reunification. \u201cTo young South Koreans, North Korea is someone they don\u2019t want anything to do with.\u201d\n\nPolling experts say that South Korean men in their 20s often get more hawkish after they finish their mandatory military service.\n\nThe skepticism was apparent this month, when the two Koreas set aside their disputes over the North\u2019s nuclear weapons and missile programs and agreed to field a joint team in the Winter Games in the town of Pyeongchang, and to march together in the opening ceremony on Feb. 9.\n\nIn the past, such gestures triggered waves of pro-unification sentiment, as in 2000, when North and South Korean athletes marched together at the Games in Sydney, Australia. (They competed separately.) The administration of President Moon Jae-in, a progressive who has long supported inter-Korean unity, hoped this latest rapprochement would create similarly warm feelings.\n\nPhoto\n\nInstead, a survey found that more than 72 percent of South Korean adults overall \u2014 and more than 82 percent of those in their 20s and 30s \u2014 were not enthusiastic about the hockey team. More than 54,000 people signed a petition opposing it, and many expressed anger that some South Korean players would cede their positions to North Koreans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI am taken aback,\u201d said Kim Sung-hwan, a former South Korean foreign minister. \u201cYoung people seem to think of North Korea as strangers who barge into their party bringing with them nothing but empty spoons.\u201d\n\nSuch pushback would have been expected from conservatives, who have long been suspicious of efforts to engage the North. But younger South Koreans tend to be politically progressive and supportive of Mr. Moon on other issues.\n\nAnalysts said that years of increasingly provocative nuclear and missile tests have darkened South Korean perceptions of the North and its young leader, Mr. Kim. Actions like Mr. Kim\u2019s executions of his own uncle and his half brother have also made the regime look brutal and grotesque.\n\n\u201cWe know that this sudden shift in mood could be confusing for people, especially given how unsettled they were over the North\u2019s missile tests up until just a month ago,\u201d said Yoon Young-chan, a spokesman for Mr. Moon. \u201cBut the Pyeongchang Olympics can go beyond South-North reconciliation and provide clues to easing tensions and building peace on the Korean Peninsula.\u201d\n\nAnalysts say a key turning point in attitudes toward the North came in 2010, when a South Korean naval ship was sunk by an apparent North Korean torpedo attack, killing 46 sailors, and North Korea launched a rocket barrage on a South Korean island that killed four people, including two civilians. These were formative events for young South Koreans, these analysts say.\n\nPhoto\n\nKey members of Mr. Moon\u2019s presidential office and governing party are progressives in their 50s, who went to college in the 1980s. Then, campuses were rife with anti-American activism, partly driven by resentment over the division of the Korean Peninsula after World War II. Students defied the authorities by sending a \u201cunification envoy\u201d to the World Festival of Youth and Students, alternative games that North Korea held in Pyongyang in 1989 to counter the previous year\u2019s Summer Olympics in Seoul.\n\nProgressives in that era believed in a peaceful process of reunification, built on the expansion of economic and social exchanges. Today, many of that generation see the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program as a desperate attempt to protect itself from the United States and the South, with which it is still technically at war.\n\nReunification is also a personal matter for Mr. Moon, 65, who was born in a refugee camp after his parents fled their native North Korea during the 1950-53 Korean War.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf Korea reunified, the first thing I would do is to take my mother\u2019s hand and visit her hometown,\u201d he said during last year\u2019s election campaign.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe assumption that the South and North belong together is shared by many South Korean conservatives, though from a very different point of view. They tend to call for the South liberating the North from the Kim family\u2019s rule, by force if necessary.\n\nThe horrors of the Korean War, which killed millions, bound older South Koreans together. Many still grow teary-eyed on those occasions when the rival governments allow select groups of aging citizens to meet relatives from the other side after decades of separation.\n\nPhoto\n\nYounger South Koreans don\u2019t share the pain caused by the peninsula\u2019s divide, or the inclination to see North Koreans as long-lost brethren. Last year\u2019s survey by the unification institute found that while more than 47 percent of respondents in their 60s and older said the two Koreas must reunify \u201cbecause they belong to the same nation,\u201d less than 21 percent of respondents in their 20s said so.\n\nOf course, warier views of the North are not limited to the young. Many South Korean conservatives, young and old, embrace the view that the North is building nuclear-tipped intercontinental missiles to drive a wedge between it and the United States, its longtime protector.\n\nThey fear that if Mr. Kim thinks the threat of a nuclear strike on the mainland United States will keep the Americans from intervening, he may try to take over the South, the dream that his grandfather, Kim Il-sung, the North\u2019s founding leader, failed to achieve during the Korean War.\n\nOn Thursday, North Korean state media called on \u201call Koreans at home and abroad\u201d to support moves toward reunification and eliminate obstacles created by \u201coutside forces,\u201d a reference to the United States.\n\nMany South Koreans are relieved that North Korea is joining the Olympics, because it is less likely to conduct a major weapons test while its own athletes are competing in Pyeongchang. But they remain deeply skeptical about Mr. Kim\u2019s sudden peace offensive.\n\nIn a town near the Olympic venues, Kang Hee-du, 54, a restaurant worker, wondered how the Koreas could possibly reunify when they have drifted so far apart, economically and ideologically. \u201cIt would be nothing but chaotic,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Choi Sang-hwan, 73, a retired auto-component maker, lamented the new attitude.\n\n\u201cOur generation knows how tragic war can be; it can take everything away,\u201d said Mr. Choi, who is also an Olympic volunteer. \u201cIt\u2019s our duty to let our future generations live peacefully in a unified Korea.\u201d", "title": "Olympic Dreams of a United Korea? Many in South Say, \u2018No, Thanks\u2019", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "The White House this week welcomed the announcement but played down its significance, noting that it was not the first time that athletes from the two Koreas had competed together.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s hope that the experience gives the North Korean athletes a small taste of freedom and that it rubs off,\u201d said Michael Anton, a spokesman for the National Security Council. \u201cNorth Korean propaganda is in a category all its own,\u201d he added. \u201cIt is not surprising that North Korea is sending more cheerleaders and musicians than athletes.\u201d\n\nThat emphasis on propaganda, other officials said, was in keeping with North Korea\u2019s longer-term goal of reunification.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn addition to marching together, the two Koreas will field a joint women\u2019s hockey team at the Games, which begin on Feb. 9 in Pyeongchang. It will be the first time the two countries have combined for an Olympics, and the first unified team of any kind since their athletes played together in a table tennis championship and a youth soccer tournament in 1991.\n\nThe Olympic agreement could bolster President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who has been pushing for dialogue with the North. \u201cThis will be a great opportunity to thaw the frozen relations,\u201d he said during a visit to the training camp for South Korean athletes.\n\n\u201cIf we unify our team with the North\u2019s, it won\u2019t necessarily improve our team\u2019s strength very much,\u201d Mr. Moon said. \u201cIt will even require extra efforts to build up teamwork with the North Korean players. But if the two Koreas unify their teams and play a great match together, that itself will be long remembered as a historic moment.\u201d\n\nFew expected that the breakthrough in sports diplomacy would lead to a broader relaxation of the decades-old standoff over the North\u2019s nuclear weapon programs. But it provided a welcome reprieve for South Koreans who have grown alarmed and weary over the tensions and relentless talk of war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has threatened the North with \u201cfire and fury like the world has never seen,\u201d should it put the security of Americans and their allies at risk, while Mr. Kim has called Mr. Trump a lunatic.\n\nDespite its wariness, the White House has been careful not to dismiss the talks between the North and the South, provided the two sides stick to issues like security at the Olympics. Mr. Trump said on Wednesday that he would be open to talks with Mr. Kim himself, though he questioned the value of such a meeting.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d sit down, but I\u2018m not sure that sitting down will solve the problem,\u201d Mr. Trump said in an interview with Reuters.\n\nHe warned that while North Korea was not yet capable of delivering a ballistic missile to the United States, \u201cthey\u2019re close \u2014 and they get closer every day.\u201d In the interview, Mr. Trump was uncharacteristically critical of Russia, saying it had weakened the global sanctions against North Korea, even as China was doing more.\n\n\u201cWhat China is helping us with, Russia is denting,\u201d he said. \u201cIn other words, Russia is making up for some of what China is doing.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nAnalysts said the agreement would be enormously popular in South Korea. Strong ethic nationalism compels people in both Koreas to cheer for each other\u2019s athletes when they compete against non-Korean teams, especially Japan.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re at one of these moments where there is this emotional, if not irrational, exuberance at the prospect of North Korean athletes coming south,\u201d said Jonathan D. Pollack, a Korea expert at the Brookings Institution, who is visiting Seoul this week.\n\nA previous such moment came in 1991, when a unified and underdog Korean team won the gold medal in the women\u2019s team competition over China in the World Table Tennis Championships in Chiba, Japan. The unified women\u2019s ice hockey team will face Japan on Feb. 14 in Pyeongchang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe problem, Mr. Pollack said, is that North Korea \u201chas put down clear markers about what it wants in return. If the expectation is that North Korea is going to get economic goodies by acting nice, they\u2019re not.\u201d\n\nFor the United States, the fear has been that North Korea\u2019s gestures will drive a wedge between it and its ally, South Korea. So far, the two allies have stayed in sync, said Daniel R. Russel, who served as assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs in the Obama administration.\n\n\u201cBut it will be harder and harder to insure that South Korea and the U.S. stay closely aligned,\u201d he said. \u201cYou have a fundamental tension between a progressive government in Seoul and a hawkish government in Washington.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon proposed in June that the two Koreas form a unified team for the Olympics, but the suggestion was not taken seriously until Mr. Kim used his New Year\u2019s Day speech to propose dialogue with the South and to discuss his country\u2019s participation in the Games.\n\nThat led to a series of talks in the border village of Panmunjom. In an earlier round of negotiations, the North agreed to send a 140-member orchestra to play during the Olympics. On Wednesday, South Korean officials said the North\u2019s delegation would include at least 550 people. The plan is for the North\u2019s athletes to enter the South over a land border on Feb. 1.\n\nSo far, the only North Korean athletes to qualify for the Games are a pairs figure skating team. North Korea missed an Oct. 31 deadline to accept invitations from South Korea and the International Olympic Committee to join the Games. But the international body has said it remains willing to consider wild-card entries for North Korean athletes.\n\nThe two Koreas negotiated to share some of the 1988 Seoul Olympics after South Korea won the right to play host to the games. But the talks collapsed, and the North bombed a South Korean passenger jet in 1987 in an attempt to disrupt them.", "title": "Olympic D\u00e9tente Upends U.S. Strategy on North Korea", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Those proposals were raised on Tuesday when delegations from both Koreas met for talks at the border village of Panmunjom, though the joint statement released at the end of the negotiations did not mention them. South Korean officials said they would continue to discuss the proposals with the North Koreans as well as the International Olympic Committee.\n\nFollow-up sessions at Panmunjom are expected to be held on Monday, when both Koreas agreed to hold working-level talks on their border and to settle details on the North\u2019s plan to send an art troupe to the Pyeongchang Olympics.\n\nSouth Korean officials said, meanwhile, that the International Olympic Committee was expected to bring together the national Olympic committees of both Koreas, as well as the international hockey federation and the Pyeongchang organizing committee, to discuss the possibility of a unified women\u2019s hockey team and other issues arising from the North\u2019s last-minute decision to join the Games.\n\nSo far, the only North Korean athletes to qualify for the Pyeongchang Games are a pairs figure-skating team. North Korea missed an Oct. 31 deadline to accept invitations from South Korea and the International Olympic Committee to join the Games. But the international body has said it remains flexible and is willing to consider wild-card entries for North Korean athletes.\n\nThe South Korean women\u2019s hockey team, which has qualified for the Olympics, would be replaced with the joint Korean team under the South\u2019s proposal. On Feb. 14, South Korea is scheduled to play Japan, which for decades ruled the Korean Peninsula as a colony; a face-off between Japan and a unified Korean team would have huge emotional resonance in both Koreas.\n\nThe prospect of inter-Korean reconciliation, through sports and other channels, has strong appeal in South Korea, so much so that all of its governments have tried for a unified Olympic team with the North.\n\nSuch efforts have sometimes led to breakthroughs. In 2000, when the Koreas held their first summit meeting, their delegations marched together at the opening ceremony of the Sydney Olympics. They did so again in Athens in 2004, carrying a blue-and-white flag representing a united Korea.", "title": "Olympics Officials Discuss a Potential First: A Unified Korean Hockey Team", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSupplements containing omega-3 fatty acids, the oils abundant in fatty fish, are ineffective for the prevention of heart disease, a large review of randomized trials has found.\n\nThe analysis, in JAMA Cardiology, pooled data from 10 randomized trials in people who had had cardiovascular disease or were at high risk for it. There were 77,917 people in the trials, 61 percent men, and their average age was 64. Studies lasted, on average, 4.4 years, and the dose of omega-3\u2019s ranged from 226 to 1,800 milligrams a day.\n\nNo matter how the researchers looked at the data, they could find no association of the supplements with lowered risk for death from heart disease, or with nonfatal heart attacks or other major cardiovascular events.\n\nThere was no effect in people with prior coronary heart disease, those with diabetes, people with high lipid levels, or in people using statins. There was no evidence for an effect in either women or men considered separately.\n\n\u201cCarefully done trials provide no support for the hypothesis that fish oil supplements help,\u201d said the senior author, Dr. Robert Clarke, a professor of epidemiology at the University of Oxford.\n\nThe American Heart Association recommends supplements for people with coronary artery disease who may not get enough omega-3\u2019s by diet alone, but the study provided \u201cno support\u201d for those guidelines, Dr. Clarke said.", "title": "Omega-3 Supplements Don\u2019t Protect Against Heart Disease", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Usually, after watching a performance that I\u2019m reviewing, I\u2019m alone with my thoughts and opinions. But that wasn\u2019t the case last week, after I caught Moriah Evans\u2019s \u201cFiguring\u201d at American Realness, the annual festival of experimental performance. Back home, I watched a short segment of the work on Instagram, part of The New York Times\u2019s weekly #SpeakingInDance series. And then I read the comments.\n\nThe video shows three women who look like they are having seizures \u2014 or, to paraphrase one of the comments, like \u201cInvasion of the Body Snatchers\u201d meets twerking. Most of the comments (thousands, it went viral) were in that vein, treating the work and its strangeness as comedy, though many reactions were more hostile, taking it as a symptom of what\u2019s wrong with art or dance or white people.", "title": "On Artists and Audiences at American Realness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Given the Trump administration\u2019s indifference to climate change, the task of reducing emissions of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas, has fallen largely to city and state governments. It is thus greatly encouraging that New Jersey, under its new governor, Phil Murphy, a Democrat, will join \u2014 more precisely, rejoin \u2014 the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a consortium of nine Eastern and New England states that has achieved substantial emissions reductions from large power plants since its start in 2009.\n\nMr. Murphy chose Highlands, a borough on the Atlantic shore hit hard by Hurricane Sandy in 2012, to announce that he would sign an executive order renewing New Jersey\u2019s participation in the consortium. His predecessor, Chris Christie, a Republican, pulled the state out of the agreement in 2011, claiming he was trying to protect New Jersey ratepayers. A more plausible explanation lay in his nascent presidential aspirations. Climate change had become an unpopular subject among Republicans, and big donors like the Koch brothers were threatening to pull the plug on any candidate who favored regulation of greenhouse gases.\n\nRGGI (pronounced \u201cReggie\u201d) has, in fact, a Republican pedigree, dating back to 2003, when Gov. George Pataki of New York invited other Northeast governors to join a regional effort to reduce carbon emissions. What followed was a regionwide system that sets a declining cap on emissions from large power plants \u2014 about 170 in total \u2014 and requires individual power producers to buy permits from state governments to pollute. As the cap declines, the price of the permits rises, giving utilities an incentive to find cheaper ways to reduce emissions.\n\nAccording to various studies, power plant emissions have declined 40 percent since 2009, while the sale of the permits has raised $2.7 billion that\u2019s been invested in efficiency measures and renewable energy. Some of these reductions would have occurred anyway as plants shifted from coal to cheaper, cleaner-burning natural gas, and the reductions are a small fraction of the total greenhouse gases generated in the nine-state region. Even so, it\u2019s a well-designed program that will only get stronger; last August, the nine states agreed to reduce emissions a further 30 percent by 2030. A national program along similar lines passed the House in 2009 but never came to a vote in the Senate.", "title": "Opinion | On Climate, Gov. Murphy Brings a New Voice to New Jersey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Like countless others headed to work on Tuesday morning, Andy Byford stood wearing a backpack on a crowded subway platform at Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan waiting for a No. 4 train to arrive. In a clear sign that he was not a native New Yorker, he politely stepped aside to allow passengers off the train before edging his way onto the crowded car.\n\nThough he remained largely unrecognizable to the crush of passengers surrounding him, Mr. Byford was not just another harried commuter \u2014 he is the man who is now running, and tasked with fixing, New York City\u2019s subway system.\n\nIt was Mr. Byford\u2019s first day of what will undoubtedly be his most challenging transportation job yet: reviving a sprawling and aging subway system that has grown increasingly unreliable after years of political and financial neglect. Still, when he exited the train at the Bowling Green station in Lower Manhattan near his office, Mr. Byford, speaking in a distinct British accent, said, \u201cI\u2019m excited to be here.\u201d\n\nMr. Byford, who most recently served as the chief executive of the Toronto Transit Commission, has said he is considering aggressive steps to improve the subway, including shutting down lines for long periods of time to speed up repairs. He said he would review the way the subway spends money and consider overhauling management. He also said that congestion pricing \u2014 charging fees to drive into the most crowded parts of Manhattan as a way to raise money for transit \u2014 was worth considering.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Byford, whose official title is president of New York City Transit, made his way from the subway to his desk trailed by news cameras and introduced himself to transit workers who matched his smile with theirs before addressing reporters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is a dream come true for me,\u201d said Mr. Byford, who was wearing a Canada Goose parka, a suit and the same worn black leather shoes he used to traverse the Toronto transit system. \u201cBut I haven\u2019t come here to be a tourist. I came here to get a job done.\u201d", "title": "On His First Day, Transit Chief Rode the Subway Into Work", "authors": ["Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The actual, not virtual, library of The New York Times is in the basement catacombs of the building, located at the end of a lab-white labyrinthine hall. Its venerable collection is rarely visited these days, since a few keystrokes deliver the world.\n\nBut sometimes you just need to hold an old book \u2014 to measure its heft, linger over its imprinted words and be open to the chance of serendipity within. This desire is how I recently came to be reading a musty forest-green copy of the autobiography of Lincoln Steffens, the legendary muckraking journalist of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.\n\nI won\u2019t go into why I needed the 1931 autobiography of Steffens, whose name has not lately been on the lips of the nation, other than to say that I have spent much of my life going down rabbit holes. And so there I was, in the familiar darkness of another rabbit hole, breathing in the book\u2019s dust mites, when I found a small snapshot tucked between yellowed Pages 694 and 695.\n\nThe time-faded photo was of a toddler in a white dress \u2014 a girl with blond hair neatly parted \u2014 posing beside a small black dog.", "title": "On Journalistic Curiosity: Down the Rabbit Hole With Dan Barry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Norman L. Eisen, who was the ethics counsel for President Barack Obama, said it was \u201coutrageous that access to the Trump family is once again being sold \u2014 this time to foreign purchasers, no less.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThis is a brazen violation of ethics best practices, but not alas a surprising one; it is of a piece with the access to the Trump family that members at domestic Trump properties get for their often steep fees.\u201d\n\nRichard W. Painter, who was the ethics counsel for President George W. Bush, said the India deal was \u201cinappropriate, but legal.\u201d\n\nHe urged the Trump children to publicly declare that they will not discuss government policy with customers. \u201cThey could dramatically reduce their risk if they categorically make it clear that they will not discuss U.S. government interests with anyone with whom they have an actual or prospective financial relationship,\u201d Mr. Painter said.\n\nThe news release for the project, which does not mention the offer of access to Donald Trump Jr., goes on about its various bells and whistles, making the project sound something like a cruise ship \u2014 with a golf course attached.\n\n\u201cResidents will enjoy an exclusive collection of super luxury amenities at the Trump Club, including Gurugram\u2019s first temperature-controlled indoor pool, spa, and fitness center with sauna, steam and massage rooms, library, lounge, games room, children\u2019s play area, a fine-dining restaurant and business center, just to name a few,\u201d the developers said.\n\nThe building will employ \u201chandpicked staff\u201d to deliver room service and park cars.\n\nThe Trump Organization, the family\u2019s business conglomerate, already has several real estate projects in the works in India, including a new apartment building in Kolkata. Quinn, who served as speaker before Ms. Mark-Viverito and represented the same West Village, Chelsea and Midtown West district as Mr. Johnson, offered advice to the incoming leader.\n\n\u201cHave fun, follow your gut, don\u2019t worry so much about the press, and stay in really close touch with your members,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is the moment in your life to take everything in your life that you ever wanted to fix, change and undo, and do it. Because you can.\u201d\n\nOver her two terms as speaker, Ms. Quinn, a Democrat, suffered politically within her own party because of what some perceived as a too-close relationship to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who ran as an independent and a Republican, and her support for Mr. Bloomberg\u2019s third term. Similarly, Ms. Mark-Viverito has been seen as too close to Mr. de Blasio, even though both are Democrats; the mayor did not veto a single Council bill during her term.\n\nFor Mr. Johnson, it will be a delicate balance, striving to be what he called \u201ca productive partner\u201d with the mayor, \u201cwhile at the same time someone who is willing to maintain the Council\u2019s independence.\u201d He said he could envision a more assertive Council bringing bills to vote that do not have Mr. de Blasio\u2019s support.\n\n\u201cI said this to the mayor: \u2018When there is disagreement, it will never be personal with me,\u2019\u201d Mr. Johnson said. \u201cBut us overriding vetoes, if the members believe we should do that and there\u2019s broad support for a bill, that\u2019s us using our charter-mandated authority.\u201d\n\nMr. Johnson became the overwhelming favorite for the position after leaders from the two most powerful Democratic county organizations, in the Bronx and in Queens, threw their weight behind him. Mr. de Blasio, who had not initially endorsed Mr. Johnson, soon followed suit.", "title": "On Next Council Speaker\u2019s Agenda: More Oversight and More Subway Aid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are well aware of the fact that the housing of immigrants in Paris needs to be improved, and it will be improved in the coming weeks,\u201d Mr. Sodini said.\n\nI spent three nights with workers from Paris Refugee Ground Support, an informal aid group that delivers blankets and other necessities to migrants living on the streets as they wait to learn their fate in France.\n\nThe details of the stories told by the migrants could not be confirmed, but all described common obstacles to finding housing in Paris.\n\nPhoto\n\nAbdelbashir, 20, said he had recently arrived from Sudan. He described escaping violence in Darfur through the Sahara, traversing the Mediterranean on a rickety fishing boat, and crossing into France from Italy on foot, wearing the same flip-flops he left home in.\n\nLike many migrants, he was waiting for an asylum appointment and longer-term housing. But even those who get a place risk losing it over minor infractions. Information in migrants\u2019 native languages is scarce, and the rules at asylum hostels \u2014 like curfews and visiting policies \u2014 change constantly.\n\nI found Ismail, a 25-year-old Somalian, asleep under a shower curtain in a urine-soaked enclave beneath a highway. As he pulled his asylum papers from his backpack, he began to cry.\n\nHe said that he had been living on the streets for more than a year, and that he had not contacted his wife or children \u2014 who were living in a refugee camp in Kenya \u2014 out of shame.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI respect France, but France does not respect me,\u201d he said.\n\nA decision on migrants\u2019 asylum claims can take as little as two weeks. Some are granted asylum and stay in France, while others are sent back to the first European Union country they landed in or deported to their home nation.\n\nBut securing an appointment with an asylum office can take weeks or months, and France provides only the bare essentials, like water and toilets, to those who wait.\n\nPhoto\n\nMohammed was sleeping with a group of nearly 70 men in a park just beyond the city limits as he waited for his appointment. The 22-year-old Sudanese man recounted seeing nearly half the people who had been crammed onto a boat with him drown when their vessel sank off the Libyan coast.\n\nI asked if he had learned any French while he was waiting. He said that it was difficult, but that he knew two words for sure: \u201cthank you\u201d and \u201cmaybe.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn recent months, even finding a place to sleep on the streets has grown difficult. Migrants fear being spotted by the heavily armed police forces, who regularly rouse encampments, crushing or slashing tents so they can no longer be used.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are allowing the words \u2018refugees\u2019 and \u2018terrorists\u2019 to become synonymous in Europe,\u201d said Deborah Hyde, an aid worker with Utopia56, a French nonprofit focused on helping migrants. In fact, she said, those arriving in Europe are often fleeing terrorism themselves.\n\nSaid, 28, left his resettlement camp in northern France to try to find work in Paris. He showed me a picture on his phone of the lakeside in his hometown, Taqba, in Syria, which he said was a short drive from Raqqa, the former Islamic State stronghold.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDo you think I want to be here?\u201d he asked, gesturing to the piece of cardboard he was sleeping on. \u201cNo, I want to be there \u2014 but it\u2019s impossible.\u201d", "title": "On Paris\u2019s Icy Streets, Migrants Wait for Word on Refuge", "authors": ["Erin Clare Brown"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Now, one is fetching many hundreds of dollars per seat on Broadway, wrote a critically-acclaimed memoir and shows no signs of slowing down. The other has just ended eight years as governor of New Jersey, following a failed push for the presidency and has a murky future.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut on Wednesday, Mr. Christie spent his first night out as a private citizen at the tiny Walter Kerr Theater to catch Mr. Springsteen cut his own boogaloo on Broadway. The lights dimmed at 8 p.m., and Mr. Christie bought a drink and found a seat in a corner off in the dark.\n\nHe had a job, and tried to put his money away, but for these close up seats, he found the cash to pay. But the Boss made no notice, no mention at all. He ran through the show to the curtain call.\n\nEvery term ends, Jersey. That\u2019s a fact. And after two terms, you just can\u2019t come back. So he crossed that big river and came into the city. On stage was Springsteen, in the audience Chris Christie.\n\nThey never quite saw eye to eye, but the two men had a brief d\u00e9tente following Hurricane Sandy, when Mr. Christie was at the apex of his popularity. A sign of how far he\u2019d come and how high he\u2019d climbed, Mr. Christie told reporters that the two men had hugged and that \u201cwe\u2019re friends\u201d after a hurricane relief telethon in 2013.\n\nBut Mr. Christie soon began to stumble. There was the battle over public pensions in which unions accused him of feeling no pain. His allies shut down the George Washington Bridge, charged with doing things he can\u2019t explain.\n\nMr. Springsteen even mocked him on a late-night show, in a song set to the tune of \u201cBorn to Run,\u201d singing: \u201cThey shut down the tollbooths of glory \u2018cause we didn\u2019t endorse Christie.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Christie\u2019s subsequent endorsement of President Trump in 2016, whom Mr. Springsteen called a \u201ccon man\u201d in a protest song, likely dashed any hope of another embrace, either with Mr. Springsteen or with many of his constituents.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond. On stage was Springsteen, in the audience Chris Christie.\n\nOn Wednesday, there was no need to rehash the glory days, or the battle outside that\u2019s still raging across that Jersey state line.
