That\u2019s good news for the city, the Police Department \u2014 and police reformers. That\u2019s because the reforms leading the department to cut back on stop-and-frisks are accompanied by such low numbers on violent crime.\n\nPolice reformers have long argued that ending stop-and-frisk would help communities, not harm them. But in objecting to the policy, we did not point to the negative long-term psychological or social effects this practice had on a generation of young black and Latino men \u2014 because we don\u2019t really know what they are. It is urgent that social scientists, police departments and advocates measure the social costs, because burdensome and disparate policing happens all around the country.\n\nWe should start by listening to targets of these policies. A Harlem teenager named Alvin recorded being stopped by the police in 2011. It was not the first time the police had stopped him. The officers threatened to punch him in his face and break his arm, and told him they had stopped him because he was a \u201cmutt.\u201d Such first-person testimonials helped spark a national debate on stop-and-frisk and decrease the practice. But the ultimate effect on Alvin\u2019s life is unknown.\n\nHow do we quantify the effects of incidents like this? We don\u2019t know because we have not done the work to measure them. But if the reason stop-and-frisk was objectionable is that it placed too great a burden on black and Latino men, shouldn\u2019t we find the time and resources? If we don\u2019t, how are we to know if other practices do even greater harm?", "title": "Opinion | On Stop-and-Frisk, We Can\u2019t Celebrate Just Yet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The circumstances, in Wenger\u2019s eyes, are not exactly parallel. Arsenal is expected to receive midfielder Henrikh Mkhitaryan in exchange, as well as a fee of $35 million or so; it is not \u201cone-way traffic,\u201d as Wenger has put it.\n\nS\u00e1nchez\u2019s relationship with Arsenal, too, is different from van Persie\u2019s. S\u00e1nchez, a Chilean, arrived fully formed; the bond is not quite as strong as it was with van Persie, a Dutchman who was signed as a prodigy and blossomed into a star. \u201cWe made a long work with him,\u201d Wenger said. \u201cWhen you get them there, to that level, and then they leave \u2014 of course that is the most painful.\u201d\n\nThere are sufficient similarities, however, that Wenger could hardly ignore them. Both van Persie and S\u00e1nchez had been allowed to enter the final years of their contracts, diminishing Arsenal\u2019s bargaining power and enabling United to sign them for relatively small fees, if not insignificant wages. Both will have departed the Emirates for Old Trafford in search of trophies, of greater glory. And both will have done so having rejected, in some way, the chance to sign for Manchester City.\n\nLike all transfers, S\u00e1nchez\u2019s move to Manchester United is about money. At 29, he will become the highest-paid player in the Premier League, earning somewhere in the region of $555,000 a week, an amount Wenger acknowledged Arsenal simply could not match.\n\nIt is also, like most transfers, about ambition. S\u00e1nchez has grown increasingly \u2014 and increasingly visibly \u2014 frustrated by Arsenal\u2019s inability to deliver tangible success, beyond broadly biennial victories in the F.A. Cup. Time is no longer on his side. He is not content to scrap around with Liverpool and Tottenham, hoping for a place in the Champions League.\n\nWhat marks this move out as different is that it is also \u2014 more than most transfers \u2014 about hierarchy, about establishing a place in the pecking order, about power.\n\nBy stripping Arsenal of its best player, again, United proves that it possesses a clout that one of its traditional peers does not; it demonstrates that it sits above Arsenal in the food chain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore important, at a time when United seems unable to beat Manchester City on the field \u2014 Pep Guardiola\u2019s team leads Jos\u00e9 Mourinho\u2019s by 12 points \u2014 securing a victory off it offers a little boost to the ego, a little balm for wounded pride.\n\nUnited, on the surface, has snatched one of the best players in the Premier League from under City\u2019s nose; it has been able to overcome S\u00e1nchez\u2019s desire to work, once more, with Guardiola, his coach for a year at Barcelona; it has been able financially to outmuscle a team backed, as Wenger hinted, by a state. It has seized a \u201cfantastic opportunity,\u201d as Mourinho described it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJust as signing van Persie in 2012 sent a message, a few weeks after City had finally claimed a first championship in four decades, United\u2019s capturing S\u00e1nchez now serves as a little reminder that City\u2019s hegemony \u2014 in Manchester, in the Premier League \u2014 is not yet complete.\n\nHere too, however, the parallel is imperfect. Van Persie did, indeed, reject City in favor of United, the team he had supported as a child in Holland. The same cannot be said of S\u00e1nchez.\n\nThis time, it was City who decided not to press ahead with the deal. It had been prepared to pay $83 million for S\u00e1nchez last summer, plus his salary demands, but balked at the idea of spending $34 million now.\n\nIf that seems curious, consider the circumstances: City was not decisively the best team in England, and perhaps Europe, in the summer. Raheem Sterling had not scored 18 goals in 33 games. Put simply, S\u00e1nchez was worth more to City six months ago than he is now. City missed out on van Persie because of its weakness and United\u2019s strength. If anything, the converse is true of S\u00e1nchez.\n\nIn 2012, United\u2019s paying $34 million for a 29-year-old in the final year of his contract was considered the height of decadence. Ferguson pressed for it, for once, because he did not care about resale value, or the club\u2019s policy of bringing in younger players. He wanted someone who would make an immediate impact, deliver instant success. He wanted to go out at the top. It was a short-term solution to a short-term problem.\n\nS\u00e1nchez is a short-term solution, too, but the nature of the problem United faces has changed. City is no longer a rising force; it is the league\u2019s dominant team. No champion has retained its crown in the Premier League since 2009, but so far ahead of its rivals is City currently that it is difficult to see how it will be overhauled in the space of a single season. Adding S\u00e1nchez is both a show of force and a sign of, if not desperation, then certainly urgency.\n\nIt is impossible to avoid the suspicion that catching and overtaking City will take more than that.\n\nMourinho\u2019s opportunism \u2014 edging his way into a deal that City seemed to have tied up \u2014 is to be praised, but it is telling that both United and Arsenal, likely to replace S\u00e1nchez by signing both Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, now out of favor at Borussia Dortmund, will end the January transfer window having invested in hugely expensive players available only by chance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt does not suggest there is much long-term planning in place at either club, any overarching vision (though Arsenal\u2019s recent front office appointments, including a director of football operations, Raul Sanllehi, and a new chief scout, Sven Mislintat, suggest one may be forthcoming in London).\n\nThe same can be said of Chelsea, currently scouring England for any forward of reasonable height, and reportedly considering an offer for Peter Crouch, 36. These clubs can all afford to indulge such whims, such is the money swilling around the Premier League. Some or all of these deals may prove noteworthy successes.\n\nBut it is hard to imagine they will be enough to claw back Manchester City; certainly not this season, possibly not for some time. It is all very well winning battles, but only if you have some plan in place to finish the war.", "title": "On S\u00e1nchez, City Passes and United Strikes", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019re lucky enough in your lifetime to do so, you should climb a volcano. If you\u2019re really lucky, you should do so when it is (mildly) erupting, so that you can witness one of nature\u2019s most awesome spectacles at close quarters. And if you\u2019re a little foolhardy and a lot lucky, you might find yourself on top of a volcano during a serious eruption, which, when you think about the volatile and violent grandeur of such an event, will leave you feeling grateful that the whims of nature let you live to see another day.\n\nLast spring\u2019s eruption of Mount Etna, which routed a party of BBC journalists and tourists with bombs of red-hot lava (their panicked flight recorded on film and dutifully fire-hosed on the internet), reminded me of an earlier expedition \u2014 similarly exhilarating, but with better luck.\n\nIn the summer of 1977, Mount Etna entered a mild phase of eruption. I was living in Rome at the time. I had made a promise to myself during an earlier visit to Sicily that if Etna ever erupted while I was still in Italy, I would drop everything, jump on the next plane to Catania, and get as close to the eruption as I could. I was 26 years old and although I had no clue that I would eventually embark on a career in science writing, I rushed headlong into this adventure with an athlete\u2019s conviction of physical invincibility and a twentysomething\u2019s faith in improvisation. The following day, after an early morning flight, I found myself in Catania, staring up into a Mediterranean sky, Homeric in the brilliance of its blue \u2014 except for that little patch of sky near the top of the 10,808-foot volcano, marked by a smudge of gray.\n\nLike most of the things I did in those days, I didn\u2019t have a plan. I took a bus from the airport to the city (its local architecture, fashioned from dark blocks of Etna\u2019s extruded lava stone, can only be described as brooding), dumped my things in a cheap pensione, and caught the first bus to the Rifugio Sapienza. This refuge, at about 6,000 feet on the lower slopes of the volcano, s erves as a lodge during \u2014 believe it \u2014 ski season, when Etna\u2019s summit typically wears a crown of snow. As I walked across the parking lot, contemplating the suddenly dubious idea of setting off on a hike up the volcano in a pair of threadbare Adidas sneakers, I happened upon a group of journalists from the Italian television network RAI. A guide from Etna was about to drive them up to the site of the eruption in a vehicle adapted to the rugged, plantless terrain of the volcano.", "title": "On Top of Mount Etna, a Lesson in Lava (and Luck)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "How do you win the battle with \u201cfake news\u201d and reach those who believe The New York Times is biased?\n\n\u2014 Cristina Chan, in San Francisco\n\nThis is a really important \u2014 and tricky \u2014 question, and one that I think about a lot.\n\nPowerful forces are stoking distrust in the news media with attacks on the press and sowing confusion by promoting clickbait, rumor, fraudulent stories and propaganda. This has been driven in no small part by various politicians and technology platforms pursuing their short-term interests over the greater good. These tactics contribute to growing polarization and undermine trust in news organizations.\n\nIt will be hard for a single institution to counteract these forces, but we\u2019re determined to try. (I\u2019m encouraged that some leaders in Washington and Silicon Valley seem to be recognizing that they need to do their part.)\n\nThe best thing we at The Times can do is stay true to our mission of finding and telling the stories that matter, without fear or favor. I believe that our rapidly growing number of readers and subscribers is a testament to how people increasingly crave news they can trust. I also believe we still have more to do to help people understand why they should trust our journalism and to provide greater transparency into our reporting.\n\nIn the past, our approach was to let our work speak for itself. Our assumption was that people intuitively understood all the hard work that goes into a New York Times article. But we\u2019ve learned we need to do more to explain how our reporting works. For example, many readers don\u2019t know that a dateline from a foreign city means our reporters are physically in that place, on the ground seeing and hearing firsthand everything they\u2019re reporting. They don\u2019t know that Adam Liptak\u2019s Supreme Court reporting is made stronger by his experience as a lawyer, or that Sheri Fink\u2019s background as a physician informs her investigations into medical misconduct. And they don\u2019t know that for every person we quote in a story, sometimes dozens more have been interviewed.\n\nOn the flip side, I look at articles like Ellen Barry\u2019s heartbreaking tale of a woman murdered in India, C. J. Chivers\u2019s deeply empathetic examination of a Marine\u2019s unraveling after returning from war, or the investigation Malachy Browne led into how Americans were attacked by a foreign leader\u2019s security detail \u2014 all are great examples of the balance between classic journalistic storytelling and sharing helpful context about how we actually found and reported that story. (And it should be no surprise that when we do this well, it has a real, meaningful impact.)", "title": "On Trust and Transparency: A.G. Sulzberger, Our New Publisher, Answers Readers\u2019 Questions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Turkey, no doubt, has real security concerns along its long frontier with Syria, where it is now squarely at odds with the United States over American support of a Kurdish force trying to secure a vast area of northern and eastern Syria. Turkey\u2019s government has long faced an insurgency from within the restive Kurdish population that straddles the border, so any bolstering of Kurdish military strength is anathema to Turkey.\n\nBut just how far Mr. Erdogan will take his offensive remains to be seen. Will it be a limited incursion to make a point, or a full-blown operation to root out the Kurdish force that the Americans have built up and the Turks desperately oppose.\n\nThe shopkeepers near the mosque in Kilis had no doubts about who was responsible for the attack. \u201cP.K.K.,\u201d they said.\n\nThe P.K.K., or the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, is an outlawed Kurdish separatist movement that has been fighting the Turkish state for three decades.\n\nThe shopkeepers make no distinction between the Kurdish militant groups in Syria and the P.K.K., which operates in southeastern Turkey and Iraq. The Kurdish militants are all one group \u2014 and one threat \u2014 to them.\n\nRUSSIA BULGARIA Black Sea GEORGIA Istanbul Ankara TURKEY IRAN Kilis Aleppo Mediterranean Sea SYRIA IRAQ 300 mileS\n\n\u201cThey want to stir the city, to muddy the waters because we stand with our state,\u201d said Ercan Emir, a barber whose shop stands by the mosque.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey think, \u2018If we hurt them, and damage their lives and their goods, they will turn against the state,\u2019 \u201d he added.\n\nKilis and other towns along the border have been convulsed since the war broke out in Syria in 2011. The violence drove about 3.5 million Syrian refugees into Turkey, bringing fighters and smugglers in their midst, and rocket fire from across the border.\n\nKilis suffered most when the fighters of the Islamic State seized territory just across the border. The militants rained missiles on the town almost daily, killing 24 people in the area in early 2016.\n\nBut the P.K.K. has been a long-term source of strife, too. Mr. Erdogan spent much of his early years in power trying to negotiate a peace deal with the P.K.K., but since talks broke down in 2015, he has overseen a crackdown on Kurdish militants and political activists.\n\nThe group returned to violence and has been blamed for 12 suicide bombings in the last two and a half years.\n\nPhoto\n\nGiven the strife, there is widespread support across the country for the military operation against Kurdish militants in the Syrian enclave of Afrin.\n\nThe Turkish news media, which is almost overwhelmingly pro-government, has been energetic in its coverage in a longstanding tradition of militaristic nationalism.\n\nOpposition, meanwhile, has been stifled. Since the Afrin operation began last Saturday a few small protests against the operation were swiftly broken up, and dozens of people who made comments opposing the operation on social media have been detained. Most of them were Kurdish activists.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Erdogan, who recently allied his Justice and Development Party with the right-wing Nationalist Movement Party, has appeared on television in military fatigues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA campaign against Kurdish separatists has always found support among nationalists and other backers of a strong Turkish state, two of the biggest political blocs in Turkey.\n\nMilitary operations into Syria have also proved to be popular. Opinion polls showed 70 percent support for an operation that Turkey mounted in 2016 to clear the area of Islamic State, despite Turkish casualties.\n\nPhoto\n\nMetin Gurcan, a security analyst and a columnist for El-Monitor, said he estimated that there was the same level of support for the Afrin operation.\n\n\u201cNow this operation is happening and it is one heart, one hand,\u201d said Mr. Ozer, one of the shopkeepers.\n\nEven the main opposition party, the Republican People\u2019s Party, has voiced its support for the operation.\n\nThe Republican party had always advocated a negotiated settlement with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, rather than backing the Syrian opposition as Mr. Erdogan has done.\n\n\u201cWe are a political party that is against war,\u201d said Mehmet Akif Perker, a local representative of the party. Yet, he added, \u201cin a moment when nationalist pride is really strong, being against it will get a much stronger reaction from the people.\u201d\n\n\u201cFor years Turkey has suffered a lot from the P.K.K.,\u201d Mr. Perker said. \u201cWe are afraid that if we negotiate with them, they will pursue terror again.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe party also considered that it was in Turkey\u2019s economic interest to prevent the creation of an independent Kurdish region to its south that could allow oil routes to bypass Turkey, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe shopkeepers hoped the military operation would allow many of the Syrian refugees to return home. Many Syrian Arabs say they were forced out of their homes by the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, which has been fighting to dislodge the Islamic State from the region.\n\nKilis, a town with a population of fewer than 100,000, has swelled to 130,000 with the influx of refugees, and although the Syrians have been widely accepted, there is local resentment, especially over economic resources.\n\nTurkey has spent billions on the refugees, noted Mr. Emir, the barber, whose shop was empty. \u201cIf the government had given that money to the Turkish population there would not be any poor people left,\u201d he said.\n\n\n\nMany shops around the mosque were shuttered Thursday. That morning the shopkeepers attended the funeral of one of the victims of the rocket attack, a 65-year-old tailor, Muzafer Aydemir. The other victim, Tarik Tabbak, was a 22-year-old Syrian refugee.\n\nThe mosque\u2019s imam and muezzin were at the funeral, too, their heads swathed in bandages after being wounded in the attack.\n\nMr. Emir had been cutting the hair of a client on Wednesday evening when the rocket struck. He heard a strange sound of grating metal and ran from his glass-fronted shop, his customer bounding after him.\n\n\u201cMy client told me I saved his life,\u201d he said, laughing, \u201cand I did not charge him.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are all going to die one day,\u201d he added, \u201cbut because we might die at any moment, people treat each other more positively.\u201d", "title": "On Turkey\u2019s Border With Syria, Many Are Eager for War", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "When Hollywood women announced that they would wear black at this Sunday\u2019s Golden Globes in solidarity with sexual misconduct victims, it was inevitable that the plan would draw eye rolls.\n\nPopular culture\u2019s fascination with \u2014 and derision for \u2014 the pomp and preening baked into awards shows can\u2019t but extend to the women fixed in the cameras\u2019 glare.\n\nAlternately revering and tearing down famous women for their red-carpet looks has become a blood sport. Any causes that actors and actresses might promote, from the carpet or the stage, can have the hollow ring of political messaging by beauty pageant contestants (with all due respect to the recent Miss Peru hopefuls who powerfully protested gender violence). Isn\u2019t the red carpet at its heart a fashion show, a parade of the ultra-privileged, the land of \u201cGood point, Cate, now let\u2019s talk about that dress\u201d? Doesn\u2019t it perpetuate the objectification of women? Better to stay home, said the critics of Operation Black Gown: silently posturing in black would achieve exactly zilch.\n\nBut then an anti-sexual-harassment action plan, impressive in its breadth and created by hundreds of powerful women in entertainment, was announced on New Year\u2019s Day. Christened Time\u2019s Up, the initiative includes a $14 million legal fund to help victims of sexual harassment nationwide, legislation to punish companies that tolerate it, and a push for gender equality among executives at talent agencies and studios.", "title": "On the Golden Globes Red Carpet, Fighting Back in Black", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | On the Iran Nuclear Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Two releases this month have put the relationship between the press and the Oval Office on display: \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House\u201d by Michael Wolff, which caused a media whirlwind and was denounced by President Donald Trump, and \u201cThe Post,\u201d the Steven Spielberg film that highlights The Washington Post\u2019s standoff with the White House over the publishing of the Pentagon Papers in the 1970s. Here are three books that examine the historical dynamic between the presidency and the fourth estate.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE BULLY PULPIT\n\nTheodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism\n\nBy Doris Kearns Goodwin\n\n910 pages. Simon & Schuster. (2013)\n\nIn this biography, Goodwin examines Theodore Roosevelt through his relationship with the press, arguing that his \u201ccomplex and sometimes contentious partnerships\u201d with investigative journalists helped him speak directly to the public to push his political agenda and expose corruption like \u201cthe human and economic costs of unchecked industrial growth.\u201d He \u201ctested his ideas on reporters,\u201d frequently exchanged correspondence with his favorites and invited them to luncheons that could last until midnight. His policy was sometimes even informed by reporting: After reading Upton Sinclair\u2019s 1906 \u201cThe Jungle,\u201d which exposed the deplorable conditions of the meatpacking industry in Chicago, Roosevelt quickly moved to pass meat inspection legislation. Michiko Kakutani wrote that Goodwin \u201cprompts us to reconsider the ways political dynamics have, and have not, changed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE MAKING OF FDR\n\nThe Story of Stephen T. Early, America\u2019s First Modern Press Secretary\n\nBy Linda Lotridge Levin\n\n500 pp. Prometheus Books. (2008)\n\nIf you\u2019re wondering how an appearance like Barack Obama\u2019s on \u201cBetween Two Ferns\u201d with Zach Galifianakis became acceptable, you might turn to this biography of Franklin D. Roosevelt\u2019s press secretary, a man who fundamentally altered the way the presidency interacts with the press. Stephen T. Early discouraged Roosevelt from calling media sources directly, having him instead deliver a single message in news conferences held twice a week. Early expanded the mediums through which the president communicated to include radio and newsreels. He also helped create \u201cFireside Chats,\u201d the series of evening radio addresses given by Roosevelt through the Great Depression.\n\nPhoto\n\nALL THE PRESIDENT\u2019S MEN\n\nBy Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward\n\n349 pp. Simon & Schuster. (1974)\n\nWritten by the reporters responsible for breaking the Watergate scandal for The Washington Post, this book turns the ordeal into \u201ca fast-moving mystery, a whodunit written with ease,\u201d wrote our reviewer. In addition to showing how Bernstein and Woodward investigated the scandal, the book also reveals the inner workings of a newsroom, including the role editors play in determining the stories that are printed and the risks publications take in printing and reporting stories. Bernstein and Woodward describe their high stakes reporting through anecdotes like a 3 a.m. meeting on an editor\u2019s lawn (they were afraid of being bugged) or clandestine encounters with Deep Throat, Woodward\u2019s deeply connected anonymous source, that are \u201csuperbly and suspensefully described.\u201d", "title": "On the Presidency\u2019s Fraught Relationship With the Press", "authors": ["Concepci\u00f3n De Le\u00f3n"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Reporting on these communities was fairly new to me, and in my article (on Page A17), I wanted to avoid advancing clich\u00e9s or stereotypes about their culture being insular and stuck in the past. Indeed, the people I spoke to had an up-to-date sensibility and a clearheaded sense of how different the \u201cplain\u201d lifestyle is from that of the \u201cEnglish.\u201d\n\nI asked Mr. Martin where I might find buggy drivers to interview. He said local Mennonites typically celebrate weddings on Thursdays, go to produce auctions on Fridays and go to church on Sundays. So I headed to a hay auction in Penn Yan, N.Y., and found groups of Amish and Mennonite farmers gathered there to buy and sell truckloads of locally grown hay.\n\nHeather Ainsworth, a photographer, and I approached buggy owners and found them receptive and happy to chat, but not eager to have their names or direct photographs printed in the newspaper, because of religious rules about modesty.\n\nI soon learned that it is hard to find an Amish or Mennonite buggy owner who has not been in some form of accident or mishap. I spoke to the Yates County sheriff, who showed me dozens of photographs of mangled buggies and dead horses.\n\nEddie Zimmerman, 58, an Old Order Mennonite, said buggy drivers want fast horses accustomed to distractions alongside and therefore buy former harness racing horses at auction. They do not spook easily, he said, but when they do, they take off like a shot. A crowd of women in bonnets and long skirts and men in suspenders and wide-brimmed hats gathered as he began regaling us about various times his horses bolted after being startled. One horse pulled the buggy at top speed into a tree. Another damaged a passing car, costing Mr. Zimmerman $3,300 in car damages. He had to put down the horse.\n\nI visited Mr. Martin in his farmhouse, and he showed us his two family buggies, offering a ride in the larger one. The smaller one was for his children: a coupe they use for courting. It was the equivalent of a sports car, with pinstriping and plenty of flashing lights run by battery. Inside was blue carpeting and a snazzy interior console with deluxe woodwork.\n\nWhen I told him that several authorities spoke of teenage Amish and Mennonites drinking and driving buggies, he said that Amish and Mennonite people allowed teenagers to experience a freewheeling period known as rumspringa, but that rumors of its being an alcohol-soaked experience were exaggerated.\n\nSome Mennonite buggy owners do race each other, on rural roads while returning from church or the market, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, he said, breezing along in the buggy, \u201cSafer than being in a car.\u201d", "title": "On the Road With the Amish", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Nothing like a bit of hilarity to start the day. Or so it seemed: the chortle of an unseen man in a subway station, the humor that provoked it a mystery, out of earshot of a passing commuter. There was a pause, then the sound restarted. And again. Each time, it came closer to crossing the tonal boundary between laughing and crying. Its evolving meaning stalked me along the mezzanine of the 181st Street station of the A train.\n\nA man sat on the steps, his feet on the uptown platform, weeping.\n\nWell groomed, neatly dressed. Old enough to have a dusting of snow in his sideburns. Small bag over his shoulder. Between gusts of audible misery, he shuddered.\n\nHe deflected a greeting with his hand.\n\nI\u2019m fine.\n\nYou\u2019re fine?\n\nHis nose was running. He resumed sobbing. A train was coming into the station. The platform edge was about 10 feet away. He coiled as if to stand, but remained seated, and wound his fingers around the rods holding the banister. His legs were drawn to lift himself, but his fingers locked onto the rods, the impulse to get up thwarted by another to stay put.\n\nNo, no, no.\n\nThat was his voice, one-syllable wails over the approaching roar of the train. When it pulled in, he fell into another round of sobs. A few passengers got off and not surprisingly, took a different flight of stairs.", "title": "On the Subway, Help Is Not Coming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "It all started in late November, when, like every journalist in Lebanon, we were digging to find out what, precisely, had just happened to the prime minister, Saad Hariri. The basics were not in question: He had abruptly flown to Saudi Arabia and resigned; officials came to realize he was being coerced; and after a diplomatic scramble, he flew home and declared he was not quitting after all. He wanted what happened in Saudi Arabia to stay in Saudi Arabia. We, of course, did not.\n\nOne Lebanese official compared his task, and ours, to examining the black box: We knew the had plane crashed, but we wanted to know how and why. We eventually told the tale here as best we could, with new details like Mr. Hariri being physically manhandled by Saudi security agents.\n\nI put out feelers to my contacts, and so did Maria Abi-Habib. Maria is an old friend, but a new colleague, just hired from The Wall Street Journal\u2019s Beirut bureau. She is headed to The Times\u2019s Delhi bureau, but has not moved yet. So now, instead of competing, we combined our sources. That was how one story led to another.\n\nFrom the start, the Hariri story opened new doors. One reason we rarely write about Lebanese politics is that many officials here stand on great ceremony: Despite wielding diluted power in a deadlocked government in a tiny state, they require long preparations and faxed questions before the simplest interview. This time, though, they kept telling us to come right over. They wanted to dish.\n\nIt was Maria who got the most tantalizing early tip. But it was a confusing one. She went to see a senior Lebanese official who, instead of talking about Mr. Hariri, began a tale about the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and his recent trip to the Saudi capital, Riyadh. Maria looked so confused that the official paused to make sure she recognized Mr. Abbas\u2019s name.", "title": "On the Trail of a Story in Lebanon, Stumbling on a Scoop", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "After 65 years of battling against the influence of organized crime on the docks, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor is fighting for its own survival. Its biggest threat has come not from the mob in Brooklyn or Bayonne, N.J., but from elected officials in Trenton.\n\nOn Monday, New Jersey\u2019s departing Republican governor, Chris Christie, signed a bill that would withdraw New Jersey\u2019s support for the commission, a move that could effectively mean its demise. The commission responded on Tuesday by suing Mr. Christie\u2019s Democratic successor, Philip D. Murphy, hours after he took the oath of office.\n\nThe commission\u2019s dispute is not with Mr. Murphy himself but with the state\u2019s effort to take away the commission\u2019s power to police the shipping industry and its unionized work force. In the complaint, filed in federal court in Newark, the commission said that the bill that Mr. Christie signed into law before leaving office would \u201ccripple the commission.\u201d\n\nThe commission argued that New Jersey cannot unilaterally decide to dissolve the agency because it was created through an interstate compact with New York. That compact, enacted by Congress in 1953, was a response to articles in The New York Sun that exposed the grip the mob had on commerce in the ports around New York City.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat influence may have subsided over the decades since the movie \u201cOn the Waterfront\u201d dramatized life on the docks, but it has not been rooted out completely, the commission argued. It said in its complaint that the shipping industry in and around New York City \u201chas been chronically plagued, historically and currently, by organized crime and labor racketeering.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the last few years, the commission investigated and helped to prosecute several union officials, shop stewards and foremen for a conspiracy to extort their own union members on behalf of the Genovese organized crime family, the complaint stated.", "title": "On the Waterfront, a Mob Watchdog Is Fighting to Survive", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLast January, as one does, I pledged to eat better. Not one to phone it in, I adopted a meal plan with almost every vice crossed off the list. I blame Instagram, which was where I first spied the hashtag #Whole30, along with hundreds of iPhone-perfect images of delicious-looking food. If I ate nothing but whole, unprocessed foods for 30 days, the Whole30 program promised, I would have less bloating, fewer cravings, better sleep and more energy.\n\nAdhering to Whole30 involved staying away from almost everything I loved. Wine? Forget it. Bread? No way. Even foods I\u2019d assumed were healthful were verboten, including peanuts and chickpeas. (There went my hummus habit.) Other no\u2019s included: no wheat, no dairy, no soy and no sugar. For one whole month I subsisted on air and water (just kidding).\n\nWatching everything I eat is nothing new for me, since I have lived with Type 1 diabetes most of my life and monitor my blood glucose levels dozens of times throughout the day. I can eat sugary foods and other carbohydrates; I just have to give myself insulin to coincide with the elevated glucose running around in my bloodstream, typically about 10 to 30 minutes after each meal. The fewer carbs I eat, the lower my insulin requirements.\n\nWhile there are no refined sugars in the Whole30 diet, there are plenty of carbs: vegetables, fruit, even nuts have them. For an entire month I happily consumed plants, protein and fat. Breakfast became coconut yogurt layered with blueberries, chia seeds and hemp hearts. Lunch was a mound of kale, carrots, tomatoes and tuna. Dinner featured roasted sweet potato, zucchini \u201cnoodles\u201d and salmon. For snacks I ate nuts, unsweetened jerky and green apples, which are generally less sweet than red ones, and less sweet means fewer carbs.", "title": "On the Whole30 Diet, Vowing to Eat \u2018Smarter\u2019 Carbs for More Than 30 Days", "authors": ["Larissa Zimberoff"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Describing an incident in which he was halted just outside his office in Santa Monica, Calif., Mr. Akil said in a recent interview, \u201cI had been stopped by the police quite a few times, but my anger in being stopped again was about to get me killed. I stopped putting on the mask of, this is how I\u2019m supposed to act in these situations.\u201d\n\n\u201cAt a certain point,\u201d he added, \u201cI closed my eyes and took a moment. And I asked myself, is this really worth dying for?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn that situation, Mr. Akil could not call on any superhuman abilities. But he sees \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d and the platform it provides as a power in its own right.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been given a gift,\u201d Mr. Akil said of the show, \u201cand I have to use it the way I think I\u2019m intended to use it, to talk about the things I feel people need to talk about.\u201d\n\nMr. Akil, who is credited with developing \u201cBlack Lightning,\u201d has worked widely as a director of films (\u201cJumping the Broom\u201d) and a writer, director and producer of television shows like \u201cGirlfriends,\u201d \u201cThe Game\u201d and \u201cBeing Mary Jane,\u201d series that were created by his wife, Mara Brock Akil. (They are also collaborating on shows for other networks, including the OWN comedy-drama \u201cLove Is ___.\u201d)\n\nMs. Akil, who is also an executive producer of \u201cBlack Lightning,\u201d said she likes to think of her TV characters as possessing \u201cblack girl magic,\u201d which she explained as \u201cpower without the suits or capes.\u201d In childhood, she said she had an affection for more traditional superheroes like Wonder Woman and the Bionic Woman.\n\nMr. Akil\u2019s youthful fascination with costumed crime-fighters was more complicated. Though he loved comic books so much that he wore a Batman costume to school one Halloween, he drifted away from the medium.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI never saw a true representation \u2014 an iconic hero \u2014 for myself,\u201d Mr. Akil said. \u201cIt just got boring, reading about all these really powerful and heroic white guys.\u201d\n\nHis interest was rejuvenated in the 1990s by the comics of Milestone Media, a publishing imprint for black writers and artists to tell stories of black superheroes. (Several of these characters have since been incorporated into the DC universe.)\n\nIn 2015, when the Akils struck an overall TV deal with Warner Bros., the parent company of DC, they inquired about the Milestone characters. Those properties were unavailable, but Warner Bros. instead offered them Black Lightning.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Mr. Akil recalled that conversation, \u201cMara\u2019s the very expressive one and I tried to be cool, like Miles Davis cool. I just sat there, like, \u2018That sounds interesting.\u2019 But inside, I was like, oh, yeah.\u201d\n\nMr. Akil added, \u201cTo me, Jefferson Pierce represented every side of me. I knew that I would be able to flesh him out.\u201d\n\nThe Black Lightning character debuted in his own DC Comics series, written by Tony Isabella and illustrated by Trevor Von Eeden, in 1977. In biographical details added in the ensuing decades, Jefferson Pierce was revealed as a child of the Metropolis slums and a former Olympic athlete who uses his control of electricity to fight criminals, corrupt politicians and other evildoers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOf particular interest to the Akils was the idea that Black Lightning had set aside his superhero status and returned to it in middle age.\n\n\u201cIt echoes the idea that we can all get into this fight, at whatever place in our lives, at whatever age,\u201d Ms. Akil said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot to fix, a lot to make right, and it\u2019s not going to solve itself.\u201d\n\nThat aspect of the character was also welcomed by Mr. Williams, the \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d star, who had nearly written off the possibility that he\u2019d get to play a superhero.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA veteran of TV shows like \u201cNash Bridges,\u201d \u201cPrison Break,\u201d \u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d and \u201cHart of Dixie,\u201d Mr. Williams had auditioned for the lead on \u201cLuke Cage,\u201d the Netflix series based on that Marvel character.\n\nWhen it instead went to Mike Colter, Mr. Williams said, \u201cThat was rough. I can be honest at this point. Everybody who knew me knew that I desperately wanted to do that. But when you don\u2019t get a role, you lick your wounds and move on.\u201d", "title": "On \u2018Black Lightning,\u2019 a Superhero Takes On Race, Justice and the Real World", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDrinking deeply from the past is a reliable form of nourishment \u2014 it can soothe, and it can comfort. Some singers lean on it like a chaise. But some see it as a challenge, a high-wire act executed while surveilled by the unforgiving eyes of history.\n\nAnderson East understands what\u2019s at stake when channeling yesteryear. \u201cEncore,\u201d his second major-label album, is an often lustrous revisiting of raucous Southern soul, rousingly delivered and pinpoint precise. He has a voice full of extremely careful scrape and crunch, but his howls never feel unhinged.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. East, 30, is originally from Alabama. In addition to songwriting \u2014 over the last two years, he\u2019s collaborated regularly with Miranda Lambert, with whom he\u2019s romantically linked \u2014 he has been tinkering with heritage soul music. His 2015 album, \u201cDelilah,\u201d was a slightly more tentative take on the style, but on \u201cEncore,\u201d he blossoms.\n\n\u201cKing For a Day,\u201d written by Mr. East with Chris and Morgane Stapleton, is a rollicking history lesson, and \u201cSurrender\u201d is a nod to the exuberant stomp of Ike and Tina Turner. Mr. East extends his approach even to covers, like his muscular soul update of the bluesman Ted Hawkins\u2019s \u201cSorry You\u2019re Sick,\u201d which is punctuated with bright horns.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExecuting at this level requires not just a vocalist who\u2019s dutifully studied, but also a team of equally faithful students. \u201cEncore\u201d is produced by Dave Cobb, who has made tactile, glossed revivalism his stock in trade in recent years; it is performed by an exceptionally sharp band that is unshy and enthused.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe downside of this approach \u2014 at least for a singer \u2014 is that at times the music is so deeply reverent that it becomes the main character, the gasoline for the song\u2019s emotional narrative, rendering the lyrics, and even the singing, immaterial. Such is the case on \u201cHouse Is a Building,\u201d which is a conversation between downcast piano and horns that Mr. East can\u2019t penetrate, and on his sweet but level cover of Willie Nelson\u2019s \u201cSomebody Pick Up My Pieces.\u201d", "title": "On \u2018Encore,\u2019 Anderson East Revisits the Rough Soul of Yesteryear", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The national uproar over sexual harassment has the entire country debating how to deal with these issues \u2014 particularly when it comes to more powerful men trying to take advantage of their underlings. That\u2019s why stories like the one Haberman and Chozick reported are important. They\u2019re a way of helping us figure this all out.\n\nWhile we don\u2019t know all the details, it doesn\u2019t sound unreasonable that an employee with first-time charges of shoulder-rubbing and a forehead kiss should get a punishment less drastic than immediate dismissal. Except, as we keep needing to point out, there was that part about Strider being the values guy.\n\nAnd he was a campaign gun-for-hire who, if he had been kicked out, would probably have moved to another political job. As he did when the campaign ended and Strider went on to a pro-Hillary group called Correct the Record, where he was fired for what Haberman and Chozick reported as \u201cworkplace issues, including allegations that he harassed a young female aide.\u201d\n\nWhoops.\n\nHere\u2019s where I\u2019m coming down: Hillary Clinton was the first woman to run for president on a major party ticket, and when she did it, she won the popular vote. She\u2019s broken a trillion barriers. She\u2019s also done enormous good work to improve the lives of women in this country.\n\nBut she\u2019s never been at her strongest when it comes to men on the prowl. While her faith adviser wasn\u2019t anywhere near the level of a Harvey Weinstein, she did hang out with Weinstein, too, cherishing him as a beloved donor. And some women have never really gotten over the fact that she did not leave her husband when she discovered he was having an affair, in the White House, with a girl far too young and powerless to be a genuinely willing partner.\n\nBecause sexual harassment is so much on our national mind right now, we\u2019d like her to be a heroine on that issue, too. But if there\u2019s anything we\u2019ve learned in all of our years with Hillary Clinton, it\u2019s that you can be both great and deeply imperfect. It\u2019s one of her gifts. Even if right now we really wish she\u2019d fired the faith adviser.", "title": "Opinion | Once Again: How Hillary Holds Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSo if you were championing the best things about the internet, it was easy to be disappointed that it was hijacked to subvert the very things it could foster,\u201d Ms. Kornbluh said. But she said few people in government were looking with a full view of how social media and other internet services posed national security, economic and other risks.\n\nMr. Ghosh and Mr. Scott played a leading role in helping to create the tech-friendly policies that helped companies like Facebook and Google flourish during the Obama administration. But as more information trickled out about the role played by technology firms in Russia\u2019s attempts to influence the presidential election, they, like many Democrats, became disillusioned.\n\n\u201cWe were always careful to condition our optimism and our advocacy that this technology was potentially a double-edged sword,\u201d said Mr. Scott, who is a senior adviser to the Open Technology Institute at New America. \u201cBut I guess we didn\u2019t expect them to hit home quite as hard as it did.\u201d\n\nTitled \u201c#DigitalDeceit: Exposing the Internet Technologies of Precision Propaganda,\u201d their report argues that the interests of internet giants in helping advertisers run persuasive campaigns are aligned with those of someone looking to spread misinformation.\n\nThe authors suggest a few ways to regulate the advertising technology industry, including requiring more transparency for political advertising, restricting data collection or ad targeting on political issues, and strengthening consumer protection and competition policies.\n\nRepublicans have also expressed concerns about internet giants. Many on President Trump\u2019s campaign suspected that Google rigged search results in favor of Mrs. Clinton, questioning the influence of high-profile supporters of hers like Eric Schmidt, who is the former executive chairman of Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet. They were outraged by claims that Facebook manipulated its trending topics feature to push down results related to Republicans.\n\nBut increasingly, the most vocal criticism is coming from Democrats. Tom Wheeler, Mr. Obama\u2019s head of the Federal Communications Commission, recently called for social media firms to make it easier to figure out how certain information goes viral, who is sending those posts and what impact that activity may have.", "title": "Once Cozy With Silicon Valley, Democrats Grow Wary of Tech Giants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "For other young athletes just striking out, there seemed little they could do but give in, buckling under the pressure of knowing so many stars had seemingly benefited from him. And so a young gymnast named Chelsea Zerfas, now 15, spoke of anguished probing, under the guise of treatment, face down on an exam room table when she was 13, feeling helpless to challenge a doctor at that age.\n\nThe occasion of the hearing, to help a judge decide Dr. Nassar\u2019s prospective sentence on state charges of nearly a dozen sexual assaults, appeared almost beside the point. He had been sentenced to 60 years in federal prison on a child pornography conviction, and the judge in this state court hearing has said that Dr. Nassar, 54, who has pleaded guilty to several sexual-assault charges, can expect to spend the rest of his life in prison.\n\nBut before then, she allowed so-called victim impact statements from the 140 girls and women whom prosecutors accuse Dr. Nassar of abusing, leading to days of wrenching testimony here that has evolved into not only a nationally televised reckoning of his crimes but an indictment of a sport that his victims say did little to protect them.\n\nAt the same time, the hearing has dovetailed with the continued expansion of the #MeToo movement that seeks to hold predatory men to account \u2014 in this case, in excruciating detail.\n\n\u201cCome hell or high water, we will find a way to take every last one of you down that could have stopped this monster,\u201d said Amy Labadie, a former gymnast who testified Friday morning. She added, \u201cIt\u2019s hard to see into the future and not think this will affect me forever.\u201d\n\nSome of the victims described how the team doctor\u2019s actions spawned suicidal thoughts and ruptured their families, how they hoped he would rot in prison, and how they desperately wanted the blame and repercussions to extend far beyond him \u2014 to the people and the organizations that turned a blind eye.\n\n\u201cImagine feeling like you have no power and no voice,\u201d Ms. Raisman said Friday. \u201cWell, you know what, Larry? I have both power and voice, and I am only just beginning to use them. All these brave women have power, and we will use our voices to make sure you get what you deserve: a life of suffering spent replaying the words delivered by this powerful army of survivors.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Nassar pleaded guilty in November to seven counts of sexual assault, and his sentencing hearing, which began Tuesday, is now expected to continue next week, as the number of women who have wanted to speak in court has grown, from 88 to 105 to 120, at last count \u2014 emboldened by what has happened here this week. Judge Rosemarie Aquilina said she had cleared her docket.\n\n\u201cYou are all superheroes,\u201d the judge said Friday morning after one of the victims, choking back tears, read her statement.\n\nDr. Nassar entered the courtroom at 9:04 a.m. He wore a dark blue prison uniform. After he reached the witness box, where he has sat with a hangdog expression since the hearing began, he appeared to recognize that Ms. Raisman and Ms. Wieber were seated together in the front row. Dr. Nassar looked down and slowly shook his head.\n\nMs. Wieber, 22, was the first person to testify on Friday \u2014 but the 69th to have her statement heard since the proceedings began. Ms. Wieber said Dr. Nassar began treating her when she was 8. Like many of those who came before her, Ms. Wieber said that Dr. Nassar had manipulated her by bringing her food and coffee at pressure-cooker training camps where such luxuries were prohibited.\n\n\u201cNobody was protecting us from being taken advantage of,\u201d Ms. Wieber said. \u201cNobody was ever concerned whether or not we were being sexually abused.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Raisman took clear aim at both U.S.A. Gymnastics and the United States Olympic Committee when she appeared in court on Friday.\n\n\u201cNeither U.S.A. Gymnastics nor the U.S.O.C. have reached out to express sympathy or even offer support,\u201d she said. \u201cNot even to ask: \u2018How did this happen? What do you think we can do to help?\u2019 Why have I and others here, probably, not heard anything from the leadership at the U.S.O.C.? Why has the United States Olympic Committee been silent? Why isn\u2019t the U.S.O.C. here right now?\u201d\n\nMark Jones, a spokesman for the Olympic committee, said in a statement that it first became aware of the possibility that a physician with the gymnastics federation had been abusing athletes in 2015.\n\n\u201cAt that time, U.S.A. Gymnastics indicated that they were in the process of contacting the appropriate law enforcement agencies,\u201d Mr. Jones said. \u201cWe are heartbroken that this abuse occurred, proud of the brave victims that have come forward and grateful that our criminal justice system has ensured that Nassar will never be able to harm another young woman.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Jones said, the Olympic committee will continue to press for \u201cmeaningful change\u201d in the gymnastics federation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe federation announced on Thursday that it would cut ties with Karolyi Ranch, a renowned training facility that was one of the places where Dr. Nassar molested the gymnasts.\n\n\u201cThe development camp taking place through Sunday is the last U.S.A. Gymnastics activity at the Ranch,\u201d the federation said in a statement on Friday. \u201cNext week\u2019s training camp for the U.S. women\u2019s national team is canceled and the Acro World Team Trials scheduled for the first week in February has been relocated.\u201d\n\nKara Johnson, now a high school student, spoke about how she was taken to Dr. Nassar for back and hip treatment when she was a 13-year-old runner. Dr. Nassar, she said, placed her on a table on her stomach and then molested her. She described how he left the room, returned with a lubricant and repeated the abuse. He then smacked her on her \u201cbare butt,\u201d called her \u201csweetie\u201d and told her that if she ever had her period when she came to see him, to be sure to let him know, she said.\n\n\u201cHow was I supposed to know at the age of 13 what was medically acceptable and what the boundaries were?\u201d she said.\n\nHer sister Madeline was also abused. Now 15, she told the court that as a 12-year-old gymnast, she was sent to Dr. Nassar for back treatment and underwent the same abuse. \u201cAt only 12 years old, I had no idea that it was inappropriate, illegal and wrong,\u201d she said.\n\nOn Thursday, McKayla Maroney, 22, another Olympic gymnast, said she had \u201cscars\u201d that might never heal after being abused by Dr. Nassar, starting when she was 13 or 14.\n\n\u201cDr. Nassar was not a doctor,\u201d she said in a statement read for her by a prosecutor. \u201cHe in fact is, was, and forever shall be, a child molester, and a monster of a human being. End of story.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe impact of the trial, and Dr. Nassar\u2019s history of assault, is spreading well beyond the courtroom. Michigan State University, which employed Dr. Nassar, was also facing increasing pressure after revelations that 14 people, including the president, Lou Anna K. Simon, had been warned about his conduct.\n\nMs. Raisman added that she had not been planning to speak in court \u2014 \u201cI was scared and nervous,\u201d she said \u2014 but decided to add her name to the list once she began listening to the impact statements that were delivered earlier this week.\n\n\u201cMy dream,\u201d she said, \u201cis that one day everyone will know what the words \u2018me, too\u2019 signify, but they will be educated and able to protect themselves from predators like Larry so that they will never, ever, ever have to say the words, \u2018me, too.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe room filled with applause as Ms. Raisman thanked the judge and backed away from the microphone. More women were waiting their turn.", "title": "One After Another, Athletes Face Larry Nassar and Recount Sexual Abuse", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola", "Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Ana Kras has never been a coffee person: \u201cI have a very strong intolerance to it,\u201d says the Serbian-born, New York-based artist. Instead, she favors a specific kind of chai latte that her friend and collaborator, the designer Beatrice Valenzuela, taught her to make on a trip to Los Angeles last winter. \u201cI immediately wrote down the recipe and started doing the same, or a version of it, every single morning,\u201d says Kras, who is known for her modernist furniture, abstract drawings and photography. She was soon recommending the drink to others, emphasizing that it\u2019s not only tasty, but also can have medicinal properties, as well \u2014 depending on which ingredients you add.\n\nThe \u201cpotion,\u201d as she now calls it, consists of vegan, organic masala chai spice and ground vanilla powder, to which she adds hot water and a selection of \u201cdusts,\u201d or pulverized forms of adaptogenic herbs (used since ancient times to fortify the body against ailments). Lately, her lineup has included ashwagandha, cordyceps, mucuna pruriens and reishi \u2014 an assortment meant to boost immunity and bring mental clarity. She blends all of this together and then adds a few spoonfuls of homemade cashew cream for thickening, which she makes herself. \u201cIt\u2019s super easy \u2014 easier than almond milk \u2014 because there\u2019s no draining,\u201d she explains.", "title": "One Artist\u2019s \u2018Life-Changing\u2019 Morning Drink", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEvery person is different,\u201d said Seamus Hughes, deputy director of the Program on Extremism at George Washington University. \u201cYou do occasionally have some form of trauma in their past that makes room for jihadism to creep in. But you also have people who\u2019ve lived the American dream. There isn\u2019t really any rhyme or reason to it.\u201d\n\nIn New York, for example, investigators are still trying to figure out what caused Sayfullo Saipov, a 29-year-old native of Uzbekistan, to allegedly climb into a rental truck on Halloween and drive it down a bike path on the West Side of Manhattan, killing eight people. After the attack, Mr. Saipov told the authorities that he had been inspired by Islamic State videos and those who knew him said that his dreams of success in the United States had not worked out as he had hoped. But the specific steps that led to the episode remain a mystery.\n\nMuch the same is true for Akayed Ullah, a Bangladeshi immigrant who is accused of strapping a pipe bomb to his chest last month and blowing it up in a Times Square subway tunnel. Though Mr. Ullah, 27, has told investigators he was radicalized online and set his bomb off to protest American airstrikes in the Middle East, the narrative of his journey is incomplete at best.\n\nWhat makes the case of Mr. Saidakhmetov remarkable is the meticulous description he has given of his own radicalization. While it is only one man\u2019s story, the 53-page memo offers a rare glimpse into a terror suspect\u2019s life.\n\n\u201cUsually with things like this, you get a letter or two from a mother or father, but this is a step-by-step rundown of everything that happened,\u201d Mr. Hughes said. \u201cIt\u2019s like reading a novel.\u201d\n\nAccording to the memo, Mr. Saidakhmetov was born along the old Silk Road in the \u201cbackwater city\u201d of Turkestan, Kazakhstan. His father, Arbor Yuylanov, was an alcoholic who beat and raped his mother, Saeira Gulyamova, the memo said. When Mr. Saidakhmetov was 4, his mother fled the marriage and took him to Chernyak, her hometown farming village on the edge of the Kazakh steppe. After that, he rarely saw his father, usually, the memo says, roaming drunk on Turkestan\u2019s streets.\n\nThough Chernyak had a mosque, religion played a limited role in Mr. Saidakhmetov\u2019s childhood. His family identified as Muslim, but did not attend the traditional Friday prayers. His life became even more secular when, after months in Chernyak, his mother moved him to Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. There, she worked long hours as a journalist and left him in their apartment. Alone most nights until 9, the memo said, Mr. Saidakhmetov learned to light a stove when he was 7 and often ate solitary dinners, waiting for his mother.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe family might have stayed in Tashkent. But Ms. Gulyamova\u2019s journalism work eventually ran her afoul of the Uzbek government. She moved to Brooklyn in 2010, settling in the neighborhood of Brighton Beach and taking a job cleaning houses. Mr. Saidakhmetov remained behind in the care of an aunt. But within about a year, he joined his mother in New York.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was 16 at the time, living in an unfamiliar country where he barely spoke the language and had no friends or family beyond his mother. He enrolled at James Madison High School, but for his first six months, the memo said, did not understand a word that was said.\n\nIn his second year at Madison, prosecutors say, Mr. Saidakhmetov attacked a safety officer and was expelled. A few months later, he transferred to Abraham Lincoln High School, but did not last long there either. \u201cThe New York City public schools didn\u2019t have the resources or energy to help him,\u201d said his lawyer, Adam Perlmutter. \u201cSo he dropped out.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was then \u2014 at a time of \u201cdisconnection, loss and lack of purpose,\u201d the memo said \u2014 that Mr. Saidakhmetov began exploring the internet and found the lectures of Sheik Abdullah Bukhari, an Uzbek cleric based in Istanbul. Sheik Bukhari encouraged young men to find meaning in their lives through the practice of Islam \u2014 and gradually, the memo said, Mr. Saidakhmetov did.\n\nBut while his new religiosity gave him direction, it also led to conflicts with his mother. He began to criticize her for leaving her head uncovered and for not attending mosque, as he had started doing. Once, the memo said, Mr. Saidakhmetov threw out some of his mother\u2019s beauty products fearing they were made with pork, which Islam forbids. After a particularly heated fight, Ms. Gulyamova moved from their home, leaving her son to live alone again.\n\n\u201cIt repeated the pattern of abandonment at the worst time possible,\u201d the memo said.\n\nMr. Saidakhmetov \u2014 18 at the time \u2014 asked a fellow Uzbek man he had met at the mosque, Abdurasul Juraboev, to move in. At 24, Mr. Juraboev was older and more devout than his new friend and quickly cast a spell on him, the memo said. Though Mr. Juraboev was also struggling in New York \u2014 he worked in a gyro shop \u2014 he seemed so versed in Islamic law that Mr. Saidakhmetov began to call him \u201csheikh.\u201d\n\nAs the men grew closer, momentous events were occurring in the Middle East. In 2014, the leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, proclaimed the formation of a new caliphate. At home in a new apartment in Midwood, Brooklyn, Mr. Saidakhmetov devoured news of the Islamic State, fueling what the memo called his \u201cnewfound sense of belonging.\u201d\n\n\u201cInstead of being a lonely kid lost in Brooklyn with limited English proficiency,\u201d it said, \u201che was part of a worldwide online community \u2014 the Ummah \u2014 supporting an Islamic religious movement.\u201d\n\nAs part of that support, prosecutors said, Mr. Saidakhmetov started posting pro-ISIS comments on Hilofatnews, an Uzbek-language jihadist website. In one of them, in August 2014, he talked about a mass execution of Iraqi soldiers by ISIS militants. \u201cI was very happy after reading this,\u201d he wrote. \u201cMy eyes joyful so much victory.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Juraboev was also posting comments on the website and one of them attracted the attention of the government. In it, he expressed an interest in killing President Obama.\n\nFour weeks later, court papers say, federal agents placed an informant in the men\u2019s mosque and the timing was precipitous. Mr. Saidakhmetov and Mr. Juraboev had already discussed getting a third roommate. \u201cNow, out of nowhere, someone had shown up at their mosque, who shared their deep religious beliefs,\u201d the memo said, \u201cand who, coincidentally, was looking for a place to live.\u201d\n\nThe case, by that point, was all but over. Within five months, Mr. Saidakhmetov had bought a round-trip ticket from New York to Istanbul. He told the informant that once he reached Turkey, he and Mr. Juraboev planned to enter Syria and fight with the Islamic State.\n\nHe had moved from believer, to planner, to doer, the memo said. \u201cAll of the pieces were perfectly fit in place.\u201d", "title": "One Brooklyn Man\u2019s Lonely Journey to Jihad", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "So when Dr. Gaster explained his directive, \u201cit just made so much sense,\u201d Ms. Vandervelde said. \u201cWhile I could make these decisions, why not make them? I filled it out right there.\u201d\n\nLike a growing number of Americans over age 60, she already had a standard advance directive, designating a decision-maker (her husband) to direct her medical care if she became incapacitated.\n\nNot all experts are convinced another directive is needed. But as Dr. Gaster and his co-authors recently argued in the journal JAMA, the usual forms don\u2019t provide much help with dementia.\n\n\u201cThe standard advance directives tend to focus on things like a \u2018permanent coma\u2019 or a \u2018persistent vegetative state,\u2019\u201d Dr. Gaster said. \u201cMost of the time, they apply to a person with less than six months to live.\u201d\n\nAlthough it\u2019s a terminal disease, dementia often intensifies slowly, over many years. The point at which dementia patients can no longer direct their own care isn\u2019t predictable or obvious.\n\nMoreover, patients\u2019 goals and preferences might well change over time. In the early stage, life may remain enjoyable and rewarding despite memory problems or difficulties with daily tasks.\n\n\u201cThey have potentially many years in which they wouldn\u2019t want a directive that says \u2018do not resuscitate,\u2019\u201d Dr. Gaster said. But if severe dementia leaves them bedridden, unresponsive and dependent, they might feel differently \u2014 yet no longer be able to say so.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhereas a persistent vegetative state occurs rarely, Dr. Gaster tells his patients, dementia strikes far more commonly.\n\nHow commonly? That\u2019s not a simple question to answer.\n\nResearchers often cite the long-term Framingham study, which in 1997 estimated the lifetime risk at age 65 as 10.9 percent for men and 12 percent for women.\n\nBut the participants in that study were overwhelmingly white. Among the populations facing higher dementia rates are African-Americans, Dr. Murali Doraiswamy, a neuroscientist at Duke University, pointed out.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast year, the journal Demography published a more representative model, estimating that for the cohort born in 1940, the lifetime risk at age 70 was 30.8 percent for men and 37.4 percent for women.\n\nDr. Gaster tells patients that \u201csomewhere between 20 and 30 percent of us will at some point develop dementia.\u201d Over the past year, as patients turn 65 and qualify for Medicare \u2014 which covers a visit to discuss advance care planning \u2014 he has offered them his dementia-specific directive, intended to supplement their other directives.\n\nFor each stage of dementia, the patient can choose among four options. \u201cFull efforts to prolong my life\u201d and \u201ccomfort-oriented care only, focused on relieving suffering\u201d represent two ends of the spectrum.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPatients can also opt for lifesaving treatments \u2014 except when their hearts stop or they can\u2019t breathe on their own, precluding resuscitation or ventilators.\n\nOr they can opt to receive care where they live but avoid hospitalization. \u201cFor someone who doesn\u2019t understand what\u2019s happening, going to an E.R. or being hospitalized can be really traumatic,\u201d Dr. Gaster said. The experience can lead to delirium and other setbacks.\n\nSo far, 50 to 60 patients have filled out the form. A few have declined his offer to discuss dementia; others \u201cnod and thank me and take it home and never mail it back.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut most appreciate the overture, Dr. Gaster said, especially if family members have experienced dementia. \u201cIt\u2019s something they think and worry about, and they welcome the idea because they do have clear wishes.\u201d In that case, he adds the completed form to their medical records.\n\nWe could debate whether a separate dementia form, on top of the general advance directive everyone should have, makes sense. Already, nurses and doctors lament that paperwork often winds up forgotten in a drawer, a safe deposit box or a lawyer\u2019s office, unavailable in a crisis.\n\nIf patients haven\u2019t updated the directive in years, their designated proxies may have moved or died. Proxies may never have learned their loved ones\u2019 preferences in the first place. Will adding another directive clarify this process?\n\nOther leaders in the campaign to persuade Americans to document their end-of-life wishes had questions, too.\n\nEllen Goodman, founder of The Conversation Project (whose dementia-related kit similarly presents choices at different stages), pointed out that the new form represents a patient-doctor agreement.\n\n\u201cWe need to have families involved,\u201d she said. \u201cNo checklist on earth is going to cover everything you encounter. Most important is the conversation with the decision-maker. That person has to understand what you value and what\u2019s important to you.\u201d\n\nDr. Rebecca Sudore, a geriatrician and palliative care specialist at the University of California, San Francisco, agreed. Her effort \u2014 Prepare for Your Care, an online guide \u2014 encourages users to incorporate their reasons for various decisions. \u201cAt the bedside, the \u2018why\u2019 is very important,\u201d she said.\n\nBoth The Conversation Project and Prepare for Your Care provide links to the advance directive/durable power-of-attorney forms legal in each state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s not in dispute: It\u2019s crucial to talk to family, friends and doctors about the quality of life we find acceptable and unacceptable, which interventions we agree to or don\u2019t \u2014 and then to document those decisions and circulate the document to designated decision-makers and everyone else who might be involved.\n\nAnd yes, we should incorporate decisions about dementia into that process, whether in a separate form or not.\n\nWhen Ann Vandervelde completed her dementia-specific directive, \u201cI felt great relief,\u201d she said. It gave her a sense of control, \u201cand that\u2019s really important to me, to be in the driver\u2019s seat all the way to the end.\u201d", "title": "One Day Your Mind May Fade. At Least You\u2019ll Have a Plan.", "authors": ["Paula Span", "The New Old Age"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "A year ago, with an impressive roster of Goldman Sachs alumni on their way to top White House positions, the return of \u201cGovernment Sachs\u201d was in full swing.\n\nThe newly inaugurated President Trump tapped Steven T. Mnuchin as treasury secretary, Gary D. Cohn as director of the National Economic Council and Dina Powell as White House adviser. Ms. Powell later served as both deputy national security adviser for strategy and senior counselor for economic initiatives.\n\nAnthony Scaramucci, another Goldman alumnus, was on the transition team en route to the post of White House communications director months later. Outranking them all was Stephen K. Bannon, the chief White House strategist, who worked at the bank early in his career and who reported directly to the president.\n\nDepending on one\u2019s point of view, this was either a sellout to Wall Street by a president who had railed against Goldman during the campaign, or a welcome check on some of Mr. Trump\u2019s more radical tendencies.", "title": "One Goldman Takeover That Failed: The Trump White House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "A night out ended in a hail of bullets for a man who was killed and two others who were wounded early Sunday near Kennedy International Airport in Queens, the police said.\n\nThe victims were sitting at a stoplight on the service road to the Van Wyck Expressway at North Conduit Avenue when two gunmen walked up to their Mercedes-Benz sport-utility vehicle and opened fire, according to the police.\n\nThe front passenger, Sherwood Beverly, 51, of Brownsville, Brooklyn, was struck in the head; he was pronounced dead at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. The driver, a 50-year-old man, was grazed on the neck, and a 50-year-old woman in the back seat was hit in the left shoulder. A 44-year-old woman sitting next to her was not injured, according to the police.", "title": "One Killed, 2 Wounded in Shooting at Stoplight in Queens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nVoting rights have been under attack recently. In several states, officials \u2014 almost all of them Republican, alas \u2014 have tried to reduce voting hours, close polling stations or erect barriers to voting, like strict ID rules. These measures have disproportionately affected minorities. In fact, that has sometimes been the stated goal.\n\nBut now a counterattack is underway.\n\nNot only are civil-rights advocates fighting the various attempts to restrict voting, they\u2019re also pushing for new laws to expand it. One of those efforts took a step forward this week.\n\nOrganizers in Florida announced that they had gathered enough signatures to put an initiative on the ballot this November that would restore voting rights to nearly 1.5 million convicted felons. Today, felon disenfranchisement denies the right to vote to one in five black Floridians \u2014 and 10 percent of the state\u2019s total voting population.", "title": "Opinion | One Person, One Vote", "authors": []}
